original: tadarthasiddhaye sūtrasandarbhasya cātisaṃkṣiptatvādavedhidyatayā vā asmadādestattvajñānaṃ na syāditi praśastapādasaṃkṣepatā /paḥ / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / tvādivadapratibhāsanādadhikāryabhāvaḥ / tadasat / upadeśavyaṅgyatvāt / tathā hi / dravyādiṣu iva kṛtasamayasya / / / / / anugataṃ jñānami / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / brāhmaṇo 'yamiti jñāne paścādbhāvibādhakānupapatteḥ pramāṇatayā śiṣṭapadārthādhikārisiddhernirviṣayatvānna doṣaḥ / nirabhidheyatvam avisiddhaṃ dravyādi / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / bhāvaśca nirasta eva / tadabhidhānāt / tathā prayojanopanyāsāt tadabhāvaśceti /
analyzed: tad artha siddhaye sūtra sandarbhasya ca ati saṃkṣipta tvāt avedhidya tayā vā asmat ādeḥ tattva jñānam na syāt iti praśasta pāda saṃkṣepa tāpaḥ tu ādi vat apratibhāsanāt adhikāri abhāvaḥ tat asat upadeśa vyaṅgya tvāt tathā hi dravya ādiṣu iva kṛta samayasya anugatam brāhmaṇaḥ yam iti jñāne paścāt bhāvi bādhaka anupapatteḥ pramāṇatayā śiṣṭa padārtha adhikāri siddheḥ nirviṣaya tvāt na doṣaḥ nirabhidheya tvam avisiddham dravya ādi bhāv
translated: For the sake of accomplishing that purpose, and because the collection of aphorisms is extremely concise, the knowledge of reality by one like us, who does not understand it, would not arise. Therefore, the commentary is a summary of Praśastapāda's aphorisms. The absence of an object to be qualified is not due to non-appearance, like the absence of a qualified object. That is not so. Because it is to be understood from the teaching. It is like this. For one who has made an agreement regarding substances etc., the knowledge that follows is not contradicted. Because the knowledge this is a Brahmin is not contradicted later, the person who is the object of the word good is established as a valid means of knowledge. Therefore, there is no fault of being objectless. The absence of denotation is not contradicted in substances etc. ... The existence is indeed refuted. Because it is mentioned. Similarly, because the purpose is stated, its absence is stated.

original: atha kiṃ punaśca vijñānaṃ kiṃ vā niḥśreyasamiti vācyam / avasthitapadārthavi / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / na vānāmātmaviśeṣaguṇānāmatyantocchittiḥ / na dharmārthakāmāḥ / teṣāmalpasādhanasādhyatvāt /
analyzed: atha kim punar ca vijñānam kim vā niḥśreyasam iti vācyam  avasthita padārtha vi na na dharma artha kāmāḥ teṣām alpa sādhana sādhya tvāt
translated: Now, what is consciousness and what is the highest good? It should be said that the destruction of the specific qualities of the soul is not absolute, nor are Dharma, Artha and Kama, because they are accomplished by small means.

original: niḥśreyasapadārthavicāraḥ
translated: Discussion on the meaning of the highest good

original: atha niḥśreyasāstitve kiṃ pramāṇam / viṣṇu /bhucetanamanumānabhāga / / / / / / / / / / / / / va / tathā hi / navānāmātmaviśeṣaguṇānāṃ santāno 'tyantamucchidyate santānatvāt / yo yaḥ santānaḥ sa so 'tyantamucchidyamāno dṛṣṭaḥ / yathā pradīpasantānaḥ / tathā cāyaṃ santānaḥ / tasmād / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / tamucchidyata iti / santānatvasya ca vyāptyā buddhayādiṣu sambhavāt pakṣadharmatayā asiddhatvābhāvaḥ / tatsamānarmiṇi ca pradīpādāvupalambhādaviruddhatvam / na ca pakṣe paramāṇvādāvasti saṃ / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / ityanaikāntikatvābhāvaḥ / viparītārthopasthāpakayoḥ pratyakṣāgamayoranupalambhānna kālātyayāpadiṣṭaḥ / na cāyaṃ satpratipakṣa iti pañcarūpatvāt pramāṇam /
analyzed: atha niḥśreyasa astitve kim pramāṇam tathā hi navānām ātma viśeṣa guṇānām tyantam ucchidyate santāna tvāt yaḥ yaḥ santānaḥ sa tyantam ucchidyamānaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ yathā pradīpa santānaḥ tathā ca ayam santānaḥ tasmāt tam ucchidyate iti santāna tvasya ca vyāptyā buddhayā ādiṣu sambhavāt pakṣa dharmatayā asiddha tva abhāvaḥ tad samāna dharmiṇi ca pradīpa ādau upalambhāt aviruddha tvam na ca pakṣe paramāṇu ādau asti sarva asti tathā asti tathā

original: atha nirhetukāvinā / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / prati / / / / / / / vaśyāntāde /reva heturvācyaḥ / yataḥ samucchidyata iti / sa tūkta eva / tattvajñānaṃ niḥśreyasaheturiti nirdeśācca tattvajñānamaviśiṣṭatvānna prativyaktyapekṣaṃ kintu / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / ityādi lakṣaṇāt / tathā hi / dravyādilakṣaṇalakṣiteṣu utpadyate tattvajñānamiti /
analyzed: atha nirhetuka avinā prati vaśyā anta ādeḥ eva hetuḥ vācyaḥ yatas samucchidyate iti sa tu uktaḥ eva tattva jñānam niḥśreyasa hetuḥ iti nirdeśāt ca tattva jñānam aviśiṣṭa tvāt na prati vyakti apekṣam kintu ityādi lakṣaṇāt tathā hi dravya ādi lakṣaṇa lakṣiteṣu utpadyate tattva jñānam iti

original: atha tattvajñānasya niśreyasakāraṇatve samutpannatattvajñānastvanantaramevāpamṛdyaṃ / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / manasyasambhave 'smadādīnāṃ tattvajñānānupapattiḥ / atha yogajadharmādupajātatattvajñāno 'smadādestattvajñānasampādanāya kaṇādaḥ sūtrāṇi karotītyavasthāṃ / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / iṣyate gatārha /tattvajñānasya niḥśreyasakāraṇe satyapyabhāvānnaiṣa doṣaḥ / viśiṣṭatattvajñānasya niḥśreyasakāraṇatvābhyupagamāt / tathā hi / upajāte 'pi śraute tattvajñāne 'smadādīnāṃ / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / niḥśreyasaṃ yogābhyāsajanitatattvajñānasyāsambhavāt / śraute hi tattvajñāne samutpanne yogābhyāse pravartamānasya abhyāsavaśādātmanyaśeṣaviśeṣāliṅgite 'ntyaṃ tattvajñānamupajātaṃ niśśreyasakāraṇamiti /
analyzed: atha tattva jñānasya niśreyasa kāraṇa tve samutpanna tattva jñānaḥ tu anantaram eva apamṛdyam manasi asambhave smat ādīnām tattva jñāna anupapattiḥ atha yoga ja dharmāt upajāta tattva jñānaḥ smat ādeḥ tattva jñāna sampādanāya kaṇādaḥ sūtrāṇi karoti iti avasthām iṣyate gatārha tattva jñānasya niḥśreyasa kāraṇe sati api abhāvāt na eṣa doṣaḥ viśiṣṭa tattva jñānasya niḥśreyasa kāraṇa tva abhyupagamāt tathā hi upajāte pi śraute tattva
translated: Now, if the knowledge of reality is the cause of final beatitude, then one who has attained the knowledge of reality would immediately be destroyed... ...in the absence of the mind in us, the knowledge of reality is not possible. If it is argued that Kaṇāda composes the aphorisms for the attainment of the knowledge of reality by us, who have attained the knowledge of reality through the dharma born from yoga, then that is not so... ...it is accepted. Even when the knowledge of reality is the cause of final beatitude, there is no fault, because it does not exist. Because the knowledge of reality is accepted as the cause of final beatitude. For instance, even when the knowledge of reality born from the Vedas is attained by us... ...final beatitude is not possible due to the impossibility of the knowledge of reality born from the practice of yoga. For one who engages in the practice of yoga after the knowledge of reality born from the Vedas has arisen, the knowledge of reality born from the practice of yoga does not arise, because the knowledge of reality born from the Vedas is stronger.

original: tathā hyupalabdhaṃ samyagjñānasya mithyājñānanivṛttau sāmarthyaṃ śuktikādāviti / samyagjñānasya jñānāntaravirodhitvād uttarakālabhāvinā mithyājñānenāpi samyagjñānasya virodhaḥ sambhavatyeva / yadi sā manaḥsantānocchittirvivakṣiteti / yathā hi samyagjñānānmithyājñānasya santānocchedaḥ / naivaṃ mithyājñānāt samyagjñānasyeti /
analyzed: tathā hi upalabdham samyak jñānasya mithyājñāna nivṛttau sāmarthyam śuktikā ādau iti samyak jñānasya jñāna antara virodhi tvāt uttara kāla bhāvinā mithyājñānena api samyak jñānasya virodhaḥ sambhavati eva yadi sā manaḥ santāna ucchittiḥ vivakṣitā iti yathā hi samyak jñānāt mithyājñānasya santāna ucchedaḥ na evam mithyājñānāt samyak jñānasya iti
translated: For thus the ability of right knowledge to remove false knowledge is perceived in the case of mother-of-pearl, etc. And since right knowledge is opposed to another knowledge, it is possible that right knowledge is opposed even by false knowledge occurring at a later time. If it is intended that the continuum of the mind is cut off, just as the continuum of false knowledge is cut off by right knowledge, so is the continuum of right knowledge by false knowledge.

original: nivṛtte ca mithyājñāne tanmūlatvād rāgādayo naśyanti kāraṇābhāvena kāryasyānutpādāditi / rāgādyabhāve ca tatkāryāpravṛttirvyāvartate / tadabhāve ca dharmādharmayoranutpattiḥ / ārabdhakāryayoścopabhogāt prakṣaya iti /
analyzed: nivṛtte ca mithyājñāne tad mūla tvāt rāga ādayaḥ naśyanti kāraṇa abhāvena kāryasya anutpādāt iti rāga ādi abhāve ca tad kārya apravṛttiḥ vyāvartate tad abhāve ca dharma adharmayoḥ anutpattiḥ ārabdha kāryayoḥ ca upabhogāt prakṣayaḥ iti
translated: And when false knowledge ceases, passion, etc., perish because they have that as their root, since the effect does not arise in the absence of the cause. And when passion, etc., do not exist, the activity that is their effect is turned away. And in their absence, virtue and vice do not arise. And when their effect has begun, they are destroyed by experience.

original: sañcitayorvicāraḥ
analyzed: sañcitayoḥ vicāraḥ
translated: The consideration of the accumulated [merits and demerits]

original: kathaṃ tattvajñānādeveti / yathoktam /
analyzed: katham tattva jñānāt eva iti yathā uktam
translated: How is it that [the accumulated merits and demerits] are destroyed only by the knowledge of reality? As it is said:

original: yathaidhāṃsi samiddho 'gnirbhasmasāt kurute kṣaṇāt /
analyzed: yathā edhāṃsi samiddhaḥ gniḥ bhasmasāt kurute kṣaṇāt
translated: Just as a well-kindled fire reduces firewood to ashes in an instant,

original: jñānāgniḥ sarvakarmāṇi bhasmasāt kurute tathā // gītā /
analyzed: jñāna agniḥ sarva karmāṇi bhasmasāt kurute tathā gītā
translated: And likewise the fire of knowledge reduces all actions to ashes.

original: iti /
analyzed: iti
translated: Thus it is said.

original: nanūpabhogādeva prakṣaya ityapyāgamoktam / yathoktam /
analyzed: nanu upabhogāt eva prakṣayaḥ iti api āgama uktam yathā uktam
translated: But it is also stated in the scriptures that destruction occurs through enjoyment alone. As it is said:

original: nābhuktaṃ kṣīyate karma kalpakoṭiśatairapi /
analyzed: na abhuktam kṣīyate karma kalpa koṭi śataiḥ api
translated: An action that has not been enjoyed does not perish even in hundreds of millions of kalpas.

original: avaśyamanubhoktavyaṃ kṛtaṃ karma śubhāśubham // devībhā / / / / /
analyzed: avaśyam anubhoktavyam kṛtam karma śubha aśubham devī bhā
translated: An action, good or bad, that has been done must certainly be experienced.

original: tathā ca viruddhārthatvādubhayoḥ kathaṃ prāmāṇyamiti / bhogācca prakṣaye 'pyanumānamapyasti / pūrvakarmāṇi / upabhogādeva kṣīyante / karmatvāt / yadyat karma tattad upabhogādeva kṣīyate yathā ārabdhaśarīraṃ karma / tathā cāmūni karmāṇi / tasmād upabhogādeva kṣīyanta iti / upabhogena ca prakṣaye karmāntarasyāvaśyambhāvāt saṃsārānucchedaḥ /
analyzed: tathā ca viruddha artha tvāt ubhayoḥ katham prāmāṇyam iti bhogāt ca prakṣaye pi anumānam api asti pūrva karmāṇi upabhogāt eva kṣīyante karma tvāt yat yat karma tat tat upabhogāt eva kṣīyate yathā ārabdha śarīram karma tathā ca amūni karmāṇi tasmāt upabhogāt eva kṣīyante iti upabhogena ca prakṣaye karma antarasya avaśyambhāvāt saṃsāra anucchedaḥ
translated: And thus, how can both be authoritative, since they have contradictory meanings? And even though there is destruction through enjoyment, there is also inference. Past actions are destroyed only through enjoyment, because they are actions. Whatever is an action is destroyed only through enjoyment, like an action that has begun the body. And these actions are like that. Therefore, they are destroyed only through enjoyment. And since there is necessarily another action when there is destruction through enjoyment, there is no end to transmigration.

original: tadasat / samādhibalādutpannatattvajñāno hi karmaṇāñca sādhyamarthaṃ viditvā yugapaccharīrāṇi nirmāyopabhoga / / kta iti / na ca karmāntarotpattirmithyājñānajanitānusandhānākhyasya sahakāriṇo 'bhāvāt /
analyzed: tat asat samādhi balāt utpanna tattva jñānaḥ hi karmaṇām ca sādhyam artham viditvā yugapad śarīrāṇi nirmāya upabhoga iti na ca karma antara utpattiḥ mithyājñāna janita anusandhāna ākhyasya sahakāriṇaḥ bhāvāt
translated: That is not so. For one who has attained true knowledge through the power of concentration, knowing the purpose to be accomplished by actions, creates bodies simultaneously and experiences enjoyment. And there is no origination of another action, because of the absence of the cooperating factor called the continuation produced by false knowledge.

original: atha mithyājñānābhāve 'bhilāṣasyābhāvād bhogānupapattiḥ / tanna / upabhogaṃ vinā hi karma / / / / / yā anupapatteḥ / jānannapi tadarthitayā pravartata eva / vaidyopadeśādāturavadauṣadhāvaraṇe / jñānamapyevam / aśeṣaśarīrotpattidvāreṇopabhogāt karmaṇāṃ vināśe vyāpārāI /dagni / / / / iti vyākhyeyaṃ na tu sākṣāt / na caitad vācyam / tattvajñānināṃ karmavināśastattvajñānāt / itareṣāntu upabhogāditi / jñānena karmavināśe prasiddhodāharaṇābhāvāt /
analyzed: atha mithyājñāna abhāve bhilāṣasya abhāvāt bhoga anupapattiḥ tat na upabhogam vinā hi karma yā anupapatteḥ jānan api tad arthi tayā pravartate eva vaidya upadeśāt ātura vat auṣadha āvaraṇe jñānam api evam aśeṣa śarīra utpatti dvāreṇa upabhogāt karmaṇām vināśe  / iti vyākhyeyam na tu sākṣāt na ca etat vācyam tattva jñāninām karma vināśaḥ tattva jñānāt itareṣām tu upabhogāt iti jñānena karma vināśe prasiddha udāharaṇa abhāvāt
translated: If it is argued that in the absence of false knowledge, there is no desire and hence no enjoyment, that is not so. For without enjoyment, action would be impossible. Even knowing, one engages in it out of desire for that, like a patient taking medicine despite knowing it is bitter, on the advice of a physician. Knowledge also functions in the destruction of actions through enjoyment by the creation of the entire body, and not directly. And this should not be said: The destruction of actions of those who have true knowledge is from true knowledge, but for others it is from enjoyment. Because there is no well-known example for the destruction of actions by knowledge.

original: anye tu mithyājñānajanitasaṃskārasya sahakāriṇo 'bhāvād vidyamānānyapi karmāṇi na janmāntare śarīrārambhakāṇīti manyante / atra ca kāryavastuno nityatvaṃ syāditi dūṣaṇam /
analyzed: anye tu mithyā jñāna janita saṃskārasya sahakāriṇaḥ bhāvāt vidyamānāni api karmāṇi na janmāntare śarīra ārambhakāṇi iti manyante atra ca kārya vastunaḥ nitya tvam syāt iti dūṣaṇam
translated: Others, however, think that even though the actions exist, they do not produce the body in another birth due to the absence of the cooperating factors of the impressions produced by false knowledge. And here the fault is that the effect would be eternal.

original: atha anāgatayordharmādharmayorutpattipratiṣedhe tattvajñānino nityanaimittikānuṣṭhānaṃ tarhi katham / pratyavāyaparihārārtham / tathā hi /
analyzed: atha anāgatayoḥ dharma adharmayoḥ utpatti pratiṣedhe tattva jñāninaḥ nitya naimittika anuṣṭhānam tarhi katham pratyavāya parihāra artham tathā hi
translated: Now, if the arising of future dharma and adharma is denied, then how can the knower of reality perform the obligatory and occasional duties? For the sake of avoiding obstacles. As follows:

original: nityanaimittikaireva kurvāṇo duritakṣayam /
analyzed: nitya naimittikaiḥ eva kurvāṇaḥ durita kṣayam
translated: By performing only the obligatory and occasional duties, one destroys evil.

original: jñānañca vimalīkurvannabhyāsena tu pācayet //
analyzed: jñānam ca vimalīkurvan abhyāsena tu pācayet
translated: And by practice, one purifies knowledge and ripens it.

original: abhyāsātpakvavijñānaḥ kaivalyaṃ labhate naraḥ //
analyzed: abhyāsāt pakva vijñānaḥ kaivalyam labhate naraḥ
translated: A man whose knowledge is ripened by practice attains liberation.

original: iti /
analyzed: iti
translated: Thus.

original: kevalantu kāmye niṣiddhe ca pravṛttipratiṣedha iti / yad vā tattvajñānino nityanaimittikānuṣṭhāne na nivartate dharmotpattistathaivābhisandhānāt / tatphalasannyāso vā / tathā hi sarvakarmaṇāṃ paramagurāvarpaṇamiti śrūyate / na vā pravṛttiḥ pratisandhānāya hīnakleśasya nyā / sū / / ityalam /
analyzed: kevalam tu kāmye niṣiddhe ca pravṛtti pratiṣedhaḥ iti yat vā tattva jñāninaḥ nitya naimittika anuṣṭhāne na nivartate dharma utpattiḥ tathā eva abhisandhānāt tad phala sannyāsaḥ vā tathā hi sarva karmaṇām parama gurau arpaṇam iti śrūyate na vā pravṛttiḥ pratisandhānāya hīna kleśasya iti alam
translated: But in the case of optional and prohibited acts, there is only a prohibition of engagement. Or, for one who has realized the truth, the arising of dharma does not cease in the performance of obligatory and occasional duties, because of the same intention, or because of the renunciation of their fruits. For it is heard that all actions are offered to the Supreme Guru. Or there is no engagement, because for one of low defilements, the intention is for liberation. Thus far.

original: athāstu tattvajñānaṃ niḥśreyasakāraṇam / avadhāraṇantu niṣidhyate / sannyāsādikriyāyāśca mokṣahetutvena śravaṇāt / tathā hi /
analyzed: atha astu tattva jñānam niḥśreyasa kāraṇam avadhāraṇam tu niṣidhyate sannyāsa ādi kriyāyāḥ ca mokṣa hetu tvena śravaṇāt tathā hi
translated: Now, let it be that the knowledge of truth is the cause of final beatitude. But the restriction is denied, because renunciation etc. are heard to be the cause of liberation. For thus:

original: sannyasyantaṃ dvijaṃ dṛṣṭvā sthānāccalati bhāskaraḥ /
analyzed: sannyasyantam dvijam dṛṣṭvā sthānāt calati bhāskaraḥ
translated: Seeing a twice-born man renouncing, the sun moves from its place.

original: mamaiṣa maṇḍalaṃ bhitvā prayātā lokamakṣayam // sannyāsopaniṣat /
analyzed: mama eṣa maṇḍalam bhitvā prayātā lokam akṣayam
translated: Having pierced through my orb, he goes to the imperishable world. The Renunciation Upanishad.

original: dvāvetau puruṣau loke sūryamaṇḍalabhedinau /
analyzed: dvau etau puruṣau loke sūrya maṇḍala bhedinau
translated: These two men in the world pierce the orb of the sun,

original: parivrāḍ yogayuktaśca raṇe cābhimukhe hataḥ // parā / smṛ / /
analyzed: parivrāj yoga yuktaḥ ca raṇe ca abhimukhe hataḥ parā
translated: The wandering ascetic and one killed in battle while facing the enemy. Parashara Smriti.

original: ityādyuktam /
analyzed: ityādi uktam
translated: Thus it is said.

original: satyam / sannyāsādikriyāyāḥ sūryamaṇḍalabheditvena ūrdhvagamanahetutvamiṣyata eva / yadi nāma lokamityabhidhānādakṣayatvamadhastanalokāpekṣayā kriyāntaraphalāpekṣayā vā draṣṭavyam / tathā hi sannyāsādilakṣaṇakriyā bhautikānyakriyāpekṣayā pradhānabhūteti /
analyzed: satyam sannyāsa ādi kriyāyāḥ sūrya maṇḍala bhedi tvena ūrdhvagamana hetu tvam iṣyate eva  yadi nāma lokam iti abhidhānāt akṣaya tvam adhastana loka apekṣayā kriyā antara phala apekṣayā vā draṣṭavyam tathā hi sannyāsa ādi lakṣaṇa kriyā bhautika anya kriyā apekṣayā pradhāna bhūtā iti
translated: True, the action of renunciation, etc., is indeed considered to be the cause of going upwards by piercing the sun's orb. If the word 'world' is mentioned, imperishability should be seen in relation to the lower worlds or in relation to the fruits of other actions. For thus, the action characterized by renunciation, etc., is the principal one in relation to other actions based on the elements.

original: na ca navānāmātmaviśeṣaguṇānāmatyantocchittirniḥśreyasaṃ sūryamaṇḍalabheditvena bhavatīti / tasya viśeṣaguṇaviyuktātmarūpatayā sarvatra bhāvāt / ata eva na tattvajñānaI /kāryatvādanityatvamiti vācyam / viśeṣaguṇocchedasya pradhvaṃsarūpatvāt tadupalakṣitātmana eva nityatvāditi / kāryavastunaścānityatvamiti / na ca buddhyādināśe guṇinastathā bhāvaḥ / tādātmyapratiṣedhasya vakṣyamāṇatvāt /
analyzed: na ca navānām ātma viśeṣa guṇānām atyanta ucchittiḥ niḥśreyasam sūrya maṇḍala bhedi tvena bhavati iti tasya viśeṣa guṇa viyukta ātma rūpatayā sarvatra bhāvāt atas eva na vācyam viśeṣa guṇa ucchedasya pradhvaṃsa rūpatvāt tad upalakṣita ātmanaḥ eva nitya tvāt iti kārya vastunaḥ ca anitya tvam iti na ca buddhi ādi nāśe guṇinaḥ tathā bhāvaḥ tādātmya pratiṣedhasya vakṣyamāṇa tvāt
translated: And the absolute destruction of the nine special qualities of the self is not the highest good by piercing the sun's orb, because it exists everywhere in the form of the self devoid of special qualities. For this very reason, it should not be said that the knowledge of reality is impermanent because it is an effect, because the destruction of special qualities is of the nature of cessation, and the self indicated by that is permanent. And the impermanence of an effect-substance is not the existence of the possessor of qualities in that way when the intellect, etc., are destroyed, because the denial of identity with that will be stated.

original: atha mokṣāvasthāyāṃ caitanyasyāpyucchedānna kṛtabuddhayaḥ pravartanta iti ānandarūpo mokṣa iṣyatāmiti manuṣe / yathoktam /
analyzed: atha mokṣa avasthāyām caitanyasya api ucchedāt na kṛtabuddhayaḥ pravartante iti ānanda rūpaḥ mokṣaḥ iṣyatām iti manuṣe yathā uktam
translated: If you maintain that in the state of liberation consciousness is also annihilated, and therefore those who have attained knowledge do not act, then let liberation be of the nature of bliss. As it is said:

original: ānandaṃ brahmaṇo rūpaṃ tacca mokṣe 'bhipadyate /
analyzed: ānandam brahmaṇaḥ rūpam tat ca mokṣe bhipadyate
translated: The form of Brahman is bliss, and that is attained in liberation.

original: iti /
analyzed: iti
translated: Thus.

original: tathā sukhenāhamasvāpsam iti suṣuptyavasthottarakālaṃ smaraṇānyathānupapattyā'nubhavo jñāyate / tatra ca abhidhānānumānayorvyāpāro 'nupalabdho bāhyendriyāṇāñca ityantaḥkaraṇasya vyāpāro jñāyata iti mānasaṃ pratyakṣam / anumānañca / ātmā / sukhasvabhāvaḥ / atyantaṃ priyabuddhiviṣayatvād ananyaparatayopādīyamānatvācca / yad yadevaṃvidhaṃ tattatsukhasvabhāvaṃ yathā vaiṣayikaṃ sukham / tathā cātmaivaṃvidhaḥ / tasmāt sukhasvabhāva iti /
analyzed: tathā sukhena aham asvāpsam iti suṣupti avasthā uttara kālam smaraṇa anyathā anupapattyā anubhavaḥ jñāyate tatra ca abhidhāna anumānayoḥ vyāpāraḥ nupalabdhaḥ bāhya indriyāṇām ca iti antaḥkaraṇasya vyāpāraḥ jñāyate iti mānasam pratyakṣam anumānam ca ātmā sukha svabhāvaḥ atyantam priya buddhi viṣaya tvāt ananya para tayā upādīyamāna tvāt ca yat yat evaṃvidham tat tat sukha svabhāvam yathā vaiṣayikam sukham tathā ca ātmā evaṃvidhaḥ tasmāt s
translated: And because remembrance in the form I slept happily is not otherwise possible after the state of deep sleep, experience is known. And there the operation of verbal testimony and inference is not perceived, nor of the external senses, so the operation of the internal organ is known. Thus there is mental perception and inference. The self is of the nature of bliss, because it is the object of the notion of absolute love, and because it is appropriated without reference to anything else. Whatever is of such a kind is of the nature of bliss, like sensual pleasure. And the self is of that kind. Therefore it is of the nature of bliss.

original: tadetadasat / bādhakopapatteḥ / tathā hi / tasya anityatāyāmutpattikāraṇaṃ vācyam / na ca mokṣāvasthāyāmātmāntaḥkaraṇasambandhaḥ śarīrasambandhāpekṣaḥ sambhavati / śarīrāderabhāvāt / na cāsamavāyikāraṇaṃ vinā vastūtpattirdṛṣṭā /🔽atha nityaṃ tat sukhamiti cet / ajñātasaṃvedanantu yadi nityaṃ muktāvasthāyāmiva saṃsārāvasthāyāmapi bhāvādaviśeṣaprasaṅgaḥ / smaraṇānupapattiśca anubhavasyaivāvasthānāt / saṃskārānupapattiśca anubhavasya niratiśayatvāt /
analyzed: tat etat asat bādhaka upapatteḥ tathā hi tasya anitya tāyām utpatti kāraṇam vācyam na ca mokṣa avasthāyām ātma antaḥkaraṇa sambandhaḥ śarīra sambandha apekṣaḥ sambhavati śarīra ādeḥ abhāvāt na ca asamavāyikāraṇam vinā vastu utpattiḥ dṛṣṭā  atha nityam tat sukham iti ced ajñāta saṃvedanam tu yadi nityam mukta avasthāyām iva saṃsāra avasthāyām api bhāvāt aviśeṣa prasaṅgaḥ smaraṇa anupapattiḥ ca anubhavasya eva avasthānāt saṃskāra anupapattiḥ ca anubhavasya niratiśaya tvāt
translated: This is not so, because of the occurrence of a sublating cognition. Thus, the cause of the origin of that impermanence must be stated. And in the state of liberation, the connection of the self with the internal organ, which depends on the connection with the body, is not possible, because of the absence of the body, etc. And an entity is not seen to originate without an inherent cause.🔽If it is argued that it is eternal, then if the unknown consciousness is eternal, there would be no difference in the state of worldly existence as in the state of liberation, because it exists. And memory would be impossible, because only experience would exist. And there would be no impression, because experience is without any superior.

original: atha saṃsārāvasthāyāṃ vā'nyaviṣayavyāsaṅgād vidyamānasyāpyanubhavasyāsaṃvedanam / tadabhāvācca mokṣāvasthāyāṃ vedanamityasti viśeṣaḥ /
analyzed: atha saṃsāra avasthāyām vā anya viṣaya vyāsaṅgāt vidyamānasya api anubhavasya asaṃvedanam tad abhāvāt ca mokṣa avasthāyām vedanam iti asti viśeṣaḥ
translated: If it is argued that in the state of worldly existence, due to being engaged with other objects, even though experience exists, it is not known, and due to its absence in the state of liberation, there is knowledge, so there is a difference.

original: tadasat / nityasukhe hyanubhavasyāpi nityatvād vyāsaṅgānupapattiḥ / tathā hi / ātmano rūpādiviṣayakajñānotpattau viṣayāntare jñānānutpattirvyāsaṅgaḥ / evamindriyasyāpyekasmin viṣaye jñānajanakatvena pravṛttasya viṣayāntare jñānājanakatvaṃ vyāsaṅgaḥ / na caivamātmano rūpādiviṣayakajñānotpattau nityasukhe jñānānupapattiḥ / tajjñānasyāpi nityatvāt / na ca śarīrādinā pratibadhyatvādasaṃvedanamiti vācyaṃ nityatvādeva / tathā hi / pratibandhakaṃ kāryavyāghātakṛducyate / na ca nityasukhajñānasyānutpattiḥ sambhavati / tathā upabhogārthatvācca śarīrāderbhogapratibandhakatvānupapattiḥ / yad yadarthaṃ tat tasyaiva I / pratibandhakamiti nopalabdham / pratibandhakatvena tadapahanturhiṃsāphalaṃ na syāt / tathā hi / pratibandhavighātaka upakāraka eveti dṛṣṭam / tena hi nityasukhasaṃvedanapratibandhakasya śarīrāderapahanturhiṃsāphalasyābhāva ityalam /
analyzed: tat asat nitya sukhe hi anubhavasya api nitya tvāt vyāsaṅga anupapattiḥ tathā hi ātmanaḥ rūpa ādi viṣayaka jñāna utpattau viṣaya antare jñāna anutpattiḥ vyāsaṅgaḥ evam indriyasya api ekasmin viṣaye jñāna janaka tvena pravṛttasya viṣaya antare jñāna ajanaka tvam vyāsaṅgaḥ na ca evam ātmanaḥ rūpa ādi viṣayaka jñāna utpattau nitya sukhe jñāna anupapattiḥ tad jñānasya api nitya tvāt  / na ca śarīra ādinā pratibadhya tvāt asaṃvedanam iti vācyam n
translated: That is not correct. For if the self is eternal and blissful, then the experience of that would also be eternal, and so there would be no possibility of obstruction. This is because in the production of knowledge in the self about objects like form, the non-production of knowledge about another object is obstruction. Similarly, for the sense organ also, when engaged in generating knowledge about one object, the non-generation of knowledge about another object is obstruction. And in the same way, in the production of knowledge in the self about objects like form, there is no possibility of non-knowledge about eternal bliss, because that knowledge is also eternal. And it cannot be said that it is not experienced because it is obstructed by the body etc., because it is eternal itself. This is because an obstruction is said to be that which defeats an effect. And the non-production of the knowledge of eternal bliss is not possible. Moreover, since the body etc. are for the purpose of enjoyment, it is not possible for them to obstruct enjoyment. It is not observed that something is an obstruction to that for the sake of which it exists. If it were an obstruction, then the result of harming the remover of that would not be possible.

original: athānityaṃ tatsaṃvedanamiti cet / na / utpattikāraṇābhāvāt /
analyzed: atha anityam tat saṃvedanam iti ced na utpatti kāraṇa abhāvāt
translated: If it is argued that the cognition is non-eternal, that is not so, because there is no cause for its origination.

original: atha yogajadharmāpekṣaḥ puruṣāntaḥkaraṇasaṃyogo 'samavāyikāraṇamiti cet / na / yogajadharmasyāpyanityatayā vināśe 'pekṣākāraṇābhāvāt /
analyzed: atha yoga ja dharma apekṣaḥ puruṣa antaḥkaraṇa saṃyogaḥ samavāyi kāraṇam iti ced na yoga ja dharmasya api anitya tayā vināśe pekṣā kāraṇa abhāvāt
translated: If it is argued that the conjunction of the soul and internal organ, dependent on the qualities produced by yoga, is the non-inherent cause, that is not so, because even the quality produced by yoga is non-eternal, and there is no cause for dependence in destruction.

original: athādyasaṃyogajadharmādupajātaṃ vijñānamapekṣya uttaraṃ vijñānaṃ tasmāccottaramiti santānaḥ / tanna / pramāṇābhāvāt / tathā ca śarīrasambandhānapekṣaṃ vijñānameva ātmāntaḥkaraṇasaṃyogasyāpekṣākāraṇamiti na dṛṣṭam / na ca dṛṣṭyā viparītaṃ śakyate hyanujñātum / ākasmikantu kāryaṃ na bhavatyeva / ata eva nityasukhajñānasyābhāvāt sukhenāhamasvāpsam iti jñānaṃ nedaṃ smaraṇam / kiṃ tarhi / duḥkhakāraṇānusmaraṇābhāvena tadabhāvānumitijñānametat sukhenāhamasvāpsam iti / viparyaye vā nityasukhavad duḥkhenāhamasvāpsam iti smaraṇād nityaduḥkhamapi syāt / atha suṣuptyavasthāntarāle duḥkhakāraṇasaṃvedanād duḥkhenāhamasvāpsamiti jñānametat / evaṃ tarhi tadabhāvāt sukhenāhamiti bhaviṣyatīti /
analyzed: atha ādi a saṃyoga ja dharmāt upajātam vijñānam apekṣya uttaram vijñānam tasmāt ca uttaram iti santānaḥ tat na pramāṇa abhāvāt tathā ca śarīra sambandha anapekṣam vijñānam eva ātma antaḥkaraṇa saṃyogasya apekṣā kāraṇam iti na dṛṣṭam na ca dṛṣṭyā viparītam śakyate hi anujñātum ākasmikan tu kāryam na bhavati eva atas eva nitya sukha jñānasya abhāvāt sukhena aham asvāpsam iti jñānam na idam smaraṇam kim tarhi duḥkha kāraṇa anusmaraṇa a
translated: Now, if the subsequent consciousness depends on the consciousness produced from the dharma born from the initial conjunction, and the subsequent [consciousness] from that, this is a continuum. That is not so, because there is no evidence. And it is not seen that consciousness itself, independent of the connection with the body, is the cause of dependence for the connection of the self and the internal organ. And what is contrary to what is seen cannot be accepted. But an effect cannot be accidental. For this very reason, because there is no eternal happiness or knowledge, the knowledge I slept happily is not memory. Then what? This is the knowledge that infers the absence of that [happiness] due to the absence of recollection of the cause of suffering, I slept happily. Or, in the opposite case, it would be eternal suffering, because of the memory I slept unhappily due to eternal suffering, I slept unhappily. Now, if this knowledge I slept unhappily is due to the experience of the cause of suffering in the interval of the state of deep sleep, then in that case, it will be I slept happily due to the absence of that [cause of suffering].

original: athāgamastarhi katham ānandaṃ brahmaṇo rūpam ityādi / mukhye hi bādhakopapattergauṇa iti / tathā hi / duḥkhābhāve 'yamānandaśabdaḥ prayukto dṛṣṭaḥ / sukhaśabdo duḥkhābhāve / yathā bhārākrāntasya vāhakasya tadapāya iti /
analyzed: atha āgamaḥ tarhi katham ānandam brahmaṇaḥ rūpam ityādi mukhye hi bādhaka upapatteḥ gauṇaḥ iti tathā hi duḥkha abhāve yam ānanda śabdaḥ prayuktaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ sukha śabdaḥ duḥkha abhāve yathā bhāra ākrāntasya vāhakasya tad apāyaḥ iti
translated: If it be argued that the Veda is the source of the knowledge of Brahman, as in the passage, “The bliss of Brahman is the form of Brahman,” we reply: In the case of the primary meaning being impossible, the secondary meaning is accepted. For instance, the word “bliss” is seen to be used in the absence of pain, and the word “happiness” in the absence of pain. Just as when a man carrying a load says, “There is relief from it.”

original: yaccānumānam ātmā sukhasvabhāva iti / tatra yadi sukhasvabhāvatvaṃ sukhatvajātisambandhitvam / tannātmani sambhāvyate guṇa evopalambhāt / na hyekā ahaṅkārādivadaparā jātirdravyaguṇayoḥ sādhāraṇyupalabdheti / atha sukhādhikaraṇatvam / tannāsti / nityānityatvavikalpānupapatteḥ / tathā sukhatvādhikaraṇatve sukhādhikaraṇatāyāṃ vā tajjñānasya nityānityatvavikalpaḥ / / / / / / sādhanaṃ vā atyantapriyabuddhiviṣayamananyaparatayopādīyamānatvañca anaikāntādasādhanaṃ duḥkhābhāve 'pi bhāvāt / ananyaparatayopādīyamānatvañcāsiddhaṃ sukhārthamupādānāt / tathā atyantapriyabuddhiviṣayatvamapyasiddhaṃ duḥkhitāyāmapriyabuddherapi bhāvādityanumānadvayamapramāṇam /
analyzed: yat ca anumānam ātmā sukha svabhāvaḥ iti tatra yadi sukha svabhāva tvam sukha tva jāti sambandhi tvam tat na ātmani sambhāvyate guṇaḥ eva upalambhāt na hi ekā ahaṅkāra ādi vat aparā jātiḥ dravya guṇayoḥ sādhāraṇī upalabdhā iti atha sukha adhikaraṇa tvam tat na asti nitya anitya tva vikalpa anupapatteḥ tathā sukha tva adhikaraṇa tve sukha adhikaraṇa tāyām vā tad jñānasya nitya anitya tva vikalpaḥ  /
translated: And as for the inference that the self has the nature of pleasure, if the nature of pleasure means being related to the universal of pleasure, that is not possible in the self, because it is perceived as a quality. For there is no other universal, like egoity, common to both substance and quality. If it means being the substratum of pleasure, that is not possible, because the alternatives of being eternal or non-eternal do not apply. Similarly, if it means being the substratum of the universal of pleasure, or being the substratum of pleasure, there is the alternative of the knowledge of that being eternal or non-eternal. The means of knowledge is inconclusive, because it exists even in the absence of pain, though it is taken up with the sole purpose of producing the idea of supreme bliss. And being taken up with the sole purpose is not established, because it is taken up for the sake of pleasure. Similarly, being the object of the idea of supreme bliss is also not established, because the idea of non-pleasure also exists in one who is in pain. Thus the two inferences are not valid means of knowledge.

original: yadi ca mokṣāvasthāyāṃ nityaṃ sukhamastītyabhilāṣeṇa pravarteta / na muktaḥ syād rāgasya bandhanarūpatvāt / atha buddhyādikamupacchedayāmīti dveṣādapi pravartamānasya tadeva I / dūṣaṇam / nānukūlatvāt / tathā ca pratikūlasyādoṣasya pratiṣedhasya tadrāge 'pi samānamityadūṣaṇametadityanyadūhyam /
analyzed: yadi ca mokṣa avasthāyām nityam sukham asti iti abhilāṣeṇa pravarteta na muktaḥ syāt rāgasya bandhana rūpa tvāt  atha buddhi ādikam upacchedayāmi iti dveṣāt api pravartamānasya tat eva dūṣaṇam na anukūla tvāt tathā ca pratikūlasya adoṣasya pratiṣedhasya tad rāge pi samānam iti adūṣaṇam etat iti anyat ūhyam
translated: If one were to engage with desire, thinking that eternal bliss exists in the state of liberation, he would not be liberated, because attachment has the nature of bondage. If one engages even with aversion, thinking I will destroy intellect and so on, the same fault applies. Not because of being favorable. And in that case, it is the same for the attachment to the negation of the unfavorable, which is not a fault. So this is not a fault. Another should be stated.

original: atha sarvaguṇocchedād varaṃ vaiṣayikaṃ sukhaṃ duḥkhasādhanaparihāreṇa bhoktavyamiti manyase / tanna / tasya duḥkhānuṣaṅgeṇa duḥkharūpatayā heyatvāt / yeṣāñcaitadupādeyaṃ na tān prati idamarthavacchāstram / santi ca vaiṣayikasukhadveṣiṇaḥ puruṣāstān pratīdaṃ śāstram / te ca yadyupadeśamapekṣante nopāyāntarādevārthaṃ pratipadyānuṣṭhāne pravartanta iti / mokṣāstitve ca pramāṇopapatteḥ / śeṣaṃ vacanamātramityupekṣyate /
analyzed: atha sarva guṇa ucchedāt varam vaiṣayikam sukham duḥkha sādhana parihāreṇa bhoktavyam iti manyase tat na tasya duḥkha anuṣaṅgeṇa duḥkha rūpa tayā heya tvāt yeṣām ca etat upādeyam na tān prati idam arthavat śāstram santi ca vaiṣayika sukha dveṣiṇaḥ puruṣāḥ tān prati idam śāstram te ca yadi upadeśam apekṣante na upāya antarāt eva artham pratipadya anuṣṭhāne pravartante iti mokṣa astitve ca pramāṇa upapatteḥ śeṣam vacana mātram iti upekṣyat
translated: If you think that it is better to enjoy sensual pleasures, which are destroyed by the attainment of all virtues, by avoiding the means of suffering, that is not so. Because it is to be abandoned as having the nature of suffering due to its connection with suffering. And this scripture is meaningful for those for whom this is to be accepted. And there are men who hate sensual pleasures. This scripture is for them. And if they require instruction, they do not understand the meaning and engage in practice by other means. And because the existence of liberation is established by means of valid knowledge. The rest is mere statement and is disregarded.

original: anye tu anyathābhūtādeva sādhanād anyathābhūtaṃ mokṣaṃ manyante / yathoktam / guṇapuruṣāntaravivekadarśanaṃ niḥśreyasasādhanamiti / tathā hi / puruṣārthena hetunā pradhānaṃ pravartate / puruṣārthaśca dvedhā śabdādyupalabdhirguṇapuruṣāntaravivekadarśanañca / sampanne hi puruṣārthe caritārthatvānna pradhānaṃ śarīrādibhāvena pariṇamata iti draṣṭuḥ svarūpeṇāvasthānaṃ bhavatīti / vijñātaṃ vā draṣṭṛtayā kuṭṭinīstrīvad bhogasampādanāya puruṣaṃ nopasarpatīti /
analyzed: anye tu anyathābhūtāt eva sādhanāt anyathābhūtam mokṣam manyante yathā uktam guṇa puruṣa antara viveka darśanam niḥśreyasa sādhanam iti tathā hi puruṣa arthena hetunā pradhānam pravartate puruṣa arthaḥ ca dvedhā śabda ādi upalabdhiḥ guṇa puruṣa antara viveka darśanam ca sampanne hi puruṣa arthe caritārtha tvāt na pradhānam śarīra ādi bhāvena pariṇamate iti draṣṭuḥ sva rūpeṇa avasthānam bhavati iti vijñātam vā draṣṭṛ tayā kuṭṭinī str
translated: Others, however, think that Liberation is of a different kind from the means employed to attain it. As it has been said: The knowledge of the distinction between the qualities and the Purusha is the means to the highest good. Thus, the Prakriti operates with the purpose of the Purusha as the cause. And the purpose of the Purusha is twofold: the perception of sound etc., and the knowledge of the distinction between the qualities and the Purusha. For when the purpose of the Purusha is accomplished, the Prakriti, being fulfilled, does not evolve into the form of the body etc. Thus there is abiding of the seer in his own form. Or, being known as the seer, it does not approach the Purusha like a courtesan woman for the sake of enjoyment.

original: tadetat sarvamasat / pradhānāsattvasya vakṣyamāṇatvāt / sthite hi pradhānasadbhāve puruṣasya tadvivekadarśanamupapadyate / upetya vā brūmaḥ / yadi pradhānaṃ puruṣasthaṃ nimittamanapekṣya pravartate muktātmanyapi śarīrādisampādanāya pravarteta / aviśeṣāt / athādarśanāpekṣamiti cet / yasya hi guṇapuruṣāntaravivekadarśanānupapattistaṃ prati pradhānaṃ pravartate / na cāsau muktātmanīti / tanna / muktātmanyapi vivekadarśanasya vināśena pravṛttiprasaṅgāt / na cānutpattivināśayoradarśanatvena viśeṣaṃ paśyāmaḥ / athādṛṣṭāpekṣaṃ pravartata iti cet / tadasat / tasyāpi pradhāne śaktirūpatayā vyavasthitasya ubhayatrāviśeṣāt / tathā śarīrādivaicitryābhāvaśca tasyaikarūpatvāt / na ca pariṇāmavaicitryāccharīrādivaicitryam / tadvaicitrye kāraṇābhāvāt / kathañca sāmyenāvasthitaṃ tatpradhānaṃ vaiṣamyamavāpnuyāt / puruṣārthasya pravṛttihetorabhāvāt / sadbhāve vā puruṣārthasya tadarthā pravṛttirna bhaved vidyamānatvādeva / na ca pravṛttihetuṃ vinā karmaṇi pravartamānasyoparamo yukto hetvabhāvāt /
analyzed: tat etat sarvam asat pradhāna asattvasya vakṣyamāṇa tvāt sthite hi pradhāna sadbhāve puruṣasya tad viveka darśanam upapadyate upetya vā brūmaḥ yadi pradhānam puruṣa stham nimittam an apekṣya pravartate mukta ātmani api śarīra ādi sampādanāya pravarteta aviśeṣāt atha adarśana apekṣam iti ced yasya hi guṇa puruṣa antara viveka darśana anupapattiḥ tam prati pradhānam pravartate na ca asau mukta ātmani iti tat na mukta ātmani api viveka darśanasya vināśena pravṛ
translated: All this is false, because the existence of primordial matter will be denied later on. For, when the existence of primordial matter is established, the doctrine of the soul's discrimination of that [primordial matter] is possible. Or, let us approach [the matter] in another way. If primordial matter operates without depending on a cause, it would operate even in a liberated soul to produce the body and so on. Because there is no difference [between the two cases]. If it is argued that it depends on non-perception, then primordial matter operates for one for whom the discrimination of the difference between the constituents and the soul is not possible. And that is not so for a liberated soul. That is not so, because there is the contingence of operation even in a liberated soul due to the destruction of the discrimination of difference. And we do not see any difference between non-arising and destruction in terms of non-perception. If it is argued that it operates depending on the unseen [force], that is not so. Because, even for that [unseen force], which exists in the form of potentiality in primordial matter, there is no difference in both cases [i.e., in a bound soul and a liberated soul]. Similarly, there is the absence of diversity in the body and so on, because it [i.e., the unseen force] is of one form. And it is not so because of the diversity of modifications.

original: yaccedaṃ draṣṭuḥ svarūpeṇāvasthānamityuktaṃ tadiṣyata eva / viśeṣaguṇarahitasyāvasthānābhyupagamāt /
analyzed: yat ca idam draṣṭuḥ sva rūpeṇa avasthānam iti uktam tat iṣyate eva viśeṣa guṇa rahitasya avasthāna abhyupagamāt
translated: And as for what has been said about the soul remaining in its own nature, that is admitted, because it is admitted that it remains without any special qualities.

original: atha cidrūpasyāvasthānam / tannāsti / anityatvena cidrūpatāyā vināśāt / na cākṣādyanvayavyatirekānuvidhāyinaścaitanyasya nityatve pramāṇamasti / ātmarūpateti cet / tasyāśca ātmatādātmye paryāyamātram / vyatireke tu saṃyogādibhiranaikāntyam / guṇaguṇinośca tādātmyapratiṣedhaṃ vakṣyāmaḥ /
analyzed: atha cit rūpasya avasthānam tat na asti anitya tvena cit rūpa tāyāḥ vināśāt  na ca akṣa ādi anvaya vyatireka anuvidhāyinaḥ caitanyasya nitya tve pramāṇam asti ātma rūpa tā iti ced tasyāḥ ca ātma tādātmye paryāya mātram vyatireke tu saṃyoga ādibhiḥ anaikāntyam guṇa guṇinoḥ ca tādātmya pratiṣedham vakṣyāmaḥ
translated: If, on the other hand, the soul remains in its nature of consciousness, that is not so, because consciousness, being non-eternal, is destroyed with the destruction of the soul. And there is no proof for the eternality of consciousness, which follows the presence and absence of the eye, etc., if it is said to be of the nature of the self, then that is mere synonymity if it is identical with the self. If it is different, then there is the fallacy of too narrow definition, as it applies to conjunction, etc. And we shall explain the denial of the identity of quality and substance.

original: yaccedaṃ draṣṭṛtayā vijñātantu puruṣaṃ nopasarpatīti / asadetat / acetanatvāt / tathā hi / acetanatayā pradhānasya ahamanena draṣṭṛtayā vijñātamiti vijñānābhāve pūrvavatpravṛtiraviśiṣṭetyalamatiprasaṅgena /
analyzed: yat ca idam draṣṭṛ tayā vijñātam tu puruṣam na upasarpati iti asat etat acetana tvāt tathā hi acetana tayā pradhānasya aham anena draṣṭṛ tayā vijñātam iti vijñāna abhāve pūrvavat pravṛtiḥ aviśiṣṭā iti alam atiprasaṅgena
translated: And as for what has been said that the soul does not approach the person who is known as the seer, that is false, because it is non-intelligent. For thus, because primordial matter is non-intelligent, there is no cognition in the form I am known as the seer by this, and the activity is the same as before. So much for the digression.

original: anye tu asthirādibhāvanāvaśād rāgādiviyuktajñānotpattirniḥśreyasamiti manyante / tathā hi / sarvaṃ kṣaṇikamiti bhāvayato viṣayeṣvāsaktirvyāvartate mamedamiti sambandhābhāvāt / tathā sarvaṃ nirātmakamiti bhāvanāyāṃ nāhaṃ paraḥ / na mamāyamiti parigrahadveṣābhāve bhavatyeva viśuddhacittasantānotpattiriti / tathā ca paṭādyarthasya pratiṣedhāt sarvaṃ śūnyamiti ca / evaṃ hi duḥkhasamudayanirodhamārgeṣu viśiṣṭajñānaṃ niḥśreyasakāraṇamiti / tathā hi / duḥkhaṃ rūpādiskandhapañcakam / tasya samudayaḥ kāraṇaṃ samudetyasmāditi / tayornirodho vināśastasyopāyo mārga ityeṣu viśiṣṭajñānavaśācchuddhacittasantānastaducchedo vā niḥśreyasamiti yuktam /
analyzed: anye tu asthira ādi bhāvanā vaśāt rāga ādi viyukta jñāna utpattiḥ niḥśreyasam iti manyante tathā hi sarvam kṣaṇikam iti bhāvayataḥ viṣayeṣu āsaktiḥ vyāvartate mama idam iti sambandha abhāvāt tathā sarvam nirātmakam iti bhāvanāyām na aham paraḥ na mama ayam iti parigraha dveṣa abhāve bhavati eva viśuddha citta santāna utpattiḥ iti tathā ca paṭa ādi arthasya pratiṣedhāt sarvam śūnyam iti ca evam hi duḥkha samudaya nirodha mārgeṣu viśiṣṭa jñān
translated: Others, however, consider that the attainment of the highest good is the arising of knowledge free from attachment etc. due to the contemplation of impermanence etc. Thus, for one who contemplates that everything is momentary, attachment to objects ceases, because there is no connection with the thought this is mine. Similarly, in the contemplation that everything is without self, there is no thought of I or other or this is mine. When there is no attachment or aversion, the arising of a pure continuum of mind certainly occurs. And thus, because cloth etc. are negated, everything is empty. Thus, the knowledge of the noble truths of suffering, origination, cessation, and path is the cause of the highest good. Thus, suffering is the five aggregates beginning with form. Its origination is the cause, because it arises from that. The cessation of those two is destruction. The means to that is the path. Thus, it is reasonable that the highest good is the arising of a pure continuum of mind or its cessation, due to the power of the knowledge of these noble truths.

original: naitadevam / kṣaṇikādibhāvanāyā mithyārūpatvāt / na ca mithyājñānasya niḥśreyasakāraṇatvamatiprasaṅgāt / yathā ca na kṣaṇikatvam / śūnyatvam / nairātmyaṃ vā tathā vakṣyāmaḥ / athāsaktipratiṣedhārthamevaṃ bhāvanīyam / tanna / anyathāpi bhāvāt / tathā hi / padārthatattvajñānaṃ pravṛtteḥ kāraṇam / doṣadarśanañca nivṛtteriti dṛṣṭam / yathā madhuviṣasaṃpṛkte 'nne doṣādarśanād guṇabuddhitaḥ pravartate doṣadarśanācca nivartate / nārthapratiṣedhāt / evaṃ putrādāvapi ātmīyavairūpyadarśanameva nivṛttikāraṇamiti vācyam / na sambandhābhāvaḥ / tatpratiṣedho bhāvyaḥ / uktañca nyāyabhāṣyakṛtā rūpādiṣu nimittasaṃjñā bhāvanīyā nānuvyañjanasaṃjñeti itthaṃ dantā itthaṃ keśāḥ / / ityādi / yā ceyaṃ duḥkhasamudayanirodhamārgeṣu bhāvanā sā yadi duḥkhaṃ tatkāraṇaṃ tayornirodhastadupāyaśceti iṣṭaṃ na pratiṣidhyate / tathā hi duḥkhaṃ svarūpata eva / anyad duḥkhakāraṇatvāt / tacca rūpaṃ saṃjñā vedanā saṃskāro vijñānamiti rūpādiskandhapañcakamanyad vā bhavatu / sukhamapi duḥkhaṃ duḥkhānuṣaṅgāditi sarvaṃ duḥkhaṃ tasya vicchedopāyastattvajñānamiṣyata eva /
analyzed: na etat evam kṣaṇika ādi bhāvanāyāḥ mithyā rūpa tvāt  na ca mithyājñānasya niḥśreyasa kāraṇa tvam atiprasaṅgāt yathā ca na kṣaṇika tvam śūnyatvam nairātmyam vā tathā vakṣyāmaḥ atha āsakti pratiṣedha artham evam bhāvanīyam tat na anyathā api bhāvāt tathā hi padārtha tattva jñānam pravṛtteḥ kāraṇam doṣa darśanam ca nivṛtteḥ iti dṛṣṭam yathā madhu viṣa saṃpṛkte nne doṣa adarśanāt guṇa buddhitaḥ pravartate doṣa darśanāt
translated: This is not so, because the meditation on momentary etc. nature is false. And false knowledge cannot be the cause of liberation, as that would lead to absurdity. And we will explain how momentariness, emptiness, and selflessness are not so. If it is meditated upon in this way for the purpose of prohibiting attachment, that is not so, because it exists in another way. Thus, it is seen that the knowledge of the truth of things is the cause of engagement, and the perception of faults is the cause of disengagement. Just as one engages in food mixed with honey and poison due to the perception of qualities and the non-perception of faults, and disengages from it due to the perception of faults, not due to the prohibition of the object. Similarly, it should be said that the perception of deformity in the self's wife etc. is the cause of disengagement, not the absence of relation. That prohibition should be meditated upon. And it has been said by the author of the Nyāyabhāṣya that the meditation on the cause etc. of form etc. should be done, not the meditation on the details. Thus the teeth, thus the hair etc. And this perception of the origin of suffering

original: yaccedaṃ rāgādiviyuktajñānaṃ viśiṣṭabhāvanāta iti / tannāsti / kṣaṇikatve kāryakāraṇabhāvapratiṣedhasya vakṣyamāṇatvāt / upetyavādena tūcyate / na rāgādimato vijñānāt tadrahitasyotpattiryukteti / tathā hi / yathā hi bodhād bodharūpatā jñānāntare / tadvad rāgādirapi syāt tattādātmyāt / viparyaye vā tadabhāvaprasaṅgāditi / na ca vilakṣaṇādapi kāraṇād vilakṣaṇakāryasyotpattidarśanād bodhād bodharūpateti pramāṇamasti / ata evāsya jñānasya jñānāntarahetutvena pūrvakālabhāvitvaṃ samānajātīyatvamekasantānatvaṃ vā na heturvyabhicārāt / tathā hi / pūrvakālabhāvitvaṃ tatsamānakṣaṇaiḥ / samānajātīyatvañca santānāntarajñānairvyabhicārīti / teṣāṃ hi pūrvakālabhāvitvena samānajātīyatve 'pi na vivakṣitajñānahetutvamiti / ekasantānatvañca antyatājñānena vyabhicārīti / atha neṣyata evāntyaṃ jñānaṃ sarvadā ārambhāt / tathā hi / maraṇaśarīrajñānamapi jñānāntaraheturjāgradavasthājñānañca suṣuptyavasthājñānasyāpīti / nanvevaṃ maraṇaśarīrajñānasyāntarābhavaśarīrajñānahetutve garbhaśarīrajñānahetutve vā santānāntare vijñānajanakatvaprasaṅgo niyamahetorabhāvāt / atha iṣyata eva upādhyāyajñānaṃ śiṣyajñānasyānyasya kasmānna bhavatīti / atha karmavāsanā niyāmiketi cet / na / tasyāpi jñānavyatirekeṇāsambhavāt / tathā hi / tattādātmye sati vijñānaṃ bodharūpatayā viśiṣṭaṃ bodhācca bodharūpatetyaviśeṣeṇa vijñānaṃ vidadhyādityalam /
analyzed: yat ca idam rāga ādi viyukta jñānam viśiṣṭa bhāvanātaḥ iti tat na asti kṣaṇika tve kārya kāraṇa bhāva pratiṣedhasya vakṣyamāṇatvāt upetya vādena tu ucyate na rāga ādimataḥ vijñānāt tad rahitasya utpattiḥ yuktā iti tathā hi yathā hi bodhāt bodha rūpa tā jñāna antare tadvat rāga ādiḥ api syāt tad tādātmyāt viparyaye vā tad abhāva prasaṅgāt iti na ca vilakṣaṇāt api kāraṇāt vilakṣaṇa kāryasya utpatti darśanāt bodhāt bodha rūpa tā i
translated: And this knowledge free from attachment etc. is due to special cultivation - that is not so, because in momentariness, the relation of cause and effect is denied, as will be stated. But it is said by the method of hypothetical negative reasoning: It is not reasonable for a knowledge free from attachment etc. to arise from a knowledge with attachment etc., because of the identity of their nature. For just as the nature of knowledge is known from knowledge in another knowledge, so too attachment etc. would be, because of the identity of their nature. Or, if it were otherwise, there would be the consequence of their non-existence. And there is no valid cognition that the nature of knowledge arises from knowledge, because an effect with a different nature is seen to arise from a cause with a different nature. For this very reason, the being prior to it, belonging to the same class, or being in the same continuum of this knowledge is not a cause for being the cause of another knowledge, because of inconstancy. For example, the being prior to it is inconsistent with those of the same moment, and the belonging to the same class is inconsistent with the knowledge of another continuum. For those, even though they are prior to it and belong to the same class, the intended knowledge

original: yaccedaṃ suṣuptyavasthājñānasya jāgradavasthājñāne kāraṇatvamiti / asadetat / suṣuptyavasthāyāṃ jñānasadbhāve jāgradavasthāto na viśeṣaḥ syād ubhayatrāpi svasaṃvedyajñānasya sadbhāvāviśeṣāt / yadvā nidrayānabhibhūtatvaṃ viśeṣa iti cet / asadetat / taddharmatayā tasyāpi tādātmyenābhibhāvakatvāsambhavāt / vyatireke tu rūpādipadārthānāmeva sattvāt tatsvarūpaṃ nirūpyam / abhibhavaśca yadi vināśaḥ / na vijñānasya sattvaṃ vināśasya vā nirhetukatvam / atha tirobhāvaḥ / na vijñānasya sattvena tatsattaiva saṃvedanamityabhyupagame tasyānupapatteḥ / atha suṣuptyavasthāyāṃ vijñānāsattvenāntyajñānasadbhāvādekasantānatvaṃ vyabhicārīti /
analyzed: yat ca idam suṣupti avasthā jñānasya jāgrat avasthā jñāne kāraṇa tvam iti asat etat suṣupti avasthāyām jñāna sadbhāve jāgrat avasthātaḥ na viśeṣaḥ syāt ubhayatra api sva saṃvedya jñānasya sadbhāva aviśeṣāt yat vā nidrayā anabhibhūta tvam viśeṣaḥ iti ced asat etat tad dharmatayā tasya api tādātmyena abhibhāvaka tva asambhavāt vyatireke tu rūpa ādi padārthānām eva sattvāt tad svarūpam nirūpyam abhibhavaḥ ca yadi vināśaḥ na vijñānasya sattvam
translated: And this is the cause of the knowledge of the waking state for the knowledge of the state of deep sleep. This is false. If there is knowledge in the state of deep sleep, there would be no difference from the waking state, because there is no difference in the presence of self-evident knowledge in both cases. Or if it is argued that the difference lies in not being overwhelmed by sleep, that is false. Because it is not possible for that to overwhelm in the same way as its property, since it is different. But if it is argued that the difference lies in the existence of form and other objects, then their nature should be determined. And if overwhelming means destruction, then knowledge does not exist, and destruction cannot be without a cause. Or if it means concealment, then knowledge does not exist, and its existence cannot be established by the cognition of its existence. Or if it is argued that the state of deep sleep is an instance of deviation from the principle of one continuum due to the existence of the final cognition in the absence of knowledge in the state of deep sleep, that is not so.

original: yaccedaṃ viśiṣṭabhāvanāvaśād rāgādivināśa iti / asadetat / nirhetukatvād vināśasyābhyāsānupapatteśca / abhyāso hyavasthitasyārthasyātiśayādhāyakatvādupapadyate / na kṣaṇikajñānamātra iti / ata eva yogini sakalakalpanāvikalaṃ vijñānamutpadyate / na ca I / santānāpekṣayātiśayastasyaivāsambhavāt / aviśiṣṭād viśiṣṭotpatterayogācca / tathā hi / pūrvasmādaviśiṣṭād uttarottaraṃ sātiśayaṃ kathamupajāyata iti cintyam /
analyzed: yat ca idam viśiṣṭa bhāvanā vaśāt rāga ādi vināśaḥ iti asat etat nirhetuka tvāt vināśasya abhyāsa anupapatteḥ ca abhyāsaḥ hi avasthitasya arthasya atiśaya ādhāyaka tvāt upapadyate na kṣaṇika jñāna mātre iti atas eva yogini sakala kalpanā vikalam vijñānam utpadyate na ca santāna apekṣayā atiśayaḥ tasya eva asambhavāt aviśiṣṭāt viśiṣṭa utpatteḥ ayogāt ca  tathā hi pūrvasmāt aviśiṣṭāt uttarottaram sa atiśayam katham upajāyate iti cintyam
translated: And this destruction of passion etc. due to the power of special meditation is false, because destruction is without cause and because repetition is not possible. For repetition is possible because it causes an excess in an existing object, but not in mere momentary cognition. For this very reason, in a yogi, cognition arises free from all conceptualization, and not in the form of a series. And the excess cannot be in relation to the series, because that itself is impossible, and because it is impossible for something special to arise from something non-special. For thus, it should be considered how something with an excess arises successively from something non-special.

original: yacca santānocchittirniḥśreyasamiti / tanna / nirhetukatayā vināśasyopāyavaiyarthyamayatnasādhyatvāt /
analyzed: yat ca santāna ucchittiḥ niḥśreyasam iti tat na nirhetuka tayā vināśasya upāya vaiyarthyam ayatna sādhya tvāt
translated: And this destruction of the series is the highest good is not so. Because destruction is without cause, the means is useless, and it is to be accomplished without effort.

original: anye tu anekāntabhāvanāto viśiṣṭapradeśe 'kṣayaśarīrādilābho niḥśreyasamiti manyante / tathā ca nityabhāvanāyāṃ grahānityatve ca dveṣa ityubhayaparihārārthamanekāntabhāvaneti / evaṃ sadasadādiṣvapi yojyam / pratyakṣañca svadeśakālakāraṇādhāratayā sattvaṃ paradeśādiṣvasattvamityubhayarūpatā / tathā ghaṭādirmṛdādirūpatayā nityaḥ sarvāvasthāsūpalambhāt / ghaṭādirūpatayā cānityastadapāyāt / evamātmāpyātmarūpatayā nityaḥ sarvadā sadbhāvāt / sukhaduḥkhādiparyyāyarūpatayā cānityastadvināśāt / evaṃ sarvatra svakāryeṣu kartṛtvaṃ kāryāntareṣu cākartṛtvamityūhyam / atha svaśabdābhidheyatvaṃ śabdāntarānabhidheyatvañceti /
analyzed: anye tu anekānta bhāvanātaḥ viśiṣṭa pradeśe kṣaya śarīra ādi lābhaḥ niḥśreyasam iti manyante tathā ca nitya bhāvanāyām graha anitya tve ca dveṣaḥ iti ubhaya parihāra artham anekānta bhāvanā iti  evam sat asat ādiṣu api yojyam pratyakṣaḥ ca sva deśa kāla kāraṇa ādhāra tayā sattvam para deśa ādiṣu asattvam iti ubhaya rūpatā tathā ghaṭa ādiḥ mṛd ādi rūpatayā nityaḥ sarva avasthāsu upalambhāt ghaṭa ādi rūpatayā ca anityaḥ tad apāyāt
translated: Others, however, consider that the highest good consists in the attainment of an imperishable body in a distinguished region due to the contemplation of non-absolutism. And thus, in the contemplation of the eternal, and in the impermanence of the planets, there is aversion. To avoid both, there is the contemplation of non-absolutism. This should be applied similarly to existence, non-existence, etc. also. And perception has a twofold nature, as existing through being the substratum of its own region, time, and cause, and as non-existing in other regions, etc. Similarly, a pot, etc. are eternal in the form of clay, etc., because they are perceived in all states. And they are impermanent in the form of a pot, etc., because that disappears. In the same way, the self is also eternal in the form of the self, because it exists at all times. And it is impermanent in the form of pleasure, pain, etc., because those perish. In the same way, it should be understood that everywhere, it is the agent in its own effects and not the agent in other effects. Or it is expressible by its own word and inexpressible by other words.

original: tadetadasāmpratam / mithyājñānasya niḥśreyasakāraṇatvena pratiṣedhāt / anekāntajñānañca mithyaiva / bādhakopapatteḥ / tathā hi / nityānityayorvidhipratiṣedharūpatvād abhinne dharmiṇyabhāvaḥ / evaṃ sadasattvāderapīti / yaccedaṃ ghaṭādirmṛdādirūpatayā nitya iti / asadetat / mṛdrūpatāyāstato 'rthāntaratvāt / tathā hi / ghaṭādarthāntaraṃ mṛdrūpatā / mṛttvaṃ sāmānyaṃ tasya tu nityatvena ghaṭasyātathābhāvastato 'nyatvāt / ghaṭasya tu kāraṇād vilayopalabdheranityatvameva / yaccedaṃ svadeśādiṣu sattvaṃ paradeśādiṣvasattvamiṣyata evetaretarābhāvasyābhyupagamāt / tathā hi / itarasmin deśādāvitarasya ghaṭasyābhāvo nānutpattirna pradhvaṃsastatra tasya sarvadā sattvāt / dvairūpye tu svadeśādiṣvanupalambhaprasaṅgaḥ / evamātmano 'pi nityatvameva / sukhaduḥkhādestadguṇatvena tato 'rthāntarasya vināśe 'pyavināśāt / kāryāntareṣu cākartṛttvaṃ na pratiṣidhyate / tathā hi / yad yasyānvayavyatirekābhyāmutpattau vyāpriyata ityupalabdhaṃ tat tasya kāraṇaṃ nānyasyetyabhyupagamyate / evaṃ śabdāntarānabhidheyatve 'pi na sarvaṃ sarvaśabdābhidheyamityabhyupagamāt /
analyzed: tat etat asāmpratam mithyājñānasya niḥśreyasa kāraṇa tvena pratiṣedhāt anekānta jñānañca mithyā eva bādhaka upapatteḥ tathā hi nitya anityayoḥ vidhi pratiṣedha rūpa tvāt abhinne dharmiṇi abhāvaḥ evam sat asat tva ādeḥ api iti yat ca idam ghaṭa ādiḥ mṛd ādi rūpatayā nityaḥ iti asat etat mṛd rūpatāyāḥ tatas rtha antara tvāt tathā hi ghaṭāt artha antaram mṛd rūpatā mṛd tvam sāmānyam tasya tu nitya tvena ghaṭasya atathābhāvaḥ tatas nyatv
translated: This is not correct. Because false knowledge is prohibited as the cause of liberation. And the knowledge of non-absolutism is itself false, because of the occurrence of refutation. Thus, because permanence and impermanence are of the nature of injunction and prohibition, there is non-existence in the undifferentiated substratum. Similarly, existence and non-existence, etc. also. And this that the pot, etc. are permanent in the form of clay, etc., is false. Because the form of clay is different from that. Thus, the form of clay is different from the pot, etc. Clay-ness is a universal, but the pot does not exist in that way, because it is different from that. But the pot's destruction is observed from its cause, so it is impermanent. And this that existence in one's own place, etc. and non-existence in another's place, etc. is accepted itself, because mutual absence is accepted. Thus, in another place, etc. the absence of another pot is not non-production, nor destruction, because it exists there always. But in duality, non-apprehension in one's own place, etc.

original: na cānekāntabhāvanāto viśiṣṭaśarīrādilābhe 'sti pratibandhaḥ / na cotpattidharmāṇāṃ śarīrādīnāmakṣayatvaṃ nyāyyam / tathā muktāvapyanekānto na vyāvartata iti mukto na muktaśceti syāt / evañca sati sa eva muktaḥ saṃsārī ceti prasaktam / evamanekānte 'pyaI /nekāntābhyupagame dūṣaṇam / vastuno hi sadasadrūpatā'naikāntikaḥ / tasyāpyanaikāntikābhyupagame rūpāntaramapi pratyakṣam / evaṃ nityānityarūpatāvyatiriktañca rūpāntaramityādi vācyam /
analyzed: na ca anekānta bhāvanātaḥ viśiṣṭa śarīra ādi lābhe sti pratibandhaḥ na ca utpatti dharmāṇām śarīra ādīnām akṣaya tvam nyāyyam tathā muktau api anekāntaḥ na vyāvartate iti muktaḥ na muktaḥ ca iti syāt evam ca sati saḥ eva muktaḥ saṃsārī ca iti prasaktam evam anekānte dūṣaṇam vastunaḥ hi sat asat rūpatā anaikāntikaḥ tasya api anaikāntika abhyupagame rūpa antaram api pratyakṣam evam nitya anitya rūpatā vyatiriktam ca rūpa antaram ityādi vācya
translated: And there is no obstruction to the attainment of a special body etc. from the contemplation of non-duality. And it is not reasonable that the bodies etc. which are subject to origination should be imperishable. Similarly, even in liberation, non-duality does not cease, so it would be that the liberated one is both liberated and not liberated. And if this is so, it follows that the very same liberated one is both transmigrating and not transmigrating. Thus, even in non-duality, the fault lies in accepting non-duality. For the reality is of the nature of both existence and non-existence, it is indeterminate. If that too is accepted as indeterminate, then another form is also directly perceived. Thus, it should be said that there is another form apart from the nature of being eternal and non-eternal, and so on.

original: anye tu ātmaikatvajñānāt paramātmani layaḥ sampadyata iti bruvate / tathā hi / ātmaiva paramārthaḥ san / tato 'nyeṣāṃ bhede pramāṇābhāvāt / pratyakṣaṃ hi padārthānāṃ sadbhāvagrāhakameva na bhedasyetyavidyāsamāropita evāyaṃ bheda iti manyante /
analyzed: anye tu ātma eka tva jñānāt paramātmani layaḥ sampadyate iti bruvate tathā hi ātmā eva paramārthaḥ san tatas nyeṣām bhede pramāṇa abhāvāt pratyakṣam hi padārthānām sadbhāva grāhakam eva na bhedasya iti avidyā samāropitaḥ eva ayam bhedaḥ iti manyante
translated: But others say that from the knowledge of the oneness of the self, there is absorption in the supreme self. Thus, the self alone is the ultimate reality, because there is no means of knowledge for the difference of anything else from it. For perception only grasps the existence of things, not their difference. Therefore, they think that this difference is only superimposed by ignorance.

original: tadapyasat / ātmaikatvajñānasya mithyārūpatayā niḥśreyasasādhanatvānupapatteḥ / mithyātvañca ātmādhikāre vakṣyāmaḥ / vyavasthāto nānātmānaḥ vai / sū / / / iti sūtreṇa /
analyzed: tat api asat ātma eka tva jñānasya mithyā rūpa tayā niḥśreyasa sādhana tva anupapatteḥ mithyātvam ca ātma adhikāre vakṣyāmaḥ vyavasthātaḥ nānā ātmānaḥ vai iti sūtreṇa
translated: That also is not so, because the knowledge of the oneness of the self being of a false nature, it cannot be the means of attaining the highest good. And the falsity of that we shall explain in the chapter on the self. And by the Sūtra, 'By reason of the arrangement, the selves are many' (Brahma Sūtra 1.3.11),

original: evaṃ śabdādvaitavijñānamapi mithyārūpatayā na niḥśreyasasādhanamiti draṣṭavyam / tathā hi / sarvārthānāṃ śabdarūpateti pramāṇābhāvaḥ / atha bhede 'pi pramāṇābhāva iti cet / tadasat / cakṣurādinā śabdarūpatāviyuktānāmarthānāṃ pratibhāsanāt / śabdarūpatā hi śrāvaṇatvamarthasya sataḥ / na cārtheṣvetadasti śrotreṇāgrahaṇāt / atha śabdasyaivāvasthābhedād grahaṇavaicitryamiti cet / tanna / śabdarūpatāyāmeva tatsyāt / tatra ca pramāṇābhāva eva / atha śabdasamparkeṇa pratibhāsa eva pramāṇamiti cet / na / akṛtasamayasya vāyvādestadantareṇāpi pratibhāsanāt / na ca śabdāntareṇa samparko yuktaḥ samayavaiyarthyaprasaṅgāditi / śabdarūpatāyāṃ sādhyāyāṃ na śabdasampṛktapratibhāsaḥ pramāṇam / ata eva vaikharī madhyamā paśyantī sūkṣmā ceti bhedapratipādanamunmattabhāṣitam / na ca śabdādvaitajñānāt sūkṣmāvasthā sampadyata ityasti pratibandhaḥ /
analyzed: evam śabda advaita vijñānam api mithyā rūpatayā na niḥśreyasa sādhanam iti draṣṭavyam tathā hi sarva arthānām śabda rūpa tā iti pramāṇa abhāvaḥ atha bhede pi pramāṇa abhāvaḥ iti ced tat asat cakṣuḥ ādinā śabda rūpa tā viyuktānām arthānām pratibhāsanāt śabda rūpatā hi śrāvaṇa tvam arthasya sataḥ na ca artheṣu etat asti śrotreṇa agrahaṇāt atha śabdasya eva avasthā bhedāt grahaṇa vaicitryam iti ced tat na śabda rūpatāyām eva tat syāt ta
translated: Thus, the knowledge of the non-duality of sound should also be seen as a means to liberation only in the sense that it is a means to the cessation of the false notion of duality. For, there is no means of valid knowledge to prove that all objects have the nature of sound. If it is argued that there is no means of valid knowledge to prove difference, that is not correct. Because objects devoid of the nature of sound appear through the eye and other sense organs. For, the nature of sound is audibility, which belongs to an existent object. And this does not exist in objects, because they are not grasped by the ear. If it is argued that the diversity of perception is due to the difference in states of sound itself, that is not so. For, that would be possible only if there were the nature of sound. And there is no means of valid knowledge to prove that. If it is argued that the appearance itself is the means of valid knowledge due to contact with sound, that is not so. Because air and other things for which no convention has been made appear even without that. And contact with another sound is not proper, because that would lead to the futility of the convention. Therefore, the appearance associated with sound is not a means of valid knowledge to prove that objects have the nature of sound. For this very reason, the external

original: ekasmiṃścādvaite pratiṣiddhe pratibandhasamānatayā sarva evādvaitabhedāḥ pratiṣiddhā bhavantītyātmaikatvapratiṣedhādevedaṃ pratiṣiddhaṃ bhaviṣyatītyuparamyate /
analyzed: ekasmin ca advaite pratiṣiddhe pratibandha samāna tayā sarve eva advaita bhedāḥ pratiṣiddhāḥ bhavanti iti ātma ekatva pratiṣedhāt eva idam pratiṣiddham bhaviṣyati iti uparamyate
translated: And when one non-duality is refuted, all non-dual distinctions are refuted by the same principle of contradiction. So this will be refuted by the refutation of the non-duality of the self alone. Thus the discussion ends.

original: anye tu maheśvaraprasādādaśuddhaiśvaryavināśe tadguṇasaṃkrāntiṃ manyante / taccāsat / anyaguṇānāmanyatra vṛtteradarśanāt / maheśvaraprasādaśca muktau na pratiṣidhyate tasyāstadadhīnatvāditi sthitamasadvādapratiṣedhāt / ṣaṭpadārthasādharmyavaidharmyatattvajñānaṃ muktasya niḥśreyasakāraṇamiti /
analyzed: anye tu maheśvara prasādāt aśuddha aiśvarya vināśe tad guṇa saṃkrāntim manyante tat ca asat anya guṇānām anyatra vṛtteḥ adarśanāt maheśvara prasādaḥ ca muktau na pratiṣidhyate tasyāḥ tad adhīna tvāt iti sthitam asadvāda pratiṣedhāt ṣaṣ padārtha sādharmya vaidharmya tattva jñānam muktasya niḥśreyasa kāraṇam iti
translated: Others, however, think that by the grace of Maheśvara, when impure lordship is destroyed, its qualities are transferred to him. But that is not correct, because the qualities of one are not seen to operate in another. And the grace of Maheśvara is not refuted in liberation, because it is established that liberation depends on that, as shown by the refutation of the doctrine of non-existence. The knowledge of the truth of the similarity and dissimilarity of the six categories is the cause of the highest good for the liberated soul.

original: sūtrasthaathetyādiśabdavicāraḥ
translated: The discussion of the words atha etc. in the aphorism.

original: athetyādivākyasya / sūtreṇāpi sambandho vyākhyānāntaramiti manyante / taccāsat / sarvasmin vyākhyāne sūtritatvopadarśanaṃ bhāṣyasyeṣyata eva / athāto dharmaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ vai / sū / / / / yato 'bhyudayaniḥśreyasasiddhiḥ sa dharmaḥ vai / sū / / / iti / pūrvasūtre athaśabdo 'pyānantarye vartata ityanyasyāsambhavānnamaskārānantaramiti labhyate / sa ca jñānaprastāvād īśvarasyaiveti / bhāṣyakāraśca sūtrakārābhimataṃ parasya gurornamaskāramanūdyāparasya namaskāraṃ karotīti vyākhyeyaṃ na tu kaṇāda eva / svātmani kriyāvirodhāt /
analyzed: atha ityādi vākyasya sūtreṇa api sambandhaḥ vyākhyāna antaram iti manyante tat ca asat sarvasmin vyākhyāne sūtrita tva upadarśanam bhāṣyasya iṣyate eva atha atas dharmam vyākhyāsyāmaḥ vai sū yatas bhyudaya niḥśreyasa siddhiḥ sa dharmaḥ vai sū iti pūrva sūtre atha śabdaḥ u pi ānantarye vartate iti anyasya asambhavāt namaskāra anantaram iti labhyate sa ca jñāna prastāvāt īśvarasya eva iti bhāṣyakāraḥ ca sūtrakāra abhimatam parasya guroḥ namaskāram anū
translated: They consider that the sentence beginning with atha is connected with the sutra as a different explanation. And that is wrong. In all explanations, the Bhāṣya is certainly intended to show what is stated in the sutra. Then, therefore, we shall explain dharma. Vai. Su. ... from which there is the attainment of prosperity and the highest good, that is dharma. Vai. Su. ... thus. In the previous sutra, the word atha also occurs in the sense of immediate sequence. Thus, due to the impossibility of anything else, it is understood to be after the salutation. And that is only of the Lord, because of the context of knowledge. And the author of the Bhāṣya should be explained as repeating the salutation to the supreme teacher approved by the author of the sutra and then making the salutation to another, not that Kaṇāda himself, because action is contradictory in relation to oneself.

original: nāpi kaṇān attīti kaṇāda iti kaṇaśabdena svakarmaphalasyābhidhānāt kaṣṭavyutpattyā saṃsāryātmanaḥ / tannamaskāre prayojanābhāvāt /
analyzed: nā api kaṇān atti iti kaṇādaḥ iti kaṇa śabdena sva karma phalasya abhidhānāt kaṣṭa vyutpattyā saṃsārya ātmanaḥ tad namaskāre prayojana abhāvāt
translated: Nor is it that Kaṇāda is one who eats particles, because the word kaṇa refers to the fruit of one's own action, and the salutation to the transmigrating self is meaningless due to the difficulty of etymological derivation.

original: athaśabdārthaḥ anuśabdenokta eva / ataḥśabdo 'pi vacanavṛttyā dharmaṃ vyākhyāsyāma iti / vividhamanekaprakāreṇa yadutpadyate yataśca notpadyata ityāiti pratibodhaṃ yāvat tāvat pratipādayiṣyāma iti dharmavyākhyānārthameva ṣaṭpadārthopavarṇanam / ata eva padārtho dharmaiḥ saṃgṛhyata iti padārthadharmasaṅgraha ityuktam / uttarasūtrasya tu vivaraṇaṃ mahodayaḥ / mahānudayaḥ svargāpavargalakṣaṇo 'smād bhavatīti mahodaya ityuktam / dharmāt sukhaṃ jñānañceti / jñānotpattau tasyaiva prādhānyāt tadupasarjanatayā śeṣaṃ vyākhyāyata iti /
analyzed: atha śabda arthaḥ anuśabdena uktaḥ eva vacana vṛttyā dharmam vyākhyāsyāmaḥ iti vividham aneka prakāreṇa yat utpadyate yatas ca na utpadyate pratibodham yāvat tāvat pratipādayiṣyāmaḥ iti dharma vyākhyāna artham eva ṣaṣ padārtha upavarṇanam atas eva padārthaḥ dharmaiḥ saṃgṛhyate iti padārtha dharma saṅgrahaḥ iti uktam uttara sūtrasya tu vivaraṇam mahodayaḥ mahān udayaḥ svarga apavarga lakṣaṇaḥ smāt bhavati iti mahodayaḥ iti uktam dharmāt sukha
translated: The word 'atha' has been explained by the word 'anu'. The word 'ataḥ' also, in its conventional sense, means 'we shall explain the Dharma'. We shall teach as long as there is understanding, as to how various things are produced and from what they are not produced. Thus, the description of the six categories is for the sake of explaining the Dharma alone. For this very reason, it is said that the categories are included under the Dharmas, hence it is called the 'Pādārdha Dharma Saṃgraha'. But the explanation of the next aphorism is 'Mahodaya'. It is said to be Mahodaya because great prosperity, characterized by heaven and final liberation, results from it. From Dharma comes happiness and knowledge. Since knowledge is primary in the production of knowledge, the rest is explained as subordinate to it.

original: athāvayavārthaḥ /
analyzed: atha avayava arthaḥ
translated: Now, the meaning of the parts.

original: praṇamya hetumīśvaram iti / pretyupasargeṇa praṇāmātiśayaṃ darśayati / hetutvaṃ nimittakāraṇatvam / taccānyeṣāmapyastīti īśvarapadam / īśvaraśabdaścānyatra vartamāno 'pi jñānaprastāvānmaheśvara eva vartate / śaṅkarāj jñānamanvicchet iti vacanāt /
analyzed: praṇamya hetum īśvaram iti pra iti upasargeṇa praṇāma atiśayam darśayati hetu tvam nimitta kāraṇa tvam tat ca anyeṣām api asti iti īśvara padam īśvara śabdaḥ ca anyatra jñāna prastāvāt maheśvare eva vartate śaṅkarāt jñānam anvicchet iti vacanāt
translated: Having bowed to the cause, the Lord. The prefix 'pra' indicates the excellence of bowing. Causality means being the instrumental cause. And that exists for others also, so the word 'Īśvara' is used. And the word 'Īśvara', though occurring elsewhere, refers to Maheśvara in the context of knowledge, because of the statement One should seek knowledge from Śaṅkara.

original: nanu vyarthaṃ tarhi hetupadam / jñānaprastāvād viśeṣaṇasiddheḥ / naitadevam / stuterguṇasaṃkīrtanarūpatayā sakalakāryakartṛtvābhidhānāt / anyathā hyanyatarābhidhānenaiva gatārthatvād vyathaṃ syādubhayābhidhānam /
analyzed: nanu vyartham tarhi hetu padam jñāna prastāvāt viśeṣaṇa siddheḥ na etat evam stuteḥ guṇa saṃkīrtana rūpatayā sakala kārya kartṛ tva abhidhānāt anyathā hi anyatara abhidhānena eva gatārtha tvāt vyatham syāt ubhaya abhidhānam
translated: But then the word 'cause' is useless, because the qualification is established by the context of knowledge. This is not so, because praise is of the nature of glorifying the qualities and mentioning the state of being the agent of all actions. Otherwise, since the meaning would be conveyed by mentioning one of the two, the mention of both would be useless.

original: tadevamīśvarapraṇāmānantaraṃ muniṃ praṇamati / munayaścānye 'pi viśiṣṭajñānavairāgyavanto bhavantīti viśeṣaṇam kaṇāda iti / viśiṣṭajñānasambandhitvañca tadabhihitapadārthānāṃ pramāṇāntareṇāsādhanād vijñāyate / ata eva tattvajñānasadbhāve mithyājñānasya rāgadveṣahetorabhāvād dveṣavairāgyaṃ niścīyate /
analyzed: tat evam īśvara praṇāma anantaram munim praṇamati munayaḥ ca anye viśiṣṭa jñāna vairāgyavantaḥ bhavanti iti viśeṣaṇam kaṇādaḥ iti viśiṣṭa jñāna sambandhi tvam ca tad abhihita padārthānām pramāṇa antareṇa asādhanāt vijñāyate atas eva tattva jñāna sadbhāve mithyājñānasya rāga dveṣa hetoḥ abhāvāt dveṣa vairāgyam niścīyate
translated: Thus, after saluting the Lord, he salutes the sage. And since other sages also possess distinguished knowledge and detachment, the qualification is stated. Kanāda means he who eats particles. And his connection with distinguished knowledge is known from the fact that the categories propounded by him cannot be established by other means of knowledge. For this very reason, the existence of true knowledge is ascertained, and the absence of false knowledge, which is the cause of attachment and aversion, is ascertained.

original: tadevaṃ parāparagurunamaskārāpekṣadharmaviśeṣe 'dharmapratibandhāt tattatkāryāṇāmabhāve bhavatyevāvighnataḥ śāstraparisamāptiriti / nanu cāyuktametat / satyapi namaskāre śāstraparisamāpteradarśanāt kādambaryādau / asatyapi darśanāt pramāṇato 'rthapratipattau nyā / bhā / / / ityevamādau /
analyzed: tat evam para apara guru namaskāra apekṣa dharma viśeṣe dharma pratibandhāt tad tad kāryāṇām abhāve bhavati eva avighnataḥ śāstra parisamāptiḥ iti nanu ca ayuktam etat sati api namaskāre śāstra parisamāpteḥ adarśanāt kādambarī ādau asati api darśanāt pramāṇataḥ rtha pratipattau nyā bhā iti evamādau
translated: Thus, in the special Dharma that depends on the salutations to the higher and lower teachers, due to the obstruction of non-Dharma, in the absence of those effects, the completion of the treatise certainly occurs without hindrance. But this is improper, because the completion of the treatise is not seen even when there is a salutation, as in the Kādambari, etc., and because it is seen even when there is none, as in the Nyā.bhā. etc., when there is the understanding of the meaning from a means of knowledge.

original: satyam / śāstraparisamāpteḥ kāryatvādavaśyaṃ kāraṇaṃ vācyamityanyasyāsambhavād dharmaviśeṣaḥ kāraṇamiti / sa ca namaskārādanyasmād vā bhavatu / na niyamyata ityeke / anye tu sādhanaviśeṣād viśiṣyata iti namaskārādevopajāyate dharmaviśeṣaḥ kāraṇamiti /
analyzed: satyam śāstra parisamāpteḥ kārya tvāt avaśyam kāraṇam vācyam iti anyasya asambhavāt dharma viśeṣaḥ kāraṇam iti sa ca namaskārāt anyasmāt vā bhavatu na niyamyate iti eke anye tu sādhana viśeṣāt viśiṣyate iti namaskārāt eva upajāyate dharma viśeṣaḥ kāraṇam iti
translated: True, but since the completion of the treatise is an effect, a cause must necessarily be stated. Since nothing else is possible, the cause is a particular dharma. And that may be from the salutation or something else. Some say it is not restricted. But others say it is distinguished by a particular means, so the cause is a particular dharma arising only from the salutation.

original: atha namaskārābhāve tarhi kathaṃ śāstraparisamāptiriti / na / tatrāpi kāryasadbhāvena kāraṇasadbhāvasiddheḥ / vācikanamaskārābhāve 'pi mānaso namaskāro jñāyata iti / ekadā hi viśiṣṭanamaskārasadbhāve parisamāpterupalambhāditi / tathā hi / mānasanamaskāropacito vāciko namaskāraḥ parisamāpteḥ kāraṇamiṣyate / mānasastu kevalo 'pīti / ata eva kvacid vācikasadbhāve 'pi mānasanamaskārābhāvādaparisamāptiryukteti / tasya cābhāvaḥ kāryānutpādenaiva jñāyata iti / namaskārācca dharmaḥ sampadyata ityāgamād vyāptigrahaṇam / tathā laukiko 'pi puruṣaḥ kṛtanamaskriyaḥ kriyākaraṇe pravartamāno dṛṣṭaḥ / kiṃ punarbhagavān muniranavadyavādī /
analyzed: atha namaskāra abhāve tarhi katham śāstra parisamāptiḥ iti na tatra api kārya sadbhāvena kāraṇa sadbhāva siddheḥ vācika namaskāra abhāve pi mānasaḥ namaskāraḥ jñāyate iti ekadā hi viśiṣṭa namaskāra sadbhāve parisamāpteḥ upalambhāt iti tathā hi mānasa namaskāra upacitaḥ vācikaḥ namaskāraḥ parisamāpteḥ kāraṇam iṣyate mānasaḥ tu kevalaḥ pi iti atas eva kvacid vācika sadbhāve pi mānasa namaskāra abhāvāt aparisamāptiḥ yuktā iti tasya ca abh
translated: If, on the other hand, there is no salutation, then how is the treatise completed? No, even there, the existence of the cause is established by the existence of the effect. Even in the absence of verbal salutation, mental salutation is understood. For, at one time, the completion is observed due to the existence of a special salutation. Thus, it is accepted that verbal salutation accumulated by mental salutation is the cause of completion, but mere mental salutation is also [a cause]. For this very reason, in some cases, even when there is verbal salutation, it is proper that there is no completion due to the absence of mental salutation.
