And its absence is known only by the non-production of the effect. The pervasion is grasped from the scriptures that virtue is accomplished by salutation. Thus, even a worldly person is seen to engage in action and instrument when he has made a salutation. What to speak of the Blessed Sage, the speaker of what is faultless.

original: anye tu asaccodyanirāsārthaṃ kaṇān dadātīti / dayata iti vā vyutpattyantaramāśrayante / atra kila vaiśeṣikasūtraracanākaraṇa ityucyata iti cintyametat / prasiddhyaparijñānaparihārārthaṃ copāttamityalam asadvyākhyānairiti /
analyzed: anye tu asat codya nirāsa artham kaṇān dadāti iti dayate iti vā vyutpatti antaram āśrayante atra kila vaiśeṣika sūtra racanā karaṇaḥ iti ucyate iti cintyam etat prasiddhi aparijñāna parihāra artham ca upāttam iti alam asat vyākhyānaiḥ iti
translated: Others, however, resort to a different derivation, he gives the particles or he has compassion, in order to refute the objection that it is false. Here it is said that the Vaiśeṣika aphorisms are composed, but this should be considered. And it is included in order to avoid the fault of not knowing what is well-known. Enough of false explanations.

original: tadevaṃ parāparagurunamaskārād yato 'ntarāyapradhvaṃso yato vā antevāsī yathoktalakṣaṇasampannaḥ / ato 'nantarameva pratipakṣakriyānantaritaḥ padārthadharmasaṃgrahaḥ pravakṣyata iti / I / na ca ktvāpratyayādeva viśiṣṭānantaryapratipattiḥ / tasya hi samānakartṛkatve sati pūrvakālabhāvitvamātre bhāvāt / tathā hi / bhojanānantaraṃ śayanādikriyāvyavadhāne 'pi bhuktvā vrajatīti prayogo bhavatyeva / atra ceśvarapraṇāmānantarameva / munernamaskārastadanantarameva pravacanakriyeti / na ca apratipakṣakriyāvyudāso 'vayavacalanāderbhāvāditi /
analyzed: tat evam para apara guru namaskārāt yatas ntarāya pradhvaṃsaḥ yatas vā antevāsī yathā ukta lakṣaṇa sampannaḥ atas nantaram eva pratipakṣa kriyā an antaritaḥ padārtha dharma saṃgrahaḥ pravakṣyate iti    na ca ktvāpratyayāt eva viśiṣṭa ānantarya pratipattiḥ tasya hi samāna kartṛka tve sati pūrva kāla bhāvi tva mātre bhāvāt tathā hi bhojana anantaram śayana ādi kriyā vyavadhāne bhuktvā vrajati iti prayogaḥ bhavati eva atra ca īśvara praṇāma anantara
translated: Thus, since the removal of obstacles comes from the salutation to the supreme and lower gurus, or since the disciple is endowed with the aforementioned characteristics, therefore immediately after that, interrupted by the practice of the antidote, the collection of the qualities of the subject matter will be explained. And the knowledge of immediate sequence is not from the ktvā suffix alone, because it exists merely in the state of being prior to the same agent. Thus, even when the action of lying down etc. is interrupted after eating, the usage having eaten, he goes certainly occurs. And here, the salutation to the sage is immediately after the salutation to God, and the action of preaching is immediately after that, and the exclusion of the absence of the practice of the antidote is not due to the existence of the movement of parts.

original: padārthadharmasaṃgrahaḥ iti / padārthānāṃ dharmāsteṣāṃ saṃgraha ityuttarapadaprādhānye 'pi dharmāṇāṃ dharminiṣṭhatayā saṃgraho bhavatyeva / dharmiṇāṃ saṃgraha iti sukhaduḥkhasādhanatvadharmāvabodhe sati pravṛttinivṛttyorbhāvād dharmāṇāmiha prādhānyaṃ na niṣidhyate / tattvajñānañcātra pradhānatayā vivakṣitam / tad dharmiṣūpasarjanatayāpi labhyata eva /
analyzed: padārtha dharma saṃgrahaḥ iti padārthānām dharmāḥ teṣām saṃgrahaḥ iti uttara pada prādhānye pi dharmāṇām dharmi niṣṭhatayā saṃgrahaḥ bhavati eva dharmiṇām saṃgrahaḥ iti sukha duḥkha sādhanatva dharma avabodhe sati pravṛtti nivṛttyoḥ bhāvāt dharmāṇām iha prādhānyam na niṣidhyate tattva jñānam ca atra pradhāna tayā vivakṣitam tat dharmiṣu upasarjana tayā api labhyate eva
translated: The collection of the properties of the objects. Even when the latter part of the compound is primary, the collection of properties is indeed the collection of the subjects, as the properties belong to the subjects. The priority of the properties is not denied here, as engagement and disengagement occur when the means to pleasure and pain are understood. And the knowledge of reality is intended here as primary, and that is indeed obtained even as secondary in the subjects.

original: yadvā tattvajñānapradhānakriyāsambandhād ubhayeṣāṃ prādhānyamiti padārthāśca dharmāśceti samāsaḥ / svātantryaṃ hi pradhānakriyāsambandha eva / na dharmitādātmyaṃ dharmāṇāmiti vakṣyāmaḥ / padārthadharmāṇāṃ saṃgraha iti nibandhāntarairvistaroktānāṃ saṃkṣepeṇābhidhānam / bhāvavyutpattyā tattvajñānamityapare /
analyzed: yat vā tattva jñāna pradhāna kriyā sambandhāt ubhayeṣām prādhānyam iti padārthāḥ ca dharmāḥ ca iti samāsaḥ svātantryam hi pradhāna kriyā sambandhaḥ eva na dharmi tādātmyam dharmāṇām iti vakṣyāmaḥ padārtha dharmāṇām saṃgrahaḥ iti nibandha antaraiḥ vistara uktānām saṃkṣepeṇa abhidhānam bhāva vyutpattyā tattva jñānam iti apare
translated: Or, both are primary due to the connection with the principal action of the knowledge of reality. Thus, the compound is of objects and properties. For independence is indeed the connection with the principal action. We will say that the properties do not have the nature of being properties. The collection of the properties of the objects is the concise statement of those extensively stated in other treatises. Others say that the knowledge of reality is by the derivation of the word bhāva.

original: sa ca pravakṣyate kathayiṣyate / kiṃviśiṣṭaḥ / mahānudayastatkāryañca niḥśreyasamasmād bhavatīti mahodayaḥ iti /
analyzed: sa ca pravakṣyate kathayiṣyate  kiṃviśiṣṭaḥ mahān udayaḥ tad kāryam ca niḥśreyasam asmāt bhavati iti mahā udayaḥ iti
translated: And that will be explained, will be taught. What is its distinguishing feature? It has great rise, and the result of that is supreme good, hence it is of great rise.

original: dravyaguṇakarmasāmānyaviśeṣasamavāyānāṃ ṣaṇṇāṃ padārthānāṃ sādharmyavaidharmyābhyāṃ tattvajñānaṃ niḥśreyasahetuḥ /PDhS
analyzed: dravya guṇa karma sāmānya viśeṣa samavāyānām ṣaṇṇām padārthānām sādharmya vaidharmyābhyām tattva jñānam niḥśreyasa hetuḥ
translated: The knowledge of the truth of the six categories of substance, quality, action, universal, particular, and inherence, through their similarities and dissimilarities, is the cause of supreme good.

original: padārthadharmasaṅgraha ityādisāmānyoktervibhajanāya dravyādivākyam / tacca viśeṣopadarśanāccheṣapratiṣedhaparam / bhavatyeva vibhāgācceyattāvadhāraṇamiti ṣaṇṇāmevābhidhānāt ṣaḍeva padārthā iti labhyate /
analyzed: padārtha dharma saṅgrahaḥ ityādi sāmānya ukteḥ vibhajanāya dravya ādi vākyam tat ca viśeṣa upadarśanāt śeṣa pratiṣedha param bhavati eva vibhāgāt ca iyattā avadhāraṇam iti ṣaṇṇām eva abhidhānāt ṣaṭ eva padārthāḥ iti labhyate
translated: Since the general statement Compendium of the Properties of Categories and so on is made, the sentences on substance etc. are for the purpose of classification. And that, due to the display of particulars, is meant to negate the remainder. Since the determination of the limit is indeed due to the division, and since only six are mentioned, it is understood that there are only six categories.

original: atha abhāvaḥ kasmānnopasaṃkhyāyate / bhāvopasarjanatayā pratibhāsanāt / tathā hi / nāprasiddhabhāvasadbhāvasya nārikeradvīpavāsinastadabhāvapratītiriti / bhāvaparijñānāpekṣitvādabhāvasya na pṛthagupasaṃkhyānam / jñāte hi bhāve tadabhāvaḥ pratīyata eva / tathā hi / dravyaparijñānāttadabhāvaparijñāname / / / / / / / / / / / / jñānaṃ labhyate / teṣāñca prādhānyamupadarśitameva /
analyzed: atha abhāvaḥ kasmāt na upasaṃkhyāyate bhāva upasarjana tayā pratibhāsanāt tathā hi na aprasiddha bhāva sadbhāvasya nārikera dvīpa vāsinaḥ tad abhāva pratītiḥ iti bhāva parijñāna apekṣi tvāt abhāvasya na pṛthak upasaṃkhyānam jñāte hi bhāve tad abhāvaḥ pratīyate eva tathā hi dravya parijñānāt tad abhāva parijñānam jñānam labhyate teṣām ca prādhānyam upadarśitam eva
translated: Now, why is non-existence not enumerated? Because it appears as subordinate to existence. For thus, one who does not know the existence of an existent thing, like one living in a coconut island, does not have the notion of its non-existence. Non-existence is not enumerated separately because it requires the knowledge of existence. For when existence is known, its non-existence is understood. Thus, for example, the knowledge of the absence of substance is obtained from the knowledge of substance. And the primacy of those [three] has been shown.

original: tattvajñānam iti samyaktvasya viśeṣyaṃ jñānamiti / na tu tattvañca tajjñānañceti / ubhayapadavyabhicāre sāmānādhikaraṇyābhāvāt / tattvaṃ hi pṛthivyāṃ gandhaḥ / I / na ca jñānam / jñānañca mithyājñānamapi / na ca tattvamiti vyabhicāre 'pi dharmadharmiśabdānna sāmānādhikaraṇyam / tattvaṃ hi samyaktvaṃ jñānadharma eva /
analyzed: tattva jñānam iti samyaktvasya viśeṣyam jñānam iti na tu tattvam ca tat jñānam ca iti ubhaya pada vyabhicāre sāmānādhikaraṇya abhāvāt tattvam hi pṛthivyām gandhaḥ na ca jñānam jñānam ca mithyājñānam api na ca tattvam iti vyabhicāre dharma dharmi śabdāt na sāmānādhikaraṇyam tattvam hi samyaktvam jñāna dharmaḥ eva
translated: The knowledge of reality is the knowledge that distinguishes reality, not the knowledge that is both reality and knowledge, because when there is a deviation of both terms, there is no co-reference. For reality is the earth's smell, and not knowledge. And knowledge is also false knowledge, and not reality. Even when there is a deviation, there is no co-reference due to the words property and property-possessor. For reality is truth, which is only a property of knowledge.

original: anye tu tattve pradhānatvādātmani sādharmyavaidharmyābhyāmupajātamiti manyante / prādhānyantu dravyādipadārthānāṃ madhye puruṣasya / tatra hi abhyāsavaśādupajātasya niḥśreyasakāraṇatvābhyupagamāt / na ca mithyājñāne prasaṅgo niḥśreyasahetutvena viśeṣaṇāt / mithyājñānasya niḥśreyasahetutvāsambhavāditi / niḥśreyasasya ca heturyathā tattvajñānaṃ tathoktamevādivākye / taccātmajñānamitaraviviktatvāditarapadārthajñānāpekṣamityarthavad dravyādisādharmyavaidharmyajñānam /
analyzed: anye tu tattve pradhāna tvāt ātmani sādharmya vaidharmyābhyām upajātam iti manyante prādhānyan tu dravya ādi padārthānām madhye puruṣasya tatra hi abhyāsa vaśāt upajātasya niḥśreyasa kāraṇa tva abhyupagamāt na ca mithyājñāne prasaṅgaḥ niḥśreyasa hetu tvena viśeṣaṇāt mithyājñānasya niḥśreyasa hetu tva asambhavāt iti niḥśreyasasya ca hetuḥ yathā tattva jñānam tathā uktam eva ādi vākye tat ca ātma jñānam itara vivikta tvāt itara padārtha jñāna
translated: Others, however, think that it arises in the Self through similarity and dissimilarity to the principal [factor] in reality. And the principal [factor] is the Purusha among the categories of substance etc. For there, it is accepted as the cause of final beatitude, which arises by the power of practice. And there is no fallacy in false knowledge, because it is qualified as the cause of final beatitude. Because false knowledge cannot be the cause of final beatitude. And the cause of final beatitude is true knowledge, as stated in the introductory statement itself. And that is the knowledge of the Self, because it is distinguished from others, and depends on the knowledge of other categories. Thus the knowledge of similarity and dissimilarity to substance etc. is meaningful.

original: tacceśvaracodanābhivyaktāddharmādeva /PDhS
analyzed: tat ca īśvara codana abhivyaktāt dharmāt eva
translated: And that arises from Dharma itself, manifested by the injunction of God.

original: athāstu saṃgrahāttattvajñānamavadhāraṇe tu vyāghātaḥ / tathā hi / yadi saṃgrahādeva tattvajñānam / sūtrakārasya na syāt saṃgrahābhāvāt / atha saṃgrahād bhavatyeva / tadasat / mandamateḥ satyapi saṃgrahe tadabhāvāt / atha saṃgrahāt tattvajñānameva / tannāsti duḥkhāderapi darśanādityāśaṅkāparihārārtham tacceśvaracodanā ityādi / tathā hi / asmadādeḥ saṃgrahādeva tattvajñānam / yacca sūtrakārasya jñānaṃ tacceśvaracodanābhivyaktād dharmādiviśeṣādeveti / na ca sa evāstviti vācyam / asmadādestathāvidhadharmābhāvāt / tathā saṃgrahād bhavatyeva tattvajñānam yadi nāma tacceśvaracodanābhivyaktād dharmādeva samuccīyamānāvadhāraṇamanirdiṣṭapratiṣedhārtham / mandamatestu viśiṣṭadharmābhāvānna bhavatyapi / astu vā saṃgrahāt tattvajñānameva na duḥkhādikam / yadi nāma īśvaracodanābhivyaktād dharmādeva / yasya viśiṣṭadharmasadbhāvastasyālpīyasā prayāsena tattvajñānaṃ sampadyata iti /
analyzed: atha astu saṃgrahāt tattva jñānam avadhāraṇe tu vyāghātaḥ tathā hi yadi saṃgrahāt eva tattva jñānam sūtrakārasya na syāt saṃgraha abhāvāt atha saṃgrahāt bhavati eva tat asat manda mateḥ sati api saṃgrahe tad abhāvāt atha saṃgrahāt tattva jñānam eva tat na asti duḥkha ādeḥ api darśanāt iti āśaṅkā parihāra artham tat ca īśvara codanā ityādi tathā hi asmad ādeḥ saṃgrahāt eva tattva jñānam yat ca sūtrakārasya jñānam tat ca īśvara codanā ab
translated: Now, let it be that true knowledge comes from the summary, but there is a contradiction in the determination. Thus, if true knowledge comes only from the summary, it would not be for the author of the aphorisms, because there is no summary. But if it does come from the summary, that is wrong, because for one of slow intellect, even though there is a summary, there is an absence of that. But if true knowledge comes from the summary itself, that is not so, because of the perception of suffering etc. To remove this doubt, the text begins with and that is from God's injunction. Thus, for one like us, true knowledge comes only from the summary, and the knowledge of the author of the aphorisms comes only from the specific dharma manifested by God's injunction. And it cannot be said that that alone should be so, because one like us does not have such dharma. Thus, true knowledge comes from the summary itself, if that is also from the specific dharma manifested by God's injunction, for the sake of determining what is included and not specifying what is prohibited. But for one of slow intellect, it does not come because of the absence of a specific dharma.

original: yad vā kasmād dharmasyādau sūtre vyāvarṇanamīśvarasya vā namaskāra iti codyaparihārārthaṃ tacca tattvajñānamīśvaracodanābhivyaktād dharmādeva bhavatītyatastasyādau pratijñānamīśvarasya ca namaskāra iti / īśvarasya codanā saṅkalpaviśeṣo 'syedamasmāt sampadyatāmiti / tayābhivyaktāt sahakṛtād dharmāt tattvajñānamiti / tathādharmasya sadbhāve kiṃ pramāṇamityapekṣāyāmidamevāvartanīyam īśvarasya codaneti / codanā hi pravartakaṃ vākyaṃ tatpradhānatvād vedaścodaneti / sā ceśvarapraṇītatvāt pramāṇam / tayābhivyaktāt / prakāśitād dharmādeveti /
analyzed: yat vā kasmāt dharmasya ādau sūtre vyāvarṇanam īśvarasya vā namaskāraḥ iti codya parihāra artham tat ca tattva jñānam īśvara codanā abhivyaktāt dharmāt eva bhavati iti atas tasya ādau pratijñānam īśvarasya ca namaskāraḥ iti īśvarasya codanā saṅkalpa viśeṣaḥ sya idam asmāt sampadyatām iti tayā abhivyaktāt sahakṛtāt dharmāt tattva jñānam iti tathā dharmasya sadbhāve kim pramāṇam iti apekṣāyām idam eva āvartanīyam īśvarasya codanā iti codanā hi p
translated: Or, why is the description of Dharma at the beginning of the Sutra, or the salutation to God? To answer this objection, and because that knowledge of reality arises only from Dharma manifested by God's injunction, therefore its promise at the beginning and the salutation to God. And God's injunction is a particular volition, May this be accomplished from this. From that manifested Dharma along with it arises the knowledge of reality. Similarly, when there is doubt about the existence of Dharma, this very [verse] should be repeated: God's injunction. For injunction is an instigating statement, and the Veda is called injunction because it is primarily that. And that is a means of knowledge because it is composed by God. From that manifested, from Dharma illuminated by that.

original: atha ke dravyādayaḥ padārthāḥ / kiṃsvarūpāḥ / kiñca teṣāṃ sādharmyam / kiṃrūpañca vaidharmyam /PDhS
analyzed: atha ke dravya ādayaḥ padārthāḥ kiṃsvarūpāḥ kiñca teṣām sādharmyam kiṃrūpam ca vaidharmyam
translated: Now, what are the categories such as substance? What is their nature? And what is their similarity? And what is their dissimilarity?

original: tadevaṃ dravyādisādharmyavaidharmyajñānasya niḥśreyasakāraṇatvamabhyupagamya tatsvarūpaparijñānārthamāha atha ke dravyādayaḥ padārthāḥ kiṃsvarūpāḥ kiñca teṣāṃ sādharmyaṃ kiṃrūpañca vaidharmyam iti / dravyādiṣu vā nānārūpatayā parairabhidhānāt saṃśaye satīdam /
analyzed: tat evam dravya ādi sādharmya vaidharmya jñānasya niḥśreyasa kāraṇa tvam abhyupagamya tad svarūpa parijñāna artham āha atha ke dravya ādayaḥ padārthāḥ kiṃsvarūpāḥ kiñca teṣām sādharmyam kiṃrūpam ca vaidharmyam iti dravya ādiṣu vā nānā rūpatayā paraiḥ abhidhānāt saṃśaye sati idam
translated: Thus, accepting that the knowledge of the similarities and dissimilarities of substances and other categories is the cause of final beatitude, in order to fully understand their nature, he says: Now, what are substances and other categories? What is their nature? And what is their similarity? And what is their dissimilarity? Or, since others have described substances and other categories in various ways, this is asked when there is doubt.

original: tathā hi / viśeṣyaṃ dravyamiti kecit /
analyzed: tathā hi viśeṣyam dravyam iti kecid
translated: For example, some say that the qualified is substance.

original: krayavikrayayogyañcetyādi / viparyasto vā dravyādīnāmasattvaṃ manyamānaḥ / atha ke dravyādayaḥ padārthāḥ / na santītyāha / tadabhāvānna sādharmyaṃ nāpi vaidharmyamiti /
analyzed: kraya vikraya yogyam ca ityādi viparyastaḥ vā dravya ādīnām asattvam manyamānaḥ atha ke dravya ādayaḥ padārthāḥ na santi iti āha tad abhāvāt na sādharmyam na api vaidharmyam iti
translated: Or one who thinks that substances and other categories do not exist, or one who is confused, says What are substances and other categories? He says They do not exist. Because of their non-existence, there is no similarity, nor any dissimilarity.

original: tathā hi / cakṣuḥsparśanābhyāṃ rūpasparśayoḥ pratibhāsanānna tadvyatiriktaṃ dravyamasti / yaccedaṃ ghaṭādijñānaṃ tanna pramāṇaṃ kalpanājñānatvāt / bādhakañca pramāṇamasti vṛttivikalpādi / tathā cāvayavā avayavini vartanta iti nābhyupagatam / avayavī cāvayaveṣu vartamānaḥ kimekadeśe vartate vyāptyā vā / ekadeśena vṛttāvavayavāntaraprasaṅgaḥ / athaikadeśe vartate / anekavṛttitvavyāghātaḥ / ekadravyañca dravyaṃ syāt / tatra cāvayavavibhāgābhāvānnityatvam / ekasya ca kramayaugapadyābhyāmajanakatvam / rūpādyanutpattiśca / anekarūpāderjanakatvābhyupagamāt / avayaveṣu cāvayavīti pratibhāsābhāvaḥ / tasyaikadravyatvāt / atha na pratyekaṃ parisamāptyā vartate / kiṃ tarhi sarvāvayaveṣveka eveti / tatrāpyekasvarūpeṇāvayavāntarapravṛttau teṣāmekatāprasaṅgaḥ / tadavayavavṛttirūpatvādavayavinaḥ / svarūpāntareṇa cānekatvam / svarūpabhedasya bhedalakṣaṇatvāditi vṛttyanupapatterasattvam / vṛttyā hi sattvaṃ vyāptam / sā ca vyāvartamānā svavyāptaṃ sattvaṃ gṛhītvā vyāvartata ityāśayaḥ / aparasya gavāśvādivad bhinnadeśatayā grahaṇam / tadagrahe tadbuddhyabhāvācca / ityavayavino 'sattve rūpādisamudāyamātraṃ ghaṭādaya iti / samudāyaḥ samudāyibhyo nārthāntaramiti saṃvṛtisanneva /
analyzed: tathā hi cakṣuḥ sparśanābhyām rūpa sparśayoḥ pratibhāsanāt na tad vyatiriktam dravyam asti yat ca idam ghaṭa ādi jñānam tat na pramāṇam kalpanā jñāna tvāt bādhakam ca pramāṇam asti vṛtti vikalpa ādi tathā ca avayavāḥ avayavini vartante iti na abhyupagatam avayavī ca avayaveṣu vartamānaḥ kim eka deśe vartate vyāptyā vā eka deśena vṛttau avayava antara prasaṅgaḥ atha eka deśe vartate aneka vṛtti tva vyāghātaḥ eka dravyam ca dravyam syāt tatra ca a
translated: For thus: Since form and touch are manifested by the eye and touch, there is no substance apart from them. And this knowledge of pot, etc. is not a means of valid knowledge, because it is a conceptual cognition. And there is a means of valid knowledge that contradicts, such as the distinction of inherence. And thus, it is not accepted that the parts inhere in the whole. And the whole inhering in the parts, does it inhere in one part or pervasively? If it inheres in one part, there is the consequence of another part. If it inheres in one part, there is the contradiction of inhering in many. And the substance would be a single substance. And there, due to the absence of division of parts, it would be eternal. And the single one does not produce by sequence and simultaneity. And there would be no production of form, etc. Because the production of many forms, etc. is accepted. And in the parts, there is no appearance of the whole. Because it is a single substance. If it does not inhere in each individually, then what? That it is only one in all the parts? There

original: evaṃ vijñānamātraṃ sarvam / tato 'rthāntarasya sadbhāve pramāṇābhāvādityevaṃ śūnyavādivādā api yathāvasaraṃ nirākartavyā iti neha pratanyate /
analyzed: evam vijñānamātram sarvam tatas ṛtha antarasya sadbhāve pramāṇa abhāvāt iti evam śūnyavādi vādāḥ api yathāvasaram nirākartavyāḥ iti na iha pratanyate
translated: Thus, everything is mere consciousness. Therefore, because there is no means of valid knowledge for the existence of anything else, the doctrines of the proponents of emptiness should be refuted as appropriate. Thus, it is not elaborated here.

original: tatra dravyāṇi pṛthivyaptejovāyvākāśakāladigātmamanāṃsi sāmānyaviśeṣasaṃjñayoktāni navaiveti / tadvyatirekeṇānyasya saṃjñānabhidhānāt /PDhS
analyzed: tatra dravyāṇi pṛthivī ap tejaḥ vāyu ākāśa kāla diś ātma manāṃsi sāmānya viśeṣa saṃjñayā uktāni nava eva iti tad vyatirekeṇa anyasya saṃjñā anabhidhānāt
translated: There, the substances are earth, water, fire, air, space, time, direction, self, and mind, which are said to be nine only, with the names of universals and particulars. Because nothing else is known or named apart from them.

original: saṃśayitāvyutpannayordravyasvarūpapratipādanārthamāha tatra dravyāṇi ityādi / tathā hi / pratyakṣeṇa rūpādivyatiriktasya dravyasyāvadhāraṇād viparyastavyudāsaḥ / rūpaṃ hi cakṣuṣaiva gṛhyate sparśastvagindriyeṇa / dvīndriyagrāhyantu dravyam / kathametat / pratisandhānāt / tathā hi / yamahamadrākṣaṃ cakṣuṣā tameva spṛśāmi / yañcāspṛśaṃ tameva paśyāmīti / na ca dvābhyāmindriyābhyāmekārthagrahaṇaṃ vinā pratisandhānaṃ nyāyyam / rūpasparśayośca pratiniyatendriyagrāhyatvādetanna sambhavatīti /
analyzed: saṃśayita avyutpannayoḥ dravya svarūpa pratipādana artham āha tatra dravyāṇi ityādi tathā hi pratyakṣeṇa rūpa ādi vyatiriktasya dravyasya avadhāraṇāt viparyasta vyudāsaḥ rūpam hi cakṣuṣā eva gṛhyate sparśaḥ tvac indriyeṇa dvi indriya grāhyan tu dravyam  katham etat pratisandhānāt tathā hi yam aham adrākṣam cakṣuṣā tam eva spṛśāmi yat ca aspṛśam tam eva paśyāmi iti na ca dvābhyām indriyābhyām eka artha grahaṇam vinā pratisandhānam nyāyyam
translated: To explain the nature of substance to those who are doubtful or ignorant, he says Among them, substances and so on. For example, by directly perceiving substance as distinct from form and so on, the mistaken [view] is excluded. For form is grasped only by the eye, while touch is grasped by the tactile sense. But substance is grasped by both senses. How is this known? From recognition. For one recognizes, What I saw with the eye, that I now touch. And what I touched, that I now see. And without the grasping of a single object by two senses, recognition is not reasonable. And since form and touch are grasped by distinct senses, this is not possible.

original: athedaṃ kalpanājñānamiti cet / kimidaṃ kalpanājñānaṃ nāmeti / atha kṣaṇikatvānnirvikalpakajñānasamakālamarthavināśe smaraṇānantarameva tadbhavatīti nirviṣayatvādapramāṇamiti cet / na / kṣaṇikatvāsiddhau smaraṇānantarabhāvino 'pi nirvikalpakajñānavadarthānvayavyatirekānuvidhānādarthajatvameva / athārthajatve nirvikalpakajñānasamakālamevārthasya sadbhāvādindriyāṇāñcāvicārakatvena syādetaditi / tanna / sahakāryabhāvāt / tathā hi / indriyamartheṣu savikalpakajñānotpattau saṅketasmaraṇāpekṣam / atha smaraṇe vārthasyendriyasya ca kimatiśayādhānamanatiśayanivṛttiriṣyate / na / tasyaivātiśayatvāt / tathā hi / yad yasya sadbhāve kāryaṃ karoti tattasyātiśayaḥ / smaraṇasadbhāve cendriyaṃ kāryakṛditi smaraṇameva tasyātiśayaḥ / smaraṇād vā kārakasākalyamevātiśayaḥ sampadyate / tadvaikalyañcānatiśayo nivartate / sākalye hi kāryakaraṇāditi / ete yadāhuḥ /
analyzed: atha idam kalpanā jñānam iti ced kim idam kalpanā jñānam nāma iti atha kṣaṇika tvāt nirvikalpaka jñāna sama kālam artha vināśe smaraṇa anantaram eva tat bhavati iti nirviṣaya tvāt apramāṇam iti ced na kṣaṇika tva asiddhau nirvikalpaka jñāna vat artha anvaya vyatireka anuvidhānāt artha ja tvam eva atha artha ja tve nirvikalpaka jñāna sama kālam eva arthasya sadbhāvāt indriyāṇām ca avicāraka tvena syāt etat iti tat na sahakāri abhāvāt tathā hi indriyam artheṣ
translated: If it is argued that this is a conceptual cognition, what is this called conceptual cognition? If it is argued that it arises only after memory, because the object is destroyed simultaneously with the momentary non-conceptual cognition, and therefore it is not a valid means of knowledge due to being objectless, it is not so. When momentariness is not established, even that which arises after memory has the object as its cause, like the non-conceptual cognition, because it conforms to the presence and absence of the object. If it is argued that if it has the object as its cause, the object would exist simultaneously with the non-conceptual cognition, and the sense faculties would not be able to discriminate, that is not so. Because of the absence of a cooperating factor. Thus, in the production of conceptual cognition regarding objects, the sense faculty depends on the memory of convention. If it is argued that in memory, what is done to the object and the sense faculty is the establishment or removal of excellence, it is not so. Because that itself is excellence. Thus, that which performs its function in the presence of something is the excellence of that. And if the sense faculty performs its function in the presence of memory, it is the excellence of memory.

original: yaḥ prāgajanako buddherupayogāviśeṣataḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ prāk ajanakaḥ buddheḥ upayoga aviśeṣataḥ
translated: He who was not the producer of cognition earlier due to lack of utility,

original: sa paścādapi tena syādarthāpāye 'pi netradhīḥ // pra / vini / / pṛ /
analyzed: sa paścāt api tena syāt artha apāye pi netra dhīḥ pra vini pṛ
translated: he would be so later also, even in the absence of the object, the cognition of the eye would be there.

original: iti / etadapāstaṃ bhavati / upayogāviśeṣasyāsiddhatvāt / tathā hi / nirvikalpakabodhe nendriyasya saṅketasmaraṇamasti / savikalpake tvastītyupayogaviśeṣaḥ /
analyzed: iti etat apāstam bhavati upayoga aviśeṣasya asiddha tvāt tathā hi nirvikalpaka bodhe na indriyasya saṅketa smaraṇam asti savikalpake tu asti iti upayoga viśeṣaḥ
translated: Thus. This is refuted, because the lack of difference in utility is not established. For, in indeterminate cognition, there is no recollection of convention for the sense organ, but in determinate cognition, there is, so there is a difference in utility.

original: savikalpakajñānasyārthajatvavicāraḥ
translated: Discussion on whether determinate cognition arises from the object

original: atha śabdākāraṃ savikalpakaṃ jñānam / śabdarūpatā cārthe nāsti / prathamendriyasannipāta eva savikalpakotpattiprasaṅgāt / cakṣurādinā vā paricchedaḥ / śrotraparicchedyatvena I / darśanāditi nirviṣayatvaṃ savikalpakajñānasya / tadasat / ākāravādapratiṣedhasya vakṣyamāṇatvānna śabdarūpatā jñāne 'sti / jñānavailakṣaṇye tu sahakārivailakṣaṇyameva kāraṇamityuktam /
analyzed: atha śabda ākāram sa vikalpakam jñānam śabda rūpa tā ca arthe na asti prathama indriya sannipāte eva sa vikalpaka utpatti prasaṅgāt cakṣuḥ ādinā vā paricchedaḥ śrotra paricchedya tvena darśanāt iti nirviṣaya tvam sa vikalpaka jñānasya tat asat ākāra vāda pratiṣedhasya vakṣyamāṇa tvāt na śabda rūpa tā jñāne sti jñāna vailakṣaṇye tu sahakāri vailakṣaṇyam eva kāraṇam iti uktam
translated: If determinate cognition has the form of words, and the form of words does not exist in the object, then there would be the undesirable consequence of determinate cognition arising even at the first contact with the sense organ, or it would be apprehended by the eye etc., because it is to be apprehended by the ear. Thus, determinate cognition would be objectless. That is not so. Because the doctrine of form will be refuted later, the form of words does not exist in cognition. But the difference in auxiliaries is the cause for the difference in cognition, as stated.

original: dravyāsattve cānyannimittaṃ vācyaṃ pratisandhānasya / athāstyevānādikālaparipuṣṭavāsaneti cet / na / tasyāḥ sadbhāve pramāṇābhāvāt / atha savikalpakaṃ jñānameva pramāṇamiti cet / na / anyathāpi bhāvāt / tathā hi / arthasadbhāve 'pyupapadyata iti kathaṃ vāsanāsadbhāve pramāṇam / anvayavyatirekābhyāmanyatrāpi ca kāryakāraṇabhāvāvagatistau vendriyasyehāpi sta iti / atha nirvikalpakajñānotpattāvindriyasya vyāpārāttadadhīnatayā ca savikalpake 'pi vyāpāra iva saṃlakṣyate na vastutaḥ / tanna / akṣaṇikatve satyubhayatrāpi vyāpārasambhavāt / na ca nirvikalpakajñānameva saṅketasmṛtidvāreṇa savikalpakajñānotpattau kāraṇamityasti pratibandhaḥ / pratyakṣasya niyamena svalakṣaṇaviṣayatvena kramāviṣayatvāt / anumānantu sāmānyaviṣayameveti / na ca pratibaddhaṃ liṅgamasti / kāryañcānyathā sambhavatīti na krame pramāṇam /
analyzed: dravya asattve ca anyat nimittam vācyam pratisandhānasya  atha asti eva anādi kāla paripuṣṭa vāsanā iti ced na tasyāḥ sadbhāve pramāṇa abhāvāt atha savikalpakam jñānam eva pramāṇam iti ced na anyathā api bhāvāt tathā hi artha sadbhāve pi upapadyate iti katham vāsanā sadbhāve pramāṇam anvaya vyatirekābhyām anyatra api ca kārya kāraṇa bhāva avagatiḥ tau vā indriyasya iha api staḥ iti atha nirvikalpaka jñāna utpattau indriyasya vyāpārāt tad adhīna tayā ca
translated: And if the substance does not exist, another cause of the recognition must be stated. If it is argued that the impression nourished from beginningless time exists, that is not so, because there is no evidence for its existence. If it is argued that determinate cognition itself is the evidence, that is not so, because it exists even otherwise. Thus, how can the existence of impression be established when it is possible even in the presence of the object? And the relation of cause and effect is understood elsewhere also by positive and negative concomitance, and those two are present here also with regard to the sense organ. If it is argued that the operation of the sense organ in the production of indeterminate cognition is inferred as the basis of the operation in determinate cognition also, that is not so, because the operation is possible in both cases even if it is not momentary. And there is no restriction that indeterminate cognition alone is the cause of the production of determinate cognition through the recollection of convention, because perception is invariably the object of specific individuality and hence cannot be the object of succession.

original: svasaṃvedanavādinaśca vijñānaṃ svaparicchede eva pramāṇaṃ nārthāntarasyeti / yadi ca vāsanaiva nimittam / sā na vijñānādarthāntaram / rūparasagandhasparśaśabdajñānavyatiriktasya nimittasyānabhyupagamāt / tādātmye tu bodharūpatayā sarvatrāviśeṣād vikalpavaicitryaṃ na syāt / atha vikalpavaicitryādeva vāsanāvaicitryaṃ na kāryata iti cet / tāsāñca vijñānādabhede vijñānavadekatāprasaṅgaḥ / vijñānasya vānekatvamanekārthatādātmyāt / viparyaye vā tādātmyānupapatteḥ / yadi ca vāsanā viśiṣṭajñānaheturbāhyā ceti / saṃjñāmātraṃ bhidyeta artho vāsaneti / atha vasturūpaiva vāsanā / na tarhi tasyā jñānajanakatvam / arthakriyākāritvasya vastulakṣaṇatvāt /
analyzed: sva saṃvedana vādinaḥ ca vijñānam sva paricchede eva pramāṇam na artha antarasya iti  yadi ca vāsanā eva nimittam sā na vijñānāt artha antaram rūpa rasa gandha sparśa śabda jñāna vyatiriktasya nimittasya anabhyupagamāt tādātmye tu bodha rūpa tayā sarvatra aviśeṣāt vikalpa vaicitryam na syāt atha vikalpa vaicitryāt eva vāsanā vaicitryam na kāryataḥ iti ced tāsām ca vijñānāt abhede vijñāna vat ekatā prasaṅgaḥ vijñānasya vā aneka tvam aneka artha tādātmyā
translated: And for those who advocate the doctrine of self-awareness, consciousness is a means of valid knowledge only in the cognition of itself, not of an external object. If the cause is only vāsanā, and that is not different from consciousness, because no cause is accepted apart from the knowledge of form, taste, smell, touch, and sound, then if they are identical, there would be no diversity of conceptual cognitions, because of the absence of any distinction in the form of cognition in all cases. If it is argued that the diversity of vāsanās is due to the diversity of conceptual cognitions, not to the effect, then, if those vāsanās are not different from consciousness, they would have to be one like consciousness. Or consciousness would have to be many, because of the identity with many external objects. In the contrary case, the identity is not possible. And if vāsanā is the cause of a particular cognition and external, then only the name would be different, the object being vāsanā. If vāsanā is of the nature of an entity, then it cannot produce cognition, because the characteristic of an entity is to perform a function.

original: atha smaraṇānantarabhāvitvaṃ savikalpakatvam / taccārthajatvasya prasādhitatvānna dūṣaṇam / abhyupagame vā nirvikalpakasyāpi savikalpakatvaprasaṅgaḥ / tathā hi / rūpasmaraṇānantaraṃ rasarasanasannipāte rasajñānamutpadyate / tatra ca rūpasmṛteḥ pūrvakālabhāvitvāt samanantarakāraṇatvaṃ bodhād bodharūpateti nyāyādastu tasyāpi kalpanātvaṃ smaraṇānantarabhāvitvāt / na cātra bodharūpatayā samanantarakāraṇatvamanyatra smṛtirūpatayeti vācyam / bodhādarthāntarasya smṛtirūpasya tādātmye satyabhāvāt / na cābhede sati I / vyavasthopapadyate kvacid bodharūpatayā samanantarakāraṇatvaṃ kvacidrūpāntareṇeti / ato na smaraṇānantarabhāvitvaṃ savikalpakatvam / na cārthajatvasiddhau nāmajātyādyullekhenotpattirdūṣaṇamiti / kalpanātvasyāsambhavāt pratisandhānaṃ dravyasiddhau pramāṇam /
analyzed: atha smaraṇa anantara bhāvi tvam savikalpaka tvam tat ca artha ja tvasya prasādhita tvāt na dūṣaṇam abhyupagame vā nirvikalpakasya api savikalpaka tva prasaṅgaḥ tathā hi rūpa smaraṇa anantaram rasa rasana sannipāte rasa jñānam utpadyate tatra ca rūpa smṛteḥ pūrva kāla bhāvi tvāt samanantara kāraṇa tvam bodhāt bodha rūpa tā iti nyāyāt astu tasya api kalpanā tvam smaraṇa anantara bhāvi tvāt na ca atra bodha rūpa tayā samanantara kāraṇa tvam anyatra smṛti rū
translated: If, on the other hand, being subsequent to recollection is conceptual cognition, and that is established as arising from the object, it is not a fault. If accepted, even non-conceptual cognition would be conceptual, because thus: after the recollection of form, when there is contact of taste with the tongue, knowledge of taste arises. And there, since recollection exists prior to that time, by the principle that the immediate cause is of the nature of cognition, let that also be conceptual, because it exists subsequent to recollection. And here it cannot be said that the immediate cause is by the nature of cognition, and elsewhere by the nature of memory, because the nature of memory, which is different from cognition, does not exist in identity with it. And when there is non-difference, the arrangement is not possible that somewhere the immediate cause is by the nature of cognition, and elsewhere by a different nature. Therefore, being subsequent to recollection is not conceptual cognition. And when the arising by the manifestation of name, genus, etc. is established as arising from the object, it is not a fault.

original: evaṃ ghaṭādijñānasyāpyālambanaṃ vācyaṃ tasya hi samyagjñānatvāt / na rūpādisamudāyaḥ / rūpādīnāṃ pratiniyatendriyagrāhyatayā tatsamudāyasyaikendriyāviṣayatvāt / na cāparamārthasato rūpādisamudāyasya jñānajanakatvam / tasya cānupalabdhatve nāṇūnāṃ sadbhāve pramāṇamasti / teṣāṃ hi kāryagamyatvāt / na cāsaṃhataḥ paramāṇurasti / ṣaṭkena yugapad yogāditi tasyāpyasattvaṃ paramārthataḥ / asañcīyamānaścāsmaddarśanaviṣayo na bhavatyeveti ghaṭādibuddhernirviṣayatvaprasaṅgaḥ / na cābādhyamānajñānasyānālambanatvamityabhinnatvādabhinnāvayaviviṣayatvam /
analyzed: evam ghaṭa ādi jñānasya api ālambanam vācyam tasya hi samyak jñāna tvāt na rūpa ādi samudāyaḥ rūpa ādīnām pratiniyata indriya grāhya tayā tad samudāyasya eka indriya aviṣaya tvāt na ca aparamārtha sataḥ rūpa ādi samudāyasya jñāna janaka tvam tasya ca anupalabdha tve na aṇūnām sadbhāve pramāṇam asti teṣām hi kārya gamya tvāt na ca asaṃhataḥ paramāṇuḥ asti ṣaṭkena yugapad yogāt iti tasya api asattvam paramārthataḥ asañcīyamānaḥ ca asmad dar
translated: Similarly, the object of the cognition of a pot etc. should also be stated, because it is a valid cognition. It is not the aggregate of form etc., because the aggregate of form etc. is not the object of a single sense organ, as form etc. are grasped by their respective sense organs. And the aggregate of form etc., which is not ultimately real, cannot produce cognition. And there is no proof for the existence of atoms when they are not perceived, because they are to be inferred from their effects. And there is no uncombined atom, because of the simultaneous conjunction with six [other atoms]. Therefore, it also does not exist ultimately. And what is not accumulated does not become the object of our perception. Thus, there would be the consequence that the cognition of a pot etc. is without an object. And the cognition that is not contradicted cannot be without an object. Therefore, because of non-difference, the object is a non-different whole.

original: athāsti vṛttivikalpādibādhakamiti cet / na / tasyāpramāṇatvāt / tathā hi / vṛttyanupapatterasattvamiti / kimidaṃ svatantrasādhanamuta prasaṅgasādhanamiti / yadi svatantrasādhanam / avayavī dharmī nāstīti sādhyamiti pratijñāvākye padayorvyāghāto yathā / idaṃ nāsti ceti / hetorāśrayāsiddhatvañca dharmiṇo 'prasiddhatvāt / tathā svamate rūpādīnāṃ sattvam / na ca vṛttirastīti vyabhicāraḥ samavāyānabhyupagamāt / atha paravyāptyā parasyāniṣṭāpādanamiti / pareṇa hi avayavī abhyupagata iti dharmitvenopāttastasya pratipādyatvāditi / tatra yadi pareṇa pramāṇāt pratipannastenaiva bādhyamānatvādanutthānaṃ viparītānumānasya / na cānenaiva tasya bādhād tadantareṇa pakṣadharmatvāditi / athāpramāṇena pratipannastarhi pramāṇaṃ vinā prameyasyāsiddhiriti vācyam / kimanumānopanyāsena / tasyāpakṣadharmatayā apramāṇatvāt / na ca parasya vṛttyā sattvaṃ vyāptaṃ tadantareṇāpyākāśādāvupalambhādityanekāntaḥ svarūpāsiddhaśca / vṛtteḥ samavāyasya siddhatvāt /
analyzed: atha asti vṛtti vikalpa ādi bādhakam iti ced na tasya apramāṇa tvāt tathā hi vṛtti anupapatteḥ asattvam iti  kim idam svatantra sādhanam uta prasaṅga sādhanam iti yadi svatantra sādhanam avayavī dharmī na asti iti sādhyam iti pratijñā vākye padayoḥ vyāghātaḥ yathā idam na asti ca iti hetoḥ āśraya asiddha tvam ca prasiddha tvāt tathā sva mate rūpa ādīnām sattvam na ca vṛttiḥ asti iti vyabhicāraḥ samavāya anabhyupagamāt atha para vyāptyā parasya aniṣṭa
translated: If it is argued that there are objections to the alternatives of inherence, etc., it is not so, because they are not valid means of knowledge. Thus, non-existence due to the impossibility of inherence - is this an independent proof or a reductio ad absurdum? If it is an independent proof, there is a contradiction between the words of the proposition that the whole does not exist, as in this does not exist, and the reason is unestablished due to the non-establishedness of the subject. And there is a fallacy, as in one's own view, the existence of form, etc., and the non-existence of inherence, due to the non-acceptance of inherence. Or, if it is argued that the undesirable consequence is imposed on the opponent by the opponent's pervasion, the opponent has accepted the whole and has therefore been included as the subject, because it is to be taught. There, if the opponent has understood it through a valid means of knowledge, then the counter-inference does not arise because it is being contradicted by that itself. And it is not because it is contradicted by this itself, due to the property of the subject being without that. Or, if the opponent has understood it through an invalid means of knowledge,

original: yaccedaṃ naikadeśena sarvātmanā vā vartata ityevamekadeśasyāvṛttitvāt / na ca bhedaśabdasyābhinnāvayavinyupapattiḥ / bahuṣu dṛṣṭatvāt / tathā hi / bahūnāmanyatamābhidhānamekadeśaḥ / niravaśeṣatā ca sarvaśabdasyārthaḥ / tathā viśeṣapratiṣedhasya śeṣābhyanujñāviṣayatvāt prakārāntareṇa vṛttiḥ prāpnoti / anyathā hi na vartata iti vācyam / na caikadeśe sati vṛttiryathā vaṃśasya stambheṣu / nirdeśānāmavṛttitvaprasaṅgāt / paramāṇūnāñca vṛttyabhāve dvyaṇukādiprakrameṇa kāryānutpattiḥ /
analyzed: yat ca idam na eka deśena sarva ātmanā vā vartate iti evam eka deśasya avṛtti tvāt  na ca bheda śabdasya abhinna avayavinī upapattiḥ bahuṣu dṛṣṭa tvāt tathā hi bahūnām anyatama abhidhānam eka deśaḥ niravaśeṣa tā ca sarva śabdasya arthaḥ tathā viśeṣa pratiṣedhasya śeṣa abhyanujñā viṣaya tvāt prakāra antareṇa vṛttiḥ prāpnoti anyathā hi na vartate iti vācyam na ca eka deśe sati vṛttiḥ yathā vaṃśasya stambheṣu nirdeśānām avṛtti tva pras
translated: And this, being neither partially nor wholly existent, the non-existence of a part is thus. And the word 'difference' is not appropriate for an indivisible whole, because it is seen in many. Thus, the designation of one among many is a part, and the meaning of the word 'all' is without remainder. Similarly, the existence in a different way is due to the subject matter of the permission of the rest by the negation of the particular. Otherwise, it should be said that it does not exist. And when there is a part, there is existence, just as a bamboo exists in its stems. Because it would follow that the designations do not exist, and because there is no existence of atoms, the effect does not arise in the process beginning with dyads.

original: athāyaṃ vikalpārthaḥ / tatra kiṃ vyāptyā vartate uta / avyāptyā veti / tatra rūpā /vat svāśrayavyāpitvenābhyupagamaḥ / saṃyogādivadavyāpyatvaṃ vṛttitveneti / tathā hi / avayaveṣu avayavī vartate samavāyavṛttyā na tu rūpāntareṇeti svabhāvakalpo 'pi nirastaḥ /
analyzed: atha ayam vikalpa arthaḥ tatra kim vyāptyā vartate uta avyāptyā vā iti tatra rūpā vat svāśraya vyāpi tvena abhyupagamaḥ saṃyoga ādi vat avyāpya tvam vṛtti tvena iti tathā hi avayaveṣu avayavī vartate samavāya vṛttyā na tu rūpa antareṇa iti svabhāva kalpaḥ api nirastaḥ
translated: Now, this is the meaning of the option. There, does it exist by pervasion or by non-pervasion? There, the form is accepted as pervading its substratum, like conjunction, etc., and non-pervasion as inherence. For instance, the inherence of the whole in the parts exists by the relation of inherence, not by another form. Thus, the assumption of nature is also refuted.

original: atha avayavī gṛhyamāṇo yadi aśeṣāvayavagrahaṇād gṛhyate madhyāparabhāgāvayavānāmagrahaṇāccāgrahaṇameva syāt / ekāvayavagrahaṇe tu sāsnāmātropalambhe 'pyupalambhaḥ syāt / naitadevam / bhūyo 'vayavendriyasannikarṣānugṛhītena avayavīndriyasannikarṣeṇa grahaṇāt / kāryasadbhāvācca kāraṇacintā pravartata ityaparokṣajñāne siddhe 'vayavinyetatkāraṇamityucyate / evaṃ deśabhedenāgrahaṇāditi rūpādibhirvyabhicāraḥ / tathā hi / rūpādayo na deśabhedena gṛhyante tathāpi santaḥ parasparaṃ bhinnāśceti pratibhāsabhedasya vidyamānatvāt / gavādayo 'pi pratibhāsabhedādeva bhidyante na deśabhedāt / nirdeśānāmabhedaprasaṅgāt / evaṃ tadagrahe tadbuddhyabhāvāccetyayamapi viruddhaḥ / tathā hi / teṣāmavayavānāmagrahe tasminnavayavini buddhyabhāva ityayamartho 'vayavagrahe 'vayavini buddhirityavayavinaḥ sattvam / tathā ca viśeṣaṇagrahaṇād viśeṣyabuddherna cāsattvaṃ na cāpyabhedaḥ / tathāvayavigrahe 'vayavagraho 'siddhaḥ / mandamandaprakāśe sati saṃsthānamātrasyāvayavino grahaṇāditi / ayañcāvayavivādo 'smadgurubhirvistareṇokta iti neha pratanyate / siddhe cāvayavini prāyastadāśritā guṇādayo 'pi sidhyanti ca /
analyzed: atha avayavī gṛhyamāṇaḥ yadi aśeṣa avayava grahaṇāt gṛhyate madhya apara bhāga avayavānām agrahaṇāt ca agrahaṇam eva syāt eka avayava grahaṇe tu sāsnā mātra upalambhe pi upalambhaḥ syāt na etat evam bhūyas vayava indriya sannikarṣa anugṛhītena avayavi indriya sannikarṣeṇa grahaṇāt kārya sadbhāvāt ca kāraṇa cintā pravartate iti aparokṣa jñāne siddhe vayavini etat kāraṇam iti ucyate evam deśa bhedena agrahaṇāt iti rūpa ādibhiḥ vyabhicāraḥ
translated: Now, if the whole is apprehended when the parts are apprehended without exception, then it would not be apprehended due to the non-apprehension of the middle and rear parts. But if a single part is apprehended, then it would be apprehended even when only the dewlap is perceived. This is not so. Because it is apprehended by the contact of the whole with the sense organ, which is aided by the contact of many parts with the sense organ. And because the consideration of the cause proceeds from the existence of the effect, when the existence of the whole is established by the direct perception, it is said that this is the cause of it. Thus, the argument because it is not apprehended as different in space is fallacious, as it is contradicted by color etc. For color etc. are not apprehended as different in space, yet they exist and are mutually different, because the difference in appearance exists. Cows etc. are also distinguished only by the difference in appearance, not by the difference in space, because it would lead to the non-difference of the designations. Thus, the argument because there is no cognition of it when it is not apprehended is also contradictory. For, when those parts are not apprehended,

original: dravyādipadārthoddeśaprakaraṇam
analyzed: dravya ādi padārtha uddeśa prakaraṇam
translated: Chapter on the classification of substance and other categories

original: tatra dravyeṣu pratijñāṃ karoti dravyāṇi paramārthasantītyabādhyamānajñānaviṣayatvāt / yad yadabādhyamānajñānaviṣayaṃ tattat paramārthasat / yathā vijñānam / tathā abādhyamānajñānaviṣayāṇyamūni / tasmāt paramārthasantīti / atra pakṣīkṛteṣvabādhyamānajñānaviṣayatvamiti pakṣadharmatvam / paramārthasati ca jñāne jñānaviṣayatvaṃ vakṣyāma iti sapakṣe sattvam / vipakṣācca kharaviṣāṇādervyāvṛttiriti / viparītārthopasthāpakayoḥ pratyakṣāgamayoranupalambhādabādhitaviṣayatvam / asatpratipakṣopapatteśca prāmāṇyamiti /
analyzed: tatra dravyeṣu pratijñām karoti dravyāṇi paramārtha santi iti abādhyamāna jñāna viṣaya tvāt yat yat abādhyamāna jñāna viṣayam tat tat paramārtha sat yathā vijñānam tathā abādhyamāna jñāna viṣayāṇi amūni tasmāt paramārtha santi iti atra pakṣīkṛteṣu abādhyamāna jñāna viṣaya tvam iti pakṣa dharma tvam paramārtha sati ca jñāne jñāna viṣaya tvam vakṣyāmaḥ iti sapakṣe sattvam vipakṣāt ca khara viṣāṇa ādeḥ vyāvṛttiḥ iti viparīta a
translated: There, regarding substances, he makes a proposition: Substances exist in reality, because they are the objects of knowledge that are not negated. Whatever is the object of knowledge that is not negated, that exists in reality, like consciousness. Similarly, these are the objects of knowledge that are not negated. Therefore, they exist in reality. Here, regarding what is posited as the subject, being the object of knowledge that is not negated is the property of the subject. And we will say that in the case of knowledge that exists in reality, being the object of knowledge is present in the similar instance. And it is excluded from the dissimilar instance, such as a barren woman's son. The object of knowledge that is not negated is due to the non-apprehension of perception and scripture, which present the opposite meaning. And the validity is due to the possibility of a counter-argument that does not exist.

original: evaṃ pṛthivyaptejovāyvākāśakāladigātmamanāṃsi ityatra dvandvaḥ samāsaḥ sarveṣāṃ svātantryāt / atra ca dravyāṇīti pratijñāyāṃ dravyatvayogaḥ sādhanaṃ vakṣyati / tathā pṛthivyādibhede ca pṛthivītvādiviśeṣalakṣaṇamiti / etāni ca sāmānyaviśeṣasaṃjñayoktāni sāmānyasaṃjñā dravyamiti / viśeṣasaṃjñā ca pṛthivītvādayastābhiruktāni / kiyanti / navaiveti avadhāryante / nyūnādhikapratipādakapramāṇābhāvāt / tathā hi / pṛthivyādisadbhāvasya vakṣyamāṇatvānna nyūnatā /
analyzed: evam pṛthivī ap tejaḥ vāyu ākāśa kāla diś ātma manāṃsi iti atra dvandvaḥ samāsaḥ sarveṣām svātantryāt  atra ca dravyāṇi iti pratijñāyām dravya tva yogaḥ sādhanam vakṣyati tathā pṛthivī ādi bhede ca pṛthivī tva ādi viśeṣa lakṣaṇam iti etāni ca sāmānya viśeṣa saṃjñayā uktāni sāmānya saṃjñā dravyam iti viśeṣa saṃjñā ca pṛthivī tva ādayaḥ tābhiḥ uktāni kiyanti nava eva iti avadhāryante nyūna adhika pratipādaka pramāṇa a
translated: Thus, earth, water, fire, air, space, time, direction, self, and mind - here there is a dvandva compound of all of them because they are independent. And here, in the proposition substances, the property of being a substance will be stated as the reason. Similarly, in the distinction of earth etc., the specific characteristics of earthness etc. will be stated. And these are said to be of the nature of universals and particulars. The universal is said to be substance. And the particulars are earthness etc. They are said to be of those. How many? It is determined that there are only nine, because there is no evidence that teaches more or less. For example, since the existence of earth etc. will be stated, there is no deficiency.

original: athādhikyopalabdhestadabhāvo 'siddhaḥ / tathā hi / chāyā dravyam / kriyāvattvād guṇavattvācceti / kriyāvattvañca pratyakṣeṇāpi jñāyate / cakṣurvyāpārād gacchatīti jñānotpatteḥ / deśāntaraprāpteśca / tathā hi / gatimatī / chāyā / deśāntaraprāptimattvāt / yo yo deśāntaraprāptimān sa sa gatimānupalabdhaḥ / yathā devadattaḥ / tathā deśāntaraprāptimatī chāyā / tasmād gatimatī / guṇavattvañca
analyzed: atha ādhikya upalabdheḥ tad abhāvaḥ siddhaḥ tathā hi chāyā dravyam kriyāvat tvāt guṇavat tvāt ca iti kriyāvat tvam ca pratyakṣeṇa api jñāyate cakṣuḥ vyāpārāt gacchati iti jñāna utpatteḥ deśa antara prāpteḥ ca tathā hi gatimatī chāyā deśa antara prāptimat tvāt yaḥ yaḥ deśa antara prāptimān sa sa gatimān upalabdhaḥ yathā devadattaḥ tathā deśa antara prāptimatī chāyā tasmāt gatimatī guṇavat tvam ca
translated: Now, because of the perception of excess, the absence of that is not established. Thus, for example, shadow is a substance, because it has action and because it has qualities. And the fact that it has action is known even by perception, because the knowledge it moves arises from the operation of the eye, and because it reaches another place. Thus, a shadow has motion, because it has the property of reaching another place. Whatever has the property of reaching another place is perceived to have motion, just as Devadatta. Similarly, a shadow has the property of reaching another place. Therefore, it has motion. And the fact that it has qualities

original: ātapaḥ kaṭuko rūkṣaśchāyā madhuraśītalā /
analyzed: ātapaḥ kaṭukaḥ rūkṣaḥ chāyā madhura śītalā
translated: The sun is bitter and rough, the shadow is sweet and cool.

original: ityāgamāt /
analyzed: iti āgamāt
translated: This is known from scripture.

original: tadetadasat / bhāsāmabhāvarūpatvācchāyāyāḥ / tathā hi / yatra yatra vārakadravyeṇa tejasaḥ sannidhirniṣidhyate tatra tatra chāyeti vyavahāraḥ / vārakadravyagatāñca kriyāmātapābhāve samāropya pratipadyate chāyā gacchatīti / anyathā hi vārakadravyagataṃ kriyāpekṣitattvaṃ na syāt / yaccedaṃ deśāntaraprāptimattvaṃ tat kiṃ deśāntareṇa saṃyogaḥ samavāyo vā / na saṃyogastasyāpi sādhyatvāt / tathā hi / dravyatvasiddhau saṃyogaḥ sidhyati saṃyogād dravyatvamitītaretarāśrayatvaṃ syāt / atha deśāntaraprāptiḥ samavāyaḥ / so 'pyasiddhaḥ / na hyekatra samaveto 'nyatra samavaitīti / chāyā tvekatra sambaddhopalabdhā punardeśāntare 'pyupalabhyate / na ca kriyāvattvaṃ deśāntarasamavāyāt sidhyati / tasyāyutasiddheṣveva bhāvāditi / kriyāvattvamasādhanam / yaccedamāgamānmādhuryaṃ śaityaṃ vā chāyāyāstadapyupacārāt / ye hi madhuradravyasya śītadravyasya vā guṇāste chāyāsaṃsevanād bhavantīti tatkāryakartṛtvena tathoktāḥ / tasmāt kriyāvattvād guṇavattvācca dravyaṃ chāyeti na vācyam / na ca dravyāntaramastītyupapannam / navaiva dravyāṇītyavadhāraṇāt /
analyzed: tat etat asat bhāsām abhāva rūpa tvāt chāyāyāḥ tathā hi yatra yatra vāraka dravyeṇa tejasaḥ sannidhiḥ niṣidhyate tatra tatra chāyā iti vyavahāraḥ vāraka dravya gatām ca kriyām ātapa abhāve samāropya pratipadyate chāyā gacchati iti  anyathā hi vāraka dravya gatam kriyā apekṣi tattvam na syāt  yat ca idam deśa antara prāptimattvam tat kim deśa antareṇa saṃyogaḥ samavāyaḥ vā na saṃyogaḥ tasya api sādhya tvāt tathā hi dravya tva siddhau saṃyogaḥ si
translated: This is not correct, because a shadow is of the nature of the absence of light. For wherever the presence of light is prohibited by an obstructing substance, there the convention of 'shadow' is used. And one understands the action belonging to the obstructing substance as projected onto the absence of light, thinking 'the shadow moves'. Otherwise, the requirement of action belonging to the obstructing substance would not be possible. And what is this having the property of reaching another place? Is it conjunction with another place or inherence? It cannot be conjunction, because that is also to be established. For thus: when substancehood is established, conjunction is established; from conjunction, substancehood - this would be mutual dependence. Now, if reaching another place is inherence, that is also unestablished. For what inheres in one thing does not inhere in another. But a shadow, being perceived as connected in one place, is perceived again in another place. And the property of having action is not established from inhering in another place. That is not established together.

original: atra kecid dravyāṇi navaiva nyūnādhikapratipādakapramāṇābhāve sati vyavacchedyavyavacchedakabhāvāpannanavalakṣaṇayogitvāt / ubhayābhimataghaṭādinavadravyādivaditi hetuṃ bruvate / tathā hi / ādhikyapramāṇābhāvo darśita eva / na ca lakṣa / / / / / / yathāvasaraṃ vakṣyāma iti / tathā sarvajñena muninā pṛthivyādisaṃjñāvyatirekeṇa saṃjñāntarānabhidhānād dravyāntarāsattvamiti / yadiha bhāvarūpaṃ tatsarvaṃ mayopasaṃkhyātavyamiti hi pratijñā muneḥ /
analyzed: atra kecid dravyāṇi nava eva nyūna adhika pratipādaka pramāṇa abhāve sati vyavacchedya vyavacchedaka bhāva āpanna nava lakṣaṇa yogitvāt ubhaya abhimata ghaṭa ādi nava dravya ādi vat iti hetum bruvate tathā hi ādhikya pramāṇa abhāvaḥ darśitaḥ eva na ca yathāvasaram vakṣyāmaḥ iti tathā sarvajñena muninā pṛthivī ādi saṃjñā vyatirekeṇa saṃjñā antara anabhidhānāt dravya antara asattvam iti yat iha bhāva rūpam tat sarvam mayā upasaṃkhyātavyam iti hi p
translated: Here, some say that there are only nine substances, because in the absence of any evidence indicating more or less, they possess the characteristic of being mutually exclusive and inclusive, like the nine substances such as pot, etc., which are accepted by both parties. Thus, the absence of evidence for excess has been shown. And the definition is not stated. We will explain as the occasion arises. Similarly, because the omniscient sage has not mentioned any other name apart from the names earth, etc., there is no existence of any other substance. For the sage has vowed that whatever exists in the form of substance should all be enumerated by me.

original: guṇāśca rūparasagandhasparśasaṃkhyāparimāṇapṛthaktvasaṃyogavibhāgaparatvāparatvabuddhisukhaduḥkhecchādveṣaprayatnāśceti kaṇṭhoktāḥ saptadaśa / caśabdasamuccitāśca gurutvadravatvasnehasaṃskārādṛṣṭaśabdāḥ saptaivetyevaṃ caturviṃśatiguṇāḥ /PDhS
analyzed: guṇāḥ ca rūpa rasa gandha sparśa saṃkhyā parimāṇa pṛthaktva saṃyoga vibhāga para tva apara tva buddhi sukha duḥkha icchā dveṣa prayatnāḥ ca iti kaṇṭha uktāḥ saptadaśa caśabda samuccitāḥ ca guru tva drava tva sneha saṃskāra adṛṣṭa śabdāḥ sapta eva iti evam caturviṃśati guṇāḥ pdhs
translated: The qualities are enumerated in the text as seventeen: color, taste, smell, touch, number, measure, separateness, conjunction, disjunction, priority, posteriority, cognition, pleasure, pain, desire, aversion, and effort. The seven qualities beginning with gravity, fluidity, viscidity, and unseen force are also included by the word and. Thus, there are twenty-four qualities.

original: tathā guṇeṣu pratijñāṃ karoti guṇāḥ paramārthasantaḥ pūrvoktādeva sādhanāt / tathā guṇavyavahāre guṇatvayogaṃ sādhanaṃ vakṣyati / rūpādibhede ca tadviśeṣalakṣaṇamiti / te tu rūparasagandhasparśasaṃkhyāparimāṇapṛthaktvasaṃyogavibhāgaparatvāparatvabuddhisukhaduḥkhecchādveṣaprayatnāśceti kaṇṭhoktāḥ sūtrakāreṇeti vacanavṛttyābhihitāḥ / tāṃśca vakṣyāmaḥ / samāsaścātra dvandvaḥ / nyūnādhikavyavacchedārthaṃ sāmarthyalabdhāḥ punarucyante saṃkhyayā saptadaśa iti / caśabdasamuccitāśca gurutvadravatvasnehasaṃskārādṛṣṭaśabdāḥ ceti / adṛṣṭaśabdena dharmādharmayorabhidhānāt sapta bhavantīti /
analyzed: tathā guṇeṣu pratijñām karoti guṇāḥ paramārtha santaḥ pūrva uktāt eva sādhanāt tathā guṇa vyavahāre guṇa tva yogam sādhanam vakṣyati rūpa ādi bhede ca tat viśeṣa lakṣaṇam iti te tu rūpa rasa gandha sparśa saṃkhyā parimāṇa pṛthaktva saṃyoga vibhāga para tva apara tva buddhi sukha duḥkha icchā dveṣa prayatnāḥ ca iti kaṇṭha uktāḥ sūtra kāreṇa iti vacana vṛttyā abhihitāḥ tān ca vakṣyāmaḥ samāsaḥ ca atra dvandvaḥ nyūna adhika
translated: Similarly, he makes a promise regarding the qualities: The qualities are ultimately real, as stated by the previously mentioned proof. Similarly, he will state the proof of the connection with the quality in the usage of qualities. And the specific definitions of those in the distinction of form etc. Those are stated by the author of the aphorisms as color, taste, smell, touch, number, measure, separateness, conjunction, disjunction, priority, posteriority, cognition, pleasure, pain, desire, aversion, and effort, with the words of the commentary. And we will explain those. And the compound here is a dvandva. In order to exclude the less and the more, they are again mentioned with the number seventeen, having obtained the capability. And the words heaviness, fluidity, viscosity, impression, and sound are included by the word and. Since the words unseen refer to dharma and adharma, there are seven.

original: atha saṃskārasthaṃ traividhyādādhikyaṃ syāt / na / saṃskāratvajātyapekṣayaikatvāt / na caivamadṛṣṭatvaṃ sāmānyamastīti / na cānyeṣāmapi kāmakrodhādīnāṃ sambhavādupasaṃkhyānaṃ kathamiti vācyam / atraivāntarbhāvasya vakṣyamāṇatvāt / ityevam uktaprakāreṇa / caturviṃśatiguṇāḥ iti nyūnādhikavyavacchedārtham / tatpratipādakapramāṇābhāve sati parasparaṃ vyavacchedyavyavacchedakabhāvāpannacaturviṃśatilakṣaṇayogitvād ubhayābhimataghaṭādicaturviṃśatidravyavaditi /
analyzed: atha saṃskāra stham traividhyāt ādhikyam syāt na saṃskāra tva jāti apekṣayā ekatvāt  na ca evam adṛṣṭa tvam sāmānyam asti iti na ca anyeṣām api kāma krodha ādīnām sambhavāt upasaṃkhyānam katham iti vācyam atra eva antarbhāvasya vakṣyamāṇatvāt iti evam ukta prakāreṇa caturviṃśati guṇāḥ iti nyūnādhika vyavaccheda artham tad pratipādaka pramāṇa abhāve sati parasparam vyavacchedya vyavacchedaka bhāva āpanna caturviṃśati lakṣaṇa yogitvāt ubhay
translated: If it is argued that there would be superiority due to the threefold division in the case of the embellishments, it is not so, because there is oneness in relation to the universal of embellishment. And there is no such general property as being unseen in this way. And it should not be said that the enumeration of other impurities like desire, anger, etc. is not complete, because their inclusion in this itself will be stated later. Thus, in the manner described, the twenty-four qualities. This is to exclude the possibility of less or more. In the absence of any evidence to establish them, they are accepted as twenty-four by both parties, like the twenty-four substances such as pot, etc., because they possess the twenty-four characteristics that are mutually exclusive and inclusive.

original: atha nirguṇatvād guṇānāṃ saṃkhyāyogo 'nupapannaḥ / na / upacārābhyupagamāt / tathā hi mukhye bādhakapramāṇasadbhāve satyupacāraḥ kalpyate / sa ca nimittāpekṣa ityasādhāraṇadharmayogo nimittam / yatra hi saṃkhyopalabdhā tatrāsādhāraṇadharmayogo 'pīti tatsmaraṇādadhyāropaḥ pravartata iti / vyāpakantu nimittamarthakriyājanakatvaṃ vā / naikārthasamavāyastasyāvyāpakatvāt / tathā hi / guṇakarmaṇāmekārthasamavāyo na sāmānyādīnāmityavyāpakamupacāre 'nimittametaditi / nāpi dharmarūpasaṃkhyā tadvyatireke pratiṣedhasya vakṣyamāṇatvāt /
analyzed: atha nirguṇa tvāt guṇānām saṃkhyā yogaḥ nupapannaḥ na upacāra abhyupagamāt tathā hi mukhye bādhaka pramāṇa sadbhāve sati upacāraḥ kalpyate sa ca nimitta apekṣaḥ iti asādhāraṇa dharma yogaḥ nimittam yatra hi saṃkhyā upalabdhā tatra asādhāraṇa dharma yogaḥ u pi iti tad smaraṇāt adhyāropaḥ pravartate iti vyāpakam tu nimittam artha kriyā janaka tvam vā na ekārtha samavāyaḥ tasya avyāpaka tvāt tathā hi guṇa karmaṇām ekārtha samavāyaḥ na sām
translated: If it be said that, because they are devoid of qualities, the number of qualities is not logically possible, (we say) no, because figurative use is admitted. For thus, figurative use is imagined when there is the presence of a valid means of knowledge that contradicts the primary meaning, and that (figurative use) requires a reason. Therefore, the possession of a unique property is the reason. For where number is perceived, there the possession of a unique property is also, and recollection of that causes superimposition to occur. But the all-pervading reason is the capacity to produce an effect, or the inherence in the same object, because that is not all-pervading. For thus, the inherence in the same object of qualities and actions is not of universals etc., so this is not an all-pervading reason for figurative use. Nor is the number in the form of a property, because the negation of that is going to be stated in the case of its exclusion.

original: anye tu viśeṣaṇaviśeṣyabhāvenaiva saṃkhyātra viśeṣaṇamityupacārāsambhavaṃ manyante / tathā hi / saṃkhyāviśiṣṭajñānānyathānupapattyā viśeṣaṇaviśeṣyabhāvasya dravya iva guṇādau cāviśeṣopalabdherupacāraḥ katham / saṃyuktaṃ samavetaṃ vā viśeṣaṇamiti niyamānabhyupagamācca / naitadevam / guṇakarmasāmānyānāṃ samavetānāmeva viśeṣaṇatvopalabdheḥ / na ca guṇeṣu nirguṇatayā saṃkhyāsamavāyaḥ sambhavati / asamavetānāñca guṇakarmasāmānyānāṃ viśeṣaṇatve mithyājñānādyabhāvaḥ / tadviśiṣṭajñānasyobhayatrāviśeṣāditi vakṣyāmaḥ / tasmādupacarita eva guṇādiṣvekādivyavahāro vyākhyeyaḥ /
analyzed: anye tu viśeṣaṇa viśeṣya bhāvena eva saṃkhyā atra viśeṣaṇam iti upacāra asambhavam manyante tathā hi saṃkhyā viśiṣṭa jñāna anyathā anupapattyā viśeṣaṇa viśeṣya bhāvasya dravye iva guṇa ādau ca aviśeṣa upalabdheḥ upacāraḥ katham saṃyuktam samavetam vā viśeṣaṇam iti niyama anabhyupagamāt ca  na etat evam guṇa karma sāmānyānām samavetānām eva viśeṣaṇa tva upalabdheḥ na ca guṇeṣu nirguṇa tayā saṃkhyā samavāyaḥ sambhavati as
translated: Others, however, think that the relation of qualifier and qualified alone is impossible as a figurative usage, since the relation of qualifier and qualified is observed in qualities etc. just as in substances, by the non-apprehension of any difference, due to the impossibility of cognition qualified by number in any other way. And because the restriction that the qualifier is either conjoined or inhering is not accepted. This is not so. Because the qualifier is observed to be inhering only in qualities, actions and universals. And the inherence of number in qualities is not possible due to their being devoid of qualities. And we will say that if non-inherent qualities, actions and universals are qualifiers, there would be no false cognition etc., because the cognition qualified by them is the same in both cases. Therefore, the usage of one etc. in qualities etc. should be explained as figurative.

original: utkṣepaṇāpakṣepaṇākuñcanaprasāraṇagamanāni pañcaiva karmāṇi / gamanagrahaṇād bhramaṇarecanasyandanordhvajvalanatiryakpavanapatananamanonnamanādayo gamanaviśeṣā na jātyantarāṇi /PDhS
analyzed: utkṣepaṇa apakṣepaṇa ākuñcana prasāraṇa gamanāni pañca eva karmāṇi gamana grahaṇāt bhramaṇa recana syandana ūrdhva jvalana tiryak pavana patana namana unnamana ādayaḥ gamana viśeṣāḥ na jāti antarāṇi pdhs
translated: The five actions are only throwing upwards, throwing downwards, contraction, expansion, and motion. By mentioning motion, the specific motions such as whirling, revolving, flowing, upward burning, sideways blowing, falling, bending, and rising are not of a different kind.

original: tathā karmaṇi pratijñāṃ karoti karmāṇi paramārthasanti pūrvoktādeva sādhanāt / karmāṇīti vyavahāre karmatvayogaṃ sādhanamiti vakṣyati / utkṣepaṇādibhede ca tattatsāmānyamiti / tathā utkṣepaṇāpakṣepaṇākuñcanaprasāraṇagamanāni iti dvandvaḥ samāsaḥ / nyūnādhikavyavacchedārthañca pañcaiva karmāṇi ityavadhāraṇam / atra tu pañcalakṣaṇayogitvaṃ saviśeṣaṇaṃ pūrvavatsādhanam /
analyzed: tathā karmaṇi pratijñām karoti karmāṇi paramārtha santi pūrva uktāt eva sādhanāt karmāṇi iti vyavahāre karma tva yogam sādhanam iti vakṣyati utkṣepaṇa ādi bhede ca tat tat sāmānyam iti tathā utkṣepaṇa apakṣepaṇa ākuñcana prasāraṇa gamanāni iti dvandvaḥ samāsaḥ nyūna adhika vyavaccheda artham ca pañca eva karmāṇi iti avadhāraṇam atra tu pañca lakṣaṇa yogitvam sa viśeṣaṇam pūrvavat sādhanam
translated: Thus he makes a promise regarding action: Actions exist in reality, due to the same reason stated earlier. In the convention, he will say that the means is the connection with the nature of action. And in the distinction of throwing upwards, etc., it is the universal of each. Thus, the compound is a dvandva: throwing upwards, throwing downwards, contraction, expansion, and motion. And the restriction 'only five actions' is for the exclusion of less or more. Here, the means is the possession of the five characteristics along with the qualification, as before.

original: atha bhramaṇādīnāmupalambhādavadhāraṇānupapattiḥ / na / gamana evāntarbhāvādityāha gamanagrahaṇād bhramaṇarecanasyandanordhvajvalanatiryakpavanapatananamanonnamanādayo gamanaviśeṣāḥ gamanasaṅgṛhītāstadbhedā eva / na jātyantarāṇi
analyzed: atha bhramaṇa ādīnām upalambhāt avadhāraṇa anupapattiḥ na gamane eva antarbhāvāt iti āha gamana grahaṇāt bhramaṇa recana syandana ūrdhvajvalana tiryak pavana patana namana unnamana ādayaḥ gamana viśeṣāḥ gamana saṅgṛhītāḥ tad bhedāḥ eva na jāti antarāṇi
translated: Now, if it is argued that the determination is not possible because of the perception of moving around etc., it is not so. Because they are included in motion itself, he says: The specific motions such as moving around, revolving, flowing, upward motion, horizontal motion, falling, bending, rising etc. are included in motion, they are just its varieties, not of a different kind.

original: anye tu gamanaviśeṣā eva na bhavanti bhramaṇādayaḥ / kiṃ tarhi / jātyantarāṇīti manyante / etacca asadvyākhyānamiti vakṣyāmaḥ karmaparīkṣāyām /
analyzed: anye tu gamana viśeṣāḥ eva na bhavanti bhramaṇa ādayaḥ kim tarhi jāti antarāṇi iti manyante etat ca asat vyākhyānam iti vakṣyāmaḥ karma parīkṣāyām
translated: Others think that moving around etc. are not just specific motions, but are of a different kind. And we will say that this is a false explanation in the examination of action.

original: sāmānyaṃ dvividhaṃ paramaparaśca / taccānuvṛttipratyayakāraṇam / tatra sattā paraṃ mahāviṣayatvāt / sā ca sattānuvṛttereva kāraṇamiti sāmānyameva / dravyatvādyaparam alpaviṣayatvāt / tacca vyāvṛtterapi hetutvāt sāmānyaṃ sad viśeṣākhyāmapi labhate /PDhS
analyzed: sāmānyam dvividham param aparaḥ ca tat ca anuvṛtti pratyaya kāraṇam tatra sattā param mahā viṣaya tvāt sā ca sattā anuvṛtteḥ eva kāraṇam iti sāmānyam eva dravya tva ādi aparam alpa viṣaya tvāt tat ca vyāvṛtteḥ api hetu tvāt sāmānyam sat viśeṣa ākhyām api labhate
translated: The universal is of two kinds: supreme and inferior. And it is the cause of the cognition of the universal. There, existence is supreme because it has a very wide scope. And that existence is the cause of the universal itself by the very continuity of existence. Substance-ness etc. are inferior because they have a limited scope. And that, being the cause of the exclusion also, obtains the designation of universal and particular.

original: evaṃ sāmānye pratijñāṃ karoti sāmānyam paramārthasaditi pūrvavatsādhanam / sāmānyavyavahāre tu lakṣaṇaṃ vakṣyamāṇaṃ sādhanamiti bhedaṃ nirūpayati dvividham kena rūpeṇetyāha paramaparañca iti / anuvṛttipratyayakāraṇam iti kāryeṇa sattāṃ darśayati / tathā hi / yadanugatajñānaṃ dravyaguṇakarmānimittaṃ tadarthāntarasambandhād bhavatīti vakṣyāmastatparīkṣāyām / tadetadasādhāraṇatvāt sāmānyasyetarasmād bhedakamapi bhavati / tathā hi / dravyaguṇakarmānimittamabādhyamānañcānugataṃ jñānaṃ na sāmānyaṃ vinā bhavatītyasādhāraṇameva / tatra parāparabhedaṃ nirūpayannāha sattā param sāmānyamiti / kutaḥ / mahāviṣayatvāt / tathā hi / dravyeṣveva dravyatvaṃ guṇeṣveva guṇatvaṃ karmasveva karmatvam / I / sattāyā dravyādiviṣayavyāpakatvena mahāviṣayatvāt paratvamiti / yo hi yadviṣayaṃ vyāpnoti sa tadapekṣayā paro yathālpaviṣayapārthivāpekṣayā mahāviṣaya iti / sā ca sattānuvṛttereva kāraṇamiti sāmānyameva / yadyapyasāmānyādibhyo vyāvartate tathāpi sāmānyaṃ vastvanuvṛttajñānasyaiva kāraṇamiti sāmānyameva / tathā dravyatvādyaparamiti / dravyatvamādiryeṣām ityādigrahaṇāt guṇatvakarmatvapṛthivītvādergrahaṇam / tacca sattāpekṣayā alpaviṣayatvād aparamiti / taddhi sāmānyalakṣaṇayogitvena sāmānyaṃ sad upacārato 'tra viśeṣākhyāmapi labhate / na copacāro nimittaṃ vinā pravartata ityāha vyāvṛtterapi hetutvāt iti / na kevalamanuvṛttereva / kiṃ tarhi / vyāvṛttajñānasyāpi hetutvāt / viśeṣaṇe hi vyāvṛttajñānajanakatvaṃ dṛṣṭaṃ taccehāpyastītyupacāraḥ pravartate / mukhyāstu viśeṣāstallakṣaṇayogina eva /
analyzed: evam sāmānye pratijñām karoti sāmānyam paramārtha sat iti pūrvavat sādhanam sāmānya vyavahāre tu lakṣaṇam vakṣyamāṇam sādhanam iti bhedam nirūpayati dvividham kena rūpeṇa iti āha param aparam ca iti anuvṛtti pratyaya kāraṇam iti kāryeṇa sattām darśayati tathā hi yat anugata jñānam dravya guṇa karma animittam tad artha antara sambandhāt bhavati iti vakṣyāmaḥ tad parīkṣāyām tat etat asādhāraṇa tvāt sāmānyasya itarasmāt bhedakam api bhavati tathā h
translated: Thus he states the general thesis that the universal is ultimately real, as before. But in the case of the usage of the universal, the proof to be stated is the definition. Thus he distinguishes the difference by saying of two kinds. By what form? He says supreme and inferior. He shows existence by the effect, saying the cause of the cognition of the universal. For thus, we will say in the examination of that, that the cognition which is pervasive is caused by the relation to a different object than substance, quality, and action. And this, because of its being uncommon, also becomes the differentiator of the universal from the other. For thus, the pervasive cognition which is not caused by substance, quality, or action, and is not contradicted, does not occur without a universal. Thus it is uncommon. There, distinguishing the difference of supreme and inferior, he says existence is the supreme universal. Why? Because it has a great scope. For thus, substantiality is only in substances, quality only in qualities, action only in actions, but existence is in all three.

original: nityadravyavṛttayo 'ntyā viśeṣāste ca khalvatyantavyāvṛttibuddhihetutvād viśeṣā eva /PDhS
analyzed: nitya dravya vṛttayaḥ ntyāḥ viśeṣāḥ te ca khalu atyanta vyāvṛtti buddhi hetu tvāt viśeṣāḥ eva
translated: The ultimate specificities that inhere in eternal substances are indeed specificities because they are the cause of the cognition of absolute exclusion.

original: evaṃ viśeṣeṣu pratijñāṃ karoti viśeṣāḥ paramārthasanta iti pūrvavatsādhanam / nityadravyavṛttayaḥ iti / tathā buddhyādayo 'pi nityadravyeṣveva vartanta iti vipakṣaikadeśavṛttivyavacchedārthaṃ nityadravyeṣu vṛttirevetyavadhāraṇam / na caivaṃ buddhyādaya iti / nityadravyeṣveva vṛttireva eṣāmiti sāvadhāraṇaṃ vākyametat / dravyaguṇakarmāṇi tu nityadravyeṣvanityadravyeṣu ca vartanta iti / sāmānyañcādravye 'pītyupapannamavadhāraṇam / nityadravyeṣvevetyanyayogavyavacchedena nityadravyeṣu vartamānatvād viśeṣā itarasmād bhidyanta iti /
analyzed: evam viśeṣeṣu pratijñām karoti viśeṣāḥ paramārtha santaḥ iti pūrvavat sādhanam nitya dravya vṛttayaḥ iti tathā buddhi ādayaḥ pi nitya dravyeṣu eva vartante iti vipakṣa eka deśa vṛtti vyavaccheda artham nitya dravyeṣu vṛttiḥ eva iti avadhāraṇam na ca evam buddhi ādayaḥ iti nitya dravyeṣu eva vṛttiḥ eva eṣām iti sa avadhāraṇam vākyam etat dravya guṇa karmāṇi tu nitya dravyeṣu anitya dravyeṣu ca vartante iti sāmānyam ca adravye pi iti upapan
translated: Thus he makes a proposition about specificities: Specificities are ultimately real. The proof is as before. They inhere in eternal substances is said to exclude their inherence in part of the dissimilar class, as cognition etc. also inhere only in eternal substances. They do not inhere in eternal substances in the same way - this sentence has the specification that they only inhere in eternal substances. But substances, qualities and actions inhere in eternal and non-eternal substances, and universals also in non-substances. Thus the specification is justified. Only in eternal substances excludes their inherence elsewhere, because they only inhere in eternal substances. Thus specificities are distinguished from others.

original: anye tu padārthāpekṣayā lakṣaṇaṃ vivakṣitamiti nityadravyeṣveva vartamānatvaṃ heturiti bruvate / taccāyuktam / vipakṣaikadeśavṛtteragamakatvāt / na ca padārthāpekṣayāpyayogavyavacchedaṃ vinā vipakṣaikadeśād buddhyāderasya vyāvṛttiriti /
analyzed: anye tu padārtha apekṣayā lakṣaṇam vivakṣitam iti nitya dravyeṣu eva vartamāna tvam hetuḥ iti bruvate tat ca ayuktam vipakṣa eka deśa vṛtteḥ agamaka tvāt na ca padārtha apekṣayā api ayoga vyavacchedam vinā vipakṣa eka deśāt buddhi ādeḥ asya vyāvṛttiḥ iti
translated: Others, however, say that the definition is intended in relation to the categories, so the reason is that it exists only in eternal substances. But that is incorrect, because it does not prove what is to be proved, as it occurs in part of the dissimilar instance. And even in relation to the categories, there is no exclusion of impossibility without exclusion from part of the dissimilar instance, such as the intellect.

original: nityadravyavṛttaya ityantyapadasya vivaraṇametat / tathā ca vakṣyati nityadravyāṇyutpattivināśayorante vyavasthitatvādantaśabdavācyāni / teṣu bhavāstadvṛttayo 'ntyā iti vyākhyāyante / te ca viśeṣā viśeṣayanti vyāvartayanti svāśrayamāśrayāntarāditi / parīkṣārthamāha te cātyantaṃ sarvadā vyāvṛttibuddhereva hetutvād viśeṣā eva / na sāmānyamapīti / I / tathā hi / samānajātiguṇakriyādhārāḥ paramāṇavaḥ / viśeṣasambandhinaḥ / vyāvṛttabuddhiviṣayatvāt / yo yo vyāvṛttajñānaviṣayaḥ sa sa viśeṣasambaddho yathā sthāṇvādi / tathā ca vyāvṛttajñānaviṣayāḥ paramāṇavaḥ / tasmād viśeṣayogina iti / vyāvṛttajñānaviṣayatvañca ghaṭādiṣūpalabdhamiti nityeṣvapi sādhyate dravyatvenaiva hetunā / na ca guṇādīnāmanyatarasyaiva paramāṇuṣu vyāvṛttajñānakāraṇatvam / samānajātiguṇakriyādhāratvena viśeṣitatvāt / na ca dṛṣṭānte guṇādiviśeṣopalabdheriti dṛṣṭāntadārṣṭāntikayorvaiṣamyāpādanena vilakṣaṇaviśeṣāsiddhiriti vācyam / sarvānumāneṣu samānatvāditi / vyāvṛttajñānajanakatvena nityeṣu viśeṣāṇāṃ sadbhāva iti sthitam / vistareṇa tu viśeṣaparīkṣāyāṃ parīkṣiṣyanta ityalam /
analyzed: nitya dravya vṛttayaḥ iti antya padasya vivaraṇam etat tathā ca vakṣyati nitya dravyāṇi utpatti vināśayoḥ ante vyavasthita tvāt anta śabda vācyāni teṣu bhavāḥ tad vṛttayaḥ ntyāḥ iti vyākhyāyante te ca viśeṣāḥ viśeṣayanti vyāvartayanti sva āśrayam āśraya antarāt iti parīkṣā artham āha te ca atyantam sarvadā vyāvṛtti buddheḥ eva hetu tvāt viśeṣāḥ eva na sāmānyam api iti   tathā hi samāna jāti guṇa kriyā dhārāḥ paramāṇavaḥ vi
translated: This is an explanation of the last word belonging to eternal substances. And he will say: The eternal substances are called 'anta' (end) because they are established at the end of origination and destruction. Those belonging to them are explained as 'antiya' (belonging to the end). And those particulars distinguish, i.e., exclude, their substratum from other substrata. For the sake of examination, he says: And because they are the cause of the cognition of absolute exclusion at all times, they are particulars only, not universals. This is because atoms, which are the substrata of similar class, quality and action, are related to particulars, because they are the objects of exclusive cognition. Whatever is the object of exclusive cognition is related to particulars, like a post etc. And atoms are the objects of exclusive cognition. Therefore, they are related to particulars. And the fact of being the object of exclusive cognition is observed in pots etc., so it is proved even in eternal substances only by the reason of being a substance. And the fact of being the object of exclusive cognition is not common to quality etc.

original: ayutasiddhānāmādhāryādhārabhūtānāṃ yaḥ sambandha ihapratyayahetuḥ sa samavāyaḥ /PDhS
analyzed: ayuta siddhānām ādhārya ādhāra bhūtānām yaḥ sambandhaḥ iha pratyaya hetuḥ sa samavāyaḥ
translated: The relation between inseparable things, which are the substratum and the supported, that is the cause of the cognition of 'this', is inherence.

original: atha ayutasiddhānām ityādinā samavāye pratijñāṃ karoti / samavāyaḥ paramārthasan pūrvoktādeva sādhanāditi / lakṣaṇamucyate / ihapratyayahetutvamantarālādarśanasyāpīti sambandhagrahaṇam / tathā hi / dūrād grāmārāmayorantarālamapaśyatāmiha grāme vṛkṣā iti jñānaṃ dṛṣṭam / tathāpyākāśaśakunisambandhena vyabhicāraḥ / tad ihapratyayahetuḥ sambandhaśceti / tathā hi / ihākāśe śakuniriti jñānaṃ dṛṣṭam / tadvyavacchedārtham ādhāryādhāragrahaṇam / na cākāśasyādhāratvamādheyatvaṃ vā / adharottarabhāvasyābhāvāt / yatra hi saṃyogidravyeṣvadharottarabhāvastatraivādhārādheyabhāvaḥ kuṇḍabadarādāvupalabdhastadabhāvaścākāśe / tasya vyāpakatvena śakuniṃ vyāpya sadbhāvāt /
analyzed: atha ayuta siddhānām ityādinā samavāye pratijñām karoti samavāyaḥ paramārtha san pūrva uktāt eva sādhanāt iti lakṣaṇam ucyate iha pratyaya hetu tvam antarāla adarśanasya api iti sambandha grahaṇam tathā hi dūrāt grāma ārāmayoḥ antarālam apaśyatām iha grāme vṛkṣāḥ iti jñānam dṛṣṭam tathā api ākāśa śakuni sambandhena vyabhicāraḥ tat iha pratyaya hetuḥ sambandhaḥ ca iti tathā hi iha ākāśe śakuniḥ iti jñānam dṛṣṭam tad vyavaccheda art
translated: Now, with the statement Then, of those that are not simultaneously perceived... he makes a promise regarding inherence. He says that inherence is ultimately real, due to the same reason stated earlier. The definition is stated: The cause of the cognition of 'here' is also the relation, even though the intervening space is not seen. The connection is grasped thus. For instance, when people do not see the intervening space between a village and a garden from a distance, they have the knowledge The trees are here in the village. Even so, there is deviation due to the relation between a bird in the sky. Therefore, here the cause of the cognition of 'here' is the relation. For instance, the knowledge The bird is here in the sky is seen. To exclude that, the grasping of the object and the substratum is mentioned. And the sky is neither the substratum nor the object. Because there is no relation of lower and higher. Where there is the relation of lower and higher in conjoined substances, there alone the relation of substratum and object is observed, as in a pot and a jujube fruit, and that is absent in the sky. Because it pervades the bird by being present as its pervader.
