original: athākāśasyātīndriyatvādiheti jñānaṃ na syāt / tasya hyaparokṣeṣveva bhāvāt / tadasat / atīndriye 'pyākāśe iheti jñānaṃ kevalaṃ bhrāntam / tasya vyavacchedārthamupapannamādhāryādhārapadam / iṣṭañca bhrāntehajñānasya vyavacchedārthaṃ sambandhapadam /
analyzed: atha ākāśasya atīndriya tvāt iha iti jñānam na syāt tasya hi aparokṣeṣu eva bhāvāt tat asat atīndriye pi ākāśe iha iti jñānam kevalam bhrāntam tasya vyavaccheda artham upapannam ādhārya ādhāra padam iṣṭam ca bhrānta iha jñānasya vyavaccheda artham sambandha padam
translated: If it is argued that the cognition of space as transcendent cannot be due to that, because space is beyond the senses, that is not so. The cognition of space as here in the transcendent is merely erroneous. The terms 'supported' and 'support' are appropriate to exclude that. And the term 'relation' is accepted to exclude the erroneous cognition of 'here'.

original: anye tvasya codyasya parihārārtham ā samantāt kāśata ityākāśam / vartata ityupacāreṇākāśaṃ raśmayo 'bhidhīyante / te ca pratyakṣamityupapannamihākāśe śakuniriti jñānamiti manyante / taccāsat / mukhyasadbhāve 'pyupacārakalpanāyāmatiprasaṅgāt / uktañcātīndriye 'pyākāśe 'parokṣajñānaṃ bhrāntaṃ tadvyavacchedārthaṃ viśeṣaṇamiti / mūrtadravyābhāvena cākāśena sambandhābhāva eveti /
analyzed: anye tu asya codyasya parihāra artham ā samantāt kāśate iti ākāśam vartate iti upacāreṇa ākāśam raśmayaḥ bhidhīyante te ca pratyakṣam iti upapannam iha ākāśe śakuniḥ iti jñānam iti manyante tat ca asat mukhya sadbhāve pi upacāra kalpanāyām atiprasaṅgāt  uktam ca atīndriye pi ākāśe parokṣa jñānam bhrāntam tad vyavaccheda artham viśeṣaṇam iti mūrta dravya abhāvena ca ākāśena sambandha abhāvaḥ eva iti
translated: Others, to avoid this objection, think that 'ākāśa' means that which exists all around, and that the rays are figuratively called 'ākāśa', and that they are perceptible, so the cognition 'the bird is in the sky here' is appropriate. But that is not so, because even when the primary meaning exists, figurative usage is too far-fetched. And it has been said that the cognition of the transcendent space as non-obstructed is erroneous, and the qualification is to exclude that. And there is no relation with space, which is the absence of corporeal substance.

original: tathā hyādhāryādhārabhūtānāṃ yaḥ sambandha ihapratyayahetuḥ sa samavāya ityukte kuṇḍabadarasambandhena vyabhicārastadarthamayutasiddhānāmiti padam / yutasiddhirvakṣyamāṇā / sā vidyate yeṣāṃ te yutasiddhāstanniṣedhena cāyutasiddhāsteṣāmiti / tathāpyayutasiddhānāṃ yaḥ sambandhaḥ saḥ samavāya ityukte vyabhicārābhāvaḥ / tanna / vācyavācakabhāvena viṣayaviṣayibhāvena ca vyabhicārāt / tathā hyākāśamahattvamākāśe samavetaṃ mahattvaśabdavācyamityākāśamahattvatacchabdayorvācyavācakabhāvaḥ sambandho na ca yutasiddhirvibhinnāśrayasamavāyitvābhāvāt / tathā hyākāśamahattvamākāśe samavetaṃ tadvācakaśca śabdastatraivetyayutasiddhatvam / evamicchādyālambanaṃ vijñānamātmani samavetamicchādayaśca tatraivetyayutasiddhatve satyeṣāṃ viṣayaviṣayibhāva ityanayorvyavacchedārthamādhāryādhārapadam / na cātrākāśamahattvaśabdastanmahattvādhāraḥ / nāpīcchādyālambanavijñānaṃ tadādhāramiti /
analyzed: tathā hi ādhārya ādhāra bhūtānām yaḥ sambandhaḥ iha pratyaya hetuḥ sa samavāyaḥ iti ukte kuṇḍa badara sambandhena vyabhicāraḥ tad artham ayuta siddhānām iti padam yuta siddhiḥ vakṣyamāṇā sā vidyate yeṣām te yuta siddhāḥ tad niṣedhena ca ayuta siddhāḥ teṣām iti tathā api ayuta siddhānām yaḥ sambandhaḥ saḥ samavāyaḥ iti ukte vyabhicāra abhāvaḥ tat na vācya vācaka bhāvena viṣaya viṣayi bhāvena ca vyabhicārāt tathā hi ākāśa mahā tv
translated: For when it is said that the relation of that which is supported and that which supports, which is the cause of the cognition of this, is inherence, there is inconstancy due to the relation of a pot and a jujube fruit. For that purpose, the phrase of things not simultaneously produced is used. Simultaneous production will be explained later. Those that have that are simultaneously produced. By negating that, they are not simultaneously produced. Even so, when it is said that the relation of those that are not simultaneously produced is inherence, there is no inconstancy. That is not so. Because there is inconstancy due to the relation of denoted and denotative, and of object and subject. For instance, the greatness of space is inherent in space and is denoted by the word greatness. The relation of denoted and denotative between the greatness of space and that word is not simultaneous production, because it is not inherent in different substrates. For instance, the greatness of space is inherent in space, and the word that denotes it is also there. Thus, it is not simultaneously produced. Similarly, consciousness that has desire etc. as its object is inherent in the self, and desire etc. are also there.

original: nanvevamapyābhyāmeva vyabhicāraḥ / tathā hyayutasiddhānāmādhāryādhārabhūtānāṃ yaḥ sambandhaḥ saḥ samavāya ityukte 'pi vācyavācakabhāvaviṣayaviṣayibhāvābhyāmeva vyabhicāraḥ / tathā hyākāśaśabdenākāśamabhidhīyata ityanayorādhāryādhārabhāve sati vācyavācakabhāvaḥ / na cāsti yutasiddhiḥ / evamātmālambanamahamiti jñānamātmanyevetyayutasiddhatve satyādhāryādhārabhūtayorasti viṣayaviṣayibhāva iti tadvyavacchedārthamavadhāraṇamādhāryādhārabhūtānāmeva yaḥ sambandhaḥ sa samavāya iti / vācyavācakaviṣayaviṣayibhāvayoścādhāryādhārabhūteṣu tadviparīteṣu ca sadbhāva iti vyavacchedaḥ /
analyzed: nanu evam api ābhyām eva vyabhicāraḥ tathā hi ayuta siddhānām ādhārya ādhāra bhūtānām yaḥ sambandhaḥ saḥ samavāyaḥ iti ukte vācya vācaka bhāva viṣaya viṣayi bhāvābhyām eva vyabhicāraḥ tathā hi ākāśa śabdena ākāśam abhidhīyate iti anayoḥ ādhārya ādhāra bhāve sati vācya vācaka bhāvaḥ na ca asti yuta siddhiḥ evam ātma ālambanam aham iti jñānam ātmani eva iti ayuta siddha tve sati ādhārya ādhāra bhūtayoḥ asti viṣaya viṣayi bhāvaḥ it
translated: But even so, there is deviation by these two [reasons]. For, even when it is said that the relation between things that are not produced separately and which are the supported and the supporter is inherence, there is deviation by the relation of denoted and denotative and of object and subject. For, when the word 'space' denotes space, there is the relation of denoted and denotative, even though there is no co-existence. Similarly, the knowledge 'I' which has the self as its object, exists only in the self. Even though there is non-co-existence, there is the relation of object and subject between the supported and the supporter. In order to exclude that, the restriction is made that inherence is only the relation between things that are not produced separately and which are the supported and the supporter. And the relation of denoted and denotative and of object and subject exist in things that are the supported and the supporter, as well as in those that are the opposite.

original: nanvevamayutasiddhānāmiti vyarthameva / na / asyāpi sāvadhāraṇasya lakṣaṇāntaratvāt / tathā hyayutasiddhānāmeva yaḥ sambandhaḥ sa samavāya iti / vācyavācakaviṣayaviṣayibhāvau tu yutasiddhānāmayutasiddhānāñceti /
analyzed: nanu evam ayuta siddhānām iti vyartham eva na asya api sāvadhāraṇasya lakṣaṇa antara tvāt tathā hi ayuta siddhānām eva yaḥ sambandhaḥ sa samavāyaḥ iti vācya vācaka viṣaya viṣayi bhāvau tu yuta siddhānām ayuta siddhānām ca iti
translated: But in that case, the definition of things not capable of being spoken of as either the same or different is useless. Not so; because that definition is restrictive, and is a different definition. For thus it is said, The relation of things not capable of being spoken of as either the same or different is Inherence. But the relation of word and meaning, and of object and subject, is of things capable of being spoken of as either the same or different, and not of things not capable of being spoken of as either the same or different.

original: atra kecid asaddūṣaṇamudbhāvayanti / samavāyāsiddhau yuteṣvāśrayeṣu samavāyo na yutasiddhiḥ / sā vidyate yeṣāṃ te na yutasiddhāḥ / tatpratiṣedhena cāyutasiddhānāmabhāve na samavāya iti / etaccāsaddūṣaṇam / lakṣaṇasya vidyamānavyavacchedakatvāt / yadi hyavidyamānaṃ lakṣaṇenotpādyeta bhavedetad dūṣaṇamayutasiddhānāmiti / lakṣaṇena samavāyākaraṇe yutasiddhānāmabhāvenāyutasiddhānāmabhāva iti lakṣaṇāsambhava iti / na caitat / lakṣaṇasya jñāpakatvāditi /
analyzed: atra kecid asat dūṣaṇam udbhāvayanti samavāya asiddhau yuteṣu āśrayeṣu samavāyaḥ na yuta siddhiḥ sā vidyate yeṣām te na yuta siddhāḥ tad pratiṣedhena ca ayuta siddhānām abhāve na samavāyaḥ iti etat ca asat dūṣaṇam lakṣaṇasya vidyamāna vyavacchedaka tvāt yadi hi avidyamānam lakṣaṇena utpādyeta bhavet etat dūṣaṇam ayuta siddhānām iti lakṣaṇena samavāya akaraṇe yuta siddhānām abhāvena ayuta siddhānām abhāvaḥ iti lakṣaṇa asambhavaḥ i
translated: Here some raise the objection that this is a false criticism. When Inherence is not established, Inherence in things capable of being spoken of as either the same or different is not capable of being spoken of as either the same or different. Those in whom that exists are not capable of being spoken of as either the same or different. By the negation of that, in the absence of things not capable of being spoken of as either the same or different, there is no Inherence. This is a false criticism, because the definition serves to distinguish what exists. For if what does not exist were produced by the definition, this criticism would be valid, that of things not capable of being spoken of as either the same or different. But when Inherence is not produced by the definition, in the absence of things capable of being spoken of as either the same or different, there is no absence of things not capable of being spoken of as either the same or different, so the definition is impossible. But this is not so, because the definition serves to make known.

original: athāyutasiddhānāmevādhāryādhārabhūtānāmeva yaḥ sambandhaḥ sa samavāya iti lakṣaṇadvayaparisamāptāvihapratyayaheturiti vyartham / na / parīkṣārthatvāt / tathā hi / tantuṣu paṭa ityādi ihapratyayaḥ / sambandhakāryaḥ / abādhyamānehapratyayatvāt / yo yo 'bādhyamānehapratyayaḥ sa sa sambandhakāryaḥ / yatheha kuṇḍe dadhīti pratyayaḥ / tathā cāyamabādhyamānehapratyayaḥ / tasmāt sambandhakārya iti / na cātra samavāyapūrvakatvaṃ sādhyate / dṛṣṭāntasya sādhyavikalatāprasaṅgāt / nāpi saṃyogapūrvakatvam / kiṃ tarhi / sambandhamātrakāryatvam / sa ca saṃyogādivilakṣaṇatvāt samavāya eveti vakṣyāmastatparīkṣāyāmityalamativistareṇa /
analyzed: atha ayuta siddhānām eva ādhārya ādhāra bhūtānām eva yaḥ sambandhaḥ sa samavāyaḥ iti lakṣaṇa dvaya parisamāptau iha pratyaya hetuḥ iti vyartham na parīkṣā artha tvāt tathā hi tantuṣu paṭaḥ ityādi iha pratyayaḥ sambandha kāryaḥ abādhyamāna iha pratyaya tvāt yaḥ yaḥ bādhyamāna iha pratyayaḥ sa sa sambandha kāryaḥ yathā iha kuṇḍe dadhi iti pratyayaḥ tathā ca ayam abādhyamāna iha pratyayaḥ tasmāt sambandha kāryaḥ iti na ca atra samavāya p
translated: If it be said that the relation of the inseparably connected things only is Inherence, and the definition of Inherence is complete with the two terms, and the cause of the notion of ‘this’ is useless,—we say no; because the purpose is to examine. For instance, the notion of ‘this’ in the expression ‘the cloth in the yarns’ is due to the relation; because it is the notion of ‘this’ which is not denied; that which is the notion of ‘this’ which is not denied is due to the relation; just as the notion of ‘this’ in the expression ‘curd in the dish’; and this notion of ‘this’ is not denied; hence it must be due to the relation. And in this case, it is not the antecedence of Inherence that is meant to be proved; because in that case the instance would be devoid of the probandum. Nor is Conjunction meant to be antecedently proved; what is meant is that it is due to a mere relation; and this relation is different from Conjunction and the rest; and we shall show later on that it is Inherence itself. Thus we desist from further details.

original: uddeśaprakaraṇopasaṃhāraḥ
analyzed: uddeśa prakaraṇa upasaṃhāraḥ
translated: Conclusion of the section on the topics of the Uddēśa.

original: evaṃ dharmairvinā dharmiṇāmuddeśaḥ kṛta iti /PDhS
analyzed: evam dharmaiḥ vinā dharmiṇām uddeśaḥ kṛtaḥ iti
translated: Thus, the denotation of the substrata without attributes has been made.

original: evaṃ dravyādiṣu padārtheṣūkteṣu sāmānyaviśeṣasamavāyānāṃ lakṣaṇaparīkṣāśravaṇādantevāsinaḥ prāktanaṃ prakaraṇaṃ kimuddeśaparaṃ lakṣaṇaparaṃ parīkṣāparaṃ veti saṃśaye sati tannirāsārthamupasaṃhāravākyam evam ityādi pradhānatayā / prādhānyaṃ tasya sarvatroddeśavidhānāt / uddeśastu saṃjñāmātreṇa padārthābhidhānamiti / lakṣaṇaparīkṣayośca sāmānyādiṣveva bhāvādanuṣaṅgato 'bhidhānamiti / yad vā dravyādipadārthaparijñānānniḥśreyasamiti matvā pravṛttastaduddeśaparijñānamātrānniḥśreyasālābhe 'tipratārakatāṃ manyamānaḥ śravaṇādantevāsī mā vyāvartatāmiti tadāśvāsanārthaṃ vākyam evaṃ dharmairvinā dharmiṇām kevalānāmuddeśaḥ kṛto na lakṣaṇaṃ nāpi parīkṣā / tattaddvāreṇa sādharmyavaidharmyaparijñānaṃ śrautamupajātamabhyāsavaśād ātmanyaśeṣaviśeṣāliṅgite vijñānamaparokṣaṃ kurvan niḥśreyasamupajanayatīti /
analyzed: evam dravya ādiṣu padārtheṣu ukteṣu sāmānya viśeṣa samavāyānām lakṣaṇa parīkṣā śravaṇāt antevāsinaḥ prāktanam prakaraṇam kim uddeśa param lakṣaṇa param parīkṣā param vā iti saṃśaye sati tad nirāsa artham upasaṃhāra vākyam evam ityādi pradhāna tayā prādhānyam tasya sarvatra uddeśa vidhānāt uddeśaḥ tu saṃjñā mātreṇa padārtha abhidhānam iti lakṣaṇa parīkṣayoḥ ca sāmānya ādiṣu eva bhāvāt anuṣaṅgataḥ bhidhānam iti yat
translated: Thus, when substances and other categories have been mentioned, and the definition, examination, and hearing of universals, particulars, and inherence are to be done, the resident disciple, being in doubt as to whether the previous topic is meant for instruction, definition, or examination, in order to remove that doubt, the concluding statement beginning with thus is stated primarily. Its primacy is due to the fact that it enjoins the instruction everywhere. Instruction is the mere mention of categories by their names. And since definition and examination are present only in universals etc., they are mentioned by implication. Or, thinking that liberation comes from the knowledge of categories like substance, and considering it to be a great deception if liberation were to be obtained merely by the knowledge of their instruction, the resident disciple might turn away from hearing. In order to reassure him, the statement is made: Thus, the instruction of the categories alone without their properties is done, not their definition or examination. The knowledge of similarity and dissimilarity through them is heard.

original: padārthasaṃkhyāvadhāraṇasya yuktatvavicāraḥ
translated: Discussion on the propriety of determining the number of categories

original: nanu ṣaḍeva padārthā ityavadhāraṇābhyupagame dharmāṇāṃ vyatirekāsambhavāt kathamastitvādibhirvinā dharmiṇāmuddeśaḥ kṛta iti / na / avadhāraṇasya dharmiviṣayatvābhyupagamāt / tanna / astitvādayo 'pi svādhikaraṇadharmāpekṣayā dharmiṇaṃ eveti / tadapekṣayāpi vyāhatamavadhāraṇam / tathā hyastitvamabhidhīyamānatvād abhidheyatvādhikaraṇam / evamabhidheyatvamastitvādhikaraṇamityādi yojyam /
analyzed: nanu ṣaṭ eva padārthāḥ iti avadhāraṇa abhyupagame dharmāṇām vyatireka asambhavāt katham astitva ādibhiḥ vinā dharmiṇām uddeśaḥ kṛtaḥ iti na avadhāraṇasya dharmi viṣaya tva abhyupagamāt tat na astitva ādayaḥ sva adhikaraṇa dharma apekṣayā dharmiṇam eva iti tad apekṣayā api vyāhatam avadhāraṇam tathā hi astitvam abhidhīyamāna tvāt abhidheya tva adhikaraṇam evam abhidheya tvam astitva adhikaraṇam ityādi yojyam
translated: But if the determination that there are only six categories is accepted, since the exclusion of attributes is impossible, how is the enunciation of the substrata made without existence, etc.? No, because the determination is accepted to have the substrata as its object. That is not so. Existence, etc. also, in relation to the attributes of their own substrata, are only the substrata. Even in relation to that, the determination is contradicted. For thus, existence, being denoted, is the substratum of the denotability. Thus, denotability is the substratum of existence, etc. This should be connected.

original: athāsādhāraṇadharmādhikaraṇatvenāvadhāraṇamarthavat / tadasat / astitvāderapyasādhāraṇadharmādhikaraṇatvāt / tathā hyastitvamabhidheyatvād bhidyate 'bhidheyatvañcāstitvād bhidyata iti / na cāsādhāraṇadharmasamparkaṃ vinā vyāvṛttirghaṭata ityasādhāraṇadharmādhikaraṇatvenāvadhāraṇāsambhava iti cet / naitadevam / kriyāvad guṇavat samavāyikāraṇamiti dravyalakṣaṇam I / vai / sū / / / / ayogānyayogavyavacchede dravyāśritatvaṃ guṇānām / tathā kṣaṇikatve sati niyamena mūrtadravyavṛttitvaṃ karmaṇām / nityatvaikatve sati samavāyenānekavartamānatvaṃ sāmānyasya / ayogānyayogavyavacchedena nityeṣveva dravyeṣu vartamānatvaṃ viśeṣāṇām / niyamenāyutasiddhasambandhatvaṃ samavāyasyetyevaṃ dharmādhikāriṇaḥ ṣaḍevetyavadhāraṇe 'pyadoṣaḥ /
analyzed: atha asādhāraṇa dharma adhikaraṇa tvena avadhāraṇam arthavat tat asat astitva ādeḥ api asādhāraṇa dharma adhikaraṇa tvāt tathā hi astitvam abhidheya tvāt bhidyate bhidheya tvam ca astitvāt bhidyate iti na ca asādhāraṇa dharma samparkam vinā vyāvṛttiḥ ghaṭate iti asādhāraṇa dharma adhikaraṇa tvena avadhāraṇa asambhavaḥ iti ced na etat evam kriyāvat guṇavat samavāyikāraṇam iti dravya lakṣaṇam vai ayoga anya yoga vyavacchede dravya āśrita tvam guṇān
translated: If, on the other hand, the determination is meaningful as the basis of uncommon properties, that is incorrect. Because existence and so on are also the basis of uncommon properties. For thus existence is distinguished from being expressible, and being expressible is distinguished from existence. And if it is argued that exclusion is not possible without contact with uncommon properties, therefore the determination is not possible as the basis of uncommon properties, that is not so. The definition of substance is: having action, having quality, being the inherent cause. The quality of being dependent on substance is for the exclusion of non-connection and other-connection. Similarly, the quality of motion is: being momentary, necessarily occurring in a corporeal substance. The universal is: being eternally one, yet presently existing in many through inherence. The quality of particularity is: occurring only in eternal substances, for the exclusion of non-connection and other-connection. Inherence is: the relation of inseparable inherence, necessarily. Thus the six are the bases of properties.

original: atha vyatiriktānāmapīyattā'sambhavādasaṃkhyātatvena tattvajñānāviṣayatvamiti cet / na / pṛthivyāmivānantye 'pyekasya nimittasyopagrahāt tattvajñānaviṣayatvamiti / nimittantu tatra pṛthivyāṃ pṛthivītvam / dharmeṣu dharmarūpateti /
analyzed: atha vyatiriktānām api iyattā sambhavāt asaṃkhyāta tvena tattva jñāna aviṣaya tvam iti ced na pṛthivyām iva ānantye pi ekasya nimittasya upagrahāt tattva jñāna viṣaya tvam iti nimittam tu tatra pṛthivyām pṛthivī tvam dharmeṣu dharma rūpa tā iti
translated: If it is argued that even for the finite, since their number is impossible, they are not objects of true knowledge due to being innumerable, it is not so. Even in infinity, like in earth, there is the object of true knowledge due to the inclusion of one cause. And the cause there in earth is earthness, and in dharmas it is the nature of dharma.

original: atha dharmeṣu nityatvamutānityatvamiti cennityatve 'pi dharmivināśe sattāvadavasthānābhyupagamādadoṣaḥ / anityatve 'pi dravyasyaiva samavāyikāraṇatvād guṇādiṣu notpattyabhāvaḥ / vināśavannimittakāraṇādevotpattyabhyupagamāt / tathā hi / dravyaguṇakarmātmakaṃ kāyaṃ samavāyyādikāraṇebhyo niṣpadyamānaṃ dṛṣṭaṃ viparītantu nimittādeva / tathā ca dharmāḥ / nimittādevotpadyante / dravyaguṇakarmavyatirekikāryatvāt / yad yad dravyaguṇakarmavyatirekikāryaṃ tattannimittakāraṇādevotpadyamānaṃ dṛṣṭam / yathā vināśaḥ / tathā ca dharmā dravyaguṇakarmavyatirekikāryāḥ / tasmānnimittakāraṇādevotpadyante / utpattidharmāṇāñcānityatvaṃ dṛṣṭamityastitvādayo 'pyanityā iti / astitvañcāstīti pratyayanimittam / yena so 'stīti pratyayo bhavatīti / abhidheyatvaṃ vābhidheyapratyayakāraṇamityādi sarvatra yojyam /
analyzed: atha dharmeṣu nitya tvam uta anitya tvam iti ced nitya tve pi dharmi vināśe sattāvat avasthāna abhyupagamāt adoṣaḥ anitya tve pi dravyasya eva samavāyi kāraṇa tvāt guṇa ādiṣu na utpatti abhāvaḥ vināśa vat nimitta kāraṇāt eva utpatti abhyupagamāt tathā hi dravya guṇa karma ātmakam kāyam samavāyi ādi kāraṇebhyaḥ niṣpadyamānam dṛṣṭam viparītam tu nimittāt eva tathā ca dharmāḥ nimittāt eva utpadyante dravya guṇa karma vyatireki kārya tvāt yat yat d
translated: If it is asked whether the dharmas are eternal or non-eternal, there is no fault even in eternality, because it is accepted that they remain as long as their substratum is destroyed. Even in non-eternality, there is no absence of origination in qualities etc. because only the substance is the inherent cause, and because origination is accepted to be only from the instrumental cause like destruction. For example, the body consisting of substance, quality and action is seen to be produced from the inherent and other causes, but the opposite is from the instrumental cause alone. So are the dharmas. They originate only from the instrumental cause, because they are effects different from substance, quality and action. Whatever effect is different from substance, quality and action is seen to originate only from the instrumental cause. Like destruction. And the dharmas are effects different from substance, quality and action. Therefore, they originate only from the instrumental cause. And the eternality of those having the property of origination is seen. Therefore, existence and others are also non-eternal. And existence is the cause of the notion of existence. By which

original: avyatireke tu vyatiriktairdharmairvinā dharmiṇāmuddeśaḥ kṛta iti vyākhyānam / vyatireke bādhakapramāṇopapattervyatirikteti viśeṣaṇaṃ sāmarthyāllabhyata eva / tathā hyavadhāraṇānupapattirvyatirekapakṣe /
analyzed: avyatireke tu vyatiriktaiḥ dharmaiḥ vinā dharmiṇām uddeśaḥ kṛtaḥ iti vyākhyānam vyatireke bādhaka pramāṇa upapatteḥ vyatiriktā iti viśeṣaṇam sāmarthyāt labhyate eva tathā hi avadhāraṇa anupapattiḥ vyatireka pakṣe
translated: But if there is no distinction, the definition is that the substrata are stated without distinct properties. In case of distinction, the qualification 'distinct' is obtained by implication itself, because the occurrence of a counter-argument is possible. For, in the case of distinction, the restriction is not possible.

original: athoktaṃ viśiṣṭadharmādhikaraṇatvenāvadhāraṇaṃ vivakṣitamiti / tanna / uktalakṣaṇānāṃ ṣaḍeva padārthā ityavadhāraṇe sādhāraṇadharmādhikaraṇānāṃ padārthāntarāṇāmaparisaṃkhyātatvāt tattvajñānāsambhava eva / tattvajñānārthañcāvadhāraṇam / na ca padārthāntarāṇāmajñeyatvam / sarvasya bhāvaprapañcasya jñeyatayopakṣepāt / teṣu ca sāmānyaviśeṣarūpatayā tattvajñānaṃ kāryam / sāmānyaṃ bhāvarūpatā / viśeṣastu dravyādivallakṣaṇayogaḥ / tadatirikteṣu ca padārtheṣu sāmānyato jñānaṃ na viśeṣata iti /
analyzed: atha uktam viśiṣṭa dharma adhikaraṇa tvena avadhāraṇam vivakṣitam iti tat na ukta lakṣaṇānām ṣaṭ eva padārthāḥ iti avadhāraṇe sādhāraṇa dharma adhikaraṇānām padārtha antarāṇām aparisaṃkhyāta tvāt tattva jñāna asambhavaḥ eva tattva jñāna artham ca avadhāraṇam na ca padārtha antarāṇām ajñeya tvam sarvasya bhāva prapañcasya jñeya tayā upakṣepāt teṣu ca sāmānya viśeṣa rūpatayā tattva jñānam kāryam sāmānyam bhāva rūpatā viśe
translated: If it is said that the restriction is intended in the sense of being the substratum of a qualified property, that is not so. In the restriction 'there are only six categories with the characteristics stated', other categories which are the substrata of common properties are not enumerated, so the knowledge of reality is not possible at all. And the restriction is for the sake of the knowledge of reality. And the other categories are not unknowable, because the entire phenomenal world is included as knowable. And the knowledge of reality in them is to be done in the form of universal and particular. The universal is the nature of existence. The particular is the possession of the characteristics of substance etc. And in the other categories besides that, the knowledge is general, not particular.

original: atha dravyādilakṣaṇavad dharmarūpatāviśeṣasya sadbhāvaviśeṣeṇāpi tattvajñānaviṣayatvamiti cet / tarhi padārthāntarasadbhāve 'pi niyatalakṣaṇāpekṣayāvadhāraṇābhyupagame ṣaḍevetyapi I / na vācyam / samavāyasadbhāve 'pi pūrvalakṣaṇāpekṣayā pañcaiveti syāt / evamuttarottarapadārthasadbhāve 'pi pūrvapūrvalakṣaṇāpekṣayāvadhāraṇābhyupagame satyeka eva padārthaḥ syāt / tathā hi / dravyalakṣaṇayoge eka eva padārtho nānyastasya hi dravyalakṣaṇayogitve dravya evāntarbhāvāt /
analyzed: atha dravya ādi lakṣaṇa vat dharma rūpatā viśeṣasya sadbhāva viśeṣeṇa api tattva jñāna viṣaya tvam iti ced tarhi padārtha antara sadbhāve pi niyata lakṣaṇa apekṣayā avadhāraṇa abhyupagame ṣaṭ eva iti api na vācyam samavāya sadbhāve pi pūrva lakṣaṇa apekṣayā pañca eva iti syāt evam uttara uttara padārtha sadbhāve pi pūrva pūrva lakṣaṇa apekṣayā avadhāraṇa abhyupagame sati ekaḥ eva padārthaḥ syāt tathā hi dravya lakṣaṇa yoge ekaḥ eva
translated: If it is argued that just as substance etc. have their own specific characteristics, the specific nature of dharma also becomes the object of true knowledge through its specific existence, then even in the existence of other categories, the acceptance of determination based on specific characteristics would lead to the statement only six. Or it cannot be said that even in the existence of inherence, there would be only five based on the previous characteristics. Similarly, even in the existence of later categories, if determination based on earlier characteristics is accepted, there would be only one category. This is because when there is conformity with the characteristic of substance, there is only one category, not another, because when it conforms to the characteristic of substance, it is included only in substance.

original: atha guṇādiṣu vibhinnalakṣaṇasambandhiṣu tattvajñānābhāvaprasaṅgānnaivamavadhāraṇam / evaṃ tarhi dharmeṣu ṣaḍlakṣaṇālakṣiteṣu tattvajñānābhāvaprasaṅgāt ṣaḍevetyavadhāraṇamanyāyyam / pratijñātañca padārtheṣu sādharmyavaidharmyapratijñānam / /
analyzed: atha guṇa ādiṣu vibhinna lakṣaṇa sambandhiṣu tattva jñāna abhāva prasaṅgāt na evam avadhāraṇam evam tarhi dharmeṣu ṣaṣ lakṣaṇa a lakṣiteṣu tattva jñāna abhāva prasaṅgāt ṣaṣ eva iti avadhāraṇam anyāyyam pratijñātam ca padārtheṣu sādharmya vaidharmya pratijñānam
translated: If it be said that this is not so, because it would follow that there is no knowledge of the truth in regard to qualities etc. which are related to different characteristics, then, in that case, because it would follow that there is no knowledge of the truth in regard to the dharmas which are not characterized by the six characteristics, the restriction to six is improper. And the assertion of similarity and dissimilarity in regard to the categories is also contradicted.

original: dharmasvarūpavicāraḥ
translated: The investigation of the nature of dharma

original: tathā dharmarūpatāyāḥ sakalabhedāvyāpitayā na dharmeṣu tattvajñānam / tathā hi / dharmarūpatāyāṃ kimanyā dharmarūpatā'sti / uta nāstīti / sadbhāve tasyāmanyābhidheyatetyanavasthāyāṃ dharmarūpatāyāścānekatvādekasya nimittasyopagrāhakasyābhāvānna dharmeṣu tattvajñānaṃ syāt /
analyzed: tathā dharma rūpa tāyāḥ sakala bheda avyāpi tayā na dharmeṣu tattva jñānam tathā hi dharma rūpa tāyām kim anyā dharma rūpatā asti uta na asti iti sadbhāve tasyām anya abhidheya tā iti anavasthāyām dharma rūpa tāyāḥ ca aneka tvāt ekasya nimittasya upagrāhakasya abhāvāt na dharmeṣu tattva jñānam syāt
translated: Similarly, because the nature of dharma does not pervade all differences, there is no knowledge of the truth in regard to dharmas. For, in the nature of dharma, is there another nature of dharma or not? If it exists, then there is the infinite regress that it has another name. And because the nature of dharma is manifold, and there is no single cause to apprehend it, there would be no knowledge of the truth in regard to dharmas.

original: na ca pṛthivītvaṃ vinānugatākāraṃ dharmeṣu sāmānyamastīti / dharmo dharma ityanugatajñānasyāsaṃvedanāt / yadi cānugatākārāśeṣadharmavyāpikā syād dharmarūpatā / tasyāstarhi sāmānyarūpatvāt tadyogitayā dharmāṇāṃ dravyādiṣvevāntarbhāvaḥ / dravyāditrayasya sāmānyaviśeṣavattvābhidhānāt / na ca dharmatvasya sāmānyalakṣaṇayogitve sāmānyād vyatirekaḥ sidhyati / dravyatvāderapi vyatirekaprasaṅgāt / tathādharmarūpatāyāśca dharmatvāyogena dharme 'pyantarbhāvāsambhavāditi padārthāntaratvaṃ syāt / yathā cāstitvādiṣu dharmarūpatvaṃ tathā dharmatve 'py anye 'stitvādayaḥ / teṣu cāpyanyad dharmatvamityanavasthāṃ nātivartate /
analyzed: na ca pṛthivī tvam vinā anugata ākāram dharmeṣu sāmānyam asti iti dharmaḥ dharmaḥ iti anugata jñānasya asaṃvedanāt yadi ca anugata ākāra aśeṣa dharma vyāpikā syāt dharma rūpatā tasyāḥ tarhi sāmānya rūpatvāt tad yogitayā dharmāṇām dravya ādiṣu eva antarbhāvaḥ dravya ādi trayasya sāmānya viśeṣa vat tva abhidhānāt na ca dharma tvasya sāmānya lakṣaṇa yogi tve sāmānyāt vyatirekaḥ sidhyati dravya tva ādeḥ api vyatireka prasaṅgāt tathā dharm
translated: And there is no universal in things apart from earthness, because the cognition of all things as dharma is not experienced. And if the form of dharma were to pervade all dharmas with a common form, then because of its being of the nature of a universal, dharmas would be included only in substance etc. because substance etc. are said to have universals and particulars. And if dharmatva has the characteristic of a universal, it cannot be established as distinct from the universal, because it would follow that dravya-tva etc. are also distinct. And because the form of dharma cannot be dharma, it cannot be included in dharma either, so it would be a separate category. And just as the form of dharma exists in existence etc., so other existences etc. also exist in dharma-tva. And in those also, another dharma-tva exists, so it does not escape infinite regress.

original: atha yadeva dharmatvamastitvāderādheyaṃ tadevānyeṣāmādhārastadādheyaśceti na yuktametat / ekasmin kāle yad yasyādhārastattasyaivādheyamityanupalambhāt / tathāstitvāderapyekasya nimittasyānekatrānuvṛttau sāmānyāntarbhāvastallakṣaṇayogitvāt /
analyzed: atha yat eva dharma tvam astitva ādeḥ ādheyam tat eva anyeṣām ādhāraḥ tad ādheyaḥ ca iti na yuktam etat ekasmin kāle yat yasya ādhāraḥ tat tasya eva ādheyam iti anupalambhāt tathā astitva ādeḥ api ekasya nimittasya anekatra anuvṛttau sāmānya antarbhāvaḥ tad lakṣaṇa yogitvāt
translated: Now, if the very nature of existence, etc., which is to be supported, were the very same thing that supports the others, and is itself supported, this would not be correct. Because it is not observed that at one time what is the support of something is itself the supported of that same thing. Similarly, if a single thing like existence were to occur in many things, it would be included under universals, because it would possess the characteristics of that.

original: yadi caikaṃ nityamastitvaṃ sarvatra padārtheṣvastīti pratyayajanakaṃ syāt kiṃ sattayā / svarūpasattvena vā / athānekaṃ pratipadārthamastitvābhidheyatvādīti cet / na / dharmivināśe 'pi sattāvadavasthānam / tathā hi / ekāśrayavināśe 'pyekatayā sattāyāḥ padārthāntare 'pi sat saditi pratyayajanakatvenāvasthānam / dharmāṇāntu pratipadārthaniyatatvād āśrayāntare 'stītipratyayajanako 'nya eva dharma iti nāśrayavināśe 'pyavasthāne pramāṇamastīti /
analyzed: yadi ca ekam nityam astitvam sarvatra padārtheṣu asti iti pratyaya janakam syāt kim sattayā svarūpa sattvena vā atha anekam prati padārtham astitva abhidheya tva ādi iti ced na dharmi vināśe pi sattāvat avasthānam tathā hi eka āśraya vināśe pi ekatayā sattāyāḥ padārtha antare pi sat sat iti pratyaya janaka tvena avasthānam dharmāṇām tu prati padārtha niyata tvāt āśraya antare sti iti pratyaya janakaḥ nyaḥ eva dharmaḥ iti na āśraya vināśe pi avasthāne pramāṇam
translated: If, on the other hand, existence were one and eternal, and were to produce the cognition of existence in all things, would it be by its own existence or by its own nature? If it is said that it is many, like existence, being denoted, etc., for each thing, no. For even when the substratum is destroyed, existence remains as before. For instance, even when the single substratum is destroyed, existence remains as one, producing the cognition of existence in another thing also. But since the properties are restricted to each thing, it is only another property that produces the cognition of existence in another substratum. Thus there is no evidence for its remaining even when the substratum is destroyed.

original: atha dravyasyaiva samavāyikāraṇatvena guṇādiṣūtpattikāraṇābhāvād āśrayavināśe 'pyavasthānamiti cet / evaṃ tarhi dravyeṣvanityaṃ guṇādiṣu ca nityamiti syāt / iṣyata eveti cet tarhi vināśavannimittakāraṇādevotpadyante 'stitvādaya iti vyāhatametat / tathāstitvādeḥ pratipadārthaniyatatvenānantyāt teṣvevāstītyādyabhinnavyavahāradarśanād ekamastitveṣvastitvamabhidheyatveṣvabhidheyatvaṃ tatrāpyanye 'stitvādaya iti prāktanameva dūṣaṇamabhyūhyam /
analyzed: atha dravyasya eva samavāyi kāraṇa tvena guṇa ādiṣu utpatti kāraṇa abhāvāt āśraya vināśe pi avasthānam iti ced evam tarhi dravyeṣu anityam guṇa ādiṣu ca nityam iti syāt iṣyate eva iti ced tarhi vināśa vat nimitta kāraṇāt eva utpadyante stitva ādayaḥ iti vyāhatam etat tathā astitva ādeḥ prati padārtha niyata tvena ānantyāt teṣu eva asti ityādi abhinna vyavahāra darśanāt ekam astitveṣu astitvam abhidheya tveṣu abhidheya tvam tatra api anye stitva ādaya
translated: If it be said that—in as much as the Substance alone is the inherent cause (of the properties, etc.), and as such there is no cause for the production of the properties, etc., they continue to exist even when their substratum is destroyed,—then, in that case, the properties, etc. would be non-eternal in substances, and eternal in the properties, etc. If it be held that “it is so admitted”,—then, it becomes contradicted by the assertion that “existence and the rest are produced by the contributory cause in the shape of destruction”. Further, if existence and the rest are restricted to each individual object, then, on account of their being endless, the use of such non-specific expressions as ‘asti’ (‘exists’), ‘nāsti’ (‘does not exist’), ‘asti tat’ (‘it exists’), ‘nāsti tat’ (‘it does not exist’) would become impossible; as these are actually found to be used in regard to existence and the rest. So that the objection urged above remains in force.

original: na cāstitvāderniyatadharmisambandhābhāve vyapadeśaniyamo 'syāyaṃ dharma iti ghaṭate / athāstitvasambandho yadi samavāyastarhi dharmāṇāṃ samavāyitayā dravyādiṣvantarbhāvaḥ / dravyādīnāṃ pañcānāṃ samavāyitvavacanāt / yadyanyaḥ sambandho dharmātmakastasyāyutasiddhasambandhatve kathaṃ samavāyād vyatirekaḥ / vyatireke vā sa eva dharmo dharmivyāpako 'stvalaṃ samavāyena / tasya ca sambandhāntarābhyupagame 'navasthā syāditi svātmavṛttitvamabhyupeyam / svātmavṛttitvaṃ samavāya eva /
analyzed: na ca astitva ādeḥ niyata dharmi sambandha abhāve sya ayam dharmaḥ iti ghaṭate atha astitva sambandhaḥ yadi samavāyaḥ tarhi dharmāṇām samavāyi tayā dravya ādiṣu antarbhāvaḥ dravya ādīnām pañcānām samavāyi tva vacanāt yadi anyaḥ sambandhaḥ dharma ātmakaḥ tasya ayuta siddha sambandha tve katham samavāyāt vyatirekaḥ vyatireke vā saḥ eva dharmaḥ dharmi vyāpakaḥ stu alam samavāyena tasya ca sambandha antara abhyupagame navasthā syāt iti sva ātma vṛtti tv
translated: And when there is no definite connection with the substratum, it is not possible to say that this is the property of that. If the relation is inherence, then the properties are included in substance etc. as inhering, because it is said that the five, substance etc., are inhering. If the relation is something else, having the nature of a property, and if it is a relation of inseparable inherence, how is it different from inherence? If it is different, let that property itself pervade the substratum, what is the use of inherence? And if that is accepted to have another relation, there would be an infinite regress, so it must be accepted to inhere in itself. Inherence inheres in itself.

original: yaccānumānaṃ nimittakāraṇādevotpadyante dharmāḥ / dravyaguṇakarmavyatirekikāryatvād vināśavad ityatra kāryatvasya svakāraṇasattāsambandharūpatāyāmasiddho hetuḥ / vināśasya ca svakāraṇasattāsambandhābhāvāt sādhanavikalaśca dṛṣṭāntaḥ / dravyādivyatireke ca pramāṇābhāvāt sandigdhaviśeṣaṇo hetuḥ / atha ṣaṭpadārtheṣvastīti jñānaṃ vyatireke pramāṇam / tathā hi / dravyādiṣvastītyādijñānāni ṣaṭpadārthavyatiriktavidhīyamānanimittanibandhanāni / ṣaṭpadārtheṣūtpadyamānatvāt / yāni tu ṣaṭpadārthavyatiriktavidhīyamānanimittanibandhanāni na bhavanti na tāni ṣaṭsūtpadyante yathā dravyādijñānāni / tathā ṣaṭsu notpadyante 'stītyādijñānāni / tasmāt ṣaṭpadārthavyatiriktavidhīyamānanimittanibandhanānīti vyatirekī / tathā hi / ṣaṭpadārtheṣvastīti jñānaṃ tathā abhidheya ityutpadyamānaṃ dṛṣṭamiti pakṣadharmatvam / na ca ṣaṭpadārthavyatiriktabhāvarūpanimittanibandhanamubhayābhimataṃ vijñānamastīti sapakṣābhāvaḥ / dravyādijñānantu ṣaṭpadārthavyatiriktabhāvarūpanimittanibandhanaṃ na bhavatīti vipakṣastasmācca ṣaṭpadārtheṣūtpadyamānatvaṃ hi dravyādivyāvṛttam / tathā hi dravyajñānaṃ dravya eva na tu guṇādiṣu / evaṃ guṇajñānaṃ guṇa eva na karmādiṣvapīti na ṣaṭsūtpattiriti vipakṣavyāvṛttireva / vipakṣe pratyakṣāgamābhyāṃ virudhyata iti na kālātyayāpadiṣṭaḥ / viśeṣānupalabdherayogād na prakaraṇasama iti / tasmād vyatirekasiddhau na sandigdhaviśeṣaṇo heturiti / naitadevam / ṣaṭsu I / padārtheṣūtadyamānatvaṃ vyaktyapekṣayā'siddham / tathā hyekamastīti jñānaṃ ṣaṭsu padārtheṣūtpadyate / evamabhidheyajñānañceti / atha asti dravyam / asti guṇa ityevaṃjātīyakaṃ jñānaṃ ṣaṭsūtpadyata iti nāstyasiddhatā / tarhi dravyaguṇādijñānaṃ jñānajātīyaṃ ṣaṭsūtpadyate / na ca ṣaṭpadārthātiriktabhāvarūpanimittanibandhanamiti vyabhicāraḥ / yacca ṣaṭpadārthātiriktaṃ bhāvarūpanimittaṃ tasyānuvṛttavyāvṛttatāyāṃ prāktanameva dūṣaṇamūhyam / sattāsambandhena ca padārtheṣu bhāvavyatirekābhyāmastīti jñānamutpadyamānaṃ dṛṣṭamiti virodhaḥ / astitvadharmādevāstitvajñānamiti cet tarhi sattāyāḥ sadbhāve kiṃ pramāṇamiti vācyam / pratyayavailakṣaṇyābhāvādityato na vyatireke pramāṇamastītyaprasiddhaviśeṣaṇo heturiti satyam / yadi ca abhūtvā bhāvitvamātraṃ kāryatvamiṣṭaṃ syāttadapyastitvādiṣu sandigdham / tathā hyāśraye satyupalambhādastitvāderna jñāyate kimāśrayā vā te santo 'bhivyajyante sāmānyavat / utotpadyante rūpādivaditi / na ca nimittakāraṇaṃ viśeṣato nirdeṣṭuṃ śakyate / atha guṇāśrayāstadādhārāsteṣāṃ nimittamiti cet / evaṃ tarhi guṇādīnāṃ kāryādhāratayā samavāyikāraṇatvāditi nimittādevotpattirvirudhyate / tathā hi / niyamenādhāryādhārayoryaḥ sambandhaḥ sa samavāya eva / anyatve vā samavāyalakṣaṇaṃ vyabhicāri syāt / asambandhe coktameva dūṣaṇamityatiriktaiḥ dharmairvinā dharmiṇāmuddeśaḥ kṛtaḥ iti siddham /
analyzed: yat ca anumānam nimitta kāraṇāt eva utpadyante dharmāḥ dravya guṇa karma vyatireki kārya tvāt vināśa vat iti atra kārya tvasya sva kāraṇa sattā sambandha rūpatāyām asiddhaḥ hetuḥ vināśasya ca sva kāraṇa sattā sambandha abhāvāt sādhana vikalaḥ ca dṛṣṭāntaḥ dravya ādi vyatireke ca pramāṇa abhāvāt sandigdha viśeṣaṇaḥ hetuḥ atha ṣaṣ padārtheṣu asti iti jñānam vyatireke pramāṇam tathā hi dravya ādiṣu asti ityādi jñānāni ṣaṣ pad
translated: And the inference that things arise only from instrumental causes, because they are effects distinct from substance, quality and action, like destruction, has an unestablished reason in the case of the nature of being related to the existence of its own cause in the case of being an effect. And the example is deficient in the probandum, because destruction does not have the relation of being related to the existence of its own cause. And the reason is doubtful in the case of being distinct from substance etc., because there is no evidence. If the knowledge that it exists among the six categories is the evidence in the case of being distinct, then the knowledge that it exists in substance etc. is based on an instrumental cause that is being enjoined as distinct from the six categories, because it arises among the six categories. But those that are not based on an instrumental cause that is being enjoined as distinct from the six categories do not arise among the six, like the knowledge of substance etc. In the same way, the knowledge that it exists etc. does not arise among the six. Therefore, it is based on an instrumental cause that is being enjoined as distinct from the six categories, by the method of difference.

original: anye tu dharmaiḥ saha dharmiṇa uddeśaḥ kṛtaḥ / keneti / vinā pakṣiṇā ulūkena / sāmānyaśabdaśca viśeṣe vartate prakaraṇāditi bruvate /
analyzed: anye tu dharmaiḥ saha dharmiṇaḥ uddeśaḥ kṛtaḥ kena iti vinā pakṣiṇā ulūkena sāmānya śabdaḥ ca viśeṣe vartate prakaraṇāt iti bruvate
translated: Others, however, say that the subject along with its properties has been stated. By whom? Without the owl, which is the subject. And the general term is used for the particular, due to the context.

original: ṣaṭpadārthasādharmyam🔽ṣaṇṇāmapi padārthānāmastitvābhidheyatvajñeyatvāni / āśritatvaścānyatra nityadravyebhyaḥ /PDhS
analyzed: ṣaṣ padārtha sādharmyam  ṣaṇṇām api padārthānām astitva abhidheya tva jñeya tvāni āśrita tvaḥ ca anyatra nitya dravyebhyaḥ
translated: The similarity of the six categories🔽The existence, nameability, knowability, and dependence of all six categories, except for the eternal substances.

original: atha avyatireke 'stitvādīnāṃ padārthāntarbhāvāt tadviśeṣe 'pi sādharmyarūpatayā parijñānārthamāha ṣaṇṇāmapi padārthānām / astitvañcābhidheyatvañca jñeyatvañceti samāhāradvandvaḥ / na paramastitvādayaḥ ṣaṇṇāṃ dharmāstathāśritatvañceti / tasya nityeṣvasambhavād avyāpakatvena pṛthagabhidhānamityāha āśritatvañcānyatra nityadravyebhyaḥ iti /
analyzed: atha avyatireke stitva ādīnām padārtha antarbhāvāt tad viśeṣe sādharmya rūpatayā parijñāna artham āha ṣaṇṇām api padārthānām astitvam ca abhidheya tvam ca jñeya tvam ca iti samāhāra dvandvaḥ na param astitva ādayaḥ ṣaṇṇām dharmāḥ tathā āśrita tvam ca iti tasya nityeṣu asambhavāt avyāpaka tvena pṛthak abhidhānam iti āha āśrita tvam ca anyatra nitya dravyebhyaḥ iti
translated: Now, if existence and so on are not different, they are included in the categories. Even in their particularities, for the purpose of knowing them as having the form of similarity, it is said: Of all six categories, existence, nameability, and knowability are a copulative compound. The existence and so on of the six are not the properties, and dependence is also like that. Since that is not possible in the eternal ones, it is stated separately because it is not all-pervading, saying and dependence is elsewhere than the eternal substances.

original: athāvyatireke 'stitvādīnāṃ kvāntarbhāva iti cet / śabdavyavahārasya vivakṣitatvādasteḥ śabdarūpasya bhāvo 'stitvaṃ jñānameva / yena satā'stītyabhidhānaṃ pravartata iti / jñānarūpasya ca asterbhāvo 'stitvamiti vivakṣāyāṃ sattāsvarūpaṃ sattvaṃ vā labhyate / tatsadbhāve dravyādiṣvastītijñānadarśanāt / asti cāyam astiśabdo jñāne / tadviṣaye 'I /bhidhāne ceti /🔽tathā abhidheyasya ca bhāvo 'bhidheyatvam / abhidheya iti jñānameva / tena satā abhidheyo 'yamartha iti śābdavyavahāradarśanāt / taccābhidhānajanitaṃ jñānamartha iti /
analyzed: atha avyatireke stitva ādīnām kva antarbhāvaḥ iti ced śabda vyavahārasya vivakṣita tvāt asteḥ śabda rūpasya bhāvaḥ ustitvam jñānam eva yena satā asti iti abhidhānam pravartate iti jñāna rūpasya ca asteḥ bhāvaḥ ustitvam iti vivakṣāyām sattā svarūpam sattvam vā labhyate tad sadbhāve dravya ādiṣu asti iti jñāna darśanāt asti ca ayam asti śabdaḥ jñāne tad viṣaye ca iti  tathā abhidheyasya ca bhāvaḥ bhidheya tvam abhidheyaḥ iti jñānam eva tena satā abhidheyaḥ yam arthaḥ iti śābda vyavahāra darśanāt tat ca abhidhāna janitam jñānam arthaḥ iti
translated: Now, if it is asked where the existence etc. are included when there is no difference, it is said: because verbal usage is intended, the existence of the word 'exists' is the state of being, which is knowledge itself. By which, when it exists, the expression 'it exists' proceeds. And in the case of the knowledge-form of 'exists', when the state of being is intended, either the nature of existence or existence is obtained. Because when that exists, the knowledge that 'it exists in substances etc.' is seen. And this word 'exists' is in knowledge, and in the expression about its object.🔽Similarly, the state of being of the object of expression is the state of being an object of expression. The object of expression is knowledge itself. Because when it exists, the verbal usage 'this object is to be expressed' is seen. And that is the object of knowledge produced by that expression.

original: tathā jñeyasya bhāvo jñeyatvaṃ jñeyamiti jñānameva / tena satā jñeyamiti śābdavyavahāradarśanāt / tacca jñānena viśeṣaṇena janitaṃ jñānamartha iti /
analyzed: tathā jñeyasya bhāvaḥ jñeya tvam jñeyam iti jñānam eva tena satā jñeyam iti śābda vyavahāra darśanāt tat ca jñānena viśeṣaṇena janitam jñānam arthaḥ iti
translated: Similarly, the state of being of the object of knowledge is the state of being an object of knowledge. The object of knowledge is knowledge itself. Because when it exists, the verbal usage 'the object of knowledge' is seen. And that is the object of knowledge produced by the knowledge-qualifier.

original: tathā āśritānāṃ bhāva āśritatvam āśrayāśrayibhāvalakṣaṇā vṛttiḥ / sā ca ākāśādiṣu na / teṣāmāśrayābhāvāt / na ca āśrayāyibhāvasya samavāyarūpatāyāṃ samavāye 'sambhavāt na ṣaṭpadārthavyāpitvam / atha pañcānāṃ samavāyalakṣaṇā vṛttirāśritatvam / samavāyastu svātmavṛttiriti cet / evaṃ tarhi pañcānāṃ samavāyitvamiti punaruktaṃ syāt / tathā hi / samavāyitvaṃ samavāyalakṣaṇā vṛttiḥ sā ca pañcānāmāśritatvapadenokteti āśritatvapadena āśritatvopalakṣitasyehābhidhānādadoṣaḥ /
analyzed: tathā āśritānām bhāvaḥ āśrita tvam āśraya āśrayi bhāva lakṣaṇā vṛttiḥ sā ca ākāśa ādiṣu na teṣām āśraya abhāvāt na ca āśrayāyibhāvasya samavāya rūpa tāyām samavāye sambhavāt na ṣaṣ padārtha vyāpi tvam atha pañcānām samavāya lakṣaṇā vṛttiḥ āśrita tvam samavāyaḥ tu sva ātma vṛttiḥ iti ced evam tarhi pañcānām samavāyi tvam iti punar uktam syāt tathā hi samavāyi tvam samavāya lakṣaṇā vṛttiḥ sā ca pañcānām āśrita
translated: Similarly, the existence of the dependent entities is their dependence, which is the relation characterized by the relation of the supported and the supporter. And that does not exist in space etc., because they have no support. And if the relation of the supported and the supporter is of the nature of inherence, then inherence does not pervade the six categories. If it is argued that the relation of the five with inherence is dependence, and inherence exists in itself, then in that case it would be a repetition to say that the five are inherents. This is because inherence is the relation characterized by inherence, and that is said to be the dependence of the five by the word dependence. So there is no fault in the statement here of dependence characterized by dependence by the word dependence.

original: atha vyatiriktasya nimittasyāsambhavāt samavāye bhāvapratyayaḥ katham / āśritasya samavāyasya bhāva āśritatvamiti / naitadevam / samavāyasya vṛttirūpatayā vṛttimadāśritatvopalabdhervṛttyantarakalpanāyāmanavasthā syādityupacaritā vṛttiriṣyate / sā ca anyanimittasyāsambhavādāśritatvajñānahetuḥ samavāye vṛttiviśeṣa eva / ātmavṛttitve tu samavāyasya svayaṃ vṛttirūpatvād vṛttyantaraṃ nāpekṣitamityupagamenāśritatvameva /
analyzed: atha vyatiriktasya nimittasya asambhavāt samavāye bhāva pratyayaḥ katham āśritasya samavāyasya bhāvaḥ āśrita tvam iti na etat evam samavāyasya vṛtti rūpa tayā vṛttimat āśrita tva upalabdheḥ vṛtti antara kalpanāyām anavasthā syāt iti upacaritā vṛttiḥ iṣyate sā ca anya nimittasya asambhavāt āśrita tva jñāna hetuḥ samavāye vṛtti viśeṣaḥ eva  ātma vṛtti tve tu samavāyasya svayam vṛtti rūpa tvāt vṛtti antaram na apekṣitam iti upagamena āśrita tv
translated: Now, since a separate cause is not possible, how is the suffix -tva in samāvāya (inherence) explained? Inherence is the existence of the dependent thing. This is not so. Since the existence of inherence is perceived as having the form of manifestation and depending on something else, an infinite regress would result if another manifestation were postulated. Therefore, a secondary manifestation is accepted. And that, due to the impossibility of another cause, is itself the special manifestation of inherence, the cause of the knowledge of dependence. But if inherence has manifestation as its nature, since it itself has the form of manifestation, another manifestation is not required. Thus, dependence itself is accepted.

original: avyatireke hi āśrayāśrayivyavahārāsambhavādataḥ samānalakṣaṇavṛttipratiṣedha eveti vakṣyāmaḥ samavāyaparīkṣāyāmityalam /
analyzed: avyatireke hi āśraya āśrayi vyavahāra asambhavāt atas samāna lakṣaṇa vṛtti pratiṣedhaḥ eva iti vakṣyāmaḥ samavāya parīkṣāyām iti alam
translated: For if there were no difference, the relation of substratum and predicated property would be impossible. Therefore, we will say in the examination of inherence that it is only the negation of having the same characteristics and manifestation.

original: pañcapadārthasādharmyam
translated: The similarity of the five categories

original: dravyādīnāṃ pañcānāmapi sādharmyaṃ samavāyitvamanekatvañca /PDhS
analyzed: dravya ādīnām pañcānām api sādharmyam samavāyi tvam aneka tvam ca
translated: The similarity of substance and the other four categories is inherence and plurality.

original: idānīṃ samavāyaparityāgena pañcānāṃ sādharmyamāha dravyādīnām ityādinā / dravyamādiryeṣāṃ te dravyādayasteṣām / na jñāyate kiyatāmityāha pañcānāmapi sādhamyaṃ samavāyitvamanekatvañca iti / samavāyo vidyate yeṣāṃ te samavāyinasteṣāṃ bhāvaḥ samavāyitvaṃ samavāyalakṣaṇā vṛttiriti / anekatvañca samānalakṣāṇayogitve sati vyaktibhedo 'nekatvasaṃkhyā vopacaritā / samavāye tu samānalakṣaṇayogini na vyaktibhedo nāpyanekatvasaṃkhyeti /
analyzed: idānīm samavāya parityāgena pañcānām sādharmyam āha dravya ādīnām ityādinā dravyam ādiḥ yeṣām te dravya ādayaḥ teṣām na jñāyate kiyatām iti āha pañcānām api sādhamyam samavāyi tvam aneka tvam ca iti samavāyaḥ vidyate yeṣām te samavāyinaḥ teṣām bhāvaḥ samavāyi tvam samavāya lakṣaṇā vṛttiḥ iti aneka tvam ca samāna lakṣāṇa yogi tve sati vyakti bhedaḥ neka tva saṃkhyā vā upacaritā samavāye tu samāna lakṣaṇa yogini na vyakti bheda
translated: Now, abandoning the doctrine of inherence, he states the similarity of the five substances etc. by of substances etc. Those for whom substance is the beginning are substances etc. It is not known how many, he says: The similarity of the five is inherence and plurality. Those in whom inherence exists are inherents, their state is inherence, the operation characterized by inherence. And plurality is the superimposition of the difference of individuals when there is the possession of the same characteristics, or the number of plurality. But in inherence, which possesses the same characteristics, there is no difference of individuals, nor the number of plurality.

original: guṇādīnāṃ pañcānāmapi nirguṇatvaniṣkriyatve /PDhS
analyzed: guṇa ādīnām pañcānām api nirguṇa tva niṣkriya tve
translated: The five, including qualities, are devoid of qualities and actions.

analyzed: idānīm dravya parityāgena sādharmyam darśayati guṇa ādīnām guṇaḥ ādiḥ yeṣām te tathā uktāḥ teṣām na jñāyate kiyatām atas pañcānām api sādharmyam nirguṇa tvam ca niṣkriya tvam ca iti nirguṇa tva niṣkriya tve nirgatāḥ guṇāḥ yebhyaḥ te nirguṇāḥ teṣām bhāvaḥ nirguṇa tvam guṇa abhāvaḥ  atha abhāvasya abhāva tayā dharma tva abhāvaḥ iti ced na viśeṣaṇa tvena tad upapatteḥ tathā hi guṇa abhāvena satā guṇa ādiṣu anvaya vyatirekābhyām nirguṇaḥ iti vyavahāra darśanāt jñāyate guṇa abhāvasya viśeṣaṇa tvena dharma tvam iti sa ca pañcasu samāna tvāt sādharmyam iti
translated: Now he shows the similarity with the abandonment of substance. Those for whom quality etc. are the beginning are said to be that. It is not known by how much. Their state is the state of being without qualities, the absence of qualities.🔽If it is argued that since absence is an absence, it cannot be a quality, it is not so. Because it is possible as a qualifier. Thus, it is seen that the usage as without qualities is due to the absence of qualities in qualities etc. through positive and negative concomitance. Therefore, it is known that the absence of qualities is a quality as a qualifier. And that is the similarity due to the equality in the five.

original: ṣaḍeva padārthā ityavadhāraṇañca bhāvaviṣayamityabhāvasya vyatireke 'pi na doṣaḥ / āśritasya dharmatve 'pi samaveta eva dharma iti niyamānabhyupagamācceti /

original: anye tu guṇābhāvopalakṣitaḥ samavāyo nirguṇatvam / kriyābhāvopalakṣitaśca niṣkriyatvamiti manyante / taccāsat / samavāye dhamiṇi samavāyāntarasyāsambhavānnirguṇavyavahāro na syāt / abhede hi dharmadharmivyavahārādarśanāt /

translated: The relation of existence is common to all three, substance and the rest. The possession of universals and particulars, being denoted by words whose meaning is fixed by convention, and being the substratum of dharma and adharma.

translated: He states the similarity of substance and the other three: of substance etc. Those for whom substance is the beginning are the substances etc. Of those. translated: If it is argued that the cognition of existence in universals etc. is due to their own existence, then in that case, let it be the same in substances etc. also. Thus, in substances etc., the cognition of existence and existence arises from their own existence, because it is the cognition of existence and existence, like the cognition of existence and existence in universals etc.

original: yad vā sāmānyādiṣu satsaditi jñānam / sattākāryam / satsaditi jñānatvāt / dravyādiṣu satsaditi jñānavad ityetadasat / sāmānyādiṣu sattāsambandhe bādhakopapatteḥ / tathā hi / sāmānye sattāsambandhakalpanāyāṃ sattāyāmapi satsaditijñānadarśanād anyaḥ sattāsambandhastatrāpi ityanavasthā /

translated: Or, the cognition of existence and existence in universals etc. is the effect of existence, because it is the cognition of existence and existence, like the cognition of existence and existence in substances etc. This is not so, because an objection can be raised to the relation of existence with universals etc. Thus, when the relation of existence with universals is imagined, the cognition of existence and existence is seen even in existence, so another relation of existence is required there also, leading to an infinite regress.

original: viśeṣeṣu ca sattāsambandhitvāt saṃśayopapattau nirṇayārthamanyo viśeṣastatrāpi anyaḥ sattāsambandha iti saṃśayaviṣayatvānnirṇayārthamanyo viśeṣa iti saṃśayanirṇayaviśeṣānavasthā atra prasajyeta /

translated: And in particulars, because of the relation to existence, when doubt is possible, for the sake of determination, another particular is needed there too, and there also the relation to existence, so the infinite regress of doubt and determination would result here, because of being the object of doubt.

original: samavāye ca sattāyā vṛttyabhāva iti bādhakopapatterna sāmānyādiṣu sattāsambandha iti /
analyzed: samavāye ca sattāyāḥ vṛtti abhāvaḥ iti bādhaka upapatteḥ na sāmānya ādiṣu sattā sambandhaḥ iti
translated: And because of the possibility of the refutation that there is no manifestation of existence in inherence, there is no relation to existence in universals etc.

original: nanu svarūpasattve 'pi samānametat / tathā hi / yadyekaṃ svarūpasattvaṃ sāmānyādiṣu tatrāpi sattāvadanavasthānādidoṣaḥ / atha pratipadārthaniyatam / tasya vyāvṛttarūpatāyāṃ satsaditi jñānajanakatvaṃ na syāt / asya hi anumatatvāt / na / anyathā tadupapatteḥ / tathā hi / sāmānyādiṣu sattāsamavāye bādhakopapatteḥ satsaditi jñānamupacaritam / upacāraśca pravartamāno nimittamapekṣate iti svātmanā sādhāraṇadharmeṇopacāranimittena sattāvattvaṃ satsaditi pratyayajanakatvam / yatra hi sattā sādhāraṇadharmo dṛṣṭa iti / tadupalambhāt sattādhyāropaḥ pravartata eveti / sāmānyādiṣu satsaditi jñānasyānyathāpi bhāvādanyathā I / siddho heturiti / na ca dravyādiṣu satsaditi jñānasyāsādhāraṇadharmādevotpattiriti vācyam / mukhye bādhakāsambhavāt / na ca mukhyaṃ vinā kvacidupacāro dṛṣṭa iti dravyādiṣu sattāsamavāyādeva satsaditi jñānaṃ dṛṣṭamiti siddham /
analyzed: nanu sva rūpa sattve pi samānam etat tathā hi yadi ekam sva rūpa sattvam sāmānya ādiṣu tatra api sattāvat anavasthāna ādi doṣaḥ atha pratipadārtha niyatam tasya vyāvṛtta rūpa tāyām sat sat iti jñāna janaka tvam na syāt asya hi anumata tvāt na anyathā tad upapatteḥ tathā hi sāmānya ādiṣu sattā samavāye bādhaka upapatteḥ sat sat iti jñānam upacaritam upacāraḥ ca pravartamānaḥ nimittam apekṣate iti sva ātmanā sādhāraṇa dharmeṇa upacāra nimittena satt
translated: But even if they exist by their own nature, this is the same. Thus, if there is one existence by own nature in universals etc., then there would be the fault of infinite regress like existence. Or if it is restricted to each object, then in the form of exclusion, it would not generate the cognition existent of the existent, because this is accepted. No, because it is logically possible otherwise. Thus, in universals etc., because the existence inhering in them is logically possible, the cognition existent of the existent is figurative. And figurative usage, when occurring, requires a reason. Therefore, by the common property in its own self, which is the reason for figurative usage, the existence of having existence is the cause of generating the cognition existent of the existent. For where existence is seen as a common property, the superimposition of existence proceeds just from the perception of that. Thus, because the cognition existent of the existent in universals etc. is logically possible in another way, the reason is established in another way. And the arising of the cognition existent of the existent in substances etc. is not only from a non-common property.

original: anye tu satsaditi jñānasya sattāviśeṣaṇajanitatvādekatra samavetatvena viśeṣaṇamanyatra viśeṣaṇaviśeṣyabhāvena ityubhayatrāpi mukhyatāṃ bruvate / tathā hi / na saṃyogasamavāyāyatto viśeṣaṇaviśeṣyabhāvaḥ / abhāve tadabhāvaprasaṅgāt / atha viśiṣṭajñānapratibandho yatra hi viśiṣṭajñānaṃ tatra viśeṣaṇaviśeṣyabhāvaḥ / tatra hi sāmānyādiṣvapi satsaditiviśiṣṭajñānotpatterviśeṣaṇaviśeṣyabhāva eva sambandha ityubhayatrāpi mukhyaṃ satsaditi jñānam /
analyzed: anye tu sat sat iti jñānasya sattā viśeṣaṇa janita tvāt ekatra samaveta tvena viśeṣaṇam anyatra viśeṣaṇa viśeṣya bhāvena iti ubhayatra api mukhya tām bruvate tathā hi na saṃyoga samavāya āyattaḥ viśeṣaṇa viśeṣya bhāvaḥ abhāve tad abhāva prasaṅgāt atha viśiṣṭa jñāna pratibandhaḥ yatra hi viśiṣṭa jñānam tatra viśeṣaṇa viśeṣya bhāvaḥ tatra hi sāmānya ādiṣu api sat sat iti viśiṣṭa jñāna utpatteḥ viśeṣaṇa viśeṣya bh
translated: Others, however, say that the cognition of 'sat' and 'sat' is produced by the qualification of existence, and the qualification is inherent in one place, and the relation of qualifier and qualified in another place, so it is primary in both cases. Thus, the relation of qualifier and qualified is not dependent on conjunction or inherence, because in negation, that would lead to the absence of that. If it is the restriction of the cognition of the qualified, then where there is the cognition of the qualified, there is the relation of qualifier and qualified. There, because the cognition of the qualified arises even in universals etc., the relation is only the relation of qualifier and qualified. Therefore, the cognition of 'sat' and 'sat' is primary in both cases.

original: etaccāsat / yatra hi guṇakarmasāmānyānāṃ viśeṣaṇatvam ubhayābhimataṃ tatra tatra samavāyeneti dṛṣṭam / sāmānyādiṣu sattāyāḥ samavāyasya vyāpakasya vyāvṛtterviśeṣaṇatvasya vyāpyasya vyāvṛttiriti kevalaṃ tatsahacaritadharmopalabdheḥ sattādhyāropa iti yuktam / anyathā hi sarvatra gauṇapratyayocchedo mithyājñānasya ceti / tathā hi / siṃho māṇavaka iti māṇavake 'pi siṃhatvaṃ viśeṣaṇam / siṃha iveti mukhyameva jñānaṃ syāt / tathā śuktikāyāṃ rajatamiti jñāne rajata iva rajatatvaṃ viśeṣaṇamiti mithyātvaṃ na syāt / asti ca mithyājñānamiti pravakṣyāmastadadhikāre /
analyzed: etat ca asat yatra hi guṇa karma sāmānyānām viśeṣaṇa tvam ubhaya abhimatam tatra tatra samavāyena iti dṛṣṭam sāmānya ādiṣu sattāyāḥ samavāyasya vyāpakasya vyāvṛtteḥ viśeṣaṇa tvasya vyāpyasya vyāvṛttiḥ iti kevalam tad sahacarita dharma upalabdheḥ sattā adhyāropaḥ iti yuktam anyathā hi sarvatra gauṇa pratyaya ucchedaḥ mithyājñānasya ca iti tathā hi siṃhaḥ māṇavakaḥ iti māṇavake pi siṃha tvam viśeṣaṇam siṃhaḥ iva iti mukhyam ev
translated: This is not correct. Where the qualification of qualities, actions, and universals is accepted by both, it is seen there that they are related by inherence. In the case of universals etc., the absence of inherence, which is all-pervasive, leads to the absence of the qualified nature, which is pervaded by it. Thus, it is proper to superimpose existence based on the perception of a property co-occurring with it. Otherwise, there would be the destruction of figurative cognition everywhere and of false cognition. This is because, for example, in the statement The boy is a lion, lionhood is a qualifier even with respect to the boy. The cognition would be primary, as if it were a lion. Similarly, in the cognition Silver with respect to a mother-of-pearl, silverhood is a qualifier, as if it were silver. Thus, it would not be false. But we shall explain that false cognition exists, in the section on that.

original: atha siṃhatvāyogini māṇavake tatsahacaritadharmopalambhāt siṃhatvādhyāropeṇotpādād gauṇatvam / tathā śuktikāyāṃ rajatasādharmye upalabdhe rajatatvādhyāropeṇotpādānmithyātvamiti cet / kathametat / māṇavake siṃhatvasya samavāyenānubhavābhāvāt / tathā śuktikāyāṃ rajatatvasya samavāyenānubhavābhāvāt / ataḥ smaryamāṇasyādhyāropeṇa siṃhatvasya māṇavake vyāpārastathā rajatatvasya śuktikāyāmiti prayuktaṃ gauṇatvaṃ mithyātvañceti / tarhi sāmānyādiṣu sattādhyāropeṇa satsaditi jñānaṃ nyāyyaṃ sattāsamavāye bādhakopapatteriti / nanvivārthasya sāmānyādau satsaditi jñāne 'pratibhāsanādupacāraḥ katham / yatra hi ivārthaḥ prathate tadupacaritaṃ jñānam / anyathā hi adhyāropāviśeṣe mithyājñānenāviśeṣa eva syāt / naitadevam / siṃhatvāyoginaṃ puruṣaṃ pratipadyamāno 'pi siṃho 'yamiti pratipadyate / na caivaṃ rajatatvāyoginīṃ śuktikāṃ pratipadyamāno rajatamiti pratyeti / tathā ca mithyājñāne paścād bādhakaṃ vedyamiti / gauṇajñāne I / tu pūrvamapi bādhakamastyeva / kevalantu śauryakhyāpanāya māṇavakaṃ siṃha iti vyavaharanti / mithyājñāne tu atasmiṃstadevedamiti manyante / asti ca sāmānyādau satsaditi jñānam / na cāsya bādhakaṃ kālatraye 'pi ityatra śeṣamūhyam /
analyzed: atha siṃha tva ayogini māṇavake tad sahacarita dharma upalambhāt siṃha tva adhyāropeṇa utpādāt gauṇa tvam tathā śuktikāyām rajata sādharmye upalabdhe rajata tva adhyāropeṇa utpādāt mithyātvam iti ced katham etat māṇavake siṃha tvasya samavāyena anubhava abhāvāt tathā śuktikāyām rajata tvasya samavāyena anubhava abhāvāt atas smaryamāṇasya adhyāropeṇa siṃha tvasya māṇavake vyāpāraḥ tathā rajata tvasya śuktikāyām iti prayuktam gauṇa tvam mithyātva
translated: If it is argued that in the case of a young boy who is not a lion, the attribution of lionhood is figurative because it arises from the perception of attributes co-occurring with it, and similarly, the falsity of silver in a shell is due to the attribution of silverness arising from the perception of similarity to silver, how is this so? Because there is no experience of lionhood inhering in the young boy, and similarly, no experience of silverness inhering in the shell. Therefore, the figurative usage of lionhood and silverness in the young boy and shell is appropriate as their operation is through attribution of what is remembered. Then, in the case of universals etc., the knowledge of being is being through the attribution of existence is proper, because the objection to the inherence of existence is applicable. But how can there be figurative usage in the knowledge of being is being in universals etc. due to the non-appearance of the word like there? For that knowledge is figurative where the word like is prominent. Otherwise, in the absence of distinction in attribution, there would be no distinction in false knowledge.

original: athāstu sāmānyādāvupacaritaṃ dravyatvādau mukhyaṃ satsaditi jñānam / sattāsambandhastu vikalpate / kiṃ sattā satām athāsatāmiti / yadi satām / atha sattāsambandhātpūrvaṃ sattvam / sattāsambadhena vinā ceti / sattāsambandhābhyupagame tatrāpyayaṃ vikalpa ityanavasthā / vineti cet / kiṃ sattayā / athāsatāṃ sattāsambandhāt sattvamityapāramārthikaṃ tarhi sattvam / upādhyapekṣitatvāt / yadi cāsatāṃ sattāsambandhena sattvam / kharaviṣāṇādīnāmapi sattvaṃ syādasattvāviśeṣāt / tathā sattāyāścāsattve tadyogānna dravyādiṣu sattvaṃ syāt / svarūpeṇa ca sattve dravyādiṣu tathābhāvaprasaṅgaḥ sattāsambandhena cānavastheti /
analyzed: atha astu sāmānya ādau upacaritam dravya tva ādau mukhyam sat sat iti jñānam sattā sambandhaḥ tu vikalpate kim sattā satām atha asatām iti yadi satām atha sattā sambandhāt pūrvam sattvam sattā sambadhena vinā ca iti sattā sambandha abhyupagame tatra api ayam vikalpaḥ iti anavasthā vinā iti ced kim sattayā atha asatām sattā sambandhāt sattvam iti apāramārthikam tarhi sattvam upādhi apekṣita tvāt yadi ca asatām sattā sambandhena sattvam khara viṣāṇa ādīnām api sattv
translated: Now, let the knowledge of existence be figurative in substance etc., and primary in existence etc. But the relation to existence is doubted - does existence belong to the existent or the non-existent? If to the existent, then existence is prior to the relation to existence, and without the relation to existence. If the relation to existence is accepted, then this doubt arises there also, so there is an infinite regress. If it is said to be without, what is the use of existence? Or if existence belongs to the non-existent by the relation to existence, then existence is not ultimate, because it depends on a limiting adjunct. And if existence belongs to the non-existent by the relation to existence, then even horns of a donkey etc. would be existent, because of the non-difference in non-existence. Similarly, if existence is non-existent, then existence would not belong to substance etc. due to the connection with that, and if it belongs by its own nature, then it would follow that it exists in substance etc. in that way, and there would be an infinite regress by the relation to existence.

original: ato 'rthakriyākāritvena sattvamiti śākyā manyante /
analyzed: atas ṛthakriyā kāri tvena sattvam iti śākyāḥ manyante
translated: Therefore, the Śākyas think that existence is by the performance of effective action.

original: vartamānakālasambandhitvenetyapare /
analyzed: vartamāna kāla sambandhi tvena iti apare
translated: Others say: in the sense of being related to the present time.

original: tatra yattadavocāma / kiṃ satāṃ sattāsambandhāt sattvam / atha asatāmiti / tadasat / niṣpādasambandhayorekakālatvāt / tathā hi / padārthānāṃ svakāraṇasattāsambandha evotpattiḥ / na pūrvaṃ sattvam / satkāryavādapratiṣedhāt / na cāsatāṃ svakāraṇasattāsambandhābhyupagame kharaviṣāṇādiṣu tathābhāvaprasaṅgaḥ / tadutpattikāraṇābhāvasya tadabhāvenaiva niścayāt / nityeṣu pūrvāparabhāvānupapattervikalpānupapattiḥ /
analyzed: tatra yat tat avocāma kim satām sattā sambandhāt sattvam atha asatām iti tat asat niṣpāda sambandhayoḥ eka kāla tvāt tathā hi padārthānām sva kāraṇa sattā sambandhaḥ eva utpattiḥ na pūrvam sattvam satkārya vāda pratiṣedhāt na ca asatām sva kāraṇa sattā sambandha abhyupagame khara viṣāṇa ādiṣu tathābhāva prasaṅgaḥ tad utpatti kāraṇa abhāvasya tad abhāvena eva niścayāt nityeṣu pūrva apara bhāva anupapatteḥ vikalpa anupapattiḥ
translated: Regarding that, what we said there - whether existence is due to the relation of existence of existent things, or of non-existent things - that is not so, because the relation of accomplishment and existence is simultaneous. Indeed, the origination of things is just the relation of their existence with their own causes, not prior existence, because the doctrine of the existence of effects is refuted. And when the relation of existence with their own causes is accepted for non-existent things, there is no logical fault of that being the case for things like a barren woman's son, because the absence of the cause of its origination is ascertained by the absence of that itself. For eternal things, the impossibility of prior and subsequent existence makes the option impossible.

original: na ca apāramārthikaṃ sattvam / sattāsambandhasya paramārthatvāt / na ca sphaṭikādau cakrādi /japādirūpamiva aupādhikaṃ dravyādiṣu sattvam / sattāyāstatra samavāyāt / upādhiścopādhīyamānaḥ samaveto vā / kvacit samavetarūpatirodhāyakaśca / tathā hi / sphaṭikādirūpe raktādidravyasānnidhyāt tirohite raktaḥ sphaṭika iti pratyayasya bhāvād yuktamaupādhikatvam / na caivaṃ sattā dravyādisvarūpaṃ tirodhāyātmānaṃ prakāśayati / dravyatvāderapi pratibhāsanāt / nāpyasamavetā / tatra samavāyopalabdheḥ /
analyzed: na ca apāramārthikam sattvam sattā sambandhasya paramārtha tvāt  / na ca sphaṭika ādau cakra ādi japa ādi rūpam iva aupādhikam dravya ādiṣu sattvam sattāyāḥ tatra samavāyāt upādhiḥ ca upādhīyamānaḥ samavetaḥ vā kvacid samaveta rūpa tirodhāyakaḥ ca  / tathā hi sphaṭika ādi rūpe rakta ādi dravya sānnidhyāt tirohite raktaḥ sphaṭikaḥ iti pratyayasya bhāvāt yuktam aupādhika tvam na ca evam sattā dravya ādi svarūpam tirodhāya ātmānam prakāśayati dravya
translated: And existence is not unreal, because the relation of existence is real. And existence in substances etc. is not adventitious like the form of a wheel etc. in a crystal etc., because existence inheres in them. And an adventitious property is either inherent or inheres in something else, and in some cases it also conceals the inherent form. This is because when the form of a crystal etc. is concealed by the proximity of a red substance, there is the cognition the crystal is red, so it is proper to say it is adventitious. And existence does not conceal its own nature by concealing the nature of substances etc., because substance-ness etc. also appear. Nor is it non-inherent, because inherence is perceived in it.

original: nanvevaṃ dravyatvādervyatireke tarhi svarūpāsambhavād dravyāderapyadṛśyatāprasaṅgaḥ / tanna dravyatvādereva dravyādiṣvasādhāraṇatvāt / tathā hi / dravye dravyatvena dravyamiti vyapadeśo I / guṇādau ca guṇatvādineti vyatirekāviśeṣe 'pi dravyeṣveva dravyatvaṃ samavetamiti tatraiva vyavahāraheturna guṇādau / evaṃ guṇatvādāvapi niyatadharmisamavāyitvaṃ niyāmakamiti vācyam / samavāyastu vyatireke 'pi samavāyyādhāratayāvabhāsata iti samavāyivyavahāraheturiti / avyatireke tu dravyatvādisvarūpāṇāmekadharmitādātmyenābhedād vibhinnavyavahārahetutvaṃ na syāt / bhede vā dharmiṇastathābhāvo viparyaye tādātmyavirahāt /
analyzed: nanu evam dravya tva ādeḥ vyatireke tarhi svarūpa asambhavāt dravya ādeḥ api adṛśyatā prasaṅgaḥ tat na dravya tva ādeḥ eva dravya ādiṣu asādhāraṇa tvāt tathā hi dravye dravya tvena dravyam iti vyapadeśaḥ guṇa ādau ca guṇa tva ādinā iti vyatireka aviśeṣe pi dravyeṣu eva dravya tvam samavetam iti tatra eva vyavahāra hetuḥ na guṇa ādau evam guṇa tva ādau api niyata dharmi samavāyi tvam niyāmakam iti vācyam samavāyaḥ tu vyatireke pi samavāyi ādhāra t
translated: If it is so, then, in case of the exclusion of substance-ness etc., there would be the undesirable consequence of the invisibility of substance etc. due to the impossibility of their own nature. That is not so, because substance-ness etc. are not common to substances etc. Indeed, in a substance, it is designated as substance by substance-ness, and in a quality etc. by quality-ness etc. Even in the case of difference, substance-ness inheres only in substances, and hence it is the cause of usage only there, not in qualities etc. Similarly, it should be said that quality-ness etc. also have the quality of inherence in a particular substratum as the determining factor. But inherence appears as the substratum of the inhered even in the case of difference, and hence it is the cause of the usage of the inhered. But in the case of non-difference, the forms of substance-ness etc. would not be the cause of different usages due to non-difference in the form of identity with one property. In case of difference, the substratum would be so due to the absence of identity in the opposite case.

original: na ca dravyādijñānasya kalpanātvamiti vācyam / arthakriyānvayavyatirekānuvidhāyinaḥ kalpanātve 'tiprasaṅgād iti siddhaṃ dravyādiṣu sattāsambandhāt satsaditi jñānam /
analyzed: na ca dravya ādi jñānasya kalpanā tvam iti vācyam artha kriyā anvaya vyatireka anuvidhāyinaḥ kalpanā tve tiprasaṅgāt iti siddham dravya ādiṣu sattā sambandhāt sat sat iti jñānam
translated: Nor can it be said that the knowledge of substance etc. is conceptual, because if that which conforms to the concomitance and non-concomitance of effective action were conceptual, there would be an overextension. Thus it is established that the knowledge of substance etc. as existent is due to the relation of existence with substance etc.

original: arthakriyākāritvena sattābhyupagame samānañcaitad dūṣaṇam / kiṃ satāmarthakriyākāritvam / atha asatāmiti / satāmarthakriyākāritve sattābhyupagame tathā duruttaramitaretarāśrayatvam / tathā hyarthakriyājanakatvena sattvam / sataścārthakriyājanakatvamityekāprasiddhāvitarāprasiddhiriti / atha arthakriyāmantareṇa sato 'rthakriyājanakatvaṃ tatrāpyayaṃ vikalpa ityanavasthā / asata evārthakriyājanakatve kharaviṣāṇādiṣu tathābhāvaḥ syāt / arthakriyāyāśca arthakriyāntareṇa sattve 'navasthā / atha svarūpeṇeti cet / padārtheṣu tathābhāvaprasaṅgaḥ /
analyzed: arthakriyā kāri tvena sattā abhyupagame samānam ca etat dūṣaṇam kim satām arthakriyā kāri tvam atha asatām iti satām arthakriyā kāri tve sattā abhyupagame tathā duruttaram itaretara āśraya tvam tathā hi arthakriyā janaka tvena sattvam sataḥ ca arthakriyā janaka tvam iti eka aprasiddhau itara aprasiddhiḥ iti atha arthakriyām antareṇa sataḥ rthakriyā janaka tvam tatra api ayam vikalpaḥ iti anavasthā asataḥ eva arthakriyā janaka tve khara viṣāṇa ādiṣu tathābhāv
translated: If existence is accepted as consisting in the capacity for effective action, then the same objection applies equally. Is the capacity for effective action of existent things? Or of non-existent things? If the capacity for effective action belongs to existent things, then the same unanswerable mutual dependence arises. For existence is due to the capacity to produce effective action, and the capacity to produce effective action belongs to what exists. Thus, if one is not established, the other is not established. If, on the other hand, the capacity to produce effective action belongs to what is not existent, then there is an infinite regress even there, as this option is repeated. If the capacity to produce effective action belongs to what is non-existent, then there would be such a capacity in the horns of a donkey, etc. And if the existence of effective action is due to another effective action, there is an infinite regress. If it is argued that it is due to its own nature, then the same would apply to the objects.

original: etena vartamānakālasambandhitvena sattvaṃ pratyuktam /
analyzed: etena vartamāna kāla sambandhi tvena sattvam pratyuktam
translated: By this, existence as connected with the present time is refuted.

original: atha arthakriyāsāmarthyaṃ sattvam / tasyānekapadārthavyāpitvena satsaditijñānajanakatve saṃjñābhedamātram / avyāpitve tvanugatajñānajanakatvaṃ na syāt / tathā arthakriyājanakatve arthakriyāsamartha iti vyavahāro na satsaditi / vilakṣaṇatvādityalam /
analyzed: atha arthakriyā sāmarthyam sattvam tasya aneka padārtha vyāpi tvena sat sat iti jñāna janaka tve saṃjñā bheda mātram avyāpi tve tu anugata jñāna janaka tvam na syāt tathā arthakriyā janaka tve arthakriyā samarthaḥ iti vyavahāraḥ na sat sat iti vilakṣaṇa tvāt iti alam
translated: If, on the other hand, existence consists in the capacity for effective action, and that capacity is present in many things, then the production of the cognition existent, existent is merely a matter of different names. If it is not present, then the production of a cognition that pervades all things would not be possible. Similarly, if it consists in the capacity to produce effective action, then the usage capable of effective action would not be existent, existent, because of the difference in nature. Thus far on this point.

original: ataḥ sthitametad dravyādīnāṃ sattāsambandha iti /
analyzed: atas sthitam etat dravya ādīnām sattā sambandhaḥ iti
translated: Therefore it is established that substance and so on are related to existence.

original: tathā sāmānyameva dravyavyāvṛttihetutvād viśeṣo dravyatvādiḥ / sa vidyate yeṣāṃ tāni sāmānyaviśeṣavanti / teṣāṃ bhāvaḥ sāmānyaviśeṣavattvam / samavetaḥ sāmānyaviśeṣastadupalakṣito vā samavāyaḥ / tena satā sāmānyaviśeṣavad dravyamityādi vyavahāradarśanāt /
analyzed: tathā sāmānyam eva dravya vyāvṛtti hetu tvāt viśeṣaḥ dravya tva ādiḥ sa vidyate yeṣām tāni sāmānya viśeṣavanti teṣām bhāvaḥ sāmānya viśeṣavat tvam samavetaḥ sāmānya viśeṣaḥ tad upalakṣitaḥ vā samavāyaḥ tena satā sāmānya viśeṣa vat dravyam ityādi vyavahāra darśanāt
translated: Similarly, the universal itself is the cause of the exclusion of substance, and the particular is the universal of substance and so on. Those that possess that are said to possess universal and particular. Their existence is the possession of universal and particular. Inherence is either the universal and particular that are inherent, or inherence as indicated by that, because usage such as substance that exists as possessing universal and particular is seen.

original: tathā svasamaye svaśāstre arthaśabdenābhidhīyanta iti svasamayārthaśabdābhidheyāni / teṣāṃ bhāvaḥ svasamayārthaśabdābhidheyatvam vācyavācakālambanaṃ jñānameva sādharmyam / arthasaṃjñākaraṇe ca prayojanaṃ śrotragrāhyo 'rthaḥ śabda iti vai / sū / / / / tathā hi / śrotragrāhyatvāI /cchabda ityukte śabdatvādibhirvyabhicāraḥ / tannirāsāyārthagrahaṇam / arthastu dravyaguṇakarmātmāpi bhavati / na ca śrotragrāhya ityetatsamuditaṃ śabdasya lakṣaṇam /
analyzed: tathā sva samaye sva śāstre artha śabdena abhidhīyante iti sva samaya artha śabda abhidheyāni teṣām bhāvaḥ sva samaya artha śabda abhidheya tvam vācya vācaka ālambanam jñānam eva sādharmyam artha saṃjñā karaṇe ca prayojanam śrotra grāhyaḥ rthaḥ śabdaḥ iti vai  / tathā hi iti ukte śabda tva ādibhiḥ vyabhicāraḥ tad nirāsāya artha grahaṇam arthaḥ tu dravya guṇa karma ātmā api bhavati na ca śrotra grāhyaḥ iti etat samuditam śabdasya lakṣaṇam
translated: Similarly, they are denoted by the words 'artha' in their own scriptures. They have the nature of being denoted by the words 'artha' in their own scriptures. The similarity is that knowledge alone is the basis of what is expressed and the means of expression. And the purpose of giving the name 'artha' is that the object is audible by the ear. For example, when it is said that the object is audible by the ear, there is an error due to the nature of sound and so on. To remove that, the word 'artha' is used. But the object may also be of the nature of substance, quality, or action. And it is not audible by the ear. This is the definition of sound.
