original: tathā dharmādharmau kurvantīti dharmādharmakartṝṇi teṣāṃ bhāvo dharmādharmakartṛtvam / tacca dravyādīnāmātmīyaṃ rūpaṃ sahakāriviśeṣaśca / tathā ca dravyamātmā dharmādharmayoḥ samavāyikāraṇam / suvarṇādridravyañca dānāpaharaṇābhyāṃ nimittakāraṇamiti / tathātmāntaḥkaraṇasaṃyogo 'samavāyikāraṇam / śuddhābhisandhirduṣṭābhisandhiśca nimittakāraṇam / evaṃ gītiviśeṣo nṛttaviśeṣaśca yathāsambhavaṃ nimittamiti / śeṣamūhyam / nanu suvarṇādidravyavajjātirapyadṛṣṭakāraṇam / astu vā upalakṣaṇena caritārthatvāt /
analyzed: tathā dharma adharmau kurvanti iti dharma adharma kartṝṇi teṣām bhāvaḥ dharma adharma kartṛ tvam tat ca dravya ādīnām ātmīyam rūpam sahakāri viśeṣaḥ ca tathā ca dravyam ātmā dharma adharmayoḥ samavāyi kāraṇam suvarṇa adri dravyam ca dāna apaharaṇābhyām nimitta kāraṇam iti tathā ātma antaḥkaraṇa saṃyogaḥ samavāyi kāraṇam śuddha abhisandhiḥ duṣṭa abhisandhiḥ ca nimitta kāraṇam evam gīti viśeṣaḥ nṛtta viśeṣaḥ ca yathāsambhavam
translated: Similarly, they are the agents of dharma and adharma, so they are the agents of dharma and adharma. And that is the intrinsic nature of substance etc. and a special cooperating factor. And thus substance is the inherent cause of dharma and adharma, and the substance of the gold mountain is the instrumental cause by giving and stealing. Similarly, the conjunction of the self and the internal organ is the non-inherent cause, and pure intention and impure intention are the instrumental causes. Similarly, the particular melody and the particular dance are the instrumental causes as appropriate. The rest should be inferred. But just as the substance like gold is the cause of unseen results, let the universal also be so. Or it is accomplished by indication, because it is a mere indication.

original: kāryatvānityatve kāraṇavatāmeva /PDhS
analyzed: kārya tva anitya tve kāraṇavatām eva
translated: Because they are effects and non-eternal, they must have a cause.

original: kāryatvañcānityatvañca kāryatvānityatve / dravyādīnāṃ trayāṇāmapi / yadi nāma kāraṇaṃ vidyate yeṣāṃ tāni kāraṇavanti teṣāmeva / pūrvadharmastu sarveṣāmiti labhyate / sāpavādatvāviśeṣe 'pi kāraṇavattvapadenāsamāsakaraṇamanayoḥ sāhacaryajñāpanārtham /
analyzed: kārya tvam ca anitya tvam ca kārya tva anitya tve dravya ādīnām trayāṇām api yadi nāma kāraṇam vidyate yeṣām tāni kāraṇavanti teṣām eva pūrva dharmaḥ tu sarveṣām iti labhyate sa apavāda tva aviśeṣe pi kāraṇavat tva padena asamāsa karaṇam anayoḥ sāhacarya jñāpana artham
translated: And being an effect and being non-eternal are the being an effect and being non-eternal of the three, substance etc. If there is a cause for some, they have a cause, and only they are so. But the previous dharma is obtained for all. Even in the absence of an exception, the compound is not made with the word having a cause in order to indicate the association of these two.

original: yad vā kāraṇavatāmakāraṇavatāñca kāraṇavatāmityasamāsakaraṇam /
analyzed: yat vā kāraṇavatām akāraṇavatām ca kāraṇavatām iti asamāsa karaṇam
translated: Or, the compound is not made with having a cause and not having a cause as having a cause.

original: kāryatvapadārthavicāraḥ
translated: Consideration of the meaning of being an effect

original: atha kimidaṃ kāryatvaṃ nāmeti / svakāraṇasattāsambandhaḥ / tena satā kāryamiti vyavahārāt /
analyzed: atha kim idam kāryatvam nāma iti sva kāraṇa sattā sambandhaḥ tena satā kāryam iti vyavahārāt
translated: Now, what is this called being an effect? It is the relation of the existence of its cause. Because of the usage that an effect exists by that.

original: abhūtvā bhavanamityeke / atrāpyabhūtvā paścād bhavanaṃ svakāraṇaiḥ sattayā ca sambandha eveti /
analyzed: a bhūtvā bhavanam iti eke atra api a bhūtvā paścāt bhavanam sva kāraṇaiḥ sattayā ca sambandhaḥ eva iti
translated: Some say it is coming into existence after not having existed. Here also, coming into existence after not having existed is just the relation with its own causes and with existence.

original: anityatvapadārthavicāraḥ
translated: Consideration of the meaning of being non-eternal

original: anityatvantu prāgabhāvapradhvaṃsābhāvopalakṣitā vastusattā / atha vastusattākāle prāgabhāvapradhvaṃsābhāvayorabhāvāt kathamupalakṣaṇatvam / na ca anityavyavahāre sattā viśeṣaṇam / vilakṣaṇatvāt / tathā hi / sattāviśeṣaṇaṃ satsaditi jñānameva / jñānāntare tu sattāyā viśeṣaṇatve sarvatra sattaiva viśeṣaṇaṃ syādityatiprasaṅgaḥ /
analyzed: anitya tvantu prāgabhāva pradhvaṃsa abhāva upalakṣitā vastu sattā  atha vastu sattā kāle prāgabhāva pradhvaṃsa abhāvayoḥ abhāvāt katham upalakṣaṇa tvam na ca anitya vyavahāre sattā viśeṣaṇam vilakṣaṇa tvāt tathā hi sattā viśeṣaṇam sat sat iti jñānam eva jñāna antare tu sattāyāḥ viśeṣaṇa tve sarvatra sattā eva viśeṣaṇam syāt iti atiprasaṅgaḥ
translated: Impermanence is the existence of a thing characterized by prior non-existence and subsequent destruction. But since prior non-existence and subsequent destruction do not exist at the time of the existence of a thing, how can they be characteristics? And in the case of impermanent usage, existence is not a qualifier, because it is different. For example, the cognition of existence as a qualifier is existence of existence. But if existence were a qualifier in another cognition, then existence would be the qualifier everywhere, which is absurd.

original: tasmād yad bhūtvā na bhavati / ātmānaṃ jahāti / tadanityamiti kecit / tadapyasat / vināśasya vastukāle 'sambhavitvena viśeṣaṇatvāyogāt / athāvidyamāno 'pi vināśo 'I /numīyamāno bhavatyupalakṣaṇamiti cet / tathāpi vinaṣṭa iti syāt / na anityamiti / na / paryāyatvāt / tathā hi / anityā viṣayā vināśina iti vyavahāraḥ / yadi ca anityajñāne 'nyannimittaṃ na syāt pratipadyemahyubhayāntopalakṣitā sattā viśeṣaṇamiti / yathā anutpattivināśayoravidyamānayorapi kayācid bhaṅgyā sattopalakṣaṇatvam / tathā vastūpalakṣaṇatāyāmapi na kiñcid bādhakamastīti / tathā hi / prāgabhāvaḥ smaryamāṇaḥ pradhvaṃsābhāvaścānumīyamāno vastūpalakṣaṇamiti /
analyzed: tasmāt yat bhūtvā na bhavati ātmānam jahāti tat anityam iti kecid tat api asat vināśasya vastu kāle sambhavi tvena viśeṣaṇa tva ayogāt vināśaḥ bhavati upalakṣaṇam iti ced tathā api vinaṣṭaḥ iti syāt na anityam iti na paryāya tvāt tathā hi anityāḥ viṣayāḥ vināśinaḥ iti vyavahāraḥ yadi ca anitya jñāne na syāt pratipadyemahi ubhaya anta upalakṣitā sattā viśeṣaṇam iti yathā anutpatti vināśayoḥ avidyamānayoḥ api kayācid bhaṅgyā sattā upal
translated: Therefore, some say that what comes into being and then ceases, abandons its own nature, and is therefore impermanent. But that is also wrong, because destruction cannot be a qualifier, as it is impossible at the time of the existence of a thing. If it is argued that even though non-existent, destruction is inferred and becomes the indicator, then even so it would be destroyed, not impermanent. No, because it is a synonym. For thus, there is the usage impermanent objects are perishable. And if there were no other cause for the impermanent cognition, we would understand that existence indicated by both ends is a qualifier. Just as non-arising and destruction, even though non-existent, are in some way indicators of existence, so there is nothing contradictory in their being indicators of the existent thing as well. For thus, the prior non-existence, when remembered, and the subsequent non-existence, when inferred, are indicators of the existent thing.

original: atha vināśānutpattiranutpattivināśaśca vidyamānatvāt sattāviśeṣaṇamiti cet / paramārthasya viśeṣaṇatvaṃ tayoḥ kalpyatāṃ kimatiprayāsena / athānityajñānamabhāvānuraktaṃ na bhavatīti viśiṣṭasattā viśeṣaṇamupakalpyate / na / sattānurāgasyānupalabdheḥ / kevalamanityatvānuraktamanityamiti jñānamutpadyate /
analyzed: atha vināśa anutpattiḥ anutpatti vināśaḥ ca vidyamāna tvāt sattā viśeṣaṇam iti ced paramārthasya viśeṣaṇa tvam tayoḥ kalpyatām kim ati prayāsena atha anitya jñānam abhāva anuraktam na bhavati iti viśiṣṭa sattā viśeṣaṇam upakalpyate na sattā anurāgasya anupalabdheḥ  kevalam anitya tva anuraktam anityam iti jñānam utpadyate
translated: If it is argued that non-destruction and non-production are the qualifiers of existence because they exist, let their qualification of the ultimate be imagined. What is the use of excessive effort? If it is argued that the qualified existence is imagined because the impermanent cognition is not connected with non-existence, no. Because the connection with existence is not perceived. Only the cognition arises that the impermanent is connected with impermanence alone.

original: anityatvantu prāgabhāvapradhvaṃsābhāvopalakṣitā vastunaḥ satteti udyotakarakalpanāyāṃ nyā / vā / / / kalpanāgauravaṃ syāditi / pradhvaṃsa evānityatvamitīṣṭaṃ bhāṣyakāreṇeti /
analyzed: anitya tvantu prāgabhāva pradhvaṃsa abhāva upalakṣitā vastunaḥ sattā iti udyota kara kalpanāyām vā kalpanā gauravam syāt iti pradhvaṃse eva anitya tvam iti iṣṭam bhāṣyakāreṇa iti
translated: But impermanence is the existence of a thing characterized by prior non-existence and destruction. In the imagination of Uddyotakara, it is reasonable. There would be the heaviness of imagination. It is accepted by the author of the commentary that destruction itself is impermanence.

original: prakṛteṣu parigaṇitānāṃ na samavāyyasamavāyitvam
analyzed: prakṛteṣu parigaṇitānām na samavāyi asamavāyi tvam
translated: The enumerated ones among the primary ones do not have the nature of inherence and non-inherence.

original: kāraṇatvañcānyatra pārimāṇḍalyādibhyaḥ /PDhS
analyzed: kāraṇa tvañca anyatra pārimāṇḍalya ādibhyaḥ pdhs
translated: And causality is elsewhere except for sphericity etc.

original: tathā kāraṇānāṃ bhāvaḥ kāraṇatvam / kāraṇatvañca samavāyyasamavāyikāraṇatvam / samavāyino 'samavāyanaścātmīyaṃ svarūpam / na nimittakāraṇatvaṃ sāmānyādiṣvapi bhāvāt / tacca pratiniyatamapyavivakṣitaviśeṣaṃ sādharmyam / tat kiṃ sarveṣāmityata āha anyatra pārimāṇḍalyādibhyaḥ iti / pārimāṇḍalyādīni varjayitvā / parimaṇḍalāḥ paramāṇavaḥ / teṣāṃ bhāvaḥ pārimāṇḍalyam / paramāṇuparimāṇam / tacca dvyaṇukāṇuparimāṇotpattāvakāraṇamiti vakṣyāmaḥ parimāṇāvasare / ādipadena ākāśādivibhudravyam / antyaḥ śabdaḥ / paratvāparatvapṛthaktvādyakāraṇamiti /🔽prakṛteṣu nityadravyātiriktānāṃ sādharmyam
analyzed: tathā kāraṇānām bhāvaḥ kāraṇa tvam kāraṇa tvañca samavāyi asamavāyi kāraṇa tvam samavāyinaḥ ca ātmīyam svarūpam na nimitta kāraṇa tvam sāmānya ādiṣu api bhāvāt tat ca pratiniyatam api avivakṣita viśeṣam sādharmyam tat kim sarveṣām iti atas āha anyatra pārimāṇḍalī ādibhyaḥ iti pārimāṇḍalī ādīni varjayitvā parimaṇḍalāḥ paramāṇavaḥ teṣām bhāvaḥ pārimāṇḍalyam paramāṇu parimāṇam tat ca dvyaṇuka aṇu parimāṇa p prakṛteṣu nitya dravya atiriktānām sādharmyam
translated: Similarly, the existence of causes is causality. And causality is the nature of being an inherent or non-inherent cause. The inherent and non-inherent causes are one's own nature. And not the nature of being an instrumental cause, because it exists even in universals etc. And that is a specific similarity, even though restricted. What is that? Therefore it is said: except for sphericity etc. Sphericity etc. should be excluded. Atoms are spherical. Their existence is sphericity. And that is the dimension of atoms. And we will say that it is not a cause in the production of the dimension of binary atoms, in the section on dimension. By the word etc. the all-pervading substance like space etc. is included. The last word is etc. It is not a cause of priority, posteriority, separateness etc.🔽The similarity of those other than eternal substances among the primary elements

original: dravyāśritatvañcānyatra nityadravyebhyaḥ /PDhS
analyzed: dravya āśrita tvañca anyatra nitya dravyebhyaḥ
translated: And the dependence on substance is except for eternal substances.

original: na ca paraṃ pūrvasādharmyam / dravyāśritānāṃ bhāvo dravyāśritatvam / taccānyatra nityadravyebhyasteṣāmāśrayābhāvāt / yadyapi ṣaṇṇāmāśritatvābhidhānena dravyādīnāmāI /śritatvamuktaṃ tathāpi dravyopalakṣitasyehābhidhānādapunaruktamiti /
analyzed: na ca param pūrva sādharmyam dravya āśritānām bhāvaḥ dravya āśrita tvam tat ca anyatra nitya dravyebhyaḥ teṣām āśraya abhāvāt yadi api ṣaṇṇām āśrita tva abhidhānena tathā api dravya upalakṣitasya iha abhidhānāt apunaruktam iti
translated: And there is no other similarity with the preceding [categories]. The existence of those that are based on substance is being based on substance. And that is in other [categories] than the eternal substances, because they have no substratum. Although the being based on substance of substance, etc. is stated by the mention of being based on the six [categories], still it is not a repetition here because of the mention of what is characterized by substance.

original: sāmānyāditritayasādharmyam
translated: The similarity of the three, beginning with the universal

original: sāmānyādīnāṃ trayāṇāṃ svātmasattvam / buddhilakṣaṇatvam / akāryatvam / akāraṇatvam / asāmānyaviśeṣavattvam / nityatvam / arthaśabdābhidheyatvañceti /PDhS
analyzed: sāmānya ādīnām trayāṇām sva ātma sattvam buddhi lakṣaṇa tvam akārya tvam akāraṇa tvam asāmānya viśeṣavat tvam nitya tvam artha śabda abhidheya tvam ca iti
translated: The three, beginning with the universal, have the existence of their own nature, the character of being characterized by cognition, the non-being of an effect, the non-being of a cause, the possession of a particular that is not a universal, eternality, and the being denoted by the words object and sound.

original: idānīṃ sāmānyādīnāṃ naikasya dvayorvā kiṃ tarhi / trayāṇāmapi sādharmyam / svātmanā sādhāraṇadharmeṇopacāranimittena sattvaṃ satsaditi pratyayajanakatvam / mukhye hyanavasthādibādhakopapatteḥ /
analyzed: idānīm sāmānya ādīnām na ekasya dvayoḥ vā kim tarhi trayāṇām api sādharmyam sva ātmanā sādhāraṇa dharmeṇa upacāra nimittena sattvam sat sat iti pratyaya janaka tvam mukhye hi anavasthā ādi bādhaka upapatteḥ
translated: Now, the similarity of the three, beginning with the universal, is not of one or two [categories], but rather of all three. The existence, which is the cause of the production of the idea existent exists, is by way of their own nature, by the common property, by the reason for the designation. For in the primary [sense], the occurrence of the refutation, such as the regressus ad infinitum, is possible.

original: anye tu svātmasattvaṃ sattānadhikaraṇānāṃ satsaditipratyayajanakatvamiti bruvate / atra hi nimittānabhidhāne satāṃ bhāvaḥ sattvamiti na kiñciduktaṃ syāt /
analyzed: anye tu sva ātma sattvam sattā anadhikaraṇānām sat sat iti pratyaya janaka tvam iti bruvate atra hi nimitta anabhidhāne satām bhāvaḥ sattvam iti na kiñcid uktam syāt
translated: Others say that the existence of the self is the cause of the cognition of the existent as existent for those that are not the substratum of existence. For here, if the cause is not mentioned, nothing would be said by the existence of the existent is existence.

original: atha sattānadhikaraṇānāṃ svātmanā nimittena satsaditi pratyayajanakatvam / tarhi tasyānuvṛttirūpatāyāṃ doṣopapatteḥ / vyāvṛttarūpatāyāñca anugatajñānajanakatvaṃ na syād ityupacāranimittatvameva nyāyyam /
analyzed: atha sattā anadhikaraṇānām sva ātmanā nimittena sat sat iti pratyaya janaka tvam tarhi tasya anuvṛtti rūpa tāyām doṣa upapatteḥ vyāvṛtta rūpa tāyām ca anugata jñāna janaka tvam na syāt iti upacāra nimitta tvam eva nyāyyam
translated: If, on the other hand, the existence of the self is the cause of the cognition of the existent as existent for those that are not the substratum of existence, then in the case of its being of the nature of continuity, there is the fault of being established. And in the case of its being of the nature of exclusion, there would not be the cause of the cognition of the universal. Therefore, the cause of the figurative usage is indeed proper.

original: nanvevaṃ sāmānyādiṣūpacaritaṃ sattvaṃ syāt / iṣyata eva sattvaṃ satsaditijñānajanakatvamupacaritam /
analyzed: nanu evam sāmānya ādiṣu upacaritam sattvam syāt iṣyate eva sattvam sat sat iti jñāna janaka tvam upacaritam
translated: But in that case, existence would be figuratively applied to universals and so on. The cause of the cognition of the existent as existent is figuratively applied existence, which is accepted.

original: atha upacaritasattvābhyupagame paramārthato 'sattvam / tadiṣṭameva / na paramārthataḥ sāmānyādau satsaditijñānam upacārābhyupagamāt /
analyzed: atha upacarita sattva abhyupagame sattvam tat iṣṭam eva na paramārthataḥ sāmānya ādau sat sat iti jñānam upacāra abhyupagamāt
translated: If existence is accepted as figurative, then non-existence in reality is accepted. That is accepted. The cognition of the existent as existent in universals and so on is not in reality, because figurative usage is accepted.

original: atha sattānadhikaraṇatve sāmānyāderabhāvaḥ syāt / tadasat / asādhāraṇadharmādhikaraṇatayā pramāṇasiddhasyābhāvābhyupagame dravyādiṣu tathābhāvaḥ syāt / ataḥ sāmānyādāvuktarūpe svarūpasattve na doṣa iti /
analyzed: atha sattā anadhikaraṇa tve sāmānya ādeḥ abhāvaḥ syāt tat asat asādhāraṇa dharma adhikaraṇa tayā pramāṇa siddhasya abhāva abhyupagame dravya ādiṣu tathā bhāvaḥ syāt atas sāmānya ādau ukta rūpe svarūpa sattve na doṣaḥ iti
translated: If, on the other hand, the absence of universals etc. were due to their not being the substratum of existence, that is not so. For if the existence of something established by valid cognition as the substratum of a unique property is denied, then there would be non-existence in substances etc. as well. Therefore, there is no fault in the existence of universals etc. in the form stated.

original: tathā buddhirlakṣaṇaṃ yeṣāṃ buddhyā lakṣyanta iti vā buddhilakṣaṇāsteṣāṃ bhāvo buddhilakṣaṇatvam / sāmānyaśabdenāpyarthādanugatavyāvṛttehabuddhyanyatamabuddhilakṣaṇatvaṃ vivakṣitamiti vijñātam / anugatā hi buddhirna viśeṣe nāpi samavāye / vyāvṛttā ca na sāmānyasamavāyayoḥ / tathehabuddhirna sāmānyaviśeṣeṣviti / vyāvṛttatvād vaidharmyaṃ syādityanyatamagrahaṇam / tacca sarveṣu samānatvādeva sādharmyam /
analyzed: tathā buddhiḥ lakṣaṇam yeṣām buddhyā lakṣyante iti vā buddhi lakṣaṇāḥ teṣām bhāvaḥ buddhi lakṣaṇa tvam sāmānya śabdena api arthāt anugata vyāvṛtta iha buddhi anyatama buddhi lakṣaṇa tvam vivakṣitam iti vijñātam anugatā hi buddhiḥ na viśeṣe na api samavāye vyāvṛttā ca na sāmānya samavāyayoḥ tathā iha buddhiḥ na sāmānya viśeṣeṣu iti vyāvṛtta tvāt vaidharmyam syāt iti anyatama grahaṇam tat ca sarveṣu samāna tvāt eva sādharmyam
translated: Similarly, those which have cognition as their characteristic, or which are characterized by cognition, their existence is being a characteristic of cognition. It is understood that by the word 'universal' also, either being a characteristic of cognition that is a cognition of an invariable concomitance or a cognition of an exclusion is intended. For an invariable cognition does not occur in a particular or inherence, and an exclusionary cognition does not occur in a universal or inherence. Similarly, an invariable cognition does not occur in universals or particulars. Because of being an exclusion, there would be a difference in properties, so the word 'either' is used. And that is the same in all, so it is a similarity.

original: yad vā buddhirviśeṣaṇāntaropacaritā lakṣaṇam itarasmād bhedakam / taccāvivakṣitaviśeṣaṃ sādharmyam / tathā hi / dravyaguṇakarmasvanugatasāmānyavaśādanugatajñānajanakatvam / sāmānye tu svarūpatayaiva tathātyantavyāvṛttyā viśeṣeṣveva / ayutasiddheṣvabādhyamānehabuddhiḥ samavāya eveti / vyāvṛttāvapi buddhivedyatvaṃ samānatvāt sādharmyam /
analyzed: yat vā buddhiḥ viśeṣaṇa antara upacaritā lakṣaṇam itarasmāt bhedakam tat ca avivakṣita viśeṣam sādharmyam tathā hi dravya guṇa karmasu anugata sāmānya vaśāt anugata jñāna janaka tvam sāmānye tu svarūpatayā eva tathā atyanta vyāvṛttyā viśeṣeṣu eva ayuta siddheṣu abādhyamāna iha buddhiḥ samavāyaḥ eva iti vyāvṛttau api buddhi vedya tvam samāna tvāt sādharmyam
translated: Or, the cognition with a qualifying factor is the definition, which distinguishes it from others. And that is similarity without a specified object. Thus, the capacity to produce a cognition that is common to substances, qualities and actions is due to a common universal. But in the universal itself, it is by its own nature. In the particularities, it is by absolute exclusion. The cognition of inherence in inseparable things is only inherence. Even in exclusion, the knowability by cognition is similarity due to sameness.

original: evaṃ kāryāṇāṃ bhāvaḥ kāryatvaṃ tadabhāvo 'kāryatvaṃ svakāraṇasattāsambandhābhāvaḥ /
analyzed: evam kāryāṇām bhāvaḥ kārya tvam tad abhāvaḥ kārya tvam sva kāraṇa sattā sambandha abhāvaḥ
translated: Thus, the existence of effects is effectuality, its non-existence is noneffectuality, the absence of the relation of the existence of its cause.

original: tathā kāraṇānāṃ bhāvaḥ kāraṇatvaṃ tadabhāvo 'kāraṇatvaṃ samavāyyasamavāyikāraṇatvābhāvaḥ / nimittakāraṇatvañca jñānotpattāviṣyata eva /
analyzed: tathā kāraṇānām bhāvaḥ kāraṇa tvam tad abhāvaḥ kāraṇa tvam samavāyi asamavāyi kāraṇa tva abhāvaḥ nimitta kāraṇa tvañca jñāna utpattau iṣyate eva
translated: Similarly, the existence of causes is causality, its non-existence is noncausality, the absence of the nature of an inherent or non-inherent cause. And the nature of an instrumental cause is accepted only in the production of knowledge.

original: tathā na sāmānyaviśeṣavattvamasāmānyaviśeṣavattvam aparasāmānyābhāvaḥ / na tadupalakṣitaḥ samavāyaḥ / samavāye tadabhāvaprasaṅgāt /
analyzed: tathā na sāmānya viśeṣavat tvam asāmānya viśeṣavat tvam apara sāmānya abhāvaḥ na tad upalakṣitaḥ samavāyaḥ samavāye tad abhāva prasaṅgāt
translated: Similarly, the absence of another universal in what possesses a universal and particular is the absence of another universal. Inherence, which is indicated by that, is not. Because in inherence, the absence of that would follow.

original: sakalāśrayavināśe 'pi sāmānyasamavāyayorna vināśaḥPDhS
analyzed: sakala āśraya vināśe pi sāmānya samavāyayoḥ na vināśaḥ
translated: Even when the substratum is destroyed, there is no destruction of the universal and inherence.

original: nityānāṃ bhāvo nityatvamavināśitvam / ubhayāntopalakṣitasattāsambandhābhāvo vā / tathā hi kāryavastuno vināśitvaṃ dṛṣṭam / sāmānyādeścākāryatvādavināśaḥ / na cāśrayavināśād vināśaḥ / tasyaikāśrayavināśe 'pyāśrayāntare svānuraktapratyayajanakatvāt / tathā hyekāśrayavināśe 'pyāśrayāntare sattā satsaditijñānahetuḥ / samavāyaścehapratyayaheturiti / anayorāśrayavināśānna vināśaḥ /
analyzed: nityānām bhāvaḥ nitya tvam avināśi tvam ubhaya anta upalakṣita sattā sambandha abhāvaḥ vā tathā hi kārya vastunaḥ vināśi tvam dṛṣṭam sāmānya ādeḥ ca akārya tvāt avināśaḥ na ca āśraya vināśāt vināśaḥ tasya eka āśraya vināśe pi āśraya antare sva anurakta pratyaya janaka tvāt tathā hi eka āśraya vināśe pi āśraya antare sattā sat sat iti jñāna hetuḥ samavāyaḥ ca iha pratyaya hetuḥ iti anayoḥ āśraya vināśāt na vināśaḥ
translated: The eternality of eternal things is their indestructibility, or the absence of the relation of existence delimited by both ends. Thus, the destructibility of an effect is seen, and the universal is not destroyed because it is not an effect. And it is not destroyed by the destruction of its substratum, because even when one substratum is destroyed, it produces effects connected with another substratum. For instance, even when one substratum is destroyed, the existence in another substratum is the cause of the cognition existent, existent, and inherence is the cause of the cognition here. The destruction of these two is not due to the destruction of their substratum.

original: anityāśrayaṃ sāmānyaṃ samastāśrayavināśena nirādhārasyābhāvād vinaṃkṣyatīti / naitadevam / akāryavastutvena avināśitvasiddheḥ samastāśrayavināśe 'pyavasthānamiṣyate / ata eva kevalamāśrayābhāvād gotvādirūpatayā na vyapadiśyata iti / akāryavastunaśca vināśe gaganādīnāmapyucchedaprasaṅgaḥ /
analyzed: anitya āśrayam sāmānyam samasta āśraya vināśena nirādhārasya abhāvāt vinaṃkṣyati iti  na etat evam akārya vastu tvena avināśi tva siddheḥ samasta āśraya vināśe pi avasthānam iṣyate atas eva kevalam āśraya abhāvāt go tva ādi rūpatayā na vyapadiśyate iti akārya vastunaḥ ca vināśe gagana ādīnām api uccheda prasaṅgaḥ
translated: The universal, which has a non-eternal substratum, will perish along with the destruction of all its substrata, being without a support. This is not so. Because its non-destruction is established by its being a non-effect, it is accepted to remain even with the destruction of all its substrata. For this very reason, it is not designated as having the form of a cow etc. due to the mere absence of a substratum. And if a non-effect is destroyed, there would be the undesirable consequence of the annihilation of space etc.

original: athānityāśrayasyāśrayotpattyanantaraṃ rūpādivadupalambhād asiddhamakāryatvamiti cet / na / upalambhasyobhayathābhāvāt /
analyzed: atha anitya āśrayasya āśraya utpatti anantaram rūpa ādi vat upalambhāt asiddham akārya tvam iti ced na upalambhasya ubhayathā bhāvāt
translated: If it is argued that the non-effect nature is not established because of the perception of the universal after the arising of its non-eternal substratum, like color etc., it is not so. Because perception can be of both kinds.

original: na jñāyate kiṃ vastūtpattyanantaramutpadyate / atha abhivyajyata iti / utpāde bādhakopapatterabhivyajyata itīṣyate / tathā hi / dravyasyaiva samavāyikāraṇatvavidhānena guṇakarmaṇostatpratiṣedhāt tadādhārasyotpattyabhāvaḥ / tadyathā sāmānyādhārasya yugapadutpattiṃ I / vinā samavāyikāraṇābhāvācceti / tathā hi / yatra samavetaṃ kāryaṃ tadavaśyaṃ samavāyikāraṇam / sāmānyasya kramabhāviṣu svādhāreṣu sarveṣu samavāyopalabdheḥ sarvaṃ samavāyikāraṇamiti / sakalādhāraniṣpattāvevotpattiriti pūrvabhāviṣūpalambho na syāt /
analyzed: na jñāyate kim vastu utpatti anantaram utpadyate atha abhivyajyate iti utpāde bādhaka upapatteḥ abhivyajyate iti iṣyate  / tathā hi dravyasya eva samavāyi kāraṇa tva vidhānena guṇa karmaṇoḥ tad pratiṣedhāt tad ādhārasya utpatti abhāvaḥ tat yathā sāmānya ādhārasya yugapad utpattim vinā samavāyi kāraṇa abhāvāt ca iti tathā hi yatra samavetam kāryam tat avaśyam samavāyi kāraṇam sāmānyasya krama bhāviṣu sva ādhāreṣu sarveṣu samavāya upalabdheḥ sarvam
translated: It is not known whether a thing arises immediately after origination or becomes manifest. Since an objection to origination is applicable, it is accepted that it becomes manifest. Thus, since the inherence cause is specified only for substance, quality and action are prohibited from that, there is no origination of its substratum. For example, the simultaneous origination of the substratum of the universal. And because there is no inherence cause without it. Thus, where the effect inheres, that is necessarily the inherence cause. Since the inherence of the universal is observed in all its sequential substrata, everything is the inherence cause. If origination occurs only when all the substrata are produced, then the prior observation would not occur.

original: atha sargādau bhūyasāṃ svādhārāṇāmutpādādutpannaṃ sāmānyaṃ kramabhāviṣvādhāreṣu samaveṣyatīti cet / na / kāryāntareṣvadarśanāt / na hi rūpādikāryaṃ svādhāreṣu samavetamupajātamanyena samavāyavṛttyā sambadhyamānaṃ dṛṣṭamiti / na ca krameṇotpadyamāneṣvanyat sāmānyamiti vācyam / bhede pramāṇābhāvāt / abhede tvanugataṃ jñānameva pramāṇamiti vakṣyāmaḥ sāmānyaparīkṣāyām /
analyzed: atha sarga ādau bhūyasām sva ādhārāṇām utpādāt utpannam sāmānyam krama bhāviṣu ādhāreṣu samaveṣyati iti ced na kārya antareṣu adarśanāt na hi rūpa ādi kāryam sva ādhāreṣu samavetam upajātam anyena samavāya vṛttyā sambadhyamānam dṛṣṭam iti na ca krameṇa utpadyamāneṣu anyat sāmānyam iti vācyam bhede pramāṇa abhāvāt abhede tu anugatam jñānam eva pramāṇam iti vakṣyāmaḥ sāmānya parīkṣāyām
translated: If it be said that when, at the beginning of creation, many substrata are produced, the universal, which has come into existence, inheres in the successive substrata, we reply: No; because we do not observe it in other effects. For we do not see that the effect, colour, etc., which has come into existence inhering in its own substratum, is connected by a different inherence with other substrata. And it cannot be said that there is another universal in the successively produced (effects); because there is no evidence of difference. And we shall show in the chapter on the universal that the cognition of identity is the only evidence of non-difference.

original: tadevam utpattipakṣe bādhakopapattervastūtpattyanantaraṃ samabhivyajyata ityakāryatvānnityatvaṃ siddham /
analyzed: tat evam utpatti pakṣe bādhaka upapatteḥ vastu utpatti anantaram samabhivyajyate iti akārya tvāt nitya tvam siddham
translated: Thus, since there is evidence of contradiction and of possibility in the case of the doctrine of production, it is established that the universal is eternal, because it is not an effect, since it is manifested simultaneously with the existence of the substance.

original: evamarthaśabdānabhidheyatvañca svasamayārthaśabdābhidheyatvābhāva iti / yadyapi dravyādereva kāryatvādividhānād ihākāryatvādirlabhyate tathāpi sādharmyasya vivakṣitatvādabhidhānamiti / sāmānyādīnāṃ kāryatvādyabhāvo 'pi sādharmyamiti /
analyzed: evam artha śabda anabhidheya tvam ca sva samaya artha śabda abhidheya tva abhāvaḥ iti yadi api dravya ādeḥ eva kārya tva ādi vidhānāt iha akārya tva ādiḥ labhyate tathā api sādharmyasya vivakṣita tvāt abhidhānam iti sāmānya ādīnām kārya tva ādi abhāvaḥ pi sādharmyam iti
translated: Thus, the meaning of not being denoted by words is the absence of being denoted by the words of one's own doctrine. Although non-action etc. is obtained here by the mere injunction of action etc. of substance etc., still the statement is made because similarity is intended. The absence of action etc. of universals etc. is also similarity.

original: navadravyasādharmyam
analyzed: nava dravya sādharmyam
translated: Similarity with the nine substances

original: pṛthivyādīnāṃ navānāmapi dravyatvayogaḥ / svātmanyārambhakatvam / guṇavattvam / kāryakāraṇāvirodhitvam /PDhS
analyzed: pṛthivī ādīnām navānām api dravya tva yogaḥ sva ātmani ārambhaka tvam guṇavat tvam kārya kāraṇa avirodhi tvam
translated: All nine substances, earth etc., have the property of being substances. Being the cause of their own selves. Having qualities. Being not opposed to cause and effect.

original: evaṃ padārthānāṃ sādharmyamabhidhāya dravyāṇāṃ sādharmyanirūpaṇārthamāha pṛthivyādīnām ityādi / pṛthivī ādiryeṣāṃ tāni pṛthivyādīni teṣām / na jñāyate kiyatāmataḥ navānāmapi dravyatvayogaḥ sādharmyam / dravyatvena yogo dravyatvopalakṣitaḥ samavāya iti / yadyapi samavāyaḥ pañcapadārthavṛttistathāpi dravyatvenopalakṣito 'sādhāraṇatvād bhavatyeva lakṣaṇamiti /🔽na ca dravyāṇāṃ bhāvo dravyatvamityukte 'rthādavagamyate yoga iti vācyam / gamyavṛttyāśrayaṇena śabdavṛttipratiṣedhe 'tiprasaṅgāt /
analyzed: evam padārthānām sādharmyam abhidhāya dravyāṇām sādharmya nirūpaṇa artham āha pṛthivī ādīnām ityādi pṛthivī ādiḥ yeṣām tāni pṛthivī ādīni teṣām na jñāyate kiyatām atas navānām api dravya tva yogaḥ sādharmyam dravya tvena yogaḥ dravya tva upalakṣitaḥ samavāyaḥ iti yadi api samavāyaḥ pañca padārtha vṛttiḥ tathā api dravya tvena upalakṣitaḥ sādhāraṇa tvāt bhavati eva lakṣaṇam iti  na ca dravyāṇām bhāvaḥ dravya tvam iti ukte rthāt avagamyate yogaḥ iti vācyam gamya vṛtti āśrayaṇena śabda vṛtti pratiṣedhe tiprasaṅgāt
translated: Having thus stated the similarity of the categories, he says of earth etc. in order to determine the similarity of the substances. Those which have earth as their beginning are the earth etc. It is not known by how much, therefore, the connection with substance is the similarity of all nine. The connection by substance is characterized by substance. Although inherence occurs in the five categories, still it is characterized by substance and is indeed the definition due to its non-commonness.🔽And it should not be said that when it is stated that the existence of substances is substance-ness, the connection is understood by implication, because of the over-extension in the prohibition of verbal usage by resorting to the usage of the understood.

original: na copacaritabhedatvādavāstavaṃ lakṣaṇamiti dūṣaṇam / śrotrasyeva viśiṣṭārthakriyājanakatvāt /
analyzed: na ca upacarita bheda tvāt avāstavam lakṣaṇam iti dūṣaṇam śrotrasya iva viśiṣṭa artha kriyā janaka tvāt
translated: And the objection that the definition is unreal due to the figurative difference is not valid, because it produces a particular effective action, like the ear.

original: nāpi asamarthaviśeṣaṇatā / yogapadaṃ vinā hi asambhavitvāśaṅkānativṛtteriti / śeṣaṃ lakṣaṇadūṣaṇasya pratisamādhānaṃ vakṣyāmaḥ pṛthivyadhikāre /
analyzed: nā api asamartha viśeṣaṇa tā yoga padam vinā hi asambhavi tva āśaṅkā anativṛtteḥ iti śeṣam lakṣaṇa dūṣaṇasya pratisamādhānam vakṣyāmaḥ pṛthivī adhikāre
translated: Nor is there a case of the qualification being incapable of being related, because even without the word 'together', the doubt of impossibility does not arise. We will state the remaining refutation of the definition in the section on earth.

original: lakṣaṇañca bhedārthaṃ vyavahārārthañceti / tathā hi / pṛthivyādīnītarasmād bhidyante / dravyāṇīti vā vyavahartavyāni dravyatvayogāt / ye tu na bhidyante nāpi dravyāṇīti vyavahriyante na te dravyatvayuktā yathā rūpādayaḥ / na ca tathā na dravyatvayuktāni pṛthivyādīnīti / tasmāditarasmād bhidyante dravyāṇīti vā vyavahartavyānīti /
analyzed: lakṣaṇam ca bheda artham vyavahāra artham ca iti tathā hi pṛthivī ādīni itarasmāt bhidyante dravyāṇi iti vā vyavahartavyāni dravya tva yogāt ye tu na bhidyante na api dravyāṇi iti vyavahriyante na te dravya tva yuktāḥ yathā rūpa ādayaḥ na ca tathā na dravya tva yuktāni pṛthivī ādīni iti tasmāt itarasmāt bhidyante dravyāṇi iti vā vyavahartavyāni iti
translated: And the definition is for the purpose of distinguishing and for the purpose of usage. Thus, earth and the others are distinguished from the others, or they should be used as substances, because they are connected with substantiality. But those which are not distinguished and are not used as substances are not connected with substantiality, like form and so on. And earth and the others are not like that, nor are they not connected with substantiality. Therefore, they are distinguished from the others, or they should be used as substances.

original: evaṃ dravyaśabdasya pravṛttau pṛthivyādīnāṃ navānāmapi dravyatvayogo nimittamiti śabdārthanirūpaṇaparatvenāpi sambadhyate vākyam / tathā ca na sāmānyavataḥ śabdārthatve kiñcid bādhakamastīti vakṣyāmaḥ /
analyzed: evam dravya śabdasya pravṛttau pṛthivī ādīnām navānām api dravya tva yogaḥ nimittam iti śabda artha nirūpaṇa para tvena api sambadhyate vākyam tathā ca na sāmānyavataḥ śabda artha tve kiñcid bādhakam asti iti vakṣyāmaḥ
translated: Thus, in the application of the word 'substance', the connection with substantiality of all nine, earth and so on, is the reason. Thus, the sentence is also connected as having the purpose of determining the meaning of the word. And we will say that there is no contradiction at all in the meaning of a word being a universal, when the meaning of a word is a universal.

original: tathā atīndriyaśaktipratiṣedhārthañca / tattu pṛthivyādīnāṃ navānāmapi dravyatvayogo nijā śaktiriti /
analyzed: tathā atīndriya śakti pratiṣedha artham ca tat tu pṛthivī ādīnām navānām api dravya tva yogaḥ nijā śaktiḥ iti
translated: And for the purpose of refuting the existence of imperceptible powers. And that is the inherent power of the nine substances beginning with earth, which is their possession of the quality of substance.

original: dravyatvasya sāmānyatvavicāraḥ
translated: Discussion on the universality of substance

original: atha akṛtasamayasya gopiṇḍeṣvivānugatākārajñānasyānupapatterna dravyatvaṃ sāmānyamastīti / yathā hi nārikeladvīpavāsino gopiṇḍopalambhādekākāratā pratibhāsate naivaṃ pṛthivyādiṣūpalabhyamāneṣviti / athāsti kṛtasamayasya dravyaṃ dravyamiti jñānam / tacca saṅketavaśādeva bhaviṣyatīti /
analyzed: atha akṛta samayasya go piṇḍeṣu iva anugata ākāra jñānasya anupapatteḥ na dravya tvam sāmānyam asti iti yathā hi nārikela dvīpa vāsinaḥ go piṇḍa upalambhāt eka ākāra tā pratibhāsate na evam pṛthivī ādiṣu upalabhyamāneṣu iti  atha asti kṛta samayasya dravyam dravyam iti jñānam tat ca saṅketa vaśāt eva bhaviṣyati iti
translated: Now, since the knowledge of a universal form is not possible for one who has not made a convention, as in the case of individual cows, substance cannot be a universal. Just as the inhabitants of the coconut islands perceive individual cows and have the idea of a single form, but this is not so in the case of earth etc. which are perceived. If it is argued that the knowledge of substance as substance exists for one who has made a convention, and that would be due to convention alone,

original: tadasat / sāmānyasya niyatavyañjakavyaṅgyatayā vyañjakānupalabdhāvapyanupalabdherabhāvāt / tathā hi / dravyatvaṃ kriyāvattvādidharmopalambhādabhivyajyate / atiśayadravyāśritatvopalabdherguṇatvamevaṃ karmalakṣaṇopalabdheḥ karmatvamiti / śeṣeṣvapi cintyam / vyañjakamapyūhyam /
analyzed: tat asat sāmānyasya niyata vyañjaka vyaṅgya tayā vyañjaka anupalabdhau api anupalabdheḥ abhāvāt tathā hi dravya tvam kriyāvat tva ādi dharma upalambhāt abhivyajyate atiśaya dravya āśrita tva upalabdheḥ guṇa tvam evam karma lakṣaṇa upalabdheḥ karma tvam iti śeṣeṣu api cintyam vyañjakam api ūhyam
translated: that is not so. Because even in the absence of the perception of the manifestor, there is no absence of perception of the universal, due to the manifestor being manifested by a particular manifestor. Thus, substance is manifested by the perception of qualities such as having action. Quality is manifested by the perception of being dependent on a substance with excess. Action is manifested by the perception of the characteristics of action. This should be thought about in the case of the remaining [categories] also. The manifestor should be inferred.

original: na ca sarveṣāṃ vyañjakopalabdhirvidyata iti sāmānyānupalambho vighātaka eva / kṛtasamayasya vyañjakopalabdherbhavatyeva dravyādiṣvanugatajñānam / sāsnādinā vā kṛtasamayenāpi saṃvedyata iti yuktaṃ gavādiṣvanugatākāravijñānamiti /
analyzed: na ca sarveṣām vyañjaka upalabdhiḥ vidyate iti sāmānya anupalambhaḥ vighātakaḥ eva kṛta samayasya vyañjaka upalabdheḥ bhavati eva dravya ādiṣu anugata jñānam sāsnādinā vā kṛta samayena api saṃvedyate iti yuktam gavādiṣu anugata ākāra vijñānam iti
translated: And since the manifester is not perceived in all cases, the non-perception of the universal is indeed a hindrance. For one who has made a convention, the knowledge of the universal in substances etc. does indeed arise from the perception of the manifester. Or it is proper that the knowledge of the universal form in cows etc. arises from what is perceived by one who has made a convention with dewlap etc.

original: yatra ca dravyaguṇakarmātmakaṃ nimittaṃ na sambhāvyate 'bādhitānugatāyāṃ saṃvidi tatra sāmānyameva nimittam / na ca dravyādiṣvanugatasaṃvedane 'bhāva iva kiñcid bādhakamastīti / tathā hi / abhāvo 'bhāva ityanugatasaṃvedanaṃ dravyaguṇakarmānimittamapi na sāmānyād I / bhavati sāmānyasyābhāvena samavāyābhāvāt / samavetañca sāmānyaṃ viśeṣamupalabdham /
analyzed: yatra ca dravya guṇa karma ātmakam nimittam na sambhāvyate bādhita anugatāyām saṃvidi tatra sāmānyam eva nimittam na ca dravya ādiṣu anugata saṃvedane bhāvaḥ iva kiñcid bādhakam asti iti tathā hi abhāvaḥ bhāvaḥ iti anugata saṃvedanam dravya guṇa karma a nimittam api na sāmānyāt bhavati sāmānyasya abhāvena samavāya abhāvāt samavetam ca sāmānyam viśeṣam upalabdham
translated: And where the cause consisting of substance, quality and action is not possible, in the unobstructed and continuous cognition, the cause is only the universal. And there is no hindrance in the continuous perception of substances etc., as in the case of non-existence. Thus, the continuous cognition of non-existence as 'non-existence' is not due to the universal, even though it has no cause in substance, quality or action. It is not due to the universal's non-inherence in non-existence. And the inhering universal is perceived as qualified.

original: athedamevābhāvatvānuraktamabhāvo 'bhāva iti jñānamabhāvatvasyābhāvena samavāyaṃ darśayatīti cet / na / anekāntāt / tathā hi / sāmānyādau satsaditi jñānaṃ vinā sattāsamavāyamityuktapūrvam / sāmānyavattve cābhāvasya bhāvarūpataiva syāt / evañca anutpatteranāditvānnityatvaṃ vināśasya ca ādimatvādanityatvaṃ prasajyeta / prāgabhāvasya ca nityatvena vastūpalambho na syāt / tayoḥ svarūpaparihārasthitivirodhāt /
analyzed: atha idam eva abhāva tva anuraktam abhāvaḥ bhāvaḥ iti jñānam abhāva tvasya abhāvena samavāyam darśayati iti ced na anekāntāt tathā hi sāmānya ādau sat sat iti jñānam vinā sattā samavāyam iti ukta pūrvam sāmānyavat tve ca abhāvasya bhāva rūpatā eva syāt evañca anutpatteḥ anādi tvāt nitya tvam vināśasya ca ādima tvāt anitya tvam prasajyeta prāgabhāvasya ca nitya tvena vastu upalambhaḥ na syāt tayoḥ svarūpa parihāra sthiti virodhāt
translated: If it be said that the cognition of the absence of the absence of absence is what shows the inherence of absence in absence, we say no, because of the inconclusive character of the reason. For instance, it has been said before that the cognition of the universal as existent is the inherence of existence in the universal. And if absence has the universal, it must be of the nature of existence. And thus, because of the non-origination, there would be eternality, and because of the beginninglessness, there would be non-eternality of destruction. And because of the eternality of the prior absence, there would be no apprehension of the existent, because of the contradiction of the existence of the two in the form of the exclusion of their own forms.

original: na ca abhāvopamardātmano bhāvasyotpattiryukteti prāgiti viśeṣaṇāsambhavaḥ / pradhvaṃsānutpattiśca / tasya hi utpattimadapekṣitatvāt / sambhave 'pi utpattimattvena vināśasya vināśe bhāvagrahaṇaṃ syāt / yathā hi vināśānutpatteḥ pūrvaṃ bhāvo gṛhyate tadvad vināśāpāye 'pi gṛhyeta / virodhābhāvasyāviśeṣāt / na caitad dṛṣṭamataḥ sāmānyavad vyatirekaḥ /
analyzed: na ca abhāva upamarda ātmanaḥ bhāvasya utpattiḥ yuktā iti prāk iti viśeṣaṇa asambhavaḥ pradhvaṃsa anutpattiḥ ca tasya hi utpattimat apekṣita tvāt sambhave pi utpattimat tvena vināśasya vināśe bhāva grahaṇam syāt yathā hi vināśa anutpatteḥ pūrvam bhāvaḥ gṛhyate tadvat vināśa apāye pi gṛhyeta virodha abhāvasya aviśeṣāt na ca etat dṛṣṭam atas sāmānya vat vyatirekaḥ
translated: And it is not proper for an existent to arise from the destruction of a non-existent. Thus the impossibility of the qualification before and the non-arising of destruction. For that [destruction] requires what has arising. Even if possible, due to having arising, the apprehension of existence would be in the destruction. For just as existence is apprehended before the non-arising of destruction, so it would be apprehended even after the removal of destruction, because there is no difference in the absence of contradiction. And this is not seen. Therefore, like the universal, there is exclusion.

original: na copādhiṃ vinā abhāvo 'bhāva iti jñānaṃ śakyaṃ bhavitum / kintarhi / ghaṭābhāvaḥ paṭābhāva iti jñānotpattervailakṣaṇyameva / athāsti ghaṭābhāvo ghaṭābhāva ityanugatajñānamiti cedatrāpyupādhivaśādupalakṣaṇatvam / sāmānyameva jñānaheturiti draṣṭavyam mukhyaṃ bādhakopatteḥ / na caivaṃ dravyaṃ dravyamiti jñāne kiñcid bādhakamastīti sāmānyasiddhernāsambhavīdaṃ lakṣaṇamiti /
analyzed: na ca upādhim vinā abhāvaḥ bhāvaḥ iti jñānam śakyam bhavitum kin tarhi ghaṭa abhāvaḥ paṭa abhāvaḥ iti jñāna utpatteḥ vailakṣaṇyam eva  atha asti ghaṭa abhāvaḥ ghaṭa abhāvaḥ iti anugata jñānam iti ced atra api upādhi vaśāt upalakṣaṇa tvam sāmānyam eva jñāna hetuḥ iti draṣṭavyam mukhyam bādhaka upatteḥ na ca evam dravyam dravyam iti jñāne kiñcid bādhakam asti iti sāmānya siddheḥ na asambhavi idam lakṣaṇam iti
translated: And without a common property, the knowledge that absence is absence cannot occur. Rather, the knowledge that arises is of a different kind, as in the absence of pot and the absence of cloth. If it is argued that there is a general knowledge of absence as the absence of pot is absence, then even here the common property is due to the common property, and it should be seen that the common property itself is the cause of knowledge, because there is no contradiction in the primary sense. And in the knowledge that substance is substance, there is no contradiction, so the definition is not impossible due to the establishment of the common property.

original: evaṃ svaścāsāvātmā ceti svātmā / tasminnārambhakatvam / svātmasamavetakāryajanakatvam samavāyikāraṇatvamiti yāvat / tacca pṛthivyādiṣveva bhāvāditarasmād bhedakam / tathā hi / kāryasamavāyo narte pṛthivyādibhyaḥ sambhavatīti /
analyzed: evam svaḥ ca asau ātmā ca iti sva ātmā tasmin ārambhaka tvam sva ātma samaveta kārya janaka tvam samavāyi kāraṇa tvam iti yāvat tat ca pṛthivī ādiṣu eva bhāvāt itarasmāt bhedakam tathā hi kārya samavāyaḥ na ṛte pṛthivī ādibhyaḥ sambhavati iti
translated: Thus, that which is its own self is the self. The cause of that is the cause of the effect inhering in itself, which is to say, the cause inhering in itself. And that is the distinguishing feature from the other, because it exists only in earth and so on. For thus, the inherence of the effect is not possible except from earth and so on.

original: tathā guṇā vidyante yeṣāṃ te guṇavantasteṣāṃ bhāvo guṇavattvaṃ guṇopalakṣitaḥ samavāyaḥ / samavetā vā guṇāḥ / te 'pyasādhāraṇatvād bhedakāḥ / yathā na guṇādiṣu guṇavattvaṃ tathā vakṣyāmo guṇasaṅkareāvasare /
analyzed: tathā guṇāḥ vidyante yeṣām te guṇavantaḥ teṣām bhāvaḥ guṇavat tvam guṇa upalakṣitaḥ samavāyaḥ samavetāḥ vā guṇāḥ te pi asādhāraṇa tvāt bhedakāḥ yathā na guṇa ādiṣu guṇavat tvam tathā vakṣyāmaḥ
translated: Similarly, those in whom qualities exist are endowed with qualities. Their state is the quality of being endowed with qualities, which is inherence characterized by qualities. Or qualities are also the causes of distinction because they are uncommon. We will explain how the quality of being endowed with qualities does not exist in qualities and so on in the section on the confusion of qualities.

original: tathā kāryakāraṇayoravirodhaḥ kāryakāraṇāvirodhaḥ / sa vidyate yeṣāṃ te kāryakāraṇāvirodhinaḥ / teṣāṃ bhāvo kāryakāraṇāvirodhitvam / kāryakāraṇayoḥ parasparāvirodhitvameka eva dharmaḥ /
analyzed: tathā kārya kāraṇayoḥ avirodhaḥ kārya kāraṇa avirodhaḥ sa vidyate yeṣām te kārya kāraṇa avirodhinaḥ teṣām kārya kāraṇa avirodhi tvam kārya kāraṇayoḥ paraspara avirodhi tvam ekaḥ eva dharmaḥ
translated: Similarly, the non-contradiction of cause and effect is the non-contradiction of cause and effect. Those in whom it exists are non-contradictory with cause and effect. Their state is the quality of being non-contradictory with cause and effect. The single property of cause and effect is the non-contradiction of each other.

original: yadi vā dharmadvayaṃ kāryāvirodhitvaṃ kāraṇāvirodhitvañceti tadā kāryeṇa na virudhyante na vināśyante iti kāryāvirodhinasteṣāṃ bhāvaḥ kāryāvirodhitvaṃ kāryeṇa vināśābhāvaḥ / sa ca sarveṣu pṛthivyādiṣvastīti sādharmyam na punarlakṣaṇaṃ vipakṣaikadeśe 'pi I / bhāvāt / tathā hi kāryeṇa virudhyante śabdabuddhyādayo na sarve guṇāḥ / tathā karmāṇy api kāryeṇa virudhyante / na kāryeṇaiva āśrayavināśe 'pi vināśāt /
analyzed: yadi vā dharma dvayam kārya avirodhi tvam kāraṇa avirodhi tvam ca iti tadā kāryeṇa na virudhyante na vināśyante iti kārya avirodhinaḥ teṣām bhāvaḥ kārya avirodhi tvam kāryeṇa vināśa abhāvaḥ sa ca sarveṣu pṛthivī ādiṣu asti iti sādharmyam na punar lakṣaṇam vipakṣa eka deśe bhāvāt tathā hi kāryeṇa virudhyante śabda buddhi ādayaḥ na sarve guṇāḥ tathā karmāṇi api kāryeṇa virudhyante na kāryeṇa eva āśraya vināśe vināśāt
translated: If the two properties are non-contradiction with effect and non-contradiction with cause, then they are not contradicted by the effect, i.e., they are not destroyed, so their existence as non-contradictory with the effect is non-contradiction with the effect, i.e., non-destruction by the effect. And that exists in all earth, etc., so there is similarity. But the definition does not exist even in part of the dissimilar class, because it exists. For example, sound, cognition, etc. are contradicted by the effect, not all qualities. Similarly, actions are also contradicted by the effect. Not only by the effect, because they are destroyed even when the substratum is destroyed.

original: na ca padārthāpekṣayāpi lakṣaṇavivakṣāyāṃ vipakṣaikadeśe vartamānasya gamakatvam / tathā kāraṇāvirodhitvaṃ yadi kāraṇena na virudhyante iti kāraṇāvirodhinasteṣāṃ bhāvaḥ kāraṇāvirodhitvam / kāraṇena vināśābhāvaḥ / sa ca ākāśādiṣvasti kāraṇābhāvāditi pakṣe vyāpakasyāpi sato na vipakṣād vyāvṛttirityalakṣaṇatvam / tathā hi / na kāraṇena guṇā vināśyante nāpi karmeti /
analyzed: na ca padārtha apekṣayā api lakṣaṇa vivakṣāyām vipakṣa eka deśe vartamānasya gamaka tvam tathā kāraṇa avirodhi tvam yadi kāraṇena na virudhyante iti kāraṇa avirodhinaḥ teṣām bhāvaḥ kāraṇa avirodhi tvam kāraṇena vināśa abhāvaḥ sa ca ākāśa ādiṣu asti kāraṇa abhāvāt iti pakṣe vyāpakasya api sataḥ na vipakṣāt vyāvṛttiḥ iti alakṣaṇa tvam tathā hi na kāraṇena guṇāḥ vināśyante na api karma iti prati kāraṇa apekṣayā api karma
translated: Nor is there any indication of the definition even in relation to the meaning of the words, when it occurs in part of the dissimilar instance. Thus, if 'not being opposed to the cause' means 'not being opposed by the cause', then the existence of those that are not opposed by the cause is 'not being opposed to the cause'. The absence of destruction by the cause. And that exists in space etc., because there is no cause. Thus, even though it is all-pervading in the hypothesis, there is no exclusion from the dissimilar instance. Therefore, it is not a definition. For thus, the qualities are not destroyed by the cause, nor is the action.

original: atha kāraṇaṃ na virundhanti na vināśayantīti kāraṇāvirodhinasteṣāṃ bhāvaḥ kāraṇāvirodhitvaṃ kāraṇāvināśakatvaṃ kāryadharma iti / atra nityadravyeṣu kāraṇābhāvāt kāraṇāvirodhitvaṃ kāraṇāvināśakatvaṃ cintanīyamiti / vipakṣaikadeśe vartamānasyāgamakatvameva / tathā hi / śabdabuddhyāderyadyapi kāraṇavināśakatvaṃ tathāpi na rūpādīnāmastītyativyāptiḥ / evaṃ karmāpi na kāraṇaṃ vināśayatīti /
analyzed: atha kāraṇam na virundhanti na vināśayanti iti kāraṇa avirodhinaḥ teṣām bhāvaḥ kāraṇa avirodhi tvam kāraṇa avināśaka tvam kārya dharmaḥ iti atra nitya dravyeṣu kāraṇa abhāvāt kāraṇa avirodhi tvam kāraṇa avināśaka tvam cintanīyam iti vipakṣa eka deśe vartamānasya āgamaka tvam eva tathā hi śabda buddhi ādeḥ yadi api kāraṇa vināśaka tvam tathā api na rūpa ādīnām asti iti ativyāptiḥ evam karma api na kāraṇam vināśayati iti kāraṇa avinā
translated: Now, if they do not contradict the cause, do not destroy it, then their existence as non-contradictory with the cause, non-destroying of the cause, is the property of the effect. Here, in eternal substances, due to the absence of a cause, non-contradiction with the cause and non-destroying of the cause should be considered. Being present in only a part of the contrary is itself inconclusive. Thus, although sound, cognition, etc. do destroy the cause, still form, etc. do not have it, so there is over-extension. Similarly, action also does not destroy the cause.

original: na ca kāryāvirodhitvenāviśeṣastatra hi kāryeṇāvināśatvaṃ kāraṇadharmaḥ / kāraṇāvirodhitvaṃ kāraṇāvināśakatvaṃ kāryadharma ityapunaruktam / tadevamubhayathāpi vipakṣaikadeśāvyāvṛttaḥ sādharmyameva na tallakṣaṇamiti siddham /
analyzed: na ca kārya avirodhi tvena aviśeṣaḥ tatra hi kāryeṇa avināśa tvam kāraṇa dharmaḥ kāraṇa avirodhi tvam kāraṇa avināśaka tvam kārya dharmaḥ iti apunaruktam tat evam ubhayathā api vipakṣa eka deśa avyāvṛttaḥ sādharmyam eva na tat lakṣaṇam iti siddham
translated: And it is not redundant to say that non-contradiction with the effect is not a property of the cause, for there non-destroying by the effect is a property of the cause, and non-contradiction with the cause, non-destroying of the cause, is a property of the effect. Thus, in both ways, the property of the similar instance is not the definition, as it does not exclude a part of the contrary.

original: antyaviśeṣavattvam anāśritatvanityatve ca anyatrāvayavidravyebhyaḥ /PDhS
analyzed: antya viśeṣavat tvam anāśrita tva nitya tve ca anyatra avayavi dravyebhyaḥ
translated: Having the last specific property, non-dependence, and eternality are in other than composite substances.

original: evamantyā viśeṣā vidyante yeṣāṃ te tadvantaḥ / teṣāṃ bhāvo 'ntyaviśeṣavattvam / antyaviśeṣopalakṣitaḥ samavāyaḥ / samavetā vā antyaviśeṣāḥ /
analyzed: evam antyāḥ viśeṣāḥ vidyante yeṣām te tadvantaḥ teṣām bhāvaḥ ntya viśeṣavat tvam antya viśeṣa upalakṣitaḥ samavāyaḥ samavetāḥ vā antya viśeṣāḥ
translated: Thus, those that have the last particularities are said to have them. Their state is having the last particularities. Inherence is characterized by the last particularities. Or the last particularities are inherent.

original: tathā anāśritatvañca nityatvañcetyanāśritatvanityatve / anāśritatvamāśritatvābhāvaḥ / nityatvamavināśitvam / ubhayāntānupalakṣitā vastusattā vā /
analyzed: tathā anāśrita tvam ca nitya tvam ca iti anāśrita tva nitya tve anāśrita tvam āśrita tva abhāvaḥ nitya tvam avināśi tvam ubhaya anta anupalakṣitā vastu sattā vā
translated: Similarly, non-dependence and eternality are non-dependence and eternality. Non-dependence is the absence of dependence. Eternality is indestructibility. Or the existence of a thing is characterized by both ends.

original: kimetaddharmatrayaṃ sarveṣu pṛthivyādiṣvasti vyāpakañcetyāha anyatrāvayavidravyebhyaḥ / iti / avayavidravyāṇi varjayitvā nityadravyeṣveveti /
analyzed: kim etat dharma trayam sarveṣu pṛthivī ādiṣu asti vyāpakam ca iti āha anyatra avayavi dravyebhyaḥ iti avayavi dravyāṇi varjayitvā nitya dravyeṣu eva iti
translated: Does this triad of properties exist in all earth etc. and is it pervasive? He says: Except for composite substances. Except for composite substances, it exists only in eternal substances.

original: nanu dharmatrayasya sāpavādatvāviśeṣe 'pyantyaviśeṣavattvenāsamāsakaraṇe kiṃ prayojanamiti / antyaviśeṣāṇāmavyāpakatve 'sādhāraṇatājñānenaiva / anāśritatvaniyatvayoścānyatrāpi sadbhāvāt sādhāraṇatvenāsamāsakaraṇam / tathā hi / nityatvaṃ guṇādiṣvapyaI /stīti sādhāraṇam / anāśritatvaṃ samavāyasyāpi mukhyavṛttau bādhakopapattergauṇavṛttyāśrayaṇena sambhāvyate / na paramārthata iti sādhāraṇam /
analyzed: nanu dharma trayasya sāpavāda tva aviśeṣe pi antya viśeṣa vat tvena asamāsa karaṇe kim prayojanam iti antya viśeṣāṇām avyāpaka tve sādhāraṇa tā jñānena eva anāśrita tva niya tvayoḥ ca anyatra api sadbhāvāt sādhāraṇa tvena asamāsa karaṇam tathā hi nitya tvam sādhāraṇam anāśrita tvam samavāyasya api mukhya vṛttau bādhaka upapatteḥ gauṇa vṛtti āśrayaṇena sambhāvyate na paramārthataḥ iti sādhāraṇam
translated: But even if there is no difference in the exceptionability of the three properties, what is the purpose of not compounding them due to their having a final distinction? Even by knowing the unsharedness of the final distinctions due to their non-pervasiveness, and because of the existence elsewhere of non-dependence and necessity, the non-compounding due to sharedness. Thus, eternality exists in qualities etc. also, so it is shared. Non-dependence is possible for inherence also by resorting to secondary usage due to the possibility of contradiction in primary usage, so it is shared.

original: dravyaṣaṭkasādharmyam
translated: Similarity to the six categories

original: pṛthivyudakajvalanapavanātmamanasāmanekatvāparajātimattve /PDhS
analyzed: pṛthivī udaka jvalana pavana ātma manasām aneka tva apara jātimat tve
translated: Earth, water, fire, air, self, and mind have multiplicity and the property of being of different species.

original: evaṃ pṛthivyādīnāṃ navānāṃ padārthāntarād vyāvṛtaṃ sādharmyamabhidhāya punasteṣāṃ svabhedād vyāvṛttaṃ sādharmyaṃ darśayati pṛthivyudakajvalanapavanātmamanasām iti / cārthe dvandvaḥ samāsaḥ / anekatvañcāparajātimattvañcetyanekatvāparajātimattve /
analyzed: evam pṛthivī ādīnām navānām padārtha antarāt vyāvṛtam sādharmyam abhidhāya punar teṣām svabhedāt vyāvṛttam sādharmyam darśayati pṛthivī udaka jvalana pavana ātma manasām iti ca arthe dvandvaḥ samāsaḥ aneka tvam ca apara jātimat tvam ca iti aneka tva apara jātimat tve
translated: Having thus stated the similarity of the nine categories beginning with earth to other things, he now shows their similarity to their own subclasses. The compound earth, water, fire, air, self, and mind is a dvandva compound in the sense of and. Many and not having another genus means having many and not having another genus.

original: anekatvañca kṣityāderviśeṣalakṣaṇayogino vyaktibhedaḥ / anekatvasaṃkhyā vā / nākāśādervyaktibhedo nānekatvasaṃkhyā vā sambhavatīti tasmād vyāvṛttiriti /
analyzed: aneka tvam ca kṣiti ādeḥ viśeṣa lakṣaṇa yoginaḥ vyakti bhedaḥ aneka tva saṃkhyā vā na ākāśa ādeḥ vyakti bhedaḥ na aneka tva saṃkhyā vā sambhavati iti tasmāt vyāvṛttiḥ iti
translated: Many refers to the individual differences of earth and so on, which possess specific characteristics, or to the number many. Space and so on do not have individual differences or the number many, therefore they are excluded.

original: anekatvādevāparajātimattvam / aparajātirdravyatvāpekṣayā pṛthivītvādirūpā / sā vidyate yeṣāṃ tāni tadvanti / teṣāṃ bhāvo 'parajātimattvam / aparajātyupalakṣitaḥ samavāyaḥ / samavetā vā aparajātiriti /🔽dravyapañcakasādharmyam🔽kṣitijalajyotiranilamanasāṃ kriyāvattvamūrtatvaparatvāparatvavegavattvāni /PDhS
analyzed: aneka tvāt eva apara jātimat tvam apara jātiḥ dravya tva apekṣayā pṛthivī tva ādi rūpā sā vidyate yeṣām tāni tadvanti teṣām bhāvaḥ para jātimat tvam apara jāti upalakṣitaḥ samavāyaḥ samavetā vā apara jātiḥ iti 🔽          🔽kṣiti jala jyotiḥ anila manasām kriyāvat tva mūrta tva para tva apara tva vegavat tvāni
translated: Not having another genus is due to being many. Another genus is in the form of earthness, etc. in relation to substantiality. Those that have it are said to possess it. The state of that is not having another genus. Another genus is inherence characterized by another genus, or another genus inheres in it.

original: evaṃ kṣitijalajyotiranilamanasām sādharmyaṃ kriyāvattvañca mūrtatvañca paratvañcāparatvañca vegavattvañceti tathoktāni / tathā ca kriyā calanarūpā / sā vidyate yeṣāṃ tāni tadvanti / teṣāṃ bhāvaḥ kriyāvattvam / samavetā kriyā / tatsamavāyo vā / tathā mūrtiravyāpi dravyaparimāṇam / sā vidyate yeṣāṃ tāni mūrtāni / teṣāṃ bhāvo mūrtatvam / samavetā mūrtistatsamavāyo vā / mūrtatvādeva ca paratvāparatvādisadbhāvaḥ kriyāvattvañceti / parāparāṇāṃ bhāvaḥ paratvāparatve yatsadbhāve kṣityādiṣu parāparavyavahāra iti / samavetau paratvāparatvaguṇau / tatsamavāyo vā / vego vidyate yeṣāṃ tāni vegavanti / teṣāṃ bhāvo vegavattvam / samaveto vegaguṇastatsamavāyo vā / etāni ca kṣityādiṣveveti niyamyante / na tu sarvadā teṣu bhavantīti /
analyzed: evam kṣiti jala jyotiḥ anila manasām sādharmyam kriyāvat tvañca mūrta tvañca para tvañca apara tvañca vegavat tvañca iti tathā uktāni tathā ca kriyā calana rūpā sā vidyate yeṣām tāni tadvanti teṣām bhāvaḥ kriyāvat tvam samavetā kriyā tad samavāyaḥ vā tathā mūrtiḥ avyāpi dravya parimāṇam sā vidyate yeṣām tāni mūrtāni teṣām bhāvaḥ mūrta tvam samavetā mūrtiḥ tad samavāyaḥ vā mūrta tvāt eva ca paratva apara tva ādi sadbhāvaḥ kriyāvat tva
translated: Thus, the earth, water, fire, air, and mind are said to have the following common properties: action, having form, having priority, having posteriority, and having velocity. And action is of the nature of motion. Those that have it are said to possess it. The state of having that is having action. Action inheres in them or is their inherence. Similarly, form is the non-pervading magnitude of a substance. Those that have it are said to have form. The state of having that is having form. And it is because of having form that priority, posteriority, etc. exist, as well as having action. The state of being prior and posterior is priority and posteriority. When they exist in earth, etc., there is the usage of prior and posterior. Priority and posteriority are inherent qualities or their inherence. Those that have velocity are said to have velocity. The state of having that is having velocity. Velocity is an inherent quality or its inherence. And these are restricted to only earth, etc. It is not so.

original: dravyacatuṣṭayasādharmyam
analyzed: dravya catuṣṭaya sādharmyam
translated: The similarity of the four substances

original: ākāśakāladigātmanāṃ sarvagatatvaṃ paramamahattvaṃ sarvasaṃyogisamānadeśatvañca /PDhS
analyzed: ākāśa kāla diś ātmanām sarva gata tvam parama mahā tvam sarva saṃyogi samāna deśa tvam ca
translated: Space, time, direction and self are all-pervading, supremely great, and have the same location as everything they are in contact with.

original: evam ākāśakāladigātmanām sarvagatatvādi sādharmyam / sarvaśabdaścānantaroktamūrteṣveva vartate / sarveṣu gatāḥ sarvagatāḥ sarvaprāptāḥ / teṣāṃ bhāvaḥ sarvagatatvam / sarvamūrtaiḥ I / saṃyogaḥ / sa cānyatarakarmajaḥ saṃyogajo vā / sa tūbhayaniṣṭhatvāviśeṣe 'pyākāśādereva sādharmyam / tasya hi sarvamūrtaiḥ saha saṃyogo na mūrtānāmanyatamasyeti /
analyzed: evam ākāśa kāla diś ātmanām sarvagata tva ādi sādharmyam sarva śabdaḥ ca anantara ukta mūrteṣu eva vartate sarveṣu gatāḥ sarva gatāḥ sarva prāptāḥ teṣām bhāvaḥ sarva gata tvam sarva mūrtaiḥ saṃyogaḥ sa ca anyatara karma jaḥ saṃyoga jaḥ vā sa tu ubhaya niṣṭha tva aviśeṣe pi ākāśa ādeḥ eva sādharmyam tasya hi sarva mūrtaiḥ saha saṃyogaḥ na mūrtānām anyatamasya iti
translated: Thus, space, time, direction and self have the similarity of being all-pervading, etc. And the word all applies only to the previously mentioned corporeal substances. They have gone to all, they are all-pervading, they have reached all. Their state is all-pervasiveness. They are in contact with all corporeal substances. And that is produced by the action of either [of the two], or it is produced by contact. And that is the similarity of space, etc., even though there is no difference in being based on both. For it is in contact with all corporeal substances, not with any one corporeal substance.

original: tathā paramamahatāṃ bhāvaḥ paramamahattvam / niratiśayaparimāṇaṃ tatsamavāyo vā /
analyzed: tathā parama mahatām bhāvaḥ parama mahā tvam niratiśaya parimāṇam tad samavāyaḥ vā
translated: Similarly, the state of being supremely great is supreme greatness. It is an unlimited magnitude, or its inherence.

original: tathā sarvasaṃyogisamānadeśatvaṃ sarvāṇi ca tāni saṃyogīni ca mūrtadravyāṇi / taiḥ samānāḥ saṃyogāsteṣāmākāśādayo deśā ādhārāsteṣāṃ bhāvaḥ sarvasaṃyogisamānadeśatvaṃ sarvasaṃyogisaṃyogādhāratvam /
analyzed: tathā sarva saṃyogi samāna deśa tvam sarvāṇi ca tāni saṃyogīni ca mūrta dravyāṇi taiḥ samānāḥ saṃyogāḥ teṣām ākāśa ādayaḥ deśāḥ ādhārāḥ teṣām bhāvaḥ sarva saṃyogi samāna deśa tvam sarva saṃyogi saṃyoga ādhāra tvam
translated: Similarly, the quality of having the same location as all conjunctions. All those are conjunctions and also substances with form. The conjunctions that are the same as those have space, etc., as their locations, i.e., as their bases. The existence of that is the quality of having the same location as all conjunctions, i.e., being the basis of the conjunctions of all conjunctions.

original: na ca saṃyogasyobhayaniṣṭhatvānmūrtānāmapyeṣa dharma iti vācyam / yathā hyekamākāśaṃ sarvamūrtasaṃyogādhāro naivamekaṃ mūrtamityarthād viśeṣo labhyate / na ca sarvagatatvenāviśeṣaḥ / sarvagatatvaṃ hi sarvasaṃyogastadupalakṣito vā samavāyaḥ / sarvasaṃyogisaṃyogādhāratvamiti /
analyzed: na ca saṃyogasya ubhaya niṣṭha tvāt mūrtānām api eṣa dharmaḥ iti vācyam yathā hi ekam ākāśam sarva mūrta saṃyoga ādhāraḥ na evam ekam mūrtam iti arthāt viśeṣaḥ labhyate na ca sarvagata tvena aviśeṣaḥ sarvagata tvam hi sarva saṃyogaḥ tad upalakṣitaḥ vā samavāyaḥ sarva saṃyogi saṃyoga ādhāra tvam iti
translated: And it should not be said that this quality belongs to substances also, because conjunction resides in both. Just as space, which is one, is the basis of the conjunction of all substances, in the same way, no substance is one. This distinction is understood implicitly. And it is not a non-distinction due to being omnipresent. For omnipresence is the conjunction of all, or inherence, which is indicated by that. The quality of being the basis of the conjunction of all conjunctions.

original: yad vā sarve ca te / saṃyogo vidyate yeṣāṃ te saṃyoginaste ca sarvasaṃyogino ghaṭādayaḥ śarāvādayaśca / teṣāṃ samānāḥ saṃyogā iti / śeṣaṃ pūrvavat /
analyzed: yat vā sarve ca te saṃyogaḥ vidyate yeṣām te saṃyoginaḥ te ca sarva saṃyoginaḥ ghaṭa ādayaḥ śarāva ādayaḥ ca teṣām samānāḥ saṃyogāḥ iti śeṣam pūrvavat
translated: Or, those in which the conjunction exists are conjunctions, and those are all conjunctions, i.e., the pot, etc., and the jar, etc. The conjunctions that are the same as those. The rest is as before.

original: anye tūpacāreṇaiva vyutpattyā vā / saṃyogiśabdena saṃyoga evocyate iti manyante / saṃyujyanta iti saṃyogāste vidyante yeṣāṃ te saṃyoginaḥ saṃyogā eva / sthānādupacāro veti / sarvasaṃyogināntu samānāśca te deśāścetyekatve satyādhāra iti /
analyzed: anye tu upacāreṇa eva vyutpattyā vā saṃyogi śabdena saṃyogaḥ eva ucyate iti manyante saṃyujyante iti saṃyogāḥ te vidyante yeṣām te saṃyoginaḥ saṃyogāḥ eva sthānāt upacāraḥ vā iti sarva saṃyoginām tu samānāḥ ca te deśāḥ ca iti ekatve sati ādhāraḥ iti
translated: Others, however, think that the word 'saṃyogī' means only conjunction, as it is derived by metaphor or by derivation. Those in whom there are conjunctions, which are connected, are saṃyogins, i.e., conjunctions themselves. Or it is metaphorically applied from the place. But all saṃyogins have the same space, and they are the substratum when there is oneness.

original: atra caikatve satīti viśeṣaṇaṃ śabdavṛttyā labhyata iti sāmarthyāśravaṇamapāstaṃ bhavati / taccāsat / indriyasāmānyalakṣaṇe viśeṣaguṇalakṣaṇādau ca tasyaiva samāśrayaṇādiha prayāsamātrameveti /
analyzed: atra ca ekatve sati iti viśeṣaṇam śabda vṛttyā labhyate iti sāmarthya āśravaṇam apāstam bhavati tat ca asat indriya sāmānya lakṣaṇe viśeṣa guṇa lakṣaṇa ādau ca tasya eva samāśrayaṇāt iha prayāsa mātram eva iti
translated: And here, the qualification 'when there is oneness' is obtained by the usage of the word. Therefore, the argument that the meaning is not heard by implication is refuted. And that is wrong, because it is only a mere effort here, since it is relied upon in the definition of the general characteristic of sense organs and in the definition of specific qualities.

original: pṛthivyādipañcakasādharmyam
translated: Similarity with the five, earth etc.

original: pṛthivyādīnāṃ pañcānāmapi bhūtatvendriyaprakṛtitvabāhyaikaikendriyagrāhyaviśeṣaguṇavattvāni /PDhS
analyzed: pṛthivī ādīnām pañcānām api bhūta tva indriya prakṛti tva bāhya ekaika indriya grāhya viśeṣa guṇavat tvāni
translated: Earth etc. are five, have the nature of elements, sense organs, and possess specific qualities that are grasped by one external sense organ each.

original: tathā pṛthivyādīnāṃ sādharmyamāha pṛthivyādīnām / pṛthivyādiryeṣāṃ tāni pṛthivyādīni / teṣām / na jñāyate kiyatāmataḥ pañcānāmapi sādharmyam bhūtatvañca indriyaprakṛtitvañca bāhyaikaikendriyagrāhyaviśeṣaguṇavattvañceti tathoktāni /
analyzed: tathā pṛthivī ādīnām sādharmyam āha pṛthivī ādīnām pṛthivī ādiḥ yeṣām tāni pṛthivī ādīni teṣām na jñāyate kiyatām atas pañcānām api sādharmyam bhūta tvam ca indriya prakṛti tvam ca bāhya ekaika indriya grāhya viśeṣa guṇavat tvam ca iti tathā uktāni
translated: Similarly, he states the similarity of earth and so on: of earth and so on. Those that have earth and so on are the earth and so on. Of those. It is not known by how much, therefore the similarity of all five is stated: being elements, being the material causes of the senses, and possessing specific qualities that are grasped by one external sense faculty.

original: bhūtānāṃ bhāvo bhūtatvaṃ tacca sāmānyameva / tathā hi / dravyaguṇakarmaṇi nimitte cābādhyamānamanugatajñānaṃ sāmānyād bhavad dṛṣṭam / yathā gaurityādi jñānam / asti ca bhūtaṃ tamityādi kṣityādiṣu jñānamataḥ samānyād bhavatīti / na cāsya sāmānyāI /dāvanumatajñānasyeva kiñcid bādhakamasti / tathā ca sāmānye sāmānyakalpanāyāmanavasthā syāditi / sāmānyaṃ dravyatvaṃ sāmānyaṃ guṇatvamiti jñānaṃ sāmānyaṃ vinā bhavatītyuktam / na ca tat bhūtaṃ bhūtamiti jñāne bādhakamasti /
analyzed: bhūtānām bhāvaḥ bhūta tvam tat ca sāmānyam eva tathā hi dravya guṇa karmaṇi nimitte ca ābādhyamānam anugata jñānam sāmānyāt bhavat dṛṣṭam yathā gauḥ ityādi jñānam asti ca bhūtam tam ityādi kṣiti ādiṣu jñānam atas samānyāt bhavati iti na ca asya kiñcid bādhakam asti tathā ca sāmānye sāmānya kalpanāyām anavasthā syāt iti sāmānyam dravya tvam sāmānyam guṇa tvam iti jñānam sāmānyam vinā bhavati iti uktam na ca tat bhūtam bhūtam iti jñāne b
translated: The existence of elements is the quality of being an element, and that is a universal. For example, the cognition that is not contradicted in the case of substance, quality, action and cause is seen to arise from a universal, like the cognition of 'cow' etc. And there is the cognition of 'earth' etc. as having the element etc., therefore it arises from a universal. And there is no contradiction in this cognition of a universal, like the cognition of a universal. And in the postulation of a universal of universals, there would be an infinite regress. It has been said that the cognition of 'universal', 'substance', 'universal', 'quality' arises without a universal. And there is no contradiction in the cognition of 'element', 'element' etc.

original: atha nārikeladvīpavāsināṃ kasmādekākāratāpratibhāso na bhavatīti / vyañjakānupalabdheḥ / yathā hi guṇatvādisāmānyaṃ nārikeladvīpavāsināṃ vyañjakānupalambhād vidyamānamapi nopalabhyate tathā bhūtatvamapīti / kimasya tarhi vyañjakamiti / brāhmaṇatvasyevopadeśaḥ / yathā hi brāhmaṇatvamupadeśād vijñāyate tadvad bhūtatvamapīti /
analyzed: atha nārikela dvīpa vāsinām kasmāt eka ākāra tā pratibhāsaḥ na bhavati iti vyañjaka anupalabdheḥ yathā hi guṇa tva ādi sāmānyam nārikela dvīpa vāsinām vyañjaka anupalambhāt vidyamānam api na upalabhyate tathā bhūta tvam api iti  kim asya tarhi vyañjakam iti brāhmaṇa tvasya iva upadeśaḥ yathā hi brāhmaṇa tvam upadeśāt vijñāyate tadvat bhūta tvam api iti
translated: Now, why do the inhabitants of the coconut island not have the appearance of a single form? Because the manifestor is not perceived. Just as the universals such as quality do not appear to the inhabitants of the coconut island even though they exist, because the manifestor is not perceived, so also the universal 'bhūta' (element). What then is its manifestor? Like the teaching of Brahminhood. Just as Brahminhood is known through teaching, so also the universal 'bhūta' (element).

original: athopadeśa evāstvalaṃ sāmānyakalpanayā / yathā anyairuktaṃ bhūtatvaṃ bhūtaśabdasya vācyatvamityabhidhānābhidheyaniyamaniyogapratipattiḥ / sā ca śabdād vṛddhavyavahārād vā anvayavyatirekābhyāṃ bhavatīti / /
analyzed: atha upadeśaḥ eva astu alam sāmānya kalpanayā yathā anyaiḥ uktam bhūta tvam bhūta śabdasya vācya tvam iti abhidhāna abhidheya niyama niyoga pratipattiḥ sā ca śabdāt vṛddha vyavahārāt vā anvaya vyatirekābhyām bhavati iti
translated: Now, let there be only the teaching, enough of postulating a universal. As others have said, the universal 'bhūta' is the denotability of the word 'bhūta'. This is the understanding of the rule that determines the relation between the expression and the expressed. And that arises from the word or from the usage of the elders through positive and negative concomitance.

original: etaccāsat / abādhyamānānugatajñānasya nimittāntarakalpanāyāṃ dravyatvāderapyasattvaṃ syāt / asti ca kṛtasamayasya bhūtaṃ bhūtamiti jñānaṃ brāhmaṇo brāhmaṇa itivat / dravyaṃ dravyamiti jñānavacca / tato 'sti bhūtatvaṃ sāmānyamiti /
analyzed: etat ca asat a bādhyamāna anugata jñānasya nimitta antara kalpanāyām dravya tva ādeḥ api asattvam syāt asti ca kṛta samayasya bhūtam bhūtam iti jñānam brāhmaṇaḥ brāhmaṇaḥ iti vat dravyam dravyam iti jñāna vat ca  tatas sti bhūta tvam sāmānyam iti
translated: This is not correct. If the existence of a universal is postulated only to explain the cognition of a thing as not being contradicted, then substance-ness etc. would also be non-existent. But there is the cognition of each element as it is for one who has made the convention, just as there is the cognition of a Brahmin as a Brahmin, and like the cognition of a substance as a substance. Therefore, there is the universal element-ness.

original: atha yathā dravyeṣvasādhāraṇaḥ samavāyikāraṇatvādirvyāpako dharmaḥ kṛtasamayasya dravyatvābhivyañjako 'sti / naivaṃ bhūteṣviti cet / na / indriyaprakṛtitvāderasādhāraṇatvāt /
analyzed: atha yathā dravyeṣu asādhāraṇaḥ samavāyi kāraṇa tva ādiḥ vyāpakaḥ dharmaḥ kṛta samayasya dravya tva abhivyañjakaḥ sti na evam bhūteṣu iti ced na indriya prakṛti tva ādeḥ asādhāraṇa tvāt
translated: If it is argued that just as there is a pervasive property like being the inherent cause in substances which is not common and manifests substance-ness for one who has made the convention, but not so for elements, it is not so, because being the nature of a sense organ etc. is not common.

original: atha tadupalambhe 'pyakṛtasamayasya nānugataṃ jñānamiti cet / dravyatvādiṣvapi samānam / tatrāpi samavāyikāraṇatvāderupalambhe 'pyakṛtasamayasya dravyaṃ dravyamiti jñānaṃ na dṛṣṭamiti /
analyzed: atha tad upalambhe pi akṛta samayasya na anugatam jñānam iti ced dravya tva ādiṣu api samānam tatra api samavāyi kāraṇa tva ādeḥ upalambhe pi akṛta samayasya dravyam dravyam iti jñānam na dṛṣṭam iti
translated: If it is argued that even on the apprehension of that, there is no universal cognition for one who has not made the convention, it is the same for substance-ness etc. also. Even there, the cognition of a substance as a substance is not seen even on the apprehension of being the inherent cause etc.

original: atha kṛtasamayasyotpatterasti dravyattvādi sāmānyam / tacca bhūtatve 'pi samānamityalam /
analyzed: atha kṛta samayasya utpatteḥ asti dravya tva ādi sāmānyam tat ca bhūta tve samānam iti alam
translated: If it is argued that substance-ness etc. are universals because they exist for one who has made the convention, and that is the same for element-ness also, it is enough.

original: tathā indriyaprakṛtīnāṃ bhāva indriyaprakṛtitvaṃ ghrāṇarasanacakṣustvakchrotrakāraṇatvaṃ yathāsaṃkhyam / tacca vakṣyāmaḥ pṛthivyadhikāre bhūyastvād gandhavattvādityādi vai / sū / / / sūtrairiti /
analyzed: tathā indriya prakṛtīnām bhāvaḥ indriya prakṛti tvam ghrāṇa rasana cakṣuḥ tvac śrotra kāraṇa tvam yathāsaṃkhyam tat ca vakṣyāmaḥ pṛthivī adhikāre bhūyaḥ tvāt gandhavat tvāt ityādi vai sū sūtraiḥ iti
translated: Similarly, the nature of the sense organs is the state of being the cause of the nose, tongue, eye, skin, and ear, respectively. And that we will explain in the section on earth, with the sutras beginning with because of the predominance of smell and so on.

original: śrotre tu karṇaśaṣkulyākāśasaṃyogopalakṣitasyākāśasya kāryatvāt tadapekṣayā ākāśasya kāraṇatvāt / svabhāvārtho vā prakṛtiśabda iti /
analyzed: śrotre tu karṇaśaṣkulī ākāśa saṃyoga upalakṣitasya ākāśasya kārya tvāt tad apekṣayā ākāśasya kāraṇa tvāt svabhāva arthaḥ vā prakṛti śabdaḥ iti
translated: But in the case of the ear, since space is the effect of the space characterized by the conjunction with the cavity of the ear, and since space is the cause in relation to that, or the word nature has the meaning of own nature.

original: nanvāhaṅkārikatvādindriyāṇāmayuktametat / tathā ca prakāśakatvaṃ sattvadharma iti sāttvikādahaṅkārādindriyāṇāmudayaḥ / kimatra pramāṇamiti cedaprāpyakāritvam / tacca śākhācandramasoryugapad grahaṇād vijñātam / anyathā hi śākhāsambandhottarakālaṃ cireṇa candramasā ca sambandhād yugapad grahaṇaṃ na syāt / asti ca / ato 'prāpyakāritvam / tacca bhautikeṣu na sambhavati pradīpādiṣvadarśanādityabhautikatvamanyeṣāmapi pratipattavyaṃ cakṣurdṛṣṭāntabalādeva /
analyzed: nanu āhaṅkārika tvāt indriyāṇām ayuktam etat tathā ca prakāśaka tvam sattva dharmaḥ iti sāttvikāt ahaṅkārāt indriyāṇām udayaḥ kim atra pramāṇam iti ced aprāpyakāritvam tat ca śākhā candramasoḥ yugapad grahaṇāt vijñātam anyathā hi śākhā sambandha uttara kālam cireṇa candramasā ca sambandhāt yugapad grahaṇam na syāt asti ca atas prāpyakāritvam tat ca bhautikeṣu na sambhavati pradīpa ādiṣu adarśanāt iti abhautika tvam anyeṣām api pratipattavyam
translated: But this is not proper, as the senses are products of egoism. And thus, the quality of illuminating belongs to the quality of goodness. So the senses arise from the egoism of the quality of goodness. If it be asked what is the proof of this, we reply: the fact of their acting without contact. And this is known from the simultaneous perception of the branch and the moon. For otherwise, the branch being connected later, and the moon being connected after a long time, there would be no simultaneous perception, but there is. Therefore, they act without contact. And this is not possible in the case of the material senses, as it is not seen in the lamp etc. Therefore, the immaterial nature of the others also should be understood, by the force of the example of the eye alone.

original: tathā mahadaṇuprakāśakatvācca / yaddhi yāvatparimāṇaṃ tāvadeva kriyāṃ kurvad dṛṣṭamiti / tathā hyalpaparimāṇaṃ vāsyādi mahāntaṃ vaṭavṛkṣaṃ vyāpya cchidāṃ na karotīti dṛṣṭam / kiṃ tarhi / svavyāptapradeśa eveti / cakṣurapi alpaparimāṇatvānna parvatādiparicchedakaṃ syāt / tattu dṛṣṭamato na bhautikamiti /
analyzed: tathā mahat aṇu prakāśaka tvāt ca  yat hi yāvat parimāṇam tāvat eva kriyām kurvat dṛṣṭam iti tathā hi alpa parimāṇam mahāntam vaṭa vṛkṣam vyāpya chidām na karoti iti dṛṣṭam kim tarhi sva vyāpta pradeśe eva iti cakṣuḥ api alpa parimāṇa tvāt na parvata ādi paricchedakam syāt tat tu dṛṣṭam atas na bhautikam iti
translated: And because it illuminates the large and the small. For it is seen that whatever has a certain magnitude performs an action to that extent. For thus, a small object like a knife does not perform the cutting action by pervading a large object like a banyan tree. What then? Only in the space it pervades. And the eye, being of small magnitude, would not delimit mountains and so on. But that is seen. Therefore it is not material.

original: tathā niyataviṣayatvācca / yadi hi cakṣustaijasaṃ syād rūpasyaiva tadguṇatvād grāhakaṃ na dravyasāmānyāderiti / evaṃ śeṣeṣvapi niyamena svaguṇagrāhakatvaprasaṅgaḥ / na caitad dṛṣṭam / ato na bhautikamiti /
analyzed: tathā niyata viṣaya tvāt ca  yadi hi cakṣuḥ taijasam syāt rūpasya eva tad guṇa tvāt grāhakam na dravya sāmānya ādeḥ iti evam śeṣeṣu api niyamena sva guṇa grāhaka tva prasaṅgaḥ na ca etat dṛṣṭam atas na bhautikam iti
translated: And also because it has a restricted object. If the eye were fiery, it would apprehend only form, because that is the quality of fire, not the general substance and so on. Similarly, in the case of the other senses, it would follow that they apprehend only their own qualities by restriction. But this is not seen. Therefore they are not material.

original: itaśca na bhautikānīndriyāṇi indriyatvāt / yad yad indriyaṃ tattadabhautikaṃ dṛṣṭaṃ yathā manaḥ / tathā cendriyāṇi / tasmānna bhautikānīti /
