analyzed: itas ca na bhautikāni indriyāṇi indriya tvāt yat yat indriyam tat tat abhautikam dṛṣṭam yathā manaḥ tathā ca indriyāṇi tasmāt na bhautikāni iti
translated: And for this reason also the senses are not material, because they are senses. Whatever is a sense is seen to be non-material, like the mind. And the senses are like that. Therefore they are not material.

original: yattāvadaprāpyakāritvāditi sādhanaṃ tadasiddham / vyavahitārthānupalabdhyā prāpterupalambhāt / anyathā hi vyavahitasyāgrahaṇamantike ca grahaṇaṃ na syād aprāpterubhayatrāviśeṣāt / āvaraṇānupapattiśca prāptipratiṣedhakatvāt / tathā ca prāptipratiṣedhaṃ kurvadāvaraṇamagrahaṇāya kalpyate / dṛṣṭañcāvaraṇasāmarthyam / dūre vā prakāśakatvamataḥ pradīpasyeva prāptārthaparicchedakatvam / tathā ca cakṣuḥ prāptārthaparicchedakaṃ vyavahitāprakāśakatvāt / yad yad vyavahitāprakāśakaṃ tattat prāptāvarthaparicchedakaṃ yathā pradīpaḥ / tathā vyavahitāprakāśakaṃ cakṣuḥ / tasmāt prāptārthaparicchedakamiti /
analyzed: yat tāvat aprāpya kāri tvāt iti sādhanam tat asiddham vyavahita artha anupalabdhyā prāpteḥ upalambhāt anyathā hi vyavahitasya agrahaṇam antike ca grahaṇam na syāt aprāpteḥ ubhayatra aviśeṣāt āvaraṇa anupapattiḥ ca prāpti pratiṣedhaka tvāt tathā ca prāpti pratiṣedham kurvat āvaraṇam agrahaṇāya kalpyate dṛṣṭam ca āvaraṇa sāmarthyam dūre vā prakāśaka tvam atas pradīpasya iva prāpta artha paricchedaka tvam tathā ca cakṣuḥ prāpta artha paricchedaka
translated: As for the proof that it acts without contact, that is unestablished. Because contact is perceived through the non-perception of distant objects. Otherwise, there would be no perception of distant objects and perception of nearby objects, because there would be no difference in non-contact in both cases. And there would be no obstruction, because it would negate contact. And thus, performing the negation of contact, obstruction is imagined to be for non-perception. And the efficacy of obstruction is seen. Or, like a lamp, it illuminates distant objects, because it illuminates distant objects. And thus, the eye, which illuminates distant objects, is not a perceiver of obstructed objects, because it does not illuminate obstructed objects. Whatever does not illuminate obstructed objects is a perceiver of distant objects, like a lamp. And the eye does not illuminate obstructed objects. Therefore, it is a perceiver of distant objects.

original: prāptisadbhāve pramāṇopapatteḥ / śākhācandramasoḥ kālabhedena grahaṇasadbhāve 'pyāśubhāvādutpalapatraśatavyatibhedābhimānavad yugapad grahaṇābhimānaḥ /
analyzed: prāpti sadbhāve pramāṇa upapatteḥ śākhā candramasoḥ kāla bhedena grahaṇa sadbhāve pi āśu bhāvāt utpala patra śata vyatibheda abhimāna vat yugapad grahaṇa abhimānaḥ
translated: Because the existence of attainment is established by valid means of knowledge. Even though the branches and the moon are grasped at different times, due to their quickness, there is the notion of simultaneous grasping, like the notion of piercing a hundred lotus petals.

original: yacca mahadanuprakāśakatvaṃ tadapyanyathāsiddhatvādasādhanam / tathā hi / cakṣurbahirgataṃ bāhyālokasambandhād viṣayaparimāṇam utpadyata iti mahadādyarthaprakāśakaṃ nābhautikatvāditi /
analyzed: yat ca mahat anuprakāśaka tvam tat api anyathā asiddha tvāt asādhanam tathā hi cakṣuḥ bahis gatam bāhya āloka sambandhāt viṣaya parimāṇam utpadyate iti mahat ādi artha prakāśakam na abhautika tvāt iti
translated: And the fact that it illuminates large objects is also not a proof, because it is established in another way. For thus: It is said that the eye, having gone outside, produces the size of the object by connection with external light, so it illuminates large objects etc. because it is not material.

original: yaccoktaṃ taijasatvādrūpasyaiva prakāśakaṃ syādityetadasat / pradīpe darśanāt / na hi pradīpastaijasatvādrūpasyaiva prakāśako dṛṣṭaḥ / kiṃ tarhi / rūpadravyasāmānyāderiti / etāvāneva viśeṣaścakṣuṣaḥ / atastaijasatvaṃ na virudhyata iti / rūpādiṣu madhye niyamena rūpasyaiva prakāśakatvaṃ taijasatve 'numānamiti vakṣyāmaḥ / niyamena gandhādiprakāśakatvañca pārthivatvādiṣu ghrāṇāderiti /
analyzed: yat ca uktam taijasa tvāt rūpasya eva prakāśakam syāt iti etat asat pradīpe darśanāt na hi pradīpaḥ taijasa tvāt rūpasya eva prakāśakaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ kim tarhi rūpa dravya sāmānya ādeḥ iti etāvān eva viśeṣaḥ cakṣuṣaḥ atas taijasa tvam na virudhyate iti rūpa ādiṣu madhye niyamena rūpasya eva prakāśaka tvam taijasa tve numānam iti vakṣyāmaḥ niyamena gandha ādi prakāśaka tvam ca pārthiva tva ādiṣu ghrāṇa ādeḥ iti
translated: And what was said - that only form would be illuminated because of being fiery - that is not so. Because of seeing in a lamp. For a lamp is not seen to illuminate only form because of being fiery. What then? It is said to be of the general class of form substances. This much is the difference of the eye. Therefore, being fiery is not contradicted. We will say that the inference of being fiery is that it is the illuminator of only form among form etc. because of being fiery. And the inference of being earthy etc. is that the nose etc. are the illuminators of smell etc. because of being earthy etc.

original: na caikaprakṛtikatve viṣayavyavasthopalabdheti nānāprakṛtikatvam / tathā hi / ekasmāt kāraṇādupajātāḥ pradīpabhedāḥ samānaviṣayā ityupalabdhaṃ tadvad indriyeṣvapi samānaviṣayatvaṃ syāt / dṛṣṭā tu ghrāṇādergandhādiṣu vyavastheti nānāprakṛtikatvam /
analyzed: na ca eka prakṛtika tve viṣaya vyavasthā upalabdhā iti nānā prakṛtika tvam tathā hi ekasmāt kāraṇāt upajātāḥ pradīpa bhedāḥ samāna viṣayāḥ iti upalabdham tadvat indriyeṣu api samāna viṣaya tvam syāt  / dṛṣṭā tu ghrāṇa ādeḥ gandha ādiṣu vyavasthā iti nānā prakṛtika tvam
translated: And when there is a restriction of objects in having one material cause, it is not the case that they have different material causes. For example, it is seen that the different lamps that arise from one cause have the same object. In the same way, the sense organs would also have the same object. But the restriction of the nose etc. to smell etc. is seen. Therefore, they have different material causes.

original: tathā nānājātyupādānānīndriyāṇi / dravyatve sati pratiniyataviṣayatvāt / yad yad dravyatve sati pratiniyataviṣayaṃ tattad nānājātyupādānaṃ dṛṣṭaṃ yathā vyaṃjanānilapradīpakastūrikādīnīti / tathā caitāni dravyatve sati pratiniyataviṣayāṇi / tasmānnānājātyupādānānīti / tathā hi / jñānaśabdeṣvekajātyupādānatvaṃ pratiniyataviṣayatvañceti vyabhicāraḥ / tadarthaṃ dravyatve satīti viśeṣaṇam / na cāsya pakṣadharmatvādimato 'prāmāṇyamatiprasaṅgāt /
analyzed: tathā nānā jāti upādānāni indriyāṇi dravya tve sati pratiniyata viṣaya tvāt yat yat dravya tve sati pratiniyata viṣayam tat tat nānā jāti upādānam dṛṣṭam yathā vyaṃjana anila pradīpa kastūrikā ādīni iti tathā ca etāni dravya tve sati pratiniyata viṣayāṇi tasmāt nānā jāti upādānāni iti tathā hi jñāna śabdeṣu eka jāti upādāna tvam pratiniyata viṣaya tvam ca iti vyabhicāraḥ tad artham dravya tve sati iti viśeṣaṇam na ca asya pakṣa dharma tva
translated: Similarly, the sense organs are composed of various substances, because they are substances with specific objects. Whatever is a substance with a specific object is seen to be composed of various substances, like the various spices, air, lamp, and kasturi. And these are substances with specific objects. Therefore, they are composed of various substances. Thus, in the case of knowledge and sound, there is the fallacy of being composed of a single substance and having a specific object. To avoid this, the qualification being a substance is added. And this [reason] cannot be invalid because it is a property of the subject, as that would lead to an overextension.

original: yaccābhautikatve 'numānamindriyatvāditi / tatra bhūtādanivṛttamabhautikam / tatpratiṣedhe ca kāraṇāntaraprabhavatvam / viśeṣapratiṣedhasya śeṣābhyanujñāviṣayatvāditi sādhyavikalo dṛṣṭāntaḥ / tathā ca manasi na bhautikatvaṃ nāpyabhautikatvamiti /
analyzed: yat ca abhautika tve numānam indriya tvāt iti tatra bhūtāt anivṛttam abhautikam tad pratiṣedhe ca kāraṇa antara prabhava tvam viśeṣa pratiṣedhasya śeṣa abhyanujñā viṣaya tvāt iti sādhya vikalaḥ dṛṣṭāntaḥ tathā ca manasi na bhautika tvam na api abhautika tvam iti
translated: And the inference that the sense organs are not composed of the elements because they are sense organs, where not composed of the elements means not excluded from the elements, and in their exclusion, arising from another cause, because the negation of a particular is the subject of the permission of the remainder, the example is inconclusive as to the conclusion. And thus, in the mind, there is neither the quality of being composed of elements nor the quality of not being composed of elements.

original: atha bhūtādutpattipratiṣedhena nityatvam / atrāpyabhyupagamavyāghātaḥ / manasyapi nityatvābhyupagamāt / indriyatvañcoktaviśeṣaṇasyāparokṣajñānajanakatvena bhūtādutpattipratiṣedhenetyanyathāsiddham /🔽nirmūlañca indriyāṇāmahaṅkāraprabhavatvam / tatsadbhāve pramāṇāsambhavāt / tathā hi pradhānasadbhāve sati eṣā prakriyā tasya cāsattvaṃ vakṣyamāṇamiti /
analyzed: atha bhūtāt utpatti pratiṣedhena nitya tvam atra api abhyupagama vyāghātaḥ manasi api nitya tva abhyupagamāt indriya tvam ca ukta viśeṣaṇasya aparokṣa jñāna janaka tvena bhūtāt utpatti pratiṣedhena iti anyathā asiddham  nirmūlam ca indriyāṇām ahaṅkāra prabhava tvam tad sadbhāve pramāṇa asambhavāt tathā hi pradhāna sadbhāve sati eṣā prakriyā tasya ca asattvam vakṣyamāṇam iti
translated: If, on the other hand, permanence is [asserted] by the denial of origination from the elements, then there is contradiction with [your own] accepted doctrine, because permanence is accepted even in the case of mind. And the quality of being a sense organ is not established by the denial of origination from the elements as the cause of the production of non-conceptual knowledge, which has the mentioned characteristics.🔽And the origin of the sense organs from ego is groundless, because there is no means of valid knowledge for their existence. For this is the procedure when the existence of primordial matter is accepted, and its non-existence will be stated [later].

original: yeṣāñca āsaṃsāramaṇḍalavyāpīni indriyāṇi teṣāmaśeṣaviṣayagrahaṇaprasaṅgaḥ / atha adṛṣṭavaśānniyatadeśe vṛttivyajyata iti cet / atra pravṛttīnāṃ tādātmye na kiñciduktaṃ syāt / vyatireke tu tadeva indriyamiti saṃjñābhedamātrameva /
analyzed: yeṣām ca āsaṃsāra maṇḍala vyāpīni indriyāṇi teṣām aśeṣa viṣaya grahaṇa prasaṅgaḥ atha adṛṣṭa vaśāt niyata deśe vṛtti vyajyate iti ced atra pravṛttīnām tādātmye na kiñcid uktam syāt vyatireke tu tat eva indriyam iti saṃjñā bheda mātram eva
translated: And for those whose sense organs extend throughout the cycle of worldly existence, there would be the consequence of grasping all objects. If it is argued that they are manifested by the manifestation in a limited place due to unseen [forces], then nothing would be said if the sense organs and the manifestations were identical. But if they are different, then it is merely a difference in name, that [the sense organs] are sense organs.

original: atha niyataviṣayāvabodhānyathānupapattyā tadākāratayaivendriyasya pariṇāmo niścīyate / tanna / anyathāpyupalambhāt / tathā hi niyatārthasannikarṣe 'pyupalambho ghaṭata eva / na ca vyāpitvaṃ parasyābhīpsitataramiti neha pratanyate / pariṇāmapakṣaśca na sambhavatīti vakṣyāma ityalam /
analyzed: atha niyata viṣaya avabodha anyathā anupapattyā tad ākāra tayā eva indriyasya pariṇāmaḥ niścīyate tat na anyathā api upalambhāt tathā hi niyata artha sannikarṣe pi upalambhaḥ ghaṭate eva na ca vyāpi tvam parasya abhīpsitataram iti nā iha pratanyate pariṇāma pakṣaḥ ca na sambhavati iti vakṣyāmaḥ iti alam
translated: If, on the other hand, the transformation of the sense-organ is ascertained only on the ground of the impossibility of any other explanation of the cognition of a definite object, then that cannot be right; because the cognition is found to appear in another way also. For instance, even when there is no contact of the object, the cognition is found to appear; and the opponent does not admit of the all-pervasiveness of the object. Hence we are not going to elaborate this aspect of the subject. We are also going to show later on that the theory of ‘modification’ is not possible; hence we are not going to elaborate it further.

original: tathā bāhyenaikaikendriyeṇa gṛhyanta iti bāhyaikaikendriyagrāhyāste ca te viśeṣaguṇāśceti / te vidyante yeṣāṃ tāni / tadvanti / teṣāṃ bhāvo bāhyaikaikendriyagrāhyaviśeṣaguṇavattvam / samavetā hi yathoktā guṇāstadupalakṣito vā samavāyaḥ / guṇavattvaṃ sarveṣvastīti viśeṣagrahaṇam / viśeṣaguṇavattvaṃ svātmanyastīti bāhyendriyagrāhyagrahaṇam / indriyagrāhyāśca saṃkhyādayo 'pi bhavanti na ca viśeṣaguṇāḥ / tathā hi ekaikagrahaṇamanarthakaṃ bāhyendriyagrāhyaviśeṣaguṇavattvasyānyatrābhāvāt / satyam / tathāpi dvitīyaṃ sādharmyamityadoṣaḥ / tathā hi saṃkhyāderdvīndriyagrāhyatvādekendriyagrāhyagrahaṇam / ekendriyagrāhyatvañca rūpādiṣvasambhavi syāt / na hi ekamindriyaṃ sarveṣāṃ prakāśakamityekaikagrahaṇam / tathāpyantaḥkaraṇasya bāhyendriyādyadhiṣṭhānadvāreṇa vyāpārāsambhavitvameveti bāhyagrahaṇam / evañca bāhyaikaikendriyagrāhyaguṇavattvaṃ viśeṣapadatyāgena dvitīyaṃ sādharmyamiti /
analyzed: tathā bāhyena ekaika indriyeṇa gṛhyante iti bāhya ekaika indriya grāhyāḥ te ca te viśeṣa guṇāḥ ca iti te vidyante yeṣām tāni tadvanti teṣām bhāvaḥ bāhya ekaika indriya grāhya viśeṣa guṇavat tvam samavetāḥ hi yathā uktāḥ guṇāḥ tad upalakṣitaḥ vā samavāyaḥ guṇavat tvam sarveṣu asti iti viśeṣa grahaṇam viśeṣa guṇavat tvam sva ātmani asti iti bāhya indriya grāhya grahaṇam indriya grāhyāḥ ca saṃkhyā ādayaḥ pi bhavanti na ca vi
translated: Similarly, they are grasped by each external sense organ, so they are grasped by each external sense organ. And they are specific qualities. Those that possess them are endowed with them. Their existence is the quality of being grasped by each external sense organ and possessing specific qualities. For the qualities mentioned above are inhered in, or inherence is indicated by them. Since the quality of possessing qualities exists in all, the word specific is used. Since the quality of possessing specific qualities exists in itself, the word grasped by external sense organs is used. Number etc. are also grasped by sense organs, but they are not specific qualities. Thus, the word each is meaningless, since the quality of being grasped by external sense organs and possessing specific qualities does not exist elsewhere. True, but the second similarity is not a fault. Thus, since number etc. are grasped by two sense organs, the word grasped by one sense organ is used. And the quality of being grasped by one sense organ would be impossible in form etc. For no single sense organ illuminates all.

original: dravyacatuṣṭayasādharmyam
analyzed: dravya catuṣṭaya sādharmyam
translated: The similarity with the four substances

original: caturṇāṃ dravyārambhakatvasparśavattve /PDhS
analyzed: caturṇām dravya ārambhaka tva sparśavat tve
translated: The four have the property of being the cause of the origination of substances and having touch.

original: tathā caturṇāṃ dravyārambhakatvaṃ sparśavattvañceti dravyārambhakatvasparśavattve / tanna jñāyate keṣāmiti / viśeṣānabhidhānāt pṛthivyādīnāmityanuvartanīyam anantaratvāditi /
analyzed: tathā caturṇām dravya ārambhaka tvam sparśavat tvam ca iti dravya ārambhaka tva sparśavat tve tat na jñāyate keṣām iti viśeṣa anabhidhānāt pṛthivī ādīnām iti anuvartanīyam anantara tvāt iti
translated: And thus the four have the property of being the cause of the origination of substances and having touch. It is not known which ones have this, because the specific ones are not mentioned. The word earth etc. should be supplied, because of the proximity.

original: kiṃ punardravyārambhakāṇāṃ bhāvo dravyārambhakatvam / dravyotpattau samavāyikāraṇatvaṃ kāryadravyasya samavāyaḥ / tena hi satā dravyaṃ dravyotpattau samavāyikāraṇamiti vyavahārāt / tathā hi / dravyārambhakāṇāṃ bhāvo dravyārambhakatvam / yena satā dravyamutpādayantīti na vivakṣitam / kiṃ tarhi / yena satā dravyamārabhanta iti / dravyotpattau samavāyikāraṇānīti vyavahāraḥ / sa ca dravyasamavāyena satā bhavatīti dravyārambhakatvaṃ dravyasamavāya eva /
analyzed: kim punar dravya ārambhakāṇām bhāvaḥ dravya ārambhaka tvam dravya utpattau samavāyi kāraṇa tvam kārya dravyasya samavāyaḥ tena hi satā dravyam dravya utpattau samavāyi kāraṇam iti vyavahārāt tathā hi dravya ārambhakāṇām bhāvaḥ dravya ārambhaka tvam yena satā dravyam utpādayanti iti na vivakṣitam kim tarhi yena satā dravyam ārabhante iti dravya utpattau samavāyi kāraṇāni iti vyavahāraḥ sa ca dravya samavāyena satā bhavati iti dravya ārambhaka tvam dravya sa
translated: What is the existence of the causes of the origination of substances that is the property of being the cause of the origination of substances? The inherence of the effect substance in the origination of the substance. For it is by that which exists that the substance is the material cause in the origination of the substance, according to the usage. Thus, the property of being the cause of the origination of substances is the existence of the causes of the origination of substances by which the substance is produced. This is not intended. What then? It is the usage that the causes of the origination of substances are the material causes in the origination of the substance by which the substance is originated. And that exists by inherence in the substance, so the property of being the cause of the origination of substances is just the inherence in the substance.

original: atha yena satā svasamavetadravyārabhanta iti vivakṣā tatra /d yadi sparśavatāmeva dravyārambhakatvadarśanāt sparśa eva / tathāpi sparśavattvena gatārthatvād vyarthaṃ syād dravyārambhakatvam /
analyzed: atha yena satā sva samaveta dravya ārabhante iti vivakṣā yadi sparśavatām eva dravya ārambhaka tva darśanāt sparśaḥ eva tathā api sparśavat tvena gatārtha tvāt vyartham syāt dravya ārambhaka tvam
translated: if it is only touch that is the cause of the origination of substance, because it is seen that only those with touch are the cause of the origination of substance, then even so, since the meaning is already conveyed by having touch, the cause of the origination of substance would be pointless.

original: atra eke sahakāriviśeṣopacitasparśe dravyārambhakatvam / sparśavatāṃ bhāvaḥ sparśavattvam / sparśopalakṣitaḥ samavāya iti parihāraṃ bruvate /
analyzed: atra eke sahakāri viśeṣa upacita sparśe dravya ārambhaka tvam sparśavatām bhāvaḥ sparśavat tvam sparśa upalakṣitaḥ samavāyaḥ iti parihāram bruvate
translated: Here, some say that the cause of the origination of substance is touch, which is accumulated with a particular auxiliary, the presence of those with touch is touch-possession, and inherence characterized by touch is the answer.

original: dravyatrayasādharmyam
analyzed: dravya traya sādharmyam
translated: The similarity of the three substances

original: trayāṇāṃ pratyakṣatvarūpavattvadravatvavattvāni /PDhS
analyzed: trayāṇām pratyakṣa tva rūpavat tva drava tva vat tvāni
translated: The three have the properties of being perceptible, having form, and having fluidity.

original: tathā pṛthivyādīnāṃ trayāṇāṃ sādharmyamāha pratyakṣatvañca / rūpavattvañca / dravatvavattvañceti / tathoktānāṃ pratyakṣāṇāṃ bhāvaḥ pratyakṣatvamaparokṣajñānaviṣayatvam / tena satā pratyakṣāṇīti vyavahārāt / mahattvādikāraṇayogo vā / ātmādestu pratyakṣatāyāṃ sādharmyamātram / apratyakṣatve ca vyāvṛttamiti /
analyzed: tathā pṛthivī ādīnām trayāṇām sādharmyam āha pratyakṣa tvañca rūpavat tvañca drava tvavat tvañca iti tathā uktānām pratyakṣāṇām bhāvaḥ pratyakṣa tvam aparokṣa jñāna viṣaya tvam tena satā pratyakṣāṇi iti vyavahārāt mahat tva ādi kāraṇa yogaḥ vā ātma ādeḥ tu pratyakṣa tāyām sādharmya mātram apratyakṣa tve ca vyāvṛttam iti
translated: Similarly, he states the similarity of the three, earth etc., as being perceptible, having form, and having fluidity. The state of being perceptible of those mentioned is perceptibility, being the object of non-obstructed cognition. This is because of the usage of perceptible things. Or it is the possession of the cause of largeness etc. But in the case of the self etc., there is mere similarity in perceptibility, and in non-perceptibility, there is exclusion.

original: anye tu arthatayā bhāvād dvīndriyavivakṣayā pratyakṣatvam atra vivakṣitam / tacca ātmādiṣu nāstīti vyāvṛttaṃ sādharmyamiti manyante / nirvikalpakasavikalpakajñānaviṣayatvañca na vyāvṛttamātmanyapi bhāvāt / tathā ca ahamiti śabdaḥ pṛthivyādiśabdavyatirekādātmani vartata ityupalabdhasamayasya tatsmaraṇād bhavatyeva savikalpakajñānamiti /
analyzed: anye tu artha tayā bhāvāt dvi indriya vivakṣayā pratyakṣa tvam atra vivakṣitam tat ca ātma ādiṣu na asti iti vyāvṛttam sādharmyam iti manyante nirvikalpaka savikalpaka jñāna viṣaya tvam ca na vyāvṛttam ātmani api bhāvāt tathā ca aham iti śabdaḥ pṛthivī ādi śabda vyatirekāt ātmani vartate iti upalabdha samayasya tad smaraṇāt bhavati eva savikalpaka jñānam iti
translated: Others, however, think that perceptibility here is intended as the existence of objects by the desire of two senses, and that this is excluded in the self etc. because it does not exist. And the state of being the object of non-conceptual and conceptual cognition is not excluded, because it exists even in the self. And thus, the word I occurs in the self because of the exclusion of the words earth etc., and the conceptual cognition arises from the recollection of that by one who has experienced it.

original: tathā rūpaṃ vidyate yeṣāṃ tāni rūpavanti / teṣāṃ bhāvo rūpavattvam / rūpasamavāyaḥ samavetaṃ vā rūpamiti / taccāvivakṣitaviśeṣam / anyathā hi kṣityādivyāvṛttarūpādhikaraṇameveti /
analyzed: tathā rūpam vidyate yeṣām tāni rūpavanti teṣām bhāvaḥ rūpavat tvam rūpa samavāyaḥ samavetam vā rūpam iti tat ca avivakṣita viśeṣam anyathā hi kṣiti ādi vyāvṛtta rūpa adhikaraṇam eva iti
translated: Similarly, those that have form are endowed with form. Their nature is the state of being endowed with form, the inherence of form, or form that inheres. And that is not intended to have a specific distinction. Otherwise, it would be only the substratum of form that excludes earth and so on.

original: tathā dravāṇāṃ bhāvo dravatvam / samaveto dravatvaguṇastatsamavāyo vā / atrāpi na viśeṣavivakṣā / anyathā kṣititejasor naimittikamapāñca sāṃsiddhikamiti viśeṣa eva syāt /
analyzed: tathā dravāṇām bhāvaḥ drava tvam samavetaḥ drava tva guṇaḥ tad samavāyaḥ vā atra api na viśeṣa vivakṣā anyathā kṣiti tejasoḥ naimittikam apām sāṃsiddhikam iti viśeṣaḥ eva syāt
translated: Similarly, the state of being liquid is the quality of liquidity that inheres, or the inherence of that. Here too, no specific distinction is intended. Otherwise, there would be a distinction that the fluidity of earth and fire is occasional, while that of water is natural.

original: dravyadvayasādharmyam
analyzed: dravya dvaya sādharmyam
translated: The similarity of two substances

original: dvayor gurutvaṃ rasavattvañceti /PDhS
analyzed: dvayoḥ guru tvam rasavat tvañca iti
translated: The two have weight and the property of taste.

original: evaṃ dvayoḥ pṛthivyudakayorgurutvaṃ rasavattvañca sādharmyam / tathā hi gurorbhāvo gurutvam / samaveto gurutvaguṇastatsamavāyo vā /
analyzed: evam dvayoḥ pṛthivī udakayoḥ guru tvam rasavat tvañca sādharmyam tathā hi guroḥ bhāvaḥ guru tvam samavetaḥ guru tva guṇaḥ tad samavāyaḥ vā
translated: Thus, earth and water have the similarity of weight and the property of taste. For example, the state of being heavy is heaviness. The quality of heaviness that inheres, or its inherence.

original: tathā raso vidyate yayoste rasavatī / tayorbhāvo rasavattvam / rasopalakṣitaḥ samavāyaḥ / samaveto vā rasaḥ /
analyzed: tathā rasaḥ vidyate yayoḥ te rasavatī tayoḥ bhāvaḥ rasavat tvam rasa upalakṣitaḥ samavāyaḥ samavetaḥ vā rasaḥ
translated: Similarly, those that have taste are tasteful. Their state is the state of being tasteful, the inherence characterized by taste, or taste that inheres.

original: dravyaṣaṭkasādharmyam
translated: The similarity of six substances

original: bhūtātmanāṃ vaiśeṣikaguṇavattvam /PDhS
analyzed: bhūta ātmanām vaiśeṣika guṇavat tvam
translated: The quality of being possessed of special qualities by the souls of the elements.

original: evaṃ bhūtāni cātmānaśceti tathoktāsteṣāṃ vaiśeṣikaguṇavattvaṃ sādharmyam / viśeṣā eva vaiśeṣikāste vidyante yeṣāṃ guṇānām te vaiśeṣikaguṇavantasteṣāṃ bhāvastattvam / tadupalakṣitaḥ samavāyaste vā samavetāḥ /
analyzed: evam bhūtāni ca ātmānaḥ ca iti tathā uktāḥ teṣām vaiśeṣika guṇavat tvam sādharmyam viśeṣāḥ eva vaiśeṣikāḥ te vidyante yeṣām guṇānām te vaiśeṣika guṇavantaḥ teṣām bhāvaḥ tattvam tad upalakṣitaḥ samavāyaḥ te vā samavetāḥ
translated: Thus, the elements and the souls are so called. Their quality of being possessed of special qualities is the similarity. The special qualities are the special ones. Those qualities that have them are possessed of special qualities. Their existence is the reality. That which is characterized by that is inherence. Or they are the inherents.

original: dravyatrayasādharmyam
analyzed: dravya traya sādharmyam
translated: Similarity of the three substances.

original: kṣityudakātmanāṃ caturdaśaguṇavattvam /PDhS
analyzed: kṣiti udaka ātmanām caturdaśa guṇavat tvam
translated: The quality of being possessed of fourteen qualities by the souls of earth and water.

original: evaṃ kṣitiścodakañcātmānaśceti tathoktāsteṣāṃ sādharmyaṃ caturdaśaguṇavattvam / tathā hi caturdaśaguṇā vidyante yeṣāṃ te tadvantaḥ / teṣāṃ bhāvastattvam / samavetāste / tatsamavāyo vā / atra cānyaguṇānāmanyatrāvṛtteḥ saṃkhyāmātraṃ sādharmyaṃ vivakṣitamiti jñeyam /
analyzed: evam kṣitiḥ ca udakam ca ātmānaḥ ca iti tathā uktāḥ teṣām sādharmyam caturdaśa guṇavat tvam tathā hi caturdaśa guṇāḥ vidyante yeṣām te tadvantaḥ teṣām bhāvaḥ tattvam samavetāḥ te tad samavāyaḥ vā atra ca anya guṇānām anyatra avṛtteḥ saṃkhyā mātram sādharmyam vivakṣitam iti jñeyam
translated: Thus, earth, water, and souls are so called. Their similarity is the quality of being possessed of fourteen qualities. Thus, those that have fourteen qualities are possessed of them. Their existence is the reality. They are the inherents. Or it is their inherence. And here, it should be known that only the number is intended as the similarity, since the qualities of others do not occur elsewhere.

original: dravyadvayasādharmyam
analyzed: dravya dvaya sādharmyam
translated: Similarity of the two substances.

original: ākāśātmanāṃ kṣaṇikaikadeśavṛttiviśeṣaguṇavattvam /PDhS
analyzed: ākāśa ātmanām kṣaṇika eka deśa vṛtti viśeṣa guṇavat tvam
translated: The quality of being possessed of a special quality that occurs in a part of the momentary by the souls of space.

original: ākāśaścātmānaśceti tathoktāsteṣāṃ sādharmyaṃ kṣaṇikaikadeśavṛttiviśeṣaguṇavattvam / kṣaṇikāśca te ekadeśavṛttayaśceti tathoktāste ca te viśeṣaguṇāśceti / te vidyante yeṣāṃ te tadvantasteṣāṃ bhāvastattvaṃ tatsamavāyaste vā samavetāḥ / guṇavattvaṃ sarveṣvastīti viśeṣagrahaṇam / tat kṣityādiṣvapi samānamityekadeśavṛttipadam /
analyzed: ākāśaḥ ca ātmānaḥ ca iti tathā uktāḥ teṣām sādharmyam kṣaṇika eka deśa vṛtti viśeṣa guṇavat tvam kṣaṇikāḥ ca te eka deśa vṛttayaḥ ca iti tathā uktāḥ te ca te viśeṣa guṇāḥ ca iti te vidyante yeṣām te tadvantaḥ teṣām bhāvaḥ tattvam tad samavāyaḥ te vā samavetāḥ guṇavat tvam sarveṣu asti iti viśeṣa grahaṇam tat kṣiti ādiṣu api samānam iti eka deśa vṛtti padam  /
translated: Ākāśa and the self are so called. Their similarity lies in possessing a specific quality that exists in only a part of the momentary [entities]. They are called momentary and existing in only a part. And they are specific qualities. Those that possess them are said to have them. Their existence is thatness, their inherence, or they are inherently related. Since possessing qualities exists in all, the word specific is used. That is common in earth and so on, so the word existing in only a part is used.

original: tathāpi kṣaṇikagrahaṇamanarthakam / ekadeśavṛttiviśeṣaguṇavattvasya anyatrābhāvāt / tanna / dvitīyasādharmyasya vivakṣitatvāt / tathā hi / viśeṣaguṇavattvam anyatrāpyastīti kṣaṇikagrahaṇam / kṣaṇikatvañca āśraye vidyamāne sati āśutaravināśitvam / kṣaṇikaguṇavattvañca vibhāgāpekṣayā anyatrāpyastīti viśeṣagrahaṇam / kṣaṇikaviśeṣaguṇavattvañca anyatrābhāvād vyāvṛttaṃ sādharmyamiti /
analyzed: tathā api kṣaṇika grahaṇam anarthakam eka deśa vṛtti viśeṣa guṇavat tvasya anyatra abhāvāt tat na dvitīya sādharmyasya vivakṣita tvāt tathā hi viśeṣa guṇavat tvam anyatra api asti iti kṣaṇika grahaṇam kṣaṇika tvam ca āśraye vidyamāne sati āśutara vināśi tvam kṣaṇika guṇavat tvam ca vibhāga apekṣayā anyatra api asti iti viśeṣa grahaṇam kṣaṇika viśeṣa guṇavat tvam ca anyatra abhāvāt vyāvṛttam sādharmyam iti
translated: Still, the mention of momentariness is meaningless, because the possession of a special quality residing in a part is absent elsewhere. That is not so. Because the similarity with the second is intended. For thus, the possession of a special quality exists elsewhere too, so momentariness is mentioned. And momentariness is the quick destruction when the substratum exists. And the possession of a momentary special quality exists elsewhere too in relation to division, so the special mention. And the possession of a momentary special quality is the similarity by exclusion due to absence elsewhere.

original: dikkālayoḥ pañcaguṇavattvam / sarvotpattimatāṃ nimittakāraṇatvañca /PDhS
analyzed: diś kālayoḥ pañca guṇavat tvam sarva utpattimatām nimitta kāraṇa tvam ca
translated: Space and time have five qualities, and are the instrumental causes of all that is produced.

original: tathā dikkālayoḥ pañcaguṇavattvam viśeṣāt sādharmyam / pañcaguṇā vidyante yayostau pañcaguṇavantau / tayorbhāvaḥ pañcaguṇavattvam / pañcaguṇopalakṣitaḥ samavāyaste vā samavetāḥ / etacca saṃkhyāmātrasāmyena sādharmyam /
analyzed: tathā diś kālayoḥ pañca guṇavat tvam viśeṣāt sādharmyam pañca guṇāḥ vidyante yayoḥ tau pañcaguṇavantau tayoḥ bhāvaḥ pañcaguṇavat tvam pañcaguṇa upalakṣitaḥ samavāyaḥ te vā samavetāḥ etat ca saṃkhyā mātra sāmyena sādharmyam
translated: Similarly, the similarity of space and time with five qualities is a special similarity. Those that have five qualities are the possessors of five qualities. Their state is the possession of five qualities. The inherence characterized by five qualities, or those inhering in it, are the possessors of five qualities. And this is the similarity by mere equality of number.

original: tathā ca sarve ca te / utpattirvidyate yeṣāṃ te utpattimantaśceti tathoktāsteṣāmutpattau nimittakāraṇatvamiti / nimittapadasya kāraṇaparyāyasyāpyabhidhānaṃ samavāyyasamavāyivyavacchedārtham / anyathā hi samavāyyasamavāyisādhāraṇatvāt tadapekṣayā asambhavitvameva syāt /
analyzed: tathā ca sarve ca te utpattiḥ vidyate yeṣām te utpattimantaḥ ca iti tathā uktāḥ teṣām utpattau nimitta kāraṇa tvam iti nimitta padasya kāraṇa paryāyasya api abhidhānam samavāyi asamavāyi vyavaccheda artham anyathā hi samavāyi asamavāyi sādhāraṇa tvāt tad apekṣayā asambhavi tvam eva syāt
translated: And so all of them. Those in whom origination exists are said to have origination. They are said to be the cause of origination. The word 'nimitta' (cause) is used to distinguish between the inherent and non-inherent causes. Otherwise, because of being common to both the inherent and non-inherent causes, it would be impossible in relation to that.

original: tathā hi nimittakāraṇasya bhāvo nimittakāraṇatvam / yena satā nimittakāraṇamiti vyavahāraḥ / sa ca kāraṇayoḥ satoḥ samavāyyasamavāyilakṣaṇābhāvaḥ / tena satā tathā vyavahārāt / yadyapi svagatasaṃkhyādyutpattāvasti samavāyikāraṇatvam / tathāpi sarveṣāmeveti viśeṣaṇādadoṣaḥ /
analyzed: tathā hi nimitta kāraṇasya bhāvaḥ nimitta kāraṇa tvam yena satā nimitta kāraṇam iti vyavahāraḥ sa ca kāraṇayoḥ satoḥ samavāyi asamavāyi lakṣaṇa abhāvaḥ tena satā tathā vyavahārāt yadi api svagata saṃkhyā ādi utpattau asti samavāyi kāraṇa tvam tathā api sarveṣām eva iti viśeṣaṇāt adoṣaḥ
translated: For thus, the existence of the instrumental cause is the instrumental causality, by which the instrumental cause is used when it exists. And that is the absence of the inherent and non-inherent characteristics of the two causes. Because it is used thus when it exists. Although there is inherent causality in the origination of number etc. belonging to itself, still there is no fault because of the qualification 'of all'.

original: kṣititejasornaimittikadravatvayogaḥ /PDhS
analyzed: kṣiti tejasoḥ naimittika drava tva yogaḥ
translated: The combination of earth and fire has instrumental fluidity.

original: evaṃ kṣitiśca tejaśceti kṣititejasī / tayornaimittikadravatvayogaḥ sādharmyam / nimittādupajātaṃ naimittikamiti / nimittaśabdaḥ sāmānyaśabdo 'pyarthādagnisaṃyoge vartate / naimittikañca tad dravatvañcetyetena yogaḥ samavāyaḥ sādharmyamiti /
analyzed: evam kṣitiḥ ca tejaḥ ca iti kṣiti tejasī tayoḥ naimittika drava tva yogaḥ sādharmyam nimittāt upajātam naimittikam iti nimitta śabdaḥ sāmānya śabdaḥ upyarthāt agni saṃyoge vartate naimittikam ca tat drava tvam ca iti etena yogaḥ samavāyaḥ sādharmyam iti
translated: Thus, earth and fire are the two, earth and fire. The property of having occasional fluidity in them is the similarity. What is produced from a cause is occasional. The word 'cause' is a general term, but in meaning it refers to contact with fire. And that occasional fluidity is the property. By this, the combination is inherence. This is the similarity.

original: evaṃ sarvatra viparyayāt sādharmyaṃ vaidharmyañca vācyamiti /PDhS
analyzed: evam sarvatra viparyayāt sādharmyam vaidharmyam ca vācyam iti
translated: Thus, everywhere, by the reverse, similarity and dissimilarity should be stated.

original: idānīmupasaṃhāravyājena śiṣyaṃ śikṣayati / yadetad vyākhyātaṃ mayā sādharmyaṃ tadeva sarvatra viparyayād vyāvṛttaṃ bhedāntarād vaidharmyaṃ vācyamiti /
analyzed: idānīm upasaṃhāra vyājena śiṣyam śikṣayati yat etat vyākhyātam mayā sādharmyam tat eva sarvatra viparyayāt vyāvṛttam bheda antarāt vaidharmyam vācyam iti
translated: Now, under the pretext of a conclusion, he teaches the student. What has been explained by me as similarity, that itself everywhere, by the reverse, is to be stated as dissimilarity, which is excluded from other differences.

original: yad vā sādharmyaṃ vyākhyātamityupasaṃhāraḥ / viparyayād vaidharmyaṃ vakṣyamāṇamityanāgatārthasūcanamiti /
analyzed: yat vā sādharmyam vyākhyātam iti upasaṃhāraḥ viparyayāt vaidharmyam vakṣyamāṇam iti anāgata artha sūcanam iti
translated: Or, the conclusion is that what has been explained as similarity. The dissimilarity by the reverse will be stated. This is an indication of a future meaning.

original: vaidharmyaprakaraṇopakramaḥ
analyzed: vaidharmya prakaraṇa upakramaḥ
translated: The beginning of the section on dissimilarity

original: ihedānīmekaikaśo vaidharmyamucyate /PDhS
analyzed: iha idānīm ekaikaśas vaidharmyam ucyate pdhs
translated: Here now, dissimilarity is stated one by one.

original: pṛthivyādīnāṃ navānāṃ / punaḥ pañcānāmityādirūpeṇa sādharmyamabhidhāya pratyekaṃ teṣāṃ vaidharmyamāha iha ityādinā / iheti kṣityādimanaḥparyanteṣu prakaraṇeṣu / idānīm sāmpratam / ekaikaśo vaidharmyamucyate iti / nanvekaikaśa iti vīpsāyāṃ śaspratyayasya vidhānād vyarthaṃ vīpsābhidhānam /
analyzed: pṛthivī ādīnām navānām punar pañcānām ityādi rūpeṇa sādharmyam abhidhāya pratyekam teṣām vaidharmyam āha iha ityādinā iha iti kṣiti ādi manaḥ paryanteṣu prakaraṇeṣu idānīm sāmpratam ekaikaśas vaidharmyam ucyate iti nanu ekaikaśas iti vīpsāyām śas pratyayasya vidhānāt vyartham vīpsā abhidhānam
translated: Of the nine, beginning with earth. Again, having stated the similarity of the five, etc., he states the dissimilarity of each of them, beginning with here and so on. Here refers to the topics beginning with earth and ending with mind. Now means at present. The dissimilarity is stated individually means one by one. But since the suffix śas is prescribed in the case of the distributive, the statement of the distributive is useless.

original: ekaikaśo vinighnanti viṣayā viṣasannibhāḥ / /
analyzed: ekaikaśas vinighnanti viṣayāḥ viṣa sannibhāḥ
translated: The objects, like poison, destroy each one individually.

original: iti vyāsaprayogādadoṣa ityeke /
analyzed: iti vyāsa prayogāt adoṣaḥ iti eke
translated: Some say there is no fault due to this application of Vyasa.

original: pratyekaṃ kṣityādervīpsāyāṃ vaidharmyalābhe punarvīpsākaraṇam avāntarabhedena śarīrādīnāṃ vaidharmyajñāpanārthamiti guravo vadanti /
analyzed: pratyekam kṣiti ādeḥ vīpsāyām vaidharmya lābhe punar vīpsā karaṇam avāntarabhedena śarīra ādīnām vaidharmya jñāpana artham iti guravaḥ vadanti
translated: The teachers say that the repetition is done again to show the dissimilarity of the body, etc. by their internal differences, when the repetition of earth, etc. is obtained individually.

original: vaidharmyantu viśiṣṭa itarasmād vyāvṛtto dharmo yasyāsau vidharmā / tasya bhāvo vaidharmyam / asādhāraṇastattvavyavasthāpako dharmaḥ / kevalavyatirekyanumānamiti yāvat /
analyzed: vaidharmyam tu viśiṣṭaḥ itarasmāt vyāvṛttaḥ dharmaḥ yasya asau vidharmā tasya bhāvaḥ vaidharmyam asādhāraṇaḥ tattva vyavasthāpakaḥ dharmaḥ kevala vyatireki anumānam iti yāvat
translated: Dissimilarity is a dharma that is distinguished, excluded from the other. It is the state of that, which is dissimilarity. It is the uncommon dharma that establishes the truth, meaning it is an inference based solely on negation.

original: dravyagranthe pṛthivīvaidharmyam
analyzed: dravya granthe pṛthivī vaidharmyam
translated: The dissimilarity from earth in the section on substance.

original: pṛthivītvābhisambandhāt pṛthivī / rūparasagandhasparśasaṃkhyāparimāṇapṛthaktvasaṃyogavibhāgaparatvāparatvagurutvadravatvasaṃskāravatī / ete ca guṇaviniveśādhikāre rūpādayo guṇaviśeṣāḥ siddhāḥ / cākṣuṣavacanāt sapta saṃkhyādayaḥ / patanopadeśād gurutvam / adbhiḥ sāmānyavacanād dravatvam / uttarakarmavacanāt saṃskāraḥ /PDhS
analyzed: pṛthivī tva abhisambandhāt pṛthivī rūpa rasa gandha sparśa saṃkhyā parimāṇa pṛthaktva saṃyoga vibhāga para tva apara tva guru tva drava tva saṃskāravatī ete ca guṇa viniveśa adhikāre rūpa ādayaḥ guṇa viśeṣāḥ siddhāḥ cākṣuṣa vacanāt sapta saṃkhyā ādayaḥ patana upadeśāt guru tvam adbhiḥ sāmānya vacanāt drava tvam uttara karma vacanāt saṃskāraḥ
translated: It is earth because it is connected with earthness. It possesses color, taste, smell, touch, number, measure, separateness, conjunction, disjunction, priority, posteriority, weight, fluidity, and unseen force. And these qualities such as color are established as specific qualities in the section on the determination of qualities. The seven beginning with number are from the statement about the visual. Weight is from the teaching about falling. Fluidity is from the general statement about water. Unseen force is from the statement about subsequent action.

original: tatrādāvuddiṣṭatvāt pṛthivyāstaducyate pṛthivītvābhisambandhāt iti / pṛthivīti lakṣyanirdeśaḥ / pṛthivītvābhisambandhāditi lakṣaṇam asādhāraṇo dharmaḥ / pṛthivītvenābhiI /sambandhaḥ pṛthivītvenopalakṣitaḥ samavāya iti / pṛthivī dharmiṇī itarebhyo bhidyata iti sādhyo dharmaḥ / pṛthivītvābhisambandhāt / yastvitarasmānna bhidyate na cāsau pṛthivītvena sambaddho yathodakādi / na ca tathā pṛthivītvena nābhisambaddhā pṛthivī / tasmāditarebhyo bhidyata iti / samavāyo hyativyāpakatvādalakṣaṇaḥ syāditi pṛthivītvaṃ viśeṣaṇam /
analyzed: tatra ādau uddiṣṭa tvāt pṛthivyāḥ tat ucyate pṛthivī tva abhisambandhāt iti pṛthivī iti lakṣya nirdeśaḥ pṛthivī tva abhisambandhāt iti lakṣaṇam asādhāraṇaḥ dharmaḥ pṛthivī tvena upalakṣitaḥ samavāyaḥ iti pṛthivī dharmiṇī itarebhyaḥ bhidyate iti sādhyaḥ dharmaḥ pṛthivī tva abhisambandhāt yaḥ tu itarasmāt na bhidyate na ca asau pṛthivī tvena sambaddhaḥ yathā udaka ādi na ca tathā pṛthivī tvena na abhisambaddhā pṛthivī tasmāt
translated: Among them, earth is mentioned first, so it is said. Because of the connection with earthness. Earth is the indication of the object to be defined. Because of the connection with earthness is the definition, which is the uncommon property. The connection with earthness is the inherence characterized by earthness. Earth is the subject, the property to be proved is that it is distinguished from the others. Because of the connection with earthness. That which is not distinguished from the others and is not connected with earthness, like water etc., is not so. And earth is not unconnected with earthness. Therefore it is distinguished from the others. Inherence would be a non-definition due to over-extension, so earthness is the qualifier.

original: nanvevaṃ pṛthivītvamevāsādhāraṇatvād vyavacchedasamarthamityasamarthaviśeṣaṇatā hetordoṣaḥ / na / pakṣe 'sambhavitvāśaṅkāparihārārthatvāt / tathā hi / pṛthivītvāt pṛthivītyukte pakṣe 'sti nāstītyāśaṅkā na nivarteta / ataḥ samarthamabhisambandhapadam /
analyzed: nanu evam pṛthivī tvam eva asādhāraṇa tvāt vyavaccheda samartham iti asamartha viśeṣaṇatā hetoḥ doṣaḥ na pakṣe sambhavi tva āśaṅkā parihāra ārthatvāt tathā hi pṛthivī tvāt pṛthivī iti ukte pakṣe sti na asti iti āśaṅkā na nivarteta atas samartham abhisambandha padam
translated: But in that case, earthness itself, being the uncommon property, is capable of exclusion, so the reason is faulty in having an unestablished property. No, because it serves to remove the doubt of impossibility in the subject. For when it is said because of earthness, it is earth, the doubt of whether it exists or not in the subject is not removed. Therefore, the word abhisambandha (connection) is capable [of removing the doubt].

original: nanu bhāvapratyayādeva sambandhādhigateḥ / ṣaṣṭhyā vā pṛthivyā bhāvaḥ pṛthivītvamiti / svaśabdena tasyābhidhānaṃ vyartham / tanna / bhāvapratyayaḥ śabdavṛttyā bhāvamabhidhatte / nābhisambandham / na ca gamyāṃ vṛttimāśritya sambandhapadasya vaiyarthyam / śāstre tathābhāve 'tiprasaṅgāt / ṣaṣṭhī cāniyatasambandhābhidhāyiketi viśiṣṭasambandhalābhāyābhisambandhapadam /
analyzed: nanu bhāva pratyayāt eva sambandha adhigateḥ ṣaṣṭhyā vā pṛthivyāḥ bhāvaḥ pṛthivī tvam iti sva śabdena tasya abhidhānam vyartham tat na bhāva pratyayaḥ śabda vṛttyā bhāvam abhidhatte na abhisambandham na ca gamyām vṛttim āśritya sambandha padasya vaiyarthyam śāstre tathā abhāve tiprasaṅgāt ṣaṣṭhī ca aniyata sambandha abhidhāyikā iti viśiṣṭa sambandha lābhāya abhisambandha padam
translated: But since the connection is understood from the verbal suffix itself, or from the genitive case, as in the existence of earth is earthness, the mention of it by its own word is useless. That is not so. The verbal suffix expresses existence by its application to words, not the connection. And the word connection is not useless based on an understood application, because of overextension if that were so in the treatise. And since the genitive case expresses an indefinite connection, the word connection is for the sake of obtaining a specific connection.

original: nanu caivamupādhibhedādavāstavo bhedaḥ samavāyasyetyavārakaṃ lakṣaṇaṃ kathamitarebhyo bhedajñāpakamiti syāt / na / kalpitabhedasyāpyarthakriyākaraṇāt / yathā śrotrasya / tathā hi / śrotraṃ karṇaśaṣkulyākāśasaṃyogopalakṣito nabhodeśaḥ / sa cāvāstavabhedo 'pi śabdopalabdhilakṣaṇāmarthakriyāṃ vidadhāti / tadvat samavāye 'pyadoṣaḥ / samavetaṃ vā pṛthivītvaṃ lakṣaṇam / pṛthivītvañca tad abhisambadhyata ityabhisambandhaśceti karmadhārayaparigrahāt /
analyzed: nanu ca evam upādhi bhedāt avāstavaḥ bhedaḥ samavāyasya iti avārakam lakṣaṇam katham itarebhyaḥ bheda jñāpakam iti syāt na kalpita bhedasya api artha kriyā karaṇāt yathā śrotrasya tathā hi śrotram karṇa śaṣkulī ākāśa saṃyoga upalakṣitaḥ nabhaḥ deśaḥ sa ca avāstava bhedaḥ śabda upalabdhi lakṣaṇām artha kriyām vidadhāti tadvat samavāye pi adoṣaḥ samavetam vā pṛthivī tvam lakṣaṇam pṛthivī tvam ca tat abhisambadhyate iti abhisambandhaḥ
translated: But in this way, the definition of inherence, which is not an obstruction to the non-real difference due to the difference of adjuncts, how can it be the indicator of difference from the others? No, because even the imagined difference performs a useful function, just as in the case of the ear. For the ear is the region of space characterized by the conjunction of the cavity of the ear, and that, even though it is an unreal difference, performs the useful function characterized by the apprehension of sound. In the same way, there is no fault in the case of inherence. Or the definition is the inherence of earthness, and earthness is related to that. Thus, by the inclusion of the karmadhāraya compound, inherence is related to that which is related to earthness.

original: nanūbhayapadavyabhicārābhāvād viśeṣaṇasamāsaḥ katham / tathā sati abhisambadhyata iti abhisambandhaḥ / samavetaṃ rūpādi dṛṣṭamityarthavat pṛthivītvam / pṛthivītvañcetyukte nāsamavetaṃ pṛthivītvaṃ sambhavatīti vyabhicārābhāvaḥ /
analyzed: nanu ubhaya pada vyabhicāra abhāvāt viśeṣaṇa samāsaḥ katham tathā sati abhisambadhyate iti abhisambandhaḥ samavetam rūpa ādi dṛṣṭam iti arthavat pṛthivī tvam pṛthivī tvam ca iti ukte na asamavetam pṛthivī tvam sambhavati iti vyabhicāra abhāvaḥ
translated: But how can there be a determinative compound when there is no absence of deviation of both terms? Thus, in that case, that which is related is inherence. Since form etc. that inheres is seen, earthness has a meaning. When it is said and earthness, it is not possible that earthness does not inhere. Thus there is no absence of deviation.

original: atha apṛthivīvyāvṛttirūpaṃ pṛthivītvamasamavetam / tannirāsāyārthavadabhisambandhapadam / na / tasyāsiddhatvāt / pramāṇena hi prasiddhasya viśeṣaṇena vyudāso dṛṣṭaḥ / yathā nīlenānīlādeḥ / na vā apohaḥ siddhaḥ / vṛttivikalpānupapatteḥ / bādhakasyāpramāṇatayā vāstavasāmānyasadbhāvādekapadāvyabhicāre 'pi karmadhārayasamāsābhyupagamādadoṣa iti /
analyzed: atha a pṛthivī vyāvṛtti rūpam pṛthivī tvam asamavetam tad nirāsāya arthavat abhisambandha padam na  / tasya asiddha tvāt pramāṇena hi prasiddhasya viśeṣaṇena vyudāsaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ yathā nīlena anīla ādeḥ na vā apohaḥ siddhaḥ vṛtti vikalpa anupapatteḥ bādhakasya apramāṇa tayā vāstava sāmānya sadbhāvāt eka pada avyabhicāre pi karmadhāraya samāsa abhyupagamāt adoṣaḥ iti
translated: If, on the other hand, the ‘universality’ of earth consists in the negation of non-earth, and is not-inherent in the individual earth, then the term ‘in a significant way’ has been added for the purpose of excluding that; but that is not right; because that (universality) is not admitted (by us). What is well known as existing by means of a proof, is always excluded by a qualification; e.g. the non-blue is excluded by the qualification ‘blue’; or (conversely) the blue is excluded by the qualification ‘non-blue’; or (conversely) the blue is excluded by the qualification ‘non-blue’; or (conversely) the blue is excluded by the qualification ‘non-blue’; or (conversely) the blue is excluded by the qualification ‘non-blue’; or (conversely) the blue is excluded by the qualification ‘non-blue’; or (conversely) the blue is excluded by the qualification ‘non-blue’; or (conversely) the blue is excluded by the qualification ‘non-blue’; or (conversely) the blue is excluded by the qualification ‘non-blue’; or (conversely) the blue is excluded by the qualification ‘non-blue’; or (conversely) the blue is excluded by the qualification ‘non-blue’; or (conversely) the blue is excluded by the qualification ‘non-blue’; or (conversely) the blue is excluded by the qualification ‘non-blue’; or (conversely) the blue is excluded by the qualification ‘non-blue’; or (conversely) the blue is excluded by the qualification ‘non-blue’; or (conversely) the blue is excluded by the qualification ‘non-blue’; or (conversely) the blue is excluded by the qualification ‘non-blue’; or (conversely) the blue is excluded by the qualification ‘non-blue’; or (conversely) the blue is excluded by the qualification ‘non-blue’; or (conversely) the blue is excluded by the qualification ‘non-blue’; or (conversely) the blue is excluded by the qualification ‘non-blue’; or (conversely) the blue is excluded by the qualification ‘non-blue’; or (conversely) the blue is excluded by the qualification ‘non-blue’; or (conversely) the blue is excluded by the qualification ‘non-blue’; or (conversely) the blue is excluded by the qualification ‘non

original: kecid abhigrahaṇam abhi samantāt sambandha iti pakṣe vyāptyartham / ābhimukhyena ca sambandha iti kevalavyatirekāvyabhicāreṇa gamakatvapradarśanārtham /
analyzed: kecid abhigrahaṇam abhi samantāt sambandhaḥ iti pakṣe vyāpti artham ābhimukhyena ca sambandhaḥ iti kevala vyatireka avyabhicāreṇa gamaka tva pradarśana artham
translated: If, on the other hand, the ‘universality of earth’ be held to be something different from earth, and not inherent in it,—then, in order to preclude this, the author has added the term ‘arthavat’, ‘significant’.—This however is not right; because such an ‘earth-universality’ has no existence at all. It is only what is well known as existing that can be denied by means of the negative word; e.g. the ‘cook’ is denied in the sentence ‘the priest, not the cook, should be fed’, and on that account is regarded as excluded (by the negative). In the case in question however, there is no such well-known entity as ‘earth-universality’, which could be denied by means of the negative word; nor is any such entity created by the words of the sentence (in which the said denial occurs). Nor is Apoha itself admitted (by us); because it is not possible for it to be either manifested or distinguished. As regards the argument that “the word ‘cow’ is not found to be applied to the horse, etc. on the basis of the absence of the absence of the universal ‘cow’,—and that it is applied to the variegated cow and other particular cows,—this is explained as being due to the absence of the absence of the particular ‘cow’ in the variegated cow, etc. and to the presence of the universal ‘cow’ in the variegated cow, etc.” (see text 1022),—this also is not right. Because, in the case of the variegated cow, etc. also, the ‘exclusion of the non-cow’ is not admitted; because the ‘exclusion of the non-cow’ is of the nature of the ‘cow’, and this ‘cow’ is not admitted (by us). If the ‘exclusion of the non-cow’ were of the nature of the ‘cow’, then, in that case, the ‘cow’ would have to be admitted; as the ‘exclusion of the non-cow’ would be of the nature of the ‘cow’. If the ‘exclusion of the non-cow’ were not of the nature of the ‘cow’, then it could not be the ‘exclusion of the non-cow’; as it would not be of the nature of the ‘cow’. Thus then, the ‘exclusion of the non-cow’ being not admitted, the ‘cow’ also cannot be admitted; as it is dependent upon that. Thus the

original: nanu kim itarasmād vyāvṛttā pramāṇasiddhā pṛthivī pakṣīkriyate / atha aprasiddheti / yadi aprasiddhā / pakṣīkaraṇamayuktam / atha pramāṇaprasiddhā vyāvṛttatayā / tarhi lakṣaṇavaiyarthyam / athāvyāvṛttatayopalabdhā / tadasat / vyāvṛttaṃ hi padārthānāṃ svarūpam / tena ca vapuṣā gṛhyamāṇā dharmiṇo na rūpāntareṇeti dṛṣṭam / naitadevam / lokaprasiddhivaśena pṛthivyāḥ pakṣīkaraṇāt / tathā hi / yatra janānāṃ pṛthivīti vyavahāraḥ sā pakṣīkṛtetyabādhaḥ /
analyzed: nanu kim itarasmāt vyāvṛttā pramāṇa siddhā pṛthivī pakṣīkriyate atha aprasiddhā iti  yadi aprasiddhā pakṣīkaraṇam ayuktam atha pramāṇa prasiddhā vyāvṛtta tayā tarhi lakṣaṇa vaiyarthyam atha avyāvṛtta tayā upalabdhā tat asat vyāvṛttam hi padārthānām sva rūpam tena ca vapuṣā gṛhyamāṇāḥ dharmiṇaḥ na rūpa antareṇa iti dṛṣṭam na etat evam loka prasiddhi vaśena pṛthivyāḥ pakṣīkaraṇāt tathā hi yatra janānām pṛthivī iti vyavah
translated: But is the earth, which is well-known as distinct from the other [elements], being taken as the subject? Or is it not well-known? If it is not well-known, it is improper to take it as the subject. If it is well-known as distinct through valid means of knowledge, then the definition is useless. If it is apprehended as not distinct, that is wrong. For the nature of things is distinct. And it is seen that things are apprehended by that form, not by another form. This is not so. Because the earth is taken as the subject according to what is well-known in the world. For thus, that which is commonly called earth by people is taken as the subject, without contradiction.

original: nanvitaretarāśrayatvam / pṛthivītarebhyo bhidyata ityatretarebhyo bhedaḥ sādhyasteṣāntu pṛthivīto bhedena pratipattāvavadhibhāvo ghaṭata iti ekāpratipattāvitarāpratipatterubhayābhāvaprasaṅgaḥ / tanna / asādhāraṇadharmopalambhasahakāriṇendriyeṇa vyāvṛttarūpatayā nirvikalpakajñāne pṛthivī pratibhāsate / tathā abādayo 'pyasādhāraṇadharmopalambhavyāvṛttyā naḥ parasparaṃ cakṣurvyāpārādeva prathante / svayaṃ pratipanne 'pi bhede parapratipādanāyānumānopanyāsaḥ / tathā hi / vipratipadyamānaḥ paraḥ parārthānumānenaiva pratipādyata iti /
analyzed: nanu itaretarāśrayatvam pṛthivī itarebhyaḥ bhidyate iti atra itarebhyaḥ bhedaḥ sādhyaḥ teṣām tu pṛthivītaḥ bhedena pratipattau avadhi bhāvaḥ ghaṭate iti eka apratipattau itara apratipatteḥ ubhaya abhāva prasaṅgaḥ tat na asādhāraṇa dharma upalambha sahakāriṇā indriyeṇa vyāvṛtta rūpatayā nirvikalpaka jñāne pṛthivī pratibhāsate tathā ap ādayaḥ pi asādhāraṇa dharma upalambha vyāvṛttyā naḥ parasparam cakṣuḥ vyāpārāt eva prathante svayam
translated: Is there not mutual dependence? Here, the difference of earth from others is to be established, but the determination of others by the difference from earth is possible only when there is determination of both. Thus, in the absence of determination of one, there would be absence of determination of the other, leading to the absence of both. That is not so. Earth appears in indeterminate cognition as having an excluded form by the sense organ, which is a cooperating factor in the perception of a unique property. Similarly, water and others also appear to us as mutually excluded by the perception of unique properties, even by the operation of the eye alone. Even when the difference is personally understood, inference is presented for the purpose of conveying it to others. Thus, when there is disagreement, the other is conveyed only by inference for the sake of others.

original: athetarebhyo bhede sādhye 'bādayo 'pītarebhyo bhidyanta iti vidyamāne sapakṣe kathaṃ kevalavyatirekāvyabhicāraḥ / na / sādhyāparijñānāt / tathā hi / pṛthivītarebhyo bhidyata iti / pṛthivītarebhyo niravaśeṣebhyo bhidyata iti sādhyārthaḥ / tathā ca sapakṣābhāvaḥ / na hyudakādayaḥ svātmabhyo bhedina iti /
analyzed: atha itarebhyaḥ bhede sādhye ba ādayaḥ pi itarebhyaḥ bhidyante iti vidyamāne sapakṣe katham kevala vyatireka avyabhicāraḥ na sādhya aparijñānāt tathā hi pṛthivī itarebhyaḥ bhidyate iti pṛthivī itarebhyaḥ niravaśeṣebhyaḥ bhidyate iti sādhya arthaḥ tathā ca sapakṣa abhāvaḥ na hi udaka ādayaḥ sva ātmabhyaḥ bhedinaḥ iti
translated: Now, if difference from the others is to be established, then a, u, and the other [vowels] are also different from the others. When there is a similar instance, how can there be invariable concomitance by mere negative instances? No, because the probandum is not recognized. For this is the meaning of the probandum: Earth is different from the others, from all without remainder. And thus there is no similar instance. For water and so on are not different from their own selves.

original: atha pṛthivītvaṃ yadyasādhāraṇadharmād bhidyate tato 'pyanyasmād bhidyata ityanavasthā / abhede tu sādhyasādhanabhāvānupapattiḥ / ataḥ svato bhidyate / kṣiterapi tathābhāvena bādhāt /
analyzed: atha pṛthivī tvam yadi asādhāraṇa dharmāt bhidyate tatas u pi anyasmāt bhidyate iti anavasthā abhede tu sādhya sādhana bhāva anupapattiḥ atas svatas bhidyate kṣiteḥ api tathābhāvena bādhāt
translated: Now, if earthness is different from the uncommon property, then it is different from that other [uncommon property] as well. Thus there is an infinite regress. But if there is no difference, then the relation of probandum and probans is not possible. Therefore, it is different from itself. Because even earth has that nature, it is contradicted.

original: atha pṛthivītvaṃ pṛthivyā viśeṣyate pṛthivī ca pṛthivītvenetītaretarāśrayatvam / naitadevam / pṛthivyāmanuvartamānavapuṣo bhedāntarād vyāvṛttasyendriyavyāpārānnirvikalpakajñāne pratibhāsanāt / tathā hyanugatasvabhāvasyāpītarasmād vyāvṛttaṃ svarūpaṃ sāmānyasya / tacca pratyakṣeṇa svayaṃ pratītamapi parapratipādanāya hetutvenābhidhīyata ityanavasthādyabhāvaḥ / na ca sarvathā vipratipadyamānaḥ pratipādyaḥ syāditi dharmijñānaṃ sāmānyena sādhanajñānañcābhyupeyam / kevalam itarebhyo bhinnā pṛthivī na pratipadyata iti sādhanopanyāsaḥ /
analyzed: atha pṛthivī tvam pṛthivyā viśeṣyate pṛthivī ca pṛthivī tvena iti itaretarāśraya tvam  na etat evam pṛthivyām anuvartamāna vapuṣaḥ bheda antarāt vyāvṛttasya indriya vyāpārāt nirvikalpaka jñāne pratibhāsanāt tathā hi anugata svabhāvasya api itarasmāt vyāvṛttam svarūpam sāmānyasya  tat ca pratyakṣeṇa svayam pratītam api para pratipādanāya hetu tvena abhidhīyate iti anavasthā ādi abhāvaḥ na ca sarvathā vipratipadyamānaḥ pratipādyaḥ syāt iti dha
translated: Now, if earthness is qualified by earth, and earth by earthness, there is mutual dependence. This is not so. Because the form of earthness, which is present in earth and distinguished from other differences, appears in non-conceptual cognition through the operation of the sense organ. Indeed, even the universal, which has a pervasive nature, has a form distinguished from others. And that, although itself cognized by perception, is stated as a reason for the purpose of communicating to others. Thus there is no infinite regress, etc. And the object to be communicated should not be entirely contradicted. Thus the knowledge of the subject and the knowledge of the proof should be accepted in a general way. Only the statement of the proof is made because earth is not cognized as distinct from others.

original: tathaikaṃ vākyamāvartyamānaṃ bhūyāṃsamarthamāheti śabdārthanirūpaṇaparatvenābhisambadhyate pṛthivītvābhisambandhāditi vākyam / tathā ca sāmānyaṃ śabdārthaḥ / tasyaikatayā saṅketaI /kāraṇāditi jaiminīyāḥ / viśeṣāstvaniyatadigdeśasambandhitayā na kārtsnyenopalabdhibhājo bhavantīti kathaṃ saṅketaviṣayāḥ /
analyzed: tathā ekam vākyam āvartyamānam bhūyāṃsam artham āha iti śabda artha nirūpaṇa paratvena abhisambadhyate pṛthivī tva abhisambandhāt iti vākyam tathā ca sāmānyam śabda arthaḥ tasya ekatayā jaiminīyāḥ viśeṣāḥ tu aniyata diś deśa sambandhi tayā na kārtsnyena upalabdhi bhājaḥ bhavanti iti katham saṅketa viṣayāḥ
translated: Similarly, a single sentence repeated expresses a greater meaning, and is connected as having the purpose of determining the meaning of words. The sentence because of the connection with earthness is thus. And thus, the universal is the meaning of the word. It is the object of convention by being one. The Jaiminiyas say that it is the cause. But the particulars, being connected with an indefinite direction, are not completely perceived. How then can they be the object of convention?

original: atha yāvatāmupalambhastāvatsveva saṅketakaraṇād vyavahāraḥ / tarhi viśeṣāntare saṃketāsambhavād vyavahārānupapattiḥ / na ca ayoginaḥ pratyekamaśeṣaviśeṣopalambhaḥ / na cānupalabdheṣvidamasya vācyamidamasya vācakamityabhidhānābhidheyaniyamaniyogapratipattiḥ / samayapratipattiñca vinā śabdaśravaṇādarthapratibhāsābhāvaḥ / athābhinnanimittamupādāya viśeṣeṣu saṅketaḥ / tadapyasat / abhinnanimittasadbhāve 'pi viśeṣāṇāmānantvaṃ nātivartata iti sāmānye saṅketāt sāmānyaṃ śabdārthaḥ /
analyzed: atha yāvatām upalambhaḥ tāvatsu eva saṅketa karaṇāt vyavahāraḥ tarhi viśeṣa antare saṃketa asambhavāt vyavahāra anupapattiḥ na ca ayoginaḥ pratyekam aśeṣa viśeṣa upalambhaḥ na ca anupalabdheṣu idam asya vācyam idam asya vācakam iti abhidhāna abhidheya niyama niyoga pratipattiḥ samaya pratipattim ca vinā śabda śravaṇāt artha pratibhāsa abhāvaḥ atha abhinna nimittam upādāya viśeṣeṣu saṅketaḥ tat api asat abhinna nimitta sadbhāve pi viśeṣāṇām
translated: If, on the other hand, usage is due to the making of conventions in regard to as many things as are perceived, then, in regard to other particulars, there can be no usage, as there can be no Convention in regard to them. And the non-yogic person cannot perceive all the particulars. And without the perception of these, there can be no idea of the restriction that ‘this is denoter’ and ‘that is denoted’, or of the relation of Name and Named. And without the idea of the Convention, there can be no idea of the meaning of the word, on the hearing of the word. If, lastly, the Convention is made in regard to the Particulars, on the basis of a common property, that also cannot be right. Even though the common property may be there, the Particulars do not cease to be infinite in number; so that the Convention could only be in regard to the Common Property, and the denotation of the word would consist in the Common Property.

original: na ca sāmānyavati saṅketopalambhena sāmānyamabhidhāyānantaraṃ viśeṣeṣu vartiṣyata iti vācyam / viramya vyāpārābhyupagamena śabdakarmabuddhyādīnāṃ viramya vyāpārāsambhavād / iti sūtravirodhāt / tathā ca viśeṣaṇapratipattāveva kṣīṇatvād viśeṣyāpratipādakam / taduktam /
analyzed: na ca sāmānyavati saṅketa upalambhena sāmānyam abhidhāya anantaram viśeṣeṣu vartiṣyate iti vācyam viramya vyāpāra abhyupagamena śabda karma buddhi ādīnām viramya vyāpāra asambhavāt iti sūtra virodhāt tathā ca viśeṣaṇa pratipattau eva kṣīṇa tvāt viśeṣya a pratipādakam tat uktam
translated: And it cannot be said that after the convention is perceived in the universal, it will operate in the particulars. Because it is contradictory to the aphorism, as the operation of words, actions, cognitions, etc. is not possible without cessation. And thus, because it is exhausted even in the cognition of the qualifier, it does not convey the qualified. That has been said:

original: viśeṣyaṃ nābhidhā gacchet kṣīṇaśaktirviśeṣaṇe / /
analyzed: viśeṣyam na abhidhā gacchet kṣīṇa śaktiḥ viśeṣaṇe
translated: The denotation does not reach the qualified, its power being exhausted in the qualifier.

original: atha sāmānyapratipatterapuruṣārthatvād viśeṣārthatayā pratipattuḥ pravṛttinivṛttī na syātāmiti / tanna / sāmānyapratipattyanyathānupapattyā viśeṣāvabodhe sati pravṛttinivṛttyorbhāvāt / tathā hi /
analyzed: atha sāmānya pratipatteḥ apuruṣa artha tvāt viśeṣa artha tayā pratipattuḥ pravṛtti nivṛttī na syātām iti tat na sāmānya pratipatti anyathā anupapattyā viśeṣa avabodhe sati pravṛtti nivṛttyoḥ bhāvāt tathā hi
translated: If it be said that the cognition of the universal is not a human goal, so the inquirer would not engage or disengage for the sake of the particular, that is not so. Because engagement and disengagement occur when the particular is understood by the impossibility of the cognition of the universal otherwise. For example:

original: nirādhāraṃ hi sāmānyaṃ bhavecchaśaviṣāṇavat / ślo / vā / / ākṛti / ślo /
analyzed: nirādhāram hi sāmānyam bhavet śaśaviṣāṇa vat
translated: The universal would be baseless, like the horn of a hare.

original: ityādhārapratipattirityalamatikalpitena /
analyzed: iti ādhāra pratipattiḥ iti alam ati kalpitena
translated: Thus, the cognition of the base is enough, not too much imagination.

original: sarvametadayuktam / abhinnanimittopādāne sati sāmānyavati saṅketakāraṇāt sāmānyavāñ śabdārthaḥ / tad yathā ānantyenāvasthitā viśeṣāḥ / tathā hyekaṃ teṣvabhinnaṃ sāmānyamekatropalabdham / tadupalambhādanupalabhyamānā api viśeṣāḥ sāmānyavantaḥ / saṅketaviṣayāḥ śabdāścānityatve 'pi viśiṣṭānupūrvīsacivā iti / tathā hi / yatra yatredṛśaṃ sāmānyaṃ paśyasi tatra tatrāyaṃ śabdaḥ prayoktavyaḥ / itthambhūtācca śabdādayamarthaḥ pratipattavya iti saṅketagraho viśeṣāṇāmānantye 'pi ghaṭata iti / tathā ca śabdaśravaṇāt sāmānyavatyarthe pratipattirdṛṣṭā / sā ca saṅketapratipattimākṣipati / saṅketaścānenaiva prakāreṇa ghaṭate nānyatheti /
analyzed: sarvam etat ayuktam abhinna nimitta upādāne sati sāmānyavati saṅketa kāraṇāt sāmānyavān śabda arthaḥ tat yathā ānantyena avasthitāḥ viśeṣāḥ tathā hi ekam teṣu abhinnam sāmānyam ekatra upalabdham tad upalambhāt anupalabhyamānāḥ api viśeṣāḥ sāmānyavantaḥ saṅketa viṣayāḥ śabdāḥ ca anitya tve viśiṣṭa ānupūrvī sacivāḥ iti tathā hi yatra yatra īdṛśam sāmānyam paśyasi tatra tatra ayam śabdaḥ prayoktavyaḥ itthambhūtāt ca śabdāt a
translated: All this is improper. When the cause is non-different, the word-meaning has the universal, because of the reason for the convention. Just as the particulars exist eternally. For thus, the non-different universal is perceived in them. By the perception of that, even the particulars that are not perceived have the universal. And the words are the objects of the convention, even though they are impermanent, they are accompanied by a particular sequence. For thus, wherever you see such a universal, there that word should be used. And from a word of such a nature, this meaning should be understood. And the grasping of the convention is possible even in the infinitude of particulars. And thus, the understanding of the meaning with the universal is seen from hearing the word. And that implies the understanding of the convention. And the convention is possible in this very way, not otherwise.

original: atha gośabdaśravaṇācchāvaleyādiviśeṣāpratipatterna viśeṣaḥ śabdārthaḥ / satyam / kiṃ tarhi / sāmānyayukto 'rthaḥ pratīyate / na śāvaleyādiviśeṣaḥ / sa ca śāvaleyādiśabdebhya eva pratīyata iti / na caitāvatā sāmānyameva śabdārthaḥ / pradhānopasarjanabhāvenobhayoḥ pratibhāsanāt / tathā gāmānayetyādiprayogeṣu sāmānyavato 'rthasyānayanādikṛtyā sambandhāt /
analyzed: atha go śabda śravaṇāt śāvaleya ādi viśeṣa apratipatteḥ na viśeṣaḥ śabda arthaḥ satyam  kim tarhi sāmānya yuktaḥ rthaḥ pratīyate na śāvaleya ādi viśeṣaḥ sa ca śāvaleya ādi śabdebhyaḥ eva pratīyate iti na ca etāvatā sāmānyam eva śabda arthaḥ pradhāna upasarjana bhāvena ubhayoḥ pratibhāsanāt tathā gām ānaya ityādi prayogeṣu sāmānyavataḥ rthasya ānayana ādi kṛtyā sambandhāt
translated: If it be said that, on hearing the word ‘cow’, there is no cognition of any particular, such as the ‘white cow’, and hence the particular cannot be denoted by the word,—our answer is that it is true that the particular is not denoted by the word; what is denoted by it is the object as associated with the Universal; the particular ‘white cow’ is cognised only through the word ‘śabaleya’ (a particular kind of cow). But this does not make the Universal the denotation of the word; because both (the Universal and the Particular) are cognised as principal and subordinate respectively; and in such expressions as ‘bring the cow’, the object (cow) as associated with the Universal is related to the act of bringing.

original: atha sāmānyamabhidhāya kathaṃ viśeṣe vartate / sūtravirodhāt / na / sūtrārthāparijñānāt / tathā ca sūtrasyārthaḥ śabdo hi ekadā viśeṣaṇaṃ pratipādya punarviśeṣaṇaṃ na pratipādayatīti viramya vyāpāro niṣiddhaḥ / na punarviśeṣaṇaṃ pratipādya viśeṣyaṃ nābhidhatta iti / tathā karma vibhāgaṃ kṛtvottarasaṃyogaṃ karoti / akṛtasaṃyogasya vināśābhāvāt / na ca vibhāgaṃ kṛtvā saṃyogaṃ karotīti viramya vyāpārapratiṣedhaḥ / tathā viśeṣaṇabuddhirviśeṣyabuddhiṃ kṛtvā na kāryāntaramārabhata iti / evaṃ sukhādiṣvapi pratiṣedhaḥ /
analyzed: atha sāmānyam abhidhāya katham viśeṣe vartate sūtra virodhāt na sūtra artha aparijñānāt tathā ca sūtrasya arthaḥ śabdaḥ hi ekadā viśeṣaṇam pratipādya punar viśeṣaṇam na pratipādayati iti viramya vyāpāraḥ niṣiddhaḥ na punar viśeṣaṇam pratipādya viśeṣyam na abhidhatte iti tathā karma vibhāgam kṛtvā uttara saṃyogam karoti akṛta saṃyogasya vināśa abhāvāt na ca vibhāgam kṛtvā saṃyogam karoti iti viramya vyāpāra pratiṣedhaḥ tathā vibhā
translated: Now, having stated the general rule, how does it apply to the particular case? Because of contradiction with the sutra. No, because of not understanding the meaning of the sutra. And the meaning of the sutra is this: Sound, having once conveyed the qualifier, does not convey the qualifier again, so the operation is prohibited after cessation. But it is not that after conveying the qualifier, it does not denote the qualified. Similarly, having performed the division of action, it makes the subsequent conjunction, because there is no destruction of what has not been conjoined. And it is not that it performs the conjunction after performing the division, so the operation is prohibited after cessation. Similarly, the cognition of the qualifier, having produced the cognition of the qualified, does not produce another effect. Thus the prohibition also applies to pleasure etc.

original: nanūktaṃ kṣīṇaśaktirviśeṣaṇe iti / viśeṣyaṃ nābhidadhyāt iti tāvacchakteḥ kāryaviṣayatvāt / kāryañca viśeṣaṇapratipattivad viśeṣyapratipattilakṣaṇamupalabhyamānaṃ śaktervyavasthāpakam / atha kāryasyaivābhāvaṃ brūyāt / sa caivaṃ bruvāṇaḥ svasaṃvedanamapi bādhate / viśeṣyapratipatteḥ saṃvedanāt / bhinnajñānālambanayośca viśeṣaṇaviśeṣyabhāvapakṣe codyaṃ naikajñānālambane iti / samānañcaitadupalabhyamānasya śabdasyārthapratipādakatvābhyupagamāt / svātmapratipattau ca kṣīṇatvāt sāmānyapratipādakatvaṃ na syāt / atha sāmānyapratipatterdṛṣṭatvānna tatra śabdaśakteḥ prakṣayaḥ / tarhi viśeṣapratipatterapi dṛṣṭatvānna śaktiprakṣayaḥ / arthapratipādanārthaśca śabdaprayoga iti /
analyzed: nanu uktam kṣīṇa śaktiḥ viśeṣaṇe iti viśeṣyam na abhidadhyāt iti tāvat śakteḥ kārya viṣaya tvāt kāryam ca viśeṣaṇa pratipatti vat viśeṣya pratipatti lakṣaṇam upalabhyamānam śakteḥ vyavasthāpakam  atha kāryasya eva abhāvam brūyāt sa ca evam bruvāṇaḥ sva saṃvedanam api bādhate viśeṣya pratipatteḥ saṃvedanāt bhinna jñāna ālambanayoḥ ca viśeṣaṇa viśeṣya bhāva pakṣe codyam na eka jñāna ālambane iti samānam ca etat upalabhyamānas
translated: But it has been said that the power is exhausted in the qualifier. It should not denote the qualified, because the function of the power is to produce the effect. And the effect, like the cognition of the qualifier, is established by the power as having the characteristic of the cognition of the qualified. If he were to say that there is simply the absence of the effect, then he who speaks thus contradicts even his own experience, because of the experience of the cognition of the qualified. And in the case of the relation of qualifier and qualified having different cognitions as their basis, the objection is the same as in the case of having a single cognition as their basis. And this is the same, because of the acceptance that the perceived word conveys meaning. And because it is exhausted in the cognition of its own self, there would be no conveying of the universal. If, because of the seenness of the cognition of the universal, there is no exhaustion of the power of the word in that case, then because of the seenness of the cognition of the particular also, there is no exhaustion of the power. And the use of the word is for the purpose of conveying meaning.

original: yaccoktaṃ śabdasāmānyapratipattyanyathānupapattyā viśeṣādhyavasāye pravṛttinivṛttī syātāmiti / tatra kiṃ sāmānyamātrapratipattyanyathānupapattyā viśeṣāvabodhaḥ / tadviśeṣapratipattyanyathānupapattyā vā / yadi sāmānyamātrapratipattyanyathānupapattyā / tathā sati sāmānyamātrapratipattau viśeṣamātrapratipattiriti pravṛttyabhāvaḥ / atha viśiṣṭasāmānyapratipattyanyathānupapattyā / sa tarhi viśeṣapratipanno viśeṣaṇamiti śabdādeva pratīyate /

translated: And what was said about engagement and disengagement being due to the ascertainment of particulars by the impossibility of the apprehension of the mere universal - there, is the understanding of particulars by the impossibility of the apprehension of the mere universal, or by the impossibility of the apprehension of its particulars? If by the impossibility of the apprehension of the mere universal, then in that case, in the apprehension of the mere universal, there is the apprehension of the mere particular, so there would be no engagement. If by the impossibility of the apprehension of the qualified universal, then that particular which is apprehended is understood as the qualifier from the word itself.

analyzed: atha pramāṇa antarāt iti yadi śabdāt katham sāmānyam eva śabda arthaḥ viśeṣasya api abhidhāyaka tvāt  atha pramāṇa antaram na vā pramāṇa antara vyāpāra ananubhavāt na ca sāmānyam para pakṣe viśeṣāt bhinnam sambhavati iti abhede sāmānya pratipatti vat viśeṣa pratipatti prasaṅgaḥ anyathā hi etad pratipattau itara pratipatteḥ bhedaḥ atha iṣyate eva kenacid rūpeṇa abhinnam bhinnam ca iti na bheda abhedayoḥ vidhi pratiṣedha rūpa tvāt abhinne dharmiṇi
translated: If it is said that it is by another means of knowledge, and if it is by verbal testimony, how can the meaning of a word be only the universal, since the particular is also denoted? If it is by another means of knowledge, or not, because the operation of another means of knowledge is not experienced, and it is not so, because in the opponent's view the universal cannot be different from the particular, so the apprehension of the particular would follow from the apprehension of the universal, if there were no difference. For if it were otherwise, the apprehension of one would not be the apprehension of the other, and there would be a difference. If it is accepted that it is both non-different and different in some respect, no, because difference and non-difference have the nature of affirmation and negation, and so cannot coexist in an undifferentiated substratum. For this is to be said: by what form it is different, is it by that same form that it is non-different, or by another form? If it is accepted that it is different in relation to spatial difference, but non-different in form difference, there is no dispute. The opponent understands difference in relation to spatial difference.

analyzed: yadi ca pṛthivī śabdaḥ pṛthivī tvam abhidadhyāt pṛthivī tva śabdasya arthaḥ vaktavyaḥ na ca abhede taddhita sāphalyam paśyāmaḥ iti sāmānyavān arthaḥ pṛthivī śabdasya iti yuktam atha ekatra saṅketitaḥ pṛthivī śabdaḥ katham artha antare pravartiṣyate iti āha pṛthivī tva abhisambandhāt nimittāt pṛthivī śabdaḥ ekatra saṅketitaḥ sa ca artha antare pi tad vaśāt pravartate iti saṅketa anupapatteḥ viśeṣaḥ eva śabda arthaḥ na sambhavati iti s
translated: And if the word 'earth' denotes earthness, the meaning of the word 'earthness' has to be stated. And we do not see any purpose in the secondary suffix in the case of non-difference. Therefore, it is proper that the meaning of the word 'earth' is a universal along with an individual. Now, how can the word 'earth', which is conventionally associated with one thing, function with regard to another thing? He says: The word 'earth', which is conventionally associated with one thing due to the connection with earthness, functions with regard to another thing also due to that. Therefore, due to the impossibility of convention, the meaning of a word is only an individual. Thus, the Sāṃkhya and Śākta views are also refuted.

original: tathā śaktayaḥ sarvabhāvānāṃ kāryārthāpattigocarāḥ ślo / vā / / śūnya / ślo / iti tannirāsaḥ / yat pṛthivītvābhisambandhāt pṛthivī kāryaṃ karotīti pṛthivītvameva nijā śaktiranyā tu caramasahakārirūpā / tatsadbhāve kāryakaraṇāt tadabhāve cākaraṇāditi / tathā hi / vidyamānā api tantavaḥ kāryaṃ nārabhante 'ntyatantusaṃyogaṃ vineti saiva śaktiḥ / atha arthāntaramarthāntarasya kathaṃ śaktiḥ / anarthāntaratve 'pi samānametat / saiva tasyaiva śaktiriti / atha yadi pūrveṣāṃ caramasahakāryeva śaktistasyāpyaśaktasyākāraṇatvādanyā śaktirvācyetyanavasthā / naitadevam / caramasya hi sahakāriṇaḥ pūrvasahakāriṇa eva śaktiḥ / itaretarābhisambandhena kāryakaraṇāt / sa eva ca samagrāṇāṃ bhāvaḥ sāmagrīti bhāvapratyayenocyate / tena hi satā samagravyapadeśadarśanāt /
analyzed: tathā śaktayaḥ sarva bhāvānām kārya artha āpatti gocarāḥ vā iti tad nirāsaḥ yat pṛthivī tva abhisambandhāt pṛthivī kāryam karoti iti pṛthivī tvam eva nijā śaktiḥ anyā tu carama sahakāri rūpā tad sadbhāve kārya karaṇāt tad abhāve ca akaraṇāt iti tathā hi vidyamānāḥ api tantavaḥ kāryam na ārabhante ntya tantu saṃyogam vinā iti sā eva śaktiḥ atha artha antaram artha antarasya katham śaktiḥ anartha antara tve pi samānam etat sā eva tasya eva śak
translated: Similarly, the potencies of all things are within the scope of the inference of effects. The refutation of that is stated in the verse beginning with śūnya. What is meant is that because it is related to earthness, earth produces an effect. Earthness itself is its own potency, while the other is in the form of the final cooperating factor. Because it produces an effect when that exists, and because it does not produce an effect when it does not exist. This is because, even though the threads exist, they do not produce an effect without the final conjunction of the threads. That itself is the potency. If it is an entirely different thing, how can it be the potency of an entirely different thing? Even if it is not entirely different, this is the same. That itself is the potency of that very thing. Now, if the potency of the previous ones is only the final cooperating factor, and that also is not able to produce the effect, another potency must be stated. Thus there is an infinite regress. This is not so. For the final cooperating factor has the potency of only the previous cooperating factors. Because the effect is produced by the mutual relationship. And that itself is the totality of the things, which is called the assemblage.

original: nanu yadi atīndriyā śaktirneṣyate / maṇimantrādinā tarhi pratibaddho 'gnirna sphoṭādikāryamārabhata iti kasya pratibandhaḥ / na cāgneḥ / na cāgnisaṃyogasya upalabhyamānatvāI /diti śakteḥ pratibandhaḥ / tadasat / maṇimantrādipratibandhakābhāvasyāpi kāryotpattau sahakāritvāt / tadabhāve tu na kāryasyodaya iti tadviśiṣṭasaṃyoga eva śaktiḥ / na punaḥ śakteḥ pratibandho nānutpattirvināśo vā sambhavatīti / cirotpannatvād vinaṣṭāyāśca punarutpattikāraṇābhāvādanutpattiprasaṅgaḥ / aśaktasya kāryānutpādakatvādityanvayavyatirekābhyāṃ pratibandhakābhāvaviśiṣṭo 'gnisaṃyoga evāgniśaktiriti jñātam / evamatrāpi pṛthivītvaṃ nijā śaktiraparā tu sahakāribhūteti /
analyzed: nanu yadi atīndriyā śaktiḥ na iṣyate maṇi mantra ādinā tarhi pratibaddhaḥ gniḥ na sphoṭa ādi kāryam ārabhate iti kasya pratibandhaḥ na ca agneḥ na ca agni saṃyogasya śakteḥ pratibandhaḥ tat asat maṇi mantra ādi pratibandhaka abhāvasya api kārya utpattau sahakāri tvāt tad abhāve tu na kāryasya udayaḥ iti tad viśiṣṭa saṃyogaḥ eva śaktiḥ na punar śakteḥ pratibandhaḥ na anutpattiḥ vināśaḥ vā sambhavati iti cira utpanna tvāt vinaṣṭāyāḥ c
translated: If power is not accepted as beyond the senses, then fire obstructed by a gem or mantra does not produce effects like sparks. Whose obstruction is it? Not of fire, nor of the contact of fire, which is perceived. Therefore, the obstruction is of power. That is wrong. Because the absence of the obstruction by gem, mantra, etc. is also a contributory cause in the production of the effect. But in its absence, the effect does not arise. Therefore, the power is only the contact qualified by that. And it is not possible for power to be obstructed, not produced, or destroyed. Because of being produced long ago and being destroyed, there is no cause for its further production, so it would not be produced. Because that which is powerless does not produce effects. Thus, by positive and negative concomitance, it is known that the contact of fire qualified by the absence of the obstruction is the power of fire. Similarly, here also, earthness is one's own power, but another is a contributory cause.
