original: pṛthivyādīnāṃ navānāṃ guṇavattvaṃ samavāyikāraṇatvaṃ kṣityudakātmanāṃ caturdaśaguṇavattvañcoktam / tatra kairguṇairguṇavatī / keṣāmutpattau samavāyikāraṇatvam / ke vā caturdaśa guṇāḥ / kiñca guṇātmakaṃ lakṣaṇamityāha rūpādivākyam / rūpādayaḥ saṃskāraparyantaṃ vidyante yasyāḥ sā rūpādisaṃskāravatī / kimete svatantratayā vṛttikṛtā pratipādyante / uta sūtrakārasyābhipretā ityāśaṅkyāha ete ca guṇaviniveśādhikāre ityādi / ete ca sūtrakāreṇābhihitāḥ / kasminnadhikāre / guṇā vividhamanekaprakāreṇa viniveśyante yasminnadhikāre sa tathokto dvitīyo 'dhyāyaḥ / tatra sūtrakāreṇa pratipāditāḥ /
analyzed: pṛthivī ādīnām navānām guṇavat tvam samavāyi kāraṇa tvam kṣiti udaka ātmanām caturdaśa guṇavat tvam ca uktam tatra kaiḥ guṇaiḥ guṇavatī keṣām utpattau samavāyi kāraṇa tvam ke vā caturdaśa guṇāḥ kiñca guṇa ātmakam lakṣaṇam iti āha rūpa ādi vākyam rūpa ādayaḥ saṃskāra paryantam vidyante yasyāḥ sā rūpa ādi saṃskāravatī  / kim ete svatantra tayā vṛtti kṛtā pratipādyante uta sūtrakārasya abhipretāḥ iti āśaṅkya āha ete ca g
translated: It has been stated that the nine substances beginning with earth possess qualities, are inhering causes, and that earth, water, and fire possess fourteen qualities. In that context, which qualities do they possess? In the production of which substances are they inhering causes? And what are the fourteen qualities? And what is the definition of a quality? The sentence beginning with color states this. That which possesses color up to modification is said to possess color and modification. Are these taught independently by the author of the commentary? Or are they intended by the author of the aphorisms? Suspecting this, he says And these are mentioned by the author of the aphorisms in the section on the various arrangements of qualities, and so on. And these are mentioned by the author of the aphorisms. In which section? In that section where the various, many kinds of qualities are arranged, that section is called thus. There, those mentioned by the author of the aphorisms.

original: tathā ca rūparasagandhasparśavatī pṛthivī vai / sū / / / ityanena viśeṣaguṇāścatvāro 'bhihitāḥ / tathā cākṣuṣavacanāt iti / saṃkhyāḥ / parimāṇāni / pṛthaktvam / saṃyogavibhāgau / paratvāparatve / karma ca rūpidravyasamavāyāccākṣuṣāṇi vai / sū / / / iti sūtraṃ darśayati /
analyzed: tathā ca rūpa rasa gandha sparśavatī pṛthivī vai sū iti anena viśeṣa guṇāḥ catvāraḥ bhihitāḥ tathā cākṣuṣa vacanāt iti saṃkhyāḥ parimāṇāni pṛthaktvam saṃyoga vibhāgau paratva aparatve karma ca rūpi dravya samavāyāt cākṣuṣāṇi vai sū iti sūtram darśayati
translated: And thus, Earth has form, taste, smell, and touch. Vai. .. by this, the four specific qualities are mentioned. And thus, Because of the statement about what is seen by the eye. The sutra shows the numbers, dimensions, separateness, conjunction and disjunction, priority and posteriority, and action are perceptible in a substance with form, because of inherence. Vai. .. by this sutra.

original: sūtrasyārthaḥ rūpidravyamupalabdhilakṣaṇaprāptaṃ mahattvādyupetam / tatra samavāyāt saṃkhyādayaśca pratyakṣagrāhyā iti / anyapareṇāpi sūtreṇa rūpavati dravye saṃkhyādīnāṃ sadbhāvo 'bhihitaḥ / anyathā hyavidyamānatvādev tatra teṣāmupalambho na syāditi /
analyzed: sūtrasya arthaḥ rūpi dravyam upalabdhi lakṣaṇa prāptam mahā tva ādi upetam tatra samavāyāt saṃkhyā ādayaḥ ca pratyakṣa grāhyāḥ iti anya pareṇa api sūtreṇa rūpavati dravye saṃkhyā ādīnām sadbhāvaḥ bhihitaḥ anyathā hi avidyamāna tvāt eva tatra teṣām upalambhaḥ na syāt iti
translated: The meaning of the sutra is: A perceptible substance endowed with greatness etc. is obtained. There, because of inherence, number etc. are also perceptible. Even by a sutra referring to something else, the existence of number etc. in a substance with form is stated. Otherwise, because of non-existence, their perception would not occur there.

original: padārthaśca saṃkhyā iti bahuvacanaṃ saṃkhyātvavyatirekeṇaikatvatvādyaparasāmānyapradarśanārtham / parimāṇānīti / tathā parimāṇatvāpekṣayāṇutvādyaparasāmānyajñāpanārtham / pṛthaktvamityekavacanaṃ pṛthaktvatvasāmānyāpekṣayā ekapṛthaktvatvādyaparasāmānyaśūnyatāpradarśanārtham / saṃyogavibhāgāviti dvivacanena saṃyogatvavibhāgatvavyatirekeṇa aparasāmānyābhāve 'pi vibhāgasya saṃyogāpekṣitājñāpanārthaṃ samāsakaraṇam / tathā paratvāparatve ityapi dvivacanaṃ paratvatvāparatvatvaṃ sāmānyāpekṣayā aparasāmānyābhāve 'pi sāhacaryajñāpanārthaṃ samāsakaraṇamiti /
analyzed: padārthaḥ ca saṃkhyā iti bahuvacanam saṃkhyā tva vyatirekeṇa ekatva tva ādi apara sāmānya pradarśana artham parimāṇāni iti tathā parimāṇa tva apekṣayā aṇu tva ādi apara sāmānya jñāpana artham pṛthaktvam iti eka vacanam pṛthaktva tva sāmānya apekṣayā eka pṛthaktva tva ādi apara sāmānya śūnyatā pradarśana artham saṃyoga vibhāgau iti dvivacanena saṃyoga tva vibhāga tva vyatirekeṇa apara sāmānya abhāve pi vibhāgasya saṃyoga apekṣi tā jñāpana
translated: And the meaning of the word is number. The plural number is for the purpose of showing other general properties like oneness, etc., apart from numberness. The words dimensions - for the purpose of showing other general properties like atomicity, etc., in relation to dimensionness. The singular number in separateness is for the purpose of showing the absence of other general properties like single separateness, etc., in relation to the general property of separateness. The compound conjunction and disjunction in the dual number is for the purpose of showing the dependence of disjunction on conjunction, even in the absence of other general properties apart from the general properties of conjunctionness and disjunctionness. Similarly, the compound farness and nearness in the dual number is for the purpose of showing their co-occurrence, even in the absence of other general properties, in relation to the general properties of farnessness and nearnessness.

original: tathā patanopadeśād iti / gurutvātpatamamiti vai / sū / / / / sūtraṃ darśayati / yathā ca patane gurutvaṃ kāraṇaṃ tathā vakṣyāmo gurutvaparīkṣāyām / adbhiḥ sāmānyavacanāt iti / sarpirjatumadhūcchiṣṭhānāṃ pārthivānāmagnisaṃyogād dravatvamadbhiḥ sāmānyam vai / sū / / / iti sūtraṃ darśayati / sarpirādīnāmagnisaṃyogād dravatvaṃ sampadyate 'dbhiḥ tathā sāmānyaṃ yathā bhavatīti sūtrārthaḥ / uttarakarmavacanāt iti / nodanādādyamiṣoḥ karma tatkarmakāritācca saṃskārāttathottaramuttarañca vai / sū / / / iti sūtraṃ darśayati iṣoḥ śarasyādyaṃ karma nodanād bhavatīti / karma ca nodanāpekṣaṃ saṃskāramārabhate / karmakāritācca saṃskārāt tathottarañca / ekaḥ saṃskāro 'nekaṃ karmārabhate patanaṃ yāvaditi / iṣoḥ samavāyikāraṇasyāvagatāyāṃ sambhavinyāmiṣoriti ṣaṣṭhyabhidhānaṃ tadavayaveṣvapi karmajñāpanārtham / yad vā ṣaṣṭhyarthasya vidyamānatvāt tadabhidhāne 'pyadoṣaḥ /
analyzed: tathā patana upadeśāt iti guru tvāt patamam iti vai sū   / sūtram darśayati yathā ca patane guru tvam kāraṇam tathā vakṣyāmaḥ guru tva parīkṣāyām adbhiḥ sāmānya vacanāt iti sarpiḥ jatu madhūcchiṣṭhānām pārthivānām agni saṃyogāt drava tvam adbhiḥ sāmānyam vai sū iti sūtram darśayati sarpiḥ ādīnām agni saṃyogāt drava tvam sampadyate dbhiḥ tathā sāmānyam yathā bhavati iti sūtra arthaḥ uttara karma vacanāt iti nodanāt ādyam iṣoḥ karma tad
translated: Similarly, because of the teaching of falling, by gravity it falls, thus he shows the aphorism. And as gravity is the cause of falling, we will explain in the examination of gravity. By water, because of the general statement, ghee, lac, and honey are earth, their fluidity from contact with fire is the same as water, thus he shows the aphorism. The meaning of the aphorism is that the fluidity of ghee etc. is produced from contact with fire, and it is the same as water, just as it occurs. Because of the statement about subsequent action, the first action of the arrow is from the impulse, and because of the modification produced by that action, it is the same for the subsequent ones, thus he shows the aphorism. The first action of the arrow is from the impulse. And the action produces a modification dependent on the impulse. And because of the modification produced by the action, it is the same for the subsequent ones. A single modification produces many actions up to falling.

original: kṣitāveva gandhaḥ / rūpamanekaprakārakaṃ śuklādi / rasaḥ ṣaḍvidho madhurādiḥ / gandho dvividhaḥ surabhirasurabhiśca / sparśo 'syā anuṣṇāśītatve sati pākajaḥ /PDhS
analyzed: kṣitau eva gandhaḥ rūpam aneka prakārakam śukla ādi rasaḥ ṣaḍvidhaḥ madhura ādiḥ gandhaḥ dvividhaḥ surabhiḥ asurabhiḥ ca anuṣṇa aśīta tve sati pāka jaḥ
translated: Smell exists only on earth. Color is of many kinds, such as white, etc. Taste is of six kinds, sweet, etc. Smell is of two kinds, fragrant and foul. Touch, in addition to being neither hot nor cold, is produced by cooking.

original: sā tu dvividhā / nityā anityā ca / paramāṇulakṣaṇā nityā / kāryalakṣaṇā tvanityā / sā ca sthairyādyavayavasanniveśaviśiṣṭajātibahutvopetā śayanāsanādyanekopakārakarī ca /PDhS
analyzed: sā tu dvividhā nityā anityā ca paramāṇu lakṣaṇā nityā kārya lakṣaṇā tu anityā sā ca sthairya ādi avayava sanniveśa viśiṣṭa jāti bahu tva upetā śayana āsana ādi aneka upakāra karī ca pdhs
translated: It is of two kinds: eternal and non-eternal. The eternal is characterized by atoms, while the non-eternal is characterized by effects. And that is endowed with the many species distinguished by the arrangement of stable parts, and it is also helpful in many ways, such as in lying down and sitting.

original: trividhaścāsyāḥ kāryaṃ śarīrendriyaviṣayasaṃjñakam /PDhS
analyzed: trividhaḥ ca asyāḥ kāryam śarīra indriya viṣaya saṃjñakam
translated: And its effect is of three kinds, called body, sense organ, and object.

original: tatra śarīraṃ dvividhaṃ yonijamayonijañca / tatrāyonijam anapekṣaśukraśoṇitaṃ devarṣīṇāṃ śarīraṃ dharmaviśeṣasahitebhyo 'ṇubhyo jāyate / kṣudrajantūnāṃ yātanāśarīrāṇyadharmaviśeṣasahitebhyo 'ṇubhyo jāyante /PDhS
analyzed: tatra śarīram dvividham yoni jam ayonijam ca tatra ayoni jam anapekṣa śukra śoṇitam devarṣīṇām śarīram dharma viśeṣa sahitebhyaḥ ṇubhyaḥ jāyate kṣudrajantūnām yātanā śarīrāṇi adharma viśeṣa sahitebhyaḥ ṇubhyaḥ jāyante
translated: There, the body is of two kinds, born from a womb and not born from a womb. Among them, that not born from a womb, independent of semen and blood, is the body of gods and sages, born from atoms accompanied by special qualities of dharma. The bodies of small creatures and those in hell are born from atoms accompanied by special qualities of adharma.

original: śukraśoṇitasannipātajaṃ yonijam / tattu dvividhaṃ jarāyujamaṇḍajañca / mānuṣapaśumṛgāṇāṃ jarāyujam / pakṣisarīsṛpāṇāmaṇḍajam /PDhS
analyzed: śukra śoṇita sannipāta jam yoni jam tat tu dvividham jarāyu jam aṇḍa jam ca  mānuṣa paśu mṛgāṇām jarāyu jam pakṣi sarīsṛpāṇām aṇḍa jam
translated: The womb-born is produced from the union of semen and blood. That is of two kinds: viviparous and oviparous. The viviparous is of humans, animals, and deer. The oviparous is of birds and reptiles.

original: indriyaṃ gandhavyañjakaṃ sarvatrāṇināṃ jalādyanabhibhūtairasampṛktaiḥ kevalaiḥ pārthivāvayavairārabdhaṃ ghrāṇam /PDhS
analyzed: indriyam gandha vyañjakam sarvatra aṇinām jala ādi anabhibhūtaiḥ asampṛktaiḥ kevalaiḥ pārthiva avayavaiḥ ārabdham ghrāṇam
translated: The nose is produced by earth elements alone, unobstructed and unmixed with water, etc., which manifest smell everywhere.

original: viṣayastu dvyaṇukādiprakrameṇārabdhastrividho mṛtpāṣāṇasthāvaralakṣaṇaḥ / tatra bhūpradeśāḥ prākāreṣṭakādayo mṛdvikārāḥ / pāṣāṇā upalamaṇivajrādayaḥ / sthāvarā vṛkṣatṛṇauṣadhigulmalatāvatānavanaspataya iti /PDhS
analyzed: viṣayaḥ tu dvi aṇuka ādi prakrameṇa ārabdhaḥ trividhaḥ mṛd pāṣāṇa sthāvara lakṣaṇaḥ tatra bhū pradeśāḥ prākāra iṣṭakā ādayaḥ mṛd vikārāḥ pāṣāṇāḥ upala maṇi vajra ādayaḥ sthāvarāḥ vṛkṣa tṛṇa oṣadhi gulma latā avatāna vanaspatayaḥ iti pdhs
translated: The object is produced in three ways, beginning with two atoms, characterized by clay, stone, and plants. Among them, the clay products are the regions of earth, such as walls and bricks. The stones are pebbles, gems, diamonds, etc. The plants are trees, grass, herbs, shrubs, vines, creepers, and forest trees.

original: rūpādayo hi asādhāraṇatvād bhedakā iti pratijñātārthasamarthanārthamasādhāraṇatvamāha kṣitāveva gandhaḥ ityādi / athodake tejasi vopalambhād gandhasyāvadhāraṇamanupapannam / na / saṃyuktasamavāyenopalambhāt / tathā hi / udake vāsakadravyasamparkād gandhābhivyaktirdṛṣṭā / tejasi vā indhanaviśeṣānuvidhānāditi / yadi punaḥ svabhāvata eva syād gandhastejasīndhanaviśeṣaṃ vinā / vāsakadravyasamparkañca vinā vāriṇyupalabhyeta / na caivam / ato yuktametat kṣitāveka gandha iti /
analyzed: rūpa ādayaḥ hi asādhāraṇa tvāt bhedakāḥ iti pratijñāta artha samarthana artham asādhāraṇa tvam āha kṣitau eva gandhaḥ ityādi atha udake tejasi vā upalambhāt gandhasya avadhāraṇam anupapannam na saṃyukta samavāyena upalambhāt tathā hi udake vāsaka dravya samparkāt gandha abhivyaktiḥ dṛṣṭā tejasi vā indhana viśeṣa anuvidhānāt iti yadi punar svabhāvataḥ eva syāt gandhaḥ tejasi indhana viśeṣam vinā vāsaka dravya samparkam ca vinā vāriṇi upalabhy
translated: For color etc. are the causes of distinction because they are not common. To support the proposition, he states their non-commonality, saying Smell exists only on earth etc. But if smell is perceived in water or fire, the restriction is illogical. No, because it is perceived through conjunction-inherence. Thus, in water, the manifestation of smell is seen through contact with fragrant substances. Or in fire, it is due to the control of specific fuel. If smell were natural, it would be perceived in fire without specific fuel and in water without contact with fragrant substances. But it is not so. Therefore, it is logical to say that smell exists only on earth.

original: rūpaṃ śuklādyanekaprakāraṃ kṣitāveva / nodake na tejasi / niyamena śuklamevodake bhāsvarañca tejasyupalabhyate / pṛthivyāntvanekaprakāram / tathā hi paṭādibhedabhinnatvāt pṛthivyāḥ kācicchuklā kāciddharitetyupalambhaḥ /
analyzed: rūpam śukla ādi aneka prakāram kṣitau eva na udake na tejasi niyamena śuklam eva udake bhāsvaram ca tejasi upalabhyate pṛthivyān tu aneka prakāram tathā hi paṭa ādi bheda bhinna tvāt pṛthivyāḥ kācid śuklā kācid haritā iti upalambhaḥ
translated: Color, of various types such as white etc., exists only on earth, not in water or fire. In water, only white is perceived, and in fire, only shining. But on earth, various types are perceived. Thus, because earth is differentiated by cloth etc., some is white, some is green, etc.

original: nanu yuktaṃ vyaktibhedāpekṣayānekarūpasambandhitvaṃ pṛthivyāḥ / yā tu golakarūpā na tasyāmanekaprakāram / atha tatrāpi kecid bhāgāḥ śuklāḥ / kecit kṛṣṇā ityādyupalambhād anekarūpasambandhitvam / na / avayavāvayavinoranyatvād avayavānāmanekarūpasambandhitve kathamavayavinastathābhāvaḥ / abhyupagame vā sūtravyāghātaḥ / avibhuni dravye samānendriyagrāhyāṇāṃ viśeṣaguṇānāmasambhavāt luptaṃ vai / sū / iti vyāhanyeteti /
analyzed: nanu yuktam vyakti bheda apekṣayā aneka rūpa sambandhi tvam pṛthivyāḥ yā tu golaka rūpā na tasyām aneka prakāram  atha tatra api kecid bhāgāḥ śuklāḥ kecid kṛṣṇāḥ ityādi upalambhāt aneka rūpa sambandhi tvam na avayava avayavinoḥ anyatvāt avayavānām aneka rūpa sambandhi tve katham avayavinaḥ tathābhāvaḥ abhyupagame vā sūtra vyāghātaḥ avibhuni dravye samāna indriya grāhyāṇām viśeṣa guṇānām asambhavāt luptam vai iti vyāhanyeta iti
translated: But it is proper for earth to be related to many forms in relation to the difference of individuals. But in the form of a globe, it does not have many kinds. If it is argued that even there, some parts are white, some are black, etc., and therefore it is related to many forms, it is not so. Because the parts and the whole are different, how can the whole have the same nature as the parts if the parts are related to many forms? Or if it is accepted, the aphorism is contradicted. Because it is said in the aphorism In an unextended substance, the impossibility of specific qualities that are grasped by the same sense faculty is lost. This is contradicted.

original: vyāpake hi dravye samānendriyagrāhyāṇāṃ bahūnāmapi sambhavo dṛṣṭo yathā śabdānāmākāśa iti tannirāsāya avibhugrahaṇam / tathā avibhuni dravye vibhinnendriyagrāhyāṇāṃ rūparasādīnāṃ sambhavāditi samānendriyagrāhyapadam / samānendriyagrāhyāṇāmapi saṃkhyādīnāṃ bahūnāmavibhuni dravye sambhavo dṛṣṭastadvyavacchedāya viśeṣagrahaṇam /
analyzed: vyāpake hi dravye samāna indriya grāhyāṇām bahūnām api sambhavaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ yathā śabdānām ākāśaḥ iti tad nirāsāya avibhu grahaṇam tathā avibhuni dravye vibhinna indriya grāhyāṇām rūpa rasa ādīnām sambhavāt iti samāna indriya grāhya padam samāna indriya grāhyāṇām api saṃkhyā ādīnām bahūnām avibhuni dravye sambhavaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ tad vyavacchedāya viśeṣa grahaṇam
translated: For in an all-pervading substance, many things are seen to exist that are apprehended by the same sense organ, just as sounds in space. To exclude that, the term 'non-pervading' is used. Similarly, in a non-pervading substance, many things are seen to exist that are apprehended by different sense organs, such as color, taste, etc. Therefore, the term 'apprehended by the same sense organ' is used. Even among things apprehended by the same sense organ, such as number, etc., many are seen to exist in a non-pervading substance. To exclude that, the term 'particular' is used.

original: ato bahūnāṃ rūpāṇāmekasyāṃ pṛthivyāmabhyupagame vyāghātaḥ / abhyupagamyāpi brūmaḥ śuklādīnāṃ bahūnāmekatra sadbhāve kimāśrayavyāpitvaṃ pradeśavartitvaṃ vā / āśrayavyāpitve satyekāvayavasahite 'pyavayavinyupalabdhe parāvayavāvaraṇe 'pyanekarūpaṃ gṛhyeta / āśrayavyāpitvādeva / atha pradeśavṛttitvam / tathāpi viśeṣaṇamāśrayavyāpitvamiti nirudhyate /
analyzed: atas bahūnām rūpāṇām ekasyām pṛthivyām abhyupagame vyāghātaḥ abhyupagamya api brūmaḥ śukla ādīnām bahūnām ekatra sadbhāve kim āśraya vyāpi tvam pradeśa varti tvam vā āśraya vyāpi tve sati eka avayava sahite pi avayavini upalabdhe para avayava āvaraṇe pi aneka rūpam gṛhyeta āśraya vyāpi tvāt eva atha pradeśa vṛtti tvam tathā api viśeṣaṇam āśraya vyāpi tvam iti nirudhyate
translated: Therefore, if many forms are accepted to exist in one earth, there is a contradiction. Even accepting it, we say that if many things like white, etc. exist in one place, do they pervade the substratum or occupy a part of it? If they pervade the substratum, then even when the composite is perceived along with one part, the many forms would be grasped even when the other parts are covered, because of the pervasiveness of the substratum. If they occupy a part, then also the qualification is said to be the pervasiveness of the substratum.

original: athaikaṃ citraṃ tad rūpamiti / yathā śuklaṃ pītamityādiviśeṣastathā citraṃ rūpaviśeṣa eva / atroktam /
analyzed: atha ekam citram tat rūpam iti yathā śuklam pītam iti ādi viśeṣaḥ tathā citram rūpa viśeṣaḥ eva atra uktam
translated: If it is said that one form is variegated, just as there are distinctions like white and yellow, in the same way variegated form is just a distinction of form. Here it is said:

original: citraṃ tadekamiti cedidaṃ citrataraṃ tataḥ / pra / vā / /
analyzed: citram tat ekam iti ced idam citrataram tatas pra vā
translated: If it is said that one form is variegated, this is even more variegated.

original: yadyekaṃ tat kathaṃ citraṃ citrañcedekatā katham /
analyzed: yadi ekam tat katham citram citram ced ekatā katham
translated: If it is one, how can it be variegated? If it is variegated, how can it be one?

original: ekaṃ citrañcetyatiśayenāścaryamiti / na parasparaviruddhānāṃ rūpāṇāmekarūpārambhakatvaṃ nyāyyam / samānarūpārambhakatvenopalambhāt śuklāt śuklamiti /
analyzed: ekam citram ca iti atiśayena āścaryam iti na paraspara viruddhānām rūpāṇām eka rūpa ārambhaka tvam nyāyyam samāna rūpa ārambhaka tvena upalambhāt śuklāt śuklam iti
translated: One and variegated - this is extremely surprising. It is not reasonable for mutually contradictory forms to produce one form, because they are perceived as producing the same form, like white from white.

original: atha pṛthivyāmapsu ca śuklādiviśeṣarūpamātramupalambhānyathānupapattyā niścīyate / anyathā hi nīrūpatvāccakṣurgrāhyatvaṃ na syāt / rūpavato dravyasya cakṣurgrāhyatvāditi / na cāvayavarūpādeva cakṣurviṣayatvam / anyarūpeṇānyasya cakṣurviṣayatve vāyorapi tathābhāvaprasaṅgāt / ataścakṣurviṣayatvād rūpamātraṃ kṣitāviti /
analyzed: atha pṛthivyām apsu ca śukla ādi viśeṣa rūpa mātram upalambha anyathā anupapattyā niścīyate anyathā hi nīrūpa tvāt cakṣuḥ grāhya tvam na syāt rūpavataḥ dravyasya cakṣuḥ grāhya tvāt iti na ca avayava rūpāt eva cakṣuḥ viṣaya tvam anya rūpeṇa anyasya cakṣuḥ viṣaya tve vāyoḥ api tathābhāva prasaṅgāt atas cakṣuḥ viṣaya tvāt rūpa mātram kṣitau iti
translated: If it is said that in earth and water, the mere form of distinctions like white is ascertained by the non-apprehension of anything else, otherwise, because of being formless, there would be no apprehensibility by the eye. Because a substance with form is apprehensible by the eye. And the apprehensibility by the eye is not due to the form of the parts alone. Because if one thing were apprehensible by the eye due to another form, then even air would be the same. And therefore, because of apprehensibility by the eye, there is mere form in earth.

original: nanvevamanekaprakāraṃ kṣiteḥ rūpamiti virudhyate / rūpamātrasya śuklādyantarbhāvābhāvāt / tathā hyanekaprakāraṃ śuklādibhedabhinnamityucyate / rūpamātrañca viśeṣarahitamiti virodhaḥ /
analyzed: nanu evam aneka prakāram kṣiteḥ rūpam iti virudhyate rūpa mātrasya śukla ādi antarbhāva abhāvāt tathā hi aneka prakāram śukla ādi bheda bhinnam iti ucyate rūpa mātram ca viśeṣa rahitam iti virodhaḥ
translated: But in that case, it is contradictory to say that the form of earth is of many kinds, because form alone is not included in white, etc. For it is said that form is differentiated by the many kinds of white, etc., and form alone is devoid of particularities, so there is a contradiction.

original: tadetat sarvamaviditārtham / śuklādyanekaprakārasya rūpasya kṣitāvabhyupagamāt / nanūktaṃ sūtravirodha iti / na / sūtrārthāparijñānāt / tathā ca sūtrasyārthaḥ / avibhunyavyāpake dravye samānendriyagrāhyāṇāṃ viśeṣaguṇānāmekākārāṇāmasambhava iti pratiṣedhaḥ / na tvanekaprakārāṇām / kathametat / anekākārasvarūpasya kṣitāvupalambhāt / tathā rasasya ṣaḍbhedasyeti /
analyzed: tat etat sarvam avidita artham śukla ādi aneka prakārasya rūpasya kṣitau abhyupagamāt nanu uktam sūtra virodhaḥ iti na sūtra artha aparijñānāt tathā ca sūtrasya arthaḥ avibhuni avyāpake dravye samāna indriya grāhyāṇām viśeṣa guṇānām eka ākārāṇām asambhavaḥ iti pratiṣedhaḥ na tu aneka prakārāṇām katham etat aneka ākāra svarūpasya kṣitau upalambhāt tathā rasasya ṣaṣ bhedasya iti
translated: But all this is unknown. Because the form of earth is accepted as having many kinds such as white, etc. But it was said that there is a contradiction with the sutra. No, because the meaning of the sutra is not understood. And the meaning of the sutra is this: The negation is that in an undivided, non-pervading substance, the particular qualities that are grasped by the same sense organ and are of one kind are impossible, but not those of many kinds. How is this? Because the form of earth is perceived to have many aspects. And so is the taste of six kinds.

original: arthaikākārāṇāṃ bahūnāṃ rūpāṇāṃ rasānāñcaikatra sadbhāvastasmānneṣyate / vaiyarthyāt / tathā hyekenaiva śuklarūpeṇa rūpapratyayasya janitatvād dvitīyasya vaiyarthyameva / tathā madhurarasena madhurapratyayasyeti /
analyzed: artha eka ākārāṇām bahūnām rūpāṇām rasānām ca ekatra sadbhāvaḥ tasmāt na iṣyate vaiyarthyāt tathā hi ekena eva śukla rūpeṇa rūpa pratyayasya janita tvāt dvitīyasya vaiyarthyam eva tathā madhura rasena madhura pratyayasya iti
translated: The presence of many forms and tastes having the same appearance as one thing is not accepted because it is useless. For, since the cognition of form is produced by just one white form, a second one is indeed useless. Similarly, by the sweet taste, [the cognition of sweetness is produced].

original: atha śuklādīnāmekasya sadbhāve kiṃ vyāpyavṛttitvam / utāvyāpyavṛttitvam ityuktam / tatrāvyāpyavṛttitve na virodhaḥ / śeṣāṇāmāśrayavyāpitvamevetyavadhāraṇānabhyupagamāt / ata evaikāvayavasahitasya paṭasyopalambhāt tadekarūpopalambho 'pi / āśrayavyāpitayā anekarūpāṇāmanupalambhāccitrapratibhāsābhāvaḥ /
analyzed: atha śukla ādīnām ekasya sadbhāve kim vyāpya vṛtti tvam uta avyāpya vṛtti tvam iti uktam tatra avyāpya vṛtti tve na virodhaḥ śeṣāṇām āśraya vyāpi tvam eva iti avadhāraṇa anabhyupagamāt atas eva eka avayava sahitasya paṭasya upalambhāt tad eka rūpa upalambhaḥ api āśraya vyāpi tayā aneka rūpāṇām anupalambhāt citra pratibhāsa abhāvaḥ
translated: Now, if one of the white etc. is present, is it pervading or not pervading? It is said that there is no contradiction if it is not pervading, because the restriction that the remaining [forms] are only pervading the substratum is not accepted. For this very reason, since a cloth together with one part is perceived, the perception of that single form is also due to pervading the substratum. Because of the non-perception of many forms, there is no appearance of a variegated [object].

original: atha kiṃ citrādutpadyate citram / athācitrāditi / citrādutpattyabhyupagame paṭakāraṇakāraṇeṣvapi citrapratibhāsaprasaṅgaḥ / athācitrādutpadyate / tadā hi ekarūpaḥ sarvatra citrarūpotpattiprasaṅgaḥ / naitad yuktam / nānārūpāṇi hi kāraṇāni nānārūpaṃ kāryamārabhanta ityupalabdham / na caivaṃ tatkāraṇakāraṇeṣu nānārūpāṇi santīti citrānutpādaḥ / na ca tantūnāṃ nīlādyanekarūpasambandhitvāt paṭe 'pyanekarūpārambhakatve kiñcid bādhakamasti / kāraṇaguṇapūrvaprakrameṇa tathāvidhasya rūpasyopādānāt / tathā hi / pratyekaṃ kāraṇeṣvavicitrādapi rūpānnīlānnīlaṃ pītātpītamiti yuktam / bhavatu caivaikaṃ citraṃ rūpaṃ nīlādirūpairekarūpārambhāt / yathā hi śuklādirviśeṣo rūpasya tathā citraṃ rūpādiviśeṣa eva / yadyapi śuklādiśabdairna vyapadiśyate tathāpi svaśabdena vyapadeśādastitvam /
analyzed: atha kim citrāt utpadyate citram atha a citrāt iti citrāt utpatti abhyupagame paṭa kāraṇa kāraṇeṣu api citra pratibhāsa prasaṅgaḥ atha a citrāt utpadyate tadā hi eka rūpaḥ sarvatra citra rūpa utpatti prasaṅgaḥ na etat yuktam nānā rūpāṇi hi kāraṇāni nānā rūpam kāryam ārabhante iti upalabdham na ca evam tad kāraṇa kāraṇeṣu nānā rūpāṇi santi iti citra anutpādaḥ na ca tantūnām nīla ādi aneka rūpa sambandhi tvāt paṭe pi aneka rūpa ārambhaka t
translated: Now, does a variegated [effect] arise from a variegated [cause], or from an unvariegated [cause]? If it is accepted that it arises from a variegated [cause], then it would follow absurdly that even in the causes of the causes of cloth, a variegated appearance would occur. But if it arises from an unvariegated [cause], then it would follow that everywhere, an unvariegated form would arise as a variegated form. This is not correct. It is observed that causes with various forms produce effects with various forms. And it is not so that in the causes of those [causes], various forms do not exist, so there is no arising of the variegated [effect]. And since the threads are related to many forms such as blue, there is nothing that obstructs the production of many forms even in the cloth. Because a form of that kind is produced by the quality of the cause, in the manner described earlier. Thus, it is reasonable that from each cause, even though the form is not variegated, blue arises from blue, and yellow from yellow. And let it be that the variegated [form] is indeed one, because the forms such as blue produce a single form. Just as whiteness, etc. are particularities of form, so too variegatedness is a particularity of form, etc.

original: atha viruddhānāṃ nīlādīnāṃ kathamekarūpārambhakatvam / yathā śuklānāmiti / yathā hi bahūni śuklarūpāṇi ekaṃ śuklarūpamārabhanta ityupalabdhaṃ tathā nīlādīnāmapi citrarūpārambhakatvaṃ dṛṣṭatvādabhyupagantavyam / atha citraśabdasya nānāparyāyatvād ekaṃ citrañca itīdameva citramāścaryamiti / tadasat / yathā nānārūpeṣu citravyapadeśaḥ citrāstantavo nīlādirūpasambandhinaḥ iti / tathā tadārabdhe 'pi paṭe citravyapadeśaḥ citraḥ paṭaḥ iti citraṃ rūpamasya iti / na cāvaśyaṃ nānārūpasambandhiṣvapi paṭādiṣu citravyapadeśo dṛṣṭaḥ / nānārūpaistu kāraṇairārabdhe 'vaśyaṃ bhavatīti /
analyzed: atha viruddhānām nīla ādīnām katham eka rūpa ārambhaka tvam yathā śuklānām iti yathā hi bahūni śukla rūpāṇi ekam śukla rūpam ārabhante iti upalabdham tathā nīla ādīnām api citra rūpa ārambhaka tvam dṛṣṭa tvāt abhyupagantavyam atha citra śabdasya nānā paryāya tvāt ekam citram ca iti idam eva citram āścaryam iti tat asat yathā nānā rūpeṣu citra vyapadeśaḥ citrāḥ tantavaḥ nīla ādi rūpa sambandhinaḥ iti tathā tad ārabdhe pi paṭe citra vyapadeśa
translated: Now, how can mutually contradictory things like blue, etc. produce a single form, just as white things do? Just as it is observed that many white forms produce a single white form, so the production of variegated forms by blue, etc. should be accepted as seen. If it is argued that the word variegated is a synonym for many and that there is only one variegated thing, this is itself the wonderful variegation. That is incorrect. Just as there is the designation variegated for many forms, saying The variegated threads are related to blue, etc. forms, similarly, there is the designation variegated for the cloth woven from them, saying The cloth is variegated. It has a variegated form. And it is not necessarily seen that the designation variegated applies to cloths, etc. that are related to many forms. But it definitely applies to what is produced by variegated causes.

original: athaikatvāccitrarūpasya ekāvayavasahite 'pyavayavinyupalabdhe śeṣāvayavāvaraṇe vicitrapratibhāsaḥ syāt / na / sahakāryabhāvāt / tathā hyavayaveṣu nānārūpopalambhasahakārīndriyamavayavini citrapratibhāsaṃ janayatītyanvayavyatirekābhyāmupalabdham / tena śeṣāvayavāvaraṇe tadrūpāṇāmagrahaṇādavayavini citrapratibhāsābhāvaḥ / na cāpratibhāsādekāntenāsattvaṃ sahakāryabhāvenāpyanupalambhāt /
analyzed: atha eka tvāt citra rūpasya eka avayava sahite pi avayavini upalabdhe śeṣa avayava āvaraṇe vicitra pratibhāsaḥ syāt na sahakāri abhāvāt tathā hi avayaveṣu nānā rūpa upalambha sahakāri indriyam avayavini citra pratibhāsam janayati iti anvaya vyatirekābhyām upalabdham tena śeṣa avayava āvaraṇe tad rūpāṇām agrahaṇāt avayavini citra pratibhāsa abhāvaḥ na ca apratibhāsāt ekāntena asattvam sahakāri abhāvena api anupalambhāt
translated: If, on the other hand, the variegated form is one, then even when the whole is perceived along with one part, there would be a variegated appearance in the remaining parts that are covered. No, because there is no cooperation. For it is observed by positive and negative concomitance that the sense organ, which is the cooperator in the perception of various forms in the parts, produces a variegated appearance in the whole. Therefore, when the remaining parts are covered, the forms of those parts are not grasped, so there is no variegated appearance in the whole. And mere non-appearance does not necessarily mean non-existence, because of non-apprehension even in the absence of cooperation.

original: yacca rūpamātramupalambhānyathānupapattyā jñāyata iti kaiściduktaṃ tatrāpi na doṣo vipratipadyamānasyānumānopanyāsāt / tathā hi / śuklādiviśeṣavyatiriktaṃ citraṃ rūpaṃ I / kṣitau vidyamānamapi vaijātyād yo na manyate taṃ pratyanumānaṃ kṣiterupalambhād rūpavattvaṃ vijñāyata iti / cakṣuṣopalambhācca / siddhe rūpavattve śuklādiśabdairvyapadeśāsambhavāccitraśabdenābhidhīyata iti siddham /
analyzed: yat ca rūpa mātram upalambha anyathā anupapattyā jñāyate iti kaiścid uktam tatra api na doṣaḥ vipratipadyamānasya anumāna upanyāsāt  tathā hi śukla ādi viśeṣa vyatiriktam citram rūpam kṣitau vidyamānam api vaijātyāt yaḥ na manyate tam prati anumānam kṣiteḥ upalambhāt rūpavat tvam vijñāyate iti cakṣuṣā upalambhāt ca siddhe rūpavat tve śukla ādi śabdaiḥ vyapadeśa asambhavāt citra śabdena abhidhīyate iti siddham
translated: And what is said by some that form alone is known by the impossibility of any other way of perceiving it, there also there is no fault, because a reasoning based on inference is stated for one who disagrees. Thus, it is an inference for one who does not think that variegated form, which is different from the particulars such as white, exists in earth, even though it is of a different kind. From the perception of earth, it is known that it has form. And from the perception of the eye. When the fact of having form is established, because it is impossible to designate it with words such as white, it is established that it is denoted by the word variegated.

original: etena raso vyākhyātaḥ / rasaḥ ṣaḍvidho madhurādiḥ kṣitāveva / vyaktibhedena ekasyāñca vyaktāviti / tathā caikasyāmapi harītakyāmupalabhyate ṣaḍvidho rasa iti / ata eva ṣaḍbhedasyānyatrānupalambhād itarebhyo bhedakatvam /
analyzed: etena rasaḥ vyākhyātaḥ rasaḥ ṣaḍvidhaḥ madhura ādiḥ kṣitau eva vyakti bhedena ekasyām ca vyaktau iti tathā ca ekasyām api harītakyām upalabhyate ṣaḍvidhaḥ rasaḥ iti atas eva ṣaṣ bhedasya anyatra anupalambhāt itarebhyaḥ bhedaka tvam
translated: By this, taste is explained. Taste is of six kinds, sweet and so on, and exists only in earth. And in one individual. And thus, in one individual amalaka fruit, the six kinds of taste are perceived. For this very reason, because the six kinds are not perceived elsewhere, it is different from the others.

original: tathā gandho dvividhaḥ surabhirasurabhiśca / ekasyāṃ pṛthivyāṃ vyaktibhedena ekasyāṃ ceti pūrvavat / atha surabhigandhābhāva evāsurabhiriti vyavahārasambhavād gandhasya dvaividhyamanupapannam / na / ubhayostīvratarādibhedabhinnatvāt / yathā hi surabhigandhe tīvratarādivyavahārastathā asurabhigandhe 'pīti / surabhigandhābhāve ca etannopapannam / abhāvasya niratiśayatvāditi /
analyzed: tathā gandhaḥ dvividhaḥ surabhiḥ asurabhiḥ ca ekasyām pṛthivyām vyakti bhedena ekasyām ca iti pūrvavat  atha surabhi gandha abhāvaḥ eva asurabhiḥ iti vyavahāra sambhavāt gandhasya dvaividhyam anupapannam na ubhayoḥ tīvratara ādi bheda bhinna tvāt yathā hi surabhi gandhe tīvratara ādi vyavahāraḥ tathā asurabhi gandhe pi iti surabhi gandha abhāve ca etat na upapannam abhāvasya niratiśaya tvāt iti
translated: Similarly, smell is of two kinds: fragrant and foul-smelling. It is in one earth, but with a difference in manifestation, as before. Now, since it is possible to have the convention that foul-smelling is simply the absence of fragrant smell, the twofold division of smell is not logically possible. No, because both are distinguished by differences such as being more intense, etc. Just as there is the convention of being more intense, etc. for fragrant smell, so also for foul-smelling smell. And this is not logically possible in the absence of fragrant smell. Because absence is without any distinction.

original: sparśo 'syāḥ pṛthivyā anuṣṇāśītatve sati pākajaḥ / anuṣṇa iti uṣṇasparśavyavacchedārtham / aśīta iti śītāt / pākaja iti vāyavīyāt / atha pākajo 'gnisaṃyogaja ityukte na vyabhicāro 'stīti kimarthamanuṣṇāśītagrahaṇamiti cet / svarūpakathanārtham /
analyzed: sparśaḥ syāḥ pṛthivyāḥ anuṣṇa aśīta tve sati pāka jaḥ anuṣṇaḥ iti uṣṇa sparśa vyavaccheda artham aśītaḥ iti śītāt pāka jaḥ iti vāyavīyāt atha pāka jaḥ gni saṃyoga jaḥ iti ukte na vyabhicāraḥ sti iti kimartham anuṣṇa aśīta grahaṇam iti ced svarūpa kathana artham
translated: Touch in this earth is produced by cooking, when not hot and not cold. The word not hot is for the purpose of excluding the hot touch. Not cold means from cold. Produced by cooking means from the air element. Now, if it is said that what is produced by cooking is produced by contact with fire, and there is no fallacy, why is not hot and not cold mentioned? For the purpose of stating the nature.

original: anye tu kila pākādagneruṣṇasparśo bhavatīti anuṣṇagrahaṇam / aśītagrahaṇameva tu svarūpārthamiti /
analyzed: anye tu kila pākāt agneḥ uṣṇa sparśaḥ bhavati iti anuṣṇa grahaṇam aśīta grahaṇam eva tu svarūpa artham iti
translated: But others say that the mention of not cold is for the sake of the nature of the object itself, while the mention of not hot is because the hot touch arises from cooking, like fire.

original: atha rūpādīnāmiva vailakṣaṇyāpratibhāsanānna pākajatvaṃ sparśasya / tanna / pratyakṣeṇa vailakṣaṇyāpratītāvapyanumānena pākajatvaprasiddheḥ / tathā ca pārthivasparśaḥ / pākajaḥ / pārthivaviśeṣaguṇatvāt / tadgatarūpādivaditi /
analyzed: atha rūpa ādīnām iva vailakṣaṇya apratibhāsanāt na pāka ja tvam sparśasya  tat na pratyakṣeṇa vailakṣaṇya apratītau api anumānena pāka ja tva prasiddheḥ tathā ca pārthiva sparśaḥ pāka jaḥ pārthiva viśeṣa guṇa tvāt tad gata rūpa ādi vat iti
translated: Now, if touch does not have the nature of being produced by cooking, because it does not appear as different like form etc., that is not so. Even though the difference is not perceived by perception, the fact that it is produced by cooking is established by inference. And thus, the touch of earth is produced by cooking, because it is a specific quality of earth, like its form etc. that exist in it.

original: nanvevaṃ sāmānyaguṇānāmapi pākajatvaprasaṅgaḥ pārthivaguṇatvād rūpavaditi / naitad yuktam / sāmānyaguṇānāṃ pakṣīkaraṇe 'gnisaṃyogenaivānekāntaḥ / tathā hi / pārthivaparamāṇāvagnisaṃyogo 'gnisaṃyogajo na bhavati pārthivaguṇaśceti / na caivaṃ pārthivaviśeṣaguṇatvaṃ vyabhicaratīti / sapakṣaikadeśe vartamānasyātyantaṃ vipakṣād vyāvṛttergamakatvameva / na ca pakṣe pratyakṣāgamābhyāṃ virudhyata iti na kālātyayāpadiṣṭaḥ / na ca prakaraṇasamaḥ tattvānupalabdheraprayojakatvāt / ataḥ pākajasparśādikāraṇatvād itarebhyo bhidyate pṛthivīti /
analyzed: nanu evam sāmānya guṇānām api pāka ja tva prasaṅgaḥ pārthiva guṇa tvāt rūpa vat iti na etat yuktam sāmānya guṇānām pakṣīkaraṇe gni saṃyogena eva anekāntaḥ tathā hi pārthiva paramāṇau agni saṃyogaḥ gni saṃyoga jaḥ na bhavati pārthiva guṇaḥ ca iti na ca evam pārthiva viśeṣa guṇa tvam vyabhicarati iti sapakṣa eka deśe vartamānasya atyantam vipakṣāt vyāvṛtteḥ gamaka tvam eva na ca pakṣe pratyakṣa āgamābhyām virudhyate iti na kāla atyay
translated: But in that case, it would follow that the general qualities also are produced by cooking, because they are qualities of earth, like color. This is not correct. If the general qualities are taken as the subject, there is inconclusiveness due to the contact with fire itself. For example, the contact of fire with an earth atom is not produced by the contact with fire, but is a quality of earth. And the being a particular quality of earth does not deviate from this. That which exists in part of the similar instance is completely excluded from the dissimilar instance, and is therefore a valid reason. And it is not contradicted by perception or scripture in the subject, so it is not fallacious due to lapse of time. And it is not similar to the context, because the non-apprehension of reality is not a reason. Therefore, earth is distinguished from the others by the reason of being the cause of the qualities produced by cooking, such as touch.

original: samānānāṃ bhāvaḥ sāmānyam bhedādhiṣṭhānamato bhedamāha sā tu dvividhā iti / sā tu pṛthivī dvividhā / kena rūpeṇetyāha nityā cānityā ca / nityā paramāṇulakṣaṇā paramāṇusvabhāvā / kāryalakṣaṇā kāryasvabhāvā tvanityeti bhedaḥ / bhede ca sati sāmānyalakṣaṇamupapadyata ityasambhavitvāśaṅkāvyudāsaḥ /
analyzed: samānānām bhāvaḥ sāmānyam bheda adhiṣṭhānam atas bhedam āha sā tu dvividhā iti sā tu pṛthivī dvividhā kena rūpeṇa iti āha nityā ca anityā ca nityā paramāṇu lakṣaṇā paramāṇu svabhāvā kārya lakṣaṇā kārya svabhāvā tu anityā iti bhedaḥ bhede ca sati sāmānya lakṣaṇam upapadyate iti asambhavi tva āśaṅkā vyudāsaḥ
translated: The universal is the nature of things that are similar. It is based on differences, therefore it speaks of difference. But that is of two kinds. That earth is of two kinds. By what form? It says: eternal and non-eternal. The eternal is characterized by atoms, having the nature of atoms. The non-eternal is characterized by effects, having the nature of effects. This is the difference. And when there is difference, the universal characteristic is possible. Thus the doubt of non-existence is removed.

original: sarvasya kāryasya vināśe samavāyikāraṇābhāvāt punarutpattirna syādityāśaṅkānirāsārthañca vākyam sā tu dvividhā nityā cānityā ca / anityāyāśca nāśe nityā punardvyaṇukādiprakrameṇa svargādau kāryamārabhata iti siddham /
analyzed: sarvasya kāryasya vināśe samavāyi kāraṇa abhāvāt punarutpattiḥ na syāt iti āśaṅkā nirāsa artham ca vākyam sā tu dvividhā nityā ca anityā ca  / anityāyāḥ ca nāśe nityā punar dvyaṇuka ādi prakrameṇa svarga ādau kāryam ārabhate iti siddham
translated: There would be no further production of all effects due to the absence of an inherent cause in destruction. To remove this doubt, the sentence But that is of two kinds, eternal and non-eternal is stated. And when the non-eternal is destroyed, the eternal again produces effects such as heaven through the process of dyads and so on. This is established.

original: kathaṃ punaḥ paramāṇusvabhāvā pṛthivī jñāyata ityāśaṅkyāha kāryalakṣaṇā / kāryeṇa lakṣyate jñāyata iti / tathā hi kāryaṃ samavāyikāraṇapūrvakaṃ tatkāraṇamapi anyasamavāyikāraṇajanyamiti yāvadādyaṃ kāryaṃ tadapi samavāyikāraṇajanyamiti / tajjanakāḥ paramāṇavaḥ / tathā kāryādalpaparimāṇaṃ samavāyikāraṇam / tasyāpyanyadalpaparimāṇamityādyaṃ kāryaṃ niratiśayāṇuparimāṇairārabdhamiti jñāyate /
analyzed: katham punar paramāṇu svabhāvā pṛthivī jñāyate iti āśaṅkya āha kārya lakṣaṇā kāryeṇa lakṣyate jñāyate iti tathā hi kāryam samavāyi kāraṇa pūrvakam tat kāraṇam api anya samavāyi kāraṇa janyam iti yāvat ādyam kāryam tat api samavāyi kāraṇa janyam iti tad janakāḥ paramāṇavaḥ tathā kāryāt alpa parimāṇam samavāyi kāraṇam tasya api anyat alpa parimāṇam iti ādyam kāryam niratiśaya aṇu parimāṇaiḥ ārabdham iti jñāyate
translated: How then is it known that earth has the nature of atoms? Suspecting this, he says: It is characterized by effect. It is known by effect. For thus, an effect has an inherent cause, that cause also is produced by another inherent cause, up to the first effect, that also is produced by an inherent cause. Those that produce it are atoms. Thus, an inherent cause of smaller dimension than the effect is known. That also has another of smaller dimension, up to the first effect, which is known to be produced by atoms of unsurpassed dimension.

original: atha tadavayavānāmapi paryavasānaṃ neṣyate nityakāraṇānabhyupagamāt / tarhi kāryasyākasmikasyāsambhavāt tatkāraṇe 'pyanyaṃ samavāyikāraṇamityanavasthāyāṃ kāryadravyasyālpatarādibhedo na syāt / tathā hi / alpakāraṇārabdhamalpaṃ bhūyaḥkāraṇārabdhaṃ mahad iti dṛṣṭam / na ca kāryadravyasya nityakāraṇānabhyupagamenānavasthāyāmetadupapadyate / sarvasyāpi anantakāraṇajanyatvāviśeṣāditi / yathā anantakāraṇairārabdhā golakarūpā pṛthivī tathā ghaṭādikāryamapītyekākāratāprasaṅgaḥ / na ca saṃkhyāpalaparimāṇairekākāratopalabdhā ghaṭāderbhinnaparimāṇatvāt bhinnapalatvācceti / tathā hi kiñciddhīnaṃ pañcapalamadhikatarañca daśapalaṃ samānakāraṇairārabdhaṃ bahubhiśceti vaicitryam / taccānavasthāyāṃ na syāt /
analyzed: atha tad avayavānām api paryavasānam na iṣyate nitya kāraṇa anabhyupagamāt tarhi kāryasya ākasmikasya asambhavāt tad kāraṇe pi anyam samavāyi kāraṇam iti anavasthāyām kārya dravyasya alpatara ādi bhedaḥ na syāt tathā hi alpa kāraṇa ārabdham alpam bhūyaḥ kāraṇa ārabdham mahat iti dṛṣṭam na ca kārya dravyasya nitya kāraṇa anabhyupagamena anavasthāyām etat upapadyate sarvasya api ananta kāraṇa janya tva aviśeṣāt iti yathā ananta kāraṇaiḥ ārabdhā
translated: If, on the other hand, the parts are not held to have an end, because of the non-acceptance of an eternal cause, then, since an effect without a cause is impossible, there must be another inherent cause even in that cause, and in the resulting infinite regress, there would be no difference of the effect-substance in terms of smallness, etc. For it is seen that what is produced from a small cause is small, and what is produced from a larger cause is large. And this is not possible in the case of the effect-substance, if there is an infinite regress due to the non-acceptance of an eternal cause, because everything would be equally produced from an infinite number of causes. Just as the earth in the form of a globe is produced from infinite causes, so too would the effect like a pot, etc., leading to the absurdity of all having the same form. And the pot, etc., are not perceived to have the same form in terms of number and measure, because they have different measures and different weights. For some are deficient in weight, some five palas, some more than ten palas, produced by many similar causes, and thus there is variety. And that would not be possible in the case of an infinite regress.

original: na ca nityānabhyupagame pralayāvasthāyāṃ sarvasya kāryadravyasya vināśe punarutpattirbhavet / abhāvasya samavāyikāraṇatvābhāvāditi / yathā ca pralayāvasthāyāṃ sambhavati tathā ca vakṣyāmo bhūtaparīkṣāyāmiti / ato nānavasthā vyāvartanīyā / paṭādikāraṇakāraṇānāmalpatarādibhāvenāvasthitānāmādikāryamabhyupagantavyam /
analyzed: na ca nitya anabhyupagame pralaya avasthāyām sarvasya kārya dravyasya vināśe punarutpattiḥ bhavet abhāvasya samavāyi kāraṇa tva abhāvāt iti yathā ca pralaya avasthāyām sambhavati tathā ca vakṣyāmaḥ bhūta parīkṣāyām iti atas nā anavasthā vyāvartanīyā paṭa ādi kāraṇa kāraṇānām alpatara ādi bhāvena avasthitānām ādi kāryam abhyupagantavyam
translated: And if the eternal is not admitted, then when all the products are destroyed at the time of dissolution, they could not be produced again; because an absence cannot be the material cause. And as to how it is possible at the time of dissolution, we shall explain in the chapter on the elements. Therefore, there is no regress to be refuted. The first product must be admitted to be produced from the causes of the cloth etc. existing in a smaller and smaller state.

original: tadādyaṃ kāryaṃ samavāyikāraṇajanyaṃ kāryatvāt / yad yat kāryaṃ tattat samavāyikāraṇajanyaṃ yathā paṭādi / tathā caitat kāryam / tasmāt samavāyikāraṇajanyamiti / I / na ca kāryatvamabhāvena vyabhicaratīti vācyam / svakāraṇasattāsambandharūpatvāt kāryatvasya / tathā ghaṭādikāraṇakāraṇeṣvalpatarādibhāvaḥ kvacid viśrāntastaratamaśabdavācyatvād mahāparimāṇavat / yatra viśrāntāste paramāṇava iti /
analyzed: tad ādyam kāryam samavāyi kāraṇa janyam kārya tvāt yat yat kāryam tat tat samavāyi kāraṇa janyam yathā paṭa ādi tathā ca etat kāryam tasmāt samavāyi kāraṇa janyam iti  / na ca kāryatvam abhāvena vyabhicarati iti vācyam sva kāraṇa sattā sambandha rūpa tvāt kārya tvasya tathā ghaṭa ādi kāraṇa kāraṇeṣu alpatara ādi bhāvaḥ kvacid viśrāntaḥ taratama śabda vācya tvāt mahā parimāṇa vat yatra viśrāntāḥ te paramāṇavaḥ iti
translated: That is the first effect, produced by an inherent cause, because it is an effect. Whatever is an effect is produced by an inherent cause, like a cloth, etc. And this is an effect. Therefore, it is produced by an inherent cause. It should not be said that the property of being an effect is fallacious with respect to non-existence, because the property of being an effect is of the nature of the relation of the existence of its cause. Similarly, the existence of the cause of a pot, etc., rests somewhere in the least, etc., because it is denoted by the words 'taratama'. Where they rest, those are atoms.

original: atha sāvayavāḥ paramāṇavo mūrtatvād ghaṭavat / ṣaṭkena yugapat sambadhyamānatvāt / tathā pūrvabhāgo 'parabhāga iti digupalakṣitairdeśairvyapadiśyamānatvāt / sāvayavakāryārambhakatvācca tantvādivaditi /
analyzed: atha sa avayavāḥ paramāṇavaḥ mūrta tvāt ghaṭa vat ṣaṭkena yugapad sambadhyamāna tvāt tathā para bhāgaḥ iti diś upalakṣitaiḥ deśaiḥ vyapadiśyamāna tvāt sa avayava kārya ārambhaka tvāt ca tantu ādi vat iti
translated: Now, atoms have parts, because they are corporeal, like a pot. Because they are connected simultaneously with six [other atoms], and because they are designated by directions indicated by space, such as 'the eastern part' and 'the western part', and because they produce effects with parts, like threads, etc.

original: sarvametadāśrayāsiddhaṃ paramāṇusadbhāvāsiddheḥ / atheṣyata eva paramāṇoḥ sadbhāvaḥ / tarhi paramāṇusadbhāvāvedakapramāṇasyābhyupagamāt tadviparītānumānaṃ nirviṣayatvādapramāṇamiti / abhedyāḥ paramāṇavaḥ pareṇābhyupagamāt tasyāniṣṭāpattiḥ kriyata iti prasaṅgasādhanam / tatra yadi pramāṇenābhyupagatāḥ pareṇa paramāṇavastasya prāmāṇyābhyupagame 'nutthānaṃ viparītānumānasya / athāpramāṇāt / evaṃ tarhi tasyāpramāṇatayā paramāṇusadbhāvo na sidhyatīti kimanumānopanyāsenāśrayāsiddhatāprasaṅgāt /
analyzed: sarvam etat āśraya asiddham paramāṇu sadbhāva asiddheḥ atha iṣyate eva paramāṇoḥ sadbhāvaḥ tarhi paramāṇu sadbhāva āvedaka pramāṇasya abhyupagamāt tad viparīta anumānam nirviṣaya tvāt apramāṇam iti abhedyāḥ paramāṇavaḥ pareṇa abhyupagamāt tasya aniṣṭa āpattiḥ kriyate iti prasaṅga sādhanam tatra yadi pramāṇena abhyupagatāḥ pareṇa paramāṇavaḥ tasya prāmāṇya abhyupagame nu tthānam viparīta anumānasya atha apramāṇāt evam tarhi tasy
translated: All this is based on an unreal substratum, because the existence of atoms is not established. But if the existence of atoms is accepted, then since the means of knowing the existence of atoms is accepted, the contrary inference has no object and is not a means of knowledge. The atoms are indivisible because they are accepted by the opponent. This is the reductio ad absurdum. If the atoms are accepted by the opponent as established by means of a means of knowledge, then the contrary inference does not arise because the means of knowledge is accepted. But if it is from a non-means of knowledge, then in that case, since that is not a means of knowledge, the existence of atoms is not established. So what is the use of stating an inference? Because of the possibility of the fallacy of the substratum being unreal.

original: tathā paramāṇavaḥ sāvayavāśceti pratijñāvākye padayorvirodhaḥ / tathā hi / paramāṇuśabdasya niratiśayāṇuvācitvam / sāvayavatve vā avayavāpekṣayādhikaparimāṇatvamiti virodhaḥ / na ca samānādhikaparimāṇatve samavāyikāraṇatvamiti tadavayavāḥ paramāṇavaḥ / teṣāmapi sāvayavatve tadavayavāḥ / teṣāmapi sāvayavatve tadavayavā ityanavasthāyāmuktaṃ dūṣaṇamalpatarādibhedānupapattiriti /
analyzed: tathā paramāṇavaḥ sa avayavāḥ ca iti pratijñā vākye padayoḥ virodhaḥ tathā hi paramāṇu śabdasya niratiśaya aṇu vāci tvam sāvayava tve vā avayava apekṣayā adhika parimāṇa tvam iti virodhaḥ na ca samāna adhika parimāṇa tve samavāyi kāraṇa tvam iti tad avayavāḥ paramāṇavaḥ teṣām api sāvayava tve tad avayavāḥ teṣām api sāvayava tve tad avayavāḥ iti anavasthāyām uktam dūṣaṇam alpatara ādi bheda anupapattiḥ iti
translated: Similarly, there is a contradiction between the two terms in the proposition that atoms have parts. For the word 'atom' means that which has no parts, while having parts means having a size greater than that of the parts. And if they have the same or greater size, they cannot be conjoined. Therefore, their parts are atoms. If they also have parts, their parts are atoms. If they also have parts, their parts are atoms. In this infinite regress, the fault mentioned is the impossibility of the distinctions of 'less', etc.

original: atha mā bhūdanavastheti niravayavāḥ paramāṇavo 'bhyupagamyante pramāṇataḥ / tarhi tena bādhyamānatvāt sāvayavatvānumānamapramāṇamiti /
analyzed: atha mā bhūt anavasthā iti niravayavāḥ paramāṇavaḥ bhyupagamyante pramāṇataḥ tarhi tena bādhyamāna tvāt sāvayava tva anumānam apramāṇam iti
translated: If it is accepted that atoms have no parts in order to avoid the infinite regress, then the inference of having parts is not a valid means of knowledge because it is contradicted by that valid means of knowledge.

original: atha niravayavatvādaṇūnāṃ ṣaṭkena yogo digdeśavyapadeśaśca na syāt / na / anyathāpi bhāvāt / tathā hi / saṃyogasyāvyāpyavṛttitayā pūrvottarādidigvyavasthite yugapat sambandhe 'pi na sāvayavatvam / evaṃ pūrvabhāgo 'parabhāga iti yadyasti vyapadeśaḥ so 'pi mukhye bādhakopapatterbhākto draṣṭavyaḥ / avyāpyavṛttisaṃyogādhāratvasāmānyāditi /
analyzed: atha niravayava tvāt aṇūnām ṣaṭkena yogaḥ diś deśa vyapadeśaḥ ca na syāt na anyathā api bhāvāt tathā hi saṃyogasya avyāpya vṛtti tayā pūrva uttara ādi diś vyavasthite yugapad sambandhe na sāvayavatvam evam para bhāgaḥ iti yadi asti vyapadeśaḥ saḥ pi mukhye bādhaka upapatteḥ bhāktaḥ draṣṭavyaḥ avyāpya vṛtti saṃyoga ādhāra tva sāmānyāt iti
translated: Now, if atoms are partless, there would be no contact with six [other atoms] and no designation of direction and place. No, because it exists in another way. For thus, since conjunction does not pervade, even when the connection with the east, west, etc. exists simultaneously, there is no partlessness. Similarly, if there is a designation as 'eastern part' and 'western part', that too should be seen as figurative, because it is established that the primary [meaning] is contradicted, due to the general nature of being the substratum of conjunction that does not pervade.

original: yacca sāvayavārambhakatvaṃ tatra /tacca yadi sahāvayavairārambhakatvaṃ tadasiddhaṃ niravayavatvāt /
analyzed: yat ca sa avayava ārambhaka tvam tatra tat ca yadi saha avayavaiḥ ārambhaka tvam tat asiddham niravayava tvāt
translated: And that which is the cause of the production of what has parts, if that is the cause of production along with the parts, that is unestablished because of partlessness.

original: atha sāvayavasya sadāvayavairvartiṣyamāṇasya kāryasya janakatvam / tadasiddham / paramāṇubhyāṃ dvyaṇukārambhāt / tathā hi / paramāṇavo dvyaṇukānyārabhante na svātmānam / I / nityatvāt / svātmani kriyāvirodhācceti / tantudṛṣṭānto 'pi sādhanavikalaḥ / te hi nāvayavasahitāḥ kāryamārabhante / nāpyavayavāsahitā iti sthitaṃ kāryeṇa /
analyzed: atha sa avayavasya sadā avayavaiḥ vartiṣyamāṇasya kāryasya janaka tvam tat asiddham paramāṇubhyām dvi aṇuka ārambhāt tathā hi paramāṇavaḥ dvi aṇukāni ārabhante na sva ātmānam nitya tvāt sva ātmani kriyā virodhāt ca iti tantu dṛṣṭāntaḥ sādhana vikalaḥ te hi na avayava sahitāḥ kāryam ārabhante na api avayava asahitāḥ iti sthitam kāryeṇa
translated: If, on the other hand, the effect is held to be produced by the entity with parts, while itself remaining as before, then that is not admitted; because the Dvyāṇuka (the binary compound) is produced out of the Atoms; that is, the Atoms produce the Dvyāṇuka, not themselves; because they are eternal; and also because any action on the eternal thing is a contradiction in terms. The instance of the yarns also is devoid of the probandum; because it has been already established that the yarns do not produce the cloth either with or without the parts.

original: lakṣyate nityā pṛthivīti / abhedavādinirāsārthañca sā dvividheti vākyam / tathā hi / pṛthivī pṛthivyantarād bhidyamānā kiṃ pṛthivīrūpatayā bhidyata utāpṛthivīrūpatayeti / pṛthivīrūpatayā pṛthivyantarād bhede tasyāḥ pṛthivītvaprasaṅgaḥ / athāpṛthivīrūpatayā bhidyate / yā tarhi bhidyate sā pṛthivī na syāt / athāvāntaraviśeṣasambandhād bhedaḥ / te 'pi yadi viśeṣāntarāt / anavasthā / athāntareṇa viśeṣaṃ viśeṣā bhidyante / pṛthivyāstathābhāvaprasaṅga ityuktaṃ dvaitavādinā /
analyzed: lakṣyate nityā pṛthivī iti abheda vādi nirāsa artham ca sā dvividhā iti vākyam tathā hi pṛthivī pṛthivī antarāt bhidyamānā kim pṛthivī rūpatayā bhidyate uta a pṛthivī rūpatayā iti pṛthivī rūpatayā pṛthivī antarāt bhede tasyāḥ pṛthivī tva prasaṅgaḥ atha a pṛthivī rūpatayā bhidyate yā tarhi bhidyate sā pṛthivī na syāt atha avāntara viśeṣa sambandhāt bhedaḥ te pi yadi viśeṣa antarāt anavasthā atha antareṇa viśeṣam viśeṣāḥ bhid
translated: The statement Earth is perceived as eternal is to refute the doctrine of non-difference. It is of two kinds, as follows. When earth is differentiated from another earth, is it differentiated as having the form of earth or as not having the form of earth? If it is differentiated as having the form of earth from another earth, then it would follow that it is earth. But if it is differentiated as not having the form of earth, then what is differentiated would not be earth. If the difference is due to the relation with a particular quality, and those qualities are also different from another quality, then there is an infinite regress. If the qualities are different from each other without a particular quality, then it would follow that earth is also like that. This has been stated by the proponent of duality.

original: bhedamāha sā ca dvividhā / nityā anityā ca nityā pṛthivī nīrūpatayā anityāto bhidyate 'nityā tu nityātaścetyavāntarabhedādeva bhedaḥ / atha teṣāmapi viśeṣāntarād bhedābhyupagame 'navasthetyuktam / tadasat / tatrāpyasādhāraṇadharmasyāsādhāraṇadharmād bhedābhyupagame 'pi jātiguṇakriyādirūpatayā ṣaṭsvevāntarbhāvādanavasthāyāmapyadoṣaḥ / vyāvṛttasvarūpaṃ padārthānāṃ nirvikalpakajñāne pratibhāsata ityuktottarametat /
analyzed: bhedam āha sā ca dvividhā nityā anityā ca nityā pṛthivī nīrūpatayā anityātaḥ bhidyate nityā tu nityātaḥ ca iti avāntarabhedāt eva bhedaḥ atha teṣām api viśeṣa antarāt bheda abhyupagame navasthā iti uktam tat asat tatra api asādhāraṇa dharmasya asādhāraṇa dharmāt bheda abhyupagame jāti guṇa kriyā ādi rūpatayā ṣaṭsu eva antarbhāvāt anavasthāyām api adoṣaḥ vyāvṛtta svarūpam padārthānām nirvikalpaka jñāne pratibhāsate iti ukta uttaram etat
translated: And that is said to be of two kinds, eternal and non-eternal. The eternal is different from the non-eternal in being formless. But the non-eternal is different from the eternal only by its own subdivisions. If it is said that even they are accepted as different by other distinctions, there is infinite regress. That is not so. Even there, when the uncommon property is accepted as different from the uncommon property, there is no infinite regress because it is included only in the six, such as class, quality, action, etc. This is answered by saying that the differentiated nature of things appears in non-conceptual cognition.

original: yad vā lakṣaṇena lakṣyamāṇasyaikānekatvopalabdheḥ saṃśaye sati tannirāsārthaṃ vākyam / sā tu dvividhā iti / naikatvamākāśasyeva iti vipratipattinirāsārtham /
analyzed: yat vā lakṣaṇena lakṣyamāṇasya eka anekatva upalabdheḥ saṃśaye sati tad nirāsa artham vākyam sā tu dvividhā iti na ekatvam ākāśasya iva iti vipratipatti nirāsa artham
translated: Or, since the characterized is perceived as one or many by the characteristic, when there is doubt, the sentence is for the purpose of refuting that. And that is said to be of two kinds. Not one, like space. This is for the purpose of refuting disagreement.

original: kāryalakṣaṇāyā dharmāntaraṃ nirūpayati sā ca sthairyādyavayavasanniveśaviśiṣṭā iti / sthirāyā bhāvaḥ sthairyam / tadādiryeṣāṃ mṛdutvakaṭhinatvādīnāṃ te sthairyādayaste cāvayavānāṃ sanniveśaśca racanāviśeṣastairviśiṣṭeti /
analyzed: kārya lakṣaṇāyāḥ dharma antaram nirūpayati sā ca sthairya ādi avayava sanniveśa viśiṣṭā iti sthirāyāḥ bhāvaḥ sthairyam tad ādiḥ yeṣām mṛdu tva kaṭhina tva ādīnām te sthairya ādayaḥ te ca avayavānām sanniveśaḥ ca racanā viśeṣaḥ taiḥ viśiṣṭā iti
translated: It is a different property from the characteristic of effect. And it is distinguished by the arrangement of parts such as stability, etc. The state of being stable is stability. Those beginning with that, such as softness, hardness, etc., are the stabilities, etc. And the arrangement of the parts is a particular configuration. It is distinguished by those.

original: gurutvavidhārakasyāsambhavāt sarvadā patanaṃ kṣitau vidyamānamapi pūrvaparabhāgādavadhāraṇānnopalabhyata iti digvāsasāṃ matam / tannirasyate / sthairyapadena sthairyaṃ sthiratvamapāta iti yāvat / yadi punaḥ pātaḥ syād gurutvātiśayena pātātiśayopalabdheḥ kṣiteratiśayena pātādupari kṣiptasya loṣṭāderbhūmisambandho na syāt / tathā hi / loṣṭasya yāvadupari gamanaṃ punarmandamāgamanaṃ tāvat kṣiteḥ śīghrapātitayā yojanaśatādivyavadhānaṃ syāditi sambandhābhāvaḥ / dṛṣṭastu sambandha iti jñāyate na patanaṃ kṣiteriti / ata eva apatanānyathānupapattyā jñāyate gurutvavidhārakaṃ kiñcidastīti / anyathā hi gurutvavidhārakābhāve pāto 'vaśyaṃ syāditi / sa tu na bhavatīti pratibandho 'numīyate / atra hi guruṇo dravyasya I / pratibandhakatve tasyāpi gurutvayogitayā pātaḥ syāditi vāyormahataḥ pratibandhakatvam / dṛṣṭaṃ hyalpīyaso 'pi vāyorupari parṇādivyavasthāpane gurutvavidhārakatvam / pṛthivīpratibandhakastvādisṛṣṭāvutpanno 'tiśayena mahān vāyuḥ pṛthivīmudakādisahitāṃ tṛṇamiva dhārayate /
analyzed: guru tva vidhārakasya asambhavāt sarvadā patanam kṣitau vidyamānam api pūrva para bhāgāt avadhāraṇāt na upalabhyate iti digvāsasām matam tat nirasyate sthairya padena sthairyam sthira tvam apātaḥ iti yāvat yadi punar pātaḥ syāt guru tva atiśayena pāta atiśaya upalabdheḥ kṣiteḥ atiśayena pātāt upari kṣiptasya loṣṭa ādeḥ bhūmi sambandhaḥ na syāt tathā hi loṣṭasya yāvat upari gamanam punar mandam āgamanam tāvat kṣiteḥ śīghra pāti tayā yojana śat
translated: The Digambara view is that the earth's downward motion, though always present due to the absence of a support for gravity, is not perceived due to the restriction of the prior and posterior parts. This is refuted. By the word stability, stability, firmness, and non-falling are meant. If there were falling, due to the excess of gravity, the excess of falling would be perceived. Due to the earth's excessive falling, a clod thrown upwards would not be connected with the ground. This is because the clod's upward motion and slow return would result in a separation of a hundred yojanas or more due to the earth's rapid falling. Thus there would be no connection. But connection is seen, so it is known that the earth does not fall. It is precisely because of the impossibility of non-falling that it is known that there is something that supports gravity. Otherwise, if there were no support for gravity, falling would necessarily occur. But this does not happen, so an obstruction is inferred. Here, the heavy

original: tathā sthairyam / pṛthivyā akṣaṇikatvamiti / kṣaṇikatvāpākaraṇārthañca sthairyagrahaṇam / yathā ca kṣaṇikatvaṃ na sambhavati tathā vakṣyāma iti /
analyzed: tathā sthairyam pṛthivyāḥ akṣaṇika tvam iti kṣaṇika tva apākaraṇa artham ca sthairya grahaṇam yathā ca kṣaṇika tvam na sambhavati tathā vakṣyāmaḥ iti
translated: Similarly, stability. The non-momentariness of earth. And the mention of stability is for the purpose of refuting momentariness. How momentariness is not possible, we will explain.

original: yetu niravayavāmakāryāñca pṛthivīṃ manyante tannirāsārthamavayavasanniveśaviśiṣṭeti / avayavā hi bhāgāste kṣitāvupalabhyante tatsanniveśo racanāviśeṣaḥ pratyakṣa iti / tathāvayavasanniveśaviśiṣṭatvācca kāryatvam / tathā hi / pṛthivī kāryā / avayavasanniveśaviśiṣṭatvāt / yad yadavayavasanniveśaviśiṣṭaṃ tattat kāryaṃ dṛṣṭam / yathā ghaṭādi / tathā cāvayavasanniveśaviśiṣṭā pṛthivī / tasmāt kāryeti /
analyzed: ye tu niravayavām akāryām ca pṛthivīm manyante tad nirāsa artham avayava sanniveśa viśiṣṭā iti avayavāḥ hi bhāgāḥ te kṣitau upalabhyante tad sanniveśaḥ racanā viśeṣaḥ pratyakṣaḥ iti tathā avayava sanniveśa viśiṣṭa tvāt ca kārya tvam tathā hi pṛthivī kāryā avayava sanniveśa viśiṣṭa tvāt yat yat avayava sanniveśa viśiṣṭam tat tat kāryam dṛṣṭam yathā ghaṭa ādi tathā ca avayava sanniveśa viśiṣṭā pṛthivī tasmāt kāryā iti
translated: But those who consider earth to be partless and non-composite, for the purpose of refuting them, [it is said] distinguished by the arrangement of parts. For parts are portions that are perceived in earth. The arrangement of those is a particular configuration that is perceptible. And because it is distinguished by the arrangement of parts, it is an effect. Thus, earth is an effect. Because it is distinguished by the arrangement of parts. Whatever is distinguished by the arrangement of parts is seen to be an effect, like a pot, etc. And earth is distinguished by the arrangement of parts in that way. Therefore, it is an effect.

original: nanu kāryatve 'pyavayavasanniveśaviśiṣṭatvānupalabdherbuddhyādāvityaprayojakatvādapramāṇamiti jaiminīyāḥ / tadasat / sapakṣaikadeśavṛttergamakatvābhyupagamāt / tathā hi / yad yadavayavasanniveśavat tattat kāryaṃ dṛṣṭam / na punaryad yat kāryaṃ tattadavayavasanniveśavaditi brūmaḥ / na ca sapakṣaikadeśe vartamānasyāgamakatvam / dhūmānumānasyāgamakatvaprasaṅgāt / tathā hi / yadi dhūmavattvaprayuktaṃ syādagnimattvam antareṇa dhūmavattvamagnimattvaṃ na bhavediti / atha viṣamavyāptikatvād yo yo dhūmavān sa so 'gnimānityeva vyāptiḥ / na punaryo yo 'gnimān sa sa dhūmavānityevam / tarhyavayavasanniveśavattvasyāpi sapakṣaikadeśe vartamānasya nāprayojakatvam /
analyzed: nanu kārya tve pi avayava sanniveśa viśiṣṭa tva anupalabdheḥ buddhi ādau iti aprayojaka tvāt apramāṇam iti jaiminīyāḥ tat asat sapakṣa eka deśa vṛtteḥ gamaka tva abhyupagamāt tathā hi yat yat avayava sanniveśavat tat tat kāryam dṛṣṭam na punar yat yat kāryam tat tat avayava sanniveśavat iti brūmaḥ na ca sapakṣa eka deśe vartamānasya agamaka tvam dhūma anumānasya agamaka tva prasaṅgāt tathā hi yadi dhūmavat tva prayuktam syāt agnimat tvam antareṇa dhūma
translated: The followers of Jaimini say that even if it is an effect, the reason because it has a particular arrangement of parts is not a valid proof, as it is not found in the similar instance like cognition etc., and hence is not a proper reason. This is not correct. Because we accept that a reason which is present in a part of the similar instance is also a valid reason. This is how it is. We say that whatever has a particular arrangement of parts is seen to be an effect, but we do not say that whatever is an effect has a particular arrangement of parts. And a reason which is present in a part of the similar instance is not an invalid reason. Otherwise, the inference of fire from smoke would also be an invalid reason. This is how it is. If the presence of fire were dependent on the presence of smoke, then the presence of smoke would not be possible without the presence of fire. If it is argued that the pervasion is uneven, and the pervasion is only that whatever has smoke has fire, but not that whatever has fire has smoke, then the reason because it has a particular arrangement of parts, which is present in a part of the similar instance, cannot be an invalid reason.

original: atha abhūtvā bhāvitvasyānupalabdherna kṣiteḥ kāryatvam / kimatra pratyakṣeṇānupalabdhiḥ / athābhūtvā bhāvitvasyānumānena vā / pratyakṣeṇānupalabdhau kasyacid ghaṭādau nopalabhyata ityakāryatāprasaṅgaḥ / atha tatrāpyabhūtvā bhāvitvamavayavasanniveśatvena jñāyata iti kṣitāvapyavayavasanniveśavattvenaivābhūtvā bhāvitvaṃ gamyata iti samānam / kāryatvena ca kartṛpūrvakatvaṃ gamyata iti vakṣyāmo bhūtaparīkṣāyām /
analyzed: atha a bhūtvā bhāvi tvasya anupalabdheḥ na kṣiteḥ kāryatvam  kim atra pratyakṣeṇa anupalabdhiḥ atha a bhūtvā bhāvi tvasya anumānena vā pratyakṣeṇa anupalabdhau kasyacid ghaṭa ādau na upalabhyate iti akārya tā prasaṅgaḥ atha tatra api a bhūtvā bhāvi tvam avayava sanniveśa tvena jñāyate iti kṣitau api avayava sanniveśa vat tvena eva a bhūtvā bhāvi tvam gamyate iti samānam kārya tvena ca kartṛ pūrvakatvam gamyate iti vakṣyāmaḥ bhūta parīkṣāyām
translated: If, on the other hand, the existence of an effect is not established because the existence of what did not exist before is not perceived, what is perceived here? Is it by perception or by inference? If it is by perception, then some pot, etc. is not perceived, so it would follow that it is not an effect. But if it is known there by the arrangement of parts that it exists after not having existed before, then the same is the case with the earth, for its existence after not having existed before is known by the arrangement of parts. And we will say in the examination of the elements that the existence of an effect is known by the existence of an agent.

original: tathā kāryalakṣaṇāyā dharmāntaramāha aparajātibahutvopetā iti / aparā tu jātiḥ pṛthivītvāpekṣayā ghaṭatvapaṭatvādirūpā / tasyā bahutvamaparisaṃkhyātatvam / tadupetā tadyukteti / na caivaṃ paramāṇulakṣaṇe 'tivailakṣaṇyam /
analyzed: tathā kārya lakṣaṇāyāḥ dharma antaram āha apara jāti bahutva upetā iti aparā tu jātiḥ pṛthivī tva apekṣayā ghaṭa tva paṭa tva ādi rūpā tasyāḥ bahu tvam aparisaṃkhyāta tvam tad upetā tad yuktā iti na ca evam paramāṇu lakṣaṇe ti vailakṣaṇyam
translated: Similarly, he states another characteristic of an effect, endowed with many other genera, where another genus is in the form of potness, clothness, etc. in relation to earthness, and its plurality is the fact that it is not enumerated. Endowed with that means connected with that. And thus there is no excessive difference in the definition of atoms.

original: tathā kāryalakṣaṇāyāḥ kāryaṃ nirūpayati śayanāsanādi / bhedenānekamupakāraṃ karotīti anekopakārakarī ca / yadevārthakriyākāri tadeva paramārthasat / arthakriyāviraho hyabhāvalakṣaṇamiti darśanasya sattāsambandhena sattābhyupagame 'pyabhyupagamavādena nirāsārthaṃ caitad bhavatīti /
analyzed: tathā kārya lakṣaṇāyāḥ kāryam nirūpayati śayana āsana ādi bhedena anekam upakāram karoti iti aneka upakāra karī ca  yat eva arthakriyā kāri tat eva paramārtha sat arthakriyā virahaḥ hi abhāva lakṣaṇam iti darśanasya sattā sambandhena sattā abhyupagame pi abhyupagama vādena nirāsa artham ca etat bhavati iti
translated: Similarly, it defines the characteristic of an effect as that which produces a bed, seat, etc., and which performs many benefits as different from each other. And that which performs many benefits is also that which is ultimately real, because the absence of the capacity for causal efficiency is the characteristic of non-existence. This is said in order to refute the view that even if existence is accepted as the relation of existence, it is refuted by the doctrine of acceptance.

original: pṛthivīkāryasyānantatvādaśakyaṃ tatparijñānaṃ mā bhūdityavāntarabhedena vaidharmyaṃ vīpsāyāṃ pratijñātamāha trividhañcāsyāḥ kāryam iti / yathā hyevaṃbhūto dharmaḥ kāryaparamāṇurūpatayā nityānityabhedaḥ / kāryarūpāyāñca sthairyādidharmayogo 'parajātibahutvañcāsyāḥ pṛthivyāstathā trividhañca kāryamiti kṣiteḥ kāryasyānantye 'pi śarīrādirūpeṇa parasparaṃ vyāvṛttātmatayā trividhāvasthitasya tattvajñānaviṣayatvam / tathā hi / śarīramindriyaṃ viṣaya iti saṃjñā yasya tat śarīrendriyaviṣayasaṃjñakam sarvaṃ kṣiteḥ kāryamiti jñeyam /
analyzed: pṛthivī kāryasya ananta tvāt aśakyam tad parijñānam mā bhūt iti avāntarabhedena vaidharmyam vīpsāyām pratijñātam āha trividham ca asyāḥ kāryam iti yathā hi evaṃbhūtaḥ dharmaḥ kārya paramāṇu rūpatayā nitya anitya bhedaḥ kārya rūpāyām ca sthairya ādi dharma yogaḥ para jāti bahu tvam ca asyāḥ pṛthivyāḥ tathā trividham ca kāryam iti kṣiteḥ kāryasya ānantye śarīra ādi rūpeṇa parasparam vyāvṛtta ātmatayā trividha avasthitasya tattva jñāna
translated: The knowledge of the infinite effects of earth is impossible, therefore, the author states the difference in the secondary divisions in the repetition of the promise, Its effect is threefold. Just as this kind of dharma is eternal and non-eternal due to the form of the atomic effect, and the earth, which has the form of an effect, possesses the qualities of stability etc. and has many other species, in the same way, Its effect is threefold. Even in the infinity of the effect of earth, the knowledge of reality is the object of the effect that exists in three states with a different nature in the form of the body etc. Indeed, that which has the designation of body, sense organ, and object is known as the body, sense organ, and object. It should be known that all the effects of earth are like that.

original: anye tvasyāḥ paramāṇulakṣaṇāyāstrividhaṃ kāryaṃ śarīrādirūpamiti manyante / vyavahitasyāpi idaṃśabdena kvacit parāmarśāditi /
analyzed: anye tu asyāḥ paramāṇu lakṣaṇāyāḥ trividham kāryam śarīra ādi rūpam iti manyante vyavahitasya api idaṃśabdena kvacid parāmarśāt iti
translated: Others, however, think that the threefold effect of this earth in the form of the body etc. has the characteristic of atoms, because sometimes the distant is referred to by the word this.

original: tatra śarīrasyetarasmād vaidharmyamāha śarīraṃ dvividham iti / viśeṣasya sāmānyāpekṣitvād viśeṣābhidhāne 'vaśyaṃ sāmānyalakṣaṇaṃ vidyamānamantevāsinohyatāmityūhanaśakteḥ saṃvardhanāya na sāmānyalakṣaṇamavocat / tathā hi / śarīrābhidhāne śarīratvaṃ śarīravyavahārakāraṇaṃ jñāyata eva lakṣaṇamiti / tathecchānuvidhāyikriyāśrayatvaṃ narte śarīrāt sambhavatīti śarīravacanādarthāllabhyata iti svaśabdenāvacanam / granthādau tu śarīrādidvāreṇetyativyāptyabhāvaḥ /
analyzed: tatra śarīrasya itarasmāt vaidharmyam āha śarīram dvividham iti viśeṣasya sāmānya apekṣi tvāt viśeṣa abhidhāne vaśyam sāmānya lakṣaṇam vidyamānam antevāsinā uhyatām iti ūhana śakteḥ saṃvardhanāya na sāmānya lakṣaṇam avocat tathā hi śarīra abhidhāne śarīra tvam śarīra vyavahāra kāraṇam jñāyate eva lakṣaṇam iti tathā icchā anuvidhāyi kriyā āśraya tvam na ṛte śarīrāt sambhavati iti śarīra vacanāt arthāt labhyate iti sva śabdena avacan
translated: There, he states the dissimilarity of the body from the other: The body is of two kinds. Since the particular requires the general, when the particular is mentioned, the existing general definition must be taught to the disciple for the purpose of enhancing his ability to understand. He did not state the general definition. For thus, when the body is mentioned, the body-ness, which is the cause of the usage of the word body, is understood to be the definition itself. Similarly, the substratum of action that conforms to desire cannot exist apart from the body. Therefore, it is understood by implication from the mention of the body. Hence, it is not stated by its own word. But at the beginning of the text, it is by way of the body etc., so there is no over-extension.

original: atha śarīratvaṃ sakalaśarīravyāpakatvād bhedāntarād vyāvṛtteśca yuktaṃ lakṣaṇam / na caivam icchānuvidhāyikriyāśrayatvam / tasya hi vipakṣād vyāvṛttasyāpi sataḥ pakṣe sarvatrāsambhavāt / tathā hi / mṛtādyavasthāyāmetanna sambhavatītyavyāpakam / atha jīvaccharīrasyaitallakṣaṇamiti cet / tanna / suptamūrchitādyavasthāyāmapyanupalabdheḥ / kathaṃ tarhīdaṃ lakṣaṇam / yogyatāśrayaṇāt / tathā hi / śarīramitarasmād bhidyate sākṣādicchānuvidhāyikriyāśrayayogyatvāt śarīratvasambandhācca / yastvevaṃ na bhavati na cāsau sākṣādicchānuvidhāyikriyāśrayayogyaḥ śarīratvayuktaśca yathendriyādiriti /
analyzed: atha śarīra tvam sakala śarīra vyāpaka tvāt bheda antarāt vyāvṛtteḥ ca yuktam lakṣaṇam na ca evam icchā anuvidhāyi kriyā āśraya tvam tasya hi vipakṣāt vyāvṛttasya api sataḥ pakṣe sarvatra asambhavāt tathā hi mṛta ādi avasthāyām etat na sambhavati iti avyāpakam atha jīvat śarīrasya etat lakṣaṇam iti ced tat na supta mūrchita ādi avasthāyām api anupalabdheḥ katham tarhi idam lakṣaṇam yogyatā āśrayaṇāt tathā hi śarīram itarasmāt bhidyate sāk
translated: If the definition of body is that it pervades the entire body and is distinguished from other differences, then it is appropriate. But the substratum of action that conforms to desire is not like this. Although it exists and is distinguished from the opposite, it is not possible everywhere in the subject. This is because it is not possible in the state of death and so on, so it is not pervasive. If it is argued that this is the definition of the living body, that is not so. Because it is not perceived even in the states of sleep, fainting, and so on. If so, then how is this definition? Because of the assumption of capability. This is because the body is directly distinguished from others by being capable of being the substratum of action that conforms to desire, and by being related to the nature of the body. But that which is not so, and is not capable of being the substratum of action that directly conforms to desire, and is not endowed with the nature of the body, such as the sense faculties and so on.

original: āmaraṇād yasya paṭutvāpaṭutvābhyāmindriyāṇāṃ paṭutvāpaṭutve taccharīramiti I / kecit / tathā hi / auṣadhopayogādapīndriyeṣu paṭutvaṃ sambhavatītyāmaraṇāditi padam / tathā cāvyādhitasya śarīrapaṭutvenāmaraṇamindriyapaṭutvaṃ dṛṣṭam / vyādhitasya tvauṣadhopayogena vyādhyupaśame śarīrapaṭutvādevendriyapaṭutvamiti paśyāmaḥ / śarīrasyāpaṭutvādevendriyeṣu ca kācakāmalādidoṣāḥ sambhavantīti tatpaṭutvena vyāvṛtta iti /
analyzed: āmaraṇāt yasya paṭu tva apaṭu tvābhyām indriyāṇām paṭu tva apaṭu tve tat śarīram iti kecid tathā hi auṣadha upayogāt api indriyeṣu paṭu tvam sambhavati iti āmaraṇāt iti padam tathā ca avyādhitasya śarīra paṭu tvena amaraṇam indriya paṭu tvam dṛṣṭam vyādhitasya tu auṣadha upayogena vyādhi upaśame śarīra paṭu tvāt eva indriya paṭu tvam iti paśyāmaḥ śarīrasya apaṭu tvāt eva indriyeṣu ca kāca kāmalā ādi doṣāḥ sambhavanti iti tad pa
translated: Some say that the body is that of which the senses are sharp or dull due to sharpness or dullness until death. Thus, sharpness of the senses is possible even through the use of medicine, so the word 'until death' is used. And thus, in the case of one who is not sick, sharpness of the senses is seen due to the sharpness of the body until death. But in the case of one who is sick, we see that sharpness of the senses is due to the sharpness of the body alone through the alleviation of the disease by the use of medicine. And since defects like cataract and jaundice are possible in the senses due to the dullness of the body alone, it is excluded by its sharpness.

original: pārthivantu śarīraṃ māṃsādyavayavajanyatve satyantyāvayavitvāditi draṣṭavyam / māṃsādyavayavajanyasyāpyaṅgyulyādeḥ śarīravyavahārāviṣayatvādityantyāvayavipadam / antyāvayavitvañcāśarīrasyāpi sambhāvyata iti māṃsādyavayavajanyapadam /
analyzed: pārthivantu śarīram māṃsa ādi avayava janya tve sati antya avayavi tvāt iti draṣṭavyam māṃsa ādi avayava janyasya api aṅgyulī ādeḥ śarīra vyavahāra aviṣaya tvāt iti antya avayavi padam antya avayavi tvam ca aśarīrasya api sambhāvyate iti māṃsa ādi avayava janya padam
translated: But the body should be seen as consisting of earth, because it is the ultimate composite, being produced from parts like flesh. The word 'ultimate composite' is used because even something produced from parts like flesh, such as a finger, is not the object of the convention of 'body'. And ultimacy is possible even in what is not a body, so the word 'produced from parts like flesh' is used.

translated: The division of the earth-element body characterized by the general characteristics is for the purpose of the specific characteristics. The body is of two kinds. By what form? Since the word womb is a synonym for cause, in order to avoid the fault of being causeless when that is negated, he says not dependent on semen and blood. That which is born from a cause other than semen and blood, not dependent on semen and blood, is not born from a womb. Of what? The bodies of gods and sages. The body of gods and sages is not born from a womb. But it is not only not born from a womb, because being born from a womb is also heard.
