translated: For, those who have such wonderful, excellent deeds are called thus. Due to their excellent deeds, their bodies are born from a womb. To avoid the mere negation of a cause, he says they are born from a womb, born from a cause. Then how are their bodies not born from a womb? He says they are not born from mother and father. The words mother and father are used figuratively to refer to blood and semen. Thus, excellent deeds are twofold: having the nature of Dharma and having the nature of non-Dharma. Among them, the bodies of divine sages are born from those having the nature of Dharma, and the bodies of small creatures and those undergoing punishment are born from those having the nature of non-Dharma. Small creatures are lice and so on. Bodies undergoing punishment are the bodies of hell beings. They are born from atoms accompanied by specific non-Dharma. Now, although the bodies of divine sages are born from specific Dharma, they are perceived as born from a womb by inference. For example, the bodies of divine sages are born from a womb because they are bodies, like our bodies. And that is not a valid means of knowledge because it is contradicted by scripture.

translated: And it is not possible for inference to be a means of valid knowledge in the domain of scripture by contradicting it. And it is proper for it to support scripture. For thus: The bodies of gods and sages are not born from a womb, because they are produced by excellent karma, like the body of a sharabha. Excellent karma in the form of non-virtue is in the body of a sharabha, but in the body of a god or sage it is in the form of virtue. Even though there is a difference, being produced by excellent karma is not distinguished in both cases. Therefore the example is not devoid of the means of knowledge.

translated: The womb-born is said to be born from the union of semen and blood. It is born from the union of semen and blood. Semen belongs to the father, and blood to the mother. At the time of their union, the enjoyer, due to the power of karma, becomes connected with the internal organ. From the union of semen and blood, a substance with a condensed form is produced. ... Then, due to the connection with the internal heat, action arises in the parts, depending on the impulse. After that, due to the separation, the conjunction that produces the substance is destroyed. Due to its destruction, the substance produced from it is destroyed. Again, from another contact with fire, the previous color and other properties cease. And from another, the production of the new color and other properties occurs. Thus, in the atoms produced by the ripening effect, action arises from the conjunction with the self, depending on unseen [forces]. It produces separation. From that, the previous conjunction ceases, and the subsequent conjunction produces the dyad. Thus, from the dyads, the triad is produced. In this way, the body is produced through the sequence of creation.

translated: And it cannot be said that the parts that have not begun the body, when they obtain the cooperating cause, produce another body, and when they obtain another cooperating cause, they produce another body. Because that would lead to the absurdity of the doctrine of the production of the produced. If it is accepted that having produced one substance, when it is not destroyed, it again becomes the producer of another substance, that is not correct. Because it would lead to the absurdity that all produced substances would exist in the atoms. Thus, a dyad is produced from two atoms. When it is not destroyed, it is again produced from those two together with another atom. It is again produced from those together with another atom. Thus there would be the absurdity of the coexistence of material substances in the same place. Thus, what is produced from two atoms exists in the atoms. What is produced again from those together with another exists in those and that. Therefore material substances would have the nature of being in the same place. translated: To avoid the fault of being a part of the effect, it is said that the effect produced by two cooperating atoms other than the two atoms exists in only one atom, and again that produced by those same atoms assisted by others exists in only one atom. Even so, the effect substance existing in one substance would be indestructible due to the absence of separation of the cause. Similarly, substance is non-substance, and substance is composed of many substances, this contradicts the statement. For this reason, substance is non-substance because there is no produced and producing substance. There is no producer of atoms, and space etc. are neither produced nor producers, thus eternal substance is non-substance. However, substance composed of many substances is produced by many substances, thus it is of two kinds: non-substance is eternal, and substance composed of many substances is produced, is an effect. And this is contradicted if one-substance is accepted as an effect substance.

translated: And it is not reasonable that one [atom] should be the cause of another by succession and simultaneity. translated: If they produce [effects] after considering the previously begun composite substance, then how can the previously begun composite substance, which is a conjoined cause, exist in the same substance? Many faults should be imagined in the case of the previous [atom] existing in itself, such as the impossibility of the cause of similar and dissimilar substances, etc. Similarly, if all composite substances exist in atoms, expressions like the cloth is in these threads and the mat is in these darbha grass would not be possible, because threads and so on would not be conjoined causes. And when the composite substance is destroyed, there would be no perception due to the non-production of an intermediate effect.

original: atha paramāṇubhiḥ pūrvapūrvasya kāryasyāvināśe satyuttarottarakāryārambhādanekaṃ kāryadravyamityantyasya vināśe pūrvapūrvasyāvasthānādanekakāryopalambha iti cet / nanvevaṃ tarhi kapālasaṃyogavināśe 'pi ghaṭasyāvināśaprasaṅgaḥ / tadavayavatadavayavasaṃyogavināśe I / ca tadavayavatadavayavānāṃ teṣāṃ samavāyitvābhāvena tatsaṃyogasyāsamavāyitvābhāvāditi / samavāyikāraṇavināśenāsamavāyikāraṇavināśena vā dravyasya vināśadarśanāt /
analyzed: atha paramāṇubhiḥ pūrva pūrvasya kāryasya avināśe sati uttara uttara kārya ārambhāt anekam kārya dravyam iti antyasya vināśe pūrva pūrvasya avasthānāt aneka kārya upalambhaḥ iti ced nanu evam tarhi kapāla saṃyoga vināśe ghaṭasya avināśa prasaṅgaḥ tad avayava tad avayava saṃyoga vināśe ca tad avayava tad avayavānām teṣām samavāyi tva abhāvena tad saṃyogasya asamavāyi tva abhāvāt iti samavāyi kāraṇa vināśena asamavāyi kāraṇa vināśena vā dravyas
translated: If it is argued that the effect is multiple because the subsequent effect is produced while the previous effect is not destroyed by the atoms, and when the last one is destroyed, the previous ones remain and the multiple effects are perceived, then in that case, even on the destruction of the conjunction of the potsherds, the destruction of the pot would not occur, because the conjunction of the parts of that is destroyed. And because the parts of that are not inhered in, their conjunction is not inhered in. Because the destruction of the substance is seen due to the destruction of the inherent cause or the non-inherent cause.

original: atha paramāṇāvutpannā kriyā saṃyogavināśadvāreṇa dravyavināśikeṣyate / tatra yadyādyadravyārambhake paramāṇāvutpannā kriyā vibhāgāt saṃyogavināśe sati dravyaṃ vināśayet tarhi pūrvapūrvasaṃyogasyottarottarasaṃyogasahakāritayā śeṣakāryotpattāvasamavāyikāraṇatvābhyupagamāt tadvināśe 'vaśyaṃ sakalakāryavināśa iti na kiñcit kāryamupalabhyeta /
analyzed: atha paramāṇau utpannā kriyā saṃyoga vināśa dvāreṇa dravya vināśikā iṣyate tatra yadi ādya dravya ārambhake paramāṇau utpannā kriyā vibhāgāt saṃyoga vināśe sati dravyam vināśayet tarhi pūrva pūrva saṃyogasya uttara uttara saṃyoga sahakāri tayā śeṣa kārya utpattau asamavāyi kāraṇa tva abhyupagamāt tad vināśe vaśyam sakala kārya vināśaḥ iti na kiñcid kāryam upalabhyeta
translated: If it is held that the action that has arisen in the atom destroys the substance by way of destroying the conjunction, then if the action that has arisen in the atom that is the cause of the first substance destroys the substance by the destruction of conjunction due to disjunction, then since the prior conjunction is accepted as the non-inherent cause in the production of the remaining effects through the cooperation of the subsequent conjunction, the destruction of that necessarily results in the destruction of all effects, so no effect would be perceived at all.

original: athāntyaparamāṇusaṃyogasya pūrvapūrvaparamāṇusaṃyogopacitasyaikakāryotpattāvasamavāyikāraṇatvamiti / tadvināśe tadārabdhasyaiva vināśādavāntarakāryasyopalambha eveti cet / nanvevamapi paramāṇusaṃyogasya vināśādupajāto ghaṭādināśo 'smadāderatīndriyaḥ syāt / yathā hyāpākanikṣipteṣu ghaṭeṣvagnisaṃyogād vināśaḥ paramāṇukriyādvāreṇeti / pratyakṣaśca kapālasaṃyogavināśād ghaṭasya vināśastena jñāyate kapālānāṃ samavāyitvamityalamativistareṇa /
analyzed: atha antya paramāṇu saṃyogasya pūrva pūrva paramāṇu saṃyoga upacitasya eka kārya utpattau asamavāyikāraṇa tvam iti tad vināśe tad ārabdhasya eva vināśāt avāntara kāryasya upalambhaḥ eva iti ced nanu evam api paramāṇu saṃyogasya vināśāt upajātaḥ ghaṭa ādi nāśaḥ smat ādeḥ atīndriyaḥ syāt  yathā hi āpāka nikṣipteṣu ghaṭeṣu agni saṃyogāt vināśaḥ paramāṇu kriyā dvāreṇa iti pratyakṣaḥ ca kapāla saṃyoga vināśāt ghaṭasya vinā
translated: If it be said that the conjunction of the ultimate atoms is the non-inherent cause of the production of one effect, which is accumulated by the conjunctions of the preceding ultimate atoms, and that the perception of the intermediate effect is due to the destruction of that [conjunction] alone, which is produced by the destruction of that [conjunction],—even so, the destruction of the jar, etc., which is produced by the destruction of the conjunction of the ultimate atoms, would be imperceptible to us, just as the destruction of the jars placed in a kiln is by the conjunction with fire through the action of the ultimate atoms. And the destruction of the jar is perceived by the destruction of the conjunction of the potsherds, which is perceptible. Therefore, it is known that the potsherds are inhering causes. Enough of this extensive [discussion].

original: ataḥ śarīre pratikṣaṇamāhāropayogānupayoge satyupacayāpacayaprapañcadarśanāt pūrvadravyanimittādutpannapākajairdvyaṇukādiprakrameṇa cotpattirvācyeti / yathā ca paramāṇuṣu pāko dvyaṇukādiprakrameṇa cotpattistathā vakṣyāmaḥ pākajotpattāviti /
analyzed: atas śarīre pratikṣaṇam āhāra upayoga anupayoge sati upacaya apacaya prapañca darśanāt pūrva dravya nimittāt utpanna pāka jaiḥ dvyaṇuka ādi prakrameṇa ca utpattiḥ vācyā iti yathā ca paramāṇuṣu pākaḥ dvyaṇuka ādi prakrameṇa ca utpattiḥ tathā vakṣyāmaḥ pāka ja utpattau iti
translated: Therefore, in the body, the production [of the body] should be explained as being produced by the preceding substances, by the modifications produced by cooking, in the process of binary compounds, etc., whether there is the use of food or not at every moment, because the expansion and contraction are seen. And how the cooking is in the ultimate atoms, and the production in the process of binary compounds, etc., we will explain in the section on the production of modifications produced by cooking.

original: idānīṃ śukraśoṇitasannipātajasyāpyavāntaravaidharmyamāha tad dvividhaṃ jarāyumaṇḍajañca iti / tathā hi / śarīraṃ garbhe pratikṣaṇaṃ pākajotpattinyāyenotpadyamānaṃ niṣkramaṇakāle jarāyuṇā veṣṭitatvājjarāyujam / aṇḍajaṃ mātṛśarīrānniḥsṛtamapi kiñcitkālamaṇḍodare pākajotpattinyāyenāveṣṭitamutpadyata ityaṇḍajam / keṣāṃ jarāyujamityāha mānuṣapaśumṛgāṇām iti / mānuṣāśca paśavaśca mṛgāśceti / paśuśabdena saṃgṛhītānāmapi mṛgaśabdenābhidhānam araṇyajatvāditi /

translated: Now he states the specific dissimilarities of that which is born from the combination of semen and blood: That is of two kinds: born from a womb and born from an egg. For example, the body, which is being produced in the womb by the principle of arising from cooking, is called born from a womb because it is enveloped by the amnion at the time of birth. The egg-born is born by the principle of arising from cooking, enveloped for some time in the egg, even after leaving the mother's body. It is called born from an egg. As to whose is born from a womb, he says of humans, animals, and deer. Humans, animals, and deer. Animals are included in the word animals, but are mentioned by the word deer because they are wild.

original: aṇḍajaṃ keṣāmityāha pakṣisarīsṛpāṇām iti / pakṣiṇaśca sarīsṛpāśceti pakṣisarīsṛpāḥ / teṣāmiti / sarīsṛpāḥ kuṭilaṃ sarpantīti sarpādayo rūḍhivaśācceti /

translated: To which he says 'birds and reptiles'. 'Birds' and 'reptiles' are birds and reptiles. 'Of them' means of reptiles. They crawl crookedly, so they are snakes and so on, by the power of popular etymology.

original: śarīrasya śarīrāt samānajātīyācca vaidharmyamabhidhāya indriyasya vaidharmyanirūpaṇārthamāha indriyaṃ gandhavyañjakam iti / tathendriyāṇāṃ nānātvāt tadvyāpi sāmānyalakṣaṇamarthāllabhyata eva / karaṇatvātīndriyatvadravyatvaniyatādhiṣṭhānavṛttitve satyaparokṣajñānajanakatvāditi / aparokṣajñānajanakatvaṃ karturātmanaḥ saṃbhavatīti tannirāsāya karaṇatvagrahaṇam / anindriyasya pradīpādeḥ karaṇatve satyaparokṣajñānajanakatvaṃ dṛṣṭamiti tannirākaraṇārthamatīndriyapadam / tathendriyārthasannikarṣaḥ karaṇatvātīndriyatve satyaparokṣajñānajanaka iti dravyatvapadam / tathā dikkālayoḥ sarvotpattimatāṃ nimittatvāt karaṇatvātīndriyatvadravyatve satyaparokṣajñānajanakatvamastīti niyatādhiṣṭhānavṛttitvapadam / dikkālayostu vyāpakatvena sakalakāryajanakatvena niyatādhiṣṭhānāsambhavāt / athātmāpi vyāpakatvādanena viśeṣaṇena vyavacchinna iti vyarthaṃ karaṇatvapadam / na / vyāpakasyāpi bhoktṛtvena śarīrādhiṣṭhānatvāt / ata indriyamitarasmād bhidyate karaṇatvātīndriyatvadravyatvaniyatādhiṣṭhānavṛttitve satyaparokṣajñānajanakatvāt / yastu na bhidyate na cāsāvuktasādhano yathā śarīrādiriti /
analyzed: śarīrasya śarīrāt samāna jātīyāt ca vaidharmyam abhidhāya indriyasya vaidharmya nirūpaṇa artham āha indriyam gandha vyañjakam iti tathā indriyāṇām nānātvāt tad vyāpi sāmānya lakṣaṇam arthāt labhyate eva karaṇa tva atīndriya tva dravya tva niyata adhiṣṭhāna vṛtti tve sati aparokṣa jñāna janaka tvāt iti aparokṣa jñāna janaka tvam kartuḥ ātmanaḥ saṃbhavati iti tad nirāsāya karaṇa tva grahaṇam anindriyasya pradīpa ādeḥ karaṇa tve sati aparok
translated: Having stated the dissimilarity of the body from another body and from a substance of the same class, he says The sense organ is the manifester of smell, in order to determine the dissimilarity of the sense organ. Similarly, because the sense organs are many, their general characteristic pervading them is understood from the object itself. It is defined as that which, being an instrument, imperceptible, a substance, and occurring in a restricted substratum, produces non-perceptual knowledge. The term instrument is used to exclude the possibility of the self, the agent, producing non-perceptual knowledge. The term imperceptible is used to exclude the lamp, which is an instrument but is seen to produce non-perceptual knowledge. Similarly, the term substance is used to exclude the contact of the sense organ and object, which is an instrument and imperceptible but produces non-perceptual knowledge. Similarly, space and time are the causes of all that is produced, and are instruments, imperceptible, and substances, but produce non-perceptual knowledge. Therefore, the term occurring in a restricted substratum is used.

original: sāmānyalakṣaṇalakṣitasya samānajātīyād bhedamāha indriyaṃ ghrāṇam indriyasāmānyalakṣaṇalakṣitatve sati gandhavyañjakatvāditarebhyo bhidyate / tathendriyaṃ gandhavyañjakamiti kāryeṇa sadbhāvaṃ darśayati / tathā hi / gandhopalabdhiḥ / karaṇakāryā / kriyātvāt / yā yā kriyā sā sā karaṇakāryā dṛṣṭā yathā cchidikriyā / tathā ceyaṃ kriyā / tasmāt karaṇakāryeti /
analyzed: sāmānya lakṣaṇa lakṣitasya samāna jātīyāt bhedam āha indriyam ghrāṇam indriya sāmānya lakṣaṇa lakṣita tve sati gandha vyañjaka tvāt itarebhyaḥ bhidyate tathā indriyam gandha vyañjakam iti kāryeṇa sadbhāvam darśayati tathā hi gandha upalabdhiḥ karaṇa kāryā kriyā tvāt yā yā kriyā sā sā karaṇa kāryā dṛṣṭā yathā chidi kriyā tathā ca iyam kriyā tasmāt karaṇa kāryā iti
translated: The sense organ of smell, characterized by the general characteristics of a sense organ, is distinguished from similar kinds by being the manifester of smell. Thus, by its effect, it shows its existence as a sense organ that manifests smell. For instance, the perception of smell is the effect of an instrument, because it is an action. Whatever action is seen to be the effect of an instrument, like the action of cutting, this action is also like that. Therefore, it is the effect of an instrument.

original: yacca gandhopalabdhisampādakaṃ karaṇaṃ tad ghrāṇam / tacca pārthivam / rūparasagandhasparśeṣu madhye niyamena gandhavyañjakatvāt / yad yad rūpādiṣu madhye niyamena gandhavyañjakaṃ tattat pārthivaṃ dṛṣṭaṃ yathā kastūrikādidravyam / tathā ca ghrāṇaṃ rūpādiṣu madhye niyamena gandhaprakāśakam / tasmāt pārthivamiti / nanu niyamena gandhavyañjakatvamasiddhaṃ gandhatvaguṇatvasattāderapi vyañjakatvādityato rūparasagandhasparśeṣu madhya iti viśeṣaṇam /
analyzed: yat ca gandha upalabdhi sampādakam karaṇam tat ghrāṇam tat ca pārthivam rūpa rasa gandha sparśeṣu madhye niyamena gandha vyañjaka tvāt yat yat rūpa ādiṣu madhye niyamena gandha vyañjakam tat tat pārthivam dṛṣṭam yathā kastūrikā ādi dravyam tathā ca ghrāṇam rūpa ādiṣu madhye niyamena gandha prakāśakam tasmāt pārthivam iti nanu niyamena gandha vyañjaka tvam asiddham gandha tva guṇa tva sattā ādeḥ api vyañjaka tvāt iti atas rūpa rasa gandha sparśeṣu madhye
translated: And that instrument which accomplishes the perception of smell is the nose, and that is of the earth element. Because it invariably manifests smell among form, taste, smell, and touch. Whatever invariably manifests smell among form etc. is seen to be of the earth element, like musk and other substances. And the nose invariably manifests smell among form etc. Therefore it is of the earth element. But the invariable manifestation of smell is not established, because smell, the quality of smell, existence, etc. also manifest. Therefore the qualification among form, taste, smell, and touch is added.

original: atha pārthivatvāviśeṣād ghrāṇaṃ gandhasyeva rūpādiprakāśakamapi syād rūpāderapi pārthivaguṇatvāt / saṃyuktasamavāyasya ca sambandhasyāviśeṣād / anyasya ca viśeṣahetorabhāvād ityata āha jalādyanabhibhūtaiḥ pārthivāvayavairārabdhaṃ ghrāṇam / ato gandhasyaiva prakāśakamiti / kathametajjñāyate kiñcijjalādinā sampṛktairanabhibhūtaiḥ pārthivāvayavaiI /rārambho ghrāṇasyeti / kāryaniyamāt / tathā ghrāṇasya vyāpārād gandhasyaivopalambho na rūpāderiti dṛṣṭam / na ca kāraṇaniyamaṃ vinā kāryaniyamaḥ sambhavatīti kiñcijjalādyasampṛktairutpādo jñāyate cādṛṣṭaviśeṣād gandhopalabdheḥ sampādakāt / anyathā hi ghrāṇavyāpārād gandhasyaivopalabdhirna bhavet / sā ca dṛṣṭā / ato jñāyate 'nyasya kāraṇatvāsambhavād viśiṣṭotpādo nimittam / sa cādṛṣṭavaśāt / adṛṣṭasya ca vyavasthākāraṇatvāditi / abhipretañcaitat sūtrakarturiti /
analyzed: atha pārthiva tva aviśeṣāt ghrāṇam gandhasya iva rūpa ādi prakāśakam api syāt rūpa ādeḥ api pārthiva guṇa tvāt saṃyukta samavāyasya ca sambandhasya aviśeṣāt anyasya ca viśeṣa hetoḥ abhāvāt iti atas āha jala ādi anabhibhūtaiḥ pārthiva avayavaiḥ ārabdham ghrāṇam atas gandhasya eva prakāśakam iti katham etat jñāyate kiñcid jala ādinā sampṛktaiḥ anabhibhūtaiḥ ghrāṇasya iti kārya niyamāt tathā ghrāṇasya vyāpārāt gandhasya eva upalambhaḥ
translated: Now, if it is argued that just as the nose perceives smell due to the non-distinction of earth, it would also perceive form etc. because form etc. are also qualities of earth, and because there is no distinction in the relation of inherence in conjunction, and because there is no other cause of distinction, then he says: The nose is produced from earth atoms that are not mixed with water etc. Therefore, it is the perceiver of smell alone. How is this known? That the nose is produced from earth atoms that are not mixed with water etc. to some extent? From the restriction of the effect. Thus, it is seen that the perception of smell alone, not of form etc., is due to the operation of the nose. And without the restriction of the cause, the restriction of the effect is not possible. Therefore, it is known that the production is from earth atoms that are not mixed with water etc. to some extent, due to the perception of smell from the unseen cause that assists. Otherwise, the perception of smell alone would not occur due to the operation of the nose. But that is seen. Therefore, it is known that due to the impossibility of being the cause of something else,

analyzed: yathā bhūyasām pārthiva avayavānām gandha upalabdhi sampādaka adṛṣṭa viśeṣa upagṛhītānām jala ādinā ca atiraskṛta vapuṣām ghrāṇa janaka tvam niyamena gandha upalabdheḥ jñāyate bhūyasām ca pārthiva avayavānām kāraṇa tva abhidhānāt alpīyasām api jala ādi avayavānām akāraṇa tvam labdham atas eva teṣām pārthiva avayavānām abhibhāvaka tvam tathā na param viśiṣṭa adṛṣṭa upagrahe sati īṣat jala avayava ādi sampṛktaiḥ ārambhāt gandha
translated: Just as the earth particles, which are the cause of the perception of smell, are held by a special unseen force, and their bodies are suppressed by water etc., their capacity to produce the nose is known by the definite perception of smell. And the non-causality of the smaller particles of water etc. is understood from the statement of the earth particles as the cause. For this very reason, those earth particles have the capacity to suppress. Similarly, in the case of the special unseen force, the smell itself is the illuminator due to the combination of water particles etc., because it has smell. Since the nose has the nature of earth, the presence of color etc. is also possible. Therefore, the superiority of having smell is intended. And due to the superiority of the inherent smell, even in the midst of color etc., despite the absence of any difference in conjunction and inherence, smell alone is the illuminator.

original: yadi vā kācideva pṛthivī gandhopalabdheḥ kāraṇam / na sarveti viśeṣaheturnāstītyukte vākyaṃ saṃbadhyate bhūyastvād gandhavattvācca gandhajñāne prakṛtiriti vai / sū / / / / gandhe jñaptiḥ jñānaṃ gandhaviṣayakajñānaṃ tasmin prakṛtiḥ kāraṇaṃ pṛthivī bhūyastvād vyākṛtād gandhavattvācceti /
analyzed: yadi vā kācid eva pṛthivī gandha upalabdheḥ kāraṇam na sarvā iti viśeṣa hetuḥ na asti iti ukte vākyam saṃbadhyate bhūyaḥ tvāt gandhavat tvāt ca gandha jñāne prakṛtiḥ iti vai
translated: Or, if some earth alone is the cause of the perception of smell, not all, then there is no special reason. When this is said, the sentence is connected: Because of abundance and because of possessing smell, earth is the natural cause of the knowledge of smell. The knowledge of smell is the cognition having smell as its object. In that, earth is the natural cause, because of abundance and because of possessing smell.

original: anyo vārthaḥ / gandhavattvānniyamena gandhopalabdheḥ kāraṇam / viśeṣaheturnāstītyukte vākyaṃ saṃbadhyaṃ ghrāṇam / tacca gandhavat pārthivatvāviśeṣāt / ghrāṇaṃ kuta ityāha bhūyastvāduktarūpāditi /
analyzed: anyaḥ vā arthaḥ gandhavat tvāt niyamena gandha upalabdheḥ kāraṇam viśeṣa hetuḥ na asti iti ukte vākyam saṃbadhyam ghrāṇam tat ca gandhavat pārthiva tva aviśeṣāt ghrāṇam kutas iti āha bhūyastvāt ukta rūpāt iti
translated: Another meaning: Because of possessing smell, it is the invariable cause of the perception of smell. When it is said that there is no special reason, the sentence is connected: The nose. And that possesses smell, because of the non-distinction of being earthy. When it is asked why the nose, it is said: Because of abundance, as stated.

original: anye tu jalādyasampṛktaiḥ śuddhaiḥ pārthivāvayavairārambho viśiṣṭādṛṣṭāpekṣaiḥ bhūyastvamiti manyante / tathā ca bhāṣyam jalādyanabhibhūtairasampṛktaiḥ kevalaiḥ pārthivāvayavairārabdhaṃ I / ghrāṇamiti / atra ceṣajjalādisamparke 'pyanabhibhavasya sambhavādasaṃpṛktairiti viśeṣaṇaṃ na budhyāmahe / na ca bhūyasāṃ bhāvo bhūyastvamityukte 'nyeṣāmatyantāsambhava upalabhyata ityalam /
analyzed: anye tu jala ādi asampṛktaiḥ śuddhaiḥ pārthiva avayavaiḥ ārambhaḥ viśiṣṭa adṛṣṭa apekṣaiḥ bhūyastvam iti manyante tathā ca bhāṣyam jala ādi anabhibhūtaiḥ asampṛktaiḥ kevalaiḥ pārthiva avayavaiḥ ārabdham ghrāṇam iti atra ceṣat jala ādi samparke pi anabhibhavasya sambhavāt asaṃpṛktaiḥ iti viśeṣaṇam na budhyāmahe na ca bhūyasām bhāvaḥ bhūyastvam iti ukte nyeṣām atyanta asambhavaḥ upalabhyate iti alam
translated: Others, however, think that it is produced by pure earth-atoms, not in contact with water, etc., and that it is predominant, in dependence on a special unseen force. And the Bhāṣya says: It is produced by earth-atoms alone, not in contact with water, etc., and not overwhelmed by them. Here, we do not understand the qualification not in contact because even when in contact with water, etc., there is still the possibility of non-overwhelm. And when it is said predominance of many, it is understood that the others are absolutely non-existent. Thus far.

original: indriyaṃ sarvaprāṇināṃ gandhavyañjakamiti sāmānyaviśeṣātmatayābhidhāya viṣayasvarūpanirūpaṇārthamāha viṣayastu dvyaṇukādiprakrameṇārabdhaḥ iti / nanu dvyaṇukādiprakrameṇārambhaḥ śarīrasyendriyasya cāstītyativyāpīdaṃ viṣayalakṣaṇamiti / naitadevam / śarīrendriyayorlakṣaṇābhidhānena viṣayād bhedasiddhau tadanyatve satīti viśeṣaṇalābhāt / tathā hi / śarīrendriyānyatve sati dvyaṇukādiprakrameṇārabdhatvād viṣayastasya hi viṣayabhāvopakārakatvāt / viṣayastūpabhogya indriyagrāhyo vāsmadādeḥ /
analyzed: indriyam sarva prāṇinām gandha vyañjakam iti sāmānya viśeṣa ātmatayā abhidhāya viṣaya svarūpa nirūpaṇa artham āha viṣayaḥ tu dvi aṇuka ādi prakrameṇa ārabdhaḥ iti nanu dvi aṇuka ādi prakrameṇa ārambhaḥ śarīrasya indriyasya ca asti iti ati vyāpi idam viṣaya lakṣaṇam iti na etat evam śarīra indriyayoḥ lakṣaṇa abhidhānena viṣayāt bheda siddhau tad anya tve sati iti viśeṣaṇa lābhāt tathā hi śarīra indriya anya tve sati dvi aṇuka ādi prak
translated: The sense organ is the manifester of smell for all living beings. Having stated this in terms of the general and specific natures, he says to define the nature of the object: The object is that which is produced by the process of two atoms and so on. But this definition of the object is too broad, since the body and the sense organ are also produced by the process of two atoms and so on. This is not so. When the definition of the body and sense organs is stated, their difference from the object is established, and the qualification being different from that is obtained. Thus, the object is that which is produced by the process of two atoms and so on, while being different from the body and sense organs, because it assists in the nature of an object. The object is either what is to be enjoyed or what is grasped by the sense organs for one like us.

original: atha tryaṇukaṃ dvyaṇukādiprakrameṇotpannaṃ śarīrendriyānyatve satyasmadādīndriyaṃ grāhyañca na bhavati iti / avyāpīdaṃ viṣayalakṣaṇamiti / dvyaṇukādiprakrameṇārabdha iti viśeṣaṇena vyavacchedāt / tathā hi / dvyaṇukamādiryasya prakramasyetyādigrahaṇaṃ tryaṇukasyāpyavarodhakamiti / asau dvyaṇukādiḥ sa cāsau prakramaśceti tenārabdho viṣayo dvyaṇukatryaṇukādiprakrameṇārabdha iti yāvat / tryaṇukantu dvyaṇukairārabdhaṃ dvyaṇukādiprakrameṇeti / tryaṇukānāntvaniyamenārambhakatvaṃ dvayorbahūnāñceti / tadārabdhasyendriyaviṣayatā sambhāvyata iti /
analyzed: atha tryaṇukam dvi aṇuka ādi prakrameṇa utpannam śarīra indriya anya tve sati asmat ādi indriyam grāhyam ca na bhavati iti avyāpi idam viṣaya lakṣaṇam iti dvyaṇuka ādi prakrameṇa ārabdhaḥ iti viśeṣaṇena vyavacchedāt tathā hi dvyaṇukam ādiḥ yasya prakramasya iti ādi grahaṇam tryaṇukasya api avarodhakam iti asau dvyaṇuka ādiḥ sa ca asau prakramaḥ ca iti tena ārabdhaḥ viṣayaḥ dvyaṇuka tryaṇuka ādi prakrameṇa ārabdhaḥ iti yāvat tryaṇukam tu
translated: Now, if the dyad is produced in the order of dyads, etc., and is different from the body and senses, it is not grasped by our senses. Thus, this definition of the object is not universal. Because it is excluded by the qualification produced in the order of dyads, etc. For thus, the word etc. in produced in the order of dyads, etc. includes the triad also. Thus, that which is produced in that order of dyads, etc. is the object, produced in the order of dyads, triads, etc. But the triad is produced by dyads in the order of dyads, etc. But for triads, the producing is irregular, by two or many. Thus, the possibility of being an object of the senses is inferred for what is produced by them.

original: viṣayasya ca sāmānyalakṣaṇalakṣitasyāpyavāntarabhedenānantyāt saṃgrahamāha trividhaḥ / kena rūpeṇa / mṛtpāṣāṇasthāvaralakṣaṇaḥ iti / mṛcca pāṣāṇaśca sthāvarāśceti lakṣaṇaṃ svabhāvo yasyāsau tathoktaḥ / svabhāvastu mṛdi mṛttvaṃ pāṣāṇeṣu pāṣāṇatvamiti /
analyzed: viṣayasya ca sāmānya lakṣaṇa lakṣitasya api avāntarabhedena ānantyāt saṃgraham āha trividhaḥ kena rūpeṇa mṛd pāṣāṇa sthāvara lakṣaṇaḥ iti mṛd ca pāṣāṇaḥ ca sthāvarāḥ ca iti lakṣaṇam svabhāvaḥ yasya asau tathā uktaḥ svabhāvaḥ tu mṛdi mṛd tvam pāṣāṇeṣu pāṣāṇa tvam iti
translated: And since the object, even when characterized by the general characteristics, is infinite due to its subdivisions, he states its inclusion as threefold. By what form? He says it is characterized by clay, stone, and immovables. That which has the characteristic of clay, stone, and immovables is said to be so. But the nature of clay is clayness in clay, and the nature of stone is stoneness in stone.

original: nanu mṛdādibhedena traividhyamanupapannam iṣṭakāderviṣayasyāsaṃgrahādityāśaṅkyāha tatra prākārāśceṣṭakāśca tadādayo ghaṭādayaste ca mṛdvikārā iti mṛcchabdena saṃgṛhītāḥ / vikārastu viśiṣṭaracanāpannāyā mṛdo 'gnisambandhāt paramāṇukriyādvāreṇa pūrvadravyavināśe śyāmādinivṛttāvutpannapākajairārambhādityucyante / tairutpannapākajairārabdhe 'pi mṛttvaṃ sāmānyaṃ na nivartata iti mṛcchabdenābhidhīyanta iti / pāṣāṇatvasāmānyayogino darśayati pāṣāṇā upalamaṇivajrādayaḥ iti / teṣāñca svarūpaṃ tacchāstraprasiddhalokaI /vyavahārato 'vagantavyam / sthāvaratvajātisambandhino darśayati sthāvarāstṛṇauṣadhivṛkṣagulmalatāvitānavanaspataya iti / tṛṇamubhayavādiprasiddham / oṣadhayaḥ phalapākāntā dhānyādayaḥ / vṛkṣāśca vṛkṣatvajātisambandhino 'śokādayaḥ / evaṃ gulmalatāvitānādiviśeṣo 'vagantavyaḥ / taduktam /
analyzed: nanu mṛd ādi bhedena traividhyam anupapannam iṣṭakā ādeḥ viṣayasya asaṃgrahāt iti āśaṅkya āha tatra prākārāḥ ca iṣṭakāḥ ca tad ādayaḥ ghaṭa ādayaḥ te ca mṛd vikārāḥ iti mṛd vikārāḥ iti mṛd vikārāḥ iti mṛd vikārāḥ iti mṛd vikārāḥ iti mṛd vikārāḥ iti mṛd vikārāḥ iti mṛd vikārāḥ iti mṛd vikārāḥ iti mṛd vikārāḥ iti mṛd vikārāḥ iti mṛd vikārāḥ iti mṛd vikārāḥ iti mṛd vikārāḥ iti mṛd vik
translated: But it is argued that the threefold division based on clay etc. is not proper, because bricks etc. are not included in the subject matter. Anticipating this doubt, he says: There, walls and bricks and so on, and pots and so on, and they are modifications of clay. By the word clay, they are included. But modification is said to be that which, when clay acquires a distinctive arrangement, is produced by the primary elements that are born from the contact of the clay with fire, through the action of the atoms, upon the destruction of the original substance, and the cessation of blackness etc. Even when produced by those born from cooking, the universal clay does not cease, and so they are denoted by the word clay. He shows those that are connected with the universal stone - stones, pebbles, diamonds and so on. And their nature should be understood from the well-known usage in the scriptures. He shows those that are related to the class immobile - immobiles, grass, herbs, trees, shrubs, creepers, vines, and forest trees. Grass is well-known to both parties. Herbs are grains and so on that end with fruit ripening.

original: oṣadhyaḥ phalapākāntā latāgulmāśca vīrudhaḥ /
analyzed: oṣadhyaḥ phala pāka antāḥ latā gulmāḥ ca vīrudhaḥ
translated: Herbs end with fruit-ripening, creepers and bushes are called virudhas.

original: phalī vanaspatirjñeyo vṛkṣāḥ puṣpaphalopagāḥ // /
analyzed: phalī vanaspatiḥ jñeyaḥ vṛkṣāḥ puṣpa phala upagāḥ
translated: A tree should be known as a vanaspatis bearing fruit, flowers and fruits.

original: iti /
analyzed: iti
translated: Thus.

original: aptvābhisambandhādāpaḥ / rūparasasparśadravatvasnehasaṃkhyāparimāṇapṛthaktvasaṃyogavibhāgaparatvāparatvagurutvasaṃskāravatyaśca / ete ca pūrvavat siddhāḥ / śuklamadhuraśītā eva rūparasasparśāḥ / sneho 'mbhasyeva sāṃsiddhikaṃ dravatvañca / tāstu pūrvavad dvividhā nityānityabhāvāt / kāryaṃ punastrividhaṃ śarīrendriyaviṣayasaṃjñakam / śarīramayonijameva dharmaviśeṣasahitebhya āpyebhyaḥ paramāṇubhyo jāyate varuṇaloke / pārthivāvayavopaṣṭambhādupabhogasamartham / indriyaṃ sarvaprāṇināṃ rasopalambhakamanyāvayavānabhibhūtairjalāvayavairārabdhaṃ rasanam / viṣayastu saritsamudrahimakarakādiriti /PDhS
analyzed: ap tva abhisambandhāt āpaḥ rūpa rasa sparśa drava tva sneha saṃkhyā parimāṇa pṛthaktva saṃyoga vibhāga para tva apara tva guru tva saṃskāravatyaḥ ca ete ca pūrvavat siddhāḥ śukla madhura śītāḥ eva rūpa rasa sparśāḥ snehaḥ mbhasi eva sāṃsiddhikam drava tvam ca  / tāḥ tu pūrvavat dvividhāḥ nitya anitya bhāvāt kāryam punar trividham śarīra indriya viṣaya saṃjñakam śarīram ayoni jam eva dharma viśeṣa sahitebhyaḥ āpyebhyaḥ paramāṇubhyaḥ j
translated: Water is so called because of its connection with fluidity. It possesses color, taste, touch, fluidity, viscosity, number, measure, separateness, conjunction, disjunction, priority, posteriority, weight, and inherence. These are established as before. The colors, tastes, and touches are white, sweet, and cold respectively. Viscosity and fluidity are natural in water. They are of two kinds as before, because of the distinction between eternal and non-eternal. The effect is of three kinds, called body, sense organ, and object. The body is born from water atoms endowed with special qualities, not produced from a womb, in the world of Varuna. It is capable of experiencing objects due to the support of earth particles. The sense organ is the tongue, which is produced by water particles that are not overwhelmed by other particles, and is the perceiver of taste for all living beings. The object is rivers, oceans, snow, hail, etc.

original: idānīmuddeśavata udakasya lakṣaṇaparīkṣārthamāha aptvābhisambandhāt ityādiprakaraṇam / aptvenābhisambandho 'ptvenābhilakṣitaḥ sambandhaḥ samavāyo lakṣaṇamiti / tathā hyāpa itarasmād bhidyante 'ptvābhisambandhāt / ye tu na bhidyante na te aptvābhisambaddhāḥ yathā kṣityādayaḥ / na ca tathāpaḥ / tasmād bhidyanta iti / vyavahāro vā sādhyate / vivādāspadībhūtadravyamāpa dravyaṃ ityevaṃ vyavahartavyamaptvābhisambandhāt / ye tvāpa ityevaṃ na vyavahriyante na te 'ptvābhisambaddhāḥ / yathā kṣityādayaḥ / na tathedam / tasmādāpa ityevaṃ vyavahartavyamiti / śeṣañca lakṣaṇasyākṣepapratisamādhānaṃ pṛthivyadhikāre jñeyam / evaṃ śabdārthanirūpaṇāya śakteratīndriyatvapratiṣedhārthañcāptvābhisambandhāditi vākyaṃ pūrvavadyojanīyam /
analyzed: idānīm uddeśavataḥ udakasya lakṣaṇa parīkṣā artham āha ap tva abhisambandhāt ityādi prakaraṇam sambandhaḥ samavāyaḥ lakṣaṇam iti tathā hi āpaḥ itarasmāt bhidyante p tva abhisambandhāt ye tu na bhidyante na te ap tva abhisambaddhāḥ yathā kṣiti ādayaḥ na ca tathā āpaḥ tasmāt bhidyante iti vyavahāraḥ vā sādhyate vivāda āspadībhūta dravyam āpa dravyam iti evam vyavahartavyam ap tva abhisambandhāt ye tu āpaḥ iti evam vyavahartavyam ap tva abhisambandh
translated: Now, for the purpose of examining the definition of water which has been stated, he begins the section with Because of the connection with water and so on. The connection with water, the connection characterized by water, the inherence is the definition. For thus, water is distinguished from the other by the connection with water. But those that are not distinguished are not connected with water, like earth and so on. And water is not like that. Therefore, it is distinguished. Or the usage is to be established. The substance which is the subject of dispute should be treated as water, thus because of the connection with water. But those that are not treated as water thus are not connected with water, like earth and so on. This is not like that. Therefore, it should be treated as water thus. And the objection and solution regarding the rest of the definition should be known in the section on earth. Thus, for the purpose of determining the meaning of the word and for the purpose of refuting the intangibility of the power, he says because of the connection with water and so on.

original: pūrvaṃ hi pṛthivyādīnāṃ navānāmapi samavāyikāraṇatvaṃ guṇatvaṃ kṣityudakātmanāṃ caturdaśaguṇavattvañcetyuktam / tatra keṣāmutpattau samavāyikāraṇatvam / kairguṇairguṇavattvam / I / ke vā caturdaśa guṇāḥ / kiṃ vā guṇātmakaṃ lakṣaṇamityāha rūparasasparśasnehasāṃsiddhikadravatvādisaṃskāraparyantā vidyante yāsāṃ tāstadvatya iti /
analyzed: pūrvam hi pṛthivī ādīnām navānām api samavāyi kāraṇa tvam guṇa tvam kṣiti udaka ātmanām caturdaśa guṇavat tvam ca iti uktam tatra keṣām utpattau samavāyi kāraṇa tvam kaiḥ guṇaiḥ guṇavat tvam ke vā caturdaśa guṇāḥ kim vā guṇa ātmakam lakṣaṇam iti āha rūpa rasa sparśa sneha sāṃsiddhika drava tva ādi saṃskāra paryantāḥ vidyante yāsām tāḥ tadvatyaḥ iti
translated: For it has been said before that earth and the other nine substances are inhering causes, that the four substances earth, water, fire and air have fourteen qualities, and that the fourteen qualities are color, taste, smell, touch, fluidity, viscidity, weight, mobility, sound, number, measure, separateness, conjunction and disjunction. Among these, in the production of which substances are they inhering causes? In which substances do they exist as qualities? What are the fourteen qualities? Or what is the definition of a quality? He says: Those in which color, taste, smell, touch, natural fluidity, etc., up to impressions exist, they have that.

original: ete ca pūrvavat iti guṇaviniveśādhikāre siddhāḥ / tathā hi / rūparasasparśavatya āpo dravāḥ snigdhāśca vai / sū / / / iti pañcaviśeṣaṇāḥ siddhāḥ / te cāsādhāraṇatvāditarasmād bhedakā ityasādhāraṇatāpratipādanārthamāha śuklamadhuraśītā eva rūparasasparśāḥ / sūtreṇa sāmānyaśabdenāpyarthādabhihitā iti / tathā hi / śuklameva hi rūpamabhāsvaramapsu / madhura eva rasaḥ / śīta eva sparśa iti /
analyzed: ete ca pūrvavat iti guṇa viniveśa adhikāre siddhāḥ tathā hi rūpa rasa sparśavatyaḥ āpaḥ dravāḥ snigdhāḥ ca vai iti pañca viśeṣaṇāḥ siddhāḥ te ca asādhāraṇa tvāt itarasmāt bhedakāḥ iti asādhāraṇa tā pratipādana artham āha śukla madhura śītāḥ eva rūpa rasa sparśāḥ sūtreṇa sāmānya śabdena api arthāt abhihitāḥ iti tathā hi śuklam eva hi rūpam abhāsvaram apsu madhuraḥ eva rasaḥ śītaḥ eva sparśaḥ iti
translated: And these are established as before, in the section on the determination of qualities. Thus, the five qualifications of water are established: Water has form, taste, and touch, is fluid, and is cohesive. And these are distinguishing factors from other substances because of their uncommonness. To demonstrate their uncommonness, he says that form, taste, and touch are only white, sweet, and cold. Even though the general terms are used in the sutra, they are implicitly indicated. Thus, only white form, sweet taste, and cold touch are in water.

original: tathā sneho 'mbhasyeva sāṃsiddhikañca dravatvamambhasyevetyasādhāraṇatvameṣām / sāṃsiddhikamityagnisaṃyogānapekṣam / na tvākasmikam / kārye kāraṇaguṇapūrvakaṃ paramāṇuṣu ca nityamiti / saṃkhyādayastu pūrvavad vyākhyeyāḥ /
analyzed: tathā snehaḥ mbhasi eva sāṃsiddhikam ca drava tvam ambhasi eva iti asādhāraṇa tvam eṣām sāṃsiddhikam iti agni saṃyoga anapekṣam na tu ākasmikam kārye kāraṇa guṇa pūrvakam paramāṇuṣu ca nityam iti saṃkhyā ādayaḥ tu pūrvavat vyākhyeyāḥ
translated: Similarly, cohesion belongs only to water, and natural fluidity belongs only to water. Thus, they are uncommon. Natural means not dependent on contact with fire, but not accidental. In effects, the qualities of the cause precede, and in atoms, it is eternal. But number and so on should be explained as before.

original: evaṃ lakṣaṇena lakṣyamāṇasyaikānekatvopalabdhau saṃśaye sati tannirākaraṇārtham aptvasāmānyasya ca bhedādhiṣṭhānatvāditi tatsamarthanārtham / advaitavādī codakasyodakāntarād bhedaṃ na pratyeti tannirākaraṇārthaṃ sarvasya kāryadravyasya vināśe pralayāvasthāyāñca sargādau punarutpattirna syādabhāvād bhāvotpatterayogāditi bījapratipādanārthañca tāstu pūrvavad dvividhāḥ iti vākyaṃ vyākhyeyam / yathā hi pṛthivī paramāṇusvabhāvā nityā kāryalakṣaṇā tvanityā tadvadāpo 'pītyāha nityānityabhāvāt iti / nityatvādanityatvāccetyanena rūpeṇa dvaividhyamityavāntarabhedena vaidharmyaṃ darśayati / kāryantu satyapyānantye trividhamiti jñeyam / kena rūpeṇetyāha śarīramindriyaṃ viṣaya iti saṃjñā yasya tattathoktam /
analyzed: evam lakṣaṇena lakṣyamāṇasya eka anekatva upalabdhau saṃśaye sati tad nirākaraṇa artham ap tva sāmānyasya ca bheda adhiṣṭhāna tvāt iti tad samarthana artham advaita vādī ca udakasya udaka antarāt bhedam na pratyeti tad nirākaraṇa artham sarvasya kārya dravyasya vināśe pralaya avasthāyām ca sarga ādau punarutpattiḥ na syāt abhāvāt bhāva utpatteḥ ayogāt iti bīja pratipādana artham ca tāḥ tu pūrvavat dvividhāḥ iti vākyam vyākhyeyam yathā hi pṛthivī pa
translated: Thus, when the existence of one or many is doubted in what is characterized by such a definition, in order to refute that and to establish the general nature of water, because it is the basis of distinctions, and because the proponent of non-duality does not recognize the difference of water from another water, in order to refute that, and in order to establish that the origination of an existent from a non-existent is illogical, because of the absence of an existent at the time of dissolution and at the beginning of creation, the statement but they are of two kinds as before should be explained. Just as earth has the nature of atoms and is eternal, but has the characteristic of an effect and is non-eternal, so also water, he says, because of the existence of the eternal and non-eternal. By this, he shows the difference in the secondary divisions, that there are two kinds in the form of eternality and non-eternality. But it should be known that the effect, even though infinite, is of three kinds. By what form? He says, that which is known as body, sense organ, and object is said to be that.

original: śarīrasya ca sāmānyalakṣaṇaṃ pūrvoktamityutpattirevocyate śarīramayonijameva iti / na śukraśoṇitasannipātajamiti / tacca dharmaviśeṣasahitebhya āpyebhyaḥ paramāṇubhyo jāyate varuṇaloke prasiddhamāgamāditi / athāpyaṃ śarīraṃ dravatvādhikaraṇatayā na viśiṣṭopabhogāya kalpyata ityāha pārthivāvayavopaṣṭambhāccopabhogasamartham iti / tathā hyāpyāvayavāḥ samavāyikāraṇam / tatsaṃyogāścāsamavāyikāraṇam / pārthivāvayavāśca nimittakāraṇamiti / evaṃ taijasā vāyavīyāśceti /
analyzed: śarīrasya ca sāmānya lakṣaṇam pūrva uktam iti utpattiḥ eva ucyate śarīram ayoni jam eva iti na śukra śoṇita sannipāta jam iti  tat ca dharma viśeṣa sahitebhyaḥ āpyebhyaḥ paramāṇubhyaḥ jāyate varuṇa loke prasiddham āgamāt iti atha āpyam śarīram drava tva adhikaraṇa tayā na viśiṣṭa upabhogāya kalpyate iti āha pārthiva avayava upaṣṭambhāt ca upabhoga samartham iti tathā hi āpya avayavāḥ samavāyi kāraṇam tad saṃyogāḥ ca asamavāyi kāraṇam
translated: And the general characteristic of the body has been stated before, so only its origin is stated: the body is born from the elements, not from the union of semen and ovum. And that is produced from the atomic elements of water, along with specific properties, in the world of Varuna, as is well-known from the scriptures. Now, even if the watery body is not conceived for the sake of special enjoyment due to its predominance of fluidity, he says: and it is capable of enjoyment due to the support of the earth-particles. For thus, the watery particles are the inherent cause, and their conjunctions are the non-inherent cause, and the earth-particles are the instrumental cause. Similarly, the fiery, airy, etc.

original: nanu cāyuktametat / śarīrasya pāñcabhautikatvaśravaṇāt / tathā hi / gandhakledapākavyūhāvakāśadānebhyaḥ pāñcabhautikam nyā / sū / / / iti /
analyzed: nanu ca ayuktam etat śarīrasya pāñcabhautika tva śravaṇāt tathā hi gandha kleda pāka vyūha avakāśa dānebhyaḥ pāñcabhautikam iti
translated: But this is improper, because it is heard that the body is composed of the five elements. For thus: The body is composed of the five elements because of the presence of smell, moisture, cooking, expansion, and space, as stated in the Nyaya Sutra.

original: gandhopalabdheḥ kṣiteḥ kāraṇatvam / kledāccāpām / pākāttejasaḥ / vyūhācca racanāviśeṣād vāyoravakāśadātṛtvena cākāśasyeti pāñcabhautikatvamiti / taccāsat / vibhinnajātīyānāmekadravyotpattau samavāyitvasyādarśanāt / na ca vibhinnajātīyāvayaveṣu samavetaṃ śarīramupalabhyate / yadi ca pañcānāṃ samavāyitvaṃ syādevañca satyebhyaḥ kaḥ pārthivo 'nyastvāpyastaijasavāyavīyāsteṣu samavetaṃ śarīramupalabhyeta / na caivam / tathā vicitraguṇādhikaraṇatvāt samavāyikāraṇānāṃ kārye 'pi tadvaicitryaṃ syāt / evañca sati pārthivāvayave śuklādīnāmanyatamaṃ rūpam / pākajasparśaḥ syāt / āpyāvayave ca śuklameva rūpam / śīta eva sparśaḥ syāt / taijase bhāsvaraṃ rūpamuṣṇa eva sparśaḥ / vāyavīye cānuṣṇāśītatve satyapākajasparśaḥ syāditi / vicitrāvayavairārabdhatvāccharīraṃ vaicitryamupalabhyeta / na tūpalabhyate / tasmādayuktametat /
analyzed: gandha upalabdheḥ kṣiteḥ kāraṇa tvam kledāt ca apām pākāt tejasaḥ vyūhāt ca racanā viśeṣāt vāyoḥ avakāśa dātṛ tvena ca ākāśasya iti pāñcabhautika tvam iti tat ca asat vibhinna jātīyānām eka dravya utpattau samavāyi tvasya adarśanāt na ca vibhinna jātīya avayaveṣu samavetam śarīram upalabhyate yadi ca pañcānām samavāyi tvam syāt evam ca satyebhyaḥ kaḥ pārthivaḥ nyastvā āpyaḥ taijasa vāyavīyāḥ teṣu samavetam śarīram upalabhyeta na ca ev
translated: Earth is the cause of the perception of smell. Water is due to moisture. Fire is due to cooking. And space is due to expansion, i.e., to the particular arrangement of parts, by providing space. Thus, it is said to be composed of the five elements. But that is not correct. Because the inherence of things of different classes in a single substance is not seen. And the body is not perceived as inhering in parts of different classes. And if there were inherence of the five, then which part of earth would be different from water, fire, and air? The body would be perceived as inhering in them. But that is not so. And because the inherent causes have diverse properties, there would be diversity in the effect also. And in that case, in the earthy part, any one of the colors like white would be the color, and the touch produced by cooking would be there. And in the watery part, the color would be only white, and the touch would be only cold. And in the fiery part, the color would be luminous, and the touch would be only hot. And in the airy part, the touch would be neither hot nor cold.

original: athāvayavasyāpyanekabhūtairārambhaḥ / tathā hi / pārthivāpyābhyāṃ paramāṇubhyāṃ dvyaṇukam / punarāpyataijasābhyām / tathā taijasavāyavīyābhyāmārabdhamiti / evaṃ vāyuśabdatanmātrābhyām / etāni dvyaṇukānyutpannāni tryaṇukādiprakrameṇa śarīramārabhanta ityabhyupagame ca rūpādīnāmutpattirna bhavet / tathā hi guṇāśca guṇāntaramārabhante vai / sū / / / iti sūtreṇānekasya guṇasya guṇārambhakatvamuktam / evañca sati pārthivāpyābhyāmaṇubhyāmārabdhe dvyaṇuke gandhotpattirna syāt / tasya hyekatvenājanakatvāt / evamāpyataijasābhyāmārabdhe dvyaṇuke raso na syāt / tathā taijasavāyavīyābhyāmārabdhe dvyaṇuke rūpābhāvaḥ / tathā vāyuśabdatanmātrābhyāmārabdhe sparśābhāva iti / tadevaṃ gandharasarūpasparśānāṃ dvyaṇukeṣvabhāve tatkāryakāryeṣvapyabhāvāditi śarīre 'pyabhāvaprasaṅgaḥ /
analyzed: atha avayavasya api aneka bhūtaiḥ ārambhaḥ tathā hi pārthiva āpyābhyām paramāṇubhyām dvyaṇukam punar āpya taijasābhyām tathā taijasa vāyavīyābhyām ārabdham iti evam vāyu śabda tanmātrābhyām etāni dvyaṇukāni utpannāni tryaṇuka ādi prakrameṇa śarīram ārabhante iti abhyupagame ca rūpa ādīnām utpattiḥ na bhavet tathā hi guṇāḥ ca guṇa antaram ārabhante vai iti sūtreṇa anekasya guṇasya guṇa ārambhaka tvam uktam evañca sati pārthiva āpyābhyām
translated: Now, if even the parts are produced by many elements, then thus: a dyad is produced from earth and water atoms. Again, from water and fire. Similarly, that produced from fire and air atoms. Thus, from air and sound tanmātra. These dyads, when produced, produce the body in the sequence beginning with triads. And in this acceptance, the production of form and so on would not occur. Thus, qualities produce another quality. In the sūtra qualities produce another quality, the production of many qualities by a quality is stated. And in this case, in a dyad produced from earth and water atoms, the production of smell would not occur. Because it is not a producer due to being one. Similarly, in a dyad produced from water and fire atoms, taste would not occur. Similarly, in a dyad produced from fire and air atoms, there would be no form. Similarly, in one produced from air and sound tanmātra, there would be no touch. Thus, the production of smell, taste, form, and touch in a triad produced from a dyad and an earth atom would not occur.

original: etacca dvyātmakādiṣvapi samānam / tathā hi / pārthivāpyābhyāmārabdhe śarīre gandhānutpattiḥ / pārthivataijasābhyāmārabdhe gandharasānutpattiḥ / pārthivavāyavīyābhyāmārabdhe śarīre gandharasarūpānutpattiḥ / evaṃ pārthivākāśābhyāmārabdhe caturṇāmanutpattiriti /
analyzed: etat ca dvyātmaka ādiṣu api samānam tathā hi pārthiva āpyābhyām ārabdhe śarīre gandha anutpattiḥ pārthiva taijasābhyām ārabdhe gandha rasa anutpattiḥ pārthiva vāyavīyābhyām ārabdhe śarīre gandha rasa rūpa anutpattiḥ evam pārthiva ākāśābhyām ārabdhe caturṇām anutpattiḥ iti
translated: And this is the same in the case of the two-natured and so on. Thus, in a body composed of earth and water, there is no production of smell. In a body composed of earth and fire, there is no production of smell and taste. In a body composed of earth and air, there is no production of smell, taste, and form. Similarly, in a body composed of earth and space, there is no production of all four.

original: na ca dravyārambhakatvamākāśasyāmūrtatvāditi / mūrtasya hi sparśavato dravyasya dravyārambhakatvadarśanāt / evamaṇvāderapītarasahakāritvenārambhe dūṣaṇamūhyam /
analyzed: na ca dravya ārambhaka tvam ākāśasya amūrta tvāt iti mūrtasya hi sparśavataḥ dravyasya dravya ārambhaka tva darśanāt evam aṇu ādeḥ api itara sahakāri tvena ārambhe dūṣaṇam ūhyam
translated: And space does not cause the production of substances because it is immaterial. For the production of substances is seen only in the case of material substances with touch. Similarly, the fault in the production of the atom and so on by the cooperation of others should be inferred.

original: tathā trayāṇāṃ pṛthivyādīnāṃ caturṇāñcārambha iti pañcānāñca kāraṇatvamiṣyata iti pāñcabhautikatvamiṣṭam / samavāyitvañcaikasyaiveti / pārthive hi śarīre pārthivasyānyasminnanyasyeti / pārthive ca kledopalambhaḥ saṃyuktasamavāyena / pākastvāntarānalasaṃyogāt / sa ca nopalabhyata evendriyeṇa śarīre sarvadā / kevalantu guṇāntaraprādurbhāvāt pūrvaśarīranivṛttāvutpannapākajairārambhaḥ kalpyate / vyūhastvavayavaracanāviśeṣaḥ / sa tu vāyukāryo na bhavatyeva / avakāśadātṛtvañca mūrtadravyābhāvasyaivetyākāśasya na liṅgamityalam /
analyzed: tathā trayāṇām pṛthivī ādīnām caturṇām ca ārambhaḥ iti pañcānām ca kāraṇa tvam iṣyate iti pāñcabhautika tvam iṣṭam samavāyi tvam ca ekasya eva iti pārthive hi śarīre pārthivasya anyasmin anyasya iti pārthive ca kleda upalambhaḥ saṃyukta samavāyena pākaḥ tu āntara anala saṃyogāt sa ca na upalabhyate eva indriyeṇa śarīre sarvadā  / kevalam tu guṇa antara prādurbhāvāt pūrva śarīra nivṛttau utpanna pāka jaiḥ ārambhaḥ kalpyate vyūhaḥ tu av
translated: Similarly, the origination of the three, earth etc., and the four is accepted, so the five are accepted as causes, and hence the five-elementality is accepted. And inherence belongs to only one. For in an earthen body, of one that is earthen, in another of another. And the perception of moisture in an earthen body is by the conjunction of inherence. But cooking is by the internal contact with fire. And that is never perceived by the sense in the body at all times. But only the origination by the cooked products that have arisen from the cessation of the previous body is imagined due to the appearance of another quality. But arrangement is a particular arrangement of parts. But that is never the effect of air. And the giving of space is only the absence of a corporeal substance. So space is not the mark of the five elements. That is enough.

original: indriyasvarūpanirūpaṇārthamāha indriyañca rasavyañjakam iti / rasopalabdhiḥ karaṇakāryā / kriyātvāt / yā yā kriyā sā sā karaṇakāryā yathā chidikriyā / tathā ceyaṃ kriyā / tasmāt karaṇakāryeti / yacca rasopalabdhisampādakaṃ karaṇaṃ tadāpyam / tadrasanam / rūparasādiṣu madhye niyamena rasavyañjakatvāt / yad yad rūpādiṣu madhye niyamena rasavyañjakaṃ tattadāpyaṃ dṛṣṭaṃ yathā dantāntargatodakam / tathā caitat / tasmādāpyamiti / rasanavyāpārād rasatvādīnāmapi grahaṇasya sambhavādasambhavitvaṃ syāditi rūpādiṣu madhye iti padam / tathā hi / śuṣkakaṇṭhasya modakādiṣu rasopalabdhirnopalabdhā / udakasadbhāve tu rūpādiṣu madhye rasasyaikasyopalabdhiriti sapakṣe sattvam / anāpye caitanna sambhavatīti vipakṣād vyāvṛttiriti / tadetadasādhāraṇatvāditarasmād bhedakamapīti jñeyam /
analyzed: indriya svarūpa nirūpaṇa artham āha indriyam ca rasa vyañjakam iti rasa upalabdhiḥ karaṇa kāryā kriyā tvāt yā yā kriyā sā sā karaṇa kāryā yathā chidi kriyā tathā ca iyam kriyā tasmāt karaṇa kāryā iti yat ca rasa upalabdhi sampādakam karaṇam tat āpyam tat rasanam rūpa rasa ādiṣu madhye niyamena rasa vyañjaka tvāt yat yat rūpa ādiṣu madhye niyamena rasa vyañjakam tat tat āpyam dṛṣṭam yathā danta antargata udakam tathā ca etat tasmāt āpyam iti rasana v
translated: To define the nature of the sense organs, it is said: The sense organ is that which manifests taste. The perception of taste is the effect of the instrument, because it is an action. Whatever is an action is the effect of an instrument, like the action of cutting. And this is such an action. Therefore, it is the effect of an instrument. And that which is the instrument that accomplishes the perception of taste is also water. It is the tongue, because it invariably manifests taste among form, taste, etc. Whatever invariably manifests taste among form, etc. is seen to be water, like the water inside the teeth. And this is so. Therefore, it is water. Since the apprehension of taste, etc. is also possible from the operation of the tongue, it would not be impossible. Therefore, the words among form, etc. are used. For example, when the throat is dry, the perception of taste in sweets, etc. is not perceived. But when water is present, the perception of taste alone among form, etc. is perceived. Thus, it exists in similar instances. And this is not possible in what is not water. Therefore, it is water.

original: atha kasmāt kiñcidevāpyaṃ dravyaṃ rūpādiṣu madhye niyamena rasavyañjakamindriyañcetyāha anyāvayavānabhibhūtaiḥ / īṣatsampṛktairapi jalāvayavairārabdhaṃ rasanam iti rasasyaiva vyañjakamiti /
analyzed: atha kasmāt kiñcid eva āpyam dravyam rūpa ādiṣu madhye niyamena rasa vyañjakam indriyam ca iti āha anya avayava anabhibhūtaiḥ īṣat sampṛktaiḥ api jala avayavaiḥ ārabdham rasanam iti rasasya eva vyañjakam iti
translated: Now, why is it that only a certain substance, among color etc., is invariably the manifester of taste and the sense organ? He says: The organ of taste is produced by water particles that are not overwhelmed by other particles, even if slightly mixed. Thus, it is the manifester of taste alone.

original: anye tu anyāvayavānabhibhūtairasaṃpṛktaiḥ śuddhairjalāvayavairārabdham iti bruvate / bhūyastvādrasavattvāccodakaṃ rasajñāne prakṛtiḥ vai / sū / / iti / asya ca sūtrasyedaṃ bhāṣyam
analyzed: anye tu anya avayava anabhibhūtaiḥ asaṃpṛktaiḥ śuddhaiḥ jala avayavaiḥ ārabdham iti bruvate bhūyaḥ tvāt rasavat tvāt ca udakam rasa jñāne prakṛtiḥ vai iti asya ca sūtrasya idam bhāṣyam
translated: Others say it is produced by pure water particles that are not overwhelmed by other particles, not mixed. Water is the natural cause for the knowledge of taste, because it is predominant and has taste. This is the sutra. And this is the commentary on it:

original: bhūyastvāditi / bhūyasāmāpyāvayavānāṃ rasopalabdhiprāpakādṛṣṭāpekṣāṇāṃ saṃyoge satīṣaditarāvayavasamparke ca viśeṣotpāda upadiśyate / ata eva anyāvayavābhibhavānupapattiḥ / jalāvayavānāṃ bhūyastvāditareṣāñca alpatvāditi / rasavattvañca rasanendriyasya rasotkarṣaḥ / sāmānyaśabdenāpyartho 'nukta iti raso jñāyate 'neneti rasajñānamindriyam / I / tasminnutpādye prakṛtiḥ kāraṇamudakaṃ bhūyastvād vyākṛtānnimittāt / tasmādetadevendriyam / rūpādiṣu madhye niyamena rasaprakāśakañceti /
analyzed: bhūyas tvāt iti bhūyasām āpya avayavānām rasa upalabdhi prāpaka adṛṣṭa apekṣāṇām saṃyoge sati īṣat itara avayava samparke ca viśeṣa utpādaḥ upadiśyate atas eva anya avayava abhibhava anupapattiḥ jala avayavānām bhūyas tvāt itareṣām ca alpa tvāt iti rasavat tvam ca rasanā indriyasya rasa utkarṣaḥ sāmānya śabdena api arthaḥ nuktaḥ iti rasaḥ jñāyate nena iti rasa jñānam indriyam  / tasmin utpādye prakṛtiḥ kāraṇam udakam bhūyas tvāt vyākṛ
translated: Because of abundance. When there is conjunction of the majority of water parts that require unseen forces to bring about the perception of taste, and when there is contact with other parts, the production of a specific quality is taught. For this very reason, the submergence of other parts is not possible. Because of the abundance of water parts and the paucity of others. And the presence of taste is the excellence of taste for the organ of taste. Even by a general word, the meaning is not stated, so taste is known by this, therefore the organ of taste. In its production, the natural cause is water, because of abundance, from the manifest cause. Therefore this alone is the organ. And it is the specific revealer of taste among form etc.

original: yad vā kāryaniyamaḥ kāraṇaniyamaṃ vinā na ghaṭata iti niyamena rasanendriyād rasopalabdherevotpattiḥ kuta ityāha bhūyastvādrasavattvācca nimittād rase jñaptiḥ jñānam / tatra prakṛtiḥ kāraṇaṃ rasanendriyamiti / tathā hi / saṃyuktasamavāyāviśeṣe 'pi niyamena rasopalambhānyathānupapattyā jñāyate niyamahetuḥ / sa cānyasyāsambhavād rasotkarṣo bhūyastvañceti kalpyate /
analyzed: yat vā kārya niyamaḥ kāraṇa niyamam vinā na ghaṭate iti niyamena rasanā indriyāt rasa upalabdheḥ eva utpattiḥ kutas iti āha bhūyaḥ tvāt rasavat tvāt ca nimittāt rase jñaptiḥ jñānam tatra prakṛtiḥ kāraṇam rasanā indriyam iti tathā hi saṃyukta samavāya aviśeṣe pi niyamena rasa upalambha anyathā anupapattyā jñāyate niyama hetuḥ sa ca anyasya asambhavāt rasa utkarṣaḥ bhūyaḥ tvam ca iti kalpyate
translated: Or, since the restriction of the effect is not possible without the restriction of the cause, the production of the cognition of taste itself is from the gustatory organ. To explain this, he says: The cognition of taste is from the cause of taste, because of abundance and because of having taste. Cognition means knowledge. There, the cause is the gustatory organ. Indeed, even in the absence of a difference in conjunction and inherence, the restriction is known by the non-apprehension of taste otherwise. And that is imagined to be the abundance and excellence of taste, because of the impossibility of anything else.

original: yad vā rasopalambhānyathānupapattyānyasyāsambhavāj jñāyate / rasotkarṣe kiṃ nimittamityāha bhūyastvamiti / tathā hyāpyatvāviśeṣe 'pi rasasyaivotkarṣo na rūpāderiti bhūyastvaṃ viśiṣṭotpāde nimittam / sa cādṛṣṭavaśāt / adṛṣṭasya ca vyavasthāhetutvāditi /
analyzed: yat vā rasa upalambha anyathā anupapattyā anyasya asambhavāt jñāyate rasa utkarṣe kim nimittam iti āha bhūyaḥ tvam iti tathā hi āpya tva aviśeṣe pi rasasya eva utkarṣaḥ na rūpa ādeḥ iti bhūyaḥ tvam viśiṣṭa utpāde nimittam sa ca adṛṣṭa vaśāt adṛṣṭasya ca vyavasthā hetu tvāt iti
translated: Or, the excellence of taste is known by the non-apprehension of taste otherwise and the impossibility of anything else. To explain what is the cause of the excellence of taste, he says abundance. Indeed, even in the absence of fluidity, the excellence is of taste alone, not of form etc. Thus abundance is the cause of special production. And that is due to unseen [forces], and because the unseen is the cause of restriction.

original: viṣayaṃ nirūpayati / śarīrendriyavyatirikto dvyaṇukādiprakrameṇārabdho viṣayaḥ / tasya hi viṣayabhāvenaivopakāritvāditi / sa tu saritsamudrahimakarakādiriti /
analyzed: viṣayam nirūpayati śarīra indriya vyatiriktaḥ dvyaṇuka ādi prakrameṇa ārabdhaḥ viṣayaḥ tasya hi viṣaya bhāvena eva upakāri tvāt iti sa tu sarit samudra hima karaka ādiḥ iti
translated: He describes the object. The object is that which is produced by the aggregation of atoms, etc., apart from the body and senses. For it is only by way of being an object that it is helpful. And that is the rivers, oceans, snow, hail, etc.

original: tejastvābhisambandhāttejaḥ / rūpasparśasaṃkhyāparimāṇapṛthaktvasaṃyogavibhāgaparatvāparatvadravatvasaṃskāravat / pūrvavadeṣāṃ siddhiḥ / śuklaṃ bhāsvarañca rūpam / uṣṇa eva sparśaḥ / naimittikañca dravatvam / saṃkhyādayaśca pūrvavat /PDhS
analyzed: tejaḥ tva abhisambandhāt tejaḥ rūpa sparśa saṃkhyā parimāṇa pṛthaktva saṃyoga vibhāga para tva apara tva drava tva saṃskāra vat pūrvavat eṣām siddhiḥ śuklam bhāsvaram ca rūpam uṣṇaḥ eva sparśaḥ naimittikam ca drava tvam saṃkhyā ādayaḥ ca pūrvavat
translated: It is fire because of its connection with heat. It has color, touch, number, dimension, separateness, conjunction, disjunction, priority, posteriority, fluidity, and inherence. Their existence is like before. Its color is white and luminous. Its touch is only hot. And its fluidity is occasional. And number, etc., are like before.

original: tadapi dvividham aṇukāryabhāvāt / kāryaṃ śarīrāditrayam / śarīramayonijameva dharmaviśeṣasahitebhyo 'ṇubhyo jāyate ādityaloke / pārthivāvayavopaṣṭambhāccopabhogasamartham / indriyaṃ sarvaprāṇināṃ rūpavyañjakamanyāvayavānabhibhūtaistejo 'vayavairārabdhaṃ cakṣuḥ / viṣayalakṣaṇaṃ caturvidhaṃ bhaumaṃ divyamudaryamākarajañca / tatra bhaumaṃ kāṣṭhendhanaprabhavamūrdhvajvalanasvabhāvaṃ pacanasvedanādisamartham / divyamabindhanaṃ sauravidyudādi / bhuktasyāhārasya rasādibhāvena pariṇāmasamarthamudaryam / ākarajaṃ suvarṇādi / tatra saṃyuktasamavāyād rasādyupalabdhiriti /PDhS
analyzed: tat api dvividham aṇu kārya bhāvāt kāryam śarīra ādi trayam śarīram ayoni jam eva dharma viśeṣa sahitebhyaḥ ṇubhyaḥ jāyate āditya loke pārthiva avayava upaṣṭambhāt ca upabhoga samartham indriyam sarva prāṇinām rūpa vyañjakam anya avayavān abhibhūtaiḥ tejaḥ vayavaiḥ ārabdham cakṣuḥ viṣaya lakṣaṇam caturvidham bhaumam divyam udaryam ākara jam ca  tatra bhaumam kāṣṭha indhana prabhavam ūrdhva jvalana svabhāvam pacana svedana ādi samartham divyam ap
translated: That is also of two kinds, due to the existence of atomic effects. The effect is the triad beginning with the body. The body is born from atoms endowed with special qualities, in the world of the sun, and is capable of enjoyment due to the support of earthly constituents. The sense organ, the eye, is produced by fiery constituents that are not overwhelmed by other constituents, and manifests form for all living beings. And the object is of four kinds: earthly, divine, gastric, and mineral. Therein, the earthly is born from firewood, has the nature of upward burning, and is capable of cooking, sweating, etc. The divine is fire-woodless, such as solar, lightning, etc. The gastric is capable of transforming what is eaten into juice, etc. The mineral is gold, etc. Therein, the perception of juice, etc. is due to conjunction-inherence.

original: idānīmuddeśavatastejolakṣaṇaparīkṣārthamāha tejastvābhisambandhāt ityādi prakaraṇam / tejastvenābhisambandhastejastvopalakṣitasamavāyo lakṣaṇamiti / tathā hi / tejaḥ / itarasmād bhidyate / tejastvābhisambandhāt / ye tu na bhidyante na te tejastvābhisambandhāḥ yathā kṣityādayaḥ / na ca tathā tejaḥ / tasmāditarasmād bhidyata iti / vyavahāro vā sādhyate / tathā tejaḥśabdasya sāmānyavānartha iti jñāpanārthamatīndriyaśaktipratiṣedhārthañca pūrvavad vyākhyeyam /
analyzed: idānīm uddeśavataḥ tejaḥ lakṣaṇa parīkṣā artham āha tejaḥ tva abhisambandhāt ityādi prakaraṇam tejaḥ tvena abhisambandhaḥ tejaḥ tva upalakṣita samavāyaḥ lakṣaṇam iti tathā hi tejaḥ itarasmāt bhidyate tejaḥ tva abhisambandhāt ye tu na bhidyante na te tejaḥ tva abhisambandhāḥ yathā kṣiti ādayaḥ na ca tathā tejaḥ tasmāt itarasmāt bhidyate iti vyavahāraḥ vā sādhyate tathā tejaḥ śabdasya sāmānyavān arthaḥ iti jñāpana artham atīndriya
translated: Now, for the purpose of examining the definition of fire, which has been stated, it is said that the section beginning with because of the connection with the nature of fire is for the purpose of defining fire. The connection with the nature of fire, characterized by the nature of fire, is the definition. Thus, fire is distinguished from other things because of its connection with the nature of fire. But those that are not distinguished are not connected with the nature of fire, like earth and so on. And fire is not like that. Therefore, it is distinguished from other things. Or the usage is to be established. In the same way, for the purpose of indicating that the word fire has a general meaning and for the purpose of negating the imperceptible power, it should be explained as before.

original: evaṃ samavāyitvaguṇavattvapratipādanārthañca rūpādivākyam / tathā hi / rūpasparśādayaḥ saṃskāraparyantā vidyante yasya tat tadvaditi / pūrvavadeṣāṃ siddhiḥ iti / yathā pṛthivyadhikāre rūpādayo viśeṣaguṇā guṇaviniveśādhikāre siddhāstadvadihāpīti / tathā tejorūpasparśavad vai / sū / / / iti sūtreṇa viśeṣaguṇāvuktau / tau cāsādhāraṇatvād itarasmād bhedakāvityasādhāraṇatāmāha śuklaṃ bhāsvarañca rūpam prakāśanaśīlamiti / uṣṇa eva sparśaḥ na sparśāntaramiti / naimittikañca dravatvam iti / saṃkhyādayaśca pūrvavat iti / trapusīsaloharajatasuvarṇānāṃ taijasānāmagnisaṃyogād dravatvamadbhiḥ sāmānyam vai / sū / / / iti sūtreṇa dravatvamuktam /
analyzed: evam samavāyi tva guṇavat tva pratipādana artham ca rūpa ādi vākyam tathā hi rūpa sparśa ādayaḥ saṃskāra paryantāḥ vidyante yasya tat tadvat iti pūrvavat eṣām siddhiḥ iti yathā pṛthivī adhikāre rūpa ādayaḥ viśeṣa guṇāḥ guṇa viniveśa adhikāre siddhāḥ tadvat iha api iti tathā tejaḥ rūpa sparśa vat vai iti sūtreṇa viśeṣa guṇau uktau tau ca asādhāraṇa tvāt itarasmāt bhedakau iti asādhāraṇa tām āha śuklam bhāsvaram ca rūpam prakāśana
translated: Thus, the statement about form etc. is also for the purpose of establishing the possession of inherent qualities. For example, that which has form, touch etc. up to modification is said to be so. Their establishment is like before. Just as form etc. are established as specific qualities in the section on earth, in the section on the manifestation of qualities, so it is here also. Similarly, fire has the form and touch of fire. The specific qualities are stated by the sutra. And those two are the causes of distinction from others due to their uncommon nature. Thus, he states the uncommon nature: The form is white and luminous, inclined to illuminate. The touch is hot only, not another touch. And the fluidity is occasional. And number etc. are as before. The fluidity of tin, lead, iron, silver and gold, which are fiery, is common with water due to the conjunction with fire. Fluidity is stated by the sutra.

original: lakṣaṇena lakṣyamāṇasyaikānekatvopalabdhau saṃśaye sati tannirāsāya / advaitavādinaśca pratiṣedhāya / sāmānyasamarthanāya / bījasadbhāvapratipādanāya ca tadapi dvividham iti pūrvavad vākyaṃ vyākhyeyam / tathā hi / na kevalaṃ pṛthivyudakañca dvividham / kiṃ tarhi / etadapīti / tejo 'pi hi dvividhamiti / kena rūpeṇetyāha aṇukāryabhāvāt iti / paramāṇusvabhāvaṃ nityaṃ kāryasvabhāvañcānityam / kāryasya cānantyādaparijñānaṃ mā bhūdityāha kāryaṃ śarīrāditrayam iti / śarīramindriyaṃ viṣayamityanena rūpeṇa jñeyamityavāntaravaidharmyam /
analyzed: lakṣaṇena lakṣyamāṇasya eka aneka tva upalabdhau saṃśaye sati tad nirāsāya advaita vādinaḥ ca pratiṣedhāya sāmānya samarthanāya bīja sadbhāva pratipādanāya ca tat api dvividham iti pūrvavat vākyam vyākhyeyam tathā hi na kevalam pṛthivī udakam ca dvividham kim tarhi etat api iti tejaḥ hi dvividham iti  kena rūpeṇa iti āha aṇu kārya bhāvāt iti paramāṇu svabhāvam nityam kārya svabhāvam ca anityam kāryasya ca ānantyāt aparijñānam mā bhūt iti āha kārya
translated: When there is doubt in the perception of oneness or manyness of what is being characterized by a characteristic, in order to remove that, and in order to refute the doctrine of non-duality, and in order to establish the general principle, and in order to demonstrate the existence of the seed, that is also of two kinds. This statement should be explained as before. Thus, it is not only earth and water that are of two kinds, but also this. Fire is also of two kinds. By what form? It is said: because of atomic existence and effects. The nature of atoms is eternal, and the nature of effects is non-eternal. And because effects are infinite, there may be lack of knowledge. Therefore, it is said: the effect is the triad beginning with the body. The body, sense organ, and object - by this form, it should be known. This is the minor difference.

original: śarīrasya sāmānyalakṣaṇamuktamityutpattirevocyate śarīramayonijameva iti / ayonijaṃ hi śukraśoṇitasannipātānapekṣam / dharmaviśeṣasahitebhyo 'ṇubhyaḥ iti / taijasāḥ paramāṇavaḥ samavāyikāraṇam / tatsaṃyogāścāsamavāyikāraṇam / pārthivādyavayavāśca nimittakāraṇamiti / taccādityaloke siddhamāgamāt / atha tejo 'vayavinaḥ kṣaṇikatāyāṃ tadārabdhaṃ viśiṣṭopabhogājanakamityāha pārthivāvayavopaṣṭambhāccopabhogasamartham iti / tacca śarīraṃ sāmānyalakṣaṇalakṣitatve sati tejo 'vayavairārabdhatvāditarasmād bhidyata iti viśeṣalakṣaṇaṃ jñeyam /
analyzed: śarīrasya sāmānya lakṣaṇam uktam iti utpattiḥ eva ucyate śarīram ayoni jam eva iti ayoni jam hi śukra śoṇita sannipāta anapekṣam dharma viśeṣa sahitebhyaḥ ṇubhyaḥ iti taijasāḥ paramāṇavaḥ samavāyi kāraṇam tad saṃyogāḥ ca asamavāyi kāraṇam pārthiva ādi avayavāḥ ca nimitta kāraṇam iti tat ca āditya loke siddham āgamāt atha tejaḥ vayavinaḥ kṣaṇikatāyām tat ārabdham viśiṣṭa upabhoga ajanakam iti āha pārthiva avayava upaṣṭambhāt
translated: The general characteristics of the body have been stated, so only its origin is mentioned: the body is not born from a womb. For what is not born from a womb does not depend on the union of semen and blood, but is produced from atoms endowed with special qualities. The atomic particles of fire are the inherent cause, and their conjunction is the non-inherent cause. The parts of earth and so on are the instrumental cause. And that is established in the world of the sun by scripture. Now, if the body of fire is momentary, it does not produce the special enjoyment that arises from it. Therefore it is said: And it is capable of enjoyment because it is supported by the parts of earth. And that body, being characterized by the general characteristics, is distinguished from other things because it is produced by the parts of fire. This should be known as the specific characteristic.

original: athendriyasvarūpanirūpaṇārthamāha indriyaṃ sarvaprāṇināṃ rūpavyañjakam iti / rūpopalabdhiḥ / karaṇakāryā / kriyātvāt yā yā kriyā sā sā karaṇakāryā yathā chidikriyā / tathā ceyaṃ kriyā / tasmāt / karaṇakāryeti / yadrūpopalabdheḥ sampādakaṃ karaṇaṃ taccakṣuriti / tacca taijasam / rūpādiṣu madhye niyamena rūpavyañjakatvāt / yad yad rūpādiṣu madhye niyamena rūpavyañjakaṃ tattaijasam / yathā pradīpaḥ / tathā ca rūpādiṣu madhye niyamena rūpavyañjakaṃ cakṣuḥ / tasmāttaijasamiti / cakṣuṣo hi rūpavaddravyādi prakāśakatvopalabdherniyamena rūpaprakāśakatvamasiddhaṃ syāditi rūpādiṣu madhye iti padam / rūparasagandhasparśeṣu madhye niyamena rūpavyañjakatvaṃ vivakṣitamiti /
analyzed: atha indriya svarūpa nirūpaṇa artham āha indriyam sarva prāṇinām rūpa vyañjakam iti rūpa upalabdhiḥ karaṇa kāryā kriyā tvāt yā yā kriyā sā sā karaṇa kāryā yathā chidi kriyā tathā ca iyam kriyā tasmāt karaṇa kāryā iti yat rūpa upalabdheḥ sampādakam karaṇam tat cakṣuḥ iti tat ca taijasam rūpa ādiṣu madhye niyamena rūpa vyañjaka tvāt yat yat rūpa ādiṣu madhye niyamena rūpa vyañjakam tat taijasam yathā pradīpaḥ tathā ca rūpa ādiṣu madhye niy
translated: Now, to describe the nature of the senses, it is said: The sense organ of all living beings that manifests form. The perception of form is the effect of the instrument, because it is an action. Whatever action is, that is the effect of the instrument, just as the action of cutting. And this is such an action. Therefore, it is the effect of the instrument. That which is the instrument that accomplishes the perception of form is the eye. And that is of the nature of fire, because it invariably manifests form among form and other sense objects. Whatever invariably manifests form among form and other sense objects is of the nature of fire, just as a lamp. And the eye invariably manifests form among form and other sense objects. Therefore, it is of the nature of fire. For if the eye were perceived as the illuminator of substances possessing form, its invariable manifestation of form would not be established. Therefore, the word among form and other sense objects is used. It is intended that the invariable manifestation of form among form, taste, smell, and touch is meant.

original: atha taijasatvāccakṣuṣo rūpasyevoṣmaprakāśakatvamapi syāt / tasya hi taijasatvāt saṃyuktasamavāyasyāviśeṣād / anyasya ca viśeṣahetorabhāvādityāha anyāvayavānabhibhūtaistejo 'vayavairārabdhaṃ cakṣuḥ ato rūpasyaiva vyañjakamiti / tathā hīṣatpārthivāvayavasaṃyuktairanabhibhūtaistejo 'vayavairārabdhaṃ cakṣuriti rūpasyaiva vyañjakam /
analyzed: atha taijasa tvāt cakṣuṣaḥ rūpasya iva ūṣma prakāśaka tvam api syāt tasya hi taijasa tvāt saṃyukta samavāyasya aviśeṣāt anyasya ca viśeṣa hetoḥ abhāvāt iti āha anya avayava anabhibhūtaiḥ tejaḥ vayavaiḥ ārabdham cakṣuḥ atas rūpasya eva vyañjakam iti tathā hi īṣat pārthiva avayava saṃyuktaiḥ anabhibhūtaiḥ tejaḥ vayavaiḥ ārabdham cakṣuḥ iti rūpasya eva vyañjakam
translated: Now, because of being fiery, like form, there would also be the property of producing heat. For that, because of being fiery, there is no difference in the conjunction inherence, and because there is no other cause of distinction, he says: The eye is produced by fiery parts that are not overpowered by other parts. Therefore, it manifests only form. Thus, the eye is produced by fiery parts that are not overpowered by slightly earthy parts. Therefore, it manifests only form.

original: atha itthambhūtārambhe kiṃ pramāṇam / kāryaniyamaḥ / tathā hi cakṣurvyāpārād rūpādiṣu madhye rūpasyaivopalabdhirdṛṣṭā / sā ca kāraṇaniyamaṃ vinā na syādityanyasyāsambhavād viśiṣṭotpādo 'tra nimittam / sa cādṛṣṭād rūpopalabdhisampādakāt tasya hi vastuvyavasthāhetutvāditi /
analyzed: atha ittham bhūta ārambhe kim pramāṇam kārya niyamaḥ tathā hi cakṣuḥ vyāpārāt rūpa ādiṣu madhye rūpasya eva upalabdhiḥ dṛṣṭā sā ca kāraṇa niyamam vinā na syāt iti anyasya asambhavāt viśiṣṭa utpādaḥ tra nimittam sa ca adṛṣṭāt rūpa upalabdhi sampādakāt tasya hi vastu vyavasthā hetu tvāt iti
translated: Now, what is the evidence for such a production? The restriction of the effect. For thus, from among form etc., the perception of only form is seen due to the operation of the eye. And that cannot be without the restriction of the cause. Because of the impossibility of anything else, the cause here is the production of the specific. And that is from the unseen, which produces the perception of form. For that is the cause of the determination of the nature of things.

original: bhūyastvād rūpavattvācca rūpajñāne prakṛtiḥ kāraṇaṃ tejaḥ vai / sū / / iti / asya ca sūtrasyedaṃ bhāṣyam / rūpaṃ jñāyate 'neneti rūpajñānaṃ cakṣustasminnutpādye prakṛtiḥ kāraṇaṃ tejo bhūyastvānnimittādato rūpasyaiva prakāśakamindriyañceti / bhūyastvaṃ hi bhūyasāṃ tejo 'vayavānāṃ viśiṣṭādṛṣṭopagṛhītānāmīṣaditarāvayavasamparke cārambhakatvamiti / yad vā rūpe jñaptirjñānam / tasminneva rūpādiṣu madhye kāraṇaṃ cakṣuḥ / kuta ityāha bhūyastvād vyākṛtād rūpavattvācca iti / rūpavattvaṃ hi rūpotkarṣo vivakṣitaḥ / anyathā hi taijasatvāduṣṇasparśavattvamapi sambhāvyata iti viśeṣābhidhānamanarthakaṃ syāt / yad vā rūpādiṣu madhye rūpasyaivopalambhānyathānupapattyā jñāyate rūpotkarṣaḥ / kuto bhavatītyāha bhūyastvāduktarūpāditi /
analyzed: bhūyaḥ tvāt rūpavat tvāt ca rūpa jñāne prakṛtiḥ kāraṇam tejaḥ vai iti  asya ca sūtrasya idam bhāṣyam rūpam jñāyate nena iti rūpa jñānam cakṣuḥ tasmin utpādye prakṛtiḥ kāraṇam tejaḥ bhūyaḥ tvāt nimittāt atas rūpasya eva prakāśakam indriyam ca iti  bhūyaḥ tvam hi bhūyasām tejaḥ vayavānām viśiṣṭa adṛṣṭa upagṛhītānām īṣat itara avayava samparke ca ārambhaka tvam iti  yat vā rūpe jñaptiḥ jñānam tasmin eva rūpa ādiṣu madhye
translated: Because of its predominance and because it possesses form, fire is the natural cause of the cognition of form. This is the commentary on that aphorism: The cognition of form is that by which form is cognized. The eye is the natural cause of its production. It is fire because of predominance. Therefore, the sense organ is the illuminator of form alone. For predominance means the state of being the cause of the combination of a majority of parts of fire, which are grasped by a special unseen force, with a few other parts. Or, the cognition of form is the knowledge of it. The eye is the cause of that alone among form and so on. Why? It says because of predominance, because of being evolved, and because it possesses form. For the possession of form is intended to be the excellence of form. Otherwise, because of being fiery, the possession of the quality of heat would also be possible, so the special mention would be meaningless. Or, the excellence of form is known by the impossibility of the perception of form alone among form and so on. From where does it come? It says

original: atha mahattvādanekadravyatvāccakṣuṣaḥ kasmādindriyeṇopalambho na bhavati / pradīpasyeva viśiṣṭarūpābhāvāt / yatra hi rūpavaddravyasya cakṣuḥsparśanābhyāmupalambha iti / I / rūpaviśeṣastu yatkṛtā kvacidviṣaye rūpopalabdhiryadabhāvācca mahadanekadravyāśrayasyāpyanupalabdhiḥ sa udbhavasamākhyāno rūpadharmaḥ sahakāriviśeṣa iti / dṛṣṭañca rūpaviśeṣābhāvād vāristhite tejasi mahadanekadravyatve 'pyagrahaṇam / udbhūtarūpasya pradīpasyāndhakāre 'pi grahaṇam / upabhogārthā hi sṛṣṭirbhāvānāmiti rūpasyodbhave cakṣuṣo 'ndhakāre 'pi grahaṇe duṣṭasattvānāmupabhogānutpattiḥ syāditi tadupabhogaprāpakādṛṣṭavaśenānudbhūtarūpaṃ cakṣurjanitaṃ prajāpatinā / tathoṣṇasparśodbhave 'pyanekacakṣuḥsannipātāt prītikare vastuni nartakyādau grīṣmasamaye 'tyuṣṇairmarīcibhiriva dāhaḥ syādityadṛṣṭavaśādevoṣṇasparśasyāpyanudbhavaḥ kalpyata iti /

translated: Now, since the eye is large and composed of many substances, why is it not perceived by the sense organ? Because it lacks the distinctive form of a lamp. Similarly, even when the hot touch is manifested, the eye is produced by Prajapati under the influence of unseen forces that bring about that experience.
