original: vāyutvābhisambandhād vāyuḥ / sparśasaṃkhyāparimāṇapṛthaktvasaṃyogavibhāgaparatvāparatvasaṃskāravān / sparśo 'syānuṣṇāśītatve satyapākajo guṇaviniveśāt siddhaḥ / arūpiṣvacākṣuṣavacanāt saptasaṃkhyādayaḥ / tṛṇakarmavacanāt saṃskāraḥ / sa cāyaṃ dvividho 'ṇukāryabhāvāt / tatra kāryalakṣaṇaścaturvidhaḥ / śarīramindriyaṃ viṣayaḥ prāṇa iti / tatra śarīramayonijameva dharmaviśeṣasahitebhyo vāyuparamāṇubhyo jāyate marutāṃ loke / pārthivāvayavopaṣṭambhāccopabhogasamartham / indriyaṃ sarvaprāṇināṃ sparśopalambhakaṃ pṛthivyādyanabhibhūtairvāyvavayavairārabdhaṃ śarīravyāpi tvagindriyam / viṣayastūpalabhyamānasparśādhiṣṭhānabhūtaḥ sparśaśabdadhṛtikampaliṅgastiryaggamanasvabhāvo meghādipreraṇadhāraṇādisamarthaḥ / tasyāpratyakṣasyāpi nānātvaṃ saṃmūrchanenānumīyate / saṃmūrchanaṃ punaḥ samānajavayorviruddhadikkriyayorvāyvoḥ sāvayavinorūrdhvagamanenānumīyate / tadapi tṛṇādīnāmūrdhvagamaneneti / prāṇo 'ntaḥśarīre I / rasamaladhātūnāṃ preraṇādiheturekaḥ san kriyābhedāt prāṇāpānādisaṃjñāṃ labhata iti /PDhS
analyzed: vāyu tva abhisambandhāt vāyuḥ sparśa saṃkhyā parimāṇa pṛthaktva saṃyoga vibhāga para tva apara tva saṃskāravān sparśaḥ syāt uṣṇa aśīta tve satya pāka jaḥ guṇa viniveśāt siddhaḥ arūpiṣu acākṣuṣa vacanāt sapta saṃkhyā ādayaḥ tṛṇa karma vacanāt saṃskāraḥ sa ca ayam dvividhaḥ ṇu kārya bhāvāt tatra kārya lakṣaṇaḥ caturvidhaḥ śarīram indriyam viṣayaḥ prāṇaḥ iti tatra śarīram ayoni jam eva dharma viśeṣa sahitebhyaḥ
translated: It is air because of its connection with air. It possesses touch, number, dimension, separateness, conjunction, disjunction, priority, posteriority, and inherence. Touch is established in it as a quality not hot or cold, being produced by cooking, because it is included in qualities. Number and so on are seven, because it is said to be without form and invisible. Inherence is said to be of two kinds, because it is the cause of atoms and effects. Among them, the characteristic of an effect is fourfold: body, sense organ, object, and life. There, the body is born only from wind atoms endowed with special qualities in the world of winds, and it is capable of experience because it is supported by earthly constituents. The sense organ is the skin sense organ, which pervades the body and is produced by wind constituents not overwhelmed by earth and so on, and it perceives touch for all living beings. The object is the basis for perceived touch, characterized by touch, sound, support, vibration, and horizontal movement, and it has the nature of moving horizontally, supporting clouds and so on, and so on.

original: idānīṃ vāyoruddeśavato lakṣaṇaparīkṣārthaṃ vāyutvābhisambandhāt ityādiprakaraṇam / vāyuriti lakṣyanirdeśo vāyutvābhisambandhāditi lakṣaṇam / vāyutvenābhisambandho vāyutvenopalakṣitaḥ samavāya iti / samavāyo hyativyāpakatvādalakṣaṇaṃ syāditi vāyutvapadam / vāyutvañcāsambaddhamapakṣadharmatayā gamakaṃ na syāditi pakṣadharmatājñāpanārthamabhisambandhapadam / tathā ca vāyutvenetarasmād bhidyate / vāyutvābhisambandhāt / ye tu na bhidyante na te vāyutvenābhisambaddhāḥ yathā kṣityādayaḥ / na ca tathā vāyutvenānabhisambaddho vāyuḥ / tasmāditarasmād bhidyata iti / vyavahāro vā sādhyate / śeṣañca lakṣaṇasya dūṣaṇapratisamādhānaṃ pṛthivyadhikāre jñeyam / tathā vāyuśabdasya sāmānyavānartha iti jñāpanārthamatīndriyaśaktipratiṣedhārthañca pūrvavad vākyaṃ vyākhyeyam /
analyzed: idānīm vāyoḥ uddeśavataḥ lakṣaṇa parīkṣā artham vāyu tva abhisambandhāt ityādi prakaraṇam vāyuḥ iti lakṣya nirdeśaḥ vāyu tva abhisambandhāt iti lakṣaṇam vāyu tvena abhisambandhaḥ vāyu tvena upalakṣitaḥ samavāyaḥ iti samavāyaḥ hi ativyāpaka tvāt alakṣaṇam syāt iti vāyu tva padam vāyu tvam ca asambaddham apakṣa dharmatayā gamakam na syāt iti pakṣa dharmatā jñāpana artham abhisambandha padam tathā ca vāyu tvena itarasmāt bhidyate vāyu tva
translated: Now, for the purpose of examining the definition of air, which is the subject matter, the chapter beginning with because of the connection with airness is started. Thus, air is distinguished from other things by airness, because of the connection with airness. But those that are not distinguished are not connected with airness, like earth and so on. And air is not unconnected with airness in that way. Therefore, it is distinguished from other things. Or, the usage is to be established. And the remaining criticism and defense of the definition should be known in the section on earth. Thus, the word air has a general meaning, to indicate this, the word air is used.

original: samavāyitvaguṇavattvapratipādanārthaṃ sparśādivākyam / sparśādayaḥ saṃskāraparyantā vidyante yasyāsau tadvāniti / sparśasya sādhāraṇatvādanyasmād bhedakatvābhāvādityasādhāraṇatāmāha sparśo 'syānuṣṇāśītatve satyapākajaḥ iti / anuṣṇa ityuṣṇasparśavyavacchedaḥ / aśīta iti śītasparśāt / apākaja iti pārthivāt / sa ca guṇaviniveśād dvitīyādhyāye siddhaḥ vāyuḥ sparśavān vai / sū / / / ityanena sūtreṇa /
analyzed: samavāyi tva guṇavat tva pratipādana artham sparśa ādi vākyam sparśa ādayaḥ saṃskāra paryantāḥ vidyante yasya asau tadvān iti sparśasya sādhāraṇa tvāt anyasmāt bhedaka tva abhāvāt iti asādhāraṇatām āha sati apāka jaḥ iti anuṣṇaḥ iti uṣṇa sparśa vyavacchedaḥ aśītaḥ iti śīta sparśāt apāka jaḥ iti pārthivāt sa ca guṇa viniveśāt dvitīya adhyāye siddhaḥ vāyuḥ sparśavān vai iti anena sūtreṇa
translated: The statement about touch etc. is for the purpose of establishing its possession of the quality of inherence. Not hot means excluding the touch of heat. Not cold means excluding the touch of cold. Not produced by cooking means excluding the earthy. And that wind is possessed of touch is established by the aphorism Wind is possessed of touch in the second chapter, by the insertion of the quality.

original: tathā vāyutvasāmānyasya bhedādhiṣṭhānatvāditi tatsamarthenārthāllakṣaṇena lakṣyamāṇasyaikānekatvopalabdhau saṃśaye sati tannirāsārtham / advaitavādipratiṣedhārthaṃ bījasadbhāvapratipādanārthañca sa cāyaṃ dvividho 'ṇukāryabhāvāt iti vākyam / tathā hyaṇusvabhāvo nityaḥ kāryasvabhāvastvanitya iti /
analyzed: tathā vāyu tva sāmānyasya bheda adhiṣṭhāna tvāt iti tad samarthena arthāt lakṣaṇena lakṣyamāṇasya eka aneka tva upalabdhau saṃśaye sati tad nirāsa artham advaita vādi pratiṣedha artham bīja sadbhāva pratipādana artham ca sa ca ayam dvividhaḥ ṇu kārya bhāvāt iti vākyam tathā hi aṇu svabhāvaḥ nityaḥ kārya svabhāvaḥ tu anityaḥ iti
translated: Similarly, because the general nature of air is the basis of distinctions, when there is doubt in the perception of oneness and manyness of what is being defined by the definition that supports that, in order to refute that, and in order to refute the proponents of non-duality and to establish the existence of the seed, the statement And this is twofold, because of the existence of effects of atoms is made. For thus, the nature of atoms is eternal, while the nature of effects is non-eternal.

original: avāntaravaidharmyaṃ darśayati kāryalakṣaṇaḥ / kāryasvabhāvaḥ / caturvidhaḥ iti / kena rūpeṇetyāha śarīramindriyaṃ viṣayaḥ prāṇaḥ iti /
analyzed: avāntara vaidharmyam darśayati kārya lakṣaṇaḥ kārya svabhāvaḥ caturvidhaḥ iti kena rūpeṇa iti āha śarīram indriyam viṣayaḥ prāṇaḥ iti
translated: He shows the secondary dissimilarity: The nature of effects, characterized by effects, is of four kinds. By what form? He says: body, sense faculty, object, and life force.

original: śarīrotpattimāha śarīramayonijameva iti / ayonijañca śukraśoṇitasannipātamanapekṣyopajātam / dharmaviśeṣasahitebhyo vāyuparamāṇubhyaḥ iti / tathā hi / vāyavīyāḥ paramāṇavaḥ samavāyikāraṇam / tatsaṃyogāścāsamavāyikāraṇam / kṣityādi ca nimittakāraṇamiti / tacca marutāṃ loke siddhamāgamāt / atha vāyostiryaggatiśīlatvāt kṣaṇikatvācca tadārabdhaśarīramupabhogājanakaṃ syādityāha pārthivāvayavopaṣṭambhāccopabhogasamartham iti /
analyzed: śarīra utpattim āha śarīram ayoni jam eva iti ayoni jam ca śukra śoṇita sannipātam an apekṣya upajātam dharma viśeṣa sahitebhyaḥ vāyu paramāṇubhyaḥ iti tathā hi vāyavīyāḥ paramāṇavaḥ samavāyi kāraṇam tad saṃyogāḥ ca asamavāyi kāraṇam kṣiti ādi ca nimitta kāraṇam iti tat ca marutām loke siddham āgamāt atha vāyoḥ tiryaggati śīla tvāt kṣaṇika tvāt ca tad ārabdha śarīram upabhoga ajanakam syāt iti āha pārthiva avayava upaṣṭambhāt ca
translated: He describes the origin of the body as follows: The body is not born from a womb, i.e., it is produced without regard to the union of semen and ovum, from air atoms accompanied by specific qualities. For thus, the air atoms are the inherent cause, and their conjunctions are the non-inherent cause, and earth etc. are the instrumental cause. And that is established in the world of air by scripture. Now, because air moves horizontally and is momentary, the body produced from it would not be a producer of experience. Therefore he says: And it is capable of experience because it is supported by the earth elements.

original: indriyasvarūpanirūpaṇārthamāha indriyaṃ sarvaprāṇināṃ sparśopalambhakam iti / tathā hi / sparśopalabdhiḥ / karaṇakāryā / kriyātvād yā yā kriyā sā sā karaṇakāryā / yathā chidikriyā / tathā ceyaṃ kriyā / tasmāt karaṇakāryeti / yad yat sparśopalabdheḥ sampādakaṃ karaṇaṃ tad vāyavīyam / rūpādiṣu madhye niyamena sparśavyañjakatvāt / yad yad rūpādiṣu madhye niyamena sparśavyañjakaṃ tad vāyavīyaṃ dṛṣṭam / yathā vyajanānilaḥ / tathā ca rūpādiṣu madhye niyamena sparśavyañjakaṃ tvagindriyam / tasmād vāyavīyamiti / tvagindriyasya sparśavaddravyādivyañjakatvopalabdherniyamena sparśavyañjakatvamasiddhaṃ syāditi rūpādiṣu madhya iti viśeṣaṇam / vyajanānile tu tadgatasparśavyaktau yadyapi rūpādyasambhavastathāpi śītādisparśavyañjakatvasadbhāvād viśeṣaṇasadbhāvaḥ /
analyzed: indriya svarūpa nirūpaṇa artham āha indriyam sarva prāṇinām sparśa upalambhakam iti tathā hi sparśa upalabdhiḥ karaṇa kāryā kriyā tvāt yā yā kriyā sā sā karaṇa kāryā yathā chidi kriyā tathā ca iyam kriyā tasmāt karaṇa kāryā iti yat yat sparśa upalabdheḥ sampādakam karaṇam tat vāyavīyam rūpa ādiṣu madhye niyamena sparśa vyañjaka tvāt yat yat rūpa ādiṣu madhye niyamena sparśa vyañjakam tat vāyavīyam dṛṣṭam yathā vyajana anilaḥ tathā ca r
translated: To define the nature of the sense organs, it is said: The sense organ of all living beings is that which perceives touch. For instance, the perception of touch is the effect of an instrument. Whatever is an action is the effect of an instrument, like the action of cutting. And this is an action. Therefore, it is the effect of an instrument. Whatever is the instrument that accomplishes the perception of touch is of the nature of air, because it invariably manifests touch among form etc. Whatever invariably manifests touch among form etc. is seen to be of the nature of air, like the breeze from a fan. And the skin sense organ invariably manifests touch among form etc. Therefore, it is of the nature of air. Since the skin sense organ is seen to manifest substances with touch, its invariable manifestation of touch would not be established. Therefore, the qualification among form etc. is used. Although in the manifestation of the touch belonging to the breeze from a fan, form etc. are impossible,

original: atha vāyavīyatvāviśeṣe kasmāt kiñcideva sparśavyañjakamindriyamiti tvagindriyañcetyāha pṛthivyādyanabhibhūtaiḥ vāyavīyairviśiṣṭādṛṣṭopagṛhītairīṣaditarāvayavasaṃpṛktaiḥ śuddhairvā ārabdham / ataḥ sparśasyaivābhivyañjakamindriyañceti / tacca śarīravyāpi sarvatra sparśopalambhād vijñātam / tasya ca saṃjñā tvagindriyam iti / tvagiti śarīrāvaguṇṭhakaṃ carma / tatsthānamindriyam upacāreṇa tvagindriyamityuktam /
analyzed: atha vāyavīya tva aviśeṣe kasmāt kiñcid eva sparśa vyañjakam indriyam iti tvac indriyam ca iti āha pṛthivī ādi anabhibhūtaiḥ vāyavīyaiḥ viśiṣṭa adṛṣṭa upagṛhītaiḥ īṣat itara avayava saṃpṛktaiḥ śuddhaiḥ vā ārabdham atas sparśasya eva abhivyañjakam indriyam ca iti tat ca śarīra vyāpi sarvatra sparśa upalambhāt vijñātam tasya ca saṃjñā tvac indriyam iti tvac iti śarīra avaguṇṭhakam carma tad sthānam indriyam upacāreṇa tvac indriyam iti
translated: Now, if there is no difference in being made of air, why is it that only one sense organ manifests touch, and that is the skin sense organ? He says: It is produced by air particles that are not overwhelmed by earth etc., that are governed by unseen forces, that are slightly connected with other parts, or that are pure. Therefore, it is the sense organ that manifests touch alone, and that is the skin sense organ. And that is known to pervade the body, since touch is perceived everywhere. And that is designated as the skin sense organ. Skin refers to the covering of the body, and the sense organ located there is figuratively called the skin sense organ.

original: atha tvagindriyasya viśiṣṭotpāde kiṃ pramāṇam / kāryaniyamaḥ / tathā ca rūpādiṣu madhye sparśasyaivopalambhānyathānupapattyā jñāyate kāraṇaniyamaḥ / sa cānyasyāsambhavād viśiṣṭotpāde nimittamiti kalpyate /
analyzed: atha tvac indriyasya viśiṣṭa utpāde kim pramāṇam kārya niyamaḥ tathā ca rūpa ādiṣu madhye sparśasya eva upalambha anyathā anupapattyā jñāyate kāraṇa niyamaḥ sa ca anyasya asambhavāt viśiṣṭa utpāde nimittam iti kalpyate
translated: Now, what is the evidence for the specific production of the skin sense organ? It is the restriction of the effect. And thus, by the impossibility of perceiving touch alone among form etc., the restriction of the cause is known. And that is imagined to be the cause of specific production due to the impossibility of anything else.

original: asya ca sūtrasyedaṃ bhāṣyam bhūyastvāt sparśavattvācca sparśajñāne prakṛtirvāyuḥ luptaṃ vai / sū / iti / sparśo jñāyate 'neneti sparśajñānamindriyamiti / tasminnutpādye prakṛtiḥ kāraṇaṃ vāyuḥ / bhūyastvānnimittāt / atastadevendriyaṃ rūpādiṣu madhye sparśasyaiva vyañjakamiti / bhūyastvāditi / bhūyasāṃ viśiṣṭādṛṣṭopagṛhītānāṃ vāyvavayavānām īṣaditarāvayavasamparkairārambhakatvam /🔽yad vā sparśe jñaptirjñānam / tasminneva rūpādiṣu madhye prakṛtiḥ kāraṇaṃ vāyuḥ / kuta ityāha bhūyastvād vyākṛtāt sparśavattvācceti / sparśavattvañcāsya sparśotkarṣo vivakṣitaḥ /
analyzed: asya ca sūtrasya idam bhāṣyam bhūyaḥ tvāt sparśavat tvāt ca sparśa jñāne prakṛtiḥ vāyuḥ luptam vai iti sparśaḥ jñāyate nena iti sparśa jñānam indriyam iti tasmin utpādye prakṛtiḥ kāraṇam vāyuḥ bhūyaḥ tvāt nimittāt atas tat eva indriyam rūpa ādiṣu madhye sparśasya eva vyañjakam iti bhūyaḥ tvāt iti bhūyasām viśiṣṭa adṛṣṭa upagṛhītānām vāyu avayavānām īṣat itara avayava samparkaiḥ ārambhaka tvam  yat vā sparśe jñaptiḥ jñānam tasmin eva rūpa ādiṣu madhye prakṛtiḥ kāraṇam vāyuḥ kutas iti āha bhūyas tvāt vyākṛtāt sparśavat tvāt ca iti sparśavat tvam ca asya sparśa utkarṣaḥ vivakṣitaḥ
translated: And this is the commentary on this sutra: Because of abundance and because of having touch, air is the natural cause of the knowledge of touch. The rest is omitted. Touch is known by this, therefore the knowledge of touch is the sense organ. In its production, air is the natural cause. Because of abundance, from the cause. Therefore, that very sense organ is the manifestor of only touch among form and so on. Because of abundance. The abundant, distinguished, unseen-comprised parts of air are the cause of production by slight contact with other parts.🔽Or, the knowledge of touch is the knowledge. In that very [knowledge], among form and so on, air is the natural cause. Why? He says because of abundance and because of having touch. And having touch is meant to be the excellence of touch.

original: yad vā sparśasyaivopalambhānyathānupapattyā jñātaḥ sparśotkarṣaḥ / kasmād bhavatītyāha bhūyastvānnimittāditi /
analyzed: yat vā sparśasya eva upalambha anyathā anupapattyā jñātaḥ sparśa utkarṣaḥ kasmāt bhavati iti āha bhūyaḥ tvāt nimittāt iti
translated: Or, the excellence of touch is known by the impossibility of the perception of touch in any other way. Why does it occur? He says because of abundance, from the cause.

original: nanu sarvametad asambaddham / vāyusadbhāve pramāṇābhāvāt / na / pratyakṣeṇopalambhāt / tathā hi spārśanavyāpārād aparokṣajñānamutpadyamānaṃ dṛṣṭam vāyurvāti / śīto vāyuḥ / uṣṇo vāyuḥ iti / na cedaṃ liṅgaliṅgisambandhānusmaraṇaparāmarśajñānānantaramutpadyata iti nānumānaprabhavam / śabdaṃ vināpyutpatterna śābdam itīndriyānuvidhānād indriyajam / yaccāparokṣajñānaṃ tatpratyakṣam /
analyzed: nanu sarvam etat asambaddham vāyu sadbhāve pramāṇa abhāvāt na pratyakṣeṇa upalambhāt tathā hi spārśana vyāpārāt aparokṣa jñānam utpadyamānam dṛṣṭam vāyuḥ vāti śītaḥ vāyuḥ uṣṇaḥ vāyuḥ iti na ca idam liṅga liṅgi sambandha anusmaraṇa parāmarśa jñāna anantaram utpadyate iti na anumāna prabhavam śabdam vinā api utpatteḥ na śābdam iti indriya anuvidhānāt indriya jam yat ca aparokṣa jñānam tat pratyakṣam  /
translated: But all this is irrelevant, because there is no evidence for the existence of air. No, because it is perceived by touch. For example, when the operation of touch is seen, the knowledge that arises is: The air is blowing, The air is cold, The air is hot. And this does not arise after the recollection and reflection of the relation between the mark and the marked, so it is not produced by inference. And because it arises even without words, it is not verbal. Thus, because it conforms to the sense organ, it is produced by the sense organ. And that which is non-conceptual knowledge is perception.

original: atha mahattvādanekadravyavattvād rūpaviśeṣācca dravyaṃ pratyakṣam vai / sū / / / iti sūtravirodhaḥ / na / sūtrārthāparijñānāt / tathā ca sūtrārthaḥ / aparokṣajñānasadbhāve sati samastaṃ vyastañca lakṣaṇamiti jñeyam / yatra hyaparokṣaṃ jñānaṃ tatrāmīṣāṃ samastavyastānāṃ kāraṇatvam / tathā hyātmā mahattvādeva pratyakṣaḥ / vāyustu mahattvānekadravyavattvābhyāñca / yatra ca cakṣuḥsparśanābhyāṃ vijñānaṃ dravye tatra samastaṃ lakṣaṇamiti / prādhānyantu yathā darśanamabhyupeyam / tathā hi rātrāvagnirdūre 'pyupalabhyate rūpātiśayāt / mahattvānekadravyavattve 'pyagrahaṇaṃ parvatāderiti rūpasya prādhānyam / evamālokasadbhāve dūre 'pi parvatādergrahaṇam / mahattve tu alpaprādhānyamityutprekṣyam /
analyzed: atha mahat tvāt aneka dravyavat tvāt rūpa viśeṣāt ca dravyam pratyakṣam vai iti sūtra virodhaḥ na sūtra artha aparijñānāt tathā ca sūtra arthaḥ aparokṣa jñāna sadbhāve sati samastam vyastam ca lakṣaṇam iti jñeyam yatra hi aparokṣam jñānam tatra amīṣām samasta vyastānām kāraṇa tvam tathā hi ātmā mahat tvāt eva pratyakṣaḥ vāyuḥ tu mahat tva aneka dravyavat tvābhyām ca yatra ca cakṣuḥ sparśanābhyām vijñānam dravye tatra samastam lakṣaṇam iti
translated: Now, if substance is perceptible because of its greatness, because of being composed of many substances, and because of its specific form, there is a contradiction with the sutra that says substance is not perceptible. No, because of not understanding the meaning of the sutra. And the meaning of the sutra is as follows: When the existence of non-obstructed knowledge is present, the entire and individual characteristics should be known. For where there is non-obstructed knowledge, these entire and individual characteristics have the nature of a cause. Thus, the self is perceptible just because of its greatness. But the wind is perceptible because of its greatness and because of being composed of many substances. And where there is knowledge of a substance by both the eye and touch, there the entire characteristic is present. But the predominance should be accepted according to what is seen. For thus, fire is perceived even from a distance at night because of the excellence of form. Even though it is great and composed of many substances, a mountain and so on are not perceived. So form is predominant. Similarly, even from a distance, a mountain and so on are perceived when there is light. But in greatness, it is to be inferred that it is of little importance.

original: atha yatra spārśanapratyakṣatvaṃ tatra darśanasyāpi vyāpāro dṛṣṭa oghaśabdādau / saṃkhyādayaśca pratyakṣā itīhāpi tathābhāvaḥ syāt / na cāstyataḥ sparśamātrameva pratyakṣam / vāristhite tejasyuṣṇatāvaditi / yathā vāristhite tejasi āśrayāpratyakṣatve 'pyuṣṇatāgrahaṇaṃ tadvadihāpyāśrayāpratyakṣatve 'pi sparśasyaiva grahaṇamiti /
analyzed: atha yatra spārśana pratyakṣa tvam tatra darśanasya api vyāpāraḥ dṛṣṭaḥ ogha śabda ādau saṃkhyā ādayaḥ ca pratyakṣāḥ iti iha api tathābhāvaḥ syāt na ca asti atas sparśa mātram eva pratyakṣam vāri sthite tejasi uṣṇa tā vat iti yathā vāri sthite tejasi āśraya apratyakṣa tve pi uṣṇa tā grahaṇam tadvat iha api āśraya apratyakṣa tve pi sparśasya eva grahaṇam iti
translated: Now, where there is the nature of tactile perception, there is also seen the operation of vision, as in the case of the word 'oṃ'. And number etc. are also perceived, so here too there would be such a nature. But it is not so, therefore touch alone is perception, like the heat of fire in water. Just as the heat of fire in water is perceived even though the substratum is not perceived, so here too, even though the substratum is not perceived, only touch is grasped.

original: naitadevam / vāristhite tejasi rūpasyānudbhūtatvāt sparśamātrasya pratyakṣatvaṃ yuktam / yatra hi rūpodbhavaḥ kāraṇaṃ pratyakṣatve tatrāvaśyaṃ cakṣuṣāpi grahaṇam / saṃkhyādayaśca pratyakṣāḥ / rūpānudbhave ca na grahaṇamiti / dṛṣṭaśca vāyau na rūpaviśeṣaḥ pratyakṣatāyāṃ kāraṇamiti cakṣuṣā agrahaṇam / saṃkhyāderapratyakṣatvaṃ yuktam /
analyzed: na etat evam vāri sthite tejasi rūpasya anudbhūta tvāt sparśa mātrasya pratyakṣa tvam yuktam yatra hi rūpa udbhavaḥ kāraṇam pratyakṣa tve tatra avaśyam cakṣuṣā api grahaṇam saṃkhyā ādayaḥ ca pratyakṣāḥ rūpa anudbhave ca na grahaṇam iti dṛṣṭaḥ ca vāyau na rūpa viśeṣaḥ pratyakṣa tāyām kāraṇam iti cakṣuṣā agrahaṇam saṃkhyā ādeḥ apratyakṣa tvam yuktam
translated: This is not so. In the case of fire in water, since form is not manifest, it is proper that only touch is perceived. Where the cause of perception is the manifestation of form, there the object is necessarily grasped by the eye also. And number etc. are perceived. And where there is no manifestation of form, there is no grasping. And in the case of air, no particular form is seen as the cause of perceptibility, so there is no grasping by the eye. It is proper that number etc. are not perceived.

original: atha rūpaviśeṣābhāve 'pratyakṣatvameva syāditi cet / na / ātmanā vyabhicārāt / tathā hi / ātmā rūpaviśeṣābhāve 'pyantaḥkaraṇapratyakṣaḥ / saṃkhyādayaḥ pratyakṣā apyātmani rūpaviśeṣābhāvādeva apratyakṣā iti /
analyzed: atha rūpa viśeṣa abhāve pratyakṣa tvam eva syāt iti ced na ātmanā vyabhicārāt tathā hi ātmā rūpa viśeṣa abhāve pi antaḥkaraṇa pratyakṣaḥ saṃkhyā ādayaḥ pratyakṣāḥ api ātmani rūpa viśeṣa abhāvāt eva apratyakṣāḥ iti
translated: If it be said that in the absence of a particular form, there would be non-perception itself, (we say) no, because the self is a counterexample. For thus, the self is perceived by the internal organ even in the absence of a particular form. Number etc., though perceived, are not perceived in the self itself due to the absence of a particular form.

original: atha dravyaspārśanapratyakṣatvaṃ rūpaviśeṣasadbhāve satyeva dṛṣṭaṃ ghaṭādau / tathā ca rūpasparśavyatiriktadravyālambanatve 'nusandhānajñāne ca pramāṇamasti yamahamadrākṣaṃ cakṣuṣā tamevaitarhi spṛśāmi / yaṃ vā asprākṣaṃ spārśanena taṃ paśyāmi iti / na ca vāyāvetadastīti sparśamātrālambanamiti cet / tadetadasat / rūpaṃ vināpi vāyoḥ spārśanena pratyakṣatvāt / atha sādhyametat / na / dṛṣṭasya sādhyatve satyatiprasaṅgāt / tathā hi / sparśanavyāpārād vāyāvaparokṣajñānam indriyabhāvavyatirekābhyāmutpadyamānaṃ dṛṣṭamityuktam / tasya ca sādhyatve ghaṭādāvapi darśanaspārśanapratyakṣaṃ sādhyameva syāt / athendriyānuvidhānānna sādhyametat / samānaṃ vāyāvapi / tathedamanusandhānam / tad dvīndriyagrāhyatvād ghaṭādāvupapannam / vāyorekendriyagrāhyatvādasambhavenātīndriyatvāditi /
analyzed: atha dravya spārśana pratyakṣa tvam rūpa viśeṣa sadbhāve sati eva dṛṣṭam ghaṭa ādau tathā ca rūpa sparśa vyatirikta dravya ālambana tve nusandhāna jñāne ca pramāṇam asti yam aham adrākṣam cakṣuṣā tam eva etarhi spṛśāmi yam vā asprākṣam spārśanena tam paśyāmi iti na ca vāyau etat asti iti sparśa mātra ālambanam iti ced tat etat asat rūpam vinā api vāyoḥ spārśanena pratyakṣa tvāt atha sādhyam etat na dṛṣṭasya sādhya tve sati atiprasaṅgā
translated: Now, the perception of substance and touch is seen to occur only when there is the presence of a particular form, as in a pot and so on. And there is evidence in the knowledge of association that it has an object different from form and touch, as in the statements I touch now that which I saw with the eye or I see that which I touched with touch. And this is not the case with air, so it has touch as its sole object, if this is argued. This is not correct, because air is perceived by touch even without form. If this is to be proven, it is not so, because if what is seen is to be proven, there is an overextension. Thus, it has been said that the imperceptible knowledge of air arises from the operation of touch, being produced by the difference from the nature of the sense organ. And if that is to be proven, then the perception of seeing and touching in a pot and so on would also be only to be proven. If this is not to be proven because it conforms to the sense organ, then the same applies to air as well. And this is the association. That is perceived by two sense organs.

original: na cānusandhānādeva ghaṭādijñānasya rūpādivyatiriktavyālambanatvam / kiṃ tarhi / ghaṭādijñānasya vilakṣaṇatvād rūpādivyatiriktārthālambanatvam / tatra cānusandhānasyāpi prāmāṇyamiti / naivaṃ vāyurvāti śīto vāyuḥ iti jñānasya sparśajñānavilakṣaṇatvāt tadvyatiriktārthālambanatvam / na ca sparśopalambhanādanumānajaṃ jñānametaditi vācyam / avinābhāvasambandhānusmaraṇāderabhāvāt / ananubhūyamānasyāpi sambandhānusmaraṇādapi /derapi vyāpārasya /tvakalpanā anyāyyā / I / ghaṭādijñānasyāpyanumānatāprasaṅgāt / vāyupratyayasamānādhikaraṇaścāyaṃ pratyaya iti vāyvālambana eva /
analyzed: na ca anusandhānāt eva ghaṭa ādi jñānasya rūpa ādi vyatirikta vyālambana tvam  kim tarhi ghaṭa ādi jñānasya vilakṣaṇa tvāt rūpa ādi vyatirikta artha ālambana tvam tatra ca anusandhānasya api prāmāṇyam iti na evam vāyuḥ vāti śītaḥ vāyuḥ iti jñānasya sparśa jñāna vilakṣaṇa tvāt tad vyatirikta artha ālambana tvam na ca sparśa upalambhanāt anumāna jam jñānam etat iti vācyam avinābhāva sambandha anusmaraṇa ādeḥ abhāvāt ananubhūyamānasya api samb
translated: And the knowledge of the jar, etc. is not based on something other than color, etc. merely because of the recollection. Rather, it is based on an object other than color, etc. because the knowledge of the jar, etc. is different. And in that case, the recollection is also valid. In the same way, the knowledge the wind is blowing cold is based on an object other than that because it is different from the knowledge of touch. And it cannot be said that this knowledge is inferential because of the perception of touch, because there is no recollection of the relation of invariable concomitance, etc. And it is not proper to assume the operation of the recollection of the relation, etc. even of what is not being experienced, because it would lead to the consequence that the knowledge of the jar, etc. would also be inferential. And this cognition has the same substratum as the cognition of wind, so it is based on wind alone.

original: anye tu anumānenāpi vāyoḥ pratyakṣatāṃ vyavasthāpayanti / svayaṃ pratyakṣeṇopalabdho 'pyarthaḥ parasmai pratipādyamāno 'numānenaiva pratipādyata iti manyamānāḥ / tathā ca asmadādyupalabhyamānasparśādhiṣṭhāno vāyuḥ / asmadāditvagindriyapratyakṣaḥ anudbhūtarūpānyatve sati asmadādyupalabhyamānasparśādhiṣṭhānatvāt / yo yo 'nudbhūtarūpānyatve sati asmadādyupalabhyamānasparśādhiṣṭhānaḥ sa so 'smāditvagindriyapratyakṣaḥ / yathā ghaṭādiḥ / tathā cānudbhūtarūpānyatve satyasmadādyupalabhyamānasparśādhiṣṭhāno vāyuḥ / tasmādasmadāditvagindriyapratyakṣa iti /
analyzed: anye tu anumānena api vāyoḥ pratyakṣa tām vyavasthāpayanti svayam pratyakṣeṇa upalabdhaḥ pi arthaḥ parasmai pratipādyamānaḥ numānena eva pratipādyate iti manyamānāḥ tathā ca asmad ādi upalabhyamāna sparśa adhiṣṭhānaḥ vāyuḥ asmad ādi tvac indriya pratyakṣaḥ anudbhūta rūpa anya tve sati asmad ādi upalabhyamāna sparśa adhiṣṭhāna tvāt yaḥ yaḥ nudbhūta rūpa anya tve sati asmad ādi upalabhyamāna sparśa adhiṣṭhānaḥ sa saḥ sma ādi tvac indr
translated: Others, however, establish the perceptibility of air even through inference, thinking that an object perceived by oneself through perception, when being conveyed to another, is conveyed only through inference. Thus, air is the substratum of the touch perceived by us, and is perceptible by our tactile sense, because it is the substratum of the touch perceived by us, while being different from the undemonstrated form. Whatever is the substratum of the touch perceived by us, while being different from the undemonstrated form, that is perceptible by our tactile sense. For example, a pot, etc. And air is the substratum of the touch perceived by us, while being different from the undemonstrated form. Therefore, it is perceptible by our tactile sense.

original: nanvevaṃ sarveṣāmapyatīndriyāṇāmasmadādipratyakṣatvaṃ syāt prameyatvāditi hetunā / na / parapratipattyaiva bādhyamānatvāt / tathā hi / paro vijānāti na me 'sti paramāṇvādiviṣayajñānam iti / svayamaparokṣajñānasadbhāve sati parapratipādanāyānumānopanyāso yuktaḥ / sa ca vāyāvasti na paramāṇvādāviti / tathā paramāṇvādirasmadādīndriyaviṣayatve paramāṇvādirūpatāṃ jahyāt / mahattvādiyoginyasmadādīndriyavyāpāropalabdheriti /
analyzed: nanu evam sarveṣām api atīndriyāṇām asmat ādi pratyakṣa tvam syāt prameya tvāt iti hetunā na para pratipattyā eva bādhyamāna tvāt tathā hi paraḥ vijānāti na me sti paramāṇu ādi viṣaya jñānam iti svayam aparokṣa jñāna sadbhāve sati para pratipādanāya anumāna upanyāsaḥ yuktaḥ sa ca vāyau asti na paramāṇu ādau iti tathā paramāṇu ādiḥ asmat ādi indriya viṣaya tve paramāṇu ādi rūpatām jahyāt mahat tva ādi yogini asmat ādi indriya vyāpāra upal
translated: But in that case, all imperceptible things would be perceptible to us, because of the reason being an object of knowledge? No, because that is contradicted by the cognition of others. For others cognize, I do not have knowledge of atoms and so on. When the existence of self-evident knowledge is admitted, it is proper to cite inference for the purpose of communicating it to others. And that does not exist in the case of atoms and so on. Moreover, if atoms and so on were the objects of our senses, they would lose their atomic nature. Because the operation of our senses, which are endowed with magnitude and so on, is observed.

original: idānīṃ pratyakṣeṇa vāyusadbhāve vyavasthāpite viṣayanirūpaṇārthamāha viṣayastūpalabhyamānasparśādhiṣṭhānam iti / upalabhyamānaścāsau sparśādhiṣṭhānabhūtaśceti tathoktaḥ / apratyakṣavādinām upalabhyamānaścāsau sparśaśca / tasyādhiṣṭhānabhūta iti vyākhyā / tatra cāsmadādipratipādanāya śāstrasyārambhād asmadādiviśeṣaṇamapyūhyam / upalambho 'pīndriyadvāreṇaiva vivakṣita iti / anyathā hi pramāṇāntareṇopalambhaḥ śarīrādāvapyastīti upalabhyamānasparśādhiṣṭhānatvaṃ vyabhicāri viṣayalakṣaṇaṃ syāt / evam asmadādīndriyopalabhyamānasparśādhiṣṭhānatvād itarasmād bhidyate / viṣaya iti vā vyavahartavyaḥ /
analyzed: idānīm pratyakṣeṇa vāyu sadbhāve vyavasthāpite viṣaya nirūpaṇa artham āha viṣayaḥ tu upalabhyamāna sparśa adhiṣṭhānam iti upalabhyamānaḥ ca asau sparśa adhiṣṭhāna bhūtaḥ ca iti tathā uktaḥ apratyakṣa vādinām upalabhyamānaḥ ca asau sparśaḥ ca tasya adhiṣṭhāna bhūtaḥ iti vyākhyā tatra ca asmat ādi pratipādanāya śāstrasya ārambhāt asmat ādi viśeṣaṇam api ūhyam upalambhaḥ upi indriya dvāreṇa eva vivakṣitaḥ iti anyathā hi pram
translated: Now, when the existence of air has been established by perception, to determine the object, he says: The object is the substratum of the perceived touch. It is said to be perceived and to be the substratum of touch. For those who do not accept perception, it is both perceived and touch. It is explained that it is the substratum of that. And there, in order to convey to us and others, the qualification of us and others should also be inferred, since the treatise is begun. It is also intended that perception is only through the sense organs. Otherwise, if perception were by another means of knowledge, it would be present in the body etc. also, so the definition of the object would be fallacious, being the substratum of the perceived touch. Thus, the object is to be designated as different from the other, or as the object, because it is the substratum of the perceived touch perceived by our and other sense organs.

original: tathā na paraṃ viṣayalakṣaṇo vāyurasmadādīndriyapratyakṣo 'numānāvagamyaścetyāha sparśaśabdadhṛtikampaliṅgaḥ iti / sparśaśca śabdaśca dhṛtiśca kampaśceti liṅgāni yasyāsau tathokta iti / tathā hyanuṣṇāśītatve sati apājakaḥ sparśaḥ / kvacidāśritaḥ / guṇatvāt / yo yo guṇaḥ sa sa āśrito dṛṣṭaḥ yathā rūpādiḥ / tathā cāyaṃ guṇaḥ / tasmādāśrita iti / guṇatvañcāsya sāmānyavattve 'dravyatve ca sati niyamenācākṣuṣapratyakṣatvād I / rasavaditi / acākṣuṣapratyakṣatvaṃ ghaṭādāvastīti niyamagrahaṇam / tathāpi sparśatvādisāmānye niyamenācākṣuṣapratyakṣatvam / na ca guṇa iti vyabhicārastadarthaṃ sāmānyavattve satīti viśeṣaṇam / sāmānyavattvaṃ dravyāditrayasyāstīti niyamenācākṣuṣapratyakṣapadam / sāmānyavattve sati niyamenācākṣuṣapratyakṣatvaṃ vāyvādāvastīti adravyatve satīti padam / asya pakṣadharmatve sati sapakṣaikadeśe vartamānasya atyantaṃ vipakṣād vyāvṛttasya abādhitaviṣayatvād asatpratipakṣatvena gamakatvam /
analyzed: tathā na param viṣaya lakṣaṇaḥ vāyuḥ asmat ādi indriya pratyakṣaḥ numāna avagamyaḥ ca iti āha sparśa śabda dhṛti kampa liṅgaḥ iti sparśaḥ ca śabdaḥ ca dhṛtiḥ ca kampaḥ ca iti liṅgāni yasya asau tathā uktaḥ iti tathā hi anuṣṇa aśīta tve sati apājakaḥ sparśaḥ kvacid āśritaḥ guṇa tvāt yaḥ yaḥ guṇaḥ sa saḥ āśritaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ yathā rūpa ādiḥ tathā ca ayam guṇaḥ tasmāt āśritaḥ iti guṇa tvam ca asya sāmānyavat
translated: Similarly, the wind is not an object characterized by touch, sound, support, and motion, perceptible by our senses, and inferred. He says: Having touch, sound, support, and motion as its characteristics. Touch, sound, support, and motion are the characteristics of this, so it is said. For example, when not hot or cold, the touch is unctuous. It is dependent on something, because it is a quality. Whatever quality is seen to be dependent, like color etc., this is also a quality. Therefore, it is dependent. And its quality is the perceptibility by non-visual perception due to its generality and non-substance. Like taste. The non-visual perceptibility exists in the pot etc., so the restriction is mentioned. Even then, there is non-visual perceptibility due to the generality of touch etc. by restriction. And it is not a quality, so there is no fallacy. For that purpose, the qualification having generality is used. The generality exists in the three, substance etc., so the word non-visual perceptibility is used by restriction.

original: athāstvanuṣṇāśītatve satyapākajasparśasya āśritatvam / apākajatve tu kiṃ pramāṇam / pākajarūpādiviyogāt / tathā hi / pākajasparśaḥ pākajarūpādisahito dṛṣṭo ghaṭādāviti / asyāpi pākajatve tathābhāvaḥ syāt / atha sadbhāve 'pyanudbhūtatvāt teṣāmanupalambhaḥ / tanna / anyatrābhāvāt / na hi pākajasparśopalambhe 'pi rūpādīnāmanyatra atyantānupalambho dṛṣṭa iti / na cātra rūpādīnāmastitve pramāṇamastītyanubhavānupapattiḥ / sadbhāve 'nudbhavakalpanopapatteḥ / atha asadbhāve kiṃ pramāṇamiti ced / atyantānupalabdhireva / tathā hi / vivakṣitasparśādhikaraṇaṃ gurutvarahitaṃ sambhavatīti sahacaritā rūpādayo na kadācidupalabhyante pramāṇata ityasantaḥ / tathā pākajasparśasya gurutvasāhacaryopalabdherasyāpi pākajatve tatsadbhāvaḥ syāt / gurutvasambandhe cordhvaṃ parṇādidhāraṇānupapattiḥ / tasyāpi gurutvasambandhitayā tatprasaṅgāt / na ca pākajasparśādhikaraṇaṃ gurutvarahitaṃ sambhavatīti pārthivasparśavilakṣaṇatvānna pṛthivyāṃ vartate / nāpyudakatejasoranuṣṇāśītatvāt / anyatrāsambhava eveti / yatrāyaṃ vartate asau vāyuriti /
analyzed: atha astu anuṣṇa aśīta tve sati apāka ja sparśasya āśrita tvam apāka ja tve tu kim pramāṇam pāka ja rūpa ādi viyogāt tathā hi pāka ja sparśaḥ pāka ja rūpa ādi sahitaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ ghaṭa ādau iti asya api pāka ja tve tathā bhāvaḥ syāt atha sadbhāve pi anudbhūta tvāt teṣām anupalambhaḥ tat na anyatra abhāvāt na hi pāka ja sparśa upalambhe pi rūpa ādīnām anyatra atyanta anupalambhaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ iti na ca atra rūpa ādīnām astitve pramāṇam asti
translated: Now, let it be that when there is no hot or cold touch, the touch produced by cooking is dependent [on something else]. But what is the evidence for its not being produced by cooking? Because it is devoid of the color etc. produced by cooking. For thus, the touch produced by cooking is seen to be accompanied by the color etc. produced by cooking in a pot etc. If this [touch of water] were also produced by cooking, it would exist in that way. But if it exists, it is not perceived because it is not manifest. That is not so, because it does not exist elsewhere. For even when the touch produced by cooking is perceived, the complete non-perception of color etc. is not seen elsewhere. And here, there is no evidence for the existence of color etc., so the experience is not possible. Because it is possible to imagine that [color etc.] do not manifest even when they exist. But if it is asked what is the evidence for their non-existence, it is only complete non-perception. For thus, it is possible for the substratum of the intended touch to be devoid of weight, so the co-occurring color etc. are never perceived by valid means of knowledge, so they do not exist. Thus, because the touch produced by cooking is perceived to be concomitant with weight, this [touch of water] is not produced by cooking.

original: tathā ādyaḥ śukaśukāśabdaḥ santatānumitaḥ / sparśavaddravyasambandhakāryaḥ / vibhāgajaśabdajaśabdānyatve sati śabdatvāt / yo yo vibhāgajaśabdajaśabdānyatve sati śabdaḥ sa sparśavaddravyasaṃyogakāryaḥ / yathā bherīdaṇḍasaṃyogajaḥ śabdaḥ / tathā cāyam / tasmād yathoktasādhya iti / nanu vibhāgajaśabdādasya viśeṣānupalabdheḥ sandigdhaṃ tadanyatve satīti viśeṣaṇam / na / rūpādimatāṃ ghanāvayavasanniveśabhājāṃ kāraṇavibhāgapūrvakavibhāgasya śabdārambhakatvopalabdhestadabhāvastu avivādāspada iti vibhāgajatvābhāvāt / tathā vibhāgajatve śukaśukādiśabdasya śākhādiṣu kampasamānakālopalabdhirna syāt / sā tu dṛṣṭā / na cātra śākhādivāyuvibhāgasya śabdārambhakatvaṃ yuktam / kāraṇavibhāgajatvānupapatteratastadanyatve satīti viśeṣaṇamasandigdhameva /
analyzed: tathā ādyaḥ śuka śukā śabdaḥ santata anumitaḥ sparśavat dravya sambandha kāryaḥ vibhāga ja śabda ja śabda anya tve sati śabda tvāt yaḥ yaḥ vibhāga ja śabda ja śabda anya tve sati śabdaḥ sa sparśavat dravya saṃyoga kāryaḥ yathā bherī daṇḍa saṃyoga jaḥ śabdaḥ tathā ca ayam tasmāt yathā ukta sādhyaḥ iti  nanu vibhāga ja śabdāt asya viśeṣa anupalabdheḥ sandigdham tad anya tve sati iti viśeṣaṇam na rūpa ādimatām ghana avayava sanniveśa bh
translated: Similarly, the first sound of the parrot's cry is continuously inferred to be produced by the contact of a tangible substance, because it is a sound, different from the sound produced by the sound produced by the disjunction. Whatever sound is different from the sound produced by the sound produced by the disjunction is produced by the contact of a tangible substance, like the sound produced by the contact of the bell and the stick. And this is so. Therefore, it has the stated conclusion. But since the difference from that is not perceived from the sound produced by the disjunction, the qualification being different from that is doubtful. No, because the disjunction of the cause of those which have color etc. and are composed of dense parts is found to be the cause of the origin of sound, and its absence is undisputed. Therefore, because it is not produced by disjunction, the sound of the parrot etc. would not be perceived simultaneously with the shaking of the branches etc. But that is seen. And here it is not proper for the disjunction of the wind in the branches etc. to be the cause of the origin of sound. Because it is not possible to be produced by the disjunction of the cause.

original: dhṛtirdhāraṇam / ākāśe parṇādīnāmavasthānam / tacca sparśavaddravyasaṃyogakāryam / prayatnādyabhāve sati dhāraṇatvāt / yad yad prayatnādyabhāve sati dhāraṇaṃ tattat sparśavaddravyasaṃyogakāryam / yathā ādhāragatodakam / tathā cedam / tasmāt sparśavaddravyasaṃyogakāryamiti /
analyzed: dhṛtiḥ dhāraṇam ākāśe parṇa ādīnām avasthānam tat ca sparśavat dravya saṃyoga kāryam prayatna ādi abhāve sati dhāraṇa tvāt yat yat prayatna ādi abhāve sati dhāraṇam tat tat sparśavat dravya saṃyoga kāryam yathā ādhāra gata udakam tathā ca idam tasmāt sparśavat dravya saṃyoga kāryam iti
translated: Dhriti (dhṛti) means holding. The state of leaves and so on in the sky. And that is the effect of contact with a tangible substance. Because it is holding when effort and so on are absent. Whatever is holding when effort and so on are absent is the effect of contact with a tangible substance. Like water in a container. And this is so. Therefore, it is the effect of contact with a tangible substance.

original: pakṣīṇāṃ /sannipatitānāṃ mūrchanamityāha saṃmūrchanaṃ punaḥ samānajavayorvāyvorviruddhadikkriyayoḥ / sannipāto hi sambandhaḥ / sa ca kayoḥ / vāyvoḥ / kiṃviśiṣṭayorityāha samānajavayoḥ / samānastulyo javo vego yayostau samānajavau tayoriti / anyathā hi ekasyālpajavatve balīyasā abhibhavānna saṃmūrchanamiti / tathā hyekadikkriyayorna saṃmūrchanamityāha viruddhadikkriyayoḥ viruddhe dikkriye yayostau viruddhadikkriyāviti / tathā hyekasya prācīnadiggamanamanyasya ca tadabhimukhamāgamanamiti kriyayorvirodhaḥ /
analyzed: pakṣīṇām sannipatitānām mūrchanam iti āha saṃmūrchanam punar samāna javayoḥ vāyvoḥ viruddha diś kriyayoḥ sannipātaḥ hi sambandhaḥ sa ca kayoḥ vāyvoḥ kiṃviśiṣṭayoḥ iti āha samāna javayoḥ samānaḥ tulyaḥ javaḥ vegaḥ yayoḥ tau samāna javau tayoḥ iti anyathā hi ekasya alpa java tve balīyasā abhibhavāt na saṃmūrchanam iti tathā hi eka diś kriyayoḥ na saṃmūrchanam iti āha viruddha diś kriyayoḥ viruddhe diś kriye yayoḥ tau viruddha di
translated: Of birds, when they assemble, it is called a 'mūrchana'. A 'sammūrchana' is again the union of two winds of equal speed moving in opposite directions. For a 'sammūrchana' is a connection, and that is of what two? Of winds. Of what kind? It is said: of equal speed. Those two are of equal speed, having equal speed, equal velocity. Otherwise, if one has less speed, it would be overcome by the stronger one, and there would be no 'sammūrchana'. For thus, when moving in the same direction, there is no 'sammūrchana'. It is said: of winds moving in opposite directions. Those two have opposite directions of motion, moving in opposite directions. For thus, one moves towards the east, and the other comes towards it, so the motions are opposed.

original: anye tu viruddhāyāṃ diśi kriye yayostau tathoktāviti manyante / atrāvirodhaścintanīyaḥ /
analyzed: anye tu viruddhāyām diśi kriye yayoḥ tau tathā uktau iti manyante atra avirodhaḥ cintanīyaḥ
translated: But others think that those two are said to have motions in opposite directions, in an opposite direction. Here the non-opposition should be considered.

original: athetthaṃ sannipātaḥ kutaḥ pratīyata ityāha so 'pi sannipātaḥ sāvayavinorūrdhvagamanenānumīyate / sahāvayavibhirvartete yau tau sāvayavināviti / tadavayavā api mahānto 'vayavina iti jñāpanārthamidamuktam / anyathā hi sāvayavayoriti syāt /
analyzed: atha ittham sannipātaḥ kutas pratīyate iti āha saḥ u pi sannipātaḥ sa avayavinoḥ ūrdhva gamanena anumīyate saha avayavibhiḥ vartete yau tau sa avayavinau iti tad avayavāḥ api mahāntaḥ vayavinaḥ iti jñāpana artham idam uktam anyathā hi sa avayavayoḥ iti syāt
translated: Now, how is this conjunction known to exist? It is said: That conjunction is inferred from the upward movement of the two extended objects. Those two are extended because they exist along with the parts. The parts of those are also large, so this is said to make that known. Otherwise, it would be of the extended objects.

original: anye tvavayavino 'tra tṛṇādayo vivakṣitā na tadavayavā iti manyante /
analyzed: anye tu avayavinaḥ tṛṇa ādayaḥ vivakṣitāḥ na tad avayavāḥ iti manyante
translated: However, others think that the extended objects intended here are grass etc., not their parts.

original: atha vāyorevordhvagamanaṃ kathaṃ pratīyata ityāha tadapi tṛṇādīnāmūrdhvagamaneneti / tathā hi / tṛṇādīnāmūrdhvagamanamacetanatvānnopapannaṃ bhavati / nāpi vegāt / kvacinmandagatitvād / ādyakarmotpattau ca tadabhāvāt / anyasya ca sāmarthyānupalabdhervegavaddravyasambandho 'numīyate / na ca tat pārthivam / āpyaṃ vā / tasyāpi gurutvādhikaraṇatayā ūrdhvagamane gurutvarahitaṃ nimittāntaraṃ vācyam / na cātra agnerūrdhvajvalanasvabhāvatayā tatsaṃyogāt tṛṇādīnāmūrdhvagamanam / indhanaviśeṣābhāvena ūrdhvajvalanāsambhavāt / tadanupalabdheśca / na cānyasyātra sāmarthyamiti vāyusambandhāt tṛṇādīnāmūrdhvagamanamiti jñāyate / tasya tiryaggatiśīlatayā nordhvaṃ gamanam / antarāle 'nyathā sambhāvyata iti vāyvantareṇa pratibandhaḥ / tathā hi vāyurbalīyān apareṇa ca balīyasā pratibandhāt sannipātāt svāṃ gatiṃ I / virahayyordhvaṃ gacchati / tatsaṃyogācca tṛṇādīnāmūrdhvagamanamiti siddhaṃ tṛṇādīnāmūrdhvagamanena vāyorūrdhvagamanam / tena ca sannipātaḥ / tasmānnānātvamiti /
analyzed: atha vāyoḥ eva ūrdhva gamanam katham pratīyate iti āha tat api tṛṇa ādīnām ūrdhva gamanena iti tathā hi tṛṇa ādīnām ūrdhva gamanam acetana tvāt na upapannam bhavati nā api vegāt kvacid manda gati tvāt ādya karma utpattau ca tad abhāvāt anyasya ca sāmarthya anupalabdheḥ vegavat dravya sambandhaḥ numīyate na ca tat pārthivam āpyam vā tasya api guru tva adhikaraṇa tayā ūrdhva gamane guru tva rahitam nimitta antaram vācyam na ca atra agneḥ ūrdhva jvalana svabhāva
translated: Now, how is the upward movement of air understood? It is said that is also inferred from the upward movement of grass etc. Indeed, the upward movement of grass etc. is not logically possible due to their insentience. Nor is it due to velocity, because sometimes it moves slowly, and because there is no such velocity at the time of the initial action. And since the operation of anything else is not perceived, the connection with a moving substance is inferred. And that is not earthly or watery. Because that also, being the substratum of gravity, would require a different cause for upward movement, devoid of gravity. And here, the upward movement of grass etc. is not due to the conjunction of fire with its nature of burning upwards, because upward burning is not possible due to the absence of a particular fuel, and because that is not perceived. And since the operation of anything else here is not perceived, it is known that the upward movement of grass etc. is due to their connection with air. And because air has a horizontal tendency, it does not move upwards. It is possible that it moves differently in the interval, so air

original: atha prāṇākhyasya vāyorupalabhyamānasparśādhiṣṭhānatayā viṣayāntarbhāve 'pi prādhānyajñāpanārthaṃ viśiṣṭārthakriyākāritayā pṛthagabhidhānam / tathā tattvajñānino yogābhyāse pravartamānasya prāṇo 'tyantamupakārīti pṛthagucyata ityāha prāṇo 'ntaḥśarīre rasamaladhātūnāṃ preraṇādihetuḥ iti / tathā hyantaḥśarīre vartamānatvāt prāṇa ityukte rasādibhirvyabhicāraḥ / tadarthaṃ rasamaladhātūnāṃ preraṇādiheturiti / tathāpi rasādipreraṇahetutvāt prāṇa ityukte 'dṛṣṭādiṣu vyabhicāraḥ / tadartham antaḥśarīre vartamāna iti / na cādṛṣṭādayo 'ntaḥśarīre vartante 'dṛṣṭasya cātmavṛttitvād / īśvarasya cāvṛttimattvāditi / tadevamantaḥśarīre vartamāno rasādipreraṇahetutvād itarasmād bhidyate / prāṇa iti vā vyavahartavyaḥ /
analyzed: atha prāṇa ākhyasya vāyoḥ upalabhyamāna sparśa adhiṣṭhāna tayā viṣaya antarbhāve pi prādhānya jñāpana artham viśiṣṭa artha kriyā kāritayā pṛthak abhidhānam tathā tattva jñāninaḥ yoga abhyāse pravartamānasya tyantam upakāri iti pṛthak ucyate iti āha prāṇaḥ ntar śarīre rasa mala dhātūnām preraṇa ādi hetuḥ iti tathā hi antar śarīre vartamāna tvāt prāṇaḥ iti ukte rasa ādibhiḥ vyabhicāraḥ tad artham rasa mala dhātūnām preraṇa ādi h
translated: Now, although the wind called prāṇa is included among the objects because it is the substratum of the touch that is perceived, it is designated separately in order to indicate its preeminence by its distinctive function. Thus, it is said that for one who is engaged in the practice of yoga with the knowledge of reality, prāṇa is of utmost benefit, so it is mentioned separately. It is said: Prāṇa is the cause of the stimulation etc. of the juices, impurities and elements within the body. For thus, when prāṇa is mentioned as existing within the body, there is an error with the juices etc. For that purpose, it is said: the cause of the stimulation etc. of the juices, impurities and elements. Still, when prāṇa is mentioned as the cause of the stimulation of the juices etc., there is an error in the unseen etc. For that purpose, it is said: existing within the body. And the unseen etc. do not exist within the body, because the unseen belongs to the self, and because God is without a body. Thus, existing within the body and being the cause of the stimulation of the juices etc., it is distinguished from the other. It is called prāṇa.

original: yad vā vāyusāmānyalakṣaṇānuvṛttau satyāmantaḥśarīre vartamānatvād rasādipreraṇahetutvācca prāṇa ityukte vyabhicārābhāvaḥ /
analyzed: yat vā vāyu sāmānya lakṣaṇa anuvṛttau satyām antar śarīre vartamāna tvāt rasa ādi preraṇa hetu tvāt ca prāṇaḥ iti ukte vyabhicāra abhāvaḥ
translated: Or, when the general characteristic of air continues, when it is said that because it exists inside the body and is the cause of driving rasa etc., it is called prana, there is no fallacy.

original: athāsau kimeko 'neka ityāha ekaḥ san kriyābhedād apānādisaṃjñāṃ labhate iti / atha vāstavabhedaḥ kasmānneṣyate / bādhakopapatteḥ / tathā hi pañca vāyavaḥ śarīre yadi vyāptyā vartante tadā sambandhādeko vāyurbhavatīti pañcatvanivṛttiḥ / athāvyāptyā / tathāpyekena śarīrasya vyāpanādapareṣāmasambhava iti manyamānaḥ kriyābhedena bhedamāha / sa eva mukhanāsikābhyāṃ niṣkramaṇaśīlo vāyuḥ prāṇākhyaḥ / adhonayanānmalāderapānaḥ / samaṃ nayanāt samānaḥ / ūrdhvaṃ nayanādudānaḥ / vividhamanekaprakāreṇa nayanād vyāna iti /🔽iti vāyuvaidharmyam
analyzed: atha asau kim ekaḥ na ekaḥ iti āha ekaḥ san kriyā bhedāt apāna ādi saṃjñām labhate iti  atha vāstava bhedaḥ kasmāt na iṣyate bādhaka upapatteḥ tathā hi pañca vāyavaḥ śarīre yadi vyāptyā vartante tadā sambandhāt ekaḥ vāyuḥ bhavati iti pañcatva nivṛttiḥ atha avyāptyā tathā api ekena śarīrasya vyāpanāt apareṣām asambhavaḥ iti manyamānaḥ kriyā bhedena bhedam āha saḥ eva mukha nāsikābhyām niṣkramaṇa śīlaḥ vāyuḥ prāṇa ākhyaḥ adha🔽iti vāyu vaidharmyam
translated: Now, if it is asked whether it is one or many, he says: Being one, it obtains the names apana etc. due to the difference in its actions. Then, why is real difference not accepted? Because of the occurrence of contradiction. Thus, if the five airs exist in the body by pervasion, then due to the connection, they become one air, and the state of being five ceases. If they exist without pervasion, then also, thinking that one pervades the body and the others are impossible, he speaks of difference due to the difference in action. That same air which goes out through the mouth and nose is called prana. Apana because it carries down waste etc. Samana because it carries equally. Udana because it carries upwards. Vyana because it carries in various ways.

original: ihedānīṃ caturṇāṃ mahābhūtānāṃ sṛṣṭisaṃhāravidhirucyate / brāhmaṇe mānena varṣaśatasyānte vartamānasya brahmaṇo 'pavargakāle saṃsārakhinnānāṃ sarvaprāṇināṃ niśi viśrāmārthaṃ sakalabhuvanapatermaheśvarasya sañjihīrṣāsamakālaṃ śarīrendriyamahābhūtopanibandhakānāṃ sarvātmagatādṛṣṭānāṃ vṛttinirodhe sati maheśvarecchātmāṇusaṃyogajakarmabhyaḥ śarīrendriyakāraṇāṇuI /vibhāgebhyastatsaṃyoganivṛttau teṣāmāparamāṇvanto vināśaḥ / tathā pṛthivyudakajvalanapavanānāmapi mahābhūtānāmanenaiva krameṇottarasminnuttarasmiṃśca sati pūrvapūrvasya vināśaḥ / tataḥ pravibhaktāḥ paramāṇavo 'vatiṣṭhante dharmādharmasaṃskārānuviddhāścātmānastāvantameva kālam /PDhS
analyzed: iha idānīm caturṇām mahābhūtānām sṛṣṭi saṃhāra vidhiḥ ucyate brāhmaṇe mānena varṣa śatasya ante vartamānasya brahmaṇaḥ upavarga kāle saṃsāra khinnānām sarva prāṇinām niśi viśrāma artham sakala bhuvana pateḥ maheśvarasya sañjihīrṣā sama kālam śarīra indriya mahābhūta upanibandhakānām sarva ātma gata adṛṣṭānām vṛtti nirodhe sati maheśvara icchā ātma aṇu saṃyoga ja karmabhyaḥ teṣām ā paramāṇu antaḥ vināśaḥ tathā pṛ
translated: Now, here the method of creation and dissolution of the four great elements is stated. At the end of a hundred years of Brahmā, when Brahmā is about to attain final liberation, for the rest of all living beings who are weary of saṃsāra, for the sake of their rest at night, at the same time as the Lord of all worlds, Maheśvara, desires to withdraw [the world], when there is cessation of the operation of all the unseen forces inherent in the self, which bind the body, senses, and great elements, due to the will of Maheśvara, from the actions produced by the conjunction of the self with the atoms, from the divisions of the atoms that are the causes of the body and senses, when their conjunction ceases, they are destroyed down to the ultimate atoms. Similarly, of the great elements - earth, water, fire, and air - by this same process, when the latter is present, the former is destroyed. Then the separated atoms remain, and the selves, imbued with the impressions of dharma and adharma, remain for that same length of time.

original: tataḥ punaḥ prāṇināṃ bhogabhūtaye maheśvarasya sisṛkṣānantaraṃ sarvātmagatavṛttilabdhādṛṣṭāpekṣebhyastatsaṃyogebhyaḥ pavanaparamāṇuṣu karmotpattau teṣāṃ pūrvadiśā parasparasaṃyogebhyo dvyaṇukādiprakrameṇa mahān vāyuḥ samutpanno nabhasi dodhūyamānastiṣṭhati /PDhS
analyzed: tatas punar prāṇinām bhoga bhūtaye maheśvarasya sisṛkṣā anantaram sarva ātma gata vṛtti labdha adṛṣṭa apekṣebhyaḥ tad saṃyogebhyaḥ pavana paramāṇuṣu karma utpattau teṣām pūrva diśā paraspara saṃyogebhyaḥ dvyaṇuka ādi prakrameṇa mahān vāyuḥ samutpannaḥ nabhasi dodhūyamānaḥ tiṣṭhati
translated: Then again, for the enjoyment of living beings, after the creation of Mahesvara, when actions arise in the air atoms in dependence on the unseen forces obtained from the conjunctions with the souls of all beings, those air atoms, by their mutual conjunctions in the eastern direction, produce a great wind through the process of dyads, etc., and it remains blowing in space.

original: tadanantaraṃ tasminnevāpyebhyaḥ paramāṇubhyastenaiva krameṇa mahān salilanidhirutpannaḥ poplūyamānastiṣṭhati / tadanantaraṃ tasminneva jalanidhau pārthivebhyaḥ paramāṇubhyo dvyaṇukādiprakrameṇa mahāpṛthivī samutpannā saṃhatā avatiṣṭhate /PDhS
analyzed: tad anantaram tasmin eva apyebhyaḥ paramāṇubhyaḥ tena eva krameṇa mahān salilanidhiḥ utpannaḥ poplūyamānaḥ tiṣṭhati tad anantaram tasmin eva jalanidhau pārthivebhyaḥ paramāṇubhyaḥ dvyaṇuka ādi prakrameṇa mahā pṛthivī samutpannā saṃhatā avatiṣṭhate
translated: After that, in that same water, from those very atoms, by that same process, a great ocean of water is produced and remains floating. After that, in that same ocean of water, from the earth atoms, by the process of dyads, etc., a great earth is produced and remains united.

original: tadanantaraṃ tasminneva mahodadhau taijasebhyo 'ṇubhyo dvyaṇukādiprakrameṇotpanno mahāṃstejorāśirdedīpyamānastiṣṭhati / evaṃ samutpanneṣu caturṣu mahābhūteṣu maheśvarasyābhidhyānamātrāt taijasebhyo 'ṇubhyaḥ pārthivaparamāṇusahitebhyo mahadaṇḍamutpadyate /PDhS
analyzed: tad anantaram tasmin eva mahā udadhau taijasebhyaḥ ṇubhyaḥ dvyaṇuka ādi prakrameṇa utpannaḥ mahān tejaḥ rāśiḥ dedīpyamānaḥ tiṣṭhati evam samutpanneṣu caturṣu mahābhūteṣu maheśvarasya abhidhyāna mātrāt taijasebhyaḥ ṇubhyaḥ pārthiva paramāṇu sahitebhyaḥ mahat aṇḍam utpadyate
translated: Then, in that very great ocean, a great mass of fire arises from fiery atoms through the process of dyad-production and so on, shining brightly. Thus, when the four great elements have arisen, from the mere contemplation of Maheśvara, a great egg arises from fiery atoms along with earthen atoms.

original: tasmiṃścaturvadanakamalaṃ sarvalokapitāmahaṃ brahmāṇaṃ sakalabhuvanasahitamutpādya prajāsarge viniyuṅkte / sa ca maheśvareṇa viniyukto brahmā atiśayajñānavairāgyaiśvaryasampannaḥ prāṇināṃ karmavipākaṃ viditvā karmānurūpajñānabhogāyuṣaḥ sutān prajāpatīn mānasān manudevarṣipitṛgaṇān mukhabāhūrupādataścaturo varṇān anyāni coccāvacāni ca sṛṣṭvā āśayānurūpairdharmajñānavairāgyaiścaryaiḥ saṃyojayatīti /PDhS
analyzed: tasmin catur vadana kamalam sarva loka pitāmaham brahmāṇam sakala bhuvana sahitam utpādya prajā sarge viniyuṅkte sa ca maheśvareṇa viniyuktaḥ brahmā atiśaya jñāna vairāgya aiśvarya sampannaḥ prāṇinām karma vipākam viditvā karma anurūpa jñāna bhoga āyuṣaḥ sutān prajāpatīn mānasān manu deva ṛṣi pitṛ gaṇān mukha bāhu ūru pādataḥ caturaḥ varṇān anyāni ca uccāvacāni ca sṛṣṭvā āśaya anurūpaiḥ dharma jñāna vairāgyaiḥ caryaiḥ saṃyoj
translated: And having produced in that [egg] the four-faced lotus, the grandfather of all worlds, Brahmā, along with all the worlds, he employs him in the creation of beings. And that Brahmā, employed by Maheśvara, endowed with superior knowledge, detachment, and power, knowing the ripening of beings' actions, creates for the enjoyment and longevity of beings in accordance with their knowledge and actions, the mental Prajāpatis, the Manus, the celestial sages, and the groups of ancestors, and the four castes from the mouth, arms, thighs, and feet, and other high and low [beings], and unites them with dharma, knowledge, detachment, and power in accordance with their aspirations.

original: sṛṣṭisaṃhāravidhiḥ
analyzed: sṛṣṭi saṃhāra vidhiḥ
translated: The method of creation and dissolution

original: athedānīṃ bhūtānāṃ parīkṣāśeṣanivartanadvāreṇeśvaraparīkṣārthaṃ caturṇām ityādiprakaraṇam / tathā hi bhūtānāmuddeśānantaraṃ pūrvaprakaraṇeṣu lakṣaṇaparīkṣābhidhāne 'pi sṛṣṭisaṃhāravidhirnoktaḥ / tatheśvara ūrdhvaṃ namaskāravyājenoddiṣṭo lakṣaṇataśca / pradhānatvād dharmaparīkṣāmantareṇa parīkṣituṃ na śakyata iti prakaraṇārambhaḥ / sṛṣṭisaṃhāravidhiśca tulyatayaikasminneva prakaraṇe 'bhidhīyate / pratiprakaraṇābhidhāne tu prakaraṇacatuṣṭayametāvat syāditi saṅgraharūpatāvyāghātaḥ /
analyzed: atha idānīm bhūtānām parīkṣā śeṣa nivartana dvāreṇa īśvara parīkṣā artham caturṇām ityādi prakaraṇam tathā hi bhūtānām uddeśa anantaram pūrva prakaraṇeṣu lakṣaṇa parīkṣā abhidhāne sṛṣṭi saṃhāra vidhiḥ na uktaḥ tathā īśvaraḥ ūrdhvam namaskāra vyājena uddiṣṭaḥ lakṣaṇataḥ ca pradhāna tvāt dharma parīkṣām antareṇa parīkṣitum na śakyate iti prakaraṇa ārambhaḥ sṛṣṭi saṃhāra vidhiḥ ca tulya tayā ekasmin eva
translated: Now, in order to examine God by way of the examination of the remaining parts of the creation, the section beginning with of the four and so on. Thus, even though the definition and examination of the creation are mentioned in the previous sections immediately after the enumeration of the elements, the method of creation and dissolution is not stated. Similarly, God is mentioned by the pretext of salutation above and by definition. Since He is the principal, He cannot be examined without the examination of Dharma, hence the beginning of the section. And the method of creation and dissolution is stated in the same section for the sake of equality. If it is stated in each section, then there would be only four sections, which would contradict the form of a summary.

original: nanvevaṃ vaidharmyāvasare sādharmyapratipādanamanyāyyam / na / pratyekaṃ bhūteṣu sṛṣṭisaṃhāravidhervailakṣaṇye 'pi ekatrābhidhānāt sādharmyajñānam / na paramārthataḥ / na ca vaidharmye 'bhidhīyamāne yad yat sādharmyaṃ tasya pratiṣedhaḥ / yathā pṛthivyādīnāṃ paramāṇukāryarūpatayā dvaividhyam / kāryañca śarīrāditrayaṃ parasparavailakṣaṇyād vaidharmye 'pi na sādharmyarūpatāṃ vijahātīti /
analyzed: nanu evam vaidharmya avasare sādharmya pratipādanam anyāyyam na pratyekam bhūteṣu sṛṣṭi saṃhāra vidheḥ vailakṣaṇye pi ekatra abhidhānāt sādharmya jñānam na paramārthataḥ na ca vaidharmye bhidhīyamāne yat yat sādharmyam tasya pratiṣedhaḥ yathā pṛthivī ādīnām paramāṇu kārya rūpatayā dvaividhyam kāryam ca śarīra ādi trayam paraspara vailakṣaṇyāt vaidharmye pi na sādharmya rūpatām vijahāti iti
translated: But in this case, the statement of similarity is improper at the time of stating dissimilarity. No, because there is knowledge of similarity from the statement in one place, even though there is a difference in the arrangement of creation and dissolution in each of the elements, not in reality. And when dissimilarity is stated, the negation of every similarity is not implied, just as the twofold nature of earth etc. in the form of atoms and effects. And the three bodies etc., which are effects, do not abandon their nature of similarity, even though there is dissimilarity due to mutual difference.

original: atha caturṇām ityukte na jñāyate keṣām ato mahābhūtānām iti / mahadgrahaṇam aṇuvyavacchedārtham / nanvevaṃ dvyaṇukasyāpi sṛṣṭisaṃhāravato vyavacchedaḥ syāt / na / mahadārambhakatvena tasyāpi mahacchabdavācyatvāt / tathā hi / dvyaṇukādiprakrameṇotpattividhānāt saṃhārasya ca paramāṇvantasya dvyaṇuke 'pi sṛṣṭisaṃhāravidhau pratijñā kāryaiva / sā caivaṃ kṛtā syāt / tathāpi mahābhūtānāmityukte na jñāyate kiyatāmiti / tathāpi caturṇāṃ bhūtānāmityukte na jñāyate keṣāmataḥ pṛthivyādīnām iti labhyate / na cākāśasya etadvyākhyānāvasarasaṃgatyā astvavasaraḥ / tadevaṃ caturṇāṃ mahābhūtānāṃ sṛṣṭisaṃhārayorvidhiḥ prakārastāvevābhidhīyete aneneti / vidhiḥ pramāṇaṃ tābhyāṃ vā pramāṇabhūtābhyāṃ vidhirvidhātā kartocyata ityāvartyamānam anekārthametadeva vākyam /
analyzed: atha caturṇām iti ukte na jñāyate keṣām atas mahābhūtānām iti mahat grahaṇam aṇu vyavaccheda artham nanu evam dvyaṇukasya api sṛṣṭi saṃhāravataḥ vyavacchedaḥ syāt na mahat ārambhaka tvena tasya api mahat śabda vācya tvāt tathā hi dvyaṇuka ādi prakrameṇa utpatti vidhānāt saṃhārasya ca paramāṇu antasya dvyaṇuke sṛṣṭi saṃhāra vidhau pratijñā kāryā eva sā ca evam kṛtā syāt tathā api mahābhūtānām iti ukte na jñāyate kiyatām iti tathā
translated: Now, when it is said 'of the four', it is not known of which ones, therefore it is said 'of the great elements'. The word 'great' is used to exclude the atoms. But in that case, even the dyad would be excluded, as it also has creation and dissolution. No, because it is also called 'great' because it is the cause of the great. Thus, because it is enjoined that creation occurs in the order of dyads and so on, and because dissolution is up to the atom, the promise must be made that even in the creation and dissolution of the dyad, it is so. And that would be made thus. Still, when it is said 'of the four great elements', it is not known of how many. Still, when it is said 'of the four elements', it is not known of which ones, therefore it is understood to be of earth and so on. And it is not the occasion for the explanation of space, so let it be the occasion. Thus, the injunction and the manner of the creation and dissolution of the four great elements are both referred to by this word. The injunction is the means of knowledge, or the injunction is the creator by those two means of knowledge.

original: tad brāhmeṇa mānena ityādinā saṃhāravidhervyākhyānaṃ kramātikrameṇādau saṃsārasyānāditvajñāpanārtham / tathā hi / saṃhārāt pūrvaṃ sṛṣṭirlabhyate tato 'pi saṃhāra ityanāditvam / sa ca saṃhāraḥ kathaṃ bhavatītyāha maheśvarecchātmāṇusaṃyogajakarmabhyaḥ śarīrendriyakāraṇāṇuvibhāgebhyastatsaṃyoganivṛttau teṣāmāparamāṇvanto vināśaḥ iti / teṣāṃ śarīrendriyāṇāmārambhakeṣvaṇuṣu dravyārambhakasaṃyoganivṛttau dvyaṇukavināśe tadārabdhaI /syāpi nivṛttirityāha maheśvarecchātmāṇusaṃyogajakarmabhyaḥ śarīrendriyakāraṇāṇuvibhāgebhyaḥ / paramāṇuryāvat tāvad vināśa iti / dravyārambhakasaṃyoganivṛttiḥ svakāraṇāṇuvibhāgebhyaḥ te ca maheśvarecchātmāṇusaṃyogajakarmabhyaḥ / tathā hi / maheśvarecchā nimittakāraṇam / ātmanām aṇubhiḥ saṃyogaśca asamavāyikāraṇam / aṇavastu samavāyina ityaṇuṣu karmāṇyutpadyante / kasminnavasara ityāha sarvātmagatādṛṣṭānām sarvātmasu gatāśca te 'dṛṣṭāśca teṣām / kiṃviśiṣṭānām / śarīrendriyamahābhūtopanibandhakānām śarīrendriyamahābhūtānyupanibadhyante sampādyante yaisteṣām / vṛttiḥ phaladānasāmarthyam / tasyopabhogād yugapannirodhe vināśe sati / sa ca sañjihīrṣāsamakālam / yadā hi sakalabhuvanapatermaheśvarasya saṃhartumicchā sampadyate / sā ca kimartham / saṃsārakhinnānām prāṇināṃ saṃsāre śarīropādānaparityāgadvāreṇa khinnānāṃ niśi rātrāviva viśrāmārtham / yathā hi śarīravyāpārādahani khinnāmāṃ tadabhāvād rātrau viśrāmastathehāpīti /
analyzed: tat brāhmeṇa mānena ityādinā saṃhāra vidheḥ vyākhyānam krama atikrameṇa ādau saṃsārasya anādi tva jñāpana artham tathā hi saṃhārāt pūrvam sṛṣṭiḥ labhyate saṃhāraḥ iti anādi tvam sa ca saṃhāraḥ katham bhavati iti āha maheśvara icchā ātma aṇu saṃyoga ja karmabhyaḥ śarīra indriya kāraṇa aṇu vibhāgebhyaḥ tad saṃyoga nivṛttau teṣām ā paramāṇu antaḥ vināśaḥ iti teṣām śarīra indriyāṇām ārambhakeṣu aṇuṣu dravya āra
translated: The explanation of the injunction of dissolution beginning with that by the measure of Brahma is given out of sequence in order to show that the world has no beginning. For thus, creation is obtained before dissolution, and after that, dissolution; thus it has no beginning. And how does that dissolution occur? He says: From the separation of the atoms that are the causes of the body and senses due to the actions born from the conjunction of the soul with Mahesvara, when the conjunctions cease, there is destruction of those up to the atoms. When the conjunctions that are the causes of the substances that compose those bodies and senses cease, there is destruction of the dyads composed of them. He says: From the separation of the atoms that are the causes of the body and senses due to the actions born from the conjunction of the soul with Mahesvara, there is destruction up to the atoms. The cessation of the conjunctions that are the causes of substances is due to the separations of its own causes, the atoms. And those are due to the actions born from the conjunction of the soul with Mahesvara. For thus, the will of Mahesvara is the instrumental cause.

original: kadā ca sañjihīrṣā / brahmaṇo 'pavargakāle / yadā hi adhikārasamāptau brahmā apavṛjyate / sa ca varṣaśatāvasāne vartamānasya brahmaṇo bhavatīti / kena mānenetyāha brāhmeṇa / brahmaṇa idaṃ brāhmaṃ teneti / tatpunaḥ
analyzed: kadā ca sañjihīrṣā brahmaṇaḥ upavarga kāle  yadā hi adhikāra samāptau brahmā apavṛjyate sa ca varṣa śata avasāne vartamānasya brahmaṇaḥ bhavati iti  kena mānena iti āha brāhmeṇa  brahmaṇaḥ idam brāhmam tena iti tat punar
translated: And when does the desire to annihilate occur? At the time of Brahma's final liberation. For when the duties are completed, Brahma is liberated, and that occurs at the end of a hundred years of Brahma. By what measure? He says by Brahma's. This belongs to Brahma, therefore it is Brahma's. That is,

original: divyaṃ dvādaśasāhasraṃ kalpaṃ viddhi caturyugam /
analyzed: divyam dvādaśa sāhasram kalpam viddhi caturyugam
translated: Know that the divine Kalpa, consisting of twelve thousand four Yugas,

original: etat sahasraparyantaṃ tadaharbrāhmamucyate //
analyzed: etat sahasra paryantam tat ahar brāhmam ucyate
translated: Is said to be a day of Brahma extending to a thousand such.

original: ityevaṃvidhairdinairmāsādayo 'pi vaktavyā iti mānam /
analyzed: iti evaṃvidhaiḥ dinaiḥ māsa ādayaḥ vaktavyāḥ iti mānam
translated: Thus, the months and other periods should be stated in terms of such days. This is the measure.

original: evaṃ yathā brahmaṇo 'pavargakāle maheśvarasya sañjihīrṣāsamakālaṃ viśiṣṭādṛṣṭānāṃ vṛttinirodhe sati śarīrendriyāṇāṃ vināśastathā pṛthivyudakajvalanapavanānāmapi mahābhūtānāmanenaiva krameṇa iti /
analyzed: evam yathā upavarga kāle maheśvarasya sañjihīrṣā sama kālam viśiṣṭa adṛṣṭānām vṛtti nirodhe sati śarīra indriyāṇām vināśaḥ tathā pṛthivī udaka jvalana pavanānām api mahābhūtānām anena eva krameṇa iti
translated: Thus, just as at the time of Brahma's final liberation, at the same time as Mahesvara's desire to annihilate, when the functioning of the specific unseen forces ceases, there is the destruction of the body and senses, so also of the great elements - earth, water, fire and air - in the same sequence.

original: paramāṇuṣu karmotpattau vibhāgebhyaḥ satsaṃyoganivṛttidvāreṇottarasminnuttarasmin sati pūrvasya pūrvasya vināśa ityutpattyapekṣayā / yad yat pūrvamutpannaṃ tattad uttarasminnuttarasmin vidyamāne sati vinaśyatīti / tathā hi / uttarasmin sati pūrvaṃ vāyorvināśastadanantaramudakasyetyādi /
analyzed: paramāṇuṣu karma utpattau vibhāgebhyaḥ sat saṃyoga nivṛtti dvāreṇa uttarasmin uttarasmin sati pūrvasya pūrvasya vināśaḥ iti utpatti apekṣayā yat yat pūrvam utpannam tat tat uttarasmin uttarasmin vidyamāne sati vinaśyati iti tathā hi uttarasmin sati pūrvam vāyoḥ vināśaḥ tad anantaram udakasya ityādi
translated: In the production of action in atoms, due to the separation of the parts, the subsequent destruction of the previous one occurs through the cessation of the real conjunction in each subsequent one, in relation to production. Whatever is produced first, that is destroyed when the subsequent one exists. For example, when the subsequent one exists, the wind is destroyed first, then the water, and so on.

original: anye tu etadvākyaṃ pāṭhāpekṣayaiva vivakṣitamiti manyante / tathā hi / yathā śarīrendriyāṇāṃ vināśastathā pṛthivyudakajvalanapavanānāmapi mahābhūtānāṃ vināśo 'nenaiva krameṇeti pāṭhakrameṇa / na kramāntareṇeti / evañca śarīrendriyamahābhūtānāṃ vināśe tadāI /śritānāṃ guṇakarmaṇāmapi vināśaḥ / tataḥ pravibhaktāḥ kāryānādhārāḥ paramāṇavo 'vatiṣṭhante / tathā na paraṃ paramāṇavo dharmādharmasaṃskārairanuviddhāḥ sambaddhā ātmānaścāvatiṣṭhante /
analyzed: anye tu etat vākyam pāṭha apekṣayā eva vivakṣitam iti manyante tathā hi yathā śarīra indriyāṇām vināśaḥ tathā pṛthivī udaka jvalana pavanānām api mahābhūtānām vināśaḥ nena eva krameṇa iti pāṭha krameṇa na krama antareṇa iti evañca śarīra indriya mahābhūtānām vināśe guṇa karmaṇām api vināśaḥ tatas pravibhaktāḥ kārya anādhārāḥ paramāṇavaḥ vatiṣṭhante tathā na param paramāṇavaḥ dharma adharma saṃskāraiḥ anuviddhāḥ sa
translated: Others, however, consider that this statement is intended only in accordance with the text. Thus, just as there is destruction of the body and senses, so too there is destruction of the great elements - earth, water, fire and air - by this very sequence, according to the sequence of the text, not by a different sequence. And thus, in the destruction of the body, senses and great elements, there is also the destruction of the qualities and actions dependent on them. Then, the separated effects remain as atoms, and likewise, the supreme atoms, pervaded and connected with the impressions of dharma and adharma, and the selves, remain.

original: athānyeṣāmapi sāmānyādīnāmavasthāne kimarthaṃ viśeṣābhidhānamiti cet / dravyavināśasya paramāṇvantatājñāpanārtham / ātmanāñca dharmādivināśakāraṇatvābhāvād dharmādharmasaṃskārānuviddhānāmavasthānam / na kevalānāmiti / anyathā hi nimittābhāvāt punarutpattirna syāt /
analyzed: atha anyeṣām api sāmānya ādīnām avasthāne kimartham viśeṣa abhidhānam iti ced dravya vināśasya paramāṇu anta tā jñāpana artham ātmanām ca dharma ādi vināśa kāraṇa tva abhāvāt dharma adharma saṃskāra anuviddhānām avasthānam na kevalānām iti anyathā hi nimitta abhāvāt punarutpattiḥ na syāt
translated: If it be asked, why the particular [atoms] are mentioned, when the universals and so on are also admitted to exist, [we reply:] in order to show that the destruction of substance ends in the atoms. And the souls, because they are not the cause of the destruction of merit and demerit, remain with the impressions of merit and demerit, not by themselves alone. Otherwise, there would be no further production, because there would be no cause.

original: atha kiyantaṃ kālamevamavasthānamityāha tāvantameva kālam iti / brāhmeṇa mānena varṣaśataṃ yāvaditi /
analyzed: atha kiyantam kālam evam avasthānam iti āha tāvantam eva kālam iti brāhmeṇa mānena varṣa śatam yāvat iti
translated: Now, for how long a time does this [soul] remain thus? He says: for just that time, for a hundred years by the Brahma measure.

original: tataḥ punarvarṣaśatānte 'pi viśrāmaprāpakādṛṣṭanivṛttau prāṇināṃ karmavipākopalambhāt bhogabhūtaye bhogabhūtyartham / maheśvarasya sisṛkṣā sraṣṭumicchā sampadyate / tadanantaraṃ pavanaparamāṇuṣu samavetāni karmāṇyutpadyante / kebhyaḥ kāraṇebhya ityāha tatsaṃyogebhyaḥ / teṣāṃ bhogināṃ saṃyogāḥ paramāṇubhistebhya ityasamavāyikāraṇanirdeśaḥ / te ca karmārambhe sāpekṣā ityāha sarvātmagatavṛttilabdhādṛṣṭāpekṣebhyaḥ iti / sarvātmasu bhogiṣu gatāḥ sarvātmagatāste ca te vṛttilabdhādṛṣṭāśceti / vṛttyā sahakārikāraṇena labdhāśca te 'dṛṣṭāśceti tathoktāstānapekṣyanta iti tadapekṣāstebhya iti / na tu vṛttirlabdhā yairiti vyākhyānam / atra niṣṭhāntasya pūrvanipātaprasaṅgāt /
analyzed: tatas punar varṣa śata ante viśrāma prāpaka adṛṣṭa nivṛttau prāṇinām karma vipāka upalambhāt bhoga bhūtaye bhoga bhūti artham maheśvarasya sisṛkṣā sraṣṭum icchā sampadyate tad anantaram pavana paramāṇuṣu samavetāni karmāṇi utpadyante kebhyaḥ kāraṇebhyaḥ iti āha tad saṃyogebhyaḥ teṣām bhoginām saṃyogāḥ paramāṇubhiḥ tebhyaḥ iti asamavāyi kāraṇa nirdeśaḥ te ca karma ārambhe sa apekṣāḥ iti āha sarva ātma gata vṛtti labdha ad
translated: Then, even after a hundred years, when the cessation of the unseen force that brings about rest is perceived in living beings, the desire to create of Maheśvara, for the sake of the enjoyment of beings, for the prosperity of enjoyment, is accomplished. After that, actions that inhere in the atoms of air arise. From what causes? He says: from their conjunctions. The conjunctions of those enjoyers with those atoms. This indicates the non-inherent cause. And those are dependent at the beginning of action. He says: from those that depend on the unseen force obtained through activity in all selves. Those that are in all selves are obtained through activity and are unseen. They are so called because they depend on those. But the explanation is not that they are obtained through activity. Because in this case, the ending would be misplaced.

original: atha kāsau vṛttiradṛṣṭānāṃ sahakārikāraṇam / viśrāmaprāpakādṛṣṭābhāvopalakṣitaḥ kālaviśeṣaḥ / tatsadbhāve kāryakaraṇāt / tathā hi / brāhmamānenāparipūrṇe varṣaśate viśrāmaprāpakādṛṣṭasya pratibandhakasya bhāvādupabhogaprāpakādṛṣṭasadbhāve 'pi sṛṣṭirna bhavati / paripūrṇe tu varṣaśate viśiṣṭādṛṣṭābhāvādupabhogaprāpakādṛṣṭānāṃ sṛṣṭyai vyāpāra iti pratibandhakābhāvaviśiṣṭaḥ kālo vṛttisteṣāmiti jñāyate / maheśvarasyāpi tatsadbhāva eva sisṛkṣā bhavatīti /
analyzed: atha kā asau vṛttiḥ adṛṣṭānām sahakāri kāraṇam viśrāma prāpaka adṛṣṭa abhāva upalakṣitaḥ kāla viśeṣaḥ tad sadbhāve kārya karaṇāt tathā hi brāhma mānena aparipūrṇe varṣa śate viśrāma prāpaka adṛṣṭasya pratibandhakasya bhāvāt upabhoga prāpaka adṛṣṭa sadbhāve sṛṣṭiḥ na bhavati paripūrṇe tu varṣa śate viśiṣṭa adṛṣṭa abhāvāt upabhoga prāpaka adṛṣṭānām sṛṣṭyai vyāpāraḥ iti pratibandhaka abhāva vi
translated: Now, what is that activity which is the unseen cooperative cause? It is a particular time characterized by the absence of the unseen that brings about cessation. Because the effect is produced when that exists. Indeed, when the Brahmic year is not complete, due to the existence of the unseen that obstructs the attainment of cessation, creation does not occur even when the unseen that brings about experience exists. But when the year is complete, due to the absence of the special unseen, it is known that time, which is characterized by the absence of the obstruction, is the activity of the unseen that brings about experience, for the creation of those. And the desire to create arises in Maheśvara only when that exists.

original: tadevaṃ pavanaparamāṇuṣu kāryotpattau satyāmanantaraṃ vibhāgaḥ / tasmāt saṃyoganivṛttau teṣāṃ paramāṇūnāṃ parasparasaṃyogebhyo dvyaṇukānyutpannāni tryaṇukānyārabhanta ityādikrameṇa mahān vāyuḥ samutpanno nabhasyākāśe dodhūyamāna ityatiśayena kampamānastiṣṭhati / sa cādāvutpanno 'tiśayavegasambandhād gurutvavatāmapātaheturbhavati / dṛṣṭañca vāyoḥ parṇādiI /patanapratibandhe sāmarthyam / ayañcātiśayena mahattve sati vegasambandhād udadhisahitāṃ pṛthivīṃ tṛṇamiva dhārayata iti na citram /
analyzed: tat evam pavana paramāṇuṣu kārya utpattau satyām anantaram vibhāgaḥ tasmāt saṃyoga nivṛttau teṣām paramāṇūnām paraspara saṃyogebhyaḥ dvyaṇukāni utpannāni tryaṇukāni ārabhante ityādi krameṇa mahān vāyuḥ samutpannaḥ nabhasi ākāśe dodhūyamānaḥ iti atiśayena kampamānaḥ tiṣṭhati sa ca ādau utpannaḥ utiśaya vega sambandhāt gurutvavatām apāta hetuḥ bhavati dṛṣṭam ca vāyoḥ sāmarthyam ayam ca atiśayena mahattve sati vega sambandhāt udad
translated: Thus, when the effect is produced in the air atoms, immediately there is disjunction. From that, when the conjunction ceases, the dyads are produced from the mutual conjunctions of those atoms, and they give rise to the triads. In this sequence, the great air is produced, blowing violently in the sky of space. It remains vibrating with excess motion. And that, being produced at the beginning, becomes the cause of the descent of heavy things due to its connection with excessive speed. And the ability of air to obstruct the falling of leaves etc. is seen. And this, when it has excess magnitude and is connected with speed, supporting the earth along with the ocean as if it were grass, is not surprising.

original: tadanantaram vāyūtpattyanantaram / tasminneva vāyāvadhikaraṇabhūta eveti / āpyebhyaḥ paramāṇubhyastenaiva krameṇa iti / karmotpattidvāreṇa vibhāgebhyaḥ saṃyoganivṛttau parasparasaṃyogebhyo dvyaṇukānyutpadyante / tatastryaṇukamiti krameṇa / mahān salilanidhiḥ samudraḥ samutpannaḥ / poplūyamānaḥ atyarthaṃ plavamānastiṣṭhati /
analyzed: tad anantaram vāyu utpatti anantaram tasmin eva vāyau adhikaraṇa bhūtaḥ eva iti āpyebhyaḥ paramāṇubhyaḥ tena eva krameṇa iti karma utpatti dvāreṇa vibhāgebhyaḥ saṃyoga nivṛttau paraspara saṃyogebhyaḥ dvyaṇukāni utpadyante tatas tryaṇukam iti krameṇa mahān salilanidhiḥ samudraḥ samutpannaḥ poplūyamānaḥ atyartham plavamānaḥ tiṣṭhati
translated: After that, after the origin of air, in that very air as the substratum. From the water atoms, in the same sequence. From the separations by the door of the origin of action, from the mutual conjunctions, the dyads are produced. From that, the triads. In this sequence, the great ocean of water is produced. Floating, extremely floating, it stands.

original: tadanantaram salilotpattyanantaram / tasmin salilanidhāvadhikaraṇe / pārthivebhyaḥ paramāṇubhyaḥ pūrvakrameṇa dvyaṇukatryaṇukotpattiriti / evamādikrameṇa mahāpṛthivī samutpadyate / sā cotpannā saṃhatāvatiṣṭhate /
analyzed: tad anantaram salila utpatti anantaram tasmin salilanidhau adhikaraṇe pārthivebhyaḥ paramāṇubhyaḥ pūrva krameṇa dvyaṇuka tryaṇuka utpattiḥ iti evamādi krameṇa mahā pṛthivī samutpadyate sā ca utpannā saṃhatā avatiṣṭhate
translated: After that, after the origin of water, in that very ocean of water as the substratum. From the earth atoms, in the previous sequence, the dyads and triads are produced. In this sequence, the great earth is produced. And that, when produced, remains in a condensed state.

original: tasminneva mahodadhau adhikaraṇe taijasebhyaḥ paramāṇubhyaḥ pūrvavad dvyaṇukotpattikrameṇotpadyate mahāṃstejorāśiḥ / sa cotpanno dedīpyamāno 'tyarthaṃ prakāśamānastiṣṭhati / na ca tejaso jalena virodhādādhārādheyabhāvānupapattiriti vācyam / ādhārādheyabhāvasyāpyupalabdheryathā vāḍavavaruṇāviti /
