analyzed: tasmin eva mahā udadhau adhikaraṇe taijasebhyaḥ paramāṇubhyaḥ pūrvavat dvyaṇuka utpatti krameṇa utpadyate mahān tejaḥ rāśiḥ sa ca utpannaḥ dedīpyamānaḥ u tyartham prakāśamānaḥ tiṣṭhati na ca tejasaḥ jalena virodhāt ādhāra ādheya bhāva anupapattiḥ iti vācyam ādhāra ādheya bhāvasya api upalabdheḥ yathā vāḍava varuṇau iti
translated: In that very great ocean, from fiery atoms, a great mass of fire is produced in the same way as before, by the process of the origin of dyads. And that produced, blazing, shining exceedingly, remains. And it should not be said that the relation of support and supported is not possible due to the incompatibility of fire with water; because the relation of support and supported is also observed, like the submarine fire and Varuna.

original: anye tu virodhaparihārārthaṃ tasminneva mahodadhāviti vākyaṃ pṛthivyāṃ sambandhayanti / tadanantaraṃ tasmin pṛthivyutpāde sati taijasebhyaḥ paramāṇubhyo dvyaṇukādiprakrameṇa mahāṃstejorāśiriti /
analyzed: anye tu virodha parihāra artham tasmin eva mahā udadhau iti vākyam pṛthivyām sambandhayanti tad anantaram tasmin pṛthivī utpāde sati taijasebhyaḥ paramāṇubhyaḥ dvyaṇuka ādi prakrameṇa mahān tejaḥ rāśiḥ iti
translated: But others, for the sake of avoiding contradiction, connect the sentence in that very great ocean with the earth. After that, when the earth is produced, from fiery atoms, a great mass of fire, by the process of dyads and so on.

original: pūrvamanena evam uktaprakāreṇa / samutpanneṣu caturṣu mahābhūteṣu satsu / maheśvarasyābhidhyānamātrāt icchāmātrāt / na śarīrādivyāpārāditi / tathā tata eva nimittāt taijasebhyaḥ paramāṇubhyaḥ pārthivaparamāṇusahitebhyo mahadaṇḍamārabhyate / kiṃviśiṣṭam / mahaditi / atra hi taijasāḥ paramāṇavaḥ samavāyikāraṇam / tatsaṃyogāścāsamavāyikāraṇam / pārthivāvayavāśca nimittakāraṇaṃ maheśvarābhidhyānañceti / dvyaṇukānyutpannāni tryaṇukādiprakrameṇa mahadaṇḍamārabhanta iti / tasmiṃśca aṇḍāntardeśe brahmāṇamutpādayati /
analyzed: pūrvam anena evam ukta prakāreṇa samutpanneṣu caturṣu mahābhūteṣu satsu maheśvarasya abhidhyāna mātrāt icchā mātrāt na śarīra ādi vyāpārāt iti tathā tatas eva nimittāt taijasebhyaḥ paramāṇubhyaḥ pārthiva paramāṇu sahitebhyaḥ mahat aṇḍam ārabhyate kiṃviśiṣṭam mahat iti atra hi taijasāḥ paramāṇavaḥ samavāyi kāraṇam tad saṃyogāḥ ca asamavāyi kāraṇam pārthiva avayavāḥ ca nimitta kāraṇam maheśvara abhidhyānam ca iti  /
translated: Previously, in the manner described, when the four great elements have arisen, by the mere contemplation, the mere will, of Maheśvara, not by the activity of the body etc., in the same way, from the fiery atoms, along with the earthen atoms, the great egg is produced, by that very cause. What is its characteristic? Great. Here, the fiery atoms are the inherent cause, and their conjunction is the non-inherent cause, and the earthen parts are the instrumental cause, and the contemplation of Maheśvara. The dyads, having arisen, produce the great egg in the process beginning with the triads. And in the inner space of that egg, he creates Brahmā.

original: kiṃviśiṣṭamityāha caturvadanakamalam iti / catvāri kamalānīva vadanāni yasyāsau tathoktastamiti / sarveṣāñca lokānāṃ bhūrādisatyāntānāṃ pitāmahaṃ svāminam / tathā sakalabhuvanaiḥ sahitañceti / tamutpādya maheśvaraḥ prajāsarge viniyuṅkte brahman / prajāsargaṃ kurviti /
analyzed: kiṃviśiṣṭam iti āha catur vadana kamalam iti catvāri kamalāni iva vadanāni yasya asau tathā uktaḥ tam iti sarveṣām ca lokānām bhūḥ ādi satya antānām pitāmaham svāminam tathā sakala bhuvanaiḥ sahitam ca iti tam utpādya maheśvaraḥ prajā sarge viniyuṅkte brahman prajā sargam kuru iti
translated: What is the special feature? He says: the four-faced lotus. He who has four faces like lotuses is so called. The grandfather of all worlds, from the earth up to truth, the lord. And along with all the worlds. Having created him, Mahesvara employs him in the creation of beings, O Brahman, to create the beings.

original: sa ca maheśvareṇa viniyukto brahmā atiśayena jñānañca / vairāgyaṃ ca aiśvaryañceti tathoktāni taiḥ sampanno yukto 'ta eva prāṇināṃ karmavipākaṃ viditvā sutān sṛjati / kiṃviśiṣṭān / prajāpatīn prajāyāḥ svāminaḥ / karmānurūpaṃ jñānañca bhogaścāyuśca yeṣāṃ te tathoktān karmānurūpajñānabhogāyuṣaḥ iti / tathā manasi bhavān mānasān manovyāpāreṇa saṅkalpamātreṇa sampāditān na kāyikavyāpāreṇetyatastāniti / tathā manavaśca devāśca ṛṣayaśca pitaraśceti tathoktāsteṣāṃ gaṇāḥ samūhāstāṃśca sṛjati / tathā hi caturo varṇān brāhmaṇakṣatriyaviśśūdrān karmānurūpabhogajñānāyuṣaḥ sṛjati / kebhya ityāha mukhabāhūrupādataḥ yathāsaṅkhyamiti / tathā anyāni coccāvacāni uttamādhamabhāvenāvasthitāni bhūtāni sṛjati / etāṃśca pūrvoktān sṛṣṭvāśayānurūpairdharmajñānavairāgyaiśvaryaiḥ saṃyojayati yasya hi yādṛśaṃ karma tasya tādṛśāni dharmajñānavairāgyaiśvaryāṇi sampādayatīti /
analyzed: sa ca maheśvareṇa viniyuktaḥ brahmā atiśayena jñānam ca vairāgyam ca aiśvaryam ca iti tathā uktāni taiḥ sampannaḥ te eva prāṇinām karma vipākam viditvā sutān sṛjati kiṃviśiṣṭān prajāpatīn prajāyāḥ svāminaḥ karma anurūpam jñānam ca bhogaḥ ca āyuḥ ca yeṣām te tathā uktān karma anurūpa jñāna bhoga āyuṣaḥ iti tathā manasi bhavān mānasān manaḥ vyāpāreṇa saṅkalpa mātreṇa sampāditān na kāyika vyāpāreṇa iti atas tān iti tathā m
translated: And that Brahman, employed by Maheśvara, is endowed with superior knowledge, detachment, and lordship, hence he is so called. Being endowed with those, he creates his sons, knowing the ripening of the actions of living beings. What kind of sons? Prajāpatis, lords of creation. Those whose knowledge, enjoyment, and lifespan are in accordance with their actions are so called. He creates those who are accomplished by the mind, who are produced by the function of the mind alone, by mere intention, not by bodily function, hence he creates them. He creates the groups of those who are called Manus, gods, sages, and ancestors. Thus he creates the four castes, Brahmins, Kshatriyas, Vaishyas, and Shudras, whose knowledge, enjoyment, and lifespan are in accordance with their actions. To whom? From the mouth, arms, thighs, and feet, respectively. He creates other beings also, high and low, existing in the superior and inferior states.

original: īśvarasiddhau śaṅkā tatsamādhānañca
analyzed: īśvara siddhau śaṅkā tad samādhānañca
translated: In the proof of God, doubt and its resolution

original: nanu sarvametadasambaddham / īśvarasadbhāve pramāṇāsambhavāt / tanna / anumānāgamābhyāṃ tatsadbhāvasiddheḥ / tathā cānumānam / kṣityādiṣu sṛṣṭisaṃhārau / kartṛpūrvakāviti / atha sṛṣṭisaṃhārayorbhūteṣvaprasiddheranumānābhāva iti cet / racanāvattvena tatsiddheḥ / tathā hi / kṣityādīni / kāryāṇi / racanāvattvāt / yad yad racanāvat tattat kāryam / yathā ghaṭādi / tathā racanāvat kṣityādi / tasmāt kāryamiti /
analyzed: nanu sarvam etat asambaddham īśvara sadbhāve pramāṇa asambhavāt tat na anumāna āgamābhyām tad sadbhāva siddheḥ tathā ca anumānam kṣiti ādiṣu sṛṣṭi saṃhārau kartṛ pūrvakau iti atha sṛṣṭi saṃhārayoḥ bhūteṣu aprasiddheḥ anumāna abhāvaḥ iti ced racanāvat tvena tad siddheḥ tathā hi kṣiti ādīni kāryāṇi racanāvat tvāt yat yat racanāvat tat tat kāryam yathā ghaṭa ādi tathā racanāvat kṣiti ādi tasmāt kāryam iti
translated: But all this is irrelevant, because there is no means of valid knowledge for the existence of God. That is not so. Because His existence is established by inference and scripture. And thus the inference: The creation and dissolution of earth etc. are preceded by an agent. If it is argued that there is no inference because creation and dissolution are not known to exist in elements, that is not so, because they are established by having arrangement. Thus, earth etc. are effects, because they have arrangement. Whatever has arrangement is an effect, like a pot etc. Earth etc. have such arrangement. Therefore, they are effects.

original: na ca racanāvattvamantareṇāpi kāryatvamupalabhyata ityaprayojakatvaṃ vācyam / sarvasyāpi sapakṣaikadeśe vartamānasyāgamakatvaprasaṅgāt / tathā hi dhūmasyāpyaprayojakatvaṃ tadantareṇāpi agnimattvopalabdheḥ / atha yatra dhūmastatrāgniriti vyāptiḥ / evaṃ tarhi yatra racanāvattvaṃ tatra kāryatvamiti samānam / tathā ca ghaṭādāvapyabhūtvā bhāvitvaṃ pratyakṣeṇānupalabdhañca racanāvattvenaiva sādhyate / tathedaṃ saṃhāre 'pi samānamiti / siddhe ca kāryatve kartṛpūrvakatvañca sādhyate / tathā ca vivādāspadaṃ bodhādhārakāraṇaṃ /kam / kāryatvāt / yad yat kāryaṃ tattad bodhādhārakāraṇa /kaṃ yathā ghaṭādi / tathā cedaṃ kāryam / tasmād bodhādhārakāraṇa /kamiti / asya ca pakṣadharmatve sati sapakṣe vartamānasya vipakṣādatyantaṃ vyāvṛtterabādhitaviṣayatvād asatpratipakṣatvena gamakatvam /
analyzed: na ca racanāvat tvam antareṇa api kāryatvam upalabhyate iti aprayojaka tvam vācyam sarvasya api sapakṣa eka deśe vartamānasya āgamaka tva prasaṅgāt tathā hi dhūmasya api aprayojaka tvam tat antareṇa api agnimat tva upalabdheḥ atha yatra dhūmaḥ tatra agniḥ iti vyāptiḥ evam tarhi yatra racanāvat tvam tatra kāryatvam iti samānam tathā ca ghaṭa ādau api a bhūtvā bhāvi tvam pratyakṣeṇa anupalabdham ca racanāvat tvena eva sādhyate tathā idam saṃhāre pi samānam iti
translated: And it cannot be said that the presence of arrangement is not a reason for being a product, because then everything present in part of the similar instance would not be a reason. Thus, smoke would also not be a reason, because the presence of fire is observed even without it. If it is argued that the pervasion is that where there is smoke, there is fire, then the same applies to the pervasion that where there is arrangement, there is being a product. And in that case, the non-apprehension by perception of the property of coming into existence after not having existed is proved by arrangement alone even in the case of a pot, and the same applies to dissolution. And when being a product is established, the fact of having a creator is proved. And thus, the subject of dispute is the cause of the substratum of consciousness. Why? Because it is a product. Whatever is a product is the cause of the substratum of consciousness, like a pot etc. And this is a product. Therefore, it is the cause of the substratum of consciousness. And this, being a property of the subject, is present in the similar instance.

original: nanvevam aśeṣajñeyajñānādhāravidhātṛpūrvakatve sādhye sādhyavikalo dṛṣṭāntaḥ kumbhādāvasarvajñapūrvakatvena vyāptasya kāryatvasyopalabdheḥ / tathā viruddhaśca hetuḥ / na vivādāspadaṃ sarvapūrvakam / kāryatvād / ghaṭavat / asarvajñapūrvakatve ca sādhye 'bhipretasyāsiddhiriti /
analyzed: nanu evam aśeṣa jñeya jñāna ādhāra vidhātṛ pūrvakatve sādhye sādhya vikalaḥ dṛṣṭāntaḥ kumbha ādau asarvajña pūrvakatvena vyāptasya kāryatvasya upalabdheḥ tathā viruddhaḥ ca hetuḥ na vivāda āspadam sarva pūrvakam kāryatvāt ghaṭa vat asarvajña pūrvakatve ca sādhye bhipretasya asiddhiḥ iti
translated: “If the existence of a Creator of the universe, who is the receptacle of all knowable things, is sought to be proved, then the Corroborative Instance cited is devoid of the Probandum; because in the case of the Jar, which is the instance cited, it is found that the character of being a product is concomitant with the character of not being produced by an omniscient being; and the Reason also is ‘contradictory’; because the object in dispute, the world, is not the product of an omniscient being; because it is a product; like the Jar. If what is meant to be proved is the fact of the world not being produced by an omniscient being, then the Reason adduced is ‘unproven’, ‘not admitted’;

original: naitadevam / bodhādhāre 'dhiṣṭhātari sādhye na sādhyavikalatvam / nāpi viruddhatvam / na ca kāryatvaṃ buddhimantamadhiṣṭhātāraṃ vyabhicaratītyavyabhicāropalambhasāmarthyād upalabhyamānaṃ pakṣe kṣityādisampādanasamarthameva adhiṣṭhātāraṃ sādhayatīti / na ca kṣityādyupādānopakaraṇānabhijñaḥ kṣityādisampādanasamartha iti paramāṇvādiviṣayajñānaṃ tatkarturlabhyate / pakṣadharmatāprasādāt sarvañcānumānaṃ sāmānyena vyāptigrahaṇabalāt pravartamānaṃ pakṣadharmatābalāt sādhyaviśeṣaṃ sādhayatīti dṛṣṭam / na ca visphūrjatāpi pareṇātra bodhādhārakāraṇakatvakāryatvayoḥ sāmānyavyāptervyāghātaḥ śakyāsādhanaḥ / viśeṣeṇa tu vyāptivirahādasādhanatve dhūmasyāpyasādhanatvaprasaṅgaḥ / tatrāpyapāstāśeṣaviśeṣeṇāgnimātreṇa dhūmamātravyāpterupalambhāditi / tathā cātrāpi viśeṣavirodhaḥ sambhavatyeva / ayaṃ parvataḥ / parvatāvaṣṭabdhāgnimān na bhavati / dhūmavattvāt / yo yo dhūmavān sa sa viśiṣṭāgnimān na bhavati yathā rasavatīpradeśaḥ / tathā cāyam / tasmād yathoktasādhya iti /
analyzed: na etat evam bodha ādhāre dhiṣṭhātari sādhye na sādhya vikalatvam na api viruddha tvam na ca kārya tvam buddhimantam adhiṣṭhātāram vyabhicarati iti avyabhicāra upalambha sāmarthyāt upalabhyamānam pakṣe kṣiti ādi sampādana samartham eva adhiṣṭhātāram sādhayati iti na ca kṣiti ādi upādāna upakaraṇa anabhijñaḥ kṣiti ādi sampādana samarthaḥ iti paramāṇu ādi viṣaya jñānam tad kartuḥ labhyate pakṣa dharmatā prasādāt sarvam ca anumānam sāmānyena v
translated: This is not so. When the substratum of consciousness is to be established as the controller, there is no absence of the probandum in the probans, nor is it contradictory. And causality does not deviate from the intelligent controller. Therefore, by the power of perception of invariable concomitance, it establishes the controller as capable of producing earth etc. in the subject. And one who is not aware of the material and instrumental causes of earth etc. is not capable of producing earth etc. Therefore, knowledge of atoms etc. is inferred for the creator. And it is seen that all inference, operating by the power of grasping the universal pervasion, establishes the particular probandum by the power of the property of the subject. And even if the opponent shouts loudly, the contradiction of the universal pervasion of being produced and being an effect in relation to the substratum of consciousness cannot be established. But if it is not established due to the absence of pervasion in the particular, then smoke also would not be an establisher. There also, fire is established by the power of the property of the subject, even though the particular is excluded.

original: atha dhūmasyāgnimātreṇa vyāpterupalambhād yatropalambhastatraivāgnistatraivāgniprasādhakatvād viruddhatānavakāśa iti cet / ihāpi samānam / kāryatvasya buddhimatā vyāpterupalambhāt pakṣe tatsādhakatvamiti / atha dhūmapradeśo 'gninā vyāpto dṛṣṭa iti pradeśāntare 'pyagnimattvaṃ prasādhayatīti yuktam / nanvevaṃ tarhi kāryatvamapi yatropalabdhaṃ tadevotpādanasamarthenaiva kartrā vyāptamiti pakṣe 'pi kṣityādisampādanasamarthaṃ kartāraṃ gamayet /
analyzed: atha dhūmasya agni mātreṇa vyāpteḥ upalambhāt yatra upalambhaḥ tatra eva agniḥ tatra eva agni prasādhaka tvāt viruddha tā anavakāśaḥ iti ced iha api samānam kāryatvasya buddhimatā vyāpteḥ upalambhāt pakṣe tad sādhaka tvam iti  atha dhūma pradeśaḥ gninā vyāptaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ iti pradeśa antare pi agnimat tvam prasādhayati iti yuktam nanu evam tarhi kāryatvam api yatra upalabdham tat eva utpādana samarthena eva kartrā vyāptam iti pakṣe kṣiti ādi sampādana sam
translated: If it be urged that “the presence of Smoke is found only where there is Fire, and hence, as it is only this that can prove the presence of Fire, there is no possibility of its being contradictory”,—the same may be said in the case in question also; as the presence of ‘being a product’ is found only where there is an intelligent Cause, and hence it is only this that can prove the existence of the intelligent Cause; and there is no possibility of its being contradictory. If it be argued that—“the place occupied by the Smoke is found to be occupied by the Fire, and hence it is right that the presence of Fire should be inferred in another place also”,—then, in the same manner, the presence of the ‘effect’ also, wherever it is found, would be invariably concomitant with the presence of the Cause capable of producing it, and hence it would be right to deduce the existence of such a Cause from the presence of the effect, even in a case where the Earth and other component factors are not there.

original: yaccedamanumānaṃ na vivādāspadaṃ sarvajñapūrvakamiti / tatra viśeṣapratiṣedhasya śeṣābhyupagame sāmarthyopalabdherasarvajñapūrvakatvaṃ syāt / kāryatvasya kartravyabhicārāditi / yaścāsau asarvajñaḥ sa yadi kṣityutpādanasamarthaḥ saṃjñāmātraṃ bhidyeteti / athāsamarthaḥ kathaṃ kṣityādeḥ kartā /
analyzed: yat ca idam anumānam na vivāda āspadam sarvajña pūrvakam iti tatra viśeṣa pratiṣedhasya śeṣa abhyupagame sāmarthya upalabdheḥ asarvajña pūrvaka tvam syāt kārya tvasya kartṛ avyabhicārāt iti  yaḥ ca asau asarvajñaḥ sa yadi kṣiti utpādana samarthaḥ saṃjñā mātram bhidyeta iti atha asamarthaḥ katham kṣiti ādeḥ kartā
translated: And as for this inference that the effect is not due to an omniscient being, which is not under dispute, there would be the absence of an omniscient cause, due to the perception of efficiency in the denial of a particular, implying the acceptance of the rest. And because causality is invariably concomitant with an agent, and the non-omniscient one, if capable of producing the earth, would differ only in name, but if incapable, how can he be the maker of the earth etc.?

original: atha parasya sarvajñatvaviśeṣaḥ kāryatvena hetunābhipretastatpratiṣedhārthaṃ vidhirasarvajñapūrvakamiti / tatra viśeṣapratiṣedhasya śeṣābhyanujñābhyupagame sāmarthyopalabdherviruddhānumānaṃ na I / kartṛmātrasyeti cet / na / kathamatra kṣityādisampādanasāmarthyaṃ saṃjñābhedamātram / asāmarthye tu kāryānutpattiriti / dṛṣṭañca kāryam / tathā samastaviśeṣapratiṣedhe nirādhārasya sāmānyasyāprasiddhernirviṣayatvenāpramāṇatāprasaṅgaḥ / na cedamapramāṇaṃ sāmānyavyāpteḥ pratiṣeddhumaśakyatvāt / atha viśiṣṭaviśeṣapratiṣedhaḥ / tadā viśeṣābhyanujñāyāṃ viśeṣāntaropagamaprāptiḥ / vāmenākṣṇā na paśyatīti yathā /
analyzed: atha parasya sarvajña tva viśeṣaḥ kārya tvena hetunā abhipretaḥ tad pratiṣedha artham vidhiḥ asarvajña pūrvakam iti tatra viśeṣa pratiṣedhasya śeṣa abhyanujñā abhyupagame sāmarthya upalabdheḥ viruddha anumānam na kartṛ mātrasya iti ced na katham atra kṣiti ādi sampādana sāmarthyam saṃjñā bheda mātram asāmarthye tu kārya anutpattiḥ iti dṛṣṭam ca kāryam tathā samasta viśeṣa pratiṣedhe nirādhārasya sāmānyasya aprasiddheḥ nirviṣaya tvena apram
translated: Now, if the opponent intends to prove the difference of the omniscience of the other by the reason of being an effect, for the purpose of refuting that, [the Mīmāṃsaka] says, It is not preceded by a non-omniscient one. There, if the negation of a particular is accepted as implying the permission of the remainder, then there is no contradictory inference due to the perception of capability. If it is argued that it is only of the mere agent, that is not so. How is there the capability of producing the earth etc. here, merely a difference in name? But if there is no capability, then there is no production of the effect. And the effect is seen. And thus, in the negation of all particulars, the universal, which has no basis, is not well-known, so there is the undesirable consequence of being a means of knowledge with no object. And this is not a means of knowledge, because the universal, which is pervaded, cannot be negated. Now, if there is the negation of a particular with a distinguishing feature, then in the permission of the particular, there is the attainment of the acceptance of another particular, like he does not see with his left eye.

original: athāgnidhūmayoḥ pratyakṣeṇa sambandhasiddheranumānapravṛttiryuktā / naivamatreti cet / na / ihāpi kāryatvasyādhiṣṭhātṛpūrvakatvena sambandhasiddheranumānaṃ pravartata eva /
analyzed: atha agni dhūmayoḥ pratyakṣeṇa sambandha siddheḥ anumāna pravṛttiḥ yuktā na evam atra iti ced na iha api kāryatvasya adhiṣṭhātṛ pūrvaka tvena sambandha siddheḥ anumānam pravartate eva
translated: If it be argued that “in the case of Fire and Smoke, the relation is cognised by Perception, and hence the operation of Inference is proper; it is not so in the case in question”, the answer is that it is not so; because in the case in question also, the relation of ‘being produced by an intelligent Cause’ is cognised, and hence Inference does become operative.

original: athāgniranumānād ūrdhvamapi pratyakṣo naivam īśvara ityanumānaṃ kathamiti cet / na / atyantaparokṣasyāpi cakṣurāderupalabdhyanumeyatvāt / athātra sāmānyena kriyāyāḥ kāraṇakāryatvopalabdheranumānam / tarhi kāryatvasya sāmānyena kartṛpūrvakatvopalabdheranumānamiti / abhyupapannañca kāryatvasya śarīrādimatā kartrā vyāptatvād / ghaṭādau tathābhūtasyaivātra siddhiriti vācyam / dṛṣṭāntadārṣṭāntikayorutkarṣāpakarṣeṇa pratyavasthānasya sarvānumānocchedakatvāt / tathā hyavidyamānasya śarīrāderāpādanam utkarṣaḥ / vidyamānasya ca sarvajñatvāderapakarṣaṇam apakarṣaḥ / na ca sarve dṛṣṭāntadharmā dārṣṭāntike 'pi bhavanti / abhede dṛṣṭāntadārṣṭāntikavyavahārocchedaprasaṅgāt / na hi chidikriyāyāḥ karaṇaṃ kuṭhārādi dṛṣṭamiti rūpopalabdhikriyāyāmapi tathā bhavati / yathā cātrāpāstaviśeṣeṇa karaṇena kriyāyā vyāptatvādanumānam evamīśvarānumāne 'pi ityanutthānaṃ jātiprayogasya /
analyzed: atha agniḥ anumānāt ūrdhvam api pratyakṣaḥ na evam īśvaraḥ iti anumānam katham iti ced na atyanta parokṣasya api cakṣuḥ ādeḥ upalabdhi anumeya tvāt  atha atra sāmānyena kriyāyāḥ kāraṇa kāryatva upalabdheḥ anumānam tarhi kāryatvasya sāmānyena kartṛ pūrvakatva upalabdheḥ anumānam iti abhyupapannam ca kāryatvasya śarīra ādimatā kartrā vyāpta tvāt ghaṭa ādau tathābhūtasya eva atra siddhiḥ iti vācyam dṛṣṭānta dārṣṭāntikayoḥ utkarṣa a
translated: If it is argued that fire is perceived even after inference, but not so God, how then is inference possible? No, because even the extremely imperceptible eye, etc. are to be inferred from perception. If it is argued that here inference is from the perception of the cause-effect relation of action in general, then inference is from the perception of the effect's antecedence to the agent in general. It must be accepted that the effect is pervaded by an agent possessing a body, etc. It cannot be said that only such an agent is established in the case of a pot, etc. because the counter-argument of superiority and inferiority between the example and the subject would destroy all inference. For, the postulation of a non-existent body, etc. is superiority, and the denial of an existent omniscience, etc. is inferiority. And not all the properties of the example are in the subject. For, if there were no difference, there would be the undesirable consequence of the destruction of the distinction between the example and the subject. For, the instrument of the act of cutting is not

original: etena yadāha /
analyzed: etena yat āha
translated: By this, what is said by him is refuted:

original: kasyacid hetumātrasya yadyadhiṣṭhātṛtocyate /
analyzed: kasyacid hetu mātrasya yadi adhiṣṭhātṛ tā ucyate
translated: If the mere cause of something is said to be the controller,

original: karmabhiḥ sarvabījānāṃ tat siddheḥ siddhasādhanam // ślo / vā / sambandhā /
analyzed: karmabhiḥ sarva bījānām tat siddheḥ siddha sādhanam
translated: then it is an established proof to establish the seed of all actions by karma.

original: iti tadapāstaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: iti tat apāstam bhavati
translated: Thus, that is refuted.

original: tathā hi buddhimatyadhiṣṭhātari sādhye kathamacetanena karmaṇā siddhasādhanam / tasyāpyacetanatayādhiṣṭhātrapekṣatvāt / tathā hi / sarvamacetanaṃ cetanādhiṣṭhitaṃ pravartamānaṃ dṛṣṭam / yathā tantvādi / tathā ca karmādi / na cāsmadādyātmaivādhiṣṭhāyakaḥ / tasya tadviṣayajñānābhāvāt / tathā cāsmadādyātmano na karmaviṣayaṃ jñānamindriyajam / nāpi paramāṇvādiviṣayam / I / na ca tadabhāve tasya preraka /tvaṃ dṛṣṭam / na cācetanasyākasmāt pravṛttirupalabdhā / pravṛttau vā pariniṣpanne 'pi kārye pravarteta / vivekaśūnyatvāt /
analyzed: tathā hi buddhimati adhiṣṭhātari sādhye katham acetanena karmaṇā siddhasādhanam tasya api acetana tayā adhiṣṭhātṛ apekṣa tvāt tathā hi sarvam acetanam cetanā dhiṣṭhitam pravartamānam dṛṣṭam yathā tantu ādi tathā ca karma ādi na ca asmat ādi ātmā eva adhiṣṭhāyakaḥ tasya tad viṣaya jñāna abhāvāt tathā ca asmat ādi ātmanaḥ na karma viṣayam jñānam indriya jam na api paramāṇu ādi viṣayam  / na ca tad abhāve tasya preraka tvam dṛṣṭam na
translated: For thus, when an intelligent controller is to be established, how can it be an established proof with an unconscious action? Because that also, being unconscious, requires a controller. For thus, everything that is unconscious is seen to operate when controlled by consciousness, like a thread etc. And so is karma etc. And the self of us etc. is not the controller itself. Because it does not have the knowledge of that object. And thus, the self of us etc. does not have knowledge of karma as an object produced by the senses, nor of an atom etc. as an object. And without that, its being an instigator is not seen. And the operation of the unconscious is not observed to occur suddenly. Or in operation, it would occur even in a fully accomplished effect, because of the absence of discrimination.

original: athācetanātmanādhiṣṭhitaṃ ca kṣīraṃ pravartate / tanna / govatsaprayatnābhāve mṛtāvasthāyāmapravṛtteḥ / sarvañcāsmadādyanadhiṣṭhitaṃ pakṣe 'ntarbhūtamiti na sādhyenaiva sādhanasya vyabhicāraḥ / sarvānumānocchedaprasaṅgāt / tathā ca acetanānyasmadanyenādhiṣṭhitāni / kāryotpattau buddhimadadhiṣṭhitāni / acetanatvāt / yad yadacetanaṃ tattad buddhimatādhiṣṭhitaṃ pravartamānaṃ dṛṣṭam yathā tantvādi / tathā caitāni / tasmād yathoktasādhyāni /
analyzed: atha acetana ātmanā adhiṣṭhitam ca kṣīram pravartate tat na go vatsa prayatna abhāve mṛta avasthāyām apravṛtteḥ sarvam ca asmat ādi anadhiṣṭhitam pakṣe ntarbhūtam iti na sādhyena eva sādhanasya vyabhicāraḥ sarva anumāna uccheda prasaṅgāt tathā ca acetanāni asmat anyena adhiṣṭhitāni kārya utpattau buddhimat adhiṣṭhitāni acetana tvāt yat yat acetanam tat tat buddhimatā adhiṣṭhitam pravartamānam dṛṣṭam yathā tantu ādi tathā ca etāni tasmāt yath
translated: The following might be urged: “If the omniscience of Kapila and others is not admitted, on the ground of there being no proof for it, then, how can it be admitted that there is no such proof?”

original: atha kartuḥ śarīrādimattvopalabdherīśvare 'pi tathābhāvaḥ / kimatra sādhyate yadi śarīrādimattve 'pi kṣityādikartṛtvamabhyupagamyate / atha śarīrādimattvād asarvajñasya na kṣityādikartṛtvam / tarhi kāryasya kartṛvyabhicārād aśarīrasyaiva kartṛtvamabhyupeyam / na ca śarīrādimattve pramāṇamasti / atha kartṛtvameva pramāṇam / tad vyāhatameva / kartṛtvena śarīrādimattvaṃ śarīrādimattvācca kṣityādyakartṛtvamiti /
analyzed: atha kartuḥ śarīra ādimattva upalabdheḥ īśvare pi tathābhāvaḥ kim atra sādhyate yadi śarīra ādimattve pi kṣiti ādi kartṛ tvam abhyupagamyate atha śarīra ādimattvāt asarvajñasya na kṣiti ādi kartṛ tvam tarhi kāryasya kartṛ vyabhicārāt aśarīrasya eva kartṛ tvam abhyupeyam na ca śarīra ādimattve pramāṇam asti atha kartṛ tvam eva pramāṇam tat vyāhatam eva kartṛ tvena śarīra ādimattvam śarīra ādimattvāt ca kṣiti ādi akartṛ tvam iti
translated: If, on the other hand, the existence of a body, etc. is perceived in the case of an agent, then the same must be the case with God. What is to be proved here? If it is accepted that the agency of the earth, etc. is possible even with the possession of a body, etc., then if it is argued that the agency of the earth, etc. does not belong to one who is not omniscient because of the possession of a body, etc., then the agency must be accepted to belong to one who is bodiless alone, because the agency of an effect is not possible with a body. And there is no proof for the possession of a body, etc. If the proof is the agency itself, then that is contradictory. The possession of a body, etc. is due to agency, and the agency of the earth, etc. is due to the possession of a body, etc.

original: na cedaṃ svatantrasādhanam / āśrayāsiddhatvāt / tathā hi siddhe kartṛsadbhāve kartṛtvasya śarīrādimattvasya ca pakṣadharmatvaṃ syāt / na caitadabhyupagatam /
analyzed: na ca idam svatantra sādhanam āśraya asiddha tvāt tathā hi siddhe kartṛ sadbhāve kartṛ tvasya śarīra ādimattvasya ca pakṣa dharma tvam syāt na ca etat abhyupagatam
translated: And this is not an independent proof, because the basis is not established. Thus, if the existence of an agent is established, then the property of the subject would be the agency and the possession of a body, etc. But this is not accepted.

original: atha pareṇa kṣityādikartā'bhyupagata ityaniṣṭāpādanametat / na yadi pramāṇāyattastadupagamastenaiva bādhyamānatvādanutthānaṃ viparītānumānasya / na caitasyānenaiva bādhaḥ syāt / tanmūlatvāt / atha pramāṇaṃ vinaivābhyupagataḥ pareṇa / tarhi pramāṇaṃ vinā prameyasyāsiddheḥ kiṃ viparītānumānena / tasyāśrayāsiddhatāprasaṅgāt / samānañcaitadanyeṣvapīśvarapratiṣedhahetuṣviti /
analyzed: atha pareṇa kṣiti ādi kartā abhyupagataḥ iti aniṣṭa āpādanam etat na yadi pramāṇa āyattaḥ tad upagamaḥ tena eva bādhyamāna tvāt anutthānam viparīta anumānasya  na ca etasya anena eva bādhaḥ syāt tad mūla tvāt atha pramāṇam vinā eva abhyupagataḥ pareṇa tarhi pramāṇam vinā prameyasya asiddheḥ kim viparīta anumānena tasya āśraya asiddha tā prasaṅgāt  samānam ca etat anyeṣu api īśvara pratiṣedha hetuṣu iti
translated: If, on the other hand, the opponent admits the existence of some other creator of the earth, etc., then this argument of yours is futile. If that admission is based on valid cognition, then the opponent's inference is refuted by that very valid cognition itself, and the contrary inference does not arise. And this [valid cognition] would not refute that [contrary inference], because it is based on that [valid cognition]. If, on the other hand, the opponent admits [the existence of God] without valid cognition, then, since the object of knowledge cannot be established without valid cognition, what is the use of a contrary inference? Because that [contrary inference] would be subject to the fallacy of having an unestablished basis. And this is the same in the case of other reasons for denying God.

original: tathā śarīrasambandhe sati niyatadeśatayā yugapadaniyatadeśaṃ kāryaṃ na syāt / tattu dṛṣṭam / athaikamaniyatadeśasya kāryasyotpattyā vyāpi śarīraṃ nityamatīndriyañceṣyate / tanna / dṛṣṭaviparītatvāt / parañcāśarīrasyaiva kartṛtvamabhyupeyamiti / tathā hi / nityaśarīrā sambhavāt / taccharīraṃ tatsampādyameveti kiṃ śarīrāntareṇa vinā cārabhyate / / śarīrāntarābhyupagame tad anyaśarīrayuktena sampādyata iti śarīraparamparāyāmupakṣīṇatvād bhagavato nānyatkāryaṃ prādurbhavediti / athathā / śarīrasyaiva śarīrakartṛtvaṃ tatkāryāvasare 'pi I / na bādhyata iti cet / tathā sati saṃhārāvasthāyāṃ śarīrasya nāśe punaḥ sargādāvaśarīrasyākartṛtve kāryotpattirna syādityaśarīrasyaiva kartṛtvamabhyupagatam /peyam /
analyzed: tathā śarīra sambandhe sati niyata deśa tayā yugapad aniyata deśam kāryam na syāt tat tu dṛṣṭam atha ekam aniyata deśasya kāryasya utpattyā vyāpi śarīram nityam atīndriyam ca iṣyate tat na dṛṣṭa viparīta tvāt param ca aśarīrasya eva kartṛ tvam abhyupeyam iti tathā hi nitya śarīrā sambhavāt tat śarīram tat sampādyam eva iti kim śarīra antareṇa vinā ca ārabhyate śarīra antara abhyupagame tat anya śarīra yuktena sampādyate iti śarīra paramparāyām upak
translated: And so, if there were a connection with the body, the effect which is not restricted to a particular place at the same time as the body would not be restricted to a particular place. But that is seen. If, on the other hand, it is accepted that the body is all-pervading, eternal, and imperceptible, due to the production of an effect which is not restricted to a particular place, that is not so. Because it is contrary to what is seen. And it must be accepted that the one without a body is the agent. Because it is not possible for the body to be eternal. That body is to be accomplished by that [agent]. So what is begun without another body? If another body is accepted, it is accomplished by one connected with another body. In the succession of bodies, the Lord would be exhausted, and no other effect would appear. If it is argued that the body itself is the agent of the body, and that is not contradicted even at the time of the effect, if that is so, then at the time of dissolution when the body is destroyed, and the one without a body is not the agent at the beginning of creation again, the effect would not be produced. Thus it is accepted that the one without a body is the agent.

original: atha prayojanāpekṣitayā kartṝṇāṃ pravṛtterupalambhāt tadabhāvācceśvare pravṛttyabhāva iti cet / tadasat / kāryasadbhāvena kartṛsadabhāvasiddheḥ / tasya ca svayaṃ paripūrṇatvāt parārthā pravṛttirgamyate / yad vā pravṛttiśīlatvād bhagavato nāyaṃ paryanuyoga iti / yathā hi bhāsvān prakāśanaśīlatvāt padārthān prakāśayati / evamitaro 'pi kāryakāraṇarūpatvāt kāryaṃ karotīti /
analyzed: atha prayojana apekṣi tayā kartṝṇām pravṛtteḥ upalambhāt tad abhāvāt ca īśvare pravṛtti abhāvaḥ iti ced tat asat kārya sadbhāvena kartṛ sadabhāva siddheḥ tasya ca svayam paripūrṇa tvāt parārthā pravṛttiḥ gamyate yat vā pravṛtti śīla tvāt bhagavataḥ na ayam paryanuyogaḥ iti yathā hi bhāsvān prakāśana śīla tvāt padārthān prakāśayati evam itaraḥ pi kārya kāraṇa rūpa tvāt kāryam karoti iti
translated: If it be said that the activity of agents is due to the requirement of a purpose, and that there is no activity in God because there is no such requirement, that is not so. Because the existence of an agent is established by the existence of an effect, and since He is Himself perfect, His activity is seen to be for the sake of others. Or, because the Lord is of the nature of activity, this objection does not apply to Him. Just as the sun illuminates objects by its nature of illuminating, so the other (God) also creates an effect because of being the cause and effect.

original: athāśarīrasyecchāmātreṇa kathaṃ prerakatvam / yathāsmadādyātmanaḥ śarīrādiprerakatvamiti / atha satyeva śarīre preryaprerakatvam / ihāpi satyeva paramāṇau preryaprerakatvamiti samānam /
analyzed: atha aśarīrasya icchā mātreṇa katham preraka tvam yathā asmat ādi ātmanaḥ śarīra ādi preraka tvam iti atha sati eva śarīre prerya preraka tvam iha api sati eva paramāṇau prerya preraka tvam iti samānam
translated: If it be said that how can one without a body be the impeller merely by will, just as the soul of us etc. is the impeller of the body etc., or if the relation of impeller and impelled exists only when there is a body, then the same applies here also, the relation of impeller and impelled exists only when there is an atom.

original: atha sisṛkṣā sañjihīrṣā vā maheśvarasya yadi nityā / satataṃ kāryotpattiḥ / athānityā / sāpīśvarecchāṃ vinā na bhavatītyaparamicchāntaram / tadapyanityatvādīśvarecchādhīnam ityanavasthāyāṃ tatsampādana evopakṣīṇatvād bhagavato na kāryāntare vyāpāraḥ syāt / atheśvarecchāṃ vināpīśvarecchā sampādyate tarhi kāryāntare 'pyevamastu /
analyzed: atha sisṛkṣā sañjihīrṣā vā maheśvarasya yadi nityā satatam kārya utpattiḥ atha anityā sā api īśvara icchām vinā na bhavati iti aparam icchāntaram tat api anitya tvāt īśvara icchā adhīnam iti anavasthāyām tad sampādane eva upakṣīṇa tvāt bhagavataḥ na kārya antare vyāpāraḥ syāt  / atha īśvara icchām vinā api īśvara icchā sampādyate tarhi kārya antare pi evam astu  /
translated: Now, if the desire to create or the desire to withhold creation of Maheśvara is eternal, then there would be constant production of effects. If it is non-eternal, then that also does not occur without the will of God, so there is another desire. That also is dependent on the will of God, which is non-eternal, so there is an infinite regress. Since it is exhausted in accomplishing that, the Lord would not be engaged in other activities. If the will of God is accomplished even without the will of God, then let it be so in other activities as well.

original: atha nityāpi sahakāriprāptau kāryaṃ karoti / sahakāriṇāmapi nityatve satataṃ kāryotpattiḥ / anityatve vā tānapi sahakāriṇaḥ sampādayantī sahakāryantaramapekṣate / teṣāmapyanityatve punaḥ sahakāryantaram ityanavasthāyāṃ pūrvadoṣānuṣaṅgaḥ /
analyzed: atha nityā api sahakāri prāptau kāryam karoti sahakāriṇām api nitya tve satatam kārya utpattiḥ anitya tve vā tān api sahakāriṇaḥ sampādayantī sahakāri antaram apekṣate teṣām api anitya tve punar sahakāri antaram iti anavasthāyām pūrva doṣa anuṣaṅgaḥ
translated: If it is eternal but produces the effect when auxiliaries are present, then if the auxiliaries are also eternal, there would be constant production of effects. If they are non-eternal, then those auxiliaries also require another auxiliary in order to accomplish them. If they too are non-eternal, then there is another auxiliary. In the case of an infinite regress, the previously mentioned faults follow.

original: naiṣa doṣaḥ / vino /cirotpannādṛṣṭasadbhāve satīcchāyāḥ kāryakaraṇāt / tathā hi / sahakārisampādane 'pyanyaṃ sahakāriṇamapekṣate tatrāpyanyamityanāditvaṃ parihāraḥ / uktañcecchāyāḥ sṛṣṭau saṃhāre ca sahakāriteti / tathā /
analyzed: na eṣa doṣaḥ vinā ucira utpanna adṛṣṭa sadbhāve sati icchāyāḥ kārya karaṇāt tathā hi sahakāri sampādane pi anyam sahakāriṇam apekṣate tatra api anyam iti anādi tvam parihāraḥ uktam ca icchāyāḥ sṛṣṭau saṃhāre ca sahakāri tā iti tathā
translated: This is not a fault. Because even without the existence of the long-arisen desire, the effect is produced. Thus, even in the provision of cooperating factors, it requires another cooperating factor there, and another there, so the solution is that it is beginningless. And it is said that desire has a cooperative role in creation and dissolution. And so:

original: viśvataścakṣuruta viśvatomukho viśvatobāhūruta viśvataspāt /
analyzed: viśvatas cakṣuḥ uta viśvatomukhaḥ viśvatobāhūḥ uta viśvataspād
translated: He who has eyes everywhere, a face everywhere, hands and feet everywhere,

original: saṃ bāhubhyāṃ dhamati saṃpatatrairdyāvābhūmī janayan deva ekaḥ // tai / āra / / nārā / pani / khaṃ /
analyzed: sam bāhubhyām dhamati saṃpatatraiḥ dyāvābhūmī janayan devaḥ ekaḥ
translated: With his two arms he blows, with his two wings, generating heaven and earth, the one God.

original: ityāgamena prasiddhaḥ /
analyzed: iti āgamena prasiddhaḥ
translated: This is well-known from the scriptures.

original: na ca svarūpapratipādakānāmaprāmāṇyaṃ pramājanakatvasya sadbhāvāt / tathā hi / pramājanakatvena pramāṇasya prāmāṇyam / na pravṛttijanakatvena / taccehāpyastyeva / pravṛttiI /nivṛttī tu puruṣasya sukhaduḥkhasādhanatvād vyavasāye samarthasyārthitvād bhavata iti /
analyzed: na ca svarūpa pratipādakānām aprāmāṇyam pramā janaka tvasya sadbhāvāt tathā hi pramā janaka tvena pramāṇasya prāmāṇyam na pravṛtti janaka tvena tat ca iha api asti eva tu puruṣasya sukha duḥkha sādhana tvāt vyavasāye samarthasya arthi tvāt bhavataḥ iti
translated: And the statements about his nature are not unauthoritative, because they produce valid knowledge. Thus, the authoritativeness of a means of valid knowledge is due to its producing valid knowledge, not to its producing activity. And this exists here also. But activity and cessation occur for a person who is capable of determining what leads to pleasure and pain, due to his desire.

original: atha vidhyaṅgatvādamīṣāṃ prādhānyaṃ na svarūpārthatvāditi cet / tadasat / svārthapratipādakatvena vidhyaṅgatvāt / tathā hi / stuteḥ svārthapratipādakatvenāpravartakatvam / nindāyāśca nivartakatvam / anyathā hi tadarthāparijñāne vihitapratiṣiddheṣvaviśeṣeṇa pravṛttinivṛttī syātām / tathā vidhivākyasyāpi svārthapratipādanadvāreṇaiva puruṣaprerakatvaṃ dṛṣṭam / evaṃ svarūpapareṣvapi vākyeṣu syāt / vākyarūpatayā aviśeṣād viśeṣahetoścābhāvāditi /
analyzed: atha vidhi aṅga tvāt amīṣām prādhānyam na svarūpa artha tvāt iti ced tat asat svārtha pratipādaka tvena vidhi aṅga tvāt tathā hi stuteḥ svārtha pratipādaka tvena apravartaka tvam nindāyāḥ ca nivartaka tvam anyathā hi tad artha aparijñāne vihita pratiṣiddheṣu aviśeṣeṇa pravṛtti nivṛttī syātām tathā vidhi vākyasya api svārtha pratipādana dvāreṇa eva puruṣa preraka tvam dṛṣṭam evam sva rūpa pareṣu api vākyeṣu syāt vākya rūpatayā aviśeṣāt
translated: If it be said that their pre-eminence is due to their being parts of the injunction, not to their expressing their own meaning, that is not so. For they are parts of the injunction by expressing their own meaning. Thus, praise does not instigate by expressing its own meaning, and censure does not cause desisting. For otherwise, if the meaning of those were not known, there would be no distinction in engaging in or desisting from what is enjoined or prohibited. Similarly, the injunctive sentence is seen to instigate a person only by expressing its own meaning. Thus it would be so even in sentences that are about their own form. For there is no distinction by way of sentence, and no reason for distinction.

original: tathā svarūpārthānāmaprāmāṇye medhyā āpo darbhāḥ pavitramamedhyaṃ / / / / / / / maśuciḥ ityevaṃrūpāparijñāne vidhyaṅgatāyāmaviśeṣeṇa pravṛttinivṛttiprasaṅgaḥ / na caitadasti / medhyeṣveva pravartante / amedhyeṣu ca nivartanta ityupalambhāt / tadevaṃ svarūpārthebhyo vākyebhyo 'rthasvarūpāvabodhe sati iṣṭe pravṛttidarśanādaniṣṭe ca nivṛttiriti jñāyate / svarūpārthānāṃ pramājanakatvena pravṛttau nivṛttau vā vidhisahakāritvamiti / aparijñānena tu pravṛttāvatiprasaṅgaḥ /
analyzed: tathā svarūpa arthānām aprāmāṇye medhyāḥ āpaḥ darbhāḥ pavitram amedhyam maśuciḥ iti evaṃrūpa aparijñāne vidhi aṅga tāyām aviśeṣeṇa pravṛtti nivṛtti prasaṅgaḥ na ca etat asti medhyeṣu eva pravartante amedhyeṣu ca nivartante iti upalambhāt tat evam svarūpa arthebhyaḥ vākyebhyaḥ rtha svarūpa avabodhe sati iṣṭe pravṛtti darśanāt aniṣṭe ca nivṛttiḥ iti jñāyate svarūpa arthānām pramā janaka tvena pravṛttau nivṛttau vā vidhi sahakār
translated: Similarly, if the statements about the nature of things were not authoritative, then in the case of the injunctions Water is pure, Darbha grass is pure, the sacred thread is pure, impure things are impure, if the nature of things were not known, then there would be the undesirable consequence of engagement and disengagement without distinction. But this is not so, because it is observed that people engage only in pure things and desist from impure things. Thus, when the nature of things is understood from statements about the nature of things, and engagement is seen in what is desirable and desisting from what is undesirable, it is known that the statements about the nature of things assist the injunctions in bringing about engagement or disengagement by generating valid knowledge. But if engagement were due to ignorance, there would be an undesirable over-extension.

original: atha svarūpārthānāṃ prāmāṇye grāvāṇaḥ plavante ityādīnāmapi yathārthatā syāt / na / mukhye bādhakopapatteḥ / yatra hi mukhye bādhakaṃ pramāṇamasti tatropacāraḥ kalpyate / tadabhāve tu prāmāṇyameva / na ceśvarasadbhāvapratipādakeṣvasti kiñcid bādhakamiti / tadevaṃ sṛṣṭisaṃhārapratipādakānāmapi vākyānāṃ svarūpe 'rthe prāmāṇyād viparītārthakalpanā anyāyyeti /
analyzed: atha svarūpa arthānām prāmāṇye grāvāṇaḥ plavante ityādīnām api yathārtha tā syāt na mukhye bādhaka upapatteḥ yatra hi mukhye bādhakam pramāṇam asti tatra upacāraḥ kalpyate tad abhāve tu prāmāṇyam eva na ca īśvara sadbhāva pratipādakeṣu asti kiñcid bādhakam iti tat evam sṛṣṭi saṃhāra pratipādakānām api vākyānām svarūpe rthe prāmāṇyāt viparīta artha kalpanā anyāyyā iti
translated: If, on the other hand, the words are accepted as having an objective basis in the form of the real state of things, then the words ‘the stones float’ also would have to be regarded as true. Not so; because in the case of the primary meaning, there is a reason for rejecting it; that is to say, it is only when there is a reason for rejecting the primary meaning of a word that the word is taken in the secondary or figurative sense; when there is no such reason for rejecting the primary meaning, the word is to be taken in that sense; and in the case of the words ‘the stones float’, there is no reason for rejecting the primary meaning; hence these words have to be taken in that sense. In the case of the words of the Veda, on the other hand, which speak of the existence of God, there is a reason for rejecting the primary meaning; hence these words have to be taken in the secondary sense. Thus then, the words of the Veda, which speak of the creation and dissolution of the world, being true in regard to their primary meaning, it is not right to assume any other meaning for them.

original: etena śākyapakṣo 'pi pratiṣiddha eva / tathā hi / śākyā api dṛṣṭāntadārṣṭāntikayorutkarṣāpakarṣeṇa pratyadhi /vatiṣṭhante / tatra coktameva pratisādha /samādhānamiti / tacca jātyuttaram / yat kāryaṃ yādṛśakartrā vyāptamupalabdhaṃ yadupalabdheretatkriyādarśinaḥ kenāpyetat sampāditam iti buddhirbhavati / tadevopalabhyamānaṃ tādṛśameva kartāraṃ gamayet / taduktam /
analyzed: etena śākya pakṣaḥ pi pratiṣiddhaḥ eva tathā hi śākyāḥ api dṛṣṭānta dārṣṭāntikayoḥ utkarṣa apakarṣeṇa pratyadhivatiṣṭhante tatra ca uktam eva pratisādha samādhānam iti tat ca jāti uttaram yat kāryam yādṛśa kartrā vyāptam upalabdham yad upalabdheḥ etad kriyā darśinaḥ kena api etat sampāditam iti buddhiḥ bhavati tat eva upalabhyamānam tādṛśam eva kartāram gamayet tat uktam
translated: By this, the Shakyas' position is also refuted. For the Shakyas also stand on the basis of the similarity and dissimilarity of the example and the subject. And there, the same answer has been given. That is a futile rejoinder. When an effect is seen to be pervaded by a certain kind of agent, and when one who sees that effect being produced thinks this has been accomplished by someone, that very thing being perceived would indicate an agent of that kind. That has been stated:

original: siddhaṃ yādṛgadhiṣṭhātṛbhāvābhāvānuvṛttimat //
analyzed: siddham yādṛś adhiṣṭhātṛ bhāva abhāva anuvṛttimat
translated: It is established that which follows the presence and absence of an agent of a certain kind.

original: sanniveśāditadyuktaṃ tasmād yadanumīyate // pra / vā / /
analyzed: sanniveśa ādi tat yuktam tasmāt yat anumīyate pra vā
translated: Therefore, what is inferred from arrangement etc. is proper.

original: na ca kṣityādikāryaṃ kartravinābhūtaṃ dṛṣṭamiti kathaṃ kartāraṃ gamayet / atha satyapi bhede kāryaśabdasāmyādanumānam / evaṃ tarhi dhūme pāṇḍutvamagninā vyāptamupalabdhamiti prāsādadeśādāvapyupalabhyamānamagniṃ gamayet / taduktam /
analyzed: na ca kṣiti ādi kāryam kartṛ avinābhūtam dṛṣṭam iti katham kartāram gamayet  atha sati api bhede kārya śabda sāmyāt anumānam evam tarhi dhūme pāṇḍu tvam agninā vyāptam upalabdham iti prāsāda deśa ādau api upalabhyamānam agnim gamayet tat uktam
translated: And since an effect like earth is not seen to be inseparable from an agent, how could it indicate an agent? But even if there is difference, inference is based on the similarity of the effect's name. If so, then since the pallor of smoke is seen to be pervaded by fire, it would indicate fire even when perceived in a palace.

original: vastubhede prasiddhasya śabdasāmyādabhedinaḥ /
analyzed: vastu bhede prasiddhasya śabda sāmyāt abhedinaḥ
translated: When there is difference of substance, it is not proper to infer the non-difference of what is well-known to be different, merely on the ground of similarity of words.

original: na yuktānumitiḥ pāṇḍudravyādiva hutāśane // pra / vā / /
analyzed: na yukta anumitiḥ pāṇḍu dravyāt iva hutāśane pra vā
translated: As in the case of the Pandu substance and fire.

original: yadi kiñcit kāryaṃ kartravinābhūtaṃ dṛṣṭamityaparidṛṣṭāvinābhāvasyāpi tatpūrvakatvaṃ syāt / tathā sati ghaṭādermṛdvikārasya kulālapūrvakatvopalambhād valmīkādīnāmapi tatpūrvakatvaṃ syāt / taduktam /
analyzed: yadi kiñcid kāryam kartṛ avinābhūtam dṛṣṭam iti aparidṛṣṭa avinābhāvasya api tad pūrvakatvam syāt tathā sati ghaṭa ādeḥ mṛd vikārasya kulāla pūrvakatva upalambhāt valmīka ādīnām api tad pūrvakatvam syāt tat uktam
translated: If it is argued that some effect is seen to be invariably connected with an agent, and therefore even an unseen invariable connection would have that as its antecedent, then, in that case, since the effect of clay such as a pot is seen to have the potter as its antecedent, even anthills etc. would have that as their antecedent. This has been stated.

original: anyathā kumbhakāreṇa mṛdvikārasya kasyacit /
analyzed: anyathā kumbhakāreṇa mṛd vikārasya kasyacid
translated: Otherwise, by the potter making some effect of clay such as a pot,

original: ghaṭādeḥ karaṇāt sidhyed valmīkasyāpi tatkṛtiḥ // pra / vā / /
analyzed: ghaṭa ādeḥ karaṇāt sidhyet valmīkasya api tad kṛtiḥ pra vā
translated: the making of an anthill would also be established.

original: kathaṃ tarhīdaṃ kṣityādikāryaṃ karmajamiti / kathaṃ hi karmajaṃ jagatāṃ vaicitryamityuktam / tacca cetanā mānasaṃ karmeti na vijñānādarthāntaramiti /
analyzed: katham tarhi idam kṣiti ādi kāryam karma jam iti katham hi karma jam jagatām vaicitryam iti uktam tat ca cetanā mānasam karma iti na vijñānāt artha antaram iti
translated: How then is this effect such as the earth etc. produced by action? How is it said that the diversity of the worlds is produced by action? And that mental action of conscious beings is not different from consciousness.

original: sarvametadasambaddham / sāmānyena kāryatvasya kartṛvyāpyatvaṃ / buddhimatā vyāpterupalambhāt kṣitāvapi tatsiddheḥ / sarvañcānumānamanyatra sāmānyena vyāptigrahaṇāpekṣaṃ pravartata ityuktam / na kiñcidapyanumānaṃ pakṣe vyāptigrahaṇāpekṣaṃ sambhavatītyadūṣaṇametat / kṣityādikāryaṃ na kartṛvyāptamupalabdhamiti / na cetthambhūtaṃ kāryaṃ kartṛ /rtravinābhūtaṃ nopalabdhamityanumānābhāva iti vācyam / sarvānumānocchedaprasaṅgāt / tathā hi / kṛtakatvādanityatvaṃ śabde 'bhyupagatam / atrāpi śakyate vaktuṃ yat śabde kṛtakatvaṃ tannānyatrānityatvāvinābhāvitayopalabdham ityanumānābhāvaḥ / atha sāmānyena kṛtakatvānityatvayoranyatra vyāptigrahaṇe satyanumānaṃ na pakṣe iti cet / samānamīśvarānumāne 'pīti / na cātra śabdasāmānya /sāmyameva / kāryatvasyobhayatrāvyabhicāriṇaḥ sadbhāvāt / na caivaṃ pāṇḍutvamagnergamakam / tasyāgnimantareṇa sadbhāvena vyabhicāritvāditi / evañca valmīkādāvapi mṛdvikāratvaṃ na kulālapūrvakatve liṅgam / vyabhicārāt / tasya hi prākāreṣṭakādiṣvakulālapūrvakeṣvapi sadbhāvāt /
analyzed: sarvam etat asambaddham sāmānyena kāryatvasya kartṛ vyāpya tvam buddhimatā vyāpteḥ upalambhāt kṣitau api tad siddheḥ sarvañca anumānam anyatra sāmānyena vyāpti grahaṇa apekṣam pravartate iti uktam na kiñcid api anumānam pakṣe vyāpti grahaṇa apekṣam sambhavati iti adūṣaṇam etat kṣiti ādi kāryam na kartṛ vyāptam upalabdham iti na ca itthambhūtam kāryam na upalabdham iti anumāna abhāvaḥ iti vācyam sarva anumāna uccheda prasaṅgāt tathā hi kṛta anumāna
translated: All this is irrelevant. The fact of being an effect is pervaded by having a maker in general. Because the pervasion by an intelligent being is perceived, it is established even on earth. And it has been said that all inference proceeds depending on the apprehension of the pervasion elsewhere in general. It is not possible for any inference to depend on the apprehension of the pervasion in the subject. Therefore this is not a fault. It is not observed that the effect such as earth is pervaded by a maker. And it should not be said that there is no inference because an effect of this kind, which is not absent from the maker, is not observed. Because it would lead to the absurdity of the cessation of all inference. For instance, impermanence is accepted as being pervaded by being produced in sound. Here too it can be said that the being produced which is in sound is not observed elsewhere as invariably concomitant with impermanence, so there is no inference. If it is argued that when the pervasion of being produced and impermanence is apprehended elsewhere in general, there is inference, not in the subject, the same applies to the inference of God.

original: yaccedaṃ karmajaṃ jagatāṃ vaicitryamiti / tadiṣyata eva / yadi nāmācetanatvāt karma cetanādhiṣṭhitaṃ kāryakaraṇe pravartata itīśvarasyāpi sadbhāvaḥ para /kāryasyāpi sadbhāvaḥ / yadyapi cetanenaiva karma tathāpi nāpi tasya vidādhāratvaṃ cetanatvameva / na ca tasya bodhena tādātmyamātmaguṇatvasya vakṣyamāṇatvāt / nāpīdamekaśākhāprabhavatvānumānena tulyam / tatra hyekaśākhāprabhavatvena hetunā phalāntarāṇāṃ pāke sādhye pratyakṣeṇa bādhodayādaprāmāṇyaṃ yuktam / na caivamīśvarānumāna iti /
analyzed: yat ca idam karma jam jagatām vaicitryam iti tat iṣyate eva yadi nāma acetana tvāt karma cetanā dhiṣṭhitam kārya karaṇe pravartate iti īśvarasya api sadbhāvaḥ para kāryasya api sadbhāvaḥ yadi api cetanena eva karma tathā api nā api tasya vid ādhāra tvam cetana tvam eva na ca tasya bodhena tādātmyam ātma guṇa tvasya vakṣyamāṇa tvāt nā api idam eka śākhā prabhava tva anumānena tulyam tatra hi eka śākhā prabhava tvena hetunā phala antarāṇām pāke sādhye praty
translated: And this diversity of the worlds resulting from action is accepted. Even if action operates in the body and senses under the control of a conscious being, the existence of God is established. And the existence of the effect is also established. Even if action is produced by a conscious being alone, still its being a property of the self is not due to consciousness itself. And it is not identical with consciousness, because it will be said to be a property of the self. Nor is this analogous to the inference of origination from a single branch. For there, when the effect is to be established in cooking by the reason of origination from a single branch, invalidity is proper due to the occurrence of contradiction by perception. And it is not so in the inference of God.

original: na ca śarīrādimattvena kartṛtvaṃ vyāptamiti sadabhāvāt tasyāpyabhāva iti ca vācyam / kāryānumānasya cāvyabhicāritve kartṛsadbhāvasiddheḥ / na cātra vyāpakānupalabdherbādhakatvam / anumānasthānumānāntareṇa bādhāyogāt / pūrvānumānena ca dharmisadbhāvasiddhāvupakṛtaviṣayatvam / asiddhau vā na pakṣadharmatvam /
analyzed: na ca śarīra ādimattvena kartṛ tvam vyāptam iti sat abhāvāt tasya api abhāvaḥ iti ca vācyam kārya anumānasya ca avyabhicāri tve kartṛ sadbhāva siddheḥ na ca atra vyāpaka anupalabdheḥ bādhaka tvam anumāna stha anumāna antareṇa bādhā ayogāt pūrva anumānena ca dharmi sadbhāva siddhau upakṛta viṣaya tvam asiddhau vā na pakṣa dharma tvam
translated: Nor can it be said that the fact of being an agent is not pervaded by having a body, etc., and therefore, because of the non-existence of that, it also does not exist. And when the inference of an effect is not contradicted, the existence of an agent is established. And here, the non-apprehension of the pervader is not a refutation, because an inference cannot be refuted by another inference. And when the existence of the subject is established by the previous inference, it is helpful to the object. If it is not established, then it is not a property of the subject.

original: atha nityasyāvyatirekitvāt sāmarthyañca duranvayam pra / vā / / ityakartṛkatvameveśvarasya / tanna / kṣaṇikatvapratiṣedhasya vakṣyamāṇatvāt / ayañceśvaravādo 'smadgurubhirvistareṇokta iti neha pratanyate /
analyzed: atha nityasya avyatireki tvāt sāmarthyam ca duranvayam pra vā iti akartṛkatvam eva īśvarasya tat na kṣaṇikatva pratiṣedhasya vakṣyamāṇatvāt ayaḥ ca īśvara vādaḥ smat gurubhiḥ vistareṇa uktaḥ iti nā iha pratanyate
translated: Now, if it is said that because the eternal is not different, and capability is difficult to follow, therefore the absence of an agent is itself God, that is not so. Because the denial of momentariness will be stated later. And these arguments for God have been stated in detail by our teachers, so they are not elaborated here.

original: ākāśakāladiśāmekaikatvādaparajātyabhāve pāribhāṣikyastisraḥ saṃjñā bhavantyākāśaṃ kālo diniti / tasya guṇāḥ śabdasaṃkhyāparimāṇapṛthaktvasaṃyogavibhāgāḥ / tatra śabdaḥ / pratyakṣatve satyakāraṇaguṇapūrvakatvād ayāvaddravyabhāvitvād āśrayādanyatropalabdheśca na sparśavadviśeṣaguṇaḥ /PDhS
analyzed: ākāśa kāla diśām eka eka tvāt apara jāti abhāve pāribhāṣikyaḥ tisraḥ saṃjñāḥ bhavanti ākāśam kālaḥ tasya guṇāḥ śabda saṃkhyā parimāṇa pṛthaktva saṃyoga vibhāgāḥ tatra śabdaḥ pratyakṣa tve satya kāraṇa guṇa pūrvaka tvāt ayāvaddravyabhāvi tvāt āśrayāt anyatra upalabdheḥ ca na sparśavat viśeṣa guṇaḥ
translated: Space, time, and direction are each one, and there being no other class, there are three conventional names: space, time, and day. Its qualities are sound, number, measure, separateness, conjunction, and disjunction. Among them, sound is not a specific quality like touch, because it is perceptible, preceded by a quality of its cause, and persists as long as the substance does, and is also perceived elsewhere than in its substratum.

original: bāhyendriyapratyakṣatvād ātmāntaragrāhyatvād ātmanyasamavāyād ahaṅkāreṇa vibhaktagrahaṇācca nātmaguṇaḥ /PDhS
analyzed: bāhya indriya pratyakṣa tvāt ātma antara grāhya tvāt ātmani asamavāyāt ahaṅkāreṇa vibhakta grahaṇāt ca na ātma guṇaḥ
translated: It is not a quality of the self, because it is perceptible by an external sense organ, because it is grasped by another self, because it is not inhered in the self, and because it is grasped as distinct by the sense of ego.

original: śrotragrāhyatvād viśeṣaguṇabhāvācca na dikkālamanasām /PDhS
analyzed: śrotra grāhya tvāt viśeṣa guṇa bhāvāt ca na diś kāla manasām
translated: It is not of direction, time, or mind, because it is grasped by the ear and is a specific quality.

original: pāriśeṣyād guṇo bhūtvākāśasyādhigame liṅgam / śabdaliṅgāviśeṣādekatvaṃ siddham / tadanuvidhānāt pṛthaktvam / vibhavavacanāt paramamahatparimāṇam / śabdakāraṇavacanāt saṃyogavibhāgāviti /PDhS
analyzed: pāriśeṣyāt guṇaḥ bhūtvā ākāśasya adhigame liṅgam śabda liṅga aviśeṣāt eka tvam siddham tad anuvidhānāt pṛthaktvam vibhava vacanāt parama mahat parimāṇam śabda kāraṇa vacanāt saṃyoga vibhāgau iti pdhs
translated: By elimination, it is a quality, and the inference of space is by the mark of sound. Unity is established by the non-distinction of the mark of sound. Separateness is by its being subordinate to that. The highest magnitude is by the statement of magnitude. Conjunction and disjunction are by the statement of the cause of sound.

original: ato guṇavattvād anāśritatvācca dravyam / samānāsamānajātīyakāraṇāsambhavācca nityam / sarvaprāṇināñca śabdopalabdhau nimittaṃ śrotrabhāvena /PDhS
analyzed: atas guṇavat tvāt anāśrita tvāt ca dravyam samāna asamāna jātīya kāraṇa asambhavāt ca nityam sarva prāṇinām ca śabda upalabdhau nimittam śrotra bhāvena
translated: Therefore, because it possesses qualities and is not dependent on anything else, it is a substance. And because it cannot be the cause of things of the same or different kind, it is eternal. And it is the cause for all living beings in perceiving sound, by being the auditory sense organ.

original: śrotraṃ punaḥ śravaṇavivarasaṃjñako nabhodeśaḥ śabdanimittopabhogaI /prāpakadharmādharmopanibaddhaḥ / tasya ca nityatve satyupanibandhakavaikalyād bādhiryamiti /PDhS
analyzed: śrotram punar śravaṇa vivara saṃjñakaḥ nabhaḥ deśaḥ    tasya ca nitya tve sati upanibandhaka vaikalyāt bādhiryam iti
translated: Moreover, the auditory sense organ is the space in the cavity of the ear, which is bound by the merit and demerit that bring about the enjoyment of the cause of sound. And when it is eternal, deafness is due to the deficiency of the binding factors.

original: idānīmākāśasyoddeśavato lakṣaṇaparīkṣārthaṃ prakaraṇam ākāśakāladiśāmekaikatvādaparajātyabhāve pāribhāṣikyastisraḥ saṃjñā bhavanti iti / etāśca samuccayaṃ vinā ākāśādīnāṃ lakṣaṇamityāha ākāśaṃ kālo digiti yathāsaṃkhyam / tathā hi itiśabdasya pratyekamabhisambandhādākāśamiti saṃjñā ākāśe / kāla iti kāle / diksaṃjñā diśi / na tisro 'pyekasminniti /
analyzed: idānīm ākāśasya uddeśavataḥ lakṣaṇa parīkṣā artham prakaraṇam ākāśa kāla diśām ekaika tvāt apara jāti abhāve pāribhāṣikyaḥ tisraḥ saṃjñāḥ bhavanti iti etāḥ ca samuccayam vinā ākāśa ādīnām lakṣaṇam iti āha ākāśam kālaḥ diś iti yathāsaṃkhyam tathā hi iti śabdasya pratyekam abhisambandhāt ākāśam iti saṃjñā ākāśe kālaḥ iti kāle diś saṃjñā diśi na tisraḥ pi ekasmin iti
translated: Now, in order to examine the definition of space, which has direction, the topic is: Since space, time, and direction are each one, and there is no other class, there are three conventional names. And these are the definitions of space, etc., without combination, he says: Space, time, and direction, in order. Thus, because the word tatha is connected with each one, the name space is in space, time is in time, and the name direction is in direction. Not all three in one.

original: atha kasmādimāḥ pāribhāṣikyaḥ / dravyaguṇakarmātmakasya nimittasyābhāvāt / athākāśatvādi sāmānyalakṣaṇaṃ nimittaṃ bhaviṣyatītyāha aparajātyabhāve iti / aparā hi jātidravyatvāpekṣayākāśatvakālatvadiktvarūpā / sā tu na sambhavatyeva ākāśāderekatvāt / sāmānyasya ca nānādhiṣṭhānatvāditi /
analyzed: atha kasmāt imāḥ pāribhāṣikyaḥ dravya guṇa karma ātmakasya nimittasya abhāvāt atha ākāśa tva ādi sāmānya lakṣaṇam nimittam bhaviṣyati iti āha apara jāti abhāve iti aparā hi jāti dravya tva apekṣayā ākāśa tva kāla tva diś tva rūpā sā tu na sambhavati eva ākāśa ādeḥ ekatvāt sāmānyasya ca nānā adhiṣṭhāna tvāt iti
translated: Now, why are these conventional? Because of the absence of a cause in the form of substance, quality, or action. If it is argued that the universal ākāśatva (ākāś-ness) etc. will be the cause, he says in the absence of another genus. For another genus, in relation to the substance-ness, is ākāśatva (ākāś-ness), kālatva (time-ness), dik-ness etc. But that is not possible at all, because ākāśa etc. are one, and a universal has many substrata.

original: na cākāśādīnāṃ pāribhāṣikyastisraḥ saṃjñā bhavantīti sādharmyābhidhānaṃ na sambaddham / vaidharmyāvasareṇa saṃjñānāṃ parasparavyāvṛttatayā vaidharmyarūpatvād / ekatrābhidhānañca śāstrasya saṅgraharūpatvāditi / tathā cākāśamiti saṃjñā anādikālapravāhāyātā / nānyatra sambhavatītyasādhāraṇatvāllakṣaṇam / etacca viśeṣaṇamarthāllabhyate / tathā hyākāśam / itarasmād bhidyate / anādikālapravāhāyātākāśaśabdavācyatvāt / yastvitarasmādanākāśāderna bhidyate / na cāsāvevam / yathā kṣityādi na ca tathākāśaḥ / tasmād bhidyata iti /
analyzed: na ca ākāśa ādīnām pāribhāṣikyaḥ tisraḥ saṃjñāḥ bhavanti iti sādharmya abhidhānam na sambaddham vaidharmya avasareṇa saṃjñānām paraspara vyāvṛtta tayā vaidharmya rūpatvāt ekatra abhidhānam ca śāstrasya saṅgraha rūpatvāt iti tathā ca ākāśam iti saṃjñā anādi kāla pravāha āyātā na anyatra sambhavati iti asādhāraṇa tvāt lakṣaṇam etat ca viśeṣaṇam arthāt labhyate tathā hi ākāśam itarasmāt bhidyate anādi kāla pravāha āyāta ākāśa
translated: And since Ākāśa and the rest do not have the three conventional names, the statement of similarity is not connected. Because at the time of dissimilarity, the names are mutually exclusive and have the form of dissimilarity. And the statement in one place is due to the nature of the treatise as a summary. Thus, the name Ākāśa has come down through an endless series of time. It does not exist elsewhere. Because of its uncommonness, it is the definition. And this qualification is obtained from the meaning. For thus, Ākāśa is distinguished from the other. Because it has been the denotation of the word Ākāśa coming down through an endless series of time. But that which is not distinguished from the other, from what is not Ākāśa, is not so. For example, earth and so on. And Ākāśa is not so. Therefore, it is distinguished.

original: nanu pāribhāṣikyaḥ saṃjñā na sambhavantyeva nimittacatuṣṭayābhāvasyeva nimittatvād iti cet / tathā hi / yatra dravyaguṇakarmasāmānyātmakaṃ nimittaṃ na sambhavati tatraiva pravartate nānyatreti tadabhāvo nimittam / naitadevam / svānuraktapratyayahetornimittasyātra vivakṣitatvāt / yathā hi dravyaguṇasāmānyānurakto daṇḍītyādivyavahārastathā ca nāyamākāśādivyavahārastadabhāvānurakta iti pāribhāṣikya eva /
analyzed: nanu pāribhāṣikyaḥ saṃjñāḥ na sambhavanti eva nimitta catuṣṭaya abhāvasya iva nimitta tvāt iti ced tathā hi yatra dravya guṇa karma sāmānya ātmakam nimittam na sambhavati tatra eva pravartate na anyatra iti tad abhāvaḥ nimittam na etat evam sva anurakta pratyaya hetoḥ nimittasya atra vivakṣita tvāt yathā hi dravya guṇa sāmānya anuraktaḥ daṇḍī ityādi vyavahāraḥ tathā ca na ayam ākāśa ādi vyavahāraḥ tad abhāva anuraktaḥ iti pāribhāṣikyaḥ eva
translated: If it be urged that such conventional names are impossible, because there is no basis for them, like the ‘fourfooted animal with a dewlap’,—because it is the basis that is the cause,—then, the answer is that it is only where the basis, in the shape of the Substance, Quality, Action and Universal, is not possible that the name is applied to the absence of that basis; it is not so in all cases; because in the present instance, what is meant by the ‘basis’ is the cause of the notion associated with that basis; for instance, the notion of ‘the man with the stick’ is associated with the stick; and the notion of ‘ākāśa’ is not associated with any such thing; hence the name is purely conventional.

original: pūrvaṃ hi dravyāṇāṃ samavāyitvaṃ guṇatvañcoktam / tatra kairguṇairguṇavat / keṣāmutpattau samavāyikāraṇam / kiñca guṇātmakaṃ lakṣaṇamityāha tasya guṇāḥ śabdasaṃkhyāI /parimāṇapṛthaktvasaṃyogavibhāgāḥ iti / etairguṇairguṇavat / atra keṣāñcidutpattau samavāyikāraṇam / śabdaścāsādhāraṇatvāllakṣaṇamiti /
analyzed: pūrvam hi dravyāṇām samavāyi tvam guṇa tvañca uktam tatra kaiḥ guṇaiḥ guṇavat keṣām utpattau samavāyi kāraṇam kiñca guṇa ātmakam lakṣaṇam iti āha tasya guṇāḥ iti etaiḥ guṇaiḥ guṇavat atra keṣāñcid utpattau samavāyi kāraṇam śabdaḥ ca asādhāraṇa tvāt lakṣaṇam iti
translated: For previously the inherence of substances and the quality of substances have been stated. Among them, with how many qualities is the substance endowed? In the production of which is it the inherent cause? And what is the characteristic consisting of qualities? He says: Its qualities are sound, number, dimension, separateness, conjunction, and disjunction. With these qualities is the substance endowed. In the production of some of these, it is the inherent cause. And sound, being unique, is the characteristic.

original: nanu sarvametadāśrayāsiddham / ākāśasadbhāve pramāṇābhāvāt / na / pratyakṣeṇānupalambhe 'pyanumānena sadbhāvasiddheḥ / kimanumānamityāha śabdaḥ iti / tathā hi / śabdaḥ kvacidāśritaḥ / guṇatvād / yo yo guṇaḥ sa sa kvacidāśritaḥ / yathā rūpādiḥ / tathā cāyaṃ guṇaḥ / tasmādāśrita iti /
analyzed: nanu sarvam etat āśraya asiddham ākāśa sadbhāve pramāṇa abhāvāt na pratyakṣeṇa anupalambhe pi anumānena sadbhāva siddheḥ kim anumānam iti āha śabdaḥ iti tathā hi śabdaḥ kvacid āśritaḥ guṇa tvāt yaḥ yaḥ guṇaḥ sa sa kvacid āśritaḥ yathā rūpa ādiḥ tathā ca ayam guṇaḥ tasmāt āśritaḥ iti
translated: But all this is unestablished as to its substratum, because there is no means of knowing the existence of space. No. Even though it is not perceived, its existence is established by inference. What is the inference? He says: Sound. For sound is dependent on something, because it is a quality. Whatever is a quality is dependent on something, like color etc. And this is a quality. Therefore it is dependent.

original: atha pṛthivyāderguṇo bhaviṣyatītyāha na sparśavadviśeṣaguṇaḥ asmadādipratyakṣatve satyakāraṇaguṇapūrvakatvāt / yo yo 'smadādipratyakṣatve satyakāraṇapūrvakaḥ sa sa sparśavatāṃ viśeṣaguṇo na bhavati / yathā sukhādiḥ / tathā cāyaṃ yathoktasādhanaḥ / tasmāt sparśavatāṃ viśeṣaguṇo na bhavatīti /
analyzed: atha pṛthivī ādeḥ guṇaḥ bhaviṣyati iti āha na sparśavat viśeṣa guṇaḥ asmat ādi pratyakṣa tve satya kāraṇa guṇa pūrvaka tvāt yaḥ yaḥ smat ādi pratyakṣa tve satya kāraṇa pūrvakaḥ sa sa sparśavatām viśeṣa guṇaḥ na bhavati yathā sukha ādiḥ tathā ca ayam yathā ukta sādhanaḥ tasmāt sparśavatām viśeṣa guṇaḥ na bhavati iti
translated: Now, if it is argued that it may be a quality of earth etc., he says: A special quality of tangible objects is not so, because it is perceptible to us etc. and preceded by a non-material quality. Whatever is perceptible to us etc. and preceded by a non-material cause is not a special quality of tangible objects, like pleasure etc. And this is established by the stated reason. Therefore, it is not a special quality of tangible objects.

original: nanu cātra viśeṣaguṇapratiṣedhe sādhye sāmānyaguṇaprāptiḥ viśeṣapratiṣedhasya śeṣābhyanujñāyāṃ sāmarthyopalabdheḥ / atha sāmānyaguṇapratiṣedhastathāpi viśeṣaguṇaprāptiriti / naitadevam / pratiyogyapekṣatvāt pakṣādivyavasthāyāḥ / tathā hi / pareṇa kṣityādiviśeṣaguṇatvaṃ śabdasyābhyupagataṃ tasyaiva pratiṣedhaḥ / sāmānyaguṇatvañca neṣṭameva / śeṣābhyanujñā tu yatrobhayoḥ pramāṇena prasiddhistatraikapratiṣedhe 'nyasyāpratiṣiddhasyāvasthānam / yathā darśanaṃ savyetaracakṣurbhyāṃ saṃpādyaṃ dṛṣṭamityekapratiṣedhe 'nyasyāpratiṣedhādavasthānamiti / na caivaṃ śabdasya kṣityādisāmānyaguṇatvaṃ parasya siddhamityadūṣaṇametat / ata eva yadyapi saṃyogavibhāgāderasmadādipratyakṣatve satyakāraṇaguṇapūrvakatvam / tathāpi sparśavadviśeṣaguṇatvaṃ nāstīti sapakṣe 'ntarbhāvādanaikāntikatvābhāvaḥ / rūpādayaśca vipakṣāste ca kāraṇaguṇapūrvakā iti sādhanaśūnyā eva / tathāpi pārthivaparamāṇurūpādayo 'kāraṇaguṇapūrvakāḥ sparśavatāṃ viśeṣaguṇāśceti vyabhicāraḥ / tadarthamasmadādipratyakṣatve satīti viśeṣaṇam / te tu yogināmeva pratyakṣā iti / asmadādipratipādanāya śāstrasyārambhādasmadādiviśeṣaṇantu labhyate /
analyzed: nanu ca atra viśeṣa guṇa pratiṣedhe sādhye sāmānya guṇa prāptiḥ viśeṣa pratiṣedhasya śeṣa abhyanujñāyām sāmarthya upalabdheḥ  atha sāmānya guṇa pratiṣedhaḥ tathā api viśeṣa guṇa prāptiḥ iti na etat evam pratiyogi apekṣa tvāt pakṣa ādi vyavasthāyāḥ tathā hi pareṇa kṣiti ādi viśeṣa guṇa tvam śabdasya abhyupagatam tasya eva pratiṣedhaḥ sāmānya guṇa tvañca na iṣṭam eva  / śeṣa abhyanujñā tu yatra ubhayoḥ pramāṇena prasid
translated: But here, when the negation of specific qualities is to be established, the attainment of general qualities is due to the observed capability of the negation of specific qualities in the permission of the remainder. Even if there is a negation of general qualities, there is still the attainment of specific qualities. This is not so, because the determination of the subject and so on depends on the counter-correlate. Thus, the opponent has accepted the quality of sound to be specific to earth and so on, and its negation is of that alone. And the quality of sound is not even accepted to be general. As for the permission of the remainder, where both are well-known by means of a means of valid knowledge, when one is negated, the other, which is not negated, remains. For example, what is accomplished by the right and left eyes is seen by the eyes. When one is negated, the other remains because it is not negated. And in this way, the quality of sound is not established by the opponent to be general to earth and so on. Therefore, this is not a fault. For this very reason, although conjunction, disjunction and so on are perceptible to us, they are not preceded by the quality of the cause.

original: anye tu saṃyogādibhirvyabhicāraparihārāya śeṣābhyanujñā /pratijñāvākyāduddhṛtya viśeṣapadaṃ hetupadena saha sambandhayanti / tathā hi na sparśavatāṃ guṇaḥ śabdaḥ / asmadādipratyakṣatve viśeṣaguṇatve ca satyakāraṇaguṇapūrvakatvāt / sukhādivat / atra hi sāmānyato viśeṣayogāt sāmānyapratiṣedhād viśeṣapratiṣedho bhavatyeva / brāhmaṇyaniṣedhād I / vājasanādipratiṣedhavaditi / atra ca pratijñāvākye samāsāntargataṃ padaṃ hetupadena kathaṃ sambadhyata iti cintyam /
analyzed: anye tu saṃyoga ādibhiḥ vyabhicāra parihārāya śeṣa abhyanujñā pratijñā vākyāt uddhṛtya viśeṣa padam hetu padena saha sambandhayanti tathā hi na sparśavatām guṇaḥ śabdaḥ asmat ādi pratyakṣa tve viśeṣa guṇa tve ca satya kāraṇa guṇa pūrvaka tvāt sukha ādi vat atra hi sāmānyatas viśeṣa yogāt sāmānya pratiṣedhāt viśeṣa pratiṣedhaḥ bhavati eva brāhmaṇya niṣedhāt vājasana ādi pratiṣedha vat iti atra ca pratijñā vākye samāsa antargatam
translated: Others, in order to avoid the fallacy of the reason being found in the contrary example, by the mention of conjunction etc., extract the word 'special' from the proposition and connect it with the reason. Thus: Sound is not a quality of tangible objects, because it is perceptible by the senses of ourselves and others and is a special quality, like pleasure etc. Here, the negation of the special is indeed implied by the negation of the general, by the connection of the general with the special. Just as the negation of the Brāhmaṇa is implied by the negation of the human being. And here it is to be considered how the word included in the compound in the proposition is connected with the reason.

original: nanvakāraṇaguṇapūrvakatvāditi heturasiddhaḥ / paradṛṣṭyā saṃyogād vibhāgācchabdācca kāraṇaguṇācchabdasya niṣpattyabhyupagamāt / tathā hi / śabdasya kāraṇamākāśaṃ tadguṇāśca saṃyogādayaḥ kāraṇaguṇāste kāraṇamasyeti kāraṇaguṇapūrvakatvam / naivam / abhiprāyāparijñānāt / tathā cāyamartho vivakṣitaḥ / samavāyikāraṇeṣu guṇāḥ kāraṇaguṇāste pūrvaṃ kāraṇaṃ yasya guṇasyāsau kāraṇaguṇapūrvakaḥ / yathā paṭarūpādistanturūpādipūrvaka iti / na caivaṃ śabdasya / ākāśasyākāryatvena samavāyikāraṇaguṇābhāvāditi /
analyzed: nanu akāraṇa guṇa pūrvaka tvāt iti hetuḥ asiddhaḥ para dṛṣṭyā saṃyogāt vibhāgāt śabdāt ca kāraṇa guṇāt śabdasya niṣpatti abhyupagamāt tathā hi śabdasya kāraṇam ākāśam tad guṇāḥ ca saṃyoga ādayaḥ kāraṇa guṇāḥ te kāraṇam asya iti kāraṇa guṇa pūrvaka tvam na evam abhiprāya aparijñānāt tathā ca ayam arthaḥ vivakṣitaḥ samavāyi kāraṇeṣu guṇāḥ kāraṇa guṇāḥ te pūrvam kāraṇam yasya guṇasya asau kāraṇa guṇa
translated: But the reason because preceded by the qualities of the cause is not established, because it is accepted that sound arises from the qualities of the cause, such as conjunction and disjunction, from the point of view of others. Thus, the cause of sound is space and its qualities such as conjunction, and those qualities of the cause are the cause of this, so it is preceded by the qualities of the cause. This is not so, due to not knowing the intention. And this meaning is intended: The qualities in the inherent causes are the qualities of the cause. That quality which has the cause preceding it is preceded by the qualities of the cause. For example, the color of the cloth is preceded by the color of the thread. But sound is not like that, because space, being non-effect, does not have the qualities of the inherent cause.

original: atha svadṛṣṭyā kāraṇaguṇapūrvakatvam / tathā ca bherīśabdastadavayavaśabdapūrvakaḥ tathā śaṅkhaśabdaśceti / na / teṣāmanupalambhāt / tathā hi / śaṅkhaśabdakāle śaṅkhāvayavaśabdā nānubhūyanta iti / yathā paṭarūpānubhavakāle tanturūpāṇāmanubhava iti /
analyzed: atha sva dṛṣṭyā kāraṇa guṇa pūrvakatvam tathā ca bherī śabdaḥ tad avayava śabda pūrvakaḥ tathā śaṅkha śabdaḥ ca iti na teṣām anupalambhāt tathā hi śaṅkha śabda kāle śaṅkha avayava śabdāḥ na anubhūyante iti yathā paṭa rūpa anubhava kāle tantu rūpāṇām anubhavaḥ iti
translated: If it is argued that the effect has the quality of the cause as seen by oneself, then the sound of a drum would have the sound of its parts as its cause, and the sound of a conch would also be like that. No, because they are not perceived. For example, at the time of the sound of a conch, the sounds of the parts of the conch are not experienced, just as at the time of the experience of the form of a cloth, the forms of the threads are not experienced.

original: athābhibhūtatvādanupalambhaḥ / na / tadastitve pramāṇābhāvāt / tathā hi / tadavayavaśabdāścirotpannā evāvayavini śabdamārabhanta iti na pramāṇamasti / yadi vā avayavaśabdānāmavayaviśabdairabhibhūtatvād vidyamānānāmapyanupalambhaḥ / tadā tadabhāve sati tadupalambhaḥ syāt / rāsabhaśabdābhāve vīṇāśabdasyeva / yathā hi vādyamānāyāṃ vīṇāyāṃ rāsabhasannidhau vidyamānasyāpi vīṇāśabdasyābhibhavādanupalambhaḥ punarabhibhāvakābhāvādupalambho dṛṣṭo na caivamavayaviśabdānāmasti saṃvedanam /
analyzed: atha abhibhūta tvāt anupalambhaḥ na tad astitve pramāṇa abhāvāt tathā hi tad avayava śabdāḥ cira utpannāḥ eva avayavini śabdam ārabhante iti na pramāṇam asti yadi vā avayava śabdānām avayavi śabdaiḥ abhibhūta tvāt vidyamānānām api anupalambhaḥ tadā tad abhāve sati tad upalambhaḥ syāt rāsabha śabda abhāve vīṇā śabdasya iva yathā hi vādyamānāyām vīṇāyām rāsabha sannidhau vidyamānasya api vīṇā śabdasya abhibhavāt anupalambhaḥ punar abhibhāv
translated: If it is argued that the non-perception is due to being overwhelmed, it is not so. Because there is no evidence for its existence. For there is no evidence that the sounds of its parts only produce the sound of the whole when they have long arisen. If the non-perception of the existing sounds of the parts is due to being overwhelmed by the sounds of the whole, then there would be perception of it when that is absent, like the sound of the lute when the sound of the donkey is absent. For when a lute is being played, the sound of the lute, though existing, is not perceived due to being overwhelmed by the sound of the donkey, but is seen to be perceived again when the overpowerer is absent. But there is no such awareness of the sounds of the whole.

original: na ca kāraṇaguṇapūrvakeṣu kāraṇābhibhāvakatvaṃ dṛṣṭaṃ tathā śabdābhibhave 'pīti / api tu śabdasya tīvrasya grahaṇānmandasyāgrahaṇamiti / na cāvayaviśabdopalambhakāla evāvayavaśabdānāmagrahaṇaṃ pūrvamapyanupalambhāt / yāvaddravyabhāvitvañca kāraṇaguṇapūrvakāṇām /
analyzed: na ca kāraṇa guṇa pūrvakeṣu kāraṇa abhibhāvaka tvam dṛṣṭam tathā śabda abhibhave pi iti api tu śabdasya tīvrasya grahaṇāt mandasya agrahaṇam iti na ca avayavi śabda upalambha kāle eva avayava śabdānām agrahaṇam pūrvam api anupalambhāt yāvaddravyabhāvi tvam ca kāraṇa guṇa pūrvakāṇām
translated: And it is not seen that in things produced from the qualities of the cause, the cause is suppressed; so also in the case of the suppression of sound. Rather, it is because the loud sound is grasped and the faint one is not grasped. And at the time of the perception of the composite sound, the component sounds are not grasped, because they were not perceived before. And the existence of the effects of the cause is due to the qualities of the cause.

original: na ca satyakāryavādabalenāvayavāvayaviśabdānāṃ sadbhāve 'pi vyañjakābhāvādanupalambha iti vācyam / tanniṣedhasya vakṣyamāṇatvāt /
analyzed: na ca satya kārya vāda balena avayava avayavi śabdānām sadbhāve pi vyañjaka abhāvāt anupalambhaḥ iti vācyam tad niṣedhasya vakṣyamāṇatvāt
translated: And it should not be said that even when the existence of the component and composite sounds is established by the force of the doctrine of effects, they are not perceived due to the absence of manifesters. Because the refutation of that will be stated.

original: na cāvayavaśabdānāmavayaviśabdavailakṣaṇyādasamavāyitvaṃ vācyam / tasya hi samānajātīyeṣvatyantavijātīyeṣu ca darśanāt / yathā hi kāraṇagatād rūpācchuklatamāt kārye tathābhūtaṃ rūpam evaṃ rasādiṣvapīti / tathātyantavijātīyasyāsamavāyikāraṇatvaṃ I / yathā pracayākhyaḥ saṃyogaḥ saṃkhyā ca parimāṇotpattau / na caivaṃ śabdaḥ / tathā hi bherīśabde gambhīraḥ / tadavayavaśabdāśca tadvidharmāṇa ityevaṃ śaṅkhādiśabdeṣvapyūhyam /
analyzed: na ca avayava śabdānām avayavi śabda vailakṣaṇyāt asamavāyi tvam vācyam tasya hi samāna jātīyeṣu atyanta vijātīyeṣu ca darśanāt yathā hi kāraṇa gatāt rūpāt śuklatamāt kārye tathābhūtam rūpam evam rasa ādiṣu api iti tathā atyanta vijātīyasya asamavāyi kāraṇa tvam yathā pracaya ākhyaḥ saṃyogaḥ saṃkhyā ca parimāṇa utpattau na ca evam śabdaḥ tathā hi bherī śabde gambhīraḥ tad avayava śabdāḥ ca tad vidharmāṇaḥ iti evam śaṅkha ādi
translated: Nor can it be said that the words for parts are not inhering words because they differ from the word for the whole, since that is seen in things of the same class and in entirely different things. Just as the form in the effect is of the same nature as the form in the cause, so also with taste etc. Thus, inherence cause is of an entirely different kind.
