For example, conjunction called aggregation and number are the cause of the production of dimension. But sound is not so. For example, in the sound of a drum, it is deep. And the sounds of its parts have the same properties. Thus it should be inferred in the case of sounds from a conch etc.

original: na ca sarvasya sukhaduḥkhamohātmakatvāt sukhādidṛṣṭāntāt sādhyasādhanamiti mantavyam / pradhānavādapratiṣedhāt / sukhādīnāñcātmaguṇatvāt /
analyzed: na ca sarvasya sukha duḥkha moha ātmaka tvāt sukha ādi dṛṣṭāntāt sādhya sādhanam iti mantavyam pradhāna vāda pratiṣedhāt sukha ādīnām ca ātma guṇa tvāt
translated: And it should not be thought that the thesis is established by the example of pleasure etc., because everything has the nature of pleasure, pain and delusion, since the doctrine of pradhāna has been refuted, and because pleasure etc. are qualities of the self.

original: tathā na sparśavatāṃ guṇaḥ śabdaḥ / asmadādipratyakṣatve satyayāvaddravyabhāvitvāt / yo yo 'smadādipratyakṣatve satyayāvaddravyabhāvī sa sa sparśavatāṃ viśeṣaguṇo na bhavati / yathā sukhādiḥ / tathā cāyamasmadādipratyakṣatve satyayāvaddravyabhāvī / tasmānna sparśavatāṃ viśeṣaguṇa iti / ye ca sparśavatāṃ viśeṣaguṇāste 'smadādiprayakṣatve sati yāvaddravyabhāvinaḥ / yathā rūpādayaḥ / atrāpi pārthivaparamāṇurūpādivyavacchedārthamasmadādipratyakṣatve satīti padam / na ca saṃyogādibhirvyabhicāraḥ / pūrvoktanyāyāt / nāpi yāvaddravyabhāvitvaṃ śabdasya / rūpādivadapratīyamānatvāt /
analyzed: tathā na sparśavatām guṇaḥ śabdaḥ asmat ādi pratyakṣa tve satya yāvat dravya bhāvi tvāt yaḥ yaḥ smat ādi pratyakṣa tve satya yāvat dravya bhāvī sa sa sparśavatām viśeṣa guṇaḥ na bhavati yathā sukha ādiḥ tathā ca ayam asmat ādi pratyakṣa tve satya yāvat dravya bhāvī tasmāt na sparśavatām viśeṣa guṇaḥ iti  ye ca sparśavatām viśeṣa guṇāḥ te smat ādi prayakṣa tve sati yāvat dravya bhāvinaḥ yathā rūpa ādayaḥ atra api pārthiva paramā
translated: Similarly, sound is not a quality of tangible objects. Because it is perceptible to us and exists as long as the substance does. Whatever is perceptible to us and exists as long as the substance does, is not a specific quality of tangible objects, like pleasure etc. And sound is perceptible to us and exists as long as the substance does. Therefore, it is not a specific quality of tangible objects. And those specific qualities of tangible objects that exist as long as the substance does when perceptible to us, like color etc. Here also, the phrase when perceptible to us is used to exclude the color etc. of earth atoms. And there is no fallacy due to conjunction etc., because of the previously stated reasoning. Nor does sound exist as long as the substance does, because it is not cognized like color etc.

original: tathā āśrayādanyatropalabdheśca iti hetvantaram / ca samuccaye / na paraṃ pūrvoktābhyām / āśrayādanyatropalabdheśca na sparśavadviśeṣaguṇaḥ śabda iti / nanu śabdasya yathākāśamāśrayastasmādanyatropalabdhirasiddhā / tenaivopalambhāt / na parābhyupagamena bheryāderāśrayaśabdenābhidhānāt / tathā hi bherīśabdastadguṇo na bhavati / tato 'nyatropalabhyamānatvāt / yo yastato 'nyatropalabhyate sa sa tadguṇo na bhavati / yathā sukhādiḥ / yaśca tadguṇaḥ sa tatraivopalabhyate yathā rūpādiḥ / na ca tathā śabdaḥ / tasmāt tadguṇo na bhavatīti / na ca siddhametat / śabdasya tatraivopalambhāt / yathā hi bheryāṃ śabda iti pratibhāso dṛṣṭo rūpavat / na cānyathā bhavitumarhatīti /
analyzed: tathā āśrayāt anyatra upalabdheḥ ca iti hetu antaram ca samuccaye na param pūrva uktābhyām āśrayāt anyatra upalabdheḥ ca na sparśavat viśeṣa guṇaḥ śabdaḥ iti  nanu śabdasya yathā ākāśam āśrayaḥ tasmāt anyatra upalabdhiḥ asiddhā tena eva upalambhāt na para abhyupagamena bherī ādeḥ āśraya śabdena abhidhānāt tathā hi bherī śabdaḥ tad guṇaḥ na bhavati tatas nyatra upalabhyamāna tvāt yaḥ yaḥ tatas nyatra upalabhyate sa sa tad guṇaḥ na bhavati ya
translated: Similarly, because it is perceived elsewhere than in the substratum, is another reason. The word ca (and) is for the purpose of including. Not only by the previously mentioned two, but also because it is perceived elsewhere than in the substratum, sound is not a special quality like touch. But it is not established that sound is perceived elsewhere than in space, which is its substratum, because it is perceived by that [space] itself. Not by the acceptance of others, because the drum and so on are designated as the substratum by the word substratum. Indeed, the sound of the drum is not its quality, because it is perceived elsewhere than that. Whatever is perceived elsewhere than that is not its quality. Like happiness and so on. And whatever is its quality is perceived there itself. Like form and so on. And sound is not like that. Therefore, it is not its quality. And this is not established. Because sound is perceived there itself. Just as the appearance sound in the drum is seen to have form, and it cannot be otherwise.

original: na ca śrotrasya tatrāsannidhānam / āhaṅkārikatvena vyāpakasya tatra sadbhāvāt / nāpi sarvaśabdānāmupalabdhiprasaṅgo 'dṛṣṭavaśena niyatadeśa eva vṛtterātmalābhāditi / avyāpakasya vā taddeśaṃ yāvat parimāṇābhyupagamaḥ / yatra āśrayapratibhāsābhāvastatra śabdasyaiva svāśrayaparimāṇadvāreṇa śrotradeśamāgamanam /
analyzed: na ca śrotrasya tatra asannidhānam āhaṅkārika tvena vyāpakasya tatra sadbhāvāt  na api sarva śabdānām upalabdhi prasaṅgaḥ dṛṣṭa vaśena niyata deśe eva vṛtteḥ ātmalābhāt iti avyāpakasya vā tad deśam yāvat parimāṇa abhyupagamaḥ yatra āśraya pratibhāsa abhāvaḥ tatra śabdasya eva sva āśraya parimāṇa dvāreṇa śrotra deśam āgamanam
translated: And the ear is not absent there, because it pervades as a product of egoism and is present there. Nor is there the contingence of the apprehension of all sounds, because the sound arises and comes into existence only in a restricted place by the force of unseen merit. Or, if it is not pervasive, its size is accepted to be as much as the place. Where there is absence of the appearance of the substratum, there the sound itself comes to the place of the ear through the medium of the size of its own substratum.

original: tadetadasāmpratam / iha bheryā śabda iti pratibhāsasya santānānumānadvāreṇādhiṣṭhānadeśa eva pratibhāsāt /
analyzed: tat etat asāmpratam iha bheryā śabdaḥ iti pratibhāsasya santāna anumāna dvāreṇa adhiṣṭhāna deśe eva pratibhāsāt
translated: This is not correct. Here, in the cognition the sound is in the drum, the appearance is only in the substratum region through the inference of the continuum.

original: nanu cātra viśeṣahetorabhāvānniścayābhāva eva / kiṃ tatsthasyaiva śabdasyopalambhaḥ santānānumitasya veti / na tatsthasyaivopalambhaḥ / kvacidāśrayaviyuktasyāpi śrotradeśe pratibhāsāt / na caivaṃ sparśavatāṃ guṇāśca āśrayaviyuktā gṛhyanta iti nāsiddhatvaṃ hetoḥ /
analyzed: nanu ca atra viśeṣa hetoḥ abhāvāt niścaya abhāvaḥ eva kim tad sthasya eva śabdasya upalambhaḥ santāna anumitasya vā iti na tad sthasya eva upalambhaḥ kvacid āśraya viyuktasya api śrotra deśe pratibhāsāt  na ca evam sparśavatām guṇāḥ ca āśraya viyuktāḥ gṛhyante iti na asiddha tvam hetoḥ
translated: But here, due to the absence of a specific reason, there is indeed absence of certainty. Is it the apprehension of the sound located there, or the inferred continuum? It is not the apprehension of only what is located there, because sometimes what is separated from the substratum is also perceived in the region of the ear. And thus, the qualities of what has touch are not apprehended as separated from the substratum. Therefore, the reason is not unestablished.

original: atha sparśavadguṇatve 'pi gandhasyeva tadāśrayāgamanādupalambho bhaviṣyatīti cet / na / gandhasya sparśavadguṇatvaprasiddhāvāśrayāvicchedena ghrāṇādhiṣṭhānadeśa eva pratibhāsāt sūkṣmasya tadādhārasyāgamanaṃ yuktam / na caivaṃ śabdasya / tathā sūkṣmadravyādhārasya bherīśabdasyāgamanameva na yuktam / bheryā samavetasyotpādāt / na hyanyatra samavetamanyatra samavaitīti / samavetyavādena tvāgamane 'pi tadavayavaśabdā bherīśabdāśceti pratibhāsa eva prasaṅgaḥ / sūkṣmadravyasamavāyasyāviśeṣāt /
analyzed: atha sparśavat guṇa tve pi gandhasya iva tad āśraya āgamanāt upalambhaḥ bhaviṣyati iti ced na gandhasya sparśavat guṇa tva prasiddhau āśraya avicchedena ghrāṇa adhiṣṭhāna deśe eva pratibhāsāt sūkṣmasya tad ādhārasya āgamanam yuktam na ca evam śabdasya tathā sūkṣma dravya ādhārasya bherī śabdasya āgamanam eva na yuktam bheryā samavetasya utpādāt na hi anyatra samavetam anyatra samavaiti iti samavetya vādena tu āgamane pi tad avayava śabdāḥ bherī śabdā
translated: If it is argued that even if sound is a quality of something tangible, like smell, it will be perceived by coming to its substratum, that is not so. When the tangibility of smell is well-known, it is reasonable that the subtle substratum comes to the place occupied by the nose itself, because it appears there without interruption of the substratum. But this is not so for sound. Similarly, it is not reasonable for the sound of a drum, which is the substratum of a subtle substance, to come at all. Because it arises as inherent in the drum. For what is inherent in one thing does not become inherent in another. But even if it comes by the doctrine of inherence, there would be the contingence of the appearance of the sounds of its parts as drum sounds, because there is no difference in the inherence of a subtle substance.

original: tathā bherīdaṇḍābhidhātād bheryāmutpannaḥ śabdo nāgacchatyeva / āśrayasya tatrāvasthānāt / tadavayaveṣu ca sūkṣmeṣu ye jātāḥ śabdāstadāśrayasyāgamanādāgacchantītyabhyupagame bheryādigambhīradhvaneraśravaṇameva syāt / na cāhaṅkārikatvād vyāpakasya bheryādideśe vṛttirghaṭata iti mantavyam / pūrvamevāhaṅkārikatvapratiṣedhāt / na ca śrotreṇa bheryādideśagrahaṇaṃ sambhavatīti tadavacchedena śabdasya grahaṇābhāvaprasaṅgaḥ /
analyzed: tathā bherī daṇḍa abhidhātāt bheryām utpannaḥ śabdaḥ na āgacchati eva āśrayasya tatra avasthānāt tad avayaveṣu ca sūkṣmeṣu ye jātāḥ śabdāḥ tad āśrayasya āgamanāt āgacchanti iti abhyupagame bherī ādi gambhīra dhvaneḥ aśravaṇam eva syāt na ca āhaṅkārika tvāt vyāpakasya bherī ādi deśe vṛttiḥ ghaṭate iti mantavyam pūrvam eva āhaṅkārika tva pratiṣedhāt na ca śrotreṇa bherī ādi deśa grahaṇam sambhavati iti tad avacchedena śabdasya gr
translated: Similarly, the sound produced in the drum by the stroke of the drumstick does not come, because the substratum remains there. And the sounds produced in its subtle parts do not come, because their substratum does not come. If it is accepted that they come, then the deep sound of the drum etc. would not be heard at all. And it should not be thought that the all-pervading sound, being produced from ego, does not occur in the place of the drum etc. Because the production from ego has already been refuted earlier. And it is not possible for the ear to grasp the place of the drum etc., so there would be the undesirable consequence of the sound not being grasped by that.

original: atha prasiddhasamayasya śabdaśravaṇādāśrayānumāne sati ayaṃ bherīśabdaḥ ityavacchedena pratibhāsata iti cet / āyātastarhi madīyaṃ panthānam / katham / śabdaśravaṇāt santānadvāreṇāśrayānumitau iha bheryāṃ śabdaḥ iti pratibhāsābhyupagamāt /
analyzed: atha prasiddha samayasya śabda śravaṇāt āśraya anumāne sati ayam bherī śabdaḥ iti avacchedena pratibhāsate iti ced āyātaḥ tarhi madīyam panthānam katham śabda śravaṇāt santāna dvāreṇa āśraya anumitau iha bheryām śabdaḥ iti pratibhāsa abhyupagamāt
translated: If it is argued that when the substratum is inferred from hearing the sound according to the well-known convention, it appears as delimited by this is the sound of the drum, then my path has been reached. How? Because it is accepted that the sound appears as the sound is in this drum when the substratum is inferred through the series from hearing the sound.

original: tadevamāśrayādanyatropalabhyamānatvānna sparśavadviśeṣaguṇaḥ śabda iti siddham /
analyzed: tat evam āśrayāt anyatra upalabhyamāna tvāt na sparśavat viśeṣa guṇaḥ śabdaḥ iti siddham
translated: Thus, it is established that sound is not a specific quality like touch, because it is perceived elsewhere than in the substratum.

original: tathaikasminneva vādye vādyamāne bahūnāṃ ṣaḍjādīnāmupalambhānna tadguṇatvam / tathā hi / yadyātodyaguṇaḥ syācchabdaḥ kathaṃ bahūnāṃ śabdānāṃ samānendriyagrāhyāṇāmavibhuni dravye sadbhāvaḥ syāt / atha citrarūpavadetat syāt / na / tatraikarūpasyārambhāt / tathā hi / nānārūpāṇyekaṃ kāryamārabhanta ityuktam / na caivaṃ nānāśabdairekaḥ śabda ārabhyamāṇo dṛṣṭa iti / na cātra citrarūpavadekasmin kāle citraśabdapratibhāsaḥ sambhavati / krameṇa pratibhāsanāt / tathā rūpādivaccitrotpāde 'bhyupagate yugapadupalabdhiprasaṅgo na ca I / krameṇābhivyaktiḥ / sadbhāve pramāṇābhāvādityuktatvāt / saṃyogācca krameṇotpattyabhyupagame śabdasya na sparśavadviśeṣaguṇatvaṃ tadvaidharmyādityalamativistareṇa /
analyzed: tathā ekasmin eva vādye vādyamāne bahūnām ṣaḍja ādīnām upalambhāt na tad guṇa tvam tathā hi yadi ātodya guṇaḥ syāt śabdaḥ katham bahūnām śabdānām samāna indriya grāhyāṇām avibhuni dravye sadbhāvaḥ syāt  / atha citra rūpa vat etat syāt na tatra eka rūpasya ārambhāt tathā hi nānā rūpāṇi ekam kāryam ārabhante iti uktam na ca evam nānā śabdaiḥ ekaḥ śabdaḥ ārabhyamāṇaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ iti  na ca atra citra rūpa vat ekasmin kāle citra śabda
translated: Similarly, when a single musical instrument is played, many notes like ṣaḍja are perceived, so it cannot be a quality of that. For, if sound were a quality of the musical instrument, how could many sounds, which are apprehended by the same sense organ, exist in an all-pervading substance? If it were like a variegated color, no. Because a single form is produced there. For it has been said that various forms produce a single effect. And a single sound is not seen being produced by many different sounds in this way. And here, unlike a variegated color, a variegated sound-appearance does not occur at the same time, because it appears in sequence. Similarly, if a variegated [sound] were accepted to arise like form and so on, there would be the consequence of simultaneous perception, but there is not. It is manifestation in sequence. Because there is no evidence for existence, it has been said. And if arising in sequence is accepted due to conjunction, sound is not a specific quality like touch, because of its dissimilarity. Enough of this extensive discussion.

original: nanu cātra hetūpanyāsānantaraṃ pratijñopanyāsādavayavavyatyaye kiṃ prayojanam / śāstre nāyaṃ niyama ityupadarśanameva / tathā hi / avayavaviparyāsavacanamaprāptakālam nyā / sū / / / nāma nigrahasthānaṃ jalpa eva na śāstra ityupadarśayati / udāharaṇādyavayavalābhārthamityanye / tacceṣadvyatyayaṃ vināpyarthakathanādeva / tasyānekadhābhyupagāt /
analyzed: nanu ca atra hetu upanyāsa anantaram pratijñā upanyāsāt avayava vyatyaye kim prayojanam śāstre na ayam niyamaḥ iti upadarśanam eva tathā hi avayava viparyāsa vacanam aprāpta kālam nāma nigrahasthānam jalpaḥ eva na śāstre iti upadarśayati udāharaṇa ādi avayava lābha artham iti anye tat ca īṣat vyatyayam vinā api artha kathanāt eva tasya anekadhā abhyupagāt
translated: But here, after the statement of the reason, why is there a change in the order of the thesis? It is shown that this is not a rule in a treatise. Thus, the statement of the change in the parts is untimely. It shows that the statement of the change in the parts is untimely, that it is a ground for defeat only in debate, not in a treatise. Others say it is for the sake of obtaining the example and other parts. And that is possible even without the change of the remaining parts, just by stating the meaning. Because that is accepted in many ways.

original: nanvekenaiva pramāṇenārthasya paricchedādekasminnarthe 'nekahetūpanyāso vyartha eva / yad vā pramāṇāntaropanyāsānyathānupapattyā jñāyate na prāktanasyārthaparicchede sāmarthyam / apūrvārthaparicchedakatvaṃ vā / adhigatārthasyānuvādakatvāt / tathā hyadhigate 'pyarthe pramāṇāntarapravṛttāvaviśrāmaprasaṅgaḥ / tasmādanyo 'nyavyāvṛttaviṣayatvāt pramāṇānāmanekahetūpanyāso parijñānāyaiva / naitadevam / sarvatra vyavasthānabhyupagamāt / tathā hyekasminnevārthe 'nekopāyadarśanaṃ śāstre na doṣāya / tasya hi parānugrāhakatvāt / tathā vibhinnābhiprāyāḥ pratipādyā ityanekahetūpanyāsāt / kaścit kenacidalpaprayāsenaiva pratipadyata iti / na cātra kasyacidaprāmāṇyam sarveṣāmapi pramājanakatvāt /
analyzed: nanu ekena eva pramāṇena arthasya paricchedāt ekasmin arthe neka hetu upanyāsaḥ vyarthaḥ eva  / yat vā pramāṇa antara upanyāsa anyathā anupapattyā jñāyate na prāktanasya artha paricchede sāmarthyam apūrva artha paricchedaka tvam vā adhigata arthasya anuvādaka tvāt tathā hi adhigate pi arthe pramāṇa antara pravṛttau aviśrāma prasaṅgaḥ tasmāt anyaḥ parijñānāya eva  na etat evam sarvatra vyavasthā anabhyupagamāt tathā hi ekasmin eva arthe neka hetu upanyāsaḥ par
translated: But since the object is apprehended by a single means of knowledge, the statement of multiple reasons for a single object is pointless. Or, it is understood through the impossibility of explaining the statement of other means of knowledge that the previous one is not capable of apprehending the object, or of apprehending a new object, because it is a restatement of what has already been understood. For thus, even when the object has been understood, there would be the consequence of the means of knowledge not resting in the case of the operation of another means of knowledge. Therefore, because the objects of the means of knowledge are mutually exclusive, the statement of multiple reasons is for the sake of complete knowledge itself. This is not so, because the establishment of everything is accepted. For thus, in a single object, the observation of multiple means is not a fault in the scripture, because it is for the benefit of others. Similarly, the objects to be taught have different intentions, so the statement of multiple reasons is for the sake of some being understood by some with little effort. And here, none of them is invalid, because all of them generate valid knowledge.

original: na ca pramāṇaparamparāprasaṅgaḥ paricchinne 'pyarthe 'vaśyaṃ pramāṇāntaropanyāsānabhyupagamāt / tathā hi / yatra pramāṇāntarasadbhāvastatraiva tadapekṣā / na tadabhāve 'pīti / yathā śabdenāvagate 'numānenāpi bubhutsite / anumānenāpyadhigate pratyakṣeṇeti / tathā pratyakṣe 'pyekena karaṇenopalabdhe punaḥ karaṇāntareṇeti / tathaikasmin sukhasādhane 'rthe 'nekapramāṇapravṛttau sukhātiśayaśca prayojanamiti /
analyzed: na ca pramāṇa paramparā prasaṅgaḥ paricchinne pi arthe vaśyam pramāṇa antara upanyāsa anabhyupagamāt tathā hi yatra pramāṇa antara sadbhāvaḥ tatra eva tad apekṣā na tad abhāve pi iti  yathā śabdena avagate numānena api bubhutsite anumānena api adhigate pratyakṣeṇa iti tathā pratyakṣe pi ekena karaṇena upalabdhe punar karaṇa antareṇa iti  tathā ekasmin sukha sādhane rthe neka pramāṇa pravṛttau sukha atiśayaḥ ca prayojanam iti
translated: And there is no occasion for a succession of means of knowledge, because even in a well-defined object, the acceptance of the application of another means of knowledge is not admitted. For instance, where there is the existence of another means of knowledge, there alone is the dependence on it, not in its absence. For example, when something is understood by verbal testimony, it may be desired to be known by inference also. When it is understood by inference, it may be by perception. Similarly, in perception also, when something is perceived by one sense organ, it may be by another sense organ. Similarly, when many means of knowledge operate on an object that is a means to happiness, the purpose is the excess of happiness.

original: na cānadhigatārthagantṛtvaṃ pramāṇasāmānyalakṣaṇaṃ pratyabhijñānāderaprāmāṇyaprasaṅgāt / tathā hyadhigata evārthe pratyabhijñānamanumānañca pravartata iti vakṣyāmaḥ /
analyzed: na ca anadhigata artha gantṛ tvam pramāṇa sāmānya lakṣaṇam pratyabhijñāna ādeḥ aprāmāṇya prasaṅgāt tathā hi adhigate eva arthe pratyabhijñānam anumānam ca pravartate iti vakṣyāmaḥ
translated: And the definition of the general nature of a means of knowledge as that which leads to an unknown object cannot be applied to recognition, etc., because they are not means of knowledge. For thus, recognition and inference operate on an object that is already known. This we shall explain.

original: athaikadeśavṛttiviśeṣaguṇatvāt kṣaṇikaviśeṣaguṇatvācca sukhādivadātmaguṇo bhaviṣyatītyāha na bāhyendriyapratyakṣatvāt ityādi /
analyzed: atha eka deśa vṛtti viśeṣa guṇa tvāt kṣaṇika viśeṣa guṇa tvāt ca sukha ādi vat ātma guṇaḥ bhaviṣyati iti āha na bāhya indriya pratyakṣa tvāt ityādi
translated: Now, it may be argued that it will be a quality of the self like pleasure, etc., because it occurs in part of it and because it is a quality of a momentary particular. To this he says Because it is perceptible by an external sense organ, and so on.

original: atha prāktanānumānasya nirduṣṭatāyāmanumānāntarasyānutthānameva / na / ātmaguṇatve sati śabdasya śrotreṇāparicchedād / āśrayāsiddhatvamanumānayoḥ / tathā hi / śrotramātmā na bhavati / akartṛtvāt / nāpyantaḥkaraṇameva śrotram / tasya hi bahiḥkaraṇatvāt / abhyupagame vā yāvat sukhādyupalabdhistāvacchabdopalabdhyā bhavitavyamiti bādhiryaṃ na syāt /
analyzed: atha prāktana anumānasya nirduṣṭa tāyām anumāna antarasya anutthānam eva na ātma guṇa tve sati śabdasya śrotreṇa aparicchedāt āśraya asiddha tvam anumānayoḥ tathā hi śrotram ātmā na bhavati akartṛ tvāt na api antaḥkaraṇam eva śrotram tasya hi bahiḥkaraṇa tvāt abhyupagame vā yāvat sukha ādi upalabdhiḥ tāvat śabda upalabdhyā bhavitavyam iti bādhiryam na syāt
translated: If the previous inference is faultless, then another inference does not arise at all. No, because sound, being a quality of the self, is not apprehended by the ear. The two inferences have an unestablished basis. For the ear is not the self, because it is not an agent. Nor is the internal organ itself the ear, because it is an external organ. If accepted, then as long as pleasure etc. are apprehended, sound should be apprehended as well, so deafness would not occur.

original: atha śabdagrahaṇamantaḥkaraṇasyoparatavyāpārāt / evaṃ tarhi sukhādīnāmagrahaṇaṃ syāt / na ca karaṇaṃ cakṣurādyekatoparatavyāpāramanyatrārthaprakāśakaṃ dṛṣṭam / kṣityādivāyuparyantañca śrotraṃ na bhavatyeva ghrāṇādisampādane sāmarthyāvadhāraṇāt / dikkālayośca śrotrarūpatā na sambhavatyeva / bhautikatvād bāhyendriyāṇām / pāriśeṣyādanyacchrotram / tena cātmaguṇasya śabdasyāgrahaṇameva syādityāśrayāsiddhatvam / gṛhyate ca bāhyendriyeṇa śabdastasmādātmaguṇo na bhavatīti / tathā ca śabdaḥ / nātmaguṇaḥ / bāhyendriyapratyakṣatvāt / yo yo bāhyendriyapratyakṣaḥ sa sa ātmaguṇo na bhavati / yathā rūpādiḥ / tathā cāyaṃ bāhyendriyapratyakṣaḥ / tasmādātmaguṇo na bhavatīti / vaidharmyeṇa tu sukhādayaḥ / tataśca nātmaguṇaḥ śabdaḥ / ātmāntaragrāhyatvāt / rūpādivat / ātmaguṇāścātmāntaragrāhyā na bhavanti / yathā sukhādayaḥ /
analyzed: atha śabda grahaṇam antaḥkaraṇasya uparata vyāpārāt  evam tarhi sukha ādīnām agrahaṇam syāt  / na ca karaṇam cakṣuḥ ādi ekatā uparata vyāpāram anyatra artha prakāśakam dṛṣṭam kṣiti ādi vāyu paryantam ca śrotram na bhavati eva ghrāṇa ādi sampādane sāmarthya avadhāraṇāt diś kālayoḥ ca śrotra rūpa tā na sambhavati eva bhautika tvāt bāhya indriyāṇām pāriśeṣyāt anyat śrotram  / tena ca ātma guṇasya śabdasya agrahaṇam eva syāt iti āśray
translated: If, on the other hand, the apprehension of sound is due to the internal organ ceasing to function, then there would be no apprehension of pleasure, etc. And it is not seen that an organ like the eye, ceasing to function in one place, manifests an object elsewhere. And the auditory organ does not extend up to earth, etc. and air, because its capacity to produce the sense of smell, etc. is not determined. And the auditory organ cannot be in the form of space and time, because the external organs are material. By elimination, there must be another auditory organ. And by that, there would be no apprehension of sound, which is a quality of the self. Thus, the reason is unestablished. But sound is apprehended by an external organ. Therefore, it cannot be a quality of the self. And thus, sound is not a quality of the self, because it is perceptible by an external organ. Whatever is perceptible by an external organ is not a quality of the self, like form, etc. And this is perceptible by an external organ. Therefore, it is not a quality of the self. But pleasure, etc. are like the self in this respect.

original: nanu śabdasyātmāntaragrāhyatvaṃ vyaktyapekṣayā na sambhavatyeva / tathā hi yā śabdavyaktirekasmin śrotre samavetopajātā na sānyatreti / jātyapekṣayā tu sukhāderapyātmāntaragrāhyatvādityanekāntikatvam / naitadevam / yenātmanā kriyate śabdastasmādanyenāpi gṛhyate / na caivaṃ sukhādiriti / tathā hi / tīvratarābhighātādekā śabdavyaktirmahāntamākāśadeśaṃ vyāpyopajāyata ityanekairupalabhyata eva / na cāvyāpyavṛttitvena virodhaḥ svāśrayāvyāpakatvāt / na ca santānābhyupagamo virudhyate tīvratarādibhedabhinnānāṃ śabdānāmutpattyabhyupagamāt / tathā hyasti tīvratarābhighātādekā śabdavyaktirmahāntamākāśadeśaṃ kalpitaṃ vyāpyopajāyate tatastīvratara ityādikrameṇānubhavāt / tathā vyaktyapekṣāyāmātmāntaragrāhyatvaṃ na sambhavatīti bruvataḥ santānābhyupagamādapasiddhāntaprasaṅga iti /
analyzed: nanu śabdasya ātma antara grāhya tvam vyakti apekṣayā na sambhavati eva tathā hi yā śabda vyaktiḥ ekasmin śrotre samavetā upajātā na sā anyatra iti jāti apekṣayā tu sukha ādeḥ api ātma antara grāhya tvāt iti anekāntika tvam na etat evam yena ātmanā kriyate śabdaḥ tasmāt anyena api gṛhyate na ca evam sukha ādiḥ iti tathā hi tīvratara abhighātāt ekā śabda vyaktiḥ mahāntam ākāśa deśam vyāpya upajāyate iti anekaiḥ upalabhyate eva na ca avyāpya vṛtti tve
translated: But the apprehensibility by another self of sound is not possible in relation to the individual, because the individual sound that is produced in conjunction with one ear is not present in another. However, in relation to the universal, even pleasure etc. are apprehensible by another self, so the reason is inconclusive. This is not so. Sound is produced by one self, but is apprehended by another as well. But pleasure etc. are not like that. For instance, one sound-individual is produced by a very strong blow, pervading a large part of space, and is thus perceived by many. And there is no contradiction in its not pervading, because it is not all-pervading in its substratum. And the acceptance of a continuum is not contradicted, because the production of sounds distinguished by differences in intensity etc. is accepted. For instance, one sound-individual is produced by a very strong blow, pervading the imagined large part of space, and is thus experienced in the order of increasing intensity etc. Thus, in relation to the individual, the apprehensibility by another self is not contradicted.

original: na ca ito 'pyātmaguṇaḥ śabdaḥ / ātmanyasamavetatvāt / rūpādivat / ye cātmaguṇāste tatraiva samavetāḥ sukhādaya iti / athātmanyasamavetatvaṃ sādhyānna viśiṣyata ityāha ahaṅkāreṇa vibhaktagrahaṇācca iti / tathā hi / nātmani samavetaḥ śabdaḥ / ahaṅkāreṇa I / vibhaktagrahaṇād / rūpādivat / te cātmanimittaṃ vinā na pravartanta iti prayogadarśanādātmopakāritvaṃ nimittamiti kalpyate /
analyzed: na ca itas pi ātma guṇaḥ śabdaḥ ātmani asamaveta tvāt rūpa ādi vat ye ca ātma guṇāḥ te tatra eva samavetāḥ sukha ādayaḥ iti atha ātmani asamaveta tvam sādhyāt na viśiṣyate iti āha ahaṅkāreṇa vibhakta grahaṇāt ca iti tathā hi na ātmani samavetaḥ śabdaḥ ahaṅkāreṇa vibhakta grahaṇāt rūpa ādi vat te ca ātma nimittam vinā na pravartante iti prayoga darśanāt ātma upakāri tvam nimittam iti kalpyate
translated: And sound is not a quality of the self, because it is not inherent in the self, like color etc. And those qualities of the self are inherent in it, like pleasure etc. If it is argued that being not inherent in the self is not a distinguishing reason, he says and because it is grasped as distinct by egoism. For sound is not inherent in the self, because it is grasped as distinct by egoism, like color etc. And those are seen to operate without a cause in the self, so a cause in the form of being helpful to the self is imagined.

original: atha dikkālamanasāṃ guṇo bhaviṣyatīti tanniṣedhārthamāha śrotragrāhyatvāt ityādi / tathā ca śabdo na dikkālamanasāṃ guṇaḥ / śrotragrāhyatvāt / yad yacchrotragrāhyaṃ tattad dikkālamanasāṃ guṇo na bhavati / yathā śabdatvādi / tathā ca śabdaḥ śrotragrāhyaḥ / tasmād dikkālamanasāṃ guṇo na bhaviṣyatīti / ye tu tadguṇāste tu śrotragrāhyā na bhavanti yathā saṃkhyādaya iti / tathā ca dikkālamanovyatiriktasya śrotrasya pratipādanāt / tattadguṇatve tena grahaṇābhāvaprasaṅgaḥ / tathā hi / dikkālābhyāṃ na sambaddhamiti tatsamavetasya śabdasyāgrahaṇam /
analyzed: atha diś kāla manasām guṇaḥ bhaviṣyati iti tad niṣedha artham āha śrotra grāhya tvāt ityādi tathā ca śabdaḥ na diś kāla manasām guṇaḥ śrotra grāhya tvāt yat yat śrotra grāhyam tat tat diś kāla manasām guṇaḥ na bhavati yathā śabda tva ādi tathā ca śabdaḥ śrotra grāhyaḥ tasmāt diś kāla manasām guṇaḥ na bhaviṣyati iti ye tu tad guṇāḥ te tu śrotra grāhyāḥ na bhavanti yathā saṃkhyā ādayaḥ iti tathā ca diś kāla manaḥ vyatiriktasya
translated: Now, if it is argued that it will be a quality of space, time, and mind, to refute that, it is said that because it is perceptible by the ear, and so on. Thus, sound is not a quality of space, time, and mind. Because it is perceptible by the ear. Whatever is perceptible by the ear is not a quality of space, time, and mind, like soundness and so on. And sound is perceptible by the ear. Therefore, it will not be a quality of space, time, and mind. But those that are its qualities are not perceptible by the ear, like number and so on. And thus, because the ear is established as distinct from space, time, and mind, if it were a quality of those, it would follow that it would not be perceived by that. This is because it is not connected with space and time, so the sound inhering in that is not perceived.

original: manasaścāṇuparimāṇatvāt tadguṇatve gambhīradhvaneraśravaṇaprasaṅgaḥ / tadabhāve ca kvacit pradeśe śabdasyānutpattiḥ syāt / na ca kāryeṇaiva kāraṇasya tatra sadbhāvaḥ / kāryasyānyathāpi bhāvāt / nāpi vibhudravyaviśeṣaguṇānāṃ sukhādīnāmiva paramāṇuviśeṣaguṇānāmindriyeṇopalambho dṛṣṭaḥ / paramāṇuparimāṇañca manaḥ / tadevaṃ dikkālamanoguṇatve śabdasya śrotragrāhyatvaṃ na syāditi / bādhakañcedaṃ vaiśeṣikaguṇabhāvācca iti / tathā viśeṣaguṇa eva vaiśeṣikastasya bhāvāditi / tathā hi / dikkālamanasāṃ pakṣīkaraṇe vaiśeṣikaguṇābhāvo 'siddhaḥ syādasyaiva /sya ca viśeṣaguṇatvāditi vyatirekamukhenānyā heturvyākhyāyate / dikkālamanasāṃ vaiśeṣikaguṇābhāva ityukte śabdastu viśeṣaguṇa iti heturlabhyata eva / tathā ca śabdaḥ / dikkālamanasāṃ guṇo na bhavati / viśeṣaguṇatvāt / yo yo viśeṣaguṇaḥ sa sa dikkālamanasāṃ guṇo na bhavati / yathā rūpādiḥ / tathā cāyaṃ viśeṣaguṇaḥ / tasmānna dikkālamanasāṃ guṇaḥ śabda iti /
analyzed: manasaḥ ca aṇu parimāṇa tvāt tad guṇa tve gambhīra dhvaneḥ aśravaṇa prasaṅgaḥ tad abhāve ca kvacid pradeśe śabdasya anutpattiḥ syāt na ca kāryeṇa eva kāraṇasya tatra sadbhāvaḥ kāryasya anyathā api bhāvāt  na api vibhu dravya viśeṣa guṇānām sukha ādīnām iva paramāṇu viśeṣa guṇānām indriyeṇa upalambhaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ paramāṇu parimāṇam ca manaḥ  / tat evam diś kāla manaḥ guṇa tve śabdasya śrotra grāhya tvam na syāt iti bādhakam
translated: And because the mind has atomic dimensions, if sound were its quality, there would be the undesirable consequence of not hearing deep sounds. And in its absence, sound would not arise in some places. And the presence of the cause there is not by the effect itself, because the effect exists in another way. Nor is the apprehension of the qualities of specific pervasive substances like pleasure etc. seen to be by the sense organ, like the qualities of specific atoms. And the mind has atomic dimensions. Thus, if sound were a quality of space, time, or mind, it would not be perceptible by the ear. And this is a countering argument, because it is a quality of the Vaiśeṣika. And because it exists as a specific quality of that. It is like this. If space, time, and mind are made the subject, the absence of Vaiśeṣika qualities would not be established for this very [sound]. And because it is a specific quality, another reason is explained by the method of difference. When it is said that space, time, and mind have no Vaiśeṣika qualities, the reason that sound is a specific quality is obtained.

original: anye tu na dikkālamanasāṃ guṇaḥ śabda iti sādhye vaiśeṣikaguṇābhāvaḥ sādhyānna viśiṣyata iti manyamānāḥ hetvantaraṃ bruvate / tathā hi na dikkālamanasāṃ guṇaḥ śabdaḥ / guṇatvena guṇino liṅgatvāt / yo yo guṇatvena guṇino liṅgaḥ sa sa dikkālamanasāṃ guṇo na bhavati / yathā sukhādayaḥ / tathā cāyaṃ śabdo guṇatvena guṇino liṅgaḥ / tasmāt tadguṇo na bhavatīti / ye tu dikkālayorliṅgaṃ na te guṇatvena guṇino liṅgam / yathā pūrvāparādipratyayā yugapadādipratyayāśceti / te hi tadviśiṣṭatvāt tayorliṅgam / guṇatvena cātmanaḥ / I / tathā yugapadādiśabdāḥ pūrvāparādiśabdāśca yadyapi tadviśiṣṭhatvāt tayorliṅgaṃ tathāpi guṇatvenāśrayāntarānumāpakā ityalamativistareṇa /
analyzed: anye tu na diś kāla manasām guṇaḥ śabdaḥ iti sādhye vaiśeṣika guṇa abhāvaḥ sādhyāt na viśiṣyate iti manyamānāḥ hetu antaram bruvate tathā hi na diś kāla manasām guṇaḥ śabdaḥ guṇa tvena guṇinaḥ liṅga tvāt yaḥ yaḥ guṇa tvena guṇinaḥ liṅgaḥ sa sa diś kāla manasām guṇaḥ na bhavati yathā sukha ādayaḥ tathā ca ayam śabdaḥ guṇa tvena guṇinaḥ liṅgaḥ tasmāt tad guṇaḥ na bhavati iti  ye tu diś kālayoḥ liṅgam na te guṇ
translated: Others, however, thinking that the non-existence of the Vaiśeṣika qualities is not distinguished in the probandum when proving that sound is not a quality of space, time, or mind, state another reason. Thus, sound is not a quality of space, time, or mind, because it is the mark of the possessor as a quality. Whatever is the mark of the possessor as a quality does not become a quality of space, time, or mind, just as pleasure, etc. And sound is like that, being the mark of the possessor as a quality. Therefore, it is not its quality. But those that are the mark of space and time are not the mark of the possessor as a quality, just as the notions of east, west, etc., and the notions of simultaneity, etc. For they are the mark of those two because they are qualified by them, and as a quality of the self. Similarly, the words simultaneously, etc., and the words east, west, etc., are the mark of those two because they are qualified by them, but they are the inferrers of another substratum as a quality. Let us stop at this point with the extensive discussion.

original: manoguṇatve coktameva dūṣaṇamiti pariśeṣād guṇo bhūtvākāśasyādhigame paricchede kartavye liṅgamiti / pariśeṣastu prasaktapratiṣedhe 'nyatrāprasaṅgāt / tadevaṃ sādhanaṃ vyatirekāvyabhicāreṇaiva viṣayavyavasthāpanāyālam / tathā hi / śabdaḥ / pṛthivyudakajvalanapavanadikkālātmamanovyatiriktadravyāśrayaḥ / tadvṛttibādhakapramāṇasadbhāve sati guṇatvāt / yastu tadvyatiriktāśrayo na bhavati na cāsau tadvṛttibādhakapramāṇasadbhāve sati guṇaḥ / yathā rūpādiḥ / na ca tathā śabdaḥ / tasmāt tadvyatiriktadravyāśrayaḥ śabda iti siddhamākāśam / tat kimekam utānekamityāha śabdaliṅgāviśeṣādekatvaṃ siddham / śabdo hi liṅgamākāśasya aviśiṣṭatayā nānātvāpratipādakamiti /
analyzed: manaḥ guṇa tve ca uktam eva dūṣaṇam iti pariśeṣāt guṇaḥ bhūtvā ākāśasya adhigame paricchede kartavye liṅgam iti pariśeṣaḥ tu prasakta pratiṣedhe nyatra aprasaṅgāt tat evam sādhanam vyatireka avyabhicāreṇa eva viṣaya vyavasthāpanāya alam tathā hi śabdaḥ pṛthivī udaka jvalana pavana diś kāla ātma manaḥ vyatirikta dravya āśrayaḥ tad vṛtti bādhaka pramāṇa sadbhāve sati guṇa tvāt yaḥ tu tad vyatirikta āśrayaḥ na bhavati na ca asau tad v
translated: And if it were a quality of the mind, the previously stated fault would apply. Therefore, by elimination, it is a quality that becomes the means of knowing and defining space. But elimination is the exclusion of what is not possible elsewhere when what is possible is negated. Thus, the proof is sufficient to establish the object by the invariable concomitance of the vyatireka (negative concomitance). For example, sound is dependent on a substance other than earth, water, fire, air, space, time, self, and mind, because it is a quality, when there is an authoritative means of knowledge that contradicts its being a quality of those. But that which is not dependent on a substance other than those, and is not a quality of those when there is an authoritative means of knowledge that contradicts its being a quality of those, like form and so on, sound is not like that. Therefore, sound is dependent on a substance other than those. Thus, space is established. Is it one or many? He says: Singularity is established due to the non-distinction of sound as the mark. For sound is the mark of space, indicating it without distinction, not teaching multiplicity.

original: nanvasiddhamaviśiṣṭatvaṃ vicitratvācchabdānām / tathā hi / kāryavaicitryaṃ kāraṇavaicitryaṃ vinā na syāditi tīvrādibhedabhinnānāṃ śabdānāṃ vicitreṇaiva kāraṇena bhavitavyamiti nānātvasiddhistadāśrayasya / yadi ca kāraṇavaicitryaṃ vināpi kāryavaicitryamiṣyeta / paramāṇūnāmapi cāturvidhyaṃ na syāt / tatrāpyekasmādeva kāraṇād vicitraṃ kṣityādikāryaṃ bhaviṣyatīti / athātra /atha tatra kāryavaicitryeṇa kāraṇavaicitryānumānamiti cet / tacchabdavaicitrye 'pi samānamityalam /
analyzed: nanu asiddham aviśiṣṭa tvam vicitra tvāt śabdānām tathā hi kārya vaicitryam kāraṇa vaicitryam vinā na syāt iti tīvra ādi bheda bhinnānām śabdānām vicitreṇa eva kāraṇena bhavitavyam iti nānātva siddhiḥ tad āśrayasya yadi ca kāraṇa vaicitryam vinā api kārya vaicitryam iṣyeta paramāṇūnām api cāturvidhyam na syāt tatra api ekasmāt eva kāraṇāt vicitram kṣiti ādi kāryam bhaviṣyati iti atha atra atha tatra kārya vaicitryeṇa kāraṇa vaicitrya anumāna
translated: Is not the non-distinction of the cause unestablished, due to the variety of words? Thus, the variety of effects cannot be without the variety of causes. Therefore, the various words distinguished by intensity etc. must have a variegated cause itself. Thus, the establishment of plurality is based on that. And if the variety of effects is accepted even without the variety of causes, then even the fourfoldness of atoms would not be possible. There also, the variegated effect like earth etc. will result from a single cause. If it is argued that in this case the variety of causes is inferred from the variety of effects, then the same applies to the variety of words. Enough of this.

original: tadasat / sahakārivaicitryeṇāpi śabdavaicitryopalabdherna tadāśrayasya nānātvam / tathā ca tīvratamādabhighātāt tīvratamaḥ śabdo mandācca manda ityādi / na ca kṣityādāvapyevamastviti vācyam / tatra hi caturvidhaṃ kāryamitaretaravyāvṛttādupādānādutpadyamānaṃ dṛṣṭamiti tajjātīyāḥ paramāṇavaścaturvidhā eva pratīyante / kāryavaicitryantu sāmagrīvaicitryādeva / tatra kvacit kāraṇabhedaḥ / kvacit karmabhedo 'nyasya ceti yathāsambhavaṃ grāhyam / atra kāraṇabhedenāpi śabdavaicitryopapatterna samavāyikāraṇād bheda iti satyam / etacchabdaliṅgāviśiṣṭatvānnānātvāpratipādana /kamiti /
analyzed: tat asat sahakāri vaicitryeṇa api śabda vaicitrya upalabdheḥ na tad āśrayasya nānātvam tathā ca tīvratamāt abhighātāt tīvratamaḥ śabdaḥ mandāt ca mandaḥ ityādi na ca kṣiti ādau api evam astu iti vācyam tatra hi caturvidham kāryam itaretara vyāvṛttāt upādānāt utpadyamānam dṛṣṭam iti tad jātīyāḥ paramāṇavaḥ caturvidhāḥ eva pratīyante kārya vaicitryam tu sāmagrī vaicitryāt eva tatra kvacid kāraṇa bhedaḥ kvacid karma bhedaḥ nyasya ca iti yath
translated: That is not so. Even due to the variety of cooperating factors, the variety of sound is observed, so its substratum is not manifold. And thus, from the strongest impact, the sound is strongest, and from the weakest, the weakest, and so on. And it cannot be said that this should be so even in the case of earth etc. For there, the four kinds of effect are seen to arise from the material cause, which is mutually exclusive, so the atoms of that class are understood to be of four kinds only. But the variety of effects is due to the variety of the assemblage itself. There, in some cases, there is a difference in the cause, in some cases, a difference in the action, and in some cases, of another. This should be understood as appropriate. Here, it is true that the variety of sound is possible even due to the difference in the cause, so there is no difference from the inherent cause. This is because the non-establishment of plurality is due to the absence of the specific mark of sound.

original: atha nānātvāprasiddhāvapyekatvaṃ pramāṇaṃ vinā na sidhyatītyabhidheyaṃ pramāṇamiti cet / na / dravyatvādeva saṃkhyāsadbhāvasiddhau nānātve pramāṇābhāvādekatvameva sidhyatīti / tathā saṃkhyānantaraṃ parimāṇamavasaraprāptaṃ parityajya kramātikrameṇa pṛthaktvanirūpaṇaṃ kasmāI /dityāha tadanuvidhānāt / tenaikatvenānuvidhānaṃ sāhacaryam / yatra hyekatvaṃ tatrāvaśyamekapṛthaktvamiti / na tvevaṃ parimāṇe 'pi tadanuvidhānamastyeva / tathā hi / yatraikatvaṃ tatrāvaśyamekapṛthaktvaṃ bhavatīti viśeṣānuvidhānam / na caivaṃ yatraikatvaṃ tatrāvaśyamaṇutvaṃ sthūlatvaṃ veti viśeṣānuvidhānamastīti pūrvaṃ pṛthaktvaṃ nirūpyate /
analyzed: atha nānātva aprasiddhau api ekatvam pramāṇam vinā na sidhyati iti abhidheyam pramāṇam iti ced na dravya tvāt eva saṃkhyā sadbhāva siddhau nānātve pramāṇa abhāvāt ekatvam eva sidhyati iti tathā saṃkhyā anantaram parimāṇam avasara prāptam parityajya krama atikrameṇa pṛthaktva nirūpaṇam tad anuvidhānāt tena ekatvena anuvidhānam sāhacaryam yatra hi ekatvam tatra avaśyam eka pṛthaktvam iti na tu evam parimāṇe tad anuvidhānam asti eva tathā hi yatra ekatvam tatra
translated: Now, if it is argued that even if plurality is not established, oneness cannot be established without a means of knowledge, and therefore number is the means of knowledge, it is not so. When the existence of number is established by substance itself, oneness is established due to the absence of a means of knowledge for plurality. Thus, after number, dimension, which has come to the occasion, is abandoned, and disjunction is defined in violation of the sequence, why is it asked? Because it is subordinate to that. Subordination is association, for where there is oneness, there is necessarily one disjunction. But in this way, there is no subordination to dimension. Thus, where there is oneness, there is necessarily one disjunction, this is subordination to the particular. And in this way, where there is oneness, there is necessarily atomicity or grossness, there is no subordination to the particular. Thus, disjunction is defined first.

original: tathā paramamahatparimāṇamākāśe kutaḥ pramāṇādityāha vibhavavacanāt iti / vibhavānmahānākāśastathā cātmā / tadabhāvādaṇu manaḥ vai / sū / / / iti sūtre darśayati / vibhavāt kāraṇād mahānākāśa iti sāmānyaśabdenāsya arthāt paramamahattvaṃ vivakṣitam / tathā hi vibhuno dravyasya paramamahattvaṃ siddhamātmādāviti ihāpi tathā sādhyate / ākāśam / paramamahad / vibhutvād / ātmavaditi / sarveṣāñcāvibhūnāṃ pakṣīkaraṇe kevalavyatirekānumānam / ākāśādīnāmātmaparyantānāṃ paramamahattvaṃ vibhutvād ityukte yeṣāntu paramamahattvaṃ nāsti na teṣāṃ vibhutvamiti vyatirekaḥ /
analyzed: tathā parama mahat parimāṇam ākāśe kutas pramāṇāt iti āha vibhava vacanāt iti vibhavāt mahān ākāśaḥ tathā ca ātmā tad abhāvāt aṇu manaḥ vai iti sūtre darśayati vibhavāt kāraṇāt mahān ākāśaḥ iti sāmānya śabdena asya arthāt parama mahā tvam vivakṣitam tathā hi vibhunaḥ dravyasya parama mahat tvam siddham ātma ādau iti iha api tathā sādhyate ākāśam parama mahat vibhu tvāt ātma vat iti sarveṣām ca avibhūnām pakṣīkaraṇe kevala vyatireka anum
translated: Similarly, how is the highest magnitude of space known? He says: from the statement of abundance. From abundance, space is great, and so is the self. From the absence of that, the mind is small. The aphorism shows: From abundance, the cause, space is great. By the general term, its highest magnitude is implied. For thus, the highest magnitude of an all-pervading substance is established in the self and so on. Here also, it is proved thus: Space is of highest magnitude. Because it is all-pervading. Like the self. And when all non-pervading things are made the subject, it is an inference of mere negative concomitance. When it is said that space and so on up to the self have highest magnitude because of being all-pervading, the negative concomitance is: those that do not have highest magnitude are not all-pervading.

original: atha kimidaṃ vibhutvam / sarvairbhūtaiḥ saṃyoga iti / anye tu sarvatropajātānāṃ śabdānāmākāśe samavāyastatsadbhāve 'pūrṇodrekatā vibhutvamiti manyante / yad vā aṇuparimāṇānadhikaraṇatve sati nityadravyatvāt paramamahattvamiti sādhyate / tathā śabdakāraṇavacanāt saṃyogavibhāgāviti saṃyogād vibhāgācchabdācca śabdaniṣpattiḥ vai / sū / / / iti sūtraṃ darśayati / tathā hi / saṃyogavibhāgau śabdotpatterasamavāyikāraṇamityabhidhānādākāśe samavāyo labhyate / anyathā hi pratyāsatterabhāvādasamavāyikāraṇatvaṃ na syāt / na cānyadasamavāyikāraṇamastīti / yata evaṃ guṇavadākāśamato guṇavattvādanāśritatvācca dravyaṃ paramāṇuvaditi / tathā hi / paramāṇorguṇavattvamanāśritatvañca dṛṣṭaṃ dravyatvañcāsti / adravye caitanna sambhavatīti /
analyzed: atha kim idam vibhu tvam sarvaiḥ bhūtaiḥ saṃyogaḥ iti anye tu sarvatra upajātānām śabdānām ākāśe samavāyaḥ tad sadbhāve pūrṇa udrekatā vibhu tvam iti manyante yat vā aṇu parimāṇa anadhikaraṇa tve sati nitya dravya tvāt parama mahat tvam iti sādhyate tathā śabda kāraṇa vacanāt saṃyoga vibhāgau iti saṃyogāt vibhāgāt śabdāt ca śabda niṣpattiḥ vai iti sūtram darśayati tathā hi saṃyoga vibhāgau śabda utpatteḥ asamavāyi kāraṇam iti abhidhānā
translated: Now, what is this omnipresence? The connection with all existing things. But others think that omnipresence is the inherence of all produced sounds in space, with full intensity when it exists. Or it is proved that it has supreme greatness, because it is a permanent substance not having atomic dimension. Thus, it shows the aphorism Sound arises from conjunction and disjunction, because it is mentioned as the cause of sound. For thus, conjunction and disjunction are the non-inherent cause of sound production, so inherence in space is obtained from this statement. Otherwise, there would be no non-inherent cause due to the absence of proximity. And there is no other non-inherent cause. Since space is thus a substance having qualities, it is a substance like an atom, because it has qualities and is not dependent. For thus, the atom is seen to have qualities and to be independent, and it is a substance.

original: atha kimākāśaṃ nityam utānityamityāha samānāsamānajātīyakāraṇābhāvācca nityam / tathā hi / na samānajātīyaṃ samavāyikāraṇam / ākāśasyaikatvāt / nāpyasamānajātīyamasamavāyikāraṇamasti / samānajātīyābhāvena tatsaṃyogasyāpyabhāvāt / na ca samavāyyasamavāyikāraṇaṃ vinā vastubhūtasya kāryasyotpattiḥ sambhavatītyakāryatvānnityatvaṃ siddhamākāśasya / ataśca sarvaprāṇināṃ śabdopalabdhau nimittam kāraṇam / ākāśasyaikatve 'pyanekārthakriyākāritvaṃ darśayati / na ca sattāmātreṇākāśaṃ śabdopalabdheḥ I / kāraṇam / sarvatra sarvaprāṇināmaviśeṣeṇa śabdopalabdhiprasaṅgaḥ / sarvaśabdānāmākāśe samavāyāviśeṣādata āha śrotrabhāvena śrotratveneti /
analyzed: atha kim ākāśam nityam uta anityam iti āha samāna asamāna jātīya kāraṇa abhāvāt ca nityam tathā hi na samāna jātīyam samavāyi kāraṇam ākāśasya ekatvāt na api asamāna jātīyam asamavāyi kāraṇam asti samāna jātīya abhāvena tad saṃyogasya api abhāvāt na ca samavāyi asamavāyi kāraṇam vinā vastu bhūtasya kāryasya utpattiḥ sambhavati iti akārya tvāt nitya tvam siddham ākāśasya  / atas ca sarva prāṇinām śabda upalabdhau nimittam kāraṇam ākāśasya eka
translated: Now, is Ākāśa eternal or non-eternal? It is eternal, because there is no cause either homogeneous or heterogeneous. For instance, there is no homogeneous cause, because Ākāśa is one only. Nor is there any heterogeneous cause, in the shape of the non-homogeneous Inherence; because there is absence of the homogeneous cause, there is absence of the Conjunction also. And without the homogeneous and heterogeneous causes, the production of an entity in the shape of the effect is not possible. Hence, on account of its not being an effect, Ākāśa is eternal. And for this reason, it is the cause, the means, of the perception of sound by all living beings. Even though Ākāśa is one only, it shows the character of doing many things. And Ākāśa is not the cause of the perception of sound by mere existence; because if it were so, then there would be the incongruity of the perception of sound everywhere, by all living beings, without any distinction. And because there is no distinction in the Inherence of all sounds in Ākāśa, therefore it is said that it is the cause of the perception of sound by becoming the Auditory Organ.

original: kiṃ tacchrotramityāha śrotraṃ punaḥ śravaṇavivarasaṃjako nabhodeśaḥ iti / śrūyate 'neneti śravaṇam / tacca tadvivarañceti tathoktam / śravaṇavivaramiti saṃjñā yasya nabhodeśasyāsau śravaṇavivarasaṃjñakaḥ karṇaśaṣkulīsaṃyogopalakṣita ākāśa iti / tathā śabdanimittopabhogaprāpakadharmādharmopanibaddhaḥ iti / śabdo nimittaṃ yasyāsau tathoktaḥ / sa cāsāvupabhogaśca taṃ prāpyata iti tatprāpako ca tau dharmādhamau tābhyāmupanibaddhaḥ sahakṛta iti /
analyzed: kim tat śrotram iti āha śrotram punar śravaṇa vivara saṃjakaḥ nabhaḥ deśaḥ iti śrūyate nena iti śravaṇam tat ca tat vivaram ca iti tathā uktam śravaṇa vivaram iti saṃjñā yasya nabhaḥ deśasya asau śravaṇa vivara saṃjñakaḥ karṇa śaṣkulī saṃyoga upalakṣitaḥ ākāśaḥ iti tathā śabda nimitta upabhoga prāpaka dharma adharma upanibaddhaḥ iti śabdaḥ nimittam yasya asau tathā uktaḥ sa ca asau upabhogaḥ ca tam prāpyate iti tad prāpakau ca tau dharm
translated: What is that ear? It is said: The ear is the space element located in the cavity of the ear. It is called the cavity of the ear because sound is heard through it. The space element that is designated as the cavity of the ear is the space characterized by the conjunction with the ear-drum. Similarly, it is connected with merit and demerit that bring about the experience of sound. It is said to be the cause of sound because it is the cause of sound. It is that which brings about the experience of sound. It is connected with merit and demerit, which means it is produced together with them.

original: nanvevamapi karṇaśaṣkulyākāśasaṃyogopalakṣitaviśiṣṭādṛṣṭopagṛhīto nabhodeśastasmādarthāntaraṃ na bhavatīti sarvaśabdopalabdhiḥ syāt / naitadevam / karṇaśaṣkulīsaṃyogopalakṣitasya nabhasaḥ śrotratve tasyāpyavyāpyavṛttitayā na sarveṣāṃ grahaṇam / yadyapi karṇaśaṣkulīsaṃyogaikārthasamavāyitvācchabdānāṃ tathāpi viśiṣṭapratyāsatterabhāvādagrahaṇam / yo hi karṇaśaṣkulīsaṃyogasya sānnidhyabhāk śabdaḥ sa evopalabhyate / na caivaṃ sarvaśabdāsteṣāmavyāpyavṛttitvāt /
analyzed: nanu evam api karṇa śaṣkulī ākāśa saṃyoga upalakṣita viśiṣṭa adṛṣṭa upagṛhītaḥ nabhaḥ deśaḥ tasmāt artha antaram na bhavati iti sarva śabda upalabdhiḥ syāt na etat evam karṇa śaṣkulī saṃyoga upalakṣitasya nabhasaḥ śrotra tve tasya api avyāpya vṛtti tayā na sarveṣām grahaṇam yadi api karṇa śaṣkulī saṃyoga eka artha samavāyi tvāt śabdānām tathā api viśiṣṭa pratyāsatteḥ abhāvāt agrahaṇam yaḥ hi karṇa śaṣkulī saṃyo
translated: Even so, the space enclosed by the cavity of the ear, characterized by the contact with the cavity of the ear, and accompanied by the unseen force, is not different from that space, so there would be perception of all sounds. This is not so. When the space characterized by the contact with the cavity of the ear is the auditory organ, since that also does not pervade all, it does not grasp all. Even though the sounds are in the same substratum as the contact with the cavity of the ear, still they are not grasped due to the absence of a specific proximity. Only that sound which is present in the vicinity of the contact with the cavity of the ear is perceived. And it is not so for all sounds, because they do not pervade.

original: na ca karṇaśaṣkulīsaṃyogāvaruddhanabhodeśavyatiriktadeśe sarveṣāmutpādanādagrahaṇameveti vācyam / śabdopalambhānyathānupapattyā santānanyāyena śrotradeśamāgatasya pratipādyamānatvādityalam /
analyzed: na ca karṇa śaṣkulī saṃyoga avaruddha nabhaḥ deśa vyatirikta deśe sarveṣām utpādanāt agrahaṇam eva iti vācyam śabda upalambha anyathā anupapattyā santāna nyāyena śrotra deśam āgatasya pratipādyamāna tvāt iti alam
translated: And it cannot be said that they are not grasped because they are produced in a space other than the space enclosed by the contact with the cavity of the ear, due to the impossibility of perceiving the sound in any other way, because they are conveyed to the auditory organ by the principle of continuity. Thus far.

original: atha kasmād badhirāṇāṃ karṇaśaṣkulīsaṃyogāvaruddhanabhodeśasadbhāve 'pi śabdāgrahaṇam / sahakāryabhāvādityāha tasya ca nityatve satyupabhoganibandhakaḥ ityādi śabdopalabdhau sahakāriṇo 'dṛṣṭasyābhāvācchabdopalabdhirna bhavatīti bādhiryamupapadyata iti /
analyzed: atha kasmāt badhirāṇām karṇa śaṣkulī saṃyoga avaruddha nabhaḥ deśa sadbhāve pi śabda agrahaṇam sahakāri abhāvāt iti āha tasya ca nitya tve sati upabhoga nibandhakaḥ ityādi śabda upalabdhau sahakāriṇaḥ dṛṣṭasya abhāvāt śabda upalabdhiḥ na bhavati iti bādhiryam upapadyate iti
translated: Now, why is there no perception of sound for the deaf, even when the space enclosed by the union of the ear and eardrum exists? He says it is due to the absence of a co-operating factor. When that [co-operating factor] is eternal, it is the cause of experience. Because there is no unseen co-operating factor in the perception of sound, there is no perception of sound. Thus deafness is logically possible.

original: kālaḥ parāparavyatikarayaugapadyāyaugapadyacirakṣiprapratyayaliṅgaḥ / teṣāṃ viṣayeṣu pūrvapratyayavilakṣaṇānāmutpattāvanyanimittābhāvād yadatra nimittaṃ sa kālaḥ / sarvakāryāṇāñcotpattisthitivināśahetustadvyapadeśāt / kṣaṇalavanimeṣakāṣṭhākalāmuhūrtayāmāhorātrārdhamāsamāsartvayanaI /saṃvatsarayugakalpamanvantarapralayamahāpralayavyavahārahetuḥ / tasya guṇāḥ saṃkhyāparimāṇapṛthaktvasaṃyogavibhāgāḥ /PDhS
analyzed: kālaḥ para apara vyatikara yaugapadya ayaugapadya cira kṣipra pratyaya liṅgaḥ teṣām viṣayeṣu pūrva pratyaya vilakṣaṇānām utpattau anya nimitta abhāvāt yat atra nimittam sa kālaḥ sarva kāryāṇām ca utpatti sthiti vināśa hetuḥ tad vyapadeśāt        tasya guṇāḥ saṃkhyā parimāṇa pṛthaktva saṃyoga vibhāgāḥ
translated: Time is the cause of the notions of distant and near, simultaneity and non-simultaneity, long and short, and is indicated by the notions of past, present and future. When these notions arise with regard to objects in a way different from previous notions, there is no other cause for them. Therefore, what is the cause here is time. And it is the cause of the origination, persistence and destruction of all effects, as indicated by that [notion of time]. It is the cause of the conventions of moment, second, minute, muhūrta, kalā, muhūrta, yāma, day and night, fortnight, month, season, half-year, year, yuga, kalpa, Manu-period, and great dissolution. Its qualities are number, dimension, separateness, conjunction and disjunction.

original: kālaliṅgāviśeṣādekatvaṃ siddham / tadanuvidhānāt pṛthaktvam / kāraṇe kāla iti vacanāt paramamahat parimāṇam / kāraṇaparatvāditi vacanāt saṃyogaḥ / tadvināśakatvād vibhāga iti / tasyākāśavaddravyatvanityatve siddhe / kālaliṅgāviśeṣādañjasaikatve 'pi sarvakāryāṇāmārambhakriyābhinirvṛttisthitinirodhopādhibhedān maṇivat pācakavad vā nānātvopacāra iti /PDhS
analyzed: kāla liṅga aviśeṣāt eka tvam siddham tad anuvidhānāt pṛthaktvam kāraṇe kālaḥ iti vacanāt parama mahat parimāṇam kāraṇa paratvāt iti vacanāt saṃyogaḥ tad vināśaka tvāt vibhāgaḥ iti tasya ākāśa vat dravya tva nitya tve siddhe kāla liṅga aviśeṣāt añjasā eka tve sarva kāryāṇām ārambha kriyā abhinirvṛtti sthiti nirodha upādhi bhedāt maṇi vat pācaka vat vā nānātva upacāraḥ iti pdhs
translated: The oneness is established due to the non-distinction of the mark of time. The separateness is due to its control. The highest magnitude is due to the statement that time is the cause. The conjunction is due to the statement that it is the cause of the highest. The disjunction is due to its being the destroyer of that. When its substantiality and eternality like space are established, although the oneness is effortless due to the non-distinction of the mark of time, the figurative usage of plurality like a jewel or a cook is due to the differences of the limiting adjuncts of the commencement, completion, continuance, and cessation of all effects.

original: idānīmuddeśavataḥ kālasya lakṣaṇaparīkṣārthaṃ kālaḥ parāparavyatikarayaugapadyāyaugapadyacirakṣiprapratyayaliṅgaḥ ityādi prakaraṇam /
analyzed: idānīm uddeśavataḥ kālasya lakṣaṇa parīkṣā artham kālaḥ para apara vyatikara yaugapadya ayaugapadya cira kṣipra pratyaya liṅgaḥ ityādi prakaraṇam
translated: Now, for the purpose of examining the definition of time, which is the subject of the section, the section beginning with Time is the mark of the notions of far and near, simultaneity and non-simultaneity, long and short, is presented.

original: atra ca kālasadbhāvapratipādakameva liṅgamitarasmād bhedakaṃ bhavatīti manyamāno lakṣaṇāntaraṃ nāvocat / tathā hi kālaḥ / itarasmād bhidyate / parāparavyatikarayaugapadyāyaugapadyacirakṣiprapratyayaliṅgatvāt / yastu na bhidyate na cāsāvuktaliṅgaḥ / yathā kṣityādiḥ / na ca tathā kālaḥ / tasmād bhidyata iti / vyavahāro vā sādhyate / vivādagocaratāpannaṃ dravyaṃ kāla iti vyavahartavyaṃ parāparavyatikarādiliṅgatvāditi /
analyzed: atra ca kāla sadbhāva pratipādakam eva liṅgam itarasmāt bhedakam bhavati iti manyamānaḥ lakṣaṇa antaram na avocat tathā hi kālaḥ itarasmāt bhidyate para apara vyatikara yaugapadya ayaugapadya cira kṣipra pratyaya liṅga tvāt yaḥ tu na bhidyate na ca asau ukta liṅgaḥ yathā kṣiti ādiḥ na ca tathā kālaḥ tasmāt bhidyate iti vyavahāraḥ vā sādhyate vivāda gocara tā āpannam dravyam kālaḥ iti vyavahartavyam para apara vyatikara ādi liṅga tvāt iti
translated: And here, thinking that the very reason establishing the existence of time is what distinguishes it from the other, he did not state another definition. For thus, time is distinguished from the other, because it is the reason for the notions of remote and proximate, simultaneity and non-simultaneity, long and short, etc. But that which is not distinguished is not the reason stated. Like earth, etc. And time is not like that. Therefore, it is distinguished. Or the usage is proved. The substance that has become the subject of dispute should be used as time, because it is the reason for the notions of remote and proximate, etc.

original: atha pratibandhānupalabdheḥ kathametāni kālasadbhāve liṅgaṃ bhavanti / viśiṣṭakāryatayā / viśiṣṭaṃ kāryaṃ viśiṣṭāt kāraṇādutpadyamānaṃ dṛṣṭam / parāparavyatikarayaugapadyāyagapadyacirakṣiprapratyayāśca viśiṣṭaṃ kāryamiti viśiṣṭakāraṇapūrvakatvaṃ sādhyate / tathā ca parāparayordikkṛtayorvyatikaro viparyayo gṛhyate / yatra hi digvivakṣayotpannaṃ paratvaṃ tatraivāparatvam yatraivāparatvaṃ tatraiva paratvamutpadyamānaṃ dṛṣṭamityarthāntarañca / vyavahartṛnimittād vyatirekaḥ sambhavatīti / tathā cādhamajātīye digvivakṣayā parasmin sthavirapiṇḍe balīpalitādisānnidhyamapekṣamāṇasyotkṛṣṭajātīyaṃ yuvānamavadhiṃ kṛtvetarasmāt paro viprakṛṣṭo 'yamiti buddhirbhavati / tāmapekṣya pareṇa kālapradeśena yogāt paratvamiti / sthavirañcāvadhiṃ kṛtvotkṛṣṭajātīye yūni paradigbhāgavyavasthite 'pi rūḍhaśmaśrukārkaśyaI /mapekṣyamānasya sannikṛṣṭā buddhirutpadyate / tāmapekṣyāpareṇa kālapradeśena yogādaparatvasyotpattir iti /
analyzed: atha pratibandha anupalabdheḥ katham etāni kāla sadbhāve liṅgam bhavanti viśiṣṭa kāryatayā viśiṣṭam kāryam viśiṣṭāt kāraṇāt utpadyamānam dṛṣṭam para apara vyatikara yaugapadya ayagapadya cira kṣipra pratyayāḥ ca viśiṣṭam kāryam iti viśiṣṭa kāraṇa pūrvakatvam sādhyate tathā ca para aparayoḥ diś kṛtayoḥ vyatikaraḥ viparyayaḥ gṛhyate yatra hi diś vivakṣayā utpannam paratvam tatra eva aparatvam yatra eva aparatvam tatra eva paratvam ut
translated: Now, since the relation is not perceived, how can these be the inferential marks for the existence of time? By the nature of the specific effect. A specific effect is seen to arise from a specific cause. And the notions of far and near, simultaneous and non-simultaneous, long and short time are specific effects. Therefore, the antecedence of a specific cause is established. And thus, the mutual exclusion of far and near, which is based on direction, is grasped. For where farness arises with reference to direction, there nearness is seen to arise. And this is a different thing. Exclusion is possible from the cause of the user. And thus, with reference to direction in a lower class, in an old lump of sugar, depending on the presence of wrinkles, grey hair, etc., taking a young man of a higher class as the limit, the notion arises that this is far from the other, being distinguished by a distant superior region. In dependence on that, there is the connection of the far with time.

original: atra diksampāditaparatvavailakṣaṇyānna tadeva nimittam / nāpi nikṛṣṭajātīyatayā jātikṛtaṃ paratvaṃ sambhavati / na ca kṣityāderanyatamaṃ nimittaṃ sāmarthyānavadhāraṇāt / yastu śiṣyate sa kāla iti /
analyzed: atra diś sampādita paratva vailakṣaṇyāt na tat eva nimittam na api nikṛṣṭa jātīya tayā jāti kṛtam paratvam sambhavati na ca kṣiti ādeḥ anyatamam nimittam sāmarthya anavadhāraṇāt yaḥ tu śiṣyate sa kālaḥ iti
translated: Here, because of the difference from the distance produced by direction, that itself is not the cause. Nor is the distance produced by the class possible due to belonging to a lower class. And among earth etc., no cause is determined due to the indeterminacy of capability. But what remains is time.

original: nanvekasminneva dine pākajotpattinyāyena piṇḍayoḥ samutpādāt kathaṃ paratvāparatvam / utpatteḥ prabhṛtyādityaparivartanāpekṣayā / tathā hi janmanaḥ prabhṛtyekasyādityaparivartanāni bhūyāṃsīti paratvam / anyasya cālpīyāṃsītyaparatvam /
analyzed: nanu ekasmin eva dine pāka ja utpatti nyāyena piṇḍayoḥ samutpādāt katham paratva aparatvam utpatteḥ prabhṛti āditya parivartana apekṣayā tathā hi janmanaḥ prabhṛti ekasya āditya parivartanāni bhūyāṃsi iti paratvam anyasya ca alpīyāṃsi iti aparatvam
translated: But in the same day, how can there be distance and nearness of the two lumps due to the production of the cooked effect according to the principle of production? It is in relation to the revolution of the sun from the beginning of production. Thus, from birth, one has more revolutions of the sun, so it is distant. And the other has fewer, so it is near.

original: athādityaparivartanamevāstu / kiṃ kāleneti cet / na / yugapadādipratyayānumeyatvāt / na cādityaparivartanādeva yugapadādipratyayāḥ sambhavantīti / ekasminnevādityaparivartane sarveṣāmanutpādād vyapadeśābhāvācca / tathā hi yugapatkāla iti vyapadeśo na yugapadādityaparivartanamiti /
analyzed: atha āditya parivartanam eva astu kim kālena iti ced na yugapad ādi pratyaya anumeya tvāt  na ca āditya parivartanāt eva yugapad ādi pratyayāḥ sambhavanti iti ekasmin eva āditya parivartane sarveṣām anutpādāt vyapadeśa abhāvāt ca tathā hi yugapad kālaḥ iti vyapadeśaḥ na yugapad āditya parivartanam iti
translated: If it be said that let there be the revolution of the sun itself, what is the use of time? No, because it is to be inferred from the notions of simultaneity, etc. And the notions of simultaneity, etc. do not arise from the revolution of the sun alone, because all [actions] do not arise from the revolution of the sun alone, and because there is no designation [of time]. For thus there is the designation of time as simultaneous, not as the revolution of the simultaneous sun.

original: na ca kriyaiva kāla iti vācyam / yugapadādipratyayābhāvaprasaṅgāt / tathā hi / kriyāyāḥ kriyārūpatayā viśeṣābhyupagamāditi pratyayābhāvaḥ / parāparavyatikarābhāvaśca / na ca kriyā kāla iti pratīyate / yadi ca kartṛkarmavyatiriktā viśiṣṭapratyayasampādikā kriyā syāt saṃjñābhedamātram / avyatireke tu viśiṣṭapratyayābhāva evetyalaṃ vistareṇa /
analyzed: na ca kriyā eva kālaḥ iti vācyam yugapad ādi pratyaya abhāva prasaṅgāt tathā hi kriyāyāḥ kriyā rūpa tayā viśeṣa abhyupagamāt iti pratyaya abhāvaḥ para apara vyatikara abhāvaḥ ca na ca kriyā kālaḥ iti pratīyate yadi ca kartṛ karma vyatiriktā viśiṣṭa pratyaya sampādikā kriyā syāt saṃjñā bheda mātram avyatireke tu viśiṣṭa pratyaya abhāvaḥ eva iti alam vistareṇa
translated: And it cannot be said that time is action itself, because the notions of simultaneity, etc. would not exist. For thus, because action is accepted as a particular in the form of action, there is no notion [of simultaneity, etc.]. And there would be no distinction between the prior and the posterior. And action is not perceived as time. And if action were to produce a particular notion apart from the agent and the object, it would be merely a difference in name. But in the absence of difference, there would be no particular notion at all. Enough of this digression.

original: tathā yugapadbhāvo yaugapadyam / bahūnāṃ kartṝṇāṃ kāryakaraṇe bahūnāṃ kāryāṇāmātmalābha iti / tathā hi yugapadete kurvantīti kartrālambanaṃ jñānam / yugapadetāni kṛtānīti kāryālambanañca dṛṣṭam / na cātra kartṛmātraṃ kāryamātrañcālambanamatiprasaṅgāt / tathā hi yatra krameṇa kāryaṃ tatrāpi kartṛkarmaṇoḥ sadbhāvāt / syādetad vijñānam / na ca katarasmād viśiṣṭaṃ kartāraṃ kāryaṃ vālambyotpadyate vijñānametaditi jñāyate / yacca tadviśeṣaṇaṃ kṣityādivilakṣaṇaṃ sa kāla iti na yaugapadyāyaugapadyakrama iti / ayugapadete kurvantīti kartrālambanaṃ jñānam / ayugapadetāni kṛtānīti kāryālambanaṃ jñānam / atrāpi viśiṣṭayoḥ kartṛkarmaṇorālambanatvāt kṣityādivilakṣaṇaṃ nimittaṃ vācyamiti kālasiddhiḥ /
analyzed: tathā yugapad bhāvaḥ yaugapadyam bahūnām kartṝṇām kārya karaṇe bahūnām kāryāṇām ātmalābhaḥ iti  / tathā hi yugapad ete kurvanti iti kartṛ ālambanam jñānam yugapad etāni kṛtāni iti kārya ālambanam ca dṛṣṭam na ca atra kartṛ mātram kārya mātram ca ālambanam atiprasaṅgāt tathā hi yatra krameṇa kāryam tatra api kartṛ karmaṇoḥ sadbhāvāt syāt etat vijñānam na ca katarasmāt viśiṣṭam kartāram kāryam vā ālambya utpadyate vijñānam etat it
translated: Similarly, the simultaneous existence of many is yaugapadyam. In the performance of many agents, the attainment of many effects occurs simultaneously. For instance, it is seen that the cognition with reference to the agent is They are performing simultaneously, and the cognition with reference to the effect is These have been produced simultaneously. And here, the reference is not merely to the agent or merely to the effect, because that would lead to an absurdity. For instance, even where the effect occurs sequentially, the agent and object are present there too. It may be said that this is consciousness, and it is not known that consciousness arises with reference to a distinguished agent or effect, thinking This is consciousness. And that which is the distinguishing factor, different from earth etc., is time. Thus, sequence is not due to simultaneity or non-simultaneity. The cognition with reference to the agent is They are performing non-simultaneously, and the cognition with reference to the effect is These have been produced non-simultaneously. Even here, since the reference is to the distinguished agent and object, a cause different from earth etc. must be stated, thus establishing time.

original: tathaika eva kartā kiñcit kāryaṃ cireṇa karoti vyāsaṅgād anarthitvād vā kiñcit kṣipraṃ tadarthitayā / tatra cireṇa kṛtaṃ kṣipraṃ kṛtamiti pratyayo vilakṣaṇatvād vilakṣaṇaṃ kāraṇamākṣipatīti / na ca kāryameva nimittaṃ tasyobhayatra samānatvāt / nāpi kartaiva / tasyāpi sādhāraṇatvāt / na ca nirnimittaṃ kadācid bhavatītyato vilakṣaṇena nimittena bhavitavyamityata āha teṣām yugapadādipratyayānām / viṣayeṣu kartṛṣu kāryeṣu / kiṃviśiṣṭānām / pūrvapratyayavilakṣaṇānām pūrvapratyayāḥ kartṛkāryeṣu tatpratyayāḥ / tadvilakṣaṇānām / utpattāvanyasya kṣityādirūpasya nimittasyāsambhavād yannimittaṃ sa kāla iti /
analyzed: tathā ekaḥ eva kartā kiñcid kāryam cireṇa karoti vyāsaṅgāt anarthi tvāt vā kiñcid kṣipram tad arthi tayā tatra cireṇa kṛtam kṣipram kṛtam iti pratyayaḥ vilakṣaṇa tvāt vilakṣaṇam kāraṇam ākṣipati iti na ca kāryam eva nimittam tasya ubhayatra samāna tvāt na api kartā eva tasya api sādhāraṇa tvāt na ca nirnimittam kadācid bhavati iti atas vilakṣaṇena nimittena bhavitavyam iti atas āha teṣām yugapad ādi pratyayānām viṣayeṣu kartṛṣu kārye
translated: Similarly, a single agent may perform an action slowly due to being engaged in something else or due to lack of desire, or quickly due to desire for it. There, the notion of done slowly and done quickly implies a different cause due to being different. And the effect cannot be the cause, because it is the same in both cases. Nor can the agent alone be the cause, because that is also common to both. And something cannot occur without a cause. Therefore, there must be a different cause. Hence he says: Of those notions of simultaneity, etc., regarding objects, agents, and effects, what are the specific features? They are different from previous notions. Previous notions are about agents and effects. They are different from those. Since the origination of something else, such as earth, etc., is impossible, that which is the cause is time.

original: atha kālasyaikarūpatayā vilakṣaṇapratyayānāmabhāvaprasaṅga eva / atha kriyāvailakṣaṇyād vilakṣaṇaḥ kālastadvaiśiṣṭyācca pratyayavaiśiṣṭyamiti cet / evaṃ tarhi duruttaramitaretarāśrayatvam / tathā hi kriyāyāḥ kriyārūpatayā viśeṣābhāvāt kathaṃ kālaviśeṣakatvam / atha yugapat kriyāviśeṣito yugapat kālastadviśeṣitā ca yugapat kriyetītaretarāśrayatvameva /
analyzed: atha kālasya eka rūpa tayā vilakṣaṇa pratyayānām abhāva prasaṅgaḥ eva atha kriyā vailakṣaṇyāt vilakṣaṇaḥ kālaḥ tad vaiśiṣṭyāt ca pratyaya vaiśiṣṭyam iti ced evam tarhi duruttaram itaretara āśraya tvam tathā hi kriyāyāḥ kriyā rūpa tayā viśeṣa abhāvāt katham kāla viśeṣaka tvam atha yugapad kriyā viśeṣitaḥ yugapad kālaḥ tad viśeṣitā ca yugapad kriyā iti itaretara āśraya tvam eva
translated: If, on the other hand, time is of one form, then it follows that there can be no different cognitions. If it be said that time is different because of the difference in the form of the action, and the difference in the cognitions is due to the difference in time, then, in that case, the mutual dependence is insuperable. For instance, how can time be the differentiator of the particular time, when the action is not different in the form of the action? If it be said that the simultaneous time is qualified by the simultaneous action, and the simultaneous action is qualified by the simultaneous time, then there is only mutual dependence.

original: naitadevam / nirvikalpikāyāṃ saṃvidi parasparavyāvṛttakriyāsvarūpāvagame sati tadviśiṣṭaḥ kālastasmācca yugapadādipratyayā ityupagamāt / nirvikalpakācca savikalpotpattiriṣyate / yad vā svarūpeṇaiva kriyāyā viśiṣṭatvam / tatsahakārī kālo yugapadādipratyayasampādaka iti / na cātra viśeṣaṇaṃ kālaḥ / kiṃ tarhi / viśiṣṭakāryotpattau viśiṣṭena nimittena bhavitavyamiti /
analyzed: na etat evam nirvikalpikāyām saṃvidi paraspara vyāvṛtta kriyā svarūpa avagame sati tad viśiṣṭaḥ kālaḥ tasmāt ca yugapad ādi pratyayāḥ iti upagamāt nirvikalpakāt ca sa vikalpa utpattiḥ iṣyate yat vā sva rūpeṇa eva kriyāyāḥ viśiṣṭa tvam tad sahakārī kālaḥ yugapad ādi pratyaya sampādakaḥ iti na ca atra viśeṣaṇam kālaḥ kim tarhi viśiṣṭa kārya utpattau viśiṣṭena nimittena bhavitavyam iti
translated: This is not so. When the mutually exclusive forms of action are cognized in indeterminate cognition, time is distinguished by that, and from that, the notions of simultaneity etc. arise, because it is accepted. And indeterminate cognition is accepted to give rise to determinate cognition. Or, the action itself is distinguished by its own form. Time, which is its contributory factor, is the producer of the notions of simultaneity etc. And here time is not the qualifier. What then? In the production of a qualified effect, there must be a qualified cause.

original: anye tu viśeṣaṇatvena gṛhītasya vyāpāra ityanumānādervyāpārānupalabdheḥ / pramāṇañca vinā asambhavāditi kālasya pratyakṣatāṃ bruvate / tathā hi viśeṣyajñānānyathānupapattyā viśeṣaṇe jñānaṃ kalpyate / tacca pramāṇāntaravyāpārānupalabdheḥ pratyakṣameva /
analyzed: anye tu viśeṣaṇa tvena gṛhītasya vyāpāraḥ iti anumāna ādeḥ vyāpāra anupalabdheḥ pramāṇam ca vinā asambhavāt iti kālasya pratyakṣa tām bruvate tathā hi viśeṣya jñāna anyathā anupapattyā viśeṣaṇe jñānam kalpyate tat ca pramāṇa antara vyāpāra anupalabdheḥ pratyakṣam eva
translated: Others, however, say that time is directly perceived, because the operation of what is grasped as a qualifier is inferred, and because it is impossible without a means of knowledge. Thus, the knowledge of the qualifier is imagined due to the impossibility of the knowledge of the qualified in any other way. And that is direct perception itself, because the operation of another means of knowledge is not perceived.

original: nanu sarveṣāmeva kārakāṇāṃ viśeṣyajñānotpattau vyāpāraviśeṣe 'pyekameva viśeṣaṇaṃ nānyaditi viśeṣaheturnāstīti / na / svālambanajñānasahitasya viśeṣyajñānotpattāvekasyaiva vyāpārāt / ayamevānurāgaḥ / svānuraktapratyayajanakañca viśeṣaṇaṃ nākārārpakam / nāpi svaśabdābhilapyajñānajanakam / asambhavāt / na hi svākārārpakatvaṃ viśeṣaṇasya / I /
analyzed: nanu sarveṣām eva kārakāṇām viśeṣya jñāna utpattau vyāpāra viśeṣe pi ekam eva viśeṣaṇam na anyat iti viśeṣa hetuḥ na asti iti na sva ālambana jñāna sahitasya viśeṣya jñāna utpattau ekasya eva vyāpārāt ayam eva anurāgaḥ sva anurakta pratyaya janakam ca viśeṣaṇam na ākāra arpakam na api sva śabda abhilapya jñāna janakam asambhavāt na hi sva ākāra arpaka tvam viśeṣaṇasya
translated: But there is no special reason why only one qualifier should be responsible for the production of the cognition of the qualified, even though all the other factors have their specific functions. No, because only one [factor] is responsible for the production of the cognition of the qualified along with the cognition of its own object. This is indeed the attachment. And the qualifier produces a cognition that is attached to itself, but it does not impart its form, nor does it produce a cognition that is denoted by its own word, because that is impossible. For it is not the case that the qualifier imparts its own form,

original: ākāravādapratiṣedhāt / nāpi viśeṣaṇaśabdābhilapyaṃ viśeṣye jñānaṃ sambhavati / puruṣe daṇḍa iti jñānānutpatteḥ /
analyzed: ākāra vāda pratiṣedhāt na api viśeṣaṇa śabda abhilapyam viśeṣye jñānam sambhavati puruṣe daṇḍaḥ iti jñāna anutpatteḥ
translated: because the theory of form has been refuted. Nor is it possible for the cognition of the qualified to be denoted by the word 'qualifier', because the cognition 'a stick in a man' does not arise.

original: atha daṇḍasyātiśayādhāyakatvānupapatterviśeṣaṇatvābhāva iti cet / na / viśiṣṭajñānajanakatvenāsyaivātiśayatvāt / tajjñānañcātiśayaḥ / tatsadbhāve kāryasadbhāvāt /
analyzed: atha daṇḍasya atiśaya ādhāyaka tva anupapatteḥ viśeṣaṇa tva abhāvaḥ iti ced na viśiṣṭa jñāna janaka tvena asya eva atiśaya tvāt tad jñānam ca atiśayaḥ tad sadbhāve kārya sadbhāvāt
translated: If it is argued that the qualifier is not so because it cannot impart superiority to itself, it is not so, because it is only the producer of the cognition of the qualified that is superior, and that cognition is the superiority, because the effect exists when it exists.

original: atha viśeṣaṇaviśeṣyayorvibhinnajñānālambanatve na pramāṇamastīti cet / tathā hi / viśeṣyajñānamutpatteḥ pūrvaṃ viśeṣaṇasya na tadrūpatāṃ darśayati na krameṇa pramāṇamiti / na ca vibhinnajñānālambanatvaṃ viśeṣaṇaviśeṣyabhāvena vyāptam / nāpi viśeṣaṇaviśeṣyabhāvaḥ krameṇetyubhayathāpi vyabhicārāt / tathā hi liṅgaliṅginorvibhinnajñānālambanatve 'pi na viśeṣyaviśeṣaṇabhāva iti vyabhicāraḥ / na ca krame sādhye viśeṣaṇaviśeṣyabhāvo hetuḥ / sādhāraṇatvāt tasya sapakṣavipakṣābhyāṃ vyāvṛtteriti / tathāpi bhinnajñānālambanatve viśeṣaṇaviśeṣyayoranumeyapratipatteḥ pratyayalakṣaṇatvaṃ syāt / tathā hi / anumānād gṛhītaṃ viśeṣaṇamindriyārthasannikarṣeṇa saha vyāpārāt pratyakṣasāmagryāmantarbhūtamiti tajjanitā pratipattiragnimāneṣa deśa iti pratyakṣaphalā syāt /
analyzed: atha viśeṣaṇa viśeṣyayoḥ vibhinna jñāna ālambana tve na pramāṇam asti iti ced tathā hi viśeṣya jñānam utpatteḥ pūrvam viśeṣaṇasya na tad rūpa tām darśayati na krameṇa pramāṇam iti  na ca vibhinna jñāna ālambana tvam viśeṣaṇa viśeṣya bhāvena vyāptam na api viśeṣaṇa viśeṣya bhāvaḥ krameṇa iti ubhayathā api vyabhicārāt tathā hi liṅga liṅginoḥ vibhinna jñāna ālambana tve pi na viśeṣya viśeṣaṇa bhāvaḥ iti vyabhicāraḥ na c
translated: If it is argued that there is no proof for the object of cognition of the qualifier and the qualified being different, it is not so. Thus, the cognition of the qualified does not show the form of the qualifier before its production, nor does it in succession. And the being the object of different cognitions is not pervaded by the relation of qualifier and qualified, nor is the relation of qualifier and qualified by succession. Because there is deviation in both ways. Thus, even though the mark and the marked are the objects of different cognitions, there is no relation of qualifier and qualified, so there is deviation. And when succession is to be proved, the relation of qualifier and qualified is not the reason, because it is common to both the similar and dissimilar instances. Even so, if the qualifier and the qualified are the objects of different cognitions, the apprehension of the inferable object would be the characteristic of the cognition. Thus, the qualifier grasped by inference, along with the operation of the contact of sense object, is included in the totality of perception, so it is produced by that.

original: na cāgnernirādhārasya pūrvamanumānaṃ sambhavati / tathāgnirapyanumīyamāno 'gnitvaviśiṣṭaḥ pratīyata iti pūrvamagnitvagrahaṇam / tatrāpyagnirviśeṣaṇamityanyonyāśrayatvam / athāgnau samavāyo 'gnitvasya viśleṣaṇam / tatrāpyagnitvamagnirvā viśeṣaṇamiti tadeva dūṣaṇamaviśiṣṭasya sarvatra sadbhāvād viśeṣakatvānupapattiḥ / atha parvato 'gnerviśeṣaṇam / tatrāpi parvatatvaṃ tatra ca samavāyo viśeṣaṇamiti pūrvavad dūṣaṇam / athāgnisaṃyogaḥ parvatasyāgneśca viśeṣaṇam / tasyāpi saṃyoginau tayorapi saṃyoga iti pūrvadoṣaprasaṅgaḥ / tasmādanumānaṃ pramāṇīkurvatā viśeṣaṇaviśeṣyālambanamekaṃ vijñānamabhyupeyam / ekañca dhūmaviśiṣṭasya parvatasyopalambhādagniviśiṣṭe pratipattirbhavati /
analyzed: na ca agneḥ nirādhārasya pūrvam anumānam sambhavati tathā agniḥ api anumīyamānaḥ gni tva viśiṣṭaḥ pratīyate iti pūrvam agni tva grahaṇam tatra api agniḥ viśeṣaṇam iti anyonya āśraya tvam atha agnau samavāyaḥ gni tvasya viśleṣaṇam tatra api agni tvam agniḥ vā viśeṣaṇam iti tat eva dūṣaṇam aviśiṣṭasya sarvatra sadbhāvāt viśeṣaka tva anupapattiḥ atha parvataḥ gneḥ viśeṣaṇam tatra api parvata tvam tatra ca samavāyaḥ viśeṣaṇam it
translated: And inference of fire without a substratum is not possible before [the perception of smoke]. Similarly, when fire is inferred, it is cognized as qualified by fireness, so there must be prior apprehension of fireness. There also, if fire is the qualifier, there is mutual dependence. If the inherence of fireness in fire is the analysis, then there also fireness or fire is the qualifier, so the same fault remains. Since it is present everywhere without distinction, it cannot be a qualifier. If the mountain is the qualifier of fire, then there also mountainness and inherence there are the qualifiers, so the fault remains as before. If the conjunction of fire with the mountain is the qualifier of both fire and the mountain, then that also has two conjoined objects, and they also have conjunction, so the previous fault arises.
