Therefore, one who accepts inference must accept a single cognition with an object qualified by a qualifier. And since there is the perception of a mountain qualified by smoke, there is cognition of a mountain qualified by fire.

original: athaikajñānālambanayoraṅgulyorivaikajñānālambanapakṣe kathaṃ viśeṣaṇaviśeṣyabhāvaḥ / pradhānopasarjanabhāvena / sa eva kasmāditi cet / vibhinnajñānālambanatve 'pi samānam / tathā hi / idaṃ viśeṣaṇamidaṃ viśeṣyamiti vibhinnajñānālambanatvāviśeṣe kathaṃ niyamaḥ / pradhānopasarjanabhāvāditi cet / iṣṭam / tadekajñānālambanatve 'pīti doṣābhāvāt /
analyzed: atha eka jñāna ālambanayoḥ aṅgulyoḥ iva eka jñāna ālambana pakṣe katham viśeṣaṇa viśeṣya bhāvaḥ pradhāna upasarjana bhāvena saḥ eva kasmāt iti ced vibhinna jñāna ālambana tve samānam tathā hi idam viśeṣaṇam idam viśeṣyam iti vibhinna jñāna ālambana tva aviśeṣe katham niyamaḥ pradhāna upasarjana bhāvāt iti ced iṣṭam tat eka jñāna ālambana tve pi iti doṣa abhāvāt
translated: Now, if the two fingers are the object of one cognition, like the two fingers, how is there the relation of qualifier and qualified? By the relation of principal and secondary. If it be asked why this is so, the same question arises even if they are the objects of different cognitions. For thus, even if there is no difference in being the objects of different cognitions, how is there a restriction? If it be said that it is by the relation of principal and secondary, that is accepted. Even if they are the objects of one cognition, there is no fault.

original: arthaikaścāryaṃ viśeṣaṇaviśeṣyabhāvo na dharmapadārthāntargataḥ / tattadvyatirekapratiṣedhāt / nāpi dravyādipadārthāntargataḥ / ṣaṭsūpalambhāditi / na hi dravyādīnāmanyatamaḥ ṣaṭsūpalabhyata iti /
analyzed: artha ekaḥ ca āryam viśeṣaṇa viśeṣya bhāvaḥ na dharma padārtha antargataḥ tad tad vyatireka pratiṣedhāt na api dravya ādi padārtha antargataḥ ṣaṭsu upalambhāt iti na hi dravya ādīnām anyatamaḥ ṣaṭsu upalabhyate iti
translated: And the relation of qualifier and qualified is not included among the categories of substance, quality, etc., because it is excluded from each of them. Nor is it included among the categories of substance, etc., because it is not perceived in the six. For none of the categories such as substance is perceived in the six.

original: atha viśiṣṭapratyayaheturadṛṣṭo viśeṣaṇaviśeṣyabhāva iti cet / tasya caikatāyāmidaṃ viśeṣaṇamidaṃ viśeṣyamiti vyavasthānupapattiḥ / viśeṣaṇaviśeṣyatvasyaikatvāditi / tathā hi yadeva viśeṣaṇatvaṃ tadeva viśeṣyatvamityekasya puruṣasyaikasminneva kāle tadeva viśeṣaṇaṃ viśeṣyañceti syāt / na caitadasti / tasmād viśiṣṭādṛṣṭo na viśeṣaṇaviśeṣyabhāvaḥ / atha naiko dṛṣṭo viśeṣaṇaviśeṣyapratiniyataḥ / tathāpi viśeṣaṇaviśeṣyayorbhāvo na syāt /
analyzed: atha viśiṣṭa pratyaya hetuḥ adṛṣṭaḥ viśeṣaṇa viśeṣya bhāvaḥ iti ced tasya ca ekatāyām idam viśeṣaṇam idam viśeṣyam iti vyavasthā anupapattiḥ viśeṣaṇa viśeṣya tvasya ekatvāt iti tathā hi yat eva viśeṣaṇa tvam tat eva viśeṣya tvam iti ekasya puruṣasya ekasmin eva kāle tat eva viśeṣaṇam viśeṣyam ca iti syāt na ca etat asti tasmāt viśiṣṭa adṛṣṭaḥ na viśeṣaṇa viśeṣya bhāvaḥ atha na ekaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ viśeṣaṇa v
translated: If it is argued that the unseen relation of qualifier and qualified is the cause of the distinct cognition, and that in the case of unity, the determination of this is that this is the qualifier and this is the qualified is not possible, because the relation of qualifier and qualified is one, then it is like this - that very qualification is the same as the qualified. For one person, at the same time, that very thing would be both the qualifier and the qualified. But this is not so. Therefore, the relation of qualifier and qualified is not seen in the qualified. If it is argued that the single, distinct, determined relation of qualifier and qualified is not seen, then even so, there would be no relation of qualifier and qualified.

original: ato yathāsambhavaṃ viśeṣaṇaviśeṣyabhāvo grāhyaḥ / kvacit saṃyogaḥ / kvacit samavāya iti / tathā cābhāve 'pi viśeṣacakṣurādisambandha eva viśeṣaṇaviśeṣyabhāvaḥ / tena satā ca viśiṣṭapratyayajananāt / na cādṛṣṭasyātra kāraṇatvaṃ niṣidhyate / sakalakāryeṣu sādhāraṇatvāt / nāpyadṛṣṭo dṛṣṭakāraṇaṃ pratyācaṣṭe / śarīrāderapyabhāvaprasaṅgāt / tathā hi sukhādisampādako 'dṛṣṭa evāstvalaṃ śarīrādiparikalpanayeti / athādṛṣṭasadbhāve 'pi śarīrādayo dṛṣṭatvādabhyupagamyante / tarhi viśeṣyacakṣurādisambandha eva dṛṣṭatvād viśeṣaṇaviśeṣyabhāvo 'bhyupagantavyaḥ /
analyzed: atas yathāsambhavam viśeṣaṇa viśeṣya bhāvaḥ grāhyaḥ kvacid saṃyogaḥ kvacid samavāyaḥ iti tathā ca abhāve pi viśeṣa cakṣuḥ ādi sambandhaḥ eva viśeṣaṇa viśeṣya bhāvaḥ tena satā ca viśiṣṭa pratyaya jananāt na ca adṛṣṭasya atra kāraṇa tvam niṣidhyate sakala kāryeṣu sādhāraṇa tvāt  na api adṛṣṭaḥ dṛṣṭa kāraṇam pratyācaṣṭe śarīra ādeḥ api abhāva prasaṅgāt tathā hi sukha ādi sampādakaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ eva ast
translated: Therefore, the relation of qualification and qualificand should be accepted as appropriate in each case - sometimes as conjunction, sometimes as inherence. And in the case of non-existence also, the relation of qualification and qualificand is only the connection with the particular sense organs like the eye. Because even an existent produces a cognition with a particular qualification. And the causal nature of the unseen is not denied here. Because it is common to all effects. Nor does the unseen reject the seen cause. Because it would lead to the non-existence of the body etc. For thus, let the unseen itself be the producer of pleasure etc., enough of assuming the body etc. But if, even in the existence of the unseen, the body etc. are accepted because they are seen, then the relation of qualification and qualificand should be accepted as seen, only as the connection with the particular eye etc.

original: atha viśeṣaṇe tasyāvṛtteḥ kathaṃ tadbhāva iti cet / na / adṛṣṭvad vyāpārāpekṣayā tadavṛttitvāt / athaikajñānālambanatve surabhi dravyam iti vibhinnendriyagrāhyayorviśeṣaṇaviśeṣyabhāvo na syāt / na hi vibhinnendriyābhyāmekaṃ vijñānaṃ sampādyaṃ dṛṣṭamiti / na / viśeṣaṇaviśeṣyayorvibhinnajñānālambanatve bādhakopapatteranusandhānajñānametat / tathā hi ghrāṇena gandhamupalabhya cakṣuṣā sparśanena vā dravyaṃ paścānmanasānusaṃdhatte surabhi dravyam iti / na ca sarvaṃ viśeṣyajñānamanusandhānajñānamiti vācyam / tatra hi bādhakānupapatteḥ / tathā viśeṣaṇaviśeṣyayorvibhinnajñānālambanatāyām ekadaṇḍinamahamadrākṣam iti smaraṇaṃ na syāt / tasya hi anubhavarūpatvāt /
analyzed: atha viśeṣaṇe tasya avṛtteḥ katham tad bhāvaḥ iti ced na adṛṣṭa vat vyāpāra apekṣayā tad avṛtti tvāt  atha eka jñāna ālambana tve surabhi dravyam iti vibhinna indriya grāhyayoḥ viśeṣaṇa viśeṣya bhāvaḥ na syāt na hi vibhinna indriyābhyām ekam vijñānam sampādyam dṛṣṭam iti na viśeṣaṇa viśeṣyayoḥ vibhinna jñāna ālambana tve bādhaka upapatteḥ anusandhāna jñānam etat tathā hi ghrāṇena gandham upalabhya cakṣuṣā sparśanena vā dra
translated: If it be asked—how can there be that (co-ordination) if there is no repetition of the qualification? (we say)—no; because there is no repetition in relation to the unseen operation. If it be said—if there is the object of one cognition, then there would be no relation of qualification and qualified between the two, which are apprehended by different sense-organs, as in the case of ‘the fragrant substance’; because it is not seen that one cognition is produced by two different sense-organs,—no; because in the case of the relation of qualification and qualified, the object of the different cognitions, there is the cognition of the connection, which is based on the occurrence of the contradiction. Thus, having perceived the odour by the nose, the substance by the eye or by the touch, one subsequently connects them by the mind, as ‘the fragrant substance.’ And it cannot be said that every cognition of the qualified is the cognition of the connection; because in that case there would be no occurrence of the contradiction. Similarly, in the case of the relation of qualification and qualified, the object of the different cognitions, there would be no recollection in the form ‘I saw the man with the stick,’ because that (recollection) is of the nature of experience.

original: atha puruṣapratyayasāmānādhikaraṇyād daṇḍinamānaya ityādiprayogeṣu puruṣasyaikakriyāsambandhāt tadālambanameva viśeṣyajñānamiti cet / na / puruṣasya viśeṣyatayā prādhānyāt kriyāsambandhaḥ sāmānādhikaraṇyañcopapadyata evetyalamativistareṇa /
analyzed: atha puruṣa pratyaya sāmānādhikaraṇyāt daṇḍinam ānaya ityādi prayogeṣu puruṣasya eka kriyā sambandhāt tad ālambanam eva viśeṣya jñānam iti ced na puruṣasya viśeṣya tayā prādhānyāt kriyā sambandhaḥ sāmānādhikaraṇyam ca upapadyate eva iti alam ati vistareṇa
translated: If it be argued that, because of the co-ordination of the man and the notion, in such expressions as ‘bring the stick-holder’, the man is connected with one action, and hence the cognition of the qualified is based upon that man,—we say—no; because the man, being the principal factor, is the qualified, and hence the co-ordination and the connection with the action are quite possible. It is not necessary to pursue this any further.

original: anye tvekajñānālambanatve viśeṣaṇaviśeṣyabhāvo na syāt / tayoḥ karaṇakarmarūpatvāditi manyante / tathā hi viśiṣyate 'neneti viśeṣaṇaṃ karaṇam / viśeṣyata iti viśeṣyaṃ karma / taccaikajñānālambanatāyāṃ na syādubhayoḥ karmatvāditi / nāpyajñātavyāpāre sahakāritvāviśeṣāccakṣurādibhyo viśeṣaḥ syāditi tajjñānaṃ kalpyate / yadi ca daṇḍatvaviśiṣṭo daṇḍaḥ puruṣasya viśeṣaṇamiṣyeta tasyāpyanyadityanavasthā / daṇḍaśced daṇḍatvasya viśeṣaṇamitaretarāśrayatvañca syāditi viśeṣyajñānābhāvaprasaṅgaḥ / asti ca viśeṣyajñānamiti tadanyathānupapattyā viśeṣaṇajñānamātraṃ jñāyate /
analyzed: anye tu eka jñāna ālambana tve viśeṣaṇa viśeṣya bhāvaḥ na syāt tayoḥ karaṇa karma rūpa tvāt iti manyante tathā hi viśiṣyate nena iti viśeṣaṇam karaṇam viśeṣyate iti viśeṣyam karma tat ca eka jñāna ālambana tāyām na syāt ubhayoḥ karma tvāt iti na api ajñāta vyāpāre sahakāri tva aviśeṣāt cakṣuḥ ādibhyaḥ viśeṣaḥ syāt iti tat jñānam kalpyate yadi ca daṇḍa tva viśiṣṭaḥ daṇḍaḥ puruṣasya viśeṣaṇam iṣyeta tasya api any
translated: Others, however, think that if there were only one cognition as the object, there would be no relation of qualifier and qualified, because they have the nature of instrument and object. Thus, they say, it is an instrument because it qualifies by this, and it is an object because it is qualified. And that would not be the case if there were only one cognition as the object, because both are objects. Nor would there be a distinction from the eye, etc., because of the non-distinction in the function of assisting in the unknown. Therefore, its cognition is imagined. And if the stick qualified by stickness is accepted as the qualifier of the man, that also would have another, so there would be an infinite regress. And if the stick were the qualifier of stickness, there would be mutual dependence, and there would be the consequence of the absence of the cognition of the qualified. But since there is the cognition of the qualified, the mere cognition of the qualifier is known by the non-apprehension of it in another way.

original: yaccedaṃ viśeṣyajñānamutpatteḥ pūrvaṃ viśeṣaṇasya na tad rūpatāṃ darśayatītyuktam / tatra keyaṃ viśeṣaṇarūpateti vicāryam / na hi daṇḍe daṇḍatvādivad viśeṣaṇarūpatā pratibhāti / atha svānuraktapratyayajanakatvaṃ viśeṣaṇatvam / tacca yadi svālambanajñānasahitasya viśeṣyajñānajanakatvam / abhyupagamavyāghātaḥ / na caikavijñānālambanatve 'nurāgārthaṃ paśyāmaḥ / tacchabdābhilapyatvādeḥ pratiṣedhāt / nāpi kramo viśeṣaṇaviśeṣyabhāvaheturanabhyupagamāt / viśeṣyajñānantu viśeṣaṇajñānaṃ darśayatyevānyathā hi tadviśiṣṭatvāyogāt / yaccedamanumānādapratipatteḥ pratyakṣaphalakatvamiti / taccāsat / bādhakasadbhāvena atraikajñānālambanatvābhyupagamāt / na caivaṃ sarvatra bādhakamastīti /
analyzed: yat ca idam viśeṣya jñānam utpatteḥ pūrvam viśeṣaṇasya na tat rūpa tām darśayati iti uktam tatra kā iyam viśeṣaṇa rūpa tā iti vicāryam na hi daṇḍe daṇḍa tva ādi vat viśeṣaṇa rūpa tā pratibhāti atha sva anurakta pratyaya janaka tvam viśeṣaṇa tvam tat ca yadi sva ālambana jñāna sahitasya viśeṣya jñāna janaka tvam abhyupagama vyāghātaḥ na ca eka vijñāna ālambana tve nurāga artham paśyāmaḥ tad śabda abhilapya tva ādeḥ pratiṣedhāt nā api
translated: And as for what was said that the knowledge of the qualified, prior to the production of the knowledge of the qualifier, does not show the form of the qualifier, there it should be considered what this form of the qualifier is. For the form of the qualifier does not appear in the stick as stick-ness and so on. If the being a qualifier consists in producing a cognition connected with itself, and that consists in producing a cognition of the qualified along with a cognition of itself as its object, then there is contradiction of your own doctrine. And we do not see the purpose of connection in being the object of a single cognition, since the designation by the word that and so on is denied. Nor is the order the cause of the relation of qualifier and qualified, because it is not accepted. But the knowledge of the qualified does indeed show the knowledge of the qualifier, otherwise, because of the impossibility of being qualified by that. And as for this, that the result of perception is the non-apprehension by inference, that is wrong, because here the acceptance of being the object of a single cognition is due to the existence of a contradiction. And it is not so in all cases.

original: anye tu dhūmopalambhānantaramagnyanumāne satyagnimānayaṃ parvata iti jñānaṃ pratyakṣameveti bruvate / anyathā hi ayam ityaparokṣatānirdeśo na syāt / atra ca sādhyadharmaviśiṣṭadharmiṇaḥ sādhyatve kathametat sādhanaṃ syāditi vācyam /
analyzed: anye tu dhūma upalambha anantaram agni anumāne sati agnimān ayam parvataḥ iti jñānam pratyakṣam eva iti bruvate anyathā hi ayam iti aparokṣa tā nirdeśaḥ na syāt atra ca sādhya dharma viśiṣṭa dharmiṇaḥ sādhya tve katham etat sādhanam syāt iti vācyam
translated: Others, however, say that the knowledge This mountain has fire after the inference of fire from the perception of smoke is itself perception. Otherwise, the designation of the object as this would not be possible. And here it should be said that if the qualified subject is to be proved, how could this be the proof?

original: yaccedaṃ viśeṣaṇaviśeṣyabhāvaḥ kimeko 'neko veti / tatraikatvābhyupagame 'pi na viśeṣaṇaviśeṣyayoravyavasthā / nimittāntarasyāsādhāraṇasya sadbhāvāt / tathā hi viśeṣaṇaṃ svānuraktapratyayotpādakatvenetyuktam / viśeṣyantu viśeṣyajñānaviṣayatvena / viśeṣaṇaviśeṣyabhāvastu paraṃ viśeṣyajñānotpattau sahakārī / na punarvyavasthākāraṇamiti /
analyzed: yat ca idam viśeṣaṇa viśeṣya bhāvaḥ kim ekaḥ na ekaḥ vā iti tatra ekatva abhyupagame pi na viśeṣaṇa viśeṣyayoḥ avyavasthā nimitta antarasya asādhāraṇasya sadbhāvāt tathā hi viśeṣaṇam sva anurakta pratyaya utpādaka tvena iti uktam viśeṣyan tu viśeṣya jñāna viṣaya tvena viśeṣaṇa viśeṣya bhāvaḥ tu param viśeṣya jñāna utpattau sahakārī na punar vyavasthā kāraṇam iti
translated: And as for the relation of qualifier and qualified, whether it is one or many, even if oneness is accepted, there is no confusion between the qualifier and the qualified, because there is a different cause, which is uncommon. For it is said that the qualifier produces a cognition that is affected by itself, while the qualified is the object of the cognition of the qualified. But the relation of qualifier and qualified is only a contributory factor in the production of the cognition of the qualified, and is not the cause of the distinction.

original: na ca saṃyogasamavāyāveva viśeṣaṇaviśeṣyabhāvaḥ / tayoḥ samavāye 'bhāve cābhāvāt / atrāpi viśeṣyendriyasambandho 'stīti cet / na / tasya viśeṣaṇāvṛttitvāt / nāpyadṛṣṭavad vyāpārāpekṣayā tadvṛttitvam / saṃyogasamavāyayoranyatrānupalabdheḥ / tathā hi saṃyogasamavāyaI /yoryadi vyāpārāpekṣayā viśeṣaṇavṛttitvamiṣyeta / viśeṣyasambandhaṃ vinā abhāvasamavāyayorgrahaṇaṃ syāt / yatra hi tayorvṛttistatraiva grahaṇajanakatvopalabdheḥ / adṛṣṭasya tvātmasamavetasyāpi sakalakāryotpattau sādhāraṇatvāt / saṃyogādisadbhāve tadabhāve ca kevalasya vyāpāro 'bhyupagamyata eva / sa cobhayatra vyāpārāpekṣayā sambaddha iva sambaddho na paramārthataḥ /
analyzed: na ca saṃyoga samavāyau eva viśeṣaṇa viśeṣya bhāvaḥ tayoḥ samavāye bhāve ca abhāvāt  / atra api viśeṣya indriya sambandhaḥ sti iti ced na tasya viśeṣaṇa avṛtti tvāt na api adṛṣṭa vat vyāpāra apekṣayā tad vṛtti tvam saṃyoga samavāyayoḥ anyatra anupalabdheḥ tathā hi vyāpāra apekṣayā viśeṣaṇa vṛtti tvam iṣyeta viśeṣya sambandham vinā abhāva samavāyayoḥ grahaṇam syāt yatra hi tayoḥ vṛttiḥ tatra eva grahaṇa janaka tva upalabd
translated: Nor are conjunction and inherence themselves the relation of qualifier and qualified, because they are absent when there is no inherence. If it is argued that the contact of the qualified object with the sense organ is present here also, that is not so, because that is not present in the qualifier. Nor is their presence due to the need for an unseen operation, like that of the sense organ, because conjunction and inherence are not perceived elsewhere. Thus, if conjunction and inherence are accepted to be present in the qualifier due to the need for an operation, then absence and inherence would be grasped without the relation to the qualified object. Because their capacity to generate cognition is perceived only where they are present. But the unseen, even though residing in the self, is common to the production of all effects. The operation of the self alone is accepted in the presence of conjunction etc. and in their absence. And that, being dependent on operation in both cases, appears as if related, but not really.

original: na copacaritasyendriyāsahakāritvam / aparokṣajñānasyānyathāsambhavena tadabhāvasiddheḥ / dṛṣṭañca śrotrānyopacaritasyāpi śabdajñānasahakāritvamiti / yaccedaṃ surabhi dravyam ityādyanusandhānajñānamityuktam / tadasat / anyatrāpyevaṃ prasaṅgāt / na cātra vibhinnajñānālambanatve kiñcid bādhakamastīti tadevābhyupeyam /
analyzed: na ca upacaritasya indriya asahakāri tvam aparokṣa jñānasya anyathā sambhavena tad abhāva siddheḥ  dṛṣṭam ca śrotra anya upacaritasya api śabda jñāna sahakāri tvam iti yat ca idam surabhi dravyam ityādi anusandhāna jñānam iti uktam tat asat anyatra api evam prasaṅgāt na ca atra vibhinna jñāna ālambana tve kiñcid bādhakam asti iti tat eva abhyupeyam
translated: Nor can the object of a metaphor be a contributory cause of a sense-perception, because the existence of such a perception is possible in some other way, and because the existence of a metaphor is not established. And it is seen that even a metaphor that is not a contributory cause of the cognition of sound can be a contributory cause of the cognition of smell. And what has been said about the knowledge of association, such as this fragrant substance, is not correct, because it would lead to the same absurdity elsewhere. And there is no contradiction in this being the object of different cognitions, so that alone should be accepted.

original: nāpi daṇḍinamahamadrākṣam iti smaraṇānupapattiḥ / viśeṣaṇajñānajanitasaṃskārasya viśeṣyajñānasahakāriṇaḥ saṃskārārambheṇāpi tadbhāvāt /
analyzed: nā api daṇḍinam aham adrākṣam iti smaraṇa anupapattiḥ viśeṣaṇa jñāna janita saṃskārasya viśeṣya jñāna sahakāriṇaḥ saṃskāra ārambheṇa api tad bhāvāt
translated: Nor is the non-apprehension of the memory I saw the man with a stick impossible, because the impression produced by the knowledge of the qualifier, which is a contributory cause of the knowledge of the qualified, exists even by the commencement of the impression.

original: yaccedamekajñānālambanatve 'pi viśeṣyasya prādhānyāt kriyāsambandhaḥ / sāmānādhikaraṇyañca ghaṭata iti / tanna / prādhānyasyaiva vicāryatvāt / ekajñānālambanatāyāṃ hi kiṃ kṛtaṃ prādhānyamiti cintyam / sāmānādhikaraṇyantvekajñānālambanatvāviśeṣe puruṣapratyayena na ca daṇḍapratyayeneti viśeṣaṇahetvabhāvaḥ /
analyzed: yat ca idam eka jñāna ālambana tve pi viśeṣyasya prādhānyāt kriyā sambandhaḥ sāmānādhikaraṇyam ca ghaṭate iti tat na prādhānyasya eva vicārya tvāt eka jñāna ālambana tāyām hi kim kṛtam prādhānyam iti cintyam sāmānādhikaraṇyam tu eka jñāna ālambana tva aviśeṣe puruṣa pratyayena na ca daṇḍa pratyayena iti viśeṣaṇa hetu abhāvaḥ
translated: And as for the argument that, even when there is the same cognition, the relation of action is due to the predominance of the qualified, and the co-reference is possible, that is not so. Because predominance itself is to be considered. For when there is the same cognition, what is done by predominance is to be thought about. And co-reference, in the absence of difference in the same cognition, is due to the human factor, not due to the factor of the stick. So there is no reason for the qualification.

original: atha vibhinnaviśeṣaṇanimittayorekasminnarthe vṛtteḥ sāmānādhikaraṇyam / daṇḍīti pratyaye daṇḍo viśeṣaṇaṃ puruṣe iti / na caivaṃ daṇḍasya viśeṣaṇatve 'nyad viśeṣaṇamastīti sāmānādhikaraṇyam / naitadevam / anekasya prameyasya pratibhāsābhyupagamāt / tathā hi na daṇḍī iti jñāne daṇḍatvādyapi prameyaṃ pratibhāsata ityabhyupagame kathanaṃ sāmānādhikaraṇyam / tathā sūtravyāghātaśca samavāyinaḥ śvaityācchvaityabuddheḥ śvete buddhistatkāryakāraṇabhūte vai / sū / / / kāryakāraṇasvabhāve iti /
analyzed: atha vibhinna viśeṣaṇa nimittayoḥ ekasmin arthe vṛtteḥ sāmānādhikaraṇyam daṇḍī iti pratyaye daṇḍaḥ viśeṣaṇam puruṣe iti  na ca evam daṇḍasya viśeṣaṇa tve viśeṣaṇam asti iti sāmānādhikaraṇyam na etat evam anekasya prameyasya pratibhāsa abhyupagamāt tathā hi na daṇḍī iti jñāne daṇḍa tva ādi api prameyam pratibhāsate iti abhyupagame kathanam sāmānādhikaraṇyam tathā sūtra vyāghātaḥ ca samavāyinaḥ śvaityāt śvaitya buddheḥ ś
translated: Now, if the qualifier and the qualified are different, then how can there be co-reference in the cognition of a single object? In the cognition 'the man with the stick', the stick is the qualifier of the man. And if the stick is the qualifier in this way, then there is no other qualifier, so there is no co-reference. This is not so, because many objects of knowledge are accepted to appear. Thus, in the cognition 'the man with the stick', if it is accepted that the object of knowledge such as stickness also appears, then how is there co-reference? And there is also contradiction with the sutra, which states that the cognition of whiteness is the effect of the inherence of whiteness. The effect and cause are of the nature of cause and effect.

original: na punarbhūtābhidhānamupamāyāṃ mukhye bādhakānupapatteḥ / nāpi prameyaviśeṣādeva pratyayaviśeṣaḥ / sahakārivailakṣaṇyenāpi bhāvāt /
analyzed: na punar bhūta abhidhānam upamāyām mukhye bādhaka anupapatteḥ nā api prameya viśeṣāt eva pratyaya viśeṣaḥ sahakāri vailakṣaṇyena api bhāvāt
translated: Moreover, the denotation of elements is not primary in metaphor, because there is no contradiction. Nor is the specific cognition due to the specific object of knowledge alone, because it occurs even due to the difference in auxiliaries.

original: nanvevaṃ tarhi viśeṣaṇavat sambandhe 'pi jñānaṃ kalpanīyam / tatra tadanurāgasyāpratibhāsena cakṣurādivad agṛhītasyāpi vyāpārābhyupagamāt /
analyzed: nanu evam tarhi viśeṣaṇa vat sambandhe jñānam kalpanīyam tatra tad anurāgasya apratibhāsena cakṣuḥ ādi vat agṛhītasya api vyāpāra abhyupagamāt
translated: If it is so, then in the case of the relation of qualification and qualified also, knowledge must be imagined, because even when the attachment to that is not manifested, like the eye etc., the operation of what is not grasped is accepted.

original: nāpyabhedopacārād viśeṣaṇāviśeṣyabhāvaḥ / puruṣe daṇḍaḥ iti jñānānupapatteḥ / atha
analyzed: na api abheda upacārāt viśeṣaṇa a viśeṣya bhāvaḥ puruṣe daṇḍaḥ iti jñāna anupapatteḥ atha
translated: Nor is the relation of qualification and qualified due to figurative usage of non-difference, because the knowledge the stick in the man is not possible. If it is said:

original: viśeṣaṇaṃ viśeṣyañ ca sambandhaṃ laukikīṃ sthitim /
analyzed: viśeṣaṇam viśeṣyam ca sambandham laukikīm sthitim
translated: The qualification and the qualified grasp the relation, the worldly state,

original: gṛhītvā saṅkalyyaiva tathā pratyeti nānyathā // /🔽iti saṅkalanājñānamiti cet / naitad yuktam / etāvato jñānakalāpasya sadbhāve pramāṇābhāvāt / tathā hi paraṃ viśeṣyajñānamutpadyamānaṃ dṛṣṭam / taccānyathā ca ghaṭata iti viśeṣaṇe 'pi jñānaṃ luptam / na punarjñānāntarasadbhāve pramāṇamastīti /
analyzed: gṛhītvā saṅkalyya eva tathā pratyeti na anyathā  iti saṅkalanā jñānam iti ced na etat yuktam etāvataḥ jñāna kalāpasya sadbhāve pramāṇa abhāvāt tathā hi param viśeṣya jñānam utpadyamānam dṛṣṭam tat ca anyathā ca ghaṭate iti viśeṣaṇe jñānam luptam na punar jñāna antara sadbhāve pramāṇam asti iti
translated: and only then cognizes thus by combining, not otherwise,🔽as the knowledge of combination. This is not correct. Because there is no evidence for the existence of such a group of knowledge. Thus, the knowledge of the qualified, which is seen to arise, is possible in another way. Therefore, the knowledge of the qualification is also lost. And there is no evidence for the existence of another knowledge.

original: na cedaṃ niriviṣayaṃ kalpanājñānam / arthānvayavyatirekānuvidhānāt / bādhakānupapatteś ca /
analyzed: na ca idam niri viṣayam kalpanā jñānam artha anvaya vyatireka anuvidhānāt bādhaka anupapatteḥ ca
translated: And this knowledge of imagination is not objectless, because it conforms to the presence and absence of the object, and because there is no contradiction.

original: tadevaṃ gṛhītasya viśeṣaṇasya viśeṣyajñānajanakatvāt liṅgādivyāpārānupalabdheśca pratyakṣatvaṃ kālasyeti / satyam / tathaikajñānālambanatve 'pi yugapādipratyayā na kālasya liṅgam / tasyāpi viśeṣaṇatayālambanatvāt / amīṣāñcendriyānuvidhānena pratyakṣaphalatvādityalam /
analyzed: tat evam gṛhītasya viśeṣaṇasya viśeṣya jñāna janaka tvāt liṅga ādi vyāpāra anupalabdheḥ ca pratyakṣa tvam kālasya iti satyam tathā eka jñāna ālambana tve pi yugapad ādi pratyayāḥ na kālasya liṅgam tasya api viśeṣaṇa tayā ālambana tvāt  amīṣām ca indriya anuvidhānena pratyakṣa phalatvāt iti alam
translated: Thus, time is perceived, because the qualified object which is thus apprehended produces the cognition of the qualified, and because the operation of inferential marks etc. is not perceived. This is true, but even when the cognitions of pairs etc. have the same object, they are not the inferential marks of time, because that [time] is also the object as a qualifier. And because these [cognitions of pairs etc.] are the result of perception, being in accordance with the senses. Thus far.

original: sarvakāryāṇāmutpattau kāraṇatvaṃ pratijñātamāha sarvakāryāṇāñcotpattisthitivināśahetuḥ iti / utpattirātmalābho bhāvānām / sthitiḥ kramabhāvyanekakāryakartṛtvam / vināśaḥ pradhvaṃsaḥ / teṣāṃ kāraṇamiti / atra tu yadyapi sarvakāryāṇāṃ heturityukte sarvametallabhyate tathāpyavāntaraviśeṣāpekṣayā bhedakathanam /
analyzed: sarva kāryāṇām utpattau kāraṇa tvam pratijñātam āha sarva kāryāṇām ca utpatti sthiti vināśa hetuḥ iti utpattiḥ ātmalābhaḥ bhāvānām sthitiḥ krama bhāvi aneka kārya kartṛ tvam vināśaḥ pradhvaṃsaḥ teṣām kāraṇam iti atra tu yadi api sarva kāryāṇām hetuḥ iti ukte sarvam etat labhyate tathā api avāntara viśeṣa apekṣayā bheda kathanam
translated: He states what was asserted as the cause of the origination of all effects: The cause of the origination, persistence, and destruction of all effects. Origination is the acquisition of self-existence by entities. Persistence is the state of being the agent of many effects that arise in succession. Destruction is the state of being destroyed. The cause of these [is time]. Although it is understood that all this is included when it is said the cause of all effects, the distinction is stated with reference to a specific difference.

original: atha teṣāṃ hetuḥ kāla iti kathaṃ jñāyata ityāha tadvyapadeśāt iti / tathā hyutpattau kālena vyapadeśo madhyāhne utpanno 'parāhṇe utpannaḥ iti / sthitau ca madhyāhnaṃ yāvat sthito 'parāhṇañca iti / vināśe tu prātarvinaṣṭo varṣānte vinaṣṭaḥ ityādi / kāraṇena tu kāryasya vyapadeśo yathā cākṣuṣaṃ vijñānam / mānasaṃ vijñānam iti /
analyzed: atha teṣām hetuḥ kālaḥ iti katham jñāyate iti āha tad vyapadeśāt iti tathā hi utpattau kālena vyapadeśaḥ madhyāhne parāhṇe utpannaḥ iti sthitau ca madhyāhnam yāvat parāhṇam ca iti vināśe tu prātar vinaṣṭaḥ varṣa ante vinaṣṭaḥ ityādi kāraṇena tu kāryasya vyapadeśaḥ yathā cākṣuṣam vijñānam mānasam vijñānam iti
translated: Now, how is it known that their cause is time? He says: because of their designation. For in origination, there is designation by time: It originated at midday, it originated in the afternoon. And in duration: It lasted until midday, and in the afternoon. And in destruction: It was destroyed in the morning, it was destroyed at the end of the year, and so on. But by the cause, there is designation of the effect, like visual consciousness, mental consciousness.

original: athākāraṇenāpi vyapadeśaḥ sambhavatyeva / mūrtāḥ paramāṇavaḥ daṇḍī puruṣaḥ iti / satyam / tathāpi sambandhe sati vyapadeśopalabdheḥ / na cānyaḥ sambandho 'tra sambhavatīti kāryakāraṇabhāvo jñāyate / athāsti saṃyogaḥ / na / guṇakarmāderavyapadeśyatāprasaṅgāt / asti ca tatrāpi vyapadeśaḥ pūrvāhṇe śabdastathotkṣepaṇam ityādi /
analyzed: atha akāraṇena api vyapadeśaḥ sambhavati eva mūrtāḥ paramāṇavaḥ daṇḍī puruṣaḥ iti satyam tathā api sambandhe sati vyapadeśa upalabdheḥ na ca anyaḥ sambandhaḥ sambhavati iti kārya kāraṇa bhāvaḥ jñāyate atha asti saṃyogaḥ na guṇa karma ādeḥ avyapadeśya tā prasaṅgāt asti ca tatra api vyapadeśaḥ pūrvāhṇe śabdaḥ tathā utkṣepaṇam ityādi
translated: Now, even if designation is possible without a cause, like the embodied atoms, the man with a stick, it is true. Nevertheless, when there is a relation, designation is observed. And since no other relation is possible here, the relation of cause and effect is known. If it is argued that there is conjunction, that is not so. Because it would lead to the undesirability of the non-designation of quality, action, etc. And there is also designation there: The sound is in the forenoon, The upward movement is likewise, and so on.

original: athāyaṃ vyapadeśaḥ saṃyuktasamavāyād bhaviṣyatīti / na / abhāve tadabhāvaprasaṅgāt / ataḥ kāryakāraṇabhāva eva sambandho 'bhyupeyaḥ / tasya hi vyāpakatvāditi / tathā niyatakāle kusumādeḥ kāryasyopalambho na kālāntare ityanvayavyatirekābhyāṃ tasya kāraṇatvaṃ vijñāyate / tathā hi vasantasamaya eva pāṭalādikusumānāmudgamo na kālāntare ityevaṃ kāryāntareṣvapyūhyam / tathā prasavakālamapekṣate iti vyavahārāt kāraṇatvaṃ kālasya / tathā hi / sahakāriṇamapekṣyopalabdheḥ / kālasya sahakāritāmantareṇa prasūtau ayaṃ vyavahāro na syāt /
analyzed: atha ayam vyapadeśaḥ saṃyukta samavāyāt bhaviṣyati iti na abhāve tad abhāva prasaṅgāt atas kārya kāraṇa bhāvaḥ eva sambandhaḥ bhyupeyaḥ tasya hi vyāpaka tvāt iti tathā niyata kāle kusuma ādeḥ kāryasya upalambhaḥ na kāla antare iti anvaya vyatirekābhyām tasya kāraṇa tvam vijñāyate tathā hi vasanta samaye eva pāṭalā ādi kusumānām udgamaḥ na kāla antare iti evam kārya antareṣu api ūhyam tathā prasava kālam apekṣate iti vyavahārāt kāraṇa tvam k
translated: Now, if it is argued that this designation would be due to the conjunction of the connected, it is not so, because in the absence of that, there would be the undesirable consequence of its absence. Therefore, the relation must be accepted as the relation of cause and effect itself, because that is all-pervading. Similarly, the effect like a flower is perceived at a fixed time, not at another time. By positive and negative concomitance, its causal nature is understood. For instance, the appearance of flowers like the pāṭala occurs only in the spring season, not at another time. In this way, it should be inferred in other effects as well. Similarly, the usage it depends on the time of birth indicates the causal nature of time. For instance, because it is perceived in dependence on the cooperating factor, if there were production without the cooperation of time, this usage would not occur.

original: tathā na paraṃ yugapadādipratyayahetuḥ kṣaṇalavanimeṣakāṣṭhākalā muhūrtayāmāhorātrārdhamāsamāsartvayanasaṃvatsarayugakalpamanvantarapralayamahāpralayavyavahārahetuḥ iti / tathā hi paramāṇoścāvaruddhanabhodeśatyāgopalakṣitaḥ kālaḥ kṣaṇaḥ /
analyzed: tathā na param yugapad ādi pratyaya hetuḥ kṣaṇa lava nimeṣa kāṣṭhā kalāḥ muhūrta yāma ahorātra ardha māsa māsa ṛtu ayana saṃvatsara yuga kalpa manvantara pralaya mahāpralaya vyavahāra hetuḥ iti tathā hi paramāṇoḥ ca avaruddha nabhaḥ deśa tyāga upalakṣitaḥ kālaḥ kṣaṇaḥ
translated: Similarly, it is not the cause of the notions of 'more' and 'simultaneous' etc. It is the cause of the usage of 'moment', 'second', 'minute', 'muhūrta', 'kalā', 'laghu', 'naimiṣa', 'kāṣṭhā', 'kṣaṇa', 'lava', 'niṣkala', 'muhūrta', 'yama', 'ahorātra', 'ardhamāsa', 'māsa', 'ṛtu', 'ayana', 'samvatsara', 'yuga', 'kalpa', 'manvantara', and 'mahāpralaya'. Thus, the time characterized by the abandonment of the space enclosed by the atoms is the 'kṣaṇa'.

original: tad dvayaṃ lava ityukto nimeṣaśca lavadvayam /
analyzed: tat dvayam lavaḥ iti uktaḥ nimeṣaḥ ca lava dvayam
translated: Two of those are said to be a 'lava', and two 'lavas' are a 'niṣkala'.

original: kāṣṭhā nimeṣāḥ pañcadaśa ceha prakīrtitāḥ //
analyzed: kāṣṭhāḥ nimeṣāḥ pañcadaśa ca iha prakīrtitāḥ
translated: Fifteen 'niṣkalas' are declared here to be a 'kāṣṭhā'.

original: triṃśat kāṣṭhāḥ kalā proktā kalāḥ triṃśanmuhūrtakaḥ / purāṇam
analyzed: triṃśat kāṣṭhāḥ kalā proktā kalāḥ triṃśanmuhūrtakaḥ purāṇam
translated: Thirty 'kāṣṭhās' are said to be a 'kalā', and thirty 'kalās' are a 'muhūrta'. The ancient

original: ityevaṃ māsāderapi lakṣaṇaṃ prasiddhaṃ grāhyam /
analyzed: iti evam māsa ādeḥ api lakṣaṇam prasiddham grāhyam
translated: Thus, the definitions of 'māsa' (month) etc. are also well-known and should be accepted.

original: sa cāyaṃ kṣaṇādivyavahāro viśiṣṭatvād viśiṣṭaṃ nimittamākṣipati / na cānyannimittaṃ sambhavatīti / kriyādeḥ pratiṣedhād iti kālasadbhāvasiddhiḥ / tasya samavāyitvaguṇavattvapratipādanārthaṃ tasya guṇāḥ saṃkhyāparimāṇapṛthaktvasaṃyogavibhāgāḥ iti vākyam / atra keṣāñcidutpattau samavāyikāraṇam / etairguṇairguṇavān kāla iti /
analyzed: sa ca ayam kṣaṇa ādi vyavahāraḥ viśiṣṭa tvāt viśiṣṭam nimittam ākṣipati na ca anyat nimittam sambhavati iti kriyā ādeḥ pratiṣedhāt iti kāla sadbhāva siddhiḥ tasya samavāyi tva guṇavat tva pratipādana artham tasya guṇāḥ saṃkhyā parimāṇa pṛthaktva saṃyoga vibhāgāḥ iti vākyam atra keṣāñcid utpattau samavāyi kāraṇam etaiḥ guṇaiḥ guṇavān kālaḥ iti
translated: And this usage of 'moment' etc. implies a specific cause due to its specificity, and no other cause is possible, so the existence of time is established by the negation of action etc. The sentence 'Its qualities are number, dimension, separateness, conjunction and disjunction' is for the purpose of establishing that it is a substance and has qualities. Here, it is the material cause in the production of some of these. Time is endowed with these qualities.

original: atha dravyatvādeva saṃkhyāsadbhāvasiddhau kimeko 'neko veti saṃśayastannirāsāyāha kālaliṅgāviśeṣādekatvaṃ siddham iti / kālasya yalliṅgaṃ yugapadādipratyayarūpaṃ tadviśiṣṭamiti nānātvāpratipādakam / nanu cāsiddhametat / yugapadādipratyayānāṃ parasparaṃ viśiṣṭatvāt / na ca kāryavailakṣaṇyaṃ kāraṇavailakṣaṇyaṃ vinā bhavatīti / nānātvameva nyāyyam / satyam / kāryavailakṣaṇyād vijñāyata eva sāmagrīvailakṣaṇyam / tacca sahakāryantarānupraveśenāpi ghaṭata iti / kathaṃ kālasya nānātvam / uktañcātra viśiṣṭakriyopacitasya viśiṣṭapratyayajanakatvamiti / na caivaṃ paramāṇūnāṃ cāturvidhyaṃ vyāhanyata iti pūrvavad vācyam / tadevaṃ nānātve pramāṇābhāvād dravyasya ca saṃkhyeyatvādityekatvaṃ siddham /
analyzed: atha dravya tvāt eva saṃkhyā sadbhāva siddhau kim ekaḥ nekaḥ vā iti saṃśayaḥ tad nirāsāya āha kāla liṅga aviśeṣāt eka tvam siddham iti kālasya yat liṅgam yugapad ādi pratyaya rūpam tat viśiṣṭam iti nānātva a pratipādakam nanu ca asiddham etat yugapad ādi pratyayānām parasparam viśiṣṭa tvāt na ca kārya vailakṣaṇyam kāraṇa vailakṣaṇyam vinā bhavati iti nānātvam eva nyāyyam satyam kārya vailakṣaṇyāt vijñāyate eva sāmagrī vailakṣaṇyam
translated: Now, if the existence of number is established just by substance-ness, then there is doubt as to whether it is one or many. To remove that doubt, he says that oneness is established due to the non-distinction of time and gender. That which is the gender of time, in the form of the cognition of simultaneity, etc., is distinguished by that, and does not indicate multiplicity. But this is not established, because the cognitions of simultaneity, etc. are distinguished from each other, and difference in effect does not occur without difference in cause. Therefore, multiplicity is reasonable. True, but the difference in effect itself indicates the difference in the assemblage [of causes], and that is possible even by the inclusion of another cooperating cause. How then is time multiple? And it has been said here that that which is accumulated by distinguished action produces distinguished cognitions. And thus the tetrad of atoms is not contradicted, as before. Thus, oneness is established because of the absence of evidence for multiplicity and because substance is countable.

original: tathā tadanuvidhānāt pṛthaktvam iti / tenaikatvenānuvidhānaṃ sāhacaryāt / yatra hyekatvaṃ tatrāvaśyamekapṛthaktvaṃ bhaviṣyatīti / na caivaṃ parimāṇaviśeṣeṇa sāhacaryamastīti jñānārthaṃ kramātikrameṇa pṛthaktvanirūpaṇamiti /
analyzed: tathā tad anuvidhānāt pṛthaktvam iti tena ekatvena anuvidhānam sāhacaryāt yatra hi ekatvam tatra avaśyam eka pṛthaktvam bhaviṣyati iti na ca evam parimāṇa viśeṣeṇa sāhacaryam asti iti jñāna artham krama atikrameṇa pṛthaktva nirūpaṇam iti
translated: And because it is invariably concomitant with that, it is distinct. Thus, it is invariably concomitant with oneness because of co-occurrence. For where there is oneness, there will necessarily be one distinctness. And there is no such co-occurrence with a particular size, so the definition of distinctness is stated out of order for the sake of knowledge.

original: tathā kāraṇe kāla iti vacanāt paramamahat parimāṇam iti / yugapadādipratyayānāṃ kāraṇe kālākhyā iti vai / sū / / / sūtraṃ darśayati / tathā hi / yugapadādipratyayānāṃ kāraṇe kāla ityākhyā saṃjñeti / te ca pratyayāḥ sarvatra bhavantīti vyāpakatvaṃ kālasya / tasmācca paramamahattvamiti / yad vā aṇuparimāṇānadhikaraṇatve sati nityadravyatvāt paramamahattvamiti pūrvavad vācyam /
analyzed: tathā kāraṇe kālaḥ iti vacanāt parama mahat parimāṇam iti yugapad ādi pratyayānām kāraṇe kāla ākhyāḥ iti vai sū sūtram darśayati tathā hi yugapad ādi pratyayānām kāraṇe kālaḥ iti ākhyā saṃjñā iti te ca pratyayāḥ sarvatra bhavanti iti vyāpaka tvam kālasya tasmāt ca parama mahā tvam iti  yat vā aṇu parimāṇa anadhikaraṇa tve sati nitya dravya tvāt parama mahat tvam iti pūrvavat vācyam
translated: Similarly, because of the statement in the cause, time, it is the supreme magnitude. The sutra shows that the notions of simultaneity, etc. have time as their cause. For thus, the designation, the name, of the notions of simultaneity, etc. is time. And those notions occur everywhere, so time is all-pervading. And from that, it is supreme magnitude. Or, it should be stated as before: because of being an eternal substance, not having a magnitude smaller than an atom, it is supreme magnitude.

original: tathā kāraṇaparatvādivacanāt saṃyogaḥ iti / kāraṇaparatvāt kāraṇāparatvācca kārye paratvāparatve vai / sū / / / iti sūtraṃ darśayati / kāraṇaparatvaṃ hi kālapiṇḍasaṃyogaḥ paratvotpādakatvādupacāreṇa vivakṣita iti vakṣyāmaḥ paratvaparīkṣāyām /
analyzed: tathā kāraṇa paratva ādi vacanāt saṃyogaḥ iti kāraṇa paratvāt kāraṇa aparatvāt ca kārye paratva aparatve vai iti sūtram darśayati kāraṇa paratvam hi kāla piṇḍa saṃyogaḥ paratva utpādaka tvāt upacāreṇa vivakṣitaḥ iti vakṣyāmaḥ paratva parīkṣāyām
translated: Similarly, because of the statement about being related to the cause, etc., conjunction is mentioned. He shows the sutra Because of being related to the cause and not being related to the cause, the priority and posteriority of the effect are due to the priority and posteriority of the cause. He will say that the relation to the cause, which is the conjunction of time and mass, is intended figuratively as the producer of priority.

original: tadvināśakatvād vibhāgaḥ iti / tasya hi saṃyogasya kṛtakatvādavaśyaṃ vināśena bhavitavyam / sa ca sarvatrāśrayavināśābhāvād vibhāgādeva vinaśyatīti vibhāgaḥ siddha iti /
analyzed: tad vināśaka tvāt vibhāgaḥ iti tasya hi saṃyogasya kṛtaka tvāt avaśyam vināśena bhavitavyam sa ca sarvatra āśraya vināśa abhāvāt vibhāgāt eva vinaśyati iti vibhāgaḥ siddhaḥ iti
translated: Because it is the destroyer of that, disjunction is mentioned. For that conjunction, being produced, must necessarily be destroyed. And that is destroyed only by disjunction everywhere, because there is no destruction of the substratum. Thus disjunction is established.

original: atha kālasya kathaṃ dravyatvaṃ nityatvañcetyāha tasyākāśavad dravyatvanityatve siddhe iti / tathā hi guṇavattvādanāśritatvācca dravyaṃ kālaḥ / samānāsamānajātīyakāraṇāsambhavāccākāryatvena nitya ityatideśārthaḥ /
analyzed: atha kālasya katham dravya tvam nitya tvam ca iti āha tasya ākāśa vat dravya tva nitya tve siddhe iti tathā hi guṇavat tvāt anāśrita tvāt ca dravyam kālaḥ samāna asamāna jātīya kāraṇa asambhavāt ca akārya tvena nityaḥ iti atideśa arthaḥ
translated: Now, how is time a substance and eternal? He says The substantiality and eternality of time are established like that of space. For time is a substance because it has qualities and is not dependent on anything else. And it is eternal because it cannot have causes of the same or different kind, and is therefore not an effect. This is the meaning of the extension.

original: nanu cātra kālasyaikatāyāṃ vartamānādivyavahāraḥ kathaṃ syādityāha kālaliṅgāviśeṣādañjasaikatve 'pi ityādi / yadyapi kālaliṅgāviśeṣādañjasā mukhyayā vṛttyaikatvaṃ siddhaṃ tathāpi sarvakāryāṇāṃ prārambhaśca kriyābhinirvṛttiśca sthitiśca nirodhaśceti tathoktāsta evopādhayaḥ / tadbhedānnānātvamiti / tathā ca prārambhakriyopalakṣito 'nāgataḥ kālaḥ / abhinirvṛttirātmalābhastadupalakṣitaśca vartamānaḥ / tathā sthitiḥ kramabhāvyanekakāryakartṛtvaṃ tadupalakṣito 'pi vartamāna eva / tasya yāvad vastusadbhāvavyāpyatvād yāvad vivartate vastu tāvad vartamāna iti / tathā nirodho vināśastadupalakṣitaścātīta iti /
analyzed: nanu ca atra kālasya ekatāyām vartamāna ādi vyavahāraḥ katham syāt iti āha kāla liṅga aviśeṣāt añjasā ekatve pi ityādi yadi api kāla liṅga aviśeṣāt añjasā mukhyayā vṛttyā ekatvam siddham tathā api sarva kāryāṇām prārambhaḥ ca kriyā abhinirvṛttiḥ ca sthitiḥ ca nirodhaḥ ca iti tathā uktāḥ te eva upādhayaḥ tad bhedāt nānātvam iti tathā ca prārambha kriyā upalakṣitaḥ nāgataḥ kālaḥ abhinirvṛttiḥ ātmalābhaḥ tad upalakṣitaḥ ca v
translated: But how can the distinction of present, etc. be made if time is one? He says: Although oneness is established directly by the non-distinction of the characteristics of time, etc. Although oneness is established directly by the principal meaning due to the non-distinction of the characteristics of time, still, those very limiting adjuncts are said to be the beginning of all effects, the accomplishment of action, continuance, and cessation. Diversity is due to their distinction. Thus, the future time is characterized by the beginning and action. The present is characterized by that, i.e., accomplishment, which is the attainment of self. Similarly, continuance, which is the performance of many effects in succession, is also characterized by that, i.e., the present itself. As long as there is the pervasion of the existence of the thing, as long as the thing evolves, it is present. Thus, cessation, which is destruction, is characterized by that, i.e., the past.

original: atha kathaṃ nānātvamupacaryata ityāha maṇivat pācakavad vā iti / yathā maṇeḥ svarūpāparityāgenaivopādhibhedādupacaryate nānātvaṃ pīto raktaḥ iti / tadvadihāpi bhinnakriyopādhivaśād vartamānādibheda iti / yathā vā svarūpāparityāgenaiva puruṣasya nānākriyāvaśāt pācakādibhedastadvadihāpīti / vāstave hi bhede bādhakopapatteḥ / tathā hi yadi vartamānādervāstavo bhedo vyāpakatvañca syād ekasya vastuno 'nekakālasambandhād avyapadeśyatā prasajyeta / na hi vartamānena vyapadeśo 'tītānāgatābhyāmapi sambandhāt / nāpyatītenetarābhyāmapi sambandhād avyāpakatvam / tarhi nānekasya puruṣasyaikasminneva deśe 'tītānāgatavartamānapratyayāḥ prāpnuvanti / te tathā dṛṣṭāḥ / tathā caikasya vidyamānakriyopalambhādekasminneva deśe vartamānapratyayaḥ / tatraivānyasya kriyoparamādatītapratyayaḥ / anyasya cotpadyamānakriyopalambhādanāgata iti / kriyāvaśādeva nānāpratyayajanakatvaṃ na punarvāstavo 'sya bheda iti sthitam /
analyzed: atha katham nānātvam upacaryate iti āha maṇi vat pācaka vat vā iti yathā maṇeḥ sva rūpa aparityāgena eva upādhi bhedāt upacaryate nānātvam pītaḥ raktaḥ iti tadvat iha api bhinna kriyā upādhi vaśāt vartamāna ādi bhedaḥ iti yathā vā sva rūpa aparityāgena eva puruṣasya nānā kriyā vaśāt pācaka ādi bhedaḥ tadvat iha api iti vāstave hi bhede bādhaka upapatteḥ tathā hi yadi vartamāna ādeḥ vāstavaḥ bhedaḥ vyāpaka tvam ca syāt ekasya vastunaḥ neka kāl
translated: Now, how is diversity figuratively applied? He says: like a gem or like a cook. Just as a gem, without abandoning its own nature, is figuratively spoken of as diverse due to the difference of limiting adjuncts, as yellow, red, etc., so here also, the difference of present, etc. is due to the difference of limiting adjuncts in the form of different actions. Or just as a person, without abandoning his own nature, is spoken of as diverse due to the difference of different actions, as cook, etc., so here also. For in real difference, the occurrence of contradiction is possible. Thus, if the difference of the present, etc. were real and all-pervading, then the inexpressibility of a single entity in relation to many times would result. For it cannot be expressed as present, because it is related to the past and future also. Nor can it be expressed as past, because it is related to the other two also. Then, in the case of a single person, the cognitions of the past, future and present would not be possible in a single place. But they are seen to be so. And thus, due to the perception of action in the present, the past and future would also be present.

original: dik pūrvāparādipratyayaliṅgā / mūrtadravyamavadhiṃ kṛtvā mūrteṣveva dravyeṣvetasmādidaṃ pūrveṇa dakṣiṇena paścimenottareṇa pūrvadakṣiṇena dakṣiṇāpareṇa aparottareṇa uttarapūrveṇa cādhastādupariṣṭācceti daśa pratyayā yato bhavanti sā digiti /PDhS
analyzed: diś pūrva apara ādi pratyaya liṅgā mūrta dravyam avadhim kṛtvā mūrteṣu eva dravyeṣu etasmāt idam pūrveṇa dakṣiṇena paścimena uttareṇa pūrva dakṣiṇena dakṣiṇa apareṇa apara uttareṇa uttara pūrveṇa ca adhastāt upariṣṭāt ca iti daśa pratyayāḥ yatas bhavanti sā diś iti pdhs
translated: Space is the cause of the notions of east, west, etc. Having taken a corporeal substance as the limit, these ten notions arise from it - this is in front, this is behind, this is to the south, this is to the north, this is to the southeast, this is to the southwest, this is to the northwest, this is to the northeast, this is below, this is above - that is space.

original: tasyāstu guṇāḥ saṃkhyāparimāṇapṛthaktvasaṃyogavibhāgāḥ / kālavadete siddhāḥ /PDhS
analyzed: tasyāḥ tu guṇāḥ saṃkhyā parimāṇa pṛthaktva saṃyoga vibhāgāḥ kāla vat ete siddhāḥ pdhs
translated: But its qualities are number, measure, separateness, conjunction, and disjunction. These are established like time.

original: digliṅgāviśeṣādañjasaikatve 'pi diśaḥ / paramarṣibhiḥ śrutismṛtilokavyavahārārthaṃ meruṃ pradakṣiṇamāvartamānasya bhagavataḥ saviturye saṃyogaviśeṣāsteṣāṃ lokapālaparigṛhītadikpradeśānāmanvarthāḥ prācyādibhedena daśavidhāḥ saṃjñāḥ kṛtāḥ /PDhS
analyzed: diś liṅga aviśeṣāt añjasā ekatve diśaḥ parama ṛṣibhiḥ śruti smṛti loka vyavahāra artham merum pradakṣiṇam āvartamānasya bhagavataḥ savituḥ ye saṃyoga viśeṣāḥ teṣām lokapāla parigṛhīta diś pradeśānām anvarthāḥ prācya ādi bhedena daśavidhāḥ saṃjñāḥ kṛtāḥ
translated: Although space is easily perceived as one due to the non-distinction of its mark, the supreme sages have given it ten names according to the different directions, such as east, which are the particular conjunctions of the sun as it revolves around Mount Meru to the right for the sake of the conduct of the Vedas, Smritis, and the world.

original: tato bhaktyā daśa diśaḥ siddhāḥ / tāsāmeva devatāparigrahāt punardaśa saṃjñā bhavanti / māhendrī / vaiśvānarī / yāmyā / nairṛtī / vāruṇī / vāyavyā / kauverī / aiśānī / brāhmī / nāgī ceti /PDhS
analyzed: tatas bhaktyā daśa diśaḥ siddhāḥ tāsām eva devatā parigrahāt punar daśa saṃjñāḥ bhavanti māhendrī vaiśvānarī yāmyā nairṛtī vāruṇī vāyavyā kauverī aiśānī brāhmī nāgī ca iti pdhs
translated: Then, the ten directions are established through devotion. Due to their very acceptance of deities, there are again ten names: Maindri, Vaishnavi, Yamya, Nairriti, Varuni, Vayavya, KauberI, Aishani, Brahmi, and NagI.

original: idānīṃ diśo 'vasaraprāptāyā lakṣaṇaparīkṣārthaṃ dik pūrvāparādipratyayaliṅgā ityādi prakaraṇam / digiti lakṣyanirdeśaḥ / pūrvāparādipratyayaliṅgeti lakṣaṇam / tathā pūrvaścāparaśca pūrvāparau / tāvādiryeṣāmiti tathoktāste ca te pratyayāśceti / te liṅgaṃ yasyāḥ sā tatheti /
analyzed: idānīm diśaḥ vasara prāptāyāḥ lakṣaṇa parīkṣā artham diś pūrva apara ādi pratyaya liṅgā ityādi prakaraṇam diś iti lakṣya nirdeśaḥ pūrva apara ādi pratyaya liṅgā iti lakṣaṇam tathā pūrvaḥ ca aparaḥ ca pūrva aparau tau ādiḥ yeṣām iti tathā uktāḥ te ca te pratyayāḥ ca iti te liṅgam yasyāḥ sā tathā iti
translated: Now, in order to examine the definition of the direction that has come to the occasion, the topic begins with The direction is indicated by the notions of east, west, etc. Direction is the indication of the object to be defined. Indicated by the notions of east, west, etc. is the definition. Thus, east and west are east and west. Those of which they are the beginning are said to be so. They are also notions. That of which that is the indication is so.

original: saṅgrahoktervivaraṇārthamāha mūrtamavadhiṃ kṛtvā mūrteṣveva dravyeṣu viṣayabhūteṣvetasmānmūrtadravyādidaṃ mūrtaṃ pūrveṇa dakṣiṇenetyādidaśa pratyayā yato nimittād bhavanti sā digiti / tathā ca digitarebhyo bhidyate / pūrvāparādipratyayaliṅgatvāt / yastu na bhidyate na cāsāvevam / yathā kṣityādiriti / vyavahāro vā sādhyaḥ /
analyzed: saṅgraha ukteḥ vivaraṇa artham āha mūrtam avadhim kṛtvā mūrteṣu eva dravyeṣu viṣaya bhūteṣu etasmāt mūrta dravyāt idam mūrtam pūrveṇa dakṣiṇena ityādi daśa pratyayāḥ yatas nimittāt bhavanti sā diś iti tathā ca diś itarebhyaḥ bhidyate pūrva apara ādi pratyaya liṅga tvāt yaḥ tu na bhidyate na ca asau evam yathā kṣiti ādiḥ iti vyavahāraḥ vā sādhyaḥ
translated: To explain what is stated in the Saṅgraha, he says: Having taken form as the limit, among only the material substances that are the objects, this form is to the east, south, etc. of that form. The ten notions such as from this cause these forms arise are direction. And thus direction is distinguished from the others, because it is the mark of the notions such as east and west. But what is not distinguished is not so, like earth, etc. Or the usage is to be established.

original: nanu ca pūrvāparādipratyayāḥ parasparāpekṣitayā mūrteṣveva bhavantītyasiddhaṃ lakṣaṇābhidhānam / naitadevam / parasparāpekṣitāyāmubhayābhāvaprasaṅgāt / tathā hi / yadi pūrvamapekṣya aparapratyayaḥ / aparañcāpekṣya pūrvapratyaya ityekābhāve 'nyatarābhāvādubhayābhāvaprasaṅgaḥ / na ca nirnimittaḥ / kadācidutpannatvādanvayavyatirekābhyāṃ mūrtadravyasya vyāpāropalabdheḥ / aṅgulyādivyapadeśāccālambanatvam / na ca tasyāviśiṣṭasya pratyayajanmani vyāpāraḥ / sarvatrāviśeṣeṇa pūrvādipratyayāviśeṣaprasaṅgāt /
analyzed: nanu ca pūrva apara ādi pratyayāḥ paraspara apekṣitayā mūrteṣu eva bhavanti iti asiddham lakṣaṇa abhidhānam  na etat evam paraspara apekṣitāyām ubhaya abhāva prasaṅgāt tathā hi yadi pūrvam apekṣya apara pratyayaḥ aparam ca apekṣya pūrva pratyayaḥ iti eka abhāve nyatara abhāvāt ubhaya abhāva prasaṅgaḥ na ca nirnimittaḥ kadācid utpanna tvāt anvaya vyatirekābhyām mūrta dravyasya vyāpāra upalabdheḥ aṅguli ādi vyapadeśāt ca ālambana tvam na ca tasya av
translated: But the notions of east, west, etc., occur only in relation to corporeal substances; so the definition is not established. This is not so. Because in mutual dependence, both would be non-existent. For if the notion of west depends on the notion of east, and the notion of east depends on the notion of west, then in the absence of one, the other would be absent, leading to the absence of both. And it is not without cause, because it arises sometimes. And by positive and negative concomitance, the operation of corporeal substances is observed. And because of designation by finger, etc., it is the object. And that, being undifferentiated, does not operate in the production of notions, because in all cases, without distinction, the notions of east, etc., would be undifferentiated.

original: atha mūrtadravyamevāvadhibhūtaṃ nimittamiti cet / na / tasya sarvapratyayeṣvaviśeṣāt / tathā hi tasya nimittatāyāṃ yatraiva pūrvapratyayastatraiva dakṣiṇādipratyayāḥ prasajyeran / aviśeṣāt / nāpi saṅketa eva nimittam / tasya hi nimittaṃ vinā sarvatrāpravṛtteḥ / tathā hyekaṃ nimittaṃ vinaikatra saṅketitaḥ pūrvaśabdo nārthāntare pravartate / athāsti pūrvādiśabdānāṃ saṅketapravṛtteḥ kāraṇamekaṃ yatsadbhāvādarthāntare 'pi pravṛttiriti cet / sā tarhi digiti / athāviśiṣṭatayā diśo na viśiṣṭapratyayajanakatvamiti cet / na / ekatve 'pi viśiṣṭasaṃyogavaśād viśiṣṭapratyayajanakatvamityanantaraṃ vakṣyāmaḥ /
analyzed: atha mūrta dravyam eva avadhi bhūtam nimittam iti ced na tasya sarva pratyayeṣu aviśeṣāt tathā hi tasya nimitta tāyām yatra eva pūrva pratyayaḥ tatra eva dakṣiṇa ādi pratyayāḥ prasajyeran aviśeṣāt na api saṅketaḥ eva nimittam tasya hi nimittam vinā sarvatra apravṛtteḥ tathā hi ekam nimittam vinā ekatra saṅketitaḥ pūrva śabdaḥ na artha antare pravartate atha asti pūrva ādi śabdānām saṅketa pravṛtteḥ kāraṇam ekam yat sadbhāvāt artha antare pi prav
translated: If it is argued that the material substance itself is the limiting adjunct, that is not so. Because it is not different in all the conditions. For, in its being the cause, if the previous condition is in the east, then the conditions in the south etc. would also be there, because there is no difference. Nor is convention itself the cause, because without a cause it does not operate everywhere. For, the word 'east', signified by a single cause, does not occur in another meaning. If it is argued that there is a single cause for the operation of the convention of the words 'east' etc., and that due to its existence there is operation in another meaning also, then that is the direction. If it is argued that the directions do not produce a specific cognition due to their non-difference, that is not so. We will say later that even in unity, the production of a specific cognition is due to the specific conjunction.

original: atha vikalpajñānatvānnirviṣayāḥ pūrvādipratyayā vāsanāvaśād bhavantīti cet / tanna / abādhyamānatvāt / abādhyamānaṃ jñānaṃ nirviṣayaṃ na bhavatyeva / śuklādivijñānavad viṣayasya cāṅgulyādivyapadiśyamānasyānvayavyatirekābhyāṃ vyāpāropalabdherityuktam / na ca vāsanaivātra nimittam / tasyā bodhavyatirekeṇāsambhavāditi pūrvanyāyāt / ato I / viśiṣṭapratyayāḥ pūrvāparādayo na viśiṣṭaṃ nimittamantareṇa bhavanti / na cānyannimittaṃ kṣityādirūpaṃ sambhavatītyato nimittāntarāsambhavād yadatra nimittaṃ sā digiti viśeṣaṇaviśeṣyaṃ nyāyaḥ / sarvotpattau kāraṇatvaṃ kālavad draṣṭavyam /
analyzed: atha vikalpa jñāna tvāt nirviṣayāḥ pūrva ādi pratyayāḥ vāsanā vaśāt bhavanti iti ced tat na abādhyamāna tvāt abādhyamānam jñānam nirviṣayam na bhavati eva śukla ādi vijñāna vat viṣayasya ca aṅguli ādi vyapadiśyamānasya anvaya vyatirekābhyām vyāpāra upalabdheḥ iti uktam na ca vāsanā eva atra nimittam tasyāḥ bodha vyatirekeṇa asambhavāt iti pūrva nyāyāt atas viśiṣṭa pratyayāḥ pūrva apara ādayaḥ na viśiṣṭam nimittam antareṇa bhavanti na
translated: If it is argued that the previous cognitions are objectless due to being conceptual cognitions arising from impressions, that is not so. Because they are not contradicted. A cognition that is not contradicted cannot be objectless, like the cognition of white etc. And it has been said that the object is perceived through concomitance and non-concomitance by the operation of the finger etc. indicated. And the impression itself is not the cause here, because it is not possible apart from the cognition, as stated by the previous reasoning. Therefore, the specific cognitions of east, west etc. do not occur without a specific cause. And no other cause in the form of earth etc. is possible. Therefore, due to the impossibility of any other cause, the cause here is direction. This is the logical rule of qualification and qualified. The causality in all production should be seen like time.

original: samavāyitvaguṇavattvapratipādanārthamāha tasyāstu guṇāḥ saṃkhyāparimāṇapṛthaktvasaṃyogavibhāgāḥ iti / tatra cātideśaṃ karoti kālavadete siddhāḥ iti / tathā digliṅgāviśeṣād viśeṣaliṅgābhāvāccaikatvaṃ diśaḥ siddham /
analyzed: samavāyi tva guṇavat tva pratipādana artham āha tasyāḥ tu guṇāḥ saṃkhyā parimāṇa pṛthaktva saṃyoga vibhāgāḥ iti tatra ca atideśam karoti kāla vat ete siddhāḥ iti tathā diś liṅga aviśeṣāt viśeṣa liṅga abhāvāt ca ekatvam diśaḥ siddham
translated: To establish its inherence and quality, it says its qualities are number, dimension, separateness, conjunction, and disjunction. And it extends the inference, these are established like time. Similarly, the oneness of directions is established due to the non-distinction of the direction-mark and the absence of a mark of distinction.

original: nanu pūrvāparādipratyayāḥ parasparaṃ vilakṣaṇasyaiva nimittasya pratipādakā iti nānātvameva yuktam / na / sahakārivailakṣaṇyenāpi pratyayavailakṣaṇyopapattirityuktanyāyāt / ato dravyatvādeva saṃkhyāyogasiddhau nānātve pramāṇābhāvād ekatvaṃ siddham /
analyzed: nanu pūrva apara ādi pratyayāḥ parasparam vilakṣaṇasya eva nimittasya pratipādakāḥ iti nānātvam eva yuktam na sahakāri vailakṣaṇyena api pratyaya vailakṣaṇya upapattiḥ iti ukta nyāyāt  atas dravya tvāt eva saṃkhyā yoga siddhau nānātve pramāṇa abhāvāt ekatvam siddham
translated: But the notions of east, west, etc. indicate a cause that is mutually distinct, so multiplicity alone is proper. Not so, because the difference in notions is possible even due to the difference in auxiliaries, as stated by the principle. Therefore, when multiplicity is established due to the substance itself, oneness is established due to the absence of evidence for multiplicity.

original: tenaikatvenānuvidhānāt sāhacaryādekapṛthaktvañceti / pūrvāparādipratyayānāṃ kāraṇe digākhyā iti vākyena paramamahattvam / tathā ca pūrvāparādipratyayāḥ sarvatra nimittaṃ vinā na sambhavantīti diśo vyāpakatvāt paramamahattvam / tathā kāraṇaparatvāt kāraṇāparatvācca paratvāparatve vai / sū / / / iti sūtreṇa saṃyogaḥ siddhaḥ / tathā hi kāraṇaparatvaṃ paratvotpādako dikpiṇḍasaṃyogaḥ / aparatvañcāparatvotpādako vivakṣita iti vakṣyāmaḥ paratvaparīkṣāyām / saṃyogaśca kṛtakatvādavaśyaṃ vināśītyāśrayavināśasya sarvatrāsambhavād vibhāgādapi naśyatīti vibhāgaḥ siddha ityatideśārthaḥ / tathā guṇavattvādanāśritatvācca dravyam / samānāsamānajātīyakāraṇāsambhavāccākāryatvena nityatvañceti draṣṭavyam /
analyzed: tena eka tvena anuvidhānāt sāhacaryāt eka pṛthaktvam ca iti pūrva apara ādi pratyayānām kāraṇe diś ākhyāḥ iti vākyena parama mahā tvam tathā ca pūrva apara ādi pratyayāḥ sarvatra nimittam vinā na sambhavanti iti diśaḥ vyāpaka tvāt parama mahā tvam tathā kāraṇa para tvāt kāraṇa apara tvāt ca paratva apara tve vai iti sūtreṇa saṃyogaḥ siddhaḥ tathā hi kāraṇa para tvam paratva utpādakaḥ diś piṇḍa saṃyogaḥ aparatvam ca aparatva utpādakaḥ viv
translated: Therefore, by the conformity with that oneness, the one-ness and separateness are due to association. The supreme greatness is stated by the sentence The directions are the cause of the notions of east, west, etc. Thus, the notions of east, west, etc. are not possible everywhere without a cause. Therefore, the directions have supreme greatness due to their all-pervasiveness. Similarly, the east and west directions are established by the sutra The east and west are due to the proximity and remoteness of the cause. Thus, the proximity of the cause to the east is the conjunction that produces the east direction, and the proximity of the cause to the west is the conjunction that produces the west direction. We will explain this in the examination of the east and west directions. And since conjunction is necessarily perishable due to being produced, and since the destruction of the substratum is not possible everywhere, it is established that conjunction is destroyed by disjunction. This is the meaning of the extension. Similarly, it should be seen that the directions are substances because they possess qualities and are not dependent on anything else, and are eternal because causes of the same and different kinds are not possible, and therefore are not effects.

original: athaikasyā diśaḥ prācyādivyavahāraḥ kathaṃ syādityāha digliṅgāviśeṣādañjasaikatve 'pi ityādi / tatra hi yadyapi diśo liṅgānāmaviśeṣānnānātvāprasiddhau añjasā mukhyayā vṛttyaikatvaṃ siddham / tathāpi saviturye saṃyogā lokapālaparigṛhītadikpradeśaiḥ saheti vibhaktivipariṇāmaḥ / yad vā bhagavataḥ saviturye saṃyogāste keṣāmiti vivakṣāyāṃ sambandhasyāpi vidyamānatvād yuktaiva ṣaṣṭhī /
analyzed: atha ekasyāḥ diśaḥ prācī ādi vyavahāraḥ katham syāt iti āha diś liṅga aviśeṣāt añjasā ekatve pi ityādi  tatra hi yadi api diśaḥ liṅgānām aviśeṣāt nānātva aprasiddhau añjasā mukhyayā vṛttyā ekatvam siddham tathā api savituḥ ye saṃyogāḥ lokapāla parigṛhīta diś pradeśaiḥ saha iti vibhakti vipariṇāmaḥ yat vā bhagavataḥ savituḥ ye saṃyogāḥ te keṣām iti vivakṣāyām sambandhasya api vidyamāna tvāt yuktā eva ṣaṣṭhī
translated: Now, how can there be the usage of one direction like east etc.? He says: Due to the non-distinction of the characteristics of directions, in simplicity, even in oneness, etc. There, although due to the non-distinction of the characteristics of directions, in the non-established plurality, simplicity, i.e. oneness is established by the primary meaning, still, the change of case endings is like this: The conjunctions of the sun with the regions of the directions occupied by the world guardians. Or, when there is the desire to know whose conjunctions with the sun are those, even the genitive case is proper because of the existence of the relation.

original: lokapālaparigṛhītadikpradeśānām iti / anvarthā anugatārthāḥ prācyādibhedena daśavidhāḥ daśaprakārāḥ / saṃjñāḥ kṛtāḥ paramarṣibhiriti / kimarthamityāha I / śrutismṛtilokavyavahārārtham / śrutiśca / smṛtiśca / lokaśceti tathoktāsteṣāṃ saṃvyavahārārthamiti / śrauto hi vyavahāraḥ vāyavyāṃ gavayamālabheta / smārtastu prāṅmukho bhuñjīta / laukiko 'pi asmadvṛddhāḥ prāṅmukhā yajante sma ityādivyavahārasya prasiddhyarthamiti /
analyzed: lokapāla parigṛhīta diś pradeśānām iti anvarthāḥ anugata arthāḥ prācya ādi bhedena daśavidhāḥ daśa prakārāḥ saṃjñāḥ kṛtāḥ parama ṛṣibhiḥ iti kimartham iti āha śruti smṛti loka vyavahāra artham śrutiḥ ca smṛtiḥ ca lokaḥ ca iti tathā uktāḥ teṣām saṃvyavahāra artham iti  / śrautaḥ hi vyavahāraḥ vāyavyām gavayam ālabheta smārtaḥ tu prāc mukhaḥ bhuñjīta asmad vṛddhāḥ prāc mukhāḥ yajante smaḥ ityādi vyavahārasya prasi
translated: The directions and their parts that are held by the Lokapālas, the names of which are tenfold, of ten kinds, according to the division into east etc., have been made by the great sages. For what purpose? He says: for the sake of usage in Śruti, Smṛti, and the world. Śruti, Smṛti, and the world are thus spoken of. For the sake of usage of those. For the sake of the well-known usage: One should sacrifice a gavaya in the northwest.  One should eat facing east. Even the worldly usage: 'Our elders worshipped facing east,' etc. For the sake of the well-known usage.

original: atha lokapālaparigṛhītadikpradeśaiḥ saṃyogo bhagavataḥ kathaṃ bhavatītyāha meruṃ pradakṣiṇamāvartamānasya iti / pradakṣiṇaṃ hi yathā bhavati tathā meruṃ paribhramato 'pi viśiṣṭasaṃyogāstadvaśācca prācyādivyavahāraḥ / anvayavyatirekābhyāmupalambhācca / tathā hi / udayasamaye saviturdikpradeśena yogāt prācīti vyavahāraḥ / tatra hi prāk prathamamañcatīti kṛtvā / evaṃ madhyāhnasamaye dikpradeśena saṃyogād dakṣiṇeti vyavahāraḥ / tathā cāparāhṇe tadyogāt pratīcīti ca / evamudīcyādiṣvapi vācyam /
analyzed: atha lokapāla parigṛhīta diś pradeśaiḥ saṃyogaḥ bhagavataḥ katham bhavati iti āha merum pradakṣiṇam āvartamānasya iti pradakṣiṇam hi yathā bhavati tathā merum viśiṣṭa saṃyogāḥ tad vaśāt ca prācī ādi vyavahāraḥ anvaya vyatirekābhyām upalambhāt ca  / tathā hi udaya samaye savituḥ diś pradeśena yogāt prācī iti vyavahāraḥ tatra hi prāk prathamam añcati iti kṛtvā evam madhyāhna samaye diś pradeśena saṃyogāt dakṣiṇā iti vyavahāraḥ tath
translated: Now, how does the connection with the regions of space that are held by the Lokapālas come about for the Blessed One? It is said: While circumambulating Mount Meru. For just as it is done in a clockwise direction, even while going around Mount Meru, there are superior connections, and the usage of east, etc. is based on that, by positive and negative concomitance and observation. For example, at sunrise, due to the connection with the region of space, it is called east. For there, it moves first, hence the name. Similarly, at midday, due to the connection with the region of space, it is called south. And likewise, in the afternoon, due to that connection, it is called west. The same should be said of north, etc.

original: nanvevaṃ tarhi sa evādityasaṃyogo 'stu pūrvādivyavahārasya nimittam / alaṃ diśaḥ kalpanayeti / na / ādityasyāpi pūrvāparādivyavahāraviṣayatve 'nyādityaparikalpanāyāmanavasthā syāditi nimittāntarameva nyāyyam / na cādityaparivartanaṃ sarvatra sambhavatīti tatra pūrvāparādivyavahārābhāvaprasaṅgaḥ / tasmādekāpyanekasaṃyogopacitā viśiṣṭavyavahārasamarthetyabhyupagantavyam /
analyzed: nanu evam tarhi saḥ eva āditya saṃyogaḥ u stu pūrva ādi vyavahārasya nimittam alam diśaḥ kalpanayā iti na ādityasya api pūrva apara ādi vyavahāra viṣaya tve nyāditya parikalpanāyām anavasthā syāt iti nimitta antaram eva nyāyyam na ca āditya parivartanam sarvatra sambhavati iti tatra pūrva apara ādi vyavahāra abhāva prasaṅgaḥ tasmāt ekā api aneka saṃyoga upacitā viśiṣṭa vyavahāra samarthā iti abhyupagantavyam
translated: If so, then let the conjunction with the sun itself be the cause of the usage of east, etc. Enough of postulating directions. No, because even if the sun is the object of the usage of east, west, etc., postulating another sun would lead to an infinite regress. Therefore, another cause is indeed proper. And since the rotation of the sun is not possible everywhere, it would follow that the usage of east, west, etc. would not exist there. Therefore, it must be accepted that even a single direction, accumulated with multiple conjunctions, is capable of specific usage.

original: ato bhaktyā upacāreṇa daśa diśaḥ siddhāḥ / tāsāñcopacaritadiśāṃ devatāparigrahavaśāt punardaśa saṃjñā bhavanti / mahendreṇa parigṛhītā māhendrī / vaiśvānareṇa parigṛhītā vaiśvānarītyevamanyāsvapīti /
analyzed: atas bhaktyā upacāreṇa daśa diśaḥ siddhāḥ tāsām ca upacarita diśām devatā parigraha vaśāt punar daśa saṃjñāḥ bhavanti mahendreṇa parigṛhītā māhendrī vaiśvānareṇa parigṛhītā vaiśvānarī iti evam anyāsu api iti
translated: Therefore, the ten directions are established figuratively, by extension. And those figurative directions have ten names again due to being grasped by deities. That grasped by Indra is Maindrī. That grasped by Agni is Āgneya. And so for the others.

original: ātmatvābhisambandhādātmā / tasya saukṣmyādapratyakṣatve sati karaṇaiḥ śabdādyupalabdhyanumitaiḥ śrotrādibhiḥ samadhigamaḥ kriyate / vāsyādaunāmiva karaṇānāṃ kartṛprayojyatvadarśanāt / śabdādiṣu prasiddhyā ca prasādhako 'numīyate /PDhS
analyzed: ātma tva abhisambandhāt ātmā tasya saukṣmyāt apratyakṣa tve sati karaṇaiḥ śabda ādi upalabdhi anumitaiḥ śrotra ādibhiḥ samadhigamaḥ kriyate karaṇānām kartṛ prayojya tva darśanāt śabda ādiṣu prasiddhyā ca prasādhakaḥ numīyate
translated: It is the self because it is related to the nature of the self. When it is subtle and imperceptible, it is cognized by the sense organs such as hearing, etc., which are inferred from the perception of sound etc. Just as the sense organs are seen to be employed by the agent in the case of a carpenter etc., and because of the well-known sound etc., the cognizer is inferred.

original: na śarīrendriyamanasāṃ caitanyam ajñatvāt / na śarīrasya caitanyam / ghaṭādivad bhūtatvāt kāryatvācca / mṛte cāsambhavāt / nendriyāṇām / I / karaṇatvāt / upahateṣu viṣayāsānnidhye cānusmṛtidarśanāt / nāpi manasaḥ karṇāntarānapekṣitve yugapadālocanasmṛtiprasaṅgāt / svayaṃ karaṇabhāvācca / pariśeṣād ātmakāryatvāt tenātmā samadhigamyate / śarīrasamavāyinībhyāñca hitāhitaprāptiparihārayogyābhyāṃ pravṛttinivṛttibhyāṃ rathakarmaṇā sārathivat prayatnavān vigrahasyādhiṣṭhātānumīyate / prāṇādibhiśceti /PDhS
analyzed: na śarīra indriya manasām caitanyam ajña tvāt  na śarīrasya caitanyam ghaṭa ādi vat bhūta tvāt kārya tvāt ca mṛte ca asambhavāt na indriyāṇām karaṇa tvāt upahateṣu viṣaya asānnidhye ca anusmṛti darśanāt na api manasaḥ karṇa antara anapekṣi tve yugapad ālocana smṛti prasaṅgāt svayam karaṇa bhāvāt ca pariśeṣāt ātma kārya tvāt tena ātmā samadhigamyate śarīra samavāyinībhyām ca hita ahita prāpti parihāra yogyābhyām pravṛtti nivṛttibhyām ra
translated: The sentience is not of the body, sense organs, or mind, because they are insentient. The body is not sentient, because it is an effect, like a pot, and because it is composed of elements. And because it is not possible when dead. Nor of the sense organs, because they are instruments. Because when they are impaired, and when the object is not present, memory is not seen. Nor of the mind, because if it did not require another sense organ, it would follow that one would simultaneously perceive and remember. And because it is itself an instrument. By elimination, it is inferred that the self is the cause of them. And by the two activities of engaging in what is beneficial and avoiding what is harmful, which are inherent in the body, the self is inferred to be the controller of the body, like a charioteer, because it is the one who makes the effort. And by the vital breaths, etc.

original: katham / śarīraparigṛhīte vāyau vikṛtakarmadarśanād / bhastrādhmāpayiteva / nimeṣonmeṣakarmaṇā niyatena dāruyantraprayokteva / dehasya vṛddhikṣatabhagnasaṃrohaṇādinimittād / gṛhapatiriva / abhimataviṣayagrāhakakaraṇasambandhanimittena manaḥkarmaṇā / gṛhakoṇeṣu pelakapreraka iva dārakaḥ / nayanaviṣayālocanānantaraṃ rasānusmṛtikrameṇa rasanavikriyādarśanād anekagavākṣāntargataprekṣakavad ubhayadarśī kaścideko vijñāyate /PDhS

original: sukhaduḥkhecchādveṣaprayatnaiśca guṇairguṇyanumīyate / te ca na śarīrendriyaguṇāḥ / kasmāt / ahaṅkāreṇaikavākyatvābhāvāt / pradeśavṛttitvādayāvaddravyabhāvitvād bāhyendriyāpratyakṣatvācca / tathāhaṃśabdenāpi pṛthivyādiśabdavyatirekāditi /PDhS

original: tasya guṇā buddhisukhaduḥkhecchādveṣaprayatnadharmādharmasaṃskārasaṃkhyāparimāṇapṛthaktvasaṃyogavibhāgāḥ ātmaliṅgādhikāre buddhyādayaḥ prayatnāntāḥ siddhāḥ / dharmādharmāvātmāntaraguṇānāmakāraṇatvavacanāt / saṃskāraḥ smṛtyutpattau kāraṇavacanāt / vyavasthāvacanāt saṃkhyā / pṛthaktvamapyata eva / tathā cātmetivacanāt paramamahat parimāṇam / sukhādīnāṃ sannikarṣajatvāt saṃyogaḥ / tadvināśakatvād vibhāga iti /PDhS

translated: Its qualities are: intelligence, pleasure, pain, desire, aversion, effort, merit, demerit, impressions, number, dimension, separateness, conjunction, and disjunction. In the chapter on the characteristics of the self, from intelligence to effort are established. Merit and demerit are not the qualities of other selves, as stated by the author. Impression is the cause of the production of memory, as stated. Number is stated by the rule. Separateness is also from the same. And thus, the highest dimension is stated by the statement of the self. Conjunction is due to the contact of pleasure etc. Disjunction is due to the destruction of that.

original: idānīmātmano lakṣaṇaparīkṣārtham ātmatvābhisambandhād ityādiprakaraṇam / ātmatvenābhisambandhaḥ / ātmopalakṣitaḥ samavāyo vā lakṣaṇamiti / tathā hyātmā / I / itarasmād bhidyate / ātmatvābhisambandhād / yastvitarasmādanātmano na bhidyate na cāsāvātmatvenābhisambaddhaḥ / yathā kṣityādiriti / na ca tathātmā / tasmād bhidyata iti / vyavahāro vā sādhyaḥ / tathā śabdārthanirūpaṇaparatvena pūrvavad vākyaṃ yojanīyam / tathā lakṣaṇasyākṣepapratisamādhānaṃ pūrvavad vācyam /

translated: Now, for the purpose of examining the definition of the self, the section beginning with because of the connection with the nature of the self [is presented]. The connection with the nature of the self. The definition is either the inherence characterized by the self, or the inherence characterized by the self. For thus, the self is distinguished from the other, because of the connection with the nature of the self. But that which is not distinguished from the other, the non-self, and is not connected with the nature of the self, like earth etc., is not so. And the self is not so. Therefore, it is distinguished. Or the usage is to be established. Thus, the sentence should be connected as before, with the purpose of determining the meaning of the word. Thus, the objection and solution regarding the definition should be stated as before.

original: nanu sarvametadasambaddham / ātmasadbhāve pramāṇābhāvāt / tathā hi na pratyakṣeṇopalabhyate rūpādivat / svabhāvānavadhāraṇāt / nāpyanumānamastyātmapratibaddhamityāśaṅkyāha tasya saukṣmyādapratyakṣatve sati karaṇaiḥ śabdādyupalabdhyanumitaiḥ śrotrādibhiḥ samadhigamaḥ kiyate iti / saukṣmyaṃ rūpaviśeṣaikārthasamavetamahattvādyabhāvo 'bhipreto nāṇuparimāṇasambandhitvam / ata eva tasyāpratyakṣatvam /
analyzed: nanu sarvam etat asambaddham ātma sadbhāve pramāṇa abhāvāt tathā hi na pratyakṣeṇa upalabhyate rūpa ādi vat svabhāva anavadhāraṇāt na api anumānam asti ātma pratibaddham iti āśaṅkya āha tasya saukṣmyāt apratyakṣa tve sati karaṇaiḥ śabda ādi upalabdhi anumitaiḥ śrotra ādibhiḥ samadhigamaḥ kiyate iti saukṣmyam rūpa viśeṣa eka artha samaveta mahat tva ādi abhāvaḥ bhipretaḥ na aṇu parimāṇa sambandhi tvam atas eva tasya apratyakṣa tvam
translated: But all this is irrelevant, because there is no evidence for the existence of the self. For it is not perceived by perception like form and so on, because its nature is not ascertained. Nor is there inference bound to the self. Anticipating this doubt, he says, When it is not perceived due to its subtlety, it is known by the ear and other sense organs inferred from the perception of sound and so on. Subtlety is intended as the absence of greatness and so on, which is the same as a particular form, not the relation to atomic size. For this very reason, it is not perceived.

original: nanu cāyuktametat / ahamiti pratyaye tasya pratibhāsanāt / tathā ca sukhyahaṃ duḥkhyahamicchāvānaham iti pratyayo dṛṣṭaḥ / na cāyamanumāpūrvakaḥ / liṅgaliṅgisambandhānusmaraṇavyāpārasyāsaṃvedanāt / nāpi śabdaḥ / tena vināpyutpadyamānatvāt / nāpi viparyayajñānametad / abādhyamānatvāt / nāpi saṃśayajñānam / tadrūpasyāsaṃvedanāt / ataḥ pramārūpatvādavaśyaṃ pramāṇāntarapratiṣedhe pratyakṣasyaiva vyāpāraḥ / na śarīrālambanam / antaḥkaraṇavyāpāreṇotpatteḥ / tathā hi / na śarīram / antaḥkaraṇaparicchedyam / bahirviṣayatvāt /
analyzed: nanu ca ayuktam etat aham iti pratyaye tasya pratibhāsanāt tathā ca sukhī aham duḥkhī aham icchāvān aham iti pratyayaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ na ca ayam anumā pūrvakaḥ liṅga liṅgi sambandha anusmaraṇa vyāpārasya asaṃvedanāt nā api śabdaḥ tena vinā api utpadyamāna tvāt nā api viparyaya jñānam etat abādhyamāna tvāt nā api saṃśaya jñānam tad rūpasya asaṃvedanāt atas pramā rūpa tvāt avaśyam pramāṇa antara pratiṣedhe pratyakṣasya eva vyāpāraḥ na śarīra
translated: But this is improper, because it appears in the cognition of 'I'. And thus it is seen that there is the cognition 'I am happy', 'I am unhappy', 'I am desirous'. And this is not preceded by inference, because the operation of remembering the relation between the inferential mark and the inferable property is not experienced. Nor is it verbal cognition, because it arises even without that. Nor is it a contradictory cognition, because it is not contradicted. Nor is it a cognition of doubt, because its form is not experienced. Therefore, because it is of the nature of valid knowledge, the operation of perception itself is necessary to negate another means of valid knowledge. It is not based on the body, because it arises by the operation of the internal organ. Thus, the body is not to be determined by the internal organ, because it is an external object.

original: nanvevaṃ kṛśo 'haṃ sthūlo 'ham iti pratyayastarhi katham / mukhye bādhakopapatterupacāreṇa / tathā hi / madīyo bhṛtyaḥ iti jñānavat madīyaṃ śarīram iti bhedapratyayadarśanād bhṛtyavadeva śarīre 'pyahamiti jñānasyaupacārikatvameva yuktam / upacārastu nimittaṃ vinā na pravartata ityātmopakārakatvaṃ nimittaṃ kalpyate / ātmani tu mukhyatvam / sukhīti jñānena samānādhikaraṇatvāt / tathā hi yatra sukhīti jñānaṃ tatraivāhamiti jñānasyopalambhaḥ / sukhādiyogaśca śarīrādivyatirekeṇātmanyeveti vakṣyāmaḥ /
analyzed: nanu evam kṛśaḥ ham sthūlaḥ ham iti pratyayaḥ tarhi katham mukhye bādhaka upapatteḥ upacāreṇa  tathā hi madīyaḥ bhṛtyaḥ iti jñāna vat madīyam śarīram iti bheda pratyaya darśanāt bhṛtya vat eva śarīre pi aham iti jñānasya aupacārika tvam eva yuktam upacāraḥ tu nimittam vinā na pravartate iti ātma upakāraka tvam nimittam kalpyate ātmani tu mukhya tvam sukhī iti jñānena samāna adhikaraṇa tvāt tathā hi yatra sukhī iti jñānam tatra eva aham iti jñānasya
translated: But then how is it that there is the idea, 'I am thin', 'I am fat'? It is in the primary sense, because the basis for contradiction is present. It is so because, like the knowledge 'my servant', the perception of difference as 'my body' is seen. Therefore, the knowledge of 'I' in the body is proper only as figurative, like the servant. But a figure of speech does not occur without a reason. Therefore, the reason is imagined to be the benefit to the self. But in the self, it is primary, because it is in the same relation as the knowledge of 'happy'. For, where there is the knowledge of 'happy', there is the perception of the knowledge of 'I'. And we will explain that the connection with happiness etc. is only in the self, apart from the body etc.

original: yaccedaṃ rūpādivat svabhāvānavadhāraṇāditi / tadasat / ahamiti svabhāvasya pratibhāsanāt / na cārthāntarasyārthāntarasvabhāvenāpratyakṣatvaṃ doṣaḥ / sarvapadārthānāmapratyakṣatāprasaṅgāt / na ca parakīye 'pyātmani aham iti pratibhāsaprasaṅgaḥ syāt / I / tasyātmāntarāpratyakṣatvāt / pratyakṣajañcedaṃ vijñānaṃ na pramāṇāntaraprabhavamityuktam / na cātmāntareṇātmāntarasyāpratyakṣatāyāṃ svātmano 'pi tathābhāvaprasaṅgaḥ / svasaṃvidā bādhyamānatvāt / nāpi rūpāntarasya saṃkhyādeḥ pratyakṣatāprasaṅgaḥ / tasya pratibhāsābhāvenāpratyakṣatvāt / tathā yatra hi rūpaviśeṣasya pratyakṣatvaṃ tatraiva saṃkhyādayaḥ pratyakṣā ityuktapūrvam /
