analyzed: yat ca idam rūpa ādi vat svabhāva anavadhāraṇāt iti tat asat aham iti svabhāvasya pratibhāsanāt na ca artha antarasya artha antara svabhāvena apratyakṣa tvam doṣaḥ sarva padārthānām apratyakṣa tā prasaṅgāt na ca parakīye pi ātmani aham iti pratibhāsa prasaṅgaḥ syāt tasya ātma antara apratyakṣa tvāt pratyakṣa jam ca idam vijñānam na pramāṇa antara prabhavam iti uktam na ca ātma antareṇa ātma antarasya apratyakṣa tāyām sva ātmanaḥ upi tathābhāva prasa
translated: And as for the argument that because its nature is not ascertained like that of color etc., that is not correct. Because the nature of I appears. And it is not a fault that one thing cannot be directly perceived by the nature of another thing, because it would lead to the absurdity that all things would be imperceptible. And it would not lead to the appearance of I in the other person's self, because that other self is not directly perceived. And it has been said that this cognition is born of perception, not from another means of knowledge. And when one self is not directly perceived by another self, it does not follow that the other self is also so, because that is contradicted by one's own cognition. And it does not lead to the absurdity that number etc., which are of a different form, are directly perceived, because they are not directly perceived due to the absence of their appearance. Thus, it has been said that where there is direct perception of a particular form, there number etc. are also directly perceived.

original: athātmanaḥ kartṛtvādekasmin kāle karmatvāsambhavenāpratyakṣatvam / tanna / lakṣaṇabhedena tadupapatteḥ / tathā hi / jñānacikīrṣādhāratvasya kartṛlakṣaṇasyopapatteḥ kartṛtvam / tadaiva ca kriyayā vyāpyatvopalabdheḥ karmatvañceti na doṣaḥ / lakṣaṇatantratvād vastuvyavasthāyāḥ / na cānayorekasmin dharmiṇyekasmiṃśca kāle kartṛkaraṇayorivāstu virodhaḥ / tathā hi svātantryaṃ kartṛtvaṃ pāratantryañca karaṇatvamiti tvanayorvidhipratiṣedharūpatvādabhinne dharmiṇyasambhavo yuktaḥ / na caivaṃ kartṛtvakarmatvayoriti /
analyzed: atha ātmanaḥ kartṛ tvāt ekasmin kāle karma tva asambhavena apratyakṣa tvam tat na lakṣaṇa bhedena tad upapatteḥ tathā hi jñāna cikīrṣā ādhāra tvasya kartṛ lakṣaṇasya upapatteḥ kartṛ tvam  / tadā eva ca kriyayā vyāpya tva upalabdheḥ karma tvam ca iti na doṣaḥ lakṣaṇa tantra tvāt vastu vyavasthāyāḥ na ca anayoḥ ekasmin dharmiṇi ekasmin ca kāle kartṛ karaṇayoḥ iva astu virodhaḥ tathā hi svātantryam kartṛ tvam pāratantryam ca karaṇa tvam i
translated: If it be said that it is not perceived because it cannot be an object at the same time that it is an agent, that is not so. Because that is possible by the difference of definition. Thus, because of the possibility of the definition of an agent as the substratum of knowledge and desire, it is an agent. And because of the perception of being pervaded by the action at that very time, it is an object. So there is no fault, because the determination of things depends on definition. And there is no contradiction in these two, like an instrument and an agent, in one substratum and at one time. Thus, because agency is independence and instrumentality is dependence, their form is affirmation and negation, so their impossibility in one substratum is proper. But it is not so for agency and instrumentality.

original: ata eva madīyaṃ śarīram ityādipratyayeṣvātmānurāgasadbhāve 'pyātmano 'vacchedakatvam / śraiharṣaṃ devakulam iti jñāne śrīharṣasyeva / ubhayatrāpi bādhakasadbhāvāt / yatra hyanurāgasadbhāve 'pi viśeṣaṇatve bādhakamasti tatrāvacchedakatvameva kalpyata iti / asti ca śrīharṣasya vidyamānatvamātmani iti kartṛtvakaraṇatvayorasambhava iti bādhakam /
analyzed: atas eva madīyam śarīram ityādi pratyayeṣu ātma anurāga sadbhāve pi ātmanaḥ vacchedaka tvam śraiharṣam devakulam iti jñāne śrīharṣasya iva ubhayatra api bādhaka sadbhāvāt yatra hi anurāga sadbhāve pi viśeṣaṇa tve bādhakam asti tatra avacchedaka tvam eva kalpyate iti asti ca śrīharṣasya vidyamāna tvam ātmani iti kartṛ tva karaṇa tvayoḥ asambhavaḥ iti bādhakam
translated: For this very reason, in the cognitions of 'my body' etc., even when there is the presence of self-love, the self is the qualifier. Like in the cognition 'the temple of Shriharsha', because there is a contradictory cognition in both cases. For where there is a contradictory cognition even when there is the presence of love in the case of qualification, there the relation of qualifier and qualified is imagined. And there is the contradictory cognition that the agency and instrumentality are impossible, because the existence of Shriharsha is present in the self.

original: na caikasminneva dharmiṇi kartrādivibhāgasyopalabdheravāstavatvameva nyāyyam / lakṣaṇabhedasya vāstavatvāt / yeṣāntu lakṣaṇabhedo nāsti teṣāmeva doṣa iti / kalpanājñānañca pūrvameva nirastamiti na kalpanā samāno 'samāropitā kāraṇādivyavasthā / tadevaṃ kartrādipravibhāgasya bhinnanimittatvādekasminnevātmanyanumānena pratyakṣeṇa vā paricchedyamānena tadeva kartṛtvaṃ na doṣāyeti /
analyzed: na ca ekasmin eva dharmiṇi kartṛ ādi vibhāgasya upalabdheḥ avāstava tvam eva nyāyyam lakṣaṇa bhedasya vāstava tvāt yeṣām tu lakṣaṇa bhedaḥ na asti teṣām eva doṣaḥ iti kalpanā jñānam ca pūrvam eva nirastam iti na kalpanā samānaḥ samāropitā kāraṇa ādi vyavasthā  / tat evam kartṛ ādi pravibhāgasya bhinna nimitta tvāt ekasmin eva ātmani anumānena pratyakṣeṇa vā paricchedyamānena tat eva kartṛ tvam na doṣāya iti
translated: And it is not proper that the division of agent etc. in one and the same substratum is unreal, because the difference in characteristics is real. For those who have no difference in characteristics, that alone is the fault. And the conceptual cognition has already been refuted earlier. Therefore, the determination of cause etc. is not the same as conceptualization. Thus, since the division of agent etc. has a different cause, when the self alone is to be determined by inference or perception, that very agency does not cause a fault.

original: nanvevamātmanyahamiti pratyayasya pratyakṣaphalatvāt tasya saukṣmyādapratyakṣatve satītyasambaddhaṃ vākyam / na / bāhyendriyavivakṣayā asyābhidhānāt / tathā hi kasmādātmā kṣityādivad bāhyendriyapratyakṣo na bhavatītyukte vākyaṃ sambadhyate / tasya saukṣmyād rūpaviśeṣaikārthasamavāyasya / mahattvasyānekadravyatvasahacaritasyābhāvānna bāhyendriyaI /pratyakṣatvam / tatra pratyakṣe 'pyapratyakṣābhidhānāllabhyate / tasmiṃśca sati karaṇaiḥ śrotrādibhiḥ samadhigamaḥ kriyate / śrotrādibhirityubhayatrāpi yojyam / tathā hi / śabdopalabdhiḥ / karaṇakāryā / kriyātvāt / chidikriyāvat / evaṃ śeṣeṣvapīti / tasya saukṣmyād yathoktāt karaṇaiḥ śrotrādibhirapratyakṣatve sati taireva liṅgabhūtaistasyādhigamaḥ kriyate /
analyzed: nanu evam ātmani aham iti pratyayasya pratyakṣa phala tvāt tasya saukṣmyāt apratyakṣa tve sati iti asambaddham vākyam na bāhya indriya vivakṣayā asya abhidhānāt tathā hi kasmāt ātmā kṣiti ādi vat bāhya indriya pratyakṣaḥ na bhavati iti ukte vākyam sambadhyate tasya saukṣmyāt rūpa viśeṣa eka artha samavāyasya mahat tvasya aneka dravya tva sahacaritasya abhāvāt na    tatra pratyakṣe pi apratyakṣa abhidhānāt labhyate tasmin ca sati karaṇaiḥ śrotra ādibhiḥ s
translated: But in this way, since the notion I with regard to the self is the result of perception, and since it is not perceived due to its subtlety, the statement because of its subtlety is unconnected. No, because this is stated with reference to the external sense organs. For when it is asked, Why is the self not perceived by the external sense organs like earth etc.? the statement is connected. Because of its subtlety, the inherence of the universal of form in one substance. Due to the absence of largeness, which co-occurs with the state of being many substances, it is not perceived by the external sense organs. There, even though it is perceived, it is stated as not perceived. And when that exists, its realization is accomplished by the sense organs such as the ear. By the ear etc. should be connected in both cases. For example, the perception of sound is the effect of the sense organ, because it is an action, like the action of cutting. Similarly in the rest. Therefore, because of its subtlety as stated, when it is not perceived by the sense organs such as the ear, its realization is accomplished by those very sense organs which become the inferential mark.

original: śrotrādīnāmapi sadbhāve 'numānamāha śabdādyupalabdhyanumitaiḥ iti / śabdasparśarūparasagandhopalabdhikriyābhiranumīyanta iti / tadanumitāni tairiti / tathā hi / śabdopalabdhiḥ / karaṇakāryā / kriyātvāt / chidikriyāvat / evaṃ śeṣeṣvapīti /
analyzed: śrotra ādīnām api sadbhāve numānam āha śabda ādi upalabdhi anumitaiḥ iti śabda sparśa rūpa rasa gandha upalabdhi kriyābhiḥ anumīyante iti tad anumitāni taiḥ iti tathā hi śabda upalabdhiḥ karaṇa kāryā kriyā tvāt chidi kriyā vat  /evam śeṣeṣu api iti
translated: He states an inference for the existence of the ear and so on, saying by the perception of sound and so on, inferred. They are inferred by the actions of perceiving sound, touch, form, taste, and smell. Those inferred by that are by them. It is like this. The perception of sound is the effect of an instrument, because it is an action, like the action of cutting. The same applies to the rest.

original: vyāptipratipādanārthamāha vāsyādīnāmiva karaṇānāṃ kartṛprayojyatvadarśanāt iti / yathā vāsyādīni karaṇāni kartṛprayojyānīti tadvacchrotrādīnyapi karaṇāni / tasmāt kartṛprayojyāni / tathā hi / śrotrādīni karaṇāni / kartṛprayojyāni / karaṇatvāt / vāsyādivaditi /
analyzed: vyāpti pratipādana artham āha vāsi ādīnām iva karaṇānām kartṛ prayojya tva darśanāt iti yathā vāsi ādīni karaṇāni kartṛ prayojyāni iti tadvat śrotra ādīni api karaṇāni tasmāt kartṛ prayojyāni tathā hi śrotra ādīni karaṇāni kartṛ prayojyāni karaṇa tvāt vāsi ādi vat iti
translated: In order to demonstrate the pervasion, he says because the instruments, like a razor and so on, are seen to be employed by an agent. Just as a razor and other instruments are employed by an agent, so too the ear and other sense organs are instruments. Therefore, they are employed by an agent. It is like this. The ear and other sense organs are employed by an agent, because they are instruments, like a razor and so on.

original: athātra sarvagatātmaprayojyatve sādhye sādhyavikalatvam / viparyaye vā siddhasādhanamiti / na / sarvānumāneṣu sāmānyenaiva sādhyasādhanabhāvopapatterviśeṣeṇānuvyāptyabhāve sarvānumānocchedaprasaṅgaḥ / pramāṇañcānumānamiti vakṣyāmastadadhikāre / siddhe ca kartṛsadbhāve tasya śarīrādivyatirekaḥ pariśeṣāt / tathā na paraṃ karaṇaiḥ śabdādiṣu prasiddhyā ca prasādhako 'numīyate / śabdādiṣu viṣayeṣu prasiddhirvijñānaṃ tayā prasādhakaḥ samavāyikāraṇamātmānumīyate / tathā hi / śabdādijñānam / kvacidāśritam / guṇatvāt / yo yo guṇaḥ sa sa āśritaḥ / yathā rūpādiḥ / tathā ca guṇo jñānam / tasmādāśritam / samavāyikāraṇapūrvakatvaṃ kāryatvād rūpādivadeva /
analyzed: atha atra sarvagata ātma prayojya tve sādhye sādhya vikala tvam viparyaye vā siddhasādhanam iti na sarva anumāneṣu sāmānyena eva sādhya sādhana bhāva upapatteḥ viśeṣeṇa anuvyāpti abhāve sarva anumāna uccheda prasaṅgaḥ pramāṇam ca anumānam iti vakṣyāmaḥ tad adhikāre siddhe ca kartṛ sadbhāve tasya śarīra ādi vyatirekaḥ pariśeṣāt tathā na param karaṇaiḥ śabda ādiṣu prasiddhyā ca prasādhakaḥ numīyate śabda ādiṣu viṣayeṣu prasiddhiḥ vijñ
translated: If it is argued that the probandum is absent in the subject or that the argument is superfluous if the opposite is accepted, it is not so. Because the relation of probandum and probans is possible only in a general way in all inferences, and if it is not so in a particular case, it would lead to the absurdity of the impossibility of all inferences. And we shall show that inference is a means of valid knowledge in the chapter on that subject. And when the existence of an agent is established, his separateness from the body etc. is inferred by elimination. Similarly, the existence of a cognizer is inferred from the existence of the cognition of objects like sound etc. and from well-known facts. The cognition of sound etc. is dependent on something, because it is a quality, whatever is a quality is dependent, like color etc. And cognition is a quality. Therefore, it is dependent. Its dependence on an inhering cause is inferred from its being an effect, like color etc.

original: atha śarīrādyāśritaṃ bhaviṣyatīti siddhasādhanamityāśaṅkyāha na śarīrendriyamanasām iti / tathā hi / pare manyante prāṇavaccharīre sati bhāvāt / tadabhāve cābhāvāccharīradharma eva caitanyamiti / evamindriyādiṣvapyūhyam / tanniṣedhārthaṃ na śarīrendriyamanasāṃ caitanyamiti / vyavahāre sādhye na sādhyāviśiṣṭo hetuḥ ajñatvāt iti / yad vā svasiddhāntopadarśanametat / asmatsiddhānte nāmīṣāṃ caitanyamiti / nanvevaṃ yadi śarīrasya caitanyaṃ nāsti tarhi kimarthaṃ parairuktaścaitanyaviśiṣṭaḥ kāyaḥ puruṣaḥ / tathendriyabhāvavyatirekānuvidhānādindriyāṇāñcetyāśaṅkyāha ajñatvāt iti / na hi viduṣo bādhakamupalabhamānasyaivaṃ vacāṃsi pravartanta iti / tathā manyanta ebhiriti I / manāṃsi śarīrendriyāṇyeva / teṣāṃ na caitanyaṃ tatkaraṇānāmajñatvāt / acetanakāraṇārabdhatvādityartha iti kecit /
analyzed: atha śarīra ādi āśritam bhaviṣyati iti siddha sādhanam iti āśaṅkya āha na śarīra indriya manasām iti tathā hi pare manyante prāṇa vat śarīre sati bhāvāt tad abhāve ca abhāvāt śarīra dharmaḥ eva caitanyam iti evam indriya ādiṣu api ūhyam tad niṣedha artham na śarīra indriya manasām caitanyam iti vyavahāre sādhye na sādhya aviśiṣṭaḥ hetuḥ ajña tvāt iti  yat vā sva siddhānta upadarśanam etat asmad siddhānte na amīṣām caitanyam iti  nanu evam yadi
translated: Now, if it is thought that it will be based on the body etc., the argument is superfluous. Fearing this, he says not of the body, senses or mind. Indeed, others think that consciousness is a property of the body, because it exists when the body exists and does not exist when it does not exist. The same should be inferred for the senses etc. To refute that, he says not of the body, senses or mind. If consciousness is to be established conventionally, the reason is not equivalent to the probandum, because of ignorance. Or this is a presentation of our own doctrine, that consciousness does not belong to these in our doctrine. If consciousness does not belong to the body in this way, then why did the others say that the person is the body qualified by consciousness? Similarly, the senses etc. are inferred to be different from the state of being a sense faculty etc. Fearing this, he says because of ignorance. Indeed, these statements do not proceed for one who knows and perceives the contradiction. Similarly, they think by these, the minds are the body and senses themselves.

original: atha karaṇānāmajñatvaṃ kutaḥ / kāryājñānāt / nanvevamitaretarāśrayatvam / na / ghaṭādikāryasyācetanatayobhayavādisampratipatteḥ karaṇānāmajñatvaṃ siddham / tajjātīyāśca paramāṇavaḥ śarīrārambhakā ityacetanakāraṇārabdhatve tasyāpyacetanatvam / evamindriyeṣvapi / yadi ca paramāṇuṣu caitanyaṃ syādekasminneva śarīre puruṣānantyāt pratisandhānādivyavahārocchedaprasaṅgāt /
analyzed: atha karaṇānām ajña tvam kutas kārya ajñānāt  nanu evam itaretara āśraya tvam na ghaṭa ādi kāryasya acetana tayā ubhaya vādi sampratipatteḥ karaṇānām ajña tvam siddham tad jātīyāḥ ca paramāṇavaḥ śarīra ārambhakāḥ iti acetana kāraṇa ārabdha tve tasya api acetana tvam evam indriyeṣu api yadi ca paramāṇuṣu caitanyam syāt ekasmin eva śarīre puruṣa ānantyāt pratisandhāna ādi vyavahāra uccheda prasaṅgāt
translated: Now, how is it known that the sense organs are not conscious? Because they are not conscious of their effects. But in that case there is mutual dependence. No, because it is agreed by both parties that the effect, such as a pot, is insentient, it is established that the sense organs are not conscious. And atoms of the same kind are the cause of the body. So if it is produced by an insentient cause, it too must be insentient. The same applies to the sense organs. And if consciousness were to exist in atoms, then in a single body there would be an infinite number of selves, leading to the undesirable consequence of the destruction of all notions of personal identity and so on.

original: śarīrendriyāṇāñca caitanyasyotpattāvanvayavyatirekau kāraṇatvādapi sambhavataḥ kathaṃ tadādhāratvamiti / athaivamadṛṣṭakalpanādoṣa iti cet / na / pramāṇopalambhāt / tathā hi pratyakṣavadanumeyasyāpyarthasyāstyeva sadbhāvaḥ /
analyzed: śarīra indriyāṇām ca caitanyasya utpattau anvaya vyatirekau kāraṇa tvāt api sambhavataḥ katham tad ādhāra tvam iti atha evam adṛṣṭa kalpanā doṣaḥ iti ced na pramāṇa upalambhāt tathā hi pratyakṣa vat anumeyasya api arthasya asti eva sadbhāvaḥ
translated: And in the case of the production of consciousness in the body and sense organs, concomitance and non-concomitance are possible even from the cause. How then can it be the substratum? If it is argued that in this way there is the fault of postulating the unseen, that is not so. Because it is perceived by valid means of knowledge. For just as perception exists, so too the object of inference exists.

original: tatra śarīrasya caitanyapratiṣedhārthamāha na śarīrasya caitanyam iti / atra tu caitanyasya pakṣīkaraṇe bhūtakāryatvamasiddhaṃ syāditi śarīrameva pakṣīkriyate / tathā hi / śarīram / paraparikalpitacaitanyaśūnyam / bhūtatvāt kāryatvācca / yad bhūtaṃ yacca kāryaṃ taccaitanyaśūnyam / yathā ghaṭaḥ / tathā ca śarīram / tasmādacetanamiti /
analyzed: tatra śarīrasya caitanya pratiṣedha artham āha na śarīrasya caitanyam iti  atra tu caitanyasya pakṣīkaraṇe bhūta kārya tvam asiddham syāt iti śarīram eva pakṣīkriyate tathā hi śarīram para parikalpita caitanya śūnyam bhūta tvāt kārya tvāt ca yat bhūtam yat ca kāryam tat caitanya śūnyam yathā ghaṭaḥ tathā ca śarīram tasmāt acetanam iti
translated: To refute the sentience of the body, he says The body is not sentient. But if sentience is taken as the subject, being an effect of the elements would be unestablished, so the body itself is taken as the subject. For example, the body is devoid of the sentience imagined by others, because it is an element and because it is an effect. Whatever is an element and whatever is an effect is devoid of sentience, like a pot. And the body is like that. Therefore, it is insentient.

original: anye tveka eva bhūtakāryatvāditi heturvivakṣita iti manyante / taccāsad bhūtatvādityuktenaiva vyabhicārābhāvāt / atha bhūtakāryatvādityukte 'styātmanā vyabhicāra iti cet / na / tasya sādhyatvāt / siddhe ca vyabhicāro bhavatīti / yasya cātmā prasiddhastaṃ pratyanumānopanyāso vyartha eva / tathā kāryatvādityukte nāsti vyabhicāra iti vyarthameva syād bhūtapadam / na ca cetanayā vyabhicāraḥ / tasyāścaitanyaśūnyatvena sapakṣatvāditi hetudvitayameva yuktam / avayavavyatyaye tūktameva pratisamādhānam /
analyzed: anye tu ekaḥ eva bhūta kārya tvāt iti hetuḥ vivakṣitaḥ iti manyante tat ca asat bhūta tvāt iti uktena eva vyabhicāra abhāvāt atha bhūta kārya tvāt iti ukte sti ātmanā vyabhicāraḥ iti ced na tasya sādhya tvāt siddhe ca vyabhicāraḥ bhavati iti yasya ca ātmā prasiddhaḥ tam prati anumāna upanyāsaḥ vyarthaḥ eva tathā kārya tvāt iti ukte na asti vyabhicāraḥ iti vyartham eva syāt bhūta padam na ca cetanayā vyabhicāraḥ tasyāḥ caitanya śūnyatvena sapakṣatvā
translated: Others, however, think that only one reason is intended, namely, because it is an effect of the elements. But that is not correct, because there is no fallacy of the reason being absent in the subject, since it has already been stated that it is an element. If it is argued that when it is said to be an effect of the elements, there is fallacy in the subject itself, that is not so, because that is what is to be proved. And fallacy occurs when something is established. And for one for whom the self is well-known, the statement of an inference is pointless. Similarly, when it is said because it is an effect, there is no fallacy, so the word element would be pointless. And there is no fallacy of consciousness, because that is a similar instance being devoid of consciousness. Thus only two reasons are appropriate. But if the parts are transposed, the same answer is given.

original: tathā mṛte cāsambhavāt iti / mṛtāvasthāyāṃ caitanyasya rūpādivadanupalabdherna śarīraviśeṣaguṇatvam / tathā hi caitamyam / śarīraviśeṣaguṇo na bhavati / sati śarīre nivartamānatvāt / ye hi sati śarīre nivartante te tadviśeṣaguṇā na bhavanti / yathā saṃyogādayaḥ / ye tu śarīraviśeṣaguṇāste tasmin sati na nivartante / yathā rūpādaya iti / na ca viśeṣaguṇatvapratiṣedhena sāmānyaguṇatvaprāptiḥ / pratiyogyapekṣitatvāt pakṣādivyavasthāyāḥ / tathā hi caitanyasya pareṇa śarīraviśeṣaguṇatvameveṣṭaṃ tasyaiva pratiṣedhaḥ I / kriyate / na cātra śarīrasyaiva pakṣīkaraṇam / mṛte cāsambhavāccaitanyasyeti hetorvyadhikaraṇatāprasaṅgāt / tathendriyāṇāṃ caitanyapratiṣedhaḥ / nendriyāṇāṃ caitanyaṃ karaṇatvād vāsyādivat / bhūtatvāt kāryatvādityapi draṣṭavyam / ito 'pi nendriyāṇāṃ caitanyam / tadupaghāte 'pi smṛtidarśanāt / na ca guṇivināśe guṇasya sadbhāvo dṛṣṭaḥ / tathā hi smaraṇam / indriyaguṇo na bhavati / tadvināśe 'pyutpadyamānatvāt / yo yadvināśe 'pyutpadyate sa tasya guṇo na bhavati / yathā ghaṭavināśe 'pi paṭarūpādiriti / tathā ca smaraṇamindriyavināśe 'pi bhavati / tasmānna tadguṇa iti /
analyzed: tathā mṛte ca asambhavāt iti mṛta avasthāyām caitanyasya rūpa ādi vat anupalabdheḥ na śarīra viśeṣa guṇa tvam tathā hi caitamyam śarīra viśeṣa guṇaḥ na bhavati sati śarīre nivartamāna tvāt ye hi sati śarīre nivartante te tad viśeṣa guṇāḥ na bhavanti yathā saṃyoga ādayaḥ ye tu śarīra viśeṣa guṇāḥ te tasmin sati na nivartante yathā rūpa ādayaḥ iti na ca viśeṣa guṇa tva pratiṣedhena sāmānya guṇa tva prāptiḥ pratiyogi apekṣita tvā
translated: And because it is not possible when dead. And because consciousness is not perceived in the state of death like color etc., it is not a quality of the body. Thus consciousness is not a quality of the body, because it ceases to exist when the body exists. Those which cease to exist when the body exists are not its specific qualities, like conjunction etc. But those which are specific qualities of the body do not cease to exist when it exists, like color etc. And the denial of being a specific quality does not imply being a general quality, because the determination of the subject etc. depends on the counter-correlate. Thus consciousness is held by the opponent to be only a specific quality of the body, and its denial is made. And here the body itself is not made the subject, because the reason and because consciousness is not possible when dead would lead to the fallacy of having a different subject.

original: yadi cendriyāṇāṃ caitanyaṃ syāt karaṇaṃ vinā kriyāyāścānupalabdheriti karaṇāntarairbhavitavyam / tāni karaṇānīndriyāṇi vivādāspadāni cātmāna ityekasminneva śarīre puruṣabahutvamabhyupagataṃ syāt / evañca sati devadattopalabdhe 'rthe yajñadattasyevendriyāntaropalabdhe 'rthe na syādindriyāntareṇa pratisandhānam / tattu dṛṣṭamato nendriyāṇāṃ caitanyam / yadi caikamindriyamaśeṣakaraṇādhiṣṭhāyakaṃ cetanamiṣyeta saṃjñābhedamātrameva syāt /
analyzed: yadi ca indriyāṇām caitanyam syāt karaṇam vinā kriyāyāḥ ca anupalabdheḥ iti karaṇa antaraiḥ bhavitavyam tāni karaṇāni indriyāṇi vivāda āspadāni ca ātmānaḥ iti ekasmin eva śarīre puruṣa bahu tvam abhyupagatam syāt evañca sati devadatta upalabdhe rthe yajñadattasya iva indriya antara upalabdhe rthe na syāt indriya antareṇa pratisandhānam tat tu dṛṣṭam atas na indriyāṇām caitanyam  / yadi ca ekam indriyam aśeṣa karaṇa adhiṣṭhāyakam cetanam iṣyet
translated: If the senses were conscious, there would have to be other instruments, because an action is not perceived without an instrument. Those instruments, the senses, are the subject of dispute, and the selves. Thus, it would be admitted that there are many selves in one body. And in that case, there would be no recollection by another sense organ of an object perceived by Devadatta's sense organ, just as there is none of an object perceived by Yajnadatta's sense organ. But that is seen, therefore the senses are not conscious. And if one sense organ were admitted to be conscious and to control all the other organs, there would be only a difference in name.

original: atha viṣayaguṇaścaitanyaṃ bhaviṣyatīti tanniṣedhārthamāha viṣayāsānnidhye cānusmṛtidarśanāt / tathā hi / viṣayāsānnidhye tadvināśe vā anusmṛtirdṛṣṭā / na ca tadguṇastadvināśe bhavatīti / atha manoguṇo bhaviṣyatīti tatpratiṣedhārthamāha nāpi manasaḥ / caitanyam / guṇaḥ / karaṇatvād vāsyādivat / yat kartṛmanastadapi sukhādyupalabdhau yadi karaṇāntaramapekṣeta saṃjñābhedamātrameva syāt / tathā hi / yat tatsukhādyupalabdheḥ karaṇaṃ tadevāntaḥkaraṇam / yaccetanaṃ manaḥ sa evātmā syāt / atha karaṇāntaraṃ nāpekṣate / tarhi karaṇāntarānapekṣitve yugapadālocanasmṛtiprasaṅgaḥ / tathā hi manasaścaitanye yugapad rūparasasparśaśabdajñānāni prasajyeran / cakṣurādīnāṃ manaḥsambandhe sati karaṇāntarānapekṣāṇāṃ svaviṣayaiḥ sambandhāt /
analyzed: atha viṣaya guṇaḥ caitanyam bhaviṣyati iti tad niṣedha artham āha viṣaya asānnidhye ca anusmṛti darśanāt tathā hi viṣaya asānnidhye tad vināśe vā anusmṛtiḥ dṛṣṭā na ca tad guṇaḥ tad vināśe bhavati iti atha manaḥ guṇaḥ bhaviṣyati iti tad pratiṣedha artham āha na api manasaḥ caitanyam guṇaḥ karaṇa tvāt vā asya ādi vat yat kartṛ manaḥ tat api sukha ādi upalabdhau yadi karaṇa antaram apekṣeta saṃjñā bheda mātram eva syāt tathā hi y
translated: Now, if consciousness is going to be a quality of the object, to refute that he says: And because memory is seen even when the object is not present. For thus, when the object is not present or when it is destroyed, memory is seen. And a quality of that does not exist when it is destroyed. Now, if it is going to be a quality of the mind, to refute that he says: Nor is consciousness a quality of the mind. Because it is an instrument, like a knife etc. If that which is the agent, the mind, also requires another instrument in the perception of pleasure etc., then there would be only a difference in name. For thus, that which is the instrument of the perception of pleasure etc. is indeed the internal organ. And that which is the conscious mind would be the self. But if it does not require another instrument, then in not requiring another instrument, there would be the contingence of simultaneous perception and memory. For thus, if the mind is conscious, there would be the contingence of simultaneous perceptions of form, taste, touch and sound. When the eye etc. are connected with the mind, if they do not require another instrument,

original: tathā hi / smṛtiyaugapadyañca karaṇānapekṣitvāt / na caikasya krameṇa kāryajanakatvam / pūrvasvarūpasyāparibhraṃśāt / nāpi yugapadeva sarvaṃ kṛtvā punarakaraṇe hetvabhāvāt / pratikāryañca pūrvasvarūpavyāvṛttyabhyupagame kṣaṇikatāprasaṅgaḥ /
analyzed: tathā hi smṛti yaugapadyam ca karaṇa anapekṣi tvāt  na ca ekasya krameṇa kārya janaka tvam pūrva svarūpasya aparibhraṃśāt  nā api yugapad eva sarvam kṛtvā punar akaraṇe hetu abhāvāt prati kāryam ca pūrva svarūpa vyāvṛtti abhyupagame kṣaṇikatā prasaṅgaḥ
translated: For thus: The simultaneity of memory is due to not depending on instruments. And one thing cannot produce effects in sequence, because its previous form is not destroyed. Nor is it that having done everything simultaneously, it does not do it again, because there is no reason. And if it is accepted that for each effect there is a cessation of the previous form, momentariness would follow.

original: atha karaṇasyāpi manasaścaitanyam / tanna / svayaṃ karaṇabhāvācca iti / tathā hi caitanyaṃ pradhānakriyā / sā ca kartari karmaṇi vā samavaiti na karaṇe bhavitumarhati / I / anupalambhāt / na hi karaṇaṃ pradhānakriyāśrayo dṛṣṭa iti / svakīyāpekṣayā tu sarvasya kartṛtvameveti / tadevaṃ pariśeṣādātmakāryatvāt caitanyasya / tenātmā samadhigamyate /
analyzed: atha karaṇasya api manasaḥ caitanyam tat na svayam karaṇa bhāvāt ca iti tathā hi caitanyam pradhāna kriyā sā ca kartari karmaṇi vā samavaiti na karaṇe bhavitum arhati anupalambhāt na hi karaṇam pradhāna kriyā āśrayaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ iti svakīya apekṣayā tu sarvasya kartṛ tvam eva iti tat evam pariśeṣāt ātma kārya tvāt caitanyasya tena ātmā samadhigamyate  /
translated: If the instrument also has consciousness, that is not so. Because it is itself an instrument. For thus: Consciousness is the principal action, and that inheres in the agent or the object, and cannot properly inhere in the instrument, because it is not perceived. For an instrument is not seen to be the substratum of the principal action. But from its own point of view, everything is only an agent. Thus, by elimination, consciousness is the effect of the self, and therefore the self is understood.

original: kaḥ punarayaṃ pariśeṣaḥ / prasakteṣu śarīrādiṣu jātyādiṣu viṣayeṣu caitanyapratiṣedhe tathā tadāśrayasya vyavasthāpanānnānātvādhigamādākāśādīnāmekatvenāprasakteḥ / śiṣyate ca dravyāntaramiti pariśeṣaḥ kevalavyatirekyanumānam / tathā ca jñānam / kṣitijalajyotirākāśadikkālamanovyatiriktadravyāśrayam / tadvṛttau bādhakapramāṇasadbhāve sati guṇatvāt / yastu tadvyatiriktāśrayo na bhavati na cāsau tadvṛttibādhakapramāṇasadbhāve sati guṇaḥ / yathā rūpādiḥ / na ca tathā jñānam / tasmād vyatiriktāśrayamiti /
analyzed: kaḥ punar ayam pariśeṣaḥ prasakteṣu śarīra ādiṣu jāti ādiṣu viṣayeṣu caitanya pratiṣedhe tathā tad āśrayasya vyavasthāpanāt nānātva adhigamāt ākāśa ādīnām ekatvena aprasakteḥ śiṣyate ca dravya antaram iti pariśeṣaḥ kevala vyatireki anumānam tathā ca jñānam kṣiti jala jyotiḥ ākāśa diś kāla manaḥ vyatirikta dravya āśrayam tad vṛttau bādhaka pramāṇa sadbhāve sati guṇa tvāt yaḥ tu tad vyatirikta āśrayaḥ na bhavati na ca asau tad v
translated: What, then, is this remainder? When consciousness is denied in the body, etc., which are connected, and in the objects such as birth, etc., by establishing the substratum in that way, the plurality of space, etc., is understood, and since they are not connected as one, the remainder is the inference of mere exclusion, which is the substratum of a different substance. And thus, knowledge is the substratum of a substance different from earth, water, fire, air, space, direction, time, and mind, because it is a quality, when there is an obstructing means of knowledge in its occurrence. But that which is not the substratum of that, and that quality is not when there is an obstructing means of knowledge in its occurrence, like form, etc. And knowledge is not like that. Therefore, it has a different substratum.

original: nanu sarvametadasambaddham / kṣaṇikatvenāśrayāśrayibhāvānupapatteḥ / tathā ca padārthānāmarthakriyayā sattvaṃ vyāptam / sā ca kramayaugapadyābhyāmakṣaṇikeṣu na sambhavati / krameṇa janakatvam / ekasvarūpatvāt / yadeva hi pūrvakāryotpattau svarūpaṃ tadevottarakāryeṣvapīti sarveṣāmekatāprasaṅgaḥ / kāraṇavailakṣaṇyaṃ vinā kāryavailakṣaṇyasyāśakyasādhanatvāt /
analyzed: nanu sarvam etat asambaddham kṣaṇika tvena āśraya āśrayi bhāva anupapatteḥ tathā ca padārthānām arthakriyayā sattvam vyāptam sā ca krama yaugapadyābhyām akṣaṇikeṣu na sambhavati krameṇa janaka tvam eka svarūpa tvāt yat eva hi pūrva kārya utpattau svarūpam tat eva uttara kāryeṣu api iti sarveṣām ekatā prasaṅgaḥ kāraṇa vailakṣaṇyam vinā kārya vailakṣaṇyasya aśakya sādhana tvāt
translated: But all this is irrelevant, because the relation of container and contained is impossible in the case of momentary things. And thus the existence of things is pervaded by their causal efficiency, and that is not possible in the case of non-momentary things, either successively or simultaneously. If it produces successively, then it is not of one and the same form, because that which is the form of the production of the first effect is the same in the case of the other effects also, there would be the contingence of all being one. Because the difference in the effects is incapable of being accomplished without the difference in the cause.

original: atha kāryavailakṣaṇyādeva jñāyate pratikāryaṃ pūrvasvarūpanivṛttāvanyadeva svarūpaṃ bhāvānāṃ bhavatīti / tarhi svarūpasyāvasthānānabhyupagamāt tathā'sattvaprasaṅgaḥ / athāvasthitasyāpi kramayaugapadyābhyāṃ sahakāriprāptau tathaiva janakatvamiti cet / na / tasya tasminnatiśayādhāyakatvenātiśayanivartakatvena ca tayoravyatirekādanyatvameva / vyatireke 'pi tadbhāve 'pi bhāvasya kathaṃ kāryasya janakatvaṃ dṛṣṭamiti / na hyarthāntarajanmanyarthāntarasya kriyājanakatvaṃ dṛṣṭamityanupakārake vastunyapekṣaiva na syāditi sahakāritvābhāvaḥ / atha sahakāriṇāmapi sahakāryantarādhīnaṃ sāmarthyam / tadapi yadi sahakāryantarādityanavasthaiva syāt / atha sahakāryantaraṃ vinaiva sahakāriṇāṃ svata eva sāmarthyamiti cedetaccānyatrāpi samānamityalam /
analyzed: atha kārya vailakṣaṇyāt eva jñāyate prati kāryam pūrva svarūpa nivṛttau anyat eva sva rūpam bhāvānām bhavati iti tarhi sva rūpasya avasthāna anabhyupagamāt tathā sattva prasaṅgaḥ atha avasthitasya api krama yaugapadyābhyām sahakāri prāptau tathā eva janaka tvam iti ced na tasya tasmin atiśaya ādhāyaka tvena atiśaya nivartaka tvena ca tayoḥ avyatirekāt anyatvam eva vyatireke pi tad bhāve pi bhāvasya katham kāryasya janaka tvam dṛṣṭam iti na hi artha antara janma
translated: If, on the other hand, it is known just from the difference in effects that for each effect, the form of the entities becomes different upon the cessation of the previous form, then, since the form is not accepted as persisting, there would be the undesirable consequence of it being non-existent in that way. If it is argued that even for what persists, the capacity to produce in that way exists when the cooperation of sequence and simultaneity is obtained, that is not so. Because of the non-difference of those two in terms of imparting an excess to that and in terms of removing the excess, there is indeed difference. Even in difference, how can the existence of the effect be produced when it exists? For the production of something different is not seen to be the production of the action of something different. Thus, dependence itself would not be on an unrelated object, so there would be no cooperation. If it is that even for the cooperators, the capacity is dependent on another cooperator, then that too would be from another cooperator, and there would be an infinite regress. If it is that the cooperators have their own capacity without another cooperator, then that is the same as the absence of cooperation.

original: tadevamakṣaṇikebhyo vyāvartamānārthakriyā svavyāptaṃ sattvaṃ gṛhītvā vyāvartata ityasanto 'kṣaṇikāḥ / tadevaṃ bādhakopalambhāt parapakṣa evākṣaṇikaśaṅkāvyavacchedasiddhau sattvameva kṣaṇikasādhanamiti / tathā nirhetukatvād vināśasyotpattyanantaramevābhāva iti kṣaṇikatvam /
analyzed: tat evam akṣaṇikebhyaḥ vyāvartamāna arthakriyā sva vyāptam sattvam gṛhītvā vyāvartate iti kṣaṇikāḥ  tat evam bādhaka upalambhāt para pakṣe eva akṣaṇika śaṅkā vyavaccheda siddhau sattvam eva kṣaṇika sādhanam iti tathā nirhetuka tvāt vināśasya utpatti anantaram eva abhāvaḥ iti kṣaṇika tvam
translated: Thus, the causal efficiency, which is excluded from the non-momentary, takes up the existence which it pervades and is excluded. Therefore, the non-momentary is non-existent. Thus, by the perception of the sublating [reason], the doubt about the non-momentary is excluded only in the opponent's position, and existence itself is the proof of momentariness. Thus, because destruction is without cause, it is non-existent immediately after origination, and so it is momentary.

original: nanu mudgarādivyāpāreṇa ghaṭādivināśasyotpādopalambhādayuktameva tat / na / ātmabhāga /saṅgatau tadvyāpārāt / yadi ca hetorarthāntarabhūto vināśa utpādyeta tadā tadabhāvasyānupalambho na syāt / tatsvarūpasyāparibhraṃśāt / tathā abhāvasyaiva kāraṇa /kāryajanakatvābhyupagame bhāvarūpatvaprasaṅgaśca /
analyzed: nanu mudgara ādi vyāpāreṇa ghaṭa ādi vināśasya utpāda upalambhāt ayuktam eva tat na ātma bhāga saṅgatau tad vyāpārāt  yadi ca hetoḥ artha antara bhūtaḥ vināśaḥ utpādyeta tadā tad abhāvasya anupalambhaḥ na syāt tad svarūpasya aparibhraṃśāt tathā abhāvasya eva kāraṇa kārya janaka tva abhyupagame bhāva rūpa tva prasaṅgaḥ ca
translated: But since the origination of the destruction of a pot, etc. is perceived due to the operation of a hammer, etc., that [reasoning] is not appropriate. No, because of the operation of that [hammer, etc.] in the connection with the part of the self. And if destruction, which is a different object from the cause, were produced, then its non-existence would not be non-apprehended, because the nature of that [destruction] would not be lost. Similarly, there would be the undesirable consequence that [destruction] would have the nature of an existent, if it were accepted that non-existence itself produces the cause and the effect.

original: na cārthāntaratvāviśeṣāt tasminnupajāte kasyacid bhāvasyānupalambho na sarvasyeti viśeṣaheturasti / nāpi kāraṇāpekṣitāyāmavaśyambhāvaḥ syāt / vastre rāgasyeva sāpekṣitvāvaśyambhāvitvayorvirodhāt / tathā hi vastre rāgaḥ sampadyamānaḥ kāraṇasadbhāvād bhavati / abhāve na bhavati / evaṃ kvacid vastuno vināśaḥ /hetupratibandhād abhāvād vā vināśitvamapi syāt / yadi cāvinaśvarasvarūpāṇāṃ ahetuto vināśo gaganādīnāmapi nityatayābhyupagatānāṃ vināśaḥ prasajyeta / atha naṅkṣorbhāvasya hetutā / tato vināśavat kiṃ tatkalpanayā / tatsvarūpatvādevāvaśyaṃ vināpi hetuṃ vināśo bhavatīti /
analyzed: na ca artha antara tva aviśeṣāt tasmin upajāte kasyacid bhāvasya anupalambhaḥ na sarvasya iti viśeṣa hetuḥ asti na api kāraṇa apekṣi tāyām avaśyambhāvaḥ syāt vastre rāgasya iva sāpekṣi tva avaśyambhāvi tvayoḥ virodhāt tathā hi vastre rāgaḥ sampadyamānaḥ kāraṇa sadbhāvāt bhavati abhāve na bhavati evam kvacid vastunaḥ vināśaḥ hetu pratibandhāt abhāvāt vā vināśi tvam api syāt yadi ca a vinaśvara svarūpāṇām ahetutaḥ vināśaḥ gagana ādīnā
translated: And there is no special reason why, when that [destruction] arises, the non-perception of any existent thing should not be universal. Nor would there necessarily be dependence on a cause, because of the contradiction between dependence and necessity. For thus, when the dye is being produced in the cloth, it exists due to the presence of the cause, and does not exist in the absence [of the cause]. In the same way, the destruction of some existent thing may be due to the obstruction of a cause, or due to the absence [of a cause]. If the destruction of things whose nature is not subject to destruction were causeless, then the destruction of space and other things accepted as eternal would follow. If the cause of the destruction of a perishable thing is [another] thing, then what is the use of postulating it, since destruction would necessarily occur even without a cause, just because of its own nature, like the destruction [itself]?

original: yadi karaṇakāryatvañca syād vināśasya kṛtakatvāt tadvināśe 'vaśyaṃ bhāvonmajjanaṃ syāt / tasmāt na tasya kiñcid bhavati na bhavatyeva kevalam iti bhāvalakṣaṇasthitadharmānāśa iti /
analyzed: yadi karaṇa kārya tvam ca syāt vināśasya kṛtaka tvāt tad vināśe vaśyam bhāva unmajjanam syāt tasmāt na tasya kiñcid bhavati na bhavati eva kevalam iti bhāva lakṣaṇa sthita dharma anāśaḥ iti
translated: If destruction were an effect of the cause, then when that is destroyed, the existence of the thing would necessarily reappear. Therefore, nothing happens to it; it simply does not exist. Thus, the non-destruction of the thing's inherent nature is established.

original: na cākṣaṇikatve pratyabhijñānaṃ pramāṇam / tasya kalpanājñānatvāt /
analyzed: na ca akṣaṇika tve pratyabhijñānam pramāṇam tasya kalpanā jñāna tvāt
translated: And recognition is not a valid means of knowledge for non-momentariness, because that is a conceptual cognition.

original: tadetat sarvamaviditārtham / kalpanājñānasya pūrvameva nirastatvāt /
analyzed: tat etat sarvam avidita artham kalpanā jñānasya pūrvam eva nirasta tvāt
translated: All this is of unknown meaning, because the conceptual cognition has already been refuted earlier.

original: atha sa evāyam iti jñāne viruddhollekhād ekatvamayuktam / tathā hi sa ityatītākāraṃ jñānam / ayam iti ca vartamānākāram / na ca viruddhākārayorekatra sambhavo dṛṣṭa iti /
analyzed: atha saḥ eva ayam iti jñāne viruddha ullekhāt eka tvam ayuktam tathā hi saḥ iti atīta ākāram jñānam ayam iti ca vartamāna ākāram na ca viruddha ākārayoḥ ekatra sambhavaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ iti
translated: If it is argued that in the cognition this is the same, oneness is not proper due to the contradiction of the two aspects, because this is in the present aspect, then it is said: It is not seen that two contradictory aspects exist in one thing.

original: tadasat / ākāravādapratiṣedhe pūrvānubhavajanitasaṃskārasmaraṇasahakārīndriyeṇa sa evāyam ityubhayollekhi jñānaṃ janyate / tasya cārthānvayavyatirekānuvidhānānnirviṣayatvamayuktam /
analyzed: tat asat ākāra vāda pratiṣedhe pūrva anubhava janita saṃskāra smaraṇa sahakāri indriyeṇa saḥ eva ayam iti ubhaya ullekhi jñānam janyate tasya ca artha anvaya vyatireka anuvidhānāt nirviṣaya tvam ayuktam
translated: That is not so. In the negation of the theory of aspects, the cognition this is the same is produced by the sense organ assisted by the memory born from the impression produced by the previous experience of both. And since that is in conformity with the presence and absence of the object, it is not proper to say it is without an object.

original: athāstu pratyabhijñānād avasthāyitvamarthānām / arthakriyākāritvantu katham / sahakārisānnidhye satīti / tathā hi krameṇa sahakārisadbhāve sati krameṇa janakatvam / I / yugapat sadbhāve ca yugapacceti / yaccoktam / kiṃ tasya sahakāriṇā kriyata iti / na kiñcit / kiṃ tarhi / sadbhāve kāryameva / anyathā sahakāritvāyogāt / yad vā tasya sāmarthyaṃ /rthyāt kārakasākalyameva kriyate tatsadbhāve kāryajananāt / asāmarthyantu vaikalyaṃ nivartate / sākalyavaikalyayoḥ parasparasadbhāvasthitivirodhāt / na ca tayorāvirbhāvatirobhāvābhyāmarthasya tathābhāvaprasaṅgaḥ / tayostadvyatirekāt /
analyzed: atha astu pratyabhijñānāt avasthāyi tvam arthānām arthakriyā kāri tvan tu katham sahakāri sānnidhye sati iti tathā hi krameṇa sahakāri sadbhāve sati krameṇa janaka tvam yugapad sadbhāve ca yugapad ca iti yat ca uktam kim tasya sahakāriṇā kriyate iti na kiñcid kim tarhi sadbhāve kāryam eva anyathā sahakāri tva ayogāt yat vā tasya sāmarthya ṛthyāt kāraka sākalyam eva kriyate tad sadbhāve kārya jananāt asāmarthyam tu vaikalyam nivartate sākalya vaikalyayoḥ paraspara s
translated: Now, let it be that the things endure because of recognition. But how can there be causal efficiency? When there is the presence of auxiliaries. For thus, when there is the presence of auxiliaries in succession, there is the production in succession; and when there is the presence simultaneously, there is the production simultaneously. And what was said - what is done by the auxiliary to that? Nothing at all. But then, the effect itself is in its existence. Otherwise, because of the impossibility of being an auxiliary. Or, the efficiency of that is made by the completeness of the causal factors, because the effect is produced when that exists. And the inefficiency is removed by the incompleteness. Because the completeness and incompleteness are mutually contradictory in the existence and non-existence of each other. And it is not that the thing becomes so by the manifestation and disappearance of those two. Because those two are different from that.

original: na ca sahakāriṇāmarthāntaratvāviśeṣād aviśeṣeṇa sarvabhāvasahakāritvam / niyatasyaiva sadbhāve bhāvavyatirekābhyāṃ kāryajanakatvadarśanāt / nāpi sahakāriṇāṃ sahakāryantarāt sāmarthyam / tannirapekṣāṇāmapi parasparasānnidhye tatsamudāyasyaikakāryajanakatvopalabdheḥ / dṛṣṭañca cakṣūrūpālokamanaskārāṇāṃ parasparasānnidhye satyekakāryajanakatvam /
analyzed: na ca sahakāriṇām artha antara tva aviśeṣāt aviśeṣeṇa sarva bhāva sahakāri tvam niyatasya eva sadbhāve bhāva vyatirekābhyām kārya janaka tva darśanāt nā api sahakāriṇām sahakāri antarāt sāmarthyam tad nirapekṣāṇām api paraspara sānnidhye tad samudāyasya eka kārya janaka tva upalabdheḥ dṛṣṭam ca cakṣu rūpa āloka manaskārāṇām paraspara sānnidhye sati eka kārya janaka tvam
translated: And it is not the case that all things are the cooperating causes of everything, without distinction, because cooperating causes are not different from each other. Because the production of an effect is seen to occur only when a specific [set of causes and conditions] is present, by the method of agreement and difference. Nor do cooperating causes derive their efficacy from another cooperating cause. Because even when [causes] are independent of each other, the collection of them is seen to produce a single effect when they are in mutual proximity. And it is seen that the eye, form, light, and attention produce a single effect when they are in mutual proximity.

original: na cātretarādhipatyenāntyāvasthāyāmatiśayaḥ sampadyata iti vācyam / avyatireke tadabhāvāt / na hi sa eva tasyaivātiśayo bhavatīti / tathātiśayarahitānāmatiśayajanakatvamiti kāryāntare 'pi na bādhāsti / athātiśayayuktānāmatiśayajanakatvam / evaṃ tarhi teṣāmapyanyasmādatiśayaḥ sampadyata ityabhyupagame 'navasthāyāṃ vivakṣitakāryānutpattiprasaṅgaḥ / tasmāt sahakāriṇāṃ parasparasānnidhyamevātiśaya iti yuktamutpaśyāmaḥ / tadevaṃ kāryavailakṣaṇyaṃ sāmagrīvailakṣaṇyād bhavatīti na pratikāryam anyatvaṃ bhāvānām /
analyzed: na ca atra itara ādhipatyena antya avasthāyām atiśayaḥ sampadyate iti vācyam avyatireke tad abhāvāt na hi saḥ eva tasya eva atiśayaḥ bhavati iti tathā atiśaya rahitānām atiśaya janaka tvam iti kārya antare pi na bādhā asti atha atiśaya yuktānām atiśaya janaka tvam evam tarhi teṣām api anyasmāt atiśayaḥ sampadyate iti abhyupagame navasthāyām vivakṣita kārya anutpatti prasaṅgaḥ tasmāt sahakāriṇām paraspara sānnidhyam eva atiśayaḥ iti yuktam utpaśyāmaḥ ta
translated: Nor can it be said that the last state is not produced by the predominance of something else, because there is no difference. For it is not that the same thing becomes the excess of the same thing. Similarly, there is no obstruction even in another effect, because of the production of excess by those devoid of excess. If it is the production of excess by those endowed with excess, then in that case, the excess of those is produced from another. Thus, in the acceptance of infinite regress, there is the undesirable consequence of the non-production of the intended effect. Therefore, we see it is proper that the excess is only the mutual presence of the auxiliaries. Thus, the difference in effects is due to the difference in the assemblage of causes. Therefore, the difference of things is not in respect of each effect.

original: yaścāyamakṣaṇikānāṃ kramayaugapadyābhyāmarthakriyāpratiṣedhaḥ sa viśeṣapratiṣedhasyāvaśyaṃ śeṣābhyanujñāyāṃ samartha iti prakārāntareṇārthakriyāprasaṅgaḥ / na ca tadasattvagrāhakaṃ pramāṇamastīti /
analyzed: yaḥ ca ayam akṣaṇikānām krama yaugapadyābhyām arthakriyā pratiṣedhaḥ sa viśeṣa pratiṣedhasya avaśyam śeṣa abhyanujñāyām samarthaḥ iti prakāra antareṇa arthakriyā prasaṅgaḥ na ca tad asattva grāhakam pramāṇam asti iti
translated: And this refutation of the operation of non-momentary things by sequence and simultaneity is certainly capable of implying operation in some other way, as a special refutation necessarily implies the acceptance of the rest. And there is no means of knowing their non-existence.

original: tathā parasparādhipatyena kāryajanakatvābhyupagamāt / rūpādīnāmekaikamanekarūpāderyugapat kāraṇamityabhyupagame yaugapadyapratiṣedhādeva tadantarbhūtaḥ kramo niṣiddha iti tasya svaśabdena punarvacanam punaruktameva syāt / tathā hi yathā rūpaṃ yugapad rūparasagandhasparśānārabhate tathā rasādayo 'pi / ekaikavivakṣāyāṃ tatraiva krama ityekasyaiva pratiṣedho vācyaḥ / na caikamekasmādevotpadyate tadārabhate ceti niyamaḥ sambhavati /
analyzed: tathā paraspara ādhipatyena kārya janaka tva abhyupagamāt rūpa ādīnām ekaikam aneka rūpa ādeḥ yugapat kāraṇam iti abhyupagame yaugapadya pratiṣedhāt eva tad antarbhūtaḥ kramaḥ niṣiddhaḥ iti tasya sva śabdena punarvacanam punaruktam eva syāt tathā hi yathā rūpam yugapad rūpa rasa gandha sparśān ārabhate tathā rasa ādayaḥ ekaika vivakṣāyām tatra eva kramaḥ iti ekasya eva pratiṣedhaḥ vācyaḥ na ca ekam ekasmāt eva utpadyate tat ārabhate ca iti niyamaḥ sa
translated: Similarly, because the production of effects by mutual dominance is accepted, if it is accepted that each of form etc. is the simultaneous cause of many forms etc., then the sequence included in that is refuted by the refutation of simultaneity itself, so the statement of it again with its own words would be mere repetition. For just as form produces form, taste, smell and touch simultaneously, so do taste etc. also. When one is specified, the sequence is there itself, so the refutation of only one should be stated. And it is not possible to have the restriction that only one is produced from only one and that it produces that.

original: na cānyathaikasya krameṇānekakāryajanakatvam / pratikṣaṇamanyatvābhyupagamāt / tasmāt / sahakārisadbhāve sati kramayaugapadyābhyāmarthakriyājananād akṣaṇikānāṃ nāsattvamiti I / nāpi nānātvamiti sattvāditi hetoravyatirekaḥ / na ca pakṣa eva tasya vyatirekaḥ / tasya rūpāntaratvāt / yaccedam akṣaṇikatvena virodhād bhāvatkapakṣa eva akṣaṇikaśaṅkāvyavacchedasiddho bādhaka ityetadasat / virodhipratipattimantareṇa virodhapratipatterayogāt / athākṣaṇikastadvirodhī pratīyata eva / sa tarhi pratipattirūpārthakriyākāritvād asanna bhavatīti kathamasyāsmād vyatirekaḥ / yadi cākṣaṇikaśaṅkāvyavacchedo bādhakādeva pratīyeta / sattvāditi hetorvaiyarthyaṃ syāt / tasyāpyatadrūpavyavacchedaviṣayatvāditi / atha maulena hetunā kṣaṇikatvameva sādhyate / tacca yadi svalakṣaṇādibhinnaṃ kathamanumānaparicchedyam / tasya hi sāmānyaviṣayatvāditi /
analyzed: na ca anyathā ekasya krameṇa aneka kārya janaka tvam pratikṣaṇam anyatva abhyupagamāt tasmāt sahakāri sadbhāve sati krama yaugapadyābhyām arthakriyā jananāt akṣaṇikānām na asattvam iti na api nānātvam iti sattvāt iti hetoḥ avyatirekaḥ na ca pakṣe eva tasya vyatirekaḥ tasya rūpa antara tvāt yat ca idam akṣaṇika tvena virodhāt bhāvatka pakṣaḥ eva akṣaṇika śaṅkā vyavaccheda siddhaḥ bādhakaḥ iti etat asat virodhi pratipattim antareṇa virodha pratipatt
translated: because it produces effects through succession and simultaneity when the cooperating factors are present, the non-momentary things are not non-existent. And because they are not different, the reason because of existence is not inconclusive. And it is not that the inconclusiveness is only with respect to the thesis, because that [thesis] is of a different form. And this statement that because of contradiction with non-momentariness, the refutation that establishes the exclusion of the doubt of non-momentariness is only with respect to your thesis is incorrect, because it is not possible to establish contradiction without understanding the contradictory. But if the non-momentary is indeed understood to be contradictory, then it cannot be non-existent because it performs the function of the form of understanding. So how can it be excluded from this [contradiction]? And if the exclusion of the doubt of non-momentariness were understood only from the refutation, then the reason because of existence would be pointless, because that [refutation] also has the excluded form as its object. Now,

original: na ca sattvāditi hetoḥ sapakṣavipakṣābhyāmanvayavyatirekābhyāmantareṇa gamakatvaṃ nyāyyam / asādhāraṇasyāpi gamakatvaprasaṅgāt / sarvasya ca pakṣāntarbhāvāt sapakṣavipakṣābhāva eva / atha kalpanāsamāropitatvāt pakṣādivyavasthāyāḥ kalpanāsamāropite sapakṣe 'nvayastadāropita eva vipakṣe vyatireka iti gamakatvam / evaṃ tarhi kalpanāsamāropitapakṣādivyavasthāpekṣaṃ kālpanikamanumānamityavāstavaṃ kṣaṇikatvameva syāt /
analyzed: na ca sattvāt iti hetoḥ sapakṣa vipakṣābhyām anvaya vyatirekābhyām antareṇa gamaka tvam nyāyyam asādhāraṇasya api gamaka tva prasaṅgāt sarvasya ca pakṣa antarbhāvāt sapakṣa vipakṣa abhāvaḥ eva atha kalpanā samāropita tvāt pakṣa ādi vyavasthāyāḥ kalpanā samāropite sapakṣe nvayaḥ tad āropitaḥ eva vipakṣe vyatirekaḥ iti gamaka tvam evam tarhi kalpanā samāropita pakṣa ādi vyavasthā apekṣam kālpanikam anumānam iti avāstavam kṣaṇika tvam eva s
translated: And the reason ‘because it exists’ cannot be said to be a valid probans, without the positive and negative concomitances with the corroboration of the sapakṣa (similar instance) and the vipakṣa (dissimilar instance); because in that case, the ‘uncommon’ reason also might be a probans; and as all things would be included under the ‘subject’ of the inference, there could be no such thing as the ‘dissimilar instance’. If it be held that “the positive concomitance of the probans lies in the assumed sapakṣa, and the negative concomitance lies in the assumed vipakṣa”,—then, in that case, the inference would be purely imaginary, based entirely upon assumptions, and hence it would not be a real entity; and the momentary character of things would be an impossibility.

original: atha vināśasya nirhetukatvena kṣaṇikatvam / tanna / nirhetukatvasyāpi katipayakālāvasthāyitvena / vināśe virodhābhāvāt / na ca nirhetukatvaṃ yuktam / bhāva ivābhāve 'pyanvayavyatirekābhyāṃ hetorvyāpāropalambhāt / atha mudgarādivyāpārāt kapālasantānasyotpādaḥ / na / tasya virodhyutpannatvāt / na ca kapālasantānastasyāvaraṇamiti / prāgiva tatkāle 'pyupalabhyeta / āvaraṇatve 'pi tadvināśe tasyopalambhaḥ syāt / na ca kapālasantānena ghaṭasya virodhaḥ / tatkāraṇatvāt kapālānām /
analyzed: atha vināśasya nirhetuka tvena kṣaṇikatvam tat na nirhetuka tvasya api katipaya kāla avasthāyi tvena vināśe virodha abhāvāt  / na ca nirhetuka tvam yuktam bhāve iva abhāve pi anvaya vyatirekābhyām hetoḥ vyāpāra upalambhāt atha mudgara ādi vyāpārāt kapāla santānasya utpādaḥ na tasya virodhi utpanna tvāt  / na ca kapāla santānaḥ tasya āvaraṇam iti prāk iva tad kāle pi upalabhyeta āvaraṇa tve pi tad vināśe tasya upalambhaḥ syāt na ca kapāla santānena ghaṭasy
translated: If, on the other hand, destruction is momentary because it is causeless, that is not so. Even causelessness lasts for some time, because there is no contradiction in destruction. And causelessness is not tenable, because the operation of a cause is observed in non-existence as well as in existence, through positive and negative concomitance. If it is argued that the series of potsherds arises from the operation of the hammer, that is not so. Because what is contradictory has already arisen. And the series of potsherds is not an obstruction to it. It would be perceived even at the time of it, as before. Even if it were an obstruction, it would be perceived upon the destruction of it. And the pot is not contradictory to the series of potsherds. Because the potsherds are its cause.

original: atha arthāntare vināśe bhāvasyopalambha ityuktam / tanna / tayoḥ sahāvasthitivirodhāt / tathā hi bhāve tūtpanne 'bhāvasyāgrahaṇam / tatkāle tu bhāvasyeti dṛṣṭam / nanvevaṃ ghaṭakāle tatprāgabhāvasya vināśe tasyāpyanyaḥ prāgabhāvastasyāpyanyo vināśa ityanavasthā syāt / tadbhāve 'pi na doṣaḥ kāryaniṣpatterdarśanāditi kecit /
analyzed: atha artha antare vināśe bhāvasya upalambhaḥ iti uktam tat na tayoḥ saha avasthiti virodhāt tathā hi bhāve tu utpanne bhāvasya agrahaṇam tad kāle tu bhāvasya iti dṛṣṭam nanu evam ghaṭa kāle tad prāgabhāvasya vināśe tasya api anyaḥ prāgabhāvaḥ tasya api anyaḥ vināśaḥ iti anavasthā syāt tad bhāve pi na doṣaḥ kārya niṣpatteḥ darśanāt iti kecid
translated: If it is said that the destruction of an existent thing is perceived as a different thing, that is not so. Because it is contradictory for them to coexist. For thus, when the existent thing is produced, the non-existence is not perceived. But at that time, the existent thing is perceived. If it is so, then at the time of the pot, there would be an infinite regress of the destruction of the prior non-existence of the pot, and of the prior non-existence of that destruction, and of the prior non-existence of that. Some say that even in that case, there is no fault, because the completion of the effect is seen.

original: anye tvanavasthāyāṃ kila kāryasya parisamāptirna syāditi ghaṭatatprāgabhāvavināśayoreka eva prāgabhāva iti manyante /
analyzed: anye tu anavasthāyām kila kāryasya parisamāptiḥ na syāt iti ghaṭa tad prāgabhāva vināśayoḥ ekaḥ eva prāgabhāvaḥ iti manyante
translated: Others, however, think that in an infinite regress, the completion of the effect would not occur, and therefore the prior non-existence of the pot and the destruction of the prior non-existence of the pot are the same prior non-existence.

original: guravastu ghaṭakāle tatprāgabhāvasyānupalabdheḥ sa eva tasya pratiṣedhaḥ / prāgabhāvastu ghaṭasyeti tayoḥ sahāvasthitivirodhāditi bruvate /
analyzed: guravaḥ tu ghaṭa kāle tad prāgabhāvasya anupalabdheḥ saḥ eva tasya pratiṣedhaḥ prāgabhāvaḥ tu ghaṭasya iti tayoḥ saha avasthiti virodhāt iti bruvate
translated: But the teachers say that at the time of the pot, the prior non-existence is not perceived, so that itself is its negation. But the prior non-existence is of the pot. Thus they say that because it is contradictory for them to coexist.

original: athābhāvasyārthāntaratvāviśeṣāt tasminnupajāte sarveṣāmanupalambhaḥ svāt / na / tasminnutpanne kasyacidanupalambhena tayoreva virodhasiddheḥ / yathā arthāntaratvāviśeṣe 'pi kiñcideva kāraṇaṃ kasyacideva kāryasya heturna tu sarvasyeti pratiniyamo dṛṣṭastadvad abhāvasya niyatenaiva bhāvena virodho dṛṣṭa ityadūṣaṇametat /
analyzed: atha abhāvasya artha antara tva aviśeṣāt tasmin upajāte sarveṣām anupalambhaḥ svāt na tasmin utpanne kasyacid anupalambhena tayoḥ eva virodha siddheḥ yathā artha antara tva aviśeṣe kiñcid eva kāraṇam kasyacid eva kāryasya hetuḥ na tu sarvasya iti pratiniyamaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ tadvat abhāvasya niyatena eva bhāvena virodhaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ iti adūṣaṇam etat
translated: If, on the other hand, non-existence is not different from other things, then when it arises, there would be non-apprehension of all things. No, because when it arises, the contradiction between those two is established by the non-apprehension of anything. Just as, even when there is no difference in being different from other things, it is seen that a certain thing is the cause of a certain effect, but not of everything, so the contradiction of non-existence is seen only with a certain existent thing. Therefore this is not a fault.

original: yaccedaṃ vināśasya kāraṇāpekṣitāyāmavaśyambhāvo na syāditi / vastre rāgasyeva sāpekṣitvāvaśyambhāvitvayorvirodhāt / tadasat / ekatra vyabhicāreṇa sarvatra tathābhāvasyānupalabdheḥ / tathā sāpekṣitve 'pi savitṛgrahanakṣatratārāṇāñcodayāstamayopalabdhernirapekṣatve ca udayānantaramevāstamayaḥ syāt / samarthasyopakṣepāyogāditi / avaśyañca uditasya saviturastamayo bhavatīti /
analyzed: yat ca idam vināśasya kāraṇa apekṣi tāyām avaśyambhāvaḥ na syāt iti vastre rāgasya iva sāpekṣi tva avaśyambhāvi tvayoḥ virodhāt tat asat ekatra vyabhicāreṇa sarvatra tathābhāvasya anupalabdheḥ tathā sāpekṣi tve savitṛ graha nakṣatra tārāṇām ca udaya astamaya upalabdheḥ nirapekṣa tve ca udaya anantaram eva astamayaḥ syāt samarthasya upakṣepa ayogāt iti avaśyam ca uditasya savituḥ astamayaḥ bhavati iti
translated: And this argument that if destruction requires a cause, it would not necessarily occur, because necessity and requiring something else are contradictory, like the dyeing of cloth, is not correct. Because the fact that something is so everywhere is not established by the contradiction in one place. Similarly, even when requiring something else, the rising and setting of the sun, planets, stars, and constellations are seen, and when they are not required, the setting would occur immediately after rising, because it is not possible for the capable to be delayed. And it is necessary that the risen sun sets.

original: athoktaṃ naṅkṣu /kṣorbhāvasya vināśābhyupagame kiṃ hetuneti / tatra vināśātmakatvāsambhavādavaśyaṃ naṅkṣu /kṣorvināśayogyasyaiva hetau sati vināśo na gaganāderiti / tathā svakāraṇāditthambhūta evotpanno bhāvo yenāsya avaśyaṃ vināśahetunā bhavitavyamiti /
analyzed: atha uktam naṅkṣu kṣoḥ bhāvasya vināśa abhyupagame kim hetunā iti tatra vināśa ātmaka tva asambhavāt avaśyam naṅkṣu kṣoḥ vināśa yogyasya eva hetau sati vināśaḥ na gagana ādeḥ iti tathā sva kāraṇāt ittham bhūtaḥ eva utpannaḥ bhāvaḥ yena asya avaśyam vināśa hetunā bhavitavyam iti
translated: Now, it is said: If the destruction of the thing is accepted, what is the reason for destruction? In that case, it is necessary that the thing to be destroyed is destroyed, because it cannot have the nature of destruction. Only that which is capable of being destroyed is destroyed when the cause is present, not space, etc. Similarly, an existent thing arises from its own cause in such a way that it must have a cause of destruction.

original: atha tarhi kāraṇādutpadyamānatvādabhāvasya bhāvādaviśeṣaprasaṅgaḥ / tanna / svarūpabhedasyopapatteḥ / yathā hi kāraṇādutpadyamānā rūpādayaḥ parasparaṃ svarūpabhedād bhidyante tathā abhāvo 'pi bhāvāditi / asti ca dravyādiṣaḍlakṣaṇālakṣitatvam bhāvapāratantryeṇa gṛhyamāṇatvamabhāvasya rūpamiti /
analyzed: atha tarhi kāraṇāt utpadyamāna tvāt abhāvasya bhāvāt aviśeṣa prasaṅgaḥ tat na sva rūpa bhedasya upapatteḥ yathā hi kāraṇāt utpadyamānāḥ rūpa ādayaḥ parasparam sva rūpa bhedāt bhidyante tathā bhāvāt iti  asti ca dravya ādi ṣaṣ lakṣaṇa a lakṣita tvam bhāva pāratantryeṇa gṛhyamāṇa tvam abhāvasya rūpam iti
translated: If that is so, then it follows that non-existence is not different from existence because it arises from a cause. That is not so. Because the difference in nature is established. Just as form, etc., which arise from a cause, differ from each other due to the difference in their own nature, so also non-existence from existence. And the nature of non-existence is that it is not characterized by the six characteristics such as substance, and is apprehended in dependence on existence.

original: athotpattimattvādabhāvasya vināśe bhāvonmajjanaprasaṅga ityuktam / tadā /tanna sadbhāvadharmavilakṣaṇatvādabhāvadharmāṇām / yathā cānutpattimataḥ prāgabhāvasya vināśastathotpattirdharmiṇo 'pi vināśasyāvināśa iti / na ca vināśavināśe bhāvonmajjanam / tasya atadrūpatvād atatkāraṇatvācca / tathā hi ghaṭavināśavināśo na ghaṭarūpo nāpi tatkāraṇamiti kathaṃ tasyonmajjanaprasaṅgaḥ /
analyzed: atha utpattimat tvāt abhāvasya vināśe bhāva unmajjana prasaṅgaḥ iti uktam tadā tat na sadbhāva dharma vilakṣaṇa tvāt abhāva dharmāṇām yathā ca anutpattimataḥ prāgabhāvasya vināśaḥ tathā utpattiḥ vināśasya avināśaḥ iti na ca vināśa vināśe bhāva unmajjanam tasya a tad rūpa tvāt a tad kāraṇa tvāt ca tathā hi ghaṭa vināśa vināśaḥ na ghaṭa rūpaḥ na api tad kāraṇam iti katham tasya unmajjana prasaṅgaḥ
translated: Now, if it is said that because non-existence has origination, there would be the consequence of the manifestation of existence upon the destruction [of non-existence], then that is not so. Because the properties of non-existence are different from the properties of existence. And just as there is destruction of prior non-existence, which has no origination, in the same way there is no destruction of the destruction, which is the property of the originated [thing]. And there is no manifestation of existence upon the destruction of destruction. Because it is not of that form and because it is not the cause of that. For thus, the destruction of the destruction of the pot is not of the form of the pot and is not its cause. So how could there be the consequence of its manifestation?

original: na ca bhāvasyāsattvam / pratyakṣādipramāṇairvyavasīyamānatvāt / tathā hi / iha bhūtale ghaṭo nāsti iti jñānamindriyabhāvavyatirekānuvidhānād indriyajam / na ca nirviṣayaḥ / ghaṭābhāvaviśiṣṭabhūtalālambanatvāt /
analyzed: na ca bhāvasya asattvam pratyakṣa ādi pramāṇaiḥ vyavasīyamāna tvāt tathā hi iha bhū tale ghaṭaḥ na asti iti jñānam indriya bhāva vyatireka anuvidhānāt indriya jam na ca nirviṣayaḥ ghaṭa abhāva viśiṣṭa bhū tala ālambana tvāt
translated: And existence is not non-existent, because it is ascertained by means of the means of valid knowledge such as perception. Thus, for example, the cognition there is no pot here on the ground is produced by the sense organs, because it conforms to the presence or absence of the sense organs. And it is not without an object, because it has as its object the ground qualified by the absence of the pot.

original: atha ghaṭaviviktabhūtalopalambha eva ghaṭānupalambho nābhāvāditi cet / avyatireke tu ghaṭāvaṣṭabdhe 'pi bhūtale syānnāstīti jñānam / tasmād ghaṭābhāvopalambha eva ghaṭasyānupalambho nopalambhābhāvamātramiti / na ca vināśānabhyupagame bhāvasya prāgiva paścādapyavasthānād anupalambho ghaṭate / atha kṣaṇasthāyitvādeva dvitīyakṣaṇe tasyānavasthānamiti / tarhi sa eva tasyābhāvo yatsadbhāve dvitīyakṣaṇe tasyānupalambha iti / anyathā hīndriyādestādavasthyād vināśābhāve nityasyānupalambho na syāt /
analyzed: atha ghaṭa vivikta bhū tala upalambhaḥ eva ghaṭa anupalambhaḥ na abhāvāt iti ced avyatireke tu ghaṭa avaṣṭabdhe bhū tale syāt na asti iti jñānam tasmāt ghaṭa abhāva upalambhaḥ eva ghaṭasya anupalambhaḥ na upalambha abhāva mātram iti na ca vināśa anabhyupagame bhāvasya prāk iva paścāt api avasthānāt anupalambhaḥ ghaṭate atha kṣaṇa sthāyi tvāt eva dvitīya kṣaṇe tasya anavasthānam iti tarhi saḥ eva tasya abhāvaḥ yat sadbhāve dvitīya kṣaṇe tas
translated: If it is argued that the perception of the ground free from the pot is itself the non-perception of the pot, not the absence, then in the absence of distinction, there would be the knowledge it does not exist even when the pot is present. Therefore, the perception of the absence of the pot is itself the non-perception of the pot, not merely the absence of perception. And if the destruction is not accepted, the non-perception is not possible, because the existence would remain as before even afterwards. If it is argued that it is due to the momentary nature itself that it does not remain in the second moment, then that itself is the non-existence of that, which is the non-perception of it in the second moment when it exists. Otherwise, due to the stability of the sense faculties etc., there would be no non-perception of the permanent in the absence of destruction.

original: yaccedaṃ na tasya kiñcid bhavati na bhavatyeva kevalam iti unmattabhāṣitametat / anutpannavināśasya pūrvamapyupalambho na syād vinaṣṭatvādeva / abhāvena cāvirodhe paścādapyavasthānamiti nityatvaṃ syāt / tathā kṣaṇikatve satyanubhaviturvinaṣṭatvādanyasya smaraṇaṃ na syāt / na hi devadattānubhūte 'rthe yajñadattasya smaraṇamiti /
analyzed: yat ca idam na tasya kiñcid bhavati na bhavati eva kevalam iti unmatta bhāṣitam etat anutpanna vināśasya pūrvam api upalambhaḥ na syāt vinaṣṭa tvāt eva abhāvena ca avirodhe paścāt api avasthānam iti nitya tvam syāt tathā kṣaṇika tve sati anubhavituḥ vinaṣṭa tvāt anyasya smaraṇam na syāt na hi devadatta anubhūte rthe yajñadattasya smaraṇam iti
translated: And this statement that it becomes nothing, it simply does not exist is the ravings of a madman. For what is unborn and perishable would not be perceived even before, because it would have perished. And if there is no contradiction with non-existence, it would remain afterwards also, and thus it would be eternal. Similarly, if it is momentary, there would be no recollection by another person, because the experiencer would have perished. For Yajnadatta does not have a recollection of an object experienced by Devadatta.

original: atha nānāsantāneṣu kāryakāraṇabhāvasyābhāvād asmaraṇam / ekaśca santāne buddhīnāmasti kāryakāraṇabhāva ityāhitasakalapūrvavāsanākaṃ kāryajñānamutpadyate iti kārakānubhūte 'rthe tasya smaraṇaṃ yuktameva / naitadevam / kāryakāraṇabhāve 'pi nānātvasya tādavasthyād devadattādisantāneṣviva kathaṃ syāt smaraṇam / na ca santānasadbhāve pramāṇamasti / buddherbuddhyantarakāryatve pramāṇābhāvāt /
analyzed: atha nānā santāneṣu kārya kāraṇa bhāvasya abhāvāt asmaraṇam ekaḥ ca santāne buddhīnām asti kārya kāraṇa bhāvaḥ iti āhita sakala pūrva vāsanākam kārya jñānam utpadyate iti kāraka anubhūte rthe tasya smaraṇam yuktam eva na etat evam kārya kāraṇa bhāve pi nānātvasya tādavasthyāt devadatta ādi santāneṣu iva katham syāt smaraṇam na ca santāna sadbhāve pramāṇam asti buddheḥ buddhi antara kārya tve pramāṇa abhāvāt
translated: If, on the other hand, the non-recollection is due to the absence of the relation of cause and effect between the cognitions in different ‘chains’, and the relation of cause and effect is there in the case of cognitions in the same ‘chain’, then the resultant cognition, born of the impressions of all the previous cognitions, would be the cause of the recollection of the object that has been experienced; and in that case, the said recollection would be quite proper. This is not so; because even when the relation of cause and effect is there, the diversity remains as before; how then could there be recollection in the case of Devadatta, of what has been experienced by Yajñadatta? Nor is there any proof for the existence of the ‘Chain’; because there is no proof for the idea that one cognition is the cause of another cognition.

original: athāsti bodhād bodharūpatā iti cet / tathā hi bodharūpaṃ kāryaṃ bodhādeva bhavati yathā śuklācchuklamityādi / nanvevaṃ tarhi dhūmasyāgnijanyatvaṃ na syāt / samānajātīyasya dhūmakṣaṇasya bhāvāt / atha vilakṣaṇādapyagnikṣaṇād dhūmasyotpattiriṣyeta / bodhasyāpi vilakṣaṇāccharīrāderutpattirbhaviṣyatīti na bodhāntarasadbhāve pramāṇamasti / atha kiñcitsadṛśatayā agnirdhūmasya kāraṇaṃ tadā jñānotpattau śarīrādāvapi samānam / tathā kṛṣṇādapi śuklasyotpattirbhavet kiñcit sādṛśyasadbhāvāt /
analyzed: atha asti bodhāt bodha rūpa tā iti ced tathā hi bodha rūpam kāryam bodhāt eva bhavati yathā śuklāt śuklam ityādi  nanu evam tarhi dhūmasya agni janya tvam na syāt samāna jātīyasya dhūma kṣaṇasya bhāvāt atha vilakṣaṇāt api agni kṣaṇāt dhūmasya utpattiḥ iṣyeta bodhasya api vilakṣaṇāt śarīra ādeḥ utpattiḥ bhaviṣyati iti na bodha antara sadbhāve pramāṇam asti atha kiñcid sadṛśa tayā agniḥ dhūmasya kāraṇam tadā jñāna utpattau śarīra ādau
translated: If it is argued that the nature of consciousness is due to consciousness itself, then it is said that an effect having the nature of consciousness arises only from consciousness, just as white arises from white, etc. If so, then the smoke would not be produced from fire, because the momentary smoke of the same class exists. If it is accepted that smoke arises even from a fire-moment of a different class, then the production of consciousness would occur even from a body, etc. of a different class. Thus there is no evidence for the existence of another consciousness. If fire is the cause of smoke by some similarity, then the same applies to the production of knowledge in the body, etc. Similarly, white could arise even from black, because of the existence of some similarity.

original: atyantasamānajātīyañca samanantarakāraṇamityabhyupagamyamāne rūpajñānādeva rūpajñānaṃ rasajñānādeva rasajñānaṃ sukhādeva sukhaṃ duḥkhādeva duḥkhamiti santānānantyaṃ syānna cāsti saṃvedanamiti / athaiteṣāṃ yugapadasaṃvedanam ananubhūyamānakṣaṇānāmutpatteḥ / tarhi tena vinā tasyānutpattestatsantāno 'pyabhyupagantavyaḥ / tathā ca sati tadaiva teṣāṃ saṃvedanañceti prāptam / na caitadasti / tasmānna sarvaṃ jñānaṃ jñānāntarajanyamiti pratibandho 'sti /
analyzed: atyanta samāna jātīyam ca samanantara kāraṇam iti abhyupagamyamāne rūpa jñānāt eva rūpa jñānam rasa jñānāt eva rasa jñānam sukhāt eva sukham duḥkhāt eva duḥkham iti santāna ānantyam syāt na ca asti saṃvedanam iti atha eteṣām yugapad asaṃvedanam ananubhūyamāna kṣaṇānām utpatteḥ tarhi tena vinā tasya anutpatteḥ tad santānaḥ u pi abhyupagantavyaḥ tathā ca sati tadā eva teṣām saṃvedanam ca iti prāptam na ca etat asti tasmāt na sarvam jñānam jñān
translated: And if it is accepted that the immediately preceding cause is of a completely similar kind, then from a cognition of form there would be only a cognition of form, from a cognition of taste there would be only a cognition of taste, from pleasure there would be only pleasure, and from pain there would be only pain. There would be an infinite series of cognitions, but there is no cognition of them. If it is argued that these are not simultaneously experienced, and that the moments not experienced arise, then it must be accepted that there is a series of them, since they do not arise without that. And if that is so, it follows that they are experienced at that very time. But this is not the case. Therefore, not all cognition is produced by another cognition. There is a restriction.

original: na ca vināśasyāvyatirekād anubhavasyāvasthāne smaraṇaṃ yuktam / atha dvitīyakṣaṇe tasyānubhavasyābhāvād anavasthānamiti cet / na / avyatireke hi tenāvirodhād avasthānameva / vyatireke tu sahāvasthitivirodhābhyupagame 'smaddarśanānupraveśaḥ / tasmāt smaraṇamavasthitamātmānaṃ prasādhayatīti /
analyzed: na ca vināśasya avyatirekāt anubhavasya avasthāne smaraṇam yuktam atha dvitīya kṣaṇe tasya anubhavasya abhāvāt anavasthānam iti ced na avyatireke hi tena avirodhāt avasthānam eva vyatireke tu saha avasthiti virodha abhyupagame smat darśana anupraveśaḥ tasmāt smaraṇam avasthitam ātmānam prasādhayati iti
translated: And it is not proper that memory should remain when the experience remains, because the destruction is not different from it. If it be said that it does not remain because of the absence of that experience in the second moment, no (says the siddhāntin); for, if it is not different from it, it remains, because there is no contradiction with it. But if you admit that there is contradiction in the co-existence of the two, you have to enter our doctrine. Therefore, memory proves the existence of a permanent self.

original: na ca kṣaṇikatve sati kāryakāraṇabhāvo ghaṭate / tathā ca yadaiva kāryasyotpādastadaiva kāraṇasya vināśaḥ / sa cotpādānna bhidyata ityabhyupagame sahotpannayorna syāt kāryakāraṇabhāvaḥ savyetarayorviṣāṇayoriva / vinaśyadavasthañca kāraṇamiṣṭaṃ vaiśeṣikaiḥ / vināśasya hetumattvāt /
analyzed: na ca kṣaṇika tve sati kārya kāraṇa bhāvaḥ ghaṭate tathā ca yadā eva kāryasya utpādaḥ tadā eva kāraṇasya vināśaḥ sa ca utpādāt na bhidyate iti abhyupagame saha utpannayoḥ na syāt kārya kāraṇa bhāvaḥ savyetarayoḥ viṣāṇayoḥ iva  vinaśyat avastham ca kāraṇam iṣṭam vaiśeṣikaiḥ vināśasya hetumat tvāt
translated: And the relation of cause and effect is not possible if there is momentariness. And so, if there is the production of the effect, then there is the destruction of the cause. And that is not different from production. If you admit this, then there would be no relation of cause and effect between the two produced together, like the right and left horns of an animal. And the Vaiśeṣikas hold that the cause is in the state of destruction. Because destruction has a cause.

original: nirhetukavināśavādināñca bhāvavināśavyatirekeṇa vinaśyadavasthānaṃ sambhavatyeva tasya vināśakāraṇasākalyarūpatvāt /
analyzed: nirhetuka vināśa vādinām ca bhāva vināśa vyatirekeṇa vinaśyat avasthānam sambhavati eva tasya vināśa kāraṇa sākalya rūpa tvāt
translated: And for those who hold that destruction is without a cause, the state of being in the process of destruction is possible even apart from the destruction of the entity, because it consists of the totality of the causes of destruction.

original: nāpi svasaṃvidvādinaḥ kāryakāraṇabhāvagrahaṇamasti / kāraṇasaṃvidaḥ svātmanyeva paryavasānāt / tathā kāryasaṃvido 'pīti / na kāraṇajñānaṃ kāryasattāmanubhavati tatsattākāle tasyātītatvāt / na ca jñānāntaramekaṃ kāraṇasattākāle kāryasattāṃ tadabhāve cāsattāṃ vijānātīti /
analyzed: nā api svasaṃvid vādinaḥ kārya kāraṇa bhāva grahaṇam asti kāraṇa saṃvidaḥ sva ātmani eva paryavasānāt tathā kārya saṃvidaḥ api iti na kāraṇa jñānam kārya sattām anubhavati tad sattā kāle tasya atīta tvāt na ca jñāna antaram ekam kāraṇa sattā kāle kārya sattām tad abhāve ca asattām vijānāti iti
translated: Nor is there any apprehension of the relation of cause and effect for the proponents of self-awareness, because the awareness of the cause ends only in itself, and so does the awareness of the effect. Thus, the knowledge of the cause does not experience the existence of the effect, because at the time of its existence, the cause is past. And no single other knowledge knows the existence of the effect at the time of the existence of the cause and its non-existence at the time of its non-existence.

original: atha kāryakāraṇajñānābhyāṃ vāsanākrameṇāsti vikalpajñānaṃ kāryakāraṇabhāvagrāhakamiti cet / tasyāpyetadrūpasamāropatvābhyupagame 'pramāṇatvena kāryakāraṇabhāvasyāsiddhireva / tathā hi yad yatra samāropyate tat tatrāvāstavameva yathā śaṅkhe pītādiriti /
analyzed: atha kārya kāraṇa jñānābhyām vāsanā krameṇa asti vikalpa jñānam kārya kāraṇa bhāva grāhakam iti ced tasya api etad rūpa samāropa tva abhyupagame pramāṇa tvena kārya kāraṇa bhāvasya asiddhiḥ eva tathā hi yat yatra samāropyate tat tatra avāstavam eva yathā śaṅkhe pīta ādiḥ iti
translated: If it is argued that there is an inferential cognition that apprehends the relation of cause and effect through the sequence of impressions from the cognitions of cause and effect, then even that, if accepted as superimposing that form, is not a valid means of knowledge, and so the relation of cause and effect is not established. This is because whatever is superimposed on something is only unreal there, like yellow on a conch.

original: atha pūrvopalabdhānusandhānaṃ vikalpamiti cet / evaṃ tarhi kāryakāraṇabhāvagrahaṇaṃ vinā na vāsanā / tadabhāvāt tadadhyavasāyavikalpaḥ kathaṃ bhaviṣyatīti anubhavānurūpatvād vāsanāyāḥ / na ca bodhādanyā vāsanā sambhavatītyuktapūrvam / tasmādavasthitaṃ pratisandhātāramantareṇa tu kāryakāraṇabhāvasyāgrahaṇameveti / ayantu kṣaṇabhaṅgo 'smadgurubhirvistareṇa nirasta iti neha pratanyate / tadevamakṣaṇikatve satyāśrayāśrayibhāvasyopapattau satyāmetat pariśeṣād vijñānasyātmāśritatvamiti /
analyzed: atha pūrva upalabdha anusandhānam vikalpam iti ced evam tarhi kārya kāraṇa bhāva grahaṇam vinā na vāsanā tad abhāvāt tad adhyavasāya vikalpaḥ katham bhaviṣyati iti anubhava anurūpa tvāt vāsanāyāḥ na ca bodhāt anyā vāsanā sambhavati iti ukta pūrvam tasmāt avasthitam pratisandhātāram antareṇa tu kārya kāraṇa bhāvasya agrahaṇam eva iti ayan tu smat gurubhiḥ vistareṇa nirastaḥ iti na iha pratanyate tat evam akṣaṇika tve sati āśraya āśrayi bhāvasya upapa
translated: If it be said that the remembrance of what was previously perceived is the conceptual content, then, in that case, there can be no Impression (or Tendency) without the apprehension of the relation of Cause and Effect; and in the absence of this, how could there be the Conceptual Content in the form of the said ‘Determination’? Because the Impression is always in accordance with the experience (that produces it); and it has been already pointed out that there can be no Impression other than the Cognition itself. From all this it follows that in the absence of a permanent Cogniser, there can be no apprehension of the relation of Cause and Effect. As regards the doctrine of ‘Perpetual Flux’, it has been refuted by our great Teachers in detail; hence we are not setting forth that argument here. Thus then, when the non-momentary character of things has been discarded, and the relation of Cause and Effect is quite possible, the fact of Cognition being dependent upon the Soul follows by elimination.
