original: tathā pravṛttinivṛttibhyām ātmā jñāyate / kiṃviśiṣṭābhyām / śarīrasamavāyinībhyāṃ hitāhitaprāptiparihārayogyābhyām iti / hitaṃ sukhamahitaṃ I / duḥkhaṃ tayoḥ prāptiparihārau tadyogyābhyāṃ tatsamarthābhyāmiti / vyāptipratipādanārthamāha yathā rathakarmaṇā sārathī rathasyādhiṣṭhātā tadvadātmā vigrahasya śarīrasyādhiṣṭhātā'numīyate / tathā hi jīvaccharīram / prayatnavadadhiṣṭhitam / jīvaccharīrasamavāyihitāhitaprāptiparihārasamarthapravṛttinivṛttyāśrayatvāt / rathavat / pravṛttinivṛttyāśrayatvaṃ vāyvādau vyabhicaratīti hitāhitaprāptiparihārasamarthapadam / tathā śākhāyantranipīḍitasya prāṇinaḥ śākhākarma ahitanivartakam / adhastanasya phalādiprāpterhitaprāpakañceti tadarthaṃ śarīrasamavāyipadam / tathāpi nadīsrotaḥpatitaśavakarmaṇā vyabhicāraḥ / tadapyadhastanasya śunastadupayogāt sukhaṃ bhakṣyata iti sukhaprāpakam / upariṣṭācca snānaṃ kurvatastapasvino durgandhatayā duḥkhaṃ janayatīti tannivartakañceti tadarthaṃ jīvaccharīrapadam /
analyzed: tathā pravṛtti nivṛttibhyām ātmā jñāyate  kiṃviśiṣṭābhyām śarīra samavāyinībhyām hita ahita prāpti parihāra yogyābhyām iti hitam sukham ahitam duḥkham tayoḥ prāpti parihārau tad yogyābhyām tad samarthābhyām iti vyāpti pratipādana artham āha yathā ratha karmaṇā sārathiḥ rathasya adhiṣṭhātā tadvat ātmā vigrahasya śarīrasya adhiṣṭhātā anumīyate tathā hi jīvat śarīram prayatna vat adhiṣṭhitam jīvat śarīra samavāyi hita ahita prāpti p
translated: Similarly, the self is known through engagement and disengagement. What are their specific characteristics? They are fit for attaining the beneficial and avoiding the harmful, which are inherent in the body. The beneficial is happiness, the harmful is suffering. Attaining and avoiding those, which are fit for that, which are capable of that. To demonstrate the pervasion, he says: Just as the charioteer is the controller of the chariot through chariot-work, similarly the self is inferred to be the controller of the body, the physical form. Because the living body is controlled by an effortful controller, because it is the substratum of engagement and disengagement capable of attaining the beneficial and avoiding the harmful inherent in the living body, like a chariot. The substratum of engagement and disengagement is fallacious in the case of wind etc., hence the phrase capable of attaining the beneficial and avoiding the harmful. Similarly, for a living being squeezed by a tree-branch, the action of the branch is a cause of avoiding the harmful, and for the one below it, it is a cause of attaining the beneficial such as fruit, hence the phrase inherent in the body.

original: nanvevamapīdaṃ viśeṣaṇaṃ vipakṣādiva sapakṣāderapi rathādernirvṛttiṃ darśayatītyasādhāraṇatvameva syāt / na hi rathe jīvaccharīrasamavetakriyāśrayatvamasti / atha jīvaccharīrasamavāyihitāhitaprāptiparihārayogyā kriyā / prayatnavat kāryā / viśiṣṭakriyātvāt / rathakriyāvad iti / ihāpi na saviśeṣaṇasya hetoḥ sapakṣasadbhāvaḥ / tathā suptasya nāvārūḍhasya yathoktaviśeṣaṇakriyā abhipretena prāptihetuḥ / ahitena nivṛttihetuśca / na ca prayatnavatkāryeti vyabhicāraḥ / tasmād icchānuvidhāyikriyāśrayatvaṃ heturiti / tathā hi jīvaccharīram / prayatnavadadhiṣṭhitam / icchānuvidhāyikriyāśrayatvāt / dravyavat / rathavat / kriyā vā / prayatnavat kāryā / icchānuvidhāyikriyātvāt / rathakriyāvat /
analyzed: nanu evam api idam viśeṣaṇam vipakṣāt iva sapakṣa ādeḥ api ratha ādeḥ nirvṛttim darśayati iti asādhāraṇa tvam eva syāt na hi rathe jīvat śarīra samaveta kriyā āśraya tvam asti atha jīvat śarīra samavāyi hita ahita prāpti parihāra yogyā kriyā prayatna vat kāryā viśiṣṭa kriyā tvāt ratha kriyā vat iti iha api na sa viśeṣaṇasya hetoḥ sapakṣa sadbhāvaḥ tathā suptasya nāvārūḍhasya yathā ukta viśeṣaṇa kriyā abhipretena prāpti hetuḥ ahiten
translated: But even so, this qualification shows the production of the sapaksa, the chariot, etc., from the vipaksa, etc., so it would still be inconclusive. For the chariot does not have the substratum of action inhering in the living body. If it is argued that action is that which is fit for attaining the beneficial and avoiding the harmful, inhering in the living body, and is produced by effort, because it is a particular kind of action, like the action of a chariot, then even here the qualified reason does not exist in the sapaksa. Similarly, when a person is asleep and not riding, the action with the stated qualifications is not the cause of attaining the intended object, nor the cause of avoiding the harmful. And it is not a fallacy, saying it is produced by effort. Therefore, the reason is the substratum of action that conforms to desire. For example, the living body is controlled by effort, because it is the substratum of action that conforms to desire, like a substance, like a chariot. Or action is produced by effort, because it is action that conforms to desire, like the action of a chariot.

original: tathā prāṇādibhiśceti / prāṇāpānanimeṣonmeṣajīvanamanogatīndriyāntaravikārāḥ sukhaduḥkhecchādveṣaprayatnāścātmaliṅgāni vai / sū / / / iti sūtraṃ darśayati /
analyzed: tathā prāṇa ādibhiḥ ca iti prāṇa apāna nimeṣa unmeṣa jīvana manaḥ gati indriya antara vikārāḥ sukha duḥkha icchā dveṣa prayatnāḥ ca ātma liṅgāni vai iti sūtram darśayati
translated: And so by the vital breaths etc. The aphorism The vital breaths, inhalation and exhalation, winking, living, mind, motion, changes in the senses, pleasure, pain, desire, aversion, and effort are the marks of the self is shown.

original: athātmanā sārdhamanupalabdheḥ kathameṣāṃ gamakatvamityāha śarīraparigṛhīte vāyau vikṛtakarmadarśanād bhastrādhmāpayiteva anumīyata iti / vyāptipratipādanametat / prayogastu jīvaccharīram / prayatnavadadhiṣṭhitam / jīvaccharīraparigṛhītavikṛtavāyvāśrayatvāt / bhastrāvat / vāyvāśrayatvamanyeṣāmapyastīti vikṛtagrahaṇam / vikārastu tiryaggatiśīlasya vāyoryadetad ūrdhvamadhaśca gamanam / tathāpi vāyurvāyvantareṇa pratihata ūrdhvaṃ gacchatīti parigṛhītapadam / tathā hyantaḥsuṣiravṛkṣe chidrapradeśena praviṣṭasya vāyorūrdhvamadhaśca gamanaṃ sambhavatīti śarīrapadam / tathāpi śuṣkānubaddhaśarīre praviṣṭasya vikāraḥ sambhavatīti jīvagrahaṇam /
analyzed: atha ātmanā sārdham anupalabdheḥ katham eṣām gamaka tvam iti āha śarīra parigṛhīte vāyau vikṛta karma darśanāt bhastrā dhmāpayitā iva anumīyate iti vyāpti pratipādanam etat prayogaḥ tu jīvat śarīram prayatnavat adhiṣṭhitam jīvat śarīra parigṛhīta vikṛta vāyu āśraya tvāt bhastrā vat vāyu āśraya tvam anyeṣām api asti iti vikṛta grahaṇam vikāraḥ tu tiryaggati śīlasya vāyoḥ yat etat ūrdhvam adhas ca gamanam tathā api vāyuḥ vāyu antareṇa p
translated: Now, since they are not apprehended along with the self, how can they be the means of knowing the self? He says: Because of the observation of modified action in the air enclosed in the body, like one blowing a bellows, it is inferred. This establishes the pervasion. The argument is: The living body is controlled by an effortful being, because it is the substratum of modified air enclosed in the living body, like a bellows. The word 'modified' is used because others also have air as their substratum. Modification is the upward and downward movement of the air that moves horizontally. Still, the air moving upward is obstructed by another air, so the word 'enclosed' is used. For thus, in a hollow tree, the air entering through the hole can move upward and downward. Still, the word 'body' is used because modification is possible for the air entering the dry and connected body. Still, the word 'living' is used because modification is not possible for the air entering the dead body.

original: nanvevamapi jīvaccharīraparigṛhītavikṛtavāyvāśrayatvaṃ bhastrāderna sambhavatīti sādhanavikalatāprasaṅgaḥ / tanna / bhastrāsādharmyāt / bhastrāśabdena mahiṣīśarīrasya vivakṣitatvād upacāreṇa / yathā hi bhastrā dhmāpyate prayatnavatā tathā mahiṣīśarīramiti dṛṣṭam / ataḥ sādhyasādhanādhikaraṇatvam /
analyzed: nanu evam api jīvat śarīra parigṛhīta vikṛta vāyu āśraya tvam bhastrā ādeḥ na sambhavati iti sādhana vikala tā prasaṅgaḥ tat na bhastrā sādharmyāt bhastrā śabdena mahiṣī śarīrasya vivakṣita tvāt upacāreṇa yathā hi bhastrā dhmāpyate prayatnavatā tathā mahiṣī śarīram iti dṛṣṭam atas sādhya sādhana adhikaraṇa tvam
translated: But even so, the fact that the bellows and so on are the substratum of modified air enclosed in the living body is not possible, so the probans is open to the fallacy of being absent in the subject. This is not so, because of similarity to the bellows. Because the body of the buffalo is intended by the word 'bellows', it is figuratively spoken of. For just as a bellows is blown by one who makes an effort, so is the body of the buffalo seen. Therefore, it is the substratum of the probandum and the probans.

original: yad vā jīvaccharīraparigṛhītavikṛto vāyuḥ prayatnavadadhiṣṭhitaḥ / jīvaccharīraparigṛhītavikṛtavāyutvāt / bhastrāparigṛhītavikṛtavāyuvat / yathoktavikṛtavāyukarma / prayatnavat kāryam / yathoktasya vāyorvikṛtakarmatvāt / bhastrāparigṛhītavikṛtavāyukarmavat /
analyzed: yat vā jīvat śarīra parigṛhīta vikṛtaḥ vāyuḥ prayatna vat adhiṣṭhitaḥ jīvat śarīra parigṛhīta vikṛta vāyu tvāt bhastrā parigṛhīta vikṛta vāyu vat yathā ukta vikṛta vāyu karma prayatna vat kāryam yathā uktasya vāyoḥ vikṛta karma tvāt bhastrā parigṛhīta vikṛta vāyu karma vat
translated: Or, the modified air enclosed in the living body is controlled by one who makes an effort, because it is modified air enclosed in the living body, like the modified air enclosed in the bellows. The action of the modified air as described is the effect of one who makes an effort, because it is the action of the modified air as described, like the action of the modified air enclosed in the bellows.

original: tathā nimeṣonmeṣakarmaṇā niyatena / iti / na vātadoṣādutpannena / dāruyantraprayokteva ātmānumīyata iti / vyāptipratipādanametat / yathā hi prayatnavatādhiṣṭhitasya dāruyantrasya nimeṣonmeṣakarma tathā jīvaccharīrasyāpīti / akṣipakṣmaṇoḥ saṃyogārthaṃ karma nimeṣaḥ / unmeṣastu tadvibhāgārthamiti / tathā hi jīvaccharīram / prayatnavadadhiṣṭhitam / nimeṣonmeṣakarmādhārasyāvayavitvād / dāruyantravat / akṣipakṣmaṇī tu / nimeṣonmeṣakarmādhāratvāt / dāruyantrākṣipakṣmavat / nimeṣonmeṣakarmaṇī vā / prayatnavatkārye / nimeṣonmeṣakarmatvāt / dāruyantranimeṣonmeṣakarmavat /
analyzed: tathā nimeṣa unmeṣa karmaṇā niyatena iti na vāta doṣāt utpannena dāruyantra prayoktā iva ātmā anumīyate iti vyāpti pratipādanam etat yathā hi prayatnavatā adhiṣṭhitasya dāruyantrasya nimeṣa unmeṣa karma tathā jīvat śarīrasya api iti akṣi pakṣmaṇoḥ saṃyoga artham karma nimeṣaḥ unmeṣaḥ tu tad vibhāga artham iti tathā hi jīvat śarīram prayatna vat adhiṣṭhitam nimeṣa unmeṣa karma ādhārasya avayavi tvāt dāruyantra vat  akṣi pakṣmaṇī tu
translated: Similarly, by the definite action of winking and opening, not arisen from wind disorders. Like the operator of a wooden machine, the self is inferred. This establishes the pervasion. Just as the action of winking and opening of a wooden machine controlled by an effortful operator, so also is the living body. Winking is the action for the conjunction of the eyelids, while opening is for their separation. Thus, the living body is controlled by an effortful operator, because it is the substratum of the action of winking and opening, being composite, like a wooden machine. The eyelids are the substratum of the action of winking and opening, because they are the substratum of the action of winking and opening, like the eyelids of a wooden machine. Or the actions of winking and opening are the effects of an effortful agent, because they are the actions of winking and opening, like the actions of winking and opening of a wooden machine.

original: tathā dehasya vṛddhikṣatabhagnasaṃrohaṇādinimittatvād gṛhapatiriva ātmānumīyata iti / vyāptipratipādanameva / vṛddhiravayavopacayaḥ / kṣatasya śastrādisambandhāt / bhagnasya vā avayavasya saṃrohaṇaṃ lokaprasiddham / vyastañcaitad vivakṣitam / sāmastye hi vyavacchedyābhāvāt / tathā jīvaccharīram / prayatnavadadhiṣṭhitam / vṛddhinimittatvāt / kṣatabhagnasaṃrohaṇādinimittatvācca / gṛhavat / ādiśabdena keśāderudbhavanaṃ puruṣaguṇapūrvakaṃ vyākhyeyaṃ gṛhe 'laṅkāraviśeṣavat / anyathā hi mṛtāvasthāyāmapyetat syāt / na caitadasti / tathā vṛddhikṣatabhagnasaṃrohaṇāni prayatnavatkāryāṇi tadrūpatvāt / gṛhagatavṛkṣādivat /
analyzed: tathā dehasya vṛddhi kṣata bhagna saṃrohaṇa ādi nimitta tvāt gṛhapatiḥ iva ātmā anumīyate iti vyāpti pratipādanam eva vṛddhiḥ avayava upacayaḥ kṣatasya śastra ādi sambandhāt bhagnasya vā avayavasya saṃrohaṇam loka prasiddham vyastam ca etat vivakṣitam sāmastye hi vyavacchedya abhāvāt tathā jīvat śarīram prayatna vat adhiṣṭhitam vṛddhi nimitta tvāt kṣata bhagna saṃrohaṇa ādi nimitta tvāt ca gṛha vat  ādi śabdena keśa ādeḥ udbhavanam puruṣ
translated: Similarly, the soul is inferred from the fact of the body's growth, injury, fracture, healing, etc., like the owner of a house. This is the presentation of the pervasion. Growth is the increase of parts. Injury is due to contact with weapons, etc. The healing of a fractured part is well-known in the world. And this is intended to be separate. For if it were taken as a whole, there would be nothing to be excluded. Similarly, the living body is controlled by an effortful being, because of the cause of growth, and because of the cause of healing, fracture, and injury, like a house. By the word 'etc.', the growth of hair and so on should be explained as preceded by the qualities of a person, like a special decoration in a house. Otherwise, this would occur even in the state of death, and that is not the case. Similarly, growth, injury, fracture, and healing are effects produced by effort, because they have that nature, like a tree in a house.

original: nanu sarvametad anaikāntikam / acetaneṣu vṛkṣādiṣūpalambhāt / tathā ca pravṛttinivṛttyoḥ pratyagātmani dṛṣṭatvāt paratrānumānam vai / sū / / / iti sūtreṇecchānuvidhāyikriyā paratra cetane pratīyata ityucyate / tathā hi svātmani viśiṣṭapravṛttinivṛttyoścetanakāryatvenopalambhād anyatropalambhane tatkāryatvaṃ yuktam / tadabhāvastu vṛkṣādau /
analyzed: nanu sarvam etat anaikāntikam acetaneṣu vṛkṣa ādiṣu upalambhāt tathā ca pravṛtti nivṛttyoḥ pratyagātmani dṛṣṭa tvāt paratra anumānam vai iti sūtreṇa icchā anuvidhāyi kriyā paratra cetane pratīyate iti ucyate tathā hi svātmani viśiṣṭa pravṛtti nivṛttyoḥ cetana kāryatvena upalambhāt anyatra upalambhane tad kāryatvam yuktam tad abhāvaḥ tu vṛkṣa ādau
translated: But all this is inconclusive, because perception occurs in insentient things like trees. And since engagement and disengagement are seen in the inner self, inference is made about others. Thus, it is said that action governed by desire is perceived in others, in the sentient. For thus, since engagement and disengagement are perceived as effects of the sentient self, it is proper to infer their causal nature elsewhere. But their absence is in trees and so on.

original: yaccedaṃ pādaprasāraṇādi tad ayaso 'yaskāntābhisarpaṇavad vastusvābhāvyād bhaviṣyatīti / āgamastu sulabhatvādupacāreṇāpi vyākhyātuṃ śakyata evetyanaikāntikatvameva / atha tadadhiṣṭhāyakasya sadbhāvānnānaikāntikatvamiti cet / na / tasya loṣṭādiṣvapi sadbhāvena vṛddhikṣatabhagnasaṃrohaṇādiprasaṅgāt /
analyzed: yat ca idam pāda prasāraṇa ādi tat ayasaḥ yaskānta abhisarpaṇa vat vastu svābhāvyāt bhaviṣyati iti āgamaḥ tu sulabha tvāt upacāreṇa api vyākhyātum śakyate eva iti anaikāntika tvam eva atha tad adhiṣṭhāyakasya sadbhāvāt na anaikāntika tvam iti ced na tasya loṣṭa ādiṣu api sadbhāvena vṛddhi kṣata bhagna saṃrohaṇa ādi prasaṅgāt
translated: And this stretching of the feet and so on will occur naturally, like the attraction of iron to the magnet. The scripture can be explained even by figurative usage because of its easy availability. Thus, the argument is inconclusive. If it is argued that it is not inconclusive because of the existence of the controller, it is not so, because of the consequence of growth, injury, breaking, and healing even in clods of earth and so on.

original: tadetat sarvamasāmpratam / vṛkṣāderapi pakṣāntarbhāvāt / na ca sādhyenaiva sādhanasya vyabhicāraḥ / nāpi sūtravyāghātastatrāpi pravṛttinivṛttyoḥ sadbhāvāt / tathā ca dravyasannidhāne ca pādaprasāraṇam / na vastusvābhāvyāt / śarīre 'pi tadbhāvaprasaṅgāt / niyatadravyābhilāṣaśca vṛkṣāyurvede paripaṭhitasteṣāṃ jñāyate / tadupabhoge puṣpādidarśanāt / āgamasya caupacārikatvamayuktam / mukhye bādhakānupapatterityalam /
analyzed: tat etat sarvam asāmpratam vṛkṣa ādeḥ api pakṣa antarbhāvāt na ca sādhyena eva sādhanasya vyabhicāraḥ nā api sūtra vyāghātaḥ tatra api pravṛtti nivṛttyoḥ sadbhāvāt tathā ca dravya sannidhāne ca pāda prasāraṇam na vastu svābhāvyāt śarīre tad bhāva prasaṅgāt niyata dravya abhilāṣaḥ ca vṛkṣāyurvede paripaṭhitaḥ teṣām jñāyate tad upabhoge puṣpa ādi darśanāt āgamasya ca aupacārika tvam ayuktam mukhye bādhaka anupapatteḥ iti alam
translated: All this is not correct. Because even a tree falls within the scope of the thesis. And the reason is not fallacious by the thesis itself. Nor is there a contradiction with the aphorism, because there is engagement and disengagement even there. And thus, in the presence of a substance, there is stretching of the feet. Not by the nature of the thing, because it would follow that it exists in the body also. And the desire for a particular substance is recited in the Ayurveda of trees, which is known from them. Because of the perception of flowers etc. in their enjoyment. And it is not proper for the scripture to be figurative, because there is no contradiction in the primary sense. Thus far.

original: atha vālukādinicayeṣu prayatnaṃ vināpi vṛddherupalambhād vyabhicāraḥ / na / īśvaraprayatnasya tatrāpi sadbhāvābhyupagamāt / tasyāpi pakṣe 'ntarbhāvāccharīravat puruṣaguṇapūrvakatvaṃ sadhanīyamiti /
analyzed: atha vālukā ādi nicayeṣu prayatnam vinā api vṛddheḥ upalambhāt vyabhicāraḥ na īśvara prayatnasya tatra api sadbhāva abhyupagamāt tasya api pakṣe ntarbhāvāt śarīra vat puruṣa guṇa pūrvakatvam sadhanīyam iti
translated: Now, there is no fallacy because growth is observed even without effort in heaps of sand etc. Not so, because the effort of God is accepted to be present there also. And because that also falls within the scope of the thesis, it should be inferred that it is preceded by the quality of a person, like the body.

original: tathā abhimataviṣayagrāhakakaraṇasambandhanimittena manaḥkarmaṇā gṛhakoṇeṣu pelakapreraka iva dārakaḥ ātmānumīyata iti vyāptipratipādanameva / yathā hi gṛhe dārakaḥ pelakaiḥ saṃkrīḍamāno hastasthitapelakena madhyasthapelakamabhihatya pelakāntareṇa sambandhayati tadvad ātmāpi śarīre manasā cakṣurādikamabhihatya viṣayaiḥ saṃyojayatīti / tathā cābhimataścāsau viṣayaśca rūpādistadgṛhṇātīti tadgrāhakam / tacca grahaṇaṃ cakṣurādi / tena saha sambandhaḥ / tannimittena manaḥkarmaṇā jñāyate / prayogastu jīvaccharīram / prayatnavadadhiṣṭhitam / abhimataviṣayagrāhakakaraṇādhāratvāt / gṛhavat / mano vā / prayatnapreryam / abhimataviṣayagrāhakakaraṇasambandhitvāt / hastasthitapelakavat / manaḥkarma vā / prayatnavat kāryam / abhimataviṣayagrāhakakaraṇasambandhikarmatvāt / hastasthitapelakakarmavat / manaso vā cakṣurādisambandhaḥ / prayatnavat kāryaḥ abhimataviṣayagrāhakakaraṇasambandhatvāt / pelakāntarasambandhisambandhavat / cakṣurādayo vā / prayatnavat preryāḥ / abhimataviṣayagrāhakakaraṇatvāt / pelakāntaravat / viṣayasambandho vā / prayatnavat kāryaḥ / abhimataviṣayagrāhakakaraṇasambandhisambandhatvāt koṇasthitapelakasambandhavat /
analyzed: tathā abhimata viṣaya grāhaka karaṇa sambandha nimittena manaḥ karmaṇā gṛha koṇeṣu pelaka prerakaḥ iva dārakaḥ ātmā anumīyate iti vyāpti pratipādanam eva yathā hi gṛhe dārakaḥ pelakaiḥ saṃkrīḍamānaḥ hasta sthita pelakena madhyastha pelakam abhihatya pelaka antareṇa sambandhayati tadvat ātmā api śarīre manasā cakṣuḥ ādikam abhihatya viṣayaiḥ saṃyojayati iti tathā ca abhimataḥ ca asau viṣayaḥ ca rūpa ādiḥ tat gṛhṇāti iti tad grāhak
translated: Similarly, by the action of the mind which is the cause of the connection with the sense organs that grasp the desired objects, the self is inferred in the corners of the house, like a child moving the ball. This is just the demonstration of the pervasion. Just as a child in a house, while playing with balls, strikes a ball in the middle with a ball in the hand and connects it with another ball, in the same way, the self also, in the body, strikes the eye etc. with the mind and connects them with the objects. And thus, that which is desired and that which is an object such as form, it grasps, therefore it is the grasper of that. And that grasping is the eye etc. Together with that, there is a connection. By the action of the mind which is the cause of that, it is known. The argument is: The living body is controlled by effort. Because it is the support of the sense organs that grasp the desired objects, like a house. Or the mind is controlled by effort. Because it is connected with the sense organs that grasp the desired objects, like a ball in the hand. Or the action of the mind.

original: tathā nayanaviṣayālocanānantaraṃ rasānusmṛtikrameṇa rasanavikriyādarśanād anekagavākṣāntargataprekṣakavad ubhayadarśī kaścid ekaḥ vijñāyate iti vyāptiI /pratipādanameva / tathā hi / yena rūpādi viśiṣṭarasāvinābhāvitayopalabdhaṃ tasya nayanaviṣayālocanānantaramiti / nayanasya viṣayo rūpam / tatrālocanād vijñānam / tadanantaramavinābhūte rase 'nusmṛtirbhavati / tatkrameṇa rasanavikriyeti rasānusmaraṇānantaraṃ rasabuddhiḥ / tataḥ prayatne sati manasi kriyāprabandhād rasanendriyasambandhaḥ / tasmād radanāntargatodakasaṃplavalakṣaṇo vikāraḥ sampadyata ityutpattikramaḥ /
analyzed: tathā nayana viṣaya ālocanā anantaram rasa anusmṛti krameṇa rasana vikriyā darśanāt aneka gavākṣa antargata prekṣaka vat ubhaya darśī kaścid ekaḥ vijñāyate iti  / tathā hi yena rūpa ādi viśiṣṭa rasa avinābhāvitayā upalabdham tasya nayana viṣaya ālocanā anantaram iti nayanasya viṣayaḥ rūpam tatra ālocanāt vijñānam tad anantaram avinābhūte rase nusmṛtiḥ bhavati tad krameṇa rasana vikriyā iti rasa anusmaraṇa anantaram rasa buddhiḥ tatas prayatne sat
translated: Similarly, after the perception of the object of the eye, the manifestation of the tongue is seen in the order of the recollection of taste, so some one seer is known to see both, like a spectator through many windows. Thus, the pervasion is established. This is the presentation itself. Indeed, that which is perceived as invariably concomitant with taste qualified by form etc., for him, after the perception of the object of the eye. The object of the eye is form. The cognition arises from the perception of that. After that, there is recollection of the taste that is invariably concomitant. In that order, there is manifestation of the tongue. The cognition of taste occurs after the recollection of taste. Then, when there is effort, the connection with the tongue sense organ occurs through the series of actions in the mind. From that, the modification characterized by the confluence of water inside the teeth is accomplished. This is the order of origination.

original: jñaptikramastu rasanendriyavikārānmanaḥsambandhaḥ / tenāpi manasi kriyāprabandho 'numīyate / tasmāt prayatnaḥ / tato 'pīcchā / tathā ca smaraṇam / tataḥ saṃskāraḥ / tasmāccānubhavaḥ / tenānubhavenānubhavitā iti /
analyzed: jñapti kramaḥ tu rasanā indriya vikārāt manaḥ sambandhaḥ tena api manasi kriyā prabandhaḥ numīyate tasmāt prayatnaḥ tatas pi icchā tathā ca smaraṇam tatas saṃskāraḥ tasmāt ca anubhavaḥ tena anubhavena anubhavitā iti
translated: But the sequence of cognition is the connection of the mind with the modification of the organ of taste. By that also, the continuity of action in the mind is inferred. From that, effort. From that, desire. And thus, memory. From that, impression. And from that, experience. By that experience, the experiencer is known.

original: atra tu mameti pratisaṃdhānaṃ sarvatropalabdham ityekakartṛkatvaṃ niścīyate / bhinnakartṛkeṣu mameti pratisandhānavyāvṛtteḥ / na hi devadattādiṣūtpannāḥ smaraṇādayo yajñadattena mama smaraṇaṃ mamecchā iti saṃvedyante / indriyāṇāntu pratiniyataviṣayatvāt sāhacaryānupalabdhau indriyāntareṇopalabdhe 'rthe na syādindriyāntareṇa smaraṇam / tadabhāvād rasanendriyasya vikārāsambhava eva syāt / sa copalabdha ityubhayadarśī ekaḥ jñāyate /
analyzed: atra tu mama iti pratisaṃdhānam sarvatra upalabdham iti eka kartṛka tvam niścīyate bhinna kartṛkeṣu mama iti pratisandhāna vyāvṛtteḥ na hi devadatta ādiṣu utpannāḥ smaraṇa ādayaḥ yajñadattena mama smaraṇam mama icchā iti saṃvedyante indriyāṇām tu pratiniyata viṣaya tvāt sāhacarya anupalabdhau indriya antareṇa upalabdhe rthe na syāt indriya antareṇa smaraṇam tad abhāvāt rasanā indriyasya vikāra asambhavaḥ eva syāt sa ca upalabdhaḥ iti ubhaya darśī
translated: But here, the recollection mine is found everywhere, so the oneness of the agent is ascertained. Because the recollection mine is absent in the case of different agents. For the memories etc. that arise in Devadatta etc. are not experienced by Yajnadatta as this is my memory, this is my desire. And since the sense organs have restricted objects, when an object is perceived by one sense organ, there would be no memory of it by another sense organ in the absence of its concomitance. Due to that absence, there would be no modification of the organ of taste at all. And that is perceived, so one who sees both is known.

original: atha śarīrasyaiva cakṣūrasanādhiṣṭhāyakatve rūparasayoḥ sāhacaryopalabdhau smaraṇamiti cet / na / tasyāpyanyatvāt / tathā hi kuvalayāmalakabilvādīnāmiva parimāṇabhedasya śarīre sadbhāvād anyatvam / na hyanyaparimāṇe 'pyavatiṣṭhamāne parimāṇavati parimāṇapratiṣedhād uttaraparimāṇena śakyaṃ bhavitumiti parimāṇānyathānupapattyā pūrvaparimāṇanivṛttiḥ / sā cāśrayavināśādevetyanyatvam / na ca śarīrasya śarīrāntarārambhakatvam / ekasyārambhakatvapratiṣedhāt / kāryakāraṇavirodhena sarveṣāmupalambhaprasaṅgāt / athāvasthābhedamātraṃ na avasthāyino bheda iti cet / tanna / yadyavasthā parimāṇam / tadbhede tasyāpyavaśyaṃ bhedaḥ / athāvayavaviśeṣaḥ / tadvināśe 'pi tadārabdhasya vināśāt / nāpi rūpādayaḥ / teṣāmapyāśrayavināśena vināśāt / na ca saṃyogi samavāyi vā dharmāntaramastīti / śarīrasyānyatvena smaraṇādyasambhava eva /
analyzed: atha śarīrasya eva cakṣūḥ rasana adhiṣṭhāyaka tve rūpa rasayoḥ sāhacarya upalabdhau smaraṇam iti ced na tasya api anyatvāt tathā hi kuvalaya āmalaka bilva ādīnām iva parimāṇa bhedasya śarīre sadbhāvāt anyatvam na hi anya parimāṇe pi avatiṣṭhamāne parimāṇavati parimāṇa pratiṣedhāt uttara parimāṇena śakyam bhavitum iti parimāṇa anyathā anupapattyā pūrva parimāṇa nivṛttiḥ sā ca āśraya vināśāt eva iti anyatvam na ca śarīrasya śarīra ant
translated: If it be said that in the case of the perception of the concomitance of colour and taste, the remembrance is due to the eye and the tongue being the substrata of the body itself, that is not so; because that also is different. Thus, because there is a difference in size in the body, like the difference in size of the blue lotus, the jujube fruit, and the wood apple, it is different. For, even when the other size remains, it is not possible by the subsequent size, due to the denial of size in the one with size. Thus, the cessation of the previous size is due to the impossibility of the size being otherwise. And that is due to the destruction of the substratum itself, so it is different. And the body is not the cause of the origin of another body, because the origin of one is denied. And because of the contradiction between cause and effect, all would be perceived. If it be said that it is merely a difference in state, not a difference in the enduring thing, that is not so. If the state is size, then in its difference, its difference is certainly necessary. If it is a particular part, then due to the destruction of that, what is produced from that is destroyed. Nor are colour etc.

original: atha buddhau kāraṇavāsanāsaṅkrāntikrameṇa smaraṇotpattau rasanendriyavikāraḥ sampadyata iti cet / na / kṣaṇikatve sati smaraṇasya pūrvameva pratiṣedhāt / tasmādekakartṛkāḥ smaraṇecchādayo mameti pratisandhīyamānatvāt / vibhinnakartṛkeṣu pratisandhānābhāvaḥ / ekakartṛkeṣu tu nartakībhrū vikṣepe kṛtasamayānām asti mameti pratisandhānam /
analyzed: atha buddhau kāraṇa vāsanā saṅkrānti krameṇa smaraṇa utpattau rasanā indriya vikāraḥ sampadyate iti ced na kṣaṇika tve sati smaraṇasya pūrvam eva pratiṣedhāt tasmāt eka kartṛkāḥ smaraṇa icchā ādayaḥ mama iti pratisandhīyamāna tvāt vibhinna kartṛkeṣu pratisandhāna abhāvaḥ eka kartṛkeṣu tu nartakī bhrū vikṣepe kṛta samayānām asti mama iti pratisandhānam
translated: If it be said that the recollection arises in the buddhi through the transference of the impressions of the cause, and that thereby there results a modification of the organ of taste, no (says the siddhāntin); because the momentary character of the recollection has been already denied. Therefore, the recollection, the desire, etc., have one and the same agent, because they are remembered as mine. But in the case of different agents there is no remembrance. But in the case of one and the same agent, there is remembrance as mine in the case of the movements of the eyebrows of the dancing girl, which are previously agreed upon as the signals.

original: atha nityasyānupakāritvād ātmanaḥ kimanubhavādyaiḥ kriyata iti cet / na kiñcit / anubhavāderevopakāritvāt / tena hi satā'nubhavitā smarteti vyapadeśāt / tatkāryaṃ vā tasyopakāraḥ / tathā cānubhavena tasya saṃskāraḥ kriyate / tena tu smaraṇamupakāraḥ / tenāpi svakāryamityuttarottaramabhyūhyam / na cānubhavāderāvirbhāvatirobhāvābhyām anubhavitustathābhāvaḥ / tadvyatirekāt / atha vyatireke kathamātmano 'nubhavādirnānyasyeti cet / tena sambandhāt / sambandhasya tu sambandhāntarānapekṣasyāpi sambandhiniṣṭhasyopalabdhernāpyanavastheti vakṣyāmaḥ /
analyzed: atha nityasya anupakāri tvāt ātmanaḥ kim anubhava ādyaiḥ kriyate iti ced na kiñcid anubhava ādeḥ eva upakāri tvāt tena hi satā anubhavitā smartā iti vyapadeśāt tat kāryam vā tasya upakāraḥ tathā ca anubhavena tasya saṃskāraḥ kriyate tena tu smaraṇam upakāraḥ tena api sva kāryam iti uttarottaram abhyūhyam na ca anubhava ādeḥ āvirbhāva tirobhāvābhyām anubhavituḥ tathā bhāvaḥ tad vyatirekāt atha vyatireke katham ātmanaḥ nubhava ādiḥ na anyasya iti ced
translated: If it be said that, since the eternal Self is not benefited by anything, what is the use of experience, etc.?—we reply: nothing. Because experience, etc. are themselves beneficial. For, when it exists through that [experience], it is designated as the experiencer and the remembrancer. Or, its benefit is its effect. And thus, by experience, its impression is made. But by that, the benefit is remembrance. And by that also, its own effect. Thus, it should be inferred successively. And the Self does not have that state by the manifestation and disappearance of experience, etc., because it is different from them. If it be said that, if it is different, how can the experience, etc. of the Self belong to it and not to another?—we reply: because of its connection with that. But we shall say that, even though the connection does not depend on another connection, and is established in the relata, there is no infinite regress, because of the apprehension of the connection.

original: na cānyasyānubhavotpāde 'nyasyānubhaviteti vyapadeśo dṛṣṭaḥ / athānubhavāderātmanyatiśayādhāyakatvāsambhave vyapadeśāsambhava iti cet / na / asyaivātiśayatvāt tatprāgabhāvaścānatiśayo nivartata iti / kārakasākalyañcātiśayastadvaikalyañcānatiśaya ityuktapūrvam / na cāvyatireke 'tiśayaḥ sambhāvyata ityalamativistareṇa /
analyzed: na ca anyasya anubhava utpāde nyasya anubhavitā iti vyapadeśaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ atha anubhava ādeḥ ātmani atiśaya ādhāyaka tva asambhave vyapadeśa asambhavaḥ iti ced na asya eva atiśaya tvāt tad prāgabhāvaḥ ca anatiśayaḥ nivartate iti kāraka sākalyam ca atiśayaḥ tad vaikalyam ca anatiśayaḥ iti ukta pūrvam na ca avyatireke tiśayaḥ sambhāvyate iti alam ati vistareṇa
translated: Nor is it seen that when one experiences, another is spoken of as the experiencer. If it be said that if the soul cannot be the bestower of any excellence on experience, then it cannot be spoken of as the experiencer, we say no; because it is itself the excellence. And the non-existence of that (soul) prior to experience is non-excellence, and is removed. It has been said before that the completeness of the causal factors is excellence, and their incompleteness is non-excellence. And when there is no difference, excellence cannot be conceived. So much for the detailed discussion.

original: tathā pūrvoktaiḥ sukhaduḥkhecchādveṣaprayatnaiśca guṇairguṇyanumīyate / tathā hi sukhādayaḥ / kvacidāśritāḥ / guṇatvād / rūpādivat / atha śarīrendriyaguṇā bhaviṣyantītyata āha te ca sukhādayaḥ na śarīrendriyaguṇāḥ / kasmādityāha ahaṅkāreṇaikavākyatvābhāvāt iti / ahaṃ pratyayenāsamānādhikaraṇatvād vijñāmavat / ye tu śarīrendriyaguṇāste 'haṅkāreṇa samānādhikaraṇā na bhavanti rūpādaya iti /
analyzed: tathā pūrva uktaiḥ sukha duḥkha icchā dveṣa prayatnaiḥ ca guṇaiḥ guṇī anumīyate tathā hi sukha ādayaḥ kvacid āśritāḥ guṇa tvāt rūpa ādi vat atha śarīra indriya guṇāḥ bhaviṣyanti iti atas āha te ca sukha ādayaḥ na śarīra indriya guṇāḥ kasmāt iti āha ahaṅkāreṇa eka vākya tva abhāvāt iti aham pratyayena asamāna adhikaraṇa tvāt vijñāma vat ye tu śarīra indriya guṇāḥ te haṅkāreṇa samāna adhikaraṇāḥ na bhavanti rūpa ādayaḥ
translated: Similarly, the existence of the soul is inferred from the qualities of pleasure, pain, desire, aversion, and effort mentioned earlier. For example, pleasure and so on are dependent on something, because they are qualities, like color and so on. If it is argued that they may be qualities of the body and sense organs, he says: and these pleasure and so on are not qualities of the body and sense organs. Why? He says: because they are not in the same sentence with the word I. That is, because they are not in the same case with the notion of I, like consciousness. But those qualities of the body and sense organs are not in the same case with the word I, like color and so on.

original: atha rūpavānaham iti pratyayadarśanād yuktameva tat / na / mukhye bādhakasadbhāvenāsya gauṇatvāt / tathā ca /na aham iti pratyayālambanatvaṃ pūrvamevoktamiti śarīraguṇairupacaritameva sāmānādhikaraṇyam / smaraṇajñānena tu sāmānādhikaraṇyam ahaṃ smartā iti dṛṣṭam / na ca smaraṇaṃ śarīre samavetamityuktam / itaśca na śarīrendriyaguṇāḥ sukhādayaḥ pradeśavṛttitvāt / viśeṣaguṇāścāśrayavyāpakā rūpādaya iti śarīraviśeṣaguṇapratiṣedhe sādhye na saṃyogādibhiranekāntaḥ / teṣāmapi ca pakṣatvāt / tathā na śarīrendriyaviśeṣaguṇāḥ sukhādayaḥ yāvaddravyābhāvitvāt śabdavat / ye tu tadviśeṣaguṇāste yāvaddravyabhāvino rūpādaya iti / na ca pārthivaparamāṇurūpādibhirvyabhicāraḥ / teṣāmapi sādhyādhikaraṇatayā sapakṣatvāt / tathā hi / śarīrendriyaviśeṣaguṇapratiṣedhe sādhye te 'pi saṃyogādivat tadviśeṣaguṇā na bhavantīti sapakṣā eva / ito 'pi na śarīrendriyaviśeṣaguṇāḥ sukhādayaḥ bāhyendriyāpratyakṣatvāt vijñānavat / ye tu I / tadviśeṣaguṇāste bāhyendriyapratyakṣā rūpādaya iti / gurutvādīnāntu bāhyendriyāpratyakṣatve 'pi na śarīrendriyaviśeṣaguṇatvamiti vyabhicārābhāvaḥ / bāhyendriyapratiṣedhena cāntaḥkaraṇapratyakṣatvaṃ vivakṣitamiti / tathā śarīraviśeṣaguṇāśca pratyakṣāḥ / na caivaṃ sukhādaya iti / atha triguṇātmakatvāt sarvaṃ sukhaduḥkhādisamanvitamiti nātmaviśeṣaguṇatvam / na / triguṇātmakatvapratiṣedhasya vakṣyamāṇatvāt pradhānapratiṣedhāvasare /
analyzed: atha rūpavān aham iti pratyaya darśanāt yuktam eva tat na  mukhye bādhaka sadbhāvena asya gauṇa tvāt  tathā ca na aham iti pratyaya ālambana tvam pūrvam eva uktam iti śarīra guṇaiḥ upacaritam eva sāmānādhikaraṇyam smaraṇa jñānena tu sāmānādhikaraṇyam aham smartā iti dṛṣṭam na ca smaraṇam śarīre samavetam iti uktam itas ca na śarīra indriya guṇāḥ sukha ādayaḥ pradeśa vṛtti tvāt viśeṣa guṇāḥ ca āśraya vyāpakāḥ rūpa ādayaḥ iti śarīra
translated: If it be argued that the said notion is due to the fact that the Body is possessed of the qualities of Colour, etc., then, the answer is that it cannot be so; because, in the case of the primary meaning, there is a reason for rejecting the secondary meaning; and it has been already pointed out that the notion of ‘I’ cannot be based upon the Body. Hence the co-ordination (in the notion of ‘I’) can only be figurative, based upon the qualities of the Body. As a matter of fact, the co-ordination is actually found in the form of ‘I am the rememberer’, in the case of the cognition of remembrance; and it has been already pointed out that the remembrance is not present in the Body. For the following reason also the feelings of Pleasure, etc. cannot be the qualities of the Body or of the Sense-organs: because they are restricted in their manifestation; while the qualities of the Body, such as Colour, etc. are all-pervading. For instance, the feelings of Pleasure, etc. are not present in the Body as a whole, nor in its parts, nor in the Sense-organs; because they are never perceived as such. Nor is there any other substratum of these feelings, apart from the Body and the Sense-organs. For these reasons, the feelings of Pleasure, etc. cannot be the qualities of the Body and the Sense-organs. Nor can the Reason be regarded as ‘Inconclusive’ on the ground of the possibility of the qualities of the Body, etc. being restricted in their manifestation; because the qualities of the Body, such as Colour, etc. are all-pervading. Nor can the Reason be regarded as ‘Contradictory’; because it is present in all cases where the Probandum is known to be present. Nor can the Reason be regarded as ‘Inadmissible’; because it has been already established that the feelings of Pleasure, etc. are not present in the Body, nor in the Sense-organs, nor in their contact, nor in the Soul.

original: yathā ca sukhaduḥkhādibhirguṇaiḥ tathāhaṃ śabdenāpi ātmā jñāyata iti / ahamśabdo bāhyā /abādhitaikapadatvādavaśyaṃ vācyamapekṣate / na ca pṛthivyādyevābhidheyam pṛthivyādiśabdavyatirekād vaiyadhikaraṇyamiti / yadi punaḥ pṛthivyādikamarthamabhidadhyād aham iti śabdaḥ / tacchabdena sāmānādhikaraṇyaṃ syād ahaṃ pṛthivī ahamudakam ityādi / na caitad dṛṣṭam / tasmādātmanyeva aham iti śabdasya pravṛttiryukteti / viṣayāntare hi pravartamānaḥ śabdo nārthāntaramabhidhatte ityabādhitaikapadam / atha śabdānāṃ vācyavācakabhāvānupapatternirviṣayatvamasyeti cet / na / vācyavācakabhāvasya vakṣyamāṇatvāt /
analyzed: yathā ca sukha duḥkha ādibhiḥ guṇaiḥ tathā aham śabdena api ātmā jñāyate iti aham śabdaḥ bāhyāḥ abādhita eka padatvāt avaśyam vācyam apekṣate na ca pṛthivī ādi eva abhidheyam pṛthivī ādi śabda vyatirekāt vaiyadhikaraṇyam iti  yadi punar pṛthivī ādikam artham abhidadhyāt aham iti śabdaḥ tad śabdena sāmānādhikaraṇyam syāt aham pṛthivī aham udakam ityādi na ca etat dṛṣṭam tasmāt ātmani eva aham iti śabdasya pravṛttiḥ yuktā iti viṣaya
translated: And just as by qualities like pleasure and pain, so also by the word 'I', the self is known. The word 'I' is external. Because of the unobstructed single word, it necessarily requires what is to be denoted. And earth etc. are not what is denoted, because of the difference from the words 'earth' etc., there is non-co-reference. If again the word 'I' were to denote the object 'earth' etc., there would be co-reference with that word, as in 'I am earth, I am water' etc. But this is not seen. Therefore, it is proper that the word 'I' occurs only with reference to the self. For a word occurring in a different context does not denote a different meaning. Thus it is an unobstructed single word. If it be said that this is objectless because the relation of denoted and denotative of words is not possible, it is not so; because the relation of denoted and denotative will be stated.

original: tadevamātmanyavasthite tasya dravyatvasamavāyikāraṇatvakṣaṇikaikadeśavṛttiviśeṣaguṇatvapratipādanārthaṃ caturdaśaguṇapratijñā / tāṃ darśayati tasya guṇā buddhisukhaduḥkhecchādveṣaprayatnadharmādharmasaṃskārasaṃkhyāparimāṇapṛthaktvasaṃyogavibhāgāḥ iti / ete tu sūtrakāreṇa pratipāditā ityāha ātmaliṅgādhikāre buddhyādayaḥ prayatnāntāḥ siddhāḥ iti /
analyzed: tat evam ātmani avasthite tasya dravya tva samavāyi kāraṇa tva kṣaṇika eka deśa vṛtti viśeṣa guṇa tva pratipādana artham caturdaśaguṇa pratijñā tām darśayati tasya guṇāḥ buddhi sukha duḥkha icchā dveṣa prayatna dharma adharma saṃskāra saṃkhyā parimāṇa pṛthaktva saṃyoga vibhāgāḥ iti ete tu sūtrakāreṇa pratipāditāḥ iti āha ātma liṅga adhikāre buddhi ādayaḥ prayatna antāḥ siddhāḥ iti
translated: Thus, when the self is established, in order to establish its qualities of being a substance, being an inherent cause, and being a specific quality occurring in only one part of a momentary entity, the fourteen qualities are asserted. He shows them: Its qualities are cognition, pleasure, pain, desire, aversion, effort, virtue, vice, impressions, number, dimension, separateness, conjunction, and disjunction. But these are taught by the author of the aphorisms, he says: In the section on the characteristics of the self, cognition and the others up to effort are established.

original: tathā dharmādharmāvātmāntaraguṇānāmakāraṇatvavacanāt iti ātmaguṇānāmātmāntaraguṇeṣvakāraṇatvād vai / sū / / / iti sūtraṃ darśayati / tathā hi dānadharmaḥ pratigrahadharmaḥ sampadyata ityanayoḥ pūrvāparabhāvaniyamāt kāryakāraṇabhāva ityāśaṅkāparihārārthametat sūtram ātmāntaraguṇānāmātmāntaraguṇeṣvakāraṇatvāt / dharmādharmau cātmaguṇāviti nātmāntaraguṇotpattau kāraṇaṃ syāt / na hyātmaguṇāt sukhād ātmāntare sukham / duḥkhācca duḥkhamutpadyamānamupalabdham /
analyzed: tathā dharma adharmau ātma antara guṇānām akāraṇa tva vacanāt iti ātma guṇānām ātma antara guṇeṣu akāraṇa tvāt vai iti sūtram darśayati tathā hi dāna dharmaḥ pratigraha dharmaḥ sampadyate iti anayoḥ pūrva apara bhāva niyamāt kārya kāraṇa bhāvaḥ iti āśaṅkā parihāra artham etat sūtram ātma antara guṇānām ātma antara guṇeṣu akāraṇa tvāt dharma adharmau ca ātma guṇau iti na ātma antara guṇa utpattau kāraṇam syāt na hi ātma guṇāt suk
translated: Similarly, because Dharma and Adharma are not the causes of the qualities of other selves, it shows the aphorism Thus, because the qualities of one self are not the causes of the qualities of another self. For instance, the quality of giving and the quality of receiving are established as cause and effect due to the rule of prior and posterior existence. This aphorism is for the purpose of removing the doubt that arises from this. Because the qualities of one self are not the causes of the qualities of another self, and Dharma and Adharma are the qualities of the self, they cannot be the cause of the production of the qualities of another self. For happiness is not produced in another self from the quality of the self, happiness, nor is suffering produced from suffering.

original: atha duhitari vartamānaṃ sukhaṃ mātari sukhasampādakaṃ dṛṣṭamiti / ayuktametat / na / tadanubhavena tadutpapapa /tteḥ / tathā hi duhitari mukhaprasādādikamupalabhya I / sukhamasyāḥ samutpannam ityanumānānmanyamānāyāḥ svānubhavānmānasaṃ sukhamutpadyate / na tat sukhāt / tadvināśe hi kālāntareṇotpatteriti /
analyzed: atha duhitari vartamānam sukham mātari sukha sampādakam dṛṣṭam iti ayuktam etat na tad anubhavena tad utpapatteḥ tathā hi duhitari mukha prasāda ādikam upalabhya sukham asyāḥ samutpannam iti anumānāt manyamānāyāḥ sva anubhavāt mānasam sukham utpadyate na tat sukhāt tad vināśe hi kāla antareṇa utpatteḥ iti
translated: If it be said that the pleasure which is seen to be produced in the mother by the pleasure of the daughter is not the same as that of the daughter, this is not so; because it is produced by the experience of that pleasure. For thus, perceiving the joy of the face, etc. in the daughter, thinking that the inference is that pleasure has arisen for her, the mental pleasure arises from her own experience, not from that pleasure; because it arises at a later time even when that pleasure is destroyed.

original: tadevaṃ dānadharmasya pratigrahadharmotpattau kāraṇatvapratiṣedhapareṇāpi sūtreṇa ātmani dharmādharmayoḥ sadbhāvo 'bhihitaḥ / tathā vakṣyāmaśca tatparīkṣāyām /
analyzed: tat evam dāna dharmasya pratigraha dharma utpattau kāraṇa tva pratiṣedha pareṇa api sūtreṇa ātmani dharma adharmayoḥ sadbhāvaḥ bhihitaḥ tathā vakṣyāmaḥ ca tad parīkṣāyām
translated: Thus, even by the Sūtra which is concerned with the denial of the cause-hood of the dharma of receiving in the production of the dharma of giving, the existence of dharma and adharma in the self is stated; and we shall also state it in the examination of that.

original: saṃskāraḥ smṛtyutpattau iti / smṛtirvāsanākhyāt vai / sū / / iti sūtraṃ darśayati / tathā hi smṛtiḥ kāryatvādavaśyaṃ kāraṇamapekṣate / na cānubhavaḥ kāraṇam / tadvināśe 'pyutpatteḥ / athānubhavapradhvaṃsaḥ kāraṇamanvayavyatirekavattvāt / tadasat / tasya niratiśayatvāt tīvrādibhedabhinnasya smaraṇasyānupapattiprasaṅgāt / na hi kāraṇātiśayaṃ vinā kāryasyātiśayo yuktaḥ / abhyāsavaiyarthyañca pradhvaṃsātiśayasya kartumaśakyatvāt / ataḥ sātiśayamātmasamavetaṃ kiñcidasādhāraṇaṃ kāraṇamasti yatastatsamavetā smṛtirjāyate / na cādṛṣṭa eva / tasya sakalakāryotpattau sādhāratvāt / asādhāraṇantu ātmasamavetaṃ sukhaduḥkhalakṣaṇaṃ kāryaṃ dṛṣṭamiti smṛteranyadasādhāraṇaṃ kāraṇaṃ vācyam / tathā hi / smṛtirātmasamavetā asādhāraṇakāraṇe satyutpadyate / ātmasamavetāsādhāraṇakāryatvāt / sukhavat / tasmādanubhavenātmani saṃskārādhāne sati smaraṇamutpadyata iti sthitam / smṛtirvāsanākhyād bhavatīti /
analyzed: saṃskāraḥ smṛti utpattau iti smṛtiḥ vāsanā ākhyāt vai iti sūtram darśayati tathā hi smṛtiḥ kārya tvāt avaśyam kāraṇam apekṣate na ca anubhavaḥ kāraṇam tad vināśe pi utpatteḥ atha anubhava pradhvaṃsaḥ kāraṇam anvaya vyatirekavat tvāt tat asat tasya niratiśaya tvāt tīvra ādi bheda bhinnasya smaraṇasya anupapatti prasaṅgāt na hi kāraṇa atiśayam vinā kāryasya atiśayaḥ yuktaḥ abhyāsa vaiyarthyam ca pradhvaṃsa atiśayasya kartum aśakya tvāt
translated: The impression is for the production of memory. Memory is from the impression called vāsanā. Thus he shows the aphorism. For thus memory, being an effect, must necessarily depend on a cause. And the experience is not the cause, because it arises even when it is destroyed. Now, if the destruction of experience is the cause, because of concomitance and non-concomitance, that is not so. Because it is without any superiority, there is the contingence of the impossibility of memory distinguished by the difference of intensity etc. For it is not proper for an effect to have superiority without the superiority of the cause. And the repetition is useless, because the superiority of destruction cannot be produced. Therefore, there is some extraordinary cause residing in the self, which has superiority, from which memory residing in that arises. And it is not merely unseen, because that is common to the production of all effects. But the effect residing in the self, which is extraordinary, is seen to be of the nature of pleasure and pain. Therefore, another extraordinary cause must be stated for memory. Thus, memory is...

original: tatra vyavasthāvacanāt saṃkhyā iti / sukhaduḥkhavyavasthāto nānātmānaḥ vai / sū / / / iti sūtraṃ darśayati / kā punariyaṃ vyavasthā / sukhaduḥkhādīnāṃ niyamaḥ / tathā hi / ekasya sukhamanyasya duḥkhamanyasyeccheti vyasthopalabdhā / aikātmye tvekasya sukhitve sarveṣāṃ sukhitvam / duḥkhitve sarveṣu duḥkhitvañcetyavyavasthāprasaṅgaḥ / niyamahetorabhāvāt /
analyzed: tatra vyavasthā vacanāt saṃkhyā iti sukha duḥkha vyavasthātaḥ nānā ātmānaḥ vai iti sūtram darśayati kā punar iyam vyavasthā sukha duḥkha ādīnām niyamaḥ tathā hi ekasya sukham anyasya duḥkham anyasya icchā iti vyasthā upalabdhā aikātmye tu ekasya sukhi tve sarveṣām sukhi tvam duḥkhi tve sarveṣu duḥkhi tvam ca iti a vyavasthā prasaṅgaḥ niyama hetoḥ abhāvāt
translated: In this regard, he shows the sutra The souls are different because of the arrangement of pleasure and pain. What is this arrangement? The restriction of pleasure, pain, etc. Indeed, it is observed that one has pleasure, another has pain, and another has desire. But if there were one soul, then when one is happy, all would be happy, and when one is unhappy, all would be unhappy. This would lead to the undesirable consequence of lack of arrangement, because there is no cause for restriction.

original: athāsti śarīrabhedo niyāmaka iti cet / na / anusandhānaprasaṅgāt / yathā hi bālakaumārayauvanāvasthābhedena śarīrasya bhede 'pyekatvādātmanaḥ pratisandhānaṃ mama sukhamāsīd bālyāvasthāyām ityupalabdham / evaṃ sarvaśarīreṣvapi prasaṅgaḥ / na caitadasti / tasmād ekatvavyāpakaṃ pratisandhānamātmano 'śvamahiṣādiśarīrebhyo vyāvartamānaṃ svavyāptamekatvaṃ gṛhītvā vyāvartata iti nānātvam / tathā hi / aśvamahiṣādiśarīre 'pyātmā dharmī ātmatve sati vyaktibhedena nāneti sādhyam / śarīrāntaropalabdhe 'rthe śarīrāntareṇāpratisandhāyakatvāt / yatra caikastatrāsti pratisandhānam / yathā bālakaumārayauvanaśarīreṣviti vyatirekaḥ / kevalavyatirekāvyabhicāreṇa hetorgamakatvaṃ vakṣyāmo I / laiṅgikajñāne / tathaikasminnapi śarīre mama pāde vedanā / śirasi vedanā ityekatvādātmanaḥ pratisandhānaṃ dṛṣṭam / na ca janmāntaraśarīrānubhūte garbhaśarīrānubhūte ca smaraṇavad aśvādiśarīropalabdhe 'pyasmaraṇaṃ yuktam / garbhaśarīrānubhavasyāpaṭutvājjanmāntarasaṃskārasya ca maraṇaduḥkhenābhibhavāt / na caivamaśvādiśarīrānubhūteṣu smaraṇe kāraṇamasti /
analyzed: atha asti śarīra bhedaḥ niyāmakaḥ iti ced na anusandhāna prasaṅgāt yathā hi bāla kaumāra yauvana avasthā bhedena śarīrasya bhede pi ekatvāt ātmanaḥ pratisandhānam mama sukham āsīt bālya avasthāyām iti upalabdham evam sarva śarīreṣu api prasaṅgaḥ na ca etat asti tasmāt ekatva vyāpakam pratisandhānam ātmanaḥ śva mahiṣa ādi śarīrebhyaḥ vyāvartamānam sva vyāptam ekatvam gṛhītvā vyāvartate iti nānātvam tathā hi aśva mahiṣa ādi śarīre pi ātmā dh
translated: If it be said that the difference of bodies is the determining factor, no; because of the possibility of recognition. Just as, in the case of the body, there is recognition, in the case of the soul, which is one, in spite of the difference of the body in the states of childhood, youth and old age, as is found in the idea ‘I was happy in the state of childhood’, so it would be in the case of all bodies. And this is not found to be the case. Therefore, recognition, which is concomitant with oneness, being absent in the case of the bodies of the horse, the buffalo and so on, sets aside the concomitance, and so there is diversity. Thus, in the case of the bodies of the horse, the buffalo and so on, the soul, the subject, is diverse by reason of the difference of individuals, while being the soul, is the conclusion. Because, when the other body is perceived, there is no recognition of the object by the other body. And where there is one, there is recognition, as in the case of the bodies of childhood, youth and old age. This is the negative concomitance. We shall show that the probans is a probans by the invariable concomitance of mere absence. In the case of inference, it is thus.

original: atha bhedasadbhāve pramāṇānupapatteḥ sarvamekamiti kalpyate / na / pratyakṣeṇaiva parasparavyāvṛttātmanāṃ padārthānāṃ bhedapratibhāsād vidhipratiṣedhagrāhakañca pratyakṣaṃ nirvikalpakajñānena padārthānāṃ bhedapratibhāse sati etasmādayaṃ bhinnaḥ iti savikalpajñānotpattyabhyupagamānnetaretarāśrayatvam / anavasthā vā / aniyamena tu viśeṣaṇaviśeṣyayorvidhipratiṣedhayorgrahaṇamiṣṭam / yadatra viśeṣaṇaṃ tat pūrvaṃ gṛhyate viśeṣyantu paścāt / aniyama /tastu viśeṣaṇaviśeṣyabhāva iti /
analyzed: atha bheda sadbhāve pramāṇa anupapatteḥ sarvam ekam iti kalpyate na pratyakṣeṇa eva paraspara vyāvṛtta ātmanām padārthānām bheda pratibhāsāt vidhi pratiṣedha grāhakam ca pratyakṣam nirvikalpaka jñānena padārthānām bheda pratibhāse sati etasmāt ayam bhinnaḥ iti sa vikalpa jñāna utpatti abhyupagamāt na itaretara āśraya tvam anavasthā vā aniyamena tu viśeṣaṇa viśeṣyayoḥ vidhi pratiṣedhayoḥ grahaṇam iṣṭam yat atra viśeṣaṇam tat pūrvam gṛhyate
translated: If it is argued that because there is no valid means of knowledge for the existence of difference, everything is one, it is not so. Because by perception itself, the mutually exclusive forms of things appear as different, and perception grasps affirmation and negation, and because when the difference of things appears in non-conceptual cognition, the conceptual cognition arises as this is different from that, there is no mutual dependence or infinite regress. But the grasping of the qualifier and qualified is accepted without restriction. What is the qualifier here is grasped first, but the qualified is grasped later. But the relation of qualifier and qualified is without restriction.

original: nanu cātra bhedo vyāvṛttiritaretarābhāva ityabhyupagame vyāvṛtterbhedaḥ kathaṃ svayaṃ vyāvṛttirūpatvāt / tadviparītāstu vyāvṛttimapekṣante / athāyaṃ bhedapratibhāso 'vidyāsamāropita iti cet / na / ātmavyatirekeṇa tadasambhavāt / vyatireke tu ekatvanivṛttiḥ / yadi ca vidyānivṛttirūpā syādavidyā / sā kathaṃ tucchasvabhāvatayā bhedena vyavahāraṃ janayet / na ca bādhakānupapatterbhedapratibhāso bhrāntaḥ / nāpi kalpitarūpāṇāṃ vāstavārthakriyājanakatvaṃ nyāyyam / rajjvāṃ tu sarpajñānād vāstavādeva bhakṣaṇaṃ /dravaṇaṃ kāryaṃ na kalpitārthāditi / na ca sarvasyaikatve pramāṇamastīti kathaṃ vidyānibandhanamekatvajñānam / yathā ca pramāṇaṃ vinā sarvasyaikatvam evaṃ nānātvamapi syāt / pramāṇābhāvasyobhayatrāviśeṣāt / athāstyekatve pramāṇamāgama iti cet / ekatvanivṛttiḥ pramāṇādervāstavabhedatvāt / abhede tu pramāṇaprameyavyavasthānupapattiriti /
analyzed: nanu ca atra bhedaḥ vyāvṛttiḥ itaretarābhāvaḥ iti abhyupagame vyāvṛtteḥ bhedaḥ katham svayam vyāvṛtti rūpatvāt tad viparītāḥ tu vyāvṛttim apekṣante atha ayam bheda pratibhāsaḥ vidyā samāropitaḥ iti ced na ātma vyatirekeṇa tad asambhavāt vyatireke tu ekatva nivṛttiḥ yadi ca vidyā nivṛtti rūpā syāt avidyā sā katham tuccha svabhāva tayā bhedena vyavahāram janayet na ca bādhaka anupapatteḥ bheda pratibhāsaḥ bhrāntaḥ nā api kalpita rūpāṇām
translated: But if difference, exclusion, and mutual absence are accepted here, how can exclusion itself be different, since it has the form of exclusion? But those that are contrary to it depend on exclusion. If it is argued that this appearance of difference is superimposed by ignorance, it is not so, because that is not possible apart from the self. But if there is difference, there is the cessation of oneness. And if ignorance were of the form of the cessation of knowledge, how could it, being of the nature of emptiness, generate the usage of difference? And the appearance of difference is not illusory due to the impossibility of contradiction. Nor is it proper for imagined forms to generate real effects. But in the case of the rope, the real effect of eating and running is produced only from the real snake, not from the imagined object. And since there is no means of knowledge for the oneness of everything, how can the knowledge of oneness be based on knowledge? And just as there is no means of knowledge for the oneness of everything, so also there would be diversity. The absence of means of knowledge is the same in both cases.

original: kathaṃ svayaṃjyotirevāyamātmeti / athāmī padārthā yadi paramātmano vyatirekiṇaḥ kathaṃ prakāśante / aprakāśasya prakāśāyogāt / atha prakāśante na paramātmavyatirekiṇaḥ / tasyaiva prakāśasvarūpatvāditi cet / naitadevam / vibhinnasvarūpasambandhināṃ pratyakṣādipramāṇaiḥ saṃvedanāt prakāśarūpatā bhāvasvarūpasambandhitvam / bodharūpatā vā syāt / sā tu padārtheṣu na sambhavatītyasattvena paramātmano 'pyasattvaprasaṅgaḥ / padārthāntarasvarūpasya padārthāntare sattvāviśeṣāt / yadi caika eva syādātmā / tasyaikatra vimokṣe sarvatra tathābhāvaḥ ityaprayāsasādhyo mokṣaḥ syāt / tathā kasyacidamuktāvanyasyāpyamuktiriti sarveṣāmanirmokṣaprasaṅgaḥ /
analyzed: katham svayam jyotiḥ eva ayam ātmā iti  atha amī padārthāḥ yadi paramātmanaḥ vyatirekiṇaḥ katham prakāśante aprakāśasya prakāśa ayogāt atha prakāśante na paramātma vyatirekiṇaḥ tasya eva prakāśa svarūpa tvāt iti ced na etat evam vibhinna sva rūpa sambandhinām pratyakṣa ādi pramāṇaiḥ saṃvedanāt prakāśa rūpatā bhāva sva rūpa sambandhi tvam bodha rūpatā vā syāt sā tu padārtheṣu na sambhavati iti asattvena paramātmanaḥ u pi asattva prasaṅgaḥ p
translated: How is this Self self-luminous? Now, if these things are distinct from the Supreme Self, how do they manifest? Because what is not manifest cannot manifest. If they do manifest, they are not distinct from the Supreme Self, because He alone is of the nature of light. If this is argued, it is not so. Because they are cognized by the means of valid knowledge such as perception, which are related to different forms, their luminous nature is related to the nature of existence. Or it may be of the nature of consciousness. But that is not possible in objects. So, due to non-existence, the Supreme Self would also be non-existent, because the existence of the form of another object in another object is not distinguished. And if there were only one Self, when it is liberated in one place, it would be so everywhere. So liberation would be accomplished without effort. Similarly, when one is not liberated, others would also not be liberated. So there would be the undesirable consequence of the non-liberation of all.

original: atha paramātmano jīvātmanāṃ niḥsaraṇaṃ saṃsāraḥ / tasminneva layo muktiriti cet / na / teṣāṃ tasmādabhede kasya muktiḥ saṃsāro vā / abhede vā dvaitahāniriti / tathā vidyāparicchinnātmapradeśānāṃ muktiravidyāparicchinnātmapradeśānāṃ saṃsāraḥ ityatrāpyetadeva dūṣaṇamūhyam / paramāṇavastu kṣityādeḥ kāryasyopādānakāraṇaṃ kāryaparimāṇāddhīnaparimāṇasya kāraṇasyopalabdheḥ / na ca paramātmā / tasya vyāpakatvāt / na cāmūrtopādānasamavetaṃ mūrtamutpadyamānaṃ dṛṣṭamiti / yadi cānekamaṇuparimāṇañcopādānaṃ paramātmeti syāt / saṃjñābhedamātram / paramāṇavastu pūrvameva vyavasthāpitāḥ / yaccaikatvapratipādakaṃ vākyaṃ tatparamātmāpekṣayā vyākhyeyam / tasya hi kāryānumānena pūrvameva vyavasthāpanāt / yaccedam eka evāyamātmā dehe dehe vyavasthitaḥ iti / ekasmin śarīre 'nekatvapratiṣedhārthametat / tathā hyekasmiñcharīre 'nekaṃ vijñānamātmeti śākyā manyante tatpratiṣedhārthaṃ pratiśarīrameko nānekaḥ / tathā nānātvapratipādakameva vākyamastītyalamatijalpitena /
analyzed: atha paramātmanaḥ jīvātmanām niḥsaraṇam saṃsāraḥ tasmin eva layaḥ muktiḥ iti ced na teṣām tasmāt abhede kasya muktiḥ saṃsāraḥ vā abhede vā dvaita hāniḥ iti tathā vidyā paricchinna ātma pradeśānām muktiḥ avidyā paricchinna ātma pradeśānām saṃsāraḥ iti atra api etat eva dūṣaṇam ūhyam paramāṇavaḥ tu kṣiti ādeḥ kāryasya upādāna kāraṇam kārya parimāṇāt hīna parimāṇasya kāraṇasya upalabdheḥ na ca paramātmā tasya vyāpaka t
translated: If, on the other hand, the Liberation of the Individual Self from the Supreme Self is Saṃsāra, and its absorption into the latter is Liberation, then, in that case, there can be no Liberation for any one, nor Saṃsāra for any one; because the Individual Self is non-different from the Supreme Self; and if there were non-difference, then there would be no room for the relation of the ‘Liberated’ and the ‘not-yet-liberated’, which is based upon difference. Similarly, if Liberation were of the part of the Self that is delimited by Cognition, and Saṃsāra were of that part of the Self that is delimited by Ignorance, then, in that case, there would be no room for the relation of the ‘Liberated’ and the ‘not-yet-liberated’, which is based upon difference. The same objection would apply also to the view that Liberation is of that part of the Self which is delimited by Cognition, and Saṃsāra is of that part of the Self which is delimited by Ignorance. The Atom is the material cause of such products as Earth and the rest; because the material cause is always found to be smaller in quantity than the product; and the Supreme Self is not the material cause of the world; because He is all-pervading. Nor is it possible for the product to be of a different shape from that of the material cause; nor is it possible for the product to be of a different shape from that of the material cause; nor is it possible for the product to be of a different shape from that of the material cause; nor is it possible for the product to be of a different shape from that of the material cause; nor is it possible for the product to be of a different shape from that of the material cause; nor is it possible for the product to be of a different shape from that of the material cause; nor is it possible for the product to be of a different shape from that of the material cause; nor is it possible for the product to be of a different shape from that of the material cause; nor is it possible for the product to be of a different shape from that of the material cause; nor is it possible for the product to be of a different shape from that of the material cause; nor is it possible for the product to be of a different shape from that of the material cause; nor is it possible for the product to be of a different shape from that of the material

original: pṛthaktvamapyata eva iti / yata eva nānātvamata eva nānāpṛthaktvam / tathā cātmeti vacanāt paramamahatparimāṇam iti / vibhavānmahānākāśastathā cātmā vai / sa / / / iti sūtraṃ darśayati / yathā vibhavānmahānākāśastathātmāpīti vibhutvādeva paramamahattvaṃ siddham / atha śarīraparimāṇatvādātmano 'siddhaṃ paramamahattvam / tathā cālpaśarīre 'lpo mahati mahānātmeti / na / śarīravyatirekeṇātmano 'stitve pramāṇamastīti /
analyzed: pṛthaktvam api atas eva iti  yatas eva nānātvam atas eva nānāpṛthaktvam tathā ca ātmā iti vacanāt parama mahat parimāṇam iti vibhavāt mahān ākāśaḥ tathā ca ātmā vai saḥ iti sūtram darśayati yathā vibhavāt mahān ākāśaḥ tathā ātmā api iti vibhu tvāt eva parama mahā tvam siddham atha śarīra parimāṇa tvāt ātmanoḥ siddham parama mahā tvam tathā ca alpa śarīre lpaḥ mahati mahān ātmā iti na śarīra vyatirekeṇa ātmanoḥ stitve pramāṇam asti iti
translated: And separateness also is due to this very fact. Because of the plurality, there is separateness. And thus, because of the statement the Self is so and so, the highest magnitude is established. The aphorism Space is great by extension, and so is the Self is shown. Just as space is great by extension, so is the Self. Thus, by extension alone, the highest magnitude is established. If the Self has the magnitude of the body, the highest magnitude is not established. And thus, in a small body, the Self is small, in a large one, large. No, there is evidence that the Self exists separate from the body.

original: nanvetasmin pakṣe saṅkocavikāśadharmakatvād bālaśarīre 'pyātmano vināśe vṛddhāvasthāyāṃ nānātmā sampadyata ityanyatve smaraṇaṃ na syāt / na ca pūrvaparimāṇasyānivṛttāvuttaraparimāṇena śakyaṃ bhavitumiti pūrvaparimāṇasyāśrayavināśādeva nivṛttiḥ /
analyzed: nanu etasmin pakṣe saṅkoca vikāśa dharmaka tvāt bāla śarīre pi ātmanaḥ vināśe vṛddha avasthāyām nānā ātmā sampadyate iti anya tve smaraṇam na syāt na ca pūrva parimāṇasya anivṛttau uttara parimāṇena śakyam bhavitum iti pūrva parimāṇasya āśraya vināśāt eva nivṛttiḥ
translated: In this view, due to having the property of contraction and expansion, even in the body of a child, the Self is destroyed, and in the state of an adult, it becomes a different Self. Thus, memory would not occur due to difference. And when the previous magnitude does not cease, it cannot exist with the subsequent magnitude. Thus, the previous magnitude ceases only due to the destruction of its substratum.

original: na ca vyāpakasyāmūrtatve gamanaṃ sambhavatīti svargādisthāneṣu śarīrasambandhānupapattāvupabhogo na syādata iṣyata evaṃ gamanam / tarhi mūrtatve sati mahāparimāṇatvād yata utpattistat kāraṇaṃ vācyamiti bhūtacaitanyavat pratiṣedhaḥ /
analyzed: na ca vyāpakasya amūrta tve gamanam sambhavati iti svarga ādi sthāneṣu śarīra sambandha anupapattau upabhogaḥ na syāt atas iṣyate evam gamanam tarhi mūrta tve sati mahā parimāṇa tvāt yatas utpattiḥ tat kāraṇam vācyam iti bhūta caitanya vat pratiṣedhaḥ
translated: And when the all-pervading is not material, movement is not possible. So, in the case of heaven and other places, there would be no enjoyment due to the impossibility of the connection of the body. Therefore, movement is accepted in this way. Then, when it is material and has great magnitude, its cause of origination must be stated. So, like the sentience of elements, it is negated.

original: tathā dharmādharmayorātmaguṇatvāt tadāśrayasyāvyāpakatve na syādagnerūrdhvajvalanaṃ vāyostiryaggamanamaṇumanasostvādyaṃ karmeti / tayoḥ svāśrayasaṃyogāpekṣitvāt / yathā prayatno hastakarmaṇyātmasaṃyogāpekṣastathā dharmādharmāvātmasaṃyogaṃ vinā na karma kuryātām / ātmaguṇatvāt / na ca tatrānyat kāraṇamastīti svāśrayasaṃyogāpekṣo 'dṛṣṭa eva kāraṇam / I / ato vyāpakatvācca paramamahattvam / tathā yogo khalu ṛddhau prādurbhūtāyāṃ sendriyāṇi śarīrāṇi nirmāya yugapad bhogānupabhuṅkte iti śrūyate / tacca vibhāvātmanyupapadyate nāvyāpake iti /
analyzed: tathā dharma adharmayoḥ ātma guṇa tvāt tad āśrayasya avyāpaka tve na syāt agneḥ ūrdhva jvalanam vāyoḥ tiryak gamanam aṇu manasoḥ tu ādyam karma iti tayoḥ sva āśraya saṃyoga apekṣi tvāt yathā prayatnaḥ hasta karmaṇi ātma saṃyoga apekṣaḥ tathā dharma adharmau ātma saṃyogam vinā na karma kuryātām ātma guṇa tvāt  na ca tatra anyat kāraṇam asti iti sva āśraya saṃyoga apekṣaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ eva kāraṇam  / atas vyāpaka tvāt ca parama mahat tvam
translated: Similarly, since Dharma and Adharma are qualities of the self, if their substratum were not all-pervading, then the upward motion of fire, the horizontal motion of air, and the initial action of atoms and mind would not occur. Because they require conjunction with their substratum. Just as effort requires conjunction with the hand and the object, similarly Dharma and Adharma would not perform their action without conjunction with the self, because they are qualities of the self. And there is no other cause there. Therefore, the unseen force alone is the cause, requiring conjunction with its substratum. And because of its all-pervasiveness, it is of the highest magnitude. Similarly, it is heard that when supernatural power manifests, the yogi creates bodies with sense organs and simultaneously experiences enjoyments. And that is possible in the all-pervading self, not in the non-pervading one.

original: tathā sukhādīnāṃ sannikarṣajatvāt saṃyogaḥ siddhaḥ / sukhādayo hi kāryatvādasamavāyikāraṇamapekṣante / na cānyat sambhavatītyātmāntaḥkaraṇasaṃyogaḥ siddhaḥ /
analyzed: tathā sukha ādīnām sannikarṣa ja tvāt saṃyogaḥ siddhaḥ sukha ādayaḥ hi kārya tvāt asamavāyi kāraṇam apekṣante na ca anyat sambhavati iti ātma antaḥkaraṇa saṃyogaḥ siddhaḥ
translated: Similarly, since pleasure etc. are produced by contact, conjunction is established. For pleasure etc., being effects, require a non-inherent cause, and since nothing else is possible, the conjunction of the self and the internal organ is established.

original: sa ca kṛtakatvādavaśyaṃ vināśītyāśrayavināśābhāvād vibhāgādeva vinaśyatīti vibhāgaḥ siddhaḥ /
analyzed: sa ca kṛtaka tvāt avaśyam vināśi iti āśraya vināśa abhāvāt vibhāgāt eva vinaśyati iti vibhāgaḥ siddhaḥ
translated: And that [cognition] is necessarily perishable because it is produced, so it perishes due to the destruction of its substratum, and hence due to separation. Thus separation is established.

original: manastvayogānmanaḥ / satyapyātmendriyārthasānnidhye jñānasukhaduḥkhānāmabhūtvotpattidarśanāt karaṇāntaramanumīyate / śrotrādyavyāpāre smṛtyutpattidarśanād bāhyendriyairagṛhītasukhādigrāhyāntarasadbhāvāccāntaḥkaraṇam /PDhS
analyzed: manaḥ tu ayogāt manaḥ sati api ātma indriya artha sānnidhye jñāna sukha duḥkhānām a bhūtvā utpatti darśanāt karaṇa antaram anumīyate śrotra ādi avyāpāre smṛti utpatti darśanāt bāhya indriyaiḥ agṛhīta sukha ādi grāhya antara sadbhāvāt ca antaḥkaraṇam
translated: The mind is inferred from the non-concomitance of the mind, because the arising of knowledge, pleasure, and pain is seen to occur without any cause, even when the soul, sense organs, and objects are present. And from the fact that memory arises even when the ear and other sense organs are not functioning, and from the fact that there is an internal organ that perceives pleasure etc. not apprehended by the external sense organs, there is an internal organ.

original: tasya guṇāḥ saṃkhyāparimāṇapṛthaktvasaṃyogavibhāgaparatvāparatvasaṃskārāḥ / prayatnajñānāyaugapadyavacanāt pratiśarīramekatvaṃ siddham / pṛthaktvamapyata eva / tadabhāvavacanādaṇuparimāṇam / apasarpaṇopasarpaṇavacanāt saṃyogavibhāgau / mūrtatvāt paratvāparatve saṃskāraśca / asparśavattvād dravyānārambhakatvam / kriyāvattvānmūrtatvam / sādhāraṇavigrahavattvaprasaṅgādajñatvam / karaṇabhāvāt pārārthyam / guṇavattvād dravyam / prayatnādṛṣṭaparigrahavaśād āśusañcāri ceti /PDhS
analyzed: tasya guṇāḥ saṃkhyā parimāṇa pṛthaktva saṃyoga vibhāga para tva apara tva saṃskārāḥ prayatna jñāna ayaugapadya vacanāt pratiśarīram eka tvam siddham pṛthaktvam api atas eva tad abhāva vacanāt aṇu parimāṇam apasarpaṇa upasarpaṇa vacanāt saṃyoga vibhāgau mūrta tvāt paratva aparatve saṃskāraḥ ca asparśavat tvāt dravya anārambhaka tvam kriyāvat tvāt mūrta tvam sādhāraṇa vigrahavat tva prasaṅgāt ajña tvam karaṇa bhāvāt pārārthyam guṇavat t
translated: Its qualities are number, dimension, separateness, conjunction, disjunction, priority, posteriority, and inherence. From the statement of the simultaneity of effort and knowledge, it is established that it is one for each body. Separateness is also due to this alone. From the statement of its absence, it has atomic dimension. From the statements of receding and approaching, it has conjunction and disjunction. From its being corporeal, it has priority, posteriority, and inherence. From its being intangible, it does not produce substances. From its being an action, it is corporeal. From the possibility of having a common body, it is not conscious. From its being an instrument, it is for the sake of others. From its having qualities, it is a substance. And from the control of effort and unseen force, it moves swiftly.

original: idānīṃ manaso lakṣaṇaparīkṣārthaṃ manastvayogānmanaḥ ityādi prakaraṇam / manastvena yogo manastvopalakṣitaḥ samavāyo lakṣaṇamiti / tathā hi / manaḥ / itarasmād bhidyate / manastvayogāt / yastvitarasmādamanaso na bhidyate na cāsau manastvena yuktaḥ / yathā kṣityādiriti / vyavahāro vā sādhyaḥ / śeṣaṃ lakṣaṇasya dūṣaṇapratisamādhānaṃ pūrvavajjñeyam / tathā śabdārthanirūpaṇaparatvañceti /
analyzed: idānīm manasaḥ lakṣaṇa parīkṣā artham manaḥ tva yogāt manaḥ ityādi prakaraṇam manaḥ tvena yogaḥ manaḥ tva upalakṣitaḥ samavāyaḥ lakṣaṇam iti tathā hi manaḥ itarasmāt bhidyate manaḥ tva yogāt yaḥ tu itarasmāt amanasaḥ na bhidyate na ca asau manaḥ tvena yuktaḥ yathā kṣiti ādiḥ iti vyavahāraḥ vā sādhyaḥ śeṣam lakṣaṇasya dūṣaṇa pratisamādhānam pūrvavat jñeyam tathā śabda artha nirūpaṇa paratvam ca iti
translated: Now, for the examination of the definition of mind, the section beginning with because of the connection with mindness is for the purpose of defining mind. The definition is the inherence characterized by the connection with mindness. Thus, mind is distinguished from other things because of the connection with mindness. That which is not distinguished from other things, the non-mind, and is not connected with mindness, like earth etc., is not mind. Or, the conclusion to be established is the usage. The rest of the refutation and re-establishment of the definition should be understood as before, and also the purpose of determining the meaning of the word.

original: atha pratyakṣeṇānupalabdhermanasaḥ sadbhāve kiṃ pramāṇam / anumānamityāha satyapyātmendriyārthasānnidhye jñānasukhaduḥkhānām abhūtvotpattidarśanāt iti / tathā hyātmā sarvagatatvādeva sarvairindriyaiḥ sambaddhaḥ / indriyāṇi tu svaviṣayairiti / tathāpi na yugapad rūpādijñānānyutpadyanta iti karaṇāntaramanumīyate /
analyzed: atha pratyakṣeṇa anupalabdheḥ manasaḥ sadbhāve kim pramāṇam anumānam iti āha sati api ātma indriya artha sānnidhye jñāna sukha duḥkhānām a bhūtvā utpatti darśanāt iti tathā hi ātmā sarvagata tvāt eva sarvaiḥ indriyaiḥ sambaddhaḥ indriyāṇi tu sva viṣayaiḥ iti tathā api na yugapad rūpa ādi jñānāni utpadyante iti karaṇa antaram anumīyate
translated: Now, what is the proof for the existence of the mind, which is not perceived by perception? He says that it is inference. Even when the soul, sense organs, and objects are present, the arising of knowledge, pleasure, and pain is seen. For thus, the soul, being all-pervading, is connected with all the sense organs. But the sense organs are with their own objects. Even so, the cognitions of form etc. do not arise simultaneously. Therefore, another instrument is inferred.

original: athendriyāṇāṃ svaviṣayaiḥ sambandhaḥ kathaṃ jñāyate / anumānāt / tathā hi / ghrāṇam / svavyāptasaṃyoginā saṃyuktam / tatsaṃyuktavyāpakatvāt / yo yaḥ saṃyuktavyāpakaḥ sa svavyāptasaṃyogisaṃyujyamāno dṛṣṭaḥ / yathā vīraṇasaṃyuktatantuvyāpakaḥ paṭo vīraṇena saṃyukta iti / sthānasaṃyuktaṃ vā karpūrādidravyam / svasaṃyuktavyāpinā saṃyujyate / tadvyāptasaṃyogitvāt / yo yadvyāptasaṃyogī sa svasaṃyuktavyāpinā saṃyujyamāno dṛṣṭaḥ / yathā paṭavyāptatantusaṃyogivīraṇaṃ paṭena saṃyujyamānamiti /
analyzed: atha indriyāṇām sva viṣayaiḥ sambandhaḥ katham jñāyate anumānāt tathā hi ghrāṇam sva vyāpta saṃyoginā saṃyuktam tad saṃyukta vyāpaka tvāt yaḥ yaḥ saṃyukta vyāpakaḥ sa sva vyāpta saṃyogi saṃyujyamānaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ yathā vīraṇa saṃyukta tantu vyāpakaḥ paṭaḥ vīraṇena saṃyuktaḥ iti sthāna saṃyuktam vā karpūra ādi dravyam sva saṃyukta vyāpinā saṃyujyate tad vyāpta saṃyogi tvāt yaḥ yad vyāpta saṃyogī sa sva saṃyukta vyāpi
translated: Now, how is the relation of the senses with their objects known? From inference. Thus, the nose is conjoined with what is conjoined with its pervasion. Because it is the pervader of what is conjoined with that. Whatever is the pervader of what is conjoined is seen to be conjoined with what is conjoined with its pervasion. For example, a cloth, which is the pervader of threads conjoined with vīraṇa, is conjoined with vīraṇa. Or a substance like camphor, which is conjoined with its location, is conjoined with what pervades what is conjoined with it. Because it is the conjoined pervasion of that. Whatever is the conjoined pervasion of something is seen to be conjoined with what pervades what is conjoined with it. For example, vīraṇa, which is the conjoined pervasion of threads, is conjoined with the cloth.

original: evaṃ rasanendriyam / svavyāptasaṃyoginā saṃyuktam / tatsaṃyuktavyāpakatvāt / vīraṇasaṃyuktatantuvyāpakapaṭavat / sthānasaṃyuktaṃ vā dravyam / svasaṃyuktavyāpinā saṃyujyate / tadvyāptasaṃyogitvāt / paṭavyāptatantusaṃyogivīraṇādivaditi / evaṃ śeṣeṣvapīti / gītadhvanistu sannihitasya tacchravaṇasātatyena śrotrasambandhe eva /
analyzed: evam rasanā indriyam sva vyāpta saṃyoginā saṃyuktam tad saṃyukta vyāpaka tvāt vīraṇa saṃyukta tantu vyāpaka paṭa vat  / sthāna saṃyuktam vā dravyam sva saṃyukta vyāpinā saṃyujyate tad vyāpta saṃyogi tvāt paṭa vyāpta tantu saṃyogi vīraṇa ādi vat iti evam śeṣeṣu api iti  gīta dhvaniḥ tu sannihitasya tad śravaṇa sātatyena śrotra sambandhe eva
translated: Similarly, the organ of taste is in contact with what is in contact with its own pervasion, because it pervades what is in contact with that, like a cloth that pervades yarns in contact with vīraṇa. Or a substance in contact with a place is in contact with what is in contact with its own pervader, because it is in contact with what pervades that, like vīraṇa, etc., which are in contact with yarns that pervade a cloth. Similarly, in the remaining cases. But the sound of singing is in contact with the ear only when it is nearby and is continuously heard.

original: yadyetāvat kāraṇaṃ jñānasukhaduḥkhānām / tatsadbhāve 'nutpattirna syāt / na hi kāraṇasākalye 'pi kāryasyānutpattirdṛṣṭeti / tasmādeṣāṃ sadbhāve 'pi kāryasya pūrvam abhūtvā paścādutpattidarśanāt kāraṇāntaramanumīyate / yasya sadbhāvāsadbhāvābhyāṃ kāryasyotpattyanutpattī / athādṛṣṭo 'syāmeva kāraṇaṃ bhaviṣyatīti / na / śrotrādīnāmapyabhāvaprasaṅgāt / tasyāpi cedānīṃ tatsādhanasyānanuṣṭhānāccirotpāde sa eva doṣaḥ /
analyzed: yadi etāvat kāraṇam jñāna sukha duḥkhānām tad sadbhāve nutpattiḥ na syāt  na hi kāraṇa sākalye pi kāryasya anutpattiḥ dṛṣṭā iti  tasmāt eṣām sadbhāve pi kāryasya pūrvam a bhūtvā paścāt utpatti darśanāt kāraṇa antaram anumīyate yasya sadbhāva asadbhāvābhyām kāryasya utpatti anutpattī atha adṛṣṭaḥ syām eva kāraṇam bhaviṣyati iti na śrotra ādīnām api abhāva prasaṅgāt tasya api ca idānīm tad sādhanasya ananuṣṭhānāt cira utpāde s
translated: If this much is the cause of knowledge, pleasure and pain, then their non-arising would not occur in its presence. For the non-arising of an effect is not seen even when the totality of causes is present. Therefore, even in their presence, since the effect is seen to arise later after not having existed before, another cause is inferred, whose presence and absence are the cause of the arising and non-arising of the effect. If it is argued that an unseen [cause] will be the cause in this [case] itself, [this is not so]. Because of the possibility of the non-existence of the ear and others. And because of the non-performance of that means [of knowledge] now, the same fault would occur in the production after a long time.

original: tadevamātmendriyārthāḥ / kāraṇāntarāpekṣāḥ / sadbhāve 'pyanutpādyotpādakatvāt / ye hi sadbhāve 'pi kāryamanutpādya paścādutpādayanti te sāpekṣāḥ / yathā tantvādayo 'nyatantusaṃyogāpekṣā iti / anye tvātmā / kramavatkāraṇāpekṣaḥ / itarasākalye 'pi krameṇa kāryajanakatvāt / yo hītarakāraṇasākalye 'pi krameṇa kāryaṃ karoti sa kramavat kāraṇāpekṣaḥ / yathā anekaśilpābhijñaḥ puruṣa iti / cakṣurādayo vā kramavatkāraṇāpekṣāḥ / sadbhāve 'pi krameṇa kāryajanakatvāt / yo hi vidyamānaḥ krameṇa kāryaṃ karoti so 'vaśyaṃ kramavatkāraṇamapekṣate / yathā vāsīkartaryādi hastamityanumānaṃ bruvate /
analyzed: tat evam ātma indriya arthāḥ kāraṇa antara apekṣāḥ sadbhāve pi an utpādya utpādaka tvāt ye hi sadbhāve pi kāryam an utpādya paścāt utpādayanti te sa apekṣāḥ yathā tantu ādayaḥ nya tantu saṃyoga apekṣāḥ iti anye tu ātmā kramavat kāraṇa apekṣaḥ itara sākalye pi krameṇa kārya janaka tvāt yaḥ hi itara kāraṇa sākalye pi krameṇa kāryam karoti sa kramavat kāraṇa apekṣaḥ yathā aneka śilpa abhijñaḥ puruṣaḥ iti cakṣuḥ ādayaḥ vā kram
translated: Thus, the self, sense faculties, and objects depend on other causes, because even when they exist, they are not necessarily productive. For those that, even when existing, do not produce an effect and later produce it, depend on something else. For example, threads depend on the conjunction with another thread. Others say the self depends on a cause that acts in succession, because even when the other factors are complete, it produces the effect in succession. For one who produces an effect in succession even when the other causes are complete, depends on a cause that acts in succession. For example, a person skilled in many crafts. Or the eye and so on depend on a cause that acts in succession, because even when they exist, they produce the effect in succession. For one who produces an effect in succession even when existing, necessarily depends on a cause that acts in succession. For example, a hand with a knife and a cutting board. They state this inference.

original: tathā ātmā indriyārthasānnidhye 'pi krameṇaiva kāryaṃ karotīti dṛṣṭam / evaṃ cakṣurādayo 'pyātmanādhiṣṭhitā viṣayasambandhakrameṇaiva kāryaṃ kurvantīti kramavatkāraṇamapekṣante / tathā śrotrādyavyāpāre smṛtyutpattidarśanāt asti karaṇāntaram / tathā hi smṛtiḥ / karaṇajanyā / kriyātvāt / chidikriyāvat / na ca śrotrādyeva karaṇam / tadavyāpāre 'pi smṛtyutpattidarśanāt / yad yadavyāpāre 'pyutpadyate tat tasya kāryaṃ na bhavatyeva / I / yathā vinaṣṭeṣu tantuṣūtpadyamāno ghaṭa iti / smṛtistu badhirādīnāṃ śrotrādyavyāpāre 'pyutpadyata iti na tatkāryā / ataḥ karaṇāntareṇa bhavitavyam /
