analyzed: tathā ātmā indriya artha sānnidhye pi krameṇa eva kāryam karoti iti dṛṣṭam evam cakṣuḥ ādayaḥ pi ātmanā adhiṣṭhitāḥ viṣaya sambandha krameṇa eva kāryam kurvanti iti kramavat kāraṇam apekṣante tathā śrotra ādi avyāpāre smṛti utpatti darśanāt asti karaṇa antaram tathā hi smṛtiḥ karaṇa janyā kriyā tvāt chidi kriyā vat na ca śrotra ādi eva karaṇam tad avyāpāre pi smṛti utpatti darśanāt yat yad avyāpāre pi utpadyate tat tasya kāryam na bh
translated: Similarly, the Self is seen to produce its effects in succession, even when the objects of the senses are present. In the same way, the eyes and other sense organs, when controlled by the Self, produce their effects in succession, in relation to the objects, and thus require a cause that operates in succession. Similarly, the fact that memory arises even when the ear and other sense organs are not functioning shows that there is another instrument. For example, memory is produced by an instrument, because it is an action, like the action of cutting. And the ear etc. are not the instrument, because memory is seen to arise even when they are not functioning. That which arises even when something is not functioning is not the effect of that, just as a pot that arises when the threads are destroyed. But memory arises even when the ear etc. are not functioning in the deaf etc., so it is not their effect. Therefore, it must be produced by another instrument.

original: tathā bāhyendriyairagṛhītasukhādigrāhyāntarasadbhāvācca karaṇāntaramasti / tathā hi sukhādayaḥ / karaṇaparicchedyāḥ / grāhyatvāt / rūpādivat / na ca cakṣurādyeva karaṇam bāhyendriyairagṛhītasya sukhādergrāhyāntarasya sadbhāvādityabhidhānāt / yathā cakṣuṣā gandho na gṛhyata iti karaṇāntaraṃ ghrāṇamanumīyate / tābhyāñca rasasyāparicchedād rasanānumānam / taiśca sparśasya tathā śabdasya ceti karaṇāntarānumānamiti / tadvad bāhyendriyaiḥ sukhādayo na gṛhyanta iti tatparicchedakaṃ mano 'numīyate /
analyzed: tathā bāhya indriyaiḥ agṛhīta sukha ādi grāhya antara sadbhāvāt ca karaṇa antaram asti tathā hi sukha ādayaḥ karaṇa paricchedyāḥ grāhya tvāt rūpa ādi vat na ca cakṣuḥ ādi eva karaṇam bāhya indriyaiḥ agṛhītasya sukha ādeḥ grāhya antarasya sadbhāvāt iti abhidhānāt  yathā cakṣuṣā gandhaḥ na gṛhyate iti karaṇa antaram ghrāṇam anumīyate tābhyām ca rasasya aparicchedāt rasanā anumānam taiḥ ca sparśasya tathā śabdasya ca iti karaṇa antara
translated: And because there is an object of perception other than pleasure etc. not grasped by the external senses, there is another sense organ. Thus, pleasure etc. are to be discriminated by a sense organ, because they are objects of perception, like form etc. And the eye etc. are not the sense organ, because there is an object of perception other than pleasure etc. not grasped by the external senses. Just as the existence of another sense organ, the nose, is inferred because smell is not perceived by the eye, and the existence of the tongue is inferred because taste is not discriminated by those two, and the existence of other sense organs is inferred in the same way for touch and sound, in the same way, since pleasure etc. are not perceived by the external senses, the mind that discriminates them is inferred.

original: siddhe ca manaḥsadbhāve dravyatvasamavāyikāraṇatvapratipādanārthaṃ tasya guṇāḥ saṃkhyāparimāṇapṛthaktvasaṃyogavibhāgaparatvāparatvasaṃskārāḥ iti vākyam / dravyatvādeva saṃkhyāsadbhāvasiddhau kimekamanekaṃ veta saṃśaye tannirāsārthamāha prayatnajñānāyaugapadyavacanāt pratiśarīramekatvaṃ siddham iti prayatnāyaugapadyājjñānāyaugapadyavacanācca pratiśarīramekaṃ manaḥ vai / sū / / / iti sūtraṃ darśayati / asamāsakaraṇañcātra sukhaduḥkhādyayaugapadyāvarodhārtham / sūtrārthastu naikamanekasmiñcharīre / nāpyekasminnanekaṃ vā manaḥ / kiṃ tarhi / pratiśarīramekam / kutaḥ / prayatnāyaugapadyāt / jñānāyaugapadyācca / yadi punarekaṃ syād vyāpakaṃ manaḥ sarvendriyāṇāṃ tadadhiṣṭhitatvād yugapad rūpādijñānānyutpadyeran prayatnāśceti / na caivaṃ dṛṣṭam /
analyzed: siddhe ca manaḥ sadbhāve dravya tva samavāyi kāraṇa tva pratipādana artham tasya guṇāḥ saṃkhyā parimāṇa pṛthaktva saṃyoga vibhāga para tva apara tva saṃskārāḥ iti vākyam dravya tvāt eva saṃkhyā sadbhāva siddhau kim ekam anekam vā ita saṃśaye tad nirāsa artham āha prayatna jñāna ayaugapadya vacanāt pratiśarīram eka tvam siddham iti prayatna ayaugapadyāt jñāna ayaugapadya vacanāt ca pratiśarīram ekam manaḥ vai iti sūtram darśayati asamāsa karaṇam ca
translated: And when the existence of mind is established, the sentence Its qualities are number, dimension, separateness, conjunction, disjunction, priority, posteriority, and inherence is stated to establish its being the inherent cause of substance. When the existence of number is established by substance itself, in the doubt whether it is one or many, it is said to refute that, showing the sutra It is established that there is one mind per body, from the statement of the non-simultaneity of effort and knowledge. The non-compositeness here is for the purpose of excluding the simultaneity of pleasure, pain, etc. The meaning of the sutra is this: There is not one mind in many bodies, nor many in one body. What then? There is one per body. Why? From the non-simultaneity of effort and from the non-simultaneity of knowledge. If, on the other hand, the mind were one, pervading, and all the senses were controlled by it, then there would be simultaneous knowledge of form, etc.

original: atha dīrghaśaṣkulīṃ bhakṣayataḥ kapilabrahmaṇo yugapat pañca / jñānānyutpadyante / tathā adhyāpakasya yugapad vākyoccāraṇagamanamārgānveṣaṇakamaṇḍaludhāraṇeṣu prayatnā utpadyanta ityasiddhametat / tanna / yaugapadye prasiddhodāharaṇābhāvāt / utpalapatraśatavyatibhedābhimānavad āśubhāvitvena yaugapadyābhimāno draṣṭavyaḥ / krame tvanekaṃ prasiddhamudāharaṇamasti / tasmādaṇuparimāṇasya manasaḥ krameṇendriyasambandhāt krameṇaiva jñānāni bhavantīti yuktam / aṇuparimāṇasyāpyekasmiñ śarīre 'nekatvābhyupagame kiñcidindriyaṃ kenacinmanasādhiṣṭhitamiti jñānayaugapadyameva syāt / krameṇa tu jñānānyutpadyamānāni saṃvedyanta iti pratiśarīramaṇuparimāṇamekaṃ manaḥ / na caivamapi manasā cakṣuradhiṣṭhitamanekārthasambaddhaṃ yugapajjñānānyutpādayet / naitadevam / ekasya karaṇasyaikakriyānirvṛttau sāmarthyopalabdheḥ / na hyekaṃ karaṇamekasmin kāle 'nekāṃ kriyāṃ kurvad dṛṣṭamiti /
analyzed: atha dīrgha śaṣkulīm bhakṣayataḥ kapila brahmaṇaḥ yugapad pañca jñānāni utpadyante tathā adhyāpakasya yugapad vākya uccāraṇa gamana mārga anveṣaṇa kamaṇḍalu dhāraṇeṣu prayatnāḥ utpadyante iti asiddham etat tat na yaugapadye prasiddha udāharaṇa abhāvāt utpala patra śata vyatibheda abhimāna vat āśu bhāvi tvena yaugapadya abhimānaḥ draṣṭavyaḥ krame tu anekam prasiddham udāharaṇam asti tasmāt aṇu parimāṇasya manasaḥ krameṇa indriya samband
translated: Now, when one is eating a long-stemmed lotus leaf, five cognitions arise simultaneously for the sage Kapila. Similarly, for a teacher, efforts arise simultaneously in speaking, walking, searching for a path, and holding a water pot. This is not established. That is not so, because there are no well-known examples of simultaneity. The notion of simultaneity should be seen as arising from the rapid occurrence, like the notion of the perforation of a hundred lotus petals. But in the case of succession, there are many well-known examples. Therefore, it is reasonable that cognitions arise only in succession, because the mind, which has atomic dimensions, comes into contact with the sense organs only in succession. Even if it is accepted that the mind, though having atomic dimensions, is many in one body, some sense organ would be controlled by some mind, and there would be simultaneity of cognitions. But cognitions arising in succession are experienced. Therefore, the mind is one, having atomic dimensions, in each body. And even so, the eye is not controlled by the mind.

original: atha kuṭhārābhighātādanekatṛṇeṣu yugapadanekakriyopalabdherayuktametat / na / bodhātmakatvena viśeṣitatvāt / yad vā kuṭhārāvayavānāṃ karaṇatvam / yathā tīkṣṇo 'vayavī tṛṇaiḥ sambaddhastathā tadavayavāstaiḥ sambaddhā eveti karaṇabahutvād yuktaṃ kriyāyaugapadyam /
analyzed: atha kuṭhāra abhighātāt aneka tṛṇeṣu yugapad aneka kriyā upalabdheḥ ayuktam etat na bodha ātmaka tvena viśeṣita tvāt yat vā kuṭhāra avayavānām karaṇa tvam yathā tīkṣṇaḥ vayavī tṛṇaiḥ sambaddhaḥ tathā tad avayavāḥ taiḥ sambaddhāḥ eva iti karaṇa bahutvāt yuktam kriyā yaugapadyam
translated: If it be argued that “the said explanation is not proper, because several actions are found to be produced simultaneously in several grasses struck by the stroke of the scythe”, the answer is that that cannot be; because the action has been defined as consisting in the ‘appearance of another place’, and the ‘appearance of another place’ cannot belong to what is non-existent. Or, the several parts of the scythe may be regarded as the ‘instruments’ (of the action); just as the sharp scythe comes into contact with the grasses, so also do its parts; so that the simultaneity of the actions is quite in accordance with the plurality of the instruments.

original: abhighātāstu karaṇānītyanye / tathā hi kuṭhārasya tṛṇaiḥ sambandhāḥ vegāpekṣā avayavāḥ parasparaṃ vibhinnā eva / naitadyuktam / karmaṇā sambaddhasyaiva kuṭhārasya karaṇatvāt / anyathā hi cakṣuṣo 'pi sambandhibhedāt sambandhabhedopapattesteṣāmapi karaṇatvena cakṣurdvāreṇa manasādhiṣṭhitatvād yugapad ghaṭādijñānotpattiprasaṅgaḥ / na caitadasti / asaṃvedanāditi / tasmād yugapat prakāśanameva ghaṭādīnāṃ na grahaṇānīti / cakṣuranekapadārthasambaddhaṃ karaṇamiti nyāyyam / ataḥ karaṇasyaikakriyānirvṛttau sāmarthyam / siddhe ca nānātve tadanuvidhānāt sāhacaryānnānāpṛthaktvaṃ sidhyatyeva /
analyzed: abhighātāḥ tu karaṇāni iti anye tathā hi kuṭhārasya tṛṇaiḥ sambandhāḥ vega apekṣāḥ avayavāḥ parasparam vibhinnāḥ eva na etat yuktam karmaṇā sambaddhasya eva kuṭhārasya karaṇa tvāt anyathā hi sambandhi bhedāt sambandha bheda upapatteḥ teṣām api karaṇa tvena cakṣuḥ dvāreṇa manasā adhiṣṭhita tvāt yugapad ghaṭa ādi jñāna utpatti prasaṅgaḥ na ca etat asti asaṃvedanāt iti tasmāt yugapad prakāśanam eva ghaṭa ādīnām na grahaṇāni i
translated: Others say that the striking is the instrument. Thus, the parts of the axe that are related to the grass and depend on velocity are indeed different from each other. This is not correct. Because only that axe which is related to the action is the instrument. Otherwise, since the difference in the relation of the eye is also possible due to the difference in the related objects, those [parts of the axe] would also be the instrument. And because they are controlled by the mind through the eye, there would be the undesirable consequence of the simultaneous arising of the knowledge of the pot etc. But this is not so. Because it is not experienced. Therefore, the simultaneous illumination of the pot etc. is not their apprehension. It is proper that the eye is the instrument related to many objects. Therefore, the instrument has the capacity to accomplish a single action. And when the plurality is established, the plurality and separateness are established by the concomitance of that [instrument] due to association.

original: tathā tadabhāvavacanādaṇuparimāṇam iti vibhavānmahānākāśastathā cātmā / tadabhāvādaṇu manaḥ vai / sū / / / iti sūtre darśayati / tasya vibhutvasyābhāvādaṇu mana iti /
analyzed: tathā tad abhāva vacanāt aṇu parimāṇam iti vibhavāt mahān ākāśaḥ tathā ca ātmā tad abhāvāt aṇu manaḥ vai iti sūtre darśayati tasya vibhu tvasya abhāvāt aṇu manaḥ iti
translated: Similarly, because of the statement of its absence, the mind is atomic in size. Thus, space is all-pervading and so is the self. Because of its absence, the mind is atomic. This is shown in the sutra The mind is atomic because of the absence of its all-pervasiveness.

original: nanvevaṃ ghaṭādāvapi vibhutvasyābhāvādaṇutvaṃ syāt / na / nityadravyasyeti viśeṣaṇāt / tathā hi manaḥ / aṇuparimāṇasambandhi / nityadravyatve sati vibhutvarahitatvāt / yad yannityadravyatve sati vibhutvarahitaṃ tat tathā dṛṣṭam / yathā paramāṇvādiḥ / tathā cedaṃ vibhutvarahitam / tasmādaṇuparimāṇamiti / ghaṭādau vibhutvarahitatve 'pi nāṇuparimāṇamiti nityatvagrahaṇam / nityatvaṃ guṇādāvapyastīti dravyapadam /
analyzed: nanu evam ghaṭa ādau api vibhu tvasya abhāvāt aṇu tvam syāt na nitya dravyasya iti viśeṣaṇāt tathā hi manaḥ aṇu parimāṇa sambandhi nitya dravya tve sati vibhu tva rahita tvāt yat yat nitya dravya tve sati vibhu tva rahitam tat tathā dṛṣṭam yathā paramāṇu ādiḥ tathā ca idam vibhu tva rahitam tasmāt aṇu parimāṇam iti ghaṭa ādau vibhu tva rahita tve pi na aṇu parimāṇam iti nitya tva grahaṇam nitya tvam guṇa ādau api asti iti dravya padam
translated: But in that case, even in a pot, atomicity would result from the absence of all-pervasiveness. No, because of the qualification of an eternal substance. Thus, the mind is related to atomic size because of being an eternal substance devoid of all-pervasiveness. Whatever is devoid of all-pervasiveness while being an eternal substance is seen to be so, like an atom and so on. And this is devoid of all-pervasiveness. Therefore, it has atomic size. In a pot, even though it is devoid of all-pervasiveness, it does not have atomic size. Thus, the word eternal is used. All-pervasiveness exists even in a quality, so the word substance is used.

original: tathā apasarpaṇopasarpaṇavacanāt saṃyogavibhāgau iti / apasarpaṇamupasarpaṇamaśitapītasaṃyogāḥ kāryāntarasaṃyogāścetyadṛṣṭakāritāni vai / sū / / / iti sūtraṃ darśayati / apasarpaṇantu mṛtaśarīrād vibhāgārthaṃ karma / pratyagreṇa śarīreṇa saṃyogārthaścopasarpaṇamiti / aśitapītam bhuktamudakādi tayornāḍyantareṇa sañcaraṇam / kāryāntaraṃ śarīrāntaram / tena saṃyogo manasaḥ / tadarthaṃ manaḥkarma yogināmityetat sarvamadṛṣṭakāritamityanyapareṇāpi sūtreṇa saṃyogavibhāgāvuktau / tathā mūrtatvāt paratvāparatve tayormūrtyanuvidhānāt / yatra hi mūrtatvaṃ tatra taddarśinaḥ parāparavyavahāraḥ sambhavatīti / dikkṛte tu paratvāparatve manasi / kālakṛtayornityatvenāsambhavāt / kāryadravyāpekṣayā tu taddarśinaḥ kālakṛtaṃ paratvaṃ manasi sambhāvyata eva / paraṃ manaḥ / aparañca kāryadravyamiti / na cāyaṃ niyamaḥ samānajātīyayoreva parāparavyavahārasya dṛṣṭatvāt / tathā na paraṃ paratvāparatve saṃskāraśca mūrtatvādeva vegākhyaḥ /
analyzed: tathā apasarpaṇa upasarpaṇa vacanāt saṃyoga vibhāgau iti apasarpaṇam upasarpaṇam aśita pīta saṃyogāḥ kārya antara saṃyogāḥ ca iti adṛṣṭa kāritāni vai iti sūtram darśayati apasarpaṇam tu mṛta śarīrāt vibhāga artham karma pratyagreṇa śarīreṇa saṃyoga arthaḥ ca upasarpaṇam iti aśita pītam bhuktam udaka ādi tayoḥ nāḍī antareṇa sañcaraṇam kārya antaram śarīra antaram tena saṃyogaḥ manasaḥ tad artham manaḥ karma yoginām iti etat sa
translated: Similarly, from the statements of moving away and moving towards, there are conjunctions and disjunctions. Moving away and moving towards are caused by unseen forces, such as the conjunctions of food and drink and other actions. The sutra shows this. But moving away is an action for the purpose of disjunction from the dead body, and moving towards is for the purpose of conjunction with the body in front. Food and drink are what is eaten, water etc., their circulation through the channels. Another action is another body, the conjunction of the mind with that. For that purpose, the action of the mind of yogis - all this is caused by unseen forces. Conjunctions and disjunctions are stated by another sutra that is not about this. Similarly, because of being material, there are farness and nearness, because they conform to the material. For where there is materiality, there the usage of far and near by the perceiver is possible. But farness and nearness created by space are in the mind. Because those created by time are impossible due to being eternal. But in relation to the effect substance, the perception of that is

original: atha manaḥ paraspareṇa sambaddhaṃ kimiti dravyaṃ nārabhate / samānajātīyamūrtadravyasambandhasya antyāvayavivyatirekeṇa dravyārambhakatvadarśanādityāha asparśavattvād dravyāI /nārambhakatvam iti / sparśavato hi dravyasya dravyārambhakatvadarśanāt / yathā paramāṇūnām / na ca manasaḥ sparśavatve pramāṇamasti / manastvajātīyasya sparśavatkāryasyānupalabdheḥ / yathā hi pṛthivītvajātīyaṃ sparśavatkāryamupalabhyamānaṃ tadārambhakāṇāmaṇūnāṃ sparśavattāṃ jñāpayati / naivaṃ manastvajātīyaṃ kāryamastīti kathaṃ manasaḥ sparśavattvam / tathā sparśavattve sati śarīre sañcarato vāyoriva pratisañcalanāt kvacidindriyāntareṇāsambandhād anekakālaṃ rūpāderviṣayasyāgrahaṇamapi syāt / na caitat suṣuptyavasthāmantareṇa dṛṣṭamiti / tasmādasparśavattvena dravyānārambhakatvamiti /
analyzed: atha manaḥ paraspareṇa sambaddham kim iti dravyam na ārabhate samāna jātīya mūrta dravya sambandhasya antya avayavi vyatirekeṇa dravya ārambhaka tva darśanāt iti āha asparśavat tvāt iti sparśavataḥ hi dravyasya dravya ārambhaka tva darśanāt yathā paramāṇūnām na ca manasaḥ sparśava tve pramāṇam asti manaḥ tva jātīyasya sparśavat kāryasya anupalabdheḥ yathā hi pṛthivī tva jātīyam sparśavat kāryam upalabhyamānam tad ārambhakāṇām aṇūnām sparśavat t
translated: Now, if the mind is connected with each other, why does it not produce a substance? Because it is seen that the connection of a substance of the same class produces a substance except in the case of the ultimate atom, he says: It does not produce a substance because it is without touch. For it is seen that a substance with touch produces a substance, like the atoms. And there is no evidence that the mind has touch. Because a product with touch of the same class as the mind is not perceived. For just as when a product with touch of the class of earth is perceived, it indicates the presence of touch in the atoms that produce it, so there is no such product of the class of mind. How then can the mind have touch? Similarly, if it had touch, then like the wind moving in the body, there would be a rebound, and there would be no apprehension of an object like form at some other time due to lack of connection with some other sense organ. And this is not so in the state of deep sleep.

original: aṇuparimāṇavyavasthāpanāt siddhe 'pi mūrtatve punaḥ sādhanamāha kriyāvattvānmūrtatvam iti / tadanuvidhānāt kriyāyāḥ / sā cendriyasambandhād vijñāyate / anyathā hi aṇuparimāṇaṃ manaḥ kathamindriyāntareṇa sambadhyate /
analyzed: aṇu parimāṇa vyavasthāpanāt siddhe mūrta tve punar sādhanam āha kriyāvat tvāt mūrta tvam iti tad anuvidhānāt kriyāyāḥ sā ca indriya sambandhāt vijñāyate anyathā hi aṇu parimāṇam manaḥ katham indriya antareṇa sambadhyate
translated: Although corporeality is established by the determination of atomic dimension, he again gives a proof, saying Corporeality is due to having action, because action is dependent on that. And that is known from the connection with the sense faculties. Otherwise, how could the mind, which has atomic dimension, be connected with another sense faculty?

original: pūrvaṃ manaścaitanyapratiṣedhe 'pi punarbādhakamāha sādhāraṇavigrahavattvaprasaṅgādajñatvam iti / yadi hi cetanaṃ manaḥ syādubhayāḥ sādhāraṇaṃ śarīramupabhogyamiti viruddhābhiprāyatve bhogānupapattiḥ syāt /
analyzed: pūrvam manaḥ caitanya pratiṣedhe punar bādhakam āha sādhāraṇa vigrahavat tva prasaṅgāt ajñatvam iti yadi hi cetanam manaḥ syāt ubhayāḥ sādhāraṇam śarīram upabhogyam iti viruddha abhiprāya tve bhoga anupapattiḥ syāt
translated: Although the sentience of the mind was previously refuted, he again states an objection, saying Ignorance is due to the possibility of having a common body, meaning that if the mind were sentient, the body would be enjoyed by both, and due to having conflicting intentions, enjoyment would be impossible.

original: atha kiṃ svārthaṃ parārthaṃ vetyāha karaṇabhāvāt pārārthyam iti / karaṇaṃ hi vāsyādi parapuruṣārthasampādakaṃ dṛṣṭam / tathā ca karaṇaṃ manaḥ / tasmāt karturātmanaḥ puruṣārthasampādakamiti / atha kiṃ dravyaṃ guṇaḥ karma vā mana ityāha guṇavattvād dravyam iti / kṣityādivat / guṇāstūktā eva /
analyzed: atha kim svārtham parārtham vā iti āha karaṇa bhāvāt pārārthyam iti karaṇam hi para puruṣa artha sampādakam dṛṣṭam tathā ca karaṇam manaḥ tasmāt kartuḥ ātmanaḥ puruṣa artha sampādakam iti atha kim dravyam guṇaḥ karma vā manaḥ iti āha guṇavat tvāt dravyam iti kṣiti ādi vat guṇāḥ tu uktāḥ eva
translated: Now, whether it is for one's own purpose or for another's purpose? He says: Because of being an instrument, it serves another's purpose. An instrument like a knife is seen to accomplish the purpose of another person. And the mind is an instrument in that way. Therefore, it is the means of accomplishing the purpose of the agent, the self. Now, whether the mind is a substance, a quality, or an action? He says: It is a substance because it has qualities, like earth etc. And the qualities have been mentioned.

original: atha aṇuparimāṇatvānmanasaḥ kathaṃ rūpādijñānānyāśūtpadyanta ityāha āśusañcāri / tacca prayatnādṛṣṭaparigrahavaśāt / prayatnena jīvanapūrvakeṇādṛṣṭaviśeṣeṇa ca parigrahavaśādāśusañcāritvamiti /
analyzed: atha aṇu parimāṇa tvāt manasaḥ katham rūpa ādi jñānāni āśu utpadyante iti āha āśu sañcāri tat ca prayatna adṛṣṭa parigraha vaśāt prayatnena jīvana pūrvakeṇa adṛṣṭa viśeṣeṇa ca parigraha vaśāt āśu sañcāri tvam iti
translated: Now, how do the cognitions of form etc. arise quickly from the mind, because of its atomic size? He says: It moves quickly. And that is due to the influence of effort and unseen [forces]. The quick movement is due to the influence of effort and a particular unseen [force] preceded by life.

original: iti śrīvyomaśivācāryaviracitāyāṃ padārthadharmasaṅgrahaṭīkāyāṃ vyomavatyāṃ dravyapadārthaḥ🔽guṇaprakaraṇam
analyzed: iti śrī vyomaśivācārya viracitāyām padārtha dharmasaṅgraha ṭīkāyām vyomavatyām dravya padārthaḥ  guṇa prakaraṇam
translated: Thus ends the chapter on the substance in the commentary called Vyomāvatī on Padārthadharmasangraha composed by the illustrious teacher Vyomasiva.🔽The Chapter on Qualities

original: guṇasāmānyasādharmyam
translated: The General Similarity of Qualities

original: rūpādīnāṃ sarveṣāṃ guṇānāṃ guṇatvābhisambandho dravyāśritatvaṃ niṣkriyatvamaguṇavattvañca /PDhS
analyzed: rūpa ādīnām sarveṣām guṇānām guṇa tva abhisambandhaḥ dravya āśrita tvam niṣkriya tvam aguṇavat tvam ca
translated: The connection of all qualities such as color etc. with the qualityhood is their dependence on substance, inactivity, and absence of qualities.

original: idānīmuddeśakrameṇāvasaraprāptānāṃ guṇānāmitarapadārthavaidharmyeṇa vyāpakaṃ sādharmyaṃ punaḥ pratiniyatānāñca svabhedāntarād vyāvṛttimapi darśayannāha rūpādīnāṃ sarveṣāṃ guṇānāṃ guṇatvābhisambandhaḥ ityādiprakaraṇam / guṇatvenābhisambandhastadupalakṣitaḥ samavāyaḥ / sa ca keṣām / rūpādīnām / tathāpyādiśabdasya aniyatārthagrāhakatvānna jñāyate kiyatāmataḥ sarveṣām / utkṣepaṇādyavarodhaparihārārthañca guṇānām iti /
analyzed: idānīm uddeśa krameṇa avasara prāptānām guṇānām itara padārtha vaidharmyeṇa vyāpakam sādharmyam punar pratiniyatānām ca sva bheda antarāt vyāvṛttim api darśayan āha rūpa ādīnām sarveṣām guṇānām guṇa tva abhisambandhaḥ ityādi prakaraṇam guṇa tvena abhisambandhaḥ tad upalakṣitaḥ samavāyaḥ sa ca keṣām rūpa ādīnām tathā api ādi śabdasya aniyata artha grāhaka tvāt na jñāyate kiyatām atas sarveṣām utkṣepaṇa ādi avarodha parihāra artham
translated: Now, showing the pervading similarity of the qualities that have come to the occasion in the order of enunciation with the other categories, and also the exclusion of their own subclasses, he says: The connection of all qualities such as color etc. with the qualityhood, etc. The connection with the qualityhood is the inherence characterized by that. And of which? Of color etc. Even so, because the word etc. conveys an indefinite meaning, it is not known by how much. Therefore, of all. And in order to exclude upward motion etc., he says of the qualities.

original: nanvevaṃ sarveṣāṃ guṇānāmityukte vyabhicārābhāvād vyarthaṃ rūpādīnāmitipadam / na / guṇatvābhisambandhāśritatvaviśeṣaṇābhyāṃ sarvo guṇaḥ iti darśanasya vyavacchedārthatvāt / tathā hi rūpādīnāmeva guṇatvābhisambandhaḥ sādharmyaṃ nānyeṣāmiti /
analyzed: nanu evam sarveṣām guṇānām iti ukte vyabhicāra abhāvāt vyartham rūpa ādīnām iti padam na guṇa tva abhisambandha āśrita tva viśeṣaṇābhyām sarvaḥ guṇaḥ iti darśanasya vyavaccheda artha tvāt tathā hi rūpa ādīnām eva guṇa tva abhisambandhaḥ sādharmyam na anyeṣām iti
translated: But if it is said that all qualities are thus stated, and there is no fallacy, the word color etc. is useless. No, because the specification by the qualifications based on the relation of quality and all quality is for the purpose of excluding the view that all are qualities. Thus, only color etc. have the relation of quality, not others.

original: na ca sāṃkhyābhyupagatasya guṇatrayasya vyavacchedārthaṃ rūpādigrahaṇamiti nyāyyam / tasya pramāṇānupalabdheḥ / prasiddhañca viśeṣaṇena vyavacchidyamānaṃ dṛṣṭaṃ yathā nīlenānīlamiti / tadevaṃ rūpādayaḥ / itarasmād bhidyante / guṇā iti vyavahartavyā vā / guṇatvābhisambandhāt / ye tu na bhidyante / na ca guṇā iti vyavahriyante / na te guṇatvābhisambaddhāḥ / yathā kṣityādaya iti / śeṣaṃ pūrvavat /
analyzed: na ca sāṃkhya abhyupagatasya guṇatrayasya vyavaccheda artham rūpa ādi grahaṇam iti nyāyyam tasya pramāṇa anupalabdheḥ prasiddham ca viśeṣaṇena vyavacchidyamānam dṛṣṭam yathā nīlena anīlam iti tat evam rūpa ādayaḥ itarasmāt bhidyante guṇāḥ iti vyavahartavyāḥ vā guṇa tva abhisambandhāt ye tu na bhidyante na ca guṇāḥ iti vyavahriyante na te guṇa tva abhisambaddhāḥ yathā kṣiti ādayaḥ iti śeṣam pūrvavat
translated: And it is not proper to take the word color etc. for the purpose of excluding the three qualities accepted by the Sāṃkhyas, because they are not perceived by any means of valid knowledge. And what is well-known is seen to be excluded by a particular, as in not blue by blue. Thus, color etc. are different from the other, or they should be spoken of as qualities, because of the relation of quality. But those that are not different, and are not spoken of as qualities, are not related to quality, like earth etc. The rest is as before.

original: tathā dravyāśritatvañca sādharmyaṃ rūpādīnām / tacca sāvadhāraṇaṃ vivakṣitam / anyathā hi dravyādīnāmapi dravyāśritatvād ativyāpi sādharmyaṃ syāt / na vyāvṛttamiti / avadhāraṇantu dravyeṣvevāśritatvameveti / dravyakarmaviśeṣā dravyeṣvevāśritā / na cāśritā eveti / sāmānyasamavāyau tu dravyeṣvāśritau / na tu dravyeṣveva / guṇādāvapi sadbhāvāt / guṇāstu dravyeṣvevāśritāḥ II / na guṇādau / tathā āśritā eva dravyeṣu / na anāśritā / nirguṇasya dravyasyānupalabdheḥ / tadevam ayogānyayogavyavacchedena dravyāśritatvād itarebhyo bhidyanta iti sādhyam /
analyzed: tathā dravya āśrita tvañca sādharmyam rūpa ādīnām tat ca sāvadhāraṇam vivakṣitam anyathā hi dravya ādīnām api dravya āśrita tvāt ativyāpi sādharmyam syāt na vyāvṛttam iti avadhāraṇam tu dravyeṣu eva āśrita tvam eva iti dravya karma viśeṣāḥ dravyeṣu eva āśritāḥ na ca āśritāḥ eva iti sāmānya samavāyau tu dravyeṣu āśritau na tu dravyeṣu eva guṇa ādau api sadbhāvāt guṇāḥ tu dravyeṣu eva āśritāḥ na guṇa ādau tathā āśritāḥ ev
translated: Similarly, the common property of form etc. is their dependence on substance. And that is intended to be qualified. Otherwise, since substance etc. are also dependent on substance, the common property would be too broad. It is not excluded. But the qualification is that dependence is only on substances. The qualities, actions and universals are dependent only on substances, not on qualities etc. But the universals and inherence are dependent on substances, but not only on substances, because they exist in qualities etc. also. But the qualities are dependent only on substances, not on qualities etc. Similarly, they are only dependent on substances, not independent. Because a qualityless substance is not perceived. Thus, by the exclusion of non-connection and connection with others, it is to be proved that they differ from the others because of their dependence on substance.

original: tathā nirgatā calanalakṣaṇakriyā yebhyaste niṣkriyāḥ / teṣāṃ bhāvo niṣkriyatvam /
analyzed: tathā nirgatā calana lakṣaṇa kriyā yebhyaḥ te niṣkriyāḥ teṣām bhāvaḥ niṣkriya tvam
translated: Similarly, those from which motion, the characteristic of action, has gone out are without action. Their state is being without action.

original: guṇā vidyante yeṣāṃ te guṇavantaḥ / teṣāṃ bhāvo guṇavattvaṃ tatpratiṣedhena cāguṇavattvamiti /
analyzed: guṇāḥ vidyante yeṣām te guṇavantaḥ teṣām bhāvaḥ guṇavat tvam tad pratiṣedhena ca aguṇavat tvam iti
translated: Those in whom qualities exist are endowed with qualities. Their state is being endowed with qualities. By negating that, there is not being endowed with qualities.

original: nanu niṣkriyatvamaguṇavattvañca guṇādīnāṃ pañcānāmapītyuktamato nedaṃ padārthāntarād vyāvṛttaṃ sādharmyam / na ca sādharmyamātreṇeha prayojanamasti pūrvamevābhidhānāt / atha guṇatvasahacaritaṃ vyāvṛttaṃ sādharmyamātrametaditi /
analyzed: nanu niṣkriya tvam aguṇavat tvañca guṇa ādīnām pañcānām api iti uktam atas na idam padārtha antarāt vyāvṛttam sādharmyam  na ca sādharmya mātreṇa iha prayojanam asti pūrvam eva abhidhānāt atha guṇa tva sahacaritam vyāvṛttam sādharmya mātram etat iti
translated: But it has been said that being without action and not being endowed with qualities apply to all five, beginning with qualities. Therefore, this is not a similarity that excludes other categories. And there is no purpose here in mere similarity, because it has already been stated before. Or if this is mere similarity that excludes what accompanies the quality of being a quality,

original: yad vā dravyapadārthādeva bhedapratipādanārthametat / tathā hi / pare manyante na guṇāḥ karma vā dravyādarthāntaramiti / niṣkriyatvāguṇatvābhyāṃ tadupapatteḥ / tathā hi / kriyāvad guṇavacca dravyam / tadrahitāśca guṇā iti dharmabhedād bhidyanta eva /
analyzed: yat vā dravya padārthāt eva bheda pratipādana artham etat tathā hi pare manyante na guṇāḥ karma vā dravyāt artha antaram iti niṣkriya tva aguṇa tvābhyām tad upapatteḥ tathā hi kriyāvat guṇavat ca dravyam tad rahitāḥ ca guṇāḥ iti dharma bhedāt bhidyante eva
translated: Or this is for the purpose of teaching the difference from the category of substance. Thus, others think that qualities or actions are not a different object from substance, because that is possible by being without action and without qualities. Thus, substance has action and qualities. And qualities are different from that, because of the difference in properties.

original: atha niṣkriyatvamaguṇavattvañca kathaṃ rūpādīnām / dravyasyaiva samavāyikāraṇatvena tadādhārāṇām utpattyabhāvāt / atha rūpādisamavetānāṃ rūpādīnāmutpatteryuktaṃ samavāyikāraṇatvam / tanna / anupalabdheḥ / yathā hi rūpavad dravyamiti jñānaṃ naivaṃ rūpavad rūpamiti pratibhāso 'sti /
analyzed: atha niṣkriya tvam aguṇavat tvam ca katham rūpa ādīnām dravyasya eva samavāyi kāraṇa tvena tad ādhārāṇām utpatti abhāvāt  atha rūpa ādi samavetānām rūpa ādīnām utpatteḥ yuktam samavāyi kāraṇa tvam tat na anupalabdheḥ yathā hi rūpavat dravyam iti jñānam na evam rūpavat rūpam iti pratibhāsaḥ u sti
translated: Now, how can form, etc. be without action and without qualities? Because only substance is the inherent cause, and those [form, etc.] do not arise as their substrata. If it is argued that the inherent forms, etc. have arising, so it is proper that they are the inherent causes, that is not so. Because of non-apprehension. Just as there is no cognition of substance as having form, there is no appearance of form as having form.

original: abhyupagamyāpyucyate / yadi ca rūpaṃ rūpotpattau samavāyikāraṇam anyenāsamavāyikāraṇena bhavitavyam / na ca kāraṇarūpamevāsamavāyikāraṇam / tasyāpi svagatarūpotpattau samavāyikāraṇatvāt / na ca tadeva samavāyikāraṇamasamavāyikāraṇañceti dṛṣṭam / nāpi saṃyogaḥ / tasya dravyotpattāvasamavāyitvāt / yadi ca tantusaṃyogastadrūpotpattāvasamavāyikāraṇam / tadutpatteḥ pūrvaṃ tadabhāvaḥ syādeveti / rūparūpeṣvapi saṃyogasya kāraṇatve tadutpatteḥ pūrvamabhāvo vācyaḥ / na caikasmādeva rūpād rūpāntaramiti vācyam / ekasya kramayaugapadyābhyāmārambhapratiṣedhāt /
analyzed: abhyupagamya api ucyate yadi ca rūpam rūpa utpattau samavāyi kāraṇam anyena asamavāyi kāraṇena bhavitavyam na ca kāraṇa rūpam eva asamavāyi kāraṇam tasya api svagata rūpa utpattau samavāyi kāraṇa tvāt na ca tat eva samavāyi kāraṇam asamavāyi kāraṇam ca iti dṛṣṭam na api saṃyogaḥ tasya dravya utpattau asamavāyi tvāt yadi ca tantu saṃyogaḥ tad rūpa utpattau asamavāyi kāraṇam tad utpatteḥ pūrvam tad abhāvaḥ syāt eva iti rūpa rūpeṣu api saṃyogas
translated: Even if we admit [the existence of color], we say: If color is the material cause in the production of color, there must be another non-inherent cause. And the color of the cause itself is not the non-inherent cause, because that [color of the cause] is the inherent cause in the production of color belonging to itself. And it is not seen that the same thing is both the inherent cause and the non-inherent cause. Nor is conjunction [the non-inherent cause], because in the production of substance, it is not an inherent cause. And if the conjunction of threads is the non-inherent cause in the production of that [cloth], then before the production of that [cloth], there would be no such [conjunction]. Even if conjunction is the cause in the case of colors, the absence of that [conjunction] before the production of that [color] must be stated. And it cannot be said that another color arises from just one color, because the production of one [color] is prohibited by sequence and simultaneity.

original: ata eva niṣkriyatvaṃ mūrtyanuvidhānāt kriyāyāḥ / sā ca guṇeṣu na sambhavati nirguṇatvāt / asarvagatadravyaparimāṇañca mūrtiriti /
analyzed: atas eva niṣkriya tvam mūrti anuvidhānāt kriyāyāḥ sā ca guṇeṣu na sambhavati nirguṇa tvāt asarva gata dravya parimāṇam ca mūrtiḥ iti
translated: For this very reason, [color] is inactive, because activity conforms to form. And that [activity] is not possible in qualities, because they are without qualities. And form is the dimension of a non-omnipresent substance.

original: athāśrayagamanena guṇeṣu gamanapratibhāsastarhi katham / mukhye bādhakopapatterupacāreṇa / dravye hi vartamānaṃ gamanamekārthasamavāyitayā guṇeṣvāropya pratipadyante guṇā gacchantīti /
analyzed: atha āśraya gamanena guṇeṣu gamana pratibhāsaḥ tarhi katham mukhye bādhaka upapatteḥ upacāreṇa  dravye hi vartamānam gamanam ekārtha samavāyi tayā guṇeṣu āropya pratipadyante guṇāḥ gacchanti iti
translated: If, on the other hand, the appearance of motion in qualities is due to the motion of their substratum, then how is it that they are spoken of as moving? It is due to figurative usage, because the primary meaning is contradicted. For motion, which resides in substances, is figuratively attributed to qualities by the relation of inherence in the same object, and people understand that the qualities move.

original: tadevaṃ niṣkriyatvādaguṇavattvācca dravyād arthāntaraṃ rūpamiti / athārthāntaratve kathaṃ niyatena dharmiṇā vyapadeśaḥ / sambandhaniyamāt / na ca sambandhasya sambandhāntaraparikalpanā sambandharūpatvādeveti vakṣyāmaḥ samavāyapadārthe /
analyzed: tat evam niṣkriya tvāt aguṇavat tvāt ca dravyāt artha antaram rūpam iti atha artha antara tve katham niyatena dharmiṇā vyapadeśaḥ sambandha niyamāt na ca sambandhasya sambandha antara parikalpanā sambandha rūpa tvāt eva iti vakṣyāmaḥ samavāya padārthe
translated: Thus, color is a different category from substance, because it is inactive and does not possess qualities. If it is a different category, how is it designated by a qualifier that is invariably related to it? Because the relation is invariable. And we will explain in the section on the category of inherence that the relation does not require another relation, because it is the very form of relation.

original: keṣāñcideva mūrtaguṇatvam
analyzed: keṣāñcid eva mūrta guṇa tvam
translated: Some are qualities of material substances.

original: rūparasagandhasparśaparatvāparatvagurutvadravatvasnehavegā mūrtaguṇāḥ /PDhS
analyzed: rūpa rasa gandha sparśa para tva apara tva guru tva drava tva sneha vegāḥ mūrta guṇāḥ
translated: Color, taste, smell, touch, priority, posteriority, heaviness, fluidity, viscosity, and velocity are the qualities of material substances.

original: athedānīṃ pratiniyatānāṃ svabhedāntarād vyāvṛttaṃ sādharmyaṃ darśayati rūpādayo vegāntā mūrtaguṇā iti / mūrtānāmeva / na tveta eva mūrtānām / anyeṣāmapi tadguṇatvāt / tathā hi / pṛthivyādiṣu triṣu rūpadravatvādayaḥ / gurutvarasau tu dvayoḥ / sparśaścaturṇām / gandhaḥ kṣitāveva / sneho 'mbhasyeva / paratvāparatvavegāstu pañcasvapi mūrteṣviti /
analyzed: atha idānīm pratiniyatānām sva bheda antarāt vyāvṛttam sādharmyam darśayati rūpa ādayaḥ vega antāḥ mūrta guṇāḥ iti mūrtānām eva na tu ete eva mūrtānām anyeṣām api tad guṇa tvāt tathā hi pṛthivī ādiṣu triṣu rūpa drava tva ādayaḥ guru tva rasau tu dvayoḥ sparśaḥ caturṇām gandhaḥ kṣitau eva snehaḥ mbhasi eva paratva aparatva vegāḥ tu pañcasu api mūrteṣu iti
translated: Now he shows the similarity of the specific ones, which is distinguished from other internal differences, by saying form and the rest up to velocity are the qualities of the corporeal. They are the qualities of the corporeal only, not just those of the corporeal. Because other things also have those qualities. For example, form, fluidity, etc. are in the three beginning with earth. Gravity and taste are in two. Touch is in four. Smell is in earth alone. Moisture is in water alone. Distance, proximity, and velocity are in all five corporeal substances.

original: keṣāñciccāmūrtaguṇatvam
analyzed: keṣāñcid ca amūrta guṇa tvam
translated: And some are the qualities of the incorporeal.

original: buddhisukhaduḥkhecchādveṣaprayatnadharmādharmabhāvanāśabdā amūrtaguṇāḥ /PDhS
analyzed: buddhi sukha duḥkha icchā dveṣa prayatna dharma adharma bhāvanā śabdāḥ amūrta guṇāḥ
translated: Intellect, pleasure, pain, desire, aversion, effort, merit, demerit, and impression are the qualities of the incorporeal.

original: buddhyādayaḥ śabdāntāstvamūrtaguṇā iti / amūrtānāmeva guṇāḥ / na tveta eva / saṃkhyādīnāmapi tadguṇatvāt / buddhyādayo bhāvanāntāḥ puruṣe / śabdaścākāśa iti /
analyzed: buddhi ādayaḥ śabda antāḥ tu amūrta guṇāḥ iti amūrtānām eva guṇāḥ na tu ete eva saṃkhyā ādīnām api tad guṇa tvāt buddhi ādayaḥ bhāvanā antāḥ puruṣe śabdaḥ ca ākāśe iti
translated: Intellect and the rest up to sound are the qualities of the incorporeal. They are the qualities of the incorporeal only, not just those of the incorporeal. Because number and the rest are also their qualities. Intellect and the rest up to impression are in the soul, and sound is in space.

original: kecinmūrtāmūrtobhayaguṇāḥ
analyzed: kecid mūrta amūrta ubhaya guṇāḥ
translated: Some are the qualities of both the corporeal and incorporeal.

original: saṃkhyāparimāṇapṛthaktvasaṃyogavibhāgā ubhayaguṇāḥ /PDhS
analyzed: saṃkhyā parimāṇa pṛthaktva saṃyoga vibhāgāḥ ubhaya guṇāḥ
translated: Number, dimension, separateness, conjunction, and disjunction are the qualities of both.

original: saṃkhyādayo vibhāgāntā ubhayaguṇāḥ / ubhayeṣāṃ mūrtāmūrtānāmeva guṇāḥ / tathaita evobhayaguṇāḥ /
analyzed: saṃkhyā ādayaḥ vibhāga antāḥ ubhaya guṇāḥ ubhayeṣām mūrta amūrtānām eva guṇāḥ tathā ete eva ubhaya guṇāḥ
translated: Number, etc., up to disjunction, belong to both. They are qualities of only the corporeal and incorporeal. Thus, they belong to both.

original: guṇeṣvanekāśritāḥ
analyzed: guṇeṣu aneka āśritāḥ
translated: In qualities, those that inhere in many are

original: saṃyogavibhāgadvitvadvipṛthaktvādayo 'nekāśritāḥ /PDhS
analyzed: saṃyoga vibhāga dvi tva dvi pṛthak tva ādayaḥ na eka āśritāḥ
translated: Conjunction, disjunction, duality, and separateness that are in many.

original: athedānīm ekānekāśritatvaṃ darśayannāha saṃyogavibhāgadvitvadvipṛthaktvādayo 'nekāśritāḥ ityādipadena tritvādikā parārdhāntā saṃkhyā tadviśiṣṭañca pṛthaktvaṃ gṛhyate / anekāśritatvañcātra vyaktyapekṣayā vivakṣitam / na jātyapekṣayā / rūpāderapi tadbhāvaprasaṅgāt /
analyzed: atha idānīm eka aneka āśrita tvam darśayan āha saṃyoga vibhāga dvi tva dvi pṛthak tva ādayaḥ neka āśritāḥ iti ādi padena tri tva ādikā parārdha antā saṃkhyā tad viśiṣṭam ca pṛthaktvam gṛhyate aneka āśrita tvam ca atra vyakti apekṣayā vivakṣitam na jāti apekṣayā rūpa ādeḥ api tad bhāva prasaṅgāt
translated: Now, showing inherence in one and many, he says Conjunction, disjunction, duality, and separateness that are in many, etc. By the word etc., number from three onwards up to the highest, and separateness qualified by that, are included. And here, inherence in many is intended in relation to individuals, not in relation to universals, because of the consequence that form, etc., would also have that nature.

original: yadyapi rūpatvādijātīyamanekasmin na vartate tathāpi ekā tadvyaktirekasminneva / na caivaṃ saṃyogādiḥ / tadvyakteranekāśritatvopalabdheḥ /
analyzed: yadi api rūpa tva ādi jātīyam anekasmin na vartate tathā api ekā tad vyaktiḥ ekasmin eva na ca evam saṃyoga ādiḥ tad vyakteḥ aneka āśrita tva upalabdheḥ
translated: Although the universal of form, etc., does not inhere in many, still that individual inheres in only one. And conjunction, etc., are not like that, because the inherence of that individual in many is observed.

original: tadbhinnānāmekāśritatvam
analyzed: tad bhinnānām eka āśrita tvam
translated: Those different from that inhere in one.

original: śeṣāstvekaikadravyavṛttayaḥ /PDhS
analyzed: śeṣāḥ tu ekaika dravya vṛttayaḥ
translated: The rest, however, occur in one substance each.

original: śeṣāstvekaikadravyavṛttayaḥ iti / uktabhyo 'nye śeṣāḥ / te hi ekaikasminneva dravye vartante / ekā hi vyaktirekasminneva samavetā tathā rasādivyaktayo 'pi / avadhāraṇantveṣām ekaikadravyavṛttitvameva / na tveṣāmeva / ubhayavṛttīnāmapi tadbhāvāt /
analyzed: śeṣāḥ tu ekaika dravya vṛttayaḥ iti uktabhyaḥ nye śeṣāḥ te hi ekaikasmin eva dravye vartante ekā hi vyaktiḥ ekasmin eva samavetā tathā rasa ādi vyaktayaḥ api avadhāraṇam tu eṣām ekaika dravya vṛtti tvam eva na tu eṣām eva ubhaya vṛttīnām api tad bhāvāt
translated: The remaining ones occur in one substance each. Those other than those mentioned are the remaining ones. They occur in each individual substance. For one individual is inherent in only one substance, and so are the individuals of taste and so on. But their restriction is that they occur in one substance each, not that they are only these. Because those that occur in both also have that nature.

original: viśeṣaguṇoddeśaḥ🔽rūparasagandhasparśasnehasāṃsiddhikadravatvabuddhisukhaduḥkhecchādveṣaprayatnadharmādharmabhāvanāśabdā vaiśeṣikaguṇāḥ /PDhS
analyzed: viśeṣa guṇa uddeśaḥ  rūpa rasa gandha sparśa sneha sāṃsiddhika drava tva buddhi sukha duḥkha icchā dveṣa prayatna dharma adharma bhāvanā śabdāḥ vaiśeṣika guṇāḥ
translated: The enumeration of specific qualities🔽Color, taste, smell, touch, fluidity, intelligence, pleasure, pain, desire, aversion, effort, merit, demerit, impression, and sound are the specific qualities.

original: sāmānyaguṇoddeśaḥ
analyzed: sāmānya guṇa uddeśaḥ
translated: The enumeration of general qualities

original: saṃkhyāparimāṇapṛthaktvasaṃyogavibhāgaparatvāparatvagurutvanaimittikadravatvavegāḥ sāmānyaguṇāḥ /PDhS
analyzed: saṃkhyā parimāṇa pṛthaktva saṃyoga vibhāga para tva apara tva guru tva naimittika drava tva vegāḥ sāmānya guṇāḥ
translated: Number, dimension, separateness, conjunction, disjunction, priority, posteriority, weight, natural fluidity, and velocity are the general qualities.

original: idānīṃ ke viśeṣaguṇāḥ / ke ca sāmānyaguṇā ityupadarśanārthamāha rūpādayaḥ śabdāntā vaiśeṣikaguṇāḥ /
analyzed: idānīm ke viśeṣa guṇāḥ ke ca sāmānya guṇāḥ iti upadarśana artham āha rūpa ādayaḥ śabda antāḥ vaiśeṣika guṇāḥ
translated: Now, in order to show which are the specific qualities and which are the general qualities, he says: Color etc. up to sound are the specific qualities.

original: kīdṛśameṣāṃ viśeṣaguṇatvam / yadyekāśritatvaṃ gurutvādāvapi syāt / athaikaikendriyagrāhyatvam / snehadravatvadharmādharmādau na syāt / athāsādhāraṇatvam / tannāsti / rūpatvādijātīyasyānekatropalabdheḥ / vyaktivivakṣayā / gurutvādāvapyastyeva / na / anyathā tadupapatteḥ / tathā hi / svasamavetaviśeṣaII /viśiṣṭatve sati svāśrayaikajātīyavyavacchedakatvād viśeṣaguṇāḥ / āśrayamātravyavacchedakatvaṃ na sambhavatīti svāśrayapadam / tathāpi nirviśeṣaṇasya rūpādernāśrayavyavacchedakatvamiti viśeṣaviśiṣṭapadam / saṃkhyādayo 'pi gandhaikārthasamavetāḥ kṣitervyavacchedakāḥ / snehaikārthasamavetāścodakasya / tannirāsāya svasamavetapadam / yathā hi / rūpe śuklatvādiviśeṣaṇaṃ samavetaṃ rase ca madhuratvādi naivaṃ sneho gandho vā saṃkhyādau samaveta iti vyavacchedaḥ / tathāpyaṇuparimāṇaṃ paramāṇūnāṃ vyavacchedakamiti svāśrayaikajātīyapadam / tathā hi paramāṇuparimāṇaṃ svasamavetaviśeṣaṇopetaṃ svāśrayasya paramāṇuvrātasya caturvidhasya vyavacchedakaṃ naikajātīyasyeti / evaṃ paramamahatvamapīti /
analyzed: kīdṛśam eṣām viśeṣa guṇa tvam yadi ekāśrita tvam guru tva ādau api syāt atha ekaika indriya grāhya tvam sneha drava tva dharma adharma ādau na syāt atha asādhāraṇa tvam tat na asti rūpa tva ādi jātīyasya anekatra upalabdheḥ vyakti vivakṣayā guru tva ādau api asti eva na anyathā tad upapatteḥ tathā hi sati sva āśraya eka jātīya vyavacchedaka tvāt viśeṣa guṇāḥ āśraya mātra vyavacchedaka tvam na sambhavati iti sva āśraya padam tathā api nirviśeṣaṇas
translated: What is the specific quality of these? If it is being dependent on one, it would also apply to heaviness etc. If it is being grasped by each sense organ, it would not apply to oiliness, fluidity, virtue, vice etc. If it is being uncommon, that is not so. Because the universal of color etc. is perceived in many. If it is meant to be the individual, it exists even in heaviness etc. No, because it is logically possible otherwise. Thus, the specific qualities are those that, while being qualified by the particulars inhering in themselves, distinguish their substrata from those of the same class, because the distinction of the mere substratum is not possible. The word 'their substratum' is used. Even then, since color etc. without any qualification does not distinguish the substratum, the word 'qualified by a particular' is used. Number etc. also distinguish earth when inhering in the same substance as smell, and water when inhering in the same substance as oiliness. To exclude those, the word 'inhering in itself' is used. For example, the qualification whiteness inheres in color, and sweetness in taste.

original: rūpañca svasamavetaśuklatvādyanekaviśeṣaṇopetamekajātīyāyāḥ kṣitervyavacchedakam / niyamena śuklatvaviśiṣṭamudakasya / śuklabhāsvarañca tejasa ityādi viśeṣaḥ pūrvokta eva draṣṭavyaḥ /
analyzed: rūpam ca sva samaveta śukla tva ādi aneka viśeṣaṇa upetam eka jātīyāyāḥ kṣiteḥ vyavacchedakam niyamena śukla tva viśiṣṭam udakasya śukla bhāsvaram ca tejasaḥ ityādi viśeṣaḥ pūrva uktaḥ eva draṣṭavyaḥ
translated: And color, endowed with many specific properties inherent in itself such as whiteness, etc., is the distinguisher of earth of the same class. Water is invariably distinguished by whiteness. And fire is distinguished by whiteness and luster. This distinction should be seen as stated earlier.

original: tadevaṃ svasamavetaviśeṣaviśiṣṭatve sati svāśrayaikajātīyavyavacchedakatvād viśeṣaguṇā eva / eta eva viśeṣaguṇā ityavadhāraṇam /
analyzed: tat evam sva samaveta viśeṣa viśiṣṭa tve sati sva āśraya eka jātīya vyavacchedaka tvāt viśeṣa guṇāḥ eva ete eva viśeṣa guṇāḥ iti avadhāraṇam
translated: Thus, being qualified by specific properties inherent in itself, and being the distinguisher of its substratum of the same class, the specific properties are only those. This is the determination that these alone are the specific properties.

original: saṃkhyādayo vegāntāḥ sāmānyaguṇā eva / viśeṣaguṇalakṣaṇarahitatvād eta eva sāmānyaguṇāḥ /
analyzed: saṃkhyā ādayaḥ vega antāḥ sāmānya guṇāḥ eva viśeṣa guṇa lakṣaṇa rahita tvāt ete eva sāmānya guṇāḥ
translated: Number etc. up to velocity are only the general properties. Being devoid of the definition of specific properties, these alone are the general properties.

original: ekaikendriyagrāhyaguṇāḥ
analyzed: ekaika indriya grāhya guṇāḥ
translated: Properties perceptible by one sense organ each

original: śabdasparśarūparasagandhā bāhyaikaikendriyagrāhyāḥ /PDhS
analyzed: śabda sparśa rūpa rasa gandhāḥ bāhya ekaika indriya grāhyāḥ pdhs
translated: Sound, touch, form, taste, and smell are perceptible by one external sense organ each.

original: idānīmekānekendriyagrāhyatvaṃ darśayannāha śabdasparśarūparasagandhāḥ bāhyenaikaikenendriyeṇa gṛhyanta iti tadgrāhyāḥ / bāhyagrahaṇamantaḥkaraṇavyavacchedārtham / tadvivakṣā hi dvīndriyagrāhyatvāt / avadhāraṇañca eta eva niyamena bāhyaikaikendriyagrāhyāḥ / tathānekendriyagrāhyā na bhavantīti /
analyzed: idānīm eka aneka indriya grāhya tvam darśayan āha śabda sparśa rūpa rasa gandhāḥ bāhyena ekaikena indriyeṇa gṛhyante iti tad grāhyāḥ bāhya grahaṇam antaḥkaraṇa vyavaccheda artham tad vivakṣā hi dvi indriya grāhya tvāt avadhāraṇam ca ete eva niyamena bāhya ekaika indriya grāhyāḥ tathā aneka indriya grāhyāḥ na bhavanti iti
translated: Now, showing the nature of being grasped by one or many sense faculties, he says: Sound, touch, form, taste, and smell are grasped by each external sense faculty, so they are graspable by that. The term external is used to exclude the internal organ, because that is intended to be grasped by two sense faculties. And the restriction is that these alone are necessarily grasped by each external sense faculty, and not in the same way by many sense faculties.

original: dvīndriyagrāhyaguṇoddeśaḥ🔽saṃkhyāparimāṇapṛthaktvasaṃyogavibhāgaparatvāparatvadravatvasnehavegā dvīndriyagrāhyāḥ /PDhS
analyzed: dvi indriya grāhya guṇa uddeśaḥ  saṃkhyā parimāṇa pṛthaktva saṃyoga vibhāga para tva apara tva drava tva sneha vegāḥ dvi indriya grāhyāḥ pdhs
translated: Enumeration of qualities grasped by two sense faculties🔽Number, dimension, separateness, conjunction, disjunction, priority, posteriority, fluidity, viscosity, and velocity are grasped by two sense faculties.

original: saṃkhyādayo vegāntā dvīndriyagrāhyā eva / niyamenaita eva dvīndriyaII /grāhyāḥ / bāhyagrahaṇamantaḥkaraṇavyavacchedārthamanuvartanīyam /
analyzed: saṃkhyā ādayaḥ vega antāḥ dvi indriya grāhyāḥ eva niyamena ete eva bāhya grahaṇam antaḥkaraṇa vyavaccheda artham anuvartanīyam
translated: Number and the others, ending with velocity, are grasped by two sense faculties alone. Necessarily, these alone are grasped by two sense faculties. The term external should be continued to exclude the internal organ.

original: atha snehasya kathaṃ dvīndriyagrāhyatvam / tvagvyāpāre sati snigdhapratyayadarśanāt / yathā hi cakṣurvyāpāreṇa snigdhāḥ keśā iti pratibhāsastathā snānottarakālamapi tvagvyāpāreṇa snigdhapratyayo dṛṣṭa ityanvayavyatirekābhyāṃ dvīndriyagrāhyatvaṃ niścīyate /
analyzed: atha snehasya katham dvi indriya grāhya tvam tvac vyāpāre sati snigdha pratyaya darśanāt yathā hi cakṣuḥ vyāpāreṇa snigdhāḥ keśāḥ iti pratibhāsaḥ tathā snāna uttara kālam api tvac vyāpāreṇa snigdha pratyayaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ iti anvaya vyatirekābhyām dvi indriya grāhya tvam niścīyate
translated: Now, how is oil grasped by two sense organs? Because when there is the operation of touch, the perception of oil is seen. Just as there is the appearance of oily hair due to the operation of the eye, so also after bathing, the perception of oil is seen due to the operation of touch. Thus, by positive and negative concomitance, it is ascertained that it is grasped by two sense organs.

original: atha kimayamāpyaḥ pārthivo veti vicārayiṣyāmaḥ snehaparīkṣāyām /
analyzed: atha kim ayam āpyaḥ pārthivaḥ vā iti vicārayiṣyāmaḥ sneha parīkṣāyām
translated: Now, we will consider whether this is water or earth in the examination of oil.

original: antaḥkaraṇagrāhyaguṇoddeśaḥ
analyzed: antaḥkaraṇa grāhya guṇa uddeśaḥ
translated: The topic of qualities grasped by the internal organ

original: buddhisukhaduḥkhecchādveṣaprayatnāstvantaḥkaraṇgrāhyāḥ /PDhS
analyzed: buddhi sukha duḥkha icchā dveṣa prayatnāḥ tu antaḥkaraṇ grāhyāḥ
translated: But cognition, pleasure, pain, desire, aversion, and effort are grasped by the internal organ.

original: atīndriyaguṇoddeśaḥ
analyzed: atīndriya guṇa uddeśaḥ
translated: The topic of imperceptible qualities

original: gurutvadharmādharmabhāvanā atīndriyāḥ /PDhS
analyzed: guru tva dharma adharma bhāvanāḥ atīndriyāḥ pdhs
translated: Gravity, virtue, vice, and disposition are imperceptible.

original: buddhyādayaḥ prayatnāntāstvantaḥkaraṇenaiva gṛhyanta iti tadgrāhyāḥ /
analyzed: buddhi ādayaḥ prayatna antāḥ tu antaḥkaraṇena eva gṛhyante iti tad grāhyāḥ
translated: But cognition and the others up to effort are grasped only by the internal organ, so they are grasped by that.

original: gurutvadharmādharmabhāvanā hi atīndriyā eva / indriyāṇyatītya vartante / tadgrāhyā na bhavantīti / yathā ca gurutvamapratyakṣaṃ tathā vakṣyāmastatparīkṣāyām /
analyzed: guru tva dharma adharma bhāvanāḥ hi atīndriyāḥ eva indriyāṇi atītya vartante tad grāhyāḥ na bhavanti iti yathā ca guru tvam apratyakṣam tathā vakṣyāmaḥ tad parīkṣāyām
translated: Gravity, virtue, vice, and disposition are indeed imperceptible, they exist beyond the sense organs, they are not grasped by them. And as gravity is imperceptible, we will explain that in the examination of it.

original: guṇeṣu kāraṇaguṇapūrvakāṇāmuddeśaḥ
analyzed: guṇeṣu kāraṇa guṇa pūrvakāṇām uddeśaḥ
translated: The enumeration of those qualities of the effect which have their cause in the qualities of the cause.

original: apākajarūparasagandhasparśaparimāṇaikatvaikapṛthaktvagurutvadravatvasnehavegāḥ kāraṇaguṇapūrvakāḥ /PDhS
analyzed: apāka ja rūpa rasa gandha sparśa parimāṇa eka tva ekapṛthaktva guru tva drava tva sneha vegāḥ kāraṇa guṇa pūrvakāḥ
translated: Color, taste, smell, touch, dimension, unity, separateness, heaviness, fluidity, viscidity, and velocity, which are not produced by baking, have their cause in the qualities of the cause.

original: apākajarūpādivegāntāḥ kāraṇaguṇapūrvakā iti / apākajagrahaṇaṃ pārthivaparamāṇurūpavyavacchedārtham /
analyzed: a pāka ja rūpa ādi vega antāḥ kāraṇa guṇa pūrvakāḥ iti a pāka ja grahaṇam pārthiva paramāṇu rūpa vyavaccheda artham
translated: Color, etc., up to velocity, which are not produced by baking, have their cause in the qualities of the cause. The mention of not produced by baking is for the purpose of excluding the color of earth atoms.

original: nanu te 'pi kāraṇaguṇapūrvā bhavantyeva / tathā hi / kāraṇaṃ paramāṇustadguṇaḥ pārthivaparamāṇvagnisaṃyogastatpūrvā rūpādaya iti kathaṃ na kāraṇaguṇapūrvakāḥ / tanna / abhiprāyāparijñānāt / tathā cāyamabhiprāyaḥ / samavāyikāraṇeṣveva guṇāḥ kāraṇaguṇāste pūrvaṃ kāraṇaṃ yeṣāṃ kāryaguṇānāṃ te 'tra kāraṇaguṇapūrvakā vivakṣitāḥ / na caivaṃ pākajā iti vyavacchidyante /
analyzed: nanu te pi kāraṇa guṇa pūrvāḥ bhavanti eva tathā hi kāraṇam paramāṇuḥ tad guṇaḥ pārthiva paramāṇu agni saṃyogaḥ tad pūrvāḥ rūpa ādayaḥ iti katham na kāraṇa guṇa pūrvakāḥ tat na abhiprāya aparijñānāt tathā ca ayam abhiprāyaḥ samavāyi kāraṇeṣu eva guṇāḥ kāraṇa guṇāḥ te pūrvam kāraṇam yeṣām kārya guṇānām te tra kāraṇa guṇa pūrvakāḥ vivakṣitāḥ na ca evam pāka jāḥ iti vyavacchidyante
translated: But aren't they also preceded by the qualities of the cause? For example, the cause is an atom, the quality of that is the conjunction of an earth atom with fire, and color, etc., are preceded by that. How are they not preceded by the qualities of the cause? That is not so, due to not understanding the intention. And this is the intention: The qualities that are in the inherent causes alone are the qualities of the cause. Those qualities of the effect which have those as their cause are intended here as preceded by the qualities of the cause. And thus the produced by baking are not excluded.

original: atha salilādiparamāṇurūpādayaḥ pākajatvābhāve 'pi na kāraṇaguṇaII /pūrvakā iti / tanna / paryudāsapratiṣedhasya vivakṣitatvāt / tathā hi / pākājjātāḥ pākajāstatpratiṣedhena anyaguṇapūrvakatvaṃ labhyata iti nityānāṃ vyavacchedaḥ /
analyzed: atha salila ādi paramāṇu rūpa ādayaḥ pāka ja tva abhāve pi na iti tat na paryudāsa pratiṣedhasya vivakṣita tvāt tathā hi pākāt jātāḥ pāka jāḥ tad pratiṣedhena anya guṇa pūrvakatvam labhyate iti nityānām vyavacchedaḥ
translated: Now, if the forms etc. of water atoms and so on are not produced by cooking, but are preceded by the qualities of their causes, that is not so. Because exclusion is intended. Thus, what is produced by cooking is excluded, and being preceded by other qualities is obtained, thus excluding the eternal ones.

original: nanvevamapi vyarthamapākajagrahaṇam / ete kāraṇaguṇapūrvakā evetyavadhāraṇāsambhavāt / tathā hi / dravatvavegāvakāraṇaguṇapūrvakāvapīti / na / spaṣṭārthatvādeta eva kāraṇaguṇapūrvakā / na tvete kāraṇaguṇapūrvakā evetyavadhāraṇam / abudhyamānasya pākajairdoṣāśaṅkā syāditi spaṣṭārthamapākajagrahaṇam /
analyzed: nanu evam api vyartham apākaja grahaṇam ete kāraṇa guṇa pūrvakāḥ eva iti avadhāraṇa asambhavāt tathā hi drava tva vegau akāraṇa guṇa pūrvakau api iti na spaṣṭa ārtha tvāt ete eva kāraṇa guṇa pūrvakāḥ na tu ete kāraṇa guṇa pūrvakāḥ eva iti avadhāraṇam a budhyamānasya pāka jaiḥ doṣa āśaṅkā syāt iti spaṣṭa artham apākaja grahaṇam
translated: Even so, the mention of non-cooking is useless, because it is not possible to restrict them as being only preceded by the qualities of their causes. Thus, fluidity and velocity are also preceded by the qualities of their causes. No, because the meaning is clear, they are only preceded by the qualities of their causes. But the restriction is not that they are only preceded by the qualities of their causes. The mention of non-cooking is for the clear meaning, because for one who does not understand, there would be doubt about faults produced by cooking.

original: atra caikatvaikapṛthaktvagrahaṇaṃ dvitvadvipṛthaktvādivyavacchedārtham / te hyakāraṇaguṇapūrvakā iti /
analyzed: atra ca ekatva ekapṛthaktva grahaṇam dvitva dvipṛthaktva ādi vyavaccheda artham te hi akāraṇa guṇa pūrvakāḥ iti
translated: And here, the mention of oneness and one-separateness is for the purpose of excluding duality, duality-separateness, and so on. For they are not preceded by the qualities of their causes.

original: akāraṇaguṇapūrvakaguṇakathanam
analyzed: akāraṇa guṇa pūrvaka guṇa kathanam
translated: The statement of qualities not preceded by the qualities of their causes

original: buddhisukhaduḥkhecchādveṣaprayatnadharmādharmabhāvanāśabdā akāraṇaguṇapūrvakāḥ /PDhS🔽buddhyādayaḥ śabdāntāstvakāraṇaguṇapūrvakā eva / samavāyiguṇapūrvakāḥ kāryaguṇā na bhavantīti / na tveta eva saṃyogavibhāgaparatvāparatvadvitvadvipṛthaktvādīnāmapyakāraṇaguṇapūrvakatvāt /
analyzed: buddhi sukha duḥkha icchā dveṣa prayatna dharma adharma bhāvanā śabdāḥ akāraṇa guṇa pūrvakāḥ pdhs buddhi ādayaḥ śabda antāḥ tu akāraṇa guṇa pūrvakāḥ eva samavāyi guṇa pūrvakāḥ kārya guṇāḥ na bhavanti iti na tu ete eva saṃyoga vibhāga para tva apara tva dvi tva dvi pṛthak tva ādīnām api akāraṇa guṇa pūrvaka tvāt
translated: Cognition, pleasure, pain, desire, aversion, effort, merit, demerit, impression, and sound are not preceded by the qualities of their causes.🔽Cognition and the rest up to sound are not preceded by the qualities of their causes. The qualities of effects are not preceded by the qualities of their components. But these are not so, because conjunction, disjunction, priority, posteriority, duality, separateness, etc. are also not preceded by the qualities of their causes.

original: athākāraṇaguṇapūrvakatvāviśeṣe 'pyasmin vākye saṃyogādīnāmavacane kiṃ prayojanamiti cintyam / athāpākajarūpādivegāntānāmeva kāraṇaguṇapūrvakatvābhidhānāt śeṣāṇāmakāraṇaguṇapūrvakatvaṃ vijñāyate / evaṃ tarhi buddhyādayo 'pi nābhidheyāḥ / śeṣāṇāmakāraṇaguṇapūrvakatvamiti vābhidheyaṃ sakalabhedasaṅgrāhakaṃ vākyam / alaṃ buddhyādiviśeṣābhidhāneneti /
analyzed: atha a kāraṇa guṇa pūrvaka tva aviśeṣe pi asmin vākye saṃyoga ādīnām avacane kim prayojanam iti cintyam atha a pāka ja rūpa ādi vega antānām eva kāraṇa guṇa pūrvaka tva abhidhānāt śeṣāṇām akāraṇa guṇa pūrvaka tvam vijñāyate evam tarhi buddhi ādayaḥ pi na abhidheyāḥ śeṣāṇām akāraṇa guṇa pūrvaka tvam iti vā abhidheyam sakala bheda saṅgrāhakam vākyam alam buddhi ādi viśeṣa abhidhānena iti
translated: Now, even if there is no difference in being preceded by the qualities of their causes, what is the purpose of not mentioning conjunction, etc. in this statement? If it is thought that the mention of the qualities of their causes for only those ending with velocity, such as the qualities produced by baking, is understood to imply that the rest are not preceded by the qualities of their causes, then in that case, cognition, etc. should also not be mentioned. Or the statement the rest are not preceded by the qualities of their causes should be mentioned to include all the differences. There is no point in mentioning the specific qualities of cognition, etc.

original: naitadevam / viśeṣavacanaṃ spaṣṭārtham / anekadhā śāstrābhihitamiti antevāsināmṛjvarthaparijñānameva syādityūhaśakteḥ saṃvardhanārthaṃ saṃyogādīnāṃ svaśabdenāvacanam /
analyzed: na etat evam viśeṣa vacanam spaṣṭa artham anekadhā śāstra abhihitam iti antevāsinām ṛju artha parijñānam eva syāt iti ūha śakteḥ saṃvardhana artham saṃyoga ādīnām sva śabdena avacanam
translated: This is not so. The statement of the specific qualities is clear in meaning. Since it has been stated in many ways in the scriptures, it is only for the proper understanding of the students that the conjunctions etc. are not mentioned by their own words, for the purpose of enhancing their ability to understand.

original: anye tvekavṛttīnāmeva viśeṣaguṇānāmatrābhidhānaṃ vivakṣitamiti manyante / tattu na buddhyāmahe / dūṣaṇasyāpratisamādhānāt /
analyzed: anye tu eka vṛttīnām eva viśeṣa guṇānām atra abhidhānam vivakṣitam iti manyante tat tu na buddhyāmahe dūṣaṇasya apratisamādhānāt
translated: Others, however, think that the mention of only those specific qualities that occur in one substance is intended here. But we do not understand that, because the objection has not been answered.

original: saṃyogajaguṇoddeśaḥ
analyzed: saṃyoga ja guṇa uddeśaḥ
translated: The section on qualities produced by conjunction

original: buddhisukhaduḥkhecchādveṣaprayatnadharmādharmabhāvanāśabdatūlaparimāṇottarasaṃyogaII /naimittikadravatvaparatvāparatvapākajāḥ saṃyogajāḥ /PDhS
analyzed: saṃyoga jāḥ
translated: Intellect, pleasure, pain, desire, aversion, effort, merit, demerit, impression, sound, fluffiness, dimension, subsequent conjunction, occasional fluidity, priority, posteriority, and those produced by cooking are produced by conjunction.

original: tathā buddhyādayaḥ pākajāntāḥ saṃyogajā ityatra buddhyādayo bhāvanāntāḥ puruṣāntaḥkaraṇasaṃyogādutpadyante / śabdaśca bheryākāśasaṃyogāt / tūlaparimāṇañca pracayāt / uttarasaṃyogaḥ sūtrapāṭhāpekṣayā / saṃyogajasaṃyogaḥ naimittikadravatvamagnisaṃyogāt / paratvāparatve tu dikkālapiṇḍasaṃyogāt / pākajā iti pārthivaparamāṇurūpādayaste 'pyagnisaṃyogajāḥ / ityeta eva saṃyogajāḥ / na tvete saṃyogajā eva / tathā hi śabdo vibhāgajaḥ śabdajo 'pyastīti /
analyzed: tathā buddhi ādayaḥ pāka ja antāḥ saṃyoga jāḥ iti atra buddhi ādayaḥ bhāvanā antāḥ puruṣa antaḥkaraṇa saṃyogāt utpadyante śabdaḥ ca bherī ākāśa saṃyogāt tūla parimāṇam ca pracayāt uttara saṃyogaḥ sūtra pāṭha apekṣayā saṃyoga ja saṃyogaḥ naimittika drava tvam agni saṃyogāt paratva aparatve tu diś kāla piṇḍa saṃyogāt pāka jāḥ iti pārthiva paramāṇu rūpa ādayaḥ te pi agni saṃyoga jāḥ iti ete eva saṃyoga jāḥ na tu et
translated: Similarly, from the statement Buddhi and others up to the products of cooking are born from conjunction, it is understood that buddhi and others up to bhāvanā arise from the conjunction of the soul with the internal organ, sound arises from the conjunction of the drum with space, the dimension of cotton arises from accumulation, the subsequent conjunction is in relation to the recitation of the sutra, the conjunction born from conjunction is the occasional fluidity from the conjunction with fire, and the priority and posteriority arise from the conjunction of the parts with space and time. The products of cooking, such as the color etc. of the earth atoms, also arise from the conjunction with fire. These are only born from conjunction. But they are not only born from conjunction. For example, sound is born from disjunction, and sound is also born from sound.

original: karmajaguṇoddeśaḥ
analyzed: karma ja guṇa uddeśaḥ
translated: The section on qualities born from action

original: saṃyogavibhāgavegāḥ karmajāḥ /PDhS
analyzed: saṃyoga vibhāga vegāḥ karma jāḥ pdhs
translated: Conjunction, disjunction, and velocity are born from action.

original: saṃyogavibhāgavegāḥ karmabhyo jātāḥ karmajā ityeta eva / na tvete karmajā eva / tathā hi / saṃyogaḥ saṃyogādutpadyate vibhāgaśca vibhāgād vego vegādapīti /
analyzed: saṃyoga vibhāga vegāḥ karmabhyaḥ jātāḥ karma jāḥ iti ete eva na tu ete karma jāḥ eva tathā hi saṃyogaḥ saṃyogāt utpadyate vibhāgaḥ ca vibhāgāt vegaḥ vegāt api iti
translated: Conjunction, disjunction, and velocity born from actions are called born from action. They are only these. But they are not only born from action. For example, conjunction arises from conjunction, and disjunction arises from disjunction, and velocity also arises from velocity.

original: vibhāgajaguṇakathanam
analyzed: vibhāga ja guṇa kathanam
translated: The explanation of qualities born from disjunction

original: śabdottaravibhāgau vibhāgajau /PDhS
analyzed: śabda uttara vibhāgau vibhāga jau
translated: Sound and the subsequent disjunction are born from disjunction.

original: śabdottaravibhāgau vibhāgājjātau vibhāgajāviti / etāveva vibhāgajau / na tvetau vibhāgajāveva / tathā hi / śabdaḥ saṃyogajaḥ śabdajo 'pyastīti / uttaravibhāgaśca / sūtrapāṭhāpekṣayā vibhāgajavibhāga eva parigṛhyate /
analyzed: śabda uttara vibhāgau vibhāgāt jātau vibhāga jau iti etau eva vibhāga jau na tu etau vibhāga jau eva tathā hi śabdaḥ saṃyoga jaḥ śabda jaḥ api asti iti uttara vibhāgaḥ ca sūtra pāṭha apekṣayā vibhāga ja vibhāgaḥ eva parigṛhyate
translated: Sound and the subsequent disjunction are born from disjunction, so they are born from disjunction. These two are only born from disjunction, but they are not only born from disjunction. Thus, sound is born from conjunction, and sound is also born from sound. And the subsequent disjunction. In relation to the recitation of the sutra, only the disjunction born from disjunction is accepted.

original: buddhyapekṣāṇāṃ / samānāsamānajātyārambhakānāñcoddeśaḥ
analyzed: buddhi apekṣāṇām samāna asamāna jāti ārambhakānām ca uddeśaḥ
translated: The enumeration of those that depend on cognition, and of those that originate from homogeneous and heterogeneous causes.

original: paratvāparatvadvitvadvipṛthaktvādayo buddhyapekṣāḥ / rūparasagandhānuṣṇasparśaśabdaparimāṇaikatvaikapṛthaktvasnehāḥ samānajātyārambhakāḥ / sukhaduḥkhecchādveṣaprayatnāśca asamānajātyārambhakāḥ / saṃyogavibhāgasaṃkhyāgurutvadravatvoṣṇasparśajñānadharmādharmasaṃskārāḥ samānāsamānajātyārambhakāḥ /PDhS
analyzed: paratva aparatva dvitva dvipṛthaktva ādayaḥ buddhi apekṣāḥ rūpa rasa gandha anuṣṇa sparśa śabda parimāṇa ekatva ekapṛthaktva snehāḥ samāna jāti ārambhakāḥ sukha duḥkha icchā dveṣa prayatnāḥ ca asamāna jāti ārambhakāḥ saṃyoga vibhāga saṃkhyā guru tva drava tva uṣṇa sparśa jñāna dharma adharma saṃskārāḥ samāna asamāna jāti ārambhakāḥ pdhs
translated: Distance, proximity, duality, and separateness depend on cognition. Color, taste, smell, hot touch, sound, dimension, unity, and separateness are produced from homogeneous causes. Pleasure, pain, desire, aversion, and effort are produced from heterogeneous causes. Conjunction, disjunction, number, heaviness, fluidity, hot touch, knowledge, virtue, vice, and impression are produced from both homogeneous and heterogeneous causes.

original: idānīṃ ke buddhyapekṣāḥ / ke ca samānajātyārambhakā ityupadarśayati paratvāparatvadvitvadvipṛthaktvādayaḥ buddhimapekṣante svotpattāviti buddhyapekṣā iti / ādipadena tritvādikā parārdhāntā saṃkhyā tadavacchinnañca pṛthaktvaṃ II / gṛhyate / avadhāraṇantu eta eva buddhyapekṣāstathaite buddhyapekṣā eva / buddhiṃ vinā na bhavantīti /
analyzed: idānīm ke buddhi apekṣāḥ ke ca samāna jāti ārambhakāḥ iti upadarśayati paratva aparatva dvitva dvipṛthaktva ādayaḥ buddhim apekṣante sva utpattau iti buddhi apekṣāḥ iti ādi padena tritva ādikā parārdha antā saṃkhyā tad avacchinnam ca pṛthaktvam gṛhyate avadhāraṇam tu ete eva buddhi apekṣāḥ tathā ete buddhi apekṣāḥ eva buddhim vinā na bhavanti iti
translated: Now, which ones require the intellect and which ones are produced by homogeneous causes? This is being shown: Distance, proximity, duality, and separateness, etc. require the intellect for their own production, hence they are said to require the intellect. By the word 'etc.' the numbers from three onwards up to the parārdha, and the separateness delimited by that, are included. But the restriction is that these alone require the intellect, and only these require the intellect, they do not exist without the intellect.

original: rūpādayaḥ snehāntāḥ samānajātyārambhakā iti / samānā tulyā jātiryeṣāṃ te samānajātayastānārabhanta iti tadārambhakā eva / na tveta eva samānajātyārambhakā ubhayārambhakāṇāmapi sadbhāvāt / atra cānuṣṇagrahaṇamuṣṇasparśavyavacchedārtham / tasyāpyubhayārambhakatvāt / ekatvaikapṛthaktvagrahaṇaṃ dvitvadvipṛthaktvādivyavacchedārtham / dvitvāderasamānajātyārambhakatvād / dvipṛthaktvādeścākāraṇatvāditi /
analyzed: rūpa ādayaḥ sneha antāḥ samāna jāti ārambhakāḥ iti samānā tulyā jātiḥ yeṣām te samāna jātayaḥ tān ārabhante iti tad ārambhakāḥ eva na tu ete eva samāna jāti ārambhakāḥ ubhaya ārambhakāṇām api sadbhāvāt  atra ca anuṣṇa grahaṇam uṣṇa sparśa vyavaccheda artham tasya api ubhaya ārambhaka tvāt ekatva ekapṛthaktva grahaṇam dvitva dvipṛthaktva ādi vyavaccheda artham dvitva ādeḥ asamāna jāti ārambhaka tvāt dvipṛthaktva ādeḥ ca akāraṇa
translated: Form and the rest up to moisture are the causes of things of the same kind. Those that have the same kind are of the same kind. They produce those. Therefore, they are only the causes of those. However, they are not just the causes of things of the same kind, because there are also causes of both kinds. And here, the mention of non-hot is for the purpose of excluding the hot touch. Because that is also a cause of both kinds. The mention of oneness and single separateness is for the purpose of excluding duality and double separateness, etc. Because duality, etc. are causes of things of different kinds, and double separateness, etc. are not causes at all.

original: tathā hyudakāvayaveṣu vartamānā rūpādayaḥ snehaparyantāḥ kārye tānārabhante / gandhastu kṣityavayaveṣu vartamānastadavayavini gandhamārabhate / śabdaścākāśe vartamānastatraiva śabdamiti /
analyzed: tathā hi udaka avayaveṣu vartamānāḥ rūpa ādayaḥ sneha paryantāḥ kārye tān ārabhante gandhaḥ tu kṣiti avayaveṣu vartamānaḥ tad avayavini gandham ārabhate śabdaḥ ca ākāśe vartamānaḥ tatra eva śabdam iti
translated: For example, form and the rest up to moisture, which exist in the parts of water, produce their effect by producing those. But smell, which exists in the parts of earth, produces smell in the whole composed of those parts. And sound, which exists in space, produces sound right there in space.

original: sukhādayaḥ prayatnāntāstvasamānajātyārambhakā iti / asamānajātīyamevārabhanta iti tadārambhakāḥ / na tveta eva / anyeṣāmapi sadbhāvāt / tathā ca sukhādicchā / dveṣād dveṣaḥ / tābhyāṃ prayatnaḥ / tasmāt kriyeti /
analyzed: sukha ādayaḥ prayatna antāḥ tu asamāna jāti ārambhakāḥ iti asamāna jātīyam eva ārabhante iti tad ārambhakāḥ na tu ete eva anyeṣām api sadbhāvāt tathā ca sukhāt icchā dveṣāt dveṣaḥ tābhyām prayatnaḥ tasmāt kriyā iti
translated: Pleasure, etc., up to effort, are producers of dissimilar kinds. They produce only dissimilar kinds, not themselves. Because others also exist. And thus, desire for pleasure, etc., aversion from pain, from those two, effort, from that, action.

original: saṃyogādayaḥ saṃskārāntāḥ samānāsamānajātyārambhakā iti / samānā jātiryeṣāṃ te samānajātayastatpratiṣedhena cāsamānajātayaḥ / tānārabhanta iti tadārambhakāḥ / eta eva samānāsamānajātyārambhakāḥ / nānye / tathaite samānāsamānajātyārambhakā eva niyamena / tathā hi / saṃyogāt saṃyogaḥ / vijātīyañca buddhyādi / vibhāgād vibhāgaḥ / vijātīyaśca śabdaḥ / saṃkhyātaḥ saṃkhyā vijātīyañca parimāṇam / gurutvād gurutvaṃ vijātīyañca patanam / dravatvād dravatvaṃ vijātīyañca syandanam / uṣṇasparśād uṣṇasparśo vijātīyāśca pākajāḥ / jñānācca jñānaṃ vijātīyāśca saṃskārāḥ / dharmādharmābhyāṃ dharmādharmau vijātīye ca sukhaduḥkhe / saṃskārāt saṃskāro vijātīyañca smaraṇam /
analyzed: saṃyoga ādayaḥ saṃskāra antāḥ samāna asamāna jāti ārambhakāḥ iti samānā jātiḥ yeṣām te samāna jātayaḥ tad pratiṣedhena ca asamāna jātayaḥ tān ārabhante iti tad ārambhakāḥ ete eva samāna asamāna jāti ārambhakāḥ na anye tathā ete samāna asamāna jāti ārambhakāḥ eva niyamena tathā hi saṃyogāt saṃyogaḥ vijātīyam ca buddhi ādi vibhāgāt vibhāgaḥ vijātīyaḥ ca śabdaḥ saṃkhyātaḥ saṃkhyā vijātīyam ca parimāṇam guru tvāt guru
translated: Conjunction and the rest, up to Impression, are producers of things of the same and different kinds. Those that have the same kind are of the same kind. By negating that, those of different kinds are of different kinds. They produce those, so they are producers of those. These alone are producers of things of the same and different kinds. Not others. Thus, these are producers of things of the same and different kinds only by rule. For example: From conjunction, conjunction. And from different kinds, intellect and the rest. From disjunction, disjunction. And from different kinds, sound. From number, number. And from different kinds, dimension. From heaviness, heaviness. And from different kinds, falling. From fluidity, fluidity. And from different kinds, flowing. From hot touch, hot touch. And from different kinds, the products of cooking. And from knowledge, knowledge. And from different kinds, impressions. From virtue and vice, virtue and vice. And from different kinds, pleasure and pain. From impression, impression. And from different kinds, memory.

original: svaparāśrayasamavetārambhakaguṇoddeśaḥ
analyzed: sva para āśraya samaveta ārambhaka guṇa uddeśaḥ
translated: The definition of qualities that originate in self and other substrata

original: buddhisukhaduḥkhecchādveṣabhāvanāśabdāḥ svāśrayasamavetārambhakāḥ / rūparasagandhasparśaparimāṇasnehaprayatnāḥ paratrārambhakāḥ / II / saṃyogavibhāgasaṃkhyaikatvaikapṛthaktvagurutvadravatvavegadharmādharmāstūbhayatrārambhakāḥ /PDhS
analyzed: buddhi sukha duḥkha icchā dveṣa bhāvanā śabdāḥ sva āśraya samaveta ārambhakāḥ rūpa rasa gandha sparśa parimāṇa sneha prayatnāḥ paratra ārambhakāḥ    saṃyoga vibhāga saṃkhyā eka tva eka pṛthak tva guru tva drava tva vega dharma adharmāḥ tu ubhayatra ārambhakāḥ
translated: Intelligence, pleasure, pain, desire, aversion, memory, and sound originate in their own substrata. Color, taste, smell, touch, dimension, fluidity, effort, and merit originate in other substrata. Conjunction, disjunction, number, unity, separateness, heaviness, fluidity, velocity, merit, and demerit originate in both.

original: idānīṃ svaparāśrayasamavetārambhakān darśayati buddhyādayaḥ śabdāntāḥ / svāśrayasamavetamevārabhanta iti svāśrayasamavetārambhakāḥ / na tveta eva ubhayatrārambhakāṇāmapi sadbhāvāt / tathā hi / buddhirātmani vartate / tatraiva jñānaṃ saṃskāraheturbhavati / sukhādicchā ātmanyeva / duḥkhād dveṣastatraiva / icchātaḥ smaraṇaprayatnāvātmanyeva / tathā dveṣādapi / bhāvanāto bhāvanā smaraṇañcātmanyeva / śabdaścākāśe vartamānastatraiva śabdamārabhata iti /
analyzed: idānīm sva para āśraya samaveta ārambhakān darśayati buddhi ādayaḥ śabdāntāḥ sva āśraya samavetam eva ārabhante iti sva āśraya samaveta ārambhakāḥ na tu ete eva ubhayatra ārambhakāṇām api sadbhāvāt tathā hi buddhiḥ ātmani vartate tatra eva jñānam saṃskāra hetuḥ bhavati sukhāt icchā ātmani eva duḥkhāt dveṣaḥ tatra eva icchātaḥ smaraṇa prayatnau ātmani eva tathā dveṣāt api bhāvanātaḥ bhāvanā smaraṇam ca ātmani eva śabdaḥ ca ākāśe va
translated: Now he shows the causes that originate in what is inherent in oneself and others: from intellect up to sound. They originate only in what is inherent in their own substratum, so they are causes that originate in what is inherent in their own substratum. However, not only these, because there are also causes that originate in both. Thus, intellect exists in the self. There itself, knowledge becomes the cause of impressions. Desire for pleasure exists in the self itself. Aversion to pain exists there itself. From desire, memory and effort exist in the self itself. Similarly, from aversion also. From cultivation, both cultivation and memory exist in the self itself. And sound, existing in space, originates sound there itself.

original: rūpādayaḥ prayatnāntāḥ paratreti / parasminnevārabhanta iti paratrārambhakā na tveta eva / tathā hi rūparasagandhasparśaparimāṇasnehāḥ kāraṇeṣu vartamānāḥ paratra kārye tānārabhante / tathā prayatnaḥ puruṣe vartamānaḥ paratra hastādau kriyāmārabhate /
analyzed: rūpa ādayaḥ prayatna antāḥ paratra iti parasmin eva ārabhante iti paratra ārambhakāḥ na tu ete eva tathā hi rūpa rasa gandha sparśa parimāṇa snehāḥ kāraṇeṣu vartamānāḥ paratra kārye tān ārabhante tathā prayatnaḥ puruṣe vartamānaḥ paratra hasta ādau kriyām ārabhate
translated: Form and the rest up to effort are in another, i.e., they originate in another alone. They are originators in another, not in themselves. Thus, form, taste, smell, touch, quantity, and fluidity, existing in the causes, originate those in the effect which is another. Similarly, effort, existing in the soul, originates action in another, in the hand etc.

original: saṃyogādayo 'dharmāntāstūbhayatrārambhakāḥ / eta evobhayatrārambhakāḥ / tathaita ubhayatrārambhakā eva niyamena / bheryākāśasaṃyogo hyākāśe vartamānastatraiva śabdamārabhate / bherīdaṇḍasaṃyogastu paratra / tathā vaṃśadalākāśavibhāgaḥ svāśraye / vaṃśadalavibhāgastu paratrākāśe śabdārambhakaḥ / saṃkhyā kāraṇe vartamānā dvitvatritvādikā kārye parimāṇam ekatvasaṃkhyā ca / ekatvaṃ svāśraye tu dvitvādikamārabhata iti / ekapṛthaktvagrahaṇaṃ dvipṛthaktvādivyavacchedārtham / teṣāmakāraṇatvāt / kāraṇeṣu vartamānamekapṛthaktvaṃ kārye 'pyekapṛthaktvamārabhate svāśrayeṣu dvipṛthaktvādikamiti / gurutvadravatvavegāstu kāraṇagatāḥ kārye 'pi gurutvādīnārabhante / svāśrayeṣu patanasyandanagamanakriyā iti / dharmādharmau ca svāśrayasamavete sukhaduḥkhe parāśraye tu kriyāmārabhete /
analyzed: saṃyoga ādayaḥ dharma antāḥ tu ubhayatra ārambhakāḥ ete eva ubhayatra ārambhakāḥ tathā ete ubhayatra ārambhakāḥ eva niyamena bherī ākāśa saṃyogaḥ hi ākāśe vartamānaḥ tatra eva śabdam ārabhate bherī daṇḍa saṃyogaḥ tu paratra tathā vaṃśa dala ākāśa vibhāgaḥ sva āśraye vaṃśa dala vibhāgaḥ tu paratra ākāśe śabda ārambhakaḥ saṃkhyā kāraṇe vartamānā dvi tva tri tva ādikā kārye parimāṇam eka tva saṃkhyā ca eka tvam sva āśray
translated: Conjunction and the others up to non-eternality are producers in both cases. These alone are producers in both cases. And they are producers in both cases only by rule. For the conjunction of the drum and space, existing in space, produces sound there only. But the conjunction of the drum and stick produces it elsewhere. Similarly, the disjunction of the bamboo and leaf in space is in its own substratum. But the disjunction of the bamboo and leaf produces sound in the other space. Number, existing in the cause, produces dimension in the effect, such as duality, triality, etc., and unity in the effect. Unity produces duality, etc. in its own substratum.
