The mention of unity is for the purpose of excluding duality, etc., because they are not causes. Unity existing in the causes produces unity in the effect, and duality, etc. in its own substrata. But gravity, fluidity and impetus, existing in the cause, produce gravity, etc. in the effect. The actions of falling, flowing and moving in their own substrata.

original: kriyāhetuguṇānāmuddeśaḥ🔽gurutvadravatvavegaprayatnadharmādharmasaṃyogaviśeṣāḥ kiyāhetavaḥ /PDhS
analyzed: kriyā hetu guṇānām uddeśaḥ  guru tva drava tva vega prayatna dharma adharma saṃyoga viśeṣāḥ kiyā hetavaḥ
translated: The enumeration of the qualities that are the causes of action🔽Gravity, fluidity, velocity, effort, merit, demerit, and conjunction are the causes of action.

original: idānīṃ kriyāhetūnāha gurutvādisaṃyogaviśeṣāntāḥ kriyāhetavaḥ iti / tathā hi / gurutvāt patanam / dravatvāt syandanam / vegād gamanam / prayatnād II / hastādau kriyā / dharmādharmābhyāmagnyādau kriyā / saṃyogaviśeṣāstu nodanābhighātasaṃyuktasaṃyogāste 'pi kriyāhetava eva / gurutvādīnāṃ gurutvajanakatvasyāpyupalabdheḥ /
analyzed: idānīm kriyā hetūn āha guru tva ādi saṃyoga viśeṣa antāḥ kriyā hetavaḥ iti tathā hi guru tvāt patanam drava tvāt syandanam vegāt gamanam prayatnāt hasta ādau kriyā dharma adharmābhyām agni ādau kriyā saṃyoga viśeṣāḥ tu nodana abhighāta saṃyukta saṃyogāḥ te pi kriyā hetavaḥ eva guru tva ādīnām guru tva janaka tvasya api upalabdheḥ
translated: Now he mentions the causes of action: Gravity and the rest, ending with specific conjunctions, are the causes of action. For example, falling is due to gravity, flowing is due to fluidity, motion is due to velocity, action in the hand and so on is due to effort, action in fire and so on is due to merit and demerit, and specific conjunctions such as impulsion, impact, and conjunction with the conjoined are also causes of action, because the production of gravity and so on by gravity and so on is also observed.

original: asamavāyyādikāraṇaguṇoddeśaḥ / akāraṇaguṇakathanañca
analyzed: asamavāyi ādi kāraṇa guṇa uddeśaḥ akāraṇa guṇa kathanañca
translated: The enumeration of the qualities that are the non-inherent and other causes, and the mention of the qualities that are not causes

original: rūparasagandhānuṣṇasparśasaṃkhyāparimāṇaikapṛthaktvasnehaśabdānāmasamavāyitvam / buddhisukhaduḥkhecchādveṣaprayatnadharmādharmabhāvanānāṃ nimittakāraṇatvam / saṃyogavibhāgoṣṇasparśagurutvadravatvavegānāmubhayathā kāraṇatvam / paratvāparatvadvipṛktvādīnāmakāraṇatvam /PDhS
analyzed: rūpa rasa gandha anuṣṇa sparśa saṃkhyā parimāṇa ekapṛthaktva sneha śabdānām asamavāyi tvam buddhi sukha duḥkha icchā dveṣa prayatna dharma adharma bhāvanānām nimitta kāraṇa tvam saṃyoga vibhāga uṣṇa sparśa guru tva drava tva vegānām ubhayathā kāraṇa tvam paratva aparatva dvipṛktva ādīnām akāraṇa tvam
translated: The non-inherence of color, taste, smell, heat, touch, number, dimension, unity, separateness, fluidity, and sound. The causal nature of intelligence, pleasure, pain, desire, aversion, effort, virtue, vice, and impression. The twofold causal nature of conjunction, disjunction, heat, touch, heaviness, fluidity, and velocity. The non-causal nature of distance, proximity, and non-contact, etc.

original: idānīmasamavāyinimittobhayathākāraṇānyāha rūpādiśabdāntānāmasamavāyikāraṇatvam iti /
analyzed: idānīm asamavāyi nimitta ubhayathā kāraṇāni āha rūpa ādi śabda antānām asamavāyi kāraṇa tvam iti
translated: Now he states the non-inherent, causal, and twofold causes: The non-inherent causal nature of color, etc., up to sound.

original: atha kimidamasamavāyikāraṇatvaṃ nāma / pratyāsannasya kāryajanakatvam / yad yasya pratyāsannaṃ sajjanakatvenopalabdhasāmarthyaṃ vyāptyā tat tasyotpattāvasamavāyikāraṇam /
analyzed: atha kim idam asamavāyi kāraṇa tvam nāma pratyāsannasya kārya janaka tvam yat yasya pratyāsannam sat janaka tvena upalabdha sāmarthyam vyāptyā tat tasya utpattau asamavāyi kāraṇam
translated: Now, what is this called non-inherent causal nature? The generative nature of what is proximate. That which is observed to have the ability to generate what is proximate to it is pervaded by that. It is the non-inherent cause of its production.

original: kā punariyaṃ pratyāsattiḥ / ekārthasamavāyaḥ / sā tu bhidyate kāryaikārthasamavāyalakṣaṇā kāryakāraṇaikārthasamavāyalakṣaṇā ceti / kāryeṇa sahaikasminnarthe samavāyo lakṣaṇaṃ cihnamasyā iti tallakṣaṇā / yathā śabdasya śabdotpattāviti / kāryaśabdo hyākāśe vartate tatraiva kāraṇaśabdo 'pīti kāryaikārthasamavāyo 'sya pratyāsattiriti / tathā buddhyādyutpattāvātmāntaḥkaraṇasaṃyogasya / sa hyātmani vartate buddhyādayo 'pi tatraiveti /
analyzed: kā punar iyam pratyāsattiḥ eka artha samavāyaḥ sā tu bhidyate kārya eka artha samavāya lakṣaṇā kārya kāraṇa eka artha samavāya lakṣaṇā ca iti kāryeṇa saha ekasmin arthe samavāyaḥ lakṣaṇam cihnam asyāḥ iti tad lakṣaṇā yathā śabdasya śabda utpattau iti kārya śabdaḥ hi ākāśe vartate tatra eva kāraṇa śabdaḥ pi iti kārya eka artha samavāyaḥ pratyāsattiḥ iti tathā buddhi ādi utpattau ātma antaḥkaraṇa saṃyogasya sa hi ātmani vartate buddh
translated: What is this proximity? It is the inherence of the effect and the cause in the same object. It is divided into that characterized by the inherence of the effect in the same object and that characterized by the inherence of the cause and the effect in the same object. That which has as its characteristic the inherence of the effect in the same object as itself is characterized by that. For example, the sound of a word in the production of another sound. For the word as effect occurs in space, and the word as cause also occurs there, so the proximity of this is the inherence of the effect in the same object. Similarly, in the production of cognition etc., there is the conjunction of the self and the internal organ. For that occurs in the self, and cognition etc. also occur there.

original: nanvevaṃ buddhyādīnāmapi svakāryotpattāvekārthasamavāyitvādasamavāyikāraṇatvameva na nimittatvam / naiṣa doṣaḥ / saṃyogasyāśeṣakāryotpattau vyāptyā sāmarthyopalabdheḥ / na caivaṃ buddhyāderanyatarasyeti / tasya pratiniyatakāryotpattāveva sāmarthyāvadhāraṇāt / ātmāntaḥkaraṇasaṃyogastvaśeṣabuddhyādyutpattāvupalabdhasāmarthyamiti sa evāsamavāyikāraṇam / na jātucinmanaḥsaṃyogādṛte buddhyādayo bhavantīti / tathā ca suṣuptyavasthāvasāne vijñānādikamutpadyata iti manaḥsaṃyogastatra kāraṇam /
analyzed: nanu evam buddhi ādīnām api sva kārya utpattau ekārtha samavāyi tvāt asamavāyi kāraṇa tvam eva na nimitta tvam na eṣa doṣaḥ saṃyogasya aśeṣa kārya utpattau vyāptyā sāmarthya upalabdheḥ na ca evam buddhi ādeḥ anyatarasya iti tasya pratiniyata kārya utpattau eva sāmarthya avadhāraṇāt ātma antaḥkaraṇa saṃyogaḥ tu aśeṣa buddhi ādi utpattau upalabdha sāmarthyam iti saḥ eva asamavāyi kāraṇam na jātucit manaḥ saṃyogāt ṛte buddhi ādayaḥ bhavanti i
translated: But in that case, intellect etc. also, being in conjunction with the same object in the production of their own effects, would be only non-inherent causes, not instrumental causes. This is not a fault. Because conjunction is found to be capable by its pervasion in the production of all effects, and not so for intellect etc. individually. Because their capability is determined only in the production of specific effects. But the conjunction of the self and internal organ is found to be capable in the production of all intellect etc., so that alone is the non-inherent cause. Because intellect etc. never occur without the conjunction of the mind. And thus, at the end of the state of deep sleep, consciousness etc. arise, so the conjunction of the mind is the cause there.

original: nanvevamapi dharmādharmayoraśeṣabuddhyādyutpattau vyāptyā kāraṇatvādasamavāyitvaṃ syāt / na / vibhuviśeṣaguṇānāṃ viśiṣṭapratyāsatterupalambhāt / yathā hi / śabdaḥ śabdāntaramārabhamāṇaḥ svāvaruddhanabhodeśasamanantaramevārabhate naikārthasamavāyitvād deśāntare tathā sati brahmabhāṣitasyāpyupalambhaprasaṅgāt / tadvad dharmādharmāvapi svāvaruddhātmapradeśānantaraṃ sukhaduḥkhādikamārabheyātām iti svargādisthāneṣu tadabhāvaḥ syāt / ārabhete tu sthānāntareṣvapi sukhaduḥkhādikamiti nimittakāraṇatvameva / tasmādātmāntaḥkaraṇasaṃyoga eva buddhyādyutpattāvekārthasamavāyitayā asamavāyikāraṇamiti sthitam /
analyzed: nanu evam api dharma adharmayoḥ aśeṣa buddhi ādi utpattau vyāptyā kāraṇa tvāt asamavāyi tvam syāt na vibhu viśeṣa guṇānām viśiṣṭa pratyāsatteḥ upalambhāt yathā hi śabdaḥ śabda antaram ārabhamāṇaḥ sva avaruddha nabhaḥ deśa samanantaram eva ārabhate na eka artha samavāyi tvāt deśa antare tathā sati brahma bhāṣitasya api upalambha prasaṅgāt tadvat dharma adharmau api sva avaruddha ātma pradeśa anantaram sukha duḥkha ādikam ārabheyātām iti svarga
translated: Even so, if virtue and vice were the cause of the production of all cognitions etc. by pervading them, they would be non-inherent causes. No, because the qualities of pervasive substances are perceived to have a specific proximity. Just as when one sound produces another sound, it produces it immediately after the space enclosed by itself, not by inhering in the same object, otherwise the sound uttered by Brahman would also be perceived in other places. Similarly, virtue and vice would produce pleasure, pain etc. immediately after the part of the self enclosed by themselves, so there would be absence of those in the abodes of heaven etc. But they do produce pleasure, pain etc. even in other abodes, so they are only instrumental causes. Therefore, it is established that the conjunction of the self and the internal organ is the non-inherent cause in the production of cognition etc. by inhering in the same object.

original: tathā kāryaṃ rūpādi paṭe vartate / paṭaśca tantuṣu / tadgatāśca rūpādayastatraiveti kāryakāraṇaikārthasamavāyasteṣāṃ pratyāsattiriti /
analyzed: tathā kāryam rūpa ādi paṭe vartate paṭaḥ ca tantuṣu tad gatāḥ ca rūpa ādayaḥ tatra eva iti kārya kāraṇa eka artha samavāyaḥ teṣām pratyāsattiḥ iti
translated: Similarly, the effect, such as color, exists in the cloth, and the cloth exists in the threads, and the colors existing in those [threads] exist right there [in the cloth]. Thus, their proximity is the inherence of the same object in the cause and effect.

original: nanvevamapi tanturūpaṃ rasādyutpattau pratyāsannam / rasaśca rūpotpattāvityasamavāyitvaṃ syāt / na / janakatvamiti viśeṣaṇāt / yad yasyotpattau pratyāsannaṃ sajjanakaṃ tadasamavāyikāraṇam / na caivaṃ rūpaṃ rasādyutpattau kāraṇaṃ tadanuvidhānasyādarśanāt / yathā hi śuklād rūpācchuklaṃ pītācca pītamiti kāraṇarūpānuvidhānamasti naivaṃ rasādineti / na hi madhurādamlād vā tacchuklaṃ pītaṃ vā rūpamityanvayo gṛhyate / tasmāt pratyāsattāvapi nāsamavāyitvam kāraṇasya satastadviśeṣanirūpaṇāt /
analyzed: nanu evam api tantu rūpam rasa ādi utpattau pratyāsannam rasaḥ ca rūpa utpattau iti asamavāyi tvam syāt na janaka tvam iti viśeṣaṇāt yat yasya utpattau pratyāsannam sat janakam tat asamavāyi kāraṇam na ca evam rūpam rasa ādi utpattau kāraṇam tad anuvidhānasya adarśanāt yathā hi śuklāt rūpāt śuklam pītāt ca pītam iti kāraṇa rūpa anuvidhānam asti na evam rasa ādinā iti  na hi madhurāt amlāt vā tat śuklam pītam vā rūpam iti anvayaḥ gṛhyate tasmāt pratyās
translated: Even so, if color in the thread is proximate in the production of taste, and taste is proximate in the production of color, there would be non-inherence. No, because the qualification is made that which is proximate in the production of something, being existent, is the non-inherent cause. And color is not the cause in the production of taste, because the conformity with that [cause] is not seen. For just as whiteness arises from white [color] and yellow arises from yellow [color], there is conformity with the causal color, but not so with taste, etc. For the whiteness or yellowness of that [taste] is not apprehended as following from sour or sweet [color], respectively. Therefore, even in proximity, there is no non-inherence, because the cause, being existent, is determined as a particular [cause].

original: na caivaṃ samavāyikāraṇe prasaṅgastasyoktapratyāsattyabhāvāt / na hi kāryeṇa tatkāraṇena ca sahaikārthasamavāyastasyāsti / tatraiva tatkāryasya samavāyāt /
analyzed: na ca evam samavāyi kāraṇe prasaṅgaḥ tasya ukta pratyāsatti abhāvāt na hi kāryeṇa tad kāraṇena ca saha eka artha samavāyaḥ tasya asti tatra eva tad kāryasya samavāyāt
translated: And there is no such contingency in the case of the inherent cause, because it is not related in the above manner. For it is not related to the effect and its cause as inhering in the same object, because the effect inheres in it alone.

original: tathā hi / rūparasagandhānuṣṇasparśaparimāṇasnehāḥ kāryakāraṇaikārthasamavāyādevāsamavāyikāraṇam / saṃkhyā tu dvitvādikā parimāṇotpattau kāryakāraṇaikārthasamavāyenāsamavāyikāraṇam / tathā kāraṇaikatvam ekapṛthaktvañca kāryaikatvaikapṛthaktvotpattāviti / dvitvadvipṛthaktvādyutpattāvekatvaikapṛthaktvādīnāṃ kāryaikārthasamavāyenaivāsamavāyikāraṇatvameva / evaṃ śabdasyāpītyuktam /
analyzed: tathā hi rūpa rasa gandha anuṣṇa sparśa parimāṇa snehāḥ kārya kāraṇa eka artha samavāyāt eva asamavāyi kāraṇam saṃkhyā tu dvi tva ādikā parimāṇa utpattau kārya kāraṇa eka artha samavāyena asamavāyi kāraṇam tathā kāraṇa eka tvam eka pṛthak tvam ca kārya eka tva eka pṛthak tva utpattau iti dvi tva dvi pṛthak tva ādi utpattau ekatva ekapṛthak tva ādīnām kārya eka artha samavāyena eva asamavāyi kāraṇa tvam eva evam śabdasya api iti uktam  /
translated: Thus, color, taste, smell, hot touch, dimension, and fluidity are the non-inherent causes only by inhering in the same object as the cause and effect. But number such as duality is the non-inherent cause in the production of dimension by inhering in the same object as the cause and effect. Similarly, the unity of the cause and the singularity of the unit are the non-inherent causes in the production of the unity and singularity of the effect. In the production of duality, double singularity, etc., the unity, singularity, etc. are the non-inherent causes only by inhering in the same object as the effect. Thus it is said that sound also is the same.

original: eteṣāmasamavāyikāraṇatvameva / na tveteṣāmeva / anyeṣāmapi sadbhāvāt /
analyzed: eteṣām asamavāyi kāraṇa tvam eva na tu eteṣām eva anyeṣām api sadbhāvāt
translated: These are only the non-inherent causes, not only these, because others also exist.

original: atra cānuṣṇagrahaṇamuṣṇasparśavyavacchedārtham / tasyobhayathā kāraṇatvāt /
analyzed: atra ca anuṣṇa grahaṇam uṣṇa sparśa vyavaccheda artham tasya ubhayathā kāraṇa tvāt
translated: And here, the mention of non-hotness is for the purpose of excluding hot touch, because it is a cause in both ways.

original: buddhyādibhāvanāntānāṃ nimittakāraṇatvam iti / samavāyyasamavāyilakṣaṇarahitasya janakatvam / na cāsiddhaṃ viśeṣaṇaṃ pratyāsannasya buddhyāderjanakatvāditi vācyam / pūrvoktanyāyāt / avadhāraṇantveteṣāṃ nimittakāraṇatvameva / na tveteṣāmeva /
analyzed: buddhi ādi bhāvanā antānām nimitta kāraṇa tvam iti samavāyi asamavāyi lakṣaṇa rahitasya janaka tvam na ca asiddham viśeṣaṇam pratyāsannasya buddhi ādeḥ janaka tvāt iti vācyam pūrva ukta nyāyāt avadhāraṇantu eteṣām nimitta kāraṇa tvam eva na tu eteṣām eva
translated: The intellect and the rest up to contemplation are the instrumental causes. The production of what is devoid of the characteristics of inherence and non-inherence is the productive cause. And it cannot be said that the qualification is unestablished, because the intellect and the rest that are proximate are the productive causes, because of the previously stated reasoning. But the restriction is that these are only the instrumental causes, not that they are only these.

original: tathā hi buddhirjñānaṃ saṃskārotpattau kāraṇam / sukhamicchāyāḥ / duḥkhaṃ dveṣasya / icchādveṣau prayatnasya / sa ca kriyāyāḥ / dharmādharmau sukhaduḥkhayoḥ / bhāvanā smaraṇasyeti /
analyzed: tathā hi buddhiḥ jñānam saṃskāra utpattau kāraṇam sukham icchāyāḥ duḥkham dveṣasya icchā dveṣau prayatnasya sa ca kriyāyāḥ dharma adharmau sukha duḥkhayoḥ bhāvanā smaraṇasya iti
translated: Thus, the intellect is the cause in the production of knowledge, pleasure is of desire, pain is of aversion, desire and aversion are of effort, and that is of action. Dharma and adharma are of pleasure and pain, and contemplation is of memory.

original: saṃyogādivegāntānām ubhayathā kāraṇatvam iti / asamavāyinimittakāraṇatvamiti / eteṣāmevobhayathā kāraṇatvam / tathaiteṣāmubhayathā kāraṇatvameveti niyamena /
analyzed: saṃyoga ādi vega antānām ubhayathā kāraṇa tvam iti asamavāyi nimitta kāraṇa tvam iti eteṣām eva ubhayathā kāraṇa tvam tathā eteṣām ubhayathā kāraṇa tvam eva iti niyamena
translated: The conjunction and the rest up to velocity are causes in both ways, i.e., they are non-inherent instrumental causes. These alone are causes in both ways. Thus, these alone are causes in both ways, by the rule.

original: tathā hi / bheryākāśasaṃyogasyāsamavāyikāraṇatvam / bherīdaṇḍasaṃyogasya nimittatvam / evaṃ vaṃśadalākāśavibhāgasyāsamavāyikāraṇatvam / vaṃśadalavibhāgasya nimittatvam / uṣṇasparśasyotpattāvasamavāyikāraṇatvam / pākajeṣu nimittatvam / evaṃ gurutvadravatvavegānāṃ svāśrayakriyotpattāvasamavāyikāraṇatvam / āśrayāntare nimittatvamiti /
analyzed: tathā hi bherī ākāśa saṃyogasya asamavāyi kāraṇa tvam bherī daṇḍa saṃyogasya nimitta tvam evam vaṃśa dala ākāśa vibhāgasya asamavāyi kāraṇa tvam vaṃśa dala vibhāgasya nimitta tvam uṣṇa sparśasya utpattau asamavāyi kāraṇa tvam pāka jeṣu nimitta tvam evam guru tva drava tva vegānām sva āśraya kriyā utpattau asamavāyi kāraṇa tvam āśraya antare nimitta tvam iti
translated: For example, the conjunction of the drum and space is the non-inherent cause, the conjunction of the drum and stick is the instrumental cause. Similarly, the disjunction of the bamboo strip and space is the non-inherent cause, the disjunction of the bamboo strip is the instrumental cause. In the production of the hot touch, the non-inherent cause is the cooking effect, the instrumental cause is the inherent cause. Similarly, gravity, fluidity, and velocity are the non-inherent causes in the production of the action of their substratum, and the instrumental cause is in another substratum.

original: paratvāparatvadvipṛthaktvādīnāmakāraṇatvamityādipadena tripṛthaktvādīnāṃ grahaṇam /
analyzed: paratva aparatva dvipṛthaktva ādīnām akāraṇa tvam iti ādi padena tripṛthaktva ādīnām grahaṇam
translated: The non-causality of distance, proximity, duality, etc. The word 'etc.' includes triplicity, etc.

original: nanveteṣāṃ jñānādyutpattāvastyeva kāraṇatvam / satyam / tadvyatirekeṇānyatrākāraṇatvaṃ vivakṣitamiti / samānajātīyārambhakādivākye 'pīdaṃ viśeṣaṇamūhyam / eteṣāmakāraṇatvameva / na tveteṣāmeva / pārimāṇḍalyāderapyakāraṇatvāt /
analyzed: nanu eteṣām jñāna ādi utpattau asti eva kāraṇa tvam satyam tad vyatirekeṇa anyatra akāraṇa tvam vivakṣitam iti samāna jātīya ārambhaka ādi vākye pi idam viśeṣaṇam ūhyam eteṣām akāraṇa tvam eva na tu eteṣām eva pārimāṇḍalya ādeḥ api akāraṇa tvāt
translated: But these do have causality in the production of knowledge, etc. True, but their non-causality elsewhere, except for that, is intended. This qualification should be understood in the statement about the origin of things of the same class. These are indeed non-causes, but not only these, because sphericity, etc. are also non-causes.

original: avyāpyavṛttiguṇānāṃ yāvaddravyabhāviguṇānāñcoddeśaḥ
analyzed: avyāpya vṛtti guṇānām yāvaddravyabhāvi guṇānām ca uddeśaḥ
translated: The definition of qualities that inhere without pervading and qualities that exist as long as the substance does.

original: saṃyogavibhāgaśabdātmaviśeṣaguṇānāṃ pradeśavṛttitvam / śeṣāṇāmāśrayavyāpitvam / apākajarūparasagandhasparśaparimāṇaikatvaikapṛthaktvasāṃsiddhikadravatvagurutvasnehānāṃ yāvaddravyabhāvitvam / II / śeṣāṇāmayāvaddravyabhāvitvañceti /PDhS
analyzed: saṃyoga vibhāga śabda ātma viśeṣa guṇānām pradeśa vṛtti tvam śeṣāṇām āśraya vyāpi tvam apāka ja rūpa rasa gandha sparśa parimāṇa ekatva ekapṛthaktva sāṃsiddhika drava tva guru tva snehānām yāvaddravyabhāvi tvam    śeṣāṇām ayāvaddravyabhāvi tvam ca iti
translated: Conjunction, disjunction, sound, and the specific qualities of the self have limited occurrence. The remaining ones pervade their substratum. The qualities of color, taste, smell, touch, number, unity, separateness, inherence, fluidity, gravity, and viscosity that are not produced by baking exist as long as the substance exists. The remaining ones do not exist as long as the substance exists.

original: idānīṃ keṣāṃ pradeśavṛttitvamāśrayavyāpitvañcetyāha saṃyogavibhāgaśabdātmaviśeṣaguṇānāṃ pradeśavṛttitvam āśrayāvyāpakatvaṃ vivakṣitam / na tu pradeśe 'vayave vṛttiḥ / niṣpradeśānāṃ tadabhāvaprasaṅgāt / eteṣāmevāśrayāvyāpitvam / eteṣāṃ pradeśavṛttitvameva /
analyzed: idānīm keṣām pradeśa vṛtti tvam āśraya vyāpi tvam ca iti āha saṃyoga vibhāga śabda ātma viśeṣa guṇānām pradeśa vṛtti tvam āśraya avyāpaka tvam vivakṣitam na tu pradeśe vayave vṛttiḥ niṣpradeśānām tad abhāva prasaṅgāt eteṣām eva āśraya avyāpi tvam eteṣām pradeśa vṛtti tvam eva
translated: Now, which ones have limited occurrence and which ones pervade their substratum? It is said: Conjunction, disjunction, sound, and the specific qualities of the self have limited occurrence. The non-pervasiveness of their substratum is intended, not occurrence in a part, because of the undesired consequence of their non-existence in what is partless. These same ones have non-pervasiveness of their substratum. These very ones have limited occurrence.

original: śeṣāṇāmāśrayavyāpitvam iti / uktebhyo 'nye śeṣāsteṣāmāśrayavyāpitvam / kathametat / āśrayopalambhe sati tajjighṛkṣāyāmavaśyaṃ grahaṇam / yathā paṭopalambhe rūpajighṛkṣāyāmavaśyaṃ tadgrahaṇamiti / yeṣāntvāśrayāvyāpitvaṃ na teṣāmāśrayopalambhe / satyāmapi jighṛkṣāyāmindriyārthasannikarṣe cāvaśyaṃ grahaṇamasti / yathā parvatasyāparabhāgavartināṃ saṃyogo nāvaśyaṃ tadupalambhe 'pyupalabhyata iti /
analyzed: śeṣāṇām āśraya vyāpi tvam iti uktebhyaḥ nye śeṣāḥ teṣām āśraya vyāpi tvam katham etat āśraya upalambhe sati tad jighṛkṣāyām avaśyam grahaṇam yathā paṭa upalambhe rūpa jighṛkṣāyām avaśyam tat grahaṇam iti yeṣām tu āśraya avyāpi tvam na teṣām āśraya upalambhe satyām api jighṛkṣāyām indriya artha sannikarṣe ca avaśyam grahaṇam asti yathā parvatasya apara bhāga vartinām saṃyogaḥ na avaśyam tad upalambhe pi upalabhyate iti
translated: The remaining ones pervade their substratum. Those other than the mentioned ones are the remaining ones. Their pervasiveness of the substratum is as follows. When the substratum is perceived, if there is a desire to grasp it, there is necessarily grasping, just as when a cloth is perceived, if there is a desire to grasp color, there is necessarily grasping of that. But for those that do not pervade the substratum, even when the substratum is perceived and there is a desire to grasp it, there is not necessarily grasping due to the contact of sense and object, just as conjunction with a part of a mountain in the rear is not necessarily perceived even when it is perceived.

original: apākajādisnehāntānāṃ yāvaddravyabhāvitvam iti / yāvaddravyaṃ bhavanti tacchīlāśceti yāvaddravyabhāvinasteṣāṃ bhāvo yāvaddravyabhāvitvam / āśraye satyavināśitvamiti yāvat /
analyzed: a pāka ja ādi sneha antānām yāvaddravyabhāvitvam iti yāvaddravyam bhavanti tad śīlāḥ ca iti yāvaddravyabhāvinaḥ teṣām bhāvaḥ yāvaddravyabhāvi tvam āśraye sati avināśi tvam iti yāvat
translated: The remaining ones end with oil that is not produced by cooking, etc. They exist as long as the substance exists. They have the nature of existing as long as the substance exists. They exist as long as the substratum exists, that is, as long as the substance exists.

original: śeṣāṇāmayāvaddravyabhāvitvam iti / uktebhyo 'nye śeṣāsteṣāṃ satyapyāśraye vināśa iti /🔽iti guṇasādharmyaprakaraṇam
analyzed: śeṣāṇām ayāvaddravyabhāvitvam iti uktebhyaḥ nye śeṣāḥ teṣām sati api āśraye vināśaḥ iti 🔽iti guṇa sādharmya prakaraṇam
translated: The remaining ones do not exist as long as the substance exists. Those other than the mentioned ones are the remaining ones. Even when the substratum exists, they are destroyed.

original: guṇavaidharmyaprakaraṇam
analyzed: guṇa vaidharmya prakaraṇam
translated: Chapter on the dissimilarity of qualities

original: rūpādīnāṃ sarvaguṇānāṃ pratyekamaparasāmānyasambandhād rūpādisaṃjñā bhavanti /PDhS
analyzed: rūpa ādīnām sarva guṇānām pratyekam apara sāmānya sambandhāt rūpa ādi saṃjñāḥ bhavanti
translated: The terms form etc. are used for all qualities such as form, because each is related to another general property.

original: athedānīṃ vaidharmyaṃ pratiniyatamāha rūpādīnāṃ sarvaguṇānāṃ pratyekamaparasāmānyasambandhād rūpādisaṃjñā bhavanti ityādi / rūpamādiryeṣāṃ te rūpādayasteṣām / na jñāyate kiyatāmataḥ sarvaguṇānāmiti / sarve ca te guṇāśceti sarvaguṇāste ca rūpādaya evābhipretā nānya iti / teṣām ekamekaṃ prati pratyekam / aparasāmānyasambandhāditi / guṇatvāpekṣayā aparasāmānyaṃ rūpatvādi / tatsambandhād rūpādisaṃjñā bhavanti / rūpatvasambandhād rūpamiti saṃjñā / rasatvasambandhācca rasa iti / evamanyeṣvapīti /
analyzed: atha idānīm vaidharmyam pratiniyatam āha rūpa ādīnām sarva guṇānām pratyekam apara sāmānya sambandhāt rūpa ādi saṃjñāḥ bhavanti ityādi rūpam ādiḥ yeṣām te rūpa ādayaḥ teṣām na jñāyate kiyatām atas sarva guṇānām iti sarve ca te guṇāḥ ca iti sarva guṇāḥ te ca rūpa ādayaḥ eva abhipretāḥ na anye iti teṣām ekam ekam prati pratyekam apara sāmānya sambandhāt iti guṇa tva apekṣayā apara sāmānyam rūpa tva ādi tad sambandhāt rūpa ādi sa
translated: Now he states the specific dissimilarity: The terms 'form' etc. are used for all qualities such as form, because each is related to another general property. Those for whom form is the beginning are the form etc. It is not known how many of all the qualities there are, therefore it is said all qualities. And all those are qualities, so those that are intended are only form etc., not others. Of those, each one is related to another general property. The other general property in relation to quality is form-ness etc. Because of that relation, the terms form etc. are used. Because of the relation to form-ness, the term form is used. And because of the relation to taste-ness, the term taste is used. The same applies to the others.

original: rūpavaidharmyam
analyzed: rūpa vaidharmyam
translated: The dissimilarity of form

original: tatra rūpaṃ cakṣurgrāhyam / pṛthivyudakajvalanavṛtti / dravyādyupalambhakam / nayanasahakāri / śuklādyanekaprakāram / salilādiparamāṇuṣu nityam / pārthivaparamāṇuṣvagnisaṃyogavirodhi / sarvakāryadravyeṣu kāraṇaguṇapūrvakam / āśrayavināśādeva vinaśyatīti /PDhS
analyzed: tatra rūpam cakṣuḥ grāhyam pṛthivī udaka jvalana vṛtti dravya ādi upalambhakam nayana sahakāri śukla ādi aneka prakāram salila ādi paramāṇuṣu nityam pārthiva paramāṇuṣu agni saṃyoga virodhi sarva kārya dravyeṣu kāraṇa guṇa pūrvakam āśraya vināśāt eva vinaśyati iti
translated: There, form is perceptible by the eye, existing in earth, water, and fire, the apprehender of substances etc., assisting the eye, of many kinds such as white etc., always in the atoms of water etc., opposed to the conjunction of fire in the atoms of earth, preceded by the qualities of the cause in all produced substances, it is destroyed only by the destruction of its substratum.

original: tatrādāvuddiṣṭatvād rūpasya sadbhāve pramāṇaṃ lakṣaṇam āśrayam arthakriyābhedaṃ nityatvam utpattivināśakāraṇañca darśayannāha rūpaṃ cakṣurgrāhyam ityādinā /
analyzed: tatra ādau uddiṣṭa tvāt rūpasya sadbhāve pramāṇam lakṣaṇam āśrayam artha kriyā bhedam nitya tvam utpatti vināśa kāraṇam ca darśayan āha rūpam cakṣuḥ grāhyam ityādinā
translated: There, since form was mentioned first, showing its existence, the means of valid knowledge, the definition, the substratum, the difference in function, permanence, and the causes of origination and destruction, he says form is perceptible by the eye and so on.

original: tatra rūpameva cakṣurgrāhyaṃ na rasādi / rūpaṃ cakṣuṣaiva gṛhyate 'nyendriyaparicchedyaṃ na bhavatītyavadhāraṇasya prakramāpekṣitayā na dravyādau cakṣurgrāhyatvapratiṣedhaḥ / tathā hi / dravyādeścakṣurgrāhyatvasiddhau anekadravyeṇa samavāyāt svagataviśeṣācca rūpaṃ pratyakṣam vai / sū / / / / etena rasādiṣu jñānaṃ vyākhyātam vai / sū / / ityatideśe cakṣurgrāhyatvāśaṅkāyāṃ tadvyavacchedārthamevāvadhāraṇaṃ na dravyādau tadvṛttitvapratiṣedhaparam / abhipretañca samudgīyamānāvadhāraṇaṃ śākyairiti vakṣyāmo laiṅgikajñāne /
analyzed: tatra rūpam eva cakṣuḥ grāhyam na rasa ādi rūpam cakṣuṣā eva gṛhyate nyendriya paricchedyam na bhavati iti avadhāraṇasya prakrama apekṣi tayā na dravya ādau cakṣuḥ grāhya tva pratiṣedhaḥ tathā hi dravya ādeḥ cakṣuḥ grāhya tva siddhau aneka dravyeṇa samavāyāt svagata viśeṣāt ca rūpam pratyakṣam vai sū etena rasa ādiṣu jñānam vyākhyātam vai sū iti atideśe cakṣuḥ grāhya tva āśaṅkāyām tad vyavaccheda artham eva avadhāraṇam na dravya ād
translated: There, form alone is perceptible by the eye, not taste etc. And form is perceived only by the eye, it is not to be determined by other sense organs. This restriction is expected in the context, not a prohibition of perceptibility by the eye in substance etc. For, thus: When the perceptibility by the eye of substance is established, form is perceived by the inherence in many substances and by its own particularities. By this, the knowledge of taste etc. is explained. In the extension, when there is a doubt of perceptibility by the eye, the restriction is only for the exclusion of that, not for the prohibition of its existence in substance etc. And we will say that the restriction being sung is intended by the Buddhists, in inferential knowledge.

original: sūtrārthastu / anekaṃ dravyaṃ janakamasyetītyanekadravyaṃ tena saha samavāyāt svagataviśeṣaniyatasadbhāve kvacid rūpopalabdhiryadabhāvāccānupalabdhiḥ sa eva sahakāriviśeṣo 'padiśyate / tasmācca rūpaṃ pratyakṣam / etacca rasanādipratyakṣe samānamiti /
analyzed: sūtra arthaḥ tu anekam dravyam janakam asya iti iti aneka dravyam tena saha samavāyāt svagata viśeṣa niyata sadbhāve kvacid rūpa upalabdhiḥ yad abhāvāt ca anupalabdhiḥ saḥ eva sahakāri viśeṣaḥ upadiśyate tasmāt ca rūpam pratyakṣam etat ca rasanā ādi pratyakṣe samānam iti
translated: The meaning of the sutra is this: That which has many substances as its producer is called aneka-dravya. Due to inherence with that, the existence of a particular quality is restricted in some cases, and there is perception of form. And due to the absence of that, there is non-perception. That very special cooperative cause is indicated. And from that, form is perceptible. And this is the same in the case of perception of taste etc.

original: pṛthivyudakajvalanavṛtti ityāśrayanirūpaṇam / pūrvapadāpekṣaṃ vā lakṣaṇamiti / tathā hi / cakṣurgrāhyatvaṃ dravyatvasyāpyastīti cakṣuṣaiva gṛhyata iti sāvadhāraṇaṃ viśeṣaṇam / tathāpi cakṣuṣaiva gṛhyate rūpatvasāmānyamiti pṛthivyudakajvalanavṛttipadam / pṛthivyādivṛttitvañcānyeṣāmapyastīti niyamagrahaṇam / ato rūpam / itarasmād bhidyate / niyamena pṛthivyudakajvalanavṛttitve sati cakṣuṣaiva gṛhyamāṇatvāt / yastu na bhidyate na cāsāvevam / yathā rasādiriti /
analyzed: pṛthivī udaka jvalana vṛtti iti āśraya nirūpaṇam pūrva pada apekṣam vā lakṣaṇam iti  / tathā hi cakṣuḥ grāhya tvam dravya tvasya api asti iti cakṣuṣā eva gṛhyate iti sāvadhāraṇam viśeṣaṇam tathā api cakṣuṣā eva gṛhyate rūpa tva sāmānyam iti pṛthivī udaka jvalana vṛtti padam pṛthivī ādi vṛtti tvañca anyeṣām api asti iti niyama grahaṇam atas rūpam itarasmāt bhidyate niyamena pṛthivī udaka jvalana vṛtti tve sati cakṣuṣā eva gṛhy
translated: The statement existing in earth, water, and fire describes the substratum. Or the definition is dependent on the preceding word. For example, the property of being perceptible by the eye belongs to substance also, so the qualification is apprehended only by the eye is specific. Still, the color-generality is apprehended only by the eye, so the word existing in earth, water, and fire is used. Since others also have existence in earth etc., the restriction is stated. Therefore, color is distinguished from the other, because it is apprehended only by the eye, while existing invariably in earth, water, and fire. But that which is not distinguished is not so, like taste etc.

original: dravyādyupalambhakam ityarthakriyākathanam / dravyādīnupalambhayatīti dravyādyupalambhakam / dravyopalabdheḥ kāraṇamiti / tathā mahattvādanekadravyavattvād rūpaviśeṣācca dravyaṃ pratyakṣam vai / sū / / / tatsamavāyācca guṇādayo 'pi pratyakṣāḥ vai / sū / / ityupalabdhau rūpaviśeṣasya kāraṇatvamuktam / pūrvapadāpekṣametallakṣaṇamabhyūhyam /
analyzed: dravya ādi upalambhakam iti artha kriyā kathanam dravya ādīn upalambhayati iti dravya ādi upalambhakam dravya upalabdheḥ kāraṇam iti tathā mahat tvāt aneka dravyavat tvāt rūpa viśeṣāt ca dravyam pratyakṣam vai sū tad samavāyāt ca guṇa ādayaḥ pi pratyakṣāḥ vai sū iti upalabdhau rūpa viśeṣasya kāraṇa tvam uktam pūrva pada apekṣam etat lakṣaṇam abhyūhyam
translated: The meaning of that which apprehends substance etc. is the statement of the function. It apprehends substance etc., so it is that which apprehends substance etc. It is the cause of the apprehension of substance etc. Similarly, it is said in the apprehension that substance is perceptible because of its largeness, because it is composed of many substances, and because of the particular form. And because of the inherence of that, qualities etc. are also perceptible. Thus, the particular form is said to be the cause in the apprehension. This definition should be inferred in dependence on the preceding word.

original: nayanasahakārī iti svagatarūpotkarṣād bāhyarūpaprakāśakamityupadarśayati / na ca pūrveṇāviśeṣaḥ / karaṇasthasya rūpotkarṣasyābhidhānāt / prāktanena tu karmagatasyeti /
analyzed: nayana sahakārī iti svagata rūpa utkarṣāt bāhya rūpa prakāśakam iti upadarśayati na ca pūrveṇa aviśeṣaḥ karaṇa sthasya rūpa utkarṣasya abhidhānāt prāktanena tu karma gatasya iti
translated: The eye is a contributory cause - it shows that it illuminates external form because of the excellence of its own form. And it is not the same as the previous one, because the excellence of form located in the instrument is mentioned. But the previous one is of that located in the object.

original: śuklādyanekaprakāram iti bhedanirūpaṇam / tadapyasādhāraṇameva / salilādiparamāṇuṣu nityam / vināśakāraṇābhāvāt / pārthivaparamāṇuṣvagnisaṃyogavirodhi iti / agnisaṃyogena virodho vināśo 'syeti / na cānutpattimato vināśaḥ sambhavatītyanyasyotpattivināśakāraṇasyābhāvād agnisaṃyogādevotpadyate / sarvakāryeṣu kāraṇaguṇapūrvaprakrameṇotpattirāśrayavināśādeva vināśa iti vakṣyāmaḥ pākajarūpaparīkṣāyām /
analyzed: śukla ādi aneka prakāram iti bheda nirūpaṇam tat api asādhāraṇam eva salila ādi paramāṇuṣu nityam vināśa kāraṇa abhāvāt pārthiva paramāṇuṣu agni saṃyoga virodhi iti agni saṃyogena virodhaḥ sya iti na ca anutpattimataḥ vināśaḥ sambhavati iti anyasya utpatti vināśa kāraṇasya abhāvāt agni saṃyogāt eva utpadyate sarva kāryeṣu kāraṇa guṇa pūrva prakrameṇa utpattiḥ āśraya vināśāt eva vināśaḥ iti vakṣyāmaḥ pāka ja rūpa parīkṣāyām
translated: The determination of the difference is that it is of many kinds, such as white and so on. That too is only uncommon. In the atoms of water and so on, it is eternal, because there is no cause for destruction. In the atoms of earth, it is opposed to the conjunction with fire. The destruction of this is opposed by the conjunction with fire. And destruction is not possible for what has not arisen. Because there is no other cause for origination and destruction, it arises only from the conjunction with fire. We will say in the examination of the color produced by cooking that the origination of all effects is in the order of the qualities of the cause, and the destruction is only from the destruction of the substratum.

original: rasavaidharmyam
analyzed: rasa vaidharmyam
translated: The dissimilarity of taste

original: raso rasanagrāhyaḥ / pṛthivyudakavṛttiḥ / jīvanapuṣṭibalārogyanimittam / II / rasanasahakārī / madhurāmlalavaṇatiktakaṭukaṣāyabhedabhinnaḥ / asyāpi nityānityatvaniṣpattayaḥ pūrvavat /PDhS
analyzed: rasaḥ rasana grāhyaḥ pṛthivī udaka vṛttiḥ jīvana puṣṭi bala ārogya nimittam   rasana sahakārī madhura amla lavaṇa tikta kaṭu kaṣāya bheda bhinnaḥ asya api nitya anitya tva niṣpattayaḥ pūrvavat
translated: Taste is to be grasped by the tongue. It exists in earth and water. It is the cause of life, nourishment, strength, and health. It is a co-operator with the tongue. It is divided into sweet, sour, salty, bitter, pungent, and astringent. The eternality and non-eternality of this are as before.

original: raso rasanagrāhyaḥ iti sadbhāve pramāṇam / pṛthivyudakavṛttiḥ ityāśrayanirūpaṇam / pūrvapadāpekṣaṃ vā lakṣaṇamiti / tathā hi / pṛthivyudakavṛttitvamanyeṣāmapyastīti rasanagrāhyapadam / rasanagrāhyañca rasatvādisāmānyaṃ bhaviṣyatīti pṛthivyudakavṛttipadam / ato rasaḥ / itarasmād bhidyate / pṛthivyudakavṛttitve sati rasanagrāhyatvāt / yastvitarasmādarasāderna bhidyate na cāsāvevam / yathā gandhādiriti /
analyzed: rasaḥ rasana grāhyaḥ iti sadbhāve pramāṇam pṛthivī udaka vṛttiḥ iti āśraya nirūpaṇam pūrva pada apekṣam vā lakṣaṇam iti  tathā hi pṛthivī udaka vṛtti tvam anyeṣām api asti iti rasana grāhya padam rasana grāhyam ca rasa tva ādi sāmānyam bhaviṣyati iti pṛthivī udaka vṛtti padam atas rasaḥ itarasmāt bhidyate pṛthivī udaka vṛtti tve sati rasana grāhya tvāt yaḥ tu itarasmāt arasa ādeḥ na bhidyate na ca asau evam yathā gandha ādiḥ iti
translated: Taste is to be grasped by the tongue - this is the proof of its existence. It occurs in earth and water - this defines its substratum. Or the definition is based on the first part of the compound. Thus, others also have occurrence in earth and water, so the phrase 'to be grasped by the tongue' is used. And the universal 'taste' etc. will be grasped by the tongue, so the phrase 'occurring in earth and water' is used. Therefore, taste is distinguished from other things, because it is to be grasped by the tongue, while occurring in earth and water. But that which is not distinguished from other things like odor etc. is not so, like odor etc.

original: jīvanapuṣṭibalārogyanimittam ityarthakriyānirūpaṇam / jīvanantu upabhogadāyakakarmasacivasyātmanaḥ svaśarīrāvaruddhena manasā saṃyogaḥ / tasya tu nimittam śarīrāpyāyananimittatvāt / puṣṭiravayavopacayaḥ / sā ca viśiṣṭarasopayogād bhavatīti / tathā hi / rasopayogādāntareṇa tejasā pūrvadravyanivṛttau svatantreṣu paramāṇuṣu śyāmādinivṛttidvāreṇotpannapākajairdvyaṇukādiprakrameṇa śarīrārambhaḥ pratikṣaṇamāhāropayoge sati draṣṭavyaḥ / na cārabhyārambhakavādaḥ sambhavatītyuktaṃ pṛthivyadhikāre / balamutsāhastasya prāṇasaṃvardhanadvāreṇa nimittam / ārogyaṃ rogābhāvastasyāpi nimittaṃ viśiṣṭarasopayoge sati tacchravaṇāt /
analyzed: jīvana puṣṭi bala ārogya nimittam iti arthakriyā nirūpaṇam jīvanam tu upabhoga dāyaka karma sacivasya ātmanaḥ sva śarīra avaruddhena manasā saṃyogaḥ tasya tu nimittam śarīra āpyāyana nimitta tvāt puṣṭiḥ avayava upacayaḥ sā ca viśiṣṭa rasa upayogāt bhavati iti tathā hi rasa upayogāt āntareṇa tejasā pūrva dravya nivṛttau svatantreṣu paramāṇuṣu śyāma ādi nivṛtti dvāreṇa utpanna pāka jaiḥ dvyaṇuka ādi prakrameṇa śarīra ārambhaḥ prat
translated: The statement of the function is for the sake of life, nourishment, strength, and health. Life is the conjunction of the soul, which is the helper of the action that gives enjoyment, with the mind confined to its own body. But its cause is because it is the cause of nourishing the body. Nourishment is the increase of the parts, and that occurs from the use of special juices. For example, from the use of juice, by the fire inside, after the cessation of the previous substance, in the independent atoms, the production of the cooked product by the cessation of blackness etc., the beginning of the body by the process of the dyad etc. should be seen at every moment with the use of food. And the doctrine of beginningless beginning is not possible, as stated in the section on earth. Strength is enthusiasm, its cause is by the increase of life. Health is the absence of disease, its cause also is from the use of special juices, as that is heard.

original: rasanasahakārī iti / svagatarasotkarṣād bāhyarasasyābhivyañjaka ityuktaṃ pūrvam /
analyzed: rasana sahakārī iti svagata rasa utkarṣāt bāhya rasasya abhivyañjakaḥ iti uktam pūrvam
translated: The sense of taste is the cooperating factor. It was said earlier that it manifests external taste due to the excellence of its own taste.

original: madhurāmlalavaṇatiktakaṭukaṣāyabhedabhinnaḥ iti vibhāgaḥ / so 'pyasādhāraṇatvāllakṣaṇam / asyāpi nityānityatvaniṣpattayaḥ pūrvavaditi / salilaparamāṇuṣu nityaṃ pārthiveṣvagnisaṃyogādutpadyate vinaśyati ca / kāryeṣu kāraṇaguṇapūrvaḥ / ādhāravināśādeva vinaśyatītyatideśārthaḥ /
analyzed: madhura amla lavaṇa tikta kaṭu kaṣāya bheda bhinnaḥ iti vibhāgaḥ saḥ u pi asādhāraṇa tvāt lakṣaṇam asya api nitya anitya tva niṣpattayaḥ pūrvavat iti salila paramāṇuṣu nityam pārthiveṣu agni saṃyogāt utpadyate vinaśyati ca kāryeṣu kāraṇa guṇa pūrvaḥ ādhāra vināśāt eva vinaśyati iti atideśa arthaḥ
translated: It is divided into sweet, sour, salty, bitter, pungent, and astringent. That division is also a characteristic due to its uniqueness. Its eternality and non-eternality are established as before. In the atoms of water it is eternal, in those of earth it arises and perishes due to contact with fire. In effects it precedes the qualities of the cause. It perishes only due to the destruction of the substratum. This is the purpose of the extension.

original: gandhavaidharmyam
translated: The dissimilarity of smell

original: gandho ghrāṇagrāhyaḥ / pṛthivīvṛttiḥ / ghrāṇasahakārī / surabhirasurabhiśca / asyāpyutpattyādayaḥ pūrvavat /PDhS
analyzed: gandhaḥ ghrāṇa grāhyaḥ pṛthivī vṛttiḥ ghrāṇa sahakārī surabhiḥ asurabhiḥ ca asya api utpatti ādayaḥ pūrvavat
translated: Smell is to be grasped by the nose, it inheres in earth, it is the cooperating factor of the nose, it is fragrant and non-fragrant. Its origination, etc. are also as before.

original: gandho ghrāṇagrāhyaḥ iti sadbhāve pramāṇam / pṛthivīvṛttiḥ ityāII /śrayanirūpaṇam / pūrvapadāpekṣaṃ vā lakṣaṇam / tathā hi ghrāṇagrāhyatvaṃ gandhatvāderapyastīti pṛthivīvṛttiriti viśeṣaṇam / pṛthivīvṛttitvamanyasyāpyastīti ghrāṇagrāhyapadam / ghrāṇagrāhyatve sati pṛthivīvṛttitvaṃ lakṣaṇamiti /
analyzed: gandhaḥ ghrāṇa grāhyaḥ iti sadbhāve pramāṇam pṛthivī vṛttiḥ pūrva pada apekṣam vā lakṣaṇam tathā hi ghrāṇa grāhya tvam gandha tva ādeḥ api asti iti pṛthivī vṛttiḥ iti viśeṣaṇam pṛthivī vṛtti tvam anyasya api asti iti ghrāṇa grāhya padam ghrāṇa grāhya tve sati pṛthivī vṛtti tvam lakṣaṇam iti
translated: The proof of the existence of smell is that it is perceptible by the nose. Existing in earth is the definition. Or the definition depends on the preceding word. Thus, since perceptibility by the nose also exists for odoriferousness, the qualification existing in earth is specified. Since existing in earth also exists for something else, the word perceptible by the nose is used. The definition is: that which is perceptible by the nose and exists in earth.

original: ghrāṇasahakārī iti svagatagandhotkarṣād bāhyagandhaprakāśakamityarthakriyānirūpaṇam / punarapi surabhirasurabhiśca iti vibhāgaḥ /
analyzed: ghrāṇa sahakārī iti svagata gandha utkarṣāt bāhya gandha prakāśakam iti arthakriyā nirūpaṇam punar api surabhiḥ asurabhiḥ ca iti vibhāgaḥ
translated: Cooperating with the nose means that it reveals external odors due to the excellence of its own odor. This is the description of its function. Again, there is a division into fragrant and non-fragrant.

original: asyāpyutpattyādayaḥ pūrvavat iti / paramāṇuṣvagnisaṃyogādutpadyate vinaśyati ca / kārye tu kāraṇaguṇapūrvakaḥ / ādhāravināśādeva vinaśyatītyatideśārthaḥ /
analyzed: asya api utpatti ādayaḥ pūrvavat iti paramāṇuṣu agni saṃyogāt utpadyate vinaśyati ca kārye tu kāraṇa guṇa pūrvakaḥ ādhāra vināśāt eva vinaśyati iti atideśa arthaḥ
translated: The origination, etc. of this are also as before. It originates and is destroyed by contact with fire in atoms. But in products, it is preceded by the quality of the cause. It is destroyed only by the destruction of the substratum. This is the purpose of the extension.

original: sparśavaidharmyam
analyzed: sparśa vaidharmyam
translated: The dissimilarity of touch

original: sparśastvagindriyagrāhyaḥ / pṛthivyudakajvalanapavanavṛttiḥ / tvaksahakārī / rūpānuvidhāyī / śītoṣṇānuṣṇāśītabhedāt trividhaḥ / asyāpi nityānityatvaniṣpattayaḥ pūrvavat /PDhS
analyzed: sparśaḥ tvac indriya grāhyaḥ pṛthivī udaka jvalana pavana vṛttiḥ tvac sahakārī rūpa anuvidhāyī śīta uṣṇa anuṣṇa aśīta bhedāt trividhaḥ asya api nitya anitya tva niṣpattayaḥ pūrvavat
translated: Touch is to be grasped by the skin sense faculty. It has the mode of earth, water, fire, and air. It is a co-operator with the skin. It conforms to form. It is of three kinds due to the distinction of cold, hot, and neither-cold-nor-hot. The eternality and non-eternality of this are as before.

original: sparśastvagindriyagrāhyaḥ iti pratyakṣaparicchedyatvaṃ darśayati / pṛthivyudakajvalanapavanavṛttiḥ ityāśrayanirūpaṇañca caturṇāṃ sparśavattvamityanena na punaruktam / tatra dravyadharmasyābhidhānāt / iha tu sparśadharmasyeti / pūrvapadāpekṣaṃ vā lakṣaṇam / tathā ca pṛthivyādivṛttitvamanyeṣāmapyastīti tvagindriyagrāhyapadam / tadgrāhyañca sparśatvādisāmānyamiti pṛthivyādivṛttipadam /
analyzed: sparśaḥ tvac indriya grāhyaḥ iti pratyakṣa paricchedya tvam darśayati pṛthivī udaka jvalana pavana vṛttiḥ iti āśraya nirūpaṇam ca caturṇām sparśavat tvam iti anena na punar uktam tatra dravya dharmasya abhidhānāt iha tu sparśa dharmasya iti pūrva pada apekṣam vā lakṣaṇam tathā ca pṛthivī ādi vṛtti tvam anyeṣām api asti iti tvac indriya grāhya padam tad grāhyam ca sparśa tva ādi sāmānyam iti pṛthivī ādi vṛtti padam
translated: It shows that touch is to be directly perceived by the skin sense faculty. The determination of its substratum as having the mode of earth, water, fire, and air is not redundant with the statement that the four have the quality of touch, because there the quality of a substance is mentioned, while here the quality of touch is mentioned. Or the definition depends on the first word. And in that case, others also have the quality of having the mode of earth, etc., so the word to be grasped by the skin sense faculty is used. And what is grasped by that is the universal of touch, etc., so the word having the mode of earth, etc., is used.

original: yadi saṃkhyādīnāmapi tvagindriyagrāhyatve sati pṛthivyādivṛttitvaṃ sambhāvyeta / avadhāraṇaṃ kāryam / ataḥ sparśaḥ / itarasmād bhidyate / tvagindriyagrāhyatve sati niyamena pṛthivyādicaturdravyavṛttitvāt / yastvitarasmād na bhidyate na cāsāvevam / yathā rūpādiriti /
analyzed: yadi saṃkhyā ādīnām api tvak indriya grāhya tve sati pṛthivī ādi vṛtti tvam sambhāvyeta avadhāraṇam kāryam atas sparśaḥ itarasmāt bhidyate tvak indriya grāhya tve sati niyamena pṛthivī ādi catur dravya vṛtti tvāt yaḥ tu itarasmāt na bhidyate na ca asau evam yathā rūpa ādiḥ iti
translated: If number etc. were also perceptible by the skin and were found to exist in earth etc., then the restriction would have to be made. Therefore, touch is different from the other, because it is invariably found to exist in the four substances like earth, while being perceptible by the skin. That which is not different from the other and is not so, like color etc.

original: tvaksahakārī iti / svagatasparśotkarṣāt tvagindriyaṃ bāhyasparśaprakāśakamityarthakriyānirūpaṇam /
analyzed: tvac sahakārī iti svagata sparśa utkarṣāt tvac indriyam bāhya sparśa prakāśakam iti arthakriyā nirūpaṇam
translated: The meaning of the action is that the skin sense organ illuminates external touch due to the excellence of its own inherent touch, in association with the skin.

original: atha tvagindriyaṃ sparśasya prakāśakam / kasmāt / saṃyuktasamavāyāt / tvagindriyeṇa saṃyuktaṃ dravyaṃ tatsamavāyāt sparśo gṛhyata iti / nanvevaṃ saṃyuktasamavāyasyāviśeṣād rūpādiprakāśakamapi syād viśeṣo vā vācyaḥ / tanna / sparśotkarṣavad rūpādyutkarṣasyābhāvāt / tathā hi / rūpādiṣu madhye sparśasyaivoII /palambhānyathānupapattyā jñāyate niyāmakaṃ kāraṇam / niyamahetuṃ vinā niyatasya kāryasyānupapatteḥ / tatra sparśotkarṣo niyāmakaḥ sparśatvaṃ vā viṣayagatam / na caitad rūpādiṣu sambhavatīti sparśatvasya tatrāsambhavāt / rūpādyutkarṣasyāpi tvagindriyeṇa kāryābhāvenaivābhāvaprasiddheḥ / tathā ca sūtrakāreṇāpyuktam rūpādiṣu spārśanaṃ jñānamiti kasmānna bhavatīti tadabhāvāt vai / sū / / sparśatvasāmānyasyābhāvāt / yatraiva sparśatvasāmānyaṃ tatraiva spārśanaṃ jñānamiti / vyatireko labhyata eva / sparśatvābhāvastu tvaggrāhyatvābhāvasya jñāpako na kāraka iti / na ca viśiṣṭasannikarṣavyatirekeṇānyā yogyatā sambhāvyate / anvayavyatirekābhyāṃ tasyaiva vyāpāropalabdherityalam /
analyzed: atha tvac indriyam sparśasya prakāśakam kasmāt saṃyukta samavāyāt tvac indriyeṇa saṃyuktam dravyam tad samavāyāt sparśaḥ gṛhyate iti nanu evam saṃyukta samavāyasya aviśeṣāt rūpa ādi prakāśakam api syāt viśeṣaḥ vā vācyaḥ tat na sparśa utkarṣa vat rūpa ādi utkarṣasya abhāvāt tathā hi rūpa ādiṣu madhye jñāyate niyāmakam kāraṇam niyama hetum vinā niyatasya kāryasya anupapatteḥ tatra sparśa utkarṣaḥ niyāmakaḥ sparśa tvam vā viṣaya gatam
translated: Now, if the skin sense is the illuminator of touch, why is it so? Because of the conjunction and inherence. The substance that is conjoined with the skin sense is grasped by inherence in it. But in that case, since there is no difference in the conjunction and inherence, it would also be the illuminator of color etc., or a distinction should be stated. That is not so. Because there is no excellence of color etc. like the excellence of touch. For thus, it is known by the impossibility of the perception of touch among color etc. that there is a limiting cause. Because a limited effect is not possible without a limiting cause. There, the excellence of touch is the limiting cause, or the quality of touch belonging to the object. And this is not possible in color etc. Thus, because of the impossibility of the quality of touch there, and because of the non-existence of the excellence of color etc. being established by the mere absence of effect in the skin sense, and thus the author of the aphorisms has also said, How is the knowledge of touch in color etc.? Because of the absence of that. Touch

original: rūpānuvidhāyī iti sāhacaryaṃ darśayati / rūpamanuvidadhāti tacchīlaśceti tadanuvidhāyī / yatra rūpaṃ tatrāvaśyaṃ sparśa iti / evaṃ rasagandhānuvidhāyitvamapīti / śītoṣṇānuṣṇāśītabhedāt trividhaḥ iti vibhāgakathanam / asyāpi nityānityatvaniṣpattayaḥ pūrvavat iti / salilādiparamāṇuṣu nityaḥ pārthiveṣvagnisaṃyogavirodhī / kāryeṣu kāraṇaguṇapūrvakastadvināśād vinaśyatītyatideśārthaḥ /
analyzed: rūpa anuvidhāyī iti sāhacaryam darśayati rūpam anuvidadhāti tad śīlaḥ ca iti tad anuvidhāyī yatra rūpam tatra avaśyam sparśaḥ iti evam rasa gandha anuvidhāyi tvam api iti śīta uṣṇa anuṣṇa aśīta bhedāt trividhaḥ iti vibhāga kathanam asya api nitya anitya tva niṣpattayaḥ pūrvavat iti salila ādi paramāṇuṣu nityaḥ pārthiveṣu agni saṃyoga virodhī kāryeṣu kāraṇa guṇa pūrvakaḥ tad vināśāt vinaśyati iti atideśa arthaḥ
translated: It shows concomitance by saying following form. One who has that habit follows form, so it follows form. Where there is form, there is necessarily touch. Similarly, it follows taste and smell. It is threefold due to the distinction of cold, hot, and neither-hot-nor-cold. This is the explanation of the division. Its eternality and non-eternality are accomplished as before. It is eternal in the atoms of water, etc., and in those of earth it opposes the conjunction of fire. In effects, it is preceded by the qualities of the cause, and it is destroyed by the destruction of that. This is the meaning of the extension.

original: rūpādīnāṃ pākajotpattiprakāraḥ
analyzed: rūpa ādīnām pāka ja utpatti prakāraḥ
translated: The mode of origination of cooked products from form, etc.

analyzed: pārthiva paramāṇu rūpa ādīnām pāka ja utpatti vidhānam
translated: The method of origination of cooked products from the form, etc. of earth atoms.

original: athedānīṃ pārthivaparamāṇurūpādīnām iti parīkṣāśeṣanivartanāprakaraṇam / tathā hi rūpādīnāṃ pūrvamuddeśalakṣaṇābhidhāne 'pi sparśo / na parīkṣitaḥ / pratijñātañca tadataḥ parīkṣārthamidamārabhyate / pṛthivyā ime pārthivāḥ /
analyzed: atha idānīm pārthiva paramāṇu rūpa ādīnām iti parīkṣā śeṣa nivartanā prakaraṇam tathā hi rūpa ādīnām pūrvam uddeśa lakṣaṇa abhidhāne sparśaḥ na parīkṣitaḥ pratijñātam ca tat atas parīkṣā artham idam ārabhyate pṛthivyāḥ ime pārthivāḥ
translated: Now begins the section on the conclusion of the examination of form, etc. of earth atoms. Thus, although form, etc. were previously defined and described in the enumeration, touch was not examined. And that was promised. Therefore, this is begun for the sake of examination. These are the earthly ones of earth.

original: nanu cātra bhedānupapatteḥ kathaṃ ṣaṣṭhī / taddhitapratyayaśceti / tayorbhede satyupalambhāt / na / kāryarūpāyāḥ pṛthivyā vivakṣitatvāt / tajjanakāśca paramāṇavastato bhinnā eveti pārthivā ityucyante / jātirvā pṛthivīśabdena vivakṣitā / tasyā ime tatsambandhinaḥ pārthivāḥ / te ca te paramāṇavaśca teṣāṃ rūpādaya iti / ādipadena rasagandhasparśā eva gṛhyante / na saṃkhyādayaḥ / tatparīkṣāśeṣaparatvenaiva sambandhāt /
analyzed: nanu ca atra bheda anupapatteḥ katham ṣaṣṭhī taddhita pratyayaḥ ca iti tayoḥ bhede sati upalambhāt na kārya rūpāyāḥ pṛthivyāḥ vivakṣita tvāt tad janakāḥ ca paramāṇavaḥ tatas bhinnāḥ eva iti pārthivāḥ iti ucyante jātiḥ vā pṛthivī śabdena vivakṣitā tasyāḥ ime tad sambandhinaḥ pārthivāḥ te ca te paramāṇavaḥ ca teṣām rūpa ādayaḥ iti ādi padena rasa gandha sparśāḥ eva gṛhyante na saṃkhyā ādayaḥ tad parīkṣā śeṣa paratv
translated: But how can the genitive ending be used here, since the difference is not established? And how can the suffix be used? Because they are perceived when there is a difference. Because they are related only to the remainder of the examination of that.

original: atasteṣāṃ pākajotpattividhānam prakāra iti / atha pākājjātāḥ pākajā ityutpattyarthasya janinā pratipāditatvād vyarthamutpattigrahaṇam / na / uttarapadena sambandhāt / tathā hi / pākajānāmutpattireva vidhīyate 'neneti vidhānaṃ pramāṇamupeyam / pūrvaguṇavilakṣaṇānāṃ rūpādīnāmutpattiḥ kārye saiva pramāṇamiti vakṣyāmaḥ /
analyzed: atas teṣām pāka ja utpatti vidhānam prakāraḥ iti atha pākāt jātāḥ pāka jāḥ iti utpatti arthasya janinā pratipādita tvāt vyartham utpatti grahaṇam na uttara padena sambandhāt tathā hi pāka jānām utpattiḥ eva vidhīyate nena iti vidhānam pramāṇam upeyam pūrva guṇa vilakṣaṇānām rūpa ādīnām utpattiḥ kārye sā eva pramāṇam iti vakṣyāmaḥ
translated: Therefore, the injunction of the origination of the products from cooking is the method. Now, if the products of cooking are called products of cooking because the meaning of origination is conveyed by the suffix jani, then the mention of origination is useless. No, because of the connection with the latter part. Thus, it is accepted that the origination of the products of cooking is enjoined by this, so the injunction is the means of knowledge. We will say that the origination of form etc., which are different from the previous qualities, is the effect, and that is the means of knowledge.

original: yadvā pacyate 'neneti pākastejodravyam / pacyata iti vā pākaḥ pārthivaparamāṇavaśceti pākau tābhyāṃ jātaḥ pākajaḥ / pārthivaparamāṇvagnisaṃyogastasmādutpattiḥ pārthivaparamāṇurūpādīnāṃ śyāmādivināśaścetyuttaravākyasāmarthyāt /

translated: Or, cooking is the fire substance, as it is cooked by this. Or, cooking is the earth atoms, so what is produced from those two is a product of cooking. The conjunction of earth atoms and fire is the origination of the form etc. of earth atoms and the destruction of the dark etc., by the power of the subsequent sentence.

original: anye tu śyāmādivināśo 'dhyāhāreṇa labhyata iti manyamānāḥ pacyate 'neneti pāko 'gnisaṃyogaḥ / tasmājjātaḥ pākajaḥ / śyāmādivināśaḥ / tata eva pākādutpattirviśiṣṭarūpādīnāmiti kaṣṭavyākhyānaṃ kurvate / taccāsat / adhyāhārāderdūṣaṇasyāparihārāt /
analyzed: anye tu śyāma ādi vināśaḥ dhyāhāreṇa labhyate iti manyamānāḥ pacyate nena iti pākaḥ gni saṃyogaḥ tasmāt jātaḥ pāka jaḥ śyāma ādi vināśaḥ tatas eva pākāt utpattiḥ viśiṣṭa rūpa ādīnām iti kaṣṭa vyākhyānam kurvate tat ca asat adhyāhāra ādeḥ dūṣaṇasya aparihārāt

original: na cābhivyaktinivṛttyarthamutpattigrahaṇamiti vācyam / paramatasyāprasiddhatvāt /

original: tatra prathamaṃ kāryadravyavināśaprakāraḥ
analyzed: tatra prathamam kārya dravya vināśa prakāraḥ

original: atha kena prakāreṇa pākajā jāyanta ityupadarśayati ghaṭāderāmadravyasya ityādinā / ghaṭāderityādipadena śarīrāderapyavarodhaḥ / tatra hi pākajotpattiparijñānāt tadāsaktinivṛttau viraktasya śreyaḥ sampadyata iti / āmadravyasyeti pakvavyavacchedārtham /
