original: tūlapiṇḍaśca tūlapiṇḍaśca tūlapiṇḍau / tayorvartamānaḥ saṃyogaḥ pracayaḥ / kiṃviśiṣṭaḥ / piṇḍārambhakapraśithilasaṃyogāpekṣa iti / piṇḍārambhakāśca II / praśithilasaṃyogāśca tānapekṣata iti tadapekṣaḥ / itaretarapiṇḍāvayavasaṃyogāpekṣaśceti / vā samuccaye / na tū vikalpe / apekṣākāraṇatvenābhyupagatayorubhayorapyatra sadbhāvāt / itarasya piṇḍasyetarapiṇḍāvayavaiḥ saṃyogastathā itarasyetarāvayavairiti / itaretarapiṇḍayorvā ye 'vayavāsteṣāṃ saṃyogāstānapekṣata iti tadapekṣaḥ / sa ca dvābhyāṃ tūlakābhyāmārabdhe 'pi tūlake mahattvamārabhata iti / tritūlakādāvapyetat samānam / pratyāsattistu mahatī dvitūlakaparimāṇe dvitūlake vartate / dvitūlake tu tūlapiṇḍayoḥ saṃyogo 'pi / tatraiva bahutvamahattvayoḥ sadbhāve 'pi kāraṇatvapratiṣedha ityāha na bahutvamahattvāni dvitūlakādau mahattvamārabhante / kutaḥ / samānasaṃkhyāpalaparimāṇairārabdhe 'tiśayadarśanāt /
analyzed: tūla piṇḍaḥ ca tūla piṇḍaḥ ca tūla piṇḍau tayoḥ vartamānaḥ saṃyogaḥ pracayaḥ kiṃviśiṣṭaḥ piṇḍa ārambhaka praśithila saṃyoga apekṣaḥ iti piṇḍa ārambhakāḥ ca praśithila saṃyogāḥ ca tān apekṣate iti tad apekṣaḥ itaretara piṇḍa avayava saṃyoga apekṣaḥ ca iti vā samuccaye na vikalpe apekṣā kāraṇa tvena abhyupagatayoḥ ubhayoḥ api atra sadbhāvāt itarasya piṇḍasya itara piṇḍa avayavaiḥ saṃyogaḥ tathā itara
translated: And a tuft of cotton is a tuft of cotton. The present conjunction of those two is aggregation. What is it distinguished by? It depends on the loose conjunctions that produce the tuft. And those that produce the tuft are also loose conjunctions. It depends on those. And it depends on the conjunctions of the parts of the other tuft. Or is in the sense of including, not in the sense of option, because both are accepted as causal factors here. The conjunction of the other tuft with the parts of the other tuft is like that. Or the conjunctions of the parts of the two tufts that depend on each other are that. And that produces largeness even in a tuft produced by two tufts. This is the same even in a tuft of three tufts. But the proximity is great in the magnitude of two tufts. But in two tufts, there is also the conjunction of the two tufts. There itself, largeness is due to plurality.

original: tathā hi / tribhistūlapiṇḍaiḥ pañcapalaiḥ praśithilāvayavasaṃyogairārabdhamekam / anyacca tadviparītaiḥ / tatra yat praśithilāvayavasaṃyogairārabdhaṃ tatra parimāṇātiśayo dṛṣṭa iti pracayasyaiva kāraṇatvam / na saṃkhyāpalaparimāṇānām / tatkāraṇatve cobhayatrāviśeṣaḥ syāt /
analyzed: tathā hi tribhiḥ tūla piṇḍaiḥ pañca palaiḥ praśithila avayava saṃyogaiḥ ārabdham ekam anyat ca tad viparītaiḥ tatra yat praśithila avayava saṃyogaiḥ ārabdham tatra parimāṇa atiśayaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ iti pracayasya eva kāraṇa tvam na saṃkhyā pala parimāṇānām tad kāraṇa tve ca ubhayatra aviśeṣaḥ syāt
translated: For example, one is composed of three cotton balls, each weighing five palas, with their component parts loosely connected, while another is composed of the same, but with the component parts tightly connected. In the former, where the component parts are loosely connected, an excess of magnitude is observed. Therefore, only compactness is the cause, not number, palas, or magnitude. And if those were the causes, there would be no difference in both cases.

original: atha palasya sarvatra parimāṇākāraṇatvāt prasaktyabhāve na yuktaḥ pratiṣedhaḥ / tathā hi / pāṣāṇādau palātiśayasadbhāve 'pi parimāṇasyātiśayābhāvaḥ / tulapiṇḍādau ca tadabhāve 'pi atiśayopalabdherna palasya gurutvaviśeṣatvāt kāraṇatvam / kimarthastatra pratiṣedhaḥ / vyāmohapratiṣedhārthaḥ / tathā ca pare vyāmohād yadyevaṃvidhasyāpi palasya kāraṇatvaṃ pratipadyeraṃstadapi nāsti / samānapalairārabdhe 'tiśayādarśanāt /
analyzed: atha palasya sarvatra parimāṇa akāraṇa tvāt prasakti abhāve na yuktaḥ pratiṣedhaḥ tathā hi pāṣāṇa ādau pala atiśaya sadbhāve pi parimāṇasya atiśaya abhāvaḥ tula piṇḍa ādau ca tad abhāve pi atiśaya upalabdheḥ na palasya guru tva viśeṣa tvāt kāraṇa tvam kimarthaḥ tatra pratiṣedhaḥ vyāmoha pratiṣedha arthaḥ tathā ca pare vyāmohāt yadi evaṃvidhasya api palasya kāraṇa tvam pratipadyeran tat api nā asti samāna palaiḥ ārabdhe tiśaya adarśan
translated: If it is argued that since palas are the cause of magnitude everywhere, the negation is not appropriate in the absence of possibility, it is said: for example, even when there is an excess of palas in stone, there is no excess of magnitude. And in cotton balls, etc., even when that is absent, magnitude is observed. Therefore, palas are not the cause because of their special weight. What is the purpose of the negation there? It is for the purpose of negating delusion. And if others were to conclude that even such a pala is the cause due to delusion, that is also not so, because no excess is seen in what is composed of equal palas.

original: anye tu asyaiva doṣasya parihārārthaṃ palaśabdasya samānaśabdaparyāyatāṃ bruvate / samānasaṃkhyāpalaparimāṇairiti samānasaṃkhyaiḥ samānaparimāṇairityarthaḥ /
analyzed: anye tu asya eva doṣasya parihāra artham pala śabdasya samāna śabda paryāyatām bruvate samāna saṃkhyā pala parimāṇaiḥ iti samāna saṃkhyaiḥ samāna parimāṇaiḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: Others, in order to avoid this very fault, say that the word pala is a synonym for the word sama. They say, With palas of equal number, meaning with palas of equal quantity.

original: nanu cāyuktamavadhāraṇaṃ pracayasyaiva kāraṇatvamiti / bahutvamahattvayorapyanyatra sāmarthyāvadhāraṇe satīha pratyāsannatvāt / na ca samānasaṃkhyāpalaparimāṇarārabdhe 'pi ekatrātiśayadarśanaṃ bahutvamahattvayoḥ kāraṇatvapratiṣedhe hetuḥ / anyāpekṣayānatiśayasadbhāve pracayasyāpyakāraṇatvaprasaṅgāt / tathā hi / samānasaṃkhyāpalaparimāṇaiḥ praśithilāvayavasaṃyogaiścaturbhirārabdhamekam anyacca tathāvidhaiII /stribhiriti / caturbhirārabdhe 'tiśayadarśanāt saṃkhyāpi kāraṇam / tathā sthūlaiścaturbhiḥ praśithilāvayavasaṃyogairārabdhamekam anyacca sthūlatamaistathāvidhairevetyatra kāraṇaparimāṇātiśayena kāryaparimāṇasyātiśayopalabdheḥ parimāṇasyāpi kāraṇatvam / yatra tu samānasaṃkhyāparimāṇaiḥ praśithilāvayavasaṃyogārabdhairmahattvamārabhyate tatrāviśeṣeṇa tritayasyāpi kāraṇatvam / anyatra sāmarthyāvadhāraṇe satīha pratyāsannatvāt / vākyasya tu vyākhyānaṃ pūrvavat /
analyzed: nanu ca ayuktam avadhāraṇam pracayasya eva kāraṇa tvam iti bahutva mahattvayoḥ api anyatra sāmarthya avadhāraṇe sati iha pratyāsanna tvāt na ca ekatra atiśaya darśanam bahu tva mahat tvayoḥ kāraṇa tva pratiṣedhe hetuḥ anya apekṣayā anatiśaya sadbhāve pracayasya api akāraṇa tva prasaṅgāt tathā hi samāna saṃkhyā pala parimāṇaiḥ praśithila avayava saṃyogaiḥ caturbhiḥ ārabdham ekam anyat ca caturbhiḥ ārabdhe tiśaya darśanāt saṃkhyā api kāraṇa tv
translated: But it is improper to restrict the cause to mere aggregation alone, for plurality and magnitude are also causes elsewhere, when their capacity is ascertained. And the observation of excess in one case, even when produced by aggregates of equal number and measure, is not a reason for denying that plurality and magnitude are causes, because if there were no excess in relation to others, aggregation would also be a non-cause. For example, one is produced by four aggregates of equal number and measure, with loose conjunction of parts, and another by three of the same kind. Since excess is observed in one produced by four, number is also a cause. Similarly, one is produced by four gross ones with loose conjunction of parts, and another by three of the same kind, but most gross. Since the excess of the effect measure is observed here due to the excess of the cause measure, measure is also a cause. But where it is produced by aggregates of equal number and measure, with loose conjunction of parts,

original: dvitvasaṃkhyā cāṇvorvartamānā dvyaṇuke 'ṇutvamārabhate /PDhS
analyzed: dvi tva saṃkhyā ca aṇvoḥ vartamānā dvi aṇuke ṇu tvam ārabhate
translated: And the number two, inhering in the atoms, produces the dimension of atomhood in the dyad.

original: aṇutvotpattau kāraṇamāha dvitvasaṃkhyā cāṇvorvartamānā dvyaṇuke 'ṇutvamārabhate iti / dvyaṇukāṇuparimāṇaṃ kāryam / tasya hi samavāyikāraṇaṃ dvyaṇukamityanyenāsamavāyikāraṇena bhavitavyam / paramāṇuparimāṇasya cārambhakatvapratiṣedhe 'nyasya cāsambhavād dvitvasaṃkhyaivāṇvorvartamānā kāryakāraṇaikārthasamavāyena dvyaṇukāṇuparimāṇotpattāvasamavāyikāraṇamiti / aṇuśabdaśca sāmānyaśabdatvāt paramāṇāvapi vartata eva / aṇutve sati parama iti viśeṣaṇāt / vināśastu dvitvasaṃkhyāyāḥ pūrvavadvyākhyeyaḥ /
analyzed: aṇu tva utpattau kāraṇam āha dvi tva saṃkhyā ca aṇvoḥ vartamānā dvyaṇuke ṇu tvam ārabhate iti dvi aṇuka aṇu parimāṇam kāryam tasya hi samavāyi kāraṇam dvyaṇukam iti anyena asamavāyi kāraṇena bhavitavyam paramāṇu parimāṇasya ca ārambhaka tva pratiṣedhe nyasya ca asambhavāt dvi tva saṃkhyā eva aṇvoḥ vartamānā kārya kāraṇa eka artha samavāyena dvi aṇuka aṇu parimāṇa utpattau asamavāyi kāraṇam iti  /
translated: He states the cause of the origination of atomhood: And the number two, inhering in the atoms, produces the dimension of atomhood in the dyad. The dimension of the dyad is the effect. For its inherent cause is the dyad, so there must be another non-inherent cause. And since the dimension of the atom is prohibited as a cause, and there is no other [possible cause], the number two, inhering in the atoms, is the non-inherent cause in the production of the dimension of the dyad and atom by inhering in the same object as the cause and effect. And the word 'atom' applies to the ultimate atom also, because it is a word for a universal. Because it is qualified as 'supreme' when it has atomhood. But the destruction of the number two should be explained as before.

original: mahattvavat tryaṇukādau kāraṇabahutvamahattvasamānajātīyapracayebhyo dīrghatvasyotpattiḥ / aṇutvavad dvyaṇuke dvitvasaṃkhyāto hrasvatvasyospattiḥ /PDhS
analyzed: mahat tva vat tryaṇuka ādau kāraṇa bahu tva mahat tva samāna jātīya pracayebhyaḥ dīrgha tvasya utpattiḥ aṇu tva vat dvyaṇuke dvi tva saṃkhyātaḥ hrasva tvasya uspattiḥ
translated: Just as with largeness, length arises from the aggregation of many causes of largeness in the triad and so on. Just as with smallness, shortness arises from the number two in the dyad.

original: dīrghatvotpattau kāraṇamāha mahattvavat tryaṇukādau kāraṇabahutvamahattvasamānajātīyapracayebhyo dīrghatvasyotpattiḥ iti / yathā hi mahattvaṃ kāraṇabahutvamahattvasamānajātīyapracayebhyo bhavati evaṃ dīrghatvamapīti / tryaṇuke kāraṇabahutvādeva dīrghatvam / dvitantuke kāraṇadīrghatvādeveti / tritantukādau bahutvadīrghatvapracayairdīrghatvamārabhyate ityatideśārthaḥ / tathā aṇutvavad dvyaṇuke dvitvasaṃkhyāto hrasvatvasyotpattiḥ iti / yathā kāraṇāntarāsambhavād dvitvasaṃkhyā aṇutvasyotpattāvasamavāyikāraṇam evaṃ hrasvatvasyāpīti /
analyzed: dīrgha tva utpattau kāraṇam āha mahat tva vat tryaṇuka ādau kāraṇa bahu tva mahat tva samāna jātīya pracayebhyaḥ dīrgha tvasya utpattiḥ iti yathā hi mahat tvam kāraṇa bahu tva mahat tva samāna jātīya pracayebhyaḥ bhavati evam dīrgha tvam api iti tryaṇuke kāraṇa bahu tvāt eva dīrgha tvam dvitantuke kāraṇa dīrgha tvāt eva iti tritantuka ādau bahu tva dīrgha tva pracayaiḥ dīrgha tvam ārabhyate iti atideśa arthaḥ tathā aṇu tva vat dvyaṇuke dvi tva saṃkhy
translated: He states the cause of the origination of length: Just as with largeness, length arises from the aggregation of many causes of largeness in the triad and so on. Just as largeness occurs from the aggregation of many causes of largeness of the same kind, so does length. In the triad, length arises from the mere plurality of causes. In the dyad, shortness arises from the mere length of the cause. In the tetrad and so on, length is produced by the aggregation of plurality and length. This is the meaning of the extension. Similarly, just as with smallness, shortness arises from the number two in the dyad. Just as the number two is the non-inherent cause of the origination of smallness due to the impossibility of other causes, so also is shortness.

original: atha tryaṇukādiṣu vartamānayormahattvadīrghatvayoḥ parasparataḥ ko viśeṣaḥ / dvyaṇukeṣu cāṇutvahrasvatvayoriti / tatrāsti mahattvadīrghatvayoḥ II / parasparato viśeṣaḥ / mahatsu dīrghamānīyatāṃ / dīrgheṣu ca mahadānīyatāmiti viśiṣṭavyavahāradarśanāditi / aṇutvahrasvatvayostu parasparato viśeṣastaddarśināṃ pratyakṣa iti /PDhS
analyzed: atha tryaṇuka ādiṣu vartamānayoḥ mahat tva dīrgha tvayoḥ parasparataḥ kaḥ viśeṣaḥ dvyaṇukeṣu ca aṇu tva hrasva tvayoḥ iti tatra asti mahat tva dīrgha tvayoḥ parasparataḥ viśeṣaḥ mahatsu dīrgham ānīyatām dīrgheṣu ca mahat ānīyatām iti viśiṣṭa vyavahāra darśanāt iti aṇu tva hrasva tvayoḥ tu parasparataḥ viśeṣaḥ tad darśinām pratyakṣaḥ iti pdhs
translated: Now, what is the difference between largeness and length, which exist in the triads and so on, and between minuteness and shortness, which exist in the dyads? There is a difference between largeness and length. For the usage is distinguished as 'bring the large among the long' and 'bring the long among the large'. But the difference between minuteness and shortness is directly perceived by those who see it.

original: etaccaturvidhamapi parimāṇamutpādyamāśrayavināśādeva vinaśyatīti /PDhS
analyzed: etat caturvidham api parimāṇam utpādyam āśraya vināśāt eva vinaśyati iti
translated: And this fourfold dimension is produced and destroyed only by the destruction of the substratum.

original: atha samānajātīyakāraṇajanyatvāt tryaṇukādiṣu vartamānayormahattvadīrghatvayoḥ parasparataḥ ko viśeṣaḥ / dvyaṇukeṣu cāṇutvahrasvatvayoḥ iti / yataḥ kāraṇabhedāt bhidyante padārthā mahattvadīrghatvādau tadabhāva iti / tanna / pratibhāsabhedena mahattvadīrghatvayorbhedasadbhāve sati tajjanakayoḥ kāraṇasāmagryorbhedopatteḥ /

analyzed: anye tu itaretara abhāvasya pratiṣedha artham nānā pratyaya janakam iti  na anitya dravyeṣu nityasya guṇasya anupalabdheḥ āśraya vināśena tad vināśe sarvatra anupalabdhiḥ eva syāt anitya tāyān tu aśeṣa dravya āśritasya utpatti kāraṇa abhāvaḥ teṣām krameṇa utpādāt na ca anyatra samavetam upajātam anyatra samavaiti iti adarśanāt ekasya ca nityasya aneka vṛttau dravya tva sāmānya rūpa tā syāt na ca dravyam dravyam iti pratyaya vat pṛthak pṛthak iti padārt
translated: Others, however, for the sake of negating mutual absence, say that it is produced by various conditions. translated: If, on the other hand, the cognitions of difference are different in nature and are distinguished by number, then, since the destruction of the cognition of dependence is possible, there is no persistence of duality, etc. at the time of double-difference, etc. And since there is destruction at the same time as the cognition of substance when duality, etc. arise before, there is no persistence at the time of the origination of duality. translated: For instance, the production of the cognition of relation which produces the notion of duality, the production of the memory of duality, the production of the duality, the production of the memory of duality, the production of duality, the destruction of the cognition of relation, the production of the cognition of the quality of duality—all this takes place at one time.

original: tato dvitvasmaraṇasya dvipṛthaktvajñānajanakatvameveti manyamānā guṇādiṣvapi etasmādayaṃ vyāvṛtto vilakṣaṇaḥ ityādivyavahāraḥ pṛthaktvanimittaḥ / sa ca nirguṇatvād guṇādīnāmupacāra iti manyante / na ca pṛthagiti jñānaṃ nirviṣayaṃ vāsanāprabhavam / tasyāḥ pūrvameva pratiṣedhāt /

analyzed: lakṣaṇena lakṣyamāṇasya eka aneka tva upalabdhau saṃśaye sati tad nirāsa artham vibhāgam āha tat punar eka dravyam aneka dravyam ca iti ekam eva dravyam āśrayaḥ sya iti eka dravyam anekam eva ca dravyam āśrayaḥ sya a vinaśyat avastha dravyasya iti aneka dravyam  / tasya tu dvividhasya api nitya anitya tva niṣpattayaḥ saṃkhyayā vyākhyātāḥ iti atideśaḥ tathā hi eka pṛthaktvam nityeṣu aniṣpadyamāna tvāt nityam kāryeṣu ca kāraṇa guṇa pūrvakam āśraya vi
translated: When there is doubt in the perception of oneness or manyness of what is being characterized by a characteristic, in order to remove that doubt, he states the division: That is again of one substance and of many substances. But for that which is of two kinds, the establishment of eternality and non-eternality is explained by number - this is the extension. For instance, one-ness is eternal in eternal substances because it does not become non-existent. And in effects, it quickly perishes due to the destruction of its substratum, preceded by the quality of its cause - this is the meaning of extension. For two-ness etc., like two-ness etc., there is origination from the cognition of dependence, but destruction is from the destruction of that, and in some cases also from the destruction of the substratum. And the origination of hundred-ness etc. is by the principle of the origination of the number hundred - this is the extension.

original: nanvevaṃ tarhi śatasaṃkhyāto na viśeṣaḥ syādityāśaṅkyāha etāvāṃstu viśeṣaḥ / ekatvādivadekapṛthaktvādiṣvaparasāmānyābhāvaḥ iti / yathā hi / saṃkhyātvavyatirekeṇāparamekatvādisāmānyamasti naivam ekapṛthaktvādīti /
analyzed: nanu evam tarhi śata saṃkhyātaḥ na viśeṣaḥ syāt iti āśaṅkya āha etāvān tu viśeṣaḥ ekatva ādi vat ekapṛthaktva ādiṣu apara sāmānya abhāvaḥ iti yathā hi saṃkhyā tva vyatirekeṇa aparam ekatva ādi sāmānyam asti na evam ekapṛthaktva ādi iti
translated: But if it is so, then there would be no difference from the number hundred, it is feared. To this he says: But there is this much difference. In the case of one-ness, etc., and one-separateness, etc., there is no other universal. Just as there is another universal like one-ness, etc., apart from number-ness, so there is no such thing as one-separateness, etc.

original: athānugatajñānādayuktametat / na / anyathā tadupapatteḥ / tathā hi / dravyaguṇakarmanimittamabādhyamānamanugataṃ jñānaṃ sāmānyasattāṃ darśayati / pṛthaktve ca ekatvādisaṃkhyāvaśādanugatajñānaṃ ghaṭata ityāha saṃkhyayā tu viśiṣyate / kutaḥ / tadviśiṣṭavyavahāradarśanāt / idamekaṃ pṛthak / dve pṛthak / trīṇi pṛthagityādi /
analyzed: atha anugata jñānāt ayuktam etat na anyathā tad upapatteḥ tathā hi dravya guṇa karma nimittam abādhyamānam anugatam jñānam sāmānya sattām darśayati pṛthaktve ca ekatva ādi saṃkhyā vaśāt anugata jñānam ghaṭate iti āha saṃkhyayā tu viśiṣyate kutas tad viśiṣṭa vyavahāra darśanāt idam ekam pṛthak dve pṛthak trīṇi pṛthak ityādi
translated: If it is argued that this is improper because of the cognition of the common property, it is not so, because it is possible in another way. Thus, the unobstructed cognition of substance, quality, and action shows the existence of a common property. And in separateness, the cognition of the common property is possible due to the number like one-ness, etc. He says: But it is distinguished by number. Why? Because of the observation of usage qualified by that. This one is separate, two are separate, three are separate, etc.

original: athāśeṣadravyeṣvekamevāstu pṛthaktvaṃ saṃkhyāvad viśeṣaṇajñānatvād viśeṣaṇamapekṣate / na ca rūpādīnāmanyatamaṃ nimittaṃ / tadvyavahāravilakṣaṇatvāditi nimittāntareṇa bhavitavyamiti /
analyzed: atha aśeṣa dravyeṣu ekam eva astu pṛthaktvam saṃkhyāvat viśeṣaṇa jñāna tvāt viśeṣaṇam apekṣate na ca rūpa ādīnām anyatamam nimittam tad vyavahāra vilakṣaṇa tvāt iti nimitta antareṇa bhavitavyam iti
translated: Now, let there be only one separateness in all substances, like number. It requires a qualifier because it is the cognition of a qualifier. And none of color etc. is the cause, because it is different from the usage of that. So it must be by some other cause.

original: itaḥprabhṛti pṛthaktvaprakaraṇāntaḥ pāṭhaḥ saṃyogaprakaraṇe ādarśapustake āsīt kintu dvipṛthaktvotpādakaprakriyānirūpakatvādayaṃ granthastatrāsaṅgato dṛśyate 'to 'tra niveśito 'pi sthānabhraṣṭatvāt pāṭhabhraṣṭatvācca saṅgatirnaiva dṛśyate / sa ca vidvadbhiḥ svayaṃ yojanīyaḥ /

translated: From here onwards, the text within the section on separateness was in the section on conjunction in the mirror book, but this text appears to be irrelevant there because it describes the process that produces double separateness. So it is inserted here, but even then, due to the loss of place and the loss of reading, no connection is seen. And that should be connected by the learned themselves.

original: tatkriyayā guṇabuddherutpādo / dravyabuddherutpadyamānatā / dvitvasmaraṇasya vinaśyattā / apekṣābuddhervināśaḥ / dvipṛthaktvaguṇasya vinaśyattā / tato dve pṛthagiti dravyabuddherutpādaḥ / guṇabuddhervinaśyattā / dvitvasmaraṇasya vināśaḥ / apekṣābuddhivināśāt guṇasya vināśaḥ / saṃskārasyotpadyamānatā / tataḥ saṃskārād dravyabuddhervināśa iti /
analyzed: tad kriyayā guṇa buddheḥ utpādaḥ dravya buddheḥ utpadyamāna tā dvi tva smaraṇasya vinaśyat tā apekṣā buddheḥ vināśaḥ dvi pṛthaktva guṇasya vinaśyat tā tatas dve pṛthak iti dravya buddheḥ utpādaḥ guṇa buddheḥ vinaśyat tā dvi tva smaraṇasya vināśaḥ apekṣā buddhi vināśāt guṇasya vināśaḥ saṃskārasya utpadyamāna tā tatas saṃskārāt dravya buddheḥ vināśaḥ iti
translated: The production of the cognition of the quality by that action, the state of being produced of the cognition of the substance, the state of being destroyed of the memory of duality, the destruction of the cognition of dependence, the state of being destroyed of the quality of twofoldness, then the cognition of the substance as two separate things, the destruction of the cognition of the quality, the destruction of the memory of duality, the destruction of the quality due to the destruction of the cognition of dependence, the state of being produced of the impression, then the destruction of the cognition of the substance due to the impression.

original: yad vā dvitvotpādikāyā apekṣābuddherutpādaḥ / dvitvasyotpadyamānatā / dvipṛthaktvotpādikāyāścāpekṣābuddherutpadyamānatā / tato dvitvasmaraṇasyotpādaḥ II / tadbuddherutpadyamānatā / dvipṛthaktvotpādikāyāścāpekṣābuddherutpādaḥ / dvipṛthaktvasyotpadyamānatā / dvitvotpādikāyā apekṣābuddhervinaśyattā / tato dvipṛthaktvasyotpādaḥ / dvitvaguṇabuddherutpādaḥ / dvitvaguṇāttajjñānāt tadekārthasamavāyācca dvipṛthaktvaguṇabuddherutpadyamānatā / apekṣābuddhervināśaḥ / dvitvasya vinaśyattā / dvipṛthaktvotpādikāyāścāpekṣābuddhervinaśyattetyekaḥ kālaḥ /
analyzed: yat vā dvi tva utpādikāyāḥ apekṣā buddheḥ utpādaḥ dvi tvasya utpadyamāna tā dvipṛthaktva utpādikāyāḥ ca apekṣā buddheḥ utpadyamāna tā tatas dvi tva smaraṇasya utpādaḥ tad buddheḥ utpadyamāna tā dvi pṛthaktva utpādikāyāḥ ca apekṣā buddheḥ utpādaḥ dvi pṛthaktvasya utpadyamāna tā dvi tva utpādikāyāḥ apekṣā buddheḥ vinaśyat tā tatas dvi pṛthaktvasya utpādaḥ dvi tva guṇa buddheḥ utpādaḥ dvi tva guṇāt tad jñānāt tad ekārtha
translated: Or, the production of the cognition of relation which produces duality, the state of being produced of duality, and the state of being produced of the cognition of relation which produces the two separate things, then the production of the memory of duality, the state of being produced of that cognition, the production of the cognition of relation which produces the two separate things, the state of being produced of the two separate things, the destruction of the cognition of relation which produces duality, then the production of the two separate things, the production of the cognition of the quality of duality, from the quality of duality, from the knowledge of that, and from the inherence of the same object, the state of being produced of the cognition of the quality of the two separate things, the destruction of the cognition of relation, the destruction of duality, and the destruction of the cognition of relation which produces the two separate things - this is one moment.

original: tato dvipṛthaktvaguṇabuddherutpādaḥ / dravyabuddherutpadyamānatā / dvitvaguṇasya vināśaḥ / tadbuddhervinaśyattā / dvipṛthaktvotpādikāyāścāpekṣābuddhervināśaḥ / dvipṛthaktvaguṇasya vinaśyattetyekaḥ kālaḥ /
analyzed: tatas dvi pṛthaktva guṇa buddheḥ utpādaḥ dravya buddheḥ utpadyamānatā dvitva guṇasya vināśaḥ tad buddheḥ vinaśyat tā dvi pṛthaktva utpādikāyāḥ ca apekṣā buddheḥ vināśaḥ dvi pṛthaktva guṇasya vinaśyat tā iti ekaḥ kālaḥ
translated: Then there is the production of the cognition of the quality of two-ness, the arising of the cognition of the substance, the destruction of the quality of two-ness, the ceasing to be of that cognition, and the destruction of the cognition of dependence that produces the quality of two-ness. The quality of two-ness is ceasing to be.

original: tato dve pṛthagiti dravyabuddherutpādaḥ / guṇabuddhervinaśyattā / dvipṛthaktvaguṇasya vināśaḥ / dvitvaguṇabuddheśca vināśaḥ / saṃskārasyotpadyamānatā / tataḥ saṃskārād dravyabuddhervināśa iti / atra tu vidyamānasya dvitvaguṇasya svānubhavasahakāriṇo dvipṛthaktvaguṇajñānotpattau vyāpāra iti viśeṣaḥ /
analyzed: tatas dve pṛthak iti dravya buddheḥ utpādaḥ guṇa buddheḥ vinaśyat tā dvi pṛthaktva guṇasya vināśaḥ dvitva guṇa buddheḥ ca vināśaḥ saṃskārasya utpadyamāna tā tatas saṃskārāt dravya buddheḥ vināśaḥ iti atra tu vidyamānasya dvi tva guṇasya sva anubhava sahakāriṇaḥ dvi pṛthaktva guṇa jñāna utpattau vyāpāraḥ iti viśeṣaḥ
translated: Then there is the production of the cognition of the substance as two separate things, the ceasing to be of the cognition of the quality, the destruction of the quality of two-ness, the destruction of the cognition of the quality of two-ness, and the arising of the impression. Then from the impression there is the destruction of the cognition of the substance. But here the difference is that the existing quality of two-ness, which is a co-operator with its own experience, has an operation in the production of the cognition of the quality of two-ness.

original: anye tvekaikaguṇālambanakā buddhirutpadyate / dvitvadvipṛthaktvayorutpadyamānateti manyante / tato dvitvadvipṛthaktvayorutpādaḥ / dvitvaguṇajñānasyotpadyamānatā / tato dvitvaguṇajñānasyotpādaḥ / dvipṛktvajñānasyotpadyamānatā / apekṣābuddhervinaśyattā / tato dvipṛthaktvaguṇajñānasyotpādaḥ / dravyajñānasyotpadyamānatā / dvitvaguṇajñānasya vinaśyattā / apekṣābuddhervināśaḥ / dvitvadvipṛthaktvayorvinaśyattā / tato dravyajñānasyotpādaḥ / dvipṛthaktvaguṇajñānasya vināśaḥ / dvitvadvipṛthaktvayorvināśaḥ / saṃskārasyotpadyamānatā / tataḥ saṃskārād dravyabuddhervināśa ityatra tu vidyamānasya dvitvaguṇasya dve pṛthagiti dravyajñānasyotpattāvapi vyāpāra iti viśeṣaḥ /
analyzed: anye tu ekaika guṇa ālambanakā buddhiḥ utpadyate dvi tva dvi pṛthaktvayoḥ utpadyamāna tā iti manyante tatas dvi tva dvi pṛthaktvayoḥ utpādaḥ dvi tva guṇa jñānasya utpadyamāna tā tatas dvi tva guṇa jñānasya utpādaḥ dvi pṛktva jñānasya utpadyamāna tā apekṣā buddheḥ vinaśyat tā tatas dvi pṛthaktva guṇa jñānasya utpādaḥ dravya jñānasya utpadyamāna tā dvi tva guṇa jñānasya vinaśyat tā apekṣā buddheḥ vināśaḥ dvi tva dvi pṛthaktvayoḥ vin
translated: Others think that the cognition arises taking each quality as its object, and then the duality and separateness arise. Then there is the arising of duality and separateness, the state of being produced of the cognition of the quality of duality, then the arising of the cognition of the quality of duality, the state of being produced of the cognition of separateness, the destruction of the cognition of dependence. Then there is the arising of the cognition of the quality of separateness, the state of being produced of the cognition of the substance. The destruction of the cognition of the quality of duality, the destruction of the cognition of dependence, the destruction of duality and separateness. Then there is the arising of the cognition of the substance, the destruction of the cognition of the quality of separateness, the destruction of duality and separateness, the state of being produced of the impression. Then from the impression, the destruction of the cognition of the substance. But here, even when the cognition of the substance two separate things arises, there is the operation of the existing quality of duality. This is the difference.

original: atha samavetānāmeva guṇakarmasāmānyānāṃ viśeṣaṇatopalabdheḥ kathaṃ dvipṛthaktvādāvavartamānaṃ dvitvādi viśeṣaṇamiti cet / bādhakopapatterupacāreṇetyuktaṃ padārthasaṅkare / tathā ca sūtraṃ 'guṇakarmasu guṇakarmābhāvāt guṇakarmāpekṣa na vidyate vai / sū / iti / guṇakarmasu samavetānāṃ guṇakarmaṇāmabhāvāt tadapekṣaṃ mukhyajñānaṃ nāstīti /
analyzed: atha samavetānām eva guṇa karma sāmānyānām viśeṣaṇatā upalabdheḥ katham dvi pṛthaktva ādau avartamānam dvi tva ādi viśeṣaṇam iti ced bādhaka upapatteḥ upacāreṇa iti uktam padārtha saṅkare tathā ca sūtram guṇa karmasu guṇa karma abhāvāt guṇa karma apekṣa na vidyate vai iti guṇa karmasu samavetānām guṇa karmaṇām abhāvāt tad apekṣam mukhya jñānam na asti iti
translated: If it be asked, how can duality, etc., which are not present in duality, etc., be the qualifiers in the case of the qualities, actions, and universals which are all assembled together, because they are perceived as qualifiers? It has been said that it is by figurative usage, because of the presence of an objection, in the case of the confusion of word meanings. And the aphorism is thus: In the case of qualities and actions, there is no cognition of qualities and actions as primary, because of the absence of qualities and actions, and because of their dependence on qualities and actions. That is to say, because of the absence of qualities and actions which are assembled in qualities and actions, there is no primary cognition of them which is independent of them.

original: saṃyogavaidharmyam
analyzed: saṃyoga vaidharmyam
translated: The dissimilarity of conjunction

original: saṃyogaḥ saṃyuktapratyayanimittam / sa ca dravyaguṇakarmahetuḥ / dravyārambhe nirapekṣastathā bhavatīti / sāpekṣebhyo nirapekṣebhyaśceti vacanāt / guṇakarmārambhe tu sāpekṣaḥ / saṃyuktasamavāyādagnervaiśeṣikamiti vacanāt /PDhS
analyzed: saṃyogaḥ saṃyukta pratyaya nimittam sa ca dravya guṇa karma hetuḥ dravya ārambhe nirapekṣaḥ tathā bhavati iti sāpekṣebhyaḥ nirapekṣebhyaḥ ca iti vacanāt guṇa karma ārambhe tu sāpekṣaḥ saṃyukta samavāyāt agneḥ vaiśeṣikam iti vacanāt
translated: Conjunction is the cause of the notion of conjunction. And it is the cause of substance, quality, and action. It exists independently in the production of substance, as stated in the text from independent and dependent causes. But in the production of quality and action, it is dependent, as stated in the text from the conjunction of conjunction, fire has a specific property.

original: idānīmuddeśavataḥ saṃyogasya lakṣaṇaparīkṣārthaṃ saṃyogaḥ saṃyuktapratyayanimittam ityādi prakaraṇam / pratītiḥ pratyayo jñānam / pratīyate 'neneti pratyayo 'bhidhānam / tayornimittaṃ sarve 'pi padārthā iti saṃyuktagrahaṇam / tathāpi saṃyuktapratyayanimittatvamākāśātmanorvidyata iti viśeṣaṇatve satīti kāryam / ataḥ saṃyoga itarebhyo bhidyate / viśeṣaṇatve sati saṃyuktapratyayanimittatvāt / yastvitarasmādasaṃyogānna bhidyate na cāsāvevam / yathā rupādiriti / parīkṣāparatvenāpi sambadhyate saṃyogaḥ saṃyuktapratyayanimittamiti vākyam /
analyzed: idānīm uddeśavataḥ saṃyogasya lakṣaṇa parīkṣā artham saṃyogaḥ saṃyukta pratyaya nimittam ityādi prakaraṇam pratītiḥ pratyayaḥ jñānam pratīyate nena iti pratyayaḥ bhidhānam tayoḥ nimittam sarve pi padārthāḥ iti saṃyukta grahaṇam tathā api saṃyukta pratyaya nimitta tvam ākāśa ātmanoḥ vidyate iti viśeṣaṇa tve sati iti kāryam atas saṃyogaḥ itarebhyaḥ bhidyate viśeṣaṇa tve sati saṃyukta pratyaya nimitta tvāt yaḥ tu itarasmāt asaṃyog
translated: Now, in order to examine the definition of conjunction, which has been mentioned, the topic begins with conjunction is the cause of the notion of conjunction. Pratiti is cognition. Pratyaya is verbal expression, as it is by this that one is made to understand. The cause of these two is all things. Thus, the word 'conjunction' is used. Nevertheless, since the cause of the notion of conjunction exists in the case of space and self also, the word 'sati' (when) is used as a qualifier. Therefore, conjunction is distinguished from other things. Because it is the cause of the notion of conjunction, when it is a qualifier. But that which is not distinguished from other non-conjunctions is not so. Like form etc. The sentence conjunction is the cause of the notion of conjunction is also connected as being for the purpose of examination.

original: atha viśiṣṭotpādād dravyameva saṃyuktavyavahāranimittam / tathā hi / viśleṣakṣaṇāt saṃśleṣakṣaṇotpāde saṃyuktavyavahāro dṛṣṭo nānyatheti / tadasat / viśiṣṭatāyā vyatirekānabhyupagame tasyā dravyarūpatayā sarvatrāviśeṣāt dravyamātre saṃyuktapratyayaḥ syāt / vyatireke tu yena satā rūpādivilakṣaṇena saṃyukta iti vyavahāraḥ sa eva saṃyoga iti na kiñcid bādhyate / saṃśleṣasyātra saṃyogarūpatvāditi / na cāyaṃ vyavahāro vāsanānimittastasyāḥ pūrvameva pratiṣedhāt /
analyzed: atha viśiṣṭa utpādāt dravyam eva saṃyukta vyavahāra nimittam tathā hi viśleṣa kṣaṇāt saṃśleṣa kṣaṇa utpāde saṃyukta vyavahāraḥ dṛṣṭaḥ na anyathā iti tat asat viśiṣṭa tāyāḥ vyatireka anabhyupagame tasyāḥ dravya rūpa tayā sarvatra aviśeṣāt dravya mātre saṃyukta pratyayaḥ syāt vyatireke tu yena satā rūpa ādi vilakṣaṇena saṃyuktaḥ iti vyavahāraḥ saḥ eva saṃyogaḥ iti na kiñcid bādhyate saṃśleṣasya atra saṃyoga rūpa
translated: If, on the other hand, the Conjunction is something different, then the Conjunction must be the basis of the notion of ‘being joined’, because it is this that is produced in a different form. For instance, when the Conjunction is produced out of the Disjunction, the notion of ‘being joined’ is found to appear, not otherwise. This is not right. If the Conjunction is not something different, then, being of the nature of the Substance itself, it could not be different in any case; and hence the notion of ‘being joined’ would be there even before the Conjunction. If, on the other hand, it is different, then that which is there in the form of something different from Colour, etc., and which is spoken of as ‘being joined’, must be the Conjunction itself; and there is nothing that is denied by this explanation. Because in this case, the ‘Conjunction’ is of the nature of the ‘Conjunction-cum-Contact’. Nor can this notion be said to be due to the Impressions left by past experience; because this has been already rejected before.

original: arthakriyāmāha sa ca dravyaguṇakarmahetuḥ iti / saṃyogasadbhāve pramāṇañcedamiti / na hi tantusaṃyogādṛte paṭasyotpattiḥ / bherīdaṇḍasaṃyogañca vinā śabdasya / hastatomarādisaṃyogābhāve ca tomarakarmaṇa iti dṛṣṭañca ato saṃyogo 'bhyupagantavyaḥ /
analyzed: arthakriyām āha sa ca dravya guṇa karma hetuḥ iti saṃyoga sadbhāve pramāṇam ca idam iti na hi tantu saṃyogāt ṛte paṭasya utpattiḥ bherī daṇḍa saṃyogam ca vinā śabdasya hasta tomara ādi saṃyoga abhāve ca tomara karmaṇaḥ iti dṛṣṭam ca saṃyogaḥ bhyupagantavyaḥ
translated: He states the function of conjunction: It is the cause of substance, quality, and action. This is the proof for the existence of conjunction. For a cloth does not arise without the conjunction of threads, nor does sound without the conjunction of a stick and a drum, nor does the action of a spear without the conjunction of hand and spear. The hawk's action produces the disjunction of the hawk from the post, because when they are in close proximity, the capacity of both is determined.
