original: ubhayakarmajo 'pyubhayoḥ karmaṇī tābhyāṃ jātaḥ / yathā mallayormeṣayorvā / atrāpyavayavakarmabhyāṃ vibhāgasamakālamavayavinaḥ karmābhyupagame saṃyogairavayavikarmabhyāñca saṃyogo janyata iti cintyam / yathā hyavayavakarma avayavāntareṇa saṃyogaṃ karoti / evaṃ tadavayavināpi itarāvayavakarmāpi / itarāvayavakarmasaṃyogavat tadavayavināpīti / saṃyogatritayam / tacca pratyāsannatve sati sāmarthyāvadhāraṇāt kāraṇamiti / meṣayoḥ samavāyikāraṇatvam / atraiva dvipṛthaktvotpādakaprakriyāpāṭho mātṛkāyāmāsīt saṃyuktapratyaye hi II / viśeṣyāvayavāvayavisaṃyogasya cāsamavāyikāraṇatvam / śeṣaṃ nimittakāraṇamiti / kevalobhayakarmajatvañca paramāṇudvayasaṃyogasya draṣṭavyam /
analyzed: ubhaya karma jaḥ upi ubhayoḥ karmaṇī tābhyām jātaḥ yathā mallayoḥ meṣayoḥ vā atra api avayava karmabhyām vibhāga sama kālam avayavinaḥ karma abhyupagame saṃyogaiḥ avayavi karmabhyām ca saṃyogaḥ janyate iti cintyam yathā hi avayava karma avayava antareṇa saṃyogam karoti evam tad avayavinā api itara avayava karma api itara avayava karma saṃyoga vat tad avayavinā api iti saṃyoga tritayam tat ca pratyāsanna tve sati sāmarthya avadhāraṇāt kāraṇam iti meṣay
translated: That produced by both actions is produced by the actions of both, like two wrestlers or two rams. Here also, if the action of the whole is accepted simultaneously with the separation by the actions of the parts, the conjunction is produced by the conjunctions and the action of the whole. Just as the action of one part produces the conjunction with another part, so does the whole with that part. The action of the other part also, like the conjunction with the other part, is with the whole. Thus there are three conjunctions. And that is the cause, because the capability is determined when there is proximity. The rams are the inherent cause. In this very place, the reading of the process that produces twofoldness was in the mother text, because of the cognition of conjunction. And the disjunction of the qualified part and the whole is the non-inherent cause. The rest is the instrumental cause. And the fact that it is produced by the action of both alone should be seen in the case of the conjunction of two atoms.

original: anye tu ubhayapadasya luptavibhaktikasya pūrvottareṇa sambandhāt saṃyogakarmajabhedasyāpi grahaṇaṃ bhaviṣyatyeveti manyante / tathā hi / saṃyogakāraṇatvenobhayorupalambhāt karmaṇaḥ svaśabdenopādāne anyataraḥ saṃyogo labhyata eva / anyataraśca karma cānyatarakarmaṇī tābhyāṃ jāto 'nyatarakarmajaḥ / sa cobhaya ekena karmaṇā saṅgatya dvitīyena janyate / dvābhyāñca saṃyogaḥ sadvitīyābhyāmiti / tathobhayaḥ kevalakarmajo 'pyekena karmaṇā janyate dvābhyāñceti / saṃyogajastu utpannamātrasya cirotpannasya vā ityubhayaḥ / tasya lakṣaṇamāha akriyasya ityādi /
analyzed: anye tu ubhaya padasya lupta vibhaktikasya pūrvottareṇa sambandhāt saṃyoga karma ja bhedasya api grahaṇam bhaviṣyati eva iti manyante tathā hi saṃyoga kāraṇa tvena ubhayoḥ upalambhāt karmaṇaḥ sva śabdena upādāne anyataraḥ saṃyogaḥ labhyate eva anyataraḥ ca karma ca anyatara karmaṇī tābhyām jātaḥ nyatara karma jaḥ sa ca ubhayaḥ ekena karmaṇā saṅgatya dvitīyena janyate dvābhyām ca saṃyogaḥ sa dvitīyābhyām iti tathā ubhayaḥ kevala karma jaḥ pi
translated: Others, however, think that even the distinction between what is produced by contact and what is produced by action will be included, because the word 'both' is used with the preceding and following [words], with the case endings omitted. Thus, since both are perceived as the cause of contact, when action is mentioned by its own word, one of the two contacts is obtained. And the other is the action, and what is produced by either of those two actions is produced by either action. And that both are produced by one action in conjunction with the other, and are produced by the second with a companion. Similarly, both are produced by one action and by two actions, even if produced only by action. But what is produced by contact is produced by one action or by two actions, whether just produced or long produced. Both of these are described by the definition beginning with 'of what is not an action'.

original: akriyasyetyayaṃ niyamaḥ / kaiḥ sahetyāha akāraṇaiḥ / kiṃviśiṣṭaiḥ / kāraṇasaṃyogibhiḥ iti / kāraṇena saṃyogāste yeṣāṃ tāni tathoktāni / taiḥ kāraṇasaṃyogibhirakāraṇaiḥ saha akriyasya yaḥ saṃyogaḥ sa saṃyogajo 'nyasya kāraṇasyābhāvāt /
analyzed: akriyasya iti ayam niyamaḥ kaiḥ saha iti āha akāraṇaiḥ kiṃviśiṣṭaiḥ kāraṇa saṃyogibhiḥ iti kāraṇena saṃyogāḥ te yeṣām tāni tathā uktāni taiḥ kāraṇa saṃyogibhiḥ akāraṇaiḥ saha akriyasya yaḥ saṃyogaḥ sa saṃyoga jaḥ nyasya kāraṇasya abhāvāt
translated: This is the rule: with what? He says: with non-causes. What is their distinction? With those that are connected with causes. Those that have a connection with a cause are said to be such. With those non-causes that are connected with causes, the connection of the inactive one is produced from the absence of another cause.

original: saṃgrahoktervivaraṇamāha kāraṇākāraṇasaṃyogapūrvakaḥ kāryākāryagataḥ saṃyogaḥ iti / kāraṇamatra samavāyikāraṇam / svakāryasya tadapekṣayānyadakāraṇam / tayoryaḥ saṃyogastatpūrvakaḥ kāryākāryagataḥ saṃyogaḥ / prakṛtasya kāraṇasya yat kāryaṃ tatsaṃyuktañcānyadakāryaṃ tayoḥ saṃyogaja iti / tatra cirotpannasyodāharaṇaṃ vibhāgajavibhāgāvasare vakṣyamāṇamityutpannamātrasya vibhāgadvāreṇodāharaṇamāha sa caikasmāt ityādi / sa ca saṃyogajasaṃyogaḥ / ekasmād dvābhyāṃ bahubhyaśca / ca śabdādekasmād dvau iti vibhāgaḥ /
analyzed: saṃgraha ukteḥ vivaraṇam āha kāraṇa akāraṇa saṃyoga pūrvakaḥ kārya akārya gataḥ saṃyogaḥ iti kāraṇam atra samavāyi kāraṇam sva kāryasya tad apekṣayā anyat akāraṇam tayoḥ yaḥ saṃyogaḥ tad pūrvakaḥ kārya akārya gataḥ saṃyogaḥ prakṛtasya kāraṇasya yat kāryam tat saṃyuktam ca anyat akāryam tayoḥ saṃyoga jaḥ iti tatra cira utpannasya udāharaṇam vibhāga ja vibhāga avasare vakṣyamāṇam iti utpanna mātrasya vibhāga dvāreṇa udā
translated: The author explains the statement in the Sāṃkhyakārikā by saying: The conjunction of effect and non-effect is preceded by the conjunction of cause and non-cause. Here, the cause is the inherent cause. That which is not a cause in relation to its own effect is a non-cause. The conjunction of those two is preceded by the conjunction of effect and non-effect. The conjunction of that which is conjoined with the effect of the original cause and that which is not an effect is produced by the conjunction. And the example of that which arises after a long time will be stated at the time of the disjunction produced by disjunction. Thus, the example of that which arises merely is stated through the door of disjunction. He says And that is from one, from two, from many. And that conjunction produced by conjunction is from one, from two, from many. From the word ca (and), the disjunction is from one, two.

original: ekasmāttāvat tantuvīraṇasaṃyogāt dvitantukavīraṇasaṃyogaḥ iti / tathā hi / tantorvīraṇena saṃsṛṣṭasya tantvantareṇābhisambandhe sati dvitantukamutpadyate / tasya ca rūpādyutpattisamakālaṃ vīraṇena saṃyogo janyata iti tadutpattāvasamavāyikāraṇamanveṣaṇīyam / na cātra kriyā sambhavati / ubhayorniṣkriyatvāt / rūpādīnāñca svakāryotpattāveva sāmarthyāvadhāraṇāt / II / asamavāyikāraṇañca vinā vastubhūtasya kāryasyotpattirnopalabdheti tantuvīraṇasaṃyoga eva samānajātīyatve sati pratyāsannatvādasamavāyikāraṇamiti / pratyāsattistu kāryaikārthasamavāyaḥ kāraṇaikārthasamavāyaścetyubhayarūpā na sambhavatyeveti / kāryaikārthasamavāyasyaiva grahaṇaṃ kāraṇenāvyavadhānāditi kecit / mahatī tu yatra kāraṇavṛttīnāmeva kārye guṇārambhakatvaṃ tatraiva grāhyeti /
analyzed: ekasmāt tāvat tantu vīraṇa saṃyogāt dvi tantuka vīraṇa saṃyogaḥ iti tathā hi tantoḥ vīraṇena saṃsṛṣṭasya tantu antareṇa abhisambandhe sati dvi tantukam utpadyate tasya ca rūpa ādi utpatti sama kālam vīraṇena saṃyogaḥ janyate iti tad utpattau asamavāyi kāraṇam anveṣaṇīyam na ca atra kriyā sambhavati ubhayoḥ niṣkriya tvāt rūpa ādīnām ca sva kārya utpattau eva sāmarthya avadhāraṇāt    asamavāyi kāraṇam ca vinā vastu bhūtasya kāryasya utp
translated: From one conjunction of thread and grass, there is a conjunction of two threads and grass. For when a thread conjoined with grass is connected with another thread, a two-threaded [cloth] is produced. And at the same time as the production of its form and so on, a conjunction with grass is produced. So in its production, an inherent cause must be sought. And here, action is not possible, because both [thread and grass] are inactive, and because the capacity of form and so on is determined only in the production of its own effect. And because the production of an existent effect is not observed without an inherent cause, the conjunction of thread and grass itself is the inherent cause, being of the same kind and being proximate. But proximity is of two kinds: inherence in the same object as the effect and inherence in the same object as the cause. Some say that only the former is grasped, because there is no obstruction by the cause. But in a case where the cause is large,

original: na caikasyārambhakatve guṇāśca guṇāntaramārabhante vai / sū / / / / iti sūtravirodhaḥ / kāraṇavṛttīnāṃ samānajātyārambhakatvameva niyamāt / tathā hi / ye kāraṇavṛttayaḥ samānajātīyamevārabhante teṣāmanekatvasaṃkhyāyuktānāmevārambhakatvamiti niyamaḥ / tadevaṃ dvitantukavīraṇayoḥ samavāyikāraṇatvam / tantuvīraṇasaṃyogasyāsamavāyikāraṇatvam / śeṣaṃ nimittakāraṇamiti /
analyzed: na ca ekasya ārambhaka tve guṇāḥ ca guṇa antaram ārabhante vai iti sūtra virodhaḥ kāraṇa vṛttīnām samāna jāti ārambhaka tvam eva niyamāt tathā hi ye kāraṇa vṛttayaḥ samāna jātīyam eva ārabhante teṣām aneka tva saṃkhyā yuktānām eva ārambhaka tvam iti niyamaḥ tat evam dvi tantuka vīraṇayoḥ samavāyi kāraṇa tvam tantu vīraṇa saṃyogasya asamavāyi kāraṇa tvam śeṣam nimitta kāraṇam iti
translated: And when one is the cause of origination, the qualities do not produce another quality, which would contradict the sutra. Because it is a rule that only those of the same class that occur in the cause are the cause of origination. Thus, it is a rule that only those qualities that occur in the cause and produce only that of the same class, when they are many in number, are the cause of origination. Thus, the conjunction of the threads and the grass is the inhering cause of the two-threaded cloth and the grass-mat. The conjunction of the threads and the grass is the non-inhering cause. The rest are the instrumental causes.

original: dvitantukavīraṇasaṃyogasyotpattiḥ dvābhyāṃ tantvākāśasaṃyogābhyāmeko dvitantukākāśasaṃyogaḥ iti / tantorākāśasambaddhasya tantvantareṇābhisambandhe sati dvitantukamutpadyate / tantukriyā ca tantvantareṇeva cākāśadeśenāpi saṃyogaṃ karoti / pratibandhakābhāvāt / utpanne tu dvitantuke rūpādyutpattisamakālamākāśenāpi saṃyogo bhavatyeva / kimatra pramāṇamiti cet / anumānam /
analyzed: dvi tantuka vīraṇa saṃyogasya utpattiḥ dvābhyām tantu ākāśa saṃyogābhyām ekaḥ dvi tantuka ākāśa saṃyogaḥ iti tantoḥ ākāśa sambaddhasya tantu antareṇa abhisambandhe sati dvi tantukam utpadyate tantu kriyā ca tantu antareṇa iva ca ākāśa deśena api saṃyogam karoti pratibandhaka abhāvāt utpanne tu dvi tantuke rūpa ādi utpatti sama kālam ākāśena api saṃyogaḥ bhavati eva  kim atra pramāṇam iti ced anumānam
translated: The origin of the conjunction of the two-stringed thread is from the two conjunctions of the string with space, one double-stringed space conjunction. When the string connected with space is connected with another string, the double string is produced. And the action of the string makes contact with the other string as well as with the space region, because there is no obstruction. But when the double string is produced, the contact with space also occurs simultaneously with the production of form and other qualities. If it is asked what is the evidence for this, the answer is inference.

original: tathā hi / dvitantukaṃ svakāraṇasaṃyoginā saṃyujyate / tatsaṃyuktakāraṇakāryatvāt / vīraṇasaṃyuktadvitantukavat / ākāśaṃ vā / svasaṃyuktakāraṇakāryeṇa saṃyujyate / tatkāraṇasaṃyogitvāt / dvitantukasaṃyuktavīraṇavat / siddhe ca saṃyoge tasya kāryatvādutpattikāraṇaṃ cintyam / tatra dvitantukākāśayoḥ samavāyikāraṇatvamiti anyenāsamavāyikāraṇena bhavitavyam / na ca rūpādyutpattisamakālaṃ dvitantuke kriyā sambhavatīti tantvākāśasaṃyogayoḥ samānajātīyatve sati pratyāsannatvādasamavāyikāraṇatvamiti / pratyāsattistūbhayarūpāpi sambhavatīti pūrvavad grāhyā /
analyzed: tathā hi dvi tantukam sva kāraṇa saṃyoginā saṃyujyate tat saṃyukta kāraṇa kārya tvāt vīraṇa saṃyukta dvi tantuka vat  / ākāśam vā sva saṃyukta kāraṇa kāryeṇa saṃyujyate tat kāraṇa saṃyogi tvāt dvi tantuka saṃyukta vīraṇa vat  / siddhe ca saṃyoge tasya kārya tvāt utpatti kāraṇam cintyam tatra dvi tantuka ākāśayoḥ samavāyi kāraṇa tvam iti anyena asamavāyi kāraṇena bhavitavyam na ca rūpa ādi utpatti sama kālam dvi tantuke kriyā sambhavati i
translated: For example, a two-stringed instrument is conjoined with what is conjoined with its cause, because it is the effect of a cause conjoined with that, like a two-stringed instrument conjoined with muñja grass. Or space is conjoined with what is conjoined with itself, because it is conjoined with the cause of that, like muñja grass conjoined with a two-stringed instrument. And when conjunction is established, since it is an effect, its originating cause is to be considered. Others say that in the case of a two-stringed instrument and space, inherence is the inherent cause, so there must be another non-inherent cause. And since action is not possible in a two-stringed instrument at the same time as the production of color, etc., the conjunction of the string and space is the non-inherent cause, because of proximity, given that they are of the same kind. But proximity can be of both kinds, so it should be grasped as before.

original: bahubhyaśca tantuturīsaṃyogebhya ekaḥ paṭaturīsaṃyogaḥ tantūnāṃ turyā saha saṃyoge sati antyatantusaṃyogānantaraṃ paṭa utpadyate / tasya tatpaṭādyutpattisamakālaṃ turyā saha saṃyogo gṛhyate ityutpattikāraṇaṃ vācyam / tatra paṭaturyoḥ II / samavāyikāraṇatvamanyasyāsamavāyikāraṇasyānupalabdhestantuturīsaṃyogānāmasamavāyikāraṇatvam / pratyāsattistu pūrvavad vācyeti /
analyzed: bahubhyaḥ ca tantu turī saṃyogebhyaḥ ekaḥ paṭa turī saṃyogaḥ tantūnām turyā saha saṃyoge sati antya tantu saṃyoga anantaram paṭaḥ utpadyate tasya tad paṭa ādi utpatti samakālam turyā saha saṃyogaḥ gṛhyate iti utpatti kāraṇam vācyam tatra paṭa turyoḥ samavāyi kāraṇa tvam anyasya asamavāyi kāraṇasya anupalabdheḥ tantu turī saṃyogānām asamavāyi kāraṇa tvam pratyāsattiḥ tu pūrvavat vācyā iti
translated: And from many conjunctions of threads and shuttle, there is one conjunction of cloth and shuttle. When the threads are in conjunction with the shuttle, after the conjunction with the last thread, the cloth is produced. At the time of the production of that cloth, the conjunction with the shuttle is perceived. Therefore, the cause of production should be stated. There, the cloth and shuttle have the nature of inherent cause. The nature of non-inherent cause is not perceived for anything else. Therefore, the conjunctions of threads and shuttle have the nature of non-inherent cause. The proximity should be stated as before.

original: nanu cāyuktametat / tantūnāṃ paṭotpattāvakāraṇatvāt / kāraṇākāraṇasaṃyogapūrvakaśca kāryākāryagataḥ saṃyogaḥ saṃyogaja iti tantostantvantareṇābhisambandhe sati dvitantukamutpadyate / punastantvantareṇābhisambandhe 'nyat kāryam ityanekakāryavyavadhānena paṭotpatteḥ kathaṃ tantūnāṃ paṭotpattau kāraṇatvam / na / ārabdhakāryasyaiva sahakāryantaraprāptāvārambhakatve sati ārabhyārambhakavādaḥ syāt / tatra ca mūrtānāṃ samānāsamānadeśatvam / tathā hi / tantubhyāmārabdhaṃ tantvorvartate / punaranyasahitābhyāmārabdhaṃ tayostatra cetyevamuttarottareṣvapyūhyam /
analyzed: nanu ca ayuktam etat tantūnām paṭa utpattau akāraṇa tvāt kāraṇa akāraṇa saṃyoga pūrvakaḥ ca kārya akārya gataḥ saṃyogaḥ saṃyoga jaḥ iti tantoḥ tantu antareṇa abhisambandhe sati dvi tantukam utpadyate punar tantu antareṇa abhisambandhe kāryam iti aneka kārya vyavadhānena paṭa utpatteḥ katham tantūnām paṭa utpattau kāraṇa tvam na ārabdha kāryasya eva sahakāri antara prāptau ārambhaka tve sati ārabhya ārambhaka vādaḥ syāt tatra ca mūrtānām samā
translated: But this is improper, because the threads are not the cause of the cloth's production. And the conjunction between the effect and the non-effect is preceded by the conjunction of the cause and the non-cause. The conjunction born of conjunction arises when the threads are connected with another thread, producing the two-threaded cloth. Then, when connected with another thread, another effect arises. Thus, with the obstruction of many effects, how can the threads be the cause of the cloth's production? No. If the commenced effect itself becomes the cause of production when it obtains another cooperating factor, then there would be the doctrine of the cause being commenced. And in that case, the material things would have the same or different locations. Thus, what is commenced by the two threads exists in the threads. Then, what is commenced by the two [threads] together with another exists in them. Thus, it should be inferred in the subsequent [cases] as well.

original: athānyasahitābhyāmārabdhamekasminneva vartata ityekadravyavṛttitvaṃ syāt / iha tantuṣu paṭaḥ iti pratyayābhāvaśca / tadvināśe cāvāntarakāryānupalambhaḥ / śeṣañca ārabhyārambhakavāde dūṣaṇaṃ pṛthivyadhikāre jñeyam / tasmād vyomādisambandhādavayavakriyādvāreṇāvāntarakāryavināśe tantvantarābhisambandhakālamavasthitasaṃyogāstantavaḥ punaḥ kāryāntaramārabhanta ityeṣa nyāyastāvad yāvadantyatantusaṃyogāt paṭotpattiriti /
analyzed: atha anya sahitābhyām ārabdham ekasmin eva vartate iti eka dravya vṛtti tvam syāt iha tantuṣu paṭaḥ iti pratyaya abhāvaḥ ca tad vināśe ca avāntara kārya anupalambhaḥ śeṣaḥ ca ārabhya ārambhaka vāde dūṣaṇam pṛthivī adhikāre jñeyam tasmāt vyoma ādi sambandhāt avayava kriyā dvāreṇa avāntara kārya vināśe tantu antara abhisambandha kālam avasthita saṃyogāḥ tantavaḥ punar kārya antaram ārabhante iti eṣa nyāyaḥ tāvat yāvat antya tantu saṃyogāt
translated: If, on the other hand, it is held that the cloth is produced by the two threads taken together, then it would be present in a single substance, and there would be no such cognition as ‘the cloth in these threads’, and there would be no perception of any intermediate product in the process. The rest of the objections against the theory of the ‘production of the effect out of the constituent cause’ should be understood to apply here also, under the chapter on ‘earth’. From all this it follows that the threads, which continue to exist along with the intervening spaces, continue to exist as associated with other threads, and they go on producing other effects, until the last thread has been brought together, and the cloth has been produced.

original: na cāvāntarakāryotpattivaiyarthyam / tadantareṇābhipretakāryānutpatteḥ / yathā hi / viśiṣṭasthānaprāptirnāvāntarasthānaprāptiṃ vinā sampadyata ityakāraṇatve 'pi tatsadbhāvaḥ / tadvadavāntarakāryaṃ vinābhipretakāryaṃ na sampadyata iti / tasmāt tatsadbhāvo 'bhyupagantavyaḥ / kāraṇatvantu niṣidhyate tadapāye 'pyutpatterityalam /
analyzed: na ca avāntara kārya utpatti vaiyarthyam tad antareṇa abhipreta kārya anutpatteḥ yathā hi viśiṣṭa sthāna prāptiḥ na avāntara sthāna prāptim vinā sampadyate iti akāraṇa tve pi tad sadbhāvaḥ tadvat avāntara kāryam vinā abhipreta kāryam na sampadyate iti tasmāt tad sadbhāvaḥ bhyupagantavyaḥ kāraṇa tvantu niṣidhyate tad apāye pi utpatteḥ iti alam
translated: And there is no uselessness of the production of the intermediate effect, because the intended effect does not arise without it. Just as the attainment of a specific place does not occur without the attainment of the intermediate places, so the intended effect does not occur without the intermediate effect, even though it is not the cause. Therefore, its existence must be accepted. But causality is denied, because it arises even when that is absent. Thus far.

original: ekasmācca dvayorutpattiḥ / katham / yadā pārthivāpyayoraṇvoḥ saṃyoge satyanyena pārthivena pārthivasya anyenāpyena cāpyasya yugapat saṃyogau bhavatastadā tābhyāṃ saṃyogābhyāṃ pārthivāpye dvyaṇuke yugapadārabhyete / tato yasmin kāle dvyaṇukayoḥ kāraṇaguṇapūrvakrameṇa rūpādyutpattistasminneva kāle itaretarakāraṇākāraṇagatāt saṃyogāditaretarakāryākāryagatau II / saṃyogau yugapadutpadyete / kiṃ kāraṇam / kāraṇasaṃyoginā hi akāraṇena kāryamavaśyaṃ saṃyujyata iti nyāyaḥ / ataḥ pārthivadvyaṇukaṃ kāraṇasaṃyoginā āpyenāṇunā sambadhyate / āpyamapi dvyaṇukaṃ kāraṇasaṃyoginā pārthiveneti / atha dvyaṇukayoritaretarakāraṇākāraṇasambaddhayoḥ kathaṃ parasparataḥ sambandha iti / tayorapi saṃyogajābhyāṃ saṃyogābhyāṃ sambandha iti /PDhS
analyzed: ekasmāt ca dvayoḥ utpattiḥ katham yadā pārthiva āpyayoḥ aṇvoḥ saṃyoge sati anyena pārthivena pārthivasya anyena āpyena ca apyasya yugapad saṃyogau bhavataḥ tadā tābhyām saṃyogābhyām pārthiva āpye dvyaṇuke yugapad ārabhyete tatas yasmin kāle dvyaṇukayoḥ kāraṇa guṇa pūrva krameṇa rūpa ādi utpattiḥ tasmin eva kāle itaretara kāraṇa akāraṇa gatāt saṃyogāt itaretara kārya akārya gatau saṃyogau yugapad utpadyete  / kim kāraṇam kāraṇa saṃyo
translated: And the origination of two from one. How? When there is a conjunction of earth and water atoms, simultaneously with that, there are two other conjunctions - one of the earth atom with another earth atom, and one of the water atom with another water atom. Then, at the same time as the origination of the two dyads of earth and water from those two conjunctions, in the same moment as the origination of color etc. in the dyads in the order of the qualities of the causes, simultaneously arise the two conjunctions in the effects and causes respectively, from the conjunction in the causes and effects respectively. What is the reason? It is the rule that the effect must be conjoined with the non-cause that is conjoined with the cause. Therefore, the earth dyad is connected with the water atom that is the cause-conjoined, and the water dyad is also connected with the earth atom that is the cause-conjoined. Now, how is there mutual connection between the two dyads that are connected with each other as cause and effect? Their mutual connection is by the two conjunctions born of the conjunctions in the causes and effects.

original: athaikasmāt saṃyogād dvayoḥ saṃyogayorutpattiḥ kathamityāha yadā pārthivāpyayoraṇvoḥ saṃyoge satyanyena pārthivena paramāṇunā saha pārthivasya / anyena āpyena cāpyasya yugapat saṃyogau bhavatastadā tābhyāṃ samānajātīyadravyasambandhāt pārthivāpye dvyaṇuke yugapadārabhyete / tato dvyaṇukotpādānantaraṃ yasminneva kāle kāraṇaguṇapūrvaprakrameṇa dvyaṇukayo rūpādyutpattiḥ tasminneva kāle itaretarakāraṇākāraṇagatāt saṃyogāditaretarakāryākāryagatau saṃyogau yugapadutpadyete / itaraḥ paramāṇuḥ kāraṇaṃ svakāryasya / itaro 'kāraṇaṃ tadapekṣayā / evamanyo 'pīti / tadgatāt tatsamavetāt saṃyogāditaretarakāryākāryagatau / itarat pārthivaṃ dvyaṇukaṃ kāryaṃ svakāraṇasya / itaraścāpyaparamāṇurakāryaḥ / tathetaradāpyaṃ dvyaṇukaṃ kāryamitaraśca pārthivaparamāṇurakāryaḥ / tadgatau saṃyogau yugapadutpadyete / tatra ca dvyaṇukaparamāṇvoḥ samavāyikāraṇatvamiti anyadasamavāyikāraṇaṃ cintyam / na cātra kriyā sambhavati / ubhayorniṣkriyatvāditi paramāṇvoḥ saṃyogaḥ pratyāsannatve sati sāmarthyāvadhāraṇāt kāraṇamiti /
analyzed: atha ekasmāt saṃyogāt dvayoḥ saṃyogayoḥ utpattiḥ katham iti āha yadā pārthiva āpyayoḥ aṇvoḥ saṃyoge sati anyena pārthivena paramāṇunā saha pārthivasya anyena āpyena ca apyasya yugapad saṃyogau bhavataḥ tadā tābhyām samāna jātīya dravya sambandhāt pārthiva āpye dvyaṇuke yugapad ārabhyete tatas dvyaṇuka utpāda anantaram yasmin eva kāle kāraṇa guṇa pūrva prakrameṇa dvyaṇukayoḥ rūpa ādi utpattiḥ tasmin eva kāle itaretara kāraṇa akāraṇa g
translated: Now, if the production of two conjunctions occurs from one conjunction, how is it? He says: When there is a conjunction of earth and water atoms, then the earth atom has a conjunction with another earth atom simultaneously, and the water atom has a conjunction with another water atom. At that time, the earth and water dyads are produced simultaneously due to the connection with substances of the same kind. Then, immediately after the production of the dyads, at the very same time as the production of color etc. in the dyads according to the previously stated rule of the qualities of the causes, the two conjunctions occurring in the effects and non-effects produced from the conjunction occurring in the causes and non-causes arise simultaneously. The other atom is the cause of its own effect, and the other is not the cause in relation to that. The same is true of the other one. Occurring in the effects and non-effects produced from the conjunction inhering in that, i.e., the earth dyad is the effect of its own cause, and the other water atom is not the effect. The same is true of the other one.

original: atha pārthivadvyaṇukasya āpyenāṇunā saṃyogaḥ / tathā āpyasya pāthiveneti kiṃ kāraṇam / kiṃ pramāṇamityāha kāraṇasaṃyoginā hi akāraṇena kāryamavaśyaṃ saṃyujyata iti nyāyaḥ pramāṇam / tathā hi / pārthivadvyaṇukaṃ svakāraṇasaṃyoginā saṃyujyate / tatsaṃyuktakāraṇakāryatvāt / vīraṇasaṃyuktadvitantukavat / āpyo vā paramāṇuḥ svasaṃyuktakāraṇakāryeṇa saṃyujyate / tatkāraṇasaṃyogitvāt / dvitantukasaṃyuktavīraṇavat / evamitaratrāpi vācyam / yata evamataḥ pārthivadvyaṇukaṃ svakāraṇasaṃyoginā āpyenāṇunā sambadhyate / āpyamapi dvyaṇukaṃ pārthiveneti /
analyzed: atha pārthiva dvyaṇukasya āpyena aṇunā saṃyogaḥ tathā āpyasya pāthivena iti kim kāraṇam kim pramāṇam iti āha kāraṇa saṃyoginā hi akāraṇena kāryam avaśyam saṃyujyate iti nyāyaḥ pramāṇam tathā hi pārthiva dvyaṇukam sva kāraṇa saṃyoginā saṃyujyate tat saṃyukta kāraṇa kārya tvāt vīraṇa saṃyukta dvi tantuka vat  āpyaḥ vā paramāṇuḥ sva saṃyukta kāraṇa kāryeṇa saṃyujyate tat kāraṇa saṃyogi tvāt dvi tantuka saṃyukta vīraṇ
translated: Now, if there is conjunction of the earth dyad with the watery atom, and similarly of the watery one with the earthy one, what is the reason? What is the evidence? He says: The principle that an effect must necessarily be conjoined with a non-cause that is conjoined with a cause is the evidence. Thus, the earthy dyad is conjoined with the watery atom that is conjoined with its cause, because it is an effect whose cause is conjoined with that, like the dyad conjoined with the virana. Or the watery atom is conjoined with the effect whose cause is conjoined with itself, because it is conjoined with the cause of that, like the virana conjoined with the dyad. The same should be said in the other case also. Since this is so, therefore the earthy dyad is connected with the watery atom that is conjoined with its cause, and the watery dyad is also with the earthy one.

original: atha dvyaṇukayoritaretarakāraṇākāraṇasambaddhayoḥ iti / itarasya pārthivadvyaṇukasya yat kāraṇam taditarasyākāraṇam / evamāpyadvyaṇukasya kāraṇamitarasya pārthivadvyaṇukasyākāraṇam / tatsambaddhayordvyaṇukayoḥ parasparataḥ kathaṃ sambandha ityāha tayorapi saṃyogajābhyāṃ saṃyogābhyāṃ sambandhaḥ iti / yau tau kāryākāryagatau saṃyogāvekasmāt saṃyogādutpannau tābhyām / dvyaṇukayoḥ samavāyikāraṇatvam / kāryākāryasaṃyogayoścāsamavāyikāraṇatvam / pratyāsasattistu ubhayarūpāpi sambhavatīti pūrvavad grāhyā / adṛṣṭādiśca nimittakāraṇamiti /
analyzed: atha dvyaṇukayoḥ itaretara kāraṇa akāraṇa sambaddhayoḥ iti itarasya pārthiva dvyaṇukasya yat kāraṇam tat itarasya akāraṇam evam āpya dvyaṇukasya kāraṇam itarasya pārthiva dvyaṇukasya akāraṇam tad sambaddhayoḥ dvyaṇukayoḥ parasparataḥ katham sambandhaḥ iti āha tayoḥ api saṃyoga jābhyām saṃyogābhyām sambandhaḥ iti yau tau kārya akārya gatau saṃyogau ekasmāt saṃyogāt utpannau tābhyām dvyaṇukayoḥ samavāyi kāraṇa tvam kārya akārya saṃ
translated: Now, if it is said that the two dyads are connected by the relation of cause and effect, then the cause of the other, i.e., the earthen dyad, is not the cause of the other. Similarly, the cause of the watery dyad is not the cause of the earthen dyad. How is there mutual connection between the two dyads connected in this way? It is said that they are connected by two conjunctions born of conjunction. The two conjunctions present in the effect and the cause, which are produced from one conjunction, are the inherent causes of the two dyads. And the conjunctions of the effect and the cause are the non-inherent causes. The proximity, however, may be of both types, as before. The unseen and other factors are the instrumental causes.

original: na ca dvyaṇukasya svakāraṇasaṃyoginā paramāṇvantareṇa dvyaṇukāntareṇāpi rūpādyutpattisamakālamekasmādeva kāraṇākāraṇasaṃyogāt saṃyogo bhaviṣyatīti vācyam / tasmin kāle dvyaṇukasya kāraṇasaṃyogitvābhāvāt / kāraṇasaṃyoginā cāpyakāryeṇa saṃyogaḥ saṃyogaja iti / tasmādāpyadvyaṇukasya pārthivena paramāṇunā saṃyogaḥ pārthivasya cāpyeneti pūrvamevābhidheyam / yena kāraṇasaṃyogitvād dvyaṇukayorapi saṃyogaḥ saṃyogajo bhavatīti /
analyzed: na ca dvyaṇukasya sva kāraṇa saṃyoginā paramāṇu antareṇa dvyaṇuka antareṇa api rūpa ādi utpatti sama kālam ekasmāt eva kāraṇa akāraṇa saṃyogāt saṃyogaḥ bhaviṣyati iti vācyam tasmin kāle dvyaṇukasya kāraṇa saṃyogi tva abhāvāt kāraṇa saṃyoginā ca api akāryeṇa saṃyogaḥ saṃyoga jaḥ iti tasmāt āpya dvyaṇukasya pārthivena paramāṇunā saṃyogaḥ pārthivasya ca apyena iti pūrvam eva abhidheyam yena kāraṇa saṃyogi tvāt dvyaṇukayoḥ
translated: And it cannot be said that the dyad, at the very time of the production of color etc. from the other atom which is conjoined with its own cause, will have conjunction with that very cause and non-cause from a single conjunction. Because at that time the dyad does not have the nature of being conjoined with its cause, and conjunction with a non-effect which is conjoined with the cause is not produced by conjunction. Therefore, it was previously stated that the dyad of water is conjoined with the atom of earth, and the atom of earth is conjoined with that of water, by which the conjunction of the two dyads also becomes produced by conjunction due to their having the nature of being conjoined with the cause.

original: nājaḥ saṃyoge 'sti / nityaparimaṇḍalavat pṛthaganabhidhānāt / yathā caturvidhaṃ parimāṇamutpādyamuktvā āha nityaṃ pārimāṇḍalyam ityevamanyatarakarmajādisaṃyogamutpādyamuktvā pṛthaṅ nityaṃ brūyān na tvevamabravīt / tasmānnāstyajaḥ saṃyogaḥ / paramāṇubhirākāśādīnāṃ pradeśavṛttiranyatarakarmajaḥ saṃyogaḥ / vibhūnāntu parasparataḥ saṃyogo nāsti yutasiddhyabhāvāt / sā punardvayoranyatarasya vā pṛthaggatimattvaṃ yutāśrayasamavāyitvañceti /PDhS
analyzed: na ajaḥ saṃyoge sti nitya parimaṇḍala vat pṛthak anabhidhānāt yathā caturvidham parimāṇam utpādyam uktvā āha nityam pārimāṇḍalyam iti evam anyatara karma ja ādi saṃyogam utpādyam uktvā pṛthak nityam brūyāt na tu evam abravīt tasmāt na asti ajaḥ saṃyogaḥ paramāṇubhiḥ ākāśa ādīnām pradeśa vṛttiḥ anyatara karma jaḥ saṃyogaḥ  / vibhūnām tu parasparataḥ saṃyogaḥ na asti yuta siddhi abhāvāt sā punar dvayoḥ anyatarasya vā pṛthak gatim
translated: There is no conjunction of the eternal. Like the eternal and circular [atoms], it is not mentioned separately. And just as after stating that dimension is of four kinds and is to be produced, it is said that the circular [dimension] is eternal, in the same way, after stating that conjunction produced by the motion of one or the other, etc. is to be produced, it would mention the eternal separately, but it did not mention it in that way. Therefore, there is no eternal conjunction. The conjunction of atoms with space, etc. occurs in a part and is produced by the motion of one or the other. But there is no conjunction between the extended [objects] due to the absence of co-existence. And that is the separate motion of two or one, and the inherence in the same substratum as the motion.

original: idānīṃ vibhāgasūtre 'jasaṃyogānabhidhānānnyūnatvamityāśaṅkya parihārārthamāha nājaḥ saṃyogo 'sti nityaparimaṇḍalavat pṛthaganabhidhānāt / yathā bhagavānṛṣiḥ sakalārthadarśī caturvidhaṃ parimāṇamutpādyamuktvā āha nityaṃ pārimāṇḍalyam paramāṇuparimāṇamastīti evamanyatarakarmajādisaṃyogam trividham / utpādyamuktvā pṛthaṅ nityam saṃyogam / brūyāt / na tvevamaII /bravīt / tasmānnāstyajaḥ saṃyogaḥ / pratijñātañca maharṣiṇā yadbhāvarūpaṃ tatsarvamabhidhāsyāmīti /
analyzed: idānīm vibhāga sūtre ja saṃyoga anabhidhānāt nyūnatvam iti āśaṅkya parihāra artham āha na ajaḥ saṃyogaḥ sti nitya parimaṇḍala vat pṛthak anabhidhānāt yathā bhagavān ṛṣiḥ sakala artha darśī caturvidham parimāṇam utpādyam uktvā āha nityam pārimāṇḍalyam paramāṇu parimāṇam asti iti evam anyatara karma ja ādi saṃyogam trividham utpādyam uktvā pṛthak nityam saṃyogam brūyāt na tasmāt na asti ajaḥ saṃyogaḥ pratijñātam ca mahā ṛṣiṇ
translated: Now, fearing that in the Vibhāga Sūtra, due to the non-mention of the conjunction of the eternal, there would be incompleteness, he says to remove that: There is no eternal conjunction, like the eternal sphericity, due to the non-mention separately. Just as the Blessed Sage, the seer of all things, having said that the four kinds of dimension are to be produced, said that eternal sphericity exists, so also having said that the three kinds of conjunction produced by the action of one or the other, etc. are to be produced, he would have mentioned eternal conjunction separately. But he did not say so. Therefore there is no eternal conjunction. And the great Sage has promised: Whatever exists, I will explain all that.

original: nanu cātra ajaḥ saṃyogo nāstīti pratijñāvākye padayorvyāghātaḥ / yathedañca nāsti ceti / na / anyathā pratijñānāt / tathā hi / paramāṇubhirākāśādīnāṃ saṃyogo nityatvenābhyupagataḥ pareṇa / tasyājatvameva niṣidhyate / na sadbhāvaḥ / paramāṇubhirākāśādīnāṃ saṃyogo 'jo na bhavati / sarvajñena maharṣiṇā ajātatvena pṛthagapratipādyamānatvāt / yacca ajaṃ tadajatvena pṛthagupadiṣṭaṃ yathā nityaṃ pārimāṇḍalyam iti /
analyzed: nanu ca atra ajaḥ saṃyogaḥ na asti iti pratijñā vākye padayoḥ vyāghātaḥ yathā idam ca na asti ca iti na anyathā pratijñānāt tathā hi paramāṇubhiḥ ākāśa ādīnām saṃyogaḥ nitya tvena abhyupagataḥ pareṇa tasya aja tvam eva niṣidhyate na sadbhāvaḥ paramāṇubhiḥ ākāśa ādīnām saṃyogaḥ jaḥ na bhavati sarvajñena mahā ṛṣiṇā ajāta tvena pṛthak apratipādyamāna tvāt yat ca ajam tat aja tvena pṛthak upadiṣṭam yathā nityam pārimāṇḍal
translated: But here, in the proposition that there is no eternal conjunction, there is a contradiction between the words, like in this is not and that is not. No, because the proposition is different. For thus, the other party has accepted the conjunction of atoms with space etc. as eternal. Only its non-eternality is being denied, not its existence. The conjunction of atoms with space etc. is not eternal, because it is not separately taught by the omniscient great sage as non-eternal, like the eternal circularity.

original: atha saṃyogasyāprāptivirodhitvam / tattu na sambhavatyeva / ākāśādervibhutvena tatparityāgānupapatteḥ / na cāśrayavināśād vināśo 'tra / āśrayasyāpi nityatvāt / na cānyad vināśakāraṇamastītyajatvameva / avacanantu vyāmohādapi sambhavatītyanyathāsiddham / asya pratiṣedhārthamāha paramāṇubhirākāśādīnāṃ pradeśavṛttiranyatarakarmajaḥ saṃyogaḥ iti / kathamākāśāparityāgena paramāṇoḥ saṃyogā vibhāgāśca bhavantīti cet / yathā vṛkṣāparityāgena devadattasya / tathā hi / mūlapradeśādūrdhvapradeśamārohataḥ puruṣasya vṛkṣāparityāgenaiva saṃyogā vibhāgāścopalabhyante / mūlapradeśe vṛkṣeṇa saṃyuktaḥ / madhyapradeśe / agrapradeśe ceti / na ca pradeśasyaiva te saṃyogāḥ / vṛkṣeṇa saṃyuktaḥ iti pratyayopalambhāt / pradeśenaiva saṃyoge pradeśena saṃyukto na vṛkṣeṇa iti jñānaṃ syāt / na caitadasti / vṛkṣeṇa saṃyuktaḥ iti jñānasya sarvasyāmavasthāyāmupalabdheḥ /
analyzed: atha saṃyogasya aprāpti virodhi tvam tat tu na sambhavati eva ākāśa ādeḥ vibhu tvena tad parityāga anupapatteḥ na ca āśraya vināśāt āśrayasya api nitya tvāt na ca anyat vināśa kāraṇam asti iti ajatvam eva avacanam tu vyāmohāt api sambhavati iti anyathāsiddham asya pratiṣedha artham āha paramāṇubhiḥ ākāśa ādīnām pradeśa vṛttiḥ anyatara karma jaḥ saṃyogaḥ iti katham ākāśa aparityāgena paramāṇoḥ saṃyogāḥ vibhāgāḥ ca bhavanti iti ced yathā
translated: Now, if conjunction is opposed to non-contact, that is not possible at all, because space and so on are all-pervading, and it is not possible to abandon them. And here there is no destruction due to the destruction of the substratum, because the substratum is also eternal. And there is no other cause of destruction, so it is eternal. But the absence of statement can also occur due to delusion, so it is not established otherwise. For the purpose of refuting this, he says: The conjunction of atoms with space and so on occurs in a part, produced by the action of one of them. If it is asked how conjunctions and disjunctions of atoms occur without abandoning space, it is like Devadatta's without abandoning the tree. For thus, when a person ascends from the root region to the upper region, conjunctions and disjunctions are observed without abandoning the tree. He is conjoined with the tree in the root region, in the middle region, and in the tip region. And those conjunctions are not of the part itself. The notion he is conjoined with the tree is observed.

original: yadi ca saṃyogasya pradeśavṛttitvāt pradeśenaiva saṃyogo na vṛkṣeṇeti / tarhi te 'pi pradeśāḥ svāvayavāpekṣayā avayavina iti tatpradeśānāṃ saṃyogaḥ / teṣāmapyavayavitvāt pradeśānāmiti tāvad yāvannirdeśāḥ paramāṇavaḥ / teṣāñca niṣpradeśatvāt saṃyogābhāvena dvyaṇukādiprakrameṇa kāryamiti kṣityāderasambhava eva /
analyzed: yadi ca saṃyogasya pradeśa vṛtti tvāt pradeśena eva saṃyogaḥ na vṛkṣeṇa iti tarhi te pi pradeśāḥ sva avayava apekṣayā avayavinaḥ iti tad pradeśānām saṃyogaḥ teṣām api avayavi tvāt pradeśānām iti tāvat yāvat nirdeśāḥ paramāṇavaḥ teṣām ca niṣpradeśa tvāt saṃyoga abhāvena dvi aṇuka ādi prakrameṇa kāryam iti kṣiti ādeḥ asambhavaḥ eva
translated: And if conjunction belongs only to the parts because it occurs in the parts, not in the tree, then those parts also are wholes in relation to their own parts, so the conjunction is of the parts of those [parts]. And because those [parts] are also wholes, the parts are as many as the directions, and those [parts] are atoms because they are partless. And because they are partless, there is no conjunction, so the effect in the sequence beginning with dyads is impossible, and thus earth and so on are impossible.

original: atha niṣpradeśatve 'pi sati paramāṇūnāṃ pradeśatvād iṣyata eva saṃyogastarhi dvyaṇukānāṃ saṃyogābhāve na tryaṇukamiti dūṣaṇaṃ tadavasthameva / na ca paramāṇuṣu vartamānaḥ saṃyogo dvyaṇukādisamavetaṃ dravyamārabhate / vyadhikaraṇasyārambhakatveII /'tiprasaṅgāt / tasmāt saṃyogasya pradeśavṛttitvamāśrayāvyāpakatvamityavayavenāvayavinā ca saṃyogo ghaṭata eva /
analyzed: atha niṣpradeśa tve sati paramāṇūnām pradeśa tvāt iṣyate eva saṃyogaḥ tarhi dvyaṇukānām saṃyoga abhāve na tryaṇukam iti dūṣaṇam tad avastham eva na ca paramāṇuṣu vartamānaḥ saṃyogaḥ dvyaṇuka ādi samavetam dravyam ārabhate    tasmāt saṃyogasya pradeśa vṛtti tvam āśraya avyāpaka tvam iti avayavena avayavinā ca saṃyogaḥ ghaṭate eva
translated: But if conjunction is accepted even when the atoms are partless because they have parts, then the criticism that the triads do not exist due to the absence of conjunction of the dyads remains the same. And the conjunction residing in the atoms does not produce the substance inhering in the dyads and so on, because there would be the fallacy of that which is not the substratum being a cause. Therefore, the fact that conjunction belongs to the parts because it does not pervade the substratum, the conjunction of the parts with the whole is possible.

original: na ca prāktanasya mūlapradeśe vṛkṣeṇa saṃyogasyāvasthāne satyuttarasaṃyogena śakyaṃ bhavitumiti tadvināśako vibhāgo 'pi siddhaḥ / yathā cātra vṛkṣāparityāgenaiva puruṣasyānyatarakarmajāḥ saṃyogā vibhāgāśca bhavanti tadvadākāśāparityāgenaiva paramāṇoḥ saṃyogā vibhāgāśca bhaviṣyantīti vyāpakatvamatantram /
analyzed: na ca prāktanasya mūla pradeśe vṛkṣeṇa saṃyogasya avasthāne sati uttara saṃyogena śakyam bhavitum iti tad vināśakaḥ siddhaḥ yathā ca atra vṛkṣa a parityāgena eva puruṣasya anyatara karma jāḥ saṃyogāḥ vibhāgāḥ ca bhavanti tadvat ākāśa a parityāgena eva paramāṇoḥ saṃyogāḥ vibhāgāḥ ca bhaviṣyanti iti vyāpaka tvam atantram
translated: And when the prior conjunction of the root-portion with the tree remains, it is not possible for the subsequent conjunction to occur, so the disjunction that destroys it is also established. And just as for the person, the conjunctions and disjunctions are produced by the action of either one without abandoning the tree, in the same way, for the atom, the conjunctions and disjunctions will occur without abandoning space, so the pervasiveness is irrelevant.

original: tadevaṃ paramāṇvākāśādisaṃyogasyotpattivināśakāraṇopapatternājatvamiti / yacca sūtrakārasyāvacanaṃ vyāmohādapi sambhavatītyuktam / tadasat / tadabhihitānāṃ padārthānāṃ pramāṇāntareṇāpi tathābhāvopalabdheḥ samyagjñānasiddhau tadviruddhasya mithyājñānasya nivṛtteḥ /
analyzed: tat evam paramāṇu ākāśa ādi saṃyogasya utpatti vināśa kāraṇa upapatteḥ na aja tvam iti  yat ca sūtrakārasya avacanam vyāmohāt api sambhavati iti uktam tat asat tad abhihitānām padārthānām pramāṇa antareṇa api tathā bhāva upalabdheḥ samyak jñāna siddhau tad viruddhasya mithyājñānasya nivṛtteḥ
translated: Thus, since the origination and destruction of the conjunction of the atom, space, etc. are possible, they are not eternal. And what was said that the author of the aphorisms' silence may be due to delusion, that is wrong. Because the existence of those things mentioned by him is perceived by other means of knowledge also, and when right knowledge is established, the contradictory false knowledge ceases.

original: atha vibhūnāṃ parasparataḥ saṃyogo bhaviṣyatīti / tathā hyākāśam ātmādinā saṃyujyate / mūrtasaṃyogitvāt / ghaṭavat / asya pratiṣedhārthamāha vibhūnāntu parasparataḥ saṃyogo nāsti / yutasiddhyabhāvāt / yatra yatra saṃyogastatra tatra yutasiddhirupalabdhā / sā ca saṃyogasya vyāpikā vyāvartamānā svavyāptaṃ saṃyogaṃ gṛhītvā vyāvartata ityanyathāsiddhaṃ sādhanam /
analyzed: atha vibhūnām parasparataḥ saṃyogaḥ bhaviṣyati iti tathā hi ākāśam ātma ādinā saṃyujyate mūrta saṃyogi tvāt ghaṭa vat asya pratiṣedha artham āha vibhūnām tu parasparataḥ saṃyogaḥ na asti yuta siddhi abhāvāt yatra yatra saṃyogaḥ tatra tatra yuta siddhiḥ upalabdhā sā ca saṃyogasya vyāpikā vyāvartamānā sva vyāptam saṃyogam gṛhītvā vyāvartate iti anyathāsiddham sādhanam
translated: If you say that there is mutual conjunction of the all-pervading substances, then space would be in conjunction with the soul etc., because it is in conjunction with the corporeal substances, like a pot. To refute this, he says: There is no mutual conjunction of the all-pervading substances, because of the absence of yutasiddhi. Wherever there is conjunction, there yutasiddhi is observed. And that, being the pervasion of conjunction, excludes itself by taking along with it the conjunction that is its pervasion. Thus the reason is otherwise established.

original: sā punaḥ yutasiddhiḥ / dvayoranyatarasya vā pṛthaggatimattvaṃ yutāśrayasamavāyitvañceti / dvayoḥ pṛthaggatimattvamanyatarasya veti / iyaṃ nityānāṃ yutasiddhiḥ / dvayoryutāśrayasamavāyitvamanyatarasya veti / anityānām / asyāstu vistareṇa vicāro vibhāgāvasare draṣṭavyaḥ / na ca vibhūnāṃ pṛthaggatimattvamamūrtatvāt / yutāśrayasamavāyitvamapi na sambhavatyevākāryatvāditi /
analyzed: sā punar yuta siddhiḥ dvayoḥ anyatarasya vā pṛthak gatimat tvam yuta āśraya samavāyi tvam ca iti  dvayoḥ pṛthak gatimat tvam anyatarasya vā iti iyam nityānām yuta siddhiḥ dvayoḥ yuta āśraya samavāyi tvam anyatarasya vā iti anityānām asyāḥ tu vistareṇa vicāraḥ vibhāga avasare draṣṭavyaḥ na ca vibhūnām pṛthak gatimat tvam amūrta tvāt yuta āśraya samavāyi tvam api na sambhavati eva akārya tvāt iti
translated: And that is conjunction, which is the separate motion of two or one, and the inherence in the same substratum as the conjoined. The separate motion of two or one is the conjunction of the permanent things. The inherence in the same substratum as the conjoined is of the impermanent things. But the detailed discussion of this should be seen at the time of the analysis of inherence. And the separate motion of the extended [objects] is not possible, because they are non-material. And the inherence in the same substratum as the conjoined is also not possible, because they are not effects.

original: saṃyogavināśaprakāraḥ
analyzed: saṃyoga vināśa prakāraḥ
translated: The mode of destruction of conjunction

original: vināśastu sarvasya saṃyogasyaikārthasamavetād vibhāgāt / kvacid āśrayavināśādapi / katham / yadā tantvoḥ saṃyoge satyanyataratantvārambhake 'ṃśau karmotpadyate / tena karmaṇā aṃśvantarād vibhāgaḥ kriyate / vibhāgācca tantvārambhakasaṃyogavināśaḥ / saṃyogavināśāt tantuvināśaḥ / tadvināśe tadāśritasya tantvantarasaṃyogasya vināśa iti /PDhS
analyzed: vināśaḥ tu sarvasya saṃyogasya eka artha samavetāt vibhāgāt kvacid āśraya vināśāt api katham yadā tantvoḥ saṃyoge sati anyatara tantu ārambhake ṃśau karma utpadyate tena karmaṇā aṃśu antarāt vibhāgaḥ kriyate vibhāgāt ca tantu ārambhaka saṃyoga vināśaḥ saṃyoga vināśāt tantu vināśaḥ tad vināśe tad āśritasya tantu antara saṃyogasya vināśaḥ iti pdhs
translated: But the destruction of all conjunction is from disjunction inhering in the same object. In some cases, it is also from the destruction of the substratum. How? And from disjunction, the destruction of the conjunction that causes the thread. From the destruction of the conjunction, the destruction of the thread. From its destruction, the destruction of the conjunction with another thread that inheres in it.

original: vināśasya ca sahetukatvāt kutaḥ saṃyogo vinaśyatītyāha vināśastu sarvasya saṃyogasyaikārthasamavetād vibhāgāt iti / yayoreva saṃyogastayoreva vibhāgāt saṃyogasya vināśaḥ / tena satā tasyānupalabdheḥ / atra kvacidāśrayavināśādapi ityādiḥ tantvārambhakasaṃyogavināśa iti ityantasya praśastapādīyagranthasya vyākhyā na dṛśyate 'to 'numīyate granthaḥ patita iti saṃyogavināśāt tantuvināśaḥ tantuvināśe tadāśritasya tantvantarasaṃyogasya vināśa iti / yadā tantusaṃyogavināśasamakālaṃ tantvantare 'pi karma sambhāvyate tadā āśrayavināśavibhāgābhyāmapi saṃyogasya vināśa iti jñeyam /
analyzed: vināśasya ca sa hetuka tvāt kutas saṃyogaḥ vinaśyati iti āha vināśaḥ tu sarvasya saṃyogasya eka artha samavetāt vibhāgāt iti yayoḥ eva saṃyogaḥ tayoḥ eva vibhāgāt saṃyogasya vināśaḥ tena satā tasya anupalabdheḥ atra kvacid āśraya vināśāt api ityādiḥ tantu ārambhaka saṃyoga vināśaḥ iti ityantasya praśastapādīya granthasya vyākhyā na dṛśyate granthaḥ patitaḥ iti saṃyoga vināśāt tantu vināśaḥ tantu vināśe tad āśritasya tantu antara s
translated: And since destruction has a cause, he says how does conjunction perish? Destruction of all conjunction is from disjunction inhering in the same object. The destruction of conjunction is from the disjunction of only those two between which there is conjunction. Therefore, it is not perceived when it exists. Here, the commentary on the text of Praśastapāda beginning with sometimes also from the destruction of the substratum and ending with the destruction of the conjunction that produces the threads is not seen. Therefore, it is inferred that the text has fallen. From the destruction of conjunction, there is the destruction of the thread. When the thread is destroyed, there is the destruction of the conjunction of the other thread that inheres in it. When action is possible in another thread at the same time as the destruction of the conjunction of the thread, then the destruction of conjunction should be known to be also from the destruction of the substratum and from disjunction.

original: vibhāgavaidharmyam

original: idānīṃ vibhāgasya lakṣaṇaparīkṣaṇārtham vibhāgo vibhaktapratyayanimittam ityādi prakaraṇam / pratītiḥ / pratyayo / jñānam / pratīyate 'neneti pratyayo 'bhidhānam / taddhetutvamanyeṣāmapīti vibhaktagrahaṇam / tathāpyākāśātmabhyāṃ vyabhicāraparihārārthaṃ dravyaviśeṣaṇatve satīti draṣṭavyam / tathā hi / vibhāgaḥ / itarebhyo bhidyate / dravyaviśeṣaṇatve sati vibhaktapratyayanimittatvāt / yastu na bhidyate na cāsāvevam / yathā rūpādiriti / tathā vibhaktapratyayo viśeṣyajñānatvānnarte viśeṣaṇād bhavatīti parīkṣāparaṃ vākyam / na cāsya vāsanāprabhavatvam / tasyāḥ pūrvameva pratiṣedhāt / viraladeśotpādaśca kṣaṇabhaṅganiṣedhādeva niṣiddhaḥ /
analyzed: idānīm vibhāgasya lakṣaṇa parīkṣaṇa artham vibhāgaḥ vibhakta pratyaya nimittam ityādi prakaraṇam pratītiḥ pratyayaḥ jñānam pratīyate nena iti pratyayaḥ bhidhānam tad hetu tvam anyeṣām api iti vibhakta grahaṇam tathā api ākāśa ātmabhyām vyabhicāra parihāra artham dravya viśeṣaṇa tve sati iti draṣṭavyam tathā hi vibhāgaḥ itarebhyaḥ bhidyate dravya viśeṣaṇa tve sati vibhakta pratyaya nimitta tvāt yaḥ tu na bhidyate na ca asau evam yathā rūpa
translated: Now, for the purpose of examining the definition of disjunction, the topic begins with Disjunction is the cause of the notion of disjunction. Pratiti means cognition. Nevertheless, in order to avoid the fallacy of disjunction with space and self, it should be seen as having the nature of qualifying a substance. Thus, disjunction is different from the others, because it is the cause of the notion of disjunction, having the nature of qualifying a substance. But that which is not different is not so, like form etc. Thus, the notion of disjunction does not occur without a qualifier, because it is the knowledge of a qualified object. The sentence is for the purpose of examination. And it is not produced from vāsanā, because that has been refuted earlier. And the production in a scattered place has been refuted by the refutation of momentariness itself.

original: atha saṃyogasyānutpāde vināśe ca vibhaktavyavahārānnānyo vibhāga iti cet / na / vibhāgaṃ vinā saṃyogavināśasyaivābhāvāt / tathā hi guṇānāmāśraya vināśād virodhiguṇaprādurbhāvācca vināśopalabdheḥ / yatrāśrayavināśastatra saṃyogasyāvināśānna vibhaktapratyayaḥ syāt / dṛṣṭaśca saṃyogavināśastena karmaṇo guṇavināśe sāmarthyādarśanāt / anyasya vināśahetorabhāvād vibhāgo 'bhyupagantavyaḥ / saṃyogābhāve ca bhākto vibhaktapratyaya iti /
analyzed: atha saṃyogasya anutpāde vināśe ca vibhakta vyavahārāt na anyaḥ vibhāgaḥ iti ced na vibhāgam vinā saṃyoga vināśasya eva abhāvāt tathā hi guṇānām āśraya vināśāt virodhi guṇa prādurbhāvāt ca vināśa upalabdheḥ yatra āśraya vināśaḥ tatra saṃyogasya avināśāt na vibhakta pratyayaḥ syāt dṛṣṭaḥ ca saṃyoga vināśaḥ tena karmaṇaḥ guṇa vināśe sāmarthya adarśanāt anyasya vināśa hetoḥ abhāvāt vibhāgaḥ bhyupagantavyaḥ saṃyoga abhā
translated: If it be said that, in the absence of conjunction, there would be no notion of separation, and therefore no other separation, this is not so. Because without separation, there would be no destruction of conjunction. Thus, the destruction of qualities is observed due to the destruction of the substratum and the appearance of contradictory qualities. Where there is destruction of the substratum, there would be no notion of separation due to the non-destruction of conjunction. And the destruction of conjunction is seen. Since the action is not seen to have the power to destroy the quality, and there is no other cause of destruction, separation must be accepted. And the notion of separation is figurative in the absence of conjunction.

original: arthakriyāmāha śabdavibhāgahetuśca / vaṃśadalavibhāgācchabdotpattiḥ / vibhāgācca vibhāgotpattiriti vakṣyāmaḥ /
analyzed: artha kriyām āha śabda vibhāga hetuḥ ca vaṃśa dala vibhāgāt śabda utpattiḥ vibhāgāt ca vibhāga utpattiḥ iti vakṣyāmaḥ
translated: And it is the cause of the separation of sound. The production of sound from the separation of bamboo pieces, and the production of separation from separation, we will explain.

original: atha kathaṃlakṣaṇaḥ katividhiśceti vākyamihāpi sambadhyata iti jñeyam / pūrvavat pratisamādhānāt /
analyzed: atha kathaṃlakṣaṇaḥ kati vidhiḥ ca iti vākyam iha api sambadhyate iti jñeyam pūrvavat pratisamādhānāt
translated: Now it should be known that the sentence What is its characteristic? How many kinds are there? is also connected here, because the answer is the same as before.

original: prāptipūrvikā aprāptirvibhāgaḥ / sa ca trividhaḥ / anyatarakarmaja ubhayakarmajo vibhāgajaśca vibhāga iti / tatrānyatarakarmajobhayakarmajau saṃyogavat / vibhāgajastu dvividhaḥ / kāraṇavibhāgāt kāraṇākāraṇavibhāgācca /PDhS
analyzed: prāpti pūrvikā aprāptiḥ vibhāgaḥ sa ca trividhaḥ anyatara karma jaḥ ubhaya karma jaḥ vibhāga jaḥ ca vibhāgaḥ iti tatra anyatara karma ja ubhaya karma jau saṃyoga vat  vibhāga jaḥ tu dvividhaḥ kāraṇa vibhāgāt kāraṇa akāraṇa vibhāgāt ca pdhs
translated: Disjunction is preceded by attainment, and it is threefold: arising from the action of one, arising from the action of both, and arising from disjunction. Among them, arising from the action of one or arising from the action of both are like conjunction. But arising from disjunction is twofold: arising from the disjunction of the cause and arising from the disjunction of the cause and non-cause.

original: lakṣaṇamāha prāptipūrvikā aprāptirvibhāgaḥ / prāptiḥ saṃyogaḥ pūrvaṃ yasyāḥ sā tatpūrvikā / aprāptirvibhāgaḥ / saṃyogānutpattiścāprāptirna ca prāptipūrviketi /
analyzed: lakṣaṇam āha prāpti pūrvikā aprāptiḥ vibhāgaḥ prāptiḥ saṃyogaḥ pūrvam yasyāḥ sā tad pūrvikā aprāptiḥ vibhāgaḥ saṃyoga anutpattiḥ ca aprāptiḥ na ca prāpti pūrvikā iti
translated: He states the definition: Disjunction is the non-attainment preceded by attainment. That which has attainment, i.e., conjunction, preceding it is preceded by that. Non-attainment is disjunction. And the non-arising of conjunction is non-attainment, but it is not preceded by attainment.

original: atha prāpteḥ pūrvakālatvāt kiṃ kāraṇatvam / sati bhāvo vā / sati bhāvamātram / na tu kāraṇatvamiti kecit / tattu na budhyāmahe / kriyāvadanvayavyatirekābhyāṃ vibhāgajanmani saṃyogasyāpi vyāpāropalabdheḥ / na hi kriyāvatsaṃyogābhāve vibhāgo bhavati / tadbhāve tu bhavatīti / na cānvayavyatirekiṇaḥ saṃyogasya vibhāgakāraṇatve kiñcid bādhakamasti / yasya bhayādakāraṇatvamiṣyeta / svakāryavirodhitvantu guṇānāmiṣṭaṃ śabdādau / pratyāsannaśca saṃyogo vibhāgotpattāvityasamavāyikāraṇam / yathoktā cāprāptirvibhāga iti lakṣaṇe saṃyogavadākṣepapratisamādhānam /
analyzed: atha prāpteḥ pūrva kāla tvāt kim kāraṇa tvam sati bhāvaḥ vā sati bhāva mātram na tu kāraṇa tvam iti kecid tat tu na budhyāmahe kriyāvat anvaya vyatirekābhyām vibhāga janmani saṃyogasya api vyāpāra upalabdheḥ na hi kriyāvat saṃyoga abhāve vibhāgaḥ bhavati tad bhāve tu bhavati iti na ca anvaya vyatirekiṇaḥ saṃyogasya vibhāga kāraṇa tve kiñcid bādhakam asti yasya bhayāt akāraṇa tvam iṣyeta sva kārya virodhi tvantu guṇānām iṣṭam śabda ādau praty
translated: Now, if non-contact is prior to contact, what is the reason for contact? Or is it mere existence when something exists? But it is not the reason for contact, some say. But we do not understand that. Because by positive and negative concomitance like action, the operation of contact is also observed in the production of disjunction. For disjunction does not occur in the absence of contact like action, but it does occur when that exists. And there is no impediment to contact, which is concomitant with positive and negative concomitance, being the cause of disjunction, out of fear of which it might be considered not to be a cause. But the contradiction with its own effect is accepted for qualities like sound. And contact is proximate in the production of disjunction, so it is the non-inherent cause. And non-contact, as stated in the definition of disjunction, is like contact in projection and resolution.

original: sa ca trividhaḥ eva / anyatarakarmaja ubhayakarmajo vibhāgajaśca vibhāga iti / tatrānyatarakarmajobhayakarmajau saṃyogavat iti / etena karmaṇā vibhāgena ca vibhāgo janyate / yathā sthāṇoḥ śyeneneti / atra hi śyenāvayavini sthāṇunā taccaraṇavibhāgasamakālaṃ karmasañcintanād ubhayoḥ pratyāsannatve sati vyāpāraḥ sambhavatīti cintanīyam / vibhūnāñca mūrtairiti kevalaikakarmajaḥ / tathā dvābhyāṃ karmabhyāṃ vibhāgaiśca vibhāgo janyate / yathā mallayormeṣayorveti / yathā hi meṣaśirasi karmotpannaṃ śiro 'ntarād vibhāgaṃ karoti evaṃ tadavayavināpi ityavayavāvayavivibhāgatrayamavayavivibhāgotpattau pratyāsannatve sati sāmarthyāvadhāraṇāt kāraṇamiti / tathā vibhāgarahitābhyāṃ vibhāgo janyate / yathā paramāṇvorityatideśārthaḥ /
analyzed: sa ca trividhaḥ eva anyatara karma jaḥ ubhaya karma jaḥ vibhāga jaḥ ca vibhāgaḥ iti tatra anyatara karma ja ubhaya karma jau saṃyoga vat iti etena karmaṇā vibhāgena ca vibhāgaḥ janyate yathā sthāṇoḥ śyenena iti atra hi śyena avayavini sthāṇunā tad caraṇa vibhāga sama kālam karma sañcintanāt ubhayoḥ pratyāsanna tve sati vyāpāraḥ sambhavati iti cintanīyam mūrtaiḥ iti kevala eka karma jaḥ tathā dvābhyām karmabhyām vibhāgaiḥ ca vibhāgaḥ janyate yath
translated: And that is of three kinds only: produced by one action, produced by both actions, and produced by separation. Among them, produced by one action and produced by both actions are like conjunction. Separation is produced by this action and separation, like a post and a hawk. For here, since the action and the separation of the feet of the hawk are simultaneous with the separation of the post, the operation is possible only when both are proximate. And it should be considered. And of extended substances by one alone, produced by one action alone. Thus, separation is produced by two actions and separations, like two wrestlers or rams. translated: For example, a self-dependent part does not begin to separate from the space region simultaneously with the separation of another part, because it is a self-dependent part. But what separates is not a self-dependent part, like a lotus leaf. But self-dependence occurs in the destruction of a substance by the order of action, as stated before. original: atha padmāvayavakarmāpi avayavavibhāgasamakālamākāśadeśena vibhāgamārabhata ityatīndriyatvādanumānaṃ pramāṇaṃ vācyam / pramāṇaṃ vinā prameyāsiddheḥ / II / tatra yadi asvatantrāvayavakarmatvaṃ vyatirekāvyabhicāreṇa gamakamitaretarāśrayatvaṃ syāt / ekāprasiddhāvitarāprasiddheriti /

translated: For example, the action of a part of a lotus produces disjunction with the space region. Without that, because the previous conjunction would remain, the subsequent conjunction would not arise, and there would be the consequence that effects would not arise in the sequence beginning with dyads.

analyzed: atas svatantra avayava karma avayava antarāt eva vibhāgam ārabhate vibhāgāt ca dravya ārambhaka saṃyoga vināśaḥ tasmin vinaṣṭe kāraṇa abhāvāt kārya abhāvaḥ iti avayavi vināśaḥ tatas svatantra avayavasya ākāśa deśena vibhāgaḥ vācyaḥ tad antareṇa pūrva saṃyogasya avasthānāt uttara saṃyoga anutpattau karmaṇaḥ kāla antara avasthāyi tvam nitya dravya samavetasya ca nitya tvam syāt na ca etat asti karmaṇaḥ kṣaṇika tva upalabdheḥ na ca vināśa hetu
translated: Therefore, the action of the independent parts gives rise to disjunction from another part itself. And from disjunction, the destruction of the conjunction that produces the substance. Then, the disjunction of the independent part from the space of the other part must be stated. Because the previous conjunction would persist without that, and if the subsequent conjunction did not arise, the action would persist for some time, and what inheres in a permanent substance would be permanent. But this is not so. Because the action is observed to be momentary. And without a cause of destruction, it does not perish, because such a destruction is denied. Therefore, due to the absence of any other cause of destruction, and because the subsequent conjunction alone is determined to be capable of destroying the action through positive and negative concomitance, it is the cause.

original: na cottarasaṃyogaḥ pūrvasyākāśadeśena saṃyogasya pratibandhakasyāvasthāne bhavatīti tadvināśaheturvibhāgo niścīyate / na cāsau kriyātaḥ sambhavatyuktaII /nyāyāt / asamavāyikāraṇaṃ vinā ca vibhāgasyotpattirnopalabdheti anyasyāsamavāyikāraṇasyābhāvāt kāraṇayorvartamāno vibhāgaḥ pratyāsannatve sati samānajātīyatvādasamavāyikāraṇamiti / yatra hi samānajātīyaṃ nāsti tatra vijātīyamevāsamvāyikāraṇamiti kalpyate / kriyā tu vidyamānāpyatra bādhakasadbhāvādakāraṇameva / tasmāt kāraṇayorvartamāno vibhāgaḥ kāryasaṃyuktāt kāryasaṃyogopalakṣitāt ākāśādideśād vibhāgamārabhata iti / ādipadenātmāderavarodhaḥ /

translated: And since the conjunction with the subsequent part does not occur while the conjunction with the prior part of space remains as an obstruction, the disjunction that is the cause of its destruction is ascertained. And since the origination of disjunction is not observed without a non-inherent cause, due to the absence of any other non-inherent cause, the disjunction that exists in the two causes, when it is proximate, is the non-inherent cause due to being of the same class. For where there is no member of the same class, there the non-inherent cause is imagined to be of a different class. But even though action exists here, it is not a cause due to the presence of an obstruction. Therefore, the disjunction that exists in the two causes produces the disjunction from the space, etc., which is characterized by the conjunction with the effect. The word etc. includes the soul, etc.

original: kimapekṣya ityāha kāryavināśaviśiṣṭaṃ kālam iti / kāryavināśo dravyavināśaḥ / tadviśiṣṭaṃ kālam / tadvināśāt svatantro 'vayavastaṃ ca apekṣyārabhata iti /

original: kasyetyāha sakriyasyaiva iti / atha kāraṇavibhāgasyobhayavṛttitvāviśeṣāt sakriyasyākāśādideśena vibhāgaḥ / na niskriyasya iti kimatra niyāmakam / uttarasaṃyogotpattiriti / tathā hi / vibhāgāt saṃyogavināśe sati karma uttarasaṃyogaṃ karoti / tasmād vibhāgaḥ karma ca vyāvartate / niṣkriye tūtpanno vibhāgaḥ kathamuttarasaṃyogānutpattau vyāvarteta na ca vibhāgāt pūrvaṃ saṃyoganivṛttāvuttarasaṃyogotpattiryuktā / kāraṇasya karmaṇo 'bhāvāt / asaṃyuktasya cākāśādibhiravasthāne teṣāmasarvagatatvaṃ syāt / na cānyakarmasampāditaḥ saṃyogo 'nyakriyājanyasya vibhāgasya nivartako dṛṣṭaḥ / tasmāt svakāraṇakarmakāryā uttarasaṃyogād vibhāgasya nivṛttirdṛṣṭeti / uttarasaṃyogānutpattāvanupabhogyatva prasaṅgaḥ iti / niṣprayojanatvasya prasaṅgaḥ / vināśitvaprasaṅgaśceti / tasya hi pūrvasaṃyoganivartanād uttarasaṃyogotpattau saprayojanatvaṃ vināśitvañca ghaṭate /
analyzed: kasya iti āha sa kriyasya eva iti  atha kāraṇa vibhāgasya ubhaya vṛtti tva aviśeṣāt sa kriyasya ākāśa ādi deśena vibhāgaḥ na niskriyasya iti kim atra niyāmakam uttara saṃyoga utpattiḥ iti tathā hi vibhāgāt saṃyoga vināśe sati karma uttara saṃyogam karoti tasmāt vibhāgaḥ karma ca vyāvartate niṣkriye tu utpannaḥ vibhāgaḥ katham uttara saṃyoga anutpattau vyāvarteta na ca vibhāgāt pūrvam saṃyoga nivṛttau uttara saṃyoga utpattiḥ yuktā kāraṇasya karm
translated: Whose? Of the active one only. Now, since the division of the cause is not distinguished as occurring in both, the division of the active one is with the space etc., not of the inactive one. What is the determiner here? The production of the subsequent conjunction. Thus, indeed, when the action produces the subsequent conjunction after the destruction of the conjunction due to the division, then the division and the action cease. But in the inactive one, how would the produced division cease in the absence of the production of the subsequent conjunction? And it is not proper for the subsequent conjunction to arise from the cessation of the conjunction prior to the division, because of the absence of the cause, action. And if the inactive one remains without conjunction with space etc., they would not be all-pervading. And a conjunction accomplished by another action is not seen to stop the division produced by another action. Therefore, since the cessation of the division is seen from the subsequent conjunction, which is the effect of the action that is its own cause, if the subsequent conjunction does not arise, there would be the undesirable consequence of non-enjoyment.

original: yad vā niṣkriyasyākāśādideśena vibhāgābhyupagame sakriyasyottarasaṃyogānutpattiḥ / kāraṇābhāvāt / na tu niṣkriyasya vibhāgajavibhāgapratiṣedhe kāraṇābhāvo hetuḥ / samavāyyādikāraṇānāṃ sambhavāt / tathā hi / niṣkriyāvayavākāśādeḥ samavāyikāraṇatvam / vibhāgasyāsamavāyikāraṇatvam / śeṣaṃ nimittakāraṇamityasti kāraṇasadbhāvaḥ / tasmāduttarasaṃyogapratiṣedhe kāraṇābhāvo hetuḥ / tathā hi / sakriyasyākāśādideśena vibhāgānabhyupagame prāktanasaṃyogasya pratibandhakasyāvasthānād uttarasaṃyogānutpattiḥ / tadanutpattāvanupabhogyatvaṃ niṣprayojanatvaṃ vibhāgakarmaṇoriti /
analyzed: yat vā niṣkriyasya ākāśa ādi deśena vibhāga abhyupagame sa kriyasya uttara saṃyoga anutpattiḥ kāraṇa abhāvāt na tu niṣkriyasya vibhāga ja vibhāga pratiṣedhe kāraṇa abhāvaḥ hetuḥ samavāyi ādi kāraṇānām sambhavāt tathā hi niṣkriya avayava ākāśa ādeḥ samavāyi kāraṇa tvam vibhāgasya asamavāyi kāraṇa tvam śeṣam nimitta kāraṇam iti asti kāraṇa sadbhāvaḥ tasmāt uttara saṃyoga pratiṣedhe kāraṇa abhāvaḥ hetuḥ tathā hi sa kriyasya ā
translated: Or, if the division of an inactive thing like space is accepted, then the subsequent conjunction of an active thing does not arise, because of the absence of a cause. But the absence of a cause is not the reason for the negation of the division arising from division in the case of an inactive thing, because the inherent and other causes are possible. Thus, the inactive parts like space are the inherent causes, the division is the non-inherent cause, and the rest are the instrumental causes. Thus, the existence of causes is there. Therefore, the absence of a cause is the reason for the negation of subsequent conjunction. Thus, if the division of an active thing with space etc. is not accepted, then the prior conjunction which is the obstruction remains, and hence the subsequent conjunction does not arise. Due to its non-arising, the disjunctive and conjuctive actions become non-enjoyable and purposeless.

original: anye tu na niṣkriyasyākāśādideśena vibhāga iti / asadetat / kutaḥ / kāraṇābhāvāt / pramāṇābhāvādityukte pareṇa bādhakamāha uttarasaṃyogānutpattāvanupabhogyatvam avināśitvaṃ vibhāgasyeti /

translated: Others, however, say that there is no disjunction of the inactive [soul] with space and other places. This is incorrect. Why? Because there is no cause. original: atha yadyapi avayavakarma avayavāntaravibhāgasamakālamākāśādideśena vibhāgaṃ nārabhate tathāpi kāryavināśādūrdhvamārapsyata iti tanniṣedhārthamāha na tu tadavayakarma ākāśādideśād vibhāgam ārabhate / viramya vyāpārapratiṣedhāt / tadetadāha tadārambhakālātītatvāt iti / tasya karmaṇo vibhāgārambhakakālaḥ / tasya vā vibhāgasyārambhakakālaḥ tadārambhakālaḥ / tasyātītatvāditi /
analyzed: atha yadi api avayava karma avayava antara vibhāga sama kālam ākāśa ādi deśena vibhāgam na ārabhate tathā api kārya vināśāt ūrdhvam ārapsyate iti tad niṣedha artham āha na tu tad avaya karma ākāśa ādi deśāt vibhāgam ārabhate viramya vyāpāra pratiṣedhāt tat etat āha tad ārambha kāla atīta tvāt iti tasya karmaṇaḥ vibhāga ārambhaka kālaḥ tasya vā vibhāgasya ārambhaka kālaḥ tad ārambha kālaḥ tasya atīta tvāt iti
translated: Now, even if the action of the parts does not produce disjunction with space and other places simultaneously with the disjunction of the other parts, it will still begin after the destruction of the effect. Because that has passed.

original: atha karmaṇo viramya vyāpārapratiṣedhe kathamuttarasaṃyogaḥ / na / viramya vyāpārapratiṣedhasyāparijñānāt / tathā hi / karma vibhāgaṃ kṛtvā punarvibhāgaṃ nārabhate / vegañca kṛtvā punarvegam / na punaḥ saṃyogaṃ nārabhate ityāha uttarasaṃyogantu /pradeśāntarasaṃyogantu karotyeva akṛtasaṃyogasya karmaṇaḥ kālātyayābhāvāt kālātyayo vināśastasyābhāvāditi / dṛṣṭaścātra sadbhāve 'pi tasya vināśaḥ / tenottarasaṃyogajanakatvaṃ karmaṇo 'bhyupeyam / tasmāt tasya nivṛttiriti /
analyzed: atha karmaṇaḥ viramya vyāpāra pratiṣedhe katham uttara saṃyogaḥ na viramya vyāpāra pratiṣedhasya aparijñānāt tathā hi karma vibhāgam kṛtvā punar vibhāgam na ārabhate vegam ca kṛtvā punar vegam na punar saṃyogam na ārabhate iti āha uttara saṃyoga ntu pradeśa antara saṃyoga ntu karoti eva a kṛta saṃyogasya karmaṇaḥ kāla atyaya abhāvāt kāla atyayaḥ vināśaḥ tasya abhāvāt iti dṛṣṭaḥ ca atra sadbhāve pi tasya vināśaḥ tena uttara saṃyoga jan
translated: Now, when an action ceases, how can there be a connection with the subsequent [action], when the operation is prohibited? Thus, having divided the action, it does not again commence division, and having created momentum, it does not again create momentum. It is not said that it does not again commence conjunction, but it does create a conjunction with a different place, because the action that has not created conjunction does not have the fault of lapse of time. The fault of lapse of time is destruction, because it does not exist. And here, even when it exists, its destruction is seen. Therefore, the action's capacity to produce the subsequent conjunction should be accepted. Therefore, its cessation is said.

original: kāraṇākāraṇavibhāgādapi katham / yadā haste karmotpannam avayavāntarād vibhāgamakurvad ākāśādideśebhyo vibhāgānārabhya pradeśāntare II / saṃyogānārabhate tadā te kāraṇākāraṇavibhāgāḥ karma yāṃ diśaṃ prati kāryārambhābhimukhaṃ tāmapekṣya kāryākāryavibhāgānārabhante / tadanantaraṃ kāraṇākāraṇasaṃyogācca kāryākāryasaṃyogāniti /PDhS
analyzed: kāraṇa akāraṇa vibhāgāt api katham yadā haste karma utpannam avayava antarāt vibhāgam akurvat ākāśa ādi deśebhyaḥ vibhāgān ārabhya pradeśa antare saṃyogān ārabhate tadā te kāraṇa akāraṇa vibhāgāḥ karma yām diśam prati kārya ārambha abhimukham tām apekṣya kārya akārya vibhāgān ārabhante tad anantaram kāraṇa akāraṇa saṃyogāt ca kārya akārya saṃyogān iti pdhs
translated: How also from the division of cause and non-cause? And then, from the destruction of the substratum and the conjunction, the destruction of the separation of the thread and the grass.

original: anye tu vā śabdasyopamārthatvāt tantuvīraṇayoriva dvyaṇukāṇvoḥ saṃyoge sati dravyaṃ notpadyate / dravyānutpattau ca dvyaṇukāṇuvibhāgasya paramāṇukarmaṇā dvyaṇukārambhakasaṃyogavināśasamakālaṃ janitasya kathaṃ vināśaḥ / pūrvoktena vidhāneneti / āśrayavināśenetyarthaḥ / yadā tu paramāṇau karmotpattau paramāṇvantaravibhāgotpattisamakālam asminneva dvyaṇuke karmasañcintanaṃ tadā pūrvoktena vidhānena āśrayavināśād vibhāgakarmaṇoryugapad vināśa iti / II / dvyaṇukārambhake ca paramāṇau karmotpattisamakālam anārambhake 'pi karmasañcintanāt tadāśrayavināśasaṃyogābhyāṃ tantuvīraṇavibhāgavināśavad vināśa ityalam /
analyzed: anye tu vā śabdasya upamā artha tvāt tantu vīraṇayoḥ iva dvyaṇuka aṇvoḥ saṃyoge sati dravyam na utpadyate dravya anutpattau ca dvyaṇuka aṇu vibhāgasya paramāṇu karmaṇā dvyaṇuka ārambhaka saṃyoga vināśa sama kālam janitasya katham vināśaḥ pūrva uktena vidhānena iti āśraya vināśena iti arthaḥ yadā tu paramāṇau karma utpattau paramāṇu antara vibhāga utpatti sama kālam asmin eva dvyaṇuke karma sañcintanam tadā pūrva uktena vidhānena āśraya vinā
translated: Others, however, say that because the word 'vā' (in the sūtra) has the sense of comparison, just as in the case of threads and grass, when there is conjunction between the two atoms, substance is not produced. And when substance is not produced, how can there be destruction of the disjunction of the two atoms and the atom, which is produced simultaneously with the destruction of the conjunction that produces the two atoms by the action of the atom? By the method stated before, meaning by the destruction of the substratum. But when, in the production of action in the atom, the accumulation of action in this very two-atom is simultaneous with the production of disjunction of another atom, then by the method stated before, there is simultaneous destruction of disjunction and action due to the destruction of the substratum. And in the two-atom that is the cause of production, when the accumulation of action is simultaneous with the production of action in the atom, even in that which is not the cause of production, its destruction is like the destruction of the disjunction of the thread and grass by the destruction of its substratum and conjunction. That is enough.

original: paratvāparatvavaidharmyam
translated: The difference in the properties of distance and proximity.

original: paratvamaparatvañca parāparābhidhānapratyayanimittam / tattu dvividhaṃ dikkṛtaṃ kālakṛtañca / tatra dikkṛtaṃ deśaviśeṣapratyāyakam / kālakṛtañca vayobhedapratyāyakam /PDhS
analyzed: paratvam aparatvam ca para apara abhidhāna pratyaya nimittam tat tu dvividham diś kṛtam kāla kṛtam ca  tatra diś kṛtam deśa viśeṣa pratyāyakam kāla kṛtam ca vayaḥ bheda pratyāyakam
translated: Priority and posteriority are the causes of the notions of far and near. It is of two kinds: produced by space and produced by time. Among them, that produced by space indicates a particular place. That produced by time indicates a difference in age.

original: idānīṃ paratvāparatvayorlakṣaṇaparīkṣārtham paratvam ityādi prakaraṇam / abhidhānañca pratyayaśceti / tayornimittam paratvamaparatvañca ityukte 'tiprasaṅgaḥ / tadarthaṃ parāparagrahaṇam / tathāpi parāparābhidhānapratyayanimittatvam ākāśātmanorna vyāvṛttamiti viśeṣaṇatve satītyūhyam / tathā sāmānyamapi viśeṣaṇatve sati parāparābhidhānapratyayanimittamato dravyagrahaṇam / tathā hi / paratvāparatve / anyasmād bhidyate dravyaviśeṣaṇatve sati parāparābhidhānapratyayanimittatvāt / yastvitarānna bhidyate na cāsāvevam / yathā rūpādiriti / vyavahāro vā sādhyaḥ / atra ca abhidhānapadena saṃkhyādilakṣaṇeṣvapi karaṇavyutpattyābhidhānam / bhāvavyutpattyā ca jñānamityubhayarūpo vyavahāraḥ pratyayaśca vivakṣita iti jñāpayati / ekasmiṃśca prakaraṇe guṇadvayanirūpaṇam ekotpatteritaropāyāpekṣikatvāt / pṛthagabhidhāne tu granthabahutvaṃ syāditi saṅgrahatvādekadābhidhānam /
analyzed: idānīm paratva aparatvayoḥ lakṣaṇa parīkṣā artham paratvam ityādi prakaraṇam abhidhānam ca pratyayaḥ ca iti tayoḥ nimittam paratvam aparatvam ca iti ukte tiprasaṅgaḥ tad artham parāpara grahaṇam tathā api parāpara abhidhāna pratyaya nimitta tvam ākāśa ātmanoḥ na vyāvṛttam iti viśeṣaṇa tve sati iti ūhyam tathā sāmānyam api viśeṣaṇa tve sati parāpara abhidhāna pratyaya nimittam atas dravya grahaṇam tathā hi paratva aparatve anyasmāt bhidyate dravya v
translated: Now, for the purpose of examining the definition of priority and posteriority, the section beginning with priority etc. is stated. And abhidhāna and pratyaya are the cause of those two. When it is said that the cause of those two is priority and posteriority, there is an overextension. For that purpose, the terms para and apara are used. Even then, the cause of the designation and cognition of the distant and near is not excluded for the self of space. Therefore, it should be understood as when there is the quality of being a qualifier. Similarly, generality is also the cause of the designation and cognition of the distant and near when there is the quality of being a qualifier. Therefore, the term substance is used. Thus, priority and posteriority are distinguished from other things, because when there is the quality of being a qualifier of substance, they are the cause of the designation and cognition of the distant and near. But that which is not distinguished from the other is not so. Like form etc. The usage or the conclusion is to be established. And here, by the term abhidhāna, the designation is also by the derivation of the instrument in number etc. characteristics, and by the derivation of the bhāva, the cognition is stated. Thus, the usage and the cognition are of both forms.

original: paratvāparatvayoḥ sadbhāve kiṃ pramāṇamityapekṣāyāṃ paratvamaparatvañca parāparābhidhānapratyayanimittamiti vākyaṃ parīkṣāparatvena ca yojanīyam / tathā hi / parāparābhidhānapratyayaḥ / viśeṣaṇapūrvakaḥ / viśeṣyābhidhānapratyayatvāt / daṇḍīti viśeṣyābhidhānapratyayavat / na ca rūpādīnāmanyatamaṃ viśeṣaṇam / tadvyavahāravilakṣaṇatvāt / abādhyamānañca jñānaṃ nimittaṃ vinā na sambhavatyeva / vāsanā tu nimittaṃ tatra na bhavatītyuktam / atha dravyameva viśiṣṭotpādavaśāt parāparavyavahārajanakam / tanna / kṣaṇikatvapratiṣedhāt / abhyupagamena tūcyate / viśiṣṭatāyā vyatirekābhyupagame viśiṣṭavyavahārajanakatve ca saṃjñābhedamātram / avyatireketu II / samānadeśāvasthitapiṇḍhe samānavayasi ca parāparavyavahāraḥ syāt / dravyasadbhāvasyāviśeṣāt / ataḥ parāparavyavahāre rūpādivilakṣaṇaṃ nimittamastīti jñātam /
analyzed: paratva aparatvayoḥ sadbhāve kim pramāṇam iti apekṣāyām paratvam aparatvam ca para apara abhidhāna pratyaya nimittam iti vākyam parīkṣā para tvena ca yojanīyam tathā hi para apara abhidhāna pratyayaḥ viśeṣaṇa pūrvakaḥ viśeṣya abhidhāna pratyaya tvāt daṇḍī iti viśeṣya abhidhāna pratyaya vat  / na ca rūpa ādīnām anyatamam viśeṣaṇam tad vyavahāra vilakṣaṇa tvāt abādhyamānam ca jñānam nimittam vinā na sambhavati eva vāsanā tu nimittam tatra na bh
translated: When there is a question about what is the means of valid knowledge for the existence of priority and posteriority, the sentence Priority and posteriority are the cause of the notions and expressions 'far' and 'near' should be connected with the purpose of examination. It is like this. The notion and expression 'far' and 'near' are preceded by a qualifier, because they are notions and expressions of a qualified object, like the notion and expression 'one who has a stick'. And none of form etc. is the qualifier, because they are different from the usage of that [qualifier]. And a cognition that is not contradicted cannot exist without a cause. It has been said that vāsanā cannot be the cause there. Now, if substance itself, by the power of being produced in a special way, generates the usage of 'far' and 'near', that is not so. Because momentariness is denied. But it is said by acceptance. If distinction is accepted as different, and if it generates the usage of the qualified, then it is merely a difference in name. But if there is no difference, then in a lump existing in the same place and of the same age, there would be no difference in the usage of 'far' and 'near'.

original: tad dvividhaṃ kāraṇabhedādityāha dikkṛtaṃ kālakṛtañca iti / nanu dikkālayoḥ sarvotpattimatāṃ nimittikāraṇatvābhidhānād viśeṣābhidhānāsambhava eva / na / dikkālapiṇḍasaṃyogayostacchabdavācyatvena tatkṛtatvopapatterdikpiṇḍasaṃyogakṛtaṃ dikkṛtam / kālapiṇḍasaṃyogakṛtañca kālakṛtamiti / tathānayoḥ parasparaṃ bhedamāha tatra dikkṛtaṃ deśaviśeṣapratyāyakam iti / deśaviśeṣaḥ pratyāyako 'syeti / deśeviśeṣaṃ vā pratyāyayatīti kālakṛtād bhidyate / kālakṛtañca vayobhedapratyāyakam iti / vayobhedaḥ pratyāyako yasyeti vayobhedapratyāyakam / vayobhedaṃ vā pratyāyayatīti dikkṛtād bhidyate /
analyzed: tat dvividham kāraṇa bhedāt iti āha diś kṛtam kāla kṛtam ca iti nanu diś kālayoḥ sarva utpattimatām nimitti kāraṇa tva abhidhānāt viśeṣa abhidhāna asambhavaḥ eva na diś kāla piṇḍa saṃyogayoḥ tad śabda vācya tvena tad kṛta tva upapatteḥ diś piṇḍa saṃyoga kṛtam diś kṛtam kāla piṇḍa saṃyoga kṛtam ca kāla kṛtam iti tathā anayoḥ parasparam bhedam āha tatra diś kṛtam deśa viśeṣa pratyāyakam iti deśa viśeṣaḥ sya iti deśe viśe
translated: That is of two kinds due to the difference in causes. He says this: Created by space and time. But since space and time are said to be the instrumental causes of all that is produced, it is impossible to specify them. No, because it is possible to say that they are created by the conjunction of space and time particles, since they are denoted by those words. That created by space is created by the conjunction of space particles. And that created by time is created by the conjunction of time particles.
