Thus he states their mutual difference: Among them, that created by space indicates a particular place. It is that which indicates a particular place. Or it indicates a particular place. It is different from that created by time. And that created by time indicates a difference in age. It is that which has a difference in age as its indicator. It indicates a difference in age. It is different from that created by space.

original: tatra dikkṛtasyotpattirabhidhīyate / katham / ekasyāṃ diśyavasthitayoḥ piṇḍayoḥ saṃyuktasaṃyogabahvalpabhāve sati ekasya draṣṭuḥ sannikṛṣṭamadhiṃ kṛtvā etasmād viprakṛṣṭo 'yam iti paratvādhāre 'sannikṛṣṭā buddhirutpadyate / tatastāmapekṣya pareṇa dikpradeśena saṃyogāt paratvasyotpattiḥ /PDhS
analyzed: tatra diś kṛtasya utpattiḥ abhidhīyate katham ekasyām diśi avasthitayoḥ piṇḍayoḥ saṃyukta saṃyoga bahu alpa bhāve sati ekasya draṣṭuḥ sannikṛṣṭam adhim kṛtvā etasmāt viprakṛṣṭaḥ yam iti paratva ādhāre sannikṛṣṭā buddhiḥ utpadyate tatas tām apekṣya pareṇa diś pradeśena saṃyogāt paratvasya utpattiḥ
translated: There, the origination of direction is being stated. How? When two objects are situated in one direction and there is a difference in the quantity of conjunction with the conjoined, for one observer, taking the nearer object as the standard, the cognition of the distant object as 'this is distant from that' arises in the non-near standard. Then, depending on that, the origination of distance occurs due to conjunction with the distant part of space.

original: tathā viprakṛṣṭañcāvadhiṃ kṛtvā etasmāt sannikṛṣṭo 'yam ityaparatvādhāre itarasmin sannikṛṣṭā buddhirutpadyate / tatastāmapekṣya apareṇa dikpradeśena saṃyogād aparatvasyotpattiḥ /PDhS
analyzed: tathā viprakṛṣṭam ca avadhim kṛtvā etasmāt sannikṛṣṭaḥ yam iti aparatva ādhāre itarasmin sannikṛṣṭā buddhiḥ utpadyate tatas tām apekṣya apareṇa diś pradeśena saṃyogāt aparatvasya utpattiḥ
translated: Similarly, taking the distant object as the standard, the cognition of the nearer object as 'this is nearer to that' arises in the other, the non-distant standard. Then, depending on that, the origination of proximity occurs due to conjunction with the nearer part of space.

original: tatra dikkṛtasyotpattirabhidhīyate / katham ityavyutpannapraśnānantaramāha ekasyāṃ diśyavasthitayoḥ piṇḍayoḥ ityādi / piṇḍayoriti samavāyikāraṇanirdeśaḥ / ekasyāṃ diśyavasthitayoḥ / na vibhinnadiśyavasthitayoriti niyamapratipādanam / saṃyuktasaṃyogabahvalpabhāve sati iti bhūpradeśān adhikṛtya / etatsaṃyuktena saha saṃyogāsteṣāṃ bahvalpabhāva iti ekasmin piṇḍe saṃyuktasaṃyogālpīyastvam / anyasmiṃstato bahutvam / tasmin sati ekasya draṣṭuḥ na vibhinnasya / sannikṛṣṭamavadhiṃ kṛtvā etasmād viprakṛṣṭo 'yamiti II / paratvādhāre utpatsyamānaparatve / buddhirutpadyate / tāmapekṣya pareṇa dikpradeśena saṃyogāt paratvotpattiriti / dikpradeśayoḥ parāparavyapadeśastatsampādakatvādupacāreṇa /
analyzed: tatra diś kṛtasya utpattiḥ abhidhīyate katham iti avyutpanna praśna anantaram āha ekasyām diśi avasthitayoḥ piṇḍayoḥ ityādi piṇḍayoḥ iti samavāyi kāraṇa nirdeśaḥ ekasyām diśi avasthitayoḥ na vibhinna diśi avasthitayoḥ iti niyama pratipādanam saṃyukta saṃyoga bahu alpa bhāve sati iti bhū pradeśān adhikṛtya etad saṃyuktena saha saṃyogāḥ teṣām bahu alpa bhāve iti ekasmin piṇḍe saṃyukta saṃyoga alpīyaḥ tvam anyasmin tatas bahu tvam tasmin
translated: There, the origination of direction is being described. How? After the questioner is not well-versed, it is said: Of two lumps situated in one direction, etc. The phrase of two lumps indicates the inherent cause. Situated in one direction indicates the rule that they are not situated in different directions. When there is much or little conjunction with the conjoined is with reference to the parts of the earth. The phrase much or little of those conjunctions with what is conjoined to this means that in one lump the conjunctions with the conjoined are fewer, while in the other they are more. When that exists, for one observer who is not different, having taken as the limit what is near, the cognition arises This is distant from that. In the substratum of distance, which is about to be produced as distance, the cognition arises. In dependence on that, from the conjunction with the distant part of space, distance is produced. The designation of the parts of space as distant and near is figuratively by way of accomplishing that.

original: viprakṛṣṭañca piṇḍamavadhiṃ kṛtvā itarasmin piṇḍasaṃyuktasaṃyogālpīyastvānnimittāt sannikṛṣṭā buddhirutpadyate / tāṃ sannikṛṣṭāṃ buddhimapekṣya apareṇa dikpradeśena yogād paratvotpattiriti / piṇḍaḥ samavāyikāraṇam / dikpiṇḍasaṃyogo 'samavāyikāraṇam / viśiṣṭā ca buddhirnimittakāraṇamiti /
analyzed: viprakṛṣṭam ca piṇḍam avadhim kṛtvā itarasmin piṇḍa saṃyukta saṃyoga alpīyaḥ tvāt nimittāt sannikṛṣṭā buddhiḥ utpadyate tām sannikṛṣṭām buddhim apekṣya apareṇa diś pradeśena yogāt paratva utpattiḥ iti piṇḍaḥ samavāyi kāraṇam diś piṇḍa saṃyogaḥ samavāyi kāraṇam viśiṣṭā ca buddhiḥ nimitta kāraṇam iti
translated: And taking the remote object as the limit, the cognition of the near object arises from the cause of the lesser conjunction with the other object. In relation to that near cognition, the arising of distance is due to the connection with another part of space. The object is the inherent cause. The conjunction of space and object is the non-inherent cause. And the specific cognition is the instrumental cause.

original: nanu cātra sannikṛṣṭamavadhiṃ kṛtvā viprakṛṣṭe buddhiḥ / viprakṛṣṭañcāvadhiṃ kṛtvā sannikṛṣṭe buddhiriti viprakṛṣṭasannikṛṣṭabuddhyoḥ parasparāpekṣitvād ubhayābhāvaprasaṅgaḥ / tanna / nirvikalpakajñāne pratibhātasyāvadhitvenābhyupagamāt / tathā hi / sannikṛṣṭaviprakṛṣṭayoḥ pratyakṣeṇaiva nirvikalpakāvabhāse sati etasmādayaṃ sannikṛṣṭo viprakṛṣṭaśca iti savikalpakaṃ jñānaṃ bhavatyeva /
analyzed: nanu ca atra sannikṛṣṭam avadhim kṛtvā viprakṛṣṭe buddhiḥ viprakṛṣṭam ca avadhim kṛtvā sannikṛṣṭe buddhiḥ iti viprakṛṣṭa sannikṛṣṭa buddhyoḥ paraspara apekṣi tvāt ubhaya abhāva prasaṅgaḥ tat na nirvikalpaka jñāne pratibhātasya avadhi tvena abhyupagamāt tathā hi sannikṛṣṭa viprakṛṣṭayoḥ pratyakṣeṇa eva nirvikalpaka avabhāse sati etasmāt ayam sannikṛṣṭaḥ viprakṛṣṭaḥ ca iti savikalpakam jñānam bhavati eva
translated: But here, taking the near object as the limit, there is cognition of the remote object. And taking the remote object as the limit, there is cognition of the near object. Thus, due to the mutual dependence of the cognitions of the remote and near objects, there would be the undesirable consequence of the absence of both. That is not so. Because the appearance in non-conceptual cognition is accepted as the limit. Indeed, when the non-conceptual appearance of the near and remote objects is by perception itself, the conceptual cognition arises as This is near from that and This is remote from that.

original: anye tu nirvikalpāvabhāsajanitasaṃskārajasmṛtyupasthāpitayoḥ sannikṛṣṭaviprakṛṣṭayoḥ parasparāvadhibhāvo ghaṭata iti bruvate / tasmānna parasparāpekṣitatvādubhayābhāva iti sthitam /
analyzed: anye tu nirvikalpa avabhāsa janita saṃskāra ja smṛti upasthāpitayoḥ sannikṛṣṭa viprakṛṣṭayoḥ paraspara avadhi bhāvaḥ ghaṭate iti bruvate tasmāt na paraspara apekṣita tvāt ubhaya abhāvaḥ iti sthitam
translated: Others say that the relation of remoteness and proximity is possible between the two, presented by memory produced from impressions generated by the non-conceptual cognition. Thus, it is established that non-existence of both is not due to mutual dependence.

original: kālakṛtayorapi katham / vartamānakālayoraniyatadigdeśasaṃyuktayoryuvasthavirayo rūḍhaśmaśrukārkaśyavalipalitādisānnidhye satyekasya draṣṭuryuvānamavadhiṃ kṛtvā sthavire viprakṛṣṭā buddhirutpadyate / tatastāmapekṣya pareṇa kālapradeśena saṃyogāt paratvasyotpattiḥ / sthavirañcāvadhiṃ kṛtvā yūni sannikṛṣṭā buddhirutpadyate / tatastāmapekṣya apareṇa kālapradeśena saṃyogād aparatvasyotpattiriti /PDhS
analyzed: kāla kṛtayoḥ api katham vartamāna kālayoḥ aniyata diś deśa saṃyuktayoḥ yuva sthavirayoḥ rūḍha śmaśru kārkaśya vali palita ādi sānnidhye sati ekasya draṣṭuḥ yuvānam avadhim kṛtvā sthavire viprakṛṣṭā buddhiḥ utpadyate tatas tām apekṣya pareṇa kāla pradeśena saṃyogāt paratvasya utpattiḥ sthaviram ca avadhim kṛtvā yūni sannikṛṣṭā buddhiḥ utpadyate tatas tām apekṣya apareṇa kāla pradeśena saṃyogāt aparatvasya utpattiḥ iti pdhs
translated: How is it for those produced by time? For those in the present time, connected with an indefinite direction and place, like a youth and an old man, when the presence of long beard, roughness, wrinkles, gray hair, etc. is there, for one observer, taking the youth as the limit, the cognition of the old man as remote arises. Then, depending on that, due to connection with the other part of time, remoteness arises. And taking the old man as the limit, the cognition of the youth as proximate arises. Then, depending on that, due to connection with the other part of time, proximity arises.

original: kālakṛtayorapi paratvāparatvayoḥ kathamutpattirityāha vartamānakālayoḥ ityādi / vartamānaḥ kālo yayoḥ piṇḍayostau ca tathoktau tayorityubhayatrāpi dikkālakṛtaparatvāparatvayorutpattau niyamaḥ / aniyatadigdeśayoḥ iti / na niyato digdeśo yayostau tathoktau tayoriti kālakṛtayorutpattāvaniyamopadarśanam / yuvasthavirayoḥ iti vayobhedopadarśanārtham / samānavayasi parāparaII /vyavahārādarśanāt / rūḍhaśmaśrukārkaśyavalipalitādisānnidhye sati rūḍhaśmaśru ca kārkaśyañca valayaśca palitāni ca tānyādiryeṣāṃ tāni / tathoktāni / teṣāṃ sānnidhye satīti / rūḍhaśmaśrukārkaśyādi sānnidhyaṃ sannikṛṣṭabuddheḥ kāraṇam / valīpalitādisānnidhyañca viprakṛṣṭabuddheriti / ekasya draṣṭuḥ iti / yo hi draṣṭā paratvāparatve draṣṭumabhivāñchati tasya / yuvānamavadhiṃ kṛtvā sthavire viprakṛṣṭā buddhirutpadyate / tāṃ viprakṛṣṭāṃ buddhimapekṣya pareṇa kālapradeśena yogāt paratvasyotpattiriti / viprakṛṣṭañca sthaviramavadhiṃ kṛtvā yūni etasmāt sthavirādayaṃ sannikṛṣṭaḥ iti sannikṛṣṭā buddhirutpadyate / tāmapekṣya apareṇa kālapradeśena saṃyogād aparatvasyotpattiriti / sannikṛṣṭaviprakṛṣṭapiṇḍayoḥ samavāyikāraṇatvam / kālapiṇḍayoḥ saṃyogasya cāsamavāyikāraṇatvam / sannikṛṣṭaviprakṛṣṭabuddhyośca nimittakāraṇatvamiti /
analyzed: kāla kṛtayoḥ api paratva aparatvayoḥ katham utpattiḥ iti āha vartamāna kālayoḥ ityādi vartamānaḥ kālaḥ yayoḥ piṇḍayoḥ tau ca tathā uktau tayoḥ iti ubhayatra api diś kāla kṛta paratva aparatvayoḥ utpattau niyamaḥ aniyata diś deśayoḥ iti na niyataḥ diś deśaḥ yayoḥ tau tathā uktau tayoḥ iti kāla kṛtayoḥ utpattau aniyama upadarśanam yuva sthavirayoḥ iti vayaḥ bheda upadarśana artham samāna vayasi    rūḍha śmaśru kārkaśya vali palita ādi
translated: How can priority and posteriority, which are produced by time, arise? He says: For those two entities that exist in the present time, they are called thus. For the arising of priority and posteriority produced by space and time, there is a rule in both cases. For those two that have an indefinite direction and place, it is said thus. For the arising of those produced by time, the lack of a rule is shown. For the young and the old, it is said thus to show the difference in age. In one of the same age, the usage of priority and posteriority is not seen. When the presence of thick beard, roughness, wrinkles, gray hair, etc. is there, they are said to be thus. When their presence is there, the presence of thick beard, roughness, etc. is the cause of the proximate cognition, and the presence of wrinkles, gray hair, etc. is the cause of the remote cognition. For one observer, he who observes priority and posteriority in one object, for him, the cognition of priority and posteriority is proximate.

original: nanu cāyuktametat āhāropayoge sati pākajotpattinyāyenaikasminnahanyupajātatvāviśeṣeṇa sannikṛṣṭaviprakṛṣṭabuddhyorabhāvāt paratvāparatvayorasambhavaḥ / naitadevam / janmanaḥ prabhṛti ekasyāṃ śarīrasantatāvādityaparivartanāpekṣayā tadupapatteḥ / tathā hi / ekasya januḥprabhṛti bhūyāṃsyādityaparivartanāni aparasyālpīyāṃsīti tadapekṣayā sannikṛṣṭaviprakṛṣṭabuddhyorbhāvaḥ / sthavire bhūyāṃsyādityaparivartanānīti viprakṛṣṭabuddhiḥ / yūni cālpīyāṃsīti sannikṛṣṭabuddhiḥ / tadapekṣayā paratvāparatvayorutpattiriti śarīrasantānasyādityaparivartanāpekṣayā ghaṭata evaitat / dikkṛtaparatvāparatvavailakṣaṇyañcānayornimittāntarāsambhave sati kālakṛtatvamiṣṭam / na hi tasmādeva nimittād vyatikaraḥ sambhavatīti /
analyzed: nanu ca ayuktam etat āhāra upayoge sati pāka ja utpatti nyāyena ekasmin ahani upajāta tva aviśeṣeṇa sannikṛṣṭa viprakṛṣṭa buddhyoḥ abhāvāt paratva aparatvayoḥ asambhavaḥ na etat evam janmanaḥ prabhṛti ekasyām śarīra santatau āditya parivartana apekṣayā tad upapatteḥ tathā hi ekasya januḥ prabhṛti bhūyāṃsi āditya parivartanāni aparasya alpīyāṃsi iti tad apekṣayā sannikṛṣṭa viprakṛṣṭa buddhyoḥ bhāvaḥ sthavire bhūyāṃsi āditya p
translated: But this is improper, because when food is consumed, due to the principle of production by cooking, there is no difference in being produced in one day, so there cannot be farness and nearness, and hence there cannot be priority and posteriority. This is not so, because it is possible in relation to the succession of the body from birth onwards and the changes of the sun. For example, for one person there are more changes of the sun from birth onwards, for another fewer. So the notions of near and far arise in relation to that. For an old person there is the notion of farness because there are more changes of the sun, and for a young person there is the notion of nearness because there are fewer. Priority and posteriority arise in relation to that. This is indeed possible in relation to the succession of the body and the changes of the sun. And the difference between these two and the priority and posteriority based on direction is accepted to be based on time, if no other cause is possible. For there cannot be a mixture of these two from the same cause.

original: tadevaṃ paratvāparatvayorutpāde vyavasthite sūtreṇābhisambandhopadarśanañca / tathā ca sūtram ekadikkālābhyāṃ sannikṛṣṭaviprakṛṣṭābhyāṃ paramaparañca vai / sū / iti / ekā dik kālaśca yayostau tathoktau tābhyāmiti samavāyikāraṇanirdeśaḥ / ekadigbhyāmiti dikkṛtaparatvāparatvāpekṣayaiva niyamaḥ / ekakālābhyāṃ vartamānakālābhyām ubhayatrāpīti / na hi asadbhyāṃ sadasadbhyāñca paratvāparatve jāyate / sannikṛṣṭaviprakṛṣṭābhyāmiti samavāyikāraṇopasarjanatayā sannikṛṣṭaviprakṛṣṭabuddhyornimittakāraṇatvamuktameva / tathā hi / II / paramaparañceti buddhyapekṣam vai / sū / ityapekṣāśabdaścātra kāraṇe vartata iti / kāraṇaparatvāt kāraṇāparatvācca paratvāparatve vai / sū / ityasamavāyikāraṇaṃ darśayati /
analyzed: tat evam paratva aparatvayoḥ utpāde vyavasthite sūtreṇa abhisambandha upadarśanam ca tathā ca sūtram eka diś kālābhyām sannikṛṣṭa viprakṛṣṭābhyām param aparam vai iti ekā diś kālaḥ ca yayoḥ tau tathā uktau tābhyām iti samavāyikāraṇa nirdeśaḥ eka digbhyām iti diś kṛta paratva aparatva apekṣayā eva niyamaḥ eka kālābhyām vartamāna kālābhyām ubhayatra api iti na hi asadbhyām sat asadbhyām ca paratva aparatve jāyate sannikṛṣṭa viprakṛṣṭ
translated: Thus, when priority and posteriority are established in this way, the connection with the aphorism is shown. And thus the aphorism: Paratva and aparatva are with respect to one direction and time, which are near and far. (1.1.10) Those that have one direction and one time are said to be so. By those two, the inhering cause is indicated. By one direction, the restriction is only with respect to paratva and aparatva produced by direction. By one time, by the present time, in both cases. For paratva and aparatva are not produced by the non-existent and the existent and non-existent. By the near and the far, the near and far cognitions are said to be the instrumental cause, with the inhering cause as subordinate. Thus, indeed, it is so. Paratva and aparatva are with respect to the cognitions. The word 'va' here in the aphorism indicates the alternative. The word 'va' in 'paramaparam ca vai' in the aphorism is used in the sense of cause. Because of the priority of the cause and the posteriority of the cause, paratva and aparatva are shown to be the non-inhering cause.

original: nanu ca kāraṇaparatvāt kāraṇāparatvācca yadi kārye paratvāparatve bhavatastarhi rūpādivaccirotpannatvāt sannikṛṣṭaviprakṛṣṭabuddhiṃ vināpi samāne deśe samāne vayasi ca piṇḍe tayorgrahaṇaṃ syāt / na caitadasti / atha anabhivyaktito 'nupalabdhiḥ / tanna / sadbhāve pramāṇābhāvāt / sannikṛṣṭaviprakṛṣṭabuddhyādisadbhāve cedānīmutpannamātrasyāpi grahaṇamupapadyata eva / tasmād dikpiṇḍasaṃyogaḥ kālapiṇḍasaṃyogaśca paratvāparatvasampādakatvādupacāreṇa paratvāparatve ityabhidhīyate / na ca paratvāparatvayoḥ parasparāpekṣitatvād asambaddhamutpattyādinirūpaṇamiti vācyam / sarvatra parasparāpekṣitatvānupalabdheḥ / tathā hi / na bījāṅkurayoḥ parasparāpekṣitvam / bījavināśe sati kālāntare dvyaṇukādiprakrameṇa aṅkurasyotpatteḥ / evamaṅkuravināśe sati uttarottarakāryāṇāṃ pūrvapūrvavināśe sati bhāvāt / nāṅkurād bījamiti parasparāpekṣitvābhāvaḥ / tathā pitṛputrayoḥ dharmaśarīrayośca na parasparāpekṣitvaṃ / yata evopalabdhistatkāraṇatvānupalabdheḥ / kāryāntare tu kāraṇatvaṃ na pratiṣidhyate ityalamatiprasaṅgena /
analyzed: nanu ca kāraṇa paratvāt kāraṇa aparatvāt ca yadi kārye paratva aparatve bhavataḥ tarhi rūpa ādi vat cira utpanna tvāt sannikṛṣṭa viprakṛṣṭa buddhim vinā api samāne deśe samāne vayasi ca piṇḍe tayoḥ grahaṇam syāt na ca etat asti atha anabhivyaktitaḥ nupalabdhiḥ tat na sadbhāve pramāṇa abhāvāt sannikṛṣṭa viprakṛṣṭa buddhi ādi sadbhāve ca idānīm utpanna mātrasya api grahaṇam upapadyate eva tasmāt diś piṇḍa saṃyogaḥ kāla piṇḍa s
translated: But if priority and posteriority exist in the effect due to the priority and posteriority of the cause, then like color etc., the apprehension of those two would occur in the same place and in the same age even without the cognition of proximity and distance due to their being produced earlier. And this is not so. If it is argued that non-apprehension is due to non-manifestation, that is not so. Because there is no evidence of their existence. And if the existence of the cognition of proximity and distance etc. is accepted, then the apprehension of what is produced now alone is indeed possible. Therefore, the conjunction of direction with the whole and the conjunction of time with the whole are figuratively called priority and posteriority because they bring about priority and posteriority. And it should not be said that the description of origination etc. is unconnected because priority and posteriority are mutually dependent. Because mutual dependence is not observed everywhere. Thus, the seed and sprout are not mutually dependent. When the seed is destroyed, the series beginning with the dyad etc. occurs after some time.

original: vināśastvapekṣābuddhisaṃyogadravyanāśāt / apekṣābuddhivināśāt tāvadutpanne paratve yasmin kāle sāmānyabuddhirutpannā bhavati tato 'pekṣābuddhervinaśyattā / sāmānyatajjñānatatsambandhebhyaḥ paratvaguṇabuddherutpadyamānatetyekaḥ kālaḥ / tato 'pekṣābuddhervināśo guṇabuddheścotpattiḥ / tato 'pekṣābuddhivināśād guṇasya vinaśyattā / guṇajñānatatsambandhebhyo dravyabuddherutpadyamānatetyekaḥ kālaḥ / tato dravyabuddherutpattirguṇasya vināśa iti /PDhS
analyzed: vināśaḥ tu apekṣā buddhi saṃyoga dravya nāśāt apekṣā buddhi vināśāt tāvat utpanne paratve yasmin kāle sāmānya buddhiḥ utpannā bhavati tatas u pekṣā buddheḥ vinaśyat tā sāmānya tad jñāna tad sambandhebhyaḥ paratva guṇa buddheḥ utpadyamāna tā iti ekaḥ kālaḥ tatas u pekṣā buddheḥ vināśaḥ guṇa buddheḥ ca utpattiḥ tatas u pekṣā buddhi vināśāt guṇasya vinaśyat tā guṇa jñāna tad sambandhebhyaḥ dravya buddheḥ utpadyamāna tā iti eka
translated: Destruction, however, is from the destruction of the relative cognition, conjunction, and substance. From the destruction of the relative cognition, when superiority has arisen, at that time when the cognition of the universal arises, then the relative cognition is destroyed. From the universal, its cognition, and their relation, the cognition of the quality of superiority is in the process of arising - this is one moment. Then there is the destruction of the relative cognition and the arising of the cognition of the quality. Then from the destruction of the relative cognition, the quality is in the process of being destroyed. From the quality, its cognition, and their relation, the cognition of the substance is in the process of arising - this is one moment. Then there is the arising of the cognition of the substance and the destruction of the quality.

original: tadevaṃ paratvāparatvayorutpattimattvādavaśyaṃ vināśa iti / tasya sahetukatvāt kāraṇaṃ vācyamityāha vināśastvapekṣābuddhisaṃyogadravyavināśāt iti tredhā / tritayavināśāccāparaḥ pakṣa iti saptadhā vināśaḥ /
analyzed: tat evam paratva aparatvayoḥ utpattimat tvāt avaśyam vināśaḥ iti tasya sa hetuka tvāt kāraṇam vācyam iti āha vināśaḥ tu apekṣā buddhi saṃyoga dravya vināśāt iti tredhā tritaya vināśāt ca aparaḥ pakṣaḥ iti saptadhā vināśaḥ
translated: Thus, since superiority and inferiority have arising, they necessarily have destruction. Since that has a cause, the cause must be stated. He says: Destruction, however, is from the destruction of the relative cognition, conjunction, and substance, thus threefold. And from the destruction of the triad, there is another position, thus sevenfold destruction.

original: tatrāpekṣābuddhivināśāt tāvad vināśamāha utpanne paratve svakāraṇād II / viśeṣaṇatvāt pūrvaṃ tatsaṃyuktasamavetasamavāyāt sāmānyabuddhirutpadyate / sā ca yasmin kāle samutpannā bhavati tadaiva tatsāmānyajñānāt apekṣābuddhervinaśyattā vināśakāraṇasānnidhyam / sāmānyatajjñānatatsambandhebhyaḥ paratvaguṇabuddherutpadyamānatā utpattikāraṇasānnidhyamityekaḥ kālaḥ / tato 'pekṣābuddhervināśo guṇajñānasyotpādo 'pekṣābuddhivināśād guṇasya vinaśyattā / sāmānyajñānasya vinaśyattā / guṇāśca tajjñānañca tatsambandhaśceti tebhyo dravyabuddherutpadyamānatetyekaḥ kālaḥ / tato dravyabuddherutpattirapekṣābuddhivināśād guṇasya ca vināśo 'nyasya vināśakāraṇasyānupalabdheḥ /
analyzed: tatra apekṣā buddhi vināśāt tāvat vināśam āha utpanne paratve sva kāraṇāt viśeṣaṇa tvāt pūrvam tad saṃyukta samaveta samavāyāt sāmānya buddhiḥ utpadyate sā ca yasmin kāle samutpannā bhavati tadā eva tad sāmānya jñānāt apekṣā buddheḥ vinaśyat tā vināśa kāraṇa sānnidhyam sāmānya tad jñāna tad sambandhebhyaḥ paratva guṇa buddheḥ utpadyamāna tā utpatti kāraṇa sānnidhyam iti ekaḥ kālaḥ  /
translated: There, he states destruction due to the destruction of the relative cognition, in the following: When the quality of posteriority arises from its own cause, due to the relation of inherence in what is conjoined with the prior, the cognition of the universal arises. And at the very moment when that arises, the relative cognition is destroyed due to the cognition of that universal. The presence of the cause of destruction is the presence of the cause of origination from the universal, its cognition, and their relation, of the cognition of the quality of posteriority. This is one moment. Then, the destruction of the relative cognition, the origination of the cognition of the quality, the destruction of the quality due to the destruction of the relative cognition, the destruction of the cognition of the universal, the origination of the cognition of the substance from those - the quality, its cognition, and their relation - this is one moment. Then, the origination of the cognition of the substance, the destruction of the quality due to the destruction of the relative cognition, the non-apprehension of any other cause of destruction.

original: saṃyogavināśādapi katham / apekṣābuddhisamakālameva paratvāparatvādhāre karmotpadyate / tena karmaṇā dikpiṇḍavibhāgaḥ kriyate / apekṣābuddhitaḥ paratvasyotpattirityekaḥ kālaḥ / tataḥ sāmānyabuddherutpattirdikpiṇḍasaṃyogasya ca vināśaḥ / tato yasmin kāle guṇabuddhirutpadyate tasminneva kāle dikpiṇḍasaṃyogavināśād guṇasya vināśaḥ /PDhS
analyzed: saṃyoga vināśāt api katham apekṣā buddhi sama kālam eva paratva aparatva ādhāre karma utpadyate tena karmaṇā diś piṇḍa vibhāgaḥ kriyate apekṣā buddhitaḥ paratvasya utpattiḥ iti ekaḥ kālaḥ tatas sāmānya buddheḥ utpattiḥ diś piṇḍa saṃyogasya ca vināśaḥ tatas yasmin kāle guṇa buddhiḥ utpadyate tasmin eva kāle diś piṇḍa saṃyoga vināśāt guṇasya vināśaḥ
translated: How also from the destruction of conjunction? At the very time of the cognition of relation, action arises in the substratum of remoteness and proximity. By that action, the division of the mass of space is made. The time of the origin of remoteness from the cognition of relation, then the origin of the cognition of the universal and the destruction of the conjunction of the mass of space. Then at the time when the cognition of the quality arises, at that very time, from the destruction of the conjunction of the mass of space, there is the destruction of the quality.

original: saṃyogavināśādapi kathaṃ vināśa ityavyutpannapraśnānantaramāha apekṣābuddhisamakālameva paratvāparatvādhāre karmotpadyate vibhāgaparatvāparatvayorutpadyamānatetyekaḥ kālaḥ / tataḥ tena karmaṇā dikpiṇḍavibhāgaḥ kriyate paratvasya cotpattiḥ / sāmānyabuddherutpadyamānatā / dikpiṇḍasaṃyogasya vinaśyattā / tataḥ sāmānyabuddherutpattirdikpiṇḍasaṃyogasya ca vināśaḥ sāmānyajñānādapekṣābuddhervinaśyattā / guṇabuddherutpadyamānatā / saṃyogavināśād guṇasya vinaśyattā / tato yasmin kāle guṇabuddhirutpadyate tasminneva kāle dikpiṇḍasaṃyogasya asamavāyikāraṇasya vināśād guṇasya paratvasya vināśaḥ / sāmānyajñānādapekṣābuddherapi vināśaḥ / ata evāpekṣābuddhivināśo guṇavināśasya kāraṇaṃ samakālatvāt /
analyzed: saṃyoga vināśāt api katham vināśaḥ iti avyutpanna praśna anantaram āha apekṣā buddhi sama kālam eva paratva aparatva ādhāre karma utpadyate vibhāga paratva aparatvayoḥ utpadyamāna tā iti ekaḥ kālaḥ tatas tena karmaṇā diś piṇḍa vibhāgaḥ kriyate paratvasya ca utpattiḥ sāmānya buddheḥ utpadyamāna tā diś piṇḍa saṃyogasya vinaśyat tā tatas sāmānya buddheḥ utpattiḥ diś piṇḍa saṃyogasya ca vināśaḥ sāmānya jñānāt apekṣā buddheḥ vina
translated: After the question How is destruction from the destruction of conjunction? which is not well-formed, he says: At the very same time as the cognition of relation, action arises in the substratum of remoteness and proximity, and the production of disjunction, remoteness and proximity occurs - this is one moment. Then, by that action, disjunction of the mass of space is produced, and the production of remoteness occurs, the production of the cognition of the universal occurs, the destruction of the conjunction of the mass of space occurs. Then, from the cognition of the universal, the cognition of relation is destroyed, the production of the cognition of the quality occurs, from the destruction of conjunction, the destruction of the quality occurs. Then, at the very moment when the cognition of the quality arises, at that very moment, from the destruction of the non-inherent cause, the conjunction of the mass of space, the destruction of the quality, remoteness, occurs. From the cognition of the universal, the cognition of relation is also destroyed. For this very reason, the destruction of the cognition of relation is the cause of the destruction of the quality, because they occur simultaneously.

original: dravyavināśādapi katham / paratvādhārāvayave karmotpannaṃ yasminneva kāle 'vayavāntarād vibhāgaṃ karoti tasminneva kāle 'pekṣābuddhirutpadyate / II / tato vibhāgād yasminneva kāle saṃyogavināśastasminneva kāle paratvamutpadyate / tataḥ saṃyogavināśād dravyavināśastadvināśācca tadāśritasya guṇasya vināśaḥ /PDhS
analyzed: dravya vināśāt api katham paratva ādhāra avayave karma utpannam yasmin eva kāle vayava antarāt vibhāgam karoti tasmin eva kāle pekṣā buddhiḥ utpadyate    tatas vibhāgāt yasmin eva kāle saṃyoga vināśaḥ tasmin eva kāle paratvam utpadyate tatas saṃyoga vināśāt dravya vināśaḥ tad vināśāt ca tad āśritasya guṇasya vināśaḥ
translated: How also from the destruction of the substance? The action that arises in the part that is the substratum of distance, at the very time it produces disjunction from another part, at that very time the cognition of dependence arises. Then from disjunction, at the very time the destruction of conjunction occurs, at that very time distance arises. Then from the destruction of conjunction, there is the destruction of the substance. And from the destruction of that, there is the destruction of the quality that depends on it.

original: dravyavināśādapi kathaṃ vināśa ityāha paratvādhārāvayave karmotpannam yasmin kāle 'vayavāntaravibhāgaṃ dravyārambhakasaṃyogina /gavirodhinamārabhate saṃyogasya vinaśyattā / tasminneva kāle svakāraṇādapekṣābuddhirutpadyate / paratvasyotpadyamānatā / vibhāgād yasmin kāle saṃyogasya dravyārambhakasya vināśo dravyasya vinaśyattā tasminneva kāle paratvamutpadyate / tatsāmānyajñānasyotpadyamānatā / tataḥ saṃyogavināśād dravyavināśaḥ / sāmānyajñānasyotpādo 'pekṣābuddhervinaśyattā / paratvaguṇasyāpi vinaśyattā / tato dravyavināśāt tadāśritasya guṇasya vināśaḥ / sāmānyajñānādapekṣābuddheśca vināśa iti pūrvakālatvādāśrayavināśa eva guṇavināśe kāraṇamiti /
analyzed: dravya vināśāt api katham vināśaḥ iti āha paratva ādhāra avayave karma utpannam yasmin kāle vayava antara vibhāgam dravya ārambhaka saṃyogi naga virodhinam ārabhate saṃyogasya vinaśyat tā tasmin eva kāle sva kāraṇāt apekṣā buddhiḥ utpadyate paratvasya utpadyamāna tā vibhāgāt yasmin kāle saṃyogasya dravya ārambhakasya vināśaḥ dravyasya vinaśyat tā tasmin eva kāle paratvam utpadyate tad sāmānya jñānasya utpadyamāna tā tatas saṃyoga vināśāt dravya vinā
translated: How is destruction from the destruction of substance? He says: The action arises in the part that is the substratum of distance. At the time when it produces the disjunction of another part, which is incompatible with the conjunction that produces the substance, the destruction of the conjunction. At that very time, the cognition of dependence arises from its own cause. The distance is in the process of arising. From the disjunction, at the time when the destruction of the conjunction that produces the substance occurs, the destruction of the substance. At that very time, the distance arises. The cognition of the universal is in the process of arising. From that, the destruction of the substance due to the destruction of the conjunction. The arising of the cognition of the universal, the destruction of the cognition of dependence. The destruction of the quality of distance also. From that, the destruction of the quality that depends on the destroyed substance. The destruction of the cognition of the universal and the cognition of dependence. Therefore, the destruction of the quality is due to the destruction of the substratum itself, because it occurs earlier.

original: dravyāpekṣābuddhyoryugapad vināśādapi katham / yadā paratvādhārāvayave karmotpadyate tadaivāpekṣābuddhirutpadyate / karmaṇā cāvayavāntarād vibhāgaḥ kriyate / paratvasyotpattirityekaḥ kālaḥ / tato yasminneva kāle 'vayavavibhāgād dravyārambhakasaṃyogavināśastasminneva kāle sāmānyabuddhirutpadyate / tadanantaraṃ saṃyogavināśād dravyavināśaḥ / sāmānyabuddheścāpekṣābuddhivināśa ityekaḥ kālaḥ / tato dravyāpekṣābuddhyorvināśāt paratvasya vināśaḥ /PDhS
analyzed: dravya apekṣā buddhyoḥ yugapad vināśāt api katham yadā paratva ādhāra avayave karma utpadyate tadā eva apekṣā buddhiḥ utpadyate karmaṇā ca avayava antarāt vibhāgaḥ kriyate paratvasya utpattiḥ iti ekaḥ kālaḥ tatas yasmin eva kāle vayava vibhāgāt dravya ārambhaka saṃyoga vināśaḥ tasmin eva kāle sāmānya buddhiḥ utpadyate tad anantaram saṃyoga vināśāt dravya vināśaḥ sāmānya buddheḥ ca apekṣā buddhi vināśaḥ iti ekaḥ kālaḥ tatas dravya apek
translated: And how is it that the substance and the cognition of relation are destroyed simultaneously? When an action arises in the part that is the substratum of distance, at that very time the cognition of relation arises. And by the action, disjunction is produced from another part. The arising of distance is at one time. Then, at the very time when the destruction of the conjunction that causes the substance occurs due to the disjunction of the parts, at that very time the cognition of the universal arises. Immediately after that, the destruction of the substance occurs due to the destruction of the conjunction, and the destruction of the cognition of relation occurs due to the destruction of the cognition of the universal. This is at one time. Then, due to the destruction of the substance and the cognition of relation, the destruction of distance occurs.

original: dravyāpekṣābuddhyoryugapad vināśādapi kathaṃ paratvāparatvayorvināśastadāha yadā paratvādhārasyotpatsyamānaparatvasyāvayave karmotpadyate vibhāgasyotpadyamānatā tadaivāpekṣābuddhirutpadyate / paratvasyotpadyamānatā / karmaṇā cāvayavāntarād dravyārambhakasaṃyogavirodhivibhāgaḥ / saṃyogasya vinaśyattā / paratvasyotpattistatsāmānyajñānasyotpadyamānatetyekaḥ kālaḥ / tato yasminneva kāle vibhāgād dravyārambhakasaṃyogavināśo dravyasya vinaśyattā / tasminneva kāle sāmānyabuddhirutpadyate / apekṣābuddhervinaśyattā / tadanantaraṃ saṃyogavināśād dravyavināśaḥ / sāmānyabuddheścāpekṣābuddhivināśaḥ II / guṇasya vinaśyattetyekaḥ kālaḥ / tato dravyāpekṣābuddhyorvināśāt tadāśritasya paratvasya vināśaḥ iti / ekaikasyānyatraguṇavināśe sāmarthyāvadhāraṇādubhayoratra pūrvakālabhāvitve sati kāraṇatvaṃ niścīyate /
analyzed: dravya apekṣā buddhyoḥ yugapad vināśāt api katham paratva aparatvayoḥ vināśaḥ tat āha yadā paratva ādhārasya utpatsyamāna paratvasya avayave karma utpadyate vibhāgasya utpadyamāna tā tadā eva apekṣā buddhiḥ utpadyate paratvasya utpadyamāna tā karmaṇā ca avayava antarāt dravya ārambhaka saṃyoga virodhi vibhāgaḥ saṃyogasya vinaśyat tā paratvasya utpattiḥ tad sāmānya jñānasya utpadyamāna tā iti ekaḥ kālaḥ tatas yasmin eva kāle vibhāgāt dravya ārambh
translated: How is it that the destruction of distance and proximity occurs even when the substance and the cognition of dependence are destroyed simultaneously? He says: When the action of the arising distance of the substratum of distance arises in a part, and the arising of the disjunction is about to occur, at that very time the cognition of dependence arises, and the arising of distance is about to occur. And by the action, there is the disjunction that is opposed to the conjunction causing the origination of the substance from another part, and the destruction of the conjunction is about to occur. And the origination of distance, and the arising of the cognition of the universal is about to occur - this is one moment. Then, in that very moment when the destruction of the conjunction causing the origination of the substance occurs due to the disjunction, and the destruction of the substance is about to occur, at that very time the cognition of the universal arises, and the destruction of the cognition of dependence is about to occur. Immediately after that, due to the destruction of the conjunction, there is the destruction of the substance, and the destruction of the cognition of dependence due to the cognition of the universal. And the destruction of the quality is about to occur - this is one moment. Then, due to the destruction of the substance and the cognition of dependence, the destruction of the distance dependent on them occurs.

original: dravyasaṃyogavināśādapi katham / yadā paratvādhārāvayave karmotpannam avayavāntarād vibhāgaṃ karoti tasminneva kāle piṇḍakarmāpekṣābuddhyoryugapadutpattiḥ / tato yasminneva kāle paratvasyotpattistasminneva kāle vibhāgād dravyārambhakasaṃyogavināśaḥ / piṇḍakarmaṇā dikpiṇḍasya ca vibhāgaḥ kriyata ityekaḥ kālaḥ / tato yasminneva kāle sāmānyabuddhirutpadyate tasminneva kāle dravyārambhakasaṃyogavināśāt piṇḍavināśaḥ / piṇḍavināśācca piṇḍasaṃyogavināśaḥ / tato guṇabuddhisamakālaṃ piṇḍadikpiṇḍasaṃyogavināśāt paratvasya nāśaḥ /PDhS
analyzed: dravya saṃyoga vināśāt api katham yadā paratva ādhāra avayave karma utpannam avayava antarāt vibhāgam karoti tasmin eva kāle piṇḍa karma apekṣā buddhyoḥ yugapad utpattiḥ tatas yasmin eva kāle paratvasya utpattiḥ tasmin eva kāle vibhāgāt dravya ārambhaka saṃyoga vināśaḥ piṇḍa karmaṇā diś piṇḍasya ca vibhāgaḥ kriyate iti ekaḥ kālaḥ tatas yasmin eva kāle sāmānya buddhiḥ utpadyate tasmin eva kāle dravya ārambhaka saṃyoga vināśāt piṇḍa vinā
translated: How also from the destruction of the conjunction of substances? When an action arises in a part that is the substratum of distance, it produces disjunction from another part. At that very moment, the action of the whole and the cognition of expectancy arise simultaneously. Then, at the very moment when distance arises, at that very moment, from disjunction, there is the destruction of the conjunction that produces the substance. By the action of the whole, disjunction of the whole from space is produced. Thus, at one moment, when the cognition of the universal arises, at that very moment, from the destruction of the conjunction that produces the substance, there is the destruction of the whole. And from the destruction of the whole, there is the destruction of the conjunction of the whole. Then, at the very moment when the cognition of the quality arises, from the destruction of the conjunction of the whole with space, there is the destruction of distance.

original: dravyasaṃyogavināśādapi kathaṃ paratvāparatvayorvināśa ityāha yadā dravyāvayave /paratvādhārāvayave karmotpannamavayavāntarād vibhāgaṃ karoti saṃyogasya vinaśyattā / tasminneva kāle piṇḍe 'pi samavāyikāraṇe karma cāpekṣābuddhiśca svakāraṇāt tayoryugapadutpattiḥ / dikpiṇḍavibhāgaparatvāparatvayorutpadyamānatetyekaḥ kālaḥ / tato yasminneva kāle paratvamutpadyate tatsāmānyajñānasyotpadyamānatā / tasminneva kāle 'vayavavibhāgād dravyārambhakasaṃyogavināśaḥ / dravyasya vinaśyattā / piṇḍakarmaṇā ca dikpiṇḍavibhāgaḥ kriyate / saṃyogasya vinaśyattetyekaḥ kālaḥ / tato yasminneva kāle sāmānyabuddhirutpadyate guṇabuddherutpadyamānatā / apekṣābuddhervinaśyattā / tatsamakālaṃ saṃyogavināśāt piṇḍavināśaḥ / vibhāgācca dikpiṇḍasaṃyogavināśaḥ / guṇasya vinaśyattā / tato guṇabuddhisamakālaṃ piṇḍasaṃyogayorvināśāt paratvasya vināśaḥ / sāmānyabuddheścāpekṣābuddhivināśa iti / ata eva samakālatvādapekṣābuddhivināśo na kāraṇam / piṇḍasaṃyogavināśayoścānyatra sāmarthyāvadhāraṇe sati pūrvakālabhāvitvāt kāraṇatvamiti /
analyzed: dravya saṃyoga vināśāt api katham paratva aparatvayoḥ vināśaḥ iti āha yadā dravya avayave paratva ādhāra avayave karma utpannam avayava antarāt vibhāgam karoti saṃyogasya vinaśyat tā tasmin eva kāle piṇḍe samavāyi kāraṇe karma ca apekṣā buddhiḥ ca sva kāraṇāt tayoḥ yugapad utpattiḥ diś piṇḍa vibhāga paratva aparatvayoḥ utpadyamāna tā iti ekaḥ kālaḥ tatas yasmin eva kāle paratvam utpadyate tat sāmānya jñānasya utpadyamāna tā tasmin eva kāle v
translated: How is it that the destruction of distance and proximity occurs due to the destruction of the conjunction of substances? He says: When an action arises in the part that is the substratum of distance, it causes separation from another part, and the conjunction is destroyed. At that very moment, in the aggregate which is the inherent cause, action and the cognition of dependence arise simultaneously from their own causes. The separation of the aggregate from space and the arising of distance and proximity occur at the same moment. Then, at the very moment when distance arises, the cognition of its universal arises. At that very moment, due to the separation of the parts, the conjunction that produces the substance is destroyed, and the substance is destroyed. And by the action of the aggregate, the separation of the aggregate from space is produced, and the conjunction is destroyed. This occurs at the same moment. Then, at the very moment when the cognition of the universal arises, the cognition of the quality is about to arise, and the cognition of dependence is destroyed. At the same time, due to the destruction of conjunction, the aggregate is destroyed.

original: saṃyogāpekṣābuddhyoryugapad vināśādapi katham / yadā paratvamutpadyate tadā paratvādhāre karma / tato yasminneva kāle paratvasāmānyabuddhirutpadyate II / tasminneva kāle piṇḍakarmaṇā dikpiṇḍavibhāgaḥ kriyate / tataḥ sāmānyabuddhito 'pekṣābuddhivināśo vibhāgācca dikpiṇḍasaṃyogavināśa ityekaḥ kālaḥ / tataḥ saṃyogāpekṣābuddhyorvināśāt paratvasya vināśaḥ /PDhS
analyzed: saṃyoga apekṣā buddhyoḥ yugapad vināśāt api katham yadā paratvam utpadyate tadā paratva ādhāre karma tatas yasmin eva kāle paratva sāmānya buddhiḥ utpadyate tasmin eva kāle piṇḍa karmaṇā diś piṇḍa vibhāgaḥ kriyate tatas sāmānya buddhitaḥ upekṣā buddhi vināśaḥ vibhāgāt ca diś piṇḍa saṃyoga vināśaḥ iti ekaḥ kālaḥ tatas saṃyoga apekṣā buddhyoḥ vināśāt paratvasya vināśaḥ pdhs
translated: And how is it that the conjunction and the cognition of expectancy are destroyed simultaneously? When distance arises, then action in the substratum of distance. Then, at the very time when the cognition of the universal distance arises, at that very time, by the action of the individual, the division of the individual of space is made. Then, from the universal cognition, the destruction of the cognition of expectancy, and from the division, the destruction of the conjunction of the individual of space - this is one moment. Then, from the destruction of the conjunction and the cognition of expectancy, the destruction of distance.

original: saṃyogāpekṣābuddhyoryugapad vināśādapi kathaṃ vināśa ityāha yadā paratvamutpadyate svakāraṇaparatvasāmānyajñānasyotpadyamānatā / tadā paratvādhāre svakāraṇāt karma / vibhāgasyotpadyamānatā / tato yasminneva kāle paratvasāmānyabuddhirutpadyate guṇabuddherutpadyamānatā / apekṣābuddhervinaśyattā / tasminneva kāle piṇḍakarmaṇā dikpiṇḍavibhāgaḥ kriyate tatsaṃyogasya vinaśyattā / tataḥ sāmānyabuddhito 'pekṣābuddhivināśo vibhāgācca dikpiṇḍasaṃyogavināśaḥ guṇasya vinaśyattetyekaḥ kālaḥ / tataḥ saṃyogāpekṣābuddhyorvināśāt paratvasya vināśaḥ iti /
analyzed: saṃyoga apekṣā buddhyoḥ yugapad vināśāt api katham vināśaḥ iti āha yadā paratvam utpadyate sva kāraṇa paratva sāmānya jñānasya utpadyamāna tā tadā paratva ādhāre sva kāraṇāt karma vibhāgasya utpadyamāna tā tatas yasmin eva kāle paratva sāmānya buddhiḥ utpadyate guṇa buddheḥ utpadyamāna tā apekṣā buddheḥ vinaśyat tā tasmin eva kāle piṇḍa karmaṇā diś piṇḍa vibhāgaḥ kriyate tad saṃyogasya vinaśyat tā tatas sāmānya buddhitaḥ upekṣā
translated: How is destruction due to the simultaneous destruction of the cognition of conjunction and the cognition of dependence? He says: When the quality of distance arises, the cognition of the universal of distance arising from its own cause arises. At that time, in the substratum of distance, the action arising from its own cause arises. Then, in the very moment when the cognition of the universal of distance arises, the cognition of the quality arises, and the cognition of dependence is destroyed. In that very moment, the action of the mass divides the mass of space by the action of the mass. The destruction of the conjunction occurs. Then, from the cognition of the universal, the destruction of the cognition of dependence, and from the division, the destruction of the conjunction of the mass of space, and the destruction of the quality - this is one moment. Then, from the destruction of the conjunction and the cognition of dependence, the destruction of distance occurs.

original: trayāṇāṃ samavāyyasamavāyinimittakāraṇānāṃ yugapad vināśādapi katham / yadāpekṣābuddhirutpadyate tadā piṇḍāvayave karma / tato yasminneva kāle karmaṇāvayavāntarād vibhāgaḥ kriyate 'pekṣābuddheḥ paratvasya cotpattistasminneva kāle piṇḍe 'pi karma / tato 'vayavavibhāgāt piṇḍārambhakasaṃyogavināśaḥ / piṇḍakarmaṇā ca dikpiṇḍavibhāgaḥ kriyate / sāmānyabuddheścotpattirityekaḥ kālaḥ / tataḥ saṃyogavināśāt piṇḍavināśaḥ / vibhāgācca dikpiṇḍasaṃyogavināśaḥ / sāmānyajñānādapekṣābuddhervināśa ityetat sarvaṃ yugapat / trayāṇāṃ samavāyyasamavāyinimittakāraṇānāṃ vināśāt paratvasya vināśa iti /PDhS
analyzed: trayāṇām samavāyi asamavāyi nimitta kāraṇānām yugapad vināśāt api katham yadā apekṣā buddhiḥ utpadyate tadā piṇḍa avayave karma tatas yasmin eva kāle karmaṇā avayava antarāt vibhāgaḥ kriyate pekṣā buddheḥ para tvasya ca utpattiḥ tasmin eva kāle piṇḍe pi karma tatas vayava vibhāgāt piṇḍa ārambhaka saṃyoga vināśaḥ piṇḍa karmaṇā ca diś piṇḍa vibhāgaḥ kriyate sāmānya buddheḥ ca utpattiḥ iti ekaḥ kālaḥ tatas saṃyoga vināśāt
translated: How also from the simultaneous destruction of the three causes - the inherent, non-inherent, and instrumental causes? When the cognition of dependence arises, then in the composite and its parts there is action. Then at the very moment when by the action a separation is produced from another part and the cognition of priority arises, at that very moment there is action in the composite also. Then from the separation of the parts, the destruction of the conjunction that produces the composite. And by the action of the composite, a separation is produced in the composite in space. And the cognition of the universal arises. This is one moment. Then from the destruction of the conjunction, the destruction of the composite. And from the separation, the destruction of the conjunction of the composite in space. And from the cognition of the universal, the destruction of the cognition of dependence. All this is simultaneous. From the destruction of the three causes - the inherent, non-inherent, and instrumental causes - there is the destruction of priority.

original: trayāṇāṃ samavāyyasamavāyinimittānāṃ yugapad vināśādapi kathaṃ vināśa ityāha yadāpekṣābuddhirutpadyate paratvasyotpadyamānatā / tadā piṇḍāvayave karma vibhāgasyotpadyamānatā / tato yasminneva kāle 'vayavāntarād dravyārambhakasaṃyogavirodhivibhāgaḥ kriyate / avayavakarmaṇā saṃyogasya vinaśyattā / paratvasyotpattiḥ / tatsāmānyajñānasyotpadyamānatā / tasminneva kāle svakāraṇāt piṇḍe 'pi karma / vibhāgasyotpadyamānatā / tato vibhāgāt piṇḍārambhakasaṃyogavināśaḥ / piṇḍasya vinaśyattā / piṇḍakarmaṇā ca vibhāgaḥ kriyate / II / dikpiṇḍasaṃyogasya vinaśyattā sāmānyabuddheścotpattiḥ / apekṣābuddhervinaśyattā / guṇabuddherutpadyamānatetyekaḥ kālaḥ / tataḥ saṃyogavināśāt piṇḍavināśaḥ / vibhāgācca dikpiṇḍasaṃyogavināśaḥ / sāmānyajñānādapekṣābuddhervināśa ityetat sarvaṃ yugapad bhavatīti / tatra trayāṇāṃ samavāyyasamavāyinimittānāṃ vināśāt paratvasya vināśa iti / anyatra hi vyastānāṃ kāraṇatvopalabdheḥ samuditānāmatra sambhavād guṇavināśe kāraṇatvamiti sambhāvyamānānekakāraṇatvopanyāsaḥ /
analyzed: trayāṇām samavāyi asamavāyi nimittānām yugapad vināśāt api katham vināśaḥ iti āha yadā apekṣā buddhiḥ utpadyate paratvasya utpadyamāna tā tadā piṇḍa avayave karma vibhāgasya utpadyamāna tā tatas yasmin eva kāle vayava antarāt dravya ārambhaka saṃyoga virodhi vibhāgaḥ kriyate avayava karmaṇā saṃyogasya vinaśyat tā paratvasya utpattiḥ tad sāmānya jñānasya utpadyamāna tā tasmin eva kāle sva kāraṇāt piṇḍe pi karma vibhāgasya utpadyamāna tā tata
translated: How is destruction due to the simultaneous destruction of the three - inherence, non-inherence, and cause? He says: When the cognition of dependence arises, the state of being produced of distance, then in the part of the lump, the action, the state of being produced of separation. Then, at that very moment, when separation opposed to the conjunction causing the substance is produced from another part, the state of being destroyed of conjunction by the action of the part, the production of distance, the state of being produced of the cognition of the universal. At that very moment, the action in the lump due to its own cause, the state of being produced of separation. Then, from that separation, the destruction of the conjunction causing the lump, the state of being destroyed of the lump, and separation is produced by the action of the lump. The state of being destroyed of the conjunction with the lump in space, and the production of the cognition of the universal, the state of being destroyed of the cognition of dependence, the state of being produced of the cognition of quality - this is one moment. Then, from the destruction of conjunction, the destruction of the lump, and from separation, the destruction of the conjunction of the lump with space.

original: buddhidharmyam
analyzed: buddhi dharmyam
translated: The property of the intellect

original: buddhirupalabdhirjñānaṃ pratyaya iti paryāyāḥ /PDhS
analyzed: buddhiḥ upalabdhiḥ jñānam pratyayaḥ iti paryāyāḥ pdhs
translated: Intellect, perception, knowledge, and cognition are synonyms.

original: athedānīṃ buddheravasaraprāptāyā lakṣaṇaparīkṣārthaṃ buddhirupalabdhiḥ ityādi prakaraṇam / buddhiriti padam āvartyamānaṃ lakṣyanirdeśo lakṣaṇanirdeśaśca bhavati / tathā hi / buddhiriti lakṣyanirdeśaḥ / buddhirupalabdhirjñānaṃ pratyaya iti paryāyā lakṣaṇam /
analyzed: atha idānīm buddheḥ avasara prāptāyāḥ lakṣaṇa parīkṣā artham buddhiḥ upalabdhiḥ ityādi prakaraṇam buddhiḥ iti padam āvartyamānam lakṣya nirdeśaḥ lakṣaṇa nirdeśaḥ ca bhavati tathā hi buddhiḥ iti lakṣya nirdeśaḥ buddhiḥ upalabdhiḥ jñānam pratyayaḥ iti paryāyāḥ lakṣaṇam
translated: Now, in order to examine the definition of intellect, which has come to the occasion, the section begins with intellect is perception and so on. The word intellect is repeated to indicate both the object to be defined and the definition. Thus, intellect indicates the object to be defined, and intellect, perception, knowledge, and cognition are synonyms is the definition.

original: atha ākāśe paryāyaśabdarūpatvāt vartamānāḥ kathaṃ vyadhikaraṇatvāt buddherlakṣaṇam / vācyavācakabhāvena taddharmatvāt / lakṣaṇavaicitryajñāpanārthañcātra paryāyalakṣaṇābhidhānam / tathā hi / na param asādhāraṇatvāt kāryakaraṇādilakṣaṇam paryāyātmakañceti /
analyzed: atha ākāśe paryāya śabda rūpa tvāt vartamānāḥ katham vyadhikaraṇa tvāt buddheḥ lakṣaṇam vācya vācaka bhāvena tad dharma tvāt lakṣaṇa vaicitrya jñāpana artham ca atra paryāya lakṣaṇa abhidhānam tathā hi na param asādhāraṇa tvāt kārya karaṇa ādi lakṣaṇam paryāya ātmakam ca iti
translated: Now, since the synonyms are in the form of words in space, how are they the definition of intellect, since they are not co-referential? Because they are its properties by the relation of denoted and denotator. The statement of the definition in the form of synonyms here is for the purpose of showing the variety of definitions. Thus, the definition of the effect, cause, etc. is not supreme, because it is not unique, and it is in the form of synonyms.

original: atha śabdānāṃ puruṣecchānuvidhāyitayā arthāntare 'pi vṛttiḥ sambhavatīti vyabhicāraḥ / na / anādikālapravāhāyātatvena viśeṣitatvāt / tathā hi / buddhiritarasmād bhidyate / anādikālapravāhāyātetthambhūtaparyāyābhidheyatvāt / yastvitarasmānna bhidyate na cāsāvevam / yathā rūpādiriti / vyavahāro vā sādhyaḥ /
analyzed: atha śabdānām puruṣa icchā anuvidhāyi tayā artha antare pi vṛttiḥ sambhavati iti vyabhicāraḥ na anādi kāla pravāha āyāta tvena viśeṣita tvāt tathā hi buddhiḥ itarasmāt bhidyate anādi kāla pravāha āyāta itthambhūta paryāya abhidheya tvāt yaḥ tu itarasmāt na bhidyate na ca asau evam yathā rūpa ādiḥ iti vyavahāraḥ vā sādhyaḥ
translated: If it be said that there is no invariable concomitance, because words can apply to other things also, in accordance with the speaker’s whim,—we say no; because the concomitance is restricted to the case where the word has been in use from time immemorial. For instance, the ‘Buddhi’ (Intellect) is something different from the ‘other things’, because it is denoted by a term the history of which cannot be traced, just like the term ‘rūpa’ (colour). That which is not different from the ‘other things’ is not so denoted, like ‘rūpa’ (form). Or what is meant to be proved is the fact of the word being used in a certain sense.

original: nanu buddheranye 'pi paryāyā vidyanta iti tatparihāreṇāmīṣāmeva lakṣaṇatvenābhidhāne viśeṣaheturvaktavyaḥ / sa cāyaṃ viśeṣo 'traiva vipratipatteḥ / lakṣaṇārthamapīdaṃ vākyaṃ sāmarthyāt tannirāsaparaṃ bhavatīti /
analyzed: nanu buddheḥ anye pi paryāyāḥ vidyante iti tad parihāreṇa amīṣām eva lakṣaṇa tvena abhidhāne viśeṣa hetuḥ vaktavyaḥ sa ca ayam vipratipatteḥ lakṣaṇa artham api idam vākyam sāmarthyāt tad nirāsa param bhavati iti
translated: Inasmuch as there are other synonyms of ‘buddhi’, it becomes necessary to state the reason for the use of the particular term ‘cetanā’ (in the conclusion); and this reason is supplied by the fact of the ‘other things’ being ‘non-intelligent’, which is the point at issue. The sentence (of the commentary) ‘cetanā’ (in the Bhāṣya) is meant to be the statement of the reason (for the conclusion).

original: tathā ca sāṃkhyāḥ / pradhānasyādyo vikāro buddhiḥ / bījasyocchūnateva / II / pradhānañca sattvarajastamasāṃ sāmyāvasthā / tadvikāro vaiṣamyam / upalabdhistu sukhaduḥkhākārapariṇatāyāṃ buddhāvātmanaḥ pratibimbodayo bhogaḥ / tadāha /
analyzed: tathā ca sāṃkhyāḥ pradhānasya ādyaḥ vikāraḥ buddhiḥ bījasya ucchūna tā iva pradhānam ca sattva rajaḥ tamasām sāmya avasthā tad vikāraḥ vaiṣamyam upalabdhiḥ tu sukha duḥkha ākāra pariṇatāyām buddhau ātmanaḥ pratibimba udayaḥ bhogaḥ tat āha
translated: And so do the Sāṃkhyas. The first modification of pradhāna is buddhi, like the swelling of a seed. And pradhāna is the state of equilibrium of sattva, rajas, and tamas. Its modification is inequality. But enjoyment is the arising of the reflection of the self in buddhi, which has become modified into the form of pleasure and pain. He says this:

original: viviktadṛkpariṇato buddhau bhogo 'sya kathyate /
analyzed: vivikta dṛś pariṇataḥ buddhau kathyate
translated: It is said that his enjoyment is the transformation of buddhi into a distinct vision.

original: pratibimbodayaḥ svacche yathā candramaso 'mbhasi // āsuriḥ
analyzed: pratibimba udayaḥ svacche yathā candramasaḥ mbhasi āsuriḥ
translated: Like the arising of a reflection of the moon in clear water.

original: iti /
analyzed: iti
translated: Āsuri.

original: viviktadṛgviṣayākārapariṇatendriyākārapariṇatiryasyāḥ sā tathoktā / tasyāṃ buddhau satyāmātmano bhogaḥ kathyate / kiṃ rūpaḥ / pratibimbodayaḥ / na vāstavaḥ / yathā candramasaḥ pratibimbanaṃ svacche / na kaluṣāmbhasi / evaṃ viśiṣṭapariṇāmopacitāyāṃ buddhāvātmana iti / vāstave hi bhoge puruṣasya pūrvasvarūpanivṛttau svarūpāntarāpattirvikāraḥ syāt / tatra cācetanatvādanekadūṣaṇamiti /
analyzed: vivikta dṛś viṣaya ākāra pariṇata indriya ākāra pariṇatiḥ yasyāḥ sā tathā uktā tasyām buddhau satyām ātmanaḥ bhogaḥ kathyate kim rūpaḥ pratibimba udayaḥ na vāstavaḥ yathā candramasaḥ pratibimbanam svacche na kaluṣa ambhasi evam viśiṣṭa pariṇāma upacitāyām buddhau ātmanaḥ iti  /
translated: That cognition in which the senses have undergone a transformation into the form of the object perceived by the isolated cognition is said to be of that kind. When such cognition exists, the enjoyment of the self is described. What is its form? The arising of a reflection, not real, just as the reflection of the moon is in clear water, not in turbid water. In the same way, in the cognition that has accumulated such a special transformation, there is the self. For if the enjoyment were real, when the previous nature of the self ceased, there would be the attainment of another nature, which would be a modification. And in that case, due to being insentient, there would be many faults.

original: anye tvanyathā bhogaṃ manyante / yathā hi /
analyzed: anye tu anyathā bhogam manyante yathā hi
translated: Others, however, think of enjoyment in another way, as follows:

original: puruṣo 'vikṛtātmaiva svanirbhāsena cetanam /
analyzed: puruṣaḥ vikṛta ātmā eva sva nirbhāsena cetanam
translated: The self, whose nature is unchanging, makes the mind conscious by its own manifestation,🔽through proximity, like a crystal with an overlay.

original: manaḥ karoti sānnidhyādupādhisphaṭikaṃ yathā // vindhyavāsī
analyzed: manaḥ karoti sānnidhyāt upādhi sphaṭikam yathā vindhya vāsī
translated: Vindhyavāsin

original: iti /
analyzed: iti
translated: Thus.

original: sānnidhyādupādhisphaṭikamatadrūpaṃ svanirbhāsaṃ svākāraṃ karoti / evamayaṃ puruṣo 'vikṛtasvarūpo 'cetanaṃ manaḥ svanirbhāsaṃ cetanamiva karoti sānnidhyāt / na punarvastutastasya caitanyaṃ vikāritvāt / jñānantu viṣayākārapariṇatendriyākāratayā buddheḥ pariṇāmaḥ / tadā bhogotsukaṃ puruṣaṃ matvā buddherākūtiḥ sampadyate / tadākūtasaṃvedanāccendriyāṇāṃ pūrvasvarūpanivṛtterviṣayākārapariṇāmaḥ / anyathā hi pūrvarūpāparityāge prāgiva paścādapi viṣayāvabodho na syāt / viṣayākārapariṇāmaśca pratikarmavyavasthāto nīlasyedaṃ pītasyedamiti jñeyam / anyathā hi viṣayākāraṃ vinā pariṇāmasyāviśeṣādiyaṃ vyavasthā na syāt / evaṃ viṣayākārapariṇatendriyeṣu tadākāratayā buddheḥ pariṇāmaḥ /
analyzed: sānnidhyāt upādhi sphaṭikam a tad rūpam sva nirbhāsam sva ākāram karoti evam ayam puruṣaḥ cetanam manaḥ sva nirbhāsam cetanam iva karoti sānnidhyāt na punar vastutas tasya caitanyam vikāri tvāt jñānan tu viṣaya ākāra pariṇata indriya ākāra tayā buddheḥ pariṇāmaḥ tadā bhoga utsukam puruṣam matvā buddheḥ ākūtiḥ sampadyate tad ākūta saṃvedanāt ca indriyāṇām pūrva sva rūpa nivṛtteḥ viṣaya ākāra pariṇāmaḥ anyathā hi pūrva rūpa aparityāg
translated: Due to proximity, the crystal with limiting adjuncts makes its own appearance in the form of that [adjunct]. Similarly, this Purusha, whose own nature is unchanged, makes the insentient mind appear as if it were sentient due to proximity. But in reality, it does not have sentience, because it is subject to change. Knowledge, however, is a transformation of the intellect in the form of the sense organs that have taken on the appearance of the object. Then, considering that the Purusha is eager for enjoyment, the intellect becomes intention. And from the awareness of that intention, due to the cessation of the previous form of the sense organs, there is a transformation into the appearance of the object. Otherwise, if the previous form were not abandoned, the object would not be cognized later just as it was before. And the transformation into the appearance of the object should be understood as belonging to this blue, to this yellow, etc., due to the restriction to each object. Otherwise, if there were no transformation into the appearance of the object, this restriction would not exist due to the non-distinction of the transformation. Thus, when the sense organs have transformed into the appearance of the object, the intellect also transforms into that appearance.

original: tathāsiddhyādipratyayāḥ pañcāśad buddheḥ pariṇāmaviśeṣā eva /
analyzed: tathā asiddhi ādi pratyayāḥ pañcāśat buddheḥ pariṇāma viśeṣāḥ eva
translated: Similarly, the fifty mental states such as non-accomplishment are only special transformations of consciousness.

original: aṣṭadhā siddhirnavadhā tuṣṭiḥ pañcaviparyayabhedāḥ /
analyzed: aṣṭadhā siddhiḥ navadhā tuṣṭiḥ pañca viparyaya bhedāḥ
translated: Accomplishment is eightfold, contentment is ninefold, the divisions of the five errors are

original: tathāśaktiraṣṭāviṃśatidhetyasiddhituṣṭyorbhedāḥ //
analyzed: tathā śaktiḥ aṣṭāviṃśatidhā iti asiddhi tuṣṭyoḥ bhedāḥ
translated: Similarly, incapacity is twenty-eightfold, thus the divisions of non-accomplishment and contentment.

original: saptadaśaikādaśendriyavadhāśceti pañcāśad bhavantīti paryāyatvaṃ buddhyādiśabdānāṃ na siddhāḥ / vibhinnārthavācakatvāt / abhinnapravṛttinimittāścaikārthavācakāḥ śabdāḥ paryāyā iti /
analyzed: saptadaśa ekādaśa indriya vadhāḥ ca iti pañcāśat bhavanti iti paryāya tvam buddhi ādi śabdānām na siddhāḥ vibhinna artha vācaka tvāt abhinna pravṛtti nimittāḥ ca eka artha vācakāḥ śabdāḥ paryāyāḥ iti
translated: And the obstructions of the seventeen and eleven faculties - thus there are fifty. Thus the identity of the words intellect etc. is not established, because they denote different meanings. Words that have the same reason for application and denote the same meaning are synonyms.

original: tadetadasāmpratam / eṣāṃ prayogataḥ paryāyatāpratīteḥ / tathā hi / buddhaḥ / upalabdhaḥ / jñātaḥ / pratītaḥ / / ityekasminnarthe prayujyamānāḥ pratīyante / vibhinnārthatāyāntu upalabdho na buddhaḥ / jñāto na pratīta iti saṃvedanaṃ syāt / na caitadasti / na ca pradhānāsattvasya vakṣyamāṇatvāt tadvikārasya buddheḥ sadbhāvaḥ / tadabhāvādātmani buddherna bimbanam / upalabdhistatpariṇāmo vā / jñānaṃ / pratyayaśceti / yadi na vāstavo bhogaḥ syāt / na saṃsāryātmano muktād viśeṣaḥ / svaniṣṭhāyāściterubhayatrāviśeṣāt /
analyzed: tat etat asāmpratam eṣām prayogataḥ paryāya tā pratīteḥ tathā hi buddhaḥ upalabdhaḥ jñātaḥ pratītaḥ iti ekasmin arthe prayujyamānāḥ pratīyante vibhinna arthatāyāntu upalabdhaḥ na buddhaḥ jñātaḥ na pratītaḥ iti saṃvedanam syāt na ca etat asti na ca pradhāna asattvasya vakṣyamāṇa tvāt tad vikārasya buddheḥ sadbhāvaḥ tad abhāvāt ātmani buddheḥ na bimbanam upalabdhiḥ tad pariṇāmaḥ vā jñānam pratyayaḥ ca iti yadi na vāstavaḥ bhogaḥ s
translated: This is not correct, because these are understood as synonyms through usage. For example, buddha (awakened), upalabdha (perceived), jñāta (known), and pratīta (realized) are used for the same object and are understood as such. But if they had different meanings, there would be the awareness that what is perceived is not awakened, what is known is not realized, and so on, but this does not happen. And since the existence of pradhāna will be denied later, its modification, buddhi, does not exist. In the absence of that, there is no reflection of buddhi in the self, which is either its perception or modification. Knowledge and cognition are not real enjoyments. If there were no real enjoyment, there would be no difference between the transmigrating self and the liberated self, because consciousness, which is self-contained, is the same in both cases.

original: na ca vyāpitvāviśeṣāt saṃsāryātmana eva buddherviśeṣeṇa sānnidhyāt pratibimbanaṃ netarasyeti vācyam / bhogyabhoktṛtvasambandhastu bhogasyāvāstavatvād vicāryaḥ / na ca karmaiva niyāmakam / tasya buddhyā sampāditvāt / tathā hi / buddhyā sampāditaṃ karma puruṣeṇa viśiṣṭasambandhābhāvād aśeṣapuruṣopabhogyaṃ syāt / na ca buddheḥ kartṛtvam / acetanatvāt / caitanyaṃ hi pradhānaṃ / na kriyākaraṇe vartata iti / kartṛtvaṃ hi svātantryam tatra karaṇatvaṃ pāratantryaṃ na syāt / svātantryapāratantryorvidhipratiṣedharūpatvāditi puruṣasyaiva kartṛtvamabhyupeyam / na ca tasya pūrvamakṛtvā kurvataḥ pariṇāmitvam / kārakasākalye kāryakaraṇāt / tadvaikalye cākaraṇāt / sākalyavaikalyayoścāvirbhāvatirobhāvābhyāṃ nātmanastathābhāvastato 'nyatvāt / ataḥ puruṣasya kartṛtve yuktaṃ vāstavaṃ bhoktṛtvam / anyathā hi bhogakriyāmakurvataḥ kathamudāsīnasya bhoktṛtvaṃ syāt / bhogasya sukhaduḥkhavedanārūpatvāt / tadādhāratā tu bhoktṛtvamiti /
analyzed: na ca vyāpi tva aviśeṣāt saṃsāri ātmanaḥ eva buddheḥ viśeṣeṇa sānnidhyāt pratibimbanam na itarasya iti vācyam bhogya bhoktṛ tva sambandhaḥ tu bhogasya avāstava tvāt vicāryaḥ na ca karma eva niyāmakam tasya buddhyā sampādi tvāt tathā hi buddhyā sampāditam karma puruṣeṇa viśiṣṭa sambandha abhāvāt aśeṣa puruṣa upabhogyam syāt na ca buddheḥ kartṛ tvam acetana tvāt caitanyam hi pradhānam na kriyā karaṇe vartate iti kartṛ tvam hi svātantryam tatra
translated: And it cannot be said that the reflection is only of the transmigrating self, not of the other, because of the non-distinction of pervasiveness, due to the proximity of the intellect of the transmigrating self in particular. But the relation of the object of enjoyment and the enjoyer is to be considered because enjoyment is unreal. And karma is not the regulator, because it is accomplished by the intellect. Thus, karma accomplished by the intellect would be enjoyed by all souls, due to the absence of a specific relation with the soul. And the intellect is not the agent, because it is insentient. For consciousness is the primordial matter. It does not engage in action or instrumentality. For agency is independence, and in that case instrumentality would not be dependence. Because independence and dependence are of the nature of injunction and prohibition. Thus, the agency of the soul alone should be accepted. And for it, which does not act before, there is no transformation in acting, because the effect is produced when all the factors are complete, and it is not produced when they are incomplete. And the completeness and incompleteness are by the manifestation and non-manifestation.

original: yaccedaṃ puruṣasya bhogotsukatāṃ manyamānāyā buddherākṛtiḥ sampadyate / tatsaṃvedanāccendriyāṇāmiti / asadetat / acetanatvāt / acetanā hi buddhistathendriyāṇi / teṣāmākūtasaṃvedanābhāve kathaṃ niyato viṣayākāratayā pariṇāmaḥ / puruṣasya tu cidrūpatāvyatirekeṇa nāparā bhogotsukatāsti / yaścāyamindriyāṇāṃ viṣayākārapariṇāmastasya viṣayākāratāyāṃ na pratikarmavyavasthā pramāṇam / tadantareṇāpi tadbhāvāt iti vakṣyamāṇanyāyāt / yadi ca buddheḥ pūrvarūpanivṛttāvindriyākāratayā pariṇāmastarhi svarūpasyāvyatirekād buddherevotpattirnivṛttiśceti / anyatve pratisandhānādyabhāva eva / na hyekenopaII /labdhamarthamanyaḥ pratisandhātumarhatīti / pariṇāmāstu buddhestādātmyena vartanta iti teṣāmanekatve buddherapyanekatvam / viparyaye tādātmyavirahāt /
analyzed: yat ca idam puruṣasya bhoga utsuka tām manyamānāyāḥ buddheḥ ākṛtiḥ sampadyate tad saṃvedanāt ca indriyāṇām iti asat etat acetana tvāt acetanā hi buddhiḥ tathā indriyāṇi teṣām ākūta saṃvedana abhāve katham niyataḥ viṣaya ākāra tayā pariṇāmaḥ puruṣasya tu cit rūpa tā vyatirekeṇa na aparā bhoga utsuka tā asti yaḥ ca ayam indriyāṇām viṣaya ākāra pariṇāmaḥ tasya viṣaya ākāra tāyām na prati karma vyavasthā pramāṇam tad antareṇa
translated: And this form of the intellect, which is supposed to be the eagerness of the soul for enjoyment, and from the perception of which the senses are said to be transformed, is not true, because they are insentient. For the intellect and the senses are insentient. How can there be a definite transformation into the form of an object in them, in the absence of the perception of an intention? But as for the soul, apart from its nature as pure consciousness, there is no other eagerness for enjoyment. And as for this transformation of the senses into the form of the object, the form of the object is not a valid means of knowledge for the determination of the specific object, because it exists even without that, as will be stated later. And if the transformation of the intellect is into the form of the senses by the cessation of its previous form, then, because it is not separate from its own nature, the intellect itself is produced and destroyed. If it were different, there would be no recollection, etc., because one cannot recollect what was experienced by another. But the transformations of the intellect occur as identical with it. Therefore, in its plurality, the intellect would be many.

original: yadapīdaṃ buddheḥ pariṇāmaviśeṣāḥ pañcāśat pratyayāḥ / tadabuddhipūrvakam / tatpariṇāmaviśeṣānāmānantyāt / na ca teṣāmeṣvevāntarbhāvaḥ pratiniyatalakṣaṇāvarodhasyānupalabdherityalamatiprasaṅgena /
analyzed: yat api idam buddheḥ pariṇāma viśeṣāḥ pañcāśat pratyayāḥ tat abuddhi pūrvakam tad pariṇāma viśeṣānām ānantyāt na ca teṣām eṣu eva antarbhāvaḥ pratiniyata lakṣaṇa avarodhasya anupalabdheḥ iti alam atiprasaṅgena
translated: And as for the fifty mental states which are particular modifications of intelligence, they are not preceded by intelligence, because of the infinite number of their particular modifications. And they cannot be included in these [five universal mental states], because their specific characteristics are not perceived. Let us stop this digression.

original: sā cānekaprakārā / arthānantyāt pratyarthaniyatatvācca /PDhS
analyzed: sā ca aneka prakārā artha ānantyāt prati artha niyata tvāt ca
translated: And that [intelligence] is of many kinds, because of the infinity of objects and because of being restricted to each object.

original: tadevaṃ buddhyādiparyāyāḥ parapakṣavyudāse sati lakṣaṇamiṣyanta iti sthite lakṣaṇena lakṣyamāṇasyaikānekatvopalabdhervipratipatteśca saṃśaye sati tannirāsārthaṃ sā cānekaprakārā iti vākyam / kuta etat / arthānantyāt pratyarthaniyatatvācca /
analyzed: tat evam buddhi ādi paryāyāḥ para pakṣa vyudāse sati lakṣaṇam iṣyante iti sthite lakṣaṇena lakṣyamāṇasya eka aneka tva upalabdheḥ vipratipatteḥ ca saṃśaye sati tad nirāsa artham sā ca aneka prakārā iti vākyam kutas etat artha ānantyāt prati artha niyata tvāt ca
translated: Thus, when the synonyms of intelligence etc. are established as intended to be the definition after the exclusion of the opponent's view, then, since the object to be defined is perceived as one or many due to disagreement, in order to refute that, the sentence And that is of many kinds is stated. Why is this? Because of the infinity of objects and because of being restricted to each object.

original: nanu cārthānantyamarthadharma iti vyadhikaraṇatvam / na / anyathā tadupapatteḥ / tathā hi / buddherarthānantyamityarthopadarśanam / etatsādhanañca anantārthatvāditi / artho 'nanto yasyāḥ sā tathoktā / tasyā bhāvo 'nantārthatvamiti / arthastu arthyate 'neneti kārakasāmagryaṃ na kārakaikadeśaḥ / tadbhede 'pi kāryasyābhedopalabdheḥ / tathā hi / anekakārakasampādyaṃ ghaṭādi ekaṃ dṛṣṭamiti / sāmagrī tu pratikāryaniyatatvānna tadbhedaṃ vyabhicaratīti / ato 'nekaprakārā buddhiranantārthatvāt / anantakārakasāmagrījanyatvāt ghaṭādivaditi / yaścaiko na cāsāvanantakārakasāmagrījanyo yathā ghaṭa iti / na tu karmavyutpattyā anantakarmakārakajanyatvaṃ sādhanaṃ vivakṣitamiti vyākhyeyam / pratyarthaniyatatvādityanena gatārthatvāt / tathā hi / arthamarthaṃ prati niyataṃ yāvadbhedabhinnaṃ karmakārakaṃ tāvadbhedabhinnā buddhaya iti buddhir anekaprakārā pratyarthaniyatatvād ghrāṇādivat /
analyzed: nanu ca artha ānantyam artha dharmaḥ iti vyadhikaraṇa tvam na anyathā tad upapatteḥ tathā hi buddheḥ artha ānantyam iti artha upadarśanam etat sādhanam ca ananta artha tvāt iti arthaḥ nantaḥ yasyāḥ sā tathā uktā tasyāḥ bhāvaḥ nanta artha tvam iti arthaḥ tu arthyate nena iti kāraka sāmagryam na kāraka eka deśaḥ tad bhede pi kāryasya abheda upalabdheḥ tathā hi aneka kāraka sampādyam ghaṭa ādi ekam dṛṣṭam iti sāmagrī tu prati kārya niyata tvāt na tad b
translated: But the word 'ananta' (infinite) is not a property of the object, so there is a difference in the substratum. No, because it can be explained otherwise. For thus, the infinity of the object is shown by the word 'ananta'. And the proof of this is 'because of the infinite object'. That which has an infinite object is called 'ananta'. The state of that is 'ananta-atva'. But the object is that which is desired by this, so it is the collection of causal factors, not just one causal factor. Because the effect is seen to be the same even when there is a difference in the causal factors. For thus, a pot etc. produced by many causal factors is seen to be one. But the collection is not contradicted by the difference in causal factors because it is determined for each effect. Therefore, the cognition is of many kinds because of the infinite object, because it is produced by the collection of infinite causal factors, like a pot etc. And that which is one and is not produced by the collection of infinite causal factors, like a pot. But it should not be explained that the proof intended is the production by infinite causal factors in the sense of the object of the verb. Because it is determined for each object.

original: anye tu pūrvasminneva vākye karmavyutpattyā anantakarmakārakajanyatvaṃ sādhanaṃ labhyata eveti pratyarthaniyatatvaṃ pratyātmavṛttitvaṃ vivakṣitamiti manyante / tathā hi / arthate 'sminnityātmā ityarthaḥ taṃ prati niyatatvaṃ pratyātmavṛttitvameva / sāmānyasya tu anantātmavṛttitvānna pratyātmaniyatatvamastīti sambhave 'pi buddherviśeṣaguṇatvād viśeṣaguṇatve satīti viśeṣaṇamabhyūhyam /
analyzed: anye tu pūrvasmin eva vākye karma vyutpattyā ananta karma kāraka janya tvam sādhanam labhyate eva iti prati artha niyata tvam pratyātma vṛtti tvam vivakṣitam iti manyante tathā hi smin iti ātmā iti arthaḥ tam prati niyata tvam pratyātma vṛtti tvam eva sāmānyasya tu ananta ātma vṛtti tvāt na pratyātma niyata tvam asti iti sambhave buddheḥ viśeṣa guṇa tvāt viśeṣa guṇa tve sati iti viśeṣaṇam abhyūhyam
translated: Others, however, think that in the very first sentence, the means of knowledge is obtained as being produced by an infinite number of actions and agents, so the intended meaning is being restricted to each object, i.e., being present in each individual self. As follows: the meaning is that in which the object exists, i.e., the self. Being restricted to that is the same as being present in each individual self. But since the universal is present in infinite individual selves, it is not restricted to each individual self. Even though possible, the qualification being a quality of the cognition should be inferred, because it is a quality of the cognition.

original: anye tu rūpajñānaṃ rasajñānamityādibuddhernānātvasya pratyakṣeṇaiva prasiddherīśvarabuddherasmadbuddheśca parasparabhedajñāpanārtham arthānantyāt pratyarthaniyatatvācceti padadvayamiti bruvate / tathā hi / īśvarabuddhiranantārthatvādasmadbuddherbhidyate / asmadbuddhiśca pratyarthaniyatatvādīśvarabuddheriti / atra ca buddheranekatvaṃ sāmānyena pratijñātamityayaṃ viśeṣaḥ kuto labhyata iti cintyam /
analyzed: anye tu rūpa jñānam rasa jñānam ityādi buddheḥ nānātvasya pratyakṣeṇa eva prasiddheḥ īśvara buddheḥ asmat buddheḥ ca paraspara bheda jñāpana artham artha ānantyāt prati artha niyata tvāt ca iti pada dvayam iti bruvate tathā hi īśvara buddhiḥ ananta artha tvāt asmat buddheḥ bhidyate asmat buddhiḥ ca prati artha niyata tvāt īśvara buddheḥ iti  atra ca buddheḥ anekatvam sāmānyena pratijñātam iti ayam viśeṣaḥ kutas labhyate iti cintyam
translated: Others, however, say that the two terms 'because of the infinity of objects' and 'because of being restricted to each object' are used to show the difference between the cognition of God and our cognition, since the plurality of cognitions such as 'cognition of form', 'cognition of taste' etc. is well-known through perception itself. Thus, the cognition of God is different from our cognition because of its infinite objects, and our cognition is different from the cognition of God because of being restricted to each object. And here it is to be considered how this particularity is obtained, since the plurality of cognitions is asserted in general.

original: atha buddhivyatirekeṇārthasya sadbhāve pramāṇābhāvād ayuktamarthānantyaṃ pratyarthaniyatatvañceti / tathā hi / vijñānaṃ svayamprakāśarūpatvādātmānaṃ prakāśayati / arthāstu jaḍātmānaḥ / teṣāṃ kathaṃ prakāśaḥ / yadi jñānaṃ pragṛhītaṃ prakāśakamiṣyeta tasyāpi jñānāntareṇa grahaṇābhyupagame jñānaparamparāyāmupakṣīṇatvād abhipretasyārthasyāprakāśanameva / na ca pūrvajñānāgrahaṇe 'pi arthasyaiva grahaṇamiti vācyam / teṣāmāsannatve sati grāhyalakṣaṇaprāptatvāt / tadāha /🔽tāṃ grāhyalakṣaṇaprāptāmāsannāṃ janikāṃ dhiyam /
analyzed: atha buddhi vyatirekeṇa arthasya sadbhāve pramāṇa abhāvāt ayuktam artha ānantyam prati artha niyata tvam ca iti tathā hi vijñānam svayamprakāśa rūpa tvāt ātmānam prakāśayati arthāḥ tu jaḍa ātmānaḥ teṣām katham prakāśaḥ yadi jñānam pragṛhītam prakāśakam iṣyeta tasya api jñāna antareṇa grahaṇa abhyupagame jñāna paramparāyām upakṣīṇa tvāt abhipretasya arthasya aprakāśanam eva na ca pūrva jñāna agrahaṇe arthasya eva grahaṇam iti vācyam te tām grāhya lakṣaṇa prāptām āsannām janikām dhiyam
translated: Now, if it is argued that the existence of objects beyond cognition is unreasonable because there is no evidence for it, and that the restriction to each object is also unreasonable, then this is the reply: Consciousness, being self-luminous, illuminates itself. But objects have an inert nature. How can they be illuminated? If it is accepted that consciousness, when grasped, is the illuminator, then even for that, if the acceptance of the apprehension by another consciousness is accepted, then due to the exhaustion in the series of consciousnesses, the intended object would not be illuminated at all. And it cannot be said that even without the apprehension of the previous consciousness, the object itself is grasped, because they have the characteristic of being graspable when they are near. He says this:🔽Without grasping the proximate producing cognition that has the characteristic of being graspable,

original: agṛhītvottaraṃ jñānaṃ gṛhaṇīyādaparaṃ katham // pra / vā / /
analyzed: a gṛhītvā uttaram jñānam gṛhaṇīyāt aparam katham pra vā
translated: how can the subsequent cognition grasp another?

original: athāgṛhītamevārthaprakāśakam / evaṃ tarhi santānāntarodbhūtānāmapi sarveṣāṃ prakāśakaṃ syāt / yathā hi / svasantatāvupajātamajñātamevārthaprakāśakam / evaṃ santānāntare 'pi syādaviśeṣāt / atha svasamvedyasvasantatau vijñānamarthaprakāśakam / evaṃ tarhi bodhaśarīrādarthāntarasya vastuno 'prakāśa eva / tathā hi / yadyamī padārthāḥ prakāśarūpāḥ kathaṃ bodhād vyatiricyante / bodhasyaiva tadrūpatvād / aprakāśarūpatayā ca sarvadā na prakāśaḥ syāt / ato jñānameva / prakāśasvarūpatvāditi vyavahriyate / prakāśarūpatayā hi sattvaṃ vyāptam / sā ca vyāvartamānā bāhyārthebhyaḥ svavyāptaṃ sattvaṃ gṛhītvā vyāvartata ityasattvaṃ bodhavyatirekiṇām /
analyzed: atha agṛhītam eva artha prakāśakam evam tarhi santāna antara udbhūtānām api sarveṣām prakāśakam syāt  / yathā hi sva santatau upajātam ajñātam eva artha prakāśakam evam santāna antare pi syāt aviśeṣāt atha sva samvedya sva santatau vijñānam artha prakāśakam evam tarhi bodha śarīrāt artha antarasya prakāśaḥ eva tathā hi yadi amī padārthāḥ prakāśa rūpāḥ katham bodhāt vyatiricyante bodhasya eva tad rūpa tvāt aprakāśa rūpatayā ca sarvadā na prakāśaḥ
translated: If, on the other hand, it illuminates objects even when not grasped, then it would illuminate all objects produced in other continua as well. Just as in one's own continuum, consciousness produced as unknown illuminates objects, so it would be in other continua as well, because there is no difference. If consciousness in one's own continuum, which is known to oneself, illuminates objects, then in that case, an object that is different from the body of consciousness is not illuminated at all. For, if these objects have the nature of illumination, how do they differ from consciousness? Because consciousness itself has that nature. And if they have the nature of non-illumination, they would never be illuminated. Therefore, they are said to be consciousness itself, because they have the nature of illumination. For existence is pervaded by the nature of illumination. And that, as it ceases, takes with it existence, which is pervaded by it, and ceases in relation to external objects. Therefore, those that differ from consciousness are non-existent.

original: na ca bodhasya bodharūpatayā sarvatrāviśeṣād viśiṣṭārthaprakāśakatvaṃ syāt / atha nīlasyedaṃ pītasyedamiti pratikarmavyavasthātaḥ sākāraṃ vijñānamiṣṭam / tarhi vijñānamevāstu tadākāramalaṃ bāhyārthakalpanayeti / taduktam /
analyzed: na ca bodhasya bodha rūpa tayā sarvatra aviśeṣāt viśiṣṭa artha prakāśaka tvam syāt atha nīlasya idam pītasya idam iti prati karma vyavasthātaḥ sa ākāram vijñānam iṣṭam tarhi vijñānam eva astu tad ākāram alam bāhya artha kalpanayā iti tat uktam
translated: And since consciousness is everywhere the same in being consciousness, it cannot be the illuminator of a particular object. If, on the other hand, consciousness is accepted as having a form, because of the determination of the object, such as 'this is blue', 'this is yellow', then let consciousness itself have that form. There is no need to imagine an external object. As it has been said:

original: dhiyo nīlādirūpatve bāhyo 'rthaḥ kiṃnibandhanaḥ / pra / vā / / iti /
analyzed: dhiyaḥ nīla ādi rūpa tve bāhyaḥ rthaḥ kiṃnibandhanaḥ pra vā iti
translated: When the mind has the form of blue etc., what is the basis for an external object?
