original: tathā vijñānakāle 'rthasyāsadbhāvād / arthakāle tu jñānasyeti kathaṃ tayorgrāhyagrāhakabhāvaḥ / sadasadrūpayostadabhāvāt / ekasmiṃśca kāle dvayorutpattyabhyupagame kiṃ grāhyaṃ kiñca grāhakamityaviśeṣāt / na ca vijñānārthayoḥ svātmanyeva paryavasāne arthādhīnatāyāḥ pratipattumaśakyatvād grāhyagrāhakabhāvaḥ / tathā avayavipratiṣedhadvāreṇa rūpādisamudāyamātram / tacca samudīyamānebhyo nārthāntaramiti vyavasthāyāmarthābhāva eva / samudāyasya paramārthasattvenāpratibhāsanāt / ye tu paramārthasantaḥ paramāṇavaste 'smaddarśanaviṣayā na bhavantyeva / atīndriyatvāt / kāryañcāparamārthasattvāt pratibhāsamānamaliṅgameva / tasmādanādivāsanāvaśād vijñānāṃśa eva grāhyagrāhakapravibhāgaḥ / etadāha /
analyzed: tathā vijñāna kāle rthasya asadbhāvāt artha kāle tu jñānasya iti katham tayoḥ grāhya grāhaka bhāvaḥ sat asat rūpayoḥ tad abhāvāt ekasmin ca kāle dvayoḥ utpatti abhyupagame kim grāhyam kiñca grāhakam iti aviśeṣāt na ca vijñāna arthayoḥ sva ātmani eva paryavasāne artha adhīna tāyāḥ pratipattum aśakya tvāt grāhya grāhaka bhāvaḥ tathā avayavi pratiṣedha dvāreṇa rūpa ādi samudāya mātram tat ca samudīyamānebhyaḥ na artha antaram iti vyavasthāyām ar
translated: Similarly, at the time of consciousness, the object does not exist, and at the time of the object, the consciousness does not exist. So how can there be the relation of the apprehended and apprehender between them? Because that is not possible between an existent and a non-existent. And if it is accepted that the two arise at the same time, then what is the apprehended and what is the apprehender? Because there is no distinction. And because it is impossible to establish dependence on the object for consciousness and the object, which are confined to their own nature, there is no relation of the apprehended and apprehender. Similarly, through the negation of the composite, it is merely a collection of form and so on. And that, being collected, is not different from the collected. So when it is established, the object itself does not exist. Because the collection does not appear as ultimately real. But the atoms, which are ultimately real, are not the objects of our perception, because they are beyond the senses. And the effect, being unreal, is not a mark of appearance. Therefore, the distinction between the apprehended and apprehender is only a part of consciousness, due to beginningless predispositions. This is stated.

original: avibhāgo 'pi buddhyātmā viparyāsitadarśanaiḥ /
analyzed: avibhāgaḥ pi buddhi ātmā viparyāsita darśanaiḥ
translated: The soul of the intellect, though undivided, is seen by those whose vision is perverted,

original: grāhyagrāhakasaṃvittibhedavāniva lakṣyate // pra / vā / /
analyzed: grāhya grāhaka saṃvitti bhedavān iva lakṣyate pra vā
translated: as if it were divided into the distinctions of the apprehended, apprehender, and consciousness.

original: na tu paramārthataḥ / tadāha /
analyzed: na tu paramārthataḥ tat āha
translated: But not ultimately. He says that.

original: nānyo 'nubhāvyo buddhyāsti tasyā nānubhavo 'paraḥ /
analyzed: na anyaḥ nubhāvyaḥ buddhyā asti tasyāḥ paraḥ
translated: There is nothing else to be experienced by the intellect, nor is there another experience of it.

original: grāhyagrāhakavaidhuryāt svayaṃ saiva prakāśate // pra / vā / /
analyzed: grāhya grāhaka vaidhuryāt svayam sā eva prakāśate pra vā
translated: Due to the absence of the apprehended and apprehender, it itself shines forth.

original: nanu tarhi nīlamahaṃ vedmi cakṣuṣeti pratibhāsaḥ katham / tathā hi / nīlamiti karma / ahamiti kartā / vedmīti kriyā / cakṣuṣeti karaṇam / eteṣāṃ parasparavyāvṛttavapuṣāṃ pratibhāsanād abhedapratipādanamunmattabhāṣitam / naitadevam / taimirikasya dvicandradarśanavadasyāpyupapatteḥ / yathā hi / taimirikasyārthābhāve 'pi tadākāraṃ vijñānamudeti evaṃ karmādiṣvavidyamāneṣvapi anādivāsanāvaśāt tadākāraṃ vijñānamiti / atha taimirikasya keśādijñānaṃ bādhyamānatvānnirviṣayam / na caivametat / tadasat / bādhyabādhakabhāvasyaivāsambhavāt / tathā hi / na vijñānamarthena bādhyate / pratīyamānāpratīyamānābhyāṃ bādhyatve 'tiprasaṅgāt / pratīyamānena hi bādhāyāṃ sarvaṃ vijñānaṃ bādhyaṃ syāt / evamapratīyamānenāpīti /
analyzed: nanu tarhi nīlam aham vedmi cakṣuṣā iti pratibhāsaḥ katham tathā hi nīlam iti karma aham iti kartā vedmi iti kriyā cakṣuṣā iti karaṇam eteṣām paraspara vyāvṛtta vapuṣām pratibhāsanāt abheda pratipādanam unmatta bhāṣitam na etat evam taimirikasya dvi candra darśana vat asya api upapatteḥ yathā hi taimirikasya artha abhāve pi tad ākāram vijñānam udeti evam karma ādiṣu avidyamāneṣu api anādi vāsanā vaśāt tad ākāram vijñānam iti atha taimirikasya keśa
translated: But then, how is there the appearance I know blue with the eye? Thus, blue is the object, I is the agent, know is the action, with the eye is the instrument. Since these appear with mutually exclusive forms, the teaching of non-difference is the talk of a madman. It is not so, because this is also possible, like the appearance of two moons to one with an eye disease. Just as for one with an eye disease, consciousness arises with that form even in the absence of an object, so also for one without beginningless impressions, consciousness arises with that form even in the absence of action etc. But the knowledge of hair etc. by one with an eye disease is objectless because it is contradicted. And it is not so in this case. That is wrong, because the relation of contradiction and contradicted is not possible at all. Thus, consciousness is not contradicted by an object, because if it were contradicted by what is cognized and what is not cognized, there would be an overextension. For if it were contradicted by what is cognized, all consciousness would be contradicted. Thus, if it were contradicted by what is not cognized,

original: atha jñānenaiva jñānaṃ bādhyate / tatrāpi na vibhinnaviṣayeṇa / rūpajñānena rasādijñānasyāpi bādhaprasaṅgāt / samānaviṣayatve tu sampādakatvameva syānna bādhakatvam / na ca vijñānasyotpattirvināśo vā bādhāt / sarvasyāpi tathāII /bhāvaprasaṅgāt / atha viṣayāntaropasarpaṇā mithyāpattirbādhaḥ / tadasat / viṣayasya karmakārakarūpatvāt / yatrotpadyate jñānaṃ sa eva tasya viṣaya iti viṣayāntaropasarpaṇamasiddham / vijñāne bādhyabādhakasadbhāvasyaivāprasiddherna mithyājñānamastīti / nāpi saṃvidi samyaktvam / pramāṇābhāvāt /
analyzed: atha jñānena eva jñānam bādhyate tatra api na vibhinna viṣayeṇa rūpa jñānena rasa ādi jñānasya api bādha prasaṅgāt samāna viṣaya tve tu sampādaka tvam eva syāt na bādhaka tvam na ca vijñānasya utpattiḥ vināśaḥ vā bādhāt sarvasya api  / atha viṣaya antara upasarpaṇā mithyā āpattiḥ bādhaḥ tat asat viṣayasya karma kāraka rūpa tvāt yatra utpadyate jñānam saḥ eva tasya viṣayaḥ iti viṣaya antara upasarpaṇam asiddham vijñāne bādhya bādhaka sadbh
translated: If, on the other hand, knowledge is annulled by knowledge itself, even there it is not by one having a different object, because in that case there would be the undesirable possibility of the annulment of the knowledge of taste etc. by the knowledge of form. But if the object is the same, there would be only the accomplishment of the same, not the annulment. And the production or destruction of consciousness is not due to annulment, because in that case everything would be like that. If annulment is the false cognition due to the approach of a different object, that is wrong, because the object has the nature of the instrument of action. The object of a cognition is that where it arises. So the approach of a different object is not established. And since the existence of the annulled and the annuller is not established in consciousness, there is no false cognition. Nor is there correctness in consciousness, because there is no evidence.

original: atha arthakriyāsaṃvādaḥ pramāṇam / na / tatrāpi saṃvādakāpekṣāyāmanavasthāprasaṅgāt / saṃvādakañca vinā na samyaktvasiddhiriti / na cārthakriyāpi bodhād bhidyate / sarvasyāpi pratibhāsamānasya bodhādavyatirekāt / yathoktam /
analyzed: atha artha kriyā saṃvādaḥ pramāṇam na tatra api saṃvādaka apekṣāyām anavasthā prasaṅgāt saṃvādakam ca vinā na samyaktva siddhiḥ iti na ca arthakriyā api bodhāt bhidyate sarvasya api pratibhāsamānasya bodhāt avyatirekāt yathā uktam
translated: If, on the other hand, the conformity with effective action is the means of valid knowledge, that is not so, because if there were dependence on another conformity, there would be the contingence of an infinite regress. And without a conforming cognition, there can be no establishment of correctness. And effective action is not different from cognition, because everything that appears is not different from cognition, as has been said:

original: prakāśamānastādātmyāt svarūpasya prakāśakaḥ /
analyzed: prakāśamānaḥ tādātmyāt svarūpasya prakāśakaḥ
translated: That which appears, by identity, illuminates its own form.

original: yathā prakāśo 'bhimatastathā dhīrātmavedinī // pra / vā / /
analyzed: yathā prakāśaḥ bhimataḥ tathā dhīra ātma vedinī pra vā
translated: Just as light is accepted, so cognition knows the self.

original: iti /
analyzed: iti
translated: Thus.

original: yadi ca padārthānāṃ nijaṃ svarūpādi yathaikasya pratibhāsastathā sarveṣāmapīti visaṃvādo na syāt / na caitadasti / tathā hi /
analyzed: yadi ca padārthānām nijam sva rūpa ādi yathā ekasya pratibhāsaḥ tathā sarveṣām api iti visaṃvādaḥ na syāt na ca etat asti tathā hi
translated: And if the inherent nature etc. of things were as they appear to one, so would they appear to all, and there would be no contradiction. But this is not so. For instance:

original: mantrādyupaplutākṣāṇāṃ yathā mṛcchakalādayaḥ //
analyzed: mantra ādi upapluta akṣāṇām yathā mṛd śakala ādayaḥ
translated: Just as clods, pebbles and so on appear differently to those whose eyes are affected by spells etc.,🔽even though devoid of that form.

original: anyathaivāvabhāsante tadrūparahitā api // pra / vā / / iti /
analyzed: anyathā eva avabhāsante tad rūpa rahitāḥ api pra vai iti
translated: Thus.

translated: This is not correct. Because without a difference in objects, the absence of a difference in cognitions would follow. Cognitions such as the cognition of form, the cognition of taste, etc. appear with mutually exclusive forms. Therefore, a difference must be accepted. Or, the difference in cognitions is due to the difference in impressions. Even if that also produces a qualified cognition, if it is different from cognition, it is merely a difference in names. If it is not different, both are of the form of cognition, and there is no difference anywhere. Thus, there would be no diversity such as the cognition of form, the cognition of taste, etc. And the difference in cognitions is not due to the difference in forms, because that also is impossible. Thus, if mere cognition is the real form, then the cognition of blue, etc. is valid because it has a real form, and the cognition of two moons, etc. is invalid because it has an unreal form. This contradicts the distinction, because the real form is not distinguished anywhere. If it has an unreal form, then also there is the loss of accepting a distinction. And for the proponent and opponent,

original: ityekatvasādhanamunmattabhāṣitam / asataḥ sattādātmye sattvam / asattādātmye tu tadrūpatvamiti / tathā paraprasiddhyā niyamena sahopalabhyamānatvaṃ bhedenaiva vyāptamiti viruddhaṃ syāt / atha sāhāyyaṃ yaugapadyaṃ vā vivakṣitaṃ sahopalabhyamānatvam / tathāpi tayorbhedenaiva vyāptatvād viruddhatvam / tathā sarvajñaḥ svacittena sahopalabhate paracittam / na ca tasya tasmādabheda iti vyabhicāraḥ / sarveṣāṃ sarvajñatāprasaṅgāt / na caikasyaivopalambhaniyamo hetuḥ / aśabdārthatvāt / sādhyāviśiṣṭatvācca / tathā anekarūpādyavayavasya hi tasyārthasyopalambhe svarūpāsiddho 'pīti /
analyzed: iti ekatva sādhanam unmatta bhāṣitam asataḥ sat tādātmye sattvam asat tādātmye tu tad rūpa tvam iti tathā para prasiddhyā niyamena saha upalabhyamāna tvam bhedena eva vyāptam iti viruddham syāt atha sāhāyyam yaugapadyam vā vivakṣitam saha upalabhyamāna tvam tathā api tayoḥ bhedena eva vyāpta tvāt viruddha tvam tathā sarvajñaḥ sva cittena saha upalabhate para cittam na ca tasya tasmāt abhedaḥ iti vyabhicāraḥ sarveṣām sarvajña tā prasaṅgāt na ca ekasya eva upalamb
translated: Thus, the proof of oneness is the babbling of a madman. If non-existence has the nature of existence, it is existent. But if it has the nature of non-existence, it is of that form. Similarly, being necessarily perceived together by what is accepted by others is pervaded only by difference, so it would be contradictory. But if being perceived together means assistance or simultaneity, even so, since those are pervaded only by difference, it is contradictory. Similarly, the omniscient one perceives the other mind together with his own mind, and it is not non-different from that. Thus, there is inconstancy. Because it would follow that all are omniscient. And the restriction of perception to one alone is not the reason, because it is not the meaning of a word, and because it is not distinguished from the probandum. Similarly, when that object consisting of many forms and parts is perceived, it is also unestablished in its own nature.

original: atha bāhyārthābhāvādekopalambhaniyamaḥ / tanna / itaretarāśrayatvaprasaṅgāt / tathā caikopalambhaniyamāt bāhyārthābhāvasiddhiḥ / tatsiddheścaikopalambhaniyamasiddhirityekābhāvāditarābhāvaḥ / athaikenaivopalabhyamānatvaṃ sādhanam / na / anyavedanābhāvasyāprasiddheḥ / arthastu tatsamānakṣaṇairanyairapyupalabhyata ityekenaivopalabhyamānatvamasiddham / saccandrāsaccandradṛṣṭānto sadasatorekatvavirodhāt sādhyavikalaḥ / sādhanavikalaśca / asataścandrasya sattvenopalambhābhāvāt /
analyzed: atha bāhya artha abhāvāt eka upalambha niyamaḥ tat na itara itara āśraya tva prasaṅgāt tathā ca eka upalambha niyamāt bāhya artha abhāva siddhiḥ tad siddheḥ ca eka upalambha niyama siddhiḥ iti eka abhāvāt itara abhāvaḥ atha ekena eva upalabhyamāna tvam sādhanam na anya vedanā abhāvasya aprasiddheḥ arthaḥ tu tad samāna kṣaṇaiḥ anyaiḥ api upalabhyate iti ekena eva upalabhyamāna tvam asiddham sat candra asatoḥ ekatva virodhāt sādhya vikalaḥ sādhana vikalaḥ c
translated: If, on the other hand, the restriction to one apprehension is due to the non-existence of external objects, that is not so, because of the contingence of the fallacy of mutual dependence. And thus, from the restriction to one apprehension, there is the establishment of the non-existence of external objects, and from the establishment of that, the establishment of the restriction to one apprehension. Thus, from the non-existence of one, there is the non-existence of the other. If the proof is that it is apprehended by only one, that is not so, because the absence of the apprehension of another is not established. But the object is apprehended by others of the same moment, so it is not established that it is apprehended by only one. The example of the real and unreal moon is inconclusive, because the oneness of the real and unreal is contradictory, and it is also inconclusive as a proof, because the unreal moon does not exist as an apprehension by the real.

original: tathā jñānaṃ grāhakasvarūpam / nīlādi grāhyasvarūpamityanayoḥ śuklapītayoriva svabhāvabhedād bhedaḥ / abhede hi bodho 'pi nīlasya grāhyaḥ / nīlañca bodhasya grāhakamiti syāt / na caitadasti / kāraṇabhedācca nīlād bodho 'rthāntaram / tathā hi / bodhād bodharūpatā / indriyād viṣayapratiniyamaḥ / viṣayādākāragrahaṇam iti bhedādeṣāṃ bheda eva / atha na kāraṇabhedaḥ / kiṃ tarhi / vyāvṛttibhedamātram / abodhavyāvṛttirbodhaḥ / nirākāratāvyāvṛttiḥ sākāratvam / atadrūpavyāvṛttirviṣayapratiniyama iti / evaṃ tarhi nīlāvabodhacakṣuṣāmākārabodhaviṣayapratiniyameṣu vyāvṛttisvarūpeṣu vyāpārāsambhavād akāraṇatvameva / vyāvṛtteravasturūpatvāt / atha vyāvṛttād bodhādabodhādivyāvṛttirnānyā / tarhi bodhasyaikarūpatvāt kāraṇabhedapratipādanamasambaddhaṃ syāt / ataḥ kāraṇabhedādeva nīlatadbodhayorbhedaḥ / citrapratibhāse tu nīlapītādyanekākāraṃ vijñānaṃ bodhamātratāyāṃ kathaṃ syāditi cintyam / tathā hi / teṣāmākārāṇāmekabodhatādātmyādekatvam / tattādātmye vā bodhasyānekatvamiti durnivāraḥ prasaṅgaḥ /
analyzed: tathā jñānam grāhaka svarūpam nīla ādi grāhya svarūpam iti anayoḥ śukla pītayoḥ iva svabhāva bhedāt bhedaḥ abhede hi nīlasya grāhyaḥ nīlam ca bodhasya grāhakam iti syāt na ca etat asti kāraṇa bhedāt ca nīlāt bodhaḥ rtha antaram tathā hi bodhāt bodha rūpa tā indriyāt viṣaya pratiniyamaḥ viṣayāt ākāra grahaṇam iti bhedāt eṣām bhedaḥ eva atha na kāraṇa bhedaḥ kim tarhi vyāvṛtti bheda mātram abodha vyāvṛttiḥ bodhaḥ nirākāra tā vyāvṛt
translated: Similarly, knowledge has the nature of the apprehender, and blue etc. have the nature of the apprehended. These two are different, like white and yellow, because of the difference in their nature. For if they were non-different, then cognition would also be apprehended by the blue, and the blue would be the apprehender of the cognition. But this is not the case. And because of the difference in causes, cognition is different from blue. For thus: the form of cognition is from cognition itself, the restriction to objects is from the sense organ, and the grasping of the form is from the object. Thus, because of this difference, they are different. If there is no difference in causes, then what is it? Merely the difference in exclusion. Cognition is the exclusion of non-cognition. Having a form is the exclusion of formlessness. The restriction to objects is the exclusion of other forms. If so, then since the eye and the cognition of blue cannot operate on the excluded forms of the restriction to objects, having a form, and cognition, they are not causes at all. Because the excluded form is not a real entity. If the exclusion from non-cognition is not different from the cognition that is excluded, then the cognition is one.

original: atha yāvantastatrākārāstāvantyeva jñānānīti / tarhi teṣāṃ pratiniyatākāratvāt citrapratibhāsābhāvaḥ / na cākārasadbhāve pratikarmavyavasthā pramāṇam / anyathāpi bhāvāt / tathā hi / sakalakārakajanyatvāviśeṣe 'pi nīlasya karmarūpatayā vyāpārāttenaiva vyapadeśo nākārārpakatvāditi / sarveṣāṃ janakatvāviśeṣe 'pi arthasyaivākārārpakatve viśeṣaheturvācyaḥ / athārthasya karmarūpatayā vyāpārāt tasyaivākārārpakatvam / tarhi karmarūpataivāstu vyapadeśaniyame hetuḥ / kimākāreṇāsambhavinā kalpiteneti / tathā hi / nīlāderasādhāraṇākārārpakatve bodharūpatā na syāt / sādhāraṇākārārpakatve tu pratikarmavyavasthābhāva iti /
analyzed: atha yāvantaḥ tatra ākārāḥ tāvanti eva jñānāni iti tarhi teṣām pratiniyata ākāra tvāt citra pratibhāsa abhāvaḥ na ca ākāra sadbhāve prati karma vyavasthā pramāṇam anyathā api bhāvāt tathā hi sakala kāraka janya tva aviśeṣe pi nīlasya karma rūpatayā vyāpārāt tena eva vyapadeśaḥ na ākāra arpaka tvāt iti sarveṣām janaka tva aviśeṣe pi arthasya eva ākāra arpaka tve viśeṣa hetuḥ vācyaḥ atha arthasya karma rūpatayā vyāpārāt tasya eva ākāra a
translated: If, on the other hand, there are as many cognitions as there are forms in the object, then, since they have specific forms, there would be no appearance of a variegated object. And the presence of a form cannot be established by the fact that there is a distinction of objects, because it exists even otherwise. For example, even though there is no difference in the fact that blue is produced by all the causes, it is designated by that [blue] itself because it operates in the form of an object, not because it impresses its form [on cognition]. Even though there is no difference in the fact that all [causes] produce [cognition], a reason for the distinction that only the object impresses its form [on cognition] must be stated. If, on the other hand, the object impresses its form [on cognition] because it operates in the form of an object, then let there be just the form of an object as the reason for the restriction of designation. What is the use of an impossible imaginary form? For example, if blue and so on impress their uncommon forms [on cognition], there would be no cognition in the form of consciousness. But if they impress their common forms [on cognition], there would be no distinction of objects.

original: atha samāropitākāraṃ vijñānamiti nāyaṃ doṣaḥ / tadasat / ātmano 'vasthitasyābhāve kathaṃ jñānātmani ākāraḥ samāropyate / na tāvadanutpannasya vinaṣṭasya vā samāropakatvam / na cotpattisamakālam / ātmalābhakāle samāropaṇe vyāpārāsambhavāt / tasmādākārasadbhāve pramāṇābhāvādarthaviśeṣādevāyaṃ viśeṣa iti yuktam /
analyzed: atha samāropita ākāram vijñānam iti na ayam doṣaḥ tat asat ātmanaḥ vasthitasya abhāve katham jñāna ātmani ākāraḥ samāropyate na tāvat anutpannasya vinaṣṭasya vā samāropaka tvam na ca utpatti sama kālam ātma lābha kāle samāropaṇe vyāpāra asambhavāt tasmāt ākāra sadbhāve pramāṇa abhāvāt artha viśeṣāt eva ayam viśeṣaḥ iti yuktam
translated: If, on the other hand, consciousness is said to be the form superimposed, then this fault does not arise. That is not so. In the absence of an established self, how can the form be superimposed on the nature of consciousness? First, that which is not yet arisen or has already ceased cannot be the superimposer. Nor is it simultaneous with arising, because at the time of self-attainment, superimposition is not possible. Therefore, since there is no evidence for the existence of form, it is reasonable to conclude that this distinction is due to the distinction in the object itself.

original: athāprakāśasvarūpatvādarthānāṃ karma /thaṃprakāśaḥ / tadviṣayajñānotpāda eva / tathā hi / yasmin viṣaye jñānamutpannaṃ sa evopalabdho netara iti viṣayaviṣayibhāvasya niyāmakatvam / ato jñānamarthaprakāśo na tu prakāśakamiti / kiṃ gṛhītamarthaprakāśakamuta agṛhītamityādivikalpaḥ paramatāsparśī / cakṣurādeḥ kārakajātasyārthaprakāśakatvābhyupagamāt / yatra ca jñānaṃ viśeṣaliṅgaṃ vā tatra gṛhītasyārthaparicchede vyāpāro 'bhyupagamyata eva / tasya ca ātmāntaḥkaraṇasambandhād grahaṇam / nāvaśyam tatrāpi jñānāntaramityanavasthābhāvaḥ /
analyzed: atha aprakāśa svarūpa tvāt arthānām tad viṣaya jñāna utpādaḥ eva tathā hi yasmin viṣaye jñānam utpannam saḥ eva upalabdhaḥ na itaraḥ iti viṣaya viṣayi bhāvasya niyāmaka tvam atas jñānam artha prakāśaḥ na tu prakāśakam iti kim gṛhītam artha prakāśakam uta agṛhītam ityādi vikalpaḥ paramatā sparśī cakṣuḥ ādeḥ kāraka jātasya artha prakāśaka tva abhyupagamāt yatra ca jñānam viśeṣa liṅgam vā tatra gṛhītasya artha paricchede vyāpāraḥ b
translated: Now, since objects have an unmanifest nature, the function of the sense organs is the production of knowledge that has them as its object. For thus, only that object with regard to which knowledge arises is perceived, not any other. Thus, the relation between object and subject is the determiner. Therefore, knowledge is the manifestation of the object, not the illuminator. The alternatives beginning with Is the illuminator of the grasped object or the ungrasped object? are relevant only to the opponent's view, because the eye and other instruments of action are accepted as illuminators of the object. And where knowledge or a specific mark is present, the operation of the grasped object in the determination is accepted itself. And that is grasped by the connection of the self with the internal organ. And there is no infinite regress, because another knowledge is not necessarily required even there.

original: na cotpanne jñāne saṃvedanābhāvasyāviśeṣāt santānāntare 'pyarthaprakāśaḥ / niyatātmasambandhasya niyāmakatvāt / tathā hi / yasminnātmani samavetaṃ tajjñānamupajātaṃ sa eva draṣṭā nānyaḥ / tatra vivakṣitajñānasamavāyāt / yasya tu svasaṃvedyaṃ jñānaṃ nirādhāraṃ tasya santānāntare 'rthaprakāśasta /ḥ kasmānna bhavatīti cintyam / kāryakāraṇabhāvastu kṣaṇikatve sati pūrvaṃ pratiṣiddha eva /

translated: And when the cognition has arisen, there is no difference in the absence of awareness, so the manifestation of the object belongs to another continuum as well. Because the relation to a restricted self is the determining factor. For instance, the one in whom that cognition inhering in the self has arisen is the seer, not another. Because of the intended relation to the cognition. But for one whose cognition is self-evident and without a basis, the manifestation of the object belongs to another continuum. It should be considered why it does not happen. As for the relation of cause and effect, that has been refuted earlier, even in the case of momentariness.

original: yaccedaṃ svasaṃvedyaṃ vijñānam ityarthāntarasyāsaṃvedanameva / tadasata / vikalpānupapatteḥ / tathā hi / yadi svasaṃvedyamātmāntaḥkaraṇasaṃyogādupalabhyaṃ tadiṣṭameva / atha tadeva jñānaṃ pramāṇaṃ prameyaṃ phalañceti / tanna / anyatra tritayasyābhedādarśanāt / bhede tvanekaṃ daṇḍādyudāharaṇam / ato na jñāne karaṇakarmaṇorabhedaḥ svasaṃvedyatvam / nāpi kriyākarmaṇoriti / tasmāt jñānāntarasaṃvedyaṃ saṃvedanaṃ vedyatvāt ghaṭādivat /
analyzed: yat ca idam sva saṃvedyam vijñānam iti artha antarasya asaṃvedanam eva tat asata vikalpa anupapatteḥ tathā hi yadi sva saṃvedyam ātma antaḥkaraṇa saṃyogāt upalabhyam tat iṣṭam eva atha tat eva jñānam pramāṇam prameyam phalam ca iti tat na anyatra tritayasya abheda adarśanāt bhede tu anekam daṇḍa ādi udāharaṇam atas na jñāne karaṇa karmaṇoḥ abhedaḥ sva saṃvedya tvam na api kriyā karmaṇoḥ iti tasmāt jñāna antara saṃvedyam saṃvedanam vedya tvāt gh
translated: And this consciousness which is self-cognized is itself the object, and there is no other object. That is not so. Because of the impossibility of an option. Thus, if the self-cognized self is perceived by the conjunction of the internal organ, that is accepted. But if that very cognition is the means of knowledge, the object of knowledge, and the result, that is not so. Because elsewhere the non-difference of the three is not seen. If there is difference, there are many examples like the stick, etc. Therefore, in cognition, the means and the object are not non-different. Nor are the action and the object. Therefore, the cognition is cognized by another cognition, because it is cognizable, like a pot, etc.

original: yaccedaṃ prakāśasvarūpatvād ātmanaiva prakāśate pradīpavat ityuktam / tatra yadi prakāśakatvaṃ bodharūpatvaṃ vivakṣitaṃ tadā sādhanavikalamudāharaṇam / pradīpe bodharūpatvasyāsambhavāt / atha prakāśakatvaṃ bhāsvararūpasambandhitvaṃ tad vijñāne nāsti / ato jñānāntarasya tadviṣayasyotpāda eva jñānasya pariccheda iti /
analyzed: yat ca idam prakāśa svarūpa tvāt ātmanā eva prakāśate pradīpa vat iti uktam tatra yadi prakāśaka tvam bodha rūpa tvam vivakṣitam tadā sādhana vikalam udāharaṇam pradīpe bodha rūpa tvasya asambhavāt atha prakāśaka tvam bhāsvara rūpa sambandhi tvam tat vijñāne na asti atas jñāna antarasya tad viṣayasya utpādaḥ eva jñānasya paricchedaḥ iti
translated: And as for what has been said that the soul shines by itself, like a lamp, on account of its being of the nature of light, if by the term 'illuminator' is meant 'of the nature of consciousness', then the example is devoid of the probandum, because consciousness is impossible in a lamp. If, on the other hand, by 'illuminator' is meant 'connected with the nature of luminosity', then that is not present in consciousness. Therefore, the definition of consciousness is the production of another consciousness which has it (i.e. the first consciousness) for its object.

original: yaccedaṃ kiṃ prakāśasvarūpāstadviparītā vā padārthā jñānena prakāśanta ityuktam / tatra yadi prakāśasvarūpatvaṃ bodharūpatvaṃ tannāsti / arthānāmabodharūpatvāt / teṣāṃ kathaṃ prakāśaḥ / tadviṣayajñānotpādāt / yadviṣayaṃ jñānamutpannam II / asāvarthaḥ paricchinna iti vyavahāraḥ / tasmānnirākāratve vijñānasya viṣayaviṣayibhāvo niyāmaka iti /
analyzed: yat ca idam kim prakāśa svarūpāḥ tad viparītāḥ vā padārthāḥ jñānena prakāśante iti uktam tatra yadi prakāśa svarūpa tvam bodha rūpa tvam tat na asti arthānām abodha rūpa tvāt teṣām katham prakāśaḥ tad viṣaya jñāna utpādāt yad viṣayam jñānam utpannam asau arthaḥ paricchinnaḥ iti vyavahāraḥ tasmāt nirākāra tve vijñānasya viṣaya viṣayi bhāvaḥ niyāmakaḥ iti
translated: And as for what has been said that objects are either of the nature of light or the opposite of that, and are illuminated by consciousness, if by 'of the nature of light' is meant 'of the nature of consciousness', then that is not so, because objects are not of the nature of consciousness. How then is there illumination of them? It is because of the production of the consciousness which has them for its object. The usage is that an object is said to be defined when a consciousness which has it for its object is produced. Therefore, when consciousness is formless, the relation of object and subject is the determining factor.

original: dhiyo nīlādirūpatve bāhyo 'rthaḥ kiṃnibandhanaḥ / pra / vā / /
analyzed: dhiyaḥ nīla ādi rūpa tve bāhyaḥ rthaḥ kiṃnibandhanaḥ pra vā
translated: If the cognition has the form of blue etc., what is the basis for the external object?

original: ityapāstameva /
analyzed: iti apāstam eva
translated: This has already been refuted.

original: yaccedaṃ grāhyagrāhakayorekakālānubhavābhāvena dūṣaṇam / tadapyapāstam / kṣaṇikatvānabhyupagamāt / yo hi kṣaṇikatvaṃ manyate tasyāyaṃ doṣo jñānakāle 'rthasyāsadbhāvo 'rthakāle jñānasyeti tayorgrāhyagrāhakabhāvānupapattiriti / tathā avayavinaḥ pūrvameva vyavasthāpanāt / na rūpādisamudāyasyāparamārthatvena vijñānaviṣayatvamiti / paramāṇūnāṃ sadbhāvasiddhervijñānamātrameveti adūṣaṇamanabhyupagamāt / ato yadāha vijñānavādī evaṃ grāhyagrāhakapravibhāgaḥ kalpanāvaśāditi tadapyapāstameva / bodharūpavyatirekeṇa bāhyārthasya cakṣurādinā pratibhāsanāt / pravṛttinivṛttyośca tadviṣayatvāditi / tathā hi / arthāvarodhe sati arthakriyārthinastadabhimukhāḥ pravartante ceti dṛṣṭam / na ca bhrāntyaiva pravṛttiḥ / avisaṃvādopalabdheḥ /
analyzed: yat ca idam grāhya grāhakayoḥ eka kāla anubhava abhāvena dūṣaṇam tat api apāstam kṣaṇikatva anabhyupagamāt yaḥ hi kṣaṇikatvam manyate tasya ayam doṣaḥ jñāna kāle rthasya asadbhāvaḥ rtha kāle jñānasya iti tayoḥ grāhya grāhaka bhāva anupapattiḥ iti tathā avayavinaḥ pūrvam eva vyavasthāpanāt na rūpa ādi samudāyasya aparama artha tvena vijñāna viṣaya tvam iti paramāṇūnām sadbhāva siddheḥ vijñāna mātram eva iti adūṣaṇam anabhyupagamāt  /
translated: And this criticism that there is no simultaneous experience of the grasped and grasper, that too is refuted, because momentariness is not accepted. For one who considers things momentary, this fault arises: at the time of cognition, the object does not exist; at the time of the object, cognition does not exist. Thus, the relation of grasped and grasper between them is not possible. Similarly, because the whole has already been established earlier, the aggregate of form and so on is not the object of consciousness as it is not ultimate. Since the existence of atoms has been established, consciousness alone is not refuted because it is not accepted. Therefore, what the Vijñānavādin says - This distinction between the grasped and grasper is due to conceptualization - that too is refuted, because the external object appears through the eye etc. apart from the form of cognition, and because engagement and disengagement have that as their object. Indeed, it is seen that when the object is present, those who seek to accomplish their purpose engage in it. And engagement is not just through error.

original: atha pravṛttinivṛttyorarthakriyāyāśca vijñānādavyatireka eva / tanna / vasturūpatayā pratibhāsamānānāṃ parasparavyāvṛttātmanāṃ jñānābhede pramāṇābhāvāt / arthānabhyupagame ca saṃvādānutpattiḥ / vyāpāravyāhārābhyāñca santānāntarānubhavāt arthākāre saṃvādaḥ / tanna / tasyāsattvāt / na cotpādanāviśeṣeṇa saṃvādaḥ / rūpajñānāntaraṃ rasajñānotpattau visaṃvādaprasaṅgāt /
analyzed: atha pravṛtti nivṛttyoḥ arthakriyāyāḥ ca vijñānāt avyatirekaḥ eva tat na vastu rūpa tayā pratibhāsamānānām paraspara vyāvṛtta ātmanām jñāna abhede pramāṇa abhāvāt artha anabhyupagame ca saṃvāda anutpattiḥ vyāpāra vyāhārābhyām ca santāna antara anubhavāt artha ākāre saṃvādaḥ tat na tasya asattvāt na ca utpādana aviśeṣeṇa saṃvādaḥ rūpa jñāna antaram rasa jñāna utpattau visaṃvāda prasaṅgāt
translated: If, on the other hand, activity, cessation, and the operation of an object are not different from consciousness, that is not so. Because there is no evidence that mutually exclusive things appearing as the form of a real entity are not different from consciousness. And if an object is not accepted, there is no agreement. And because of activity and speech, the experience of another continuum is from the form of an object. That is not so. Because it does not exist. And agreement is not by the difference of production. Because if the knowledge of taste arises after the knowledge of form, there is the fault of disagreement.

original: atha svasantatau vyāpāravyāhārayoḥ svacittehāpūrvakatvenopalambhāt santānāntare 'pi tatpūrvakatvānumānamiti santānāntarasiddhiḥ / na / pratīyamānayorvyāpāravyāhārayoḥ svacittādabhede paracittapūrvakatvābhāvaprasaṅgāt / bhede ca bahirmukhāvabhāsitvena pratīyamānatve kathaṃ na bāhyārthasadbhāvaḥ /
analyzed: atha sva santatau vyāpāra vyāhārayoḥ sva citta īhā pūrvaka tvena upalambhāt santāna antare pi tad pūrvaka tva anumānam iti santāna antara siddhiḥ na pratīyamānayoḥ vyāpāra vyāhārayoḥ sva cittāt abhede para citta pūrvaka tva abhāva prasaṅgāt bhede ca bahirmukha avabhāsi tvena pratīyamāna tve katham na bāhya artha sadbhāvaḥ
translated: If, on the other hand, it is argued that because activity and speech in one's own continuum are observed to be preceded by one's own mind, their being preceded by that is inferred in another continuum as well, and thus the existence of another continuum is established, that is not so. Because if activity and speech that are cognized are not different from one's own mind, there is the fault that they are not preceded by another's mind. And if they are different, how can there not be the existence of an external object, since they are cognized as appearing externally?

original: na ca svasaṃvidvādino 'vinābhāvagrahaṇābhāve 'numānapravṛttiryuktā / tathā hi / vyāpāravyāhāraḥ pratibhāsijñānātmanaścittāntarapūrvakatāṃ gṛhṇāti / ātmanyeva paryavasānāt / etatkāraṇamapi cittaṃ na tatkāraṇatāṃ gṛhṇāti / nāpyubhābhyāṃ II / vāsanākrameṇa vikalpajñānaṃ kāryakāraṇabhāvagrāhakamiti vācyam / anubhavānurūpatvād vāsanāyāḥ kathaṃ kāryakāraṇabhāvāgrahe tadadhyavasāyivikalpa iti / na cātadrūpasamāropito vikalpaḥ / tasya pāramparyeṇāpyarthāviṣayatve kāryakāraṇabhāvāgrahe 'numānāpravṛttireva / tasmādubhayorliṅgaliṅginoridamasya vyāpyamidamasya vyāpakamityavinābhāvagrahe sati anumānaṃ pravartata iti bodhādanyo 'rtho 'bhyupagantavyaḥ /
analyzed: na ca sva saṃvid vādinaḥ vinābhāva grahaṇa abhāve numāna pravṛttiḥ yuktā tathā hi vyāpāra vyāhāraḥ pratibhāsi jñāna ātmanaḥ citta antara pūrvakatām gṛhṇāti ātmani eva paryavasānāt etad kāraṇam api cittam na tad kāraṇatām gṛhṇāti na api ubhābhyām vāsanā krameṇa vikalpa jñānam kārya kāraṇa bhāva grāhakam iti vācyam anubhava anurūpa tvāt vāsanāyāḥ katham kārya kāraṇa bhāva agrahe tad adhyavasāyi vikalpaḥ iti na ca a tad rūpa sam
translated: And for one who maintains the doctrine of self-awareness, the operation of inference is not proper in the absence of the apprehension of invariable concomitance. Thus, the operation of the mind and speech grasps the antecedence of the cognition in the form of appearance, because it terminates in the self itself. And that mind which is the cause of this also does not grasp its causal nature, nor do both. It cannot be said that the conceptual cognition grasping the relation of cause and effect arises through the succession of impressions, because the impression is in accordance with the experience. How can there be a conceptual cognition determining that when the relation of cause and effect is not grasped? And a conceptual cognition superimposing a form that is not real. If that [conceptual cognition] is not the object of the [relation of] cause and effect even indirectly, then inference does not operate at all in the non-grasping of the relation of cause and effect. Therefore, when there is the apprehension of the invariable concomitance of both the mark and the marked, that this is pervaded by that, inference operates. Thus, a meaning other than the cognition should be accepted.

original: yaccedaṃ nīlamahaṃ vedmīti jñānaṃ taimirikasya dvicandradarśanavad bhrāntamiti / asadetat / abādhyamānatvāt / tathā hi / taimirikasya timiravināśādūrdhvamekatvajñāne sati dvicandradarśanaṃ bhrāntamiti pratibhāti / anutpannatimirasyānyasya / naivaṃ nīlamityādi jñāne viparītārthagrāhakapramāṇānupapatterna mithyātvamiti /
analyzed: yat ca idam nīlam aham vedmi iti jñānam taimirikasya dvi candra darśana vat bhrāntam iti asat etat abādhyamāna tvāt tathā hi taimirikasya timira vināśāt ūrdhvam ekatva jñāne sati dvi candra darśanam bhrāntam iti pratibhāti anutpanna timirasya anyasya na evam nīlam ityādi jñāne viparīta artha grāhaka pramāṇa anupapatteḥ na mithyātvam iti
translated: And this cognition I know the blue is false like the perception of two moons by one suffering from an optical disorder. This is not so, because it is not contradicted. For example, when one suffering from an optical disorder has the cognition of oneness after the removal of the disorder, the perception of two moons appears to be false to one who has not developed the disorder. It is not so in the case of the cognition of blue, etc., because there is no possibility of a valid cognition apprehending an opposite meaning. Therefore, it is not false.

original: nanūktaṃ / kiṃ kena bādhyate / jñānaṃ jñāneneti / tathā hi / udakajñānasyodakaṃ viṣayaḥ sarvajanapratītaḥ / tatparityāgena viṣayāntare marīcyādāvutpannaṃ tadgrāhiṇā jñānena bādhyate mithyātvaviśiṣṭatayā jñāpyate mithyedaṃ mamodakajñānamutpannamiti / tajjanitasaṃskāranivṛttirvā / tathā hi / marīcijñāne sati udakajñānajanitasaṃskāranivṛttau kālāntare 'pi udakaṃ mayā dṛṣṭamiti smaraṇānutpattau taddeśābhimukhyena pravṛttyabhāva iti / bādhakānabhyupagame ca jñānasya satyetaravivekānupapattervādiprativādinorjayaparājayavyavasthā na syādityuktam /
analyzed: nanu uktam kim kena bādhyate jñānam jñānena iti  tathā hi udaka jñānasya udakam viṣayaḥ sarva jana pratītaḥ tad parityāgena viṣaya antare marīci ādau utpannam tad grāhiṇā jñānena bādhyate mithyātva viśiṣṭa tayā jñāpyate mithyā idam mama udaka jñānam utpannam iti tad janita saṃskāra nivṛttiḥ vā tathā hi marīci jñāne sati udaka jñāna janita saṃskāra nivṛttau kāla antare udakam mayā dṛṣṭam iti smaraṇa anutpattau tad deśa ābhimukhyena prav
translated: But it has been said: By what is what contradicted? Knowledge by knowledge. For thus: The object of the knowledge of water is water, well-known to all people. By the knowledge arising about another object, such as a mirage, abandoning that [water], it is contradicted, it is made known as having the qualification of being false, that this knowledge of water that arose in me is false. Or the cessation of the impression produced by that [knowledge of water]. For thus: When there is the knowledge of a mirage, by the cessation of the impression produced by the knowledge of water, even at a later time, there is no arising of the memory water was seen by me, and thus there is no activity directed towards that place. And if contradiction is not accepted, the distinction of true and false knowledge being impossible, there would be no establishment of victory and defeat for the proponent and opponent, as stated.

original: yattu mantrādyupaplutākṣāṇām ityādi vākyam / tanna parihārārham / svata eva pratibhāsasyānyathātvābhyupagamāt / tathā hi / mṛcchakalādayo 'nyathā pratibhāsante na svarūpeṇopaplutacakṣuṣām / na sarveṣāmitīṣyata evedaṃ mithyājñānam / bādhakopapatteḥ / iṣṭañca bādhakaṃ tathaiva darśanaṃ teṣāmanupaplutacakṣuṣām iti / dūre ca maruṣu alpo 'pi mahānupalabhyate sannikṛṣṭe cālpa eveti / anena tasya bādhā / na ca tenaivāsya bādhā / pramātṛmātrasya sarvadeśeṣvatadrūpatayā pratibhāsanāt / mahattvañca deśaviśeṣa eva pratibhāsate nānyatretyasadeva / tadeva hi padārthānāṃ svarūpaṃ yadavisaṃvādi svasthātmanāmarthakriyāsampādakañceti / ato mṛcchakalādayo yena rūpeṇāviplutacakṣuṣāṃ pratibhāsante 'rthakriyāñca II / sampādayanti tenaiva rūpeṇa santo na rūpāntareṇeti / katham / arthānāmavyavasthānāt / atha svapnāvasthāyāmarthānāmasattve 'pi pratibhāso viśiṣṭārthakriyā ca retaso visargaḥ sambhavatīti / nanvevaṃ tarhi svapnāvasthāyāmarthānāmasattvaṃ kathaṃ jñātamiti vācyam / yadi jāgradavasthāyāmanupalambhāt / tarhi yeṣāmupalambhasteṣāṃ sattvamāyātam / anyathā hi jāgradavasthāyāmanupalambhena svapnāvasthāyāmasattvaṃ na syāt / ataḥ pratīyamānatvāt svapnāvasthāyāmiva jāgradavasthāyāmapyasattvamiti na vācyam / pratibhāsamānatvasya sādhanasya sadbhāve 'pi asattvasya sādhyasyāniścayāt / pratīyamānatvañca bodhe 'sti na cāsattvamiti vyabhicāraḥ / tathā arthānāmasattve pratīyamānatvasya sādhanasyāpakṣadharmatvaṃ syāt / udāharaṇe pratīyamānatvena nāsattvam / api tu pramāṇato 'nupalabdherityanyathāsiddhañceti / na ca sarvaṃ vijñānam iti vādinaḥ svapnāvasthā jāgradavasthā ceti viśeṣaḥ sambhavati / ubhayatrāpi svasaṃvedyasya jñānasyāvasthānābhyupagamāt / vratavaśca / pūrvaṃ nirastā eva / tasmādakṣādijanitajñānasamavāyo jāgradavasthā / tadviparītā tu svapnāvastheti yuktam /
analyzed: yat tu mantra ādi upapluta akṣāṇām ityādi vākyam tat na parihāra arham svatas eva pratibhāsasya anyathātva abhyupagamāt tathā hi mṛd śakala ādayaḥ nyathā pratibhāsante na svarūpeṇa upapluta cakṣuṣām na sarveṣām iti iṣyate eva idam mithyājñānam bādhaka upapatteḥ iṣṭam ca bādhakam tathā eva darśanam teṣām anupapluta cakṣuṣām iti dūre ca maruṣu mahān upalabhyate sannikṛṣṭe ca alpe eva iti anena tasya bādhā na ca tena eva asya bādhā pramāt
translated: As for the statement beginning with when the eyes are affected by mantras etc., that is not worthy of being a solution, because the appearance itself is accepted to be otherwise. For example, clay, water etc. appear differently to those whose eyes are affected, not in their own form. It is indeed accepted that this is false knowledge, because it is contradicted. And the contradiction is accepted to be just that, the perception of those whose eyes are not affected. And it is far away that even a small thing is perceived as great in the desert, and in close proximity it is perceived as small only. This contradicts it. And it is not contradicted by that itself, because the knower alone appears in all places without that form. And greatness appears only in a particular place, not elsewhere, so it is non-existent. For that alone is the nature of things which is non-contradictory and which accomplishes the desired result for those with healthy minds. Therefore, clay, water etc. appear in that form to those whose eyes are not affected, and accomplish the desired result.

original: yaccedaṃ buddhyā vivecanād bhāvānāmasattvam ityuktam / tadasat / svabuddhipratibhāsamānavapuṣāmasattve bodhasyāpyasattvaprasaṅgāt / tathā hi / rūpādayaḥ parasparasvarūpaparihāreṇa vyavasthitāḥ svabuddhiviṣayāḥ / paṭādayo 'pyevam / ato yadyapi paṭastantvādibuddhau na pratibhāsate tathāpi svabuddhiviṣayatvāt paramārthasanneva / tadevaṃ paṭādayaḥ parasparavyāvṛttabuddhiviṣayā viśiṣṭārthakriyākāriṇaśceti paramārthasanta eva /
analyzed: yat ca idam buddhyā vivecanāt bhāvānām asattvam iti uktam tat asat sva buddhi pratibhāsamāna vapuṣām asattve bodhasya api asattva prasaṅgāt tathā hi rūpa ādayaḥ paraspara sva rūpa parihāreṇa vyavasthitāḥ sva buddhi viṣayāḥ paṭa ādayaḥ pi evam atas yadi api paṭaḥ tantu ādi buddhau na pratibhāsate tathā api sva buddhi viṣaya tvāt paramārtha san eva tat evam paṭa ādayaḥ paraspara vyāvṛtta buddhi viṣayāḥ viśiṣṭa arthakriyā kāriṇaḥ ca iti par
translated: And what has been said that things are non-existent due to discrimination by the intellect, that is not so. Because if the forms appearing in one's own intellect are non-existent, then consciousness would also be non-existent. This is because form and so on are established by the exclusion of each other's nature as objects of one's own intellect, and so are cloth and so on. Therefore, although cloth does not appear in the cognition of threads and so on, it is still ultimately existent because it is the object of one's own intellect. Thus, cloth and so on are objects of cognition that are mutually exclusive and perform specific functions, and are therefore ultimately existent.

original: na ca pramāṇaṃ vinā prameyasiddhiriti vijñānavyatirekiṇāmasattve pramāṇamabhidheyam / pramāṇaṃ vinā ca padārthānāmasattvasiddhau sattvamapi syāt / pramāṇābhāvasyobhayatrāviśeṣāt / atha arthānāmasattvasiddhau grāhyalakṣaṇāyogaḥ pramāṇam / na / tasyāpi bhāvadharmatve viruddhatvam / abhāvadharmatve cāśrayāsiddhatvam / ubhayadharmatve tu vyabhicārādasādhanatvamiti / vyadhikaraṇatvācca / tathā hi / grāhyalakṣaṇasyāyogo na grāhyadharma iti / kathaṃ tasyāsattvaṃ sādhayet / svarūpāsiddhaśca / grāhyalakṣaṇasya sadbhāvāt / tathā ca / mahattvādi grāhyalakṣaṇaṃ vakṣyaII /mānamiti / sādhyāviśiṣṭañca / grāhyalakṣaṇāyogasyāpi sādhyatvāt / na ca pramāṇāntaramastīti /
analyzed: na ca pramāṇam vinā prameya siddhiḥ iti vijñāna vyatirekiṇām asattve pramāṇam abhidheyam pramāṇam vinā ca padārthānām asattva siddhau sattvam api syāt pramāṇa abhāvasya ubhayatra aviśeṣāt atha arthānām asattva siddhau grāhya lakṣaṇa ayogaḥ pramāṇam na tasya api bhāva dharma tve viruddha tvam abhāva dharma tve ca āśraya asiddha tvam ubhaya dharma tve tu vyabhicārāt asādhana tvam iti vyadhikaraṇa tvāt ca  /
translated: And since the object of knowledge cannot be established without a means of knowledge, the means of knowledge should be stated, when the existence of things other than consciousness is not accepted. And if the non-existence of things is established without a means of knowledge, their existence would also be so, because the absence of a means of knowledge is the same in both cases. If it is argued that the incompatibility of the characteristic of the object of knowledge is the means of knowledge for establishing the non-existence of objects, it is not so. For that also, if it is a property of an existent, it is contradictory. If it is a property of an absence, then the basis is not established. If it is a property of both, then it is not a proof due to deviation. And because it has a different substratum. For thus, the incompatibility of the characteristic of the object of knowledge is not a property of the object of knowledge. How would it establish its non-existence? And it is not established in its own nature, because the characteristic of the object of knowledge exists. And thus, the characteristic of the object of knowledge such as largeness will be stated later. And it is the same as the probandum, because the incompatibility of the characteristic of the object of knowledge is also to be proved. And there is no other means of knowledge.

original: etena śūnyavādo 'pi nirasta eveti na pṛthagabhidhīyate / tathā hi / sarvārthānāmasattve vijñānasyāpi grāhyagrāhakākārarahitatvād asatve ca / sarvaṃ śūnyamiti syāt / tacca nirastameva / pramāṇābhāvena prameyasyāsiddheḥ / bodhasyārthānāñca pramāṇato vyavasthāpanāditi / tadevaṃ bodhavyatirekeṇārthasadbhāvasiddherānantyāt pratyarthaniyatatvācca buddheranekatvaṃ yuktamiti /
analyzed: etena śūnyavādaḥ pi nirastaḥ evā iti na pṛthak abhidhīyate tathā hi sarva arthānām asattve vijñānasya api grāhya grāhaka ākāra rahita tvāt asatve ca sarvam śūnyam iti syāt tat ca nirastam eva pramāṇa abhāvena prameyasya asiddheḥ bodhasya arthānām ca pramāṇataḥ vyavasthāpanāt iti tat evam bodha vyatirekeṇa artha sadbhāva siddheḥ ānantyāt prati artha niyata tvāt ca buddheḥ aneka tvam yuktam iti
translated: By this, the doctrine of emptiness is also refuted, so it is not stated separately. For thus, if all objects are non-existent, and consciousness is also non-existent due to lacking the form of grasper and grasped, everything would be empty. And that is indeed refuted, because the object is not established due to the absence of a means of valid cognition, and because cognition and objects are established by means of valid cognition. Thus, since the existence of objects apart from cognition is established in this way, due to their infinity and because cognition is restricted to each object, it is reasonable that cognition is manifold.

original: anye tu ātmanaḥ pariṇāmaviśeṣo buddhistadrūpatayā cānityā / ātmarūpatayā tu nityeti matam / tasya nirāsārthaṃ sā cānekaprakāreti vākyaṃ manyante / tathā hi / buddheranekatvādātmano 'pyanekatvam / abhedāt / ātmaikatve vā buddherekatvam / na ca bhedābhedapakṣaḥ sambhavati / anekāntavādasya pūrvameva pratiṣedhāt / ato buddherguṇatvādanekatve 'pyātmanastathābhāvo na bhavatīti digvāsasāṃ mataṃ niṣiddham /
analyzed: anye tu ātmanaḥ pariṇāma viśeṣaḥ buddhiḥ tad rūpatayā ca anityā ātma rūpatayā tu nityā iti matam tasya nirāsa artham sā ca aneka prakārā iti vākyam manyante tathā hi buddheḥ aneka tvāt ātmanaḥ pi aneka tvam abhedāt ātma eka tve vā buddheḥ eka tvam na ca bheda abheda pakṣaḥ sambhavati anekāntavādasya pūrvam eva pratiṣedhāt atas buddheḥ guṇa tvāt aneka tve pi ātmanaḥ tathābhāvaḥ na bhavati iti digvāsasām matam niṣiddham
translated: Others, however, think that the sentence And that is of many kinds is meant to refute the view that the intellect is a particular modification of the self, and is non-eternal in the form of that [modification], but eternal in the form of the self. Thus, they argue, because the intellect is of many kinds, the self must also be of many kinds, due to non-difference. Or, if the self is one, the intellect must be one. And the view of difference and non-difference is not possible, because the doctrine of non-absolutism has already been refuted. Therefore, the view of the Digambara Jains is refuted, that the self is of the same nature as the intellect, even though it is of many kinds, because the intellect is a quality [of the self].

original: tasyāḥ satyapyanekavidhatve samāsato dve vidhe / vidyā cāvidyā ceti / tatrāvidyā caturvidhā saṃśayaviparyayānadhyavasāyasvapnalakṣaṇā /PDhS
analyzed: tasyāḥ sati api anekavidha tve samāsatas dve vidhe vidyā ca avidyā ca iti tatra avidyā caturvidhā saṃśaya viparyaya anadhyavasāya svapna lakṣaṇā
translated: Although that [intellect] is of many kinds, it is in brief of two kinds: knowledge and ignorance. Among them, ignorance is of four kinds, characterized by doubt, error, indecision, and dreams.

original: nanvevaṃ tarhi buddherānantyāt kathaṃ tattvajñānaviṣayatvamityāha tasyāḥ satyapyanekavidhatve samāsataḥ saṃkṣepato dvividheti parijñānaṃ kāryamiti / kena rūpeṇa dvaividhyamityāha vidyā cāvidyā ceti /
analyzed: nanu evam tarhi buddheḥ ānantyāt katham tattva jñāna viṣaya tvam iti āha tasyāḥ sati api anekavidha tve samāsatas saṃkṣepataḥ dvividhā iti parijñānam kāryam iti kena rūpeṇa dvaividhyam iti āha vidyā ca avidyā ca iti
translated: If so, then how can it be the object of the knowledge of reality due to the infinity of intellect? He says: although it has many kinds, its twofold nature should be known in brief. By what form is it twofold? He says: knowledge and ignorance.

original: anye tu vedāntamate vidyāvidyayoḥ śravaṇāt buddherānantyapratipādanamāgamaviruddhaṃ syādityāśaṅkāniṣedhārthamāha tasyāḥ satyapyanekavidhatve samāsataḥ saṃkṣepato dvaividhyamiṣyata eva vidyā cāvidyā ceti /
analyzed: anye tu vedānta mate vidyā avidyayoḥ śravaṇāt buddheḥ ānantya pratipādanam āgama viruddham syāt iti āśaṅkā niṣedha artham āha tasyāḥ sati api anekavidha tve samāsatas saṃkṣepataḥ dvaividhyam iṣyate eva vidyā ca avidyā ca iti
translated: Others, however, fearing that the teaching of the infinity of intellect would contradict the scriptures due to the mention of knowledge and ignorance in the Vedanta view, say: although it has many kinds, its twofold nature is accepted in brief, namely knowledge and ignorance.

original: vidyā hi deśakālāvasthādibhedenābādhyamāno 'dhyavasāyaḥ / tadviparītārthā cāvidyati / na tu pramāṇāpramāṇatve vidyāvidyatve / vyabhicārāt / tathā hi / yadi pramīyate 'neneti pramāṇamiti vivakṣitam saṃśayāderapyātmāntaḥkaraṇādhigame pramāṇatvamastīti vyabhicāraḥ / sarveṣu ca pratyakṣādijñāneṣu kāraṇatvānupapatteravyāptiśca / phalavivakṣāyāntu na smṛteḥ pramāṇaphalatvamiti vidyātvaṃ na syāt /
analyzed: vidyā hi deśa kāla avasthā ādi bhedena ābādhyamānaḥ dhyavasāyaḥ tad viparīta arthā ca avidyati na tu pramāṇa apramāṇa tve vidyā avidya tve vyabhicārāt tathā hi yadi pramīyate nena iti pramāṇam iti vivakṣitam saṃśaya ādeḥ api ātma antaḥkaraṇa adhigame pramāṇa tvam asti iti vyabhicāraḥ sarveṣu ca pratyakṣa ādi jñāneṣu kāraṇa tva anupapatteḥ avyāptiḥ ca phala vivakṣāyām tu na smṛteḥ pramāṇa phala tvam iti vidyā tvam na syāt
translated: For knowledge is a determination that is not contradicted by differences of place, time, and condition, and ignorance is the opposite of that in meaning, not in terms of being a means of valid knowledge or not, because of deviation. For example, if it is intended that a means of valid knowledge is that by which something is known, then doubt and others also have the nature of a means of valid knowledge in the understanding of the self and the internal organ, so there is deviation. And there is also non-pervasion, because in all the cognitions such as perception, the nature of being a cause is not possible. But if the result is intended, then memory is not the result of a means of valid knowledge, so it would not have the nature of knowledge.

original: guravastu viśiṣṭavyavahārakāraṇaṃ vijñānaṃ vidyā / viparītañcāvidyeti bruvate / tatra yadi pravṛttinivṛttilakṣaṇo viśiṣṭavyavahāro vivakṣitastadā saṃśayādijñāneṣvapi bhāvādativyāptiḥ / na ca pakṣe sarvatrāstīti avyāptiśca / atha deśādibhedenāpi samyaktayā mayopalabdhamiti jñānaṃ viśiṣṭavyavahāraḥ / tajjanakatvamapi na sarveṣu vidyābhedeṣvastītyavyāptiḥ / tathā ca samyaṅ mayopalabdhamiti vyavahāro na sarveṣu vidyābhedeṣu vidyata ityavyāpakatvameva /
analyzed: guravaḥ tu viśiṣṭa vyavahāra kāraṇam vijñānam vidyā viparītam ca avidyā iti bruvate tatra yadi pravṛtti nivṛtti lakṣaṇaḥ viśiṣṭa vyavahāraḥ vivakṣitaḥ tadā saṃśaya ādi jñāneṣu api bhāvāt ativyāptiḥ na ca pakṣe sarvatra asti iti avyāptiḥ ca  atha deśa ādi bhedena api samyaktayā mayā upalabdham iti jñānam viśiṣṭa vyavahāraḥ tad janaka tvam api na sarveṣu vidyā bhedeṣu asti iti avyāptiḥ tathā ca samyak mayā upalabdham iti vyavah
translated: The teachers, however, say that knowledge is that which is the cause of a special kind of activity, and that which is contrary to that is ignorance. If, in that case, a special kind of activity characterized by engagement and disengagement is intended, then there is over-extension, because it exists even in doubtful knowledge and other [forms of knowledge]. And there is also under-extension, because it does not exist everywhere in the subject [of knowledge]. If, on the other hand, a special kind of activity is [defined as] the knowledge that I have perceived correctly even in different places and so on, and if the cause of that [knowledge] is also not present in all the different kinds of knowledge, then there is under-extension. And thus, the non-pervasiveness [of the definition] is that the activity of I have perceived correctly does not exist in all the different kinds of knowledge.

original: tatrāpyavidyā caturvidheti kramātikrameṇāvidyāyāḥ svarūpanirūpaṇamarthaprakāśasya vivakṣitatvāt taducchedyatvajñāpanārthamiti cānye / avidyā hi vidyayā samucchidyata iti /

translated: Others say that ignorance is of four kinds, and that the definition of ignorance is given out of order, because the manifestation of the object is intended, and in order to show that it is to be destroyed by knowledge. For ignorance is destroyed by knowledge.

analyzed: atha kena rūpeṇa caturvidhā saṃśaya viparyaya anadhyavasāya svapna lakṣaṇā svarūpā iti  nanu ūha jñānam api asti tasya antarbhāvaḥ na vidyāyām na api avidyāyām ubhayatra api cāturvidhya abhidhānāt  na yuktam etat saṃśaya niścaya vyatirekeṇa ūha jñānasya asaṃvedanāt atha asti saṃśayāt ūrdhvam bāhya āli pradeśe sambandha upalabdheḥ sthāṇu pakṣa pratiṣedhe sati puruṣeṇa anena bhavitavyam iti sambhāvanā pratyayaḥ sa tu tasmin tat iti rūpa tvāt

original: saṃśayavaidharmyam🔽saṃśayastāvat prasiddhānekaviśeṣayoḥ sādṛśyamātradarśanāt / ubhayaviśeṣānusmaraṇāt / adharmācca kiṃsvidityubhayāvalambī vimarṣaḥ saṃśayaḥ /PDhS

original: saṃśayastāvad vyākhyāyate 'vasaraprāptatvāditi / prasiddhā aneke viśeṣā yayostau tathoktau tayoriti viṣayanirūpaṇam / na tu prasiddhau ca tāvanekaviśeṣau ceti karmadhārayaparigrahaḥ / saṃśayasya ca dharmiviṣayatvāt / atha ekasyaiva dharmiṇastatra sadbhāvād ubhayoḥ kathaṃ viṣayatvasambhavaḥ / pakṣopanyāsādadoṣaḥ / tathāhi / yatrāneke viśeṣāḥ prasiddhāstatraiva saṃśaya iti niyamyate / na tvekasminneva kāle tayorviṣayatvam / ekasya tatrāsambhavāt / kālabhedena tu ubhayorviṣayatvam / yad yatra sambhāvyate / saṃśayotpattau sa tasya viṣaya iti /

It is restricted that doubt occurs only where many distinctions are well-known. But the two are not objects at the same time. Because one cannot exist there. But with a difference in time, both can be objects. Whatever is possible there, when doubt arises, that is its object.

original: kāraṇamiha sādṛśyamātradarśanāt iti / sādṛśyamātraṃ dṛśyate 'sminniti sādṛśyaviśeṣina /tadharmidarśanaṃ labhyata iti vyākhyeyam / na tu sādṛśyamātrasya darśanamityabhyupagamena dharmopalambhād dharmiṇi saṃśayasya vyadhikaraṇatvāt / atra sādṛśyamātradarśanāt iti mātrābhidhānenātyantaviśeṣānupalabdhiṃ darśayati / sāmānyasya viśeṣasahitasyopalambhe 'pi saṃśayādarśanāditi / na ca sāmānyopalambhaṃ vinā viśeṣānupalabdhiḥ saṃśayajaniketyubhayābhidhānam / tathāpi nāvādyārūḍhasya vṛkṣādiṣūbhayasadbhāve 'pi na saṃśaya iti ubhayaviśeṣānusmaraṇāt iti padam / viśeṣānusmaraṇañca na pūrvoktaṃ vinā saṃśayajanakaṃ dṛṣṭamiti samuditaṃ kāraṇam / tadevaṃ sāmānyadarśanād viśeṣādarśanād ubhayaviśeṣānusmaraṇād adharmādibhyaścotpadyamānatvāt saṃśaya itarebhyo bhidyata iti kāraṇātmakaṃ lakṣaṇam / tathā ca sūtram sāmānyapratyakṣād viśeṣāpratyaII /kṣād viśeṣasmṛteśca saṃśayaḥ vai / sū / / / iti / sāmānyaṃ pratyakṣaṃ yasmin dharmiṇyasau tathoktastasmāditi / pratyakṣaśabdaśca dṛḍhapramāṇavacanaḥ / atrānumānikasyāpi saṃśayasyābhyupagamāt / viśeṣāpratyakṣāditi viśeṣānupalabdhestatsmṛteśca saṃśaya iti /
analyzed: kāraṇam iha sādṛśya mātra darśanāt iti sādṛśya mātram dṛśyate smin iti sādṛśya viśeṣi nata dharmi darśanam labhyate iti vyākhyeyam na tu sādṛśya mātrasya darśanam iti abhyupagamena dharma upalambhāt dharmiṇi saṃśayasya vyadhikaraṇa tvāt atra sādṛśya mātra darśanāt iti mātra abhidhānena atyanta viśeṣa anupalabdhim darśayati sāmānyasya viśeṣa sahitasya upalambhe saṃśaya adarśanāt iti na ca sāmānya upalambham vinā viśeṣa anupalabdhiḥ sa
translated: The reason here is the mere perception of similarity. It should be explained that the perception of the possessor of similarity is said to be the perception of the mere similarity in this, but not the perception of mere similarity. Because the doubt regarding the possessor is due to the perception of the property, not because of the non-perception of the property, since the doubt is with a different substratum. Here, by mentioning mere in from the mere perception of similarity, it shows the non-apprehension of the extreme particular. Even when the universal is apprehended along with the particular, there is no doubt. Thus, both are mentioned, because the non-apprehension of the particular without the apprehension of the universal does not generate doubt. Even so, when both are present in a tree etc. that is not mounted on the first, there is no doubt. Therefore, the word from the recollection of both particulars is used. And the recollection of the particulars is seen to generate doubt only when the above-mentioned [conditions] are not present. Thus, the combined [conditions] are the cause. Thus, from the perception of the universal, from the non-perception of the particular, and from the recollection of both particulars,

original: nanu cāyuktametat / devadattasya svapriyatamāṃ parityajya vrajato deśavyavadhānāt tritayasadbhāve 'pi tatra saṃśayānupalabdheḥ / tathāhi / strītvasāmānyopalambhe 'pyanekādiviśeṣopalambhāt tatsmaraṇācca kiṃ madīyā anyadīyā veti saṃśayo na dṛṣṭaḥ / parapakṣapratiṣedhakasya deśakālaviśeṣasya bādhakasyopalabdheḥ / ekasmin deśe kāle cānyā na sambhavatīti / ato 'sya vyavacchedārthaṃ bādhakasādhakapramāṇāvyavasthātaśceti padaṃ kāryam / na / viśeṣānupalabdhipadenaiva nirastatvāt / tathāhi / viśeṣānupalabdhipadena samastaviśeṣānupalabdhirvivakṣitā / sā cātra nāsti / deśakālaviśeṣasya niścitatvāt / ato viśeṣānupalabdhipadenaivāsya nirastatvāditi vyavacchedyābhāvaṃ manyamāno munirna viśeṣāntaramāheti /
analyzed: nanu ca ayuktam etat devadattasya sva priyatamām parityajya vrajataḥ deśa vyavadhānāt tritaya sadbhāve tatra saṃśaya anupalabdheḥ tathā hi strī tva sāmānya upalambhe pi aneka ādi viśeṣa upalambhāt tad smaraṇāt ca kim madīyā anyadīyā vā iti saṃśayaḥ na dṛṣṭaḥ parapakṣa pratiṣedhakasya deśa kāla viśeṣasya bādhakasya upalabdheḥ ekasmin deśe kāle ca anyā na sambhavati iti vyavaccheda artham bādhaka sādhaka pramāṇa avyavasthātaḥ ca iti padam kāry
translated: But this is improper. For Devadatta, leaving his own beloved and going to another place, even when the three are present, there is no doubt due to the obstruction of the country. For thus: Even on the perception of the general property of womanhood, due to the perception of many specific properties and the recollection of them, the doubt is this mine or another's? is not seen, due to the perception of the negation of the country and time, which negates the opponent's view. For another cannot exist in the same country and time. Therefore, for the purpose of excluding this, the words due to the non-establishment of negating and establishing valid cognitions should be used. No, because it has already been refuted by the words non-perception of specific properties. For thus: By the words non-perception of specific properties, the non-perception of all specific properties is intended. And that is not here, because the specific country and time are certain. Therefore, because it has already been refuted by the words non-perception of specific properties, considering the absence of the object to be excluded, the sage did not mention another specific property.

original: tasya svarūpamāha kiṃ svidityubhayāvalambī vimarśaḥ saṃśayaḥ iti / saṃśītiḥ saṃśayaḥ / saṃśayyate 'nenātmā supta iva bhavatīti niruktirlakṣaṇam / vimarśanaṃ vimarśaḥ / kimidameva āhosvidevaṃ na bhavatīti pratyayaḥ / sa cobhayamālambate tacchīlaścetyubhayāvalambī vimarśaḥ saṃśaya iti / na cobhayorviṣayatvaṃ ghaṭata ityubhayollekhīti vyākhyeyam / ato vimarśa itarasmād bhidyate / saṃśaya iti vā vyavahartavyo / vimarśarūpatvāt / kiṃ syādityubhayālambitvād veti /
analyzed: tasya svarūpam āha kim svid iti ubhaya avalambī vimarśaḥ saṃśayaḥ iti saṃśītiḥ saṃśayaḥ saṃśayyate nena ātmā suptaḥ iva bhavati iti niruktiḥ lakṣaṇam vimarśanam vimarśaḥ kim idam eva āhosvit evam na bhavati iti pratyayaḥ sa ca ubhayam ālambate tad śīlaḥ ca iti ubhaya avalambī vimarśaḥ saṃśayaḥ iti na ca ubhayoḥ viṣaya tvam ghaṭate iti ubhaya ullekhi iti vyākhyeyam atas vimarśaḥ itarasmāt bhidyate saṃśayaḥ iti vā vyavahartavyaḥ vimar
translated: He states its nature: What is this? - the doubt is a consideration that rests on both. Doubt is the state of being doubtful. The definition is that by this, the self becomes as if asleep. Consideration is reflection. The idea is Is this so or does it not exist in this way? And that rests on both, and one who has that habit is one who rests on both. The consideration that rests on both is doubt. And it should not be explained that the object of both is not possible, so it is said to indicate both. Therefore, consideration is different from the other. Or it should be referred to as doubt. Because it has the form of consideration. Or because it rests on both, like What might it be?

original: sa ca dvividhaḥ iti vibhāgaḥ / kena rūpeṇa / antarbahiśca / nanu pañcavidhatvāt saṃśayasya dvaividhyamanupapannam / na / asyaivāvāntara bhedena tadupapatteḥ / tathāhi / samānadharmopapatteḥ / anekadharmopapatteḥ / vipratipatteśceti bāhyastrividhaḥ saṃśayaḥ / upalabdhyanupalabdhyośca manaḥparicchedyatvādāntaro dvividha iti / abhipretañcaitad bhāṣyakarturyata āha samāno 'nekaśca dharmo jñeyasthaḥ / upalabdhyanupalabdhī punarjñātṛsthe ityavirodhaḥ / saṅgrahānabhyupagame ca pratyakṣāpratyakṣaviṣayabhedenāpi saṃśayasya bhedāt pañcatvamasambaddhaṃ syāt / II / athānenaiva saṅgrahādanabhidhānam / tarhi dvaividhyenaiva saṅgrahānna pañcatvamabhidhīyate / tasya hi tadbhedatvāditi /
analyzed: sa ca dvividhaḥ iti vibhāgaḥ kena rūpeṇa antar bahis ca  nanu pañcavidha tvāt saṃśayasya dvaividhyam anupapannam na asya eva avāntara bhedena tad upapatteḥ tathā hi samāna dharma upapatteḥ aneka dharma upapatteḥ vipratipatteḥ ca iti bāhyaḥ trividhaḥ saṃśayaḥ upalabdhi anupalabdhyoḥ ca manaḥ paricchedya tvāt āntaraḥ dvividhaḥ iti abhipretam ca etat bhāṣya kartuḥ yatas āha samānaḥ nekaḥ ca dharmaḥ jñeya sthaḥ upalabdhi anupalabdhī punar jñātṛ s
translated: And it is of two kinds - this is the division. By what form? Internally and externally. But since doubt is of five kinds, its twofold nature is illogical. No, it is logical by its own subdivisions. Thus, external doubt is threefold: from the cognition of common properties, from the cognition of multiple properties, and from contradiction. Internal doubt is twofold, to be determined by the mind from perception and non-perception. And this is intended by the author of the commentary, since he says: The common and multiple properties are based on the object of knowledge. Perception and non-perception, on the other hand, are based on the knower. So there is no contradiction. And if you do not accept the inclusion, then the fivefold nature of doubt would be illogical, even by the distinction of the object of perception and non-perception. If, on the other hand, it is not mentioned because it is included by this alone, then the fivefold nature is not mentioned just because it is included by the twofold nature, since that is its subdivision.

original: anekaśca dharmo sādhāraṇatvāt saṃśayaheturna bhavatyeva / viruddhaviśeṣaiḥ sahānupalambhena tatsmaraṇājanakatvāt / nāpi viruddhāvyabhicārī saṃśayahetustasyaivāsambhavāditi vakṣyāmo 'naikāntikāvasare /
analyzed: anekaḥ ca sādhāraṇa tvāt saṃśaya hetuḥ na bhavati eva viruddha viśeṣaiḥ saha anupalambhena tad smaraṇa ajanaka tvāt na api viruddha avyabhicārī saṃśaya hetuḥ tasya eva asambhavāt iti vakṣyāmaḥ na aikāntika avasare
translated: And a manifold property, being common, is not a cause of doubt at all, because it does not produce the recollection of that [property] together with contradictory particulars, through non-apprehension. Nor is a contradictory non-deviator a cause of doubt, because that [contradictory non-deviator] is impossible, as we will explain at the occasion of the inconclusive [reason].

original: antastāvad ādeśikasya samyaṅ mithyā coddiśya punarādiśatastriṣu kāleṣu saṃśayo bhavati kinnu samyaṅ mithyā veti /PDhS
analyzed: antar tāvat ādeśikasya samyak mithyā ca uddiśya punar ādiśataḥ triṣu kāleṣu saṃśayaḥ bhavati kinnu samyak mithyā vā iti
translated: To begin with, when one is taught something by an instructor, whether correctly or incorrectly, and then teaches it again to others at three different times, there is doubt: Is it correct or incorrect?

original: tatra antaḥsaṃśayasya svarūpanirūpaṇārtham antastāvadādeśikasya ityādi / yathā hi / ādeśikena viśiṣṭaṃ nimittamupalabhyādiṣṭamekadā vṛṣṭirbhaviṣyatīti samyak jātamanyadā tu viparītam / punastathaivādiśatastriṣu kāleṣu asatsu tasmin jñāne saṃśayo bhavati kinnu samyaṅ mithyā veti / atha jñānasya sāmānyadarśanaviśeṣānusmaraṇakāle 'vasthānābhāvāt kathaṃ saṃśayaviṣayatvam / tathāhi / tasmin jñāne bhaviṣyadvṛṣṭiviṣayatvaṃ samāno dharmastadviśiṣṭe jñāne jñānamutpadyate / tasya tu vinaśyattā / samyaktvāsamyaktvaviśeṣasmaraṇasyotpadyamānatā / tato viśeṣasmaraṇakāle jñānamatītaṃ kathaṃ viṣayaḥ / tadupalakṣitātmano viṣayatvādadoṣaḥ / tathā ca / kinnu samyak jñānavānahaṃ mithyājñānavān veti saṃśayaḥ /
analyzed: tatra antar saṃśayasya svarūpa nirūpaṇa artham antar tāvat ādeśikasya ityādi  yathā hi ādeśikena viśiṣṭam nimittam upalabhya ādiṣṭam ekadā vṛṣṭiḥ bhaviṣyati iti samyak jātam anyadā tu viparītam punar tathā eva ādiśataḥ triṣu kāleṣu asatsu tasmin jñāne saṃśayaḥ bhavati kin nu samyak mithyā vā iti atha jñānasya sāmānya darśana viśeṣa anusmaraṇa kāle vasthāna abhāvāt katham saṃśaya viṣaya tvam tathā hi tasmin jñāne bhaviṣyat vṛ
translated: There, to describe the nature of doubt within, he says first of all, of the one who is instructed. Just as when an instructor, having perceived a specific sign, once declares rain will occur, it is correct. But another time, it is the opposite. Again, when those three times do not exist, there is doubt in that knowledge - whether it is correct or false. Now, since knowledge does not exist at the time of seeing the general and remembering the specific, how can it be the object of doubt? Thus, in that knowledge, the common property of being about future rain is the same. Knowledge arises in that specific knowledge. But it is in the process of destruction. The specific memory of correctness and incorrectness is in the process of arising. Therefore, when the specific memory is present, how can the past knowledge be the object? There is no fault, because it is the object of the self indicated by that. And thus, there is doubt - Am I one who has correct knowledge or one who has false knowledge?

original: anye tu vidyamānasyevātītasyāpi viṣayatvamastīti bruvate /🔽bahirdvividhaḥ / pratyakṣaviṣaye cāpratyakṣaviṣaye ca / tatrāpratyakṣaviṣaye tāvat sādhāraṇaliṅgadarśanādubhayaviśeṣānusmaraṇād adharmācca saṃśayo bhavati / yathā aṭavyāṃ viṣāṇamātradarśanād gaurgavayo veti /PDhS
analyzed: anye tu vidyamānasya iva atītasya api viṣaya tvam asti iti bruvate  bahis dvividhaḥ pratyakṣa viṣaye ca apratyakṣa viṣaye ca  tatra apratyakṣa viṣaye tāvat sādhāraṇa liṅga darśanāt ubhaya viśeṣa anusmaraṇāt adharmāt ca saṃśayaḥ bhavati yathā aṭavyām viṣāṇa mātra darśanāt gauḥ gavayaḥ vā iti
translated: But others say that the past also has the nature of an object, just as the present does.🔽External doubt is of two kinds: regarding perceptible objects and imperceptible objects. Regarding imperceptible objects, doubt arises from seeing a common mark, from remembering the particulars of both, and from non-inherence, like wondering if it is a cow or a gavaya when only seeing a horn in the forest.

original: bahirdvividhaḥ kena rūpeṇa / pratyakṣaviṣaye cāpratyakṣaviṣaye ca iti / tatrāpratyakṣaviṣaye tāvat abhidhīyate saṃśayaḥ sādhāraṇaliṅgadarśanāt iti / yalliṅgaṃ viruddhaviśeṣaiḥ sahopalabdhaṃ taddarśanād viśeṣānupalabdheḥ / ubhayaviśeṣānusmaraṇādadharmāt dikkālādibhyaśca saṃśayo bhavati / yathāṭavyāṃ viṣāṇamātradarśanāt tadgataviśeṣānupalabdhestatsmaraṇāt saṃśayo bhavati gaurgavayo veti /
analyzed: bahis dvividhaḥ kena rūpeṇa pratyakṣa viṣaye ca apratyakṣa viṣaye ca iti tatra apratyakṣa viṣaye tāvat abhidhīyate saṃśayaḥ sādhāraṇa liṅga darśanāt iti yat liṅgam viruddha viśeṣaiḥ saha upalabdham tad darśanāt viśeṣa anupalabdheḥ ubhaya viśeṣa anusmaraṇāt adharmāt diś kāla ādibhyaḥ ca saṃśayaḥ bhavati yathā aṭavyām viṣāṇa mātra darśanāt tad gata viśeṣa anupalabdheḥ tad smaraṇāt saṃśayaḥ bhavati gauḥ gavayaḥ vā iti
translated: External doubt is of two kinds: in what form? Regarding perceptible objects and imperceptible objects. Regarding imperceptible objects, doubt is first explained as arising from seeing a common mark. From seeing a mark that is perceived along with contradictory particulars, due to the non-perception of particulars, from remembering the particulars of both, and from non-inherence, like direction, time, etc., doubt arises. For example, from only seeing a horn in the forest, due to the non-perception of its specific features, from remembering that, doubt arises as to whether it is a cow or a gavaya.

original: atha pratyakṣādasya viśeṣaḥ katham / sāmānyaviśeṣitasya dharmiṇaḥ pratyakṣatvaṃ viśeṣalakṣaṇānabhidhānāt / / atha kiṃ gogavayaviṣāṇeṣu sāmānyam / tulyāvayavaracanāyogaḥ / yathābhūtā hi avayavaracanā goviṣāṇe dṛṣṭā tathā gavayaviṣāṇe 'pīti / ye tu goviṣāṇaviśeṣā gavayaviṣāṇaviśeṣāśca pūrvopalabdhāsteṣāmatrānupalambha iti / ataḥ sādṛśyamātraviśeṣitaṃ viṣāṇamupalabhamānasya viśeṣānupalabdhestatsmaraṇācca kiṃ gauḥ syāt / gavayo veti saṃśayaḥ /
analyzed: atha pratyakṣāt asya viśeṣaḥ katham sāmānya viśeṣitasya dharmiṇaḥ pratyakṣa tvam viśeṣa lakṣaṇa anabhidhānāt    atha kim go gavaya viṣāṇeṣu sāmānyam tulya avayava racanā yogaḥ yathā bhūtā hi avayava racanā go viṣāṇe dṛṣṭā tathā gavaya viṣāṇe pi iti ye tu go viṣāṇa viśeṣāḥ gavaya viṣāṇa viśeṣāḥ ca pūrva upalabdhāḥ teṣām atra anupalambhaḥ iti atas sādṛśya mātra viśeṣitam viṣāṇam upalabhamānasya viśeṣ
translated: Now, how is this different from perception? The perceived object is qualified by the universal, because the specific characteristics are not mentioned.🔽Now, what is the universal in the horns of a cow and a gayal? It is the arrangement of similar parts. For the arrangement of parts is seen in the cow's horn as it is in the gayal's horn. But those specific features of the cow's horn and the gayal's horn that were previously perceived are not perceived here. Therefore, for one who perceives the horn qualified by mere similarity, there is doubt: Is it a cow or a gayal? due to the non-perception of the specific features and the recollection of them.

original: pratyakṣaviṣaye 'pi sthāṇupuruṣayorūrdhvatāmātrasādṛśyadarśanāt vakrā / atādiviśeṣānupalabdhitaḥ sthāṇutvādisāmānyaviśeṣānabhivyaktāvubhayaviśeṣānusmaraṇādubhayatrākṛṣyamāṇasyātmanaḥ pratyayo dolāyate kinnu khalvayaṃ sthāṇuḥ syāt puruṣo veti /PDhS
analyzed: pratyakṣa viṣaye pi sthāṇu puruṣayoḥ ūrdhva tā mātra sādṛśya darśanāt vakrāḥ ata ādi viśeṣa anupalabdhitaḥ sthāṇu tva ādi sāmānya viśeṣa anabhivyaktau ubhaya viśeṣa anusmaraṇāt ubhayatra ākṛṣyamāṇasya ātmanaḥ pratyayaḥ dolāyate kim nu khalu ayam sthāṇuḥ syāt puruṣaḥ vā iti
translated: Even in the case of a directly perceived object, due to the perception of mere similarity in height between a post and a man, and the non-perception of specific features like crookedness, etc., when the specific features of both, such as being a post, etc., are not manifested, the cognition oscillates between the two, being drawn to both, thinking What is this, a post or a man?

original: pratyakṣaviṣaye 'pi sthāṇupuruṣayorūrdhvatāmātrasādṛśyadarśanāt vakrā /atādiviśeṣānupalabdhitaḥ iti / ādipadena kākanilayanādayaḥ sthāṇau / śiraḥpāṇyādayaśca puruṣeṣu viśeṣāsteṣāmanupalambhāditi / sthāṇutvamādiryasyetyādipadena puruṣatvagrahaṇam / tacca sāmānyameva viśeṣaḥ / tasyānabhivyaktirvyañjakasya śiraḥpāṇyāderanupalambhāt / atastad anabhivyaktāvubhayaviśeṣānusmaraṇādubhayatra sthāṇau puruṣe ca / ākṛṣyamāṇasyātmanaḥ pratyayo dolāyate naikakoṭau vyavatiṣṭhate / sa ca kiṃsvarūpa ityāha kinnu khalvayaṃ sthāṇuḥ syāt puruṣo veti /
analyzed: pratyakṣa viṣaye pi sthāṇu puruṣayoḥ ūrdhva tā mātra sādṛśya darśanāt vakrāḥ ata ādi viśeṣa anupalabdhitaḥ iti ādi padena kāka nilayana ādayaḥ sthāṇau śiraḥ pāṇi ādayaḥ ca puruṣeṣu viśeṣāḥ teṣām anupalambhāt iti sthāṇu tvam ādiḥ yasya iti ādi padena puruṣa tva grahaṇam tat ca sāmānyam eva viśeṣaḥ tasya anabhivyaktiḥ vyañjakasya śiraḥ pāṇi ādeḥ anupalambhāt  atas tat anabhivyaktau ubhaya viśeṣa anusmaraṇāt ubhay
translated: Even in the case of perception, due to seeing mere similarity in height between a post and a man, it is doubtful, because the specific features such as crookedness, etc. are not perceived. The word 'ādi' (etc.) includes the specific features such as the crow's nest, etc. in the post, and the head, hands, etc. in the man. Because those are not perceived. The word 'ādi' (etc.) includes the word 'puruṣatva' (humanness), where 'sthāṇutva' (postness) is the first. And that generality itself is a specific feature. Its non-manifestation is due to the non-perception of the manifestor, such as the head, hands, etc. Therefore, in that non-manifestation, due to the recollection of both specific features, in both - the post and the man. The cognition of the soul being dragged oscillates between two alternatives and does not remain fixed on one alternative. And what is its nature? He says: What indeed could this be? Either a post or a man.

original: atha kimidamekaṃ jñānam / āhosvidanekamiti / yadyanekaṃ krameṇotpadyate sthāṇurityekaṃ puruṣa iti cānyat / tarhi yat tasmiṃstaditi rūpaṃ tat samyak jñānam / viparītantu mithyājñānamiti saṃśayocchedaḥ / na / anekatvānabhyupagamāt / tathāhi / ekameva kimayaṃ sthāṇuḥ syāt puruṣo veti viruddhollekhijñānam / viruddhaviśeṣānusmaraṇopalakṣitasāmagrījanyatvāt / ekastu saṃskāro viśeṣānubhavāt pūrvapūrvasaṃskārasacivādutpadyata ityekaṃ smaraṇaṃ viruddhaviśeṣaviṣayaṃ janayatyeva /
analyzed: atha kim idam ekam jñānam āhosvit anekam iti  yadi anekam krameṇa utpadyate sthāṇuḥ iti ekam puruṣaḥ iti ca anyat tarhi yat tasmin tat iti rūpam tat samyak jñānam viparītam tu mithyājñānam iti saṃśaya ucchedaḥ na aneka tva anabhyupagamāt tathā hi ekam eva kim ayam sthāṇuḥ syāt puruṣaḥ vā iti viruddha ullekhi jñānam viruddha viśeṣa anusmaraṇa upalakṣita sāmagrī janya tvāt ekaḥ tu saṃskāraḥ viśeṣa anubhavāt pūrva pūrva saṃskāra sacivāt utpad
translated: Now, is this one cognition or many? If many, and they arise in sequence - one is 'a post', another is 'a man' - then what has the form 'that is it' is right knowledge, while the opposite is false knowledge. Thus doubt is removed. No, because multiplicity is not accepted. For thus, the cognition that arises is one, 'Is this a post or a man?' It is contradictory, because it is produced from a collection characterized by the recollection of contradictory particulars. But one impression arises from the experience of particulars and from the preceding impressions, so a single recollection produces an object with contradictory particulars.

original: yadvā pratiniyataviśeṣānubhavajanitāḥ saṃskārāḥ saṃśayopabhogaprāpakādṛṣṭaniyamitāḥ saṃskāramārabhante tasmādanekaviśeṣaviṣayaṃ smaraṇamiti / viṣayaII /saṃśayotpattāvaviśeṣāt / pratyakṣatvañcobhayatrāpi samānamiti / satyam / tathāpi sāmānyaviśeṣitasya liṅgopalambhāt sādhyadharmaviśeṣite dharmiṇi saṃśayābhyupagamo 'nyatra ca aliṅgabhūte sādhyadharmarahite sāmānyavati pratyakṣe dharmiṇīti viśeṣaḥ / kiñcit sādharmyantu na niṣidhyate / sāmānyalakṣaṇākrāntiścānvayavyatirekābhyāmupalabhyate / pratyabhijñānācca / tathā hi / mamātra saṃśayajñānamutpannamiti paścād vijānātīti saviṣayatvamasya /
analyzed: yat vā pratiniyata viśeṣa anubhava janitāḥ saṃskārāḥ saṃśaya upabhoga prāpaka adṛṣṭa niyamitāḥ saṃskāram ārabhante tasmāt aneka viśeṣa viṣayam smaraṇam iti pratyakṣa tvam ca ubhayatra api samānam iti satyam tathā api sāmānya viśeṣitasya liṅga upalambhāt sādhya dharma viśeṣite dharmiṇi saṃśaya abhyupagamaḥ nyatra ca aliṅga bhūte sādhya dharma rahite sāmānyavati pratyakṣe dharmiṇi iti viśeṣaḥ kiñcid sādharmyam tu na niṣidhyate s
translated: Or, the impressions produced by the experience of specific particulars give rise to impressions regulated by unseen forces that lead to doubt and enjoyment. Therefore, recollection has many specific objects. The arising of doubt is due to the non-apprehension of a specific object. And the character of being a means of valid knowledge is the same in both cases. This is true. Nevertheless, there is a difference in that doubt is accepted with regard to the subject qualified by the property to be proved, because of the apprehension of an inferential mark qualified by the general and specific, while in the other case, in perception of a subject that is not an inferential mark and is devoid of the property to be proved but possesses the general, the general characteristic is not denied. And the presence of the general characteristic is perceived through positive and negative concomitance, and also through recognition.
