For thus, one later cognizes that the knowledge of doubt arose in me here. Thus, it has an object.

original: viparyayavaidharmyam
analyzed: viparyaya vaidharmyam
translated: The difference from error

original: viparyayo 'pi pratyakṣānumānaviṣaya eva bhavati /PDhS
analyzed: viparyayaḥ pi pratyakṣa anumāna viṣayaḥ eva bhavati
translated: Error also occurs only with regard to the objects of perception and inference.

original: atha viparyayasya kāraṇasvarūpaviṣayavibhāganirūpaṇārthaṃ na paraṃ saṃśayo viparyayo 'pi pratyakṣānumānaviṣaya eva bhavati ityevamādi prakaraṇam / yadvā / saṃśayasya pratyakṣānumānaviṣayatvābhyupagamād viparyayasya viṣayābhāvādasambhavo mā bhūdityāha viparyayo 'pi pratyakṣānumānaviṣaya eva bhavati iti / na ca viṣayābhedādekatvam / svarūpabhedasya kāraṇabhedasya ca sambhavāt / āgamike 'pi viṣaye visaṃvādopalabdherviparyayadarśanād vyāhatamavadhāraṇaṃ pratyakṣānumānaviṣaya eva viparyaya iti / na / nirviṣayatvapratiṣedhaparatvāt /
analyzed: atha viparyayasya kāraṇa svarūpa viṣaya vibhāga nirūpaṇa artham na param saṃśayaḥ viparyayaḥ u pi pratyakṣa anumāna viṣayaḥ eva bhavati iti evamādi prakaraṇam yat vā saṃśayasya pratyakṣa anumāna viṣaya tva abhyupagamāt viparyayasya viṣaya abhāvāt asambhavaḥ mā bhūt iti āha viparyayaḥ u pi pratyakṣa anumāna viṣayaḥ eva bhavati iti na ca viṣaya abhedāt ekatvam svarūpa bhedasya kāraṇa bhedasya ca sambhavāt āgamike pi viṣaye visaṃvāda upalabd
translated: Now, in order to determine the division of the nature of the cause and the object of error, the topic begins with the statement that error is also only with regard to perception and inference, or else, because doubt is accepted as being with regard to perception and inference, in order to avoid the impossibility of error due to the absence of an object, it is said that error is also only with regard to perception and inference. And it is not the same because of the difference in nature and the difference in cause. And because contradiction is seen even in scriptural objects, the determination that error is only with regard to perception and inference is contradicted. No, because it is intended to negate the absence of an object.

original: yaccedam asatyapi pratyakṣe pratyakṣābhimāna iti vākyaṃ tadanyathā vyākhyeyamiti kecit /
analyzed: yat ca idam asati api pratyakṣe pratyakṣa abhimānaḥ iti vākyam tat anyathā vyākhyeyam iti kecid
translated: And some say that this statement Even in the absence of perception, there is the conceit of perception, should be explained otherwise.

original: anye tu parābhyupagatasya kalpanājñānasya nirāsārthaṃ viparyayo 'pi pratyakṣānumāna viṣaya eva / na tu sarvaḥ saviṣayaḥ kvacidaviṣayasyāpi sambhavāt / yatra hi viṣayo 'nvayavyatirekābhyāmupalabhyate 'sau saviṣayo 'nyastu nirviṣayo na tu sarva iti /
analyzed: anye tu para abhyupagatasya kalpanā jñānasya nirāsa artham viparyayaḥ pratyakṣa anumāna viṣayaḥ eva na tu sarvaḥ sa viṣayaḥ kvacid aviṣayasya api sambhavāt yatra hi viṣayaḥ nvaya vyatirekābhyām upalabhyate sau sa viṣayaḥ nyastu nirviṣayaḥ na tu sarvaḥ iti
translated: Others, however, say that error also has only perception and inference for its object, in order to refute the idea that it is a form of knowledge accepted by others. Not all error has an object, because in some cases it may be without an object. Where the object is perceived through positive and negative concomitance, that error has an object, but another may be without an object, but not all.

original: anye tu pratyakṣānumānaviṣayo bhavatyeva viparyaya ityabhavanapratiṣedho vivakṣito nityaviparyayavyavacchedārthamiti bruvate / tadayuktaṃ vyākhyānam / tasyaivāsiddheḥ / na ca nityasya pratyakṣānumānaviṣayatvaṃ vyāpārādṛte sambhāvyata iti kathamasyātra abhavanapratiṣedha ityalam /
analyzed: anye tu pratyakṣa anumāna viṣayaḥ bhavati eva viparyayaḥ iti abhavana pratiṣedhaḥ vivakṣitaḥ nitya viparyaya vyavaccheda artham iti bruvate tat ayuktam vyākhyānam tasya eva asiddheḥ na ca nityasya pratyakṣa anumāna viṣaya tvam vyāpārāt ṛte sambhāvyate iti katham asya atra abhavana pratiṣedhaḥ iti alam
translated: Others, however, say that error indeed has only perception and inference for its object. The negation of non-existence is intended, not the exclusion of eternal error. This explanation is incorrect, because that itself is unestablished. And the eternality of error cannot be conceived to have perception and inference for its object without some operation. So how can there be a negation of non-existence here? That is enough.

original: pratyakṣaviṣaye tāvat prasiddhānekaviśeṣayoḥ pittakaphānilopahatendriyasyāyathārthālocanād asannihitaviṣayajñānajasaṃskārāpekṣādātmanasoḥ II / saṃyogād adharmāccātasmiṃstaditi pratyayo viparyayaḥ / yathā gavyevāśva iti /PDhS
analyzed: pratyakṣa viṣaye tāvat prasiddha aneka viśeṣayoḥ pitta kapha anila upahata indriyasya ayathārtha ālocanāt asannihita viṣaya jñāna ja saṃskāra apekṣāt ātma nasoḥ saṃyogāt adharmāt ca a tasmin tat iti pratyayaḥ viparyayaḥ yathā gavi eva aśvaḥ iti pdhs
translated: As for the domain of perception, when there are many well-known particulars, due to the unreal perception of one whose senses are affected by bile, phlegm, or wind, from the conjunction of the self and mind that depend on the impressions born from the knowledge of an absent object, and from non-dharma, there is the notion that is in this which is a mistake, like the horse is indeed a cow.

original: asatyapi pratyakṣe pratyakṣābhimāno bhavati / yathā vyapagataghanapaṭalamacalajalanidhisadṛśavapurambaramañjanacūrṇapuñjaśyāmaṃ śārvaraṃ tama iti /PDhS
analyzed: asati api pratyakṣe pratyakṣa abhimānaḥ bhavati yathā vyapagata ghana paṭalam acala jalanidhi sadṛśa vapuḥ ambaram añjana cūrṇa puñja śyāmam śārvaram tamaḥ iti pdhs
translated: Even in the absence of perception, there is the conceit of perception, like the nocturnal darkness is dark like a mass of collyrium, with a body like the sky free from thick clouds and still oceans.

original: pratyakṣaviṣaye tāvad viparyayamāha prasiddhānekaviśeṣayoḥ prasiddhā anekā viśeṣā yayostau tathoktau tayoriti viṣayanirūpaṇam / pittakaphānilopahatendriyasya iti pittañca kaphaścānilaśceti pittakaphānilāstairupahatānīndriyāṇi yasyāsau sa tathoktastasya viparyayo bhavati / kebhya ityāha ayathārthālocanāt ityādi / ayathārthamālocyate 'nenetyayathārthālocanaṃ sādṛśyajñānam /
analyzed: pratyakṣa viṣaye tāvat viparyayam āha prasiddha aneka viśeṣayoḥ prasiddhāḥ anekāḥ viśeṣāḥ yayoḥ tau tathā uktau tayoḥ iti viṣaya nirūpaṇam pitta kapha anila upahata indriyasya iti pittam ca kaphaḥ ca anilaḥ ca iti pitta kapha anilāḥ taiḥ upahatāni indriyāṇi yasya asau sa tathā uktaḥ tasya viparyayaḥ bhavati kebhyaḥ iti āha ayathārtha ālocanāt ityādi ayathārtham ālocyate nena iti ayathārtha ālocanam sādṛśya jñānam
translated: As regards the object of Perception, he states the error that is possible: ‘In regard to things, etc. etc.’; i.e. in regard to things which are well-known and have many details also well-known. ‘Pitta, Kapha and Anīla’ are the three humours of the body; when these affect the sense-organs, the man becomes known as ‘having the sense-organs affected by the humours’; in this man, there is an error; as to what, the text adds ‘due to the wrong apprehension, etc. etc.’; ‘wrong apprehension’ is the cognition of similarity; ‘by that’ i.e. by the wrong apprehension.

original: yadvā ālocitirālocanam / ayathārthañca tadālocanañcetyupacāreṇa sādṛśyajñānamayathārthālocanahetutvād vivakṣitam / tasmāt / asannihitaścāsau viṣayaśceti tathoktastasmin jñānam / tasmājjāto 'sannihitaviṣayajñānajaḥ / sa cāsau saṃskāraśceti / saṃskārakāryatvāt smṛtiḥ saṃskārapadena vivakṣitā / tatsaṃskāramapekṣata ityātmamanaḥsaṃyogastadapekṣaḥ / tasmādasamavāyikāraṇād adharmācca viparyayaḥ / sa ca kiṃ svarūpaḥ / atasmiṃstaditi pratyayaḥ iti / tathāhi / atasmiṃstaditi pratyayaḥ / itarasmād bhidyate / viparyaya iti vā vyavahartavyaḥ / ayathārthālocanādibhya utpadyamānatvāditi / yastvevaṃ na bhavati na cāsāvuktakāraṇebhyo niṣpadyate tasmiṃstaditi pratyayaśca / yathā saṃśayādiriti / tasyodāharaṇaṃ yathā gavyevāśva iti / yathāhi / dūrād viṣāṇādiviśeṣamanupalabhamānasyāśvasādṛśyaviśeṣitapiṇḍopalambhād aśvānusmaraṇācca gavyevāśvo 'yamiti jñānamutpadyate / tathā marīciṣūdakajñānam / śuktikāyāṃ rajatajñānamiti /
analyzed: yat vā ālocitiḥ ālocanam ayathārtham ca tat ālocanam ca iti upacāreṇa sādṛśya jñānam ayathārtha ālocana hetu tvāt vivakṣitam tasmāt asannihitaḥ ca asau viṣayaḥ ca iti tathā uktaḥ tasmin jñānam tasmāt jātaḥ sannihita viṣaya jñāna jaḥ sa ca asau saṃskāraḥ ca iti saṃskāra kārya tvāt smṛtiḥ saṃskāra padena vivakṣitā tad saṃskāram apekṣate iti ātma manaḥ saṃyogaḥ tad apekṣaḥ tasmāt asamavāyi kāraṇāt adharmāt ca viparyayaḥ sa
translated: Or, ālocanam is the act of perceiving. And that which is non-real and is the act of perceiving is figuratively called the knowledge of similarity, because it is the cause of non-real perception. Therefore, that which is not present and is the object is called that. The knowledge of that is born from the knowledge of the object that is not present. And that is the impression. Because it is the effect of the impression, memory is intended by the word impression. That depends on the impression. The contact of the self and mind depends on that. Therefore, error arises from that non-inherent cause and from non-merit. And what is its nature? It is the notion that what is not that is that. It is thus. The notion that what is not that is that is distinguished from the other. It should be designated as error. Because it arises from non-real perception and so on. But that which is not so and does not arise from the stated causes, and the notion that what is that is that, like doubt and so on. An example of that is

original: nanu cāyuktametat / viparyayajñānasampādakasya kārakasyaivāsambhavāt / tathāhi / indriyāṇi samyajjñānasampādanāyotpannāni tasmiṃstaditi rūpatvāt / kathaṃ mithyājñānaṃ kuryuriti / na ca kācakāmalādidoṣavaśād viparītajñānajanakatvam / duṣṭasya kārakasya kāryājanakatvāt / yathā hi / śālibījasya tailādinābhyaktasya II / śālyaṅkurājanakatvam / na punaryavāṅkurasampādakatvam / evamindriyāṇāṃ samyajjñānasampādakatvameva syāt / na viparītajñānotpādakatvamiti / na ca rajatādijñānasya śuktikādyālambanatve pramāṇamasti / tasmāt sādṛśyajñānānantaraṃ svākāraparibhraṣṭaṃ smaraṇamutpadyate idaṃ rajatamiti / tathāhi / idamiti sādṛśyajñānaṃ rajatamiti smaraṇaṃ tadityākāraśūnyam /
analyzed: nanu ca ayuktam etat viparyaya jñāna sampādakasya kārakasya eva asambhavāt tathā hi indriyāṇi samyak jñāna sampādanāya utpannāni tasmin tat iti rūpa tvāt katham mithyājñānam kuryuḥ iti na ca kāca kāmalā ādi doṣa vaśāt viparīta jñāna janaka tvam duṣṭasya kārakasya kārya ajanaka tvāt yathā hi śāli bījasya taila ādinā abhyaktasya śāli aṅkura ajanaka tvam na punar yava aṅkura sampādaka tvam evam indriyāṇām samyak jñāna sampādaka tvam eva syāt na vipar
translated: But this is improper, because there is no cause that produces erroneous knowledge. For, the sense organs arise for the purpose of producing correct knowledge, because they have the form of that. How can they produce false knowledge? And it is not that they produce contradictory knowledge due to defects like a cataract or jaundice, because a defective cause does not produce an effect. Just as a rice seed anointed with oil, etc. does not produce a rice sprout, but does not produce a barley sprout either. In the same way, the sense organs would only produce correct knowledge, not produce contradictory knowledge. And there is no proof that the knowledge of silver, etc. has mother-of-pearl, etc. as its object. Therefore, after the knowledge of similarity, a memory arises that has lost its own form, saying this is silver. For, this is the knowledge of similarity, silver is the memory, and it is devoid of the form that.

original: naitadyuktam / rajatārthinaḥ pravṛttinivṛttyorabhāvaprasaṅgāt / atha jñānayorbhade 'pi idameva rajatamiti sāmānādhikaraṇyaṃ manyamānaḥ pravartate / tarhīdameva vyadhikaraṇayoḥ sāmānādhikaraṇyajñānaṃ mithyājñānamiti / atha idamiti sādṛśyaṃ tatra rajatamiti bhedāpratibhāse sati pravṛttirveṣyate / tanna / pratipattyabhāvasyāpravartakatvāt / tathāhi / rajatārthī idameva / rajatamiti manyamānaḥ pravartate / netarathā / idamiti jñānasyāparokṣatānirdeśo na jñānāntaram / anyathā hi idaṃ rūpam ayaṃ rasa ityādāvapi smṛtipramoṣaḥ syāt /
analyzed: na etat yuktam rajata arthinaḥ pravṛtti nivṛttyoḥ abhāva prasaṅgāt atha jñānayoḥ bhade pi idam eva rajatam iti sāmānādhikaraṇyam manyamānaḥ pravartate tarhi idam eva vyadhikaraṇayoḥ sāmānādhikaraṇya jñānam mithyājñānam iti  atha idam iti sādṛśyam tatra rajatam iti bheda apratibhāse sati pravṛttiḥ vā iṣyate tat na pratipatti abhāvasya apravartaka tvāt tathā hi rajata arthī idam eva rajatam iti manyamānaḥ pravartate na itarathā idam iti jñānasya apa
translated: This is not proper, because then there would be no engagement and disengagement for one who desires silver. If one engages thinking that this very thing is silver, even though there is a difference between the two cognitions, then this very cognition of identity between two distinct things is false knowledge. If it is argued that the cognition of identity is due to similarity, and engagement occurs when there is no clear perception of difference, that is not so. Because the absence of understanding does not cause engagement. Thus, one who desires silver engages thinking this very thing is silver, not otherwise. The term 'this' refers to the non-manifest cognition, not to another cognition. Otherwise, in cases like 'this is form', 'this is taste', etc., there would be loss of memory.

original: yaccedaṃ rajatamiti jñānasya śuktikādyālambanatve pramāṇābhāva ityuktam / tadasat / pratyabhijñānādeḥ sambhavāt / tathāhi / iyaṃ śuktikā mama rajatamiti pratibhātā / tathā nedaṃ rajatamiti jñānasya śuktikāviṣayatvād rajatamiti jñānasya tadviṣayatvam / anyathā hi rajatamiti jñānasya śuktikāviṣayatāmantareṇa nedaṃ rajatamiti pratiṣedho na syāt prasaktyabhāvāt / aprasaktasya ca niṣedhe nāyaṃ ghaṭādirityapi syāt / tathā ca sati sarvatra pratiṣedhaparamparāprasaṅgaḥ / na caitadasti / tasmājjñānadvāreṇa rajataṃ tatra prasaktamiti niṣidhyate /
analyzed: yat ca idam rajatam iti jñānasya śuktikā ādi ālambana tve pramāṇa abhāvaḥ iti uktam tat asat pratyabhijñāna ādeḥ sambhavāt tathā hi iyam śuktikā mama rajatam iti pratibhātā tathā na idam rajatam iti jñānasya śuktikā viṣaya tvāt rajatam iti jñānasya tad viṣaya tvam anyathā hi rajatam iti jñānasya śuktikā viṣaya tām antareṇa na idam rajatam iti pratiṣedhaḥ na syāt prasakti abhāvāt aprasaktasya ca niṣedhe na ayam ghaṭa ādiḥ iti api syāt tathā ca sat
translated: And as for the argument that there is no evidence for the knowledge that this is silver having for its substratum the mother-of-pearl, etc., that is not so, because of the possibility of recognition, etc. For instance, this mother-of-pearl appears to me as silver. And because the knowledge that this is not silver has the mother-of-pearl for its object, therefore the knowledge that this is silver has that for its object. For otherwise, in the absence of the knowledge that this is silver having the mother-of-pearl for its object, the negation that this is not silver would not be possible, because there would be no occasion for it. And if there were a negation of what is not suggested, then it would be possible to say that this is not a jar, etc. And if that were so, then there would be the contingence of a series of negations everywhere. But that is not so. Therefore, by the way of knowledge, silver is suggested there and is negated.

original: yaccedam utpattikāraṇābhāvādityuktam / tadasat / doṣānugṛhītasyendriyāderjñānajanakatvāt / yathāhi / doṣābhāve satīndriyaṃ bhāvavyatirekābhyāṃ samyajjñānasya janakamupalabdhaṃ tathā doṣasadbhāve sati mithyājñānasyāpītyubhayarūpasya kāryasyendriyavyāpāreṇopalabdherubhayārthamindriyāṇāṃ sargo niścīyate / mithyātvañcāsya svaviṣayaparityāgena viṣayāntaropasarpaṇāt /
analyzed: yat ca idam utpatti kāraṇa abhāvāt iti uktam tat asat doṣa anugṛhītasya indriya ādeḥ jñāna janaka tvāt yathā hi doṣa abhāve sati indriyam bhāva vyatirekābhyām samyak jñānasya janakam upalabdham tathā doṣa sadbhāve sati mithyājñānasya api iti ubhaya rūpasya kāryasya indriya vyāpāreṇa upalabdheḥ ubhaya artham indriyāṇām sargaḥ niścīyate mithyātvam ca asya sva viṣaya parityāgena viṣaya antara upasarpaṇāt
translated: And as for what has been said about the absence of a cause for production, that is not so, because the senses etc. which are accompanied by faults are the generators of knowledge. For just as the senses, when the absence of faults is present, are seen to be the generators of correct knowledge by the methods of agreement and difference, so also when the presence of faults is present, they are the generators of false knowledge. Thus, since the activity of the senses is seen to be the cause of both kinds of effects, the creation of the senses is ascertained to be for both purposes. And its falsity is due to its approaching another object by abandoning its own object.

original: athālaukikaṃ rajatamevāsya viṣayamiti viṣayāntaropasarpaṇamasiddham / tanna / alaukikarajatādhyavasāye sati pravṛttinivṛttyorabhāvaprasaṅgāt / athāII /laukikasyāpi laukikatāṃ manyamānaḥ pravartate / kathaṃ tarhi mithyājñānasya sambhava iti / na caitasmin pakṣe mithyedaṃ mamotpannaṃ jñānamiti bādhakaṃ jñānaṃ syāt / pratyabhijñānādyasambhavaśca / asti pratyabhijñānaṃ śuktikādau / mamātra rajatajñānamutpannam / mithyātvapratipattiśceti kathaṃ mithyājñānasyāsambhavaḥ /
analyzed: atha alaukikam rajatam eva asya viṣayam iti viṣaya antara upasarpaṇam asiddham tat na alaukika rajata adhyavasāye sati pravṛtti nivṛttyoḥ abhāva prasaṅgāt   laukika tām manyamānaḥ pravartate katham tarhi mithyājñānasya sambhavaḥ iti  na ca etasmin pakṣe mithyā idam mama utpannam jñānam iti bādhakam jñānam syāt pratyabhijñāna ādi asambhavaḥ ca  asti pratyabhijñānam śuktikā ādau mama atra rajata jñānam utpannam mithyātva pratipattiḥ ca iti katham mithyājñā
translated: If, on the other hand, the object of the cognition is non-empirical silver, then the contact with another object is not established. This is not so. Because if there is the determination of non-empirical silver, then the occurrence of activity and cessation of activity would follow. If, on the other hand, one acts on the supposition that the empirical silver is empirical, then how is the possibility of false knowledge? And in this view, there would be no knowledge of contradiction, that this knowledge has arisen falsely in me. And there would be no recognition, etc. There is recognition in the case of mother-of-pearl, etc. My knowledge of silver has arisen here. And there is the apprehension of falsity. So how is the impossibility of false knowledge?

original: yadi cedaṃ rajatamiti jñānaṃ rajatālambanameva syāt / tasyopalabdhilakṣaṇaprāptatvāt samīpavartinaḥ kathamagrahaṇam / yad vastūpalabdhilakṣaṇaprāptaṃ dūrasthenāpyupalabhyate tadavaśyaṃ samīpavartinā gṛhyata eva / indriyādestādavasthyāt / na caitadasti / tasmād rajatādijñānaṃ śuktikādāvutpannamiti /
analyzed: yadi ca idam rajatam iti jñānam rajata ālambanam eva syāt tasya upalabdhi lakṣaṇa prāpta tvāt samīpa vartinaḥ katham agrahaṇam yat vastu upalabdhi lakṣaṇa prāptam dūra sthena api upalabhyate tat avaśyam samīpa vartinā gṛhyate eva indriya ādeḥ tādavasthyāt na ca etat asti tasmāt rajata ādi jñānam śuktikā ādau utpannam iti
translated: If this cognition this is silver were only about silver, how is it that the silver which is present and perceptible is not apprehended? For, what is present and perceptible is certainly apprehended by one who is near it, because the sense-organs etc. remain the same. But this is not so. Therefore, the cognition of silver etc. arises in regard to mother-of-pearl etc.

original: anye tu yadeva rajatamanyadeśakālaviśeṣitamupalabdhaṃ tadevānyadeśādiviśeṣitamupalabhyata iti mithyātvaṃ bruvate / tadasat / tasyātrāvidyamānatayā viṣayatvāsambhavāt / tasmādindriyavyāpāraviṣayo 'ṅgulyādinā vyapadiśyamānaśca śuktikādireva viṣayaḥ / anyathā viṣayāntarotpannaṃ rajatajñānaṃ kathaṃ śuktikājñānena bādhyeta / vibhinnaviṣayatve bādhyabādhakabhāvasyaivāsambhavāt / ato rajatajñānaṃ śuktikāyāmupajātaṃ śuktikājñānena svaviṣayasahakāriṇā bādhyate mithyātvaviśiṣṭatayā jñāpyate / viṣayāntaropasarpaṇāt / rajatajñānasya tu rajataṃ viṣayaḥ sarvajanapratītastattyāgena śuktikāyāmutpadyamānatvād vyabhicāritvam / etena nirviṣayaṃ kalpanājñānametad ityapāstam / viṣayasya śuktikādeḥ pramāṇato vyavasthāpanāt /
analyzed: anye tu yat eva rajatam anya deśa kāla viśeṣitam upalabdham tat eva anya deśa ādi viśeṣitam upalabhyate iti mithyātvam bruvate tat asat tasya atra avidyamāna tayā viṣaya tva asambhavāt tasmāt indriya vyāpāra viṣayaḥ ṅguli ādinā vyapadiśyamānaḥ ca śuktikā ādiḥ eva viṣayaḥ anyathā viṣaya antara utpannam rajata jñānam katham śuktikā jñānena bādhyeta vibhinna viṣaya tve bādhya bādhaka bhāvasya eva asambhavāt  atas rajata jñānam śuktikāyām upajātam
translated: Others, however, say that the very silver which is perceived as qualified by a particular place and time is perceived as qualified by a different place, etc., and hence it is false. That is not correct, because it cannot be the object here, as it does not exist here. Therefore, the object is only the mother-of-pearl, etc., which is the object of the operation of the sense organ and is indicated by the finger, etc. Otherwise, how could the cognition of silver produced with reference to another object be contradicted by the cognition of mother-of-pearl? Because when the objects are different, there cannot be the relation of the contradictory and the contra-dictory. Therefore, the cognition of silver produced with reference to mother-of-pearl is contradicted by the cognition of mother-of-pearl, which is its auxiliary with reference to its own object, and is made known as qualified by falsity, due to the approach of another object. But the cognition of silver has silver as its object, which is well-known to all people. Due to its being produced with reference to mother-of-pearl by abandoning that, it is fallacious. By this, the view that this is a conceptual cognition without an object is refuted. The object, such as mother-of-pearl, etc., is established by a means of valid knowledge.

original: asatyapi pratyakṣe pratyakṣābhimānaḥ ityādinā nirviṣayaṃ viparyayamāheti kecit /
analyzed: asati api pratyakṣe pratyakṣa abhimānaḥ ityādinā nirviṣayam viparyayam āha iti kecid
translated: Some people have held the following opinion: “Even in the absence of Perception, there may be an illusion of Perception, etc. etc.” (Text 2121).

original: udāharaṇantu yathā vyapagataghanapaṭalam / acalajalanidhisadṛśavapuḥ / ambaram / añjanacūrṇapuñjaśyāmaṃ śārvaraṃ tamaḥ iti / vyapagatāni ghanānāṃ paṭalāni yasmin ambare tat tathoktam / tathā na calo 'calaḥ / sa cāsau jalanidhiśca tena sadṛśaṃ tulyaṃ vapuḥ svarūpamasyeti / tacca jalanidhisadṛśavapurambaramiti jñānam ambarasyātīndriyatvāt uktarūpasyāpi na jalanidhinā sādṛśyagrahaṇaṃ sambhavatīti nirviṣayaḥ pratyakṣābhimānaḥ / tathā śarvaryāṃ bhavaṃ śārvaraṃ tamaḥ / kiṃviśiṣṭam / añjanacūrṇapūñjaśyāmamiti / na cābhāvarūpasya II / tamasaḥ śyāmarūpasambandhitvamastīti nirviṣayatvam / saviṣayatvābhyupagame 'pi deśakālaviśeṣitasya tejaso 'bhāvasyālambanatvādadoṣaḥ /
analyzed: udāharaṇam tu yathā vyapagata ghana paṭalam acala jalanidhi sadṛśa vapuḥ ambaram añjana cūrṇa puñja śyāmam śārvaram tamaḥ iti vyapagatāni ghanānām paṭalāni yasmin ambare tat tathā uktam tathā na calaḥ sa ca asau jalanidhiḥ ca tena sadṛśam tulyam vapuḥ svarūpam asya iti tat ca jalanidhi sadṛśa vapuḥ ambaram iti jñānam ambarasya atīndriya tvāt ukta rūpasya api na jalanidhinā sādṛśya grahaṇam sambhavati iti nirviṣayaḥ pratyakṣa abhimānaḥ tathā
translated: An example is like the sky free from the covering of clouds, having a body similar to the unmoving ocean, the darkness of night dark like a heap of collyrium powder. That sky in which the coverings of clouds have departed is said to be so. Similarly, it is unmoving, immovable, and its form is similar, equal, to that. And that sky having a body similar to the ocean, due to the sky being supersensible, even though it is of the described form, the apprehension of similarity with the ocean is not possible. Thus, the pride of perception is objectless. Similarly, the darkness of night arises in the night. What is it distinguished by? It is dark like a heap of collyrium powder. And since darkness, which is of the nature of absence, does not have the relation of being dark-colored, it is objectless. Even if the acceptance of having an object is admitted, there is no fault because the absence of light qualified by a particular place and time is the object.

original: tathā svāśrayād vinivṛttāścakṣuraśmayaḥ svātmīyaṃ golakarūpaṃ yathoktena jalanidhinā sadṛśavapurambaramityupalambhaṃ janayanti / ādarśāt pratiskhalitānāṃ svamukhagrahaṇavaditi / yathā hi / ādarśāt pratiskhalitāścakṣuraśmayaḥ svamukhe viparyayamutpādayanti ādarśamukhamiti tadvad ihāpi dūrād vinivṛttāḥ svagolakamevāmbaramityupadarśayanti /
analyzed: tathā sva āśrayāt vinivṛttāḥ cakṣu raśmayaḥ svātmīyam golaka rūpam yathā uktena jalanidhinā sadṛśa vapuḥ ambaram iti upalambham janayanti ādarśāt pratiskhalitānām sva mukha grahaṇa vat iti yathā hi ādarśāt pratiskhalitāḥ cakṣu raśmayaḥ sva mukhe viparyayam utpādayanti ādarśa mukham iti tadvat iha api dūrāt vinivṛttāḥ sva golakam eva ambaram iti upadarśayanti
translated: Similarly, the rays of the eye, turning back from their own substratum, produce the perception of the sky as having a body similar to the ocean of water as described, and as having the form of their own globe. Like the apprehension of one's own face from the reflection in a mirror. For just as the rays of the eye, turning back from a mirror, produce an error in one's own face, thinking it is a face in the mirror, in the same way here also, turning back from a distance, they show one's own globe as the sky.

original: anumānaviṣaye 'pi vāṣpādibhirdhūmābhimatairvahnyanumānam / gavayaviṣāṇadarśanācca gauriti /PDhS
analyzed: anumāna viṣaye vāṣpa ādibhiḥ dhūma abhimataiḥ vahni anumānam gavaya viṣāṇa darśanāt ca gauḥ iti
translated: Or, even in the domain of inference, the inference of fire from smoke, which is considered to be like steam, and the inference of a cow from seeing the horn of a gavaya.

original: anumānaviṣaye 'pi viparyayamāha vāṣpādibhiḥ ityādinā / atrādipadena nīhāramaśakāvartādigrahaṇam / taiḥ kimbhūtaiḥ dhūmābhimataiḥ dhūmarūpatayā jñātairagnyanumānamiti / tathā gavayaviṣāṇadarśanācca gauriti jñānaṃ viparyayaḥ / atra tu liṅge viparyayajñānamindriyajam / tadvyāpārajañcānumānikam /
analyzed: anumāna viṣaye viparyayam āha vāṣpa ādibhiḥ ityādinā atra ādi padena nīhāra maśaka āvarta ādi grahaṇam taiḥ kimbhūtaiḥ dhūma abhimataiḥ dhūma rūpa tayā jñātaiḥ agni anumānam iti tathā gavaya viṣāṇa darśanāt ca gauḥ iti jñānam viparyayaḥ atra tu liṅge viparyaya jñānam indriya jam tad vyāpāra jañca ānumānikam
translated: He states the error even in the domain of inference with by mistaking smoke etc. etc. Here, the word etc. includes mist, insects, whirlwinds, etc. What are they like? Those regarded as smoke, known as having the form of smoke, there is inference of fire. Similarly, the knowledge that a cow is so from seeing the horn of a gavaya is error. But here, the knowledge of error regarding the inferential mark is produced by the sense organ, and the inferential knowledge is produced by its operation.

original: trayīdarśanaviparīteṣu śākyādidarśaneṣu idaṃ śreya iti mithyāpratyayo viparyayaḥ / śarīrendriyamanaḥsu ātmābhimānaḥ / kṛtakeṣu nityatvadarśanam / kāraṇavaikalye kāryotpattijñānam / hitamupadiśatsu ahitamiti jñānam / ahitamupadiśatsu hitamiti jñānam /PDhS
analyzed: trayī darśana viparīteṣu śākya ādi darśaneṣu idam śreyaḥ iti mithyā pratyayaḥ viparyayaḥ śarīra indriya manaḥsu ātma abhimānaḥ kṛtakeṣu nitya tva darśanam kāraṇa vaikalye kārya utpatti jñānam hitam upadiśatsu ahitam iti jñānam ahitam upadiśatsu hitam iti jñānam pdhs
translated: In the false doctrines of the Śākyas etc., which are contrary to the three Vedas, the false notion that this is the highest good is error. The notion of self in the body, senses, and mind. The notion of permanence in what is produced. The knowledge that an effect can arise in the absence of a cause. The knowledge that what is beneficial is harmful when taught by those who teach what is beneficial. The knowledge that what is harmful is beneficial when taught by those who teach what is harmful.

original: idānīmasaddarśanābhyāsād viparyayamāha trayīdarśanaviparīteṣu śākyādidarśaneṣu idaṃ śreya iti mithyāpratyayaḥ ityādinā / trayāṇāṃ samāhārastrayī rūḍhivaśād ṛgyajuḥsāmalakṣaṇā gṛhyate / trayyeva darśanam / tadviparītāni śākyādidarśanānītyādi padena naiśanā /jainādidarśanasyāvarodhaḥ / teṣu idaṃ śreyaḥ iti / sarvaṃ kṣaṇikamiti jñānam / śūnyaṃ nirātmakamiti jñānaṃ śreyaḥsādhakatvācchreya iti śākyadarśanābhyāsād viparyayaḥ / kṣaṇikādipakṣe bādhakasyoktatvāt / eṣvartheṣvanekāntajñānena darśane viparyayaḥ / tathetareṣvapyūhyaḥ / na ca śākyādidarśanaviparītatvāt trayyāmapi viparyaya iti II / vācyam / pradhānārtheṣvātmādiṣu artheṣu bādhakānupapatteḥ / śākyādidarśaneṣu kṣaṇikatvādipadārtheṣūktaṃ bādhakamabādhyamānamiti /
analyzed: idānīm asat darśana abhyāsāt viparyayam āha trayī darśana viparīteṣu śākya ādi darśaneṣu idam śreyaḥ iti mithyā pratyayaḥ ityādinā trayāṇām samāhāraḥ trayī rūḍhi vaśāt ṛk yajuḥ sāma lakṣaṇā gṛhyate trayī eva darśanam tad viparītāni śākya ādi darśanāni ityādi padena naiśana ajaina ādi darśanasya avarodhaḥ teṣu idam śreyaḥ iti sarvam kṣaṇikam iti jñānam śūnyam nirātmakam iti jñānam śreyaḥ sādhaka tvāt śreyaḥ iti śākya
translated: Now, due to the practice of seeing what is unreal, he speaks of error in the doctrines of the Śākyas and others, which are contrary to the three-fold vision, saying this is the highest good and so on. The combination of three is three-fold, which is accepted by the power of convention as referring to the Ṛg, Yajur, and Sāman Vedas. The three-fold itself is the vision. The doctrines of the Śākyas and others are contrary to that. By the word and so on, the doctrines of the Nāsatyas and Jains are included. In those, this is the highest good - the knowledge that everything is momentary, the knowledge that it is empty and without self, is the highest good because it leads to liberation. The error is due to the practice of the Śākya doctrine, because the refutation has been stated in the case of the momentary and other positions. The error in the doctrine is due to the knowledge of the non-one-sidedness in these objects. The same should be inferred in the case of others. And it should not be said that there is error even in the three-fold [Vedas] because it is contrary to the doctrines of the Śākyas and others, because there is no refutation in the case of the principal objects such as the self. In the doctrines of the Śākyas and others, the refutation has been stated in the case of the objects such as momentariness.

original: anye tu trayāṇāṃ pratyakṣānumānāgamānāṃ samāhārastrayī / tadeva dṛśyate 'neneti darśanam / tadviparītāni śākyādidarśanāni / tairbādhopapatteḥ / tadupalakṣitaṃ vā vaiśeṣikadarśanam / tadviparītāni śākyādidarśanāni / bādhyamānatvādityuktam /
analyzed: anye tu trayāṇām pratyakṣa anumāna āgamānām samāhāraḥ trayī tat eva dṛśyate nena iti darśanam tad viparītāni śākya ādi darśanāni taiḥ bādhā upapatteḥ tad upalakṣitam vā vaiśeṣika darśanam tad viparītāni śākya ādi darśanāni bādhyamāna tvāt iti uktam
translated: Others say that the three-fold is the combination of the three, perception, inference, and verbal testimony. That is seen by this, therefore it is the seeing. The opposite of that are the doctrines of the Śākyas and others. Because it is possible to be contradicted by them. Or it is characterized by that, the Vaiśeṣika doctrine. The opposite of that are the doctrines of the Śākyas and others. It is said that it is contradicted.

original: tathā śarīrendriyamanaḥsu ātmābhimānaḥ viparyayaḥ / śarīramevātmeti viparyayo laukāyatikānām / indriyāṇyevātmeti indriyacaitanyavādinām / manaścaitanyavādināṃ mana eveti /
analyzed: tathā śarīra indriya manaḥsu ātma abhimānaḥ viparyayaḥ śarīram eva ātmā iti viparyayaḥ laukāyatikānām indriyāṇi eva ātmā iti indriya caitanya vādinām manaḥ caitanya vādinām manaḥ eva iti
translated: Similarly, the superimposition of the self onto the body, senses, and mind is a mistake. The Lokāyatas have the mistake that the body itself is the self. Those who say the senses are conscious have the mistake that the senses themselves are the self. Those who say the mind is conscious have the mistake that the mind itself is the self.

original: kṛtakeṣu nityatvadarśanam viparyayo mīmāṃsakānām / tathāhi / kṣityādeḥ kṛtakatvaṃ pūrvameva vyavasthāpitam / tatra ca nityatvadarśanaṃ teṣāmiti / yadvā sāṃkhyānāmayaṃ viparyayaḥ / kṛtakeṣu ghaṭādiṣu nityatvadarśanamiti / na samutpadyate bhāvo na svātmānaṃ jahātīti /
analyzed: kṛtakeṣu nitya tva darśanam viparyayaḥ mīmāṃsakānām tathā hi kṣiti ādeḥ kṛtaka tvam pūrvam eva vyavasthāpitam tatra ca nitya tva darśanam teṣām iti yat vā sāṃkhyānām ayam viparyayaḥ kṛtakeṣu ghaṭa ādiṣu nitya tva darśanam iti na samutpadyate bhāvaḥ na sva ātmānam jahāti iti
translated: The view of permanence in created things is a mistake for the Mīmāṃsakas. For example, the artificiality of earth and so on has been established before. And there, the view of permanence is theirs. Or this is a mistake for the Sāṃkhyas. The view of permanence in created things like pots, that it does not arise and does not abandon its own nature.

original: ukta kāraṇavaikalye kāryotpattijñānam viparyayaḥ svabhāvavādinām / tathā ca / niruktaṃ kṣityādivaicitryaṃ kartāramantareṇa svabhāvata eva bhavatīti / etaccāsat / kāryatvasya svakartṛpūrvakatvena vyāptasyopalambhāt / kṣityādāvapi kartṛpūrvakatvasya vyavasthāpitatvāt svabhāvavādināṃ viparyayajñānametat / tathā cetanamadhiṣṭhātāraṃ vinā kāryasyānupalabdheḥ / jaiminīyānāṃ śauddhodaneḥ śiṣyāṇāñca kartāraṃ vinā kṣityādikāryavijñānaṃ viparyayaḥ /
analyzed: kāraṇa vaikalye kārya utpatti jñānam viparyayaḥ svabhāva vādinām tathā ca niruktam kṣiti ādi vaicitryam kartāram antareṇa svabhāvataḥ eva bhavati iti etat ca asat kāryatvasya sva kartṛ pūrvaka tvena vyāptasya upalambhāt kṣiti ādau api kartṛ pūrvaka tvasya vyavasthāpita tvāt svabhāva vādinām viparyaya jñānam etat tathā cetanam adhiṣṭhātāram vinā kāryasya anupalabdheḥ jaiminīyānām śauddhodaneḥ śiṣyāṇām ca kartāram vinā kṣiti ādi kārya vij
translated: The knowledge of the production of an effect in the absence of the deficiency of its cause is contrary for those who maintain that things arise from themselves. And thus, the diversity of earth etc. as defined arises from itself alone without a maker. This is not correct. Because the invariable concomitance of being an effect with having its own maker is perceived. And because the priority of a maker is established even in the case of earth etc., this knowledge of the contrary is for those who maintain that things arise from themselves. And thus, because an effect is not perceived without an intelligent supervisor, the knowledge of the effect of earth etc. without a maker is contrary for the followers of Jaimini and the disciples of Shuddhodana.

original: pradhāne pralīnayośca dharmādharmayorabhivyaktatvānna kāryotpattau vyāpāraḥ sambhavatīti tadvaikalye kāryotpattijñānaṃ viparyayaḥ sāṃkhyānām /
analyzed: pradhāne pralīnayoḥ ca dharma adharmayoḥ abhivyakta tvāt na kārya utpattau vyāpāraḥ sambhavati iti tad vaikalye kārya utpatti jñānam viparyayaḥ sāṃkhyānām
translated: And because Dharma and Adharma, which are merged in Prakriti, are manifest, there can be no operation in the production of an effect. Therefore, the knowledge of the production of an effect in the absence of that is contrary for the Samkhyas.

original: saugātānāñca kāraṇavaikalye kāryotpattijñānaṃ viparyayaḥ / katham / utpattivināśayostādātmyāt / kṣaṇikatve sati yadaiva kāryotpādastadaiva kāraṇasya vināśaḥ / sa cotpatternārthāntaramiti / sahotpannayorna kāryakāraṇabhāva iti kāraṇavaikalye kāryotpattijñānaṃ viparyayaḥ /
analyzed: saugātānām ca kāraṇa vaikalye kārya utpatti jñānam viparyayaḥ katham utpatti vināśayoḥ tādātmyāt kṣaṇika tve sati yadā eva kārya utpādaḥ tadā eva kāraṇasya vināśaḥ sa ca utpatteḥ na artha antaram iti saha utpannayoḥ na kārya kāraṇa bhāvaḥ iti kāraṇa vaikalye kārya utpatti jñānam viparyayaḥ
translated: And for the Saugatas, the knowledge of the production of an effect in the absence of a cause is an error. How? Because production and destruction are identical. When there is momentariness, the production of the effect is itself the destruction of the cause. And that is not different from production. Therefore, for what is produced together, there is no relation of cause and effect. So the knowledge of the production of an effect in the absence of a cause is an error.

original: tathā sarvamidaṃ kāryaṃ parameśapūrvakaṃ / tadārādhanañca paramasya śreyasaḥ II / sādhanam / vedānāñca svarūpe 'pyarthe prāmāṇyamityevaṃ hitamupadiśatsu vaiśeṣikeṣu naivaṃ bhavatīti jñānaṃ viparyayo mīmāṃsakasaugatajainānām /
analyzed: tathā sarvam idam kāryam parameśa pūrvakam tad ārādhanam ca paramasya śreyasaḥ sādhanam vedānām ca svarūpe pi arthe prāmāṇyam iti evam hitam upadiśatsu vaiśeṣikeṣu na evam bhavati iti jñānam viparyayaḥ mīmāṃsaka saugata jainānām
translated: Similarly, for the Mimamsakas, Saugatas and Jains, the knowledge that this is not so when the Vaisheshikas teach that all this effect is preceded by the Supreme Lord, and the worship of Him is the means of attaining the highest good, and the Vedas are authoritative even in their form and meaning, is an error.

original: yadā tu na paramaśivādeḥ sadbhāva iti vaiyātyād vadanti vaiśeṣikāstadā nedaṃ paramārthato hitamiti hitamupadiśatsu vaiśeṣikeṣu ahitamevedamiti jñānaṃ viparyayasteṣām /
analyzed: yadā tu na paramaśiva ādeḥ sadbhāvaḥ iti vaiyātyāt vadanti vaiśeṣikāḥ tadā na idam paramārthataḥ hitam iti hitam upadiśatsu vaiśeṣikeṣu ahitam eva idam iti jñānam viparyayaḥ teṣām
translated: But when the Vaisheshikas, out of arrogance, say that there is no existence of the Supreme Shiva and so on, then the knowledge that this is not really beneficial when the Vaisheshikas teach what is beneficial, that this is harmful, is an error for them.

original: yadvā saṃsāryātmanāṃ nānātvam / paramaśivaścaitebhyo bhinnaḥ / tadārādhanāccāsmadādeḥ śreyo bhavatītyevaṃ hitamupadiśatsu vaiśeṣikeṣu ahitamiti jñānaṃ viparyayaḥ /
analyzed: yat vā saṃsāri ātmanām nānātvam paramaśivaḥ ca etebhyaḥ bhinnaḥ tad ārādhanāt ca asmad ādeḥ śreyaḥ bhavati iti evam hitam upadiśatsu vaiśeṣikeṣu ahitam iti jñānam viparyayaḥ
translated: Or, the plurality of individual souls, and the Supreme Śiva is different from them, and by worshipping Him, one like us attains the highest good. When the Vaiśeṣikas teach this beneficial doctrine, the knowledge that it is harmful is a misconception.

original: dvaitavādināṃ tadarthānabhyupagamena ca vacanena hitamiti jñānaṃ viparyayaḥ / teṣāṃ kṣityādikāryaṃ paramāṇubhirdvyaṇukādiprakrameṇārabdhamīśvarakartṛkañceti / evaṃ hitamupadiśatsu / vaiśeṣikeṣu naivametat pradhānapūrvakatvājjagata iti jñānaṃ viparyayaḥ sāṃkhyānām / pradhānāstitve pramāṇābhāvāt /
analyzed: dvaita vādinām tad artha anabhyupagamena ca vacanena hitam iti jñānam viparyayaḥ teṣām kṣiti ādi kāryam paramāṇubhiḥ dvyaṇuka ādi prakrameṇa ārabdham īśvara kartṛkam ca iti evam hitam upadiśatsu vaiśeṣikeṣu na evam etat pradhāna pūrvaka tvāt jagataḥ iti jñānam viparyayaḥ sāṃkhyānām pradhāna astitve pramāṇa abhāvāt
translated: And when the dualists do not accept that meaning, the knowledge that the statement is beneficial is a misconception. For them, the effect like earth is produced by atoms in the process beginning with dyads, and is created by God. When the Vaiśeṣikas teach this beneficial doctrine, the knowledge that it is not so, because the world is preceded by primordial matter, is a misconception for the Sāṃkhyas, because there is no evidence for the existence of primordial matter.

original: athāsti anvayaparimāṇaśaktipravṛttyupakāryopakārakabhāvavaiśvarūpyebhyaḥ pradhānam / tathāhi / sarvamidaṃ śarīrādikāryaṃ sukhaduḥkhamohānvitamupalabhyate / yaccānvitaṃ tadekasmāt kāraṇādutpadyamānaṃ dṛṣṭam / yathaikasmāt mṛtpiṇḍāt mṛdanvitamanekaghaṭādi / tathācānumānam / bhuvanādikāryam ekasmāt kāraṇādutpadyate anvitatvāt ghaṭādivat / tathā cāsya pakṣadharmatvaṃ sukhaduḥkhādisamanvayasya sarveṣu śarīrādiṣu bhāvāt / na ca atatsvabhāvāt kāraṇāt sukhāderutpattiriti śarīrādeḥ sukhaduḥkhamohātmakatvam / tajjanakatvāt / tathā prasādādijanakatvopalabdheśca tatsvabhāvatvam / sukhādayastu sattvarajastamasāṃ pariṇāmaviśeṣāstato 'rthāntaraṃ na bhavanti / kāryasya kāraṇād bhedānupapatteḥ / ataḥ sattvarajastamāṃsyeva śabdādyātmanā vyavatiṣṭhamānāni sukhaduḥkhamohātmakaṃ kāryamupajanayantīti śabdādayo 'pi na sattvādibhyo vyatiricyante / sattvarajastamasāñca sāmyāvasthā pradhānam /
analyzed: atha asti anvaya parimāṇa śakti pravṛtti upakārya upakāraka bhāva vaiśvarūpyebhyaḥ pradhānam tathā hi sarvam idam śarīra ādi kāryam sukha duḥkha moha anvitam upalabhyate yat ca anvitam tat ekasmāt kāraṇāt utpadyamānam dṛṣṭam yathā ekasmāt mṛd piṇḍāt mṛd anvitam aneka ghaṭa ādi tathā ca anumānam bhuvana ādi kāryam ekasmāt kāraṇāt utpadyate anvita tvāt ghaṭa ādi vat  / tathā ca asya pakṣa dharma tvam sukha duḥkha ādi samanvayasya sarveṣu śa
translated: Now, if there is a primordial matter that is the cause of the various forms of mutual help based on the operation of the power of inherence, then it is as follows. This entire effect like the body etc. is seen to be endowed with pleasure, pain and delusion. And that which is endowed is seen to arise from a single cause, like a pot etc. endowed with clay arising from a single lump of clay. And there is inference: The effect like the world arises from a single cause because it is endowed, like a pot etc. And thus it has the property of the subject, because the conjunction with pleasure, pain etc. exists in all bodies etc. And the effect like the body etc. has the nature of pleasure, pain and delusion because pleasure etc. does not arise from a cause that is not of that nature. Because it produces that. And because the production of serenity etc. is observed, it has that nature. But pleasure etc. are particular modifications of sattva, rajas and tamas, and are not different from that, because the effect cannot be different from the cause. Therefore, sattva etc.

original: tathā parimitatvācca / yat parimitaṃ tat ekasmāt kāraṇādutpadyate / yathāṅkurādi bījāt / parimitatvañca iyattāvadhāraṇaviṣayatvam / tathā śarīrādi kāryam ekasmādutpadyate parimitatvāt aṅkurādivat /
analyzed: tathā parimita tvāt ca  yat parimitam tat ekasmāt kāraṇāt utpadyate yathā aṅkura ādi bījāt parimita tvam ca iyattā avadhāraṇa viṣaya tvam tathā śarīra ādi kāryam ekasmāt utpadyate parimita tvāt aṅkura ādi vat
translated: And because it is limited. What is limited arises from one cause, like a sprout from a seed. And being limited is being the object of the determination of extent. Similarly, the effect such as the body arises from one [cause], because it is limited, like a sprout etc.

original: śaktipravṛtteśca / śaktyā hi kāraṇaṃ kāryārthinopādīyata iti sarvaṃ kāryaṃ svakāraṇe śaktirūpatayā vyavasthitaṃ tāvad yāvat pradhānamiti / nanvevaṃ sarvasyāpi kāryasya pradhānādabhede vidyamānatvāt kathamutpattivināśāviti / asataḥ kharaviṣāṇāderiva kāryatvānupapatteḥ sata evāvirbhāvatirobhāvāviti brūmaḥ / śaktirūpatayā hi vyavasthitaṃ kāryaṃ paraṃ vyaktirūpatāmāpadyate / punastu tirobhāve śaktirūpatayā vyavatiṣṭhate / na sannirudhyata iti /
analyzed: śakti pravṛtteḥ ca śaktyā hi kāraṇam kārya arthinā upādīyate iti sarvam kāryam sva kāraṇe śakti rūpatayā vyavasthitam tāvat yāvat pradhānam iti nanu evam sarvasya api kāryasya pradhānāt abhede vidyamāna tvāt katham utpatti vināśau iti asataḥ khara viṣāṇa ādeḥ iva kārya tva anupapatteḥ sataḥ eva āvirbhāva tirobhāvau iti brūmaḥ śakti rūpatayā hi vyavasthitam kāryam param vyakti rūpatām āpadyate punar tu tirobhāve śakti rūpatayā vyavatiṣṭhate
translated: And because of the operation of potency. For a cause is accepted by one who desires an effect because of its potency. Therefore, all effects are established in their causes in the form of potency as long as [the cause] is primordial matter. But if everything is non-different from primordial matter in this way, how can there be origination and destruction? We say that the manifestation and disappearance of what exists is [of] what is existent, because what is non-existent, like the horn of a donkey, cannot be an effect. For an effect, which is established in the form of potency, attains the form of manifestation, but again, in disappearance, it is established in the form of potency. It is not destroyed.

original: tathā parasparamupakāryopakārakabhāvenāvasthitānām āsandikāṅgānāmekasmāt kārakād utpatterupalambhāccharīrāderapi tathābhāvopalabdherekakāraṇapūrvakatvaṃ sādhyate /
analyzed: tathā parasparam upakārya upakāraka bhāvena avasthitānām āsandika aṅgānām ekasmāt kārakāt utpatteḥ upalambhāt śarīra ādeḥ api tathā bhāva upalabdheḥ eka kāraṇa pūrvaka tvam sādhyate
translated: Similarly, it is proved that the body, etc. also have a single cause, because they are perceived to arise from a single cause, like the parts of a chair, which are seen to exist in a relationship of mutual support.

original: tathā dadhyādivaiśvarūpyasyaikasmāt kṣīrādutpatterupalambhāccharīrādivaicitryasyāpyekakāraṇapūrvakatvaṃ sādhyate / yaccaikaṃ kāraṇaṃ tat pradhānamiti / tasmācca mahān / mahato 'haṅkāraḥ / tasmāt pañcatanmātrāṇi ekādaśendriyāṇi / tebhyo bhūtānīti /
analyzed: tathā dadhi ādi vaiśvarūpyasya ekasmāt kṣīrāt utpatteḥ upalambhāt śarīra ādi vaicitryasya api eka kāraṇa pūrvakatvam sādhyate yat ca ekam kāraṇam tat pradhānam iti tasmāt ca mahān mahataḥ haṅkāraḥ tasmāt pañca tanmātrāṇi ekādaśa indriyāṇi tebhyaḥ bhūtāni iti
translated: Similarly, the diversity of curd, etc. is proved to have a single cause, because it is perceived to arise from a single thing like milk. And that which is the single cause is the primordial nature. From that, Mahat. From Mahat, Ahamkara. From that, the five subtle elements and the eleven sense organs. From them, the gross elements.

original: sarvametadasat / anvayādergamakatvānupapatteḥ / tathāhi / śarīrāderekakāraṇapūrvakatve sādhye 'nvitatvamahetuḥ sandigdhatvāt / atha sukhaduḥkhādisamanvitatvaṃ hetuḥ / tanna / svarūpāsiddhatvāt / tathāhi / sukhaduḥkhādīnāṃ pūrvamevātmaguṇatvena pratipāditatvāt śarīrādiguṇatvamasiddham / ghaṭādidṛṣṭānto 'pi sādhanavikalaḥ / tatrānvitasyaikakāraṇapūrvakatvena vyāptasyānupalambhāt / atha mṛdanvitatvaṃ ghaṭādāvasti / taccāsiddham / pakṣe pratyakṣeṇa ca śarīrāderupādānaṃ pratiniyatajātīyamanekamupalabhyata iti / kālātyayāpadiṣṭañca sādhanam /
analyzed: sarvam etat asat anvaya ādeḥ gamaka tva anupapatteḥ tathā hi śarīra ādeḥ eka kāraṇa pūrvakatve sādhye nvitatvam ahetuḥ sandigdha tvāt  atha sukha duḥkha ādi samanvitatvam hetuḥ tat na svarūpa asiddha tvāt tathā hi sukha duḥkha ādīnām pūrvam eva ātma guṇa tvena pratipādita tvāt śarīra ādi guṇa tvam asiddham ghaṭa ādi dṛṣṭāntaḥ api sādhana vikalaḥ tatra anvitasya eka kāraṇa pūrvakatvena vyāptasya anupalambhāt  atha mṛd anvitatvam ghaṭa ādau
translated: All this is false, because the invariable concomitance of the reason is not established. Thus, if the body etc. having one cause as their antecedent is to be proved, being endowed is not a reason, because it is doubtful. If being endowed with pleasure, pain etc. is the reason, that is not so, because of the non-establishment of its own nature. Thus, because pleasure, pain etc. have already been established as the qualities of the self, their being the qualities of the body etc. is not established. The example of the pot etc. is also defective in the proof. Because there is no perception of the pervasion of the endowed by having one cause as its antecedent there. If being endowed with clay exists in the pot etc., and that is not established, because the material cause of the body etc. is perceived to be restricted to a particular class by perception in the case of the subject, the proof is also contradicted by the passage of time.

original: evaṃ parimitatvamiyattāvadhāraṇaviṣayatvamasiddham / avāntarabhedena śarīrāderānantyāt / atha vargāpekṣayā parimitatvam / tathāpyanaikāntikatvam / paradṛṣṭyā nityeṣvapi bhāvāt / sattvarajastamāṃsi ca parimitāni na caikakāraṇapūrvakānīti / pradhānasyaiva tadrūpatvāt / tathā ekakāraṇapūrvakatvābhāve 'pi paramāṇvādīni vargāpekṣayā parimitānīti / aṅkurāderapi bhaumānalasambandhād bījāvayavakriyākrameṇa pūrvadravyavināśe sati dvyaṇukādiprakrameṇotpādād ekakāraṇapūrvakatvamasiddham /
analyzed: evam parimita tvam iyattā avadhāraṇa viṣayatvam asiddham avāntarabhedena śarīra ādeḥ ānantyāt  / atha varga apekṣayā parimita tvam tathā api anaikāntika tvam para dṛṣṭyā nityeṣu api bhāvāt sattva rajaḥ tamāṃsi ca parimitāni na ca eka kāraṇa pūrvakāni iti pradhānasya eva tad rūpa tvāt tathā eka kāraṇa pūrvaka tva abhāve pi paramāṇu ādīni varga apekṣayā parimitāni iti aṅkura ādeḥ api bhauma anala sambandhāt bīja avayava kriyā krameṇa pūrva
translated: Thus, finiteness, which is the subject of the determination of extent, is not established, because the body and so on are infinite due to their internal divisions. If finiteness is in relation to a class, then even in eternal things, it is not contradictory, because they exist from the perspective of others. Sattva, rajas, and tamas are finite, but not preceded by a single cause, because they are of the nature of prakriti itself. Similarly, even in the absence of being preceded by a single cause, atoms and so on are finite in relation to classes. Even in the case of a sprout and so on, the non-establishment of being preceded by a single cause is due to the destruction of the previous substance through the action of the parts of the seed in relation to the earth and fire, and the production through the sequence of dyads and so on.

original: yaccedaṃ śaktānāṃ kāraṇānāṃ kāryotpattau vyāpārācchaktirūpatayā kāryasyāvasthānamityuktam / tadasat / śakteścaramasahakārirūpatayā kāryādarthāntaratvāt / na ca kāryakāraṇayorekatvam / vibhinnapratibhāsaviṣayatvāt / pratibhāsabhedaśca padārthānāṃ bhedavyavahāre hetuḥ / tatsadbhāve 'pyekatvābhyupagame sarveṣāmekatāprasaṅgānna caturviṃśatitattvānīti syāt / tathā svarūpabhedo 'rthakriyābhedaśca kāryakāraṇayoḥ / sūkṣmamanekañca samavāyikāraṇam / adhikamekañca kāryamiti / tasya pūrvaṃ kāraṇeṣvasattvam / anupalambhāt / athānabhivyakteranupalambhaḥ / sadbhāve kiṃ pramāṇam / utpatteriti cet / na / vidyamānasyotpatterayogāt / atha avidyamānasyotpattau kharaviṣāṇādīnāmutpattiḥ syāt / na / kāraṇābhāvāt / yeṣāṃ hi kāraṇamasti janakaṃ teṣāmevotpattirna kharaviṣāṇādiṣvetadasti / kāryābhāvenaiva kāraṇābhāvapratīteḥ / evaṃ tantuṣu ghaṭādermṛtpiṇḍe ca paṭāderanutpattirvācyā / pratiniyatasāmagryāḥ pratiniyatakāryajanakatvāt / tantūpalakṣitā hi sāmagrī paṭasyaiva janikopalabdhā / anyā tu anyasyetyupādāneṣu kāryaniyamo / na sattvāditi / yaccotpadyate tadutpatteḥ pūrvamasat / na punaryad yadasat tadutpadyata iti vyāptiḥ /
analyzed: yat ca idam śaktānām kāraṇānām kārya utpattau vyāpārāt śakti rūpatayā kāryasya avasthānam iti uktam tat asat śakteḥ carama sahakāri rūpatayā kāryāt artha antara tvāt na ca kārya kāraṇayoḥ ekatvam vibhinna pratibhāsa viṣaya tvāt pratibhāsa bhedaḥ ca padārthānām bheda vyavahāre hetuḥ tad sadbhāve pi ekatva abhyupagame sarveṣām ekatā prasaṅgāt na caturviṃśati tattvāni iti syāt tathā svarūpa bhedaḥ rthakriyā bhedaḥ ca kārya kāraṇayoḥ sūk
translated: And what has been said that the effect remains in the form of potency due to the operation of the capable causes in the production of the effect, that is not correct. Because potency is different from the effect in the form of the final cooperating factor. And the cause and effect are not one, because they are the objects of different appearances. And the difference in appearance is the reason for the usage of difference among things. Even in the existence of that, if oneness is accepted, there would be the consequence of all being one, and it would not be the twenty-four principles. Similarly, there is difference in nature and difference in function between cause and effect. The inherent cause is subtle and many, and the effect is more and one. Its non-existence in the causes before is due to non-apprehension. If it is non-apprehension due to non-manifestation, what is the evidence for its existence? If it is said to be due to production, no, because the production of what exists is not possible. If the production of what does not exist is accepted, the production of the horn of a donkey and so on would occur. No, due to the absence of a cause.

original: yaccotpadyamānatvena hetunā sattvam / tadasat / tasyāsādhāraṇatvenāgamakatvāt / tathāhi / sati ākāśādau / asati ca kharaviṣāṇādau / utpadyamānatvaṃ nāstīti /
analyzed: yat ca utpadyamāna tvena hetunā sattvam tat asat tasya asādhāraṇa tvena āgamaka tvāt tathā hi sati ākāśa ādau asati ca khara viṣāṇa ādau utpadyamāna tvam na asti iti
translated: And the existence that is inferred by the reason of being in the process of arising is not correct, because that is not a valid reason due to being unestablished. Thus, in the case of space and so on, which exist, and in the case of a barren woman's son and so on, which do not exist, there is no being in the process of arising.

original: yaccāyaṃ vyapadeśo 'ṅkuro jāyate / ghaṭaṃ kurviti ayamapi mukhya bādhakapramāṇasadbhāvād bhākto draṣṭavyaḥ / tathāhi / yadi vidyamānasyaiva ghaṭasya karmatvamaṅkurasya ca kartṛtvamiṣyetotpattirvyāhatā syāt / vidyamānatvādeva kārakavyāpāravaiyarthyañca / athābhivyaktyarthaṃ vyāpāraḥ / tadasat / abhivyakterapi vidyamānatvāt / athābhivyaktiravidyamānaiva kriyate / tarhi sadutpadyata iti vyāhatam / abhivyaktestu svarūpopalambhasya avidyamānasyaivotpatteḥ / na cāvaraṇavyapagamo 'bhivyaktiḥ / āvaraṇasyaivānupalabdheḥ / tasmād vidyamānasya utpattyarthāsambhavād upacaritamaṅkurādeḥ svajanikartṛtvaṃ karmatvañceti vyapadeśasyānyathāsiddhatvam /
analyzed: yat ca ayam vyapadeśaḥ ṅkuraḥ jāyate ghaṭam kuru iti ayam api mukhya bādhaka pramāṇa sadbhāvāt bhāktaḥ draṣṭavyaḥ tathā hi yadi vidyamānasya eva ghaṭasya karma tvam aṅkurasya ca kartṛ tvam iṣyeta utpattiḥ vyāhatā syāt vidyamāna tvāt eva kāraka vyāpāra vaiyarthyam ca  / atha abhivyakti artham vyāpāraḥ tat asat abhivyakteḥ api vidyamāna tvāt atha abhivyaktiḥ avidyamānā eva kriyate tarhi sat utpadyate iti vyāhatam abhivyakteḥ tu svarūpa upalambhasya
translated: And this designation, the sprout is born, one makes a pot, this also should be seen as figurative due to the existence of a primary invalidating means of knowledge. It is like this. If the pot's existence as an object and the sprout's existence as an agent are accepted, then origination would be contradicted, and due to its very existence, the operation of the instrumental cause would be pointless. If the operation is for the sake of manifestation, that is wrong, because manifestation also exists. If manifestation is produced as non-existent, then it is contradicted to say the existent is produced. But because the manifestation, which is the perception of the nature, is produced as non-existent, and because the removal of obstruction is not manifestation, due to the non-apprehension of obstruction itself, therefore, because the origination of the existent is impossible, the figurative agency of the sprout etc. and the instrumental nature are established. Thus the designation is otherwise established.

original: yaccedam upakāryopakārakabhāvāpannatvādekakāraṇapūrvakatvamityuktaṃ tadapyasat / yadi parasparāpekṣāṇāmekakāryajanakatvamupakāryopakārakabhāvo vivakṣitaḥ / sa ca nityeṣvastīti vyabhicārī / sādhyavikalaśca dṛṣṭāntaḥ / vibhinnakārakajanyatvādāsandikāṅgānām /
analyzed: yat ca idam upakārya upakāraka bhāva āpanna tvāt eka kāraṇa pūrvakatvam iti uktam tat api asat yadi paraspara apekṣāṇām eka kārya janaka tvam upakārya upakāraka bhāvaḥ vivakṣitaḥ sa ca nityeṣu asti iti vyabhicārī sādhya vikalaḥ ca dṛṣṭāntaḥ vibhinna kāraka janya tvāt āsandika aṅgānām
translated: And what has been said, that they have a common cause because they are related as that which is benefited and that which benefits, that also is wrong. If the relation of that which is benefited and that which benefits is intended to be the production of a common effect by those which are mutually dependent, and that exists in the eternal things, then it is inconclusive. And the example is devoid of the probandum, because the parts of the couch are produced by different causes.

original: tathā dadhyādivaiśvarūpyamapyuktakāraṇapūrvakaṃ na bhavati / svāvayavakāryatvāt / tathāhi / svāvayavebhyo dadhyutpadyate / na kṣīrāt / bhaumānalasambandhādavayavakriyānyāyena vinaṣṭe hi kṣīre punaḥ utpannapākajairdvyaṇukādikrameṇa dadhyāderutpattirityato vaiśvarūpyasyaikakāraṇapūrvakatvābhāvaḥ / pratyakṣeṇa ca pakṣe pratiniyatajātīyamanekaṃ kāraṇamupalabdhamiti kālātyayāpadiṣṭañca vaiśvarūpyamiti /
analyzed: tathā dadhi ādi vaiśvarūpyam api ukta kāraṇa pūrvakam na bhavati sva avayava kāryatvāt tathā hi sva avayavebhyaḥ dadhi utpadyate na kṣīrāt bhauma anala sambandhāt avayava kriyā nyāyena vinaṣṭe hi kṣīre punar utpanna pāka jaiḥ dvyaṇuka ādi krameṇa dadhi ādeḥ utpattiḥ iti atas vaiśvarūpyasya eka kāraṇa pūrvaka tva abhāvaḥ pratyakṣeṇa ca pakṣe pratiniyata jātīyam anekam kāraṇam upalabdham iti kāla atyaya apadiṣṭam ca vaiśvarūpyam iti
translated: Similarly, the diversity of curd and so on is not preceded by a single cause, because it is the effect of its own parts. Thus, curd is produced from its own parts, not from milk. For when milk is destroyed by the connection with the earth-fire, curd and so on are produced again in the order of dyads etc. produced by the post-cooking effects. Therefore, there is no single cause for the diversity. And by perception, a plurality of causes of a particular kind is observed in the case, so the diversity is also contradicted by the passage of time.

original: na ca kiñcitkāryamekasmādeva kāraṇādutpadyamānamupalabdhamiti avidyamānasapakṣasya anvayādervipakṣe sadbhāvaḥ / tadevamanvayādīnāmagamakatvāt pradhānāsiddhau buddhyāderasambhava eva / pratihataśca pradhānavādo 'smadgurubhirvistareṇeti neha pratanyate / ataḥ sāṃkhyānāmayaṃ viparyayaḥ pradhānapūrvakam jagaditi /
analyzed: na ca kiñcid kāryam ekasmāt eva kāraṇāt utpadyamānam upalabdham iti avidyamāna sapakṣasya anvaya ādeḥ vipakṣe sadbhāvaḥ tat evam anvaya ādīnām agamaka tvāt pradhāna asiddhau buddhi ādeḥ asambhavaḥ eva pratihataḥ ca pradhāna vādaḥ smat gurubhiḥ vistareṇa iti na iha pratanyate atas sāṃkhyānām ayam viparyayaḥ pradhāna pūrvakam jagat iti
translated: And it is not observed that anything is produced from a single cause alone. Thus, for what is absent in similar instances, the presence of concomitance in dissimilar instances is not established. Thus, since concomitance and so on are not probative, in the non-establishment of pradhāna, the impossibility of intellect and so on is itself. And the doctrine of pradhāna has been refuted in detail by our teachers, so it is not elaborated here. Therefore, this error of the Sāṃkhyas is that the world has pradhāna as its antecedent.

original: tathā śarīrasya parimāṇabhedena bhedopapatteḥ śarīramevātmetyabhyupagame pratisandhānaṃ na syādityātmanaḥ śarīrādivyatirekeṇa nityatvaṃ pratipattavyamiti hitamupadiśatsu vaiśeṣikeṣvahitajñānaṃ viparyayo laukāyatikānām / samānañcaitat saugatajainānām / tathāhi / saṅkocavikāsadharmakatvādātmanaḥ sapariṇāmatve 'nyatvena bhedopapatteḥ smaraṇaṃ na syāt / bodhācca bodharūpateti pratibandhapratiṣedhād bodhamātre 'pyātmani smaraṇānutpattau śreyobuddherabhāva ityalaṃ vistareṇeti /
analyzed: tathā śarīrasya parimāṇa bhedena bheda upapatteḥ śarīram eva ātmā iti abhyupagame pratisandhānam na syāt iti ātmanaḥ śarīra ādi vyatirekeṇa nitya tvam pratipattavyam iti hitam upadiśatsu vaiśeṣikeṣu ahita jñānam viparyayaḥ laukāyatikānām samānam ca etat saugata jainānām tathā hi saṅkoca vikāsa dharmaka tvāt ātmanaḥ sa pariṇāma tve nya tvena bheda upapatteḥ smaraṇam na syāt bodhāt ca bodha rūpa tā iti pratibandha pratiṣedhāt bodha mātre pi ātmani
translated: Similarly, because the difference of the body is possible by the difference of dimension, if it is accepted that the body itself is the self, there would be no recollection. Therefore, it should be understood that the self is eternal, different from the body etc. The Lokāyata philosophers have the opposite view, the knowledge of what is harmful, when the Vaiśeṣikas teach what is beneficial. And this is the same for the Buddhists and Jains. Thus, because the self has the property of contraction and expansion, if it undergoes change, there would be difference by being different, so there would be no recollection. And because of cognition, it has the nature of cognition. Therefore, because of the negation of restriction, even in the self which is mere cognition, if recollection does not arise, there would be no knowledge of what is beneficial. Thus, enough of this extensive discussion.

original: anadhyavasāyavaidharmyam
translated: The dissimilarity of indecision

original: anadhyavasāyo 'pi pratyakṣānumānaviṣaye eva sañjāyate / tatra pratyakṣaviṣaye tāvat prasiddhārtheṣvaprasiddhārtheṣu vā vyāsaṅgādanarthitvād vā kimityālocanamātramanadhyavasāyaḥ / yathā bāhīkasya panasādiṣvanadhyavasāyo bhavati / tatra sattādravyatvapṛthivītvavṛkṣatvarūpādiḥ śākhādyapekṣo 'dhyavasāyo bhavati / panasatvamapi panaseṣvanuvṛttamāmrādibhyo vyāvṛttaṃ pratyakṣameva / kevalantūpadeśābhāvād viśeṣasaṃjñāpratipattirna bhavati /PDhS
analyzed: pratyakṣa anumāna viṣaye eva sañjāyate tatra pratyakṣa viṣaye tāvat prasiddha artheṣu aprasiddha artheṣu vā vyāsaṅgāt anarthi tvāt vā kim iti ālocana mātram anadhyavasāyaḥ yathā bāhīkasya panasa ādiṣu anadhyavasāyaḥ bhavati tatra sattā dravya tva pṛthivī tva vṛkṣa tva rūpa ādiḥ śākhā ādi apekṣaḥ dhyavasāyaḥ bhavati panasa tvam api panaseṣu anuvṛttam āmra ādibhyaḥ vyāvṛttam pratyakṣam eva kevala ntu upadeśa abhāvāt viśeṣa saṃj
translated: Non-determination also arises only with regard to the objects of perception and inference. There, with regard to the objects of perception, whether well-known or unknown, mere reflection on what is it is non-determination due to confusion or lack of interest. For example, a foreigner has non-determination regarding jackfruit trees etc. There, the determination is based on branches etc. regarding existence, substance, earthness, treeness, color etc. Even the universal jackfruitness, which occurs in jackfruits and is distinguished from mangoes etc., is directly perceived. However, due to lack of instruction, the understanding of specific terms does not occur.

original: idānīmanadhyavasāyasya kāraṇasvarūpaviṣayavibhāganirūpaṇārthaṃ na paraṃ viparyayaḥ anadhyavasāyo 'pi pratyakṣānumānaviṣaye sañjāyate ityādi prakaraṇam / anadhyavasitiranadhyavasāyaḥ / jñānamaniścayātmakam / tacca saṃśayādibhyo 'rthāntaram / kāraṇabhedād / viṣayabhedācceti /
analyzed: idānīm anadhyavasāyasya kāraṇa svarūpa viṣaya vibhāga nirūpaṇa artham na param viparyayaḥ pratyakṣa anumāna viṣaye sañjāyate ityādi prakaraṇam anadhyavasitiḥ anadhyavasāyaḥ jñānam aniścaya ātmakam tat ca saṃśaya ādibhyaḥ rtha antaram kāraṇa bhedāt viṣaya bhedāt ca iti
translated: Now, in order to explain the division of the cause, nature, and object of non-ascertainment, the topic is introduced that not only error but also non-ascertainment arises regarding the objects of perception and inference. Non-ascertainment is non-ascertainment, which is knowledge of the nature of indecision. And that is different from doubt etc. due to the difference in causes and the difference in objects.

original: tatra pratyakṣaviṣaye tāvat vyākhyāyate / prasiddhārtheṣvaprasiddhārtheṣu ca viṣayeṣu bhavatītyataḥ saṃśayād bhidyate / saṃśayo hi prasiddhārtheṣveva bhavatīti / atha prasiddhārtheṣu kutaḥ kāraṇādanadhyavasāya ityāha vyāsaṅgādanarthitvād vā iti / yathā vyāsaṅgāt iṣukārasya iṣāvāsaktamanaso mahati gate 'pi rājani kinnāmāyaṃ gataḥ ityanadhyavasāyaḥ / anarthitvāt svānuṣṭhānaniratasya tapasvino mahatyapi rājanyanadhyavasāyaḥ kinnāmāyaṃ gataḥ iti /
analyzed: tatra pratyakṣa viṣaye tāvat vyākhyāyate prasiddha artheṣu aprasiddha artheṣu ca viṣayeṣu bhavati iti atas saṃśayāt bhidyate saṃśayaḥ hi prasiddha artheṣu eva bhavati iti atha prasiddha artheṣu kutas kāraṇāt anadhyavasāyaḥ iti āha vyāsaṅgāt anarthi tvāt vā iti yathā vyāsaṅgāt iṣukārasya iṣau āsakta manasaḥ mahati gate rājani kinnāmā ayam gataḥ iti anadhyavasāyaḥ anarthi tvāt sva anuṣṭhāna niratasya tapasvinaḥ mahati api rājani anadhyav
translated: Of these, the author first explains the one that has a perceptible object. It arises with regard to well-known objects as well as unknown objects, hence it differs from doubt. For doubt arises only with regard to well-known objects. Now, why is there non-ascertainment with regard to well-known objects? He says: due to distraction or lack of interest. For example, due to distraction, a fletcher whose mind is absorbed in the arrow has non-ascertainment even when a great king has passed by, thinking What is his name? Due to lack of interest, an ascetic engrossed in his own practice has non-ascertainment even when a great king has passed by, thinking What is his name?

original: na cāyaṃ saṃśayaḥ / tasyobhayollekhitvāt / sāmānyopalambhādibhyaścotpadyamānatvācca / ityato 'nadhyavasāya itarasmād bhidyate yathoktakāraṇajanyatvāt / yathoktaṃ vā jñānam anadhyavasāya iti vyavahartavyam uktakāraṇebhyo niṣpadyamānatvāt / yastu na bhidyate na caivaṃ vyavahriyate / na cāsāvuktakāraṇebhyo niṣpadyate / yathā saṃśayādiriti /
analyzed: na ca ayam saṃśayaḥ tasya ubhaya ullekhi tvāt sāmānya upalambha ādibhyaḥ ca utpadyamāna tvāt ca iti atas itarasmāt bhidyate yathā ukta kāraṇa janya tvāt yathā uktam vā jñānam anadhyavasāyaḥ iti vyavahartavyam ukta kāraṇebhyaḥ niṣpadyamāna tvāt yaḥ tu na bhidyate na ca evam vyavahriyate na ca asau ukta kāraṇebhyaḥ niṣpadyate yathā saṃśaya ādiḥ iti
translated: And this is not doubt, because it does not indicate both alternatives, and because it arises from the perception of the universal, etc. Therefore, non-ascertainment is different from the other, because it is produced by the stated causes. Or the stated cognition should be designated as non-ascertainment, because it arises from the stated causes. But that which is not different and is not designated thus, and that which does not arise from the stated causes, like doubt, etc.

original: tasya svarūpamāha kimityālocanamātram kiṃ nāmeti jñānaṃ viśeṣasaṃjñollekhaśūnyamanadhyavasāya iti /
analyzed: tasya svarūpam āha kim iti ālocana mātram kim nāma iti jñānam viśeṣa saṃjñā ullekha śūnyam anadhyavasāyaḥ iti
translated: He states its nature: What is mere reflection? What is cognition devoid of the indication of a particular name is non-ascertainment.

original: aprasiddhārtheṣu yathā bāhīkasya panasādiṣvanadhyavasāyo bhavati bāhīko hiṭhakaḥ /hiraṭhakaḥ tasya panasādiṣu saṅketābhāvād viśeṣasaṃjñollekhaśūnyaṃ kinnāmāyam iti jñānamutpadyate / tatra hi sattādravyatvapṛthivītvavṛkṣatvarūpādiśākhādyapekṣo 'dhyavasāyaḥ eva / tathāhi / sannayam iti niścayajñānam / tathā dravyaṃ pṛthivī vṛkṣo rūpādimāṃśchākhādimāṃśceti adhyavasāya eva / tathā panasatvamapi nirvikalpakabodhe panaseṣvanuvṛttamāmrādibhyo vyāvṛttaṃ pratyakṣameva /
analyzed: aprasiddha artheṣu yathā bāhīkasya panasa ādiṣu anadhyavasāyaḥ bhavati bāhīkaḥ hiṭhakaḥ hiraṭhakaḥ tasya panasa ādiṣu saṅketa abhāvāt viśeṣa saṃjñā ullekha śūnyam kim nāma ayam iti jñānam utpadyate tatra hi sattā dravya tva pṛthivī tva vṛkṣa tva rūpa ādi śākhā ādi apekṣaḥ dhyavasāyaḥ eva tathā hi san ayam iti niścaya jñānam tathā dravyam pṛthivī vṛkṣaḥ rūpa ādimān śākhā ādimān ca iti adhyavasāyaḥ eva tathā panasa tvam
translated: In the case of words denoting well-known objects, there is no doubt. But in the case of words denoting unknown objects, there is doubt, as in the case of a foreigner hearing the word 'panasa' etc. A foreigner hearing the word 'panasa' etc. has no convention regarding them, so he gets the knowledge 'what is this?' devoid of the impression of a specific name, due to lack of convention. There, the determination is only in relation to existence, substance, earth, tree, form, branches etc. Thus, the knowledge of ascertainment is 'it exists'. Similarly, the determination is only 'it is a substance, earth, tree, having form, having branches etc.'. Thus, the universal 'panasatva' also, which is present in all 'panasas' in non-conceptual cognition and is distinguished from mango etc., is only perception.

original: nanvevaṃ tarhi kva viṣaye 'nadhyavasāya ityāha kevalantūpadeśābhāvāt saṅketābhāvād viśeṣasaṃjñollekhinī panaso 'yamiti pratipattirna bhavati iti / II / nanvevaṃ tarhi pratipattyabhāvo 'nadhyavasāyaḥ syāt / tasya cābhāvarūpatvād avidyāyāmantarbhāvo 'nupapannaḥ / naitadevam / kinnāmāyamityaniścayātmakajñānasya saṃśayādivilakṣaṇasyānubhūyamānatayāpalāpāyogāt / tasya cāvidyālakṣaṇayuktatvādavidyāyāmantarbhāva iti /
analyzed: nanu evam tarhi kva viṣaye nadhyavasāyaḥ iti āha saṅketa abhāvāt viśeṣa saṃjñā ullekhinī panasaḥ yam iti pratipattiḥ na bhavati iti   nanu evam tarhi pratipatti abhāvaḥ nadhyavasāyaḥ syāt tasya ca abhāva rūpa tvāt avidyāyām antarbhāvaḥ nupapannaḥ na etat evam kim nāma ayam iti aniścaya ātmaka jñānasya saṃśaya ādi vilakṣaṇasya anubhūyamāna tayā apalāpa ayogāt tasya ca avidyā lakṣaṇa yukta tvāt avidyāyām antarbhāvaḥ iti
translated: If so, then where is non-ascertainment regarding the object? He says: But only due to the absence of instruction and the absence of convention, there is no cognition that points to a particular name, such as this is a jackfruit tree. If so, then non-ascertainment would be the absence of cognition. And since that is of the nature of non-existence, its inclusion within ignorance is not tenable. This is not so. Rather, because the knowledge that is of the nature of uncertainty, such as what is this?, is experienced as distinct from doubt, etc., it cannot be denied. And since that is endowed with the characteristics of ignorance, it is included within ignorance.

original: anumānaviṣaye 'pi nārikeladvīpavāsinaḥ sāsnāmātradarśanāt ko nu khalvatra prāṇī syādityanadhyavasāyo bhavati /PDhS
analyzed: anumāna viṣaye pi nārikela dvīpa vāsinaḥ sāsnā mātra darśanāt kaḥ nu khalu atra prāṇī syāt iti anadhyavasāyaḥ bhavati
translated: Even regarding the object of inference, for those dwelling in the coconut islands, due to seeing only the dewlap, there is non-ascertainment, thinking what kind of animal could this be?

original: anumānaviṣaye 'pi nālikeradvīpavāsinaḥ akṛtasamayasya piṇḍānupalambhe sāsnāmātradarśanāt ko nu khalvatra prāṇī syādityanadhyavasāyo bhavati pūrvaṃ hi saṅketāpratipattāvapi sāsnā prāmāṇyāvinābhūtopalabdhā / tadupalambhāt piṇḍānupalambhe 'pi avinābhāvasambandhasmaraṇānantaraṃ parāmarśajñāne sati ko nu khalvatra pradeśe prāṇīti / kinnāmātra prāṇīti syādityanadhyavasāyaḥ /🔽svapnavaidharmyam🔽uparatendriyagrāmasya pralīnamanaskasyendriyadvāreṇeva yadanubhavanaṃ mānasaṃ tat svapnajñānam /PDhS
analyzed: anumāna viṣaye pi nālikera dvīpa vāsinaḥ akṛta samayasya piṇḍa anupalambhe sāsnā mātra darśanāt kaḥ nu khalu atra prāṇī syāt iti anadhyavasāyaḥ bhavati pūrvam hi saṅketa apratipattau api sāsnā prāmāṇya avinābhūta upalabdhā tad upalambhāt piṇḍa anupalambhe pi avinābhāva sambandha smaraṇa anantaram parāmarśa jñāne sati kaḥ nu khalu atra pradeśe prāṇī iti kinnāma atra prāṇī iti syāt iti anadhyavasāyaḥ 🔽svapna vaidharmyam 🔽uparata indriya grāmasya pralīna manaskasya indriya dvāreṇa iva yat anubhavanam mānasam tat svapna jñānam
translated: Even in the domain of inference, for one dwelling in the coconut islands who has not made a convention, upon not perceiving a cow, seeing only the hump, there is indecision as to what animal it might be. For previously, even before understanding the convention, the hump was perceived as invariably concomitant with the cow. From that perception, even upon not perceiving the cow, after the recollection of the relation of invariable concomitance, when there is the reflective awareness What animal is there in this place?, there is indecision as to whether it is just a hump or an animal.

original: tadevamanadhyavasāyasya kāraṇādibhedena bhedamabhidhāya svapnanirūpaṇamāha uparatendriyagrāmasya ityādi / uparataḥ svaviṣayagrahaṇaṃ prati nivṛtta indriyāṇāṃ grāmo yasyāsau tathoktastasya / pralīnamanaskasya iti / pralīnaṃ nendriyadeśena saṃyuktaṃ mano yasyāsau tasya pralīnamanaskasya / indriyadvāreṇeva yadanubhavanaṃ mānasam utpadyate / tat svapnajñānam iti / manasi bhavaṃ mānasaṃ tacca smaraṇasukhādyapi bhavatīti tannivṛttyarthamanubhavanapadam / anubhavanañca bāhyendriyajamapīti mānasagrahaṇam / tathāpi sukhaduḥkhādyanubhavairvyabhicārastadarthamuparatendriyagrāmasyeti / sukhādyanubhavaścendriyaja eva manasastatra vyāpārāt / athoparatendriyagrāmasya mānasaṃ svapnāntikamapi bhavatīti vyabhicāraḥ / tanna / tasya smṛtirūpatayā anubhavanapadenaiva vyavacchinnatvāt /
analyzed: tat evam anadhyavasāyasya kāraṇa ādi bhedena bhedam abhidhāya svapna nirūpaṇam āha uparata indriya grāmasya ityādi uparataḥ sva viṣaya grahaṇam prati nivṛttaḥ indriyāṇām grāmaḥ yasya asau tathā uktaḥ tasya pralīna manaskasya iti pralīnam na indriya deśena saṃyuktam manaḥ yasya asau tasya pralīna manaskasya indriya dvāreṇa iva yat anubhavanam mānasam utpadyate tat svapna jñānam iti manasi bhavam mānasam tat ca smaraṇa sukha ādi api bhavati iti tad nivṛtti
translated: Having thus described the difference of non-ascertainment according to the difference of cause etc., he states the definition of dream: Of one whose group of senses has ceased, whose mind is merged, the experience that arises through the mind is dream-knowledge. Ceased means turned away from grasping its own objects. Group of senses is that of which he is so described. Whose mind is merged means whose mind is not united with the region of the senses. The experience that arises through the mind as if through the door of the senses is dream-knowledge. Mental means belonging to the mind, and that is also recollection, pleasure etc. Therefore, the word experience is used to exclude that. And experience arises from the external senses also, so the word mental is used. Still, there is deviation by the experiences of pleasure, pain etc. Therefore, of one whose group of senses has ceased is stated. And the experience of pleasure etc. arises from the senses only, because the mind operates there. Now, even the mental experience at the end of sleep belongs to one whose group of senses has ceased. Therefore there is deviation.

original: anye tvasya vyavacchedārthamavidyāsāmānyalakṣaṇamanuvartayantīti /
analyzed: anye tu asya vyavaccheda artham avidyā sāmānya lakṣaṇam anuvartayanti iti
translated: Others, however, follow the general definition of ignorance for the purpose of distinguishing it from this.

original: na ca nimīlitākṣasya nīlapītādijñānamuparatendriyagrāmasya bhavatītyāśaṅkanīyam / viṣayasānnidhye satīndriyāntareṇa tasya jñānotpādāt / yadā hi II / viṣayasānnidhye 'pi nendriyeṇa jñānaṃ tadaivoparatendriyagrāmaḥ puruṣo 'bhidhīyata iti / na ca cakṣurvyāpāraṃ vinā nīlapītādiṣvanubhavanaṃ sambhavatīti smaraṇametannyāyyam / taccānubhavapadenaiva vyavacchinnam / nanvevamapyuparatendriyagrāmasya mānasānubhavanatvāt svapnajñānam itarasmād bhidyate ityukte vyabhicārābhāvaḥ / kimarthaṃ pralīnamanaskasyendriyadvāreṇeveti padadvayam / lakṣaṇāntarārtham / tathāhi / pralīnamanaskasya yadanubhavanaṃ mānasaṃ tat svapnajñānamiti dvitīyaṃ lakṣaṇam / pralīnamanaskasya svapnāntikamapi bhavatītyanubhavanapadam / anubhavanañca sukhādiṣu bhavatīti pralīnamanaskapadam /
analyzed: na ca nimīlita akṣasya nīla pīta ādi jñānam uparata indriya grāmasya bhavati iti āśaṅkanīyam viṣaya sānnidhye sati indriya antareṇa tasya jñāna utpādāt yadā hi viṣaya sānnidhye na indriyeṇa jñānam tadā eva uparata indriya grāmaḥ puruṣaḥ bhidhīyate iti na ca cakṣuḥ vyāpāram vinā nīla pīta ādiṣu anubhavanam sambhavati iti smaraṇam etat nyāyyam tat ca anubhava padena eva vyavacchinnam nanu evam api uparata indriya grāmasya mānasa anubhavana tvāt svapna
translated: Nor should it be suspected that the knowledge of blue, yellow, etc. of one with closed eyes, or of one with faculties withdrawn, does not occur. Because that knowledge arises through another sense faculty when the object is present. For when there is no knowledge through the sense faculty even when the object is present, then alone is one called a person with faculties withdrawn. And since the experience of blue, yellow, etc. is not possible without the operation of the eye, this is properly remembered. And that is excluded by the word 'experience' itself. But even so, if it is said that dream knowledge is different from the other because it is mental experience of one with faculties withdrawn, there is no fallacy. Why are the two words 'only through the door of the sense faculties' used? For the sake of another definition. Thus, the second definition is that the experience of one with faculties withdrawn is dream knowledge. The word 'experience' includes even that which is near sleep.

original: ataḥ pralīnamanaskānubhavatvāt itarasmād bhidyate / tathendriyadvāreṇevotpadyamānatve sati mānasānubhavanatvāditi / indriyadvāreṇevotpadyate svapnāntikamato 'nubhavanamiti / anubhavanañca sukhādāvapi bhavatīti indriyadvāreṇeveti padam /
analyzed: atas pralīna manaska anubhava tvāt itarasmāt bhidyate tathā indriya dvāreṇa iva utpadyamāna tve sati mānasa anubhavana tvāt iti indriya dvāreṇa iva utpadyate svapnāntikam atas nubhavanam iti anubhavanam ca sukha ādau api bhavati iti indriya dvāreṇa iva iti padam
translated: Therefore, it differs from the other because it is the experience of one whose mind is merged. Similarly, it is said to arise through the door of the senses because it is a mental experience. And the experience arises through the door of the senses, like in a dream. And experience also occurs in pleasure etc., so the word 'through the door of the senses' is used.

original: svapnotpattiprakāraḥ
analyzed: svapna utpatti prakāraḥ
translated: The mode of origination of dreams

original: katham / yadā buddhipūrvādātmanaḥ śarīravyāpārādahani khinnānāṃ prāṇināṃ niśi viśrāmārthamāhārapariṇāmāthaṃ vā adṛṣṭakāritaprayatnāpekṣādātmāntaḥkaraṇasambandhānmanasi kriyāprabandhādantarhṛdaye nirindriye ātmapradeśe niścalaṃ manastiṣṭhati tadā pralīnamanaska ityākhyāyate /PDhS
analyzed: katham yadā buddhi pūrvāt ātmanaḥ śarīra vyāpārāt ahani khinnānām prāṇinām niśi viśrāma artham āhāra pariṇāma atham vā adṛṣṭa kārita prayatna apekṣāt ātma antaḥkaraṇa sambandhāt manasi kriyā prabandhāt antar hṛdaye nirindriye ātma pradeśe niścalam manaḥ tiṣṭhati tadā pralīna manaskaḥ iti ākhyāyate pdhs
translated: How? When the mind of living beings who are tired during the day due to the activity of the body preceded by intellect, remains motionless in the inner part of the heart, which is devoid of senses, in the form of the self, due to the continuity of activity in the mind for the purpose of rest at night or for the transformation of food, depending on the effort caused by unseen force and the connection of the self and the internal organ, then he is called one whose mind is merged.

original: pralīne ca tasminnuparatendriyagrāmo bhavati / tasyāmavasthāyāṃ prabandhena prāṇāpānasantānapravṛttāvātmamanaḥsaṃyogaviśeṣāt svāpākhyāt saṃskārāccendriyadvāreṇeva asatsu viṣayeṣu pratyakṣākāraṃ svapnajñānamutpadyate /PDhS
