analyzed: pralīne ca tasmin uparata indriya grāmaḥ bhavati tasyām avasthāyām prabandhena prāṇa apāna santāna pravṛttau ātma manaḥ saṃyoga viśeṣāt svāpa ākhyāt saṃskārāt ca indriya dvāreṇa iva asatsu viṣayeṣu pratyakṣa ākāram svapna jñānam utpadyate pdhs
translated: And when that (sleep) has subsided, the group of senses ceases to function. In that state, when the continuity of the flow of inhalation and exhalation is going on, from the specific conjunction of the self and mind, and from the impression called sleep, dream-knowledge arises in the form of perception, as if through the senses, even when the objects do not exist.

original: atha kathaṃ svapnajñānamutpadyate / puruṣaścoparatendriyagrāmaḥ pralīnamanaskaśca bhavatītyāha yadā ityādi / yadāntarhṛdaye na bāhye / nirgatānīndriyāṇi yasyāsau tathoktastasminnātmapradeśe / niścalaṃ kriyāśūnyaṃ manastiṣṭhati tadā puruṣaḥ pralīnamanaska ityākhyāyate /
analyzed: atha katham svapna jñānam utpadyate puruṣaḥ ca uparata indriya grāmaḥ pralīna manaskaḥ ca bhavati iti āha yadā ityādi yadā antar hṛdaye na bāhye nirgatāni indriyāṇi yasya asau tathā uktaḥ tasmin ātma pradeśe niścalam kriyā śūnyam manaḥ tiṣṭhati tadā puruṣaḥ pralīna manaskaḥ iti ākhyāyate
translated: Now, how does dream-knowledge arise? And the person has ceased senses and merged mind, to this he says when etc. When the senses have gone inside the heart and not outside, he is said to be that way. When the mind remains motionless and actionless in that part of the self, then the person is said to have merged mind.

original: anye tvāgamābhimatam adhomukhaṃ kamalaṃ nirindriyātmapradeśastatra niścalaṃ manastiṣṭhatīti bruvate /
analyzed: anye tu āgama abhimatam adhomukham kamalam niḥ indriya ātma pradeśaḥ tatra niścalam manaḥ tiṣṭhati iti bruvate
translated: Others, however, say that the mind remains motionless in the lotus facing downwards, which is accepted as scripture, in that part of the self devoid of senses.

original: sa ca viśiṣṭātmasambandhaḥ kriyāprabandhāt kriyāsantānād bhavati / kriyāII /prabandhaścātmāntaḥkaraṇasaṃyogādadṛṣṭakāritāt prayatnāpekṣādutpadyate / tathāhi / manaḥ samavāyikāraṇam / ātmamanaḥsaṃyogo 'samavāyikāraṇam / adṛṣṭakāritaprayatno nimittakāraṇamityevaṃ manasi kriyāprabandhād viśiṣṭātmapradeśena saṃyogaḥ svāpākhyaḥ sampadyate /
analyzed: sa ca viśiṣṭa ātma sambandhaḥ kriyā prabandhāt kriyā santānāt bhavati    prayatna apekṣāt utpadyate tathā hi manaḥ samavāyi kāraṇam ātma manaḥ saṃyogaḥ samavāyi kāraṇam adṛṣṭa kārita prayatnaḥ nimitta kāraṇam iti evam manasi kriyā prabandhāt viśiṣṭa ātma pradeśena saṃyogaḥ svāpa ākhyaḥ sampadyate
translated: And that connection with the distinguished self arises from the continuity of action, from the series of actions. And that continuity arises from the conjunction of the self and the internal organ, which is caused by the unseen [potency], and which depends on effort. For thus, the mind is the inherent cause, the conjunction of the self and the mind is the non-inherent cause, and the effort caused by the unseen [potency] is the instrumental cause. Thus, from the continuity of action in the mind, a conjunction with a distinguished part of the self called sleep comes about.

original: sa ca kadā / niśi iti bāhulyāpekṣayā tasya / kimarthañca bhavatīti viśrāmārthamāhārapariṇāmārthaṃ vā iti / puruṣabhedāpekṣayā samastaṃ vyastañcaitad vivakṣitam / kasyacidekaṃ prayojanaṃ kasyacidubhayamapi bhavatīti / kiṃviśiṣṭasya prāṇinaḥ / ahani khinnasya / kutaḥ / śarīravyāpārāt / sa ca nāvādyārūḍhasyāpi sambhavati na ca tasmāt khedaḥ / tadartham buddhipūrvāt buddhiśca smaraṇecchādvāreṇa vyāpārotpattau kāraṇaṃ na sākṣāt / tathāpi śarīrāntareṣu buddhipūrvako vyāpāro niyogadvāreṇa sambhavati / na ca tasmāt khedastadartham ātmanaḥ svaśarīrasyeti / evamuktakrameṇa nirindriyapradeśasambaddhaṃ pralīnaṃ mano 'padiśyate / pralīne ca tasmin uparatendriyagrāmaḥ puruṣo bhavati / manasānadhiṣṭhitānāmindriyāṇāṃ svaviṣaye vyāpārāsambhavāt / jīvanantu tasyāmavasthāyāmanumīyate / prabandhena sātatyena / prāṇāpānasantānasya pravṛttau satyām / tathāhi / prāṇāpānasantānapravṛttiḥ prayatnakāryā na cecchādveṣapūrvakaḥ prayatno 'tra sambhavatyato jīvanapūrvakaḥ prayatno 'numīyata iti vakṣyāmaḥ prayatnādhikāre /
analyzed: sa ca kadā niśi iti bāhulya apekṣayā tasya kimartham ca bhavati iti viśrāma artham āhāra pariṇāma artham vā iti puruṣa bheda apekṣayā samastam vyastam ca etat vivakṣitam kasyacid ekam prayojanam kasyacid ubhayam api bhavati iti kiṃviśiṣṭasya prāṇinaḥ ahani khinnasya kutas śarīra vyāpārāt sa ca nāvā ādi ārūḍhasya api sambhavati na ca tasmāt khedaḥ tad artham buddhi pūrvāt buddhiḥ ca smaraṇa icchā dvāreṇa vyāpāra utpattau kāraṇam na sākṣāt ta
translated: And when does that occur? At night, in relation to the majority. And for what purpose does it occur? For the purpose of rest or for the purpose of digesting food. This is stated both collectively and individually in relation to the differences in individuals. For some, it serves one purpose, for some, both. Of what kind of living being? Of one fatigued during the day. Why? Because of bodily activity. And that does not occur even for one who has boarded a boat, nor is there fatigue from that. For that purpose, from an act preceded by intelligence. And intelligence is the cause in the production of activity through the medium of memory and desire, not directly. Still, in other bodies, activity preceded by intelligence occurs through the medium of injunction. And there is no fatigue from that. For that purpose, of the self, of one's own body. Thus, the mind connected with a part of the body devoid of sense organs is said to be dissolved in the manner described. And when that has dissolved, the person with the senses withdrawn,

original: athaivaṃ pralīnamanaskasyoparatendriyagrāmasyātmanaḥ kutaḥ svapnajñānamutpadyata ityāha ātmamanaḥsaṃyogaviśeṣāt asamavāyikāraṇāt / svāpa ityākhyā saṃjñā yasyātmamanaḥsaṃyogaviśeṣasyāsau tathoktastasmāt / saṃskārācca iti / saṃskāraḥ smṛtyutpattidvāreṇa svapnajñānotpattau kāraṇamiti /
analyzed: atha evam pralīna manaskasya uparata indriya grāmasya ātmanaḥ kutas svapna jñānam utpadyate iti āha ātma manaḥ saṃyoga viśeṣāt asamavāyi kāraṇāt svāpaḥ iti ākhyā saṃjñā yasya ātma manaḥ saṃyoga viśeṣasya asau tathā uktaḥ tasmāt saṃskārāt ca iti saṃskāraḥ smṛti utpatti dvāreṇa svapna jñāna utpattau kāraṇam iti
translated: Now, when the mind has thus dissolved, and the group of senses has ceased, how does the knowledge of dreams arise from the self? He says: From a special conjunction of the self and mind, which is the non-inherent cause. The state called sleep is a special conjunction of the self and mind, and it is said to be so. And from impressions. Impressions are the cause for the arising of dream knowledge through the door of memory.

original: yadvā svāpākhyāditi saṃskāraviśeṣaṇam / yo hi saṃskāraḥ svāpāvasthāyāṃ smṛtidvāreṇa svasaṃjñānaheturbhavatyasau svāpākhya iti / tasmād dikkālādibhyaścendriyadvāreṇeva asatsu avidyamāneṣu viṣayeṣu hastyādiṣu pratyakṣākāraṃ pratyakṣamiva svapnajñānamutpadyate /
analyzed: yat vā svāpa ākhyāt iti saṃskāra viśeṣaṇam yaḥ hi saṃskāraḥ svāpa avasthāyām smṛti dvāreṇa sva saṃjñāna hetuḥ bhavati asau svāpa ākhyaḥ iti tasmāt diś kāla ādibhyaḥ ca indriya dvāreṇa iva asatsu a vidyamāneṣu viṣayeṣu hasti ādiṣu pratyakṣa ākāram pratyakṣam iva svapna jñānam utpadyate
translated: Or, the term from sleep qualifies the impressions. For that impression which in the state of sleep becomes the cause of its own cognition through memory is called from sleep. Therefore, from that and from space, time, etc., through the senses, dream knowledge arises with the form of perception, as if it were perception, when the objects such as elephants do not exist, are not present.

original: anye tu kuḍyādaya eva hastyātmanā vyavasthitāḥ svapnajñānasyālambanamiti manyante / yaccedam asatsu viṣayeṣūtpadyate svapnajñānamityuktaṃ tadapi hastyādisvarūpāpekṣayā / tena hi rūpeṇa teṣāmasattvāditi /
analyzed: anye tu kuḍya ādayaḥ eva hasti ātmanā vyavasthitāḥ svapna jñānasya ālambanam iti manyante yat ca idam asatsu viṣayeṣu utpadyate svapna jñānam iti uktam tat api hasti ādi svarūpa apekṣayā tena hi rūpeṇa teṣām asattvāt iti
translated: Others, however, think that walls, etc., themselves, existing in the form of elephants, are the objects of the cognition in a dream. And what has been said, that the cognition in a dream arises in the absence of objects, is said with reference to the form of elephants, etc. For in that form they are non-existent.

original: tadetadasat / kuḍyāderālambanatve pramāṇābhāvāt / na ca svapnotthitasya mamaite kuḍyādayo hastyādirūpatayā pratibhātā iti pratyabhijñānamasti / nāpīndriyāṇāṃ kuḍyādiṣu hastyādijñānajanmani vyāpāraḥ sambhavati / tadvyāpāroparame sati tatra jñānasya bhavanāt / manaso 'pi bahirviṣaye svātantryeṇa vyāpāraḥ pratiṣiddha eva / tasmānnirviṣaya eva svapnajñānamiti /
analyzed: tat etat asat kuḍya ādeḥ ālambana tve pramāṇa abhāvāt na ca svapna utthitasya mama ete kuḍya ādayaḥ hasti ādi rūpa tayā pratibhātāḥ iti pratyabhijñānam asti na api indriyāṇām kuḍya ādiṣu hasti ādi jñāna janmani vyāpāraḥ sambhavati tad vyāpāra uparame sati tatra jñānasya bhavanāt bahis viṣaye svātantryeṇa vyāpāraḥ pratiṣiddhaḥ eva tasmāt nirviṣayaḥ eva svapna jñānam iti
translated: This is not correct. Because there is no evidence for walls, etc., being the objects. And there is no recognition that these walls, etc., which appeared to me in the form of elephants, etc., when I was awake, nor is it possible for the senses to function in producing the cognition of elephants, etc., in walls, etc., because the cognition occurs there even when the functioning of the senses has ceased. And the independent functioning of the mind towards external objects has been refuted. Therefore, the cognition in a dream is indeed without an object.

original: atha svapnajñānaṃ na viparyayādibhyo 'rthāntaram / tathāhi / svapnajñānam atasmiṃstadityutpadyamānaṃ viparyayajñānameva / kimayaṃ sthāṇuḥ puruṣo vetyubhayollekhitve sati saṃśayajñānam / kiṃnāmāyamiti cotpāde 'nadhyavasāya iti na svapnajñānametebhyo 'rthāntaram / pṛthagabhidhānantu śubhāśubhasūcakatvāditi /
analyzed: atha svapna jñānam na viparyaya ādibhyaḥ rtha antaram tathā hi svapna jñānam a tasmin tat iti utpadyamānam viparyaya jñānam eva kim ayam sthāṇuḥ puruṣaḥ vā iti ubhaya ullekhi tve sati saṃśaya jñānam kiṃnāmā ayam iti ca utpāde na adhyavasāyaḥ iti na svapna jñānam etebhyaḥ rtha antaram pṛthak abhidhānam tu śubha aśubha sūcaka tvāt iti
translated: Now, if dream-knowledge is not a different thing from error etc., then thus: dream-knowledge arising as that which is not that is just erroneous knowledge. When there is the indication of both is this a post or a man?, it is a knowledge of doubt. And when there is the production of what is this called?, it is indecision. Thus dream-knowledge is not a different thing from these. But the separate designation is because it indicates good and bad.

original: naitad yuktam / kāraṇādibhedenāsya viparyayādibhyo 'rthāntaratvāditi kecit / tathāhi / viparyayajñānaṃ pratyakṣānumānaviṣaye pittakaphānilopahatendriyasya puruṣasyotpadyate / saṃśayastu sāmānyopalambhāditaḥ pratyakṣānumānaviṣaye prasiddhobhayaviśeṣasya bhavatītyevamanadhyavasāyasyāpi vilakṣaṇameva kāraṇamuktam / tadviparītāni tu svapnajñānotpattau kāraṇānīti kāraṇabhedād bhedaḥ / lakṣaṇabhede 'pyabhedābhyupagame sarvatra tathābhāvaprasaṅgaḥ / tathātyantāprasiddhe 'pyarthe svapnajñānamutpadyate / na caivaṃ viparyayādāviti / tasmādubhayollekhitvādisadbhāve 'pi svapnalakṣaṇopapatteḥ saṃśayādivilakṣaṇaṃ svapnajñānamevaitadityabhyupagantavyam /
analyzed: na etat yuktam kāraṇa ādi bhedena asya viparyaya ādibhyaḥ rtha antara tvāt iti kecid tathā hi viparyaya jñānam pratyakṣa anumāna viṣaye pitta kapha anila upahata indriyasya puruṣasya utpadyate saṃśayaḥ tu sāmānya upalambhāt itas pratyakṣa anumāna viṣaye prasiddha ubhaya viśeṣasya bhavati iti evam anadhyavasāyasya api vilakṣaṇam eva kāraṇam uktam tad viparītāni tu svapna jñāna utpattau kāraṇāni iti kāraṇa bhedāt bhedaḥ lakṣaṇa bhede pi abheda abhyu
translated: Some say this is not correct, because it is different from error etc. due to the difference in its cause etc. Indeed, erroneous knowledge arises in a person whose senses are affected by bile, phlegm, and wind, regarding the object of perception and inference. Doubt, on the other hand, arises from the perception of a common characteristic regarding the object of perception and inference, and has both well-known and unknown aspects. Thus, even indecision is said to have a distinct cause. But the causes of the arising of dream knowledge are different from those. Thus, it is different due to the difference in causes. Even if there is a difference in definition, if non-difference is accepted, then that would be the case everywhere. Similarly, dream knowledge arises even regarding a completely unknown object, and not so in the case of error etc. Therefore, even if the presence of characteristics like grasping both is possible, dream knowledge is to be accepted as different from doubt etc. because the definition of dream is applicable.

original: svapnabhedāḥ
analyzed: svapna bhedāḥ
translated: Distinction of dreams

original: tattu trividham / saṃskārapāṭavāt dhātudoṣāt / adṛṣṭācca /PDhS
analyzed: tat tu trividham saṃskāra pāṭavāt dhātu doṣāt adṛṣṭāt ca
translated: That is of three kinds: from the sharpness of impressions, from the humors of the body, and from unseen [causes].

original: tatra saṃskārapāṭavāt tāvat kāmī kruddho vā yadā yamarthamādṛtaścintayan svapiti tadā saiva cintāsantatiḥ pratyakṣākārā sañjāyate /PDhS
analyzed: tatra saṃskāra pāṭavāt tāvat kāmī kruddhaḥ vā yadā yam artham ādṛtaḥ cintayan svapiti tadā sā eva cintā santatiḥ pratyakṣa ākārā sañjāyate
translated: Among them, first, from the sharpness of impressions: when a lustful or angry person, being attentive to a certain object while thinking, falls asleep, then that very continuity of thought arises in the form of perception.

original: dhātudoṣāt / vātaprakṛtistaddūṣito vā ākāśagamanādīn paśyati / pittaprakṛtiḥ pittadūṣito vā agnipraveśakanakaparvatādīn paśyati / śleṣmaprakṛtiḥ śleṣmadūṣito vā saritsamudraprataraṇahimaparvatādīn paśyati /PDhS
analyzed: dhātu doṣāt vāta prakṛtiḥ tad dūṣitaḥ vā ākāśa gamana ādīn paśyati pitta prakṛtiḥ pitta dūṣitaḥ vā agni praveśa kanaka parvata ādīn paśyati śleṣma prakṛtiḥ śleṣma dūṣitaḥ vā sarit samudra prataraṇa hima parvata ādīn paśyati
translated: From the humors of the body: one of windy constitution, or one afflicted by wind, sees flying through the air and so on; one of bilious constitution, or one afflicted by bile, sees entering fire, golden mountains, and so on; one of phlegmatic constitution, or one afflicted by phlegm, sees crossing rivers and oceans, snowy mountains, and so on.

original: yat svayamanubhūteṣvananubhūteṣu vā prasiddhārtheṣvaprasiddhārtheṣu vā yacchubhāvedakaṃ gajārohaṇacchatralābhādi tat sarvaṃ saṃskāradharmābhyāṃ bhavati / viparītañca tailābhyañjanakharoṣṭrārohaṇādi tat sarvamadharmasaṃskārābhyāṃ bhavati /PDhS
analyzed: yat svayam anubhūteṣu an anubhūteṣu vā prasiddha artheṣu aprasiddha artheṣu vā yat śubha āvedakam gaja ārohaṇa chatra lābha ādi tat sarvam saṃskāra dharmābhyām bhavati viparītam ca taila abhyañjana khara uṣṭra ārohaṇa ādi tat sarvam adharma saṃskārābhyām bhavati
translated: Whatever is pleasant, such as riding an elephant, obtaining an umbrella, and so on, whether experienced or not, well-known or not, all that arises from good dharmas and impressions. And the opposite, such as anointing with oil, riding a donkey or camel, and so on, all that arises from bad dharmas and impressions.

original: atyantāprasiddhārtheṣvadṛṣṭādeveti /PDhS
analyzed: atyanta aprasiddha artheṣu adṛṣṭāt eva iti
translated: In the case of utterly unknown objects, it arises only from the unseen [causes].

original: tasya kāraṇabhedād bhedamāha tattu svapnajñānam / trividham saṃskārapāṭavād dhātudoṣād adṛṣṭācca iti / saṃskārapāṭavāt tāvat svapnajñānamāha kāmī yasyāmaṅganāyāmanuraktastāmādṛto 'tiśayena prayatnayuktaścintayan / kruddho vāyaṃ śatruṃ prayatnāccintayan svapiti / saiva suptasya / cintāsantatiḥ pratyakṣākārā sañjāyate nādṛṣṭāt /
analyzed: tasya kāraṇa bhedāt bhedam āha tat tu svapna jñānam trividham saṃskāra pāṭavāt dhātu doṣāt adṛṣṭāt ca iti saṃskāra pāṭavāt tāvat svapna jñānam āha kāmī yasyām aṅganāyām anuraktaḥ tām ādṛtaḥ u tiśayena prayatna yuktaḥ cintayan kruddhaḥ vā ayam śatrum prayatnāt cintayan svapiti sā eva suptasya cintā santatiḥ pratyakṣa ākārā sañjāyate na adṛṣṭāt
translated: He states its division due to the difference in its causes: That dream cognition is of three kinds - due to the vividness of impressions, to the fault of the elements, and to the unseen. First, due to the vividness of impressions, the dream cognition is stated: One who is attached to a certain woman, thinking of her with great respect and effort, or one who is angry and thinking of an enemy with effort goes to sleep. That very continuity of thought of the sleeping person arises in the form of direct perception, not from the unseen.

original: dhātudoṣāt svapnamāha vātaprakṛtiḥ vātamadhikaṃ nimittamapekṣamāṇaiḥ paramāṇubhirārabdhaḥ / vātadūṣitaśca tathāvidhāhāropagamād ākāśādigamanāni paśyati / evaṃ pittaprakṛtirityādāvapi draṣṭavyam /
analyzed: dhātu doṣāt svapnam āha vāta prakṛtiḥ vātam adhikam nimittam apekṣamāṇaiḥ paramāṇubhiḥ ārabdhaḥ vāta dūṣitaḥ ca tathāvidha āhāra upagamāt ākāśa ādi gamanāni paśyati evam pitta prakṛtiḥ ityādau api draṣṭavyam
translated: Due to the fault of the elements, the dream is stated: One of a windy constitution, whose atoms are produced in excess by the fault of wind, and who has consumed food that is vitiated by wind, sees such things as traveling through space and so on. The same should be seen in the case of one of a bilious constitution and so on.

original: adṛṣṭakāritaṃ svapnamāha yatsvayamanubhūteṣvananubhūteṣu artheṣu / prasiddheṣvaprasiddheṣu vā śubhāvedakamutpadyate svapnajñānaṃ tadadṛṣṭāt / tatra yad gajārohaṇacchatralābhādiśubhāvedakaṃ tat sarvaṃ saṃskāradharmābhyām utpadyate / saṃskāro hi pūrvānubhavajanitaḥ / sa ca smṛtyutpattidvāreṇa svapnajñānotpattau kāraṇam /
analyzed: adṛṣṭa kāritam svapnam āha yat svayam anubhūteṣu ananubhūteṣu artheṣu prasiddheṣu aprasiddheṣu vā śubhā vedakam utpadyate svapna jñānam tat adṛṣṭāt tatra yat gaja ārohaṇa chatra lābha ādi śubhā vedakam tat sarvam saṃskāra dharmābhyām utpadyate saṃskāraḥ hi pūrva anubhava janitaḥ sa ca smṛti utpatti dvāreṇa svapna jñāna utpattau kāraṇam
translated: The dream knowledge that arises from unseen causes, regarding things experienced or not experienced, well-known or unknown, conveying auspiciousness, that arises from the unseen. There, that which conveys auspiciousness such as riding an elephant, obtaining an umbrella, etc., all that arises from impressions and the nature of things. For impression is produced by previous experience, and that is the cause for the arising of dream knowledge through the door of the arising of memory.

original: viparītamaśubhāvedakam tailābhyañjanakharoṣṭrārohaṇādi taccādharmasaṃskārābhyāṃ bhavati /
analyzed: viparītam aśubha āvedakam taila abhyañjana khara uṣṭra ārohaṇa ādi tat ca adharma saṃskārābhyām bhavati
translated: The opposite, conveying inauspiciousness such as oil massage, riding a donkey or camel, etc., that arises from non-dharmic impressions.

original: atyantāprasiddheṣu ananubhūteṣvadṛṣṭādeva svapnajñānamutpadyate / tathāhi / brahmādipadārūḍhātmānaṃ paśyatīti /
analyzed: atyanta aprasiddheṣu ananubhūteṣu adṛṣṭāt eva svapna jñānam utpadyate tathā hi brahma ādi pada ārūḍha ātmānam paśyati iti
translated: Regarding things utterly unknown, not experienced, dream knowledge arises only from the unseen. For example, one sees oneself mounted on Brahma and other beings.

original: svapnāntikaṃ yadyapyuparatendriyagrāmasya bhavati tathāpyatītajñānaprabandhapratyavekṣaṇāt smṛtireveti bhavatyeṣā caturvidhā avidyeti /PDhS
analyzed: svapnāntikam yadi api uparata indriya grāmasya bhavati tathā api atīta jñāna prabandha pratyavekṣaṇāt smṛtiḥ eva iti bhavati eṣā caturvidhā avidyā iti pdhs
translated: Although the dream knowledge occurs when the collection of sense faculties has ceased, it is still memory because it examines the continuum of past knowledge. Thus, this ignorance is of four kinds.

original: atha svapnāntaṃ svapnajñānameva / āhosvidarthāntaramityāha svapnāntikam svapnānte svapnāvasāne bhavaṃ svapnāntikam / yadyapyuparatendriyagrāmasya bhavati tathāpi smṛtireveti / atītajñānaprabandhapratyavekṣaṇāt iti / II / atītaścāsau jñānaprabandhaśca tasmin pratyavekṣaṇarūpatvāt smṛtireveti /
analyzed: atha svapnāntam svapna jñānam eva āhosvit artha antaram iti āha svapnāntikam svapnānte svapna avasāne bhavam svapnāntikam yadi api uparata indriya grāmasya bhavati tathā api smṛtiḥ eva iti atīta jñāna prabandha pratyavekṣaṇāt iti    atītaḥ ca asau jñāna prabandhaḥ ca tasmin pratyavekṣaṇa rūpa tvāt smṛtiḥ eva iti
translated: Now, is the knowledge of the end of dreams itself, or is it something else? He says: The end of dreams is that which occurs at the end of dreams, at the conclusion of dreams. Although it occurs for one whose sense faculties have ceased, it is still memory, because it is the inspection of the past continuum of knowledge. It is past and it is also the continuum of knowledge, because it has the form of inspection, it is still memory.

original: evaṃ yathoktarūpā caturvidhā bhavatyavidyetyupasaṃhāraḥ /
analyzed: evam yathā ukta rūpā caturvidhā bhavati avidyā iti upasaṃhāraḥ
translated: Thus, ignorance has the form described above and is of four kinds, this is the conclusion.

original: anye tu eṣā yathā mayā vyākhyātā tathā caturvidhā bhavatyavidyā / anyathā hi vividhaiveti /
analyzed: anye tu eṣā yathā mayā vyākhyātā tathā caturvidhā bhavati avidyā anyathā hi vividhā evā iti
translated: Others say: Ignorance is of four kinds as I have explained it. For if it were otherwise, it would be manifold.

original: vidyāvaidharmye tadbhedakathanam
translated: The explanation of the difference between ignorance and knowledge

original: vidyāpi caturvidhā / pratyakṣalaiṅgikasmṛtyārṣalakṣaṇā /PDhS
analyzed: vidyā api caturvidhā pratyakṣa laiṅgika smṛti ārṣa lakṣaṇā
translated: Knowledge is also of four kinds: direct perception, inference, memory, and scriptural testimony.

original: athedānīṃ vidyāsvarūpanirūpaṇārthaṃ na kevalamavidyā vidyāpi caturvidhā ityādi prakaraṇam / kena rūpeṇetyāha pratyakṣalaiṅgikasmṛtyārṣalakṣaṇā tatsvarūpeti / pratyaṣṭiḥ pratyakṣam / liṅgadarśanāt sañjāyamānaṃ laiṅgikam / smaraṇaṃ smṛtiḥ / ṛṣīṇāmidaṃ jñānam / ārṣamiti /
analyzed: atha idānīm vidyā svarūpa nirūpaṇa artham na kevalam avidyā vidyā api caturvidhā ityādi prakaraṇam kena rūpeṇa iti āha pratyakṣa laiṅgika smṛti ārṣa lakṣaṇā tad svarūpā iti pratyaṣṭiḥ pratyakṣam liṅga darśanāt sañjāyamānam laiṅgikam smaraṇam smṛtiḥ ṛṣīṇām idam jñānam ārṣam iti
translated: Now, in order to describe the nature of knowledge, the section beginning with Knowledge is also of four kinds is not just about ignorance, but also about knowledge. In what form? He says: It is characterized by perception, inference, memory, and the knowledge of the sages. That is its nature. Perception is direct. Inference arises from seeing the mark. Memory is recollection. This knowledge of the sages is called of the sages.

original: nanu śābdajñānasyāpi vidyārūpatvādihānupanyāse kiṃ prayojanam / vipratipattijñāpanamiti / tathā hi / śābdamanumāne 'ntarbhavatīti kecit / anye tu pramāṇāntaramiti vaiśeṣikāṇāṃ vipratipattistenehānabhidhānam / atra tu vidyāvibhāgapareṇāpi vākyenopasarjanatayā tajjanakamapi sāmagryāṃ pratijñātameva / prādhānyena tu karaṇavyutpattidvāreṇa pratyakṣādivibhāgābhyupagame vidyāvibhāganirūpaṇamupasarjanatayā syāt / tattu na yuktam / buddhibhedasya pūrvaṃ pratijñātasyeha nirūpaṇāt /
analyzed: nanu śābda jñānasya api vidyā rūpa tvāt iha anupanyāse kim prayojanam vipratipatti jñāpanam iti tathā hi śābdam anumāne ntarbhavati iti kecid anye tu pramāṇa antaram iti vaiśeṣikāṇām vipratipattiḥ tena iha anabhidhānam atra tu vidyā vibhāga pareṇa api vākyena upasarjanatayā tat janakam api sāmagryām pratijñātam eva prādhānyena tu karaṇa vyutpatti dvāreṇa pratyakṣa ādi vibhāga abhyupagame vidyā vibhāga nirūpaṇam upasarjanatayā syāt tat tu na yuktam budd
translated: But since verbal cognition also is a form of knowledge, what is the purpose of not mentioning it here? To show the disagreement. Thus, some think that verbal cognition is included in inference, while others consider it a separate means of knowledge. The Vaisheshikas disagree on this point. Therefore, it is not mentioned here. But even by a statement concerned with the division of knowledge, the cause of that is promised in the collection as a subordinate factor. But if the division of perception etc. is accepted through the derivation of the instrument as primary, the determination of the division of knowledge would be subordinate. But that is not proper, because the determination of the previously promised difference of cognition is being presented here.

original: nirvikalpakapratyakṣanirūpaṇam
analyzed: nirvikalpaka pratyakṣa nirūpaṇam
translated: The definition of indeterminate perception

original: tatrākṣamakṣaṃ pratītyotpadyata iti pratyakṣam / akṣāṇīndriyāṇi ghrāṇarasanacakṣustvakchrotramanāṃsi ṣaṭ / taddhi dravyādiṣu padārtheṣūtpadyate / dravye tāvat trividhe mahatyanekadravyavattvodbhūtarūpaprakāśacatuṣṭayasannikarṣād dharmādisāmagrye ca svarūpālocanamātram /PDhS
analyzed: tatra akṣam akṣam pratītya utpadyate iti pratyakṣam akṣāṇi indriyāṇi ghrāṇa rasana cakṣuḥ tvac śrotra manāṃsi ṣaḍ tat hi dravya ādiṣu padārtheṣu utpadyate dravye tāvat trividhe mahati aneka dravyavat tva udbhūta rūpa prakāśa catuṣṭaya sannikarṣāt dharma ādi sāmagrye ca sva rūpa ālocana mātram
translated: Among them, pratyakṣa is that which arises in dependence on the senses. The senses are the six: nose, tongue, eyes, skin, ears, and mind. It arises in regard to substances and so on. First, in a substance, which is of three kinds, there is mere perception of its own form from the contact of the four: the great one, many substances, inherent form, and light, and the assemblage of dharma and so on.

original: tatra pratyakṣasya nirūpaṇārthamāha akṣamakṣaṃ pratītyotpadyata iti pratyakṣam / pratigatamakṣaṃ pratyakṣamiti prādisamāsaḥ / anyathāvyayībhāvasamāsābhyupagame pratyakṣaṃ rūpam / pratyakṣāḥ pumāṃsaḥ / pratyakṣā strīti liṅgabhedo vacanabhedaśca na syāt / akṣamakṣamiti vīpsāvidhānaṃ sakalendriyāvarodhārtham / athākṣamiti sāmānyaśabdāt sakalendriyāvarodho bhavatyeva / na / sāmānyaśabdasyobhayathāpi pravṛtteḥ / tathāhi / brāhmaṇo na hantavyaḥ iti sakalabrāhmaṇāII /pekṣayā pratiṣedhaḥ / brāhmaṇān bhojaya iti brāhmaṇaviśeṣāpekṣayā niyogaḥ / tasmād vyāptyarthaṃ vīpsākaraṇamiti / atha vīpsāsadbhāve 'pi vyāptirnopalabdhā / yathā antarvedyāṃ grāmaḥ / grāmo ramaṇīyaḥ / ramaṇīyaḥ puruṣaḥ / puruṣe guṇaviśeṣa iti vīpsākaraṇamatra / satyam / tathāpyalpasaṃkhyāyogini padārthe vyāptāveva vīpsopalabdheti /
analyzed: tatra pratyakṣasya nirūpaṇa artham āha akṣam akṣam pratītya utpadyate iti pratyakṣam pratigatam akṣam pratyakṣam iti prādi samāsaḥ anyathā avyayībhāva samāsa abhyupagame pratyakṣam rūpam pratyakṣāḥ pumāṃsaḥ pratyakṣā strī iti liṅga bhedaḥ vacana bhedaḥ ca na syāt akṣam akṣam iti vīpsā vidhānam sakala indriya avarodha artham atha akṣam iti sāmānya śabdāt sakala indriya avarodhaḥ bhavati eva na sāmānya śabdasya ubhayathā api pravṛtteḥ ta
translated: To explain perception, he says: Perception arises in dependence on the sense faculty and the object, hence it is perception. The compound pratyakṣa is a tatpuruṣa compound meaning that which has the sense faculty as its object. Otherwise, if it were accepted as a dvandva compound, there would be a difference in gender and number, such as pratyakṣaṃ rūpam, pratyakṣāḥ pumāṃsaḥ, and pratyakṣā strī, which would not be possible. The repetition akṣam akṣam is stated for the purpose of including all sense faculties. If it is argued that the inclusion of all sense faculties follows from the general term akṣam, that is not so. Because a general term can be used in both ways. For example, in the statement A Brahmin should not be killed, the prohibition is based on all Brahmins. In the statement Feed the Brahmins, the injunction is based on a specific Brahmin. Therefore, the repetition is used for the purpose of including all. Even if the repetition is present, the inclusion is not understood, just as in A village within the altar, A beautiful village, A beautiful man, In a man, the qualities are...

original: anye tu dvitīyākṣapadamavadhāraṇārthamiti manyante / akṣameva pratītya prāpya yadutpadyate jñānaṃ tatpratyakṣam / atha jñānasyānutpannatvād akṣeṇa prāptirnāstīti kathamakṣaṃ prāpyotpadyate / upacārasya vivakṣitatvādadoṣaḥ / yathāhi / śiśuraya mātaraṃ bhakṣayitvopajāta iti / ata evākṣāśritaṃ kāryamiti / tattvena tajjñānamiti / indriyarūpādiścendriyāśrito na ca jñānamiti /
analyzed: anye tu dvitīya akṣa padam avadhāraṇa artham iti manyante akṣam eva pratītya prāpya yat utpadyate jñānam tat pratyakṣam  atha jñānasya anutpanna tvāt akṣeṇa prāptiḥ na asti iti katham akṣam prāpya utpadyate upacārasya vivakṣita tvāt adoṣaḥ yathā hi śiśuḥ aya mātaram bhakṣayitvā upajātaḥ iti atas eva akṣa āśritam kāryam iti tattvena tat jñānam iti indriya rūpa ādiḥ ca indriya āśritaḥ na ca jñānam iti
translated: Others, however, consider the second pada of the verse to be for the purpose of restriction. That knowledge which arises in dependence on the sense faculty, having attained it, is pratyakṣa. But if knowledge has not yet arisen, there is no attainment by the sense faculty. So how does it arise having attained the sense faculty? There is no fault, because figurative usage is intended. For example, This child was born having eaten his mother. For this very reason, it is the effect based on the sense faculties. That knowledge is so in reality. And form, etc. of the sense faculties are based on the sense faculties, but knowledge is not.

original: nanvevamapi saṃśayajñānañcākṣaṃ pratītyotpadyata ityatiprasaṅgaḥ / tanna / vidyāsāmānyalakṣaṇānuvṛttistu viśeṣalakṣaṇe 'nukte 'pi labhyata iti / vakṣyati ca yadavitathamavyapadeśyaṃ jñānamutpadyate tatpratyakṣaṃ pramāṇam iti / na vitathamavitathamityanena viparyayasaṃśayajñānayorvyudāsaḥ / vitathaṃ hi saṃśayajñānaṃ vipayayajñānañceti /
analyzed: nanu evam api saṃśaya jñānam ca akṣam pratītya utpadyate iti atiprasaṅgaḥ tat na vidyā sāmānya lakṣaṇa anuvṛttiḥ tu viśeṣa lakṣaṇe labhyate iti vakṣyati ca yat avitatham avyapadeśyam jñānam utpadyate tat pratyakṣam pramāṇam iti na vitatham avitatham iti anena viparyaya saṃśaya jñānayoḥ vyudāsaḥ vitatham hi saṃśaya jñānam vipaya ya jñānam ca iti
translated: Even so, there is the contingence of the knowledge of doubt arising on the basis of perception. That is not so. The continuity of the general characteristic of knowledge is obtained even when the specific characteristic is not stated. He will say: That knowledge which arises as non-erroneous and inexpressible is perception, a means of valid knowledge. The words non-erroneous and erroneous exclude doubt and erroneous knowledge. For doubt is erroneous knowledge, and erroneous knowledge is also erroneous.

original: anye tu pratitantranyāyena vyavasāyātmakapadamanuvartanīyamiti manyante / avyapadeśyamiti / vyapadeśaḥ śabdastasyedaṃ vyapadeśyam / na vyapadeśyamavyapadeśyam aśabdajanyaṃ jñānamiti / nanvakṣaṃ prāpya notpadyate śābdajñānamityanenaiva vyavacchinnam / na / indriyasahakāriṇā śabdena yajjanyate tasya vyavacchedārthatvāt / tathāhi / akṛtasamayo rūpaṃ paśyannapi cakṣuṣā rūpamiti na jānīte / rūpamiti śabdoccāraṇānantaraṃ pratipadyata ityubhayajaṃ jñānam /
analyzed: anye tu prati tantra nyāyena vyavasāya ātmaka padam anuvartanīyam iti manyante avyapadeśyam iti vyapadeśaḥ śabdaḥ tasya idam vyapadeśyam na vyapadeśyam avyapadeśyam aśabda janyam jñānam iti nanu akṣam prāpya na utpadyate śābda jñānam iti anena eva vyavacchinnam na indriya sahakāriṇā śabdena yat janyate tasya vyavaccheda artha tvāt tathā hi akṛta samayaḥ rūpam paśyan api cakṣuṣā rūpam iti na jānīte rūpam iti śabda uccāraṇa anantaram pratipadyate iti ubhaya j
translated: Others, however, think that the word determinate should be repeated according to the principle of each treatise. Non-verbal means that which is to be designated by words. That which is not to be designated is non-verbal, i.e., knowledge not produced by words. But is not verbal knowledge produced by coming into contact with the sense organs? It is excluded by this very [statement]. No, because it is meant to exclude that which is produced by words that assist the sense organs. For example, even when seeing form without having made an agreement [about the meaning of the word form], one does not know it as form. One understands it as form after the utterance of the word form, so knowledge is produced by both [sense organ and word].

original: nanu ca śabdendriyayorekasminneva kāle vyāpārāsambhavādayuktametat / tathāhi / manasādhiṣṭhitantu śrotraṃ śabdaṃ gṛhṇāti / punaḥ kriyākrameṇa cakṣuṣā sambandhe sati rūpagrahaṇam / na ca śabdajñānasyaitāvatkālamavasthānaṃ sambhavatīti kathamubhayajaṃ jñānam / atraikā śrotrasambaddhe manasi kriyotpannā vibhāgamārabhate / vibhāgācca yadaiva saṃyogasya vinaśyattā tadaiva śabdajñānasyotpadyamānatā / tataḥ II / śabdajñānasyotpādaḥ / saṃyogasya vināśaḥ / uttarasaṃyogasyotpadyamānatā tato viṣayasambaddhena cakṣuṣā saha saṃyogasyotpādo rūpajñānasyotpadyamānatā / tataḥ svajñānasahāyaśabdasahakāriṇā cakṣuṣā rūpajñānamutpadyate ityubhayajaṃ jñānam /
analyzed: nanu ca śabda indriyayoḥ ekasmin eva kāle vyāpāra asambhavāt ayuktam etat tathā hi manasā adhiṣṭhita ntu śrotram śabdam gṛhṇāti punar kriyā krameṇa cakṣuṣā sambandhe sati rūpa grahaṇam na ca śabda jñānasya etāvatkālam avasthānam sambhavati iti katham ubhaya jam jñānam atra ekā śrotra sambaddhe manasi kriyā utpannā vibhāgam ārabhate vibhāgāt ca yadā eva saṃyogasya vinaśyat tā tadā eva śabda jñānasya utpadyamāna tā tatas śabda jñānasya utpādaḥ s
translated: But this is not proper, because the operation of the word and sense organs is not possible at the same time. For, the ear controlled by the mind grasps the sound. Then, in the sequence of action, when there is connection with the eye, there is grasping of form. And since the knowledge of sound cannot last for that long, how can there be knowledge arising from both? In this case, an action arises in the mind connected with the ear, which produces separation. And at the very moment when the conjunction is destroyed, the knowledge of sound is produced. Then, the production of the knowledge of sound, the destruction of the conjunction, the production of the subsequent conjunction, then the production of the conjunction with the eye connected with the object, the production of the knowledge of form. Then, the knowledge of form arises from the eye assisted by its own knowledge and the cooperation of sound, thus the knowledge arising from both.

original: yad vā gṛhītasya śabdasyārthaparicchede vyāpāra ityayaṃ niyamo nāvaśyaṃ grahaṇasahakāriṇā iti / kālāntareṇāpi manasaścakṣuṣā sambandhe rūpaśabdasya gṛhītatvāt bhavatyevobhayajaṃ jñānam / kāryasadbhāvena ca kāraṇakalpanā kriyate / taccehopalabdhamityanena krameṇotpattiścintyate / tathā śabdena vyapadeśāccakṣuṣā paśyatāpi rūpamiti mayā na jñātaṃ rūpaśabdācca pratipannamityubhayajaṃ jñānam / yādi śabdasya vyāpārādapratyakṣaṃ tarhi indriyavyāpārānna śābdamiti pramāṇāntaraphalaṃ syāt / naitadevam / pratyakṣalakṣaṇe 'vyapadeśyamiti viśeṣaṇavacchabdalakṣaṇe 'nindriyajamiti viśeṣaṇāśravaṇāt śabde sahakāriniyamābhāvaḥ / śābdaṃ hi jñānaṃ śabdādindriyasahakāriṇaḥ / tadrahitād vā bhavatu sarvathā tajjanakaṃ śābdaṃ pramāṇaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: yat vā gṛhītasya śabdasya artha paricchede vyāpāraḥ iti ayam niyamaḥ na avaśyam grahaṇa sahakāriṇā iti kāla antareṇa api manasaḥ cakṣuṣā sambandhe rūpa śabdasya gṛhīta tvāt bhavati eva ubhaya jam jñānam kārya sadbhāvena ca kāraṇa kalpanā kriyate tat ca iha upalabdham iti anena krameṇa utpattiḥ cintyate tathā śabdena vyapadeśāt cakṣuṣā paśyatā api rūpam iti mayā na jñātam rūpa śabdāt ca pratipannam iti ubhaya jam jñānam  /
translated: Or, the rule that the function of the apprehended sound is in the determination of meaning does not necessarily require that it should be a concomitant of apprehension. Even when the mind is related to the eye at a later time, since the form and sound are already apprehended, the knowledge arising from both does indeed occur. And the postulation of a cause is done by the existence of the effect. And this is perceived here. In this way, the origination is contemplated. Similarly, because of the designation by the word, even when seeing with the eye, one says I did not know the form, but understood it from the word form, so the knowledge is arising from both. If it is not directly perceived due to the operation of the word, then the result of the other means of knowledge would be from the operation of the sense organ. This is not so. In the definition of perception, the qualification indeterminate is used, but in the definition of verbal knowledge, the qualification not produced by the sense organ is not mentioned. Therefore, there is no restriction on the cooperation of the word. Verbal knowledge may arise from the sense organ cooperating with the word, or from that which lacks it. In any case, it is born from that.

original: atra cākṣaṃ pratītyotpadyate yajjñānaṃ tatpratyakṣamiti vākye vivaraṇavākyeṣū catuṣṭayādisannikarṣābhidhānāt ṣoḍhā sambandho labhyata eva / sa ca saṃyogaḥ / saṃyuktasamavāyaḥ / saṃyuktasamavetasamavāyaḥ / samavāyaḥ / samavetasamavāyo / viśeṣaṇaviśeṣyabhāvaśceti /
analyzed: atra ca akṣam pratītya utpadyate yat jñānam tat pratyakṣam iti vākye vivaraṇa vākyeṣu catuṣṭaya ādi sannikarṣa abhidhānāt ṣoḍhā sambandhaḥ labhyate eva sa ca saṃyogaḥ saṃyukta samavāyaḥ saṃyukta samaveta samavāyaḥ samavāyaḥ samaveta samavāyaḥ viśeṣaṇa viśeṣya bhāvaḥ ca iti
translated: And in the sentence That knowledge which arises in dependence on the sense faculty is perception, and in the explanatory sentences, since the contact of the four and so on is mentioned, the sixfold relation is indeed obtained, and that is conjunction, inherence in the conjoined, inherence in the inherence in the conjoined, inherence, inherence in the inhering, and the relation of qualifier and qualified.

original: nanvevamapīndriyārthasannikarṣapadenaiva vyavacchinnam / athendriyaṃ mano 'rthaścātmā tatsannikarṣād anumānādijñānamapi bhavatīti pratyakṣaphalaṃ syāt / na / jñānamātrotpattāvantaḥkaraṇasyendriyatvānupapatteḥ / karaṇatvādiviśeṣaṇasyāparokṣajñānajanakatvamindriyalakṣaṇamityuktam / na cānumānajñānamindriyagrāhye 'rthe bhavatīti / tadevamindriyaṃ pratītyārthe yadavitathamavyapadeśyaṃ vyavasāyātmakaṃ jñānamutpadyate / tad yato bhavati tat pratyakṣamiti phalaviśeṣaṇapakṣaḥ / etāni tvavyabhicāritvādīni vyavacchedakāni atīte 'pi viśeṣyajñāne buddhisamāropaṇād bhavantīti /
analyzed: nanu evam api indriya artha sannikarṣa padena eva vyavacchinnam atha indriyam manaḥ rthaḥ ca ātmā tad sannikarṣāt anumāna ādi jñānam api bhavati iti pratyakṣa phalam syāt na jñāna mātra utpattau antaḥkaraṇasya indriya tva anupapatteḥ karaṇa tva ādi viśeṣaṇasya aparokṣa jñāna janaka tvam indriya lakṣaṇam iti uktam na ca anumāna jñānam indriya grāhye rthe bhavati iti tat evam indriyam pratītya arthe yat avitatham avyapadeśyam vyavasāya ātmakam jñānam utpad
translated: But even so, it would be excluded by the phrase 'contact of sense and object'. If it be said that the soul, the sense, the mind and the object, their contact, would also be the result of perception, because inference, etc. also arise from that, we say no. Because when mere knowledge arises, the internal organ cannot be a sense. It has been said that the definition of a sense is that which produces non-deceptive, inexpressible, determinate knowledge. And an inference is not a knowledge of an object apprehended by a sense. Thus, the result-qualification theory is that perception is that knowledge which arises in regard to an object, depending on a sense, which is non-erroneous, inexpressible, and determinate. But these qualifications such as non-deviation, etc. are also present in the knowledge of a qualified past object, because they are superimposed on the cognition.

original: sāmagrīviśeṣaṇapakṣe tu na sākṣādavyabhicāritvādiviśeṣaṇayogaḥ / athāII /kṣamakṣaṃ pratītyotpadyate sāmagrī / tasyāḥ kārakasākalyarūpatvāt / sākalyantu caramasahakāriprāptāveva na pūrvamityutpadyata eva / tathā jñāyate 'nayeti jñānamakṣādyupalakṣitā sāmagryeva avyabhicāri / vyavasāyātmikā / avyapadeśyapadena jñānajanakatvena sāmagryāstad vyapadeśa iti sāmagrīviśeṣaṇapakṣe 'pi viśeṣaṇayogaḥ / satyam / tathāpi avyabhicāritvādiviśeṣaṇāni phalasya / taddvāreṇa tu sāmagryā bhavantīti paraṃ phalaviśeṣaṇapakṣaḥ /
analyzed: sāmagrī viśeṣaṇa pakṣe tu na sākṣāt avyabhicāri tva ādi viśeṣaṇa yogaḥ pratītya utpadyate sāmagrī tasyāḥ kāraka sākalya rūpa tvāt sākalyan tu carama sahakāri prāptau eva na pūrvam iti utpadyate eva tathā jñāyate naya iti jñānam akṣa ādi upalakṣitā sāmagrī eva avyabhicāri vyavasāya ātmikā avyapadeśya padena jñāna janaka tvena sāmagryāḥ tat vyapadeśaḥ iti sāmagrī viśeṣaṇa pakṣe pi viśeṣaṇa yogaḥ satyam tathā api avyabhicāri tva
translated: But in the view that the collection is qualified, there is no direct connection with the qualifications of infallibility, etc. Now, the collection arises in dependence on the capable and the incapable, because it consists in the totality of the causes. And the totality occurs only when the final auxiliary is reached, not before, so it arises only then. Thus, it is known by this, so the collection itself, indicated by the sense organ etc., is infallible, determinate, and nondiscriminative. By the word nondiscriminative, the collection is discriminated by the fact of generating knowledge. So even in the view that the collection is qualified, there is a connection with the qualifications. True, but infallibility, etc. are qualities of the result. But they belong to the collection by way of that, so the other view is that the result is qualified.

original: svarūpaviśeṣaṇapakṣastu nirasta eva / pramāṇaśabdasya karaṇārthatvāt / tathāhi / pramīyate 'neneti pramāṇam / yena kartṛkarmavilakṣaṇena pramā kriyate / svarūpaviśeṣaṇapakṣe tu na janyajanakarūpatayā pramāṇasya prāmāṇyam / kintvavyabhicāritvādidharmopetatvenaiva / taccātivyāpakamavyāpakañca / tathā ca parāmarśādijñānasyāpyevaṃ rūpamasti / na ca tasya pratyakṣatvam / anumitijanakatvenānumānatvāt / sāmagryāstu pratyakṣatvenābhimatāyāḥ pratyakṣatvaṃ na labhyata ityavyāptiḥ /
analyzed: svarūpa viśeṣaṇa pakṣaḥ tu nirastaḥ eva pramāṇa śabdasya karaṇa artha tvāt tathā hi pramīyate nena iti pramāṇam yena kartṛ karma vilakṣaṇena pramā kriyate svarūpa viśeṣaṇa pakṣe tu na janya janaka rūpatayā pramāṇasya prāmāṇyam kintu avyabhicāri tva ādi dharma upeta tvena eva tat ca ati vyāpakam avyāpakam ca  / tathā ca parāmarśa ādi jñānasya api evam rūpam asti na ca tasya pratyakṣa tvam anumiti janaka tvena anumāna tvāt sāmagryāḥ tu pratya
translated: As for the view that it is a qualifier of the form, that has already been refuted, because the word 'pramāṇa' means an instrument. For, it is said to be pramāṇa because it is by this that one is made to know (pramīyate). By that which is different from the agent and the object, knowledge (prama) is produced. But if it were a qualifier of the form, then pramāṇa would not have the nature of being produced and a producer, but would have the nature of being non-deviating and possessing other properties. And that is too wide and not wide enough. And thus, such a form exists even in the knowledge that is a reflection and so on. And that is not perception, because it is inference due to generating inference. And the collection, which is accepted as perception, does not attain the nature of perception. Thus, there is over-extension.

original: saugatānāntu pramāṇaphalayoravyatireka iti tatpakṣe svarūpaviśeṣaṇataiva ghaṭate / tathā hi / sautrāntikānāmākāraḥ pramāṇaṃ prameyo 'rthaḥ svasaṃvit phalamiṣyata iti jñānaṃ sa eva pramāṇaphalavyavahāraḥ kalpanaṃ vā / na caitad yuktam / kriyākaraṇayorabhedānupalabdheḥ / na ca bodhe viṣayākāraḥ sambhavatītyuktam / kathaṃ tasya prāmāṇyam / na ca meyarūpatayā viṣayaparicchedye prāmāṇyaṃ yuktam / viṣayasyātyantaparokṣatayā tena saha pratibandhānupalabdheḥ / yadi cāgṛhītapratibandho vyāpāro viṣayaviśeṣaṃ gamayet atiprasaṅgaḥ syāt / tathā ca rūpākārasya rūpavad rasādivyavasthāpakatvamapi syāt / ubhayatrāpi pratibandhānupalambhasyāviśeṣāt / na cākāramātrasaṃvedanavādino viṣayaviśeṣāntaragrahaṇam ākāre sambhavati / viṣayasyātyantaparokṣatve 'vasthitasya pratisandhāturabhāve ca anvayavyatirekayoratyantaparokṣatvāt /
analyzed: saugatānām tu pramāṇa phalayoḥ avyatirekaḥ iti tad pakṣe svarūpa viśeṣaṇa tā eva ghaṭate tathā hi sautrāntikānām ākāraḥ pramāṇam prameyaḥ rthaḥ sva saṃvid phalam iṣyate iti jñānam saḥ eva pramāṇa phala vyavahāraḥ kalpanam vā na ca etat yuktam kriyā karaṇayoḥ abheda anupalabdheḥ na ca bodhe viṣaya ākāraḥ sambhavati iti uktam katham tasya prāmāṇyam na ca meya rūpa tayā viṣaya paricchedye prāmāṇyam yuktam viṣayasya atyanta parokṣa
translated: But for the Buddhists, the means of knowledge and its result are not different. Therefore, in their view, only the nature of a qualifier is appropriate. Thus, for the Sautrantikas, the form is the means of knowledge, the object is the object of knowledge, and self-awareness is considered the result. Thus, knowledge itself is the means and result of knowledge, or it is an assumption. But this is not correct. Because the means and the result are not observed to be non-different. And it has been said that the form of the object is not possible in consciousness. Then how can it be a means of valid knowledge? And it is not proper for a means of valid knowledge to be determined by the object in the form of the object, because the object is absolutely imperceptible, and the connection with it is not observed. And if an operation without a grasped connection were to indicate a particular object, there would be an overextension. And in that case, the form of color would also be a determiner of taste, etc., like color, because there would be no difference in the non-observation of a connection in both cases. And for those who maintain the awareness of form alone, there is no grasping of another particular object, because the form of the object is not grasped.

original: parakīyañca pratyakṣalakṣaṇaṃ gurubhirvistareṇa nirastamiti noktam /
analyzed: parakīyam ca pratyakṣa lakṣaṇam gurubhiḥ vistareṇa nirastam iti na uktam
translated: And the definition of perception accepted by others has been refuted in detail by our teachers, so it is not stated here.

original: akṣaśabdasyānekārthatvādāha akṣāṇīndriyāṇi / tāni tu ghrāṇarasanaII /cakṣustvakchrotramanāṃsi na karmendriyāṇi parābhyupagatāni / nirviṣayajñānasya pratiṣedhena smṛtivyavacchedārthamāha taddhi pratyakṣaṃ yasmāt dravyādiṣu padārtheṣūtpadyate tasmānna nirviṣayamiti / atra ca ādiśabdena guṇakarmasāmānyāni gṛhyante / samavāyo 'pītyanye /
analyzed: akṣa śabdasya aneka artha tvāt āha akṣāṇi indriyāṇi tāni tu na karmendriyāṇi para abhyupagatāni nirviṣaya jñānasya pratiṣedhena smṛti vyavaccheda artham āha tat hi pratyakṣam yasmāt dravya ādiṣu padārtheṣu utpadyate tasmāt na nirviṣayam iti atra ca ādi śabdena guṇa karma sāmānyāni gṛhyante samavāya u pi iti anye
translated: Since the word akṣa has many meanings, he says the sense faculties are the akṣas. But the nose, tongue, eye, skin, ear, and mind are not accepted by others as sense faculties. In order to exclude memory by negating cognition without an object, he says that is perception which arises in relation to substances and other categories, therefore it is not without an object. And here, others include qualities, actions, and universals in the word ādi.

original: anye tu indriyasyārthena sannikarṣapratipādanārthaṃ taddhi dravyādiṣu padārtheṣūtpadyate pratyakṣam / tasmādastīndriyeṇa saṃyuktasamavāyādisambandhaḥ /
analyzed: anye tu indriyasya arthena sannikarṣa pratipādana artham tat hi dravya ādiṣu padārtheṣu utpadyate pratyakṣam tasmāt asti indriyeṇa saṃyukta samavāya ādi sambandhaḥ
translated: But others say that in order to show that the sense faculty is in contact with the object, perception arises in relation to substances and other categories. Therefore, there is a relation of inherence in the sense faculty and so on.

original: yato vā dravyādiṣu padārtheṣūtpadyate pratyakṣamato dravye tāvat vyākhyāyata iti / kiṃ viśiṣṭe / trividhe tisro vidhā yasya tat tathoktaṃ tasmin / mahati mahattvādhikaraṇe svarūpālocanam nirvikalpakaṃ jñānamutpadyate / kutaḥ / anekadravyavattvodbhūtarūpaprakāśacatuṣṭayasannikarṣāt anekadravyavat /tvaṃ ca udbhūtarūpañca prakāśaśca catuṣṭayasannikarṣaśceti tathoktastasmāt / dharmādisāmagrye ca iti / anekañca dravyañcetyanekadravyaṃ tad yasyāsti tat / tadvat tasya bhāvo 'nekadravyavattvam / rūpañcātra rūpaviśeṣo vivakṣitaḥ / tathā ca sūtram mahattvādanekadravyavattvād rūpaviśeṣācca dravyaṃ pratyakṣam vai / sū / / / iti / aparokṣajñānasadbhāve sati samastaṃ vyastañcedaṃ pratyakṣajñānasya kāraṇaṃ vivakṣitamityuktaṃ vāyvadhikāre / catuṣṭaya sannikarṣaśca ātmā manasā saṃyujyate / mana indriyeṇa / indriyamartheneti catuṣṭayasannikarṣastasmāt / dharmādisāmagrye ceti ādipadād dikkālādergrahaṇamiti /
analyzed: yatas vā dravya ādiṣu padārtheṣu utpadyate pratyakṣam atas dravye tāvat vyākhyāyate iti  kim viśiṣṭe trividhe tisraḥ vidhāḥ yasya tat tathā uktam tasmin mahati mahat tva adhikaraṇe sva rūpa ālocanam nirvikalpakam jñānam utpadyate kutas aneka dravyavat tva udbhūta rūpa prakāśa catuṣṭaya sannikarṣāt aneka dravyavat tvam ca udbhūta rūpam ca prakāśaḥ ca catuṣṭaya sannikarṣaḥ ca iti tathā uktaḥ tasmāt dharma ādi sāmagrye ca iti anekam ca dravyam ca iti
translated: Because perception arises in regard to substances etc., therefore it is explained first in substances. In what way? In the three-fold, that which has three modes is said to be so. In the great, in the section on greatness, the knowledge of the form is produced without conceptualization. Why? From the contact of the four - the presence of many substances, the manifest form, the light, and the four. The presence of many substances, the manifest form, the light, and the four is said to be so. From that, and from the collection of dharma etc. Many and substance is many substances. That which has that is so. The state of that is the presence of many substances. And here, form is intended to be a particular form. And thus the aphorism: Substance is perceptible because of greatness, because of the presence of many substances, and because of the particular form. The entire collection and the individual are the cause of this perceptual knowledge when the existence of non-obstructed knowledge is present.

original: athāstvevaṃ nirvikalpakajñānotpattiḥ / sadbhāve kiṃ pramāṇam / savikalpakajñānotpattireva / anyathā hi viśiṣṭārthānupalabdhau viśiṣṭasya saṅketasmaraṇasyānupapatteḥ savikalpakaṃ jñānaṃ na syāt / tasya tatkāryatvāt / na ca saṅketasmaraṇameva tasya nimittam / akṣaṇikatve sati arthasya nirvikalpajñānotpattāviva savikalpakajñānotpattāvanvayavyatirekābhyāṃ vyāpāropalabdherityuktanyāyāt /
analyzed: atha astu evam nirvikalpaka jñāna utpattiḥ sadbhāve kim pramāṇam savikalpaka jñāna utpattiḥ eva anyathā hi viśiṣṭa artha anupalabdhau viśiṣṭasya saṅketa smaraṇasya anupapatteḥ savikalpakam jñānam na syāt tasya tad kārya tvāt na ca saṅketa smaraṇam eva tasya nimittam akṣaṇika tve sati arthasya nirvikalpa jñāna utpattau iva savikalpaka jñāna utpattau anvaya vyatirekābhyām vyāpāra upalabdheḥ iti ukta nyāyāt
translated: Now, let it be so that non-conceptual cognition arises. What is the evidence for its existence? The arising of conceptual cognition itself. For otherwise, in the absence of the perception of a qualified object, the recollection of the qualified convention would be impossible, and conceptual cognition would not occur, because it is the effect of that. And the recollection of the convention itself is not the cause of that, because even when the object is not momentary, like in the arising of non-conceptual cognition, the operation is observed through positive and negative concomitance in the arising of conceptual cognition. This is the established reasoning.

original: savikalpakapratyakṣanirūpaṇam
analyzed: sa vikalpaka pratyakṣa nirūpaṇam
translated: Definition of conceptual perception

original: sāmānyaviśeṣadravyaguṇakarmaviśeṣaṇāpekṣādātmamanaḥsannikarṣāt pratyakṣamutpadyate saddravyam pṛthivī / viṣāṇī / śuklo gaurgacchatīti /PDhS
analyzed: sāmānya viśeṣa dravya guṇa karma viśeṣaṇa apekṣāt ātma manaḥ sannikarṣāt pratyakṣam utpadyate sat dravyam pṛthivī viṣāṇī śuklaḥ gauḥ gacchati iti
translated: Perception arises from the contact of the self and mind, in dependence on the qualifications of universals, particulars, substances, qualities, and actions, as in the existent substance is earth, the horned one, the white cow, goes. Pshk

original: tadevaṃ nirvikalpakaṃ pratipādya savikalpakaṃ viśeṣyajñānamāha sāmānyaII /viśeṣadravyaguṇakarmaviśeṣaṇāpekṣāt ityādinā / sāmānyañca sāmānyaviśeṣaśca dravyañca guṇaśca karma ceti tathoktāni / tānyeva viśeṣaṇāni / tānyapekṣata iti tadapekṣaḥ samuccaye / na kevalaṃ svarūpālocanamātramuktakāraṇebhyo niṣpadyate / sāmānyādiviśeṣaṇāpekṣañca tata evotpadyata iti /
analyzed: tat evam nirvikalpakam pratipādya savikalpakam viśeṣya jñānam āha ityādinā sāmānyam ca sāmānya viśeṣaḥ ca dravyam ca guṇaḥ ca karma ca iti tathā uktāni tāni eva viśeṣaṇāni tāni apekṣate iti tad apekṣaḥ samuccaye na kevalam svarūpa ālocana mātra mukta kāraṇebhyaḥ niṣpadyate sāmānya ādi viśeṣaṇa apekṣaḥ ca tatas eva utpadyate iti
translated: Having thus explained indeterminate perception, he now explains determinate perception, which is the cognition of particulars, beginning with depending on universals, etc. Universals and particular universals, substances, qualities, and actions are so called. Those are the qualifications. It depends on those, in the sense of depending on them collectively. It is not said that perception arises merely from the mentioned causes, but that it arises from them depending on qualifications such as universals.

original: nanu catuṣṭayasannikarṣasyāpavādaṃ vinā ūrdhvaṃ sarvatrānuvṛtterabhyupagamād vyartham ātmamanaḥsannikarṣasyābhidhānam / na / anantarajñāne 'pyasyāsamavāyikāraṇatvajñāpanārthatvāt /
analyzed: nanu catuṣṭaya sannikarṣasya apavādam vinā ūrdhvam sarvatra anuvṛtteḥ abhyupagamāt vyartham ātma manaḥ sannikarṣasya abhidhānam na anantara jñāne pi asya asamavāyi kāraṇa tva jñāpana artha tvāt
translated: But since the conjunction of the four is accepted to continue everywhere except in the case of exceptions, the mention of the conjunction of the self and mind is useless. Not so, because it is for the purpose of showing that it is the non-inherent cause even in the subsequent cognition.

original: tatra saditi sattāviśeṣaṇaṃ dravyamiti sāmānyam / viśeṣāpekṣaṃ pṛthivīti / tathā viṣāṇīti dravyaviśeṣaṇam / śukla iti guṇaviśeṣaṇāpekṣam / gauriti sāmānyaviśeṣaviśeṣaṇāpekṣam / gacchatīti kriyāviśiṣṭaṃ jñānamityudāharaṇāni /
analyzed: tatra sat iti sattā viśeṣaṇam dravyam iti sāmānyam viśeṣa apekṣam pṛthivī iti tathā viṣāṇi iti dravya viśeṣaṇam śuklaḥ iti guṇa viśeṣaṇa apekṣam gauḥ iti sāmānya viśeṣa viśeṣaṇa apekṣam gacchati iti kriyā viśiṣṭam jñānam iti udāharaṇāni
translated: Among them, 'sat' is a qualifier of existence, 'dravya' is a general term, 'pṛthivī' is dependent on a particular. Similarly, 'viṣāṇī' is a qualifier of substance, 'śukla' is dependent on a qualifier of quality, 'gaura' is dependent on a qualifier of a general particular. 'Gacchati' is knowledge qualified by action. These are examples.

original: guṇādiṣu pratyakṣotpattiprakāraḥ
analyzed: guṇa ādiṣu pratyakṣa utpatti prakāraḥ
translated: The mode of origin of perception in qualities etc.

original: rūparasagandhasparśeṣvanekadravyasamavāyāt svagataviśeṣāt svāśrayasannikarṣānniyatendriyanimittamutpadyate / śabdasya trayasannikarṣācchrotrasamavetasya tenaivopalabdhiḥ / saṃkhyāparimāṇapṛthaktvasaṃyogavibhāgaparatvāparatvasnehadravatvavegakarmaṇāṃ pratyakṣadravyasamavāyāccakṣuḥsparśanābhyāṃ grahaṇam / buddhisukhaduḥkhecchādveṣaprayatnānāṃ dvayorātmamanasoḥ saṃyogādupalabdhiḥ /PDhS
analyzed: rūpa rasa gandha sparśeṣu aneka dravya samavāyāt svagata viśeṣāt sva āśraya sannikarṣāt niyata indriya nimittam utpadyate śabdasya traya sannikarṣāt śrotra samavetasya tena eva upalabdhiḥ saṃkhyā parimāṇa pṛthaktva saṃyoga vibhāga para tva apara tva sneha drava tva vega karmaṇām pratyakṣa dravya samavāyāt cakṣuḥ sparśanābhyām grahaṇam buddhi sukha duḥkha icchā dveṣa prayatnānām dvayoḥ ātma manasoḥ saṃyogāt upalabdhiḥ pdhs
translated: In color, taste, smell, and touch, due to the inherence of many substances, from the specific property of itself, and from the proximity of its substratum, it arises with a restricted sense organ as its cause. The perception of sound, which inheres in the three, is by the ear itself. Number, dimension, separateness, conjunction, disjunction, distance, proximity, fluidity, velocity, and action are grasped by both the eye and touch due to inherence in perceptible substances. The perception of cognition, pleasure, pain, desire, aversion, and effort is by the union of the two, the self and the mind.

original: guṇādiṣu pratyakṣamāha rūparasagandhasparśeṣu viṣayeṣu anekadravyeṇa saha samavāyāt / svagataviśeṣāt ca / yatkṛtā kvacid viṣaye teṣāmupalabdhiryadabhāvāccānupalabdhiḥ sa udbhavasamākhyāto rūpādidharmaḥ sahakāriviśeṣastasmāt / svāśrayasannikarṣāt ca / svāśrayeṇa dravyeṇa saṃyuktamindriyaṃ tatsamavāyāt / dharmādisāmagrye ca sati pratiniyatendriyanimittamutpadyate jñānam / śabdasya trayasannikarṣāt iti / ātmā manasā saṃyujyate mana indriyeṇeti trayasya sannikarṣaḥ / śrotrasamavetasya iti / indriyārthasannikarṣo 'pyupadarśita eva / tenaiva śrotreṇopalabdhirnendriyāntaraṇeti /
analyzed: guṇa ādiṣu pratyakṣam āha rūpa rasa gandha sparśeṣu viṣayeṣu aneka dravyeṇa saha samavāyāt svagata viśeṣāt ca yad kṛtā kvacid viṣaye teṣām upalabdhiḥ yad abhāvāt ca anupalabdhiḥ saḥ udbhava samākhyātaḥ rūpa ādi dharmaḥ sahakāri viśeṣaḥ tasmāt sva āśraya sannikarṣāt ca sva āśrayeṇa dravyeṇa saṃyuktam indriyam tad samavāyāt dharma ādi sāmagrye ca sati pratiniyata indriya nimittam utpadyate jñānam śabdasya traya sannikarṣāt iti ātm
translated: He states the perception of qualities etc. in the objects of form, taste, smell and touch, due to inherence with many substances, and due to specific qualities inherent in them. The perception of those objects is produced by that, and their non-perception is due to the absence of that. That is the quality of form etc., which is called origination, and is a specific cooperative factor. And due to the proximity of its substratum. The sense organ is conjoined with its own substance, due to inherence in that. And when the totality of dharma etc. is present, knowledge arises with a specific sense organ as its cause. It is said that sound is perceived due to the proximity of the three. The self is conjoined with the mind, and the mind with the sense organ - thus there is proximity of the three. It is said to be inherent in the ear. The proximity of the sense organ and object is also shown. Perception is by that very ear, not by another sense organ.

original: anye tu trayaścāsau sannikarṣaścetīndriyārthasannikarṣo 'pyupalabhyate / tasmācchrotrasamavetasya tenaivopalabdhiriti /
analyzed: anye tu trayaḥ ca asau sannikarṣaḥ ca iti indriya artha sannikarṣaḥ u pi upalabhyate tasmāt śrotra samavetasya tena eva upalabdhiḥ iti
translated: However, others perceive the proximity of the three as well as the proximity of the sense organ and object. Therefore, perception is by that very [ear] which is inherent in the ear.

original: saṃkhyāparimāṇapṛthaktvasaṃyogavibhāgaparatvāparatvasnehadravatvavegakarmaṇām II / grahaṇam / kutaḥ / pratyakṣadravyasamavāyāccakṣuḥsparśanābhyām tatsamavāyāt saṃkhyādīnāṃ grahaṇamiti / buddhisukhaduḥkhecchadveṣaprayatnānāṃ dvayorātmanasoḥ sannikarṣādupalabdhiḥ / buddhyādayo hi ātmani samavetāstatsambaddhena manasā gṛhyante /
analyzed: saṃkhyā parimāṇa pṛthaktva saṃyoga vibhāga para tva apara tva sneha drava tva vega karmaṇām grahaṇam kutas pratyakṣa dravya samavāyāt cakṣuḥ sparśanābhyām tad samavāyāt saṃkhyā ādīnām grahaṇam iti buddhi sukha duḥkha icchā dveṣa prayatnānām dvayoḥ ātma nasoḥ sannikarṣāt upalabdhiḥ buddhi ādayaḥ hi ātmani samavetāḥ tad sambaddhena manasā gṛhyante  /
translated: Number, dimension, separateness, conjunction, disjunction, priority, posteriority, fluidity, viscidity, and velocity are grasped. Why? Because of the inherence of number etc. in the perceptible substance, they are grasped by the eye and touch.🔽The cognition, pleasure, pain, desire, aversion, and effort of the two, the self and the mind, are perceived due to contact. For cognition etc. inhere in the self and are grasped by the mind connected with it.

original: bhāvadravyatvaguṇatvakarmatvādīnāmupalabhyādhārasamavetānāmāśrayagrāhakairindriyairgrahaṇamityetadasmadādīnāṃ pratyakṣam /PDhS
analyzed: bhāva dravya tva guṇa tva karma tva ādīnām upalabhya ādhāra samavetānām āśraya grāhakaiḥ indriyaiḥ grahaṇam iti etat asmat ādīnām pratyakṣam
translated: The perception of substance, quality, action, etc., which inhere in the perceptible substratum, is by the senses that grasp the substratum. This is perception for us and others.

original: sāmānye pratyakṣamāha bhāvadravyatvaguṇatvakarmatvādīnāmupalabhyādhārasamavetānāmāśrayagrāhakairindriyairgrahaṇam bhāvaśca dravyatvañca karmatvañca tathoktāni / tānyādiryeṣāmityādipadena pṛthivītvotkṣepaṇatvādīnāṃ grahaṇam / upalabhyaścāsāvādhāraśca / tatsamavetānāmāśrayagrāhakairindriyairgrahaṇam / yenaivendriyeṇāśrayagrahaṇaṃ tenaiva tatsamavetānāṃ sattādīnāṃ grahaṇamiti / tathāhi / sattā dravye vartamānā saṃyuktasamavāyena cakṣuḥsparśanābhyāmupalabhyate / gandharasarūpasparśeṣu samavetā ghrāṇarasanacakṣustvagindriyairupalabhyante saṃyuktasamavetasamavāyena / śabde tu samavetasamavāyācchrotreṇa / sukhādi tu saṃyuktasamavetasamavāyānmanasā gṛhyate / guṇatvamapyevam / ataḥ sattāyāṃ guṇatve ca sarvendriyaṃ jñānamiti / dravyatvaṃ saṃyuktasamavāyena cakṣuḥsparśanābhyāmupalabhyate / karmatvañca saṃyuktasamavetasamavāyāt / rūpatvādāvapyevaṃ grahaṇam / ityetadasmadādīnāṃ pratyakṣam ityupasaṃhāraḥ /
analyzed: sāmānye pratyakṣam āha bhāva dravya tva guṇa tva karma tva ādīnām upalabhya ādhāra samavetānām āśraya grāhakaiḥ indriyaiḥ grahaṇam bhāvaḥ ca dravya tvam ca karma tvam ca tathā uktāni tāni ādiḥ yeṣām iti ādi padena pṛthivī tva utkṣepaṇa tva ādīnām grahaṇam upalabhyaḥ ca asau ādhāraḥ ca tad samavetānām āśraya grāhakaiḥ indriyaiḥ grahaṇam yena eva indriyeṇa āśraya grahaṇam tena eva tad samavetānām sattā ādīnām grahaṇam iti tathā
translated: The author now describes perception of universals. The existence, substantiality, quality, action, etc., which are perceived as inhering in their substratum, are apprehended by the sense organs that grasp their substratum. Existence, substantiality, and action are so called. The word 'etc.' includes earthness, upward motion, etc. The substratum is also perceived. Those inhering in it are apprehended by the sense organs that grasp their substratum. By the same sense organ by which the substratum is grasped, the existence, etc., inhering in it are also grasped. Thus, existence, which inheres in substances, is perceived by the eye and the skin through the conjunction-inherence relation. The odor, taste, color, and touch inhering in them are perceived by the nose, tongue, eye, and skin through the conjunction-inherence-inherence relation. But in sound, it is perceived by the ear through the inherence-inherence relation. But pleasure, etc., are grasped by the mind through the conjunction-inherence-inherence relation. Qualityness is also so. Therefore, in existence and qualityness,

original: yogipratyakṣanirūpaṇam
translated: Description of yogic perception

original: asmadviśiṣṭānāntu yogināṃ yuktānāṃ yogajadharmānugṛhītena manasā svātmāntarākāśadikkālaparamāṇuvāyumanassu tatsamavetaguṇakarmasāmānyaviśeṣeṣu samavāye cāvitathaṃ svarūpadarśanamutpadyate / viyuktānāṃ punaścatuṣṭayasannikarṣād yogajadharmānugrahasāmarthyāt sūkṣmavyavahitaviprakṛṣṭeṣu pratyakṣamutpadyate /PDhS
analyzed: asmad viśiṣṭānām tu yoginām yuktānām yoga ja dharma anugṛhītena manasā sva ātma antar ākāśa diś kāla paramāṇu vāyu manassu tad samaveta guṇa karma sāmānya viśeṣeṣu samavāye ca avitatham sva rūpa darśanam utpadyate viyuktānām punar catuṣṭaya sannikarṣāt yoga ja dharma anugraha sāmarthyāt sūkṣma vyavahita viprakṛṣṭeṣu pratyakṣam utpadyate pdhs
translated: For yogis who are superior to us, who are engaged in yoga, a true perception of their own self, internal space, direction, time, atoms, air, mind, their inherent qualities, actions, universals, particulars, and inherence arises through the mind aided by the qualities produced by yoga. And for those who are not engaged, perception arises regarding subtle, obstructed, and distant objects due to the conjunction of the four [sense organs] and the power of being aided by the qualities produced by yoga.

original: tathāsmadviśiṣṭānāṃ yogināṃ keṣvartheṣu kathañca pratyakṣamutpadyata iti vyākhyāyate / tatra yuktānāṃ samādhyavasthānāṃ yogajadharmānugṛhītena tatsahakāriṇā manasā aparokṣasvarūpadarśanaṃ janyate / keṣvartheṣu / svātmā cātmāntarañcāII /kāśañca dik ca kālaśca vāyuśca paramāṇavaśca manaśceti tathoktāni teṣu / tathā na paraṃ svātmādiṣu saṃyuktena manasā yogināmaparokṣagrahaṇaṃ tatsamaveteṣu guṇakarmasāmānyādiviśeṣeṣu saṃyuktasamavāyena / samavāye ca saṃyuktaviśeṣaṇaviśeṣyabhāvena grahaṇam / ata eva samavāyasya pṛthagabhidhānaṃ vibhinnasannikarṣaparicchedyatvāt / guṇakarmasu paramāṇvādigateṣu yatsāmānyaṃ tatra saṃyuktasamavetasamavāyena /
analyzed: tathā asmat viśiṣṭānām yoginām keṣu artheṣu kathaṃca pratyakṣam utpadyate iti vyākhyāyate tatra yuktānām samādhi avasthānām yoga ja dharma anugṛhītena tad sahakāriṇā manasā aparokṣa sva rūpa darśanam janyate keṣu artheṣu svātmā diś ca kālaḥ ca vāyuḥ ca paramāṇavaḥ ca manaḥ ca iti tathā uktāni teṣu tathā na param svātma ādiṣu saṃyuktena manasā yoginām aparokṣa grahaṇam tad samaveteṣu guṇa karma sāmānya ādi viśeṣeṣu saṃyuk
translated: Similarly, it is explained in which objects and how the perception arises for some yogis who are superior to us. There, for the yogis in the state of concentration, the direct perception of the imperceptible nature is produced by the mind aided by the dharmas born of yoga, which is its contributory cause. In which objects? The self, other selves, space, direction, time, air, atoms, and mind are called thus. The perception of the yogis is not only by the mind connected with their own self etc., but also by the connected inherence in the qualities, actions, universals etc. that inhere in them. And the inherence is grasped by the relation of qualifier and qualified with the connected particulars. For this very reason, inherence is separately mentioned, because it is to be determined by a different conjunction. In the universals that reside in the atoms etc. and in the qualities and actions, it is by the inherence of the connected inherence.

original: atha yogī yadā svamantaḥkaraṇaṃ gṛhṇāti tadā kiṃ karaṇam / ātmamanaḥsaṃyogaḥ / tasmin manaḥparicchedye mana eva karaṇamiti / parakīyena ca manasā sūkṣmaśarīrasthaṃ manaḥ preryamabhisambandhayati / tatsambaddhañca tadgṛhṇātīti /
analyzed: atha yogī yadā svam antaḥkaraṇam gṛhṇāti tadā kim karaṇam ātma manaḥ saṃyogaḥ tasmin manaḥ paricchedye manaḥ eva karaṇam iti parakīyena ca manasā sūkṣmaśarīra stham manaḥ preryam abhisambandhayati tad sambaddham ca tat gṛhṇāti iti
translated: Now, when the yogi perceives his own internal organ, what is the instrument? It is the conjunction of the self and mind. In that which is to be determined by the mind, the mind itself is the instrument. And by another's mind, the mind located in the subtle body is impelled and connected. And that which is connected, he perceives.

original: viyuktānāṃ punaścatuṣṭayasannikarṣāt asmadādīnāmiva pratyakṣamutpadyate jñānam / keṣvartheṣu / sūkṣmavyavahitaviprakṛṣṭeṣu iti / sūkṣmāḥ paramāṇavo vyavahitā nāgabhuvanādayo viprakṛṣṭā mervādayasteṣvaparokṣaṃ jñānam / asamādhyavasthānāṃ yogajadharmānugrahasāmarthyāt tadutpadyate / yogīndriyāṇāṃ hi dharmaviśeṣānugraheṇa sarvatrāpratibandhāt / catuṣṭayasannikarṣagrahaṇamudāharaṇārtham / trayasannikarṣeṇāpi grahaṇāt / tathā hi yogī brahmādibhāṣitaṃ yogajadharmānugrahādapratibadhyamānasantānanyāyena śrotradeśamāgataṃ gṛhṇāti trayasannikarṣeṇa /
analyzed: viyuktānām punar catuṣṭaya sannikarṣāt asmat ādīnām iva pratyakṣam utpadyate jñānam  keṣu artheṣu sūkṣma vyavahita viprakṛṣṭeṣu iti sūkṣmāḥ paramāṇavaḥ vyavahitāḥ nāga bhuvana ādayaḥ viprakṛṣṭāḥ meru ādayaḥ teṣu aparokṣam jñānam asamādhi avasthānām yoga ja dharma anugraha sāmarthyāt tat utpadyate yogi indriyāṇām hi dharma viśeṣa anugraheṇa sarvatra apratibandhāt catuṣṭaya sannikarṣa grahaṇam udāharaṇa artham traya
translated: And for those who are separated, perception arises from the contact of the four, like for us ordinary people. In what objects? In subtle, obstructed, and distant objects. Subtle means atoms, obstructed means the abodes of the nāgas and so on, distant means the Meru mountains and so on. Perception of those is unobstructed. It arises by the power of the grace of the yoga-born qualities of those who are not in the state of samādhi. For the sense faculties of the yogi, by the grace of the special qualities, there is no obstruction anywhere. The mention of the contact of the four is for the purpose of illustration. Because it is grasped even by the contact of the three. Thus, the yogi, by the principle of the continuum being unobstructed by the grace of the yoga-born qualities, hears what comes to the ear region, spoken by Brahmā and so on, by the contact of the three.

original: nanu sarvametadasat / yogināṃ sadbhāve pramāṇābhāvād / bādhakopapatteśca / tathā ca na yogī atīndriyārthadraṣṭā prāṇitvād asmadādivat / yogīndriyāṇi vā na sarvaviṣayāṇi indriyatvād asmadādīndriyavat / naitad yuktam / svatantre yogināmaprasiddhatayā prāṇitvādihetorāśrayāsiddhatvāt / atha paravyāptyā parasyāniṣṭāpādanametat / tatra yadi samyak pramāṇena paraprasiddhistenaiva bādhyamānatvādanutthānaṃ tatpratiṣedhahetūnām / na ca kāryeṇaiva kāraṇasya vyāghātaḥ / tadantareṇāpakṣadharmatayā tanmūlasya hetoraprāmāṇyaprasaṅgāt / atha pramāṇaṃ vinaiva pareṇābhyupagatā yogina iti pratiṣidhyante / tarhi pramāṇābhāvenaiva prameyasyāprasiddhervyarthaṃ tatpratiṣedhānumānam /
analyzed: nanu sarvam etat asat yoginām sadbhāve pramāṇa abhāvāt bādhaka upapatteḥ ca  / tathā ca na yogī atīndriya artha draṣṭā prāṇi tvāt asmat ādi vat yogi indriyāṇi vā na sarva viṣayāṇi indriya tvāt asmat ādi indriya vat  na etat yuktam svatantre yoginām aprasiddha tayā prāṇi tva ādi hetoḥ āśraya asiddha tvāt  atha para vyāptyā parasya aniṣṭa āpādanam etat tatra yadi samyak pramāṇena para prasiddhiḥ tena eva bādhyamāna tvāt anutthānam tad pratiṣedha
translated: But all this is false, because there is no evidence for the existence of yogis, and because refuting evidence is applicable. And thus, a yogi is not a seer of supersensible objects, because of being a living being, like us. Or the yogic senses are not of all objects, because of being senses, like our senses. This is not correct. Because of the non-establishedness of the basis of the reason being a living being etc. due to the non-acknowledged independence of yogis. Now, if this is the undesirable consequence for the opponent by the pervasion of the other, then if there is proper acknowledgment by the opponent through evidence, then the reasons refuting that are not established because they are contradicted by that itself. And the effect does not contradict the cause. Because without that, due to being a property of the subject, there is the undesirable consequence of the invalidity of the reason rooted in that. Or if yogis are refuted as accepted by the opponent without evidence, then due to the non-establishment of the object of knowledge by the absence of evidence itself, the inference refuting that is pointless.

original: asti ca yogināṃ sadbhāve 'numānam / tathāhi / asmadādīnāṃ pratyakṣeṇāII /nupalabhyamānāḥ paramāṇvādayaḥ kasyacit pratyakṣāḥ prameyatvād ghaṭādivaditi / pakṣīkṛteṣu paramāṇvādiṣu prameyatvasya hetoḥ sadbhāvāt pakṣadharmatvam / tathā kasyacit pratyakṣeṇa sādhyena prameyatvasya hetorghaṭādau vyāpterupalambhaḥ / na cāsya pratyakṣāgamābhyāmasti bādhā / nāyaṃ satpratipakṣa ityavyabhicāritvād gamaka eva /
analyzed: asti ca yoginām sadbhāve numānam tathā hi asmat ādīnām paramāṇu ādayaḥ kasyacid pratyakṣāḥ prameya tvāt ghaṭa ādi vat iti pakṣīkṛteṣu paramāṇu ādiṣu prameya tvasya hetoḥ sadbhāvāt pakṣa dharma tvam tathā kasyacid pratyakṣeṇa sādhyena prameya tvasya hetoḥ ghaṭa ādau vyāpteḥ upalambhaḥ na ca asya pratyakṣa āgamābhyām asti bādhā na ayam sat pratipakṣaḥ iti avyabhicāri tvāt gamakaḥ eva
translated: And there is inference for the existence of yogis. For example, atoms and so on, which are not perceived by the perception of us and others, are the objects of perception of someone, because they are objects of knowledge, like pots and so on. The reason being an object of knowledge exists in the subject, atoms and so on, which have been formulated. Similarly, the pervasion of the reason being an object of knowledge by the probandum being the object of perception of someone is observed in pots and so on. And this is not contradicted by perception or scripture. It is not a true counter-argument, so it is indeed an indicator because it is not deviant.

original: sarvañcānumānaṃ sāmānyena vyāptigrahaṇāpekṣaṃ pravartamānaṃ pakṣe viśeṣaṃ prasādhayatītyataḥ kasyacit pratyakṣameva paramāṇvādeḥ sāmānyena sādhyate / yasya ca pratyakṣāḥ paramāṇvādayaḥ so 'smadādivilakṣaṇo yogī /
analyzed: sarvam ca anumānam sāmānyena vyāpti grahaṇa apekṣam pravartamānam pakṣe viśeṣam prasādhayati iti atas kasyacid pratyakṣam eva paramāṇu ādeḥ sāmānyena sādhyate yasya ca pratyakṣāḥ paramāṇu ādayaḥ saḥ smat ādi vilakṣaṇaḥ yogī
translated: And all inference, operating by depending on the apprehension of pervasion in general, establishes a particular in the subject. Therefore, the perception of someone is established in general for atoms and so on. And the yogi who has atoms and so on as objects of perception is different from us.

original: tathā abhyāsavaśād buddhestāratamyamupalabhyamānaṃ kvacid viśrāntaṃ tāratamyaśabdavācyatvādaṇuparimāṇatāratamyavat / yatra viśrāmaste 'smadādivilakṣaṇā yoginaḥ ityanumānasya tu nirdiṣṭatāyāṃ yogisadbhāvasiddheḥ / śeṣaṃ vacanamātraṃ na bādhakamityupekṣyate /
analyzed: tathā abhyāsa vaśāt buddheḥ tāratamyam upalabhyamānam kvacid viśrāntam tāratamya śabda vācya tvāt aṇu parimāṇa tāratamya vat  yatra viśrāmaḥ te smat ādi vilakṣaṇāḥ yoginaḥ iti anumānasya tu nirdiṣṭatāyām yogi sadbhāva siddheḥ  / śeṣam vacana mātram na bādhakam iti upekṣyate
translated: Similarly, the gradation of the intellect being perceived due to practice, resting somewhere, is called gradation, like the gradation of atomic dimensions. Where there is rest, those yogis are different from us. But when the indication of this inference is accepted, the existence of yogis is established. The rest is mere statement and is disregarded as not being a refutation.

original: pratyakṣapramāṇasya phalavibhāgapradarśanam
analyzed: pratyakṣa pramāṇasya phala vibhāga pradarśanam
translated: The demonstration of the division of the result of the means of valid knowledge, perception

original: tatra sāmānyaviśeṣeṣu svarūpālocanamātraṃ pratyakṣaṃ pramāṇaṃ / prameyā dravyādayaḥ padārthāḥ / pramātā ātmā / pramitirdravyādiviṣayaṃ jñānam / sāmānyaviśeṣajñānotpattāvavibhaktamālocanamātraṃ pratyakṣaṃ pramāṇam / asmin nānyat pramāṇāntaramasti / aphalarūpatvāt /PDhS
analyzed: tatra sāmānya viśeṣeṣu svarūpa ālocana mātram pratyakṣam pramāṇam prameyāḥ dravya ādayaḥ padārthāḥ pramātā ātmā pramitiḥ dravya ādi viṣayam jñānam sāmānya viśeṣa jñāna utpattau avibhaktam ālocana mātram pratyakṣam pramāṇam asmin na anyat pramāṇa antaram asti aphala rūpa tvāt pdhs
translated: There, the mere observation of the nature of universals and particulars is the means of valid knowledge, perception. The objects of valid knowledge are substances etc. The knower is the self. The result of valid knowledge is the cognition having substances etc. as its object. In the production of the knowledge of universals and particulars, the mere observation that is not differentiated is the means of valid knowledge, perception. In this, there is no other means of valid knowledge. Because it is not of the nature of a result.

original: tadevaṃ yogināmayogināñca pratyakṣaṃ vyākhyāya śiṣyavyutpādanāya vipratipattinirāsārthañca pramāṇaphalavibhāgaṃ nirūpayati tatra sāmānyaviśeṣeṣu svarūpālocanamātram ityādinā / sāmānyaviśeṣeṣu dravyatvaguṇatvakarmatvādiṣu svarūpālocanamātram / ālocitirālocanaṃ nirvikalpakaṃ jñānam / pratyakṣaṃ pramāṇam tadupalakṣitā sāmagrī pratyakṣaṃ pramāṇamiti / mātrābhidhānāt jñānāntarābhāvaṃ darśayati prameyāḥ iti / pramīyanta iti prameyāḥ pramāṇaparicchedyā dravyādayaḥ padārthāḥ / pramiṇotīti pramādhāratvāt pramātā ātmā / pramitiḥ pramāṇādisādhyā pratītirdravyādiviṣayaṃ jñānaṃ phalam / ityevamitaretaravyāvṛttalakṣaṇayogitvāt pramāṇādayaḥ parasparaṃ vibhinnā iti tadabhedavādino nirastā bhavanti /
analyzed: tat evam yoginām ayoginām ca pratyakṣam vyākhyāya śiṣya vyutpādanāya vipratipatti nirāsa artham ca pramāṇa phala vibhāgam nirūpayati tatra sāmānya viśeṣeṣu sva rūpa ālocana mātram ityādinā sāmānya viśeṣeṣu dravya tva guṇa tva karma tva ādiṣu sva rūpa ālocana mātram ālocitiḥ ālocanam nirvikalpakam jñānam pratyakṣam pramāṇam tad upalakṣitā sāmagrī pratyakṣam pramāṇam iti mātra abhidhānāt jñāna antara abhāvam darśayati prameyāḥ iti pra
translated: Having thus explained perception for both yogis and non-yogis, in order to instruct disciples and to remove disagreements, he determines the division of the means of valid knowledge and their result, beginning with The mere observation of the nature of universals and particulars... The mere observation of the nature of universals and particulars, such as substance, quality, action, etc. Observation is the act of observing, which is non-conceptual knowledge. Perception is the means of valid knowledge. The collection of causes that is indicated by that is the means of valid knowledge. By the word mere, it shows that there is no other knowledge. The objects of valid knowledge are the categories such as substance, etc., which are to be determined by the means of valid knowledge, because they are what is to be known. The knower is the self, because it is the basis of knowledge. Knowledge is the result, which is the cognition of substance, etc., and is to be accomplished by the means of valid knowledge, etc. Thus, because they have the property of mutually exclusive characteristics, the means of valid knowledge, etc., are different from each other. Therefore, those who assert their non-difference are refuted.
