original: atha pramāṇaphalayorvyatirekābhyupagamāt sāmānyaviśeṣeṣu svarūpālocanasya pramārūpatvādutpattau kiṃ pramāṇamityāha sāmānyaviśeṣajñānotpattāvavibhaktam viśeṣaṇajñānaśūnyam / ālocyate 'nenetyālocanamātram / indriyārthasannikarṣādyupalakṣitaṃ kārakasāmagryaṃ pratyakṣaṃ pramāṇaṃ / prameyaṃ sāmānyaviśeṣā iti / atha tasminnapi svarūpālocane kasmānna jñānāntaramiṣyata ityāha na tasmin svarūpālocane 'nyat pramāṇāntaraṃ jñānāntaramastīti / aphalarūpatvānniṣprayojanatvāditi / tathāhi / viśeṣyajñānaṃ viśeṣaṇānuraktam / anyathānupapadyamānaṃ viśeṣaṇajñānasattāṃ darśayati / na caivaṃ viśeṣaṇajñāne viśeṣaṇānurāgo 'sti / jñānāntarābhyupagame cānavasthā syāditi viśeṣyajñānānutpattireva / dṛṣṭañca viśeṣyajñānam / ato na viśeṣaṇajñāne jñānāntaramastīti /
analyzed: atha pramāṇa phalayoḥ vyatireka abhyupagamāt sāmānya viśeṣeṣu sva rūpa ālocanasya pramā rūpa tvāt utpattau kim pramāṇam iti āha sāmānya viśeṣa jñāna utpattau avibhaktam viśeṣaṇa jñāna śūnyam ālocyate nena iti ālocana mātram indriya artha sannikarṣa ādi upalakṣitam kāraka sāmagryam pratyakṣam pramāṇam prameyam sāmānya viśeṣāḥ iti atha tasmin api sva rūpa ālocane kasmāt na jñāna antaram iṣyate iti āha na tasmin sva rūpa ālocane pramāṇa
translated: Now, since the means of valid knowledge and its result are admitted to be distinct, and since the mere perception of the universal and particular is the nature of valid knowledge in the case of origination, what is the means of valid knowledge? He says: In the origination of the knowledge of the universal and particular, the mere perception, which is not differentiated and devoid of the knowledge of the qualifier, is the means of valid knowledge called perception. The object of valid knowledge is the universal and particular. Now, why is another cognition not accepted even in that mere perception of the form? He says: In that mere perception of the form, there is no other means of valid knowledge, no other cognition. Because it is not of the nature of a result, because it is purposeless. For example, the knowledge of the qualified is tinged with the qualifier, and manifesting in a way that cannot be otherwise, it shows the existence of the knowledge of the qualifier. But in the knowledge of the qualifier, there is no tinge of the qualifier. And if another cognition is accepted, there would be an infinite regress. Therefore, there is only the non-origination of the knowledge of the qualified. And the knowledge of the qualified is seen to be the cause of the knowledge of the qualifier.

original: anye tu sāmānyaviśeṣeṣu svarūpālocanamātram iti mātrābhidhānena nirākāraṃ pratyakṣaṃ pramāṇaphalamiti bruvate / sāmānyaviśeṣāśca dravyādaya evānugatavyāvṛttajñānaviṣayatvādupacāreṇa vivakṣitāḥ / atra hi jñānaviśeṣasyākārapratiṣedhe 'nyatrākārabhyupagamaḥ syāt / śeṣaṃ pūrvavat / yathā jñāne nākāraḥ sambhavati tathoktaṃ jñānākāravādapratiṣedhāvasare /
analyzed: anye tu sāmānya viśeṣeṣu sva rūpa ālocana mātram iti mātra abhidhānena nirākāram pratyakṣam pramāṇa phalam iti bruvate sāmānya viśeṣāḥ ca dravya ādayaḥ eva anugata vyāvṛtta jñāna viṣaya tvāt upacāreṇa vivakṣitāḥ atra hi jñāna viśeṣasya ākāra pratiṣedhe nyatra ākāra abhyupagamaḥ syāt śeṣam pūrvavat yathā jñāne na ākāraḥ sambhavati tathā uktam jñāna ākāra vāda pratiṣedha avasare
translated: Others, however, deny the existence of any form in the cognition produced by the contact of the sense-organs with their objects, by the word 'mātra' (in the aphorism), and declare that the result of perception is a cognition devoid of any form. They hold that the 'general' and the 'particular' are the substance, etc., themselves, which are figuratively spoken of as the objects of cognition that is both inclusive and exclusive. For, if the form of the cognition were denied here, it would be admitted elsewhere. The rest is as before. As to how the form of the cognition is not possible, it has been stated in the section on the denial of the form of the cognition.

original: athavā sarveṣu padārtheṣu catuṣṭaya sannikarṣād yad avitathamavyapadeśyaṃ jñānamutpadyate tatpratyakṣaṃ pramāṇam / prameyā dravyādayaḥ padārthāḥ / pramātā ātmā / pramitirguṇadoṣamādhyasthyadarśanamiti /PDhS
analyzed: athavā sarveṣu padārtheṣu catuṣṭaya sannikarṣāt yat avitatham avyapadeśyam jñānam utpadyate tat pratyakṣam pramāṇam prameyāḥ dravya ādayaḥ padārthāḥ pramātā ātmā pramitiḥ guṇa doṣa mādhyasthya darśanam iti
translated: Or, perception is that valid cognition which arises from the contact of the four (sense-organs, soul, mind and object), is not false, and is inexpressible. The objects of valid knowledge are substance, etc. The cognizer is the self. The result of valid knowledge is the perception of the good, bad, and indifferent qualities.

original: athavā iti pramāṇaphalavibhāge prakārāntaropadarśanam / na tu vikalpanārtham / heyādijñānotpattāvapi dravyādijñānaṃ pramāṇamiti vākyārthaḥ / tadāha sarveṣu padārtheṣu dravyādiṣu / yadavitathamavyapadeśyaṃ jñānamutpadyate tatpratyakṣaṃ pramāṇam / prameyā dravyādayaḥ padārthāḥ / pramātā ātmā / pramitirguṇadoṣamādhyasthyadarśanam iti / guṇadarśanamupādeyajñānam / doṣadarśanaṃ heyajñānam / upekṣaṇīyajñānañca mādhyasthyadarśanamiti /
analyzed: athavā iti pramāṇa phala vibhāge prakāra antara upadarśanam na tu vikalpana artham heya ādi jñāna utpattau api dravya ādi jñānam pramāṇam iti vākya arthaḥ tat āha sarveṣu padārtheṣu dravya ādiṣu yat avitatham avyapadeśyam jñānam utpadyate tat pratyakṣam pramāṇam prameyāḥ dravya ādayaḥ padārthāḥ pramātā ātmā pramitiḥ guṇa doṣa mādhyasthya darśanam iti guṇa darśanam upādeya jñānam doṣa darśanam heya jñānam upekṣaṇīya jñānam ca mādhy
translated: Or, the word 'vā' (in fact) indicates another way of dividing the means and objects of knowledge, not as an option. The meaning of the sentence is that even when knowledge of what is to be abandoned etc. arises, the knowledge of substance etc. is the means of knowledge. He says that in all things, substances etc., the knowledge that arises as undeceiving and inexpressible is perception, the means of knowledge. The objects of knowledge are substances etc., the things. The knower is the self. The result of knowledge is the perception of virtues, faults, and neutrality. The perception of virtues is the knowledge of what is to be accepted. The perception of faults is the knowledge of what is to be abandoned. The perception of what is to be disregarded is the perception of neutrality.

original: nanu dravyādijñānotpattāvanekakālavyavadhānenopādeyādijñānasyotpatteḥ kathaṃ dravyādijñānaphalatvam / pāramparyeṇeti / tathāhi / dravyatvādijātīyasya pūrvaṃ II / sukhaduḥkhasādhanatvopalabdhestajjñānānantaraṃ yad yad dravyatvādijātīyaṃ tattat sukhasādhanamityavinābhāvasmaraṇam / tathā cedaṃ dravyatvādijātīyamiti parāmarśajñānam / tasmāt sukhasādhanamiti viniścayaḥ / tata upādeyajñānam / ataḥ pāramparyeṇa dravyādijñānaphalatvam / samānañcaitaddheyopekṣaṇīyajñānotpattāvapīti /
analyzed: nanu dravya ādi jñāna utpattau aneka kāla vyavadhānena upādeya ādi jñānasya utpatteḥ katham dravya ādi jñāna phalatvam pāramparyeṇa iti  / tathā hi dravya tva ādi jātīyasya pūrvam sukha duḥkha sādhanatva upalabdheḥ tad jñāna anantaram yat yat dravya tva ādi jātīyam tat tat sukha sādhanam iti avinābhāva smaraṇam tathā ca idam dravya tva ādi jātīyam iti parāmarśa jñānam tasmāt sukha sādhanam iti viniścayaḥ tatas upādeya jñānam atas pāramparyeṇa dravya
translated: But when the knowledge of the desirable etc. arises with the interruption of many times in the arising of the knowledge of substance etc., how can it be the fruit of the knowledge of substance etc.? It is indirectly. Thus, because the means of producing pleasure and pain of the class of substantiality etc. was perceived before, after the knowledge of that, there is the recollection of invariable concomitance that whatever belongs to the class of substantiality etc. is a means of producing pleasure. And thus there is the knowledge of reflection that this belongs to the class of substantiality etc. From that there is the ascertainment that it is a means of producing pleasure. From that there is the knowledge of the desirable. Therefore, the knowledge of substance etc. is the fruit indirectly. And this is the same in the arising of the knowledge of the undesirable and the indifferent.

original: athopādeyādijñānasya sukhasādhanatvādiviniścayād viṣayabhedo vaktavyaḥ / anyathā hyanumānaphalatvameva syāt / pratyakṣaphalatvañca sukhaduḥkhādisādhanatvādi viniścayānantaramindriyārthasannikarṣeṇopādeyādijñānasyotpatteḥ / satyam / tathāpi viṣayabhedo viśeṣaṇabhedāt / sukhādisādhanatvaviśeṣaṇaṃ sukhasādhanādijñānāt / tasmāccopādeyādijñānamiti /
analyzed: atha upādeya ādi jñānasya sukha sādhana tva ādi viniścayāt viṣaya bhedaḥ vaktavyaḥ anyathā hi anumāna phalatvam eva syāt pratyakṣa phalatvam ca sukha duḥkha ādi sādhana tva ādi viniścaya anantaram indriya artha sannikarṣeṇa upādeya ādi jñānasya utpatteḥ satyam tathā api viṣaya bhedaḥ viśeṣaṇa bhedāt sukha ādi sādhana tva viśeṣaṇam sukha sādhana ādi jñānāt tasmāt ca upādeya ādi jñānam iti
translated: If it is argued that the difference in objects should be stated because of the ascertainment of the means of attaining happiness etc. from the knowledge of what is to be adopted etc., otherwise it would be the result of inference only, and the result of perception is the ascertainment of the means of attaining happiness, sorrow etc., and the arising of the knowledge of what is to be adopted etc. from the contact of the sense organ with the object after that ascertainment, it is true. Still, the difference in objects is due to the difference in qualifications. The qualification of being the means of attaining happiness etc. is from the knowledge of the means of attaining happiness etc. And from that arises the knowledge of what is to be adopted etc.

original: laiṅgikajñānalakṣaṇam
translated: The definition of inferential knowledge

original: liṅgadarśanāt sañjāyamānaṃ laiṅgikam /PDhS
analyzed: liṅga darśanāt sañjāyamānam laiṅgikam
translated: Inferential knowledge arises from the perception of the inferential mark.

original: pratyakṣānantaramuddeśavato laiṅgikasya lakṣaṇaparīkṣārthamāha liṅgadarśanāt sañjāyamānaṃ laiṅgikam iti / yadyapi liṅgadarśanāt saṃskāro viparyayajñānaṃ saṃśayajñānañca bhavati tathāpi vidyāsāmānyalakṣaṇānuvṛttau viśeṣalakṣaṇasyābhidhānānnātiprasaṅgaḥ /
analyzed: pratyakṣa anantaram uddeśavataḥ laiṅgikasya lakṣaṇa parīkṣā artham āha liṅga darśanāt sañjāyamānam laiṅgikam iti yadi api liṅga darśanāt saṃskāraḥ viparyaya jñānam saṃśaya jñānam ca bhavati tathā api vidyā sāmānya lakṣaṇa anuvṛttau viśeṣa lakṣaṇasya abhidhānāt na atiprasaṅgaḥ
translated: After perception, for the sake of defining and examining inferential knowledge, which has a topic, it is said: Inferential knowledge arises from the perception of the inferential mark. Although from the perception of the inferential mark, there arises a latent impression, erroneous knowledge, and doubtful knowledge, still, when the general definition of knowledge is applied, there is no over-extension due to the statement of the specific definition.

original: yad vā avitathaṃ vyavasāyātmakamavyapadeśyamiti viśeṣaṇamihāpyanuvartanīyam / avinābhāvasambandhasmaraṇantu vidyārūpaliṅgadarśanāt sañjāyate tadvyavacchedārthaṃ dravyādiṣūtpadyata ityanuvartanīyam / tadevaṃ liṅgadarśanād yadavyabhicāritvādiviśeṣaṇaṃ jñānamanumeye tad yataḥ parāmarśajñānopalakṣitāt kārakasamūhād bhavati tallaiṅgikamiti / parāmarśajñānaṃ vā liṅgadarśanād yathoktaviśeṣaṇajñānamutpadyate sādhakatamatvāpekṣayānumānam /🔽liṅganirūpaṇam
analyzed: yat vā avitatham vyavasāya ātmakam avyapadeśyam iti viśeṣaṇam iha api anuvartanīyam avinābhāva sambandha smaraṇam tu vidyā rūpa liṅga darśanāt sañjāyate tad vyavaccheda artham dravya ādiṣu utpadyate iti anuvartanīyam tat evam liṅga darśanāt yat avyabhicāri tva ādi viśeṣaṇam jñānam anumeye tat yatas parāmarśa jñāna upalakṣitāt kāraka samūhāt bhavati tat laiṅgikam iti parāmarśa jñānam vā liṅga darśanāt yathā ukta viśeṣaṇa jñānam utpadyate s
translated: Or, the qualification not false, determinate, incapable of being spoken of should be applied here also. But the recollection of the relation of invariable concomitance arises from the perception of the mark in the form of knowledge. In order to exclude that, arises in substances etc. should be applied. Thus, the knowledge which has the characteristics of non-deviation etc. with regard to the object to be inferred, arises from the collection of causes characterized by the knowledge of reflection. That is called inference. Or, the knowledge with the mentioned characteristics arises from the perception of the mark. Inference is that which is most effective in producing the knowledge.🔽The definition of the mark

original: liṅga punaḥ
analyzed: liṅga punar
translated: The mark is that which

original: yadanumeyena sambaddhaṃ prasiddhañca tadanvite /
analyzed: yad anumeyena sambaddham prasiddham ca tad anvite
translated: is related to the object to be inferred and is well-known, and is present in what possesses that,

original: tadabhāve ca nāstyeva talliṅgamanumāpakam //
analyzed: tad abhāve ca na asti eva tat liṅgam anumāpakam
translated: and is absent where that is absent. That is the mark which causes inference.

original: viparītamato yat syādekena dvitayena vā /
analyzed: viparītam atas yat syāt ekena dvitayena vā
translated: Therefore, what is contrary to that, either by one or both,

original: viruddhāsiddhasandigdhamaliṅgaṃ kāśyapo 'bravīt //PDhS
analyzed: viruddha asiddha sandigdham aliṅgam kāśyapaḥ bravīt
translated: Kāśyapa said that the contradictory, unestablished, and doubtful are invalid marks.

original: kiṃ punarliṅgamityāha liṅgaṃ punaḥ yadanumeyena sambaddham ityādi / II / anumeyaḥ pakṣaḥ pratyayādyadharma /pratipipādayiṣitadharmaviśiṣṭo dharmī tena vyāptyā sambaddham / vyāptistu vivaraṇavākyasahacaritapadāllabhyate / anyathā hi pakṣaikadeśe vartamānasyānumeyena sāhacaryaṃ syāt / yathā nityāḥ paramāṇavo gandhavattvād ato 'sya vyavacchedaḥ sahacaritapadena /
analyzed: kim punar liṅgam iti āha liṅgam punar yat anumeyena sambaddham ityādi   anumeyaḥ pakṣaḥ pratyaya ādi adharma pratipipādayiṣita dharma viśiṣṭaḥ dharmī tena vyāptyā sambaddham vyāptiḥ tu vivaraṇa vākya sahacarita padāt labhyate anyathā hi pakṣa eka deśe vartamānasya anumeyena sāhacaryam syāt yathā nityāḥ paramāṇavaḥ gandhavat tvāt vyavacchedaḥ sahacarita padena
translated: What again is the mark? He says: The mark is that which is connected with the inferable object, etc. The inferable object is the subject, the property to be established, the property possessor qualified by the property to be proved, connected with that by pervasion. But the pervasion is understood from the word accompanying the explanatory sentence. Otherwise, there would be concomitance with the inferable object of that which exists in a part of the subject, just as atoms are eternal because they possess smell. This is excluded by the word 'concomitant'.

original: anye tu punariti vīpsābhidhānasya vivakṣitatvālliṅgaṃ punaḥ punaryadanumeyena sambaddhamiti pakṣe vyāptirlabhyata iti bruvate /
analyzed: anye tu punar iti vīpsā abhidhānasya vivakṣita tvāt liṅgam punar punar yat anumeyena sambaddham iti pakṣe vyāptiḥ labhyate iti bruvate
translated: But others say that since the repetition is intended by the expression 'punah', the pervasion is understood in the subject 'the mark is that which is repeatedly connected with the inferable object'.

original: anumeyena sambaddhamevetyavadhāraṇād bhāgāsiddhavyudāsa iti cānye / tadasat / yata evakārakaraṇaṃ tato 'nyatrāvadhāraṇamiti nyāyābhyupagamenānumeyasamadhṛtaṃ /vyāptaṃ syāt na / liṅgam / anumeyo hi liṅgaṃ na jahātīti vyāptyā pakṣe sambandho jñāyate / liṅgasya tvanavadhāraṇādanyatrāpi vṛttirjñāyata iti vyarthaṃ tadanvite prasiddhamiti padamavadhāraṇārthaṃ kriyate / tatrāpi tadanvite prasiddhamevetyavadhāraṇābhyupagame sapakṣaikadeśavṛtteragamakatvaprasaṅgāt / atha vipakṣavṛttipratiṣedhārthaṃ tadanvita eva prasiddhamityavadhāryate / nanvevamanavadhāraṇenaiva vipakṣād vyāvṛttisiddheḥ vyarthaṃ tadabhāve ca nāstyeva iti padam / tathānumeyenaiva sambaddhamityavadhāraṇaṃ bādhitam / atha samuccīyamānāvadhāraṇametat / tathāhi / pakṣe vṛttau siddhāyāṃ vipakṣādeva vyavacchedārthamavadhāraṇam / tathāpyavadhāraṇasya vidyamānajñāpakatvād vipakṣādatyantaṃ vyāvṛttistato 'pi labhyata iti vyarthaṃ tadabhāve ca nāstyeva iti padam / tasyāpi vidyamānajñāpakatvāditi / na cānvayopadarśane sati vyatirekābhidhānam / vyatirekābhidhāne tvanvayasyāpratipādanam / ekābhidhānenāparasyārthādāpannatvāt svaśabdena punarvacanaṃ punaruktameva syādityevaṃvidhārthakathanārtham tadabhāve ca nāstyeva iti vacanamaśabdārthatvāt / parārthānumānasya cāprastutatvāt / tatraiṣa nyāya iti / tasmādavadhāraṇaṃ vinaiva prakārāntareṇa pakṣaikadeśavṛttivyudāso vācyaḥ /
analyzed: anumeyena sambaddham eva iti avadhāraṇāt bhāga asiddha vyudāsaḥ iti ca anye tat asat yatas evakāra karaṇam tatas nyatra avadhāraṇam iti nyāya abhyupagamena anumeya samadhṛtam vyāptam syāt na liṅgam anumeyaḥ hi liṅgam na jahāti iti vyāptyā pakṣe sambandhaḥ jñāyate liṅgasya tu anavadhāraṇāt anyatra api vṛttiḥ jñāyate iti vyartham tad anvite prasiddham iti padam avadhāraṇa artham kriyate tatra api tad anvite prasiddham eva iti avadhāraṇa abhyupagame sapakṣ
translated: Others say that the exclusion of partial inapplicability is due to the restriction that it is only what is related to the inferable object. That is incorrect. Because the rule is that the restriction is to be made from where the word eva is used, it would be the inferable object that is restricted, not the inferential mark. For the inferential mark is not abandoned by the inferable object, so the relation in the subject is known through pervasion. But because the inferential mark is not restricted, its occurrence elsewhere is known, so the word prasiddham eva in tadanvita is made to have the meaning of restriction. Even there, if the restriction prasiddham eva tadanvite is accepted, then there would be the undesirable consequence that what occurs in only a part of the similar instance would not be an indicator. If it is restricted to prasiddham eva tadanvite in order to exclude occurrence in the dissimilar instance, then since exclusion from the dissimilar instance is established by the non-restriction itself, the word ca na asti in tadabhāve is useless. Similarly, the restriction by the inferable object alone is contradicted. If it is added together with the dissimilar instance,

original: yeṣāntu sarvaṃ vākyaṃ sāvadhāraṇamiti mataṃ tallakṣaṇe hyetad dūṣaṇamanivāryamūhyam / yathā /
analyzed: yeṣām tu sarvam vākyam sāvadhāraṇam iti matam tad lakṣaṇe hi etat dūṣaṇam anivāryam ūhyam yathā
translated: But for those who consider that all statements are restrictive, this fault should be understood as unavoidable in their definition, as follows.

original: anumeye 'tha tattulye sadbhāvo 'sati nāstitā
analyzed: anumeye tha tad tulye sati na astitā
translated: Existence in the inferable object and its equivalent, non-existence in the absence of that,

original: iti / anumeyaḥ pakṣastatra sadbhāvaḥ / tattulyaḥ sapakṣastatra ceti / athaśabdaḥ caśabdasthāne / asati vipakṣe nāstitā vyāvṛttiryasya tālliṅgamiti / vipakṣastu tato 'nyaḥ / tadviruddhastadabhāvo vā / trividho 'pyasatītyanenāvaruddhaḥ / sādhyābhāvarūpatāyāḥ sarvatra samānatvāt / tatrānumeye eva sadbhāva ityavadhāraṇe 'sādhāraṇasya gamakatvaprasaṅgaḥ / na cāsmād bhāgāsiddhivyudāsaḥ / padāntaravaiyarthyañca / athānumeye sadbhāva evetyayogavyavacchedaḥ / tathāpi sadbhāvasyānavadhāraṇālliṅgasyānyatrāpi vṛttirlabhyata iti vyarthaṃ tattulye sadbhāvaḥ iti padam / athāvadhāraṇārthaṃ kriyate / tatrāpi tattulya eva sadbhāva ityavadhāraṇe pūrvottaravyāghātaḥ / atha pakṣe vṛttau siddhāyāṃ vipakṣādervyavacchedārthaṃ samuccīyamānāvadhāraṇametat / tathāpi asati nāstitā iti na kāryam / avadhāraṇena gatārthatvāt / na ca tulye sadbhāva evetyavadhāraṇaṃ yuktam / sapakṣaikadeśavṛtterapi gamakatvābhyupagamāt / atha asatyeva nāstītyavadhāraṇārthaṃ padam / tathāpi vipakṣaikadeśavṛttergamakatvaprasaṅgaḥ / tasya hi vipakṣa eva nāstiteti / asati nāstyevetyavadhāraṇam / tathāpi nāstitāyā vipakṣavyatirekeṇānyatrāpi sadbhāvo labhyata ityasādhāraṇādergamakatvaprasaṅgaḥ / tasmāt sarvaṃ vākyaṃ sāvadhāraṇamiti pakṣe dūṣaṇametadanivāryam /
analyzed: iti anumeyaḥ pakṣaḥ tatra sadbhāvaḥ tad tulyaḥ sapakṣaḥ tatra ca iti atha śabdaḥ caśabda sthāne asati vipakṣe na astitā vyāvṛttiḥ yasya tālliṅgam iti vipakṣaḥ tu tatas nyaḥ tad viruddhaḥ tad abhāvaḥ vā trividhaḥ pi asati iti anena avaruddhaḥ sādhya abhāva rūpa tāyāḥ sarvatra samāna tvāt tatra anumeye eva sadbhāvaḥ iti avadhāraṇe sādhāraṇasya gamaka tva prasaṅgaḥ na ca asmāt bhāga asiddhi vyudāsaḥ pada antara vaiyarthyam ca atha anum
translated: Thus, the subject is what is to be inferred, and its presence there is similar to that in a similar instance. The word atha is used in place of ca. The inferential mark is that which has the exclusion of non-existence in the dissimilar instance. The dissimilar instance is that which is different from it, or that which is contradictory to it, or the absence of it. All three types are included by the phrase asati. Because the form of being the absence of the probandum is the same everywhere. There, if it is restricted to the presence only in the subject, then there would be the consequence of the uncommon being the indicator. And from this, there would be no exclusion of the fallacy of incompleteness. And there would be the uselessness of the other word. If it is a negation of impossibility, saying only in the subject, then even so, because the presence is not determined, the occurrence of the inferential mark elsewhere is obtained. Therefore, the phrase present in what is similar to that is useless. If it is done for the purpose of restriction, then even there, if it is restricted to the presence only in what is similar to that, there is contradiction between the previous and subsequent statements. If it is said that the occurrence in the subject is established, and then the exclusion of the dissimilar instance and so on is done, then there is the fallacy of incompleteness.

original: vistareṇa cāvadhāraṇapakṣo 'smadgurubhirnirasta iti neha pratanyate /
analyzed: vistareṇa ca avadhāraṇa pakṣaḥ smat gurubhiḥ nirastaḥ iti nā iha pratanyate
translated: And our teachers have refuted the view of restriction in detail; therefore it is not elaborated here.

original: athāstu avadhāraṇaṃ vinaiva sahacaritapadāt bhāgāsiddhivyudāsastathāpyetadrūpaṃ viruddhāsādhāraṇayorastīti tadvyavacchedārthaṃ prasiddhañca tadanvite iti / tenānumeyasamānadharmeṇānvito yuktastasmin tadanvite prasiddham / na caivaṃ viruddhāsādhāraṇāviti / tathāpyanaikāntikasya pakṣadharmatvaṃ sapakṣe sattvañcāstīti tadabhāve ca nāstyeva iti padam / tasya sādhyasamānadharmasyābhāvo yasmin dharmiṇi tatrātyantaṃ nāstyeveti / na caivamanaikāntikam /
analyzed: atha astu avadhāraṇam vinā eva sahacarita padāt bhāga asiddhi vyudāsaḥ tathā api etad rūpam viruddha asādhāraṇayoḥ asti iti tad vyavaccheda artham prasiddham ca tad anvite iti tena anumeya samāna dharmeṇa anvitaḥ yuktaḥ tasmin tad anvite prasiddham na ca evam viruddha asādhāraṇau iti tathā api anaikāntikasya pakṣa dharma tvam sapakṣe sattvam ca asti iti tad abhāve ca na asti eva iti padam tasya sādhya samāna dharmasya abhāvaḥ yasmin dharmiṇi tatra atyantam na asti
translated: Now, let there be restriction even without the co-occurring word, to exclude the fallacy of partial inapplicability. Even so, this form exists for the contradictory and the uncommon. Therefore, to exclude them, the word well-known is used in connection with that. Thus, it is well-known in that which is connected with that which has the same property as the inferable. And the contradictory and the uncommon do not have this. Even so, the inconclusive has the property of the subject and exists in the similar instance. And when it is absent, it does not exist. The word absence means that the absence of that probandum-sharing property is absolutely non-existent in that subject. And the inconclusive is not like this.

original: nanvevamapi prakaraṇasamakālātyayāpadiṣṭayostrailakṣaṇyopapattergamakatvaprasaṅgaḥ / tathā ca anuṣṇastejo 'vayavī kṛtakatvāt ghaṭavaditi satyapi trailakṣaṇye pratyakṣeII /ṇoṣṇatāgrāhiṇā bādhyamānatvāt kālātyayāpadiṣṭaḥ / prakaraṇasamastāvat nityaḥ śabdaḥ anupalabhyamānānityadharmakatvāt ākāśādivat / anityaḥ śabdaḥ anupalabhyamānanityadharmakatvāt ghaṭavat / atrāpi trailakṣaṇyasadbhāve 'pyagamakatvaṃ satpratipakṣatvāt / ataścānayorvyavacchedārthamabādhitaviṣayatvamasatpratipakṣatvañca samānatantragatamabhyūhyam / caśabdasyānuktasamuccayārthatvāt /
analyzed: nanu evam api prakaraṇasama kālātyayāpadiṣṭayoḥ trailakṣaṇya upapatteḥ gamaka tva prasaṅgaḥ tathā ca anuṣṇaḥ tejaḥ vayavī kṛtaka tvāt ghaṭa vat iti sati api trailakṣaṇye bādhyamāna tvāt kālātyaya apadiṣṭaḥ prakaraṇasamaḥ tāvat nityaḥ śabdaḥ anupalabhyamāna anitya dharmaka tvāt ākāśa ādi vat anityaḥ śabdaḥ anupalabhyamāna nitya dharmaka tvāt ghaṭa vat atra api trailakṣaṇya sadbhāve pi agamaka tvam sat pratipakṣa tvāt atas ca
translated: Even so, the three characteristics being present in the too wide and contradictory fallacies, there is the contingence of their being probans. And so, fire is not hot, because it is an aggregate, like a jar, although the three characteristics are present, it is contradicted by the perception of heat. The too wide fallacy is as follows: Sound is eternal, because it is not perceived to have non-eternal properties, like ākāśa. Sound is non-eternal, because it is not perceived to have eternal properties, like a jar. Even here, although the three characteristics are present, it is not a probans, because it has a counter-probans. And so, for the exclusion of these two, the condition of having an uncontradicted content and the absence of a counter-probans should be understood to be implied by the word and in the definition, since it has the sense of including what is not stated.

original: anye tu pratijñādoṣeṇa gatārthatvānna kālātyayāpadiṣṭo hetvābhāsāntaram / tathā ca nityānityaviśeṣānupalabdheritaretaravādyabhiprāyeṇa asiddhe 'ntarbhāva iti bruvate / taccāsat / pratijñādoṣasadbhāve 'pi hetorduṣṭapakṣopanyāsānantaramupanyāsāt kālātyayāpadiṣṭatvamucyate / atha bādhāvinābhāvayorvirodhānna pratyakṣeṇa trilakṣaṇasya bādhā / abhyupagame vā na trailakṣaṇyamiti / tanna / tejo 'vayavino 'nuṣṇatve sādhye kṛtakatvasya hetostrailakṣaṇyasadbhāve 'pi pakṣeṇa viparītārthopasthāpanād bādhitaviṣayatvenāvinābhāvasyaivāprasiddheḥ / pratyakṣavyavasthāpitena ca vapuṣā sarvaprāṇabhṛtāmarthakriyājanako 'gnirna rūpāntareṇeti svaviṣayasahakāri pratyakṣam / na caivamanumānamiti bādhyate /
analyzed: anye tu pratijñā doṣeṇa gatārtha tvāt na kāla atyaya apadiṣṭaḥ hetvābhāsa antaram tathā ca nitya anitya viśeṣa anupalabdheḥ itaretara vādi abhiprāyeṇa asiddhe ntarbhāvaḥ iti bruvate tat ca asat pratijñā doṣa sadbhāve pi hetoḥ duṣṭa pakṣa upanyāsa anantaram upanyāsāt kāla atyaya apadiṣṭa tvam ucyate atha bādhā vinābhāvayoḥ virodhāt na pratyakṣeṇa tri lakṣaṇasya bādhā abhyupagame vā na trailakṣaṇyam iti tat na tejaḥ vayavinaḥ sādhy
translated: Others, however, say that since it is already covered by the fault of the thesis, the fallacy of being beyond temporal limitation is not a separate fallacy. And thus, they say, since the distinction between eternal and non-eternal is not perceived, it is included in the unestablished when it is intended by the proponent or opponent. But that is wrong. Even when the fault of the thesis exists, it is said to be beyond temporal limitation because it is stated after the faulty position of the reason has been presented. Now, if it is said that the three characteristics are not contradicted by perception because contradiction and invariable concomitance are incompatible, or that if they are accepted, there is no three-fold characteristic, that is not so. Even when the reason of being produced has the three characteristics in proving that the part of fire is not hot, the invariable concomitance is not established because of the subject's presentation of the opposite meaning. And perception establishes the body of all living beings as the producer of practical efficiency, fire, not in another form. Thus, perception is the cooperative condition of its own object. And inference is not like that. Therefore, it is contradicted.

original: atha duṣṭasyaivānumānasya pratyakṣeṇaiva bādhanād yena doṣeṇa duṣṭaṃ tadevāstu dūṣaṇamalaṃ pratyakṣabādhayā / na / pratyakṣeṇa dūṣaṇasyaiva jñāpanāt / tathāhi / viparītārthamupasthāpayatā pratyakṣeṇopadarśitaṃ bādhitaviṣayametadanumānamiti / atha kāryasyānuṣṇatve sādhye taijasaparamāṇūnāmuṣṇānuṣṇatve pramāṇābhāvāt sandigdhavyatirekitvena kṛtakatvasyāgamakatvaṃ na kālātyayāpadiṣṭatvāditi cet / naitadevam / yo hi paramāṇuṣūṣṇatvamabhyupagamya tatkārye 'nuṣṇatvaṃ prasādhayet taṃ prati vyatirekaniścayopapatteḥ / na ca sandigdhavyatirekasyāpi uṣṇapakṣopanyāsānantaramabhidhānāt kālātyayāpadiṣṭatvaṃ virudhyate / na cāyaṃ niyamo yatraikaṃ dūṣaṇaṃ tatrānyannāstīti / yathānekaviśeṣaṇāsiddhatvādihetoriti /
analyzed: atha duṣṭasya eva anumānasya pratyakṣeṇa eva bādhanāt yena doṣeṇa duṣṭam tat eva astu dūṣaṇam alam pratyakṣa bādhayā na pratyakṣeṇa dūṣaṇasya eva jñāpanāt tathā hi viparīta artham upasthāpayatā pratyakṣeṇa upadarśitam bādhita viṣayam etat anumānam iti atha kāryasya anuṣṇa tve sādhye taijasa paramāṇūnām uṣṇa anuṣṇa tve pramāṇa abhāvāt sandigdha vyatireki tvena kṛtaka tvasya āgamaka tvam na kāla atyaya apadiṣṭa tvāt iti ced
translated: If it is argued that since inference itself is contradicted by perception, let the fault by which it is defective be the refutation, what is the use of contradiction by perception? No, because the refutation is known by perception itself. Thus, when perception presents a contrary meaning, it shows that this inference has a contradicted object. If it is argued that when the effect's non-hotness is to be proved, since there is no evidence for the hot and non-hotness of fiery atoms, the reason of being produced is inconclusive due to doubtful difference, and is not fallacious due to being contradicted by a later proof, that is not so. Because for one who accepts hotness in atoms and proves non-hotness in their effect, the ascertainment of difference is possible. And even for one with doubtful difference, after stating the side of heat, the contradiction by being contradicted by a later proof is not reasonable. And there is no rule that where there is one fault, there are not others. As in the case of a reason with many unestablished qualifiers, etc.

original: yaccedaṃ tattvānupalabdheritaretaravādyabhiprāyeṇāsiddhatvam ityuktam / tadasat / ubhayoḥ sandigdhatvāt / tathāhi / sāmānyopalambhādisadbhāve sati viśeṣānupalambhād vādiprativādinoḥ pūrvamupajātaḥ saṃśayaḥ / tatraikaḥ sandigdhaḥ parapratāraṇābhiprāyeṇa saṃśaya /yitaṃ hetumeva dharminirṇayārthamupādatte / tathetaro 'pi sandigdhaḥ / II / tadevamubhayoḥ saṃśayānnānyatarasyāpi asiddhatodbhāvane sāmarthyamiti / yadi cānyataro 'pi nityānityaviśeṣopalambhaṃ pramāṇena brūyāt tadā asiddhatvameva na prakaraṇasamatvamiti / na ca sandigdhāvasthāyāṃ viruddhāvyabhicāriṇaḥ prayoga iti tasmād vyatirekaḥ / nāpi viruddhāvyabhicārī sambhavatīti vakṣyāmaḥ /
analyzed: yat ca idam tattva anupalabdheḥ itaretara vādi abhiprāyeṇa asiddha tvam iti uktam tat asat ubhayoḥ sandigdha tvāt tathā hi sāmānya upalambha ādi sadbhāve sati viśeṣa anupalambhāt vādi prativādinoḥ pūrvam upajātaḥ saṃśayaḥ tatra ekaḥ sandigdhaḥ para pratāraṇa abhiprāyeṇa saṃśaya yitam hetum eva dharmi nirṇaya artham upādatte tathā itaraḥ pi sandigdhaḥ  / tat evam ubhayoḥ saṃśayāt na anyatarasya api asiddha tā udbhāvane sāmarthyam iti  /
translated: And as for what has been said regarding the ‘falsity’ of the Reason, on the ground of its being suspected of being ‘unproven’,—that is not right; because both are open to doubt. For instance, when there is a doubt as to the presence of the ‘Universal’ and the rest, the disputants, on the ground of the non-apprehension of the specific peculiarity, have their doubt aroused; one of them, being in doubt, and suspecting the other of having a motive behind him, puts forward the Reason in question, for the purpose of ascertaining the real state of things; the other also is in doubt; so that neither of them is in a position to urge the falsity of the Reason; if, on the other hand, either of them were to assert the presence of the particular ‘Universal’ and the rest, by means of a valid means of cognition, then the Reason would be ‘unproven’, and not ‘inconclusive’; and when there is doubt, there can be no ‘contradictory’ or ‘inconclusive’ reason; hence the Reason is not ‘inconclusive’. Nor is it ‘contradictory’; as we shall explain later on.

original: tadevamanayorvyavacchedārtham abādhitaviṣayatvamasatpratipakṣitatvañca rūpāntaramabhyupagantavyam / anyathā hi praty /tryavayavaṃ vākyaṃ syānna pañcāvayavam / avayavadvayasyaitadvyavacchedārthaparatvāditi /
analyzed: tat evam anayoḥ vyavaccheda artham abādhita viṣaya tvam asat pratipakṣita tvam ca rūpa antaram abhyupagantavyam anyathā hi pratyartham vākyam syāt na pañca avayavam avayava dvayasya etad vyavaccheda artha paratvāt iti
translated: Thus, in order to distinguish these two, it is necessary to accept another form, namely, that the object is not contradicted and that it is not opposed by valid cognition. Otherwise, the sentence would have three parts, not five, because the two parts are for the purpose of distinguishing this.

original: nanvevamapi nyūnaṃ lakṣaṇavākyam / kevalānvayinaḥ kevalavyatirekiṇaścāvyāpanāditi / asti ca tayoḥ sādhyasādhanatvam / tathā ca yatra sāmānyameva sādhyaṃ tatra sāmānyameva hetuḥ / yathā abhidheyo viśeṣaḥ prameyatvāt sāmānyavaditi / viśeṣāṇāmabhidheyatve sādhye 'nabhidheyasya vastuno 'sambhavād vipakṣābhāvaḥ / pramāṇena hi vipakṣamupalabhya tasmād vyatirekaṃ vacanenopapādayatastatrābhidheyatvaprameyatvayoḥ prāptestasya sapakṣatvameva syāditi na vipakṣād vyatireko 'stītyato 'nvayāvyabhicāreṇaiva gamakatvam /
analyzed: nanu evam api nyūnam lakṣaṇa vākyam kevala anvayinaḥ kevala vyatirekiṇaḥ ca avyāpanāt iti asti ca tayoḥ sādhya sādhana tvam tathā ca yatra sāmānyam eva sādhyam tatra sāmānyam eva hetuḥ yathā abhidheyaḥ viśeṣaḥ prameya tvāt sāmānya vat iti viśeṣāṇām abhidheya tve sādhye sambhavāt vipakṣa abhāvaḥ pramāṇena hi vipakṣam upalabhya tasmāt vyatirekam vacanena upapādayataḥ tatra abhidheya tva prameya tvayoḥ prāpteḥ tasya sapakṣa tvam eva syāt iti
translated: But even so, the definition is incomplete, as it does not cover only positive or only negative examples. However, they do have the nature of probans and probandum. And in that case, where the universal alone is the probandum, the reason is also a universal, as in The particular is expressible, because it is an object of knowledge, like a universal. When the particularity of being expressible is the probandum, there is no counter-example, as there is no possible object that is not expressible. For by means of a valid means of knowledge one perceives the counter-example, and then establishes its exclusion from that by verbal statement. Since expressibility and being an object of knowledge are obtained in that case, it would be a similar instance, and there is no exclusion from the counter-example. Therefore, it is only by invariable concomitance with the positive instance that it is an indicator.

original: tathā jīvaccharīraṃ nirātmakaṃ na bhavati / aprāṇādimattvaprasaṅgād / yad yad nirātmakaṃ tattadaprāṇādimad yathā ghaṭādi / na ca tathā jīvaccharīram / tasmānnirātmakaṃ na bhavatīti / sarvasya nirātmakatvābhyupagamājjīvaccharīrasya nairātmyapratiṣedhe sādhye na sapakṣo 'sti / prāṇādimattvañca vipakṣādevātyantavyāvṛttam / ato vyatirekāvyabhicāreṇaiva gamakatvam / na caivamasādhāraṇam / tasya pakṣādivat sapakṣādapi vyāvṛttervyabhicāreṇāgamakatvāt / atha nairātmyapratiṣedhenātra sātmakatvaṃ vivakṣitam / na cātmā prasiddha ityaprasiddhaviśeṣaṇaḥ pakṣaḥ / tannairātmye 'pi samānam / aprasiddhatvādātmanaḥ kathaṃ tatpratiṣedhaḥ / na ca kalpanāsamāropitasya pratiṣedhaḥ / vāstavatvena pratipādanāt / pratyakṣādipramāṇaiśca ātmā pratipādakasya prasiddhastadapekṣayā na aprasiddhaviśeṣaṇatā pakṣadoṣaḥ / pratipādyāpekṣayā tu naitad dūṣaṇam / apratipannatattvasya pratipādyatvāt / sapakṣe tu aprasiddhatvaṃ na vyatirekiṇo dūṣaṇam / tasya vyatirekāvyabhicāreṇaiva gamakaII /tvāt / ayaṃ sapakṣābhāva eva sapakṣastasminnanuvṛttāvanvayopapattiḥ / vyāvṛttau tu asādhāraṇatvameva / taduktam /
analyzed: tathā jīvat śarīram nirātmakam na bhavati aprāṇa ādimattva prasaṅgāt yat yat nirātmakam tat tat aprāṇa ādimat yathā ghaṭa ādi na ca tathā jīvat śarīram tasmāt nirātmakam na bhavati iti sarvasya nirātmaka tva abhyupagamāt jīvat śarīrasya nairātmya pratiṣedhe sādhye na sapakṣaḥ sti prāṇa ādimattvam ca vipakṣāt eva atyanta vyāvṛttam atas vyatireka avyabhicāreṇa eva gamaka tvam na ca evam asādhāraṇam tasya pakṣa ādi vat sapakṣāt api vyāvṛtteḥ
translated: Similarly, the living body is not without a self, because it would follow that it would be devoid of life and so on. Whatever is without a self is devoid of life and so on, like a pot and so on. And the living body is not like that. Therefore, it is not without a self. Since the non-existence of a self is accepted in all cases, there is no similar instance in the case of the living body when the negation of non-self is to be established. And the possession of life and so on is entirely excluded from the dissimilar instance. Therefore, it is only by the invariable concomitance of the negative concomitance that it is an indicator. And it is not so in the case of the uncommon [reason], because it is not an indicator due to the invariable concomitance of the exclusion from the similar instance and so on. Now, if the possession of a self is intended here by the negation of non-self, and the self is not well-known, then the subject is one whose qualifier is not well-known. That is the same even in the case of non-self. How can there be a negation of that [self] when it is not well-known? And the negation is not of what is superimposed by imagination, because it is taught as real.

original: nivṛttiryadi tasminna hetorvṛttiḥ kimiṣyate /
analyzed: nivṛttiḥ yadi tasmin na hetoḥ vṛttiḥ kim iṣyate
translated: If there is no cessation in that [non-example], what is the cause for the occurrence [of the reason in the similar example]?

original: sāpi na pratiṣedho 'yaṃ nivṛttiḥ kiṃ niṣidhyate // pra / vā / /
analyzed: sā api na pratiṣedhaḥ yam nivṛttiḥ kim niṣidhyate pra vā
translated: That too is not a negation. Is this cessation being negated?

original: iti /
analyzed: iti
translated: Thus.

original: asyārthaḥ / tasmin sapakṣābhāve hetoryadi nivṛttirnāsti / vṛttiḥ syāt / tadvyāvṛttirūpatvāt / vṛttipratiṣedhe tu nivṛttireva syāditi / na ca vidhipratiṣedhavyatirekeṇāparaḥ śābdo vyavahāraḥ sambhavatīti mūkatāprasaṅgaḥ / tadetadasat / pakṣābhāvasyāpi sādhyānadhikaraṇatvena vipakṣatvāt / tasmācca nivṛttireva aprāṇādimattvāditi hetoḥ /
analyzed: asya arthaḥ tasmin sapakṣa abhāve hetoḥ yadi nivṛttiḥ na asti vṛttiḥ syāt tad vyāvṛtti rūpatvāt vṛtti pratiṣedhe tu nivṛttiḥ eva syāt iti na ca vidhi pratiṣedha vyatirekeṇa aparaḥ śābdaḥ vyavahāraḥ sambhavati iti mūka tā prasaṅgaḥ tat etat asat pakṣa abhāvasya api sādhya anadhikaraṇa tvena vipakṣa tvāt tasmāt ca nivṛttiḥ eva aprāṇa ādimat tvāt iti hetoḥ
translated: The meaning of this is: If there is no cessation of the reason in the absence of the similar example, there would be occurrence, because it has the form of that exclusion. But in the negation of occurrence, there would be only cessation. And since verbal usage other than affirmation and negation is not possible, there would be the consequence of muteness. This is not correct, because even the absence of the similar example is the dissimilar example, since it is not the locus of what is to be proved. And from that, there is only cessation of the reason because it does not have life, etc.

original: na ca kalpanāsamāropitatvāt pakṣādivyavasthāyāḥ kalpite sapakṣe hetorvṛttāvanvayavyatirekitvam / vyāvṛttau tvasādhāraṇatvamiti dūṣaṇam / vāstavatvāt pakṣādivyavasthāyāḥ / kalpitatve tu kathaṃ hetutadābhāsavyavasthā / kalpanāyāḥ sarvatrāviśeṣāt / atha ghaṭādau kiṃ sātmakatvavyāvṛttyā prāṇādimattvavyāvṛttiruta vastusvābhāvyāditi sandigdho vyetirekaḥ / na ca ghaṭādau sātmakatvasya sadasattve pramāṇamasti / naitadevam / prāṇādimattvasya kāryaviśeṣasyābhāvena tatkāraṇaviśeṣasya sātmakatvasya tatra vyāvṛttiprasiddheḥ / tathā hi / prāṇādimati śarīre prāṇādyutpādanasamarthātmasambandhaviśeṣaḥ sātmakatvaṃ sādhayati / tadabhāvastu prāṇādikāryābhāvenaiva jñāyate ghaṭādāviti /
analyzed: na ca kalpanā samāropita tvāt pakṣa ādi vyavasthāyāḥ kalpite sapakṣe hetoḥ vṛttau anvaya vyatireki tvam vyāvṛttau tu asādhāraṇa tvam iti dūṣaṇam vāstava tvāt pakṣa ādi vyavasthāyāḥ kalpita tve tu katham hetu tad ābhāsa vyavasthā kalpanāyāḥ sarvatra aviśeṣāt  atha ghaṭa ādau kim sātmaka tva vyāvṛttyā prāṇa ādimattva vyāvṛttiḥ uta vastu svābhāvyāt iti sandigdhaḥ vyetirekaḥ na ca ghaṭa ādau sātmaka tvasya sat asattve pramāṇam asti
translated: And the establishment of the subject and so on is not superimposed by imagination. When the reason occurs in the imagined similar instance, it has concomitance and non-concomitance. But in the excluded instance, it is a fallacy to say it is not common, because the establishment of the subject and so on is real. But if it were imagined, how could there be an establishment of the reason and its fallacies? Because imagination is not distinguished anywhere. Now, in the case of a pot, is the exclusion of having a soul the exclusion of having breath and so on, or is it due to the nature of the thing itself? Thus the non-concomitance is doubtful. And there is no evidence as to whether having a soul exists or does not exist in a pot. This is not so. Because the exclusion of having a soul, which is the cause of a particular effect, is established by the absence of that particular effect, such as breath and so on. Thus, in a body that has breath and so on, the special connection with the soul that is capable of producing breath and so on proves having a soul. But its absence is known by the mere absence of the effect of breath and so on in a pot and so on.

original: nanvevaṃ kāryasya kāraṇapūrvakatvenopalambha /bdhatvādanvayopapatteḥ kathaṃ kevalavyatirekitvam / na / kāryaviśeṣeṇa kāraṇaviśeṣe sādhye 'nvayābhāvāt / jīvaccharīre hi prāṇādyutpādanasamarthātmasambandhaviśeṣaḥ sādhyastena cānvayābhāva eva / yasya tu sarvaṃ nirātmakamiti pakṣaḥ sa kathaṃ ghaṭādau kiṃ / sātmakatvaṃ vyāvṛttaṃ na veti sandehaṃ brūyāt /
analyzed: nanu evam kāryasya kāraṇa pūrvaka tvena upalambha bdha tvāt anvaya upapatteḥ katham kevala vyatireki tvam na kārya viśeṣeṇa kāraṇa viśeṣe sādhye nvaya abhāvāt jīvat śarīre hi prāṇa ādi utpādana samartha ātma sambandha viśeṣaḥ sādhyaḥ tena ca anvaya abhāvaḥ eva yasya tu sarvam nirātmakam iti pakṣaḥ sa katham ghaṭa ādau kim sātmaka tvam vyāvṛttam na vā iti sandeham brūyāt
translated: But in that case, since the effect is found to be preceded by the cause, the positive concomitance being established, how can it be a purely negative inference? No, because when a particular cause is to be established by a particular effect, there is no positive concomitance. For in the living body, the particular connection with the self capable of producing life etc. is to be established, and there is no positive concomitance with that. But for one who holds that everything is without self, how can he say whether the presence of self is excluded or not in a pot etc.?

original: nāpi buddhyādinivṛttāveva prāṇādinivṛttirghaṭādāviti vācyam / ādiśabdena sarveṣāmavarodhāt / tadutpādanasamarthaśca ātmasambandhaviśeṣaḥ sādhyastadabhāve tu kathaṃ buddhyādīnāmutpattiḥ / jīvaccharīre kāraṇābhāvena kāryasyābhāvaII /prasaṅgāt / kṣaṇikatve ca sati kāryakāraṇabhāvaḥ pūrvaṃ pratiṣiddha iti na bodhād buddhyādīnāmutpattiḥ / tadevaṃ prāṇādikāryaviśeṣaḥ kāraṇaviśeṣe sādhye vyatirekāvyabhicāreṇaiva gamaka iti /
analyzed: nā api buddhi ādi nivṛttau eva prāṇa ādi nivṛttiḥ ghaṭa ādau iti vācyam ādi śabdena sarveṣām avarodhāt tad utpādana samarthaḥ ca ātma sambandha viśeṣaḥ sādhyaḥ tad abhāve tu katham buddhi ādīnām utpattiḥ jīvat śarīre kāraṇa abhāvena
translated: Nor can it be said that the cessation of life, etc. is only when there is cessation of intellect, etc., in a pot, etc., because all are included by the word 'etc.' And the special relation with the self, which is capable of producing that, is to be established. But in the absence of that, how can there be the origination of intellect, etc.? Because there is the contingence of the absence of effect due to the absence of cause in the living body. And the relation of cause and effect, when there is momentariness, has been previously refuted. Therefore, the origination of intellect, etc. is not from consciousness. Thus, the special effect of life, etc. is the convincer only by invariable concomitance in the absence of the special cause, when the special cause is to be established.

original: nanu śaśaviṣāṇādivaccharīraṃ prāṇādimattvena sādhyaṃ syāditi dūṣaṇam / tadabhāvāyattavyāvṛtteḥ pratipattumaśakyatvāditi / prāṇādyutpattau ca kāraṇatvābhyupagamena kāryaviśeṣavyāvṛttyā yadi kāraṇaviśeṣavyāvṛttiriṣyate saṃjñābhedamātraṃ syāt / viparyaye tu sa na syāt tadabhāvāyattapratipattyabhāva ityalam /
analyzed: nanu śaśaviṣāṇa ādi vat śarīram prāṇa ādimattvena sādhyam syāt iti dūṣaṇam tad abhāva āyatta vyāvṛtteḥ pratipattum aśakyatvāt iti prāṇa ādi utpattau ca kāraṇatva abhyupagamena kārya viśeṣa vyāvṛttyā yadi kāraṇa viśeṣa vyāvṛttiḥ iṣyate saṃjñā bheda mātram syāt viparyaye tu sa na syāt tad abhāva āyatta pratipatti abhāvaḥ iti alam
translated: But the objection is that the body should be proved to have life etc. like the horns of a rabbit, because it is impossible to understand the exclusion dependent on its absence. And if the production of life etc. is accepted as the cause, if the exclusion of a particular effect is accepted, there would be only a difference in name. But if it is the opposite, it would not be so, because there is no understanding dependent on its absence. That is enough.

original: nanvevaṃ kathamanayorlakṣaṇavākyenāvarodhaḥ / vākyabhedena / tathāhi / 'yadanumeyena sambaddhaṃ vipakṣābhāve ca tadanvita eva prasiddhamiti kevalānvayī / pakṣadharmatve sati sapakṣābhāvāt tadabhāva eva nāstyeveti kevalavyatirekī / sāmānyalakṣaṇantu sati sādhane sādhyasyāvaśyambhāvaniyamaḥ / sādhyasādhanatvamanumāpakatvapadenoktamiti / liṅgabhāsanirūpaṇārthamāha
analyzed: nanu evam katham anayoḥ lakṣaṇa vākyena avarodhaḥ vākya bhedena tathā hi yat anumeyena sambaddham vipakṣa abhāve ca tad anvite eva prasiddham iti kevala anvayī pakṣa dharma tve sati sapakṣa abhāvāt tad abhāvaḥ eva na asti eva iti kevala vyatirekī sāmānya lakṣaṇam tu sati sādhane sādhyasya avaśyambhāva niyamaḥ sādhya sādhana tvam anumāpaka tva padena uktam iti liṅga bhāsa nirūpaṇa artham āha
translated: But how can these two be included in the definition sentence in this way? By a difference in sentences. Thus, That which is related to the inferable object and is known to be invariably concomitant with it in the absence of the contrary is the positive example. When it is a property of the subject, it is necessarily absent in the absence of the similar instance, so it is the negative example. But the general definition is the rule that the probandum must necessarily be present when the probans is present. The relation of probandum and probans is stated by the word inferable. To define the inferential mark, he says:

original: viparītamato yat syādekena dvitayena vā /
analyzed: viparītam atas yat syāt ekena dvitayena vā
translated: Kāśyapa said that what is contrary to that, either by one or by two,

original: viruddhāsiddhasandigdhamaliṅgaṃ kāśyapo 'bravīt //
analyzed: viruddha asiddha sandigdham aliṅgam kāśyapaḥ bravīt
translated: is contradictory, unestablished, and doubtful, a non-reason.

original: iti /
analyzed: iti
translated: Thus.🔽From the reason stated, what is contrary, either by one property, or by two properties,

original: ata ityuktarūpālliṅgād yad viparītamekena dharmeṇa dharmadvitayena / vāśabdāt tribhiśceti / tadaliṅagaṃ liṅagapratirūpakamiti kāśyapo 'bravīt / viruddhāsiddhasandigdhamiti viśeṣasaṃjñānirdeśaḥ / tatra dharmadvayasadbhāve 'pi sandigdho na vipakṣād vyāvṛtta ityekena dharmeṇa viparītaḥ / viruddhastu pakṣadharmatvasadbhāve 'pi na sapakṣe vartate nāpi vipakṣād vyāvṛtta iti dharmadvayena viparītaḥ / asiddhastvekena dvābhyāṃ tribhiśca viparīto bhavatīti /
analyzed: atas iti ukta rūpāt liṅgāt yat viparītam ekena dharmeṇa dharma dvitayena vā śabdāt tribhiḥ ca iti tat aliṅagam liṅaga pratirūpakam iti kāśyapaḥ bravīt viruddha asiddha sandigdham iti viśeṣa saṃjñā nirdeśaḥ tatra dharma dvaya sadbhāve sandigdhaḥ na vipakṣāt vyāvṛttaḥ iti ekena dharmeṇa viparītaḥ viruddhaḥ tu pakṣa dharma tva sadbhāve na sapakṣe vartate na api vipakṣāt vyāvṛttaḥ iti dharma dvayena viparītaḥ asiddhaḥ tu ekena dvābhyām trib
translated: or by three, indicated by the word or, that is a non-reason, a semblance of a reason, Kāśyapa said. The specific names contradictory, unestablished, and doubtful are indicated. Among them, even though the two properties exist, the doubtful one is not excluded from the dissimilar instance, so it is contrary by one property. But the contradictory one, even though the property of the subject exists, does not occur in the similar instance nor is it excluded from the dissimilar instance, so it is contrary by two properties. The unestablished one, however, is contrary by one, two, or three.

original: tatra nityaḥ śabdaḥ sāmānyavattve sati cākṣuṣatvādityekena viparītaḥ / tathā ca / asya sapakṣe ghaṭādau sadbhāve 'pi vipakṣācca sāmānyādervyāvṛttāvapi na pakṣadharmatvamastīti / tathā nityaḥ śabdo 'prameyatvāditi dvitayana viparītaḥ / aprameyatvasya hi vipakṣādeva vyāvṛttirna sapakṣe sadbhāvo nāpi pakṣa iti / tribhiśca viparīto yathā anityaḥ śabdaḥ akāryatvādityasya hi na śabde pakṣe sadbhāvo na sapakṣe ghaṭādau nāpi vipakṣād vyāvṛttiriti /
analyzed: tatra nityaḥ śabdaḥ sāmānyavat tve sati cākṣuṣa tvāt iti ekena viparītaḥ tathā ca asya sapakṣe ghaṭa ādau sadbhāve vipakṣāt ca sāmānya ādeḥ vyāvṛttau api na pakṣa dharma tvam asti iti tathā nityaḥ śabdaḥ prameya tvāt iti viparītaḥ aprameya tvasya hi vipakṣāt eva vyāvṛttiḥ na sapakṣe sadbhāvaḥ na api pakṣaḥ iti tribhiḥ ca viparītaḥ yathā anityaḥ śabdaḥ akārya tvāt iti asya hi na śabde pakṣe sadbhāvaḥ na sapakṣe ghaṭa ādau
translated: There, one is reversed by one, as 'sound is eternal, because it is visible, although it exists in the similar instance of a pot, and is excluded from the dissimilar instance of a universal, it does not have the property of the subject.' Similarly, 'sound is eternal, because it is not an object of knowledge,' is reversed by two, for the property of not being an object of knowledge is excluded only from the dissimilar instance, it does not exist in the similar instance, nor in the subject. And it is reversed by three, as 'sound is non-eternal, because it is not an effect,' for it does not exist in the subject, sound, nor in the similar instance, a pot, nor is it excluded from the dissimilar instance.

original: yadanumeyenārthena deśaviśeṣe kālaviśeṣe vā sahacaritam / anumeyadharmānvite cānyatra sarvasminnekadeśe vā prasiddham / anumeyaviparīte ca sarvasmin pramāṇato 'sadeva tadaprasiddhārthasyānumāpakaṃ liṅgaṃ bhavatīti /PDhS
analyzed: yat anumeyena arthena deśa viśeṣe kāla viśeṣe vā sahacaritam anumeya dharma anvite ca anyatra sarvasmin eka deśe vā prasiddham anumeya viparīte ca sarvasmin sat eva tat aprasiddha arthasya anumāpakam liṅgam bhavati iti
translated: That which is concomitant with the inferable object in a particular place or time, and is well-known in everything that possesses the properties of the inferable object, or in a part of it, and is known to be non-existent by valid means of knowledge in everything that is contrary to the inferable object, that is the inferential mark that causes the inference of an unknown object.

original: pūrvasya saṅgrahavākyasya spaṣṭārthaṃ vivaraṇamāha yadanumeyenārthena ityādi / anumeyena sambaddhamityasya vivaraṇamanumeyenārthena paricchedyamānena sahacaritamajahadvṛttīti / deśaviśeṣe kālaviśeṣe vā sarvasmin deśe sarvasmiṃśca kāla iti / prasiddhañca tadanvite ityasya vivaraṇam anumeyadharmānvite cānyatra sarvasminnekadeśe vā prasiddham iti / anumeyaḥ pakṣastasya dharmastena tatsamānadharmeṇānvito yuktaḥ sapakṣastasmin sarvatraikadeśe vā prasiddha ityādi niyamaḥ / tadabhāve ca nāstyevetyasya vivaraṇam anumeyaviparīte ca sarvasmin pramāṇato 'sadeva iti / anumeyaviparīto 'numeyadharmarahito vipakṣastasmin sarvatrāsadeva / pramāṇataḥ iti pramāṇena sādhyavyāvṛttyā sādhanavyāvṛttirvācyetyupadarśayati / anumāpakam ityasya vivaraṇam yadetaduktarūpaṃ liṅgaṃ tadaprasiddhārthasyānumāpakam bhavatīti /
analyzed: pūrvasya saṅgraha vākyasya spaṣṭa artham vivaraṇam āha yat anumeyena arthena ityādi anumeyena sambaddham iti asya vivaraṇam anumeyena arthena paricchedyamānena sahacaritam ajahat vṛtti iti deśa viśeṣe kāla viśeṣe vā sarvasmin deśe sarvasmin ca kāle iti prasiddham ca tad anvite iti asya vivaraṇam anumeya dharma anvite ca anyatra sarvasmin eka deśe vā prasiddham iti anumeyaḥ pakṣaḥ tasya dharmaḥ tena tad samāna dharmeṇa anvitaḥ yuktaḥ sapakṣaḥ tasmin sarvatr
translated: He states the clear meaning of the summary statement of the previous [verse] beginning with that which is connected with the object to be inferred. The explanation of connected with the object to be inferred is co-occurring, not abandoning its occurrence, with that which is to be delimited by the object to be inferred. In a particular place or time, or in all places and all times. And the explanation of and that which is well-known to be associated with it is and in other things associated with the properties of the object to be inferred, it is well-known in all or in part. The object to be inferred is the subject, and that which is associated with the property of that by the same property is the similar instance. It is well-known in all or in part of that. And the explanation of and in the absence of that, it does not exist is and in all that is contrary to the object to be inferred, it is indeed non-existent by valid cognition. That which is contrary to the object to be inferred, which is devoid of the properties of the object to be inferred, is the dissimilar instance. In all of that, it is indeed non-existent. By valid cognition means that the exclusion of the probandum by the probans should be stated by valid cognition.

original: liṅgābhāsalakṣaṇam🔽yattu yathoktāt trirūpālliṅgādekena dharmeṇa dvābhyāṃ vā viparītaṃ tadanumeyasyādhigame liṅgaṃ na bhavatītyetadevāha sūtrakāraḥ aprasiddho 'napadeśo 'san sandigdhaścānapadeśaḥ iti /PDhS
analyzed: yat tu yathā uktāt trirūpāt liṅgāt ekena dharmeṇa dvābhyām vā viparītam tad anumeyasya adhigame liṅgam na bhavati iti etat eva āha sūtrakāraḥ aprasiddhaḥ san sandigdhaḥ ca anapadeśaḥ iti
translated: The definition of a fallacious mark🔽But that which is contrary to one or two properties from the triply characterized mark as stated is not a mark for the understanding of the inferable object. The author of the aphorisms states this: The unknown, the indefinite, and the doubtful are indefinite.

original: dvitīyasya saṅgrahavākyasya vivaraṇam yattu yathoktāt trirūpālliṅgāt iti / abādhitaviṣayatvāt satpratipakṣatvasahitādekena dharmeṇa dvābhyāṃ vā dharmābhyāṃ tribhiśca viparītaṃ tadanumeyasyādhigame kartavye liṅgaṃ na bhavatīti / etadevāha sūtrakāraḥ / aprasiddho 'napadeśo 'san sandigdhaśca vai / sū / iti sūtritatvopadarśanam /
analyzed: dvitīyasya saṅgraha vākyasya vivaraṇam yat tu yathā uktāt trirūpāt liṅgāt iti abādhita viṣaya tvāt sat pratipakṣa tva sahitāt ekena dharmeṇa dvābhyām vā dharmābhyām tribhiḥ ca viparītam tad anumeyasya adhigame kartavye liṅgam na bhavati iti etat eva āha sūtrakāraḥ aprasiddhaḥ san sandigdhaḥ ca vai iti sūtrita tva upadarśanam
translated: The explanation of the second summary statement: But that which is contrary to one or two properties from the triply characterized mark as stated, that is, from the one that is not contradicted, together with the one that is counterbalanced, by one property, two properties, or three properties, is not a mark for the understanding of the inferable object that needs to be done. The author of the aphorisms states this: The unknown, the indefinite, and the doubtful are indefinite. This is shown to be the statement of the aphorism.

original: aprasiddho 'napadeśaḥ iti viruddhāvarodhaḥ / tasya sapakṣe 'prasiddhatvāt / asan ityasiddhaḥ / tasya hi pakṣadharmatvenāsattvāt / sandigdhaścānapadaśaḥ ityanaikāntikasaṅgrahaḥ / kālātyayāpadiṣṭaprakaraṇasamayoścāprasiddhapadenaivāvarodhaḥ / tayorabādhitaviṣayatvāsatpratipakṣatvenāprasiddhatvāt / samānatantranyāyena vā saṅgrahaḥ /
analyzed: aprasiddhaḥ iti viruddha avarodhaḥ tasya sapakṣe prasiddha tvāt asan iti asiddhaḥ tasya hi pakṣa dharma tvena asat tvāt sandigdhaḥ ca iti anaikāntika saṅgrahaḥ kāla atyaya apadiṣṭa prakaraṇa samayoḥ ca aprasiddha padena eva avarodhaḥ tayoḥ abādhita viṣaya tva asat pratipakṣa tvena aprasiddha tvāt samāna tantra nyāyena vā saṅgrahaḥ
translated: The contradictory is included by unproven and unspecified, because it is unproven in the similar instance. Non-existent is unestablished, because it does not exist as a property of the subject. And doubtful and unspecified include the inconclusive. And time-lapsed and equal to the case are included by unproven, because they are unproven due to not being unobstructed with respect to their object and not being a countering reason. Or they are included by the principle of the same treatise.

original: vidhivyāptinirūpaṇam
translated: The definition of the pervasion of the affirmative

original: vidhistu yatra yatra dhūmastatra tatrāgniragnyabhāve ca dhūmo 'pi na bhavatīti / evaṃ prasiddhasamayasyāsandigdhadhūmadarśanāt sāhacaryānusmaraṇāt tadanantaramagnyadhyavasāyo bhavatīti / evaṃ sarvatra deśakālāvinābhūtamitarasya liṅgam /PDhS
analyzed: vidhiḥ tu yatra yatra dhūmaḥ tatra tatra agniḥ agni abhāve ca na bhavati iti evam prasiddha samayasya asandigdha dhūma darśanāt sāhacarya anusmaraṇāt tad anantaram agni adhyavasāyaḥ bhavati iti evam sarvatra deśa kāla avinābhūtam itarasya liṅgam
translated: The affirmative is that wherever there is smoke, there is fire, and in the absence of fire, smoke also does not occur. Thus, from seeing smoke without doubt by one who has established this convention, remembering its concomitance, immediately after that there is the ascertainment of fire. Thus, in all cases, the other is the mark of that which is invariably concomitant with place and time.

original: yathoktarūpaṃ liṅgaṃ nāgahītāvinābhāvasya gamakamityavinābhāvasvarūpopadarśanātham vidhistu yatra yatra dhūmaḥ ityādi vākyam / vidhirvyāptiravinābhāva iti /
analyzed: yathā ukta rūpam liṅgam nāga hīta avinābhāvasya gamakam iti avinābhāva svarūpa upadarśana atham vidhiḥ tu yatra yatra dhūmaḥ ityādi vākyam vidhiḥ vyāptiḥ avinābhāvaḥ iti
translated: The statement where there is smoke, there is fire is for the purpose of showing the nature of invariable concomitance. Invariable concomitance is the relation of pervasion.

original: atha yadi sāmānyayoravinābhāvaḥ siddhasādhanam / apāstaviśeṣasya sāmānyasya siddhatvāt / niyatadeśāvacchedena viśeṣārthināṃ pravṛttinivṛttyorabhāvaprasaṅgaḥ / na ca viśeṣayoravinābhāvaḥ / teṣāmānantyenāprasiddhestadāyattasyāvinābhāvasyāprasiddheḥ / manuṣya /anuktadharmāṇāñca sarva eva viśeṣāḥ pratipattuṃ na śakyanta iti yāvatāmupalambhastāvatsvevāvinābhāvagrahaṇe ca nāgṛhītāvinābhāvasya viśeṣāntarasyopalambhādanumānaṃ syāt /
analyzed: atha yadi sāmānyayoḥ avinābhāvaḥ siddha sādhanam apāsta viśeṣasya sāmānyasya siddha tvāt niyata deśa avacchedena viśeṣa arthinām pravṛtti nivṛttyoḥ abhāva prasaṅgaḥ na ca viśeṣayoḥ avinābhāvaḥ teṣām ānantyena aprasiddheḥ tad āyattasya avinābhāvasya aprasiddheḥ manuṣya anukta dharmāṇām ca sarve eva viśeṣāḥ pratipattum na śakyante iti yāvatām upalambhaḥ tāvatsu eva avinābhāva grahaṇe ca na agṛhīta avinābhāvasya viśeṣa antarasya
translated: Now, if the invariable concomitance of universals is established, it is a futile argument, because the universal, which is devoid of particulars, is already established. And there would be the undesirable consequence of the absence of engagement and disengagement for those seeking particulars by delimiting a specific place. And there is no invariable concomitance of particulars, because of their infinitude and unestablishedness, and because the invariable concomitance dependent on them is unestablished. And all particulars of human beings with unmentioned properties cannot be understood at all. And if the invariable concomitance is grasped only of as many as are perceived, then there would be inference even from the perception of another particular whose invariable concomitance is not grasped.

original: naitad dūṣaṇam / sāmānyavatoravinābhāvagrahaṇābhyupagamāt / yadyapyagniviśeṣā dhūmaviśeṣāścānantyenāvasthitāstathāpi teṣvevāvasthitamagnitvaṃ dhūmatvañca sāmānyam upagrāhakamastīti tadupagrāhakavaśād bhūyodarśanabalādagnidhūmayordeśādivyabhicāre 'pyavyabhicāragrahaṇam / tathāhi / prātarmadhyāhnādibhedena kālasya bhede / samaviṣamādibhedena ca deśabhede dhūmasyāgninā sāhacaryopalabdherdeśāntare kālāntare ca dhūmo 'gniṃ vināpi bhaviṣyatītyāśaṅkā na syāt / ata eva na kulālasya rāsabhena vyāptigrahaṇaprasaṅgaḥ / kālāntare ca tena vināpyupalambhāt /
analyzed: na etat dūṣaṇam sāmānyavatoḥ avinābhāva grahaṇa abhyupagamāt yadi api agni viśeṣāḥ dhūma viśeṣāḥ ca ānantyena avasthitāḥ tathā api teṣu eva avasthitam agni tvam dhūma tvañca sāmānyam upagrāhakam asti iti tad upagrāhaka vaśāt bhūyas darśana balāt agni dhūmayoḥ deśa ādi vyabhicāre pi avyabhicāra grahaṇam tathā hi prātar madhyāhna ādi bhedena kālasya bhede sama viṣama ādi bhedena ca deśa bhede dhūmasya agninā sāhacarya upalabdheḥ deśa antare
translated: This is not a fault, because the invariable concomitance of the general and particular is accepted. Although the particular fires and particular smokes exist in infinity, still there is a general fire-ness and smoke-ness that exists in them as the connecting factor. Therefore, by the power of that connecting factor, the invariable concomitance of fire and smoke is grasped by the force of repeated observation, even in the case of deviation from place etc. For example, due to the observation of the concomitance of smoke with fire in the distinction of time such as morning, noon etc., and in the distinction of place such as even, uneven etc., there would be no doubt that smoke could exist without fire in another place or time. For this very reason, there is no possibility of grasping the pervasion of the potter with the donkey, because it is observed even without it at another time.

original: anye tu vyāptigrahaṇakāle pratipatturyogina iva aśeṣaviṣayaṃ parijñānamastīti bruvate / anyathā hi sarvo dhūmo 'gniṃ vinā na bhavatīti vyāptismaraṇaṃ na syāt / vivekena cāpratibhāsaḥ samānābhivyāhārāt / yathā dhānyarāśinikṣiptāyā dhānyavyakteriti /
analyzed: anye tu vyāpti grahaṇa kāle pratipattuḥ yoginaḥ iva aśeṣa viṣayam parijñānam asti iti bruvate anyathā hi sarvaḥ dhūmaḥ gnim vinā na bhavati iti vyāpti smaraṇam na syāt vivekena ca apratibhāsaḥ samāna abhivyāhārāt yathā dhānya rāśi nikṣiptāyāḥ dhānya vyakteḥ iti
translated: Others, however, say that at the time of apprehending the pervasion, the learner has complete knowledge of the object, like a yogi. Otherwise, the recollection of the pervasion that all smoke does not occur without fire would not be possible. And the non-appearance of the distinction is due to the same expression, just as the individual grain thrown into a heap of grain.

original: tadevaṃ yatra yatra iti vīpsārthasya vivakṣitatvāt yatra yatra dhūmastatra II / tatrāgniragnyabhāve ca dhūmo 'pi na bhavatītyevaṃ prasiddhasamayasya gṛhītāvinābhāvasya pratipatturasandigdhadhūmadarśanānantaraṃ sāhacaryānusmaraṇam 'yatra yatrāhaṃ dhūmamadrākṣaṃ tatra tatrāgnirastīti sāhacaryānusmaraṇāt tadanantaram agniradhyavasīyate aneneti agnyadhyavasāyaḥ parāmarśajñānam / tasmāccāgnipratipattiriti /
analyzed: tat evam yatra yatra iti vīpsā arthasya vivakṣita tvāt yatra yatra dhūmaḥ tatra tatra agniḥ agni abhāve ca na bhavati iti evam prasiddha samayasya gṛhīta avinābhāvasya pratipattuḥ asandigdha dhūma darśana anantaram sāhacarya anusmaraṇam yatra yatra aham dhūmam adrākṣam tatra tatra agniḥ asti iti sāhacarya anusmaraṇāt tad anantaram agniḥ adhyavasīyate anena iti agni adhyavasāyaḥ parāmarśa jñānam tasmāt ca agni pratipattiḥ iti
translated: Thus, since the meaning of the repetition wherever is intended, wherever there is smoke, there is fire, and where there is no fire, smoke also does not occur. Thus, the remembered invariable concomitance of the well-known convention, after the undoubting perception of smoke, is the recollection of the concomitance. From the recollection of the concomitance wherever I saw smoke, there fire existed, after that, fire is ascertained. This is the inferential knowledge. And from that, the cognition of fire occurs.

original: anye tu parāmarśajñānasyābhāvameva bruvate / taccāsat / avinābhāvasambandhasmaraṇasyāniyatatvānniyatapradeśe 'gnipratipattirna syāt / upanayavaiyarthyañca / upanayārthasyānabhyupagamāt / tasmād vyutpattyā upacāreṇa vā agnyadhyavasāyaḥ parāmarśajñānaṃ vyākhyeyamiti /
analyzed: anye tu parāmarśa jñānasya abhāvam eva bruvate tat ca asat avinābhāva sambandha smaraṇasya aniyata tvāt niyata pradeśe gni pratipattiḥ na syāt upanaya vaiyarthyam ca upanaya arthasya anabhyupagamāt tasmāt vyutpattyā upacāreṇa vā agni adhyavasāyaḥ parāmarśa jñānam vyākhyeyam iti
translated: Others, however, say that the knowledge of the mark is non-existent. And that is not correct. Because the recollection of the relation of invariable concomitance is not fixed, there would be no cognition of fire in a fixed place. And there would be the uselessness of the application. Because the meaning of the application is not accepted. Therefore, either by derivation or by figurative use, the cognition of fire should be explained as the knowledge of the mark.

original: anye tu kāryakāraṇabhāvāt / svabhāvācca niyāmakādavinābhāvagrahaṇamiti manyante / taccāsat / kāryakāraṇabhāve 'pyavaśyaṃ bhūyodarśanabalādevāvinābhāvagrahaṇamiti vācyam / anyathā hi deśāntare kālāntare vā agniṃ vināpi dhūmo bhaviṣyatītyāśaṅkā syāt / athāgnidhūmayoḥ kāryakāraṇabhāvāvagatau kathamagniṃ vinā dhūmasya sambhava ityāśaṅkā / tasya nirhetukatvapratiṣedhenāvaśyaṃ svakāraṇādevotpatteriti / satyametat / yadi nāma sarvo dhūmo 'gnikārya iti jñānamapi bhūyodarśanaṃ vinā na bhavatīti tadabhyupagantavyam /
analyzed: anye tu kārya kāraṇa bhāvāt svabhāvāt ca niyāmakāt avinābhāva grahaṇam iti manyante tat ca asat kārya kāraṇa bhāve pi avaśyam bhūyas darśana balāt eva avinābhāva grahaṇam iti vācyam anyathā hi deśa antare kāla antare vā agnim vinā api dhūmaḥ bhaviṣyati iti āśaṅkā syāt atha agni dhūmayoḥ kārya kāraṇa bhāva avagatau katham agnim vinā dhūmasya sambhavaḥ iti āśaṅkā tasya nirhetuka tva pratiṣedhena avaśyam sva kāraṇāt eva utpatteḥ iti satyam
translated: Others, however, think that the invariable concomitance is determined by the relation of cause and effect and by the nature of things. But that is wrong. Even in the case of the relation of cause and effect, it must be said that the invariable concomitance is grasped only through the force of repeated observation. Otherwise, there would be the doubt that smoke might exist even without fire in another place or at another time. If the relation of cause and effect between fire and smoke is known, how can there be the doubt that smoke can exist without fire? Because it is denied that it is without a cause, it must necessarily arise from its own cause. This is true. If it is admitted that the knowledge that all smoke is the effect of fire does not arise without repeated observation, then that must be accepted.

original: na cāgnerasādhāraṇaṃ kāryaṃ dhūmaḥ / tasya dhumāntarādapyutpattyabhyupagamāt / tathā hi gopālaghuṭikādiṣu ciranivṛtte vahnau dhūmakṣaṇādeva dhūmotpattiriti katham atatkāryasya dhūmasyopalabdheragnyanumānam / athāgnikāryasyopalambhādanumānamiti cet / na / agnipratipattiṃ vinā dhūme tajjanyatvaviniścayasyāsambhavāt / pratipattau vā kimanumānena / dhūmasvarūpapratipattivaccāgṛhītānalasya nārikeladvīpavāsino dhūme 'gnijanyatvapratipattirdṛṣṭā / tathā prayogānupapatteśca / tathāhi / parvatasyāgnimattve sādhye kāryatvamanaikāntikameva / atha dhūmasyāgnimattvaṃ sādhyeta / tatrāpi kāryatvamanaikāntikameva / dhūmatve sati kāryatvaṃ hetuḥ / tarhi dhūmatvameva samarthamiti vyarthaviśeṣyatā hetordoṣaḥ / na cāgnikāryatvaṃ dhūmasyāgnisambandhāt / pūrvadravyanivṛttāvutpannapākajairdvyaṇukādiprakrameṇotpatterityalam /
analyzed: na ca agneḥ asādhāraṇam kāryam dhūmaḥ tasya dhuma antarāt api utpatti abhyupagamāt tathā hi gopālaghuṭikā ādiṣu cira nivṛtte vahnau dhūma kṣaṇāt eva dhūma utpattiḥ iti katham atatkāryasya dhūmasya upalabdheḥ agni anumānam atha agni kāryasya upalambhāt anumānam iti ced na agni pratipattim vinā dhūme tad janya tva viniścayasya asambhavāt pratipattau vā kim anumānena dhūma svarūpa pratipatti vat ca agṛhīta analasya nārikela dvīpa vāsinaḥ dhūme gni janya
translated: And smoke is not the uncommon effect of fire, because it is accepted that it arises even from another smoke. For example, in the case of cowherds' huts and such, smoke arises from a moment of smoke even when the fire has long ceased. How then is there inference of fire from the perception of smoke, which is not its effect? If it is argued that inference is from the perception of what is produced by fire, that is not so. Because without the cognition of fire, the ascertainment of being produced by it in smoke is impossible. Or if there is cognition, what is the use of inference? And just as there is cognition of the nature of smoke, so too for one who has not cognized fire, the ascertainment of being produced by fire in smoke is seen for one dwelling in the coconut islands. And also because of the impossibility of the argument. For example, in proving the existence of fire in a mountain, being an effect is inconclusive. Or if the existence of fire in smoke is to be proved, there too being an effect is inconclusive. The reason is being an effect while having the nature of smoke. If so, having the nature of smoke alone is sufficient. So the fault of the reason is the uselessness of the qualification.

original: tathā vṛkṣatvaśiṃśapātvayorna tādātmyapratibandhaḥ / tathā ca sati sādhyasādhanabhāvānupapattiprasaṅgāt / tathāhi / dharmiṇyupalabdhe tattādātmyādubhayorapyupalambhe kathaṃ sādhyasādhanabhāvaḥ / tadupalambhe 'pyanupalabdhau tu tādātmyaṃ na syāditi / atha sāmānyaviśeṣavattvādanumānasya samāropavyāvṛttyorgamyagamakabhāvaḥ / tatra ca tādātmyatadutpattyorasambhava eva / tādātmyābhyupagame 'pi na sādhyasādhanatvamekatāprasaṅgāditi / tathā ubhayostādātmyāviśeṣe 'pi śiṃśapātvena vṛkṣatvasya pratipattivad vṛkṣatvena śiṃśapātvapratipattirapi syāt /
analyzed: tathā vṛkṣa tva śiṃśapā tvayoḥ na tādātmya pratibandhaḥ tathā ca sati sādhya sādhana bhāva anupapatti prasaṅgāt tathā hi dharmiṇi upalabdhe tad tādātmyāt ubhayoḥ api upalambhe katham sādhya sādhana bhāvaḥ tad upalambhe pi anupalabdhau tu tādātmyam na syāt iti atha sāmānya viśeṣa vat tvāt anumānasya samāropa vyāvṛttyoḥ gamya gamaka bhāvaḥ tatra ca tādātmya tad utpattyoḥ asambhavaḥ eva tādātmya abhyupagame pi na sādhya sādhana tvam ekatā prasa
translated: Similarly, there is no relation of identity between tree-ness and shimshapa-ness. And if that were so, there would be the undesirable consequence of the impossibility of the relation of probandum and probans. It is like this. When the substratum is perceived, if both [tree-ness and shimshapa-ness] are perceived due to their identity, how can there be the relation of probandum and probans? But if there is non-perception even when that [substratum] is perceived, then there would not be identity. Or, if the relation of probandum and probans is due to the exclusion of superimposition because inference has both a universal and particular [aspect], then the relation of what is to be known and what is to be known is impossible in the case of identity and origination from that [particular]. Even if identity is accepted, there is no relation of probandum and probans because of the consequence of oneness. Similarly, even though there is no difference in identity between the two, just as tree-ness is cognized by shimshapa-ness, the cognition of shimshapa-ness by tree-ness would also occur.

original: na ca tādātmyatadutpattilakṣaṇapratibandhābhyupagame rūpadarśanāt sparśānumānam / udayādastamayapratipattiḥ / kṛttikodayācca rohiṇya /ṇyudayānumānaṃ na syāt / tādātmyatadutpattyabhāvāt / atha ekasāmagryadhīnatayā rūpāt sparśānumānam / tadasat / samānakṣaṇayorgamyagamakabhāvopalabdheḥ / tathāhi / rūpakṣaṇāt samānakālaḥ sparśo 'numīyate na pūrvaḥ / tatra caikasāmagryadhīnatvāsambhava eva / na ca rūpasparśayoḥ parasparotpattau kāraṇatve pramāṇamasti / itarānvayasyetaratrānupalabdherityalamatiprasaṅgena /
analyzed: na ca tādātmya tad utpatti lakṣaṇa pratibandha abhyupagame rūpa darśanāt sparśa anumānam udayāt astamaya pratipattiḥ kṛttikā udayāt ca rohiṇī aṇī udaya anumānam na syāt tādātmya tad utpatti abhāvāt atha eka sāmagrī adhīna tayā rūpāt sparśa anumānam tat asat samāna kṣaṇayoḥ gamya gamaka bhāva upalabdheḥ tathā hi rūpa kṣaṇāt samāna kālaḥ sparśaḥ numīyate na pūrvaḥ tatra ca eka sāmagrī adhīna tva asambhavaḥ eva na ca rūpa sparśayoḥ par
translated: And when the relation of identity and origination is accepted, there is no inference of touch from the perception of form, nor the cognition of sunrise and sunset, nor the inference of the rising of Rohini from the rising of Krittika, because of the absence of identity and origination. If the inference of touch from form is due to dependence on the same causal complex, that is wrong, because the relation of what is to be inferred and what is the means of inference is observed to occur in the same moment. Thus, touch occurring at the same time as the moment of form is inferred, not the prior one. And in that case, dependence on the same causal complex is impossible. And there is no evidence that form and touch are causes in relation to each other's origination. The concomitance of one with the other is not observed in the other. Thus, let us stop this digression.

original: evaṃ sarvatra deśakālāvinābhūtamitarasya sādhyasya / liṅgam / ityupasaṃhāraḥ / deśāvinābhūtaṃ yathā kedāragirimārohatāṃ kalakalāśabdaśravaṇādaśanipātānumānamiti /
analyzed: evam sarvatra deśa kāla avinābhūtam itarasya sādhyasya liṅgam iti upasaṃhāraḥ deśa avinābhūtam yathā kedāra girim ārohatām kalakalā śabda śravaṇāt aśani pāta anumānam iti
translated: Thus, in all cases, what is invariably concomitant with place and time is the mark of what is to be inferred. This is the conclusion. What is invariably concomitant with place is like the inference of lightning from hearing the sound kalakala by those climbing Mount Kedara.

original: atha asya sūtreṇāsaṅgrahaḥ / tathā ca sūtram asyedaṃ kāryaṃ kāraṇaṃ saṃyogi samavāyi virodhi ceti laiṅgikam vai / sū / / na ca kalakalāśabdo 'śanipātakāryaḥ / tadantareṇāpi svakāraṇādevotpatteḥ / nāpi kāraṇamaśanipātasya / pratibandhakābhāvaviśiṣṭagurutvakāryatvāt / ubhayoścādravyatvānna saṃyogitvam / parasparamekasminnarthe samavāyābhāvāt svātmanyanārambhakatvānna samavāyitvam / parasparavirodhābhāvāccāvirodhitvamityarthāntaratvam /
analyzed: atha asya sūtreṇa asaṅgrahaḥ tathā ca sūtram asya idam kāryam kāraṇam saṃyogi samavāyi virodhi ca iti laiṅgikam vai sū na ca śanipāta kāryaḥ tad antareṇa api sva kāraṇāt eva utpatteḥ na api kāraṇam aśanipātasya pratibandhaka abhāva viśiṣṭa guru tva kārya tvāt ubhayoḥ ca adravya tvāt na saṃyogi tvam parasparam ekasmin arthe samavāya abhāvāt sva ātmani anārambhaka tvāt na samavāyi tvam paraspara virodha abhāvāt ca avirodhi tvam iti artha antara tvam
translated: If it is not included in this Sutra, then this is its function, cause, conjoined, inhering, and contradictory - this is the inferential. And the sound kalakala is not the effect of lightning strike. Because it arises from its own cause even without that. Nor is it the cause of lightning strike. Because it is the effect of heaviness qualified by the absence of obstruction. And because both are not substances, there is no conjoinedness. Because there is no inherence in one object, there is no inherence due to not being a cause in one's own self. And because there is no mutual contradiction, there is no contradiction - this is a different meaning.

original: atha kāryādeḥ kathaṃ liṅgatvam / avinābhūtatvāt / tathāhi / kāryaṃ kāraṇapūrvakatvenopalambhādupalabhyamānaṃ sad gamakam / yathā hi viśiṣṭanadīpūropalambhād upariṣṭād vṛṣṭo deva iti / tathā ca bahulasvarūpaphenaphenilaparṇakāṣṭhādivahanaII /viśiṣṭasya nadīpūrasya vṛṣṭikāryatvena pūrvamupalambhāt punastadupalambhe sati yuktamanumānam ayaṃ nadīpūraḥ vṛṣṭikāryaḥ viśiṣṭanadīpūratvāt pūrvopalabdhanadīpūravaditi / pūrastūbhayataṭavyāpakodakasaṃyogaḥ / sa pāramparyeṇa vṛṣṭikārya iti kāraṇamapi / kāryajanakatvena pūrvamupalabdherupalabhyamānaṃ talliṅgam /
analyzed: atha kārya ādeḥ katham liṅga tvam avinābhūta tvāt tathā hi kāryam kāraṇa pūrvaka tvena upalambhāt upalabhyamānam sat gamakam  yathā hi viśiṣṭa nadī pūra upalambhāt upariṣṭāt vṛṣṭaḥ devaḥ iti tathā ca nadī pūrasya vṛṣṭi kārya tvena pūrvam upalambhāt punar tad upalambhe sati yuktam anumānam ayam nadī pūraḥ vṛṣṭi kāryaḥ viśiṣṭa nadī pūra tvāt pūrva upalabdha nadī pūra vat iti pūraḥ tu ubhaya taṭa vyāpaka udaka saṃyogaḥ sa
translated: Now, how can the effect and other [factors] be the inferential mark? Because they are inseparable. Thus, an effect is cognized as preceded by a cause, and when it is cognized, it is an indicator. Just as from the perception of a particular flood in the river, it is inferred that it rained upstream. And so, with a flood carrying much foam, foam-like leaves, logs, and so on. When a particular flood in the river is previously perceived as the effect of rain, and upon its subsequent perception, it is proper to infer that this flood in the river is the effect of rain, because it is a particular flood in the river, like the flood in the river perceived before. A flood is the conjunction of water extending to both banks. That is indirectly the effect of rain, so the cause is also [an inferential mark]. Because it is previously perceived as producing the effect, when it is perceived, it is the inferential mark.

original: yathā ca viśiṣṭameghonnatirvarṣakarmaṇa iti / atha kāraṇasyāvaśyaṃ kāryajanakatvenānupalambhāt / kāryāṇāñca aniyatāt kāraṇādutpattervyabhicāraḥ / tathāhi / meghonnatisadbhāve 'pyekadā vṛṣṭirna dṛṣṭā / kāryañca aniyatāt kāraṇādutpadyamānaṃ dṛṣṭam / yathā vṛścikād vṛściko jāyate / gomayāt / sarpācceti / evamanyatrāpyaniyataṃ kāraṇamabhyūhyam iti kathaṃ kāryāt kāraṇaviśeṣapratipattiḥ / kāraṇācca kāryaviśeṣasyeti / naitadevam / kāraṇaviśeṣasya kāryaviśeṣagamakatvamityabhyupagamāt / yastu vidyamānamapi viśeṣaṃ nāvabudhyate tasyāparādho nānumānasyetyadoṣaḥ /
analyzed: yathā ca viśiṣṭa megha unnatiḥ varṣa karmaṇaḥ iti atha kāraṇasya avaśyam kārya janaka tvena anupalambhāt kāryāṇām ca aniyatāt kāraṇāt utpatteḥ vyabhicāraḥ tathā hi megha unnati sadbhāve pi ekadā vṛṣṭiḥ na dṛṣṭā kāryam ca aniyatāt kāraṇāt utpadyamānam dṛṣṭam yathā vṛścikāt vṛścikaḥ jāyate gomayāt sarpāt ca iti evam anyatra api aniyatam kāraṇam abhyūhyam iti katham kāryāt kāraṇa viśeṣa pratipattiḥ kāraṇāt ca kār
translated: And just as the special elevation of clouds is for the act of raining.
