Now, if the cause is necessarily the producer of the effect, there is no perception of it, and the effect arises from an uncertain cause, there is a fallacy. For example, even when the elevation of clouds exists, rain is not seen at one time. And an effect is seen to arise from an uncertain cause, just as a scorpion is born from a scorpion, from cow dung, and from a snake. In the same way, another uncertain cause should be inferred elsewhere. How then is the specific cause known from the effect, and the specific effect from the cause? This is not so, because the specific cause is accepted as the indicator of the specific effect. But for one who does not understand the existing specific cause, the fault is his, not of inference. Thus there is no fault.

original: tathā dhūmo 'gneḥ saṃyogī / atha saṃyogasyobhayaniṣṭhatvāviśeṣe kathamekaṃ niyamena sādhanamitaracca sādhyamiti vyavasthā / tadavinābhāve 'pi samānam / tasyāpyubhayaniṣṭhatvāt kathameṣā vyavasthā syāt / atha yasyopalambhādanumeye pratipattistadeva sādhanaṃ nānyaditi cet / saṃyogitve 'pi samānametat / avinābhūtasyāvāntaraviśeṣanirūpaṇāt /
analyzed: tathā dhūmaḥ gneḥ saṃyogī atha saṃyogasya ubhaya niṣṭha tva aviśeṣe katham ekam niyamena sādhanam itarat ca sādhyam iti vyavasthā tad avinābhāve pi samānam tasya api ubhaya niṣṭha tvāt katham eṣā vyavasthā syāt atha yasya upalambhāt anumeye pratipattiḥ tat eva sādhanam na anyat iti ced saṃyogi tve pi samānam etat avinābhūtasya avāntara viśeṣa nirūpaṇāt
translated: Similarly, smoke is connected with fire. Now, if there is no difference in the mutual dependence of connection, how is it that one is invariably the means of knowledge and the other the object to be known? This is the same even in invariable concomitance. How could this distinction be made, since that also depends on both? If it is argued that that alone is the means of knowledge whose perception leads to the understanding of the object to be inferred, not anything else, this is the same even in the case of connection, because the specific difference of what is invariably concomitant is determined.

original: samavāyī coṣṇasparśo vāristhaṃ tejo gamayatīti / virodhī ca yathā ahirvisphūrjanaviśiṣṭo nakulāderliṅgamiti /
analyzed: samavāyī ca uṣṇa sparśaḥ vāri stham tejaḥ gamayati iti virodhī ca yathā ahiḥ visphūrjana viśiṣṭaḥ nakula ādeḥ liṅgam iti
translated: And hot touch inhering in water conveys the existence of fire there. And a contradictory mark, like a snake distinguished by hissing, is the mark of a mongoose and so on.

original: śāstre kāryādigrahaṇaṃ nidarśanārthaṃ kṛtaṃ nāvadhāraṇārtham / kasmāt / vyatirekadarśanāt / tad yathā adhvaryuroṃ śrāvayan vyavahitasya hoturliṅgam / candrodayaḥ samudravṛddheḥ kumudavikāśasya ca / śaradi jalaprasādo 'gastyodayasyetyevamādi tatsarvam asyedam iti sambandhamātravacanāt siddham /PDhS
analyzed: śāstre kārya ādi grahaṇam nidarśana artham kṛtam na avadhāraṇa artham kasmāt vyatireka darśanāt tat yathā adhvaryuḥ om śrāvayan vyavahitasya hotuḥ liṅgam candra udayaḥ samudra vṛddheḥ kumuda vikāśasya ca śaradi jala prasādaḥ gastya udayasya iti evamādi tat sarvam asya idam iti sambandha mātra vacanāt siddham pdhs
translated: In the treatise, the mention of effect etc. is done for the purpose of illustration, not for the purpose of restriction. Why? Because of the observation of exclusion. For example, the Adhvaryu priest calling out is the mark of the absent Hotṛ priest. The rising of the moon is for the swelling of the ocean and the blooming of lilies. The clarity of water in autumn is due to the rising of Agastya. All this is established by the mere statement of the relation this is all of that.

original: atha sūtre kāryādigrahaṇamudāharaṇārthamavadhāraṇārthaṃ vetyāha śāstre kāryādigrahaṇaṃ nidarśanārthaṃ kṛtaṃ nāvadhāraṇārtham / kathametajjñāyate / vyatirekadarśanāt / tad yathā adhvaryuroṃ śrāvayan vyavahitasya hoturliṅgam II / iti / na ca hoturoṃ śrāvayeti śabdaḥ kāraṇaṃ kāryaṃ vā / anvayavyatirekābhāvāt / tathā ca hotāraṃ vinaivopapattiḥ / hotuścānena vināpīti / saṃyogādiṣvapyantarbhāvānupapattiḥ / sa ca yāgabhūmāvevāsyāvinābhāvo na ca deśāntare iti / tathā cāyamadhvaryurapi dūradeśena hotrā tadvān oṃ śrāvayeti śabdakartṛtvāt / pūrvopalabdhādhvaryuvat / candrodayaḥ samudravṛddheḥ kumudavikāśasya ca liṅgam / samudrasya ca vṛddhiravayavopacayaḥ / sa ca svāvayavebhyo niṣpadyate na candrodayāt / kumudavikāśo 'pyavayavānāmārabdhakāryāṇāṃ parasparaṃ vibhāgo dravyārambhakasaṃyogāvirodhikriyākārya iti / kāraṇañcātrābhivyaṅgyasya janakaṃ vivakṣitaṃ na pratipatteḥ / sarveṣāṃ kāraṇabhāva evāntarbhāvaprasaṅgāt / śaradi jalaprasādo 'gastyodayasya liṅgam / asyāpi tatkāryādiṣvanantarbhāvaḥ / śaradi jalaprasādo 'gastyodayavān jalaprasādatvāt pūrvopalabdhaivaṃvidhajalaprasādavat / ityevamādi ityādipadenodayādirudayāderastaścāstāderliṅgamityūhyam /
analyzed: atha sūtre kārya ādi grahaṇam udāharaṇa artham avadhāraṇa artham vā iti āha śāstre kārya ādi grahaṇam nidarśana artham kṛtam na avadhāraṇa artham katham etat jñāyate vyatireka darśanāt tat yathā adhvaryuḥ om śrāvayan vyavahitasya hotuḥ liṅgam iti na ca hotuḥ om śrāvaya iti śabdaḥ kāraṇam kāryam vā anvaya vyatireka abhāvāt tathā ca hotāram vinā eva upapattiḥ hotuḥ ca anena vinā api iti saṃyoga ādiṣu api antarbhāva anupapattiḥ sa ca yāga bh
translated: Now, as for the mention of effect etc. in the sutra, he says whether it is for the purpose of illustration or for the purpose of restriction. The mention of effect etc. in the treatise is done for the purpose of illustration, not for the purpose of restriction. How is this known? From the observation of the exception. Just as the Adhvaryu, while saying Oṃ, proclaim, is the indicator of the distant Hotṛ. And the word Oṃ, proclaim is neither the cause nor the effect of the Hotṛ, because of the absence of concomitance and non-concomitance. And thus there is a possibility without the Hotṛ, and of the Hotṛ without this. And there is also the impossibility of inclusion in conjunction etc. And this invariable concomitance of it is only on the sacrificial ground, not in another place. And thus this Adhvaryu also, by the distant Hotṛ, is the doer of the word Oṃ, proclaim, because of the possession of that, like the previously perceived Adhvaryu. The rising of the moon is the indicator of the swelling of the ocean and the blooming of the lilies. And the swelling of the ocean is the accumulation of parts, and that results from its own parts, not from the rising of the moon.

original: atha kathameṣāṃ sūtreṇa saṅgrahastadāha tatsarvam asyedam iti sambandhamātravacanāt siddham / tathāhi / idamasya gamakam / idamasya gamyam / iti sāmānyena sarvaliṅgaparigrahaḥ / viśeṣāpekṣayā tu idamasya kāryaṃ kāraṇamityādi yojyam /
analyzed: atha katham eṣām sūtreṇa saṅgrahaḥ tat āha tat sarvam asya idam iti sambandha mātra vacanāt siddham tathā hi idam asya gamakam idam asya gamyam iti sāmānyena sarva liṅga parigrahaḥ viśeṣa apekṣayā tu idam asya kāryam kāraṇam ityādi yojyam
translated: Now, how are they included in the Sutra? He says that is established by the mere statement of the connection this entire belongs to that. Indeed, this is its indicator, this is its object to be indicated - thus, in general, all the reasons are included. But with regard to the particulars, it should be connected as this is its effect, this is its cause, etc.

original: anye tvavadhāraṇārthametat sūtramiti manyante / śāstre kāryādigrahaṇaṃ nidarśanārtham iti vākyamanyathā vyākhyāyante / tathāhi / taduktaṃ paraiḥ vyatirekadarśanācchāstre kāryādigrahaṇaṃ nidarśanārthaṃ kṛtamiti jñāyate ityetanna / kintvavadhāraṇārthaṃ sarveṣāmatraivāntarbhāvena vyatirekadarśanasyāsiddhatvāt / tathā ca hotari sannihite 'dhvaryuroṃ śrāvayeti śabdamuccārayati yāgabhūmau / na tena vināpi / iti kathaṃ na tasya kāraṇatvam / evaṃ candrodayo 'pi samudravṛddheḥ kāraṇamanvayavyatirekavattvāt / tathā ca tena satā jalanidhervṛddhirna tadabhāva iti kāryeṇa meghapaṭalāntaritaścandro 'numīyate / gṛhītavyāptikasya deśāntare 'pi candrodayopalambhādambhonidhervṛddhyanumānam / evaṃ kumudavikāśe 'pīti / yad vā raśmidvāreṇa II / saṃyogitvameva / tathā agastyodayo 'pi jalaprasādasya kāraṇam saṃyogi vā raśmidvāreṇeti /
analyzed: anye tu avadhāraṇa artham etat sūtram iti manyante śāstre kārya ādi grahaṇam nidarśana artham iti vākyam anyathā vyākhyāyante tathā hi tat uktam paraiḥ vyatireka darśanāt śāstre kārya ādi grahaṇam nidarśana artham kṛtam iti jñāyate iti etat na kintu avadhāraṇa artham sarveṣām atra eva antarbhāvena vyatireka darśanasya asiddha tvāt tathā ca hotari sannihite dhvaryuḥ om śrāvaya iti śabdam uccārayati yāga bhūmau na tena vinā api iti katham na tasya kāraṇa t
translated: Others, however, consider this sutra to be for the purpose of restriction. The statement The mention of effect etc. in the treatise is for the purpose of illustration is explained differently. As it is said by others: It is known that the mention of effect etc. in the treatise is made for the purpose of illustration by showing exceptions. This is not so. But it is for the purpose of restriction, because the observation of exceptions is not established by the inclusion of all in this itself. And thus, when the Hotri priest is present, the Adhvaryu priest utters the sound Om, let it be heard on the sacrificial ground, not without him. So how can it not be the cause of that? And thus, the rising of the moon is the cause of the swelling of the ocean, because it has concomitance and non-concomitance. And thus, when it is present, there is swelling of the ocean, not in its absence. The moon, obscured by a mass of clouds, is inferred by the effect. For one who has grasped the pervasion, the swelling of the ocean is inferred even in another country from the perception of the rising of the moon. Thus, the blooming of the lilies,

original: pakṣadvaye ca guṇadoṣanirūpaṇaṃ svata eva kāryaṃ parīkṣakairiti /
analyzed: pakṣa dvaye ca guṇa doṣa nirūpaṇam svatas eva kāryam parīkṣakaiḥ iti
translated: And in both cases, the determination of merits and faults should be done by the investigators themselves.

original: laiṅgikajñānabhedaḥ
analyzed: laiṅgika jñāna bhedaḥ
translated: The difference in inferential knowledge

original: tattu dvividham / dṛṣṭaṃ sāmānyato dṛṣṭañca / tatra dṛṣṭaṃ prasiddhasādhyayorjātyabhede 'numānam / yathā gavyeva sāsnāmātramupalabhya deśāntare 'pi sāsnāmātradarśanād gavi pratipattiḥ / prasiddhasādhyayoratyantajātibhede liṅgānumeyadharmasāmānyānuvṛttito 'numānaṃ sāmānyato dṛṣṭam / yathā karṣakavaṇigrarājapuruṣāṇāñca pravṛtteḥ phalavattvamupalabhya varṇāśramiṇāmapi dṛṣṭaṃ prayojanamanudiśya pravartamānānāṃ phalānumānamiti /PDhS
analyzed: tat tu dvividham dṛṣṭam sāmānyatas dṛṣṭam ca tatra dṛṣṭam prasiddha sādhyayoḥ jāti abhede numānam yathā gavi eva sāsnā mātram upalabhya deśa antare sāsnā mātra darśanāt gavi pratipattiḥ prasiddha sādhyayoḥ atyanta jāti bhede liṅga anumeya dharma sāmānya anuvṛttitaḥ numānam sāmānyatas dṛṣṭam yathā karṣaka vaṇij gra rāja puruṣāṇām ca pravṛtteḥ phalavat tvam upalabhya varṇa āśramiṇām api dṛṣṭam prayojanam anudiśya pravarta
translated: That is of two kinds: seen and seen in general. Among them, the seen is inference when there is no difference in the class between the well-known and the to-be-inferred, like when only the dewlap is perceived in a cow, and even in another country, by seeing only the dewlap, there is understanding of it as a cow. When there is complete difference in the class between the well-known and the to-be-inferred, inference is seen in general from the continuation of the general property to be inferred from the reason, like when the presence of a result is perceived from the activity of farmers, traders, and royal servants, and by inferring the result of those belonging to the varnas and ashramas who are engaged in activity with a seen purpose.

original: bhedamāha tat anumānam / dvividham / kena rūpeṇa / dṛṣṭaṃ sāmānyato dṛṣṭañca iti / tatra dṛṣṭaṃ prasiddhasādhyayorjātyabhede 'numānam prasiddhaśca sādhyaśceti prasiddhasādhyau / tayoḥ prasiddhasādhyayordṛṣṭāntadārṣṭāntikayorjātyabhede sati yadanumānaṃ tad dṛṣṭam / yathā hi sādhyadharmo dṛṣṭāntadharmiṇi pratyakṣārhastathā dārṣṭāntike 'pīti sādhyadharmābhedo na tu jāteḥ sāmānyasya / tathāhi / brāhmaṇakartṛkaṃ citrādikāryaṃ pratipadya punaḥ kṣatriyādikartṛkasyāpyupalambhāt kenacit kartrā sampāditametat / citrādikāryatvāt pūrvopalabdhaivaṃvidhacitrādikāryavadityanumānaṃ jāteḥ sāmānyasya bhede 'pi dṛṣṭameva / sādhyadharmasyānumānāt pūrvaṃ ūrdhvañca pratyakṣagrahaṇārthatvāt /
analyzed: bhedam āha tat anumānam dvividham kena rūpeṇa dṛṣṭam sāmānyatas dṛṣṭam ca iti tatra dṛṣṭam prasiddha sādhyayoḥ jāti abhede numānam prasiddhaḥ ca sādhyaḥ ca iti prasiddha sādhyau tayoḥ prasiddha sādhyayoḥ dṛṣṭānta dārṣṭāntikayoḥ jāti abhede sati yat anumānam tat dṛṣṭam yathā hi sādhya dharmaḥ dṛṣṭānta dharmiṇi pratyakṣa arhaḥ tathā dārṣṭāntike pi iti sādhya dharma abhedaḥ na tu jāteḥ sāmānyasya tathā hi brāhma
translated: He states the difference: that inference is of two kinds. By what form? The seen and the seen in general. Among them, the seen is inference when there is no difference in the universal of the well-known and the probandum. The well-known and the probandum are the well-known and the probandum. When there is no difference in the universal of those two, the example and the subject, that inference is seen. For just as the property to be proved is fit to be perceived in the property-possessor of the example, so also in the subject. Thus, there is no difference in the property to be proved, but in the universal, the general. For example, having recognized the effect such as a painting etc. produced by a Brahmin, one again observes it produced by a Kshatriya etc. This is produced by some agent, because it is an effect such as a painting etc., like a previously observed effect such as a painting etc. of this kind. This inference is seen even when there is a difference in the universal, the general. Because the perception of the property to be proved is before and after the inference.

original: anye tu prasiddhau ca tau sādhyau ceti prasiddhasādhyāviti samāsaṃ kurvate / tatra dṛṣṭāntadharmī prasiddhatvāt sādhyo na bhavati / dārṣṭāntikaśca na prasiddha iti kathametat / upacārasya vivakṣitatvādadoṣaḥ / tathā hi / dṛṣṭāntadhamā sādhyasamānadharmādhikaraṇatvādupacāreṇa sādhyaḥ / dārṣṭāntikastvanumānādūrdhvaṃ prasiddhiṃ yāsyatīti pūrvamapi prasiddhaḥ / śeṣaṃ pūrvavaditi /
analyzed: anye tu prasiddhau ca tau sādhyau ca iti prasiddha sādhyau iti samāsam kurvate tatra dṛṣṭānta dharmī prasiddha tvāt sādhyaḥ na bhavati dārṣṭāntikaḥ ca na prasiddhaḥ iti katham etat upacārasya vivakṣita tvāt adoṣaḥ tathā hi dṛṣṭānta dhamā sādhya samāna dharma adhikaraṇa tvāt upacāreṇa sādhyaḥ dārṣṭāntikaḥ tu anumānāt ūrdhvam prasiddhim yāsyati iti pūrvam api prasiddhaḥ śeṣam pūrvavat iti
translated: Others, however, make the compound 'prasiddhasādhya' by taking 'prasiddha' and 'sādhya' separately, meaning 'that which is well-known and also to be established'. There, the example-subject is not to be established because it is well-known, and the subject of the conclusion is not well-known. How is this? There is no fault because figurative usage is intended. Thus, the example-subject is figuratively called 'to be established' because it is the locus of the property to be established, which is the same as the property of the conclusion. And the subject of the conclusion will become well-known after the inference, so it is well-known even before. The rest is as before.

original: asyodāharaṇaṃ yathā gavyeva sāsnāmupalabhya punardeśāntare gopiṇḍavyavadhāne 'pi sāsnādarśanād gavi pratipattiḥ gauriyaṃ sāsnāvattvāt pūrvopalabdhasāsnādivaditi /
analyzed: asya udāharaṇam yathā gavi eva sāsnām upalabhya punar deśa antare go piṇḍa vyavadhāne sāsnā darśanāt gavi pratipattiḥ gauḥ iyam sāsnāvat tvāt pūrva upalabdha sāsnā ādi vat iti
translated: An example of this is as follows: Having perceived a cow with dewlap, again in another place, even when the individual cow is obstructed, by seeing the dewlap, one understands it to be a cow, thinking 'this is a cow because it has a dewlap, like the previously perceived dewlap etc.'

original: sāmānyato dṛṣṭañca prasiddhasādhyayoḥ dṛṣṭāntadārṣṭāntikayoratyantaṃ sarvathā jātibhede sādhyadharmabhede 'numānam / tathā ca sādhyadharmo 'numānāt pūrvamūrdhvañca sarvadā aprasiddha eveti / atha sādhyadharmasya bhede 'vinābhāvasyaivāprasiddheḥ kathamanumānamityāha liṅgānumeyadharmasāmānyānuvṛttitaḥ iti / liṅgañca anumeyadharmaśca tayoḥ sāmānyenānuvṛttiḥ / yatra yatredaṃ sādhanasāmānyam / tatra tatredaṃ sādhyasāmānyamiti / tadgrahaṇe 'numānaṃ pravartata eva / yathā karṣakavaṇigrājapuruṣāṇāṃ pravṛtterabhipretaphalatvena phalavattvamupalabhya / varṇāśramiṇāmapi / kiṃ viśiṣṭānām / dṛṣṭaṃ bhikṣālābhādikaṃ prayojanamanuddiśya pravartamānānāmabhipretaphalānumānam / tathāhi / varṇāśramiṇāñca pravṛttiḥ abhipretaphalena phalavatī prekṣāpūrvakāripravṛttitvāt karṣakādipravṛttivat /
analyzed: sāmānyatas dṛṣṭam ca prasiddha sādhyayoḥ dṛṣṭānta dārṣṭāntikayoḥ atyantam sarvathā jāti bhede sādhya dharma bhede numānam tathā ca sādhya dharmaḥ numānāt pūrvam ūrdhvam ca sarvadā aprasiddhaḥ eva iti atha sādhya dharmasya bhede vinābhāvasya eva aprasiddheḥ katham anumānam iti āha liṅga anumeya dharma sāmānya anuvṛttitaḥ iti liṅgam ca anumeya dharmaḥ ca tayoḥ sāmānyena anuvṛttiḥ yatra yatra idam sādhana sāmānyam tatra tatra idam sādhya
translated: And inference is when there is complete and total difference in the class, i.e., difference in the property to be proved, between the example and the subject, in the case of a well-known probandum and probans, as in the case of inference from a universal. And in that case, the property to be proved is indeed always unknown, prior to and after the inference. Now, if there is difference in the property to be proved, since invariable concomitance itself is unknown, how can there be inference? He says: Because of the universal concomitance of the inferential mark with the general property to be inferred. The inferential mark and the property to be inferred, their universal concomitance is that wherever this general means is, there this general end is. When that is grasped, inference proceeds, just as when the activity of farmers, traders, and royal servants is observed to have a desired result, the presence of a result is inferred in the case of the varnas and ashramas as well. What kind of activity? That which is seen to be undertaken without reference to a purpose such as obtaining alms, etc., the inference of a desired result. For thus, the activity of the varnas and ashramas is also seen to be undertaken without reference to a purpose such as obtaining alms, etc.,

original: na ca dṛṣṭaprayojanāpekṣayā siddhasādhanamiti dūṣaṇam / dṛṣṭaṃ prayojanamanuddiśyeti pakṣaviśeṣaṇena nirastatvāt / ye tu dṛṣṭamevoddiśya pravartate na te pakṣīkriyanta iti / nāpyadṛṣṭaphalena phalavattvaṃ sādhyate yena dṛṣṭāntaḥ sādhyavikalo hetuśca viruddhaḥ syāt / kiṃ tarhi / sāmānyenābhipretaphalena phalavattvaṃ sādhyate / tacca karṣakādipravṛttāvastyeveti na dṛṣṭāntasya sādhyavikalatvaṃ viruddhatvaṃ vā hetordoṣaḥ /
analyzed: na ca dṛṣṭa prayojana apekṣayā siddhasādhanam iti dūṣaṇam dṛṣṭam prayojanam an uddiśya iti pakṣa viśeṣaṇena nirasta tvāt  ye tu dṛṣṭam eva uddiśya pravartate na te pakṣīkriyante iti  na api adṛṣṭa phalena phalavat tvam sādhyate yena dṛṣṭāntaḥ sādhya vikalaḥ hetuḥ ca viruddhaḥ syāt  kim tarhi sāmānyena abhipreta phalena phalavat tvam sādhyate tat ca karṣaka ādi pravṛttau asti eva iti na dṛṣṭāntasya sādhya vikala tvam viruddha tv
translated: Nor is it a fault to say that the proof is superfluous in relation to a visible purpose, because that has been refuted by the qualification without specifying a visible purpose in the thesis. Those who engage in action only with reference to what is visible are not taken as the subject. Nor is the fact of being fruitful by means of an unseen result being proved, so that the example would be deficient in the probandum and the reason would be contradictory. Rather, what is being proved is the fact of being fruitful by a result that is intended in general, and that does exist in the engagement of farmers and so on. Therefore, the example is not deficient in the probandum, nor is the reason contradictory, which would be a fault.

original: sarvānumāneṣu samānañca viśeṣaviruddhānumānamityanumānamātrasyocchedaprasaṅgaḥ / atheṣyata evānumānasyāprāmāṇyam / tathā ca sāmānye siddhasādhanaṃ viśeṣe 'nugamābhāvaḥ / dharmiṇośca samudāye sādhye na hetoḥ pakṣadharmatvam / na cānvayaḥ samudāyasyānyatrāvṛtteḥ / atha samudāyaikadeśe 'pi vartamānaḥ samudāye varteta ityupacaryate / tarhi pramāṇasya gauṇatvād anumānārthaniścayo durlabhaḥ / tathā hi / pramāṇaṃ pratyakṣam / gauṇam anumānam / vā upacaritapakṣadharmāpekṣitvāt / gauṇamityapramāṇam / dharmasyāpi sādhyatve 'nvayasadbhāve 'pi na pakṣadhamatvaṃ samudāyasyānyatra / atha pratipādyamānadharmaviśiṣṭo dharmī sādhyaḥ / tena cānvayābhāva eveti sarvamanumānamapramāṇam /
analyzed: sarva anumāneṣu samānam ca viśeṣa viruddha anumānam iti anumāna mātrasya uccheda prasaṅgaḥ atha iṣyate eva anumānasya aprāmāṇyam tathā ca sāmānye siddhasādhanam viśeṣe nugama abhāvaḥ dharmiṇoḥ ca samudāye sādhye na hetoḥ pakṣa dharma tvam na ca anvayaḥ samudāyasya anyatra avṛtteḥ atha samudāya eka deśe vartamānaḥ samudāye varteta iti upacaryate tarhi pramāṇasya gauṇa tvāt anumāna artha niścayaḥ durlabhaḥ tathā hi pramāṇam pratyakṣam ga
translated: And in all inferences, there is the same contradictory inference regarding particulars, so there is the undesirable consequence of the destruction of inference itself. But if the invalidity of inference is accepted, then in general there is the fault of proving what is already established, and in particular there is the absence of concomitance. And when the whole is to be proved, the reason does not have the property of the subject. And there is no positive concomitance, because the whole does not occur elsewhere. But if it is assumed that what occurs in even a part of the whole occurs in the whole, then because the means of knowledge is secondary, the ascertainment of the meaning of inference is difficult to obtain. For example, perception is the primary means of knowledge, while inference is secondary. Or it is figurative, because it requires the property of the subject in a figurative sense. What is secondary is not a means of knowledge. Even if the property to be proved exists, if the whole does not have the property of the subject elsewhere, then the whole is not the subject. But if the subject qualified by the property being conveyed is to be proved, then there is indeed the absence of positive concomitance. Thus all inference is not a means of knowledge.

original: tadatadasat / pratipādyadharmaviśiṣṭasya dharmiṇaḥ sādhyatve pakṣadharmatvopapatteḥ / anvayastu sādhyasamānadharmeṇa / nahi ekatra deśe hetorvṛttiḥ vyatirekastu tadabhāve II / vyāvṛttiriti / liṅgopalambhācca sādhyadharmiṇi pratipatterdṛṣṭatvād itthambhūtānvayaparikalpanā kriyate / anabhyupagame vā /ca vyabhicārijñānameva na syāt / tattu dṛṣṭamiti viśeṣaḥ / viruddhena tu niyataviśeṣapratiṣedhe viśeṣāntaropagamaḥ syāt / samastaviśeṣapratiṣedhe tu tanniyatasya sāmānyasyāpyasiddhiḥ / sādhanasāmānyavyāpakaṃ vā avaśyaṃ sādhyasāmānyaṃ sidhyatīti / ataḥ sādhyasāmānyasyaiva ākṣiptaviśeṣasyaiva anumānāt prasiddhervarṇāśramiṇāṃ phalantu adṛṣṭaṃ viśeṣātītameva sidhyatīti /
analyzed: tat atadasat pratipādya dharma viśiṣṭasya dharmiṇaḥ sādhya tve pakṣa dharma tva upapatteḥ anvayaḥ tu sādhya samāna dharmeṇa nahi ekatra deśe hetoḥ vṛttiḥ vyatirekaḥ tu tad abhāve vyāvṛttiḥ iti liṅga upalambhāt ca sādhya dharmiṇi pratipatteḥ dṛṣṭa tvāt ittham bhūta anvaya parikalpanā kriyate anabhyupagame vāca vyabhicāri jñānam eva na syāt tat tu dṛṣṭam iti viśeṣaḥ viruddhena tu niyata viśeṣa pratiṣedhe viśeṣa antara upagamaḥ sy
translated: That is not so. When the subject qualified by the property to be proved is what is to be established, the property of the subject is logically possible. But the positive concomitance is by a property common to the probandum. For the presence of the reason in one place, and the absence of the probandum in the absence of that, is exclusion. And because the understanding of the probandum in the subject of the inference is seen to be from the perception of the inferential mark, the imagination of such positive concomitance is made. Or, if it is not accepted, there would not even be the knowledge of the fallacious concomitance. But that is seen, so there is a distinction. But by the contradictory, there would be the acceptance of another particular in the negation of a particular determined by it. But in the negation of all particulars, even the generally established particular determined by that is not established. Or, the general probandum which is necessarily pervaded by the general means of knowledge is necessarily established. Therefore, because the general probandum itself, which is implied by the particulars, is established by inference, the unseen result of the varnas and ashramas is established as only transcending the particulars.

original: laiṅgikajñānasya pramāṇaphalavibhāgaḥ🔽tatra liṅgadarśanaṃ pramāṇam / anumeyaṃ jñānaṃ phalam / prameyo 'gniḥ / pramātā ātmā / athavā agnijñānameva pramāṇaṃ pramitiragnau guṇadoṣamādhyasthyadarśanam / ityetat svaniścayārthamanumānam /PDhS
analyzed: laiṅgika jñānasya pramāṇa phala vibhāgaḥ  tatra liṅga darśanam pramāṇam anumeyam jñānam phalam prameyaḥ gniḥ pramātā ātmā athavā agni jñānam eva pramāṇam pramitiḥ agnau guṇa doṣa mādhyasthya darśanam iti etat sva niścaya artham anumānam
translated: The distinction between the means of knowledge and the result in the case of inferential knowledge🔽There, the perception of the mark is the means of knowledge. The object to be inferred is the result. Fire is the object to be known. The knower is the self. Or, the knowledge of fire itself is the means of knowledge. The ascertainment is the perception of the qualities, faults, and neutrality in fire. This is inference for one's own conviction.

original: śiṣyavyutpādanāya pramāṇaphalavibhāgaṃ darśayati tatra liṅgadarśanaṃ pramāṇam / anumeyaṃ jñānaṃ phalam / prameyo 'gniḥ / pramātā ātmā iti / nanu liṅgadarśanaṃ vyadhikaraṇatvāt kathamagnijñānotpattau pramāṇam / vyāpārāpekṣayā tadviṣayatvāt / yathā hi dhūmajñānaṃ dhūmaviṣayam ātmalābhāpekṣayā / tathā agnipratipattau vyāpārāpekṣayā agniviṣayamapīti / svāvayavasamavetasya cakṣuṣaḥ samutpāde vyāpārāpekṣayā rūpaviṣayatvamiveti /
analyzed: śiṣya vyutpādanāya pramāṇa phala vibhāgam darśayati tatra liṅga darśanam pramāṇam anumeyam jñānam phalam prameyaḥ gniḥ pramātā ātmā iti  nanu liṅga darśanam vyadhikaraṇa tvāt katham agni jñāna utpattau pramāṇam vyāpāra apekṣayā tad viṣaya tvāt yathā hi dhūma jñānam dhūma viṣayam ātma lābha apekṣayā tathā agni pratipattau vyāpāra apekṣayā agni viṣayam api iti sva avayava samavetasya cakṣuṣaḥ samutpāde vyāpāra apekṣayā rūpa viṣay
translated: In order to instruct the disciples, he shows the distinction between the means of knowledge and the result: There, the perception of the mark is the means of knowledge. The object to be inferred is the result. Fire is the object to be known. The knower is the self. But how can the perception of the mark, being about a different thing, be the means of knowledge in the production of the knowledge of fire? Because it is about that [fire] in relation to its operation. Just as the knowledge of smoke is about smoke in relation to its own attainment, so it is about fire in relation to its operation in the ascertainment of fire. Just as the eye, which is inherent in its own parts, is about form in relation to its operation in the production of itself.

original: nanvevamekasmin viṣaye vyāpārāpekṣayā karaṇādivyavasthānupapattiḥ / vibhinnalakṣaṇayogitvena tadbhāvāt / tathāhi / pramādhāratvaṃ pramāturlakṣaṇamuktam / evaṃ pramiterviṣayaḥ prameyam / tadvyatiriktañca pramājanakaṃ pramāṇam / tatsādhyañca phalamityevaṃ lakṣaṇabhedādeṣāṃ bheda iti /
analyzed: nanu evam ekasmin viṣaye vyāpāra apekṣayā karaṇa ādi vyavasthā anupapattiḥ vibhinna lakṣaṇa yogitvena tad bhāvāt tathā hi pramā ādhāra tvam pramātuḥ lakṣaṇam uktam evam pramiteḥ viṣayaḥ prameyam tad vyatiriktam ca pramā janakam pramāṇam tad sādhyam ca phalam iti evam lakṣaṇa bhedāt eṣām bhedaḥ iti
translated: But in this way, the distinction of the instrument, etc. based on the relation of operation with regard to one object is not possible, because that exists due to the possession of different characteristics. Thus, the definition of the knower is said to be the basis of valid knowledge. Similarly, the object of valid knowledge is the knowable. That which produces valid knowledge other than that is the means of valid knowledge. And the result is that which is to be accomplished. Thus, the distinction of these is due to the distinction of definitions.

original: athavā iti pramāṇaphalavibhāge prakārāntaramāha agnijñānameva pramāṇaṃ pramitiragnau guṇadoṣamādhyasthyadarśanam iti / agnijñāne satyavinābhāvasambandhasmaraṇāt parāmarśajñānāt sukhaṃsādhanatvāvabodhe sati upādeyajñānam / duḥkhasādhanatvāvabodhe ca heyajñānam / yasya nedaṃ sukhasādhanaṃ nāpi duḥkhasādhanam ityevaṃ bodhastasyopekṣaṇīyajñānamiti / agnijñānaphalatvañcopādeyādijñānasya pāramparyeṇeti pūrvavad vācyam /
analyzed: athavā iti pramāṇa phala vibhāge prakāra antaram āha agni jñānam eva pramāṇam pramitiḥ agnau guṇa doṣa mādhyasthya darśanam iti agni jñāne sati avinābhāva sambandha smaraṇāt parāmarśa jñānāt sukham sādhana tva avabodhe sati upādeya jñānam duḥkha sādhana tva avabodhe ca heya jñānam yasya na idam sukha sādhanam na api duḥkha sādhanam iti evam bodhaḥ tasya upekṣaṇīya jñānam iti agni jñāna phala tvam ca upādeya ādi jñānasya pāramparyeṇa iti pūrvav
translated: Or, the author states another method of dividing the means and the end of valid knowledge: The knowledge of fire itself is the means of valid knowledge, and the perception of the qualities, defects, and neutrality in fire is the object of valid knowledge. When there is knowledge of fire, the remembrance of the relation of invariable concomitance arises from the reflective cognition, and when there is the understanding that fire is the means of producing pleasure, there is the knowledge of what is to be adopted. And when there is the understanding that fire is the means of producing pain, there is the knowledge of what is to be rejected. For one who has the understanding that fire is neither the means of producing pleasure nor pain, there is the knowledge of what is to be ignored. And the knowledge of what is to be adopted, etc. is indirectly the result of the knowledge of fire. This should be stated as before.

original: ityetat svaniścayārthamanumānam ityupasaṃhāraḥ parārthānumānasaṃsūcakaḥ /
analyzed: iti etat sva niścaya artham anumānam iti upasaṃhāraḥ para artha anumāna saṃsūcakaḥ
translated: Thus, this is the conclusion that inference is for one's own ascertainment, and it indicates inference for the sake of others.

original: śabdādīnāṃ anumāne 'ntarbhāvaḥ
analyzed: śabda ādīnām anumāne ntarbhāvaḥ
translated: Inclusion of verbal testimony and others in inference

original: śabdādīnāmapyanumāne 'ntarbhāvaḥ samānavidhitvāt / yathā prasiddhasamayasyāsandigdhaliṅgadarśanaprasiddhyanusmaraṇābhyāmatīndriye 'rthe bhavatyanumānamevaṃ śabdādibhyo 'pīti / śrutismṛtilakṣaṇo 'pyāmnāyo vaktṛprāmāṇyāpakṣaḥ / tadvacanādāmnāyaprāmāṇyam / liṅgāccānityo buddhipūrvā vākyakṛtirvede buddhipūrvo dadātirityuktatvāt /PDhS
analyzed: śabda ādīnām api anumāne ntarbhāvaḥ samāna vidhi tvāt  yathā prasiddha samayasya asandigdha liṅga darśana prasiddhi anusmaraṇābhyām atīndriye rthe bhavati anumānam evam śabda ādibhyaḥ pi iti śruti smṛti lakṣaṇaḥ u pi āmnāyaḥ vaktṛ prāmāṇya apakṣaḥ tad vacanāt āmnāya prāmāṇyam liṅgāt ca anityaḥ buddhi pūrvā vākya kṛtiḥ vede buddhi pūrvaḥ dadātiḥ iti ukta tvāt pdhs
translated: Sound and other [means of knowledge] are also included in inference, because they have the same method. Just as inference occurs regarding a supersensible object through the observation of an ascertained mark and the recollection of its established concomitance, so it is also from sound and other [means of knowledge]. Even the revealed texts characterized by Śruti and Smṛti are based on the authority of the speaker. The authority of the revealed texts is due to His statement. And from the mark, the composition of sentences in the Veda is non-eternal and intentional, because it has been said that the word 'gives' is intentional.

original: athedānīṃ pramāṇavibhāgasya nyūnatāparihārāya tatsāmānyalakṣaṇasya vyabhicāraparihārārthaṃ śabdādīnāmapyanumāne 'ntarbhāvaḥ ityādi prakaraṇam / nanu pūrvamanyeṣāmanumāne 'ntarbhāvasyānuktatvāt apiśabdavaiyarthyam / na / anumānapadenābhisambandhāt / na paraṃ pratyakṣa eva anumāne 'pyantarbhāva iti / pramāṇavibhāgaśca vidyāvibhāgapareṇāpi vākyena pūrvamupadarśita eva / tatra ca śabdādīnāmapi pramāṇānāṃ sadbhāvādanupapanno 'yamityāśaṅkā / tadvyudāsārthamantarbhāvaprakaraṇam / tathā śabdādeḥ kārakajātasyānumānasāmagryāmantarbhāve tatphalasyāpi phale 'ntarbhāvo jñāyata eva /
analyzed: atha idānīm pramāṇa vibhāgasya nyūnatā parihārāya tad sāmānya lakṣaṇasya vyabhicāra parihāra artham śabda ādīnām api anumāne ntarbhāvaḥ ityādi prakaraṇam nanu pūrvam anyeṣām anumāne ntarbhāvasya anukta tvāt apiśabda vaiyarthyam na anumāna padena abhisambandhāt na param pratyakṣe eva anumāne pi antarbhāvaḥ iti pramāṇa vibhāgaḥ ca vidyā vibhāga pareṇa api vākyena pūrvam upadarśitaḥ eva tatra ca śabda ādīnām api pramāṇānām sadbhāvāt anupap
translated: Now, in order to remove the deficiency of the division of means of knowledge and to avoid fallacies in their general definition, the topic begins with the inclusion of verbal testimony etc. also in inference. But since the inclusion of others in inference was not stated before, the word 'api' (also) is meaningless. No, because of the connection with the word 'anumāna' (inference). It means not only in perception, but also in inference. And the division of means of knowledge was already shown by the statement which is concerned with the division of knowledge. And there, since verbal testimony etc. are also means of knowledge, this is not appropriate. The topic of inclusion is for the purpose of refuting that doubt. Thus, when verbal testimony etc. are included in the assemblage of inference, it is understood that the result of that is also included in the result.

original: tatra śabda ādau yeṣāṃ tāni tathoktāni / atasteṣāmanumāne 'ntarbhāvo lakṣaṇaikyamiti tadguṇasaṃvijñānabahuvrīhyabhyupagame śabdasyāpyanumāne 'ntarbhāvaḥ / atadguṇasaṃvijñāne śabdaṃ vinā apareṣāmiti /
analyzed: tatra śabdaḥ ādau yeṣām tāni tathā uktāni atas teṣām anumāne ntarbhāvaḥ lakṣaṇa aikyam iti tad guṇa saṃvijñāna bahuvrīhi abhyupagame śabdasya api anumāne ntarbhāvaḥ a tad guṇa saṃvijñāne śabdam vinā apareṣām iti
translated: Those for whom sound is the first are said to be such. Therefore, their inclusion in inference is due to the identity of definition. When accepting the bahuvrīhi compound with the quality of that, sound is also included in inference. When not recognizing that quality, others are without sound.

original: antarbhāvavyavahāre ca samānavidhitvāt samānalakṣaṇayogitvāditi hetūpanyāsaḥ kathaṃ sādhyānna viśiṣyate / lakṣaṇaikatvasya tadvyavahārādanyatvāt / samāno vidhirupāyo lakṣaṇaṃ yeṣāṃ tāni tathoktāni / teṣāṃ bhāvastattvaṃ tasmāditi / tadevāha yathā prasiddhasamayasyāsandigdhaliṅgadarśanaprasiddhyanusmaraṇābhyām atīndriye 'rthe bhavatyanumānamevaṃ śabdādibhyo 'pīti / yathā hi gṛhītasambandhasya liṅgadarśanānantaram avinābhāvasambandhasmaraṇaṃ tābhyāmatīndriye 'rthe paricchedye bhavatyanumānam / anumīyate 'neneti parāmarśajñānamevopacāreṇa vyutpattyā vā / tad vivakṣitam / evaṃ śabdādibhyo 'pīti dārṣṭāntikavyākhyānam /
analyzed: antarbhāva vyavahāre ca samāna vidhi tvāt samāna lakṣaṇa yogi tvāt iti hetu upanyāsaḥ katham sādhyāt na viśiṣyate lakṣaṇa ekatvasya tad vyavahārāt anya tvāt samānaḥ vidhiḥ upāyaḥ lakṣaṇam yeṣām tāni tathā uktāni teṣām bhāvaḥ tattvam tasmāt iti  tat eva āha yathā prasiddha samayasya asandigdha liṅga darśana prasiddhi anusmaraṇābhyām atīndriye rthe bhavati anumānam evam śabda ādibhyaḥ pi iti  yathā hi gṛhīta sambandhasya liṅga darśana an
translated: And in the case of internal usage, how is the statement of the reason because of having the same rule and because of having the same characteristics not distinguished from the probandum? Because the oneness of characteristics is different from that usage. Those that have the same rule, which is the means, as the characteristics are said to be like that. The state of those is the truth. Therefore, he says: Just as inference occurs regarding a supersensible object through the well-known connection and the recollection of the seen indicative mark, so it is also from words and so on. For just as, after seeing the indicative mark, for one who has grasped the connection, the recollection of the relation of invariable concomitance occurs, and that inference occurs regarding a supersensible object to be determined by those two, by the knowledge of the indicative mark and the recollection of the connection, so it is also from words and so on. Inference is that by which one infers. The knowledge of reflection is metaphorically or etymologically called inference. That is intended. Thus, so it is also from words and so on is the explanation of the example.

original: anye tu parāmarśajñānasyāsattvameveti manyante / taccāsat / avinābhāvasambandhasmaraṇasya aniyatatvānniyatadeśe pratipattirna syāt / upanayavaiyarthyañcetyuktamataḥ pūrvameva nyāyyam /
analyzed: anye tu parāmarśa jñānasya asattvam eva iti manyante tat ca asat avinābhāva sambandha smaraṇasya aniyata tvāt niyata deśe pratipattiḥ na syāt upanaya vaiyarthyam ca iti uktam atas pūrvam eva nyāyyam
translated: Others, however, think that the knowledge of the conclusion does not exist at all. And that is wrong. Because the remembrance of the relation of invariable concomitance is not definite, there would be no definite cognition in a definite place, and because the application [of the reason] would be useless, as stated before, the former [view] is proper.

original: atra tadguṇasaṃvijñānapakṣe śabdasyāpyanumāne 'ntarbhāvaḥ / tathā ca śabdaśravaṇāt samayānusmaraṇe sati parāmarśajñānaṃ tasmāt parokṣārthapratipattiriti / ayaṃ gośabdaḥ kakudādimadarthavān gośabdatvāt pūrvopalabdhaivaṃvidhagośabdavaditi / sambandhāvagamenārthapratipādakatvācca dhūmavat /
analyzed: atra tad guṇa saṃvijñāna pakṣe śabdasya api anumāne ntarbhāvaḥ tathā ca śabda śravaṇāt samaya anusmaraṇe sati parāmarśa jñānam tasmāt parokṣa artha pratipattiḥ iti ayam go śabdaḥ kakud ādimat arthavān go śabda tvāt pūrva upalabdha evaṃvidha go śabda vat iti sambandha avagamena artha pratipādaka tvāt ca dhūma vat
translated: Here, in the case of the [view] with the implication of its quality, word is also included in inference. And thus, from hearing the word, when the remembrance of convention is present, there is the knowledge of the conclusion, and from that, the cognition of the inferred object. This word 'cow' has the meaning possessing a dewlap, etc., because it is a word 'cow', like the previously perceived word 'cow' of that kind. And because it conveys the meaning by the understanding of the relation, like smoke.

original: vyomaśivācāryamate śabdasyānumāne nāntarbhāvaḥ
analyzed: vyomaśiva ācārya mate śabdasya anumāne na antarbhāvaḥ
translated: In the opinion of the teacher Vyoman Shiva, word is not included in inference.

original: tadetadasat / gośabdasya kakudādimadarthavattāyāḥ pratipādayitumaśakyatvāt / tathāhi / śabdasyārthena anyasambandhābhāvād vācyavācakatvenārthapratipādakatve sādhye gośabdatvamahetuḥ / pratipādakatvasya pratipattyavaseyatvāt / svābhāvikasambandhānupapatteśca / dhūmo hi svābhāvikasambandhena sarvaprāṇabhṛtāmanumeyārthapratipādakaḥ / na caivaṃ śabdaḥ / puruṣecchāsampāditasamayāpekṣasyārthapratipādakatvāt / svābhāvikasambandhe hi vināpi saṅketaṃ mlecchādiśabdaśravaṇād arthapratipattiḥ syāt / saṅketāpekṣasya tu arthapratipādakatve sa evāstu / alaṃ nityasambandheneti / na ca nityasambandhābhāve 'tiprasaṅgaḥ / naimittikaśabdānāṃ dravyatvādinimittasadbhāve satyeva saṅketāt / yādṛcchikaśabdānāntu puruṣecchānuvidhānāditi / yatra ca viśiṣṭānupūrvīmattvasadbhāvastadeva niyamena vācakam / itaracca vācyamiti vyavasthā saṅketajñānasyobhayaniṣṭhatvāviśeṣāditi /
analyzed: tat etat asat go śabdasya kakud ādimat arthavat tāyāḥ pratipādayitum aśakya tvāt tathā hi śabdasya arthena anya sambandha abhāvāt vācya vācaka tvena artha pratipādaka tve sādhye go śabda tvam ahetuḥ pratipādaka tvasya pratipatti avaseya tvāt svābhāvika sambandha anupapatteḥ ca  dhūmaḥ hi svābhāvika sambandhena sarva prāṇabhṛtām anumeya artha pratipādakaḥ na ca evam śabdaḥ puruṣa icchā sampādita samaya apekṣasya artha pratipādaka tvāt svābhāvika sambandhe
translated: This is not correct. Because it is impossible to establish that the word 'cow' denotes an object with a dewlap etc. For thus: In proving that a word denotes an object by the relation of denoter and denoted, because of the absence of any other relation with the object, the fact of being a word 'cow' is not a reason. Because the fact of being a denoter is to be known by understanding, and because a natural relation is not possible. For smoke, by a natural relation, is a denoter of the object to be inferred, for all living beings. And a word is not so. Because the fact of being a denoter depends on a convention accomplished by the will of a person. For if there were a natural relation, then even without a convention, on hearing the words of barbarians etc., there would be the understanding of the meaning. But if the fact of being a denoter depends on a convention, then let that alone be. Enough of a permanent relation. And even in the absence of a permanent relation, there is no overextension. Because of the words that depend on a cause, the convention is only when the cause such as the quality of being a substance etc. is present. But for the words that are accidental, the convention is only when the cause such as the desire to speak etc.

original: saṅketastu śabdād vṛddhavyavahārataśca pratīyate / tathāhi / idamasya vācakam / idamasya vācyam iti vākyāt saṅketapratipattiḥ / vṛddhavyavahārād yathā devadatta / gāmabhyāja śuklāṃ daṇḍena iti prayogād avyutpanno 'nvayavyatirekābhyāṃ devadattādiśabdeṣu saṅketaṃ pratipadyate / vṛddhavyavahartṝṇāmapi saṅketapratipattiranyato vyavahārādityanāditvaṃ parihāraḥ / yad vā ādipuruṣaḥ sākṣāddraṣṭā keṣāñcit saṅketakartā astīti / vākyarūpastu śabdo 'rthapratipattau samayamapi nāpekṣata iti sambandhabalenārthapratipādakatvamasiddham /
analyzed: saṅketaḥ tu śabdāt vṛddha vyavahārataḥ ca pratīyate tathā hi idam asya vācakam idam asya vācyam iti vākyāt saṅketa pratipattiḥ vṛddha vyavahārāt yathā devadatta gām abhyāja śuklām daṇḍena iti prayogāt avyutpannaḥ nvaya vyatirekābhyām devadatta ādi śabdeṣu saṅketam pratipadyate vṛddha vyavahartṝṇām api saṅketa pratipattiḥ anyatas vyavahārāt iti anādi tvam parihāraḥ yat vā ādi puruṣaḥ sākṣāt draṣṭā keṣāñcid saṅketa kartā asti
translated: Convention, on the other hand, is understood from words and the usage of elders. Thus, from a sentence, one understands the convention as this is its denotator or this is its denotatum. From the usage of elders, like Devadatta, bring the white cow with the stick, one who is not learned understands the convention in words like Devadatta through positive and negative concomitance. Even for elders who have understood the convention from others, the usage is the answer to the question of beginninglessness. Or, the first person, the direct seer, is the maker of conventions for some. But a sentence-form word does not depend on convention even for conveying meaning. Therefore, the argument that it conveys meaning by the power of relation is unestablished.

original: na ca śabdasyānumānatvameva niṣidhyate / vivakṣākāśā /ayoradhigame liṅgatvāt / yathāhi / ākāśādhigame sarvaḥ śabdo 'numānam / vivakṣākāryastu vivakṣādhigame 'pīti / na ca śabdajñānavallaiṅgikajñānamāptoktatvamapekṣate / tathāhi / śabdajñāne kimidaṃ samyaṅ mithyā veti saṃśayotpattāvāptoktamanāptoktaṃ cā /vānvīkṣate / laiṅgikantu pakṣadharmatvādikamiti vyatirekaḥ /
analyzed: na ca śabdasya anumāna tvam eva niṣidhyate vivakṣā ākāśa āayoḥ adhigame liṅga tvāt  yathā hi ākāśa adhigame sarvaḥ śabdaḥ numānam vivakṣā kāryaḥ tu vivakṣā adhigame pi iti na ca śabda jñāna vat laiṅgika jñānam āpta ukta tvam apekṣate tathā hi śabda jñāne kim idam samyak mithyā vā iti saṃśaya utpattau āpta uktam anāpta uktam laiṅgikam tu pakṣa dharma tva ādikam iti vyatirekaḥ
translated: And it is not only the inferential nature of the word that is denied, because it is the cause of the desire to speak. For just as all sound is an inference in the cognition of space, so it is also in the cognition of the desire to speak. And the knowledge of the word, unlike the knowledge of the word, does not depend on the truthfulness of the speaker. For thus, when doubt arises as to whether the knowledge of the word is correct or false, one examines whether it is spoken by a trustworthy person or an untrustworthy person. But the knowledge of the word is not like that.

original: tadāha śrutismṛtilakṣaṇo 'pyāmnāyo vaktṛprāmāṇyāpekṣaḥ iti / na ca paraṃ laukikaḥ śabdo vaktṛprāmāṇyamapekṣate śrutismṛtilakṣaṇo 'pīti /
analyzed: tat āha śruti smṛti lakṣaṇaḥ u pi āmnāyaḥ vaktṛ prāmāṇya apekṣaḥ iti na ca param laukikaḥ śabdaḥ vaktṛ prāmāṇyam apekṣate śruti smṛti lakṣaṇaḥ u pi iti
translated: He says: Even the Veda, which is characterized by Śruti and Smṛti, depends on the truthfulness of the speaker. And worldly words, even if characterized by Śruti and Smṛti, do not depend on the truthfulness of the speaker.

original: nanu vaktṛprāmāṇyenāmnāyaprāmāṇyābhyupagame bahūnāmanyo 'nyāśrayatvaṃ syāt / tathāhi / arthaprāptyā āptoktatvaṃ śabde niścīyate niścayāccārthāvabodhe sati pravartamānasyārthaprāptiriti / tathā pauruṣeye vacasi satyāsatyatvopalabdhervede 'pi puruṣānupraveśe tadāśaṅkāyāmaprāmāṇyameva syāt / na ca sākṣādatīndriyārthadraṣṭā puruṣaḥ sambhavatīti kathaṃ tadvācakāni vacāṃsi tatpūrvakānīti /
analyzed: nanu vaktṛ prāmāṇyena āmnāya prāmāṇya abhyupagame bahūnām anyaḥ nyāśraya tvam syāt tathā hi artha prāptyā āpta ukta tvam śabde niścīyate niścayāt ca artha avabodhe sati pravartamānasya artha prāptiḥ iti tathā pauruṣeye vacasi satya asatya tva upalabdheḥ vede pi puruṣa anupraveśe tad āśaṅkāyām aprāmāṇyam eva syāt na ca sākṣāt atīndriya artha draṣṭā puruṣaḥ sambhavati iti katham tad vācakāni vacāṃsi tad pūrvakāni iti
translated: If the validity of the Veda is accepted on the ground of the speaker being a valid source of knowledge, there would be a mutual dependence of many things. Thus, the fact of the Veda being the utterance of a trustworthy person is ascertained by the attainment of the intended object, and the attainment of the object is possible only when there is ascertainment of the meaning, and when one engages in activity. Thus, since truthfulness and untruthfulness are seen in human statements, if there is human intervention in the Veda also, there would be doubt and hence invalidity. And since a person who directly perceives supersensible objects is not possible, how can the statements expressing them be based on that?

original: yadi cānyasmād vedavākyādarthaṃ pratipadya vacanaracanāṃ kuryāt / tasyāpi nityatvena kiñcid bādhitaṃ syāt / anityatve tu tatkarturapyanyasmād vākyādarthāvabodha ityanavasthā syāt / na cānityatvaṃ vedavākyānāṃ pramāṇaprasiddhamiti kathaṃ vaktṛviśeṣāpekṣaṃ prāmāṇyam /
analyzed: yadi ca anyasmāt veda vākyāt artham pratipadya vacana racanām kuryāt tasya api nitya tvena kiñcid bādhitam syāt anitya tve tu tad kartuḥ api anyasmāt vākyāt artha avabodhaḥ iti anavasthā syāt na ca anitya tvam veda vākyānām pramāṇa prasiddham iti katham vaktṛ viśeṣa apekṣam prāmāṇyam
translated: Moreover, if one were to compose a statement after understanding the meaning from another Vedic statement, since that also would be eternal, something would be contradicted. But if it is non-eternal, then the understanding of the meaning of that statement would also be from another statement, leading to an infinite regress. And since the non-eternality of Vedic statements is not established by any valid means of knowledge, how can their validity depend on a particular speaker?

original: arthapratipattau ca śabdasya svābhidhāśaktibalenaiva vyāpāro nāptoktatvamapekṣamāṇasyeti / sā ca tasya svātmabhūtaiva / na paścāt pareṇa sampādyata iti svata eva prāmāṇyam / na cāptoktatvaṃ śakyate pratipattuṃ pratipakṣā /bandhāderaviṣayatvāt / aprāmāṇyantu duṣṭapuruṣapraṇītatvāpekṣamiti parataḥ /
analyzed: artha pratipattau ca śabdasya sva abhidhā śakti balena eva vyāpāraḥ na āpta ukta tvam apekṣamāṇasya iti sā ca tasya svātma bhūtā eva na paścāt pareṇa sampādyate iti svatas eva prāmāṇyam na ca āpta ukta tvam śakyate pratipattum pratipakṣa ābandha ādeḥ aviṣaya tvāt aprāmāṇyam tu duṣṭa puruṣa praṇīta tva apekṣam iti paratas
translated: And in the cognition of the meaning, the operation of the word is only by the power of its own expressive potency, not by depending on the statement of a trustworthy person. And that is its own nature, not accomplished later by another. Thus, its validity is inherent. And the statement of a trustworthy person cannot be ascertained, because bondage etc. are not its objects. But invalidity depends on being composed by a faulty person, thus it is extrinsic.

original: tathā sarvapramāṇānāmapi prāmāṇye na parāpekṣitā sambhavati / svakāraṇebhyo 'rthāvabodhasvarūpāṇāmutpatteḥ / yadi cāvidyamānamarthaparicchedakatvaṃ pariniṣpanne vijñāne kārakāntarādutpadyate / pratipadyemahi parataḥ prāmāṇyam / na caitadastītyāha /
analyzed: tathā sarva pramāṇānām api prāmāṇye na para apekṣi tā sambhavati sva kāraṇebhyaḥ rtha avabodha svarūpāṇām utpatteḥ  yadi ca avidyamānam artha paricchedaka tvam pariniṣpanne vijñāne kāraka antarāt utpadyate pratipadyemahi paratas prāmāṇyam na ca etat asti iti āha
translated: Similarly, in the validity of all means of knowledge also, dependence on another is not possible, because they arise from their own causes in the form of the cognition of objects. And if the non-existent power to distinguish objects arises in the fully accomplished cognition from another cause, we would accept validity as extrinsic. But this is not so, he says.

original: svataḥ sarvapramāṇānāṃ prāmāṇyamiti gṛhyatām /
analyzed: svatas sarva pramāṇānām prāmāṇyam iti gṛhyatām
translated: Let it be accepted that all means of knowledge have inherent validity.

original: na hi svato 'satī śaktiḥ kartumanyena śakyate // ślo / vā / /
analyzed: na hi svatas satī śaktiḥ kartum anyena śakyate    vā
translated: For a power that does not exist inherently cannot be produced by another.

original: na ca jñānasyārthaparicchedakatvaṃ kāraṇaguṇapūrvakam / indriyeṣu tadabhāvāt tadāha /
analyzed: na ca jñānasya artha paricchedaka tvam kāraṇa guṇa pūrvakam indriyeṣu tad abhāvāt tat āha
translated: And the knowledge of an object is not preceded by the quality of the cause, because it is absent in the sense organs. He says this.

original: vyāpāraḥ kārakāṇāṃ hi dṛṣṭo janmātirekataḥ /
analyzed: vyāpāraḥ kārakāṇām hi dṛṣṭaḥ janma atirekataḥ
translated: The operation of the causal factors is seen to be distinct from the production.

original: pramāṇe 'pi tathā mā bhūditi janma vivakṣyate // ślo / vā / pṛ /
analyzed: pramāṇe tathā mā bhūt iti janma vivakṣyate
translated: In the case of a means of knowledge also, let it not be so. Therefore, the production is intended.

original: yathā hīndriyāṇāṃ janmavyatirekeṇāparo vyāpāro naivaṃ jñānasya / anantarameva phalasampādakatvāt / dṛṣṭañca pareṇāpi viśeṣaṇādijñānasya viśeṣyādijñānajanmani prāmāṇyamiti / athopajātamapi jñānaṃ na kārakapariśuddherbodhaṃ vinā arthaparicchedakatvabhāk / tarhi tatrāpi kārakapariśuddhigrahaṇaṃ vācyamityanavasthā / tadāha /
analyzed: yathā hi indriyāṇām janma vyatirekeṇa aparaḥ vyāpāraḥ na evam jñānasya anantaram eva phala sampādaka tvāt  dṛṣṭam ca pareṇa api viśeṣaṇa ādi jñānasya viśeṣya ādi jñāna janmani prāmāṇyam iti atha upajātam api jñānam na kāraka pariśuddheḥ bodham vinā artha paricchedaka tva bhāj tarhi tatra api kāraka pariśuddhi grahaṇam vācyam iti anavasthā tat āha
translated: Just as the sense organs have no other operation apart from production, so also knowledge does not. Because it produces the result immediately. And the other party also admits the validity of the knowledge of the qualified, etc. in the production of the knowledge of the qualifier, etc. Now, even if the knowledge is produced, it cannot be a distinguisher of the object without the apprehension of the purity of the causal factors. Then, in that case also, the apprehension of the purity of the causal factors should be stated. Thus there is an infinite regress. He says this.

original: jāte 'pi yadi vijñāne tāvannārtho 'vadhāryate /
analyzed: jāte yadi vijñāne tāvat na arthaḥ vadhāryate
translated: Even if the knowledge is produced, as long as the object is not ascertained,

original: yāvat kāraṇaśuddhatvaṃ na pramāṇāntarāgatam // ślo / vā / pṛ /
analyzed: yāvat kāraṇa śuddha tvam na pramāṇa antara āgatam
translated: as long as the purity of the causal factors is not obtained from another means of knowledge.

original: tatra jñānāntarotpādaḥ pratīkṣyaḥ kāraṇāntarāt /
analyzed: tatra jñāna antara utpādaḥ pratīkṣyaḥ kāraṇa antarāt
translated: In that case, the production of another knowledge is awaited from another causal factor.

original: yāvaddhi na paricchinnā śuddhistāvadasat samā // ślo / vā / pṛ /
analyzed: yāvat hi na paricchinnā śuddhiḥ tāvat asat samā
translated: As long as purity is not ascertained, so long is it not a valid means of knowledge.

original: tasyāpi kāraṇe śuddhe tajjñānasya pramāṇatā /
analyzed: tasya api kāraṇe śuddhe tad jñānasya pramāṇa tā
translated: Even in that case, when the cause is pure, the knowledge of that is a valid means of knowledge.

original: tasyāpyevamitītthañca na kaścid vyavatiṣṭhate // ślo / vā / pṛ /
analyzed: tasya api evam iti ittham ca na kaścid vyavatiṣṭhate
translated: Even in that case, it is like this, and thus nothing is established.

original: atha vidyamānamapi pramāṇasya prāmāṇyaṃ na pramāṇāntarasaṃvādaṃ vinā pramāṇavyavahārakāraṇam / tarhi pramāṇaparamparāyāmapakṣīṇaśaktervivakṣitajñāne pramāṇavyavahāro na syāt / tadāha /
analyzed: atha vidyamānam api pramāṇasya prāmāṇyam na pramāṇa antara saṃvādam vinā pramāṇa vyavahāra kāraṇam tarhi pramāṇa paramparāyām apakṣīṇa śakteḥ vivakṣita jñāne pramāṇa vyavahāraḥ na syāt tat āha
translated: If, even when existing, the validity of a means of knowledge is not the cause of the usage of a means of knowledge without the agreement of another means of knowledge, then in the case of a series of means of knowledge, the usage of a means of knowledge with regard to the intended knowledge would not be due to the exhausted power. He says this.

original: sammatyā yadi ceṣyeta pūrvapūrvapramāṇatā /
analyzed: sammatyā yadi ca iṣyeta pūrva pūrva pramāṇa tā
translated: If it were accepted by agreement that the validity of the preceding means of knowledge is due to the subsequent means of knowledge,

original: pramāṇāntaramicchanto na vyavasthāṃ labhemahi // ślo / vā / pṛ / 🔽yadi ca kasyacit svata eva prāmāṇyamiṣyeta param / ādyasyaivāstu ityāha
analyzed: pramāṇa antaram icchantaḥ na vyavasthām labhemahi  yadi ca kasyacid svatas eva prāmāṇyam iṣyeta param ādyasya eva astu iti āha
translated: we would not obtain a settled conclusion if we desired another means of knowledge.🔽And if the validity of some means of knowledge is accepted as being due to itself, then let it be so for the first one alone. He says

original: kasyacittu yadīṣyeta svata eva pramāṇatā /
analyzed: kasyacid tu yadi iṣyeta svatas eva pramāṇa tā
translated: But if the validity of some means of knowledge is accepted as being due to itself,

original: prathamasya tathābhāve pradveṣaḥ kiṃ nibandhanaḥ // ślo / vā / pṛ /
analyzed: prathamasya tathā abhāve pradveṣaḥ kim nibandhanaḥ
translated: then what is the basis for the aversion to the first one being like that?

original: prathamottarayoḥ parasparāpekṣaṃ prāmāṇyamityabhyupagame cetaretarāśrayatvaṃ syāt / ataḥ svata eva prāmāṇyam aprāmāṇyantu parataḥ / tathāhi / laukikānāmeva śabdānāmaprāmāṇyam / puruṣadoṣānupraveśāt / vaidikānāntu tadabhāvādaprāmāṇyaśaṅkaiva nāstīti /
analyzed: prathama uttarayoḥ paraspara apekṣam prāmāṇyam iti abhyupagame ca itaretarāśraya tvam syāt atas svatas eva prāmāṇyam aprāmāṇyam tu paratas tathā hi laukikānām eva śabdānām aprāmāṇyam puruṣa doṣa anupraveśāt vaidikānām tu tad abhāvāt aprāmāṇya śaṅkā eva na asti iti
translated: And if it is admitted that the validity of the first and the subsequent cognitions is mutual, there would be mutual dependence. Therefore, validity is intrinsic, while invalidity is extrinsic. Thus, only worldly words are invalid, because they are influenced by human faults. But Vedic words are free from that, so there is no doubt of their invalidity at all.

original: athendriyāṇāṃ kācakāmalādidoṣavaśādaprāmāṇyaṃ na svarūpataḥ / tathāhi / kācakāmalādidoṣasadbhāve sati mithyājñānajanakatvaṃ na tadabhāva iti /
analyzed: atha indriyāṇām kāca kāmalā ādi doṣa vaśāt aprāmāṇyam na svarūpataḥ tathā hi kāca kāmalā ādi doṣa sadbhāve sati mithyājñāna janaka tvam na tad abhāve iti
translated: Now, the invalidity of the senses is due to faults like cataract and jaundice, not to their intrinsic nature. Thus, when there is the presence of faults like cataract and jaundice, they produce false knowledge, not when they are absent.

original: jñaptau cāvabodhakatvena mithyāmaterautsargikamānatvaṃ na nivṛttamiti bādhakapratyayānmithyātvāvagatau vyāvartate / na cāsmatpakṣe śuktikājñānenāpi aśuktikājñānasya bādhāyāmanavasthā / kārakaśuddhigrahaṇaparamparā veti vācyam / avabodhakatvenautsargikasya pramāṇatvasya doṣa /ādarśanamātreṇaivāva /ānavasthānāt / tadāha /
analyzed: jñaptau ca avabodhaka tvena mithyāmateḥ autsargika mānatvam na nivṛttam iti bādhaka pratyayāt mithyātva avagatau vyāvartate na ca asmad pakṣe śuktikā jñānena api a śuktikā jñānasya bādhāyām anavasthā kāraka śuddhi grahaṇa paramparā vā iti vācyam avabodhaka tvena autsargikasya pramāṇa tvasya doṣa ādarśana mātreṇa eva tat āha
translated: And in the case of cognition, the natural validity of false cognition as an illuminator is not removed, so it is excluded in the understanding of falsity by a contradictory cognition. And in our view, even by the cognition of a shell, when there is contradiction of the cognition of a non-shell, there is no infinite regress. Nor should it be said that there is a series of grasping the purity of the cause. Because the natural validity as an illuminator is removed merely by the presentation of a fault. He says that:

original: yadā svataḥ pramāṇatvaṃ tadānyaṃ naiva mṛgyate /
analyzed: yadā svatas pramāṇa tvam tadā anyam nā eva mṛgyate
translated: When there is natural validity, then another is not sought at all.

original: nivartate ca mithyātvaṃ doṣajñānādayatnataḥ // ślo / vā / pṛ /
analyzed: nivartate ca mithyātvam doṣa jñānāt ayatnataḥ
translated: And falsity is removed effortlessly by the knowledge of faults.

original: doṣajñāne tvanutpanne nāśaṅkā niṣpramāṇikā /
analyzed: doṣa jñāne tu anutpanne nā āśaṅkā niṣpramāṇikā
translated: But when the knowledge of faults has not arisen, the doubt is baseless.

original: evaṃ tricaturajñānajanmano nādhikā matiḥ // ślo / vā / pṛ /
analyzed: evam tri catur ajñāna janmanaḥ na adhikā matiḥ
translated: Thus, the cognition arising from three or four cognitions is not excessive.

original: ityanavasthāparihāraḥ /
analyzed: iti anavasthā parihāraḥ
translated: Thus, the avoidance of infinite regress.

original: tadetat sarvamaviditārtham / sarvapramāṇānāmutpattau jñaptau ca parāpekṣitopalabdheḥ / tathāhi āptoktatvamapekṣamāṇaḥ śabdo 'rthe samyag jñānamupajanayati / na tadantareṇeti dṛṣṭam / yacca bahūnāmanyonyāśrayatvamuktam / tanna yuktam / āptoktatvasyāgṛhyamāṇasyaiva śabdasahakāritvābhyupagamāt / arthaprāptau ca pramāṇāntareṇa paścāt tadgrahaṇamiṣyata eva / tathāhi / laukikaśabdānāmarthaprāptyāptoktatvaṃ niścīyate / pratyakṣeṇāpi gṛhyata ityanye / tathā ca śrotravyāpārād vākyaśravaṇe sati cāṇakyoktaṃ kālidāsoktañcaitadityabādhyamānaḥ pratyayo dṛṣṭaḥ / vadikavākyānāntu pradhānārtheṣu avisaṃvādādāptoktatvaniścayaḥ /
analyzed: tat etat sarvam avidita artham sarva pramāṇānām utpattau jñaptau ca para apekṣita upalabdheḥ  / tathā hi āpta ukta tvam apekṣamāṇaḥ śabdaḥ rthe samyak jñānam upajanayati na tat antareṇa iti dṛṣṭam yat ca bahūnām anyonya āśraya tvam uktam tat na yuktam āpta ukta tvasya agṛhyamāṇasya eva śabda sahakāri tva abhyupagamāt artha prāptau ca pramāṇa antareṇa paścāt tad grahaṇam iṣyate eva tathā hi laukika śabdānām artha prāptyā āpta ukta tvam niścīy
translated: All this is unknown. Because in the origination and cognition of all means of knowledge, dependence on something else is observed. Thus, it is seen that sound, depending on being uttered by a trustworthy person, generates correct knowledge of the meaning, not without that. And what was said about mutual dependence of many, that is not proper. Because the fact of being uttered by a trustworthy person, which is not grasped, is accepted as assisting sound. And after the meaning is obtained by another means of knowledge, its grasping is accepted later. Thus, the fact of being uttered by a trustworthy person is ascertained by the attainment of the meaning of ordinary words. Others say it is also grasped by perception. And thus, when there is hearing of a sentence due to the operation of the auditory organ, the unquestioned cognition this is spoken by Cāṇakya and this is spoken by Kālidāsa is seen. But in the primary meanings of the words of a speaker, the ascertainment of being uttered by a trustworthy person is due to non-contradiction.

original: yadi pauruṣeye vacasi dvaividhyopalabdhervede 'pi puruṣānupraveśe 'prāmāṇyaśaṅkā syāditi dūṣaṇam / tanna / tatkarturdoṣābhāvāt / tathāhi / yasya rāgādidoṣo 'sti / II / tadvacanamevāpramāṇamityupalabdham / vedakartuśca tatsadbhāve pramāṇābhāvaḥ / sākṣādatīndriyārthadraṣṭā puruṣaḥ sambhavatītyuktamadhastāt / ataḥ tadvacanādāmnāyasya vedarāśeḥ / prāmāṇyam iti sūtrakāreṇoktam /
analyzed: yadi pauruṣeye vacasi dvaividhya upalabdheḥ vede pi puruṣa anupraveśe prāmāṇya śaṅkā syāt iti dūṣaṇam tat na tad kartuḥ doṣa abhāvāt tathā hi yasya rāga ādi doṣaḥ sti tad vacanam eva apramāṇam iti upalabdham veda kartuḥ ca tad sadbhāve pramāṇa abhāvaḥ sākṣāt atīndriya artha draṣṭā puruṣaḥ sambhavati iti uktam adhastāt  atas tad vacanāt āmnāyasya vedarāśeḥ prāmāṇyam iti sūtrakāreṇa uktam  /
translated: If it is argued that since two kinds of statements by human beings are observed, there would be doubt about the validity of the Veda also if a human being were involved, that is not a fault. Because there is no fault in the author of that [Veda]. It is observed that the statement of one who has faults like attachment is not a valid means of knowledge. And there is no evidence for the existence of those [faults] in the author of the Veda. It has been said below that a person who directly perceives imperceptible objects is possible. Therefore, the author of the aphorisms has said that the validity of the Veda, the body of injunctions, is due to the statement of that [person].

original: atha śabdasyānityatve satyāptoktatvena prāmāṇyaṃ syāt / tattu nāstītyāśaṅkyāha liṅgāccānityaḥ śabdaḥ vai / sū / iti / paraṃ pratyakṣeṇoccāraṇāt prāg ūrdhvañcānupalambhādanityaḥ śabda iti pratīyate / liṅgācceti / tattu vakṣyāmaḥ śabdaparīkṣāyām / vedānāñcānityatve 'numānam / anityāni vedavākyāni vākyatvādubhayābhimatavākyavat / tathā buddhipūrvā vākyakṛtiḥ vākyaracanā / vede buddhirpūrvāvākyaracanātvād ubhayābhimatavākyaracanāvat / yaccedaṃ vedaracanāyāḥ sarvadā anyathātvopalambhāditi vaidhamyeṇa pratyavasthānam / tat sarvānumāneṣu samānamiti / evaṃ vede / buddhipūrvo dadātiḥ vede buddhipūrvo dadātiśabdaḥ dadātītyuktatvād ubhayābhimatadadātītiśabdavat /
analyzed: atha śabdasya anitya tve sati āpta ukta tvena prāmāṇyam syāt tat tu na asti iti āśaṅkya āha liṅgāt ca anityaḥ śabdaḥ vai iti param pratyakṣeṇa uccāraṇāt prāk ūrdhvam ca anupalambhāt anityaḥ śabdaḥ iti pratīyate liṅgāt ca iti tat tu vakṣyāmaḥ śabda parīkṣāyām vedānām ca anitya tve numānam anityāni veda vākyāni vākya tvāt ubhaya abhimata vākya vat tathā buddhi pūrvā vākya kṛtiḥ vākya racanā vede buddhiḥ pūrvā vākya racanā tvāt ubhay
translated: Now, if sound were impermanent, it could be authoritative by being spoken by a trustworthy person. But that is not so, fearing this, he says: And from inference, sound is impermanent. The opponent understands that sound is impermanent because it is not perceived before and after its utterance by direct perception. And from inference, we will explain that in the examination of sound. And the inference of the impermanence of the Vedas: The Vedic statements are impermanent, because they are statements, like the statements accepted by both parties. Similarly, the composition of statements is preceded by intelligence. In the Veda, the composition of statements is preceded by intelligence, because it is a composition of statements, like the composition of statements accepted by both parties. And this objection by way of dissimilarity, that the composition of the Veda is always perceived to be otherwise, is the same in all inferences. Thus, in the Veda, the word dadāti is preceded by intelligence, because it is said dadāti, like the word dadāti accepted by both parties.

original: yā ceyaṃ puruṣānupraveśe satyaprāmāṇyaśaṅkā / sā nityatve 'pi na nivartate / śrotuḥ puruṣasya tatrāpyanupraveśāt / tadvaiguṇyena cāprāmāṇyopalabdheḥ / tathāhi / śroturapratibhādermithyājñānotpattau kāraṇatvaṃ tadabhāvaśca samyag jñānotpattāvityupalabdhameva / na ca nityatvaṃ vedānām ekāntena prāmāṇyahetuḥ / tadbhāve 'pi śrotrāntaḥkaraṇayoḥ pratipattṛdoṣānupraveśena kvacidaprāmāṇyāt /
analyzed: yā ca iyam puruṣa anupraveśe satya prāmāṇya śaṅkā sā nitya tve pi na nivartate śrotuḥ puruṣasya tatra api anupraveśāt tad vaiguṇyena ca aprāmāṇya upalabdheḥ tathā hi śrotuḥ apratibhā ādeḥ mithyājñāna utpattau kāraṇa tvam tad abhāvaḥ ca samyak jñāna utpattau iti upalabdham eva na ca nitya tvam vedānām ekāntena prāmāṇya hetuḥ tad bhāve pi śrotra antaḥkaraṇayoḥ pratipattṛ doṣa anupraveśena kvacid aprāmāṇyāt
translated: And this doubt of invalidity when there is the intrusion of a person, does not cease even in the case of eternality, because the hearer, the person, enters there also, and because invalidity is found due to the defects of that (person). For thus, the incapacity of the hearer etc. is found to be the cause of the origin of false knowledge, and its absence is found to be the cause of the origin of true knowledge. And eternality of the Vedas is not the sole cause of validity, because even when that is present, there is sometimes invalidity due to the intrusion of the defects of the hearer and the internal organ.

original: svābhidhāśaktibalenaiva śabdasya prāmāṇyamityabhyupagame ca aṅgulyagre kariṇastiṣṭhantītyevamāderaprāmāṇyaṃ na syāt / athānāptapraṇītatvena visaṃvādādaprāmāṇyameṣām / tarhi yadāptapraṇītam / tadeva pramāṇamiti prāptam / yathā hi puruṣagatasya rāgāderaprāmāṇye 'nvayavyatirekābhyāṃ vyāpārastathā tadguṇādeḥ prāmāṇye 'pītyubhayaṃ parataḥ /
analyzed: sva abhidhā śakti balena eva śabdasya prāmāṇyam iti abhyupagame ca aṅguli agre kariṇaḥ tiṣṭhanti iti evamādeḥ aprāmāṇyam na syāt atha anāpta praṇīta tvena visaṃvādāt aprāmāṇyam eṣām tarhi yat āpta praṇītam tat eva pramāṇam iti prāptam yathā hi puruṣa gatasya rāga ādeḥ aprāmāṇye nvaya vyatirekābhyām vyāpāraḥ tathā tad guṇa ādeḥ prāmāṇye pi iti ubhayam paratas
translated: And if it is accepted that the validity of a word is due to the power of its own denotative capacity, then such statements as an elephant stands on the tip of the finger would not be invalid. If it is argued that they are invalid because they are contradicted, then it follows that only that which is composed by a reliable person is valid. For just as the presence or absence of passion etc. in a person is ascertained through positive and negative concomitance in determining invalidity, similarly the presence or absence of his qualities etc. is ascertained in determining validity. Thus both are extrinsic.

original: abhidhānasya ca varṇatvā /ānupūrvīsaṅketavyatirekeṇa atīndriyā śaktirna vidyate / tasyāḥ pūrvameva pratiṣedhāt / varṇatvādisadbhāve ca kāryakaraṇāt / sa ca parata eva pratiniyatajātisambandhasyādṛṣṭakāryatvāt / saṅketasyāpyanyat kāraṇamuktamiti /
analyzed: abhidhānasya ca varṇa tva ānupūrvī saṅketa vyatirekeṇa atīndriyā śaktiḥ na vidyate tasyāḥ pūrvam eva pratiṣedhāt varṇa tva ādi sadbhāve ca kārya karaṇāt sa ca paratas eva pratiniyata jāti sambandhasya adṛṣṭa kārya tvāt saṅketasya api anyat kāraṇam uktam iti
translated: And the denotation has no imperceptible power apart from the order of letters and convention, because that has already been refuted earlier. And the existence of the nature of being a letter etc. is due to the effect of the instrument. And that is also extrinsic, because the relation with a particular universal is an unseen effect. And the cause of convention has been stated to be something else.

original: yattu sākṣāddarśanādiḥ puruṣasya rāgādivināśe vyāpriyate na jñānotpattāvityuktam / tadasat / samyagjñānotpattāvanvayavyatirekopapatteḥ / yathārthadraṣṭā tacchiṣyāṇāmupadeṣṭā ceti samuditamāptalakṣaṇaṃ yathārthopadeśe hetustadantareṇānupadeśāt / yadi cānvayavyatirekavato 'pi yathārthadarśitvāde rāgādivināśa eva vyāpāraḥ / tarhi rāgāderapyetadvināśakatvamevetyubhayaṃ parataḥ syāt / tasmād rāgderaprāmāṇyotpattāviva yathārthopalambhāderapi samyagjñānotpattau vyāpāro 'bhyupagantavyaḥ /
analyzed: yat tu sākṣāt darśana ādiḥ puruṣasya rāga ādi vināśe vyāpriyate na jñāna utpattau iti uktam tat asat samyak jñāna utpattau anvaya vyatireka upapatteḥ yathārtha draṣṭā tad śiṣyāṇām upadeṣṭā ca iti samuditam āpta lakṣaṇam yathārtha upadeśe hetuḥ tad antareṇa anupadeśāt yadi ca anvaya vyatirekavataḥ pi yathārtha darśi tva ādeḥ rāga ādi vināśaḥ eva vyāpāraḥ tarhi rāga ādeḥ api etad vināśaka tvam eva iti ubhayam paratas syāt tasmāt rā
translated: As for the argument that the man’s direct perception and the rest operate towards the destruction of Love, etc., and not towards the bringing about of the Cognition, that is not right; because, in the matter of the appearance of the right cognition, there is found to be the relation of ‘pervasion’ and ‘pervaded’, For instance, the man who has the right knowledge is the teacher of his pupils; and the combination of these two, right knowledge and teaching, is the cause of the right cognition; as there is no teaching without the right knowledge. If, even though there is the relation of ‘pervasion and pervaded’, the man with right knowledge were to operate only towards the destruction of Love, etc., then Love, etc. also would operate only towards the destruction of the said knowledge. Thus both would be dependent upon something else. Hence, just as the appearance of the wrong cognition is due to the presence of Love, etc., so also the appearance of the right cognition must be due to the presence of the right knowledge and teaching. The following might be urged: “The man with right knowledge may be the teacher of his pupils; but how could the right knowledge be the cause of the right cognition? because it is not invariably concomitant with it; for instance, even though Devadatta has seen the cow, he does not remember it always; and even when he does remember it, he does not always speak of it; and even when he does speak of it, he does not always make the right assertion.” This is not right. Because, in the case of Devadatta, the memory of the cow is not invariably concomitant with the seeing of the cow; because he is devoid of the right knowledge of the connection between the two. In the case of the man with right knowledge, on the other hand, the memory of the cow is invariably concomitant with the seeing of the cow; because he has the right knowledge of the connection between the two. Thus the invariable concomitance being there, why is it that the memory does not appear? It is because the man does not wish to remember it. Translation: यत्तु साक्षाद्दर्शनादिः पुरुषस्य रागादिविनाशे व्याप्रियते न ज्ञानोत्पत्तावित्युक्तम्, तदसत्; सम्यग्ज्ञानोत्पत्तावन्वयव्यतिरेकोपपत्तेः । यथार्थदर्शी तच्छिष्याण

original: tathendriyāṇāmapi kācakāmalādidoṣasadbhāve 'pi / mithyājñānameva tadbhāve samyagjñānajananādubhayaṃ parataḥ / pareṇāpyabhāvasya kāraṇatvamanekadheṣṭam / yathā sadupalambhakapramāṇapañcakavyāvṛttermānasajñānotpattau pakṣadharmatādyanyatamāpāye ca liṅgasya mithyājñānotpattāvityādi / atha kācakāmalāderdoṣasya mithyājñānotpattau kāraṇatopalabdheḥ / tadabhāve tasyaivānupalabdhirna samyagjñānamiti cet / na / anvayavyatirekavato 'kāraṇatve 'tiprasaṅgāt yadi /tathā ca doṣābhāve 'nvayavyatirekavānapi na samyagjñānotpattau kāraṇaṃ / tatsadbhāve 'pi na mithyājñānotpattāvityubhayaṃ svataḥ syāt / sargaścendriyāṇāmubhayarūpasya kāryasyopalabdherubhayārthamiti jñāyeta /
analyzed: tathā indriyāṇām api kāca kāmalā ādi doṣa sadbhāve pi mithyājñānam eva tad bhāve samyagjñāna jananāt ubhayam paratas pareṇa api abhāvasya kāraṇa tvam anekadhā iṣṭam yathā sat upalambhaka pramāṇa pañcaka vyāvṛtteḥ mānasa jñāna utpattau pakṣa dharmatā ādi anyatama apāye ca liṅgasya mithyājñāna utpattau ityādi  atha kāca kāmalā ādeḥ doṣasya mithyājñāna utpattau kāraṇatā upalabdheḥ tad abhāve tasya eva anupalabdhiḥ na samyagjñānam iti
translated: Similarly, even when defects like eye disease and jaundice are present in the senses, that is false knowledge. When they are present, the production of correct knowledge is both due to something else. The non-existence of something else is accepted in many ways as a cause, such as in the production of mental knowledge when there is an absence of the five means of valid knowledge that perceive existence, and in the production of false knowledge when one of the conditions such as the property of the subject is absent, and so on. If it is argued that since the cause of the production of false knowledge is perceived in the case of defects like eye disease and jaundice, and in their absence, there is only the non-perception of that, not correct knowledge, it is not so. Because if something that has concomitance and non-concomitance is not a cause, there would be an overextension. If it were so, even something with concomitance and non-concomitance would not be a cause in the production of correct knowledge, and even when it is present, it would not be a cause in the production of false knowledge. Thus both would be due to itself. And since the production of both kinds of effects is perceived in the case of the senses, it would be understood that they serve both purposes.

original: nanu doṣasadbhāve sati indriyaṃ mithyājñānaṃ janayati / tadabhāve ca samyag jñānamityabhyupagamād ubhayābhāve ca ubhayavikalaṃ vijñānaṃ kuryādityetadacodyam / ubhayavikalasyendriyasyāsambhavāt / yathā hi pūrvamasatāṃ doṣāṇāmutpattirūrdhvañca pradhvaṃsa iti nāstyubhayavikalamindriyam / na cobhayaviśeṣavikalaṃ jñānatvasāmānyaṃ sambhavati / sāmānyavato viśeṣayogāt / yathā gotvasāmānyādhārasya śāvaleyādiviśeṣa iti /
analyzed: nanu doṣa sadbhāve sati indriyam mithyājñānam janayati tad abhāve ca samyak jñānam iti abhyupagamāt ubhaya abhāve ca ubhaya vikalam vijñānam kuryāt iti etat acodyam ubhaya vikalasya indriyasya asambhavāt yathā hi pūrvam asatām doṣāṇām utpattiḥ ūrdhvam ca pradhvaṃsaḥ iti na asti ubhaya vikalam indriyam na ca ubhaya viśeṣa vikalam jñāna tva sāmānyam sambhavati sāmānyavataḥ viśeṣa yogāt yathā go tva sāmānya ādhārasya śāvaleya ādi viśeṣaḥ iti
translated: “When the defects are present, the sense-organ produces wrong cognition; and when they are absent, it produces right cognition; so that when neither is present, it would produce a cognition which is devoid of both; and this would be a third kind of cognition”. This is not possible; because the sense-organ devoid of both is an impossibility. Just as the defects, being non-entities, cannot come into existence after having been non-existent, and cannot also become destroyed after having come into existence, so also the sense-organ cannot be devoid of both. Nor is it possible for the mere ‘cognition’ to be devoid of both; because the Universal can never be devoid of what is concomitant with it; just as the particular cow, ‘Śāvaleya’ for instance, is never devoid of the Universal ‘Cow’.

original: yaccedaṃ na kāraṇaguṇapūrvakaṃ paricchedakatvaṃ tadiṣyata eva / anubhavajñānasyendriyādutpannasyārthaparicchittirūpatvāt / tajjanakañcendriyādikārakaṃ kārakāntarāpekṣañceti parataḥ prāmāṇyam / kārakasāmagryantu na paścādabhāvinimittamapekṣata iti / tadapekṣayā tūbhayaṃ svata iti na mithyājñānaṃ parataḥ syāt /
analyzed: yat ca idam na kāraṇa guṇa pūrvakam paricchedaka tvam tat iṣyate eva anubhava jñānasya indriyāt utpannasya artha paricchitti rūpa tvāt tad janakam ca indriya ādi kārakam kāraka antara apekṣat ca iti paratas prāmāṇyam kāraka sāmagryan tu na paścāt abhāvi nimittam apekṣate iti tad apekṣayā tu ubhayam svatas iti na mithyājñānam paratas syāt
translated: And this limiting adjunctship which is not preceded by the qualities of the cause is indeed accepted, because the cognition of experience has the form of the determination of the object, arising from the sense organ. And the cause such as the sense organ that produces it requires another cause, so the validity is extrinsic. But the totality of causes does not require a subsequent non-existent cause, so in relation to that, both are intrinsic. Thus false cognition would not be extrinsic.

original: atha jñātṛvyāpāro jñānaṃ tacca arthaparicchede 'napekṣamiti svataḥ / tanmithyājñāne 'pi samānam / atha mithyājñānaṃ doṣamapekṣate / tarhi samyag jñānamapi tadabhāvādyapekṣata iti / na ca jñātṛvyāpāraḥ sambhāvyate / arthapratipatteranyathābhāvāt / tathā hi sarvaṃ kārakaṃ caramasahakārisadbhāve sati kāryaṃ karotīti na tasmādanyo vyāpāraḥ / sadbhāve 'pi nityatāyāṃ sarvakāryotpattiprasaṅgastasyānapekṣakāraṇatvābhyupagamāt / anityatve tu tadutpattāvapi nirvyāpārasya kāraṇatvāyogādanyo vyāpārastadutpattāvapyanya ityanavasthā syāt / caramasahakārirūpe tu vyāpāre nāyaṃ doṣastatsadbhāve kāryakaraṇaṃ na tadabhāva iti /
analyzed: atha jñātṛ vyāpāraḥ jñānam tat ca artha paricchede napekṣam iti svatas tat mithyājñāne samānam  atha mithyājñānam doṣam apekṣate tarhi samyak jñānam api tad abhāva ādi apekṣate iti na ca jñātṛ vyāpāraḥ sambhāvyate artha pratipatteḥ anyathābhāvāt tathā hi sarvam kārakam carama sahakāri sadbhāve sati kāryam karoti iti na tasmāt anyaḥ vyāpāraḥ sadbhāve pi nitya tāyām sarva kārya utpatti prasaṅgaḥ tasya anapekṣa kāraṇa tva abhyupagamāt anitya
translated: If, on the other hand, knowledge is the operation of the knower, and that is independent in the determination of the object, then it is self-evident. That is the same even in false knowledge. If, on the other hand, false knowledge depends on a fault, then correct knowledge also depends on the absence of that. And the operation of the knower is not possible, because the cognition of the object is otherwise. Thus, all the instruments of action produce the effect only when the final auxiliary is present, so the operation is not different from that. Even in the case of existence, there is the contingence of the production of all effects, because it is accepted that it is a cause independent of others. But if it is non-eternal, then even in its production, it is not proper for a cause to be without operation. So another operation would be for its production, and even in that there would be an infinite regress.
