But in the case of the final auxiliary operation, this fault does not arise, because the effect is produced when it is present, not when it is absent.

original: yaccedaṃ kārakaśuddhergrahaṇāpekṣitāyāṃ dūṣaṇam / tadapāstam / anabhyupagame neti / atha pramāṇasya prāmāṇyaṃ vinaiva pramāṇaṃ vijñāyata iti / tadasat / sarvasya prameyasya pramāṇaparicchedyatvopalabdheḥ / tathā ca prāmāṇyaṃ pramāṇaparicchedyaṃ prameyatvād ghaṭādivat / na cānavasthā / sarvatrāvaśyaṃ prāmāṇyagrahaṇānabhyupagamāt / yatra hi jñānodaye sati kimidaṃ samyaṅmithyā veti saṃśayotpattistatraiva pramāṇāntarāpekṣā / arthaprāptiparyantavyavahārasambhave vā apekṣāvinivṛtternānavasthādidoṣaḥ /
analyzed: yat ca idam kāraka śuddheḥ grahaṇa apekṣitāyām dūṣaṇam tat apāstam anabhyupagame na iti  / atha pramāṇasya prāmāṇyam vinā eva pramāṇam vijñāyate iti tat asat sarvasya prameyasya pramāṇa paricchedya tva upalabdheḥ tathā ca prāmāṇyam pramāṇa paricchedyam prameya tvāt ghaṭa ādi vat na ca anavasthā sarvatra avaśyam prāmāṇya grahaṇa anabhyupagamāt yatra hi jñāna udaye sati kim idam samyak mithyā vā iti saṃśaya utpattiḥ tatra eva pramāṇa antara a
translated: And the objection that has been raised against the acceptance of the purity of the cause, is also set aside by the words ‘not being admitted’; if it be held that the validity of the cognition is apprehended without any means of cognition, that cannot be right; because all cognisable things are found to be apprehended by means of a means of cognition; and validity being a cognisable thing, it must be apprehended by a means of cognition; just like the jar and other things. Nor can there be an infinite regress; because it is not admitted that in every case, there is a suspicion regarding the validity (of the means of cognition). In a case where, on the appearance of the cognition, there arises the doubt as to whether it is right or wrong,—there alone can there be a need for another means of cognition; or when the activity of the man is dependent upon the apprehension of the object,—and when the said apprehension is not there, he would not undertake the activity; and in this case, there would be no infinite regress.

original: yadi ca jñānadharmatvāt prāmāṇyasya svasaṃvedyatvamiṣyeta / aprāmāṇyamapyevaṃ syāditi kathaṃ parataḥ / tathā mithyājñānotpāde na pravartate mithyātvasya pratipannatvāt / samyagjñānotpattau ca samyaktādhyavasāye kimidaṃ samyaṅ mithyā veti saṃśayādyabhāvaḥ /
analyzed: yadi ca jñāna dharma tvāt prāmāṇyasya sva saṃvedya tvam iṣyeta aprāmāṇyam api evam syāt iti katham paratas tathā mithyājñāna utpāde na pravartate mithyātvasya pratipanna tvāt samyak jñāna utpattau ca samyaktā adhyavasāye kim idam samyak mithyā vā iti saṃśaya ādi abhāvaḥ
translated: And if the validity of knowledge is held to be self-evident because it is a property of knowledge, then invalidity also would be so. How then can it be extrinsic? Similarly, in the production of false knowledge, one does not engage because falsity is recognized. And in the production of true knowledge, when truth is ascertained, there is no doubt as to whether this is true or false.

original: yaccedam avabodhakatvena pramāṇasya prāmāṇyaṃ doṣādarśanamātreṇaivāvatiṣṭhata ityuktam / tatra yadi doṣādarśanadoṣajñānānutpattirna tayā prāmāṇyaṃ jñāpyate / nāpi kriyata iti kathamaniścitasthiteravasthānavacanam / atha doṣadarśanasya bādhakapratyayasya mithyātvajñāpakatvamiva tadabhāvajñānasya prāmāṇyajñāpakatvamiṣyeta / tarhi tasyāpi prāmāṇyamanyasmād vijñāyata ityanavasthā syāt / atha jñānotpattau saṃśayaṃ vinā na sarvatra prāmāṇyagrahaṇāpekṣeti parihāraḥ / tarhi na svataḥ prāmāṇyam / utpattau jñaptau ca parāpekṣitvābhyupagamāt /
analyzed: yat ca idam avabodhaka tvena pramāṇasya prāmāṇyam doṣa adarśana mātreṇa eva avatiṣṭhate iti uktam tatra yadi doṣa adarśana doṣa jñāna anutpattiḥ na tayā prāmāṇyam jñāpyate na api kriyate iti katham aniścita sthiteḥ avasthāna vacanam atha doṣa darśanasya bādhaka pratyayasya mithyātva jñāpaka tvam iva tad abhāva jñānasya prāmāṇya jñāpaka tvam iṣyeta tarhi tasya api prāmāṇyam anyasmāt vijñāyate iti anavasthā syāt atha jñāna utpattau saṃśayam
translated: And as for what has been said that the validity of a proof is established by its being a source of knowledge, and rests on the mere non-perception of sublating (cognitions), if it be said that the non-perception of the non-perception of a sublating (cognition) does not make known the validity (of the proof), nor does it produce it, how can it be said that it remains (in force) when its position is not ascertained? But if it be held that the knowledge of the absence of a sublating (cognition), which makes known the falsity of the perception of a sublating (cognition), makes known the validity (of the proof), then there would be an infinite regress, since the validity of that (knowledge of the absence of a sublating cognition) would have to be known from another (source). But if the answer be that, in the production of knowledge, there is no need to ascertain the validity in every case, except in the case of doubt, then validity is not self-evident, because it is admitted that (the validity of a proof) depends on something else in its production and in its ascertainment.

original: atha indriyādikārakeṣu vidyamānaṃ samyaktvaṃ na kāraṇaguṇaprakrameṇa jñāneṣūtpadyata iti svataḥ / tadaprāmāṇye 'pi samānam / tatrāpi hi viparyayādirūpatā na indriyādiṣu vidyamānā jāyata iti /
analyzed: atha indriya ādi kārakeṣu vidyamānam samyaktvam na kāraṇa guṇa prakrameṇa jñāneṣu utpadyate iti svatas tad aprāmāṇye samānam tatra api hi viparyaya ādi rūpa tā na indriya ādiṣu vidyamānā jāyate iti
translated: Now, if the correctness that exists in the sense organs and other instruments of action does not arise in the cognitions by the method of the qualities of the cause, then it is self-evident. Even in their invalidity, it is the same, for there also the form of error etc. that exists in the sense organs etc. does not arise.

original: bodhātmakapramāṇāpekṣayā tu svataḥ prāmāṇyaṃ vivakṣitamityabhyupagamasya codanāyā vaktṛviśeṣāpekṣaṃ prāmāṇyamityabhyupagamenāvirodhād avivāda eva syāt / asya hi samarthanārtham anyapramāṇānāṃ parataḥ prāmāṇyopadarśanāt / na ca codanāyāḥ svataḥ prāmāṇyābhyupagame / codanājanitaṃ jñānaṃ pramāṇam / doṣavarjitaiḥ kārakairjanyamānatvāt / liṅgāt pratyakṣabuddhivaditi parīkṣārthaṃ prayāso ghaṭate / atha apareṣāṃ vyāmohavyāvartanadvāreṇa samyagjñānasampādanārthaṃ parīkṣāvākyam / tajjanitajñāne 'pi vyāmohe sati anyā parīkṣā syādityanavasthā / sā coktanyāyenaiva parihriyata iti kathaṃ na parataḥ pramāṇasya prāmāṇyamutpadyate jñāyate veti /
analyzed: bodha ātmaka pramāṇa apekṣayā tu svatas prāmāṇyam vivakṣitam iti abhyupagamasya codanāyāḥ vaktṛ viśeṣa apekṣam prāmāṇyam iti abhyupagamena avirodhāt avivādaḥ eva syāt asya hi samarthana artham anya pramāṇānām paratas prāmāṇya upadarśanāt na ca codanāyāḥ svatas prāmāṇya abhyupagame codanā janitam jñānam pramāṇam doṣa varjitaiḥ kārakaiḥ janyamāna tvāt liṅgāt pratyakṣa buddhi vat iti parīkṣā artham prayāsaḥ ghaṭate atha apareṣ
translated: But if it is admitted that the validity of the Veda is self-sufficient, in view of the fact that it is a form of valid cognition, then there would be no dispute, since this admission is not incompatible with the admission that the validity of the Veda is dependent on the speaker in the case of injunctions. For the purpose of establishing this, it is shown that the validity of other means of knowledge is dependent on something else. And when the validity of the Veda is admitted to be self-sufficient, the effort to examine it is made in order to show that the cognition produced by the Veda is a means of valid knowledge, because it is produced by persons free from defects, like the cognition produced by inference. If, on the other hand, the statement of examination is for the purpose of producing true knowledge by removing the delusion of others, then there would be an infinite regress, since there would be delusion even in the cognition produced by that [statement of examination], and another examination would be required. And that is avoided by the same reasoning as before. So how can the validity of a means of knowledge not arise or be known from something else?

original: śeṣañcātra dūṣaṇapratisamādhānam asmadgurubhirvistareṇābhihitamiti nehoktam / ataḥ śabdasyāptoktatvena prāmāṇyānnānumāne 'ntarbhāvaḥ /🔽atha śabdānāmarthena pratibandhābhāvād aprāmāṇyameva / tathā ca dṛśyavikalpyāvarthāvekīkṛtya tatsamāropeṇa śrotuḥ pravṛttinivṛttī ityuktam / yo 'yaṃ vikalpagata ākāraḥ / sa eva bāhyo 'rtha iti manyamānaḥ pratipattā pravartate / na bāhyārthapratipattau arthadarśane sati vivakṣākrameṇa / śabdotpattikāle 'rthasya kṣaṇikatvenātikrāntatvāt /
analyzed: śeṣam ca atra dūṣaṇa pratisamādhānam asmad gurubhiḥ vistareṇa abhihitam iti na iha uktam atas śabdasya āpta ukta tvena prāmāṇyāt na anumāne ntarbhāvaḥ  atha śabdānām arthena pratibandha abhāvāt aprāmāṇyam eva tathā ca dṛśya vikalpyau arthau ekīkṛtya tad samāropeṇa śrotuḥ pravṛtti nivṛttī iti uktam  yaḥ yam vikalpa gataḥ ākāraḥ saḥ eva bāhyaḥ rthaḥ iti manyamānaḥ pratipattā pravartate na bāhya artha pratipattau artha darśane sati vivakṣā krameṇa śabda utpatti kāle rthasya kṣaṇika tvena atikrānta tvāt
translated: And the rest of the refutation and reply here has been stated in detail by our teachers, so it is not stated here. Therefore, because verbal testimony is authoritative by being the statement of a trustworthy person, it is not included in inference.🔽Now, if verbal testimony is not authoritative because there is no relation between words and their meaning, and it is said that the seen and imagined objects are identified and the listener is engaged by superimposition of that, the listener engages thinking that this form in the conceptual cognition is itself the external object, not in the understanding of an external object, because when the word is produced, the object has passed away due to being momentary.

original: pratyakṣānumānaviṣayasyā /ātirikta /āviṣayābhāvācca / na śabdaḥ pramāṇāntaram / tathā hi svalakṣaṇaviṣayaṃ pratyakṣaṃ sāmānyaviṣayamanumānam / prameyadvaividhyāt pramāṇadvaividhyamiti kathaṃ śabdo 'rthāntaratve sati pramāṇam /
analyzed: pratyakṣa anumāna viṣayasya a atirikta a viṣaya abhāvāt ca na śabdaḥ pramāṇa antaram tathā hi sva lakṣaṇa viṣayam pratyakṣam sāmānya viṣayam anumānam prameya dvaividhyāt pramāṇa dvaividhyam iti katham śabdaḥ rtha antara tve sati pramāṇam
translated: And because the object of perception and inference is not a separate object, verbal testimony is not a separate means of knowledge. Thus, perception has as its object the particular, inference has as its object the universal. Since there are only two kinds of objects of knowledge, there are only two means of knowledge. How then can verbal testimony be a means of knowledge if it is a separate object?

original: yadi cendriyeṇa samānaviṣayaḥ śabdo bhavedandhānandhayoraviśeṣaḥ syāt / tadāha /
analyzed: yadi ca indriyeṇa samāna viṣayaḥ śabdaḥ bhavet andha anandhayoḥ aviśeṣaḥ syāt tat āha
translated: If sound were of the same object as the sense organ, there would be no difference between the blind and the non-blind. He says:

original: anyadevendriyagrāhyamanyaḥ śabdasya gocaraḥ /
analyzed: anyat eva indriya grāhyam anyaḥ śabdasya gocaraḥ
translated: The object grasped by the sense organ is indeed different, the domain of sound is different.

original: śabdāt pratyeti bhinnākṣo na tu pratyakṣamīkṣate //
analyzed: śabdāt pratyeti bhinna akṣaḥ na tu pratyakṣam īkṣate
translated: One with different eyes understands from sound, but does not perceive by direct perception.

original: anyadeva rūpādisvalakṣaṇamindriyagrāhyam / tasmādanyaḥ śabdasya gocaro 'II /pohaviṣaya iti gṛhyatām / yataḥ śabdāt pratyeti bhinnākṣaḥ pradhvastanayanaḥ / na tu pratyakṣaṃ yathā bhavati tathekṣate / samānaviṣayatve vā anandhasyevāndhasyāpi śabdādaparokṣaiva pratipattiḥ syāt / tathātve indriyāgnisambandhādivad dāhaśabdādapi dāhārthapratipattiḥ syādityāha /
analyzed: anyat eva rūpa ādi sva lakṣaṇam indriya grāhyam tasmāt anyaḥ śabdasya gocaraḥ iti gṛhyatām yatas śabdāt pratyeti bhinna akṣaḥ pradhvasta nayanaḥ na tu pratyakṣam yathā bhavati tathā īkṣate samāna viṣaya tve vā anandhasya iva andhasya api śabdāt aparokṣā eva pratipattiḥ syāt tathātve indriya agni sambandha ādi vat dāha śabdāt api dāha artha pratipattiḥ syāt iti āha
translated: The particular characteristic of form etc. is indeed different, grasped by the sense organ. From that, the domain of sound is different, the object of exclusion should be accepted. Because one with different eyes, whose eyes are destroyed, understands from sound. But it is not perceived as it is by direct perception. Or, if the object were the same, then even for the blind, like for the non-blind, there would be non-indirect understanding from sound. In that case, the understanding of the meaning of burning would be from the word 'burning' like from the connection with the fire of the sense organ. He says:

original: anyathaivāgnisambandhād dāhaṃ dagdho 'bhimanyate /
analyzed: anyathā eva agni sambandhāt dāham dagdhaḥ bhimanyate
translated: One who is burned thinks of burning in a different way from the connection with fire.

original: anyathā dāhaśabdena dāhārthaḥ sampratīyate //
analyzed: anyathā dāha śabdena dāha arthaḥ sampratīyate
translated: The meaning of burning is understood in a different way from the word 'burning'.

original: tasmānnendriyeṇa samānaviṣayatvaṃ śabdasya / tathā padādiśabdasya svalakṣaṇaviṣayatve tasya nirbhāgatayā śuklādiśabdānāmapi paryāyatā bhavet / apohaviṣayatve tu nāyaṃ doṣaḥ / vibhinnānāṃ samāropavyavacchedaparatvāditi /
analyzed: tasmāt na indriyeṇa samāna viṣaya tvam śabdasya tathā pada ādi śabdasya sva lakṣaṇa viṣaya tve tasya nirbhāga tayā śukla ādi śabdānām api paryāya tā bhavet apoha viṣaya tve tu na ayam doṣaḥ vibhinnānām samāropa vyavaccheda para tvāt iti
translated: Therefore, sound does not have the same object as the sense faculty. Similarly, if the word pada etc. has the particular as its object, then due to its being partless, even the words white etc. would be synonyms. But if it has the exclusion as its object, this fault does not arise, because it is meant to exclude superimposition on different things.

original: vāstavārthaviṣayatve ca śabdānāṃ puruṣecchāvaśena aniyatārthatvaṃ na syāt / vyavahārastu śabdānmayā pratipannaṃ śabdena ca pratipādayāmīti / pratipādyapratipādakayostamirikadvayadvicandradarśanavad bhaviṣyatīti / yathaikastaimirikaścandradvayaṃ pratipadya pratipādayati / aparaśca pratipadyate / tathā sarvatra vyavahartṝṇāmayaṃ śabdo vyavahāra iti / atha parīkṣakāstarhi śabdārthādhyavasāye sati mithyātvaṃ manyamānāḥ pravartante / lokavyavahārānusāritayā / lokavyavahāraṃ prati sadṛśau bālapaṇḍitau iti nyāyāt / mithyājñānasya cārthapratipādakatvaṃ kvacidupalabdham / yathā maṇipradīpaprabhayormaṇibuddhyābhidhāvatormithyājñānāviśeṣe 'pi viśeṣo 'rthakriyāṃ prati /
analyzed: vāstava artha viṣaya tve ca śabdānām puruṣa icchā vaśena aniyata artha tvam na syāt vyavahāraḥ tu śabdāt mayā pratipannam śabdena ca pratipādayāmi iti pratipādya pratipādakayoḥ tamirika dvaya dvi candra darśana vat bhaviṣyati iti yathā ekaḥ taimirikaḥ candra dvayam pratipadya pratipādayati aparaḥ ca pratipadyate tathā sarvatra vyavahartṝṇām ayam śabdaḥ vyavahāraḥ iti atha parīkṣakāḥ tarhi śabda artha adhyavasāye sati mithyātvam manyamānāḥ pravarta
translated: And if words had real objects as their content, they would not have indeterminate meanings based on the speaker's will. The usage is that I understand from the word and communicate through the word. It will be like the two people with eye disease seeing two moons. Just as one person with eye disease understands and communicates the two moons, and another understands, so in all cases this is the usage of words for those engaged in worldly transactions. But then the investigators, considering falsity when there is ascertainment of the meaning of a word, engage [in analysis], following worldly usage, because of the principle that the child and the learned are equal with respect to worldly usage. And the ability of false knowledge to communicate an object is observed somewhere, just as in the case of those who run towards a gem and a lamp with the idea of a gem, there is a difference with respect to effective action, even though there is no difference in the false knowledge.

original: tadetadasat / śabdādarthādhyavasāye sati pravartamānasya arthāvisaṃvādena akṣajajñānavad abhrāntatvena prāmāṇyopapatteḥ / tathā hi indriyajñānasyāpi samyaktve na arthāvisaṃvādaṃ vinā pramāṇāntaramasti / sa ca śābdajñāne 'pyastīti kathamapramāṇam /
analyzed: tat etat asat śabdāt artha adhyavasāye sati pravartamānasya artha avisaṃvādena akṣa ja jñāna vat abhrānta tvena prāmāṇya upapatteḥ tathā hi indriya jñānasya api samyaktve na artha avisaṃvādam vinā pramāṇa antaram asti sa ca śābda jñāne pi asti iti katham apramāṇam
translated: This is not so. When a person acts on the basis of the ascertainment of meaning from the word, his action being not contradicted by the object, the verbal cognition is valid like the sense-cognition, because it is not erroneous. For instance, even in the case of sense-cognition, if it is correct, there is no other means of valid knowledge except non-contradiction by the object. And that exists in the case of verbal cognition also. How then can it be invalid?

original: pratibandho 'pi kāryaviśeṣopalabdherindriyāṇāmiva śabdasyāpyarthena vācyaḥ / sa ca vācyavācakālambanaṃ saṅketajñānameva / anyasyāsambhavāt / tasya ca viśeṣāṇāmānantye 'pi ekasāmānyasyopagrahādupapattirityuktameva / yadi ca śabdānāmaprāmāṇyam / pramāṇādisvarūpāvabodhārthaṃ śāstramanarthakaṃ syāt / pramāṇādisvarūpasya pāramparyeṇāpi tasmādapratīteḥ /
analyzed: pratibandhaḥ u pi kārya viśeṣa upalabdheḥ indriyāṇām iva śabdasya api arthena vācyaḥ sa ca vācya vācaka ālambanam saṅketa jñānam eva anyasya asambhavāt tasya ca viśeṣāṇām ānantye pi eka sāmānyasya upagrahāt upapattiḥ iti uktam eva yadi ca śabdānām aprāmāṇyam pramāṇa ādi svarūpa avabodha artham śāstram anarthakam syāt pramāṇa ādi svarūpasya pāramparyeṇa api tasmāt apratīteḥ
translated: The relation (between the word and its meaning) also, which is the cause of the cognition of the particular object, should be stated to be that of denoter and denoted, as in the case of the sense-organs. And that is the knowledge of convention itself, which has the denoter and denoted as its basis, because nothing else is possible. And that is established even in the case of infinite particulars by the apprehension of a single universal. If, on the other hand, words are invalid, the scriptures would be useless for understanding the nature of the means of valid knowledge etc., because the nature of the means of valid knowledge etc. is not apprehended even indirectly from them.

original: yadi ca vivakṣāsūcakatvenaiva prāmāṇyamiṣyeta / tarhi sarvavākyānāṃ tatrāvyabhicārādaviśeṣeṇa prāmāṇye vādiprativādinorvivāde jayaparājayavyavasthā na syāt / atha yadvākyamarthapratibandhāṃ /ddhāṃ vivakṣāṃ sūcayati / tadeva pramāṇaṃ na sarvamiti cet / na / śabdavad vivakṣāṇāmapi ekāntena arthapratibandhābhāvāt / tathā ca arthadarśanānusmaraṇakrameṇa vivakṣākāle nārthasyāvasthānamastīti / ato bāhyārthādhyavasāye satyeva pravartante na dṛśyavikalpyāvarthāvekīkṛtya tatsamāropeṇa iti /
analyzed: yadi ca vivakṣā sūcaka tvena eva prāmāṇyam iṣyeta tarhi sarva vākyānām tatra avyabhicārāt aviśeṣeṇa prāmāṇye vādi prativādinoḥ vivāde jaya parājaya vyavasthā na syāt atha yat vākyam artha pratibandhāṃddhām vivakṣām sūcayati tat eva pramāṇam na sarvam iti ced na śabda vat vivakṣāṇām api ekāntena artha pratibandha abhāvāt tathā ca artha darśana anusmaraṇa krameṇa vivakṣā kāle na arthasya avasthānam asti iti atas bāhya artha adhyavasāye sati e
translated: And if validity were accepted as merely indicating the speaker's intention, then all statements would be invariably valid in that regard, and there would be no establishment of victory and defeat in the dispute between the proponent and opponent due to lack of distinction. If it is argued that only that statement which indicates the intention bound to the meaning is valid, not all, that is not so. Because even intentions, like words, are absolutely devoid of connection with the meaning. And thus, due to the sequence of seeing and remembering the meaning, the meaning does not remain at the time of intention. Therefore, they operate only when there is the ascertainment of an external object, not by identifying the seen and imagined objects and superimposing them.

original: na ca dṛśyasyānupalabdhervikalpyenakīkaraṇaṃ yuktam / upalabhyamānapadārthe hi candrādau dvitvādisamāropasyānyatropalabdheḥ / śabdārthapratipattau bādhakānupapatteśca mṛṣaiṣā kalpanā /
analyzed: na ca dṛśyasya anupalabdheḥ vikalpya inakīkaraṇam yuktam upalabhyamāna padārthe hi candra ādau dvi tva ādi samāropasya anyatra upalabdheḥ śabda artha pratipattau bādhaka anupapatteḥ ca mṛṣā eṣā kalpanā
translated: And it is not proper to identify the seen with the imagined when the seen is not perceived, because the superimposition of duality etc. on the object of perception like the moon is due to perception elsewhere, and because this imagination is false due to the non-applicability of contradiction in the understanding of the meaning of words.

original: yaccedaṃ vivakṣākrameṇa śabdotpattikāle nārthasyāvasthānamastīti / tadapāstam / kṣaṇikatvānabhyupagamena /
analyzed: yat ca idam vivakṣā krameṇa śabda utpatti kāle na arthasya avasthānam asti iti tat apāstam kṣaṇika tva anabhyupagamena
translated: And as for the statement that at the time of the production of the word by the speaker's volition, the object does not exist, that is refuted by the non-acceptance of momentariness.

original: atha sāmānyaviśeṣavyatiriktaviṣayābhāvādapramāṇatvaṃ śabdānām / tadasat / ekāntena pramāṇeṣu vyavasthānabhyupagamāt / tathā ca / āgamādātmā pratīyate / punarutpādaliṅgaiḥ yogabalācca pratyakṣato 'pīti saṃplavaḥ / kvacid vyavasthā ca / yathā āgamasya medhyāmedhyapratipattau / indriyāṇāṃ svaviṣayeṣviti / ataḥ pratyakṣādiviṣaye 'pi śabdasya pravṛtterna viṣayāntarābhāvastadaprāmāṇye heturiti / viṣayadvaividhyena ca pramāṇadvitvāvadhāraṇe dūṣaṇaṃ gurubhirvistareṇābhihitamiti nehocyate /
analyzed: atha sāmānya viśeṣa vyatirikta viṣaya abhāvāt apramāṇa tvam śabdānām tat asat ekāntena pramāṇeṣu vyavasthā anabhyupagamāt tathā ca āgamāt ātmā pratīyate punar utpāda liṅgaiḥ yoga balāt ca pi iti saṃplavaḥ kvacid vyavasthā ca yathā āgamasya medhya amedhya pratipattau indriyāṇām sva viṣayeṣu iti atas pratyakṣa ādi viṣaye pi śabdasya pravṛtteḥ na viṣaya antara abhāvaḥ tad aprāmāṇye hetuḥ iti viṣaya dvaividhyena ca pramāṇa dvi tva avad
translated: If it is argued that words are not a means of valid knowledge because they do not have an object different from the universal and the particular, that is not so, because the means of valid knowledge are not accepted to be absolutely fixed. And thus, the self is cognized from scripture, again from the marks of rebirth, and also directly from the power of yoga. There is a combination [of means of valid knowledge], but sometimes there is restriction, like the restriction of scripture to the cognition of what is pure and impure, and of the senses to their own objects. Therefore, even in the domain of perception etc., since words operate, the absence of a different object is not a reason for their invalidity. And the refutation of determining the means of valid knowledge to be two by the twofold division of objects has been stated in detail by the teachers, so it is not stated here.

original: yattu śabdānāṃ svalakṣaṇaviṣayatve andhānandhayoraviśeṣaprasaṅga ityuktam / tadasat / viṣayaikatve 'pi karaṇabhedena pratipattyorbhedāt / andhasya hi śabdād rūpaviṣayaṃ vijñānamutpadyate / na tu cākṣuṣamiti / yasya ca aparokṣaṃ cākṣuṣaṃ vijñānamasti / asau anandhaḥ / śabdo hi vyavahitamapyarthaṃ prakāśayati / sannikṛṣṭañca indriyam ityanayorvibhinnapratipattijanakatvam /
analyzed: yat tu śabdānām sva lakṣaṇa viṣaya tve andha anandhayoḥ aviśeṣa prasaṅgaḥ iti uktam tat asat viṣaya ekatve pi karaṇa bhedena pratipattyoḥ bhedāt andhasya hi śabdāt rūpa viṣayam vijñānam utpadyate na tu cākṣuṣam iti yasya ca aparokṣam cākṣuṣam vijñānam asti asau an andhaḥ śabdaḥ hi vyavahitam api artham prakāśayati sannikṛṣṭam ca indriyam iti anayoḥ vibhinna pratipatti janaka tvam
translated: As regards the argument that, if words denoted the Specific Individuality, then the blind and the non-blind would have the same experience, that cannot be right; because even though the object may be one and the same, the cognition of it may be different, on account of the difference in the character of the means of cognition; for instance, the blind man has the cognition of the colour of the object through the word, and not through the eye; and he who has the direct visual perception of the colour is not blind; the word expresses the object even when it is not in close proximity to it, while the sense-organ apprehends only what is in close proximity to it; hence the difference in the character of the means of cognition.

original: yattu tvagindriyāgnisambandhādiva dāhaśabdādapi dāhārthaḥ sampratīyetetyuktam / tatra yadi dāho duḥkham / tatpratīyata eva dāhaśabdāt / na caivaṃ śroturduḥkhiII /tvaprasaṅgaḥ / duḥkhāsamavāyāt / yasya hi duḥkhaṃ samavetamupajātam / sa eva duḥkhī / na tu dāhaśabdād ātmani samavetaṃ duḥkhamutpadyate / kiṃ tarhi / parātmasamavetamapi tato vijānātīti / sphoṭādilakṣaṇastu dāhastvaco 'gnisambandhādupajāyate / na dāhaśabdāditi / tasmādedhāgnisambandhādutpannasphoṭādikāryastajjanitaduḥkham ātmāntaḥkaraṇasambandhād anubhavatīti duḥkhītyatidiśyate / dāhaśabdañca anyathaiva anutpannasphoṭādikāryo duḥkhaṃ parātmagataṃ pratipadyate / ityadūṣaṇametat /
analyzed: yat tu tvac indriya agni sambandhāt iva dāha śabdāt api dāha arthaḥ sampratīyeta iti uktam tatra yadi dāhaḥ duḥkham tat pratīyate eva dāha śabdāt na ca evam duḥkha asamavāyāt yasya hi duḥkham samavetam upajātam saḥ eva duḥkhī na tu dāha śabdāt ātmani samavetam duḥkham utpadyate kim tarhi parātma samavetam api tatas vijānāti iti sphoṭa ādi lakṣaṇaḥ tu dāhaḥ tvacaḥ gni sambandhāt upajāyate na dāha śabdāt iti tasmāt edha agni sambandhāt utpanna spho
translated: As for what was said that the meaning of burning is understood even from the word 'burning' due to the connection of the skin with fire, if burning is suffering, then that is understood from the word 'burning' itself. And there is no consequence of the hearer being in suffering, because of the absence of suffering in the composite whole. For only he who has suffering as a part of himself is in suffering, but from the word 'burning' suffering does not arise as a part of the self. Then what? He knows that which arises as a part of the other self from that. But the burning characterized by the sound 'sphoṭa' etc. arises from the connection of the skin with fire, not from the word 'burning'. Therefore, the effect characterized by the sound 'sphoṭa' etc. that arises from the connection of fuel with fire, he experiences that suffering produced by it through the connection of the self with the internal organ, and is therefore called 'in suffering'. And the word 'burning' is understood in a different way by one who has not yet produced the effect characterized by the sound 'sphoṭa' etc., as suffering belonging to the other self. Thus this is not a fault.

original: na ca svalakṣaṇasya nirbhāgatayā śuklādiśabdānāṃ paryāyatvaprasaṅgaḥ / dharmadharmiṇorvyatirekāt pratyayabhedasya bhedalakṣaṇatvādityuktam / tasmād bhinnapravṛttinimittānāṃ śabdānāmekārthatve 'pi na paryāyatvamiti /
analyzed: na ca sva lakṣaṇasya nirbhāga tayā śukla ādi śabdānām paryāya tva prasaṅgaḥ dharma dharmiṇoḥ vyatirekāt pratyaya bhedasya bheda lakṣaṇa tvāt iti uktam tasmāt bhinna pravṛtti nimittānām śabdānām eka artha tve pi na paryāya tvam iti
translated: And it is not the case that the particular characteristic, being partless, is subject to the fault of the words white etc. being synonyms, because it has been said that the difference of the cognition is the characteristic of the difference of the object, since the property and the possessor of the property are different. Therefore, even when words having different causes of application have the same meaning, they are not synonyms.

original: na cāpohaḥ śabdārthaḥ / tasyaivāsambhavāditi vakṣyāmaḥ /
analyzed: na ca apohaḥ śabda arthaḥ tasya eva asambhavāt iti vakṣyāmaḥ
translated: And we will say that the exclusion is not the meaning of the word, because it itself is impossible.

original: yattu vāstavārthaviṣayatve puruṣecchāvaśena aniyatārthatvaṃ na syāditi / tadasat / naimittikaśabdānāṃ nimittavaśena pravṛtternāniyatārthatvam / yādṛcchikānāntu puruṣecchāvaśena aniyatārthatvamiṣyata eva / bādhakānupapatteśca na taimirikasya dvicandradarśanavacchābdo vyavahāraḥ / tathāhi / taimirikasya dvicandradarśane timirotpatteḥ prāgūrdhvañca bādhakamasti / anupajātatimirasya tu sarvadā / na caivaṃ śabdavyavahāre /
analyzed: yat tu vāstava artha viṣaya tve puruṣa icchā vaśena aniyata artha tvam na syāt iti tat asat naimittika śabdānām nimitta vaśena pravṛtteḥ na aniyata artha tvam yādṛcchikānām tu puruṣa icchā vaśena aniyata artha tvam iṣyate eva bādhaka anupapatteḥ ca na taimirikasya dvi candra darśana vat śābdaḥ vyavahāraḥ tathā hi taimirikasya dvi candra darśane timira utpatteḥ prāk ūrdhvam ca bādhakam asti anupajāta timirasya tu sarvadā na ca evam śabda vyavahāre anupajāta
translated: As for the objection that if the word has a real object as its content, its meaning cannot be indefinite due to the speaker's wish, that is not so. For words that are occasioned have their application due to the occasion, so they are not indefinite in meaning. But for accidental [words], it is accepted that their meaning is indefinite due to the speaker's wish. And because there is no contradiction, the verbal usage is not like the seeing of two moons by one with an eye disease. For example, in the case of one with an eye disease seeing two moons, there is a contradiction before and after the eye disease arises, but not for one who has not contracted the eye disease at all. And it is not so in the case of verbal usage.

original: yattu mithyājñānāviśeṣe 'pyarthakriyāsiddhiḥ / yathā maṇipradīpaprabhayorityuktam / tadaparijñānāt / tathāhi / samīpavartino yanmaṇāveva vijñānaṃ tadevārthakriyājanakam / na prabhāyāmiti / śābdajñānantu arthaprāptiparyantavyavahāropalabdherindriyajajñānavad bhrāntaṃ na bhavatīti /
analyzed: yat tu mithyā jñāna aviśeṣe pi arthakriyā siddhiḥ yathā maṇi pradīpa prabhayoḥ iti uktam tad aparijñānāt tathā hi samīpa vartinaḥ yat maṇau eva vijñānam tat eva arthakriyā janakam na prabhāyām iti śābda jñānam tu artha prāpti paryanta vyavahāra upalabdheḥ indriya ja jñāna vat bhrāntam na bhavati iti
translated: As for what was said, that even in the absence of a distinction in false cognition, there is the establishment of the result of an object, as in the case of a gem and lamplight, that is due to lack of understanding. For thus, the cognition that arises in regard to a gem that is nearby alone generates the result of the object, not in regard to the light. But the verbal cognition, unlike the cognition arising from a sense organ, is not false, because the usage up to the attainment of the object is observed.

original: na ca vāstavasambandhābhāve śabdānām aśvaśabdādaśvādhyavasāyo gośabdācca gavyadhyavasāya iti vikalpaniyamo ghaṭate / dṛṣṭaścāsāviti / tathāśvaśabde 'pi sambandhāgrahe sambandhipratyayo na syādityalamativistareṇa /
analyzed: na ca vāstava sambandha abhāve śabdānām aśva śabdāt aśva adhyavasāyaḥ go śabdāt ca gavi adhyavasāyaḥ iti vikalpa niyamaḥ ghaṭate dṛṣṭaḥ ca asau iti tathā aśva śabde pi sambandha agrahe sambandhi pratyayaḥ na syāt iti alam ati vistareṇa
translated: And when there is no real relation, the restriction of the verbal cognition, that the word 'horse' produces the cognition of a horse and the word 'cow' produces the cognition of a cow, is not possible. And that is observed. Similarly, in the word 'horse' also, if there is no apprehension of the relation, there would be no cognition of the related object. Enough of this extensive discussion.

original: tadevaṃ tādātmyatadutpattipratibandhasya pūrvameva pratiṣedhāt śabdānāntu II / samayavaśenārthapratipādakatvād upapannam anumānādarthāntaratve sati prāmāṇyamiti /
analyzed: tat evam tādātmya tad utpatti pratibandhasya pūrvam eva pratiṣedhāt śabdānām tu samaya vaśena artha pratipādaka tvāt upapannam anumānāt artha antara tve sati prāmāṇyam iti
translated: Thus, since the restriction of identity and origination has already been refuted earlier, and since words convey meaning by convention, it is reasonable that they are a means of valid knowledge, being different from inference in this respect.

original: ceṣṭāyā anumāne 'ntarbhāvaḥ
analyzed: ceṣṭāyāḥ anumāne ntarbhāvaḥ
translated: The inclusion of bodily gestures in inference

original: prasiddhābhinayasya ceṣṭayā pratipattidarśanāt tadapyanumānamevaPDhS
analyzed: prasiddha abhinayasya ceṣṭayā pratipatti darśanāt tat api anumānam eva
translated: And because the understanding of well-known acting is seen through gesture, that too is inference only.

original: atha ceṣṭāpramāṇāntaramiti kecit / tanniṣedhārthamāha prasiddhābhinayasya ceṣṭayā pratipattidarśanāt tadapyanumānameva prasiddho 'bhinayaśceṣṭā kāyiko vyāpāro 'rthaviśeṣāvinābhūto yasyāsau tathoktaḥ / tasya ceṣṭayā arthaviśeṣe pratipattiḥ / yathā mukhāñjalisaṃyogād viśiṣṭāt pipāsāpratipattiḥ / tasya tayā pūrvamavinābhāvopalabdheḥ / tathā ca / ayaṃ pipāsānvitaḥ / viśiṣṭamukhāñjalisaṃyogavattvāt / tadanyaivaṃvidhadevadattavat / ataḥ pakṣadharmatvādibalena gamakatvād etadapyanumānameveti / evamanyāpi ceṣṭā nāṭyaśāstraprasiddhā anumāne 'ntarbhāvanīyeti /
analyzed: atha ceṣṭā pramāṇa antaram iti kecid tad niṣedha artham āha prasiddha abhinayasya ceṣṭayā pratipatti darśanāt tat api anumānam eva prasiddhaḥ bhinayaḥ ceṣṭā kāyikaḥ vyāpāraḥ rtha viśeṣa avinābhūtaḥ yasya asau tathā uktaḥ tasya ceṣṭayā artha viśeṣe pratipattiḥ yathā mukha añjali saṃyogāt viśiṣṭāt pipāsā pratipattiḥ tasya tayā pūrvam avinābhāva upalabdheḥ tathā ca ayam pipāsā anvitaḥ viśiṣṭa mukha añjali saṃyoga vat tvā
translated: Now, some think that gesture is a separate means of knowledge. To refute that, he says: And because the understanding of well-known acting is seen through gesture, that too is inference only. Well-known acting is a bodily activity inseparable from a particular meaning, of which it is said to be so. And through that, there is understanding of a particular meaning. Just as from a special combination of mouth and water, there is understanding of thirst. Because its invariable concomitance was previously observed with that. And so, this person is endowed with thirst, because of having a special combination of mouth and water, like another person of that kind. Therefore, because it is a reason by virtue of being a property of the subject and so on, this too is inference only. In the same way, other gestures known from the science of dramaturgy should be included in inference.

original: upamānasyānumāne 'ntarbhāvaḥ
analyzed: upamānasya anumāne ntarbhāvaḥ
translated: The inclusion of comparison in inference

original: āptenāprasiddhagavayasya gavā gavayapratipādanādupamānamāptavacanameva /PDhS
analyzed: āptena aprasiddha gavayasya gavā gavaya pratipādanāt upamānam āpta vacanam eva
translated: Because the known cow conveys the gavaya which is unknown, comparison is the statement of a reliable person.

original: athopamānaṃ pramāṇāntaramiti kecit / tanniṣedhārthamāha āptenāprasiddhagavayasya gavā gavayapratipādanād upamānamāptavacanameva iti / āptena prasiddhagogavayasārūpyeṇa aprasiddhagavayasya gavā gavayapratipādanāditi / yathā gaurevaṃ gavaya ityupamānamiṣṭam / tad āptavacanameva na pramāṇāntaramiti / na cāsya upamārūpatvāt pramāṇāntaratvam / vidhyarthavādādibhedenāpi pramāṇānantyaprasaṅgāt / atha satyapyavāntarabhede nāmīṣām āptopadeśād bhedaḥ / tadupamāne 'pi samānam /
analyzed: atha upamānam pramāṇa antaram iti kecid tad niṣedha artham āha āptena aprasiddha gavayasya gavā gavaya pratipādanāt upamānam āpta vacanam eva iti āptena prasiddha go gavaya sārūpyeṇa aprasiddha gavayasya gavā gavaya pratipādanāt iti yathā gauḥ evam gavayaḥ iti upamānam iṣṭam tat āpta vacanam eva na pramāṇa antaram iti na ca asya upamā rūpa tvāt pramāṇa antara tvam vidhi artha vāda ādi bhedena api pramāṇa ānantya prasaṅgāt atha sati api avāntarabhede na am
translated: Now some consider comparison to be a separate means of valid knowledge. To refute that, he says: Because the known cow conveys the gavaya which is unknown, comparison is the statement of a reliable person. Because the reliable person, by the similarity of the known cow and gavaya, conveys the gavaya which is unknown by the cow. As it is said, The gavaya is like the cow, this is accepted as comparison. It is just the statement of a reliable person, not a separate means of valid knowledge. And it is not a separate means of valid knowledge because it has the form of comparison, because there would be an infinite regress of means of valid knowledge even by the distinction of injunction, explanatory passage, etc. Now, even though there is a subordinate distinction, there is a difference among these [means of valid knowledge] because of the teaching of a reliable person. That is the same in comparison also.

original: atha vākyādupalabdhasādṛśyasyāṭavyāmaṭato gavayārthino madīyā gauranena sadṛśīti jñānamupamānam / asadetat / phalābhāvāt / ajñānanivṛttiḥ phalamityuktam / nivṛtteḥ pradhvaṃsatvāt / tathāhi / yadi jñānānutpattiḥ / viparītaṃ vā jñānamajñānam ubhayathāpi tannivṛttiḥ pradhvaṃsa eva / pramājanakañca pramāṇam / na ca heyādibuddhayaḥ phalam / tadapāye sati kālāntareṇa sukhaduḥkhādiviniścayānantaramutpatteḥ / na ca sādṛśyasya prameyatvam / tajjñānasyāphalatvāt / abhyupagame vā anyat pramāṇaṃ vācyamiti /
analyzed: atha vākyāt upalabdha sādṛśyasya aṭavyām aṭataḥ gavaya arthinaḥ madīyā gauḥ anena sadṛśī iti jñānam upamānam asat etat phala abhāvāt ajñāna nivṛttiḥ phalam iti uktam nivṛtteḥ pradhvaṃsa tvāt tathā hi yadi jñāna anutpattiḥ viparītam vā jñānam ajñānam ubhayathā api tad nivṛttiḥ pradhvaṃsaḥ eva pramā janakam ca pramāṇam na ca heya ādi buddhayaḥ phalam tad apāye sati kāla antareṇa sukha duḥkha ādi viniścaya anantaram utpatteḥ  /
translated: Or, the knowledge of one who has perceived similarity through a sentence, that my cow is similar to this, of one seeking a gavaya while wandering in a forest, is analogy. This is incorrect. Because of the absence of a result. It has been said that the cessation of non-knowledge is the result. Because cessation is a destruction. It is like this. If there is non-arising of knowledge, or if knowledge is contrary, in both cases its cessation is only a destruction. And a means of valid knowledge produces valid knowledge. And the notions of what is to be rejected etc. are not the result. Because they arise later, at a different time, after the ascertainment of pleasure, pain etc. when that has ceased. And similarity is not the object of knowledge. Because the knowledge of that is fruitless. Or, if it is accepted, another means of valid knowledge should be stated.

original: atha gavayajñānamupamānaṃ madīyā gauranena sadṛśīti jñānaphalam / sādṛśyāvacchinnaḥ piṇḍaḥ / tadavacchinnaṃ vā sādṛśyaṃ prameyamiti / na cedaṃ jñānamindriyajam / aṭavyāṃ vyavasthitasya gṛhāvasthitapiṇḍaviṣayatvenotpatteḥ / na cānumānajam / liṅgavyāpārānupalabdheḥ / gosādṛśyantu gavaye gṛhyamāṇamapyasiddham / vyadhikaraṇatvāt / tathā ca / madīyā gauranena sadṛśī / asya tatsadṛśatvād iti vyadhikaraṇataiva / anupapadyamānasyārthasyābhāvād nārthāpattijam / śabdaṃ vināpyutpatterna śābdam / abhāvasya ca niyataviṣayatvam / na cedaṃ smaraṇam / gavayasādṛśyasya gopiṇḍe pūrvamananubhūtatvāt / ataḥ pramāṇāntaraphalametadityāśayaḥ parasya /
analyzed: atha gavaya jñānam upamānam madīyā gauḥ anena sadṛśī iti jñāna phalam sādṛśya avacchinnaḥ piṇḍaḥ tad avacchinnam vā sādṛśyam prameyam iti na ca idam jñānam indriya jam aṭavyām vyavasthitasya gṛha avasthita piṇḍa viṣaya tvena utpatteḥ na ca anumāna jam liṅga vyāpāra anupalabdheḥ go sādṛśyam tu gavaye gṛhyamāṇam api asiddham vyadhikaraṇa tvāt tathā ca madīyā gauḥ anena sadṛśī asya tad sadṛśa tvāt iti vyadhikaraṇa tā eva anupapady
translated: Now, if the knowledge of the gavaya is inference, its result is the knowledge that 'my cow is similar to this'. The individual delimited by similarity, or the similarity delimited by that, is the object of knowledge. And this knowledge is not produced by the senses, because it arises with reference to an individual located in the house, while one is situated in the forest. Nor is it produced by inference, because the operation of the inferential mark is not perceived. And although the similarity to the cow is perceived in the gavaya, it is not established, because it has a different substratum. And so, 'my cow is similar to this', because it is similar to that. Thus, it has a different substratum. Since there is no object whose meaning is not established, it is not produced by presumption. Since it arises even without words, it is not verbal. And absence has a limited object. And this is not recollection, because the similarity to the gavaya was not previously experienced in the individual cow. Thus, the opponent's idea is that this is the result of a different means of knowledge.

original: yadi ca gosādṛśyāvacchinnaṃ gavayapiṇḍam indriyārthasannikarṣādevopalabhyate / tadā pratyakṣaphalameva / na pramāṇāntaraphalam / tatra kiṃ smaraṇāpekṣamindriyamevaṃ jñānaṃ janayati / anapekṣaṃ vā / anapekṣasya jñānajanakatve 'prasiddhagopiṇḍasya smaraṇe 'pyetat syāt / atha piṇḍamātrasmaraṇe / aśvādipiṇḍasmaraṇe 'pi syāt / atha gavayasādṛśyāvacchinnasmaraṇāpekṣaṃ janakam / tatrāpi yadi smaraṇamātramapekṣeta / gajādismaraṇe 'pi syāt / atha gopiṇḍasmaraṇāpekṣam / tatrāpi kiṃ gopiṇḍamātrasmaraṇamapekṣate / gavayasādṛśyāvacchinnaṃ gopiṇḍasmaraṇaṃ vā / gopiṇḍamātrasmaraṇe 'śvādipiṇḍasmaraṇe 'pi /ṇḍe 'pi syāt / gavayasādṛśyāvacchinnagopiṇḍasmaraṇāpekṣitve pūrvamevānubhavo vācyastadantareṇa saṃskārānutpatteḥ smaraṇasyaivābhāvāt / ataḥ savikalpakajñānābhāve 'pi gavayasādṛśyāvacchinne gopiṇḍe pūrvamanubhavo 'bhyupagantavyaḥ / yena hi saṃskārotpattau smaraṇād madīyayā gavā sadṛśo 'yaṃ gavaya iti jñānaṃ syāt / pūrvañca gavayasādṛśyāvacchinnagopiṇḍe 'nubhavaprasiddhau gavayopalambhād madīyā gauranena sadṛśīti kathametat smaraṇaṃ na syāt / tathā pṛṣṭo bravīti etatsadṛśī mayopalabdhā / na tu pramāṇāntaraṃ nirdiśatīti manyamānaḥ praśasto bhagavān antarbhāvamāheti /
analyzed: yadi ca go sādṛśya avacchinnam gavaya piṇḍam indriya artha sannikarṣāt eva upalabhyate tadā pratyakṣa phalam eva na pramāṇa antara phalam  / tatra kim smaraṇa apekṣam indriyam evam jñānam janayati anapekṣam vā anapekṣasya jñāna janaka tve prasiddha go piṇḍasya smaraṇe pi etat syāt atha piṇḍa mātra smaraṇe aśva ādi piṇḍa smaraṇe syāt atha gavaya sādṛśya avacchinna smaraṇa apekṣam janakam tatra api yadi smaraṇa mātram apekṣeta gaja ādi smara
translated: And if the individual gavaya, distinguished by similarity to a cow, is perceived only through the contact of sense and object, then it is the result of perception itself, not the result of another means of knowledge. In that case, does the sense organ, requiring memory, generate such knowledge, or without requiring it? If the sense organ generates knowledge without requiring memory, then it would occur even in the recollection of an unknown individual gavaya. If it requires the mere recollection of an individual, then it would occur even in the recollection of an individual horse. If it is generated requiring the recollection distinguished by similarity to a gavaya, then if it requires mere recollection, it would occur even in the recollection of an elephant. If it requires the recollection of an individual cow, then in that case, does it require the mere recollection of an individual cow, or the recollection of an individual cow distinguished by similarity to a gavaya? If it requires the mere recollection of an individual cow, then it would occur even in the recollection of an individual horse. If it requires the recollection of an individual cow distinguished by similarity to a gavaya, then the prior experience must be stated, without which there would be no impression.

original: anye tu yathā gaurgavayastatheti vanecaravākyāt sādṛśyopalambhe sati upajātasaṃskārasyāṭavyāṃ paribhramato gośādṛśyāvacchinnagavayadarśane sati avinābhāvasambandhasmaraṇānantaraṃ tathā cāyaṃ gosadṛśa iti jñānamupamānaṃ II / manyante / tasmāccānantaraṃ gavayanāme /māyamiti saṃjñāsaṃjñisambandhapratipattiḥ / phalaṃ saṃjñāsaṃjñirūpam / saṃjñāvacchinno vā piṇḍaḥ prameyamiti / na ca vākyādeva saṅketapratipattirgavayapiṇḍasya parokṣatvāt / pratyakṣaṃ saṃjñākarma vai / sū / iti sūtravyāghātācca /
analyzed: anye tu yathā gauḥ gavayaḥ tathā iti vanecara vākyāt sādṛśya upalambhe sati upajāta saṃskārasya aṭavyām paribhramataḥ go śādṛśya avacchinna gavaya darśane sati avinābhāva sambandha smaraṇa anantaram tathā ca ayam go sadṛśaḥ iti jñānam upamānam manyante tasmāt ca anantaram gavaya nāmā imā ayam iti saṃjñā saṃjñi sambandha pratipattiḥ phalam saṃjñā saṃjñi rūpam saṃjñā avacchinnaḥ vā piṇḍaḥ prameyam iti na ca vākyāt eva saṅketa prati
translated: Others, however, think that when one hears the statement of a forester that a gavaya is like a cow, and then, having acquired the impression, wanders in the forest, and then sees a gavaya delimited by similarity to a cow, then after the recollection of the relation of invariable concomitance, the knowledge that this is like a cow is inference. And from that immediately follows the cognition of the relation between the name and the object named. The result is the relation between the name and the object named, or the object delimited by the name is the object of knowledge. And the cognition of the relation between the name and the object named does not come from the statement itself, because the individual gavaya is not directly perceived. And because it would contradict the sutra that says the application of names is by direct perception.

original: na yuktametat / vākyādeva saṅketasya pratītatvāt / tathāhi / sādṛśyavākyasyāyamartho yo gosadṛśaḥ / sa gavaya ityevaṃ vyavahartavyaḥ / sa ca vākyādupalabdhasaṅketaḥ sādṛśyāvacchinnaṃ piṇḍamupalabhamānaḥ paraṃ vyavaharati ayaṃ gavayaḥ iti / na tu saṅketaṃ pratipadyate pratipiṇḍam / anyatrāpi saṅketaprasaṅgāt / tathāhi / yatra yatra gotvaṃ paśyasi / tatra tatra gośabdaḥ prayoktavyaḥ / tasmācca asāvarthaḥ pratipattavya iti saṅketagrahe sati gopiṇḍopalambhādayaṃ gauriti pratipadyate / na tu gonā me /māyamiti / vyavahārābhāvaprasaṅgāt / na tu sūtravyāghātaḥ / pratyakṣaśabdasya dṛḍhapramāṇopalakṣaṇatvāt / dṛḍhapramāṇaparicchinne 'rthe saṃjñā pravartate / yathā deśāntaravyavasthito 'pi pitā svaputrasya nāma karoti yajñadatta nāmāsau iti /
analyzed: na yuktam etat vākyāt eva saṅketasya pratīta tvāt tathā hi sādṛśya vākyasya ayam arthaḥ yaḥ go sadṛśaḥ sa gavayaḥ iti evam vyavahartavyaḥ sa ca vākyāt upalabdha saṅketaḥ sādṛśya avacchinnam piṇḍam upalabhamānaḥ param vyavaharati ayam gavayaḥ iti na tu saṅketam pratipadyate prati piṇḍam anyatra api saṅketa prasaṅgāt tathāhi yatra yatra go tvam paśyasi tatra tatra go śabdaḥ prayoktavyaḥ tasmāt ca asau arthaḥ pratipattavyaḥ iti saṅketa grahe
translated: This is not correct. Because the convention is understood from the sentence itself. The meaning of the sentence about similarity is that whatever is similar to a cow, that should be referred to as a gavaya. And one who has understood the convention from the sentence, perceiving an individual delimited by similarity, uses the expression this is a gavaya. But one does not learn the convention for each individual, because it would lead to the absurdity of the convention being applied elsewhere. It would be like this: Wherever you see cowness, there you should use the word 'cow.' And from that, that meaning should be understood. Thus, when the convention is grasped, one understands this is a cow from the perception of a cow-individual, but not this is not a cow, because it would lead to the absurdity of the absence of usage. But there is no contradiction with the sutra, because the word perception indicates a firm means of knowledge. A name is applied to an object delimited by a firm means of knowledge, just as a father, though situated in a different country, is called father by his son.

original: atha jātiśabdasya pratyakṣa evārthe saṅketaḥ / na / atīndriyeṣu asaṅketaprasaṅgāt / dṛṣṭañca manaḥ śabdasyātīndriye 'pi manasi dṛḍhapramāṇaparicchinne saṅketaḥ / tathā ayaṃ gavaya iti kathaṃ punarbhavān jānātīti pareṇa pṛṣṭo vanecareṇa mamākhyātamiti vacanameva nirdiśati / na tu sādṛśyāt pratipannamiti / kārakeṇa ca vyapadeśaḥ / yathā cakṣuṣā pratipannamanumānācca pratipannamiti / tathā nirviṣayavācyapramāṇamupamānam / athāsti saṃjñāsaṃjñirūpaṃ prameyam / na / sambandhapratipatteḥ phalatve sambandhinaḥ prameyatvānupapatteḥ / atha sambandha iva sambandhinaḥ pratipattireva ubhayaniṣṭhatayā upacāreṇābhidhīyate / tathāpi na saṃjñāsaṃjñirūpaṃ prameyam / saṃjñāyāstadabhāvāt / atha svayamuccārya śabdaṃ pratipadyate / na / vivakṣākrameṇa śabdotpattikāle sādṛśyajñānasya pramāṇasyāsambhavāt / atha jagato vistīrṇatayā kvacidutpanno gavayaśabdaḥ prameyaḥ / na / tasyāśrūyamāṇasya prameyatvānupapatteḥ / atha apratibandhanyāyena dūrasthasyāgamane brahmabhāṣitasyāgamanaṃ syāt /
analyzed: atha jāti śabdasya pratyakṣaḥ eva arthe saṅketaḥ na atīndriyeṣu a saṅketa prasaṅgāt dṛṣṭam ca manaḥ śabdasya atīndriye manasi dṛḍha pramāṇa paricchinne saṅketaḥ tathā ayam gavayaḥ iti katham punar bhavān jānāti iti pareṇa pṛṣṭaḥ vanecareṇa mama ākhyātam iti vacanam eva nirdiśati na tu sādṛśyāt pratipannam iti kārakeṇa ca vyapadeśaḥ yathā cakṣuṣā pratipannam anumānāt ca pratipannam iti tathā nirviṣaya vācya pramāṇam upamā
translated: If the convention is only for the directly perceived meaning of the word 'cow', then it would not apply to imperceptible things. But we see that even for imperceptible things like the mind, convention is made based on firm knowledge. Similarly, when asked by another person in the forest 'How do you know this is a gavaya?', one simply points to the words 'I was told by someone' and does not say 'I understand by similarity'. And the designation is by the instrument, just as one says 'I understand by the eye' and 'I understand by inference'. Thus, analogy is a means of knowledge with no object to denote. If there is an object of knowledge in the form of a name and its bearer, no. Because the establishment of the relation is the result, it is not possible for the relata to be the object of knowledge. If the establishment of the relata is itself said figuratively to be the relation, since it is based on both, even then the object of knowledge is not in the form of a name and its bearer, because the name does not have that form. If it is argued that the name is uttered by oneself and then applied to the object, and the object is understood through the name, then the name would be the object of knowledge, not the object.

original: na ca sannihitaḥ kvacit tadaiva śabdamuccarati / asaṃvedanāt / atha smṛtisamāropitasya gavayaśabdasya prameyatvam / na / tatkalpanāyāṃ kāraṇābhāvāt / sādṛśyajñānānantaraṃ ayaṃ gavayanāmeti pratipadyate / na cāntarāle tatsmṛteranupraveśe pramāṇamastīti / saṃjñāvacchinnasya tu piṇḍasya prameyatvena sambandhajñānaṃ syāt / tasyobhayālambanatvāditi / tathā pareṇāpi anumānādupamānasya bhedamupadarśayatā yathā tathetyupasaṃhārādupamānasiddhernāviśeṣaḥ iti vākyarūpamupamānamiṣṭamava / tasya cāgame 'ntarbhāvo na doṣāyeti /
analyzed: na ca sannihitaḥ kvacid tadā eva śabdam uccarati asaṃvedanāt  / atha smṛti samāropitasya gavaya śabdasya prameya tvam na tad kalpanāyām kāraṇa abhāvāt sādṛśya jñāna anantaram ayam gavaya nāmā iti pratipadyate na ca antarāle tad smṛteḥ anupraveśe pramāṇam asti iti saṃjñā avacchinnasya tu piṇḍasya prameya tvena sambandha jñānam syāt tasya ubhaya ālambana tvāt iti tathā pareṇa api anumānāt upamānasya bhedam upadarśayatā yathā tathā iti upasaṃhārāt
translated: And the word is not uttered at that very time when it is present, because it is not perceived. If the object of knowledge is the word 'gavaya' superimposed by memory, no. Because there is no reason for that imagination. After the knowledge of similarity, one understands 'this is the one named gavaya'. And there is no means of knowledge for the inclusion of that memory in between. But there would be the knowledge of the relation of the individual delimited by the name as the object of knowledge, because that has both as its object. Similarly, even by the opponent who shows the difference of upamāna from inference, there is no difference because upamāna is established by the conclusion 'as it is', so the form of a sentence is accepted as upamāna. And its inclusion in scripture is not a fault.

original: arthāpatteranumāne 'ntarbhāvaḥ
analyzed: arthāpatteḥ anumāne ntarbhāvaḥ
translated: Arthāpatti (presumption) is included in inference.

original: darśanārthādarthāpattistadapyanumānameva /PDhS
analyzed: darśana arthāt arthāpattiḥ tat api anumānam eva pdhs
translated: Arthāpatti (presumption) is for the purpose of seeing, that too is inference.

original: atha arthāpatteranumāne 'ntarbhāvārthaṃ darśanārthādarthāpattistadapyanumānameva iti vākyam / dṛśyata iti darśanaṃ tasmādupalabhyamānādarthādanyathānupapadyamānād arthasyāptiḥ prāptiḥ prasaṅga iti / taduktam /
analyzed: atha arthāpatteḥ anumāne ntarbhāva artham darśana arthāt arthāpattiḥ tat api anumānam eva iti vākyam dṛśyate iti darśanam tasmāt upalabhyamānāt arthāt anyathā anupapadyamānāt arthasya āptiḥ prāptiḥ prasaṅgaḥ iti tat uktam
translated: Now, the sentence Presumption is included in Inference or Presumption is also Inference itself is for the purpose of showing that Presumption is seen to be included in Inference. Dṛśyate means is seen. Artha means object. Anyathānupapannāt means from an object that is not otherwise possible. Arthasya means of the object. Āptiḥ means attainment, acquisition, implication. This is stated:

original: pramāṇaṣaṭkavijñāto yatrārtho nānyathā bhavet /
analyzed: pramāṇa ṣaṭka vijñātaḥ yatra arthaḥ na anyathā bhavet
translated: Where the object known by the six means of knowledge cannot be otherwise,

original: adṛṣṭaṃ kalpayedanyā sārthāpattirudāhṛtā // ślo / vā / pṛ /
analyzed: adṛṣṭam kalpayet anyā sā arthāpattiḥ udāhṛtā
translated: Presumption is stated to be the implication of something unseen. (Ślo. Va. Pṛ. 1. 1. 6)

original: iti ṣaḍbhedā arthāpattiḥ / tatra pratyakṣapūrvikā tu yathā sphoṭādilakṣaṇaṃ kāryamupalabhya tadanyathānupapattyā vahnerdāhikā śaktiḥ pratīyate / na cātra pramāṇāntareṇa avinābhāvagrahaṇam / śakteḥ pramāṇāntarāgocaratvāt / anupalabdhāvinābhāvaśca liṅgaṃ na bhavatyeva / ataḥ pramāṇāntarametat /
analyzed: iti ṣaṭ bhedāḥ arthāpattiḥ tatra pratyakṣa pūrvikā tu yathā sphoṭa ādi lakṣaṇam kāryam upalabhya tad anyathā anupapattyā vahneḥ dāhikā śaktiḥ pratīyate na ca atra pramāṇa antareṇa avinābhāva grahaṇam śakteḥ pramāṇa antara agocara tvāt anupalabdha avinābhāvaḥ ca liṅgam na bhavati eva atas pramāṇa antaram etat
translated: Thus, Presumption is of six kinds. Among them, that which is preceded by Perception is like inferring the burning power of fire from the effect characterized by a sound, etc., by the non-apprehension of anything else. And here, the invariable concomitance is not grasped by another means of knowledge, because the power is not the domain of another means of knowledge. And an unperceived invariable concomitance is not a logical ground at all. Therefore, this is another means of knowledge.

original: anumānapūrvikā tu yathā dhūmādagniṃ pratipadya tadanyathānupapattyā tadviśeṣapratītiriti / upamānapūrvikā ca yathā aṭavyāṃ gavayadarśanāntaraṃ madīyā gauranena sadṛśīti gāṃ pratipadya tadanyathānupapattyā vāhadohādisāmarthyapratipattiḥ / arthāpattipūrvikā tu rūpopalambhānyathānupapattyā avagatasya cakṣuṣaḥ paricchedikā śaktiḥ pratīyata iti / āgamapūrvikā tu jīvati devadatte gṛhe nāstīti vākyād gṛhe 'sattvaṃ pratipadya tadanyathānupapattyā bahirbhāvapratipattiḥ / na bahirbhāvāvinābhūtaṃ kiñcilliṅgamastīti pramāṇāntaraphalametat /
analyzed: anumāna pūrvikā tu yathā dhūmāt agnim pratipadya tad anyathā anupapattyā tad viśeṣa pratītiḥ iti upamāna pūrvikā ca yathā aṭavyām gavaya darśana antaram madīyā gauḥ anena sadṛśī iti gām pratipadya tad anyathā anupapattyā vāha doha ādi sāmarthya pratipattiḥ arthāpatti pūrvikā tu rūpa upalambha anyathā anupapattyā avagatasya cakṣuṣaḥ paricchedikā śaktiḥ pratīyate iti āgama pūrvikā tu jīvati devadatte gṛhe na asti iti vākyāt gṛhe sattvam pratipa
translated: That which is preceded by inference is like the cognition of the particulars of fire by the non-apprehension of smoke, as in the cognition of fire from smoke. That which is preceded by analogy is like the cognition of the cow by one who has seen the gavaya in the forest, thinking My cow is similar to this, and the cognition of the capacity to carry and milk by the non-apprehension of that. That which is preceded by presumption is the cognition of the power of the eye to discriminate, which is understood by the non-apprehension of form. That which is preceded by verbal testimony is like the cognition of Devadatta's absence in the house from the statement Devadatta is alive but not in the house, and the cognition of his presence outside by the non-apprehension of that. There is no other mark that is inseparable from his presence outside, so this is the result of another means of knowledge.

original: abhāvapūrvikā tu yathā sadupalambhakapramāṇapañcakavyāvṛttyā devadattasya gṛhe 'sattvaṃ pratipadya tadanyathānupapattyā bahirdeśasambandhaḥ pratīyate /
analyzed: abhāva pūrvikā tu yathā sat upalambhaka pramāṇa pañcaka vyāvṛttyā devadattasya gṛhe sattvam pratipadya tad anyathā anupapattyā bahis deśa sambandhaḥ pratīyate
translated: That which is preceded by non-apprehension is like the cognition of Devadatta's connection with an external place by the non-apprehension of his presence in the house through the exclusion of the five means of knowing existence.

original: antarbhāvamāha tadapyanumānameva na pramāṇāntaram / tathā ca sphoṭādikāryeṇa agneratīndriyā śaktiḥ pratīyate / ityasadetat / tasyāścaramasahakārivyatirekeṇa pūrvameva pratiṣedhāt / pratibandhakābhāvaviśiṣṭo 'gnisaṃyoga eva agneḥ śaktiḥ / tatsadbhāve kāryakaraṇāt / agnitvantu nijā śaktiḥ / sāpi pratyakṣaiva / yaccānumānāt sāmānyāvabodhe satyāpattito viśeṣāvabodha iti / tadapāstameva / sāmānyaviśeṣasya sādhyatvāditi vadatā / upamānasya tu smaraṇādabhede 'pi tatpūrvikārthāpattiranumānameva / vyāpteḥ pūrvameva grahaṇāt / tathā ca sādṛśyāvacchinno gopiṇḍo vāhādisamarthaḥ / tatpiṇḍatvāt pūrvopalabdhaivaṃvidhagopiṇḍavat / arthāpattipūrvikāpi arthāpattiranumitānumānameva / tathā ca rūpopalabdhiḥ karaṇakāryā kriyātvāt / chidikriyāvaditi / cakṣuḥ prasiddham / taccānumitaṃ śaktimat karaṇatvāt vāsyādivaditi /
analyzed: antarbhāvam āha tat api anumānam eva na pramāṇa antaram tathā ca sphoṭa ādi kāryeṇa agneḥ atīndriyā śaktiḥ pratīyate iti asat etat tasyāḥ carama sahakāri vyatirekeṇa pūrvam eva pratiṣedhāt pratibandhaka abhāva viśiṣṭaḥ gni saṃyogaḥ eva agneḥ śaktiḥ tad sadbhāve kārya karaṇāt agni tvan tu nijā śaktiḥ sā api pratyakṣā eva  yat ca anumānāt sāmānya avabodhe satya āpattitaḥ viśeṣa avabodhaḥ iti tat apāstam eva sāmānya viśeṣasya sādh
translated: He says that it is also inference only, not a separate means of knowledge. And thus, the supersensible power of fire is cognized by the effect such as sphoṭa. This is incorrect. Because that has already been refuted before, except for the final contributory factor. The power of fire is only the conjunction with fire qualified by the absence of obstruction. Because the effect is produced when that exists. But the universal of fire is its own power. That too is directly perceived. And what is said, that when the universal is cognized by inference, the particular is cognized by presumption - that too has been refuted, by one who says that the particular is to be proved. As for analogy, although it is not different from memory, the presumption based on that is inference itself. Because the pervasion is grasped before. And thus, the individual cow qualified by similarity is capable of carrying etc. Because it is an individual of that kind, like the previously perceived individual cow of that kind. Even the presumption based on presumption is inferred inference. And thus, the perception of form is the cause.

original: yā ceyaṃ jīvati devadatte gṛhe nāstītyanyathānupapattyā bahirbhāvapratipattiḥ / sāpyanumānameva / vyāpteḥ pūrvameva grahaṇāt / tathāhi devadatto bahirdeśasambandhī jīvanasambandhitve sati gṛhe 'nupalabhyamānatvād viṣṇumitravat / jīvanasambandhitvañca devadattasya arthāpattivādināpi āgamādeva pratipattavyam / anyathā athāpattirna pravarteta / samānañcaitadabhāvapūrvikāyāmapyarthāpattāviti /
analyzed: yā ca iyam jīvati devadatte gṛhe na asti iti anyathā anupapattyā bahirbhāva pratipattiḥ sā api anumānam eva vyāpteḥ pūrvam eva grahaṇāt tathā hi devadattaḥ bahis deśa sambandhī jīvana sambandhi tve sati gṛhe nupalabhyamāna tvāt viṣṇumitra vat jīvana sambandhi tvañca devadattasya arthāpatti vādinā api āgamāt eva pratipattavyam anyathā atha āpattiḥ na pravarteta samānam ca etat abhāva pūrvikāyām api arthāpattau iti
translated: And this cognition of the external existence of Devadatta by the non-apprehension of him in the house, when he is alive, is also inference itself, because the pervasion is grasped earlier. It is like this: Devadatta, who is related to the external place, is related to life, and is not apprehended in the house, like Vishnu. And the relation to life of Devadatta should be understood by the proponent of presumption only through scripture, otherwise presumption would not operate. And this is the same in the case of presumption based on non-existence.

original: pramāṇapañcakābhāvenāpi jīvato devadattasya gṛhe 'sattvapratipattau bahirdeśasambandho 'numīyate / evamanyadapyudāharaṇamarthāpatteravinābhāvopadarśanena anumāna eva antarbhāvanīyam / tathotpattiṃ vinā anyathānupapatterupadarśayitumaśakyatvāditi /
analyzed: pramāṇa pañcaka abhāvena api jīvataḥ devadattasya gṛhe sattva pratipattau bahis deśa sambandhaḥ numīyate evam anyat api udāharaṇam arthāpatteḥ avinābhāva upadarśanena anumāne eva antar bhāvanīyam tathā utpattim vinā anyathā anupapatteḥ upadarśayitum aśakya tvāt iti
translated: And when the non-existence of Devadatta in the house is apprehended even by the absence of the five means of knowledge, the relation to the external place is inferred. In the same way, other examples of presumption should also be included in inference itself by showing invariable concomitance. Similarly, because it cannot be shown that origination is impossible without it.

original: atha virodhinaḥ sarpādervisphūrjanādiśabdaśravaṇād tadanumitau virodhinyeva nakulādau pratipattiḥ pramāṇāntaramiṣṭaṃ kaiścit / tadanumitānumānameva / vyāpteḥ pūrvameva grahaṇāt / prayogastu visphūrjanaśabdo bhujaṅgakāryo visphūrjanaśabdatvāt pūrvopalabdhaivaṃvidhavisphūrjanaśabdavat / evamanumitaḥ sarpaḥ sannihitena virodhinā tadvān / visphūrjanaśabdakartṛtvāt pūrvopalabdhaivaṃvidhāhivaditi /🔽sambhavasyānumāne 'ntarbhāvaḥ
analyzed: atha virodhinaḥ sarpa ādeḥ visphūrjana ādi śabda śravaṇāt tad anumitau virodhinī eva nakula ādau pratipattiḥ pramāṇa antaram iṣṭam kaiścid tad anumita anumānam eva vyāpteḥ pūrvam eva grahaṇāt prayogaḥ tu visphūrjana śabdaḥ bhujaṅga kāryaḥ visphūrjana śabda tvāt pūrva upalabdha evaṃvidha visphūrjana śabda vat  / evam anumitaḥ sarpaḥ sannihitena virodhinā tadvān visphūrjana śabda kartṛ tvāt pūrva upalabdha evaṃvidha ahi vat iti  sambhavasya anumāne ntarbhāvaḥ
translated: Now, some people hold that when there is a contradiction, as in the case of hearing the sound of thunder etc. of a snake, and in the inference of that, the cognition of the contradictory itself, as in the case of a mongoose etc., is accepted as a separate means of knowledge. That is an inference based on an inference, because the pervasion is grasped earlier. The argument is: the sound of thunder is the effect of a snake, because it is a sound of thunder, like the sound of thunder previously perceived in this way. In the same way, the snake, which is inferred, is the possessor of that, by the contradictory present, because it is the agent of the sound of thunder, like the snake previously perceived in this way.🔽Possibility is included in inference

original: sambhavo 'pyavinābhāvitvādanumānameva /PDhS
analyzed: sambhavaḥ pi avinābhāvi tvāt anumānam eva
translated: Possibility is also inference, because of the relation of invariable concomitance.

original: sambhavaḥ pramāṇāntaramiṣṭaṃ paraiḥ / tanniṣedhārthaṃ sambhavo 'pyavinābhāvitvādanumānameva iti vākyam / yatra hi sahasraṃ tatrāvaśyaṃ śataṃ sambhavatītyavinābhāvasya grahaṇāt / tathā ca sahasraṃ svasamudāyi śatavat sahasratvāt pūrvopalabdhasahasravat /
analyzed: sambhavaḥ pramāṇa antaram iṣṭam paraiḥ tad niṣedha artham sambhavaḥ u pi avinābhāvi tvāt anumānam eva iti vākyam yatra hi sahasram tatra avaśyam śatam sambhavati iti avinābhāvasya grahaṇāt tathā ca sahasram sva samudāyi śatavat sahasra tvāt pūrva upalabdha sahasra vat
translated: Existence is accepted by others as a separate means of knowledge. The statement Existence is also inference because of the relation of invariable concomitance is for the purpose of refuting that. Because the relation of invariable concomitance is grasped that where there is a thousand, there must be a hundred. And thus a thousand exists as a member of its own aggregate because of being a thousand, like a previously perceived thousand.

original: abhāvasyānumāne 'ntarbhāvaḥ
analyzed: abhāvasya anumāne ntarbhāvaḥ
translated: Inclusion of non-existence in inference

original: abhāvo 'pyanumānameva / yathā utpannaṃ kāryaṃ kāraṇasadbhāve liṅgam / evamanutpannaṃ kāryaṃ kāraṇāsadbhāve liṅgam /PDhS
analyzed: abhāvaḥ pi anumānam eva yathā utpannam kāryam kāraṇa sadbhāve liṅgam evam anutpannam kāryam kāraṇa asadbhāve liṅgam
translated: Non-existence is also inference. Just as an arisen effect is the reason for the existence of its cause, in the same way a non-arisen effect is the reason for the non-existence of its cause.

original: kāryānutpādena kāraṇābhāvaḥ pratīyata ityabhāvarūpatayaiva pramāṇāntaramiti kecit / tanniṣedhārthaṃ na paraṃ sambhavaḥ abhāvo 'pyanumānameva iti / yathā utpannaṃ kāryaṃ kāraṇasadbhāve liṅgam avinābhāvasya pūrvameva grahaṇāt / tathā anutpannaṃ kāryaṃ kāraṇāsadbhāve kāryānutpādasya kāraṇābhāvenāvyabhicārāt / tathā ca kāryānutpattiḥ kāraṇābhāvavatī kāryānutpattitvād ubhayābhimatakāryānutpattivat /
analyzed: kārya anutpādena kāraṇa abhāvaḥ pratīyate iti abhāva rūpatayā eva pramāṇa antaram iti kecid tad niṣedha artham na param sambhavaḥ abhāvaḥ pi anumānam eva iti yathā utpannam kāryam kāraṇa sadbhāve liṅgam avinābhāvasya pūrvam eva grahaṇāt tathā anutpannam kāryam kāraṇa asadbhāve kārya anutpādasya kāraṇa abhāvena avyabhicārāt tathā ca kārya anutpattiḥ kāraṇa abhāvavatī kārya anutpatti tvāt ubhaya abhimata kārya anutpatti vat
translated: Some say that the non-existence of a cause is inferred from the non-production of an effect, and that the cognition of non-existence is a separate means of knowledge. To refute that, it is said that non-existence is also inference, not a separate means of knowledge. Just as a produced effect is the mark of the existence of a cause, because the invariable concomitance has been grasped before, similarly an unproduced effect is the mark of the non-existence of a cause, because the non-production of an effect is invariably concomitant with the absence of a cause. And thus the non-production of an effect has the absence of a cause, because it is the non-production of an effect, like the non-production of an effect accepted by both parties.

original: atha sadupalambhakapramāṇapañcakavyāvṛttyā vastuno 'bhāvasya grahaṇamiti pramāṇāntaramabhāvaḥ / yathā hi / bhāvāṃśaparicchede bhāvasya vyāpārastathā tadabhāvaparicchede abhāvasyāpyabhyupagantavyaḥ / taduktam /
analyzed: atha sat upalambhaka pramāṇa pañcaka vyāvṛttyā vastunaḥ bhāvasya grahaṇam iti pramāṇa antaram abhāvaḥ yathā hi bhāva aṃśa paricchede bhāvasya vyāpāraḥ tathā tad abhāva paricchede abhāvasya api abhyupagantavyaḥ tat uktam
translated: If it is argued that the cognition of the non-existence of an object is by the exclusion of the five means of knowing existent objects, and that non-existence is a separate means of knowledge, then just as the existence of an object operates in the determination of the existent part, similarly the operation of non-existence should be accepted in the determination of the absence of that. As it is said:

original: pratyakṣādyavatārastu bhāvāṃśo grahyate yadā /
analyzed: pratyakṣa ādi avatāraḥ tu bhāva aṃśaḥ grahyate yadā
translated: When the existent part is grasped by perception etc.,

original: vyāpārastadabhāvasyāpyabhāvāṃśe jighṛkṣate // ślo / vā / pṛ /
analyzed: vyāpāraḥ tad abhāvasya api abhāva aṃśe jighṛkṣate ślo vā pṛ
translated: The operation of that [perception] desires to grasp the part of non-existence of the absence [of the object].

original: tathā hi / na pratyakṣeṇābhāvasya grahaṇam / tena sambandhābhāvāt /
analyzed: tathā hi na pratyakṣeṇa abhāvasya grahaṇam tena sambandha abhāvāt
translated: Thus, absence is not apprehended by perception, because there is no relation [between perception and absence].

original: sambaddhaṃ vartamānañca gṛhyate cakṣurādinā / ślo / vā / pṛ /
analyzed: sambaddham vartamānam ca gṛhyate cakṣuḥ ādinā ślaḥ vā pṛ
translated: What is related and present is apprehended by the eye and other [sense organs].

original: pratyakṣābhāvādanumānasyāpyapravṛttiḥ / tasya sambandhigrahaṇāpekṣitvāt / evaṃ śabdasyāpi / upamānārthāpattyoścāvyāpārāt pramāṇapañcakābhāvenaiva prameyābhāvasya grahaṇamiti / taduktam /
analyzed: pratyakṣa abhāvāt anumānasya api apravṛttiḥ tasya sambandhi grahaṇa apekṣi tvāt evam śabdasya api upamāna arthāpattyoḥ ca avyāpārāt pramāṇa pañcaka abhāvena eva prameya abhāvasya grahaṇam iti tat uktam
translated: Because there is no perception, inference also does not operate, because it requires the apprehension of what is related. The same applies to verbal testimony. Since comparison and presumption do not operate, the absence of the object is apprehended only by the absence of the five means of valid knowledge. This is stated:

original: pramāṇapañcakaṃ yatra vasturūpe na jāyate /
analyzed: pramāṇa pañcakam yatra vastu rūpe na jāyate
translated: Where the five means of valid knowledge do not arise regarding the form of an object,

original: vastusattāvabodhārthaṃ tatrābhāvapramāṇatā // ślo / vā / pṛ /
analyzed: vastu sattā avabodha artham tatra abhāva pramāṇa tā
translated: the absence of the object is the means of valid knowledge for understanding the existence of the object.

original: nanvevaṃ tarhi vyavahite 'pyarthe pramāṇapañcakavyāvṛtteḥ sadbhāvādabhāvagrahaṇaprasaṅgaḥ / na / vastugrahaṇapratiyogismaraṇāderapi vyāpārāt / taduktam /
analyzed: nanu evam tarhi vyavahite pi arthe pramāṇa pañcaka vyāvṛtteḥ sadbhāvāt abhāva grahaṇa prasaṅgaḥ na vastu grahaṇa pratiyogi smaraṇa ādeḥ api vyāpārāt tat uktam
translated: If it is so, then there would be the apprehension of absence even when the object is distant, because the five means of valid knowledge are excluded. No, because the operation of remembering and so on, which are the counter-correlates of apprehending the object, is also [necessary]. This is stated:

original: gṛhītvā vastusadbhāvaṃ smṛtvā ca pratiyoginam /
analyzed: gṛhītvā vastu sadbhāvam smṛtvā ca pratiyoginam
translated: Having apprehended the existence of the object and remembered the counter-correlate,

original: mānasaṃ nāstitājñānaṃ jāyate 'kṣānapekṣayā // ślo / vā / pṛ /
analyzed: mānasam nāstitā jñānam jāyate kṣā an apekṣayā
translated: The mental cognition of non-existence arises without depending on the senses.

original: vastuno bhūtalādeḥ sadbhāvaṃ gṛhītvā pratiyoginaṃ ghaṭañca smṛtvā indriyavyāpāraṃ vinaiva manasā pratipadyate neha bhūtale ghaṭo 'stīti / tathā devakulaṃ dṛṣṭavā bahirnirgato hastinā deśāntaravyavadhānād indriyasambandhaṃ vināpi pareṇa pṛṣṭastadaiva hastinaḥ nāstitāṃ pratipadyate / taduktam /
analyzed: vastunaḥ bhū tala ādeḥ sadbhāvam gṛhītvā pratiyoginam ghaṭam ca smṛtvā indriya vyāpāram vinā eva manasā pratipadyate na iha bhū tale ghaṭaḥ sti iti tathā devakulam dṛṣṭavā bahis nirgataḥ hastinā deśa antara vyavadhānāt indriya sambandham vinā api pareṇa pṛṣṭaḥ tadā eva hastinaḥ nāstitām pratipadyate tat uktam
translated: Having grasped the existence of the object such as the ground, and remembering the counter-entity such as the pot, one understands by the mind alone without the operation of the senses that there is no pot on this ground. Similarly, having seen the temple and gone out, even without the connection with the senses due to the obstruction of the intervening space by the elephant, one immediately understands the non-existence of the elephant when asked by another. It is said:

original: vastumātraṃ gṛhītvāpi paścāt kiñcit smarannapi /
analyzed: vastu mātram gṛhītvā api paścāt kiñcid smaran api
translated: Even by grasping the mere object, and later remembering something,

original: tatrānyenāstitāṃ pṛṣṭastadaiva pratipadyate // ślo / vā / pṛ /
analyzed: tatra anyena astitām pṛṣṭaḥ tadā eva pratipadyate
translated: when asked about the existence of that by another, one understands it immediately.

original: tathā /
analyzed: tathā
translated: Similarly,

original: pratyakṣāderanutpattiḥ pramāṇābhāva ucyate /
analyzed: pratyakṣa ādeḥ anutpattiḥ pramāṇa abhāvaḥ ucyate
translated: The non-arising of perception etc. is said to be the absence of valid cognition.

original: sātmanaḥ pariṇāmo vā vijñānaṃ vānyavastunī // ślo / vā / pṛ /
analyzed: sa ātmanaḥ pariṇāmaḥ vā vijñānam vā anya vastunī
translated: Or it is the transformation of the self, or consciousness in another object.

original: sarvametadasat / pratyakṣādinaiva abhāvasya pratīteḥ / tathā ca / akṣavyāpārād iha bhūtale ghaṭo nāstīti jñānam aparokṣamutpadyamānaṃ dṛṣṭam / atha indriyāṇāṃ bhūtalagrahaṇe vyāpāro nābhāva iti cet / na / bhūtalagrahaṇe pramāṇābhāvāt / viśeṣaṇasya hi pūrvaṃ grahaṇaṃ paścād viśeṣyasya / bhūtalañca viśeṣyamiti na tasya pūrvaṃ grahaṇe pramāṇamasti / upetyavādena tūcyate / yadi vastumātragrahaṇe sati pratiyogismaraṇaṃ ghaṭāvaruddhabhūtalopalambhe 'pi tatsmaraṇe nāstitājñānaprasaṅgaḥ / II / atha viśiṣṭavastugrahaṇe sati pratiyogismaraṇam / tarhi yena viśeṣaṇena viśiṣṭaṃ tad vastu pūrvaṃ pratipattavyamiti kim indriyādeva pratīyate / prāmāṇāntarād veti / indriyādeva pratipattyabhyupagame kathaṃ nābhāvaḥ pratyakṣaviṣayo viśiṣṭatāyāstadrūpatvāt / na cānumānādervyāpāre pramāṇamasti /
analyzed: sarvam etat asat pratyakṣa ādinā eva abhāvasya pratīteḥ tathā ca akṣa vyāpārāt iha bhū tale ghaṭaḥ na asti iti jñānam aparokṣam utpadyamānam dṛṣṭam atha indriyāṇām bhū tala grahaṇe vyāpāraḥ na abhāvaḥ iti ced na bhū tala grahaṇe pramāṇa abhāvāt viśeṣaṇasya hi pūrvam grahaṇam paścāt viśeṣyasya bhū talam ca viśeṣyam iti na tasya pūrvam grahaṇe pramāṇam asti upetyavādena tu ucyate yadi vastu mātra grahaṇe sati pratiyogi smaraṇam
translated: All this is false, because absence is cognized only by perception etc. And thus, the knowledge that there is no pot here on the ground arises from the operation of the senses, and is seen to arise as non-manifest. If it is argued that the senses operate in apprehending the ground, not in absence, it is not so, because there is no means of knowing the ground. For the qualifier is apprehended first, and then the qualified. And since the ground is the qualified, there is no means of knowing its prior apprehension. But it is said by the method of presumption. If, when only the mere object is apprehended, there is recollection of the counter-correlate, then even in the perception of the ground obstructed by the pot, there would be the cognition of absence, due to the recollection of the counter-correlate. If it is argued that when there is the apprehension of the qualified object, there is recollection of the counter-correlate, then it must be said that the object qualified by a particular qualifier must be cognized first. Is it cognized by the senses alone, or by another means of knowledge? If it is accepted that it is cognized by the senses alone, then how is it not cognized by the senses alone in the case of absence?

original: yadi ca anyayā pramāṇapañcakavyāvṛttyaiva viśiṣṭatā pratīyate / tatrāpyanyavastugrahaṇābhyupagame viśiṣṭatāgrahaṇamevābhyupeyamityanavasthā syāt / tasmādindriyeṇaiva itarapadārthaviviktaṃ bhūtalamupalabhya pratiyoginaṃ smaratītyabhyupagame ghaṭābhāvasya pratītatvād alaṃ pramāṇapañcakavyāvṛttyeti /
analyzed: yadi ca anyayā pramāṇa pañcaka vyāvṛttyā eva viśiṣṭa tā pratīyate tatra api anya vastu grahaṇa abhyupagame viśiṣṭa tā grahaṇam eva abhyupeyam iti anavasthā syāt tasmāt indriyeṇa eva itara padārtha viviktam bhū talam upalabhya pratiyoginam smarati iti abhyupagame ghaṭa abhāvasya pratīta tvāt alam pramāṇa pañcaka vyāvṛttyā iti
translated: And if distinction is apprehended by mere exclusion from the other five means of knowledge, then if the apprehension of other objects is admitted, the apprehension of distinction itself must be admitted, so there would be an infinite regress. Therefore, when it is admitted that the ground is perceived by the sense organ as distinguished from other objects, and one remembers the counter-correlate, since the absence of pot is cognized, it is enough to say that it is excluded from the five means of knowledge.

original: sadaṃśaprakāśakasyaiva asadaṃśe 'pyanvayavyatirekābhyāṃ vyāpāropalabdherna pramāṇapañcakāparicchedya vastuni abhāvasya pramāṇateti vācyam / na cendriyeṇa sambandhābhāvādagrahaṇam / tasya kāryeṇaiva sadbhāvasiddheḥ / tathā ca pareṇāpi aparokṣajñānasadbhāvena indriyārthayoryogyatālakṣaṇaḥ sambandho 'bhyupagataḥ / sa ca rūpādāvivābhāve 'pyabhyupagantavyaḥ / kāryasyobhayatrāviśeṣāt tathā vaiśeṣikairapi aparokṣajñānasadbhāvena indriyārthayoḥ ṣoḍhā sambandho 'bhyupagata ityabhāvena viśeṣaṇaviśeṣyabhāvo 'styeva / tena hi satā aparokṣajñānotpatteḥ /
analyzed: sat aṃśa prakāśakasya eva asat aṃśe pi anvaya vyatirekābhyām vyāpāra upalabdheḥ na vastuni abhāvasya pramāṇa tā iti vācyam na ca indriyeṇa sambandha abhāvāt agrahaṇam tasya kāryeṇa eva sadbhāva siddheḥ tathā ca pareṇa api aparokṣa jñāna sadbhāvena indriya arthayoḥ yogyatā lakṣaṇaḥ sambandhaḥ bhyupagataḥ sa ca rūpa ādau iva abhāve pi abhyupagantavyaḥ kāryasya ubhayatra aviśeṣāt tathā vaiśeṣikaiḥ api aparokṣa jñāna sadbhāvena indriya a
translated: It cannot be said that in a thing that is not apprehended by the five means of knowledge, the absence is not a means of knowledge, because the functioning of the means of knowledge is observed even in the non-existent part by the method of agreement and difference of the revealer of the existent part. And it is not that it is not apprehended due to the absence of connection with the sense organ, because its existence is established by the effect itself. And thus, by the other party also, the relation characterized by fitness between the sense organ and the object is accepted by the existence of non-perceptual knowledge. And that should be accepted even in the absence, just as in color etc., because the effect is the same in both cases. Thus, even by the Vaiśeṣikas, the sixfold relation between the sense organ and the object is accepted by the existence of non-perceptual knowledge. Therefore, the relation of qualifier and qualified certainly exists with the absence. Because the non-perceptual knowledge arises from that.
