original: sadupalambhakapramāṇapañcakavyāvṛttyā tu abhāvagrahaṇe kathaṃ ṣaḍeva pramāṇānītyavadhāraṇam / pramāṇāgrahe tasyānupapatteḥ / na hi sadupalambhakapramāṇābhāvasya paricchedyatve anyat tasya paricchedakaṃ pramāṇamasti / atha pramāṇapañcakābhāvasyānekatvāt kaścit kasyacid grāhako bhavati / evaṃ tarhi tasyāpyanyena grahaṇaṃ tasyāpyanenetyanavasthā syāt / na ca pramāṇavyakteranekatvāt tadagrahaṇe tanniṣṭhasya ṣaḍevetyavadhāraṇasya sambhavaḥ syāt / vaiśeṣikāṇāntu pramāṇavyaktīnāmānantye 'pi ekaṃ lakṣaṇamupagrāhakamastīti yuktaṃ pramāṇagrahaṇe satyavadhāraṇamiti /
analyzed: sat upalambhaka pramāṇa pañcaka vyāvṛttyā tu abhāva grahaṇe katham ṣaḍ eva pramāṇāni iti avadhāraṇam pramāṇa agrahe tasya anupapatteḥ na hi sat upalambhaka pramāṇa abhāvasya paricchedya tve anyat tasya paricchedakam pramāṇam asti atha pramāṇa pañcaka abhāvasya aneka tvāt kaścid kasyacid grāhakaḥ bhavati evam tarhi tasya api anyena grahaṇam tasya api anena iti anavasthā syāt na ca pramāṇa vyakteḥ aneka tvāt tad agrahaṇe tad niṣṭhasya ṣaṣ eva it
translated: But when the apprehension of non-existence is by the exclusion of the five means of valid knowledge that apprehend existence, how can there be a restriction to only six means of valid knowledge? Because that is not possible when the means of valid knowledge are not apprehended. For when the absence of the means of valid knowledge that apprehend existence is to be delimited, there is no other means of valid knowledge that delimits it. If it is argued that since the absence of the five means of valid knowledge is manifold, some may be the apprehender of some, then in that case, there would be an infinite regress, as its apprehension would be by another, and that by another. And when the individual means of valid knowledge are manifold, it would not be possible for the restriction to only six to apply to that which is based on them, when they are not apprehended. But for the Vaiśeṣikas, even though the individual means of valid knowledge are infinite, there is a single characteristic that apprehends them, so it is proper to restrict them when the means of valid knowledge are apprehended.

original: yaccedaṃ devakulamātraṃ dṛṣṭavā niṣkrānto 'nyena pṛṣṭastadaiva hastyādernāstitā pratipadyata ityuktam / tanna / asya smaraṇatvāt / yadyapi pūrvaṃ hastītyādi savikalpakaṃ jñānaṃ notpannam / tathāpi hastyādyabhāvaviśiṣṭe devakule nirviII /kalpakaṃ jñānamutpannam / anyathā hi yadāhaṃ devakulamadrākṣam / na tadā taṃ samīpavartinaṃ hastinamiti praśnānantaraṃ smaraṇaṃ na syāt / tattu dṛṣṭam / yasya vastunaḥ pūrvaṃ nābhāvaḥ paricchinnastatra parapraśnānantaraṃ saṃśete / na nirīkṣitaṃ mayā kiṃ tatra devadatto 'sti uta nāstīti / na cedānīmabhāvaṃ niścinoti āgamasyāpi pramāṇāntareṇārthatathābhāvapratipattiḥ / nāptopadeśena kadācit sambhavāt / ataḥ pūrvameva hastyādyabhāvasya pratīteryuktametat smaraṇaṃ na mayā tatra hastī dṛṣṭa ityādi / abhāvasya ca prameyatvaṃ kṣaṇabhaṅgāvasare vyavasthāpitameveti /
analyzed: yat ca idam devakula mātram dṛṣṭavā niṣkrāntaḥ nyena pṛṣṭaḥ tadā eva hasti ādeḥ nāstitā pratipadyate iti uktam tat na asya smaraṇa tvāt yadi api pūrvam hasti ityādi sa vikalpakam jñānam na utpannam tathā api hasti ādi abhāva viśiṣṭe devakule jñānam utpannam anyathā hi yadā aham devakulam adrākṣam na tadā tam samīpa vartinam hastinam iti praśna anantaram smaraṇam na syāt tat tu dṛṣṭam yasya vastunaḥ pūrvam na abhāvaḥ paricchinnaḥ tatra par
translated: And it has been said that when one comes out of the temple having seen only the temple, and is asked by another, he immediately understands the non-existence of the elephant etc. That is not so, because this is a recollection. Even though the determinate cognition beginning with 'elephant' was not produced before, still a non-determinate cognition was produced in the temple qualified by the absence of elephant etc. Otherwise, if one were to say 'when I saw the temple, I did not see the elephant nearby', there would be no recollection after the question. But that is seen. For one who has not previously ascertained the absence of an object, there is doubt after the question by another: 'Did I not see whether Devadatta is there or not?' And if one does not ascertain the absence now, the scripture also ascertains the existence of the object in that way by another means of knowledge, not by the instruction of a reliable person, because it is sometimes possible. Therefore, it is proper that this is a recollection, because the absence of elephant etc. was already understood.

original: aitihyasyāptopadeśatvakathanam
analyzed: aitihyasya āpta upadeśa tva kathanam
translated: Explanation of the trustworthiness of tradition

original: tathaitihyamapyavitathamāptopadeśa eveti /PDhS
analyzed: tathā aitihyam api avitatham āpta upadeśaḥ eva iti
translated: Similarly, tradition is also an untruthful instruction of a trustworthy person.

original: atha anirdiṣṭapravaktṛkaṃ pravādapāramparyaṃ yathā iha vaṭe yakṣaḥ prativasatīti / asyāpi yadi pramāṇāntareṇa arthatathābhāvapratipattirna āptopadeśādarthāntaratvamityāha tathaitihyamavitathamāptopadeśa eva / tathā hi pūrvapramāṇāni nārthāntaram / tathā aitihyamapi avitathaṃ yathārthamāptopadeśa eva / na pramāṇāntaram / viparyaye tu aprāmāṇyamiti /
analyzed: atha anirdiṣṭa pravaktṛkam pravāda pāramparyam yathā iha vaṭe yakṣaḥ prativasati iti asya api yadi pramāṇa antareṇa artha tathābhāva pratipattiḥ na āpta upadeśāt artha antara tvam iti āha tathā aitihyam avitatham āpta upadeśaḥ eva tathā hi pūrva pramāṇāni na artha antaram tathā aitihyam api avitatham yathārtham āpta upadeśaḥ eva na pramāṇa antaram viparyaye tu aprāmāṇyam iti
translated: Now, a tradition of doubtful origin is like the saying that a yaksha dwells in this fig tree. If the truth of this is not established by another means of knowledge, it is different from the instruction of a trustworthy person. Therefore, he says: Similarly, tradition is an untruthful instruction of a trustworthy person. For example, the previous means of knowledge are not different from the instruction of a trustworthy person. Similarly, tradition is also an untruthful, true instruction of a trustworthy person. It is not a different means of knowledge. But if it is the opposite, it is not a means of valid knowledge.

original: pañcāvayavena vākyena svaniścitārthapratipādanaṃ parārthānumānam / pañcāvayavenaiva vākyena saṃśayitaviparyastāvyutpannānāṃ pareṣāṃ svaniścitārthapratipādanaṃ parārthānumānaṃ vijñeyam /PDhS
analyzed: pañca avayavena vākyena sva niścita artha pratipādanam para artha anumānam pañca avayavena eva vākyena saṃśayita viparyasta avyutpannānām pareṣām sva niścita artha pratipādanam para artha anumānam vijñeyam pdhs
translated: Inference for the sake of others is the communication of one's own ascertained meaning by a statement with five parts. Inference for the sake of others should be understood as the communication of one's own ascertained meaning to others who are doubtful, mistaken, or ignorant by a statement with five parts.

original: atha prāk sūcitasya parārthānumānasya vyākaraṇārthaṃ pañcāvayavena ityādi prakaraṇam / parārthānumitiriti lakṣyanirdeśaḥ / pañcāvayavena vākyena svaniścitārthapratipādanam iti lakṣaṇam / svaniścitārthaḥ sādhyaḥ / pratipādyate 'neneti svaniścitārthapratipādanaṃ liṅgam / tat pañcāvayavena vākyena sahitaṃ parārthamanumānam / pratipattirvā pratipādanam / svaniścitārthaviṣayaṃ jñānaṃ pañcāvayavena vākyena janitam / yataḥ kārakasamūhād bhavati tat parārthānumānamiti sādhyārthavākyārthavādinā vyākhyānam / liṅgavākyārthapakṣe tu arthyate 'nenetyartho liṅgam / pratipādyata iti pratipādanam / pañcāvayavena vākyena pratipādyamānaṃ liṅgaṃ parārthānumānamiti / yadvā svaniścitārthapratipattiḥ pratipādanam / tacca pañcāvayavena vākyena janitaṃ parārthānumānamiti /
analyzed: atha prāk sūcitasya parārtha anumānasya vyākaraṇa artham pañcāvayavena ityādi prakaraṇam parārthā anumitiḥ iti lakṣya nirdeśaḥ pañcāvayavena vākyena sva niścita artha pratipādanam iti lakṣaṇam sva niścita arthaḥ sādhyaḥ pratipādyate nena iti sva niścita artha pratipādanam liṅgam tat pañcāvayavena vākyena sahitam parārtham anumānam pratipattiḥ vā pratipādanam sva niścita artha viṣayam jñānam pañcāvayavena vākyena janitam yatas kāraka samūhāt bhava
translated: Now, in order to explain inference for others, which was indicated earlier, the section begins with consisting of five parts, etc. Inference for others is the statement of the object to be inferred. The definition is: The communication of one's own ascertained object by a statement consisting of five parts. The object to be inferred is the probandum. Communication means that by which it is communicated. The communication of one's own ascertained object is the logical mark. That, along with a statement consisting of five parts, is inference for others. Or, communication means the knowledge generated by a statement consisting of five parts, which has as its object one's own ascertained object. That from which it arises, from a collection of causal factors, is inference for others. This is the explanation of the proponent of the statement meaning the object to be inferred. But in the case of the statement meaning the logical mark, the logical mark is that by which the object is sought, and communication is the communication. The logical mark being communicated by a statement consisting of five parts is inference for others. Or, the communication is the ascertainment of one's own ascertained object.

original: nanvetasmin pakṣe kathaṃ svārthād viśiṣyate parārthānumānam / cakṣurādinā śabdena vā liṅgaṃ pratipadya tasmāt sādhyaṃ pratipadyata iti kutaḥ svārthaparārtha iti bhedaḥ / na ca parasampāditācchabdālliṅgaṃ pratipadyata iti viśeṣaḥ / cakṣurāderapi parasampāditatvāt śabdarūpatāvailakṣaṇyantu vaidharmyamātrameva / ataḥ sādhyavākyārthapakṣo doṣānupapattera /grāhya iti / tathā ca kevalaṃ liṅgaṃ cakṣurādinā pratipannaṃ sādhyapratipattau svārthānumānamaśabdasahitam / śabdasahitantu parārthānumānamiti viśeṣaḥ / tasmādityanena samarthaliṅgaparāmarśānantaram anitya evāyam iti sādhyapratipatteḥ saṃvedanācca sādhyameva vākyārthaḥ / tasmādityevamantameva vākyam / śeṣañca abhiprāyanivedanamiti / na tvārtham / sādhyavākyārthapakṣe bādhakānupapatterityalamativistareṇa /
analyzed: nanu etasmin pakṣe katham svārthāt viśiṣyate parārtha anumānam cakṣuḥ ādinā śabdena vā liṅgam pratipadya tasmāt sādhyam pratipadyate iti kutas svārtha parārthaḥ iti bhedaḥ na ca para sampāditāt śabdāt liṅgam pratipadyate iti viśeṣaḥ cakṣuḥ ādeḥ api para sampādita tvāt śabda rūpatā vailakṣaṇyam tu vaidharmya mātram eva atas sādhya vākya artha pakṣaḥ doṣa anupapatteḥ agrāhyaḥ iti tathā ca kevalam liṅgam cakṣuḥ ādinā pratipannam sād
translated: If this is the case, how is inference for others distinguished from inference for oneself? One understands the conclusion from the reason, whether through the eyes or through words. How then is there a distinction between inference for oneself and for others? And it is not the case that one understands the reason from the words produced by another. The difference is merely in the absence of similarity, as the eyes etc. are also produced by another. Therefore, the conclusion is to be understood from the statement of the reason, because the faults are not possible in the statement of the conclusion. Thus, when the mere reason is understood through the eyes etc., and the conclusion is understood, it is inference for oneself, not accompanied by words. But when accompanied by words, it is inference for others. This is the distinction. Therefore, by the word tasmāt, the understanding of the conclusion anitya eva ayam is indicated immediately after the comprehension of the valid reason. And because this is experienced, the conclusion alone is the meaning of the sentence. Therefore, the sentence ends with tasmāt. The rest is merely to convey the intention, not the meaning.

original: pūrvasya saṅgrahavākyasya vivaraṇam pañcāvayavenaiva vākyena / na dvyavayavena daśāvayavena veti / keṣām / saṃśayitaviparītā /ryastāvyutpannānām svaniścitārthapratipādanaṃ parārthānumānaṃ vijñeyam /
analyzed: pūrvasya saṅgraha vākyasya vivaraṇam pañca avayavena eva vākyena na dvi avayavena daśa avayavena vā iti keṣām saṃśayita viparīta āryasta avyutpannānām sva niścita artha pratipādanam para artha anumānam vijñeyam
translated: The explanation of the summary statement of the previous [verse] is that [inference for others] should be known as a statement with five parts, not with two parts or ten parts. For whom? For those who are doubtful, mistaken, uncertain, and unlearned. The statement of one's own ascertained meaning is to be known as inference for others.

original: atha niravayavatvād vākyasyānupapannametat pañcāvayaveneti / tathā ca varṇānāṃ na samuditānāmarthapratipādakatvam / kramabhāvināmāśuvināśitvena samudāyāsambhavāt / na vyastānām / ekasmādevārthapratītāvanyeṣāmuccāraṇavaiyarthyāt / upalabhyate ca śabdād uccaritārthapratipattiḥ / atastadanyathānupapattyā varṇakalāpādatiricyamānaḥ sphoṭātmā pratīyata iti / tathā gauriti śabdoccāraṇād abhinnākāraṃ vijñānaṃ śrotravyāpārādutpadyamānaṃ dṛṣṭam / na cedaṃ saṃśayaviparyayavyatirekādavayavijñānavad abhinnamarthaṃ vinā bhavatīti / varṇoccāraṇantu sphoṭasvarūpābhivyaktaye kriyata iti na vyartham /
analyzed: atha niravayava tvāt vākyasya anupapannam etat pañca avayavena iti  tathā ca varṇānām na samuditānām artha pratipādaka tvam krama bhāvinām āśu vināśi tvena samudāya asambhavāt  na vyastānām ekasmāt eva artha pratītau anyeṣām uccāraṇa vaiyarthyāt upalabhyate ca śabdāt uccarita artha pratipattiḥ atas tad anyathā anupapattyā varṇa kalāpāt atiricyamānaḥ sphoṭa ātmā pratīyate iti tathā gauḥ iti śabda uccāraṇāt abhinna ākāram vijñānam śrotra vyāpārā
translated: If it be urged that, on account of the sentence being indivisible, the division into five parts is impossible, and as such, the sentence cannot be expressive of meaning, and hence the letters also cannot be expressive of meaning, because they are not capable of being combined, being destroyed as soon as produced, nor can the individual letters be expressive, because if the meaning were expressed by any one of them, the utterance of the rest would be useless. And yet we find that the meaning is comprehended from the word, therefore, it is concluded that the sphoṭa is the essence of the word, which is something different from the letters, and is manifested by them. Similarly, when the word ‘cow’ is uttered, we find that the cognition that arises is of the same form as the word, and is produced by the operation of the ear; and this cannot be either doubtful or wrong, like the cognition of the ‘man with the stick’ (which is different from the stick), and hence it must be of the same form as the word. The utterance of the letters is for the purpose of manifesting the sphoṭa, and is not useless.

original: asadetat / pūrvavarṇānugṛhītasyāntyavarṇasya svānubhavasahakāriṇo 'rthapratipādakatvāt / yathā ca / ekasmin varṇe jñānam / tena kriyate saṃskāraḥ / punardvitīyavarṇajñānam / tenāpi pūrvavarṇasaṃskārasahakāriṇā saṃskāra iti krameṇa antyavarṇajñānam / tasmāt pūrvasaṃskārābhivyaktāvaśeṣavarṇānusmaraṇe sati antyavarṇādarthapratipattiḥ / na caivaṃ ghaṭādyanubhavajanitasaṃskārasya anubhavāntarasahakāriṇaḥ saṃskārārambhakatvenātiprasaṅgaḥ / tatra viśiṣṭādṛṣṭābhāvāt / tadabhāvastu kāryāII /bhāvenaiva jñāyata iti / atra ca kāryasya sadbhāvād viśiṣṭo 'dṛṣṭaḥ kāraṇatvena kalpyata iti /
analyzed: asat etat pūrva varṇa anugṛhītasya antya varṇasya sva anubhava sahakāriṇaḥ rtha pratipādaka tvāt yathā ca ekasmin varṇe jñānam tena kriyate saṃskāraḥ punar dvitīya varṇa jñānam tena api pūrva varṇa saṃskāra sahakāriṇā saṃskāraḥ iti krameṇa antya varṇa jñānam tasmāt pūrva saṃskāra abhivyakta avaśeṣa varṇa anusmaraṇe sati antya varṇāt artha pratipattiḥ na ca evam ghaṭa ādi anubhava janita saṃskārasya anubhava antara sahakāriṇaḥ sa
translated: This is not so. Because the final letter, aided by the preceding letters and its own experience, conveys the meaning. And just as there is cognition of a single letter, by that an impression is produced. Again, the cognition of the second letter, by that also aided by the impression of the preceding letter, an impression is produced. Thus in sequence, there is cognition of the final letter. Therefore, from the manifestation of the previous impressions and the recollection of the remaining letters, the meaning is understood from the final letter. And thus there is no over-extension in the impression produced by the experience of a pot, etc., being the cause of another experience, because there is no specific unseen [result] there. And that absence is known only by the presence of the effect. And here, because the effect exists, a specific unseen [result] is imagined as the cause.

original: anye tu śabdārthopabhogaprāpakādṛṣṭaniyamitāḥ pūrvavarṇānubhavajanitasaṃskārāḥ pūrvavarṇeṣvekaṃ smaraṇamārabhante tatsahakārī cāntyo varṇaḥ padam / yadvā saṃskāramekaṃ vicitramārabhante / tasmācca pūrvavarṇeṣvekaṃ smaraṇamiti /
analyzed: anye tu śabda artha upabhoga prāpaka adṛṣṭa niyamitāḥ pūrva varṇa anubhava janita saṃskārāḥ pūrva varṇeṣu ekam smaraṇam ārabhante tad sahakārī ca antyaḥ varṇaḥ padam yat vā saṃskāram ekam vicitram ārabhante tasmāt ca pūrva varṇeṣu ekam smaraṇam iti
translated: Others (say that) the impressions produced by the experience of the preceding letters, which are regulated by the unseen force that brings about the enjoyment of the meaning of the word, give rise to a single recollection of the preceding letters. And the final letter, which is a contributory cause of that, is the word. Or (they say that) they produce a single variegated impression, and from that arises a single recollection of the preceding letters.

original: anye tu pūrvavarṇānāṃ tajjñānānāñca atītānāmapi antyavarṇasahakāritvam / anvayavyatirekopapatteḥ / yathā hi / vartamānasya kāraṇatvam anvayavyatirekābhyāṃ vijñātam / evamatītasyāpīti / yad vā pūrvavarṇavināśāstajjñānapradhvaṃsāśca samīpavartino 'ntyavarṇasahakāriṇa iti kṣīṇārthāpattiḥ / evaṃvidhakalpanānabhyupagame ca varṇoccāraṇavaiyarthyameva syāt / na ca sphoṭābhivyakta /ñjakamuccāraṇam / samastavyastavikalpānupapatteḥ / na samastairabhivyajyate / samudāyānabhyupagamāt / na vyastaiḥ / ekenaivābhivyaktau śeṣoccāraṇavaiyarthyaprasaṅgāt / atha kalpanā āśrīyate / sā arthapratipattāvapi samarthetyalaṃ sphoṭaparikalpanayā / abhinnākārañca jñānamantyavarṇaviṣayaṃ varṇatvaviṣayaṃ vā /
analyzed: anye tu pūrva varṇānām tad jñānānām ca atītānām api antya varṇa sahakāri tvam anvaya vyatireka upapatteḥ yathā hi vartamānasya kāraṇa tvam anvaya vyatirekābhyām vijñātam evam atītasya api iti yat vā pūrva varṇa vināśāḥ tad jñāna pradhvaṃsāḥ ca samīpa vartinaḥ ntya varṇa sahakāriṇaḥ iti kṣīṇa arthāpattiḥ evaṃvidha kalpanā anabhyupagame ca varṇa uccāraṇa vaiyarthyam eva syāt na ca sphoṭa abhivyakta añjakam uccāraṇam samasta vyasta vi
translated: Others, however, maintain that the past letters and their cognitions also assist the final letter, because of the possibility of positive and negative concomitance. Just as the present is known to be the cause by positive and negative concomitance, so also is the past. Or, the destruction of the previous letters and their cognitions, which are nearby, assist the final letter. Thus, the presumption of meaning is exhausted. And if such a hypothesis is not accepted, the utterance of the letters would be pointless. And the utterance does not manifest the sphoṭa, because the alternatives of the whole and the parts being manifested are not possible. It is not manifested by the whole, because the collection is not accepted. Nor by the parts, because if it is manifested by one alone, the utterance of the rest would be pointless. If a hypothesis is accepted, it is capable of conveying the meaning also. So, there is no need to assume the sphoṭa. And the cognition having an undifferentiated form is either about the final letter or about the letterhood.

original: yad vā ghanāvasthitipratyakṣeṣviva varṇeṣu bhrāntamabhinnākāraṃ vijñānamiti na sphoṭasiddhiḥ / śabdābhivyaktāviva sphoṭābhivyaktāvapi doṣā iti samānatayā śabdaparīkṣāyāmevābhidhāsyanta ityalam /
analyzed: yat vā ghana avasthiti pratyakṣeṣu iva varṇeṣu bhrāntam abhinna ākāram vijñānam iti na sphoṭa siddhiḥ śabda abhivyaktau iva sphoṭa abhivyaktau api doṣāḥ iti samāna tayā śabda parīkṣāyām eva abhidhāsyante iti alam
translated: Or, the cognition of the letters, like the cognition of the presence of the cloth, is erroneous, having an undifferentiated form; thus there is no establishment of the sphoṭa. And as in the case of the manifestation of the word, so also in the case of the manifestation of the sphoṭa, the objections are the same; so they will be stated in the chapter on the examination of sound. Thus far is enough.

original: vākyakalpanā tvekasmin pade jñānasyotpādaḥ / saṃskārasya saṅketasmaraṇasya ca utpadyamānatā / tataḥ saṃskārasya saṅketasmaraṇasya ca utpādaḥ / padārthapratipatterutpadyamānatā / padajñānasya vinaśyattā / tataḥ padārthapratipatterutpattiḥ / smaraṇasya vinaśyattā / padajñānasya vināśaḥ / saṃskārasya dvitīyapadajñānasya ca utpadyamānatā / tato dvitīyapadajñānasyotpādaḥ / pūrvasaṃskārasacivena padārthajñānena saṃskārasyotpādaḥ / saṃskārāntarasyotpadyamānatā saṅketasmaraṇasyāpyutpadyamānatā / padārthapratipattevinaśyattā / pūrvasaṅketasmaraṇasya vināśaḥ / tato dvitīyapadajñānasaṃskārasyotpādaḥ saṅketasmaraṇasyāpyutpādaḥ / padajñānasya vinaśyattā / padārthapratipatterutpadyamānatā / pūrvapadārthapratipattervināśa ityayaṃ II / nyāyastāvad yāvadantyapade jñānam / tena ca kalpanayā tatsaṃskārābhivyakteraśeṣapadārthaviṣayaṃ smaraṇaṃ janyate / tena ca svānubhavena ca viśiṣṭamantyapadameva vākyam / tasmācca vākyārthapratipattiriti /
analyzed: vākya kalpanā tu ekasmin pade jñānasya utpādaḥ saṃskārasya saṅketa smaraṇasya ca utpadyamāna tā tatas saṃskārasya saṅketa smaraṇasya ca utpādaḥ padārtha pratipatteḥ utpadyamāna tā pada jñānasya vinaśyat tā tatas padārtha pratipatteḥ utpattiḥ smaraṇasya vinaśyat tā pada jñānasya vināśaḥ saṃskārasya dvitīya pada jñānasya ca utpadyamāna tā tatas dvitīya pada jñānasya utpādaḥ pūrva saṃskāra sacivena padārtha jñānena saṃskārasya utpāda
