original: nanu padajñānotpatteḥ pūrvam adṛṣṭavaśāt padapadārthaviṣayasmaraṇotpādābhyupagame tasya padajñānāt saṅketasmaraṇakāle nāvasthānamiti padārthapratipatterūrdhvaṃ kathaṃ vākyārthapratipattiḥ / na ca padārthapratipattiṃ vinaiva vākyārthapratipattiḥ / adarśanāt / atha padajñānādūrdhvaṃ kalpanayā tatsaṃskāreṇa smaraṇaṃ janyate tataḥ padajñānasya vinaśyatteti saṅketasmaraṇakāle tasyānavasthānāt padārthapratipattyabhāve na vākyārthapratipattiriti dūṣaṇaṃ tadavasthameva /
analyzed: nanu pada jñāna utpatteḥ pūrvam adṛṣṭa vaśāt pada padārtha viṣaya smaraṇa utpāda abhyupagame tasya pada jñānāt saṅketa smaraṇa kāle na avasthānam iti padārtha pratipatteḥ ūrdhvam katham vākya artha pratipattiḥ na ca padārtha pratipattim vinā eva vākya artha pratipattiḥ adarśanāt atha pada jñānāt ūrdhvam kalpanayā tad saṃskāreṇa smaraṇam janyate tatas pada jñānasya vinaśyat tā iti saṅketa smaraṇa kāle tasya anavasthānāt padārtha pratipatti ab
translated: “But before the appearance of the cognition of the word, the remembrance of the word and its denotation is brought about by the unseen potency; and this remembrance does not continue to exist at the time of the remembrance of the convention (relating to the word and its denotation); how then can there be any comprehension of the meaning of the sentence, after the comprehension of the meanings of the words? And yet, without the comprehension of the meaning of the words, there can be no comprehension of the meaning of the sentence; as nothing of the kind has ever been seen. If, on the other hand, the remembrance of the convention is brought about by the potency of the word-cognition, then, as the word-cognition would have ceased at the time of the remembrance of the convention, there would be no word-cognition present at the time of the comprehension of the meaning of the sentence; and in that case, there could be no comprehension of the meaning of the sentence, as the comprehension of the meaning of the word having ceased, there would be no comprehension of the meaning of the sentence.” (1313-1314) This criticism does not affect our position at all.

original: asadetat / vākye saṅketānupapatteḥ / antyapadaṃ vākyameva / tad antyārthastu vākyārtha iti / yadā ca pūrvavarṇatajjñānādūrdhvaṃ kalpanayā tatsaṃskāreṇa smaraṇaṃ janyate / tataḥ padajñānasya vinaśyatteti saṅketasmaraṇābhāvaviśiṣṭo 'ntyo vaṇaḥ padam / tadeṣā vākyakalpanā / anyathā pūrvavarṇeṣu jñānadvāreṇa saṃskārād vicitrasmaraṇānugṛhīto 'ntyo varṇaḥ padamityabhyupagamena padārthajñānānantaraṃ padajñānaṃ syāt / varṇajñānavyavadhānāt /
analyzed: asat etat vākye saṅketa anupapatteḥ antya padam vākyam eva tat antya arthaḥ tu vākya arthaḥ iti  yadā ca pūrva varṇa tad jñānāt ūrdhvam kalpanayā tad saṃskāreṇa smaraṇam janyate tatas pada jñānasya vinaśyat tā iti saṅketa smaraṇa abhāva viśiṣṭaḥ ntyaḥ vaṇaḥ padam tat eṣā vākya kalpanā anyathā pūrva varṇeṣu jñāna dvāreṇa saṃskārāt vicitra smaraṇa anugṛhītaḥ ntyaḥ varṇaḥ padam iti abhyupagamena padārtha jñāna anantaram pada
translated: This is not correct; because Convention cannot be made in regard to a sentence; the sentence itself consists of the last word; and the meaning of this last word is the meaning of the sentence. When, after the cognition of the preceding letters, the remembrance of the Convention is brought about by the ‘Impression’ left by that cognition, then the last letter, as qualified by the absence of the cognition of the word, constitutes the ‘word’; and this is what is called the ‘sentence’. If it were not so, then, in the case of the preceding letters, the remembrance would be brought about by the ‘impression’ left by the cognition of those letters, and the last letter would be the ‘word’, as helped by that remembrance; and in this case, the cognition of the last word would come after the cognition of the meaning of the preceding words; because the cognition of the last letter would be obstructed by the cognition of the meaning of the preceding words.

original: anye tu pūrvārthasya pratisamādhānārthamantyapadajñānānantaraṃ kalpanayā tatsaṃskāraḥ saṅketānubhavajanitasaṃskāraśca ekaṃ smaraṇamārabhate / tataḥ padārthajñānasyotpādaḥ / padajñānasya vinaśyattā / smaraṇānubhavayoścāvirodha iti / tataḥ smaraṇānubhavaviśiṣṭād antyapadād vākyārthapratipattiriti /🔽anye tu yadyapyantyapadajñānānantaraṃ saṅketasmaraṇāt padārthāvabodhe sati padajñānaṃ vinaṣṭam / tathāpi punastasminneva jñānamutpadyate / tataḥ kalpanayā tatsaṃskārāt smaraṇotpāde sati antyapadād vākyārthapratipattiriti /
analyzed: anye tu pūrva arthasya pratisamādhāna artham antya pada jñāna anantaram kalpanayā tad saṃskāraḥ saṅketa anubhava janita saṃskāraḥ ca ekam smaraṇam ārabhate tatas padārtha jñānasya utpādaḥ pada jñānasya vinaśyat tā smaraṇa anubhavayoḥ ca avirodhaḥ iti tatas smaraṇa anubhava viśiṣṭāt antya padāt vākya artha pratipattiḥ iti  anye tu yadi api antya pada jñāna anantaram saṅketa smaraṇāt padārtha avabodhe sati pada jñānam vinaṣṭam tathā api punar tasmin eva jñānam utpadyate tatas kalpanayā tad saṃskārāt smaraṇa utpāde sati antya padāt vākya artha pratipattiḥ iti
translated: Others, however, say that in order to recollect the meaning of the previous word, after the cognition of the last word, a recollection is produced by the impression of that [recollection] and the impression produced by the experience of the convention. Then there is the production of the cognition of the meaning of the word, the destruction of the cognition of the word, and there is no contradiction between the recollection and the experience. Therefore, the understanding of the meaning of the sentence is from the last word, qualified by the recollection and the experience.🔽Others say that even though after the cognition of the last word, when the understanding of the meaning of the word is due to the recollection of the convention, the cognition of the word is destroyed, still that [cognition of the word] arises again. Then, from that, when the recollection is produced by the impression of that [cognition of the word] by imagination, the understanding of the meaning of the sentence is from the last word.

original: asadetat / śabdasya viramya vyāpārapratiṣedhāt / ekadā padaṃ svaviṣayajñānaṃ kṛtvā punarna karotīti /
analyzed: asat etat śabdasya viramya vyāpāra pratiṣedhāt ekadā padam sva viṣaya jñānam kṛtvā punar na karoti iti
translated: This is incorrect, because it is denied that a word operates after ceasing, that is, a word, having produced the cognition of its own meaning once, does not do so again.

original: anye tu pratijñādipadasya padāntaroccāraṇakāle 'pi ākāśe padāntarāmbhakatvenāvasthānaṃ tāvad yāvadantyapadam / tataḥ pañcabhiḥ padaiḥ śrotradeśe II / vākyam avayavibhūtamārabhyate / tato vākyārthapratipattiriti / nirastañcaitad anubhavena / na hi pūrvapūrvapadasyottarottarapadakāle sarveṣāñca vākyakāle 'nubhavo 'stīti /
analyzed: anye tu pratijñā ādi padasya pada antara uccāraṇa kāle ākāśe pada antara ambhaka tvena avasthānam tāvat yāvat antya padam tatas pañcabhiḥ padaiḥ śrotra deśe vākyam avayavi bhūtam ārabhyate tatas vākya artha pratipattiḥ iti nirastam ca etat anubhavena na hi pūrva pūrva padasya uttara uttara pada kāle sarveṣām ca vākya kāle asti iti
translated: Others again say that the word of the proposition, etc., remains in the ether as the material cause of the other words, as long as the last word is uttered; then the sentence, which is a whole different from the words, is produced in the region of the ear by the five words; then there is the cognition of the meaning of the sentence. But this is refuted by experience. For there is no experience of the preceding words at the time of the succeeding words, nor of all the words at the time of the last word.

original: anye tu ekasmin pade jñānam / tena kriyate saṃskāraḥ / punardvitīyapadajñānam / tena prāktanena saṃskāreṇānyaḥ saṃskāra iti tāvad yāvadantyapade jñānamiti / tataḥ prāktanasaṃskārābhivyaktī padacatuṣṭayaviṣayaṃ smaraṇamutpayate / tadviśiṣṭañcāntyapadaṃ vākyamiti / na cātrānubhavena virodhaḥ / karaṇāṃśasyaiva kīrtanāt /
analyzed: anye tu ekasmin pade jñānam tena kriyate saṃskāraḥ punar dvitīya pada jñānam tena prāktanena saṃskāreṇa anyaḥ saṃskāraḥ iti tāvat yāvat antya pade jñānam iti tatas prāktana saṃskāra abhivyaktī pada catuṣṭaya viṣayam smaraṇam utpayate tad viśiṣṭam ca antya padam vākyam iti na ca atra anubhavena virodhaḥ karaṇa aṃśasya eva kīrtanāt
translated: Others say that there is cognition of one word, and by that a modification is produced. Again, cognition of the second word, and by that previous modification another modification is produced. Thus, as long as there is cognition of the last word. Then, by the manifestation of the previous modifications, a recollection arises having as its object the four words. And the last word qualified by that is the sentence. And there is no contradiction here with experience, because only the part of the instrument is mentioned.

original: anye smaraṇenānubhavasyāvirodhaṃ manyamānāḥ kalpanāmāśrayante / padajñānāt saṅketasmaraṇasyotpādaḥ / padārthapratipatterutpadyamānatā / tataḥ padārthajñānasyotpādaḥ pūrvapadajñānasya vinaśyattā / dvitīyapadajñānasyotpadyamānatā / tato dvitīyapadajñānasyotpādaḥ / padārthajñānasya vinaśyattā / padajñānasya vināśaḥ / saṅketasmaraṇasyotpadyamānatetyanena krameṇa antyapadajñāne sati vākyārthapratipattiḥ / na cātra pūrvapadapadārthānusmaraṇena prayojanamasti / tatkāryasya vinaśyadavasthapadajñānenaiva kṛtatvāt / pūrvapadānurakte hi dvitīyapade jñānamutpannam / tadanuraktaṃ tṛtīyapadamiti aśeṣapadānuraktam antyapadaṃ vākyamiti /
analyzed: anye smaraṇena anubhavasya avirodham manyamānāḥ kalpanām āśrayante pada jñānāt saṅketa smaraṇasya utpādaḥ padārtha pratipatteḥ utpadyamāna tā tatas padārtha jñānasya utpādaḥ pūrva pada jñānasya vinaśyat tā dvitīya pada jñānasya utpadyamāna tā tatas dvitīya pada jñānasya utpādaḥ padārtha jñānasya vinaśyat tā pada jñānasya vināśaḥ saṅketa smaraṇasya utpadyamāna tā iti anena krameṇa antya pada jñāne sati vākya artha pratipattiḥ na ca atra p
translated: Others, considering that memory is not incompatible with experience, resort to imagination. From the cognition of the word, there is the production of the recollection of the convention. The production of the cognition of the meaning of the word. Then the production of the cognition of the word. The destruction of the previous cognition of the word. The production of the cognition of the second word. Then the production of the cognition of the second word. The destruction of the cognition of the meaning of the word. The destruction of the cognition of the word. The production of the recollection of the convention. In this sequence, when there is the cognition of the last word, there is the understanding of the meaning of the sentence. And here there is no purpose in the recollection of the previous word and its meaning, because that function has already been done by the cognition of the word in the state of destruction. For the cognition that arises from the second word connected with the previous word is connected with that, and the third word is connected with that. Thus the last word connected with all the words is the sentence.

original: etaccāsat / pūrvapadānurāgasyāntyapade 'pratibhāsanāt / yathā hi / daṇḍīti jñānaṃ daṇḍānuraktameva / naivaṃ dvitīyādipadajñānaṃ pūrvapadānuraktamiti / na cāyaṃ niyamaḥ sambhavati pūrvapadānantarameva dvitīyādipadoccāraṇam / katipayakālavyavadhāne 'pi uccāraṇe 'rthapratipattidarśanāditi pūrvaiva kalpanā nyāyyā /
analyzed: etat ca asat pūrva pada anurāgasya antya pade pratibhāsanāt yathā hi daṇḍī iti jñānam daṇḍa anuraktam eva na evam dvitīya ādi pada jñānam pūrva pada anuraktam iti na ca ayam niyamaḥ sambhavati pūrva pada anantaram eva dvitīya ādi pada uccāraṇam katipaya kāla vyavadhāne uccāraṇe rtha pratipatti darśanāt iti pūrvā eva kalpanā nyāyyā
translated: This is not correct. Because the last word does not appear in the cognition affected by the first word. For instance, the cognition of one having a stick is affected only by the stick, but the cognition of the second and subsequent words is not affected by the first word. And this rule is not possible: that the second and subsequent words are uttered only after the first word. Because even when the utterance is interrupted for some time, the understanding of the meaning is seen. Therefore, the previous assumption is reasonable.

original: athāstvevaṃ vākyaparikalpanā vācakatvantu niṣidhyata / anvayavyatirekābhāvāt / padārthabhyastu vākyārthapratipattiḥ / yatra hi pramāṇāntareṇāpi padārthaprasiddhistatrāntareṇāpi vākyaṃ vākyārthaprattipatirdṛṣṭā / yathā /
analyzed: atha astu evam vākya parikalpanā vācaka tvantu niṣidhyata anvaya vyatireka abhāvāt padārthabhyaḥ tu vākya artha pratipattiḥ yatra hi pramāṇa antareṇa api padārtha prasiddhiḥ tatra antareṇa api vākyam vākya artha prattipatiḥ dṛṣṭā yathā
translated: Now, let there be such assumption of a sentence. But denotation is denied, because of the absence of concomitance and non-concomitance. But the understanding of the meaning of a sentence is from the meanings of the words. Where the meanings of the words are established even by other means of knowledge, there the understanding of the meaning of the sentence is seen even without the sentence, just as:

original: paśyataścakṣuṣā rūpaṃ heṣāśabdaśca śṛṇvataḥ /
analyzed: paśyataḥ cakṣuṣā rūpam heṣā śabdaḥ ca śṛṇvataḥ
translated: Seeing with the eye the form, and hearing the sound of neighing,

original: khuranikṣepaśabdañca śveto 'śvo dhāvatīti dhīḥ // ślo / vā / pṛ /
analyzed: khura nikṣepa śabdaḥ ca śvetaḥ śvas dhāvati iti dhīḥ
translated: The cognition arises that the white horse is running and the sound of the hoofs is heard.

original: tathā ca dūrāccakṣuṣā śvetaṃ rūpamupalabhya heṣāśabdena vā aśvatvajātimanuminoti / khuranikṣepaśabdena ca dhāvanakriyāmavagatya vākyaṃ vināpi vākyārthaṃ pratipadyate / satyapi ca vākye padārthānāmapratipatterna vākyārthapratipattiḥ / yathā prasiddhapadārthaiḥ kavibhirviracite vākya iti / tasmādabhihitapadārthānām ākāṅkṣāyogyatāsannidhidvāreṇa vākyārthagamakatvamiti /
analyzed: tathā ca dūrāt cakṣuṣā śvetam rūpam upalabhya heṣā śabdena vā aśva tva jātim anuminoti khura nikṣepa śabdena ca dhāvana kriyām avagatya vākyam vinā api vākya artham pratipadyate sati api ca vākye padārthānām apratipatteḥ na vākya artha pratipattiḥ yathā prasiddha padārthaiḥ kavibhiḥ viracite vākye iti tasmāt abhihita padārthānām ākāṅkṣā yogyatā sannidhi dvāreṇa vākya artha gamaka tvam iti
translated: And so, having perceived a white form with the eye from a distance, he infers the universal of horsehood by the sound of neighing. Or having understood the action of running by the sound of hoofbeats, he comprehends the meaning of the sentence even without a sentence. And even when there is a sentence, if the meanings of the words are not understood, there is no comprehension of the meaning of the sentence. As in a sentence composed by poets whose meanings are well-known. Therefore, the meanings of the stated words are the means of understanding the meaning of the sentence by way of requirement, fitness, and proximity.

original: na yuktametat / śabdasyāprāmāṇyaprasaṅgāt / tathā ca padarūpasya tāvad aprāmāṇyam / anuvādakatvāt / taduktam /
analyzed: na yuktam etat śabdasya aprāmāṇya prasaṅgāt tathā ca pada rūpasya tāvat aprāmāṇyam anuvādaka tvāt tat uktam
translated: This is not correct, because it would lead to the invalidity of the word. And so, the form of the word is indeed invalid, because it is a restatement. That has been said:

original: padamabhyadhikābhāvāt smārakānna viśiṣyate /
analyzed: padam abhyadhika abhāvāt smārakāt na viśiṣyate
translated: The word is not distinguished from the reminder because of the absence of anything additional.

original: yaccādhikyaṃ bhavedetat sa padasya na gocaraḥ // ślo / vā / pṛ /
analyzed: yat ca ādhikyam bhavet etat sa padasya na gocaraḥ
translated: And that which would be the excess is not the domain of the word.

original: vākyantu pāramparyeṇāpyavācakamiti kathaṃ śabdaḥ pramāṇaṃ syāt / atha padairabhihitānāñca padārthānāṃ gamakatvāditi pāramparyeṇa śabdaḥ pramāṇam / tarhi śrotraparicchinnasya śabdasyārthaparicchede vyāpārāditi pāramparyeṇa pratyakṣasyāpi codanāviṣaye sannidhiprāmāṇyopapatteḥ kathaṃ codanaiva dharma pramāṇam / pramāṇameva codaneti nāsyāvadhāraṇasya vyāghātaḥ / vākyasyārthaparicchedakatvānabhyupagame ca pramāṇāntarāsambhavāt padārthānāṃ pratyakṣādiṣvantarbhāvaścintanīyaḥ /
analyzed: vākyantu pāramparyeṇa api avācakam iti katham śabdaḥ pramāṇam syāt atha padaiḥ abhihitānām ca padārthānām gamaka tvāt iti pāramparyeṇa śabdaḥ pramāṇam tarhi śrotra paricchinnasya śabdasya artha paricchede vyāpārāt iti pāramparyeṇa pratyakṣasya api codanā viṣaye sannidhi prāmāṇya upapatteḥ katham codanā eva dharma pramāṇam pramāṇam eva codanā iti na asya avadhāraṇasya vyāghātaḥ vākyasya artha paricchedaka tva anabhyupagame ca pramāṇa antara
translated: If a sentence is not expressive even indirectly, how can it be a means of knowledge? If it is argued that a sentence is a means of knowledge indirectly because the meanings of its words are expressive, then the auditory sense organ, which is limited to sound, would also be a means of knowledge in the matter of comprehending meaning, since it operates in that comprehension. Thus, perception too, indirectly, would be applicable in the matter of Vedic injunctions. How then can Vedic injunction alone be the means of knowing Dharma? And if it is argued that Vedic injunction alone is the means of knowing Dharma, then there is no contradiction in the restriction. And if the expressive power of a sentence is not accepted, then, since another means of knowledge is not possible, it should be considered whether the meanings of words are included in perception etc.

original: tatrendriyārthasannikarṣeṇa saha vyāpārānupalabdherna pratyakṣe 'ntarbhāvaḥ / avinābhāvasyānupapatternānumāne / anupapadyamānārthāsambhavānnārthāpattau / upamānābhāvayośca niyataviṣayatvameva / pramāṇāntarasya ca anabhyupagamādayuktametat /
analyzed: tatra indriya artha sannikarṣeṇa saha vyāpāra anupalabdheḥ na pratyakṣe ntarbhāvaḥ avinābhāvasya anupapatteḥ na anumāne anupapadyamāna artha asambhavāt na artha āpattau upamāna abhāvayoḥ ca niyata viṣaya tvam eva pramāṇa antarasya ca anabhyupagamāt ayuktam etat
translated: There, since the operation is not perceived along with the contact of sense object, it is not included in perception. Since invariable concomitance is not possible, it is not inference. Since the non-occurrence of a non-occurring object is not possible, it is not presumption. And the limited scope of analogy and non-apprehension itself. And since another means of knowledge is not accepted, this is improper.

original: na ca padānāṃ svārthapratipattāveva caritārthatvam / uktanyāyena vākyārthapratipattāvapi vyāpārāt / viramya vyāpārastu ekamarthaṃ pratipādya punastam pratipādayantīti pratiṣiddhaḥ /
analyzed: na ca padānām svārtha pratipattau eva caritārtha tvam ukta nyāyena vākya artha pratipattau api vyāpārāt viramya vyāpāraḥ tu ekam artham pratipādya punar tam pratipādayanti iti pratiṣiddhaḥ
translated: And the words are not complete in the understanding of their own meaning. Because of the stated principle, there is operation even in the understanding of the meaning of a sentence. But the operation after cessation is refuted as follows: Having taught one meaning, it teaches that again.

original: yaccedaṃ vināpi vākyaṃ vākyārthapratipattirityuktam / tadaparijñānāt / vākyena hi janitā vākyārthapratipattiḥ / pratyakṣānumānasampāditāḥ śveto 'śvo dhāvatīti buddhayaḥ / yadapīdaṃ padārthāpratipattau satyapi vākyena vākyārthapratipattiriti / tadasat / pūrvapadārthasmaraṇānugṛhītasya antyapadasya vākyatvācca avaśyamarthapratipādakatvamiti vyabhicārābhāvaḥ /
analyzed: yat ca idam vinā api vākyam vākya artha pratipattiḥ iti uktam tad aparijñānāt vākyena hi janitā vākya artha pratipattiḥ pratyakṣa anumāna sampāditāḥ śvetaḥ śvas dhāvati iti buddhayaḥ yat api idam padārtha apratipattau sati api vākyena vākya artha pratipattiḥ iti tat asat pūrva padārtha smaraṇa anugṛhītasya antya padasya vākya tvāt ca avaśyam artha pratipādaka tvam iti vyabhicāra abhāvaḥ
translated: And as for the statement that the meaning of a sentence is apprehended even without a sentence, that is due to ignorance. For the cognition of the meaning of a sentence is produced by a sentence, like the cognitions produced by perception and inference, such as 'the white horse is running'. And the statement that the meaning of a sentence is apprehended by a sentence even when the meanings of the words are not apprehended, is false. For a sentence consists of the final word aided by the recollection of the meanings of the preceding words, and therefore it necessarily conveys the meaning. So there is no deviation from our position.

original: anvitābhidhānantu na sarvapadānām / ekenaiva kriyākārakasaṃsargānvitasya padārthasyābhidhāne śeṣapadoccāraṇavaiyarthyaprasaṅgāt / atha antyaṃ padamanvitābhidhāyakam / tasyāpi pūrvapadānapekṣitve taduccāraṇavaiyarthyam / sāpekṣitve tu na asmatsiddhāntād bhedaḥ /
analyzed: anvita abhidhānam tu na sarva padānām ekena eva kriyā kāraka saṃsarga anvitasya padārthasya abhidhāne śeṣa pada uccāraṇa vaiyarthya prasaṅgāt atha antyam padam anvita abhidhāyakam tasya api pūrva pada anapekṣi tve tad uccāraṇa vaiyarthyam sāpekṣi tve tu na asmad siddhāntāt bhedaḥ
translated: But the expression of the related meaning is not by all the words, because if the meaning of one word is expressed as related to the action and its factors, it would be pointless to utter the remaining words. If the final word expresses the related meaning, then it would be pointless to utter it if it did not depend on the preceding words. But if it does depend on them, then there is no difference from our position.

original: avayavoddeśaḥ pratijñāvaidharmyañca
analyzed: avayava uddeśaḥ pratijñā vaidharmyam ca
translated: The statement of the parts, and the dissimilarity to the proposition.

original: avayavāḥ punaḥ pratijñāpadeśanidarśanānusandhānapratyāmnāyāḥ / tatrānumeyoddeśo 'virodhī pratijñā / pratipipādayiṣitadharmaviśiṣṭasya dharmiṇo 'padeśaviṣayamāpādayitum uddeśamātraṃ pratijñā / yathā dravyaṃ vāyuriti /PDhS
analyzed: avayavāḥ punar pratijñā apadeśa nidarśana anusandhāna pratyāmnāyāḥ tatra anumeya uddeśaḥ virodhī pratijñā pratipipādayiṣita dharma viśiṣṭasya dharmiṇaḥ upadeśa viṣayam āpādayitum uddeśa mātram pratijñā yathā dravyam vāyuḥ iti
translated: The members are again: thesis, statement, example, application, and conclusion. Among them, the thesis is the statement of what is to be inferred, which is not contradictory. The thesis is merely the statement to establish the subject qualified by the property to be proved as the object of the statement, like Air is a substance.

original: avirodhigrahaṇāt pratyakṣānumānābhyupagatasvaśāstrasvavacanavirodhino anumeyoddeśā nirastā bhavanti / yathā anuṣṇo 'gniriti / pratyakṣavirodhī / ghanamambaram ityanumānavirodhī / brāhmaṇena surā peyā ityāgamavirodhī / vaiśeṣikasya sat kāryam iti bruvataḥ svaśāstravirodhī / na śabdo 'rthapratyāyaka iti svavacanavirodhī /PDhS
analyzed: avirodhi grahaṇāt pratyakṣa anumāna abhyupagata sva śāstra sva vacana virodhinaḥ anumeya uddeśāḥ nirastāḥ bhavanti yathā anuṣṇaḥ gniḥ iti pratyakṣa virodhī ghanam ambaram iti anumāna virodhī brāhmaṇena surā peyā iti āgama virodhī vaiśeṣikasya sat kāryam iti bruvataḥ sva śāstra virodhī na śabdaḥ rtha pratyāyakaḥ iti sva vacana virodhī pdhs
translated: By the word non-contradictory, theses that are contradictory to perception, inference, accepted scriptures, and one's own words are excluded. For example, Fire is not hot is contradictory to perception. The sky is solid is contradictory to inference. Brahmins should drink alcohol is contradictory to scriptures. For a Vaisheshika who says The effect exists, it is contradictory to his own scriptures. Sound does not convey meaning is contradictory to his own words.

original: ke punaravayavāstadāha pratijñāpadeśanidarśanānusandhānapratyāmnāyāḥ vākyaikadeśatvāt / na punaḥ paropagatā jijñāsādayaḥ / teṣāmaśabdarūpatvāt /
analyzed: ke punar avayavāḥ tat āha pratijñā apadeśa nidarśana anusandhāna pratyāmnāyāḥ vākya eka deśa tvāt na punar para upagatāḥ jijñāsā ādayaḥ teṣām aśabda rūpa tvāt
translated: And what are the members? He says: thesis, statement, example, application, and conclusion, because they are parts of a sentence. And not the inquiry and so on accepted by others, because they are not in the form of words.

original: tata upadeśakrameṇāvasaraprāptāyāḥ pratijñāyāstāvallakṣaṇamucyate anumeyoddeśo 'virodhī pratijñā iti / anumeyaḥ pratipipādāyiṣitadharmaviśiṣṭo dharmī / dharmaviśiṣṭatā hi astitvādyapekṣayā sarvapadārtheṣvastīti pratipipādayiṣitapadam / yo hi dharmaḥ pratipādayitumiṣṭaḥ / tadviśiṣṭo dharmī pakṣaḥ / tasyoddeśamātraṃ pratyakṣādyaviruddhaṃ pareṣām aniścitārthābhidhāyakaṃ vacanaṃ pratijñeti / apadeśasya hetorviṣayāpādanam arthaḥ prayojanamasyeti prayojanopanyāsaḥ / prayogastu / pratijñā itarasmād bhidyate / pratyakṣādyaviruddhānumeyoddeśatvāt / yastu na bhidyate / na cāsāvevaṃ yathā udāharaṇādiriti / anumeyoddeśo vā pratijñeti vyavahartavyaḥ / yathoktānumeyoddeśatvāt / yaścaivaṃ na vyavahriyate / na cāsāvevam / yathā apadeśa iti / udāharaṇantu yathā dravyaṃ vāyuriti /
analyzed: tatas upadeśa krameṇa avasara prāptāyāḥ pratijñāyāḥ tāvat lakṣaṇam ucyate anumeya uddeśaḥ virodhī pratijñā iti anumeyaḥ pratipipādāyiṣita dharma viśiṣṭaḥ dharmī dharma viśiṣṭa tā hi astitva ādi apekṣayā sarva padārtheṣu asti iti pratipipādayiṣita padam yaḥ hi dharmaḥ pratipādayitum iṣṭaḥ tad viśiṣṭaḥ dharmī pakṣaḥ tasya uddeśa mātram pratyakṣa ādi aviruddham pareṣām aniścita artha abhidhāyakam vacanam pratijñā iti apad
translated: Now, the definition of the thesis, which has come up in the order of instruction, is stated: The thesis is a non-contradictory statement of what is to be inferred. What is to be inferred is the subject qualified by the property to be proved. For the qualification by a property exists in all things in relation to existence, etc., so the word to be proved refers to the property that is intended to be proved. The subject qualified by that is the thesis. Merely stating that, a statement that is not contradicted by perception, etc., and that expresses an uncertain meaning to others is called a thesis. The purpose is the attainment of the object of the reason, which is the means of inference. This is the statement of the purpose. The argument is: The thesis is different from the other [parts of a proof], because it states what is to be inferred, which is not contradicted by perception, etc. But what is not different is not so, like the example, etc. Or, what is to be inferred should be referred to as the thesis, because it states what is to be inferred as stated. And what is not referred to in this way,

original: nanu ca asādhanāṅgaṃ pratijñāvacanam / tadantareṇāpi sambandhavacanamātrāII /darthapratīteḥ / tathāhi / yad yat kṛtakam / tattad anityaṃ dṛṣṭam / yathā ghaṭaḥ / tathā ca kṛtakaḥ śabda ityatra sāmarthyādeva pratijñārthasiddhervyarthaṃ tadabhidhānam / atra ca prameyasya pramāṇenaiva siddheḥ sāmarthyaṃ kiṃrūpamiti cintyam / na pratyakṣasvarūpam / indriyārthasannikarṣeṇa vipratipattiviṣayasyāparicchedāt / evamāgamenāpīti / athānumānameva sāmarthyaṃ tadavaśyamarthapratipattau pakṣadharmatvādikamapekṣata iti pratijñāvacanamantareṇa sapakṣāsapakṣāpravibhāge sati tadarthāpratīterna gamakamiti / atha abhidhīyamānānumānavyatirekeṇa anyadanumānaṃ prastutānumānasāmarthyam / na / tasyāpi avinābhāvānapekṣitve na gamakatvam / pratijñāvacanañca vinā tadarthāpratīteriti pūrvadoṣānuṣaṅgāt / na cābhipretārthapratipādanāya anumānopanyāsakāle tadarthasiddhaye 'numānāntaraṃ paśyāmaḥ /
analyzed: nanu ca asādhana aṅgam pratijñā vacanam tad antareṇa api  / tathā hi yat yat kṛtakam tat tat anityam dṛṣṭam yathā ghaṭaḥ tathā ca kṛtakaḥ śabdaḥ iti atra sāmarthyāt eva pratijñā artha siddheḥ vyartham tat abhidhānam atra ca prameyasya pramāṇena eva siddheḥ sāmarthyam kiṃrūpam iti cintyam na pratyakṣa svarūpam indriya artha sannikarṣeṇa vipratipatti viṣayasya aparicchedāt evam āgamena api iti  atha anumānam eva sāmarthyam tat avaśyam artha pratipatt
translated: But the statement of the conclusion is not a part of the proof. Even without it, the meaning is understood just by the statement of the relation. For example, in the statement Whatever is produced is seen to be impermanent, like a pot, and sound is produced in the same way, the meaning of the conclusion is established by implication alone, so its statement is useless. And here, since the object of knowledge is established by the means of knowledge itself, the nature of the implication should be considered. It cannot be the form of perception, because the object of dispute is not ascertained by the contact of sense with object. The same applies to inference. If implication is just inference, then it necessarily requires the property of the subject and so on for the understanding of the meaning. So without the statement of the conclusion, when the distinction between similar and dissimilar instances is not made, the meaning is not understood, and it is not a means of knowledge. If implication is another kind of inference different from the stated inference, then it does not require invariable concomitance.

original: na ca kṛtakatvānityatvayoḥ sāmānyena vyāptyabhidhāne samarthasādhanasya śabda evopasaṃhārād vijñāyate atraivānityatvam asyābhipretamiti / sambandhābhidhānasya viruddhāviruddhābhiprāyeṇāpi samānatayā vivekapratipatterabhāvaprasaṅgāt /
analyzed: na ca kṛtaka tva anitya tvayoḥ sāmānyena vyāpti abhidhāne samartha sādhanasya śabdaḥ eva upasaṃhārāt vijñāyate atra eva anitya tvam asya abhipretam iti sambandha abhidhānasya viruddha aviruddha abhiprāyeṇa api samāna tayā viveka pratipatteḥ abhāva prasaṅgāt
translated: And when the pervasion between the two universals 'being produced' and 'being non-eternal' is stated, it is not understood from the conclusion of the capable means 'sound' alone that 'non-eternality' is intended here, because even if the statement of the relation is the same with regard to the intention of the contradictory and non-contradictory, there would be the undesirable consequence of the absence of the understanding of the distinction.

original: atha yadyat kṛtakaṃ tattannityaṃ dṛṣṭamiti vyāptivacane viruddhavādī / anityatvena ca kṛtakatvasya vyāptivacane tattvavādīti viniścayaḥ / tanna / kṛtakatvanityatvayorvyāpteḥ pratipādayitumaśakyatvāt / tathā ca / na kṛtakeṣu ghaṭādiṣu nityatvam / nityeṣu cākāśādiṣu kṛtakatvamiti dṛṣṭāntadoṣeṇa gatārthatvāt kathaṃ viruddhatvam / yadā ca nityaḥ śabda iti pratijñāya kṛtakatvānityatvayorvyāptiṃ brūte / tadā abhipretārthaviparītena vyāptikathanād viruddhavādyayamiti viśeṣādhyavasāyo bhavatyeva /
analyzed: atha yat yat kṛtakam tat tat nityam dṛṣṭam iti vyāpti vacane viruddha vādī anitya tvena ca kṛtaka tvasya vyāpti vacane tattva vādī iti viniścayaḥ tat na kṛtaka tva nitya tvayoḥ vyāpteḥ pratipādayitum aśakya tvāt tathā ca na kṛtakeṣu ghaṭa ādiṣu nitya tvam nityeṣu ca ākāśa ādiṣu kṛtaka tvam iti dṛṣṭānta doṣeṇa gatārtha tvāt katham viruddha tvam yadā ca nityaḥ śabdaḥ iti pratijñāya kṛtaka tva anitya tvayoḥ vyāptim brūte tadā abhipre
translated: If one says that whatever is produced is seen to be impermanent, then he is a contradictory speaker in stating the pervasion. And if one says that the pervasion of being produced by impermanence, then he is a true speaker. This is not so. Because the pervasion of being produced and being permanent cannot be demonstrated. And thus, in produced things like pots there is no permanence, and in permanent things like space there is no being produced. Since this is already established by the fault in the example, how can it be contradictory? And when one asserts that sound is permanent and then states the pervasion of being produced and impermanence, then because he states the pervasion in a way contrary to the intended meaning, he is a contradictory speaker. This is indeed a specific determination.

original: nanu nityānityābhiprāyeṇaivāpi nityaḥ śabda iti vacanasambhavāt pratijñāvacane satyapi tattvātattvavādinoraniścaya eva / na / vacanenaivābhiprāyaviśeṣaprasiddheḥ / na hi vaktṝṇāṃ vacanādṛte 'bhiprāyāvabodhe pramāṇāntaramastīti nityavacanānnityābhiprāya eva niścīyate / abhiprāyāntarakalpanāyāṃ pramāṇābhāvāt / ata eva vādiprativādinorjayaparājayavyavasthā prāśnikaiḥ kriyate / yatrāpyanyathā pratipadyamānā vicitrābhiprāyatayā prakaraṇārthamanyathā bruvate / tatrāpi vacanaviśeṣeṇaiva abhiprāyaviśeṣo 'numeyaḥ / vivakṣāntarād vacanāntarānutpatteḥ / II / abhyupagame vā sambandhavacanādapi aniścaya eva syāt kiṃ nityatvavivakṣātaḥ kṛtakatvānityatvayoḥ sambandhavacanam / uta anityatvavivakṣāta iti /
analyzed: nanu nitya anitya abhiprāyeṇa eva api nityaḥ śabdaḥ iti vacana sambhavāt pratijñā vacane sati api tattva atattva vādinoḥ aniścayaḥ eva na vacanena eva abhiprāya viśeṣa prasiddheḥ na hi vaktṝṇām vacanāt ṛte bhiprāya avabodhe pramāṇa antaram asti iti nitya vacanāt nitya abhiprāyaḥ eva niścīyate abhiprāya antara kalpanāyām pramāṇa abhāvāt atas eva vādi prativādinoḥ jaya parājaya vyavasthā prāśnikaiḥ kriyate yatra api anyathā pratipadyamānā vicitra
translated: Or, if accepted, there would be no certainty even from the statement of the relation. Is the statement of the relation between being produced and being non-eternal due to the intention of eternality? Or is it due to the intention of non-eternality?

original: atha hetutadabhāvavyavasthāyā vāstavasambandhāpekṣitvād viparītavivakṣayāpi kṛtakatvānityatvayorastyeva sambandha iti gamakatvam / tarhi nityatvābhiprāyeṇāpi evaṃsambandhamupadarśayataḥ tattvavāditvaṃ syāt / prakārāntareṇa sambandhopadarśanasyavābhāvāt / tathā pratijñāvacanaṃ vinā sandigdhaviparyastāvyutpannapuruṣaviśeṣāṇāṃ prameyaviśeṣeṣu ākāṅkṣāpratipattau vādino viśeṣeṇa puruṣamātrasya prameyamātrapratipādanāya pravartamānasya unmattavāditvaṃ syāt /
analyzed: atha hetu tad abhāva vyavasthāyāḥ vāstava sambandha apekṣi tvāt viparīta vivakṣayā api kṛtaka tva anitya tvayoḥ asti eva sambandhaḥ iti gamaka tvam tarhi nitya tva abhiprāyeṇa api evaṃsambandham upadarśayataḥ tattva vādi tvam syāt prakāra antareṇa tathā pratijñā vacanam vinā sandigdha viparyasta avyutpanna puruṣa viśeṣāṇām prameya viśeṣeṣu ākāṅkṣā pratipattau vādinaḥ viśeṣeṇa puruṣa mātrasya prameya mātra pratipādanāya pravartamānasya
translated: Now, since the establishment of the reason and its absence requires a real relation, even if the relation is stated in the opposite way, there is indeed a relation between being produced and being non-eternal, so there is the property of being an indicator. Then, even if one points out such a relation with the intention of eternality, one would be a proponent of reality, because there is no other way of showing the relation. Or, without the statement of the thesis, for those who are doubtful, mistaken, or not well-versed in particular objects of knowledge, when there is a desire to understand, the proponent who engages in presenting only a person and only the object of knowledge, without specifying, would be like a mad proponent.

original: atha vivādāt puruṣaviśeṣasya prameyaviśeṣāpekṣitvapratipattiḥ / tarhi pratijñā abhyupagataiva / vivādasya tadrūpatvāt / pratijñā hi pratiyogipratijñāntaramapekṣamāṇo vivādaḥ / sādhanasahitā tu pratijñeti / na ca śāstrādeva yathoktapratipattiḥ / anumānopanyāsakāle tasyāpramāṇatvāt / prāmāṇye vā kimanumāneneti / tasmāt parārthānumānamicchatā avaśyaṃ kāryaṃ pratijñāvacanamiti / yaccedam
analyzed: atha vivādāt puruṣa viśeṣasya prameya viśeṣa apekṣi tva pratipattiḥ tarhi pratijñā abhyupagatā eva vivādasya tad rūpa tvāt pratijñā hi pratiyogi pratijñā antaram apekṣamāṇaḥ vivādaḥ sādhana sahitā tu pratijñā iti na ca śāstrāt eva yathā ukta pratipattiḥ anumāna upanyāsa kāle tasya apramāṇa tvāt prāmāṇye vā kim anumānena iti tasmāt parārtha anumānam icchatā avaśyam kāryam pratijñā vacanam iti  yat ca idam anumānam avaśyam kāryam pratijñā
translated: If, on the other hand, the ascertainment of the requirement of a particular object of knowledge by a particular person is due to dispute, then the proposition is admitted, because dispute has that form. For dispute requires a counter-proposition. But when accompanied by proof, it is a proposition. And the ascertainment as stated is not from the treatise itself, because it is not a means of knowledge at the time of stating the inference. Or if it is a means of knowledge, what is the use of inference? Therefore, one who desires to state an inference for the sake of another must necessarily state the proposition. And this

original: arthādarthagatau śaktiḥ pakṣahetvabhidhānayoḥ //
analyzed: arthāt artha gatau śaktiḥ pakṣa hetu abhidhānayoḥ
translated: The power of the statement of the proposition and reason to convey the meaning is from the meaning.

original: nārthe tena tayornāsti svataḥ sādhanasaṃsthitiḥ // pra / vā / /
analyzed: na arthe tena tayoḥ na asti svatas sādhana saṃsthitiḥ pra vā
translated: The meaning does not have it, therefore they do not have self-sufficient establishment as proof.

original: ityutkam / tatra arthasyārthagatau sāmarthyaṃ na niṣidhyate / kevalayośca pakṣahetvabhidhānayornārthaparicchede sāmarthyam / avayavāntarasadbhāve ca svārthopasthāpanadvāreṇa sāmarthyamiṣyata eva / anyathā hetvabhidhānasyāpi asāmarthye parārthānumānasyāpravṛttireva /
analyzed: iti utkam tatra arthasya artha gatau sāmarthyam na niṣidhyate kevalayoḥ ca pakṣa hetu abhidhānayoḥ na artha paricchede sāmarthyam avayava antara sadbhāve ca sva artha upasthāpana dvāreṇa sāmarthyam iṣyate eva anyathā hetu abhidhānasya api asāmarthye parārtha anumānasya apravṛttiḥ eva
translated: Thus it is a question. There, the capacity of the meaning to convey the meaning is not denied. And the mere statement of the proposition and reason does not have the capacity to determine the meaning. And when there is the presence of another part, the capacity is indeed accepted through the means of presenting one's own meaning. Otherwise, if the statement of the reason also were incapable, there would be no engagement in inference for the sake of others.

original: atha hetuvacanaṃ svayamasamarthamapi samarthahetusaṃsūcakatvāt parapratipattāvupahīyate /ādīyate na caivaṃ pratijñetyāha /
analyzed: atha hetu vacanam svayam asamartham api samartha hetu saṃsūcaka tvāt para pratipattau upahīyate ādīyate na ca evam pratijñā iti āha
translated: Now, even though the statement of the reason is itself incapable, it is accepted in the understanding of others because it indicates the capable reason. But the proposition is not so, he says.

original: sādhyābhidhānāt pakṣoktiḥ pāramparyeṇa nāpyalam /
analyzed: sādhya abhidhānāt pakṣa uktiḥ pāramparyeṇa nā api alam
translated: The statement of the proposition is not sufficient even indirectly, because it states what is to be established.

original: śaktasya sūcakaṃ hetuvaco 'śaktamapi svayam // pra / vā / /
analyzed: śaktasya sūcakam hetu vacaḥ śaktam api svayam pra vā
translated: The statement of the reason, though itself incapable, is capable of indicating the capable reason.

original: tatra pakṣoktiḥ pratijñāvacanaṃ pāramparyeṇāpyalaṃ samarthaṃ na bhavatīti asādhanāṅgamiti / sādhye sādhyābhidhānamasādhāraṇameva / sapakṣāsapakṣayoraII /prasiddheḥ / tathā sādhyābhidhānasya pakṣokteḥ paryāyatvāt sādhyāviśiṣṭatā ceti / atha sādhyānupayogitvāt sādhyānabhidhānam / tadapyavayavāntarasahitasya sādhyapratipādakatvādasiddham / viparyaye tu anaikāntikam / kevalasya hetuvacanasyāpi asādhakatvāt / tathā pratijñāvacanamapi asādhanāṅgamiti vadatā abhyupagataiva pratijñeti vyāghātaḥ /
analyzed: tatra pakṣa uktiḥ pratijñā vacanam pāramparyeṇa api alam samartham na bhavati iti asādhana aṅgam iti sādhye sādhya abhidhānam asādhāraṇam eva  / tathā sādhya abhidhānasya pakṣa ukteḥ paryāya tvāt sādhya aviśiṣṭa tā ca iti atha sādhya anupayogi tvāt sādhya anabhidhānam tat api avayava antara sahitasya sādhya pratipādaka tvāt asiddham viparyaye tu anaikāntikam kevalasya hetu vacanasya api asādhaka tvāt tathā pratijñā vacanam api asādhana aṅgam iti vadatā ab
translated: There, the statement of the proposition is the statement of the conclusion, which is not even indirectly capable of establishing, so it is not a part of the proof. The mere statement of the probandum is not uncommon, because it is well-known in both similar and dissimilar instances. Similarly, the statement of the probandum is a synonym of the statement of the proposition, so there is no specification of the probandum. If it is argued that the statement of the probandum is not a part of the proof because it is not useful for the probandum, that is also unestablished because it is a statement of the probandum along with other parts. But in the contrary case, it is inconclusive, because even the mere statement of the reason is not a proof. Similarly, the statement of the conclusion is also not a part of the proof, so by saying that, it is contradictory to accept the conclusion.

original: atha svapratipattau pratijñāvacanasyānupalambhāt parapratipattāvanupādānam / evaṃ tarhi hetuvacanasyāpi adarśanādanupādānaṃ syāt / atha hetvarthasyopalambhād yuktaṃ hetuvacanam / tarhi pratijñārthasyopalabdheḥ kāryaṃ pratijñāvacanam / yathā hetvarthaḥ kāraṇaṃ sādhyapratipattau / evaṃ pratijñārthaḥ karmetyubhayoḥ kāraṇatvāviśeṣāt pakṣasyāvacane pramāṇaṃ nāstīti / upasthāpite ca karmaṇi karaṇānāṃ pravṛtterupalambhāt tadupasthāpanārthamavaśyaṃ kāryaṃ pratijñāvacanamityalaṃ vistareṇa /
analyzed: atha sva pratipattau pratijñā vacanasya anupalambhāt para pratipattau anupādānam evam tarhi hetu vacanasya api adarśanāt anupādānam syāt  / atha hetvarthasya upalambhāt yuktam hetu vacanam tarhi pratijñā arthasya upalabdheḥ kāryam pratijñā vacanam yathā hetvarthaḥ kāraṇam sādhya pratipattau evam pratijñārthaḥ karma iti ubhayoḥ kāraṇa tva aviśeṣāt pakṣasya avacane pramāṇam na asti iti upasthāpite ca karmaṇi karaṇānām pravṛtteḥ upalambhāt tad upasthāpan
translated: If, on the other hand, the statement of the proposition is not stated because it is not perceived in one's own understanding, and is not stated in the understanding of others, then in that case the statement of the reason also would not be stated because it is not perceived. If, on the other hand, the statement of the reason is proper because the meaning of the reason is perceived, then the statement of the proposition should be made because the meaning of the proposition is perceived. Just as the meaning of the reason is the cause in the ascertainment of what is to be established, in the same way the meaning of the proposition is the action. Thus, because there is no difference in the causal nature of both, there is no means of valid knowledge in the non-statement of the position. And because of the perception of the engagement of the instruments of action when the action is presented, the statement of the proposition must necessarily be made for the purpose of presenting it. Thus ends the detailed discussion.

original: avirodhigrahaṇāt pratyakṣānumānābhyupagatasvaśāstrasvavacanavirodhino 'numeyoddeśā nirastā bhavanti iti vyavacchedyaṃ darśayati / yo hyanumeyoddeśo na pratyakṣādinā virudhyate / sā pratijñeti /
analyzed: avirodhi grahaṇāt pratyakṣa anumāna abhyupagata sva śāstra sva vacana virodhinaḥ numeya uddeśāḥ nirastāḥ bhavanti iti vyavacchedyam darśayati yaḥ hi anumeya uddeśaḥ na pratyakṣa ādinā virudhyate sā pratijñā iti
translated: By the use of the word non-contradictory, those intended inferences that are contradictory to perception, inference, what is accepted, one's own scriptures, and one's own words are excluded. Thus, it shows what is to be excluded. For, an intended inference that is not contradicted by perception, etc., is a proposition.

original: anye tu pratyakṣādyaviruddho 'numeyastasyoddeśaḥ pratijñeti vyākhyāṃ kurvate / yadyapi anumeyasya sādhyasya sādhanārhatayā pratyakṣādivirodhābhāvānna vyavacchedyatvamasti / tathāpi kimbhūtaṃ sādhyamityapekṣāyāṃ svarūpopavarṇanārthaṃ pratyakṣādyaviruddhapadam / pratyakṣaśabdenaiva viśiṣṭārthapratītau indriyārthasannikarṣādipadavaditi / taccāsat / avirodhipadasyoddeśapadena sāmānādhikaraṇyāt / karmaṇaḥ karaṇena virodhābhāvācceti / yathābhūtamupalabhyamānaṃ karma tathābhūtamanupalabhyamānamapi iti uddyotakarapādairuktam / pratijñā tu karaṇamiti yuktastatra virodhaḥ /
analyzed: anye tu pratyakṣa ādi aviruddhaḥ numeyaḥ tasya uddeśaḥ pratijñā iti vyākhyām kurvate yadi api anumeyasya sādhyasya sādhana arhatayā pratyakṣa ādi virodha abhāvāt na vyavacchedya tvam asti tathā api kimbhūtam sādhyam iti apekṣāyām svarūpa upavarṇana artham pratyakṣa ādi aviruddha padam pratyakṣa śabdena eva viśiṣṭa artha pratītau indriya artha sannikarṣa ādi pada vat iti tat ca asat avirodhi padasya uddeśa padena sāmānādhikaraṇyāt karmaṇaḥ karaṇena
translated: Others, however, explain that the statement of the inferable object, which is not contradicted by perception etc., is the thesis. Although the inferable object to be established does not need to be excluded, since it is worthy of being established and is not contradicted by perception etc., still, when there is a need to know what kind of object is to be established, the phrase not contradicted by perception etc. is used to describe its nature. And this is not correct, because the phrase not contradicted is in apposition with the phrase statement, and because there is no contradiction between the object and the means of knowledge. As Uddyotakara and Pātrasvāmin have said, the object that is perceived as it is is also not perceived as it is. And the thesis is the means of knowledge, so the contradiction is appropriate there.

original: tatra pratyakṣavirodhī yathā anuṣṇo 'gniḥ iti / anu /uṣṇatāyāstvagindriyeṇa pratibhāsanāt / ghanamambaramityanumānavirodhī ākāśasya anumānādeva amūrtatvavibhutvaprasiddheḥ / ghanaṃ niviḍāvayavamityuddeśastena virudhyata eva / ghanatve sati asmadādīnāmasañcāraprasaṅgācceti / abhyupagataśāstravirodhī yathā vaiśeṣikasya sarvakāryamutpatteḥ pūrvaṃ sadutpadyata /t II / iti bruvataḥ / vaiśeṣikaśāstre hi asadutpadyata iti prasiddham / na śabdo 'rthapratyāyaka iti svavacanavirodhī / yadi hi śabdo 'rthapratyāyako na bhavati / kathamasyārthasya jñāpanārthaṃ śabdoccāraṇaṃ na virudhyeta iti /
analyzed: tatra pratyakṣa virodhī yathā anuṣṇaḥ gniḥ iti anuuṣṇatāyāḥ tvac indriyeṇa pratibhāsanāt  ghanam ambaram iti anumāna virodhī ākāśasya anumānāt eva amūrta tva vibhu tva prasiddheḥ ghanam nibiḍa avayavam iti uddeśaḥ tena virudhyate eva ghana tve sati asmat ādīnām asañcāra prasaṅgāt ca iti abhyupagata śāstra virodhī yathā vaiśeṣikasya sarva kāryam utpatteḥ pūrvam sat utpadyatat iti bruvataḥ vaiśeṣika śāstre hi asat utpadyate iti prasiddham na ś
translated: Among them, the one contradicting perception is like fire is not hot, because heat is perceived by the skin sense organ. The one contradicting inference is like 'the sky is dense,' because the sky is known to be incorporeal and all-pervading by inference itself. The statement 'dense' means having closely packed parts contradicts that, because if it were dense, it would follow that it cannot move for us and others. The one contradicting the accepted scripture is like for a Vaisheshika, who says all effects exist before arising and arise from that, because in the Vaisheshika scripture it is well-known that the non-existent arises. The one contradicting one's own statement is like sound does not convey meaning, because if sound does not convey meaning, how could the utterance of sound not be contradictory for the purpose of conveying this meaning?

original: atha pramāṇatritve sati kathaṃ virodhabahutvam / lokaprasiddhayapekṣayā / yadyapi āgamaviruddhasya pratyakṣaviruddhasya cāmī bhedāstathāpi svavacanaviruddhaḥ svaśāstraviruddhaścetyādivyapadeśo janānām atastathaivābhidhānam / anumānasya tu anumānāntareṇa virodhāsambhave 'pi svakīyānumānasya balavattvādayaṃ vyapadeśo 'numānena pratijñā bādhyata iti /
analyzed: atha pramāṇa tritve sati katham virodha bahutvam loka prasiddhaya apekṣayā yadi api āgama viruddhasya pratyakṣa viruddhasya ca amī bhedāḥ tathā api sva vacana viruddhaḥ sva śāstra viruddhaḥ ca ityādi vyapadeśaḥ janānām atas tathā eva abhidhānam anumānasya tu anumāna antareṇa virodha asambhave svakīya anumānasya balavat tvāt ayam vyapadeśaḥ numānena pratijñā bādhyate iti
translated: Now, if there are only three means of valid knowledge, how can there be many kinds of contradiction? It is in relation to what is well-known in the world. Although these differences are between what is contradicted by scripture and what is contradicted by perception, the people speak of it as self-contradiction, contradiction with one's own doctrine, and so on. Therefore, it is mentioned in that way. Although there cannot be contradiction of one inference by another inference, this designation of the thesis is contradicted by inference is due to the strength of one's own inference.

original: hetuvaidharmyam
analyzed: hetu vaidharmyam
translated: The reason is dissimilar.

original: liṅgavacanamapadeśaḥ / yadanumeyena sahacaritaṃ tatsamānajātīye ca sāmānyena prasiddhaṃ / tadaviparīte ca sarvasminnasadeva talliṅgamuktam / tasya vacanamapadeśaḥ / yathā kriyāvattvād guṇavattvācca / tathā ca tadanumeye 'sti tatsamānajātīye ca sarvasmin guṇavattvam asarvasmin kriyāvattvam / ubhayamapyetad adravye nāstyeva / tasmāt tasya vacanamapadeśa iti siddham /PDhS
analyzed: liṅga vacanam apadeśaḥ yat anumeyena sahacaritam tad samāna jātīye ca sāmānyena prasiddham tad aviparīte ca sarvasmin asat eva tat liṅgam uktam tasya vacanam apadeśaḥ yathā kriyāvat tvāt guṇavat tvāt ca tathā ca tad anumeye sti tad samāna jātīye ca sarvasmin guṇavat tvam asarvasmin kriyāvat tvam ubhayam api etat adravye na asti eva tasmāt tasya vacanam apadeśaḥ iti siddham pdhs
translated: An indication is a statement. That which is concomitant with what is to be inferred, and is well-known in general in what is of the same class, and is indeed non-existent in all that is not contrary to that, that is said to be the indication. The statement of that is an indication. For example, because of having action and because of having quality. And that exists in what is to be inferred, and in all that is of the same class, there is having quality, and in all that is not, there is having action. Both of these do not exist in what is not a substance. Therefore, the statement of that is an indication. This is established.

original: pratijñānantaraṃ hetulakṣaṇamāha liṅgavacanamapadeśaḥ iti / arthalakṣaṇatvād vacasāmiti liṅgalakṣaṇānuvādena apadeśasya lakṣaṇābhidhānamiti / yadanumeyena sahacaritaṃ tatsamānajātīye sarvatra ca sāmānyena prasiddham yathābhūto dharmo pakṣe tatsamānaḥ sapakṣe prasiddho na punarviśeṣaḥ / anyadharmāṇāmanyatrāvṛtteḥ / sarvatra ceti vyāpakāvyāpakabhedaṃ darśayati / tadviparīte ca vipakṣe sarvatra nāstyeveti vipakṣādyatyantavyāvṛttiṃ darśayati / prakaraṇasamakālātyayāpadiṣṭayośca vyudāsaḥ pūrvavadityetat liṅgamuktam iti lakṣaṇānuvādaḥ / tasya vācakaṃ vacanaṃ tṛtīyāntaṃ pañcamyantaṃ vā apadeśaḥ / tathā ca ayam itarasmāt bhidyate yathoktaliṅgavacanatvāt / yastu na bhidyate na cāsāvevam / yathā pratijñādiriti /
analyzed: pratijñā anantaram hetu lakṣaṇam āha liṅga vacanam apadeśaḥ iti artha lakṣaṇa tvāt vacasām iti liṅga lakṣaṇa anuvādena apadeśasya lakṣaṇa abhidhānam iti yat anumeyena sahacaritam tat samāna jātīye sarvatra ca sāmānyena prasiddham yathābhūtaḥ dharmaḥ pakṣe tad samānaḥ sapakṣe prasiddhaḥ na punar viśeṣaḥ anya dharmāṇām anyatra āvṛtteḥ sarvatra ca iti vyāpaka avyāpaka bhedam darśayati tad viparīte ca vipakṣe sarvatra na asti eva iti vipak
translated: After the thesis, the definition of the reason is stated: Indication is the statement of the mark. Since words have the nature of meaning, the definition of indication is stated by way of restating the definition of the mark. That which co-occurs with the inferable object is generally well-known everywhere in things of the same class, such as the property of being smoky. A property that is similar in the subject is well-known in similar instances, but not a specific one, because other properties do not occur elsewhere. And everywhere shows the difference between the all-pervading and non-all-pervading. And in the contrary, which is the opposite of that, it does not exist at all shows the complete exclusion from the contrary, etc. The exclusion of the inconclusive and the contradictory is as before. This is the stated mark. The statement of that is the definition restated. The statement that expresses that, either ending in the instrumental or dative case, is the indication. And thus this differs from the other, because it has the stated mark and statement. But that which does not differ is not so, like the thesis. For example,

original: tasya vyāpakāvyāpakasvarūpopadarśanārtham udāharaṇadvayam yathā kriyāII /vattvād guṇavattvācca iti / caśabdena prakārāntaraṃ kriyāvattvena guṇavattvena ceti darśayati / anayorlakṣaṇenābhisambandhopadarśanārthamanuvādaḥ / tathā ca tat kriyāvattvaṃ guṇavattvañcānumeye pakṣe 'sti / tatsamānajātīye ca sapakṣe sarvasmin guṇavattvam asarvasmin kriyāvattvamastīti / ubhayamapyetad adravye sattādau nāstyeveti tasya guṇavattvasya kriyāvattvasya ca yathoktam vacanamapadeśa iti siddham /
analyzed: tasya vyāpaka avyāpaka svarūpa upadarśana artham udāharaṇa dvayam yathā guṇavat tvāt ca iti caśabdena prakāra antaram kriyāvat tvena guṇavat tvena ca iti darśayati anayoḥ lakṣaṇena abhisambandha upadarśana artham anuvādaḥ tathā ca tat kriyāvat tvam guṇavat tvam ca anumeye pakṣe sti tad samāna jātīye ca sapakṣe sarvasmin guṇavat tvam asarvasmin kriyāvat tvam asti iti ubhayam api etat adravye sattā ādau na asti eva iti tasya guṇavat tvasya kriyāvat tvasya ca yath
translated: In order to illustrate its all-pervading and non-pervading nature, two examples are given: Just as from the fact of having action and from the fact of having qualities. The word ca (and) shows another way: from having action and from having qualities. The repetition is for the purpose of showing the connection with the definition. And thus, that having action and having qualities exist in the subject to be inferred, and in all similar instances, in all that belongs to the same class, having qualities exists, and in all that does not belong to the same class, having action exists. And both of these do not exist at all in non-substance, such as existence, etc. Thus, the statement of having qualities and having action as described is established as an indication.

original: hetvābhāsanirūpaṇam
translated: The definition of fallacious reasons

original: etenāsiddhaviruddhasandigdhānadhyavasitavacanānāmanapadeśatvamuktaṃ bhavati / tatrāsiddhaścaturvidhaḥ / ubhayāsiddho 'nyatarāsiddhastadbhāvāsiddho 'numeyāsiddhaśceti / tatrobhayāsiddhaḥ / ubhayorvādiprativādinorasiddho yathā anityaḥ śabdaḥ sāvayavatvāditi / anyatarāsiddho yathā anityaḥ śabda kāryatvāditi / taddhāvāsiddho yathā dhūmabhāvenāgnyadhigatau kartavyāyāmupanyasyamāno vāṣpo dhūmabhāvenāsiddha iti / anumeyāsiddho yathā pārthivaṃ dravyaṃ tamaḥ kṛṣṇarūpavattvāditi /PDhS
analyzed: etena asiddha viruddha sandigdha anadhyavasita vacanānām anapadeśa tvam uktam bhavati tatra asiddhaḥ caturvidhaḥ ubhaya asiddhaḥ nyatara asiddhaḥ tad bhāva asiddhaḥ numeya asiddhaḥ ca iti tatra ubhaya asiddhaḥ ubhayoḥ vādi prativādinoḥ asiddhaḥ yathā anityaḥ śabdaḥ sāvayava tvāt iti anyatara asiddhaḥ yathā anityaḥ śabda kārya tvāt iti tad hāva asiddhaḥ yathā dhūma bhāvena agni adhigatau kartavyāyām upanyasyamānaḥ vāṣpaḥ dhūma bhāvena asiddhaḥ it
translated: By this, it is said that the statements that are unestablished, contradictory, doubtful, and inconclusive are not to be taught. Among them, the unestablished is of four kinds: unestablished for both, unestablished for one, unestablished as that, and unestablished as the inferable. Among them, unestablished for both is like saying sound is impermanent because it has parts, which is unestablished for both the proponent and the opponent. Unestablished for one is like saying sound is impermanent because it is a product, which is unestablished for the proponent. Unestablished as that is like when smoke is being presented as a means of knowing fire, the mist is unestablished as smoke. Unestablished as the inferable is like saying darkness is a substance made of earth because it has the quality of blackness, which is unestablished as the inferable.

original: etena sāmarthyād apadeśābhāsā nirastā bhavantīti svavākye parivarjanārthaṃ paravākye codbhāvanārthaṃ saṃlakṣyate / tatredaṃ sāmānyalakṣaṇam / apadeśavadābhāsamānāḥ samyaṅ matau apadeśābhāsāḥ / aheturavi /rapi viparyastabuddherhetuvadā /dbhāsate iti samyaṅmatāviti padam / etasmiṃśca pakṣe 'nyatarāsiddhasya samyaṅmatau hetuvadābhāsamānatvaṃ cintyam / tasya hi pakṣadharmatvādimattvamityato hetuvadābhāsamānatvād hetvābhāsā iti siddhaṃ lakṣaṇam / yasya tu heturapi tasya pakṣadharmatvādyupadarśanena hetutvapratipattau yatnaḥ kāryastatpratipatterhyarthapratipattau kāraṇatvāditi / ata eva anyatarāsiddho yadyapi vastuvṛttyā hetustathāpi pakṣadharmatayā pareṇāpratipannatvād asiddhabuddhiṃ janayatīti / pratipanne ca pramāṇataḥ pakṣadharmatvena sādhyasiddherbhāvād hetureveti /
analyzed: etena sāmarthyāt apadeśa ābhāsāḥ nirastāḥ bhavanti iti sva vākye parivarjana artham para vākye ca udbhāvanā artham saṃlakṣyate tatra idam sāmānya lakṣaṇam apadeśa vat ābhāsamānāḥ samyak matau apadeśa ābhāsāḥ ahetuḥ aviḥ api viparyasta buddheḥ hetu vadāt bhāsate iti samyak matau iti padam etasmin ca pakṣe nyatara asiddhasya samyak matau hetu vat ābhāsamāna tvam cintyam tasya hi pakṣa dharma tva ādimat tvam iti atas hetu vat ābhāsamāna tvāt hetvābhā
translated: By this, it is understood that the apparent fallacies are refuted by implication, for the purpose of avoiding them in one's own statement and for the purpose of pointing them out in the statements of others. There, this is the general definition: The apparent fallacies are those that appear as if they were fallacies, in a correct cognition. The word in a correct cognition means that even though the reason is non-existent and contradictory, it appears as if it were a reason. And in this case, it is to be considered how that which is not established for one of the two parties appears as if it were a reason in a correct cognition. For that [reason] has the nature of being a property of the subject and so on. Therefore, because it appears as if it were a reason, the definition of fallacious reasons is established as those that appear as if they were reasons. But for one for whom the reason is [established], effort must be made to establish its nature as a reason by showing that it is a property of the subject and so on, because the ascertainment of that [reason] is the cause for the ascertainment of the conclusion. For this very reason, even though the reason that is not established for one of the two parties is a reason in reality, it still generates the notion of non-establishment because it is not understood by the other party as a property of the subject and so on.

original: anye tu ahetavaḥ pakṣadharmatvādyanyatamarūpānanuvidhānāt samānadharmāṇo hetvābhāsā iti /
analyzed: anye tu ahetavaḥ pakṣa dharma tva ādi anyatama rūpa an anuvidhānāt samāna dharmāṇaḥ hetvābhāsāḥ iti
translated: Others, however, say that the fallacies of reason are similar to the valid reason in having the same properties, but do not conform to any one of the forms such as being a property of the subject, etc.

original: atha kiyatāṃ punarevamanapadeśatvamityāha asiddhaviruddhasandigdhānadhyavasitavacanānāmanapadeśatvamuktaṃ bhavati iti / tatrāsiddhaścaturvidhaḥ iti vibhāgaḥ / sāmānyalakṣaṇañca āśaṅkyamānapakṣavṛttitvam arthāllabhyate / āśaṅkyamāne hi pakṣe vattiḥ sarvasya viśeṣaṇāsiddhādiprapañcasyāstīti pakṣavyāpīdaṃ sāmānyalakṣaṇam / na caivaṃ pakṣāvṛttitvaṃ tasya asamarthaviśeṣaṇādibhedeṣu asambhavāt /
analyzed: atha kiyatām punar evam anapadeśa tvam iti āha asiddha viruddha sandigdha anadhyavasita vacanānām anapadeśa tvam uktam bhavati iti tatra asiddhaḥ caturvidhaḥ iti vibhāgaḥ sāmānya lakṣaṇam ca āśaṅkyamāna pakṣa vṛtti tvam arthāt labhyate āśaṅkyamāne hi pakṣe vattiḥ sarvasya viśeṣaṇa asiddha ādi prapañcasya asti iti pakṣa vyāpi idam sāmānya lakṣaṇam na ca evam pakṣa avṛtti tvam tasya asamartha viśeṣaṇa ādi bhedeṣu asambhavāt
translated: Now, how many of these are not fallacious? He says: It is said that the non-fallaciousness of the statements of the unestablished, contradictory, doubtful, and undetermined is stated. There, the unestablished is of four kinds, this is the division. And the general characteristic is understood from the meaning as being the occurrence in the subject that is suspected. For all the details such as the unestablished qualifier, etc. have occurrence in the suspected subject, so this general characteristic pervades the subject. And it is not like this, the occurrence in the subject, because it is impossible in the varieties of the incapable qualifier, etc.

original: kena rūpeṇa caturvidha ityāha ubhayāsiddho 'nyatarāsiddhastadbhāvāsiddho 'numeyāsiddhaśceti / tatra ubhayorvādiprativādinorasiddho yathā anityaḥ śabdaḥ sāvayavatvāditi śabde hi sāvayavatvaṃ nityānityavādinorna prasiddhamiti / anyatarāsiddho yathā anityaḥ śabdaḥ kāryatvāditi mīmāṃsakasya hi pratyabhijñānādikamupalabhamānasya śabde kāryatvaṃ tāvadasiddhaṃ yāvad anyatarapakṣavyudāsadvāreṇa pramāṇato na / vyavasthāpyata iti niścīyate / niścite tu pakṣadhamatve tataḥ sādhyaṃ pratipadyata eva / tadbhāvāsiddho yathā dhūmabhāvenāgnyadhigatau iti / dhūmatvenāniścitaṃ vāṣpādikamupalabhamānasyāgnyadhigatau kartavyāyāṃ tadbhāvāsiddho dhūmabhāvasyāniścitatvāditi / anumeyāsiddho yathā pārthivaṃ dravyaṃ tamaḥ kṛṣṇarūpavat /tvāditi /
analyzed: kena rūpeṇa caturvidhaḥ iti āha ubhaya asiddhaḥ nyatara asiddhaḥ tad bhāva asiddhaḥ numeya asiddhaḥ ca iti tatra ubhayoḥ vādi prativādinoḥ asiddhaḥ yathā anityaḥ śabdaḥ sāvayava tvāt iti śabde hi sāvayava tvam nitya anitya vādinoḥ na prasiddham iti anyatara asiddhaḥ yathā anityaḥ śabdaḥ kārya tvāt iti mīmāṃsakasya hi pratyabhijñāna ādikam upalabhamānasya śabde kārya tvam tāvat asiddham yāvat anyatara pakṣa vyudāsa dvāreṇa pramāṇataḥ na vy
translated: By what form is it fourfold? He says: Unestablished for both, unestablished for one, unestablished for the existence of that, and unestablished for the inferable. Among them, what is unestablished for both the proponent and the opponent is like Sound is impermanent because it has parts, for the existence of parts in sound is not established for either the proponent or the opponent of permanence. What is unestablished for one is like Sound is impermanent because it is a product, for a Mimamsaka who perceives recognition and so on, the fact that sound is a product is not established as long as it is not ascertained by a means of knowledge through the exclusion of either alternative. But when the fact that it is a property of the subject is ascertained, he certainly understands the probandum. What is unestablished for the existence of that is like When smoke is cognized as existing, for one who perceives what is not ascertained as smoke, such as steam, and so on, in the cognition of fire, is unestablished for the existence of that, because the existence of smoke is not ascertained. What is unestablished for the inferable is like The substance is earthy because it is a substance, for one who perceives water and so on, which are not ascertained as smoke, in the cognition of fire, is unestablished for the inferable, because the fact that it is a property of the subject is not ascertained.

original: sāṃkhyābhyupagatasya tamaso 'prasiddhatvād ayamāśrayāsiddho na tu abhāvarūpatamo 'pekṣayā / tasya tu pramāṇena prasiddheḥ pakṣīkaraṇe kṛṣṇarūpavat /tvaṃ svarūpāsiddhaṃ / na tvāśrayāsiddhamiti /
analyzed: sāṃkhya abhyupagatasya tamasaḥ prasiddha tvāt ayam āśraya asiddhaḥ na tu abhāva rūpa tamaḥ upekṣayā tasya tu pramāṇena prasiddheḥ pakṣīkaraṇe kṛṣṇa rūpavat tvam svarūpa asiddham na tu āśraya asiddham iti
translated: Since the darkness accepted by the Sāṃkhyas is not well-known, this is a fallacy of the locus being unestablished, not in relation to the darkness that is of the nature of non-existence. But when it is made the subject by establishing it through a means of knowledge, like the form of darkness, it is unestablished in its own nature, not unestablished in the locus.

original: nanvevamapi eṣāmubhayāsiddhe 'nyatarāsiddhe 'ntarbhāvavat tadbhāvāsiddhānumeyāsiddhayorapyantarbhāvaḥ syāditi kathaṃ cāturvidhyam / tayoravāntarabhedāpekṣayā tadbhāvāsiddhaḥ / parārthānumānasya prastutatvād ubhayāsiddho 'nyatarāsiddhaśceti bhidyate / evam anumeyāsiddho 'pīti cāturvidhyam /
analyzed: nanu evam api eṣām ubhaya asiddhe nyatara asiddhe ntarbhāva vat tad bhāva asiddha anumeya asiddhayoḥ api antarbhāvaḥ syāt iti katham cāturvidhyam tayoḥ avāntarabheda apekṣayā tad bhāva asiddhaḥ parārtha anumānasya prastuta tvāt ubhaya asiddhaḥ nyatara asiddhaḥ ca iti bhidyate evam anumeya asiddhaḥ u pi iti cāturvidhyam
translated: But even so, just as these [hetu-s] are included in the other two [hetu-s] which are not established for both [parties] and which are not established for one [party], the two [hetu-s] which are not established because of non-existence of the substratum and which are not established because of non-existence of the object to be inferred would also be included [in those two]. So how can there be a classification into four? [Answer:] Because of the need for further subdivisions, [the hetu-s] which are not established because of non-existence of the substratum are divided into [hetu-s] which are not established for both [parties] and [hetu-s] which are not established for one [party], since inference for the sake of others is the topic at hand. Similarly, [hetu-s] which are not established because of non-existence of the object to be inferred are also divided [in the same way]. Thus there is a classification into four.

original: anye tūbhayāsiddhaṃ yatra viśeṣaṇaṃ viśeṣyañca asiddhamiti / anyatarāsiddhantu viśeṣaṇāsiddhaṃ viśeṣyāsiddhaṃ veti manyante / na caitad bhāṣyakarturabhipretam / vādyabhiprāyeṇa udāharaṇopanyāsāt /
analyzed: anye tu ubhaya asiddham yatra viśeṣaṇam viśeṣyam ca asiddham iti anyatara asiddham tu viśeṣaṇa asiddham viśeṣya asiddham vā iti manyante na ca etat bhāṣya kartuḥ abhipretam vādi abhiprāyeṇa udāharaṇa upanyāsāt
translated: Others, however, think that [a hetu] which is not established for both [parties] is one where the qualifier and the qualified are not established, while [a hetu] which is not established for one [party] is either one where the qualifier is not established or one where the qualified is not established. But this is not the intention of the author of the commentary, because the example is presented from the point of view of the proponent.

original: anye tu svārthānumānasya tadbhāvāsiddho 'numeyāsiddhaśceti bhadaḥ sakalabhedasaṅgrāhakaḥ / parārthānumānasya tūbhayāsiddho 'nyatarāsiddhaśceti / atra tu svārthānumānena parārthasya bhedanirūpaṇamiṣṭameva / svātantryantu niṣidhyate /
analyzed: anye tu svārtha anumānasya tad bhāva asiddhaḥ numeya asiddhaḥ ca iti bhadaḥ sakala bheda saṅgrāhakaḥ parārtha anumānasya tu ubhaya asiddhaḥ nyatara asiddhaḥ ca iti atra tu svārtha anumānena parārthasya bheda nirūpaṇam iṣṭam eva svātantryam tu niṣidhyate
translated: Others, however, say that for inference for one's own sake, there are two types: the one not established for oneself and the one not established for both [self and other], while for inference for the sake of others, there are two types: the one not established for both [self and other] and the one not established for either [self or other]. But here, it is accepted that the distinction of inference for the sake of others is made from inference for one's own sake, but independence is denied.

original: yo hi anumeye 'vidyamāno 'pi tatsamānajātīye sarvasmin nāsti tadviparīte cāsti sa viparītasādhanād viruddho yathā yasmād viṣāṇī tasmād aśva iti /PDhS
analyzed: yaḥ hi anumeye vidyamānaḥ tad samāna jātīye sarvasmin na asti tad viparīte ca asti sa viparīta sādhanāt viruddhaḥ yathā yasmāt viṣāṇī tasmāt aśvaḥ iti
translated: That which does not exist in the inferable object but does not exist in anything of the same class and does exist in the opposite, is contradictory because it proves the opposite, like saying because it has horns, therefore it is a horse.

original: viruddhalakṣaṇamāha yo hyanumeye pakṣe vyāptyā avidyamāno 'pi tatsamānajātīye ca sapakṣe sarvasmin nāsti tadviparīte ca vipakṣe 'sti sa viparītasādhanād viruddho yathā yasmād viṣāṇī tasmād aśva iti / viṣāṇināṃ piṇḍaṃ pakṣīkṛtya aśvo 'yam iti sādhayato viṣāṇitvād iti heturviruddhaḥ / asya hi anaśvenaiva vyāptatvāt / ayantu vipakṣaikadeśavṛttiḥ / vidyamānasapakṣastathā vipakṣavyāpakaḥ nityaḥ śabdaḥ kāryatvād iti / avidyamānasapakṣo vipakṣavyāpakaḥ sarvaṃ kāryaṃ sarvajñakartṛkaṃ prameyatvāditi / vidyamānasapakṣo vipakṣaikadeśavṛttiḥ / jīvaccharīraṃ sātmakaṃ kāryatvāditi / ataścaturvidhaḥ /
analyzed: viruddha lakṣaṇam āha yaḥ hi anumeye pakṣe vyāptyā avidyamānaḥ tad samāna jātīye ca sapakṣe sarvasmin na asti tad viparīte ca vipakṣe sti sa viparīta sādhanāt viruddhaḥ yathā yasmāt viṣāṇī tasmāt aśvaḥ iti viṣāṇinām piṇḍam pakṣīkṛtya aśvaḥ yam iti sādhayataḥ viṣāṇi tvāt iti hetuḥ viruddhaḥ asya hi an aśvena eva vyāpta tvāt ayan tu vipakṣa eka deśa vṛttiḥ vidyamāna sapakṣaḥ tathā vipakṣa vyāpakaḥ nityaḥ śabdaḥ k
translated: The contradictory is stated: That which, though not present in the inferable subject by pervasion, is absent in all similar instances, i.e., in all sapakṣas, and is present in the dissimilar instances, i.e., in all vipakṣas, is contradictory because it proves the opposite, like saying because it has horns, therefore it is a horse. For one who posits this is a horse by taking an individual with horns as the subject, the reason because it has horns is contradictory, because it is pervaded only by non-horses. But this [reason] occurs in part of the vipakṣa. That which has a present sapakṣa and is pervasive of the vipakṣa is like sound is eternal because it is a product. That which has no present sapakṣa and is pervasive of the vipakṣa is like everything that is a product is created by an omniscient creator because it is an object of knowledge. That which has a present sapakṣa and occurs in part of the vipakṣa is like the living body has a soul because it is a product. Therefore, it is of four kinds.

original: yastu sannanumeye tatsamānāsamānajātīyayoḥ sādhāraṇaḥ sanneva sandehajanakatvāt sandigdho yathā yasmād viṣāṇī tasmād gauriti /PDhS
analyzed: yaḥ tu san anumeye tad samāna asamāna jātīyayoḥ sādhāraṇaḥ san eva sandeha janaka tvāt sandigdhaḥ yathā yasmāt viṣāṇī tasmāt gauḥ iti
translated: That which is present in the inferable object, and is common to both similar and dissimilar classes, is indeed present, but is doubtful because it generates doubt, like because it has horns, therefore it is a cow.

original: ekasmiṃśca dvayorhetvoryathoktalakṣaṇayorviruddhayoḥ sannipāte sati saṃśayadarśanādayamanyaḥ sandigdha iti kecit / yathā mūrtatvāmūrtatvaṃ prati manasaḥ kriyāvattvāsparśavatvayoriti /
analyzed: ekasmin ca dvayoḥ hetvoḥ yathā ukta lakṣaṇayoḥ viruddhayoḥ sannipāte sati saṃśaya darśanāt ayam anyaḥ sandigdhaḥ iti kecid yathā mūrta tva amūrta tvam prati manasaḥ kriyāvat tva asparśava tvayoḥ iti
translated: And some say that when two reasons with the stated characteristics are contradictory and combined in one thing, there is doubt, so this is another kind of doubt, like the perceptibility and imperceptibility of the mind due to its being an action and being intangible.

original: nanvayamasādhāraṇa eva acākṣuṣatvapratyakṣatvavat saṃhatayoranyatarapakṣāsambhavāt / tataścānadhyavasita iti vakṣyāmaḥ /
analyzed: nanu ayam asādhāraṇaḥ eva acākṣuṣa tva pratyakṣa tva vat saṃhatayoḥ anyatara pakṣa asambhavāt tatas ca anadhyavasitaḥ iti vakṣyāmaḥ
translated: But this is indeed the uncommon [reason], like being imperceptible to the eye and being perceptible, because it is impossible for either of the two combined to be the subject. Therefore we will say it is inconclusive.

original: nanu śāstre tatra tatra ubhayathā darśanaṃ saṃśayakāraṇamapadiśyata iti / na / saṃśayo viṣayadvaitadarśanāt / saṃśayotpattau viṣayadvaitadarśanameva kāraṇam / tulyabalatve ca tayoḥ parasparavirodhāt nirṇayānutpādakatvaṃ syānna tu saṃśayahetutvam / na ca tayostulyabalatvamasti anyatarasyānumeyoddeśasyāgamabādhitatvād ayantu viruddhabheda eva /
analyzed: nanu śāstre tatra tatra ubhayathā darśanam saṃśaya kāraṇam apadiśyate iti na saṃśayaḥ viṣaya dvaita darśanāt saṃśaya utpattau viṣaya dvaita darśanam eva kāraṇam tulya bala tve ca tayoḥ paraspara virodhāt nirṇaya anutpādaka tvam syāt na tu saṃśaya hetu tvam na ca tayoḥ tulya bala tvam asti anyatarasya anumeya uddeśasya āgama bādhita tvāt ayan tu viruddha bhedaḥ eva
translated: But it is said in the scriptures that the seeing of both ways is the cause of doubt. No, doubt arises from seeing two objects. In the production of doubt, the seeing of two objects is the only cause. And if they are of equal strength, due to mutual contradiction, there would be no production of certainty, not the cause of doubt. And they are not of equal strength, because one of them, the object of inference, is contradicted by scripture. This is indeed the contradiction of opposites.

original: yastu sannanumeye vyāptyā tatsamānāsamānajātīyayoḥ sapakṣavipakṣayoḥ sanneva / sa sandigdho 'naikāntikaḥ / sandehajanakatvāt iti kāryopanyāso na tu lakṣaṇam / indriyādiṣvapi sadbhāvenātivyāpakatvāt / udāharaṇantu yathā yasmād viṣāṇī tasmād gauriti viṣāṇinaṃ piṇḍaṃ pakṣīkṛtya gauriti sādhayato viṣāṇitvāditi heturanaikāntikaḥ / pakṣatrayavṛttitvāt / ayantu sapakṣavyāpakatve sati vipakṣaikadeśavṛttiḥ / agaurayaṃ viṣāṇitvāt iti sapakṣaikadeśavṛttitve sati vipakṣavyāpakaḥ / sapakṣavipakṣaikadeśavṛttiśca nityaḥ śabdaḥ asparśavattvāt iti caturvidho 'naikāntikaḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ tu san anumeye vyāptyā tad samāna asamāna jātīyayoḥ sapakṣa vipakṣayoḥ san eva sa sandigdhaḥ na aikāntikaḥ sandeha janaka tvāt iti kārya upanyāsaḥ na tu lakṣaṇam indriya ādiṣu api sadbhāvena ativyāpaka tvāt udāharaṇam tu yathā yasmāt viṣāṇī tasmāt gauḥ iti viṣāṇinam piṇḍam pakṣīkṛtya gauḥ iti sādhayataḥ viṣāṇi tvāt iti hetuḥ anaikāntikaḥ pakṣa traya vṛtti tvāt  / ayam tu sapakṣa vyāpaka tve sati vipakṣa eka deśa
translated: That which is present in the inferable object by pervasion, and is present only in similar and dissimilar classes, is the doubtful uncertain. It is uncertain because it causes doubt. This is a statement of the effect, not the definition, because it is too wide, being present even in sense organs etc. An example is like because it has horns, therefore it is a cow. When a particular having horns is taken as the subject, and it is proved that it is a cow, the reason because it has horns is uncertain, because it occurs in three subjects. This is the fourfold uncertain: 1. occurring in a part of the similar class while pervading the dissimilar class, 2. occurring in a part of the similar class while pervading the dissimilar class, 3. occurring in a part of the similar class and a part of the dissimilar class, 4. occurring in a part of the similar class and a part of the dissimilar class. Sound is eternal because it is not in contact with the skin, this is the fourfold uncertain.

original: atha cāturvidhyamanupapannam / anaikāntikasya lakṣaṇañcāvyāpakam / viruddhāvyabhicāryasādhāraṇayoravyāpanād ityāśaṅkāpratiṣedhārtham ekasmiṃśca dvayoḥ ityādi prakaraṇam / dvayorhetvorvibhinnadharmisthayoḥ sannipāte saṃśayādarśanāt yathā nityaḥ śabdaḥ kāryatvāt / nityamākāśam akāryatvād iti ekasmin dharmiṇīti padam / tathātathāpyekasmin dharmiṇi dvayoḥ sannipāte 'pi na saṃśayo yathā anityaḥ śabdaḥ kāryatvāt / nityastvamūrtakāryatvāditi tadarthaṃ / yathoktalakṣaṇayoḥ /
analyzed: atha cāturvidhyam anupapannam anaikāntikasya lakṣaṇam ca avyāpakam viruddha avyabhicārya sādhāraṇayoḥ avyāpanāt iti āśaṅkā pratiṣedha artham ekasmin ca dvayoḥ ityādi prakaraṇam dvayoḥ hetvoḥ vibhinna dharmi sthayoḥ sannipāte saṃśaya adarśanāt yathā nityaḥ śabdaḥ kārya tvāt nityam ākāśam akārya tvāt iti ekasmin dharmiṇi iti padam tathā tathā api ekasmin dharmiṇi dvayoḥ sannipāte na saṃśayaḥ yathā anityaḥ śabdaḥ kārya tvāt nityaḥ tu
translated: Now, the fourfold division is not proper, and the definition of the inconclusive is not all-pervading, because the contradictory and the over-exclusive are not pervaded. To refute this doubt, the section beginning with in one and in two is stated. When two reasons are present in different subjects, there is no doubt, just as sound is eternal because of being a product and space is eternal because of being a non-product. The word in one subject is used. Even so, when two are present in one subject, there is no doubt, just as sound is non-eternal because of being a product and you are eternal because of being a non-material product. For that purpose, of those having the defined characteristics.

original: tathāpyaviruddhārthasādhakayorevaṃvidhayorapi na saṃśayahetutvaṃ yathā nityaḥ II / śabdaḥ kāryatvāt / āśrito guṇatvāt / ato viruddhayoḥ viruddhārthasādhakayoḥ sannipāte saṃśayasya darśanāt ayamanyaḥ sandigdhaḥ anaikāntika iti kecit / udāharaṇantu yathā mūrtatvāmūrtatvaṃ prati manasaḥ kriyāvattvāsparśavattvayoriti / mūrtaṃ manaḥ kriyāvattvāt chatravat ityekaḥ / amūrtaṃ manaḥ asparśavattvāt ākāśavat ityaparaḥ / ubhayośca pakṣadharmānvayavyatirekavattvopalabdheḥ kiṃ mūrtaṃ manaḥ syāduta amūrtamiti saṃśayaḥ /
analyzed: tathā api aviruddha artha sādhakayoḥ evaṃvidhayoḥ api na saṃśaya hetutvam yathā nityaḥ śabdaḥ kārya tvāt āśritaḥ guṇa tvāt  atas viruddhayoḥ viruddha artha sādhakayoḥ sannipāte saṃśayasya darśanāt ayam anyaḥ sandigdhaḥ anaikāntikaḥ iti kecid udāharaṇam tu yathā mūrta tva amūrta tvam prati manasaḥ kriyāvat tva asparśavat tvayoḥ iti mūrtam manaḥ kriyāvat tvāt chatra vat iti ekaḥ amūrtam manaḥ asparśavat tvāt ākāśa vat iti aparaḥ ubhayo
translated: Even so, when two such [reasons] establish non-contradictory meanings, they do not cause doubt, just as [the reasons] 'because of being an effect' and 'because of being a quality' [establish] that sound is eternal. Therefore, when two contradictory [reasons] establishing contradictory meanings come together, since doubt is seen, some say that this is another kind of inconclusive [reason] called 'doubtful'. But an example is like the case of the mind being both material and immaterial, [based on] the reasons 'because of being active' and 'because of being intangible'. One [argues] that the mind is material because it is active, like a stick. Another [argues] that the mind is immaterial because it is intangible, like space. Since both are seen to have the property of the subject, positive and negative concomitance, there is doubt as to whether the mind should be material or immaterial.

original: tadasat / ubhayoḥ prayogāsambhavāt / tathāhi / ekasmin sādhane prayukte tasya nirduṣṭatāyāṃ sādhyasiddheranyasya upanyāsānupapattiḥ / duṣṭatāyāṃ vā saiva asya abhidheyeti / na ca parasparaviruddhārthasādhakatvameva anumānayordoṣaḥ / pramāṇena ubhayorekatra sadbhāvasiddhau virodhasyābhāvaprasaṅgāt / avyabhicāryānumānayośca avaśyamarthavyavasthāpakatvam / avyabhicārasya tallakṣaṇatvāt / viparyaye tu vyabhicāritvameva / yathā mūrtaṃ mano 'sparśavattve sati kriyāvattvāt / amūrtañca kriyāvattve satyasparśavattvāt iti samastayoḥ prayogaḥ /
