analyzed: tat asat ubhayoḥ prayoga asambhavāt tathā hi ekasmin sādhane prayukte tasya nirduṣṭa tāyām sādhya siddheḥ anyasya upanyāsa anupapattiḥ duṣṭa tāyām vā sā eva asya abhidheyā iti  na ca paraspara viruddha artha sādhaka tvam eva anumānayoḥ doṣaḥ pramāṇena ubhayoḥ ekatra sadbhāva siddhau virodhasya abhāva prasaṅgāt avyabhicārya anumānayoḥ ca avaśyam artha vyavasthāpaka tvam avyabhicārasya tad lakṣaṇa tvāt viparyaye tu vyabhicāri tvam eva yathā mūrtam ma
translated: That is not so. Because both cannot be used. Thus, when one proof is used, if it is faultless, the conclusion is established and there is no scope for another. If it is faulty, it is itself to be refuted. And it is not a fault in two inferences to prove mutually contradictory things, because if both are established as existing in one place by a valid means of knowledge, there would be no contradiction. And in the case of two infallible inferences, there must be a determination of the meaning, because infallibility is the definition of that. In the opposite case, there would be fallibility itself. For example, the inference that the mind is material because it is active while being non-resistant, and the inference that it is immaterial because it is active while being non-resistant - the use of both together.

original: tatrāpi asādhāraṇamityāha nanvayamasādhāraṇa eva acākṣuṣatvapratyakṣatvavat / saṃhatayoranyatarapakṣāsambhavāt iti / yathā hi / rūpātīndriyaguṇavyatirekeṇa anyaguṇānāṃ guṇavyavahāre sādhyasāmānyavattvād dravyatve sati niyamenācākṣuṣatvaṃ heturna sapakṣe rūpādāvasti / nāpi vipakṣe ghaṭādāvityasādhāraṇaḥ / tadvat sahacarayoḥ kriyāvattvāsparśavattvayoranyatarapakṣāsambhavādityanyatarasmin sapakṣe vipakṣe vā asambhavād asādhāraṇatvam / na cāsyāsaṅgraha ityāha tataścānadhyavasita iti vakṣyāmaḥ /
analyzed: tatra api asādhāraṇam iti āha nanu ayam asādhāraṇaḥ eva acākṣuṣa tva pratyakṣa tva vat saṃhatayoḥ anyatara pakṣa asambhavāt iti yathā hi rūpa atīndriya guṇa vyatirekeṇa anya guṇānām guṇa vyavahāre sādhya sāmānyavat tvāt dravya tve sati niyamena acākṣuṣa tvam hetuḥ na sapakṣe rūpa ādau asti na api vipakṣe ghaṭa ādau iti asādhāraṇaḥ tadvat sahacarayoḥ kriyāvat tva asparśavat tvayoḥ anyatara pakṣa asambhavāt iti anyatarasmin sapakṣe v
translated: Even there, it is said to be uncommon, like being imperceptible to the eye and being perceptible. Because it is impossible for either of the two combined to be a subject. Just as, in the usage of qualities other than form and imperceptible qualities, the reason of being imperceptible when a substance, which is the universal of what is to be proven, is present, does not exist in the similar instance of form, nor in the dissimilar instance of a pot, so it is uncommon. Similarly, because it is impossible for either of the two co-occurring, being an action and being intangible, to be a subject, the fact that it is impossible for either of them to be in the similar instance or the dissimilar instance makes it uncommon. And it is not included in this, so it is said that we will say it is inconclusive.

original: yad vā cākṣuṣatvapratyakṣatvavat iti vaidharmyodāharaṇam / yathā hi guṇaḥ śabdaḥ sāmānyavattvād dravyatve sati niyamena acākṣuṣapratyakṣatvāt andhādivaditi / asya sapakṣaikadeśe vartamānasya vipakṣādatyantaṃ vyāvṛttirna caivaṃ kriyāvattvāsparśavattvayorityāha saṃhatayoranyatarapakṣāsambhavāt iti /
analyzed: yat vā cākṣuṣa tva pratyakṣa tva vat iti vaidharmya udāharaṇam yathā hi guṇaḥ śabdaḥ sāmānyavat tvāt dravya tve sati niyamena acākṣuṣa pratyakṣa tvāt andha ādi vat iti  asya sapakṣa eka deśe vartamānasya vipakṣāt atyantam vyāvṛttiḥ na ca evam kriyāvat tva asparśavat tvayoḥ iti āha saṃhatayoḥ anyatara pakṣa asambhavāt iti
translated: Or, like the example of dissimilarity, as in the case of being perceptible by the eye and being perceptible. Just as sound, being a quality, is necessarily imperceptible by the eye, because it has universals, while being a substance, like blindness, etc. This, occurring in part of the similar instance, has complete exclusion from the dissimilar instance. But this is not so in the case of being an action and being non-tangible. Therefore he says, because the combination cannot belong to either of the two parties.

original: evaṃ viruddhāvyabhicāriṇo 'sādhāraṇasya ca saṃśayahetutve nirākṛte sūtravirodhamudbhāvayannāha nanu ca / śāstre tatra tatrobhayathā darśanaṃ saṃśayakāraṇamapadiśyate II / iti / tatra tatra śāstre tasmiṃstasmin sūtre dṛṣṭañca dṛṣṭavat vai / sū / dṛṣṭvā saṃśayo bhavati / dṛṣṭañca manasi kriyāvattvaṃ punardṛṣṭena tulyaṃ vartata iti dṛṣṭavad asparśavattvam / ato viruddhasādhānābhisambaddhaṃ mano dṛṣṭvā saṃśete kiṃ mūrtam uta amūrtaṃ mana iti / 'yathā dṛṣṭam ayathādṛṣṭañca va / sū / ubhayathā dṛṣṭatvāt saṃśaya ityasādhāraṇasya ca saṃśayahetutvamuktam / yathā dṛṣṭaṃ pakṣe / punarayathā dṛṣṭaṃ sapakṣe / vipakṣe ca na dṛṣṭam / ata ubhayathā dṛṣṭatvāt saṃśayaḥ /
analyzed: evam sādhāraṇasya ca saṃśaya hetu tve nirākṛte sūtra virodham udbhāvayan āha nanu ca śāstre tatra tatra ubhayathā darśanam saṃśaya kāraṇam apadiśyate iti tatra tatra śāstre tasmin tasmin sūtre dṛṣṭam ca dṛṣṭa vat vai dṛṣṭvā saṃśayaḥ bhavati dṛṣṭam ca manasi kriyāvat tvam punar dṛṣṭena tulyam vartate iti dṛṣṭa vat asparśavat tvam atas viruddha sādhāna abhisambaddham manaḥ dṛṣṭvā saṃśete kim mūrtam asparśavat tvam atas vir
translated: Thus, when contradictory non-deviating and uncommon causes of doubt have been refuted, pointing out the contradiction with the aphorisms, he says: But in that and that treatise, doubt is shown to arise from seeing both ways. There, in that and that treatise, in that and that aphorism, and what is seen is seen as seen. Having seen, doubt arises. And what is seen as having activity in the mind again occurs as similar to what is seen. Therefore, having seen the mind connected with contradictory means of proof, one doubts whether the mind is material or immaterial. As seen and not as seen. And because it is seen both ways, doubt is stated to arise from the uncommon. As seen in the proposition, again not as seen in the similar instance, and not seen in the dissimilar instance. Therefore, doubt arises from being seen both ways.

original: yad vā yathādṛṣṭaṃ kriyāvattvena punarayathādṛṣṭam asparśavattvena / ata ubhayathā ubhābhyāṃ saha dṛṣṭatvāt saṃśaya ityuktaṃ pareṇāha na yuktam etat / saṃśayasya viṣayadvaitadarśanādutpatteḥ / asyaiva vivaraṇam saṃśayotpattau viṣayadvaitadarśanameva kāraṇam iti / viṣayadvaite dṛśyata iti viṣayadvaitadarśanaṃ sāmānayameva / viṣayasya vā dvaitaṃ dvaividhyaṃ yasya / tat tathoktaṃ sāmānyaṃ taddarśanameva / viruddhaviśeṣānuvṛttihetutvāt saṃśayakāraṇaṃ na viruddhahetusannipātaḥ / asādhāraṇadharmo vā / viruddhaviśeṣaiḥ sahānupalambhena tasya tatsmārakatvānupapatteḥ / viruddhaviśeṣānusmṛtihetuśca dharmaḥ saṃśayakāraṇaṃ na parasparavirodhī samānabala iti / samānabalatve ca tayoḥ parasparavirodhāt itarasyetareṇa pratibandhāt nirṇayānutpādakatvaṃ syānna tu / saṃśayahetutvam tailādinābhyaktasya śālibījasya svāṅkurānutpādakatvavaditi abhyupagamyaitaduktam / paramārthato na ca tayostulyabalatvamasti anyatarasya amūrtaṃ mana iti anumeyoddeśasyāgamavirodhitvāt iti / tathā cāgamaḥ tadabhāvādaṇu manaḥ vai / sū / iti / mūrtatvañca avyāpiparimāṇasambandhitvameva /
analyzed: yat vā yathādṛṣṭam kriyāvat tvena punar ayathādṛṣṭam asparśavat tvena atas ubhayathā ubhābhyām saha dṛṣṭa tvāt saṃśayaḥ iti uktam pareṇa āha na yuktam etat saṃśayasya viṣaya dvaita darśanāt utpatteḥ asya eva vivaraṇam saṃśaya utpattau viṣaya dvaita darśanam eva kāraṇam iti viṣaya dvaite dṛśyate iti viṣaya dvaita darśanam sāmānayam eva viṣayasya vā dvaitam dvaividhyam yasya tat tathā uktam sāmānyam tat darśanam eva viruddha viśeṣa an
translated: Or, it may be that what is seen as having action is again unseen as devoid of touch. Therefore, it is said by the opponent that doubt arises from seeing both in both ways, which is not correct. Because doubt arises from seeing the duality of the object. The explanation of this is that in the arising of doubt, the very seeing of the duality of the object is the cause. The duality of the object is seen, so the seeing of the duality of the object is a general characteristic. Or, the duality is the twofoldness of the object, that which has it is said to be so, that is the general characteristic, the seeing of that. Because it is the cause of the continuation of contradictory particulars, it is the cause of doubt, not the combination of contradictory causes. Or, it is the uncommon property. Because the non-apprehension along with the contradictory particulars cannot be the cause of its recollection. And the property that is the cause of the recollection of contradictory particulars is the cause of doubt, not the mutually contradictory equal strength. And in the case of their equal strength, because of their mutual contradiction, it is not the cause of doubt.

original: athedaṃ vacanamapramāṇam / tarhi manaḥsadbhāvāsiddherāśrayāsiddhamanumānamiti yathoktalakṣaṇānupapattiḥ / na ca mūrtatvānabhyupagame yugapajjñānānutpattyāpi manaḥsadbhāvasiddhiḥ / amūrtasya sakalendriyādhiṣṭhāyakatvena yugapajjñānotpattiprasaṅgāt / ataḥ pratijñāvacanasyāgamena virodhād amūrtānumānaṃ na yathoktalakṣaṇamiti / ayantu viruddhabhedaḥ pratijñāvasare 'bhihita eva / viruddhād bhidyate iti viruddhabhedaḥ kālātyayāpadiṣṭaḥ / duṣṭapakṣopanyāsānantaramupanyāsāt /
analyzed: atha idam vacanam apramāṇam tarhi manaḥ sadbhāva asiddheḥ āśraya asiddham anumānam iti yathā ukta lakṣaṇa anupapattiḥ na ca mūrta tva anabhyupagame yugapad jñāna anutpattyā api manaḥ sadbhāva siddhiḥ amūrtasya sakala indriya adhiṣṭhāyaka tvena yugapad jñāna utpatti prasaṅgāt atas pratijñā vacanasya āgamena virodhāt amūrta anumānam na yathā ukta lakṣaṇam iti ayam tu viruddha bhedaḥ pratijñā avasare bhihitaḥ eva viruddhāt bhidyate iti viruddha bhedaḥ
translated: If this statement is not valid, then since the existence of the mind is not established, the inference has an unestablished basis, and so does not fulfill the stated definition. And if incorporeality is not accepted, the existence of the mind cannot be established even by the non-simultaneity of cognitions, because the non-simultaneity of cognitions would follow from the incorporeal being the controller of all the senses. Therefore, since the inference of incorporeality contradicts the scriptures, it does not fulfill the stated definition. This contradiction was already mentioned at the time of the thesis. The contradiction with the contradictory is the fallacy of being contradicted by the passage of time. It is mentioned after the mention of the faulty thesis.

original: sūtradvitayañca ekadharmiviṣayatvena saṃśayapratipādanārthamiti vyākhyeyam / tathā ca / niyatasāmānyavastu pratiniyataviśeṣaiḥ sahacaritamekadā dṛṣṭaṃ punastattulyam anyaviśeṣāvinābhūtam / ataḥ kālāntare deśavyavadhānavaśāt taddṛṣṭvā saṃśete kimidamevam āhosvidevaṃ na bhavatīti / tathā ekadharmiviṣayatve 'pi / yathādṛṣṭam iti kiñcit sāmānyavadvastu kenacid viśeṣeṇa saha dṛṣṭam / ayathādṛṣṭam tadevopalabdhiviśeṣaśūnyaṃ viśeṣāntarasahitaṃ dṛṣṭam / ata ubhayathā dṛṣṭatvādubhābhyāṃ saha dṛṣṭatvād ubhayaśūnyasyopalabdhau tatsmaraṇe tu asati / saṃśayo bhavatīti / yathā devadattaṃ sakeśamupalabhya punarniṣkeśam / ataḥ kālāntare tameva veṣṭitaśirasamupalabhamānasya kimayaṃ sakeśo niṣkeśo veti saṃśayo bhavatīti /
analyzed: sūtra dvitayam ca eka dharmi viṣaya tvena saṃśaya pratipādana artham iti vyākhyeyam tathā ca niyata sāmānya vastu pratiniyata viśeṣaiḥ sahacaritam ekadā dṛṣṭam punar tat tulyam anya viśeṣa avinābhūtam atas kāla antare deśa vyavadhāna vaśāt tat dṛṣṭvā saṃśete kim idam evam āhosvit evam na bhavati iti tathā eka dharmi viṣaya tve pi yathādṛṣṭam iti kiñcid sāmānyavat vastu kenacid viśeṣeṇa saha dṛṣṭam ayathā dṛṣṭam tat eva upalabdhi vi
translated: And the two sūtras should be explained as presenting doubt by having the same substratum. Thus, a particular substance with a definite general property, when seen at one time as co-occurring with particularities, is again seen as similar to that, inseparable from other particularities. Therefore, seeing it at another time due to the influence of spatial separation, one doubts: Is this just so, or does it not exist in this way? Similarly, even when having the same substratum, what is seen as it was seen is a substance with a certain general property seen with a certain particularity. What is not seen as it was seen is that same [substance] devoid of the particularity of perception, seen with another particularity. Therefore, because it is seen in both ways, because it is seen with both, when there is no recollection of the absence of both upon perception, doubt arises. For example, having perceived Devadatta with hair, seeing him again without hair, at another time seeing him with his head wrapped, one doubts: Does he have hair or not?

original: yaśca sannanumeye tatsamānāsamānajātīyayorasanneva so 'nyatarāsiddho 'nadhyavasāyahetutvād anadhyavasitaḥ / yathā / sat kāryam utpatteḥ iti / ayam aprasiddho 'napadeśa iti vacanādavaruddhaḥ /PDhS
analyzed: yaḥ ca san anumeye tad samāna asamāna jātīyayoḥ asan eva saḥ nyatara asiddhaḥ na adhyavasāya hetu tvāt anadhyavasitaḥ yathā sat kāryam utpatteḥ iti ayam aprasiddhaḥ iti vacanāt avaruddhaḥ
translated: And that which is existent in the inferable object, but non-existent in objects of the same and different kinds, is either unestablished or undetermined, because it is not a cause of indecision, like the argument An effect exists because it originates. This is not a well-known indeterminate, as stated by the text.

original: nanu cāyaṃ viśeṣaḥ saṃśayaheturabhihitaḥ śāstre tulyajātīyeṣvarthāntarabhūteṣu viśeṣasyobhayathā dṛṣṭatvāditi / na / anyārthatvāt / śabde viśeṣadarśanāt saṃśayānutpattirityukte nāyaṃ dravyādīnāmanyatamasya viśeṣaḥ syācchrāvaṇatvam / kintu sāmānyameva sampadyate / kasmāt / tulyajātīyeṣvarthāntarabhūteṣu dravyādibhedānām ekaikaśo viśeṣasyobhayathā dṛṣṭatvādityuktaṃ na saṃśayakāraṇam / anyathā ṣaṭsvapi padārtheṣu saṃśayaprasaṅgāt / tasmāt sāmānyapratyayādeva saṃśaya iti /PDhS
analyzed: nanu ca ayam viśeṣaḥ saṃśaya hetuḥ abhihitaḥ śāstre tulya jātīyeṣu artha antara bhūteṣu viśeṣasya ubhayathā dṛṣṭa tvāt iti na anya artha tvāt śabde viśeṣa darśanāt saṃśaya anutpattiḥ iti ukte na ayam dravya ādīnām anyatamasya viśeṣaḥ syāt śrāvaṇa tvam kintu sāmānyam eva sampadyate kasmāt tulya jātīyeṣu artha antara bhūteṣu dravya ādi bhedānām ekaikaśas viśeṣasya ubhayathā dṛṣṭa tvāt iti uktam na saṃśaya kāraṇam anyathā
translated: But this distinction has been stated as a cause of doubt in the treatise: Because a distinction is seen in both ways among objects of the same kind that are different from the object in question. No, because it has a different purpose. When it is said that doubt does not arise from seeing a distinction in sound, this distinction of audibility would not be a distinction of any one of substance and so on, but would be a universal. Why? Because it is said that a distinction is seen in both ways among the different substances and so on that are different from the object in question, this is not a cause of doubt. Otherwise, doubt would arise regarding all six categories. Therefore, doubt arises only from the cognition of a universal.

original: samastasapakṣe tu asādhāraṇasyānadhyavasitvamāha yaśca sannanumeye tatsamānāsamānajātīyayoḥ sapakṣavipakṣayoḥ / asanneva ca / so 'nyatarāsiddho 'nadhyavasāyahetutvāt niścayānutpādakatvāt / atastaddhetutvād anadhyavasitaḥ / yathā sat kāryam utpatteḥ ityudāharaṇam / sakalaṃ kāryamutpatteḥ prāk sadanu /dutpadyamānatvāditi hetarna pratyā /ākāśādau nāpi kharaviṣāṇādāvityanadhyavasitaḥ
analyzed: samasta sapakṣe tu asādhāraṇasya anadhyavasitvam āha yaḥ ca san anumeye tad samāna asamāna jātīyayoḥ sapakṣa vipakṣayoḥ asan eva ca saḥ nyatara asiddhaḥ na adhyavasāya hetu tvāt niścaya anutpādaka tvāt atas tad hetu tvāt anadhyavasitaḥ yathā sat kāryam utpatteḥ iti udāharaṇam sakalam kāryam utpatteḥ prāk sat anudutpadyamāna tvāt iti hetoḥ na prati ākāśa ādau na api khara viṣāṇa ādau iti anadhyavasitaḥ
translated: But in the case of all similar instances, he says that the uncommon reason is inconclusive: That which exists in the object to be inferred, and in similar and dissimilar instances, and also that which does not exist, is either unestablished or inconclusive, because it does not produce certainty, it does not generate definite knowledge. Therefore, because it is the cause of that, it is inconclusive. For example, The effect exists because of origination. The reason because of origination is inconclusive, as it applies to all effects, which exist before origination, because they are about to originate. It does not apply to space, etc., nor to a barren woman's son, etc.

original: na cāsya sūtreṇāsaṅgraha ityāha ayamaprasiddho 'napadeśaḥ vai / sū / iti vacanādavaruddhaḥ sapakṣavipakṣayoraprasiddhatvāditi / evamasādhāraṇasya saṃśayahetutve niraste satravirodhamudbhāvayannāha nanu cāyaṃ viśeṣaḥ saṃśayaheturabhihitaḥ śāstre / tulyajātīyeṣu sapakṣeṣu / arthāntarabhūteṣu viśeṣeṣu /vipakṣeṣu ca / viśeṣasya asādhāraṇadharmasya / ubhayathā dṛṣṭatvāt sapakṣe vipakṣe ca dṛṣṭatvāt iti / anenāsādhāraṇasya saṃśayahetutvamuktamityāśaṅkyāha na / sūtrasya anyārthatvāt sattāsambandhitvāt / arthaśabdavācyatvācca kiṃ dravyaṃ guṇaḥ karma vā śabda iti saṃśayaḥ / na paraṃ sattāsambandhāt / śrāvaṇatvācca ityukte sūtrakāreṇa / paro brūte śrāvaṇatvaviśeṣasyopalabdheḥ kathaṃ śabde saṃśaya ityāśaṅkyāha nāyaṃ dravyādīnāmanyatamasya iti / na dravyasya guṇasya karmaṇo vā viśeṣaḥ śrāvaṇatvam / kintu sāmānyameva sampadyate / kasmāt / yasmāt guṇatve śabdasya sādhye tulyajātīyeṣu rūpādiṣu śuklatvādiviśeṣo guṇatvena sahacarito dṛṣṭaḥ / arthāntarabhūteṣu ca / utkṣepaṇādiṣu karmatvena sahacarita utkṣepaṇatvādiviśeṣo dṛṣṭastathā pṛthivyādiṣu pṛthivītvādirdravyatveneti / dravyādibhedānām dravyaguṇakarmaṇām / ekaikaśaḥ pratyekam / viśeṣasyobhayathā dṛṣṭvāt dravyaguṇatvādisahacaritasya dṛṣṭatvāt / upalabhyate ca śabde śrāvaṇatvaṃ viśeṣastad dravyatvādiviṣayaṃ smaraṇaṃ bhavatyeva / ataḥ kiṃ dravyasya sato 'yaṃ viśeṣaḥ śrāvaṇatvam / guṇasya karmaṇo vā / ityuktena nyāyena saṃśayakāraṇaṃ śrāvaṇatvam / na tu asādhāraṇatvena / ṣaṭsvapi padārtheṣu asādhāraṇadharmopalabdhau saṃśayaprasaṅgāt / utkṣepaṇatvādiviśeṣānupalabdheśca saṃśayakāraṇatvam anvayavyatirekābhyāmupalabdham na tadupalabdheḥ /
analyzed: na ca asya sūtreṇa asaṅgrahaḥ iti āha ayam aprasiddhaḥ vai iti vacanāt avaruddhaḥ sapakṣa vipakṣayoḥ aprasiddha tvāt iti evam asādhāraṇasya saṃśaya hetu tve niraste satra virodham udbhāvayan āha nanu ca ayam viśeṣaḥ saṃśaya hetuḥ abhihitaḥ śāstre tulya jātīyeṣu sapakṣeṣu artha antara bhūteṣu viśeṣeṣu vipakṣeṣu ca viśeṣasya asādhāraṇa dharmasya ubhayathā dṛṣṭa tvāt sapakṣe vipakṣe ca dṛṣṭa tvāt iti anena asādhāraṇas
translated: And it is not included in the Sutra, therefore he says: This is the unknown, the undefined, because of the statement This is not included in the Sutra. It is not included because it is unknown in both the similar and dissimilar cases. Thus, when the cause of doubt by the uncommon [reason] has been refuted, pointing out the contradiction with the Sutra, he says: But is not this special cause of doubt stated in the treatise? In similar cases, in the similar class, in special cases that are different objects, and in dissimilar cases, of the special, the uncommon property, because it is seen in both ways, because it is seen in the similar class and in the dissimilar class. By this, it is suspected that the cause of doubt by the uncommon [reason] is stated. He says: No, because the Sutra has another meaning, because of the relation to existence, and because of being denoted by the word object. The doubt is: Is sound a substance, a quality, or an action? Not ultimately, because of the relation to existence, and because of being audible, as stated by the author of the Sutra. When the other says: How is there doubt about sound, because of the perception of the special property of being audible?

original: na ca sarvasmād vyāvṛttaṃ viśeṣamupalabhamānasya viruddhaviśeṣānusmṛterabhāvāt saṃśayo yuktaḥ / sadbhāve 'pyanucchedaḥ syāt / nirṇayotpattikāraṇābhāvāt / tasmāt sāmānyapratyakṣādeva saṃśayaḥ na viśeṣadarśanādityupasaṃhāraḥ /
analyzed: na ca sarvasmāt vyāvṛttam viśeṣam upalabhamānasya viruddha viśeṣa anusmṛteḥ abhāvāt saṃśayaḥ yuktaḥ sadbhāve pi anucchedaḥ syāt nirṇaya utpatti kāraṇa abhāvāt tasmāt sāmānya pratyakṣāt eva saṃśayaḥ na viśeṣa darśanāt iti upasaṃhāraḥ
translated: And when one perceives a particular that is excluded from everything, doubt is not proper because there is no absence of the recollection of contradictory particulars. Even if it exists, there would be no cessation, because there is no cause for the arising of ascertainment. Therefore, doubt arises only from the perception of the universal, not from the perception of particulars. This is the conclusion.

original: yad vā viśeṣavattvasyobhayathā sapakṣavipakṣāviśeṣitasyopalabdhestadupalambhācca śabde saṃśayaḥ / na saṃśayakāraṇam asādhāraṇo dharmaḥ / ṣaṭsvapi padārtheṣu II / saṃśayaprasaṅgāditi / śeṣaṃ pūrvavat /
analyzed: yat vā viśeṣavat tvasya ubhayathā sapakṣa vipakṣa aviśeṣitasya upalabdheḥ tad upalambhāt ca śabde saṃśayaḥ na saṃśaya kāraṇam asādhāraṇaḥ dharmaḥ ṣaṭsu api padārtheṣu saṃśaya prasaṅgāt iti śeṣam pūrvavat
translated: Or, doubt arises from the perception of the presence of a particular in both, and from the perception of that in sound, because it is not specified as being only in similar or dissimilar instances. An uncommon property is not the cause of doubt, because doubt would arise in all six categories. The rest is as before.

original: dvividhaṃ nidarśanaṃ sādharmyeṇa vaidharmyeṇa ca / tatra anumeyasāmānyena liṅgasāmānyasyānuvidhānadarśanaṃ sādharmyanidarśanam / tad yathā / yad yat kriyāvat tat tad dravyaṃ dṛṣṭaṃ yathā śara iti / anumeyaviparyaye ca liṅgasyābhāvadarśanaṃ vaidharmyanidarśanam / tad yathā / yad yad adravyaṃ tat tat kriyāvanna bhavati yathā satteti /PDhS
analyzed: dvividham nidarśanam sādharmyeṇa vaidharmyeṇa ca  tatra anumeya sāmānyena liṅga sāmānyasya anuvidhāna darśanam sādharmya nidarśanam tat yathā yat yat kriyāvat tat tat dravyam dṛṣṭam yathā śaraḥ iti anumeya viparyaye ca liṅgasya abhāva darśanam vaidharmya nidarśanam tat yathā yat yat adravyam tat tat kriyāvat na bhavati yathā sattā iti pdhs
translated: An example is of two kinds: by similarity and by dissimilarity. Among them, the observation of the conformity of the universal of the inferential mark with the universal of the object to be inferred is the example by similarity. It is like this: Whatever is an action-possessor is seen to be a substance, like an arrow. And the observation of the absence of the inferential mark in the absence of the object to be inferred is the example by dissimilarity. It is like this: Whatever is not a substance does not have an action, like existence.

original: athāpadeśānantaraṃ nidarśanasvarūpanirūpaṇārtham dvividhaṃ nidarśanam ityādi prakaraṇam / dvividhamiti vibhāgo nidarśanamiti niruktirlakṣaṇam / nidarśyate sādhyasādhanayorbahirvyāptirasmin iti nidarśanaṃ dṛṣṭāntaḥ / tathā nidarśyate sādhyasādhanayorvyāptiraneneti nidarśanaṃ vyāptipratipādakaṃ dṛṣṭāntavacanam / tathāhi / nidarśanam itarasmād bhidyate yathoktadṛṣṭāntavacanatvāt / yastu na bhidyate na cāsāvevaṃ yathā pratijñādiriti /
analyzed: atha apadeśa anantaram nidarśana svarūpa nirūpaṇa artham dvividham nidarśanam ityādi prakaraṇam dvividham iti vibhāgaḥ nidarśanam iti niruktiḥ lakṣaṇam nidarśyate sādhya sādhanayoḥ bahis vyāptiḥ asmin iti nidarśanam dṛṣṭāntaḥ tathā nidarśyate sādhya sādhanayoḥ vyāptiḥ anena iti nidarśanam vyāpti pratipādakam dṛṣṭānta vacanam tathā hi nidarśanam itarasmāt bhidyate yathā ukta dṛṣṭānta vacana tvāt yaḥ tu na bhidyate na ca asau evam yathā
translated: Now, after the definition, the section beginning with The example is of two kinds is for the purpose of describing the nature of the example. Of two kinds is the division. Example is the definition. It is an example because the external pervasion of the probandum and probans is shown in it - the example is a statement of the pervasion. It is an example because the pervasion of the probandum and probans is shown by it - the example is a statement of the pervasion that establishes the pervasion. Thus, the example is distinguished from others because it is a statement of the example as described. But that which is not distinguished is not so, like the thesis and so on.

original: tat kena rūpeṇa dvividham / sādharmyeṇa vaidharmyeṇa ca iti / tatrānumeyasāmānyena sādhyasāmānyena / liṅgasāmānyasya sādhanasāmānyasya / anuvidhānadarśanaṃ sādharmyanidarśanam / sādhanasāmānyaṃ vyāpyam / vyāpakaṃ ca sādhyasāmānyamiti / yad yat kriyāvat tattad dravyaṃ dṛṣṭaṃ yathā śaraḥ ityudāharaṇam / atra hi dravyatvavyāptau kriyāvattvaṃ sādhanamastīti / anumeyaviparyaye sādhyaviparyaye / liṅgasya sādhanasya / abhāvadarśanaṃ vaidharmyanidarśanam tadyathā yad yad adravyaṃ tat tat kriyāvanna bhavati / yathā satteti / sattāyāṃ hi dravyatvavyāvṛttyā kriyāvattvavyāvṛttirastīti vaidharmyodāharaṇam /
analyzed: tat kena rūpeṇa dvividham sādharmyeṇa vaidharmyeṇa ca iti tatra anumeya sāmānyena sādhya sāmānyena liṅga sāmānyasya sādhana sāmānyasya anuvidhāna darśanam sādharmya nidarśanam sādhana sāmānyam vyāpyam vyāpakam ca sādhya sāmānyam iti yat yat kriyāvat tat tat dravyam dṛṣṭam yathā śaraḥ iti udāharaṇam atra hi dravya tva vyāptau kriyāvat tvam sādhanam asti iti anumeya viparyaye sādhya viparyaye liṅgasya sādhanasya abhāva darśanam vaidharmya nidarśanam
translated: In what form is it twofold? By similarity and dissimilarity. There, the observation of the concomitance of the universal of the inferable object with the universal of the probandum, and of the universal of the logical mark with the universal of the probans, is the illustration of similarity. The universal of the probans is the pervaded, and the universal of the probandum is the pervader. The example is: Whatever is an action-possessor is seen to be a substance, like an arrow. For here, in the pervasion of substantiality, there is the probans of being an action-possessor. In the absence of the inferable object, in the absence of the probandum, the observation of the absence of the logical mark, of the probans, is the illustration of dissimilarity. It is like this: Whatever is not a substance does not have action, like existence. For in existence, there is the exclusion of action-possession by the exclusion of substantiality, so it is an illustration of dissimilarity.

original: anena nidarśanābhāsā nirastā bhavanti / tad yathā nityaḥ śabdaḥ amūrtatvāt yad amūrtaṃ dṛṣṭaṃ tannityam / yathā paramāṇuḥ / yathā karma / yathā sthālī / yathā tamaḥ ambaravaditi / yad yad dravyaṃ tat tat kriyāvad dṛṣṭamiti ca liṅgānumeyobhayāśrayāsiddhānanugataviparītānugatāḥ sādharmyanidarśanābhāsāḥ /PDhS
analyzed: anena nidarśana ābhāsāḥ nirastāḥ bhavanti tat yathā nityaḥ śabdaḥ amūrta tvāt yat amūrtam dṛṣṭam tat nityam yathā paramāṇuḥ yathā karma yathā sthālī yathā tamaḥ ambara vat iti yat yat dravyam tat tat kriyāvat dṛṣṭam iti ca liṅga anumeya ubhaya āśraya asiddha ananugata viparīta anugatāḥ sādharmya nidarśana ābhāsāḥ pdhs
translated: By this, the fallacies of example are excluded. For example, Sound is eternal, because it is incorporeal. What is seen to be incorporeal is eternal, like an atom. Like an action. Like a pot. Like darkness. Like space. And Whatever is a substance, that is seen to be active, are the fallacies of positive example based on the reason, inference, and both, as well as the fallacies of non-establishment of the substratum, non-pervasion, and contrary pervasion.

original: yadanityaṃ tanmūrtaṃ dṛṣṭaṃ yathā karma / yathā paramāṇuḥ / yathākāśaṃ yathā II / tamaḥ ghaṭavat / yanniṣkriyaṃ tad adravyaṃ dṛṣṭañceti liṅgānumeyobhayāvyāvṛttāśrayāsiddhāvyāvṛttaviparītavyāvṛttā vaidharmyanidarśanābhāsā iti /PDhS
analyzed: yat anityam tat mūrtam dṛṣṭam yathā karma yathā paramāṇuḥ yathā ākāśam yathā tamaḥ ghaṭa vat yat niṣkriyam tat adravyam dṛṣṭam ca iti liṅga anumeya ubhaya avyāvṛtta āśraya asiddha avyāvṛtta viparīta vyāvṛttāḥ vaidharmya nidarśana ābhāsāḥ iti pdhs
translated: What is non-eternal is seen to be corporeal, like an action. Like an atom. Like space. Like darkness. Like a pot. What is inactive is seen to be non-substantial, are the fallacies of negative example based on the reason, inference, and both, as well as the fallacies of non-establishment of the substratum, non-exclusion, and contrary exclusion.

original: anena nidarśanābhāsāḥ nidarśanavadābhāsanta iti nidarśanābhāsāstatsamānadharmāṇaḥ / nirastā bhavanti iti svavākye parivarjanārthaṃ paravākye codbhāvanārthaṃ nirūpyante / tad yathā nityaḥ śabdaḥ amūrtatvāt / yad / yad amūrtaṃ dṛṣṭaṃ tannityaṃ dṛṣṭaṃ / yathā paramāṇuḥ iti / sādhanasyāmūrtasya paramāṇāvabhāvāt sādhanavikalamudāharaṇam / asminneva sādhye yathā karmeti sādhyavikalam / nityatvasya karmaṇyabhāvāt / yathā sthālī ityubhayavikalam / nityatvasyāmūrtatvasya ca sthālyāmabhāvāt / yathā tamaḥ iti dharmāsiddham / sāṃkhyābhyupagatasya tamaso 'prasiddhatvāt / ambaravat iti sādhyasādhanādhikaraṇatve 'pi ananugato vacanadoṣaḥ / yad yad amūrtaṃ dṛṣṭaṃ tattannityaṃ dṛṣṭaṃ yathā ambaramiti vacanaṃ vinā anugatasyāpratīteḥ /
analyzed: anena nidarśana ābhāsāḥ nidarśana vat ābhāsante iti nidarśana ābhāsāḥ tad samāna dharmāṇaḥ nirastāḥ bhavanti iti sva vākye parivarjana artham para vākye ca udbhāvanā artham nirūpyante tat yathā nityaḥ śabdaḥ amūrta tvāt yat yat amūrtam dṛṣṭam tat nityam dṛṣṭam yathā paramāṇuḥ iti sādhanasya amūrtasya paramāṇau abhāvāt sādhana vikalam udāharaṇam asmin eva sādhye yathā karma iti sādhya vikalam nitya tvasya karmaṇi abhāvāt yathā sthāl
translated: By this, the fallacies of example are shown. They appear as if they were examples, so they are fallacies of example, having the same characteristics as them. They are refuted, so they are described for the purpose of avoiding them in one's own statements and for the purpose of pointing them out in the statements of others. For example, sound is eternal because it is incorporeal. Whatever is seen to be incorporeal is seen to be eternal, like an atom. This example is defective in the reason, because incorporeality does not exist in an atom. In this very probandum, like an action, it is defective in the probandum, because eternality does not exist in an action. Like a pot, it is defective in both, because eternality and incorporeality do not exist in a pot. Like darkness, it is defective in the property, because darkness accepted by the Samkhyas is not well-known. Like space, even if the locus of the probandum and the probans is not well-known, it is a verbal fault. Whatever is seen to be incorporeal is seen to be eternal, like space, this statement

original: yad vā samyagdṛṣṭānto 'pi ākāśāsattvavādino na sādhyasiddhiṃ karoti yāvanna pramāṇato vyavasthāpyata ityābhāsa ucyate /
analyzed: yat vā ākāśa asattva vādinaḥ na sādhya siddhim karoti yāvat na pramāṇataḥ vyavasthāpyate iti ābhāsaḥ ucyate
translated: Or rather, even a correct example does not establish the probandum for one who maintains the non-existence of space until it is established by a means of valid knowledge, so it is called a semblance.

original: anye tu ābhāsāvasare samyagdṛṣṭāntopadarśanam ābhāsānām ābhāsatājñāpanārtham / itthambhūtaṃ hi nidarśanam / etatpratirūpakāṇi ca tadābhāsā iti /
analyzed: anye tu ābhāsa avasare samyak dṛṣṭānta upadarśanam ābhāsānām ābhāsa tā jñāpana artham ittham bhūtam hi nidarśanam etad pratirūpakāṇi ca tad ābhāsāḥ iti
translated: But others say that the presentation of a correct example at the time of a semblance is to make known the semblance nature of the semblances. For such is the example, and those that resemble it are its semblances.

original: yad yad dravyaṃ tattat kriyāvad dṛṣṭam iti ca viparītānugamaḥ / tathā ca evaṃ bruvato dravyatvaṃ vyāpyaṃ kriyāvattvañca vyāpakaṃ syāditi viparītā vyāpyavyāpakabhāvapratipattiḥ / na caitadasti / ākāśādau kriyāvattvaṃ vināpi dravyatvopalabdheḥ / samavyāptike 'pi sādhanasya vyāpakatvābhidhāne sādhyasya pratipattirna syāditi dūṣaṇam / viṣamavyāptike viparītānugamo doṣo na samavyāptike iti cānye / atropasaṃhāravākyaṃ liñgañca / anumeyaśca / ubhayañca / āśrayaśceti liṅgānumeyobhayāśrayāḥ / te asiddhā yeṣu ābhāseṣu te tathoktāḥ / te ca ananugatāśca / viparītānugatāśceti liṅgānumeyobhayāśrayāsiddhānanugataviparītānanugatāḥ sādharmyanidarśanābhāsāḥ /
analyzed: yat yat dravyam tat tat kriyāvat dṛṣṭam iti ca viparīta anugamaḥ tathā ca evam bruvataḥ dravya tvam vyāpyam kriyāvat tvañca vyāpakam syāt iti viparītā vyāpya vyāpaka bhāva pratipattiḥ na ca etat asti ākāśa ādau kriyāvat tvam vinā api dravya tva upalabdheḥ sama vyāptike sādhanasya vyāpaka tva abhidhāne sādhyasya pratipattiḥ na syāt iti dūṣaṇam viṣama vyāptike viparīta anugamaḥ doṣaḥ na sama vyāptike iti ca anye atra upasaṃhāra vākyam liñgaḥ ca
translated: And the reverse inclusion is: whatever is a substance is seen to be an action. And thus, for one who speaks thus, substantiality would be the pervaded and action-possessorship would be the pervader, so there is the understanding of the reverse pervaded and pervader relationship. And this is not so, because substantiality is observed even without action-possessorship in space and so on. And even when the reason has the same pervasion as the pervaded, the probandum is not established, so this is a fault. Others say that in the case of different pervasion, the reverse inclusion is a fault, but not in the case of the same pervasion. Here, the concluding statement, the inferential mark, and the object to be inferred, both of these, and the basis, are the basis of the inferential mark, the object to be inferred, and both. Those which are unestablished in them, the fallacies, are called thus. And they are non-concomitant and reversely concomitant, so the fallacies of similarity are the non-concomitant, reversely concomitant, and unestablished basis of the inferential mark, the object to be inferred, and both.

original: vaidharmyanidarśanābhāsān darśayati yadanityaṃ tanmūrtaṃ dṛṣṭaṃ yathā karma iti sādhanāvyāvṛttam / tasya hi amūrtatvāditi / tasminneva sādhye yathā paramāṇuḥ iti sādhyāvyāvṛttaṃ vyatirekodāharaṇam / paramāṇornityatvāditi / yathā ākāśam ityubhayāvyāvṛttam / amūrtatvasya nityatvasya ca tatrāvyāvṛttiriti / yathā tamaḥ iti dharmāsiddham / sāṃkhyābhyupagatasya tamaso 'prasiddhatvāditi / ghaṭavat ityubhayāvyāvṛttāvapi avyatirekaḥ / yad yannityaṃ na bhavati tattadamūrtaṃ na bhavatīti vacanaṃ vinā vyatirekasyāpratipatteḥ / ghaṭāsattvavādino vā pramāṇenāpratipādito na sādhyasiddhiṃ karotīti ābhāsa ucyate / yanniṣkriyaṃ tad adravyaṃ dṛṣṭam iti vyatirekaḥ / sādhyavyāvṛttyā hi sādhanavyāvṛttirvācyā / na tu sādhanavyāvṛttyā sādhyavyāvṛttiḥ / kriyāvattvābhāve 'pi ākāśādau dravyatvasya sādhyasyāvyāvṛtteḥ / sādhanābhāvo hi vyāpakaḥ sādhyābhāvo vyāpya iti / eteṣāmupasaṃhāraḥ / liṅgañca / anumeyaśca / ubhayañceti liṅgānumeyobhayāni / tāni avyāvṛttāni yeṣu ābhāseṣu te liṅgānumeyobhayāvyāvṛttāḥ / te ca āśrayāsiddhañca avyāvṛttañca viparītavyāvṛttañceti liṅgānumeyobhayāvyāvṛttāśrayāsiddhāvyāvṛttaviparītavyāvṛttā vaidharmyanidarśanābhāsāḥ iti /
analyzed: vaidharmya nidarśana ābhāsān darśayati yat anityam tat mūrtam dṛṣṭam yathā karma iti sādhana avyāvṛttam tasya hi amūrta tvāt iti tasmin eva sādhye yathā paramāṇuḥ iti sādhya avyāvṛttam vyatireka udāharaṇam paramāṇoḥ nitya tvāt iti yathā ākāśam iti ubhaya avyāvṛttam amūrta tvasya nitya tvasya ca tatra avyāvṛttiḥ iti yathā tamaḥ iti dharma asiddham sāṃkhya abhyupagatasya prasiddha tvāt iti ghaṭa vat iti ubhaya avyāvṛttau api avyatirekaḥ yat ya
translated: He shows the fallacious examples of negative concomitance: What is impermanent is seen to be material, like action, this is an example of the absence of the presence of the reason. For that [impermanent thing] is not material. In the same probandum, like an atom, this is an example of the absence of the presence of the probandum. Because an atom is permanent. Like space, this is an example of the absence of both. Because the absence of materiality and permanence is not present there. Like darkness, this is an example of the non-establishment of the property. Because darkness, which is accepted by the Sāṃkhyas, is not well-known. Like a pot, this is an example of the absence of both, but also of non-concomitance. Because without the statement What is not permanent is not material, the negative concomitance is not understood. Or, for one who advocates the non-existence of a pot, a means of knowledge that is not presented does not bring about the establishment of the probandum, so it is called fallacious. What is inactive is seen to be non-substance, this is negative concomitance. For the absence of the presence of the reason must be stated by the absence of the probandum.

original: nidarśane 'numeyasāmānyena saha dṛṣṭasya liṅgasāmānyasya anumeye 'nvānayanamanusandhānam / anumeyadharmamātratvenābhihitaṃ liṅgasāmānyamanupalabdhaśaktikaṃ nidarśane anumeyadharmasāmānyena saha dṛṣṭam anumeye yena vacanenānusandhīyate tadanusandhānam / tathā ca vāyuḥ kriyāvāniti / anumeyābhāve ca tasyāsattvamupalabhya / na ca tathā vāyurniṣkriya iti /PDhS
analyzed: nidarśane numeya sāmānyena saha dṛṣṭasya liṅga sāmānyasya anumeye nu ānayanam anusandhānam anumeya dharma mātra tvena abhihitam liṅga sāmānyam anupalabdha śaktikam nidarśane anumeya dharma sāmānyena saha dṛṣṭam anumeye yena vacanena anusandhīyate tat anusandhānam tathā ca vāyuḥ kriyāvān iti anumeya abhāve ca tasya asattvam upalabhya na ca tathā vāyuḥ niṣkriyaḥ iti pdhs
translated: In the example, the bringing of the general mark seen along with the general inferable object to the inferable object is the connecting. The general mark stated as merely the property of the inferable object, whose power has not been observed, is seen along with the general property of the inferable object in the example. The statement by which it is connected is the connecting. And thus, air is active. And when the inferable object is absent, its non-existence is observed. And not so, air is inactive.

original: evaṃ saha ābhāsairnidarśanamupadarśya anusandhānanirūpaṇārthamāha nidarśane 'numeyasāmānyena saha ityādi / nidarśane dṛṣṭānte / anumeyasāmānyena sādhyasāmānyena / saha dṛṣṭasya liṅgasāmānyasya anumeye pakṣe / anvānayanamanusandhānam / ānayanaṃ pratipādanamanyasyāpi sambhavatīti liṅgasyeti padam / tathāpi liṅgasya nidarśane pratipādanamastīti tadvyudāsāya anumeyapadam / anumeye ca gṛhītāvinābhāvasya liṅgasya pratipādakaṃ hetuvacanamapīti nidarśaneII /'numeyasāmānyena saha dṛṣṭasya liṅgasāmānyasyeti padam / ataḥ anusandhānamitarasmād bhidyate nidarśane gṛhītavyāptikasya liṅgasyānumeye 'nvānayanarūpatvāt / yastu na bhidyate na cāsāvevaṃ yathā pratijñādiriti /
analyzed: evam saha ābhāsaiḥ nidarśanam upadarśya anusandhāna nirūpaṇa artham āha nidarśane numeya sāmānyena saha ityādi nidarśane dṛṣṭānte anumeya sāmānyena sādhya sāmānyena saha dṛṣṭasya liṅga sāmānyasya anumeye pakṣe anvānayanam anusandhānam ānayanam pratipādanam anyasya api sambhavati iti liṅgasya iti padam tathā api liṅgasya nidarśane pratipādanam asti iti tad vyudāsāya anumeya padam anumeye ca gṛhīta avinābhāvasya liṅgasya pratipādakam hetu vacanam a
translated: Having thus shown the example along with the manifestation, he says to determine the connection, In the example, along with the universal of the inferable and so on. In the example, the illustration. Along with the universal of the probandum, the universal of the probandum. Of the seen universal of the reason in the inferable, in the subject. The bringing, the connection. Bringing, the presentation, is possible for another also, therefore the word of the reason. Still, the presentation of the reason in the example exists, to exclude that, the word inferable. And in the inferable, the statement of the reason, which is known to be invariably concomitant, is also the presentation. Therefore, the word of the reason in the example, along with the universal of the inferable is used. Thus, the connection is distinguished from the other, because in the example, the reason whose pervasion is known is brought to the inferable in the form of connection. But that which is not distinguished, and that is not so, like the proposition and so on.

original: saṅgrahoktervivaraṇamāha anumeyadharmamātratvenābhihitaṃ liṅgasāmānyam na tu samarthamiti mātrābhidhānena darśayati / anupalabdhaśaktikam iti / anupalabdhā śaktiravinābhāvo yasya tat tathoktam / punaḥ nidarśane 'numeyadharmasāmānyena saha dṛṣṭam / anumeye pakṣe yena vacanena anu paścāt sandhīyate pakṣadharmatayā khyāpyate tad anusandhānam /
analyzed: saṅgraha ukteḥ vivaraṇam āha anumeya dharma mātra tvena abhihitam liṅga sāmānyam na tu samartham iti mātra abhidhānena darśayati anupalabdha śaktikam iti anupalabdhā śaktiḥ avinābhāvaḥ yasya tat tathā uktam punar nidarśane numeya dharma sāmānyena saha dṛṣṭam anumeye pakṣe yena vacanena anu paścāt sandhīyate pakṣa dharma tayā khyāpyate tat anusandhānam
translated: He states the explanation of the statement in the Saṅgraha: The general mark is stated as merely the property of the inferable, but not as capable. He shows this by the statement merely. He says whose power is not perceived, meaning that whose invariable concomitance is not perceived. Again, it is seen together with the general property of the inferable in an example. The statement by which it is connected afterwards, i.e., made known as the property of the subject, in the inferable subject, is the connection.

original: tadapi dvividham / sādharmyeṇa vaidharmyeṇa ca / tatra anumeyasāmānyena saha liṅgasāmānyasya nidarśane sattvamupalabhyābhisandhatte tathā cāyaṃ kriyāvān vāyuriti / vaidharmyanidarśane tu anumeyasya dravyatvasyābhāve ca tasya kriyāvattvasyāsattvamupalabhya na ca tathā vāyurniṣkriya ityupasaṃhāraḥ / niṣkriyatvapratiṣedhena kriyāvattvamupasaṃharatīti / pṛthagvacanantu pratiṣedhābhiprāyeṇaiva /
analyzed: tat api dvividham sādharmyeṇa vaidharmyeṇa ca  / tatra anumeya sāmānyena saha liṅga sāmānyasya nidarśane sattvam upalabhya abhisandhatte tathā ca ayam kriyāvān vāyuḥ iti vaidharmya nidarśane tu anumeyasya dravya tvasya abhāve ca tasya kriyāvat tvasya asattvam upalabhya na ca tathā vāyuḥ niṣkriyaḥ iti upasaṃhāraḥ niṣkriya tva pratiṣedhena kriyāvat tvam upasaṃharati iti pṛthak vacanam tu pratiṣedha abhiprāyeṇa eva
translated: That also is of two kinds: by similarity and by dissimilarity. There, in the illustration by similarity, having perceived the existence of the universal of the inferential mark along with the universal of the object to be inferred, one concludes In the same way, this air is an agent, and in the illustration by dissimilarity, having perceived the non-existence of the universal of being an agent in the absence of the universal of being a substance in the object to be inferred, one concludes The air is not inactive in the same way, by negating inactivity, one concludes it is an agent. The separate statement is made with the intention of negation.

original: nanu vyarthamanusandhānavacanam / tadantareṇāpi hetuvacanād gṛhītavyāptikāt sādhyasiddheḥ / na / anena vinā abādhitaviṣayatvasyāpratipatteḥ / hetuvacanantu kāraṇamātropasthāpakam / na tu gṛhītavyāptikasya antarvyāptipratipādakamiti / yathābhūtena dravyatvāvinābhāvinā pramāṇāntarāviruddhena kriyāvattvena kriyāvān karaḥ / tathā ca vāyurityantarvyāptipratipattiḥ / tadabhāve tu bahirvyāptisadbhāve 'pi na gamakatvam / yathā śabdasya anityatve sādhye sāmānyavattve sati cākṣuṣapratyakṣaḥ / tasya kālātyayāpadiṣṭasya /tvaṃ ceti / ata evātropanayavacanaṃ na nirviṣayatvādapramāṇam /
analyzed: nanu vyartham anusandhāna vacanam tad antareṇa api hetu vacanāt gṛhīta vyāptikāt sādhya siddheḥ na anena vinā abādhita viṣaya tvasya apratipatteḥ hetu vacanan tu kāraṇa mātra upasthāpakam na tu gṛhīta vyāptikasya antar vyāpti pratipādakam iti yathā bhūtena dravya tva avinābhāvinā pramāṇa antara aviruddhena kriyāvat tvena kriyāvān karaḥ tathā ca vāyuḥ iti antar vyāpti pratipattiḥ tad abhāve tu bahis vyāpti sadbhāve pi na gamaka tvam yathā śabdasya anitya
translated: But it may be objected that the statement of the conclusion is useless, since the probandum can be established from the statement of the reason, even without it, by one who has grasped the pervasion. No, because without this, the fact that the subject is not contradicted is not understood. For the statement of the reason merely presents the mere cause, but does not convey the internal pervasion to one who has grasped the pervasion. For example, by the real, invariably concomitant property of being a substance, which is not contradicted by another means of knowledge, the hand is shown to possess action, and thus the wind is also shown to possess action, conveying the internal pervasion. But without that, even if the external pervasion exists, it is not a means of knowledge. For example, in establishing that sound is non-eternal, the fact that it is perceptible by the visual sense, which possesses generality, is an inconclusive reason, being contradicted by time. And so on. Therefore, the statement of the application is not a means of knowledge because it is devoid of an object, but because it conveys the internal pervasion.

original: na copasaṃhāraṃ vinā dharmiviśeṣeṇa sambandhāprasiddhau tatraiva sādhyaviśeṣapratipattiḥ syāt / svārthānumānakāle ca upanayārthasyopalabdheḥ kāryaṃ tadvacanam / svapratipattyanusāreṇa parārthānumānapravṛtteḥ / na ca svapratipattāvetasyāsatvam / avinābhāvasambandhasmaraṇānantaraṃ parāmaśaṃjñānasyānubhavāt / anabhyupagame ca sambandhasmaraṇasyāniyatatvāt niyatapradeśe pratipattirna syādityuktam /
analyzed: na ca upasaṃhāram vinā dharmi viśeṣeṇa sambandha aprasiddhau tatra eva sādhya viśeṣa pratipattiḥ syāt svārtha anumāna kāle ca upanaya arthasya upalabdheḥ kāryam tat vacanam sva pratipatti anusāreṇa parārtha anumāna pravṛtteḥ na ca sva pratipattau etasya asattvam avinābhāva sambandha smaraṇa anantaram parāmaśam jñānasya anubhavāt anabhyupagame ca sambandha smaraṇasya aniyata tvāt niyata pradeśe pratipattiḥ na syāt iti uktam
translated: And without a conclusion, when the connection with the particular subject is not established, the understanding of the particular probandum would not occur there itself. And since the meaning of the application is perceived at the time of one's own inference, the statement of that is necessary, because the inference for others proceeds in accordance with one's own understanding. And this is not absent in one's own understanding, because the knowledge of the object is experienced after the recollection of the relation of invariable concomitance. And if it is not accepted, it has been said that the knowledge in a particular place would not occur because the recollection of the relation would be uncertain.

original: tasmād ayamityaparokṣatānirdeśasyāvinābhāvasambandhasmaraṇānantaramupalabdherasti parāmarśajñānam / atastadupanyāsārthaṃ kāryamanusandhānavacanamiti /
analyzed: tasmāt ayam iti aparokṣa tā nirdeśasya avinābhāva sambandha smaraṇa anantaram upalabdheḥ asti parāmarśa jñānam atas tad upanyāsa artham kāryam anusandhāna vacanam iti
translated: Therefore, after the recollection of the relation of invariable concomitance, there is the knowledge of the object indicated by the expression this is in the non-perceptual designation. Hence, the statement of the conclusion is necessary for the purpose of stating that.

original: anumeyatvenoddiṣṭe cāniścite ca pareṣāṃ niścayāpādanārthaṃ pratijñāyāḥ punarvacanaṃ pratyāmnāyaḥ / pratipādyatvenoddiṣṭe cāniścite ca pareṣāṃ hetvādibhiravayavairāhitaśaktīnāṃ parisamāptena vākyena niścayāpādanārthaṃ pratijñāyāḥ punarvacanaṃ pratyāmnāyaḥ / tasmād dravyameveti /PDhS
analyzed: anumeya tvena uddiṣṭe ca aniścite ca pareṣām niścaya āpādana artham pratijñāyāḥ punarvacanam pratyāmnāyaḥ pratipādya tvena uddiṣṭe ca aniścite ca pareṣām hetu ādibhiḥ avayavaiḥ āhita śaktīnām parisamāptena vākyena niścaya āpādana artham pratijñāyāḥ punarvacanam pratyāmnāyaḥ tasmāt dravyam eva iti pdhs
translated: And when something is indicated as being to be inferred, and is uncertain to others, the repetition of the thesis is a restatement, for the purpose of bringing about certainty in others. And when something is indicated as being to be taught, and is uncertain, the repetition of the thesis is a restatement, for the purpose of bringing about certainty by the sentence that has completed the power imparted by the parts such as the reason, etc. Therefore, it is substance alone.

original: atha pratyāmnāyasvarūpopadarśanārtham anumeyatvenoddiṣṭe ityādi prakaraṇam / anumeyatvena anumānayogyatvena / uddiṣṭe cāniścite ca pareṣām saṃśayitaviparyastāvyutpannānām / punaḥ niścayāpādanārthaṃ pratijñāyāḥ punarvacanaṃ pratyāmnāyaḥ /
analyzed: atha pratyāmnāya svarūpa upadarśana artham anumeya tvena uddiṣṭe ityādi prakaraṇam anumeya tvena anumāna yogya tvena uddiṣṭe ca aniścite ca pareṣām saṃśayita viparyasta avyutpannānām punar niścaya āpādana artham pratijñāyāḥ punarvacanam pratyāmnāyaḥ
translated: Now, in order to show the nature of restatement, the section beginning with when something is indicated as being to be inferred is given. Being to be inferred means being suitable for inference. And when it is indicated and uncertain to others, who are doubtful, mistaken, or unlearned, the repetition of the thesis is a restatement, for the purpose of bringing about certainty.

original: saṅgrahoktervivaraṇamāha anumeye dharmamātre pratipādyatvena sādhyatvena / uddiṣṭe cāniścite ca pareṣām / kiṃ viśiṣṭānām / hetvādibhiravayavair /āhitaśaktīnām iti / āhitā śaktiravinābhāvo yasya liṅgasya yaistaistathoktaisteṣām / etasmāt sādhanād bhaviṣyati sādhyasiddhirityevaṃ kṛtāsthānāmiti bhāvaḥ / niścayāpādanārthaṃ pratijñāyāḥ punarvacanaṃ pratyāmnāyaḥ iti / punaruktamātravyavacchedārthaṃ pratijñāyāḥ punarvacanamiti padam / tathāpi anityaḥ śabdo 'nityaḥ śabda iti punaruktavyudāsārthaṃ niścayāpādanārthamiti padam / avipratipannasya etasmādapi niścayo bhavatīti tadarthaṃ pareṣāmiti / tathāpi teṣāṃ madhye kasyacid ekāvayavopadarśanena anvayavyatirekānusmaraṇadvāreṇa arthapratipattirbhavatīti parisamāptena vākyena iti grahaṇam / yasminnavayave sati vākyaṃ parisamāpyata iti / tadevaṃ pratyāmnāyaḥ itarasmād bhidyate yathoktalakṣaṇatvāditi /
analyzed: saṅgraha ukteḥ vivaraṇam āha anumeye dharma mātre pratipādya tvena sādhya tvena uddiṣṭe ca aniścite ca pareṣām  / kim viśiṣṭānām hetu ādibhiḥ avayavaiḥ āhita śaktīnām iti āhitā śaktiḥ avinābhāvaḥ yasya liṅgasya yaiḥ taiḥ tathā uktaiḥ teṣām etasmāt sādhanāt bhaviṣyati sādhya siddhiḥ iti evam kṛtāsthānām iti bhāvaḥ niścaya āpādana artham pratijñāyāḥ punarvacanam pratyāmnāyaḥ iti punar ukta mātra vyavaccheda artham pratijñāy
translated: He says the explanation of what is stated in the Saṅgraha: When the mere property of the inferable object is to be taught and proved, and is mentioned but not ascertained by others, what kind of? Those having the power produced by the parts such as the reason, etc. Those for whom the power of the inferential mark, which is the invariable concomitance, is produced by those very things mentioned thus. The idea is that from this proof, the establishment of the probandum will occur, thus having made a resolve. The restatement of the proposition for the purpose of bringing about ascertainment is the restatement. The word restatement of the proposition is for the purpose of excluding mere repetition. Even so, in order to exclude the repetition sound is impermanent, sound is impermanent, the word for the purpose of bringing about ascertainment is used. The idea is that even for one who is not in disagreement, ascertainment arises from this. For that purpose, the word of others is used. Even so, among them, for some, the understanding of the meaning occurs by the presentation of a single part, through the recollection of concomitance and non-concomitance.

original: nanu pratijñāvacanasya tu vināśitvena avasthānāsambhavāt kathaṃ punarvacanamiti / tatsamānaśabdoccāraṇāt / yathā kṣaṇikatve 'pi karmaṇaḥ pūrvaṃ samānābhinayakaraṇāt punarnṛtyatīti vyapadeśastadvat pratijñāsamānaśabdaprayogakaraṇāt punarvacanamiti vyapadeśo bhavatyeva / atiśaye pūnaḥśabdo vivakṣita iti pratijñā pakṣastasya punarvacanaṃ ghaṭata eva /
analyzed: nanu pratijñā vacanasya tu vināśi tvena avasthāna asambhavāt katham punarvacanam iti tad samāna śabda uccāraṇāt yathā kṣaṇika tve karmaṇaḥ pūrvam samāna abhinaya karaṇāt punar nṛtyati iti vyapadeśaḥ tadvat pratijñā samāna śabda prayoga karaṇāt punarvacanam iti vyapadeśaḥ bhavati eva atiśaye pūnaḥ śabdaḥ vivakṣitaḥ iti pratijñā pakṣaḥ tasya punarvacanam ghaṭate eva
translated: But since the statement of the proposition is destroyed, how can there be a repetition, since it cannot remain? It is because the same word is uttered. Just as an action is momentary, but due to the performance of the same dance before, it is designated as dancing again, similarly, because the same word of the proposition is used again, the designation of repetition is indeed made. When there is an excess, the word 'again' is intended. Thus, the proposition is the thesis, and its repetition is indeed possible.

original: liṅgavākyārthavādinastu pratijñāyate 'neneti pratijñā liṅgaṃ tasya punarvacanaṃ pratyāmnāya iti /
analyzed: liṅga vākya artha vādinaḥ tu pratijñāyate nena iti pratijñā liṅgam tasya punarvacanam pratyāmnāyaḥ iti
translated: But for one who asserts the meaning of the sentence as the reason, the proposition is that by which it is affirmed. The repetition of that is the restatement.

original: udāharaṇantu tasmād dravyameveti / etena adravyatvapratipādakapramāṇābhāvo 'pyupadarśita eva /
analyzed: udāharaṇam tu tasmāt dravyam eva iti etena adravya tva pratipādaka pramāṇa abhāvaḥ pi upadarśitaḥ eva
translated: The example is 'Therefore, it is a substance alone.' By this, the absence of a means of knowledge that establishes non-substance is also shown.

original: atha vyarthaṃ pratyāmnāyavacanam / sambandhābhidhānādeva vivakṣitārthaprasiddheḥ / taduktam /
analyzed: atha vyartham pratyāmnāya vacanam sambandha abhidhānāt eva vivakṣita artha prasiddheḥ tat uktam
translated: Now, the statement of the restatement is useless, because the intended meaning is established by the mere mention of the connection. That is said:

original: ḍiṇḍikarāgaṃ parityajyākṣiṇī nimīlya cintaya tāvat kiṃ iyatārthapratipattirbhavati naveti / yadi iha bhavati kimanayā śabdamālayā / na bhavatīti na vācyaṃ dṛṣṭatvāt hetubinduḥ / baḍodā / pṛṣṭha /
analyzed: ḍiṇḍika rāgam parityajya akṣiṇī nimīlya cintaya tāvat kim iyatā artha pratipattiḥ bhavati na vā iti yadi iha bhavati kim anayā śabda mālayā na bhavati iti na vācyam dṛṣṭa tvāt hetu binduḥ
translated: Abandoning the passion of the Dindika, closing your eyes, think for a while whether the understanding of the meaning occurs only with this much or not. If it occurs here, what is the use of this garland of words? It should not be said that it does not occur, because it is seen. The drop of reason. Vadod. Back.

original: naitadevaṃ / pratijñāvacanaṃ vinā anvayanyatirekāprasiddhau sambandhābhidhānasyāgamakatvena pūrvameva vyavasthāpitatvāt /
analyzed: na etat evam pratijñā vacanam vinā anvaya nyatireka aprasiddhau sambandha abhidhānasya āgamaka tvena pūrvam eva vyavasthāpita tvāt
translated: This is not so. Without the statement of the thesis, when the positive and negative concomitance are not established, the statement of the relation being non-indicative, it has been established earlier itself.

original: ne hyetasminnasati pareṣāmavayavānāṃ samastānāṃ vyastānāṃ vā tadarthavācakatvamasti / gamyamānārthatvāditi cenna / atiprasaṅgāt / tathāhi / pratijñānantaraṃ hetumātrābhidhānaṃ kartavyam / viduṣāmanvayavyatirekasmaraṇāt tadarthāvagatirbhaviṣyatīti / tasmādatraivārthaparisamāptiḥ /PDhS
analyzed: hi etasmin asati pareṣām avayavānām samastānām vyastānām vā tad artha vācaka tvam asti gamyamāna artha tvāt iti ced na atiprasaṅgāt tathā hi pratijñā anantaram hetu mātra abhidhānam kartavyam viduṣām anvaya vyatireka smaraṇāt tad artha avagatiḥ bhaviṣyati iti tasmāt atra eva artha parisamāptiḥ pdhs
translated: For, in the absence of this, the whole or the parts of others do not have the power to express that meaning. If it is argued that it is because the meaning is understood, it is not so, because of the absurdity. Thus, after the thesis, only the reason should be stated. The wise ones will remember the positive and negative concomitance and there will be understanding of the meaning. Therefore, the meaning is completed here itself.

original: katham / anitya śabdaḥ ityanena aniścitānityatvamātraviśiṣṭaḥ śabdaḥ kathyate / prayatnānantarīyakatvādityanena anityatvasādhanaṃ dharmamātramabhidhīyate / iha yat prayatnānantarīyakaṃ tadanityaṃ dṛṣṭam / yathā ghaṭa ityanena sādhyasāmānyena sādhanasāmānyasya anugamamātramucyate / nityam aprayatnānantarīyakaṃ dṛṣṭam / yathā ākāśam ityanena sādhyābhāvena saha sādhanasya asattvaṃ pradarśyate / tathā ca prayatnānantarīyakaḥ śabdo dṛṣṭaḥ / na ca tathā ākāśavadaprayatnānantarīyakaḥ śabda ityanvayavyatirekābhyāṃ dṛṣṭasāmarthyasya sādhanasāmānyasya śabde 'nusandhānaṃ gamyate / tasmād anityaḥ śabda ityanena anitya eva śabda iti pratipipādayiṣitārthaparisamāptirgamyate /PDhS
analyzed: katham anitya śabdaḥ iti anena aniścita anitya tva mātra viśiṣṭaḥ śabdaḥ kathyate prayatna ānantarīyaka tvāt iti anena anitya tva sādhanam dharma mātram abhidhīyate iha yat prayatna ānantarīyakam tat anityam dṛṣṭam yathā ghaṭaḥ iti anena sādhya sāmānyena sādhana sāmānyasya anugama mātram ucyate nityam aprayatna ānantarīyakam dṛṣṭam yathā ākāśam iti anena sādhya abhāvena saha sādhanasya asattvam pradarśyate tathā ca prayatna ānantarīyakaḥ śabda
translated: How? By sound is impermanent, only sound qualified by uncertain mere impermanence is stated. By because of being subsequent to effort, only the property that is the proof of impermanence is expressed. By whatever is subsequent to effort is seen to be impermanent, like a pot, the mere conformity of the general proof with the general probandum is stated. By the permanent is seen to be not subsequent to effort, like space, the non-existence of the proof along with the absence of the probandum is shown. And thus, sound is seen to be subsequent to effort. And sound is not like that, not not-subsequent-to-effort like space. By the positive and negative concomitance, the comprehension of the general proof, whose capacity has been seen, in sound is understood. Therefore, by sound is impermanent, it is understood that the intended meaning of sound is indeed impermanent is completed.

original: tasmāt pañcāvayavenaiva vākyena pareṣāṃ svaniścitārthapratipādanaṃ kriyata ityetat parārthānumānaṃ siddhamiti /PDhS
analyzed: tasmāt pañca avayavena eva vākyena pareṣām sva niścita artha pratipādanam kriyate iti etat parārtha anumānam siddham iti
translated: Therefore, the communication of one's own ascertained meaning to others is done only through a five-membered statement. Thus, this is established as inference for others.

original: atha pratijñāderevārthapratipādakatvamastu / kiṃ pratyāmnāyena / tathāhi / pratijñāvacanairviṣayavyavasthāpanād hetūdāharaṇābhyāṃ bahirvyāptiprasiddhau upanayenāntarvyāptyupadarśane sati avaśyamabhipretārthasiddhiriti / satyametat / tathāpi avaśyambhāvino 'rthasya pratijñādinā pratipāditasya pratipādanārthamavaśyaṃ kāryaṃ nigamanamityāha na hyetasmin iti / na pūrveṣāmavayavānāṃ samastānāṃ tadarthavācakatvamasti / vyastānāmitaretaravyāvṛttasvārthavyavasthāpane caritārthatvamityanyadato vācyaṃ yasya sahakāriṇāṃ pūrvapadānāṃ samastānāmapi smṛtyupasthāpitānāṃ vākyārthapratipādakatvamiti /
analyzed: atha pratijñā ādeḥ eva artha pratipādaka tvam astu kim pratyāmnāyena tathā hi pratijñā vacanaiḥ viṣaya vyavasthāpanāt hetu udāharaṇābhyām bahis vyāpti prasiddhau upanayena antar vyāpti upadarśane sati avaśyam abhipreta artha siddhiḥ iti satyam etat tathā api avaśyambhāvinaḥ rthasya pratijñā ādinā pratipāditasya pratipādana artham avaśyam kāryam nigamanam iti āha na hi etasmin iti na pūrveṣām avayavānām samastānām tad artha vācaka tvam asti vyastānām itar
translated: Now, let the statement of the thesis itself convey the meaning. What is the use of repetition? Thus, by the statements of the thesis, the subject is determined. When the external pervasion is established by the reason and example, and the internal pervasion is shown by the application, the desired meaning is necessarily accomplished. This is true. Nevertheless, the conclusion must be stated for the purpose of conveying the meaning of the necessarily occurring meaning that is conveyed by the thesis and so on. He says: For, the previous members taken together do not express that meaning. And when the individual meanings are mutually excluded and determined, the purpose is fulfilled. Therefore, something else must be stated, whose meaning is conveyed by the collective and remembered previous words that are its auxiliaries.

original: atha sādhanasya antarvyāptibahirvyāptyabhidhāne sati sādhyaviśeṣo gamyata evetyāha gamyamānārthatvāditi cenna / atiprasaṅgāt / tathāhi / pratijñānantaraṃ hetumātrābhidhānaṃ kartavyam svata eva viduṣāṃ hetūpalambhe sati anvayavyatirekānusmaraṇaṃ / tasmāccādhigatirbhaviṣyatīti viśeṣābhidhānavaiyarthyaṃ syāt /
analyzed: atha sādhanasya antar vyāpti bahis vyāpti abhidhāne sati sādhya viśeṣaḥ gamyate eva iti āha gamyamāna artha tvāt iti ced na atiprasaṅgāt tathā hi pratijñā anantaram hetu mātra abhidhānam kartavyam svatas eva viduṣām hetu upalambhe sati anvaya vyatireka anusmaraṇam tasmāt ca adhigatiḥ bhaviṣyati iti viśeṣa abhidhāna vaiyarthyam syāt
translated: If it is argued that when the internal and external pervasion of the proof is stated, the specific conclusion is understood itself, it is said: If it is argued that the meaning is understood, it is not so, because of overextension. Thus, after the thesis, only the reason should be stated, because the wise understand the reason by themselves, and then remember the positive and negative concomitance, and from that there will be understanding. Therefore, stating the specific conclusion would be pointless.

original: atha paraṃ pratipādayatā vacanenaiva pratipādanaṃ kāryamiti śeṣāṇāṃ prayogaḥ / tarhi vākyārthapratipādanārthaṃ nigamanamapi kāryam / na ca pratipādyābhiprāyeṇa prayogo yuktaḥ / tasya manuṣyadharmaṇā sākṣādapratīteravyavasthāpanācca / tathāhi / II / kaścidekasmādeva avayavādarthaṃ pratipadyate / kaścid dvābhyām / anyastribhirityanavasthitatvāt pratipādyānāṃ tadabhiprāyāniścaye prayogānupapattireva syāt / ataḥ paraṃ pratipādayatā svapratipattyupāyopadarśanaṃ kāryamiti pañcānāṃ prayogo yuktaḥ / tathāhi / pradeśasthaṃ dhūmamupalabhya avinābhāvasambandhaṃ smṛtvā tathā cāyaṃ dhūmavāniti parāmṛśati / tataḥ sādhyaṃ pratipadyate tasmādagnimāniti nigamanārthasyāpyupalabdheḥ parapratipādanāya tadupanyāso yukta eveti pañcānāṃ prayogaḥ kārya ityāha bhāṣyakāraḥ tasmādatraivārthaparisamāptiḥ iti /
analyzed: atha param pratipādayatā vacanena eva pratipādanam kāryam iti śeṣāṇām prayogaḥ tarhi vākya artha pratipādana artham nigamanam api kāryam na ca pratipādya abhiprāyeṇa prayogaḥ yuktaḥ tasya manuṣya dharmaṇā sākṣāt apratīteḥ avyavasthāpanāt ca  tathā hi kaścid ekasmāt eva avayavāt artham pratipadyate kaścid dvābhyām anyaḥ tribhiḥ iti anavasthita tvāt pratipādyānām tad abhiprāya aniścaye prayoga anupapattiḥ eva syāt atas param pratipādayatā sva pratip
translated: Now, if it is to be taught by the teacher through words alone, then the use of the remaining [parts] is as follows. Then, for the purpose of teaching the meaning of the sentence, the conclusion should also be stated. And it is not proper to use [the parts] according to the intention of the one to be taught, because that [intention] is not directly known by human means and because it is not established. It is like this. Some understand the meaning from just one part, some from two, and others from three. Because of the lack of a fixed rule for those to be taught, if their intention were uncertain, the use [of the parts] would not be possible at all. Therefore, it is proper for the five [parts] to be used, because the one who teaches should show the means of his own understanding. It is like this. Having perceived smoke located in a particular place, remembering the relation of invariable concomitance, he reflects thus: This has smoke. Then he understands the probandum. Therefore it has fire. Because the meaning of the conclusion is also perceived, for the purpose of teaching others, that [conclusion] is stated.

original: anye tu antarvyāptipratipādanārthaṃ nigamanamiti manyante / anusandhānāt pakṣavyāpakatvaprasiddhau viparītaprasaṅgapratiṣedhārthaṃ nigamanamiti /
analyzed: anye tu antar vyāpti pratipādana artham nigamanam iti manyante anusandhānāt pakṣa vyāpaka tva prasiddhau viparīta prasaṅga pratiṣedha artham nigamanam iti
translated: Others, however, think that the conclusion is stated in order to show the internal pervasion. The conclusion is stated in order to refute the opposite when the pervasion of the subject is established by the connection.

original: viparītārthavyavasthāpakapramāṇasyāprāmāṇyopadarśane sati pakṣe vyāptiḥ pratīyata eva / yatra ca parapakṣāpratiṣedhastatra hetorna gamakatvam / yathā mūrkho 'sau tatputratvāt upalabhyamānatatputravaditi / atra hi tatputrasya amūrkhatve na kiñcid bādhakamastīti tatsādhakapramāṇābhāvaśca niścita eveti anyathāsiddhaṃ sādhanametat /
analyzed: viparīta artha vyavasthāpaka pramāṇasya aprāmāṇya upadarśane sati pakṣe vyāptiḥ pratīyate eva yatra ca para pakṣa apratiṣedhaḥ tatra hetoḥ na gamaka tvam yathā mūrkhaḥ sau tatputra tvāt upalabhyamāna tatputra vat iti  atra hi tatputrasya amūrkha tve na kiñcid bādhakam asti iti tad sādhaka pramāṇa abhāvaḥ ca niścitaḥ eva iti anyathā asiddham sādhanam etat
translated: When the evidence establishing the opposite meaning is shown to be invalid, the pervasion in the subject is understood. And where there is no refutation of the opponent's position, the reason is not conclusive, like He is foolish because he is his son, like a son of his who is observed to be so. For here there is nothing contradictory in the son's non-foolishness, and the absence of evidence establishing that is certainly ascertained, so this is a reason that is otherwise established.

original: athāvinābhūtasya pramāṇavirodhābhāvānna yuktaṃ viparītapramāṇasyāprāmāṇyopadarśanamiti cenna / tadantareṇāvinābhāvasyaivāprasiddheḥ / tathāhi / nityatvapratipādakapramāṇasya prāmāṇye sati na śabde kṛtakatvasyānityatvena vyāptiḥ syāditi / na ca parapakṣapratiṣedhakādeva svapakṣasiddhiḥ / vyadhikaraṇatvāt / hetorapi vaiyarthyaprasaṅgācceti / parapakṣapratiṣedhe tūpadarśitabahirvyāptikaṃ pakṣe copalabhyamānaṃ bhavatyeva sādhanamiti nigamanaprayogaḥ kāryaḥ /
analyzed: atha avinābhūtasya pramāṇa virodha abhāvāt na yuktam viparīta pramāṇasya aprāmāṇya upadarśanam iti ced na tad antareṇa avinābhāvasya eva aprasiddheḥ tathā hi nitya tva pratipādaka pramāṇasya prāmāṇye sati na śabde kṛtaka tvasya anitya tvena vyāptiḥ syāt iti na ca parapakṣa pratiṣedhakāt eva sva pakṣa siddhiḥ vyadhikaraṇa tvāt hetoḥ api vaiyarthya prasaṅgāt ca iti parapakṣa pratiṣedhe tu upadarśita bahis vyāptikam pakṣe ca upalabhyamānam bhavat
translated: If it be said that, because there is no contradiction of the means of right knowledge in the case of what is inseparable from it, it is not proper to show that a contrary means of right knowledge is not a means of right knowledge, we say—no; because the inseparability from it is not known without that. For instance, if the means of right knowledge which teaches eternality is a means of right knowledge, then there would not be the pervasion of the producedness of sound by non-eternality. And the establishment of one’s own position is not from the negation of the position of another; because the reason is not in the same substratum, and because there would result the uselessness of the reason. But in the negation of the position of another, the means of right knowledge is indeed present in the position, which has the pervasion of the external shown, and which is present in the position. Therefore, the application of the conclusion should be made.

original: atha pratijñāvacanameva parapakṣapratiṣedhasahāyaṃ sādhanamiti cenna / tasya sādhyamātrābhidhāyakatvāt / sādhyam iti arhatyarthe / śakyārthe vā kṛtya /tābhidhānāt kathaṃ tadvacanāt tasya siddhiḥ / tasmād bahirvyāptivadantarvyāptiṃ samarthayatā abādhitaviṣayatvāsatpratipakṣatvapratipādanārthameva avayavāntaramabhidheyam /
analyzed: atha pratijñā vacanam eva parapakṣa pratiṣedha sahāyam sādhanam iti ced na tasya sādhya mātra abhidhāyaka tvāt sādhyam iti arhati arthe śakya arthe vā kṛtyatā abhidhānāt katham tad vacanāt tasya siddhiḥ tasmāt bahis vyāpti vat antar vyāptim samarthayatā abādhita viṣayatva asat pratipakṣatva pratipādana artham eva avayava antaram abhidheyam
translated: If it be said that the statement of the proposition itself is the proof, which is able to refute the opponent's view, that is not so. Because it merely expresses what is to be proved. The suffix kṛtya has the sense of what is to be done, or what is possible, in the sense of arhati (is worthy). How can that be established from its statement? Therefore, by one who seeks to establish internal pervasion like external pervasion, another part should be stated in order to show that the subject is not contradicted and that there is no counter-argument.

original: atha prakaraṇasamakālātyayāpadiṣṭayorapi bahirvyāptisadbhāvāt gamakatvaṃ / asti ca tayoḥ pakṣavyāpakatve satyanvayavyatirekasadbhāva iti / ayuktaII /metat / tādātmyatadutpattilakṣaṇapratibandhāyattastu avyabhicāro na bhavatītyuktaṃ vyāptisamarthanāvasare / tasmāduktanyāyena atraivārthaparisamāptiriti /
analyzed: atha prakaraṇa sama kāla atyaya apadiṣṭayoḥ api bahis vyāpti sadbhāvāt gamaka tvam asti ca tayoḥ pakṣa vyāpaka tve sati anvaya vyatireka sadbhāvaḥ iti tādātmya tad utpatti lakṣaṇa pratibandha āyattaḥ tu avyabhicāraḥ na bhavati iti uktam vyāpti samarthana avasare tasmāt ukta nyāyena atra eva artha parisamāptiḥ iti
translated: If it be said that even in the case of the similar locus and the fallacy of non-established reason, there is implication because external pervasion exists, and that there is the presence of positive and negative concomitance when the subject is pervaded by it, that is not correct. It has been said during the establishment of pervasion that invariable concomitance depends on the relation of identity and origination, and is not otherwise. Therefore, by the stated reasoning, the matter ends here itself.

original: evaṃ vibhinnaprakaraṇeṣu avayavānāṃ svarūpopadarśane 'pi ekatra tatsvarūpaparijñānāpekṣayā praśnaḥ katham iti / anityaḥ śabda ityanena aniścitānityatvamātraviśiṣṭaḥ śabdaḥ kathyate iti pratijñaiṣā / prayatnānantarīyakatvādityanena anityatvasādhanadharmamātramabhidhīyate na tu samarthamiti hetuvacanam / iha yat prayatnānantarīyakaṃ tadanityaṃ dṛṣṭaṃ yathā ghaṭa ityanena sādhyasāmānyena saha / sādhanasāmānyasyānugamamātramucyate iti sādharmyodāharaṇam / nityam aprayatnānantarīyakaṃ dṛṣṭaṃ yathā ākāśam ityanena sādhyābhāvena saha sādhanasyāsattvaṃ vyākhyāyate /pradarśyate iti vaidharmyodāharaṇam / tathā ca prayatnānantarīyakaḥ śabdaḥ na ca tathā prayatnānantarīyako na bhavatīti / anvayavyatirekābhyāṃ dṛṣṭasāmarthyasya sādhanasāmānyasya śabde 'nusandhānaṃ gamyate / tasmādanityaḥ eva /śabdaḥ ityanena anitya eva śabda iti pratipipādayiṣitārthaparisamāptirgamyate ityabhipretārthasiddhirbhavatīti / ataḥ pañcāvayavenaiva vākyena pareṣāṃ svaniścitārthapratipādanaṃ kriyate iti siddham /
analyzed: evam vibhinna prakaraṇeṣu avayavānām svarūpa upadarśane ekatra tad svarūpa parijñāna apekṣayā praśnaḥ katham iti anityaḥ śabdaḥ iti anena aniścita anitya tva mātra viśiṣṭaḥ śabdaḥ kathyate iti pratijñā eṣā prayatna ānantarīyaka tvāt iti anena anitya tva sādhana dharma mātram abhidhīyate na tu samartham iti hetu vacanam iha yat prayatna ānantarīyakam tat anityam dṛṣṭam yathā ghaṭaḥ iti anena sādhya sāmānyena saha sādhana sāmānyasya anugama māt
translated: Thus, even when the nature of the parts is shown in different sections, the question is asked with regard to the requirement of knowing their nature in one place. By sound is impermanent, only impermanence is stated without determination. This is the thesis. By because it is subsequent to effort, only the property that proves impermanence is mentioned, but not the valid [reason]. By whatever is subsequent to effort is seen to be impermanent, like a pot, the mere conformity of the general proof with the general probandum is stated. This is the example of similarity. The permanent is seen to be not subsequent to effort, like space, by this, the non-existence of the proof along with the absence of the probandum is explained. It is shown, this is the example of dissimilarity. And thus, sound is subsequent to effort, and it is not like that, not being subsequent to effort. The affirmative and negative concomitances

original: atra ca śabdaviśeṣasya pakṣīkaraṇe prayatnānantarīyakatvaṃ sādhanaṃ vivakṣitamiti jñeyam / anyathā hi śabdamātraparigrahe prayatnānantarīyakatvaṃ bhāgāsiddhaṃ syāt / na hi prayatnānantaraṃ sarvaśabdānāṃ janmāstīti /
analyzed: atra ca śabda viśeṣasya pakṣīkaraṇe prayatna ānantarīyaka tvam sādhanam vivakṣitam iti jñeyam anyathā hi śabda mātra parigrahe prayatna ānantarīyaka tvam bhāga asiddham syāt na hi prayatna anantaram sarva śabdānām janma asti iti
translated: And here, it should be understood that when a particular sound is taken as the subject, the intended reason is being preceded by effort. Otherwise, if only sound in general were taken, being preceded by effort would be partially unestablished, because not all sounds arise immediately after effort.

original: nirṇayavaidharmyam
analyzed: nirṇaya vaidharmyam
translated: The definition of ascertainment

original: viśeṣadarśanajamavadhāraṇajñānaṃ saṃśayavirodhī nirṇayaḥ / etadeva pratyakṣamanumānaṃ vā / yadviśeṣadarśanāt saṃśayavirodhyutpadyate sa pratyakṣanirṇayaḥ / yathā sthāṇupuruṣayorūrdhvatāmātrasādṛśyālocanād viśeṣevapratyakṣeṣu ubhayaviśeṣānusmaraṇāt kimayaṃ sthāṇuḥ puruṣo veti saṃśayotpattau satyāṃ / śiraḥpāṇyādiviśeṣa /darśanāt puruṣa evāyamityavadhāraṇajñānaṃ pratyakṣanirṇayaḥ /PDhS
analyzed: viśeṣa darśana jam avadhāraṇa jñānam saṃśaya virodhī nirṇayaḥ etat eva pratyakṣam anumānam vā yat viśeṣa darśanāt saṃśaya virodhi utpadyate sa pratyakṣa nirṇayaḥ yathā sthāṇu puruṣayoḥ ūrdhva tā mātra sādṛśya ālocanāt viśeṣa iva pratyakṣeṣu ubhaya viśeṣa anusmaraṇāt kim ayam sthāṇuḥ puruṣaḥ vā iti saṃśaya utpattau satyām śiraḥ pāṇi ādi viśeṣa darśanāt puruṣaḥ eva ayam iti avadhāraṇa jñānam pratyakṣa nirṇ
translated: Ascertainment is the knowledge of determination arising from the perception of particulars, which is opposed to doubt. This is either perception or inference. When from the perception of particulars, knowledge opposed to doubt arises, that is perceptual ascertainment. For example, when from seeing the mere similarity of uprightness in a post and a man, and from the recollection of the particulars of both, the doubt arises Is this a post or a man?, and then from the perception of the particulars of the head, hands, etc., the knowledge of determination This is a man is perceptual ascertainment.

original: viṣāṇamātradarśanād gaurgavayo veti saṃśayotpattau sāsnāmātradarśanād gaurevāyamityavadhāraṇajñānamanumānanirṇayaḥ /PDhS
analyzed: viṣāṇa mātra darśanāt gauḥ gavayaḥ vā iti saṃśaya utpattau sāsnā mātra darśanāt gauḥ eva ayam iti avadhāraṇa jñānam anumāna nirṇayaḥ
translated: When doubt arises upon seeing only the horn, thinking is it a cow or a gavaya, the ascertainment knowledge that it is indeed a cow upon seeing only the dewlap is the determination of inference.

original: atha nirṇayo vidyāntaramiti kecit / tanniṣedhārthaṃ viśeṣadarśanajam ityādi prakaraṇam / parārthānumānānantaramasyāntarbhāvanirūpaṇamatrāpi antarbhāvajñāpanārtham / nirṇaya iti lakṣyanirdeśo 'vaśiṣṭaṃ lakṣaṇam / avadhāraṇajñānaṃ hi viparyayajñānamapi bhavati na tu viśeṣadarśanājjāyate / viśeṣadarśanajaṃ cobha /ca saṃśayajñānamapītyavadhāraṇagrahaṇam /
analyzed: atha nirṇayaḥ vidyā antaram iti kecid tad niṣedha artham viśeṣa darśana jam ityādi prakaraṇam parārtha anumāna anantaram asya antarbhāva nirūpaṇam atra api antarbhāva jñāpana artham nirṇayaḥ iti lakṣya nirdeśaḥ lakṣaṇam avadhāraṇa jñānam hi viparyaya jñānam api bhavati na tu viśeṣa darśanāt jāyate viśeṣa darśana jam saṃśaya jñānam api iti avadhāraṇa grahaṇam
translated: Now, some think that determination is a different branch of knowledge. To refute that, the section beginning with arising from the perception of a specific feature is for the purpose of showing that it is included here, after the inference for others, in order to show that it is included here. Determination is the statement of the object to be defined. The rest is the definition. For ascertainment knowledge can also be erroneous knowledge, but it does not arise from the perception of a specific feature. And both doubt knowledge and ascertainment knowledge arise from the perception of a specific feature. Therefore, the word ascertainment is used.

original: tathāpi viśeṣadarśanajamavadhāraṇajñānaṃ nirṇaya ityukte vyabhicārābhāvād vyarthaṃ saṃśayavirodhīti padam / na / viśiṣṭanirṇayalakṣaṇārthatvāt / yadyapi viśeṣadarśanajamavadhāraṇajñānamiti sakalanirṇayavyāpīdaṃ sāmānyalakṣaṇaṃ tathāpi saṃśayavirodhīti padaṃ saṃśayapūrvakasya nirṇayasya lakṣaṇārtham / tathā ca naiyāyikairuktaṃ vimṛśya pakṣapratipakṣābhyāmarthāvadhāraṇaṃ nirṇayaḥ nyā / sū / / / iti saṃśayapūrvakasya lakṣaṇam / vimṛśyeti vimarśaṃ kṛtvā / pakṣapratipakṣābhyāmiti tadvacanābhyām / sa punaḥ sādhanadūṣaṇābhyāṃ nirṇaya iti /
analyzed: tathā api viśeṣa darśana jam avadhāraṇa jñānam nirṇayaḥ iti ukte vyabhicāra abhāvāt vyartham saṃśaya virodhi iti padam na viśiṣṭa nirṇaya lakṣaṇa ārtha tvāt yadi api viśeṣa darśana jam avadhāraṇa jñānam iti sakala nirṇaya vyāpi idam sāmānya lakṣaṇam tathā api saṃśaya virodhi iti padam saṃśaya pūrvakasya nirṇayasya lakṣaṇa artham tathā ca naiyāyikaiḥ uktam vimṛśya pakṣa pratipakṣābhyām artha avadhāraṇam nirṇayaḥ iti saṃś
translated: Still, when it is said that the determinate cognition arising from the perception of a particular is ascertainment, there is no fallacy, so the word 'contradictory to doubt' is useless. No, because it serves the purpose of defining a particular kind of ascertainment. Although this general definition applies to all kinds of ascertainment, namely, the determinate cognition arising from the perception of a particular, still the word 'contradictory to doubt' serves the purpose of defining ascertainment that is preceded by doubt. And thus it has been stated by the Naiyāyikas: Ascertainment of an object by deliberation through the prima facie view and the counter-view is decision (Nyāya Sūtra). This is the definition of that which is preceded by doubt. 'By deliberation' means after reflection. 'Through the prima facie view and the counter-view' means through those statements. And that is again decision through the proof and the refutation.

original: atha viśeṣadarśanāt saṃśayo vyāvartate / na nirṇayāditi kathaṃ tadvirodhitvam / upacāreṇa / nirṇayakāraṇasya saṃśayavirodhitvāt nirṇayastadvirodhītyuktam /
analyzed: atha viśeṣa darśanāt saṃśayaḥ vyāvartate na nirṇayāt iti katham tad virodhi tvam upacāreṇa nirṇaya kāraṇasya saṃśaya virodhi tvāt nirṇayaḥ tad virodhi iti uktam
translated: Now, if doubt is removed by the perception of a particular, not by ascertainment, how can it be contradictory to that? It is by metonymy. Because the cause of ascertainment is contradictory to doubt, ascertainment is said to be contradictory to it.
