original: asyāntarbhāvamāha etadeva pratyakṣamanumānaṃ vā na jñānāntaram / pratyakṣasāmagrījanyaṃ hi pratyakṣamanumānasāmagrījanyantu anumānamiti / yad viśeṣadarśanāt saṃśayavirodhyutpadyate sa nirṇayaḥ iti prāktanasya vivaraṇam /
analyzed: asya antarbhāvam āha etat eva pratyakṣam anumānam vā na jñāna antaram pratyakṣa sāmagrī janyam hi pratyakṣam anumāna sāmagrī janyantu anumānam iti yat viśeṣa darśanāt saṃśaya virodhi utpadyate sa nirṇayaḥ iti prāktanasya vivaraṇam
translated: He states its inclusion: This is either perception or inference, not a different kind of cognition. For perception is produced by the assemblage of causes of perception, and inference is produced by the assemblage of causes of inference. The explanation of the previous statement That which arises in contradiction to doubt from the perception of a particular is determination is this.

original: atra sthāṇupuruṣayorūrdhvatāmātrasādṛśyālocanād viśeṣeṣvapratyakṣeṣūbhayaviśeṣānusmaraṇāt kimayaṃ sthāṇuḥ puruṣo veti saṃśayotpattau satyāṃ śiraḥpāṇyādiviśeṣadarśanāt puruṣa evāyamityavadhāraṇajñānam indriyārthasannikarṣādutpatteḥ pratyakṣanirṇayaḥ / viṣāṇamātradarśanāt iti piṇḍavyavadhāne 'pi sādṛśyaviśiṣṭaviṣāṇadarśanāt / gaurgavayo veti saṃśayotpattau satyām / sāsnāmātradarśanāt avinābhāvasambandhasmaraṇe sati parāmarśajñānānantaram / gaurevāyamityavadhāraṇajñānaṃ anumānanirṇayaḥ /
analyzed: atra sthāṇu puruṣayoḥ ūrdhva tā mātra sādṛśya ālocanāt viśeṣeṣu apratyakṣeṣu ubhaya viśeṣa anusmaraṇāt kim ayam sthāṇuḥ puruṣaḥ vā iti saṃśaya utpattau satyām śiraḥ pāṇi ādi viśeṣa darśanāt puruṣaḥ eva ayam iti avadhāraṇa jñānam indriya artha sannikarṣāt utpatteḥ pratyakṣa nirṇayaḥ viṣāṇa mātra darśanāt iti piṇḍa vyavadhāne sādṛśya viśiṣṭa viṣāṇa darśanāt gauḥ gavayaḥ vā iti saṃśaya utpattau sa
translated: Here, due to the mere similarity of uprightness in a post and a man, when there is the arising of doubt as to whether this is a post or a man due to the recollection of both particulars while the particulars are imperceptible, the determinate cognition that this is indeed a man arises from the perception of the particulars of the head, hands, etc., and is a perceptual determination because it arises from the contact of sense and object. Even when obstructed by the body, the perception of the horn qualified by similarity leads to the arising of doubt as to whether this is a cow or a gavaya, and the determinate cognition that this is indeed a cow arises after the recollection of the relation of invariable concomitance upon seeing the mere dewlap. This is a inferential determination.

original: smṛtivaidharmyam
analyzed: smṛti vaidharmyam
translated: The difference from memory

original: liṅgadarśanecchānusmaraṇādyapekṣādātmamanasoḥ saṃyogaviśeṣāt paṭvabhyāsādarapratyayajanitācca saṃskārād dṛṣṭaśrutānubhūteṣvartheṣu śeṣānuvyavasāyānusmaraṇecchādveṣaheturatītaviṣayā smṛtiriti /PDhS
analyzed: liṅga darśana icchā anusmaraṇa ādi apekṣāt ātma manasoḥ saṃyoga viśeṣāt paṭu abhyāsa ādara pratyaya janitāt ca saṃskārāt dṛṣṭa śruta anubhūteṣu artheṣu śeṣa anuvyavasāya anusmaraṇa icchā dveṣa hetuḥ atīta viṣayā smṛtiḥ iti pdhs
translated: Memory is the cause of the determination, recollection, desire, and aversion towards objects that have been seen, heard, or experienced, and is produced from the specific conjunction of the self and mind that depends on the perception, desire, recollection, etc., and from the impression generated by the vivid practice and respect. It has a past object.

original: atha smṛteḥ kāryakāraṇaviṣayasvarūpanirūpaṇārthaṃ liṅgadarśanecchānusmaraṇādyapekṣāt ityādi prakaraṇam / liṅgadarśanecchānusmaraṇādyapekṣāt liṅgadarśanañca icchā ca anusmaraṇañceti tathoktāni / tānyādiryeṣāmityādipadena praṇidhānādergrahaṇam / tānyapekṣata iti tadapekṣastasmāt / ātmamanasoḥ saṃyogaviśeṣāt ityasamavāyikāraṇanirdeśaḥ / liṅgadarśanecchānusmaraṇādyapekṣāt paṭvabhyāsādarapratyayajanitācca saṃskārāt iti nimittakāraṇanirdeśaḥ / dṛṣṭaśrutānubhūteṣvartheṣu iti dṛṣṭaḥ pratyakṣeṇa / śrutaḥ śabdena / anubhūto 'numānena /
analyzed: atha smṛteḥ kārya kāraṇa viṣaya svarūpa nirūpaṇa artham liṅga darśana icchā anusmaraṇa ādi apekṣāt ityādi prakaraṇam liṅga darśana icchā anusmaraṇa ādi apekṣāt liṅga darśanam ca icchā ca anusmaraṇam ca iti tathā uktāni tāni ādiḥ yeṣām iti ādi padena praṇidhāna ādeḥ grahaṇam tāni apekṣate iti tad apekṣaḥ tasmāt ātma manasoḥ saṃyoga viśeṣāt iti asamavāyi kāraṇa nirdeśaḥ liṅga darśana icchā anusmaraṇa ādi apekṣāt pa
translated: Now, in order to describe the nature of the cause and effect of memory, the section begins with depending on the perception of an inferential mark, desire, recollection, etc. Perception of an inferential mark, desire, and recollection are mentioned as such. The word 'etc.' includes concentration and so on. It depends on those, therefore it depends on that. From a specific conjunction of the self and mind - this indicates the non-inherent cause. Depending on the perception of an inferential mark, desire, recollection, etc., and also from a latent impression produced by intense practice and respect - this indicates the instrumental cause. Regarding objects that are seen, heard, or experienced - seen by direct perception, heard by verbal testimony, and experienced by inference.

original: anye tu dṛṣṭaścakṣuṣā / anubhūtastvagindriyeṇeti /
analyzed: anye tu dṛṣṭaḥ cakṣuṣā anubhūtaḥ tvac indriyeṇa iti
translated: Others say: seen by the eye, and experienced by the tactile sense organ.

original: tatra liṅgaṃ darśayati śeṣānuvyavasāyānusmaraṇecchādveṣahetuḥ iti / upayuktālliṅgād anumeyaḥ śeṣaḥ / so 'nuvyavasīyate aneneti śeṣānuvyavasāyaḥ parāmarśajñānam / tasya heturavinābhāvasambandhasmaraṇam / tathā padasmaraṇād vākyasmaraṇam / sukhasmaraṇādicchā duḥkhasmaraṇād dveṣa iti / atītaviṣayā iti svarūpakathanam / atīto viṣayo yasyāḥ sā tathokteti /
analyzed: tatra liṅgam darśayati śeṣa anuvyavasāya anusmaraṇa icchā dveṣa hetuḥ iti upayuktāt liṅgāt anumeyaḥ śeṣaḥ saḥ nu vyavasīyate anena iti śeṣa anuvyavasāyaḥ parāmarśa jñānam tasya hetuḥ avinābhāva sambandha smaraṇam tathā pada smaraṇāt vākya smaraṇam sukha smaraṇāt icchā duḥkha smaraṇāt dveṣaḥ iti atīta viṣayā iti svarūpa kathanam atītaḥ viṣayaḥ yasyāḥ sā tathā uktā iti
translated: There, he shows the mark: The cause of subsequent ascertainment, recollection, desire, and aversion. The remainder to be inferred is from the employed mark. It is ascertained by this, therefore the subsequent ascertainment is the knowledge of reflection. The cause of that is the recollection of the relation of invariable concomitance. Similarly, the recollection of the sentence from the recollection of the word. Desire from the recollection of pleasure, aversion from the recollection of pain. The statement of its nature is having past objects. That which has past objects is said to be so.

original: nanvayuktametat / vidyamāne 'pi vastuni smaraṇasya darśanādityavyāptiḥ / ativyāptiśca anumānāderatītaviṣayatvāditi /
analyzed: nanu ayuktam etat vidyamāne vastuni smaraṇasya darśanāt iti avyāptiḥ ativyāptiḥ ca anumāna ādeḥ atīta viṣaya tvāt iti
translated: But this is not proper. Because recollection is seen even when the object exists, there is over-extension. And there is over-extension because inference and others have past objects as their objects, so it is not pervasion.

original: atha codanaiva bhūtaṃ bhaviṣyantaṃ viprakṛṣṭādikamarthaṃ prakāśayati nānyat kiñcana indriyādikamiti cenna / anumānasyāpi atītādyarthaprakāśakatvenopalambhāt / tathā ca / meghonnatyā bhaviṣyati vṛṣṭirityanumīyate / nadīpūrād viśiṣṭād upariṣṭād vṛṣṭirityuktam / pratyakṣañcātra avinābhāvagrāhakamabhyupeyam / anyathā vyāptigrahaṇābhāve 'numānameva na pravarteta / na cānumānenaivāvinābhāvagrahaṇam / anavasthāprasaṅgāt / vartamānena cāvinābhāvagrahaṇe katham atītāII /dyarthānumānaṃ syāt / anyenāvinābhāvagrahaṇe 'nyasyānumitau atiprasaṅgāt / tasmādatītaviṣayatvaṃ vyākhyeyamupacāreṇa / yatra hi viṣaye 'nubhavo 'tītastatra smṛtirutpadyata iti /
analyzed: atha codanā eva bhūtam bhaviṣyantam viprakṛṣṭa ādikam artham prakāśayati na anyat kiñcana indriya ādikam iti ced na anumānasya api atīta ādi artha prakāśaka tvena upalambhāt tathā ca megha unnatyā bhaviṣyati vṛṣṭiḥ iti anumīyate nadīpūrāt viśiṣṭāt upariṣṭāt vṛṣṭiḥ iti uktam pratyakṣam ca atra avinābhāva grāhakam abhyupeyam anyathā vyāpti grahaṇa abhāve numānam eva na pravarteta na ca anumānena eva avinābhāva grahaṇam anavasthā prasa
translated: The term ‘anvīkṣā’ (in the Sūtra) has been explained as ‘anvīkṣaṇam’ (which is the verbal form corresponding to the nominal ‘anvīkṣā’); the verbal form being changed into the nominal, in accordance with Pāṇini’s Sūtra 2.1.28. The term ‘anvīkṣaṇam’ is synonymous with ‘adhyavasāya’, ‘determinate cognition’, which is of the nature of ‘saṃśaya’ (doubt), ‘vipratipatti’ (contradictory cognition) and ‘nirṇaya’ (certainty).

original: anye tu atīto vyavahito viṣayo yasyānubhavasyāsau atītaviṣayaḥ / sa viṣayo yasyāḥ sā atītaviṣayeti prāpte sati ekasya viṣayasya lopo draṣṭavya ityatītānubhavaviṣayatvaṃ labhyata iti manyante /
analyzed: anye tu atītaḥ vyavahitaḥ viṣayaḥ yasya anubhavasya asau atīta viṣayaḥ sa viṣayaḥ yasyāḥ sā atīta viṣayā iti prāpte sati ekasya viṣayasya lopaḥ draṣṭavyaḥ iti atīta anubhava viṣaya tvam labhyate iti manyante
translated: Others, however, think that the meaning is that it has a past object, because it is an experience whose object is past, and that it is one whose object is past, because it is that whose object is past. When this is reached, it is to be seen that one object is omitted, and so it is thought that the meaning is that it is the object of a past experience.

original: atha arthajatvameva smṛteḥ kasmānneṣyate / arthavināśe 'pyutpādāt / na ca yaddeśakālāliṅgite 'nubhavajñānamutpannaṃ tadālambanameva nyāyyam / smṛtikāle tasyāvidyamānatayā viṣayatvābhāvāt / bāhyendriyāṇāñca smṛtijanmani pratyekaṃ vyabhicārādantaḥkaraṇasya vyāpāro niścīyate / na ca tasya svātantryeṇa bahirviṣaye vyāpāraḥ sambhavatīti anarthajatvameva nyāyyam / avaśyañca arthajatve sati avyabhicāritvādidharmopetatvāt pramārūpatāyāṃ smṛteḥ pramāṇādutpattirvācyā / anumānādeśca vyāpārānupalabdherantaḥkaraṇasya svātantryeṇa tadutpattau prāmāṇye sati smṛteraparokṣatvaṃ syāt / na caitadasti / tasmānnirviṣayatvameva /
analyzed: atha artha ja tvam eva smṛteḥ kasmāt na iṣyate artha vināśe pi utpādāt na ca yad deśa kāla āliṅgite nubhava jñānam utpannam tad ālambanam eva nyāyyam smṛti kāle tasya avidyamāna tayā viṣaya tva abhāvāt bāhya indriyāṇām ca smṛti janmani pratyekam vyabhicārāt antaḥkaraṇasya vyāpāraḥ niścīyate na ca tasya svātantryeṇa bahis viṣaye vyāpāraḥ sambhavati iti anartha ja tvam eva nyāyyam avaśyam ca artha ja tve sati avyabhicāri tva ādi dharma upeta tvāt
translated: Now, why is it not accepted that memory arises from the object itself? Because it arises even when the object is destroyed. And it is not reasonable that a memory-cognition which is not connected with a particular place, time and form should have that as its object, because at the time of memory, that [object] does not exist and cannot be its object. And because of the individual inconstancy of the external sense organs in the production of memory, the operation of the internal organ is ascertained. And since its operation with independence towards an external object is not possible, it is reasonable that [memory] arises from the object itself. And if it must arise from the object, then because of the property of non-deviation etc., it must be said that memory, which has the form of valid cognition, arises from a means of valid cognition. And because the operation of inference etc. is not perceived, if it arises by the independence of the internal organ, then when it is a means of valid cognition, memory would be non-conceptual. But this is not so. Therefore, it is only proper that it be objectless.

original: ārṣajñānavaidharmyam
analyzed: ārṣa jñāna vaidharmyam
translated: Dissimilarity with the knowledge of the sages

original: āmnāyavidhātṝṇāmṛṣīṇāmatītānāgatavartamāneṣvatīndriyeṣu dharmādiṣu granthopanibaddheṣvanupanibaddheṣa ca ātmamanasoḥ saṃyogād dharmaviśeṣācca yat prātibhaṃ yathātmanivedanaṃ jñānamutpadyate tad ārṣamityācakṣate / tattu prastāreṇa devarṣīṇām / kadācideva laukikānām / yathā kanyakā bravīti śvo me bhrātā āganteti hṛdayaṃ me kathayatīti /PDhS
analyzed: āmnāya vidhātṝṇām ṛṣīṇām atīta anāgata vartamāneṣu atīndriyeṣu dharma ādiṣu grantha upanibaddheṣu anupanibaddheṣu ca ātma manasoḥ saṃyogāt dharma viśeṣāt ca yat prātibham yathā ātma nivedanam jñānam utpadyate tat ārṣam iti ācakṣate tat tu prastāreṇa devarṣīṇām kadācid eva laukikānām yathā kanyakā bravīti śvas me bhrātā āgantā iti hṛdayam me kathayati iti pdhs
translated: The knowledge that arises in the seers who are the authors of the Vedas, regarding the Vedas, which are composed of words and sentences, and also regarding the past, future and present supersensuous things like Dharma, etc., whether composed in the texts or not, from the contact of the soul and mind and from the special quality of Dharma, that knowledge which reveals the soul is called Ārṣa. That is in a series for the celestial seers, but sometimes for the worldly ones also. As a girl says, My brother will come tomorrow, my heart tells me.

original: atha ārṣajñānasya kāraṇaviṣayapramāṇanirūpaṇārtham āmnāyavidhātṝṇām ityādi prakaraṇam / āmnāyo vedaḥ śrutismṛtilakṣaṇaḥ / tasya vidhātāraḥ kartāraḥ / teṣāmṛṣīṇāmutpadyate yat prātibhaṃ jñānam iti pratibhayā saṃskāraviśeṣeṇa nirvartitam / yathātmanivedanam yathā tasya padārthasyātmā svarūpaṃ tannivedanam tadālambanamutpadyate tad ārṣamityācakṣate / II / keṣvartheṣūtpadyate / atītānāgatavartamāneṣu / kiṃviśiṣṭeṣu / atīndriyeṣu dharmādiṣu ādipadena paramāṇvādergrahaṇamiti / granthopanibaddheṣvanupanibaddheṣu ca granthopanibaddheṣu ātmādiṣu / anupanibaddheṣu ca paramāṇvādiṣu iyān dharma iti / kutaḥ kāraṇādeṣu yathārthavijñānam / ātmamanasoḥ saṃyogāt asamavāyinaḥ dharmaviśeṣācca nimittāditi / tattu prastāreṇa ṛṣīṇāmatastadārṣam / tattu kadācideva laukikānāmapyarṣīṇāmevaṃvidhaṃ vijñānamastīti / kimasmadādīnāṃ /tra pramāṇamityāha kadācideva laukikānām tat prātibhaṃ jñānamiti / yathā kanyakā bravīti śvo me bhrātā āganteti / na cendriyajaṃ tat / tadvyāpāraṃ vināpyutpatteḥ /
analyzed: atha ārṣa jñānasya kāraṇa viṣaya pramāṇa nirūpaṇa artham āmnāya vidhātṝṇām ityādi prakaraṇam āmnāyaḥ vedaḥ śruti smṛti lakṣaṇaḥ tasya vidhātāraḥ kartāraḥ teṣām ṛṣīṇām utpadyate yat prātibham jñānam iti pratibhayā saṃskāra viśeṣeṇa nirvartitam yathā ātma nivedanam yathā tasya padārthasya ātmā svarūpam tat nivedanam tad ālambanam utpadyate tat ārṣam iti ācakṣate    keṣu artheṣu utpadyate atīta anāgata vartamāneṣu k
translated: Now, in order to describe the means of knowing the cause of the knowledge of the sages, the section begins with the authors of the scriptures and so on. The scripture is the Veda, characterized by the śruti and smṛti. The authors of that are the creators. The knowledge that arises in those sages is called prātibha (inspired), produced by a special impression. Yathātmani-vedanam means the knowledge that arises with reference to the nature, the essential form, of that object. That is called āṛṣa (of the sages). In which objects does it arise? In the past, future, and present. What are its special features? In the supersensible dharma and so on. By the word ādi (and so on), atoms and so on are included. In the scripturally established, such as the self, and in the scripturally unestablished, such as atoms and so on. This much is dharma. From what cause does this arise? From the contact of the self and the mind, which is not an inherent cause, and from a special quality of dharma. That...

original: atha bāhyendriyāṇāṃ vyāpārāsambhave 'pi antaḥkaraṇasya vyāpārāt pratyakṣaphalatvam / sambandho 'pi indriyeṇa saha bhrātuḥ saṃyuktaviśeṣaṇaviśeṣyabhāvaḥ / tathāhi / tadviśiṣṭamātmānaṃ deśaṃ kālaṃ vā ālambyotpadyate jñānametad ityuktaṃ paraiḥ / taccāsat / asyāparokṣatvānupa /patteḥ / yatra hi aparokṣajñānaṃ tatraiva indriyavyāpārakalpanā kriyate / na cātra tadastīti / na ca bahirviṣaye viśeṣaṇe 'pi manasaḥ svātantryeṇa vyāpāraḥ sambhavatītyuktam / liṅgaliṅgisambandhānusmaraṇānanubhavācca nānumānajam / śabdaṃ vināpyutpatterna śābdam / ataḥ pramāṇāntaraphalametat / tathā praśne kṛte sati na pratyakṣādikaṃ nirdiśati / api tu hṛdayaṃ me kathayatīti brūte /
analyzed: atha bāhya indriyāṇām vyāpāra asambhave antaḥkaraṇasya vyāpārāt pratyakṣa phala tvam sambandhaḥ indriyeṇa saha bhrātuḥ saṃyukta viśeṣaṇa viśeṣya bhāvaḥ tathā hi tad viśiṣṭam ātmānam deśam kālam vā ālambya utpadyate jñānam etat iti uktam paraiḥ tat ca asat asya aparokṣa tva anupapatteḥ yatra hi aparokṣa jñānam tatra eva indriya vyāpāra kalpanā kriyate na ca atra tat asti iti na ca bahis viṣaye viśeṣaṇe manasaḥ svātantryeṇa vyāpāra
translated: If the operation of the external senses is impossible, but the result of perception is due to the operation of the internal organ, and the relation is the brother's relation of qualifier and qualified with the sense organ, then it is said by others that knowledge arises taking as its object the self qualified by that, or a place or time. And that is wrong, because of the impossibility of its being non-perceptual. For where there is non-perceptual knowledge, there alone the operation of the sense organ is imagined. And that is not present here. And it has been said that even when the external object is the qualifier, the operation of the mind by itself is not possible. And because of the non-experience of the recollection of the relation between the mark and the marked, it is not inferential. And because it arises even without words, it is not verbal. Therefore, this is the result of a different means of knowledge. Thus, when a question is asked, it does not indicate perception etc., but rather says my heart tells me.

original: atha kasmāt pratyakṣānumānānantaramārṣajñānasya na nirūpaṇam / asmadādīnāṃ tena vyavahārābhāvāt / yatastattu prastāreṇa ṛṣīṇāmeva / kadācideva laukikānāmiti /
analyzed: atha kasmāt pratyakṣa anumāna anantaram ārṣa jñānasya na nirūpaṇam asmat ādīnām tena vyavahāra abhāvāt yatas tat tu prastāreṇa ṛṣīṇām eva kadācid eva laukikānām iti
translated: Now, why is the knowledge of the sages not described immediately after perception and inference? Because we and others have no dealings with it. For that knowledge is only of the sages in succession, and occasionally of worldly people.

original: siddhadarśanasya vidyāntaratvanirāsaḥ
translated: Refutation of the view that the knowledge of the accomplished is a different kind of knowledge

original: siddhadarśanaṃ na jñānāntaram / kasmāt / prayatnapūrvakam añjanapādalepakhaḍgagulikādisiddhānāṃ dṛśyadraṣṭṝṇāṃ sūkṣmavyavahitaviprakṛṣṭeṣvartheṣu yad darśanaṃ tatpratyakṣameva / atha divyāntarikṣabhaumānāṃ prāṇināṃ grahanakṣatrasañcārādinimittaṃ dharmādharmavipākadarśanamiṣṭaṃ tadapyanumānameva / atha II / liṅgānapekṣaṃ dharmādiṣu darśanamiṣṭaṃ tadapi pratyakṣārṣayoranyatarasmin antarbhūtamityevaṃ buddhiriti /PDhS
analyzed: siddha darśanam na jñāna antaram kasmāt prayatna pūrvakam añjana pāda lepa khaḍga gulikā ādi siddhānām dṛśya draṣṭṝṇām sūkṣma vyavahita viprakṛṣṭeṣu artheṣu yat darśanam tat pratyakṣam eva atha divya āntarikṣa bhaumānām prāṇinām graha nakṣatra sañcāra ādi nimittam dharma adharma vipāka darśanam iṣṭam tat api anumānam eva atha liṅga anapekṣam dharma ādiṣu darśanam iṣṭam tat api pratyakṣa ārṣayoḥ anyatarasmin antarbhūtam iti ev
translated: The knowledge of the accomplished is not a different kind of knowledge. Why? The knowledge of those who have accomplished the means of knowledge such as collyrium, foot ointment, sword, pill, etc., regarding visible objects, is perception itself. Now, the knowledge of the results of virtue and vice regarding the movements of heavenly, atmospheric and earthly beings, planets and stars, etc., which is accepted, is inference itself. Now, the knowledge regarding virtue, etc., which is accepted as independent of inference, is included in either perception or the knowledge of the sages. Thus, this is the understanding.

original: siddhadarśanaṃ vidyāntaramiṣṭaṃ paraistanniṣedhārthamāha siddhadarśanaṃ na jñānāntaram iti / ārṣajñānānantaramasya antarbhāvanirūpaṇam ārṣe 'pyantarbhāvārtham / yat siddhānāṃ darśanamutpadyate tatpratyakṣameva / keṣvartheṣu / sūkṣmavyavahitaviprakṛṣṭeṣu iti / sūkṣmāḥ paramāṇavaḥ / vyavahitā nāgabhuvanādayo asmadādīndriyāpekṣayā / na tu siddhendriyāṇāṃ vyavadhāyakamasti / viprakṛṣṭā mervādayaḥ / teṣu / siddhānāṃ kiṃ viśiṣṭānām / muktātmavyavacchedārthaṃ dṛśyadraṣṭṝṇām iti / kiñca teṣāṃ sadbhāve pramāṇamityāha dṛśyānām / kadācid añjanādiviyuktāḥ pratyakṣeṇāpyupalabhyante / kā punasteṣāṃ siddhirityāha añjanapādalepakhaḍgagulikādisiddhānām iti / ādipadena cintāmaṇiprabhṛtīnāṃ grahaṇam / añjanādivaśācca siddhendriyāṇāṃ sūkṣmādyarthaprakāśanam / ataḥ tat pratyakṣameva na jñānāntaramiti /
analyzed: siddha darśanam vidyā antaram iṣṭam paraiḥ tad niṣedha artham āha siddha darśanam na jñāna antaram iti ārṣa jñāna anantaram asya antarbhāva nirūpaṇam ārṣe pi antarbhāva artham yat siddhānām darśanam utpadyate tat pratyakṣam eva keṣu artheṣu sūkṣma vyavahita viprakṛṣṭeṣu iti sūkṣmāḥ paramāṇavaḥ vyavahitāḥ nāga bhuvana ādayaḥ asmat ādi indriya apekṣayā na tu siddha indriyāṇām vyavadhāyakam asti viprakṛṣṭāḥ meru ādayaḥ teṣ
translated: The Siddhadarśana (the vision of the Siddhas) is accepted by others as a separate means of knowledge. To refute that, it is said that Siddhadarśana is not a separate means of knowledge. The determination of its inclusion after the knowledge of the sages is for the purpose of inclusion even in the Vedic knowledge. That vision which arises to the Siddhas is indeed perception itself. In which objects? In the subtle, the obstructed, and the distant. The subtle are the atoms. The obstructed are the regions of the serpents and so on, in relation to our senses, but there is nothing that obstructs the senses of the Siddhas. The distant are the Merus and so on. In those. Of which Siddhas? Of the seers and the seen, in order to exclude liberated souls. And what is the proof of their existence? It is said: of the seen. Sometimes they are perceived even by perception, when they are separated from collyrium and so on. But what is their accomplishment? It is said: of those accomplished through collyrium, foot ointment, sword pills, and so on. By the word and so on, the wish-fulfilling gem and so on are included. Collyrium,

original: atha jyotiṣāmayanaṃ dṛṣṭvā prāṇināṃ śubhamaśubhaṃ vā bhaviṣyatīti jñānaṃ jñāntaramiṣṭaṃ tanniṣedhārtham divyāntarikṣabhaumānām ityādi / divi bhavaṃ divyamulkāpātādi / antarikṣe bhavañcāntarikṣaṃ digdāhādi / bhūmau bhavaṃ bhaumaṃ bhūsañcalanādi / teṣām / grahanakṣatrasañcārādinimittam upalabhya prāṇināṃ dharmādharmayorvipākaḥ phaladānasāmarthyaṃ taddarśanaṃ na jñānāntaramiṣṭam tadapyanumānameva liṅgadarśanānubandhasmaraṇādijanyatvāt /
analyzed: atha jyotiṣām ayanam dṛṣṭvā prāṇinām śubham aśubham vā bhaviṣyati iti jñānam jñā antaram iṣṭam tad niṣedha artham divya antarikṣa bhaumānām ityādi divi bhavam divyam ulkā pāta ādi antarikṣe bhavan ca antarikṣam digdāha ādi bhūmau bhavam bhaumam bhū sañcalana ādi teṣām graha nakṣatra sañcāra ādi nimittam upalabhya prāṇinām dharma adharmayoḥ vipākaḥ phala dāna sāmarthyam tat darśanam na jñāna antaram iṣṭam tat api anumānam eva liṅga
translated: Now, if the knowledge of what will happen to living beings, good or bad, by observing the movements of the stars, is accepted as a different kind of knowledge, to refute that, it is said of the celestial, atmospheric and terrestrial and so on. What happens in the sky is celestial, such as falling stars. What happens in the atmosphere is atmospheric, such as conflagrations in the directions. What happens on the earth is terrestrial, such as earthquakes. From observing the signs such as the movements of planets and stars, the ripening of the dharma and adharma of living beings, the capacity to give fruits, that knowledge is not accepted as a different kind of knowledge. That too is inference only, because it is produced by the recollection of the connection with the perception of the mark and so on.

original: yad vā divyāntarikṣabhaumānāṃ surasiddhamanuṣyāṇāṃ prāṇināṃ grahanakṣatrasañcārādinimittamupalabhya dharmādharmayorvipākadarśanamiṣṭaṃ tadapyanumānameveti /
analyzed: yat vā divya āntarikṣa bhaumānām sura siddha manuṣyāṇām prāṇinām graha nakṣatra sañcāra ādi nimittam upalabhya dharma adharmayoḥ vipāka darśanam iṣṭam tat api anumānam eva iti
translated: Or, the knowledge of the ripening of dharma and adharma by observing the signs such as the movements of planets and stars of celestial, atmospheric and terrestrial beings, gods, sages and humans, is accepted as inference only.

original: atha liṅagānapekṣaṃ dharmādharmādiṣu darśanamiṣṭaṃ tadapi yadi indriyārthasannikarṣādaparokṣamutpadyate pratyakṣameva / athendriyārthasannikarṣaṃ vinaiva dharmaviśeṣādutpadyate tathāpyārṣamityāha pratyakṣārṣayoranyatarasminnantarbhūtamiti / evaṃ buddhiriti upasaṃhāraḥ paropagatāyā buddhervināśapara iti /
analyzed: atha liṅaga anapekṣam dharma adharma ādiṣu darśanam iṣṭam tat api yadi indriya artha sannikarṣāt aparokṣam utpadyate pratyakṣam eva  atha indriya artha sannikarṣam vinā eva dharma viśeṣāt utpadyate tathā api ārṣam iti āha pratyakṣa ārṣayoḥ anyatarasmin antarbhūtam iti  / evam buddhiḥ iti upasaṃhāraḥ para upagatāyāḥ buddheḥ vināśa paraḥ iti
translated: Now, if it is accepted that the perception of dharma, adharma, etc. does not depend on the liṅga, and if that also arises without the contact of sense and object, being non-perceptual, then it is perception itself. But if it arises even without the contact of sense and object due to a special quality of dharma, then it is also included in either perception or scriptural testimony, he says. Thus, the conclusion regarding the cognition accepted by others is about its destruction.

original: sukhavaidharmyam
analyzed: sukha vaidharmyam
translated: The dissimilarity of pleasure

original: anugrahalakṣaṇaṃ sukham / sragādyabhipretaviṣayasānnidhye sati iṣṭopaII /labdhīndriyārthasannikarṣād dharmādyapekṣād ātmamanasoḥ saṃyogād anugrahābhiṣvaṅganayanādiprasādajanakamutpadyate tat sukham / atīteṣu viṣayeṣu smṛtijam / anāgateṣu saṅkalpajam / yattu viduṣām asatsu viṣayānusmaraṇecchāsaṅkalpeṣvāvirbhavati tad vidyāśamasantoṣadharmaviśeṣanimittamiti /PDhS
analyzed: anugraha lakṣaṇam sukham sraj ādi abhipreta viṣaya sānnidhye sati dharma ādi apekṣāt ātma manasoḥ saṃyogāt anugraha abhiṣvaṅga nayana ādi prasāda janakam utpadyate tat sukham atīteṣu viṣayeṣu smṛti jam anāgateṣu saṅkalpa jam yat tu viduṣām asatsu viṣaya anusmaraṇa icchā saṅkalpeṣu āvirbhavati tat vidyā śama santoṣa dharma viśeṣa nimittam iti pdhs
translated: Pleasure is characterized by satisfaction. When a desired object such as a garland is present, pleasure arises from the contact of sense and object, in dependence on dharma, etc., from the conjunction of self and mind, generating delight, attachment, joy, etc. That is pleasure. Regarding past objects, it arises from memory. Regarding future objects, it arises from imagination. But that which manifests in the wise when objects are absent, in the recollection, desire, and imagination of objects, that is caused by special knowledge, tranquility, contentment, and dharma.

original: atha buddheranantaraṃ sukhasya kāryakāraṇasvarūpopadarśanārtham anugrahalakṣaṇaṃ sukham ityādi / anugrahalakṣaṇamanugrahasvarūpam / yasminnutpanne sati ātmā anugṛhītamātmānaṃ manyata iti / sragādyabhipretaviṣayasānnidhye sati iti / sragādayaśca te abhipretaviṣayāśceti teṣāṃ sānnidhyam / anabhipretā rāgādayaḥ sukhahetavo na bhavantīti abhipretagrahaṇam / iṣṭopalabdhiśca indriyārthasannikarṣaśceti tathoktaṃ tasmāt / dharmādyapekṣādityādipadena dikkālādergrahaṇam / tānyapekṣata iti tadapekṣastasmāt / iṣṭopalabdhīndriyārthasannikaṣād dharmādyapekṣād ātmamanasoḥ saṃyogāt asamavāyikāraṇād ātmani sukhamutpadyate / anugrahābhiṣvaṅganayanādiprasādajanakam iti kāryanirūpaṇam / anugṛhītiranugrahaḥ sukhaviṣayaṃ jñānam / āsattirabhiṣvaṅgaḥ / nayanādiprasādaḥ prasannatā / ādipadena mukhādiprasannatā gṛhyata iti / tadetat asādhāraṇatvāditarasmād bhedakamiti jñeyam / na ca sarvaṃ vivekinaḥ svarūpato duḥkham / anugrahātmakasya sukhasyāpyanubhavāt / ata eva na duḥkhābhāve sukhavyavahāra iti vācyam / vibhinnakāraṇajanyasya tīvratarādibhedabhinnasya pratibhāsanāt / evaṃ duḥkhasyāpi na sukhābhāvarūpateti /
analyzed: atha buddheḥ anantaram sukhasya kārya kāraṇa svarūpa upadarśana artham anugraha lakṣaṇam sukham ityādi anugraha lakṣaṇam anugraha svarūpam yasmin utpanne sati ātmā anugṛhītam ātmānam manyate iti sraj ādi abhipreta viṣaya sānnidhye sati iti sraj ādayaḥ ca te abhipreta viṣayāḥ ca iti teṣām sānnidhyam anabhipretāḥ rāga ādayaḥ sukha hetavaḥ na bhavanti iti abhipreta grahaṇam iṣṭa upalabdhiḥ ca indriya artha sannikarṣaḥ ca iti tathā uktam tasmāt dh
translated: Now, in order to show the nature of the cause and effect of pleasure after intellect, it is said pleasure characterized by favor, etc. The nature of favor is characterized by favor. When it arises, the self thinks that the self is favored. When there is the presence of desired objects such as garlands, etc. Garlands, etc. are also desired objects. Their presence is the presence of those. Undesired things such as passion, etc. are not causes of pleasure, so the word desired is used. The attainment of the desired and the contact of the senses with their objects are called thus. Therefore, from the contact of the self and mind, which depends on dharma, etc., from the non-inherent cause, pleasure arises in the self. It is characterized by its effect as producing favor, attachment, and the clarity of the eyes, etc. Favor is the feeling of being favored by pleasure.

original: yadetaduktaṃ sukhaṃ tat sannihite vastuni indriyārthasannikarṣādutpadyata / atītānāgateṣu smaraṇasaṅkalpābhyāmityāha atīteṣu sukhasādhaneṣu / smṛtijam / anāgateṣu saṅkalpajam ityetad heyamupadarśitam /
analyzed: yat etat uktam sukham tat sannihite vastuni indriya artha sannikarṣāt utpadyata atīta anāgateṣu smaraṇa saṅkalpābhyām iti āha atīteṣu sukha sādhaneṣu smṛti jam anāgateṣu saṅkalpa jam iti etat heyam upadarśitam
translated: What has been said here is that happiness arises from the contact of the sense organs with the present objects. In the past and future, it arises from memory and imagination. It is said that the happiness arising from the past means of happiness is born of memory, and that arising from the future is born of imagination. This is shown to be what should be abandoned.

original: yattu viduṣāmasatsu viṣayānusmaraṇecchāsaṅkalpeṣu viṣayānusmaraṇañcecchā ca saṅkalpaśceti tathoktāḥ / teṣvavidyamāneṣvāvirbhavati tadupādeyameva / vidyāśamasantoṣadharmaviśeṣanimittam iti kāraṇopanyāsaḥ / vidyā tattvajñānaṃ tasmāt tattvajñānināṃ sukham / tathā śamo rāgādivināśaḥ / II / tasmācca śāntamanasāṃ sukham / santoṣo viṣayeṣvalampratyayaḥ / tasmācca sukham / keṣāñcid dharmaviśeṣācceti /
analyzed: yat tu viduṣām asatsu viṣaya anusmaraṇa icchā saṅkalpeṣu viṣaya anusmaraṇam ca icchā ca saṅkalpaḥ ca iti tathā uktāḥ teṣu avidyamāneṣu āvirbhavati tat upādeyam eva vidyā śama santoṣa dharma viśeṣa nimittam iti kāraṇa upanyāsaḥ vidyā tattva jñānam tasmāt tattva jñāninām sukham tathā śamaḥ rāga ādi vināśaḥ tasmāt ca śānta manasām sukham santoṣaḥ viṣayeṣu alampratyayaḥ tasmāt ca sukham keṣāñcid dharma viśeṣāt ca iti
translated: But that which arises in the wise when the desire and imagination for non-existent objects are absent, that arises without them. It is said to be what should be accepted. The cause is stated as being due to the special qualities of knowledge, tranquility, contentment, and virtue. Knowledge is the knowledge of reality. Therefore, happiness arises for those who have the knowledge of reality. Similarly, tranquility is the destruction of attachment and so on. And from that, the happiness of those whose minds are tranquil. Contentment is the satisfaction with regard to objects. And from that, happiness. And from the special qualities of virtue, for some.

original: anye tu vidyayā janitaḥ saḥ śamaḥ / tasmāt sukhamiti / śeṣaṃ pūrvavat /
analyzed: anye tu vidyayā janitaḥ saḥ śamaḥ tasmāt sukham iti śeṣam pūrvavat
translated: But others say that tranquility is produced by knowledge, and from that, happiness. The rest is as before.

original: duḥkhavaidharmyam
analyzed: duḥkha vaidharmyam
translated: The opposite of pain

original: upaghātalakṣaṇaṃ duḥkham / viṣādyanabhipretaviṣayasānnidhye sati aniṣṭopalabdhīndriyārthasannikarṣād adharmādyapekṣādātmamanasoḥ saṃyogād yad amarṣopaghātadainyanimittamutpadyate / tad duḥkham / atīteṣu sarpavyāghracaurādiṣu smṛtijam / anāgateṣu saṅkalpajamiti /PDhS
analyzed: upaghāta lakṣaṇam duḥkham viṣa ādi anabhipreta viṣaya sānnidhye sati aniṣṭa upalabdhi indriya artha sannikarṣāt adharma ādi apekṣāt ātma manasoḥ saṃyogāt yat amarṣa upaghāta dainya nimittam utpadyate tat duḥkham atīteṣu sarpa vyāghra caura ādiṣu smṛti jam anāgateṣu saṅkalpa jam iti pdhs
translated: Suffering is characterized by harm. When there is proximity of undesirable objects such as poison, etc., from the contact of the sense organs with an undesirable object, from the conjunction of the self and mind in dependence on non-virtue, etc., that which arises with the causes of impatience, harm, and dejection, that is suffering. Regarding those in the past, it arises from memory of snakes, tigers, thieves, etc. Regarding those in the future, it arises from imagination.

original: duḥkhanirūpaṇārthamāha upaghātalakṣaṇam upaghātasvarūpaṃ duḥkhamiti / upahanyate 'neneti upahatamātmānaṃ manyata iti / kāraṇamāha viṣādyanabhipretaviṣayasānnidhye sati viṣādayaśca te 'nabhipretaviṣayāśceti / teṣāṃ sānnidhye satīti / abhipretāśca viṣayādayaḥ sūkhahetava evetyanabhipretagrahaṇam / anniṣṭopalabdhīndriyārthasannikarṣādadharmādyapekṣāt aniṣṭopalabdhiśca indriyārthasannikarṣaśceti tathoktaḥ / tasmādadharmāpekṣādityādipadena dikkālādergrahaṇam / tasmādaniṣṭopalabdhīndriyārthasannikarṣād adharmādyapekṣādātmamanasoḥ saṃyogādasamavāyikāraṇād ātmani samavetaṃ yad utpadyate tad duḥkham / amarṣopaghātadainyānāṃ nimittaṃ kāraṇam / taditarasmād bhedakamiti jñeyam / atīteṣu sarpādiṣviti kāryanirūpaṇam / amarṣo 'sahiṣṇutā / upahatirupaghāto duḥkhālambanaṃ jñānamiti / dainyaṃ dīnarūpatā duḥkhādutpadyata iti / tadetad asādhāraṇatvād itarasmād bhedakamiti jñeyam / atīteṣu sarpavyāghracaurādiṣu duḥkhasādhaneṣu / smṛtijam / anāgateṣu saṅkalpajamiti /
analyzed: duḥkha nirūpaṇa artham āha upaghāta lakṣaṇam upaghāta svarūpam duḥkham iti upahanyate nena iti upahatam ātmānam manyate iti kāraṇam āha viṣa ādi anabhipreta viṣaya sānnidhye sati viṣa ādayaḥ ca te na abhipreta viṣayāḥ ca iti teṣām sānnidhye sati iti abhipretāḥ ca viṣaya ādayaḥ sūkha hetavaḥ eva iti anabhipreta grahaṇam aniṣṭa upalabdhi indriya artha sannikarṣāt adharma ādi apekṣāt aniṣṭa upalabdhiḥ ca indriya artha sannikarṣaḥ ca it
translated: To define suffering, it is said: Suffering has the characteristic of harm. Suffering has the nature of harm. It is thought that the self is harmed by this. The cause is stated: when undesirable objects such as poison are present. Poison and those are undesirable objects. When they are present, desirable objects and so on are the causes of happiness. Therefore, undesirable objects are mentioned. From the contact of the senses with the undesirable, in dependence on non-virtue, etc., the undesirable is also the contact of the senses with objects. It is said to be so. From that, in dependence on non-virtue, etc., the word etc. includes direction, time, etc. Therefore, from the contact of the senses with the undesirable, in dependence on non-virtue, etc., from the conjunction of the self and mind, which is the non-inherent cause, that which arises as inherent in the self is suffering. The cause of intolerance, harm, and dejection is to be known as the differentiator from the other. In the past, with snakes, etc., it is the cause.

original: icchāvaidharmyam
analyzed: icchā vaidharmyam
translated: The diversity of desire

original: svārthaṃ parārthaṃ vā aprāptaprārthanecchā / sā cātmamanasoḥ saṃyogāt sukhādyapekṣāt smatyapekṣād vā utpadyate / prayatnasmṛtidharmādharmahetuḥ / kāmo 'bhilāṣaḥ / rāgaḥ saṅkalpaḥ / kāruṇyam / vairāgyam / upadhā / bhāva ityevamādaya icchābhedāḥ / maithunecchā kāmaḥ / abhyavahārecchā abhilāṣaḥ / punaḥ II / punarviṣayānurañjanecchā rāgaḥ / anāsannakriyecchā saṅkalpaḥ / svārthamanapekṣya paraduḥkhaprahāṇecchā kāruṇyam / doṣadarśanād viṣayatyāgecchā vairāgyam / paravañcanecchā upadhā / antarnigūḍhecchā bhāvaḥ / cikīṣājihīrṣetyādikriyābhedād icchābhedā bhavanti /PDhS
analyzed: sva artham para artham vā aprāpta prārthanā icchā sā ca ātma manasoḥ saṃyogāt sukha ādi apekṣāt smati apekṣāt vā utpadyate prayatna smṛti dharma adharma hetuḥ kāmaḥ bhilāṣaḥ rāgaḥ saṅkalpaḥ kāruṇyam vairāgyam upadhā bhāvaḥ iti evamādayaḥ icchā bhedāḥ maithuna icchā kāmaḥ abhyavahāra icchā abhilāṣaḥ punar punar viṣaya anurañjana icchā rāgaḥ anāsanna kriyā icchā saṅkalpaḥ sva artham an apekṣya para duḥkha prahāṇa icchā kā
translated: Desire is the wish for something not yet obtained, either for one's own sake or for another's sake. It arises from the conjunction of the self and mind, from the consideration of pleasure, etc., or from the consideration of memory. It is the cause of effort, memory, virtue, and vice. Desire is longing, passion, imagination, compassion, detachment, pretense, and so on. These are the different kinds of desire. The desire for sexual intercourse is passion. The desire for food is longing. The desire for repeated enjoyment of objects is passion. The desire for action that is not imminent is imagination. The desire to remove the suffering of others without regard for one's own interests is compassion. The desire to abandon objects due to seeing their faults is detachment. The desire to deceive others is pretense. The hidden desire is pretense. The different kinds of desire arise from the different kinds of action such as seeking and avoiding.

original: icchāyāḥ kāryakāraṇasvarūpanirūpaṇārthaṃ svārthaṃ parārthaṃ vā ityādi / aprāpte vastuni prārthanārūpatvādiccheti / svārthaṃ parārthaṃ veti vipratipattinirāsārthaṃ vibhāgakathanam / na kevalaṃ svārthameva parārthamapi / utpattikāraṇamāha sā cātmamanasoḥ saṃyogāt asamavāyikāraṇādutpadyate / kimapekṣāt / sukhādyapekṣāt smṛtyapekṣād vā iti / prayatnasmṛtidharmādharmahetuḥ iti kāryanirūpaṇam / śuddhābhisandhirdhamaheturduṣṭābhisandhiścādharmaheturiti /
analyzed: icchāyāḥ kārya kāraṇa svarūpa nirūpaṇa artham svārtham parārtham vā ityādi  aprāpte vastuni prārthanā rūpa tvāt icchā iti svārtham parārtham vā iti vipratipatti nirāsa artham vibhāga kathanam na kevalam svārtham eva parārtham api utpatti kāraṇam āha sā ca ātma manasoḥ saṃyogāt asamavāyi kāraṇāt utpadyate kim apekṣāt sukha ādi apekṣāt smṛti apekṣāt vā iti prayatna smṛti dharma adharma hetuḥ iti kārya nirūpaṇam śuddha abhisandhiḥ dhama hetu
translated: In order to describe the nature of the cause and effect of desire, it is said for one's own sake or for the sake of others and so on. Desire is in the form of longing for an unattained object. The statement of division is for the purpose of refuting the disagreement that it is only for one's own sake or for the sake of others. It is not only for one's own sake, but also for the sake of others. The origination cause is stated: And that arises from the conjunction of the self and the mind, from the non-inherent cause. From what is it dependent? From the dependence on pleasure etc. or from the dependence on memory. The statement of the effect is: The cause of effort, memory, virtue and vice. The pure intention is the cause of virtue, and the impure intention is the cause of vice.

original: anye 'pi guṇāḥ kāmādayaḥ santi ca śabde /te ca kiṃ na sucitā iti codyasya parihārārthamantarbhāvaṃ nirūpayati kāmo 'bhilāṣo rāgaḥ saṅkalpaḥ kāruṇyaṃ vairāgyam upadhā bhāva ityevamādaya icchābhedāḥ tadviśeṣā iti / maithunecchā kāmaḥ / tatsadbhāve kāmīti vyapadeśāt / necchāmātramiti / abhyavaharaṇecchā abhilāṣaḥ / abhilāṣalakṣaṇecchā / sāmānyena sarvasmin vastuni abhyavaharaṇamādānaṃ vivakṣitam / tadicchā abhilāṣa iti cānye / punaḥ punarviṣayānurañjanecchā rāgaḥ tena hi satā rāgīti vyapadeśāt / anāsannakriyāyām anāgatakriyāyāmicchā saṅkalpaḥ / svārthamanapekṣya paraduḥkhaprahāṇecchā tadvināśecchā kāruṇyam / doṣadarśanād viṣayeṣu parityāgecchā vairāgyam / tatsadbhāve viraktavyavahārāt / paravañcanecchā upadhā / antarnigūḍhecchā bhāvaḥ iti / yadyapi icchā sarvā antarna bāhyeti / tathāpi iyamanyāpekṣayā kathañcid vijñāyata ityantarnigūḍhetyucyate / cikīrṣājihīrṣetyādikriyābhedādicchābhedā bhavanti kartumicchā cikīrṣā / hartumicchā jihīrṣeti /
analyzed: anye pi guṇāḥ kāma ādayaḥ santi ca ca kim na su citāḥ iti codyasya parihāra artham antarbhāvam nirūpayati kāmaḥ bhilāṣaḥ rāgaḥ saṅkalpaḥ kāruṇyam vairāgyam upadhā bhāvaḥ iti evamādayaḥ icchā bhedāḥ tad viśeṣāḥ iti maithuna icchā kāmaḥ tad sadbhāve kāmī iti vyapadeśāt na icchā mātram iti abhyavaharaṇa icchā abhilāṣaḥ abhilāṣa lakṣaṇa icchā sāmānyena sarvasmin vastuni abhyavaharaṇam ādānam vivakṣitam tad icchā abhilāṣa
translated: Other qualities such as desire etc. also exist in sound. Why are they not well-defined? To answer this objection, he determines the inclusion: Desire, longing, attachment, resolve, compassion, detachment, intention, and so on are different types of desire, and their specific forms. Desire for sexual intercourse is desire. When it exists, one is called passionate. It is not mere desire. Longing is the desire to consume. Longing is the desire characterized by longing. In general, the desire to consume all things is intended as grasping. The desire for that is longing, according to others. Attachment is the desire to enjoy objects again and again. When it exists, one is called attached. Resolve is the desire for future action, when action is not imminent. Compassion is the desire to abandon the suffering of others, the desire for their destruction, without regard for one's own interests. Detachment is the desire to renounce objects due to seeing their faults. When it exists, one is called detached. Deceit is the desire to deceive others.

original: dveṣavaidharmyam
analyzed: dveṣa vaidharmyam
translated: The dissimilarity of hatred

original: prajvalanātmako dveṣaḥ / yasmin sati prajvalitamivātmānaṃ manyate / II / sa dveṣaḥ / sa cātmamanasoḥ saṃyogād duḥkhāpekṣāt smṛtyapekṣād votpadyate / prayatnasmṛtidharmādharmahetuḥ / drohaḥ / krodhaḥ / manyurakṣamā amarṣa iti dveṣabhedāḥ /PDhS
analyzed: prajvalana ātmakaḥ dveṣaḥ yasmin sati prajvalitam iva ātmānam manyate sa dveṣaḥ sa ca ātma manasoḥ saṃyogāt duḥkha apekṣāt smṛti apekṣāt vā utpadyate prayatna smṛti dharma adharma hetuḥ drohaḥ krodhaḥ manyuḥ akṣamā amarṣaḥ iti dveṣa bhedāḥ pdhs
translated: Hatred has the nature of burning. When it exists, one thinks that one's self is burning. That is hatred. And that arises from the conjunction of the self and the mind, or from the consideration of suffering, or from the consideration of memory. It is the cause of effort, memory, virtue and vice. It is hostility, anger, pride, intolerance, and impatience. These are the varieties of hatred.

original: dveṣanirūpaṇārthamāha prajvalanātmakaḥ prajvalanasvarūpo dveṣaḥ / yasmin sati prajvalitamivātmānaṃ manyate / sa dveṣaḥ iti pūrvasya vivaraṇam / sa cātmanasoḥ saṃyogāt asamavāyikāraṇāt / duḥkhāpekṣāt smṛtyapekṣād vā ātmanyutpadyata iti / prayatnasmṛtidharmādharmahetuḥ iti kāryanirūpaṇam / yathā hi dveṣād vadhādau pravartamānasyādharmo bhavatyevaṃ yajanādau pravartamānasya dharmo 'pīti / bhedanirūpaṇārthamāha drohaḥ krodho manyurakṣamā amarṣa iti dveṣabhedāḥ tadviśeṣā iti / svāmino 'pakāro drohaḥ / krodhastu yasminnutpanne śarīrendriyāvayavānāṃ vikāraḥ sampadyate / manyurapakṛtasyāpakartumasamarthasya kaṇṭhākṣavikārajanakaḥ / akṣamā asahiṣṇutā / amarṣo 'pakarturvarṣādivyavadhānenāpyapakaraṇam /
analyzed: dveṣa nirūpaṇa artham āha prajvalana ātmakaḥ prajvalana svarūpaḥ dveṣaḥ yasmin sati prajvalitam iva ātmānam manyate sa dveṣaḥ iti pūrvasya vivaraṇam sa ca ātma nasoḥ saṃyogāt asamavāyi kāraṇāt duḥkha apekṣāt smṛti apekṣāt vā ātmani utpadyate iti prayatna smṛti dharma adharma hetuḥ iti kārya nirūpaṇam yathā hi dveṣāt vadha ādau pravartamānasya adharmaḥ bhavati evam yajana ādau pravartamānasya dharmaḥ api iti bheda nirūpaṇa artham āha dr
translated: To define hatred, it says: Hatred has the nature of burning, i.e., it has the form of burning. When it exists, one considers oneself as if burning. That is hatred. This is an explanation of the previous [definition]. And it arises in the self from the conjunction of the self and mind, which is the non-inherent cause, or from the consideration of suffering or from memory. The definition of its effect is: It is the cause of effort, memory, virtue, and vice. Just as one acquires demerit by engaging in killing out of hatred, so one acquires merit by engaging in sacrifice and other [virtuous acts]. To define the distinctions, it says: Malice, anger, resentment, intolerance, and impatience are the distinctions of hatred, i.e., its specific forms. Malice is the harmfulness towards a master. Anger is that arising from which there is a disturbance of the body and sense faculties. Resentment is the disturbance of the throat and eyes of one who has been harmed but is unable to retaliate. Intolerance is lack of endurance. Impatience is the inability to retaliate even with a delay of a year or more.

original: nanvete sukhaduḥkhecchādveṣāḥ kathaṃ vijñānād vyatiricyante / samānakāraṇajanyatvād antarmukhākāratayā pratīyamānatvācceti kāraṇabhedena hi padārthā bhidyanta ityuktam / taduktam
analyzed: nanu ete sukha duḥkha icchā dveṣāḥ katham vijñānāt vyatiricyante samāna kāraṇa janya tvāt antarmukha ākāra tayā pratīyamāna tvāt ca iti kāraṇa bhedena hi padārthāḥ bhidyante iti uktam tat uktam
translated: But how do these pleasure, pain, desire, and aversion differ from consciousness? Because they are produced by the same cause, they are cognized as having an internalized form. It has been said that things are distinguished by the difference in their causes. That has been stated:

original: tadatadrūpiṇo bhāvāstadatadrūpahetujāḥ /
analyzed: tad a tad rūpiṇaḥ bhāvāḥ tad a tad rūpa hetu jāḥ
translated: Things that have the form of that and not that are produced by causes that have the form of that and not that.

original: tatsukhādi kimajñānaṃ vijñānābhinnahetujam // pra / vā / /
analyzed: tat sukha ādi kim ajñānam vijñāna abhinna hetu jam pra vā
translated: Is that pleasure, etc. an ignorance produced by a cause that is not different from consciousness?

original: iti /
analyzed: iti
translated: Thus it is said.

original: tathāhi / kecid bhāvastadrūpiṇo dhānyādirūpiṇaḥ / anye 'tadrūpiṇastadvidharmāṇa iti / kasmāt / tadatadrūpahetujatvāt / dhānyarūpāt kāraṇādutpannāstadrūpiṇaḥ / anye tu vilakṣaṇā atadrūpiṇaḥ / ityukte satyāha yadyevaṃ tatsukhādivijñānenābhinnahetujaṃ kimajñānamiṣṭam / naitadevam / abhede sādhye samavāyyasamavāyinimittāpekṣayāpi samānakāraṇajanyatvasya vyabhicārāt / tathāhi / ekasmāt samavāyikāraṇādutpadyante pākajāḥ parasparaṃ vibhinnāśceti / asamavāyikāraṇantu pārthivaparamāṇvagnisaṃyogasteṣāmeka eva / tathā eko 'pyuṣṇasparśasteṣāṃ nimittakāraṇamiti / tadapekṣayāpi vyabhicāraḥ / sāmagryapekṣayā II / tvasiddhaṃ samānakāraṇajanyatvam / tasyāḥ pratikāryaniyatatvāt / uktañca ekatra sragādyupalakṣitā sāmagrī kāraṇam / anyatrānyathābhūteti / tathā pratiniyatajāteḥ prāgabhāvasya cānupraveśe sarvatra sāmagrībhedo bhavatyeveti / antarmukhākāratayā pratīyamānatvañca jñānadharmairvyabhicārīti / asti ca dharmadharmiṇorbheda ityuktam / tathā jñānasyānutpattivināśābhyāṃ vyabhicāraḥ / tayorantarmukhākāratayā pratīyamānatvam / na ca bodharūpatetyalamatiprasaṅgena /
analyzed: tathā hi kecid bhāvaḥ tad rūpiṇaḥ dhānya ādi rūpiṇaḥ anye tad rūpiṇaḥ tad vidharmāṇaḥ iti kasmāt tad a tad rūpa hetu ja tvāt dhānya rūpāt kāraṇāt utpannāḥ tad rūpiṇaḥ anye tu vilakṣaṇāḥ a tad rūpiṇaḥ iti ukte sati āha yadi evam tat sukha ādi vijñānena abhinna hetu jam kim ajñānam iṣṭam na etat evam abhede sādhye samavāyi asamavāyi nimitta apekṣayā api samāna kāraṇa janya tvasya vyabhicārāt tathā hi ekasmāt samavāyi kāraṇāt
translated: For some are of that form, having the form of grain etc., while others are not of that form, having different properties. Why? Because they are produced from causes that are of that form and not of that form. Those that are produced from causes having the form of grain are of that form. Others, which are different, are not of that form. When this is said, he asks: If so, is ignorance accepted as produced from a cause that is not different from consciousness of pleasure etc.? This is not so. When non-difference is to be proved, the fact of being produced from the same cause is also fallacious, depending on the inherent, non-inherent and instrumental causes. For example, the products of cooking arise from a single inherent cause, but are mutually different. But the non-inherent cause is the conjunction of the earth atom and fire for them, and that is the same for all. Similarly, a single hot touch is the instrumental cause for them. Even in relation to that, there is fallacy. The fact of being produced from the same cause is not established in relation to the assemblage, because that is determined for each effect. And it is said that in one place, a garland etc. is perceived,

original: prayatnavaidharmyam
analyzed: prayatna vaidharmyam
translated: The difference from effort

original: prayatnaḥ saṃrambha utsāha iti paryāyāḥ / sa dvividho jīvanapūrvakaḥ / icchādveṣapūrvakaśca / tatra jīvanapūrvakaḥ suptasya prāṇāpānasantānaprarekaḥ / prabodhakāle ca antaḥkaraṇasyendriyāntaraprāptihetuḥ / asya jīvanapūrvakasya ātmamanasoḥ saṃyogād dharmādharmāpekṣādutpattiḥ / itarastu hitāhitaprāptiparihārasamarthasya vyāpārasya hetuḥ / śarīravidhārakaśca / sa ca ātmamanasoḥ saṃyogād icchāpekṣād dveṣāpekṣād votpadyate /PDhS
analyzed: prayatnaḥ saṃrambhaḥ utsāhaḥ iti paryāyāḥ sa dvividhaḥ jīvana pūrvakaḥ icchā dveṣa pūrvakaḥ ca  tatra jīvana pūrvakaḥ suptasya prāṇa apāna santāna prarekaḥ prabodha kāle ca antaḥkaraṇasya indriya antara prāpti hetuḥ asya jīvana pūrvakasya ātma manasoḥ saṃyogāt dharma adharma apekṣāt utpattiḥ itaraḥ tu hita ahita prāpti parihāra samarthasya vyāpārasya hetuḥ śarīra vidhārakaḥ ca  /
translated: Effort, exertion, enthusiasm are synonyms. It is of two kinds: preceded by life, and preceded by desire and aversion. Among them, that preceded by life is the forward movement of the stream of inhalation and exhalation in one who is asleep. And at the time of waking, it is the cause of the internal organ's attainment of another sense organ. The origin of this life-preceded [effort] is from the conjunction of the self and mind, depending on virtue and vice. The other, however, is the cause of the activity capable of attaining what is beneficial and avoiding what is harmful. And it is the supporter of the body. And that arises from the conjunction of the self and mind, depending on desire or depending on aversion.

original: atha prayatnasya kāraṇasvarūpavibhāganirūpaṇārthamāha prayatnaḥ sarambha utsāha iti paryāyāḥ lakṣaṇam / asādhāraṇatvāt / tathāhi / prayatna itarasmād bhidyate / anādikālapravāhāyātetthambhūtaparyāyābhidheyatvāt / yastu na bhidyate / na cāsāvevam / yathā rūpādiriti / sa dvividhaḥ kāraṇabhedādityāha jīvanapūrvaka icchādveṣapūrvakaśca jīvanaṃ pūrvaṃ kāraṇamasyeti jīvanapūrvakaḥ / sa kathaṃ vijñāyata ityāha suptasya prāṇāpānasantānaprerakaḥ iti / yeyaṃ suptasya prāṇāpānasantānakriyā / sā prayatnakāryā śarīrakriyātvāt / jāgradavasthāyāṃ prāṇakriyādivaditi / na paraṃ prāṇādisantānaprerakaḥ prabodhakāle cāntaḥkaraṇasyendriyāntareṇa prāptihetuḥ iti / yathā hi prabodhasamaye yenaivendriyeṇopalambhastenaiva sambandhārthamantaḥkaraṇasya nirindriyātmāpradeśe vartamānasyāvaśyaṃ karmābhyupeyam / tacca prayatnakāryaṃ parigṛhītāntaḥkaraṇakarmatvāt / jāgradavasthāyāṃ tatkarmavat / ata eva nādṛṣṭasyaivātra kāraṇatvam / anumānena prayatnakāryatvopalabdheḥ / kāraṇāntarāsambhave cādṛṣṭasyaiva nimittakāraṇatvamiṣyata iti /
analyzed: atha prayatnasya kāraṇa svarūpa vibhāga nirūpaṇa artham āha prayatnaḥ sarambhaḥ utsāhaḥ iti paryāyāḥ lakṣaṇam asādhāraṇa tvāt tathā hi prayatnaḥ itarasmāt bhidyate anādi kāla pravāha āyāta itthambhūta paryāya abhidheya tvāt yaḥ tu na bhidyate na ca asau evam yathā rūpa ādiḥ iti sa dvividhaḥ kāraṇa bhedāt iti āha jīvana pūrvakaḥ icchā dveṣa pūrvakaḥ ca jīvanam pūrvam kāraṇam asya iti jīvana pūrvakaḥ sa katham vijñāyate iti āha supt
translated: Now, in order to describe the division of the nature of the cause of effort, he says that effort, exertion, and enthusiasm are synonyms. The definition is due to their being uncommon. Thus, effort is distinguished from others, because it has such synonyms that have been transmitted since beginningless time. But that which is not distinguished, and that is not so, like form and so on. He says that it is of two kinds due to the difference in causes. It is preceded by life and preceded by desire and aversion. Life is the prior cause of this, so it is preceded by life. How is that known? He says: it is the instigator of the continuum of inhalation and exhalation in one who is asleep. This action of the continuum of inhalation and exhalation in one who is asleep is the effect of effort, because it is an action of the body, like the action of inhalation in the waking state. Not only is it the instigator of the continuum of inhalation and so on, but at the time of awakening it is also the cause of the attainment of the internal organ by another sense organ. For example, at the time of awakening, the sense organ by which there is perception,

original: sthite hi sadbhāve jīvanapūrvakasyotpattikāraṇamāha ātmamanasoḥ saṃyogāt asamavāyikāraṇād viśiṣṭadharmādharmāpekṣādutpattiriti / itarastu icchādveṣapūrvakaḥ hitāhitaprāptiparihārasamarthasya vyāpārasya kāyikavyāpārasya hetuḥ / tathā śarīravidhārakaśca / tena hi pratibaddhaṃ śarīre gurutvaṃ na patanamārabhate / tasyotpattikāraṇamāha ātmamanasoḥ saṃyogāt asamavāyikāraṇāt / icchāpekṣād dveṣāpekṣād votpadyate iti /
analyzed: sthite hi sadbhāve jīvana pūrvakasya utpatti kāraṇam āha ātma manasoḥ saṃyogāt asamavāyi kāraṇāt viśiṣṭa dharma adharma apekṣāt utpattiḥ iti itaraḥ tu icchā dveṣa pūrvakaḥ hita ahita prāpti parihāra samarthasya vyāpārasya kāyika vyāpārasya hetuḥ tathā śarīra vidhārakaḥ ca tena hi pratibaddham śarīre guru tvam na patanam ārabhate tasya utpatti kāraṇam āha ātma manasoḥ saṃyogāt asamavāyi kāraṇāt icchā apekṣāt dveṣa apekṣāt vā utpa
translated: For when existence is established, it states the cause of origination of that which is preceded by life: From the conjunction of the self and mind, which is the non-inherent cause, origination occurs in dependence on the specific virtues and vices. But the other [i.e., life] is the cause of bodily activity, which is preceded by desire and aversion, and is capable of attaining the beneficial and avoiding the harmful. And it is also the support of the body. For gravity in the body, which is restrained by that, does not produce falling. It states the cause of its origination: From the conjunction of the self and mind, which is the non-inherent cause. It arises in dependence on desire or in dependence on aversion.

original: gurutvavaidharmyam
translated: The dissimilarity of gravity

original: gurutvaṃ jalabhūmyoḥ patanakarmakāraṇam / apratyakṣam / patanakarmānumeyam / saṃyogaprayatnasaṃskāravirodhi / asya ca abādiparamāṇurūpādivannityānityatvaniṣpattayaḥ /PDhS
analyzed: guru tvam jala bhūmyoḥ patana karma kāraṇam apratyakṣam patana karma anumeyam saṃyoga prayatna saṃskāra virodhi asya ca ap ādi paramāṇu rūpa ādi vat nitya anitya tva niṣpattayaḥ
translated: Gravity is the cause of the action of falling in water and on the ground. It is not directly perceived. It is inferred from the action of falling. It is opposed to conjunction, effort, and impression. And its establishment as eternal or non-eternal is like that of the form, etc. of the atoms of earth, etc.

original: gurutvasya lakṣaṇaparīkṣārthaṃ gurutvaṃ jalabhūmyoḥ ityādi prakaraṇam / apratyakṣatve sati patanakarmakāraṇatvād gurutvam itarasmād bhidyate / vego 'pi patanakarmakāraṇamityapratyakṣagrahaṇam / jalabhūmyoriti āśrayanirūpaṇam / itarapadāpekṣaṃ vā lakṣaṇam / jalabhūmyoreva vartamānatve sati patanakarmakāraṇatvād gurutvam / raso 'pi jalabhūmyoreva vartate / na tu patanakāraṇam / abhyupagame vā /ca kāraṇātiśayena kāryātiśayasya anyatropalabdheḥ pāṣāṇāde rasātiśayābhāvena pātātiśayābhāvaḥ / pippalyādau ca tatsadbhāvena sadbhāvaḥ syāt / sa nāstīti na rasaḥ kāraṇaṃ patanotpattau / rūpādeśca kāraṇatve analādāvapi sadbhāvāt pātaḥ syāt / na cāstītyato rūpādivyatiriktaṃ kāraṇamanumīyata ityata āha patanakarmānumeyam iti / ādyasya hi patanakarmaṇo 'samavāyikāraṇaṃ gurutvam / dvitīyādestu saṃskāro 'pīti / sa cāsau jalabhūmyoreva vartate /
analyzed: guru tvasya lakṣaṇa parīkṣā artham guru tvam jala bhūmyoḥ ityādi prakaraṇam apratyakṣa tve sati patana karma kāraṇa tvāt guru tvam itarasmāt bhidyate  / patana karma kāraṇam iti apratyakṣa grahaṇam jala bhūmyoḥ iti āśraya nirūpaṇam itara pada apekṣam vā lakṣaṇam jala bhūmyoḥ eva vartamāna tve sati patana karma kāraṇa tvāt guru tvam rasaḥ pi jala bhūmyoḥ eva vartate na tu patana kāraṇam abhyupagame kāraṇa atiśayena kārya atiśayasya anyatra upa
translated: The section beginning with Gravity in water and earth is for the purpose of examining the definition of gravity. Gravity is distinguished from other things by being the cause of the action of falling, while being imperceptible. Momentum is also the cause of the action of falling, so the word imperceptible is used. In water and earth specifies the substratum. Or the definition is in relation to the word other. Gravity exists only in water and earth, and is the cause of the action of falling. Taste also exists only in water and earth, but is not the cause of falling. Or, if accepted, the excess of the effect is observed elsewhere due to the excess of the cause. In stone, etc., there is no excess of falling due to the absence of excess of taste. And in pepper, etc., it would exist due to its presence. But that does not exist, so taste is not the cause of the production of falling. And if form, etc. were the cause, falling would occur even in fire, etc. due to its presence. But that does not occur, so a cause other than form, etc. is inferred to exist. Therefore it is said: falling

original: nanu tvagindriyasya vyāpārāt pañcapalaṃ daśapalamiti pratibhāsanād gurutvaṃ pratyakṣam / na / tvagindriyeṇa sambandhopapatteḥ pṛthivyādigurutvasyāpi pratyakṣatāprasaṅgāt / atha ādheyagatameva gurutvaṃ paricchinatti tvagindriyam / na ca tat pṛthvyādigurutve 'stīti / nanvevamapi makṣikādigurutvaṃ paricchindyāt / II / tasyāpyādheyagatatvāditi / na ca tasya aviśiṣṭatvādaparicchedaḥ / pratyakṣadravyasamavāyasyāviśeṣāt / atha adhogatihetutvaṃ vaiśiṣṭyam / tarhi tvagindriyasambandhena adhogativiśeṣamupalabhamānasya pañcapalaṃ daśapalamityānumānika eva pratyayaḥ /
analyzed: nanu tvac indriyasya vyāpārāt pañca palam daśa palam iti pratibhāsanāt guru tvam pratyakṣam na tvac indriyeṇa sambandha upapatteḥ pṛthivī ādi guru tvasya api pratyakṣa tā prasaṅgāt atha ādheya gatam eva guru tvam paricchinatti tvac indriyam na ca tat pṛthvī ādi guru tve sti iti nanu evam api makṣikā ādi guru tvam paricchindyāt tasya api ādheya gata tvāt iti na ca tasya aviśiṣṭa tvāt aparicchedaḥ pratyakṣa dravya samavāyasya aviśeṣāt atha adhas gati hetutvam
translated: But weight is perceived because of the operation of the tactile sense, as we perceive 'five palas' and 'ten palas'. No, because the tactile sense can come in contact with weight in earth etc., it would lead to the absurdity of the perceptibility of the weight of earth etc. If the tactile sense perceives only the weight that resides in what is supported, and that is not present in the weight of earth etc., then even so it would perceive the weight of a fly etc. Because that also resides in what is supported. And it is not that it is not perceived because it is not distinguished. Because there is no distinction in the inherence in a perceptible substance. If the distinction lies in being the cause of downward motion, then for one who perceives the specific downward motion by contact with the tactile sense, the cognition of 'five palas' and 'ten palas' is only inferential.

original: atha daśapalaistantubhirārabdhe paṭe gurutvātiśayasyānupalabdheḥ / kāraṇa eva gurutvam / na tu kārye / tadasat / ubhayatrāpi pātopalabdheḥ / na ca svagatagurutvābhāve 'pi āśrayāntaragurutvādeva patanam / vāyvāderapi pātaprasaṅgāt / tasmādubhayatrāpi kāryeṇa sadbhāvasiddhergurutvamastīti / avanativiśeṣānupalambhaśca kārye makṣikādigurutvasamparkeṇāpi samāna iti / tathāhi / tantuṣu mīyamāneṣu makṣikādisamparke 'pi avanativiśeṣā nopalabhyante / na ca tadgurutvasyāsattvamityalam /
analyzed: atha daśa palaiḥ tantubhiḥ ārabdhe paṭe guru tva atiśayasya anupalabdheḥ kāraṇe eva guru tvam na tu kārye tat asat ubhayatra api pāta upalabdheḥ na ca svagata guru tva abhāve pi āśraya antara guru tvāt eva patanam vāyu ādeḥ api pāta prasaṅgāt tasmāt ubhayatra api kāryeṇa sadbhāva siddheḥ guru tvam asti iti avanati viśeṣa anupalambhaḥ ca kārye makṣikā ādi guru tva samparkeṇa api samānaḥ iti tathā hi tantuṣu mīyamāneṣu makṣikā ādi samparke pi ava
translated: If it is argued that the excess of weight is not perceived in a cloth woven with ten palas of thread, then weight exists only in the cause, not in the effect. This is not correct. Because falling is perceived in both cases. And even in the absence of inherent weight, falling is not due to the weight of another substratum, because then even air etc. would fall. Therefore, since existence is established in both cases by the effect, weight exists. And the non-perception of a special bending is the same even in the effect due to the contact of the weight of a fly etc. Thus, when the threads are being weighed, even in the contact of a fly etc., no special bending is perceived. And it is not that their weight does not exist. Enough of this.

original: atha gurutvasya pātahetutve kimiti sarvadā pāto na bhavati / pratibandhādityāha saṃyogaprayatnasaṃskāravirodhi iti / vṛntaphalasaṃyogena pratibaddhaṃ na phale patanamārabhate / prayatnapratibandhād ākāśāvasthiteṣu śakuniṣu gurutvaṃ na patanaṃ karoti / dhanurnikṣipteṣu śareṣu gurutvaṃ na patanaṃ karoti vegākhyasaṃskārapratibandhāt / eṣāmapāye phalādiṣu pātadarśanāt /
analyzed: atha guru tvasya pāta hetu tve kim iti sarvadā pātaḥ na bhavati pratibandhāt iti āha saṃyoga prayatna saṃskāra virodhi iti vṛnta phala saṃyogena pratibaddham na phale patanam ārabhate prayatna pratibandhāt ākāśa avasthiteṣu śakuniṣu guru tvam na patanam karoti dhanuḥ nikṣipteṣu śareṣu guru tvam na patanam karoti vega ākhya saṃskāra pratibandhāt eṣām apāye phala ādiṣu pāta darśanāt
translated: Now, if gravity is the cause of falling, why does it not always cause falling? It says opposed by conjunction, effort, and impressions. Gravity, obstructed by the conjunction with the stalk, does not initiate falling in the fruit. Gravity does not cause falling in birds resting in the sky due to the obstruction of effort. Gravity does not cause falling in arrows shot from a bow due to the obstruction of the impression called velocity. Because falling is seen in fruits etc. when these are removed.

original: tasya cābādiparamāṇurūpādivannityānityatvaniṣpattayaḥ iti / abādayaśca te paramāṇavaśceti tathoktāḥ / tatparamāṇurūpādīnāmiveti / yathā āpyaparamāṇurūpādīnāmaniṣpadyamānatvānnityatvam / evameva gurutvaṃ nityeṣvaniṣpatternityam / anitye tu kāraṇaguṇapūrvaprakrameṇa niṣpadyamānatvāt tadrūpavadevānityamityatideśārthaḥ /
analyzed: tasya ca ap ādi paramāṇu rūpa ādi vat nitya anitya tva niṣpattayaḥ iti ap ādayaḥ ca te paramāṇavaḥ ca iti tathā uktāḥ tad paramāṇu rūpa ādīnām iva iti yathā āpya paramāṇu rūpa ādīnām aniṣpadyamāna tvāt nitya tvam evam eva guru tvam nityeṣu aniṣpatteḥ nityam anitye tu kāraṇa guṇa pūrva prakrameṇa niṣpadyamāna tvāt tat rūpavat eva anityam iti atideśa arthaḥ
translated: And the establishment of the eternality or non-eternality of that [gravity] is like that of the form etc. of earth atoms and so on. Those [atoms] are called earth atoms and so on. Like the form etc. of those atoms means that just as the form etc. of water atoms is eternal because it is not produced, in the same way gravity is eternal because it is not produced in eternal [substances]. But in non-eternal [substances], it is non-eternal like their form, because it is produced according to the previously stated principle of the qualities of the cause. This is the meaning of the extension [of the argument].

original: dravatvavaidharmyam
analyzed: drava tva vaidharmyam
translated: The dissimilarity of fluidity

original: dravatvaṃ spandanakarmakāraṇam / tridravyavṛtti / tattu dvividham / sāṃsiddhikam / naimittikañca / sāṃsiddhikamapāṃ viśeṣaguṇaḥ / naimittikaṃ pṛthivītejasoḥ sāmānyaguṇaḥ / sāṃsiddhikasya gurutvavannityānityatvaniṣpattayaḥ /PDhS
analyzed: drava tvam spandana karma kāraṇam tri dravya vṛtti tat tu dvividham sāṃsiddhikam naimittikam ca sāṃsiddhikam apām viśeṣa guṇaḥ naimittikam pṛthivī tejasoḥ sāmānya guṇaḥ sāṃsiddhikasya guru tva vat nitya anitya tva niṣpattayaḥ
translated: Fluidity is the cause of the action of vibration. It occurs in three substances. It is of two kinds: natural and accidental. Natural fluidity is a specific quality of water. Accidental fluidity is a general quality of earth and fire. The natural and accidental kinds of fluidity are established as eternal and non-eternal like gravity.

original: saṅghātadarśanāt sāṃsiddhikatvamayuktamiti cet / na / divyatejaḥII /saṃyuktānāmāpyānāṃ paramāṇūnāṃ parasparaṃ saṃyogo dravyārambhakaḥ saṅghātākhyaḥ / tena paramāṇudravatvasya pratibandhāt kārye himakarakādau dravatvānutpattiḥ /PDhS
analyzed: saṅghāta darśanāt sāṃsiddhika tvam ayuktam iti ced na paramāṇūnām parasparam saṃyogaḥ dravya ārambhakaḥ saṅghāta ākhyaḥ tena paramāṇu drava tvasya pratibandhāt kārye himakaraka ādau drava tva anutpattiḥ
translated: If it is argued that natural fluidity is not tenable because of the perception of conglomeration, it is not so. The conjunction of the atoms of water, united with divine fire, is the conglomeration called the cause of the origin of substance. By that, because the fluidity of the atoms is obstructed, fluidity does not arise in the effect such as snow and hail.

original: naimittikañca pṛthivītejasoragnisaṃyogajam / katham / sapirjatumadhūcchiṣṭādīnāṃ kāraṇeṣu paramāṇuṣvagnisaṃyogād vegāpekṣāt karmotpattau tajjebhyo vibhāgebhyo dravyārambhakasaṃyogavināśāt kāryadravyanivṛttāvagnisaṃyogād auṣṇyāpekṣāt svatantreṣu paramāṇuṣu dravatvamutpadyate / tatasteṣu bhogināmadṛṣṭāpekṣād ātmāṇusaṃyogāt karmotpattau tajjebhyaḥ saṃyogebhyo dvyaṇukādiprakrameṇa kāryadravyamutpadyate / tasmiṃśca rūpādyutpattisamakālaṃ kāraṇaguṇaprakrameṇa dravatvamutpadyata iti /PDhS
analyzed: naimittikam ca pṛthivī tejasoḥ agni saṃyoga jam katham sapiḥ jatu madhūcchiṣṭa ādīnām kāraṇeṣu paramāṇuṣu agni saṃyogāt vega apekṣāt karma utpattau tad jebhyaḥ vibhāgebhyaḥ dravya ārambhaka saṃyoga vināśāt kārya dravya nivṛttau agni saṃyogāt auṣṇya apekṣāt svatantreṣu paramāṇuṣu drava tvam utpadyate tatas teṣu bhoginām adṛṣṭa apekṣāt ātma aṇu saṃyogāt karma utpattau tad jebhyaḥ saṃyogebhyaḥ dvyaṇuka ādi prakrameṇa
translated: And the occasional fluidity is produced in earth and fire by the contact of fire. How? In the causes, the atoms, of clarified butter, lac, beeswax, etc., from the contact of fire, in the production of motion depending on velocity, from the disjunctions produced by that, from the destruction of the conjunctions producing the effect substance, in the cessation of the effect substance, from the contact of fire, depending on heat, in the independent atoms, fluidity is produced. Then in them, from the contact of the soul atoms depending on the unseen force of the experiencers, in the production of motion, from the conjunctions produced by that, the effect substance is produced in the series beginning with the dyad, etc. And in that, at the time of the production of color, etc., fluidity is produced in the series of qualities of the cause.

original: dravatvasya lakṣaṇaparīkṣārthamāha dravatvaṃ syandanakarmakāraṇam iti / syandanakarma vakṣyamāṇam / tatkāraṇaṃ dravatvamityukte vegena vyabhicāraḥ / tadarthaṃ tridravyavṛttīti / tathāpi tridravyavṛttitvaṃ vegasyāpi sambhavatīti niyameneti padamūhyam / rūpantu niyamena tridravyavṛtti / na tu syandanakamakāraṇam / ato dravatvaṃ / itarasmādbhidyate / niyamena tridravyavṛttitve sati syandanakarmakāraṇatvāditi /
analyzed: drava tvasya lakṣaṇa parīkṣā artham āha drava tvam syandana karma kāraṇam iti syandana karma vakṣyamāṇam tad kāraṇam drava tvam iti ukte vegena vyabhicāraḥ tad artham tri dravya vṛtti iti tathā api tri dravya vṛtti tvam vegasya api sambhavati iti niyamena iti padam ūhyam rūpam tu niyamena tri dravya vṛtti na tu syandana kama kāraṇam atas drava tvam itarasmāt bhidyate niyamena tri dravya vṛtti tve sati syandana karma kāraṇa tvāt iti
translated: To define and examine fluidity, it is said: fluidity is the cause of the action of flowing. The action of flowing will be explained later. When it is said that fluidity is the cause of that, there is deviation due to velocity. Therefore, it is said to occur in three substances. Even so, velocity also occurs in three substances, so the word necessarily should be supplied. But form necessarily occurs in three substances, but it is not the cause of the action of flowing. Therefore, fluidity is distinguished from the other. Because it is necessarily the cause of the action of flowing, while occurring in three substances.

original: tattu dvividhamiti vibhāgaḥ / kena rūpeṇa / sāṃsiddhikaṃ naimittikañceti / tayoḥ parasparaṃ vailakṣaṇyanirūpaṇārthamāha sāṃsiddhikamapāṃ viśeṣaguṇaḥ / naimittikaṃ pṛthivītejasoḥ sāmānyaguṇaḥ iti parasparabhedaḥ / sāṃsiddhikasya gurutvavannityānityatvaniṣpattayaḥ iti / yathā gurutvaṃ nityeṣvaniṣpadyamānatvānnityam anityeṣu niṣpatteranityaṃ kāraṇaguṇapūrvakamāśrayavināśācca vinaśyati / evaṃ sāṃsiddhikadravatvamapītyatideśārthaḥ /
analyzed: tat tu dvividham iti vibhāgaḥ kena rūpeṇa sāṃsiddhikam naimittikam ca iti tayoḥ parasparam vailakṣaṇya nirūpaṇa artham āha sāṃsiddhikam apām viśeṣa guṇaḥ naimittikam pṛthivī tejasoḥ sāmānya guṇaḥ iti paraspara bhedaḥ sāṃsiddhikasya guru tva vat nitya anitya tva niṣpattayaḥ iti yathā guru tvam nityeṣu aniṣpadyamāna tvāt nityam anityeṣu niṣpatteḥ anityam kāraṇa guṇa pūrvakam āśraya vināśāt ca vinaśyati evam sāṃsiddhika drava tvam a
translated: That is of two kinds - this is the division. By what form? Innate and adventitious. To determine their mutual difference, it says: Innate fluidity is a specific quality of water, adventitious is a general quality of earth and fire - this is the mutual difference. The establishment of innate fluidity as eternal or non-eternal is like that of heaviness. Just as heaviness is eternal in eternal substances because it is not established, and non-eternal in non-eternal substances because it is established, and it is destroyed by the destruction of the substratum which is preceded by the quality of the cause, similarly innate fluidity also - this is the meaning of extension.

original: nanu cāyuktametad apāṃ sāṃsiddhikadravatvamiti / himakarakādāvanupalambhāt / tadāha saṅghātadarśanāt sāṃsiddhikatvamayuktamiti cet / naitadevam / anyatra salile sāṃsiddhikadravatvasyopalabdheḥ / āpyaparamāṇuṣu tatsadbhāvasiddhau himakarakādau tasyānutpādāt pratibandhakamastīti niścīyate / tacca anyasyānupalambhād divyatejaḥsaṃyoga evetyāha divyatejaḥsaṃyuktānāmāpyānāṃ paramāṇūnāṃ parasparaṃ saṃyogo dravyārambhakaḥ / sa ca saṅghātākhyaḥ / tena paramāṇudravatvasya pratibandhāt kārye himakarakādau dravatvānutpattiḥ iti / tejaḥsadbhāvastu II / sphoṭādikāryānumeyaḥ / tathā ca himakarakāsambandhādupalabhyate sphoṭādilakṣaṇaṃ kāryaṃ śarīre vṛkṣādau ca dāha iti / vilayanañcāsya divyatejaḥsambandhāt / avayave kriyā / tato vibhāgastasmāt saṃyoganivṛttau dravyavināśe sati paramāṇavaḥ kāryamārabhante / tatra ca divyatejaḥsaṃyogasya pratibandhakasya nivṛtteḥ paramāṇudravatvaṃ kārye dravatvamārabhate /
analyzed: nanu ca ayuktam etat apām sāṃsiddhika drava tvam iti himakaraka ādau anupalambhāt tat āha saṅghāta darśanāt sāṃsiddhika tvam ayuktam iti ced na etat evam anyatra salile sāṃsiddhika drava tvasya upalabdheḥ āpya paramāṇuṣu tad sadbhāva siddhau himakaraka ādau tasya anutpādāt pratibandhakam asti iti niścīyate tat ca anyasya anupalambhāt divya tejaḥ saṃyogaḥ eva iti āha divya tejaḥ saṃyuktānām āpyānām paramāṇūnām parasparam saṃyogaḥ dravya ārambhakaḥ
translated: But this is not proper, that water has inherent fluidity, because it is not perceived in snow and frost. He says: If it is argued that inherent fluidity is not proper because of the perception of aggregation, this is not so. Because inherent fluidity is perceived elsewhere in water. When its existence is established in the water atoms, it is ascertained that there is an obstruction in snow and frost because it is not produced there. And that is only the conjunction of water atoms with divine fire, he says. The conjunction of water atoms conjoined with divine fire is the cause of the origin of substance. And that is called aggregation. By that, the inherent fluidity of the atoms is obstructed, and fluidity is not produced in the effect, snow and frost. And the existence of fire is inferred from effects like bursting. And thus, the effect characterized by bursting etc. is perceived in the body and in trees etc. due to the connection with snow and frost, in the form of burning. And its melting is due to the connection with divine fire.

original: na cedaṃ naimittikam / sarpirādāviva punaḥ saṃgrahānupalabdheḥ / yathāhi naimittikadravatvaṃ sarpirādāviti drutasya saṃgrahaḥ / tathehāpi syāt / na caitadastīti /
analyzed: na ca idam naimittikam sarpiḥ ādau iva punar saṃgraha anupalabdheḥ yathā hi naimittika drava tvam sarpiḥ ādau iti drutasya saṃgrahaḥ tathā iha api syāt na ca etat asti iti
translated: And this is not occasional, like fluidity in ghee, because re-collection is not observed again. For just as the occasional fluidity in ghee and so on is the liquefaction of the solid, so it would be here too. But this is not the case.

original: naimittikañca pṛthivītejasoragnisaṃyogajam / kathamityavyutpannapraśnaḥ / tatrāha sarpirādīnāṃ kāraṇeṣvityādipadena sūtroktānāṃ saṃgrahaḥ / tathāhi sapirjatumadhūcchiṣṭānāṃ pārthivānāmagnisaṃyogād dravatvamadbhiḥ sāmānyam / trapusīsaloharajatasuvarṇānāṃ taijasānāmagnisaṃyogāddravatvamadbhiḥ sāmānyamiti vai / sū / / / / ataḥ sapirādikāraṇeṣu ca paramāṇuṣvagnisaṃyogāpekṣād vegāpekṣāt karmotpattau satyantato vibhāgā jāyante / tebhyo vibhāgebhyo dravyārambhakasaṃyogavināśaḥ / tataḥ kāryadravyanivṛttistasyāñca satyāmagnisaṃyogād auṣṇyāpekṣāt svatantreṣu paramāṇuṣu dravatvamutpadyate / paramāṇavaḥ samavāyikāraṇam / agnisaṃyogo 'samavāyikāraṇamuṣṇasparśo nimittakāraṇamiti / tato 'nantaramutpannadravatveṣu bhogināmadṛṣṭāpekṣādātmāṇusaṃyogāt karmotpadyata iti / paramāṇuḥ samavāyikāraṇam / ātmāṇusaṃyogo 'samavāyikāraṇam / bhogināmadṛṣṭo nimittakāraṇamiti / tato vibhāgebhyaḥ prāktanasaṃyogavināśe sati tebhyaḥ karmabhyaḥ paramāṇvantareṇa saṃyogā jāyante / tebhyaḥ saṃyogebhyo dvyaṇukāṇyutpadyante / tadādikrameṇa tryaṇukādikāryamutpadyate / tasmiṃśca dvyaṇukādau rūpādyutpattisamakālaṃ kāraṇaguṇapūrvakrameṇa dravatvamutpadyata iti pākajotpattinyāyo 'tra draṣṭavyaḥ / etāvāṃstu viśeṣaḥ / tatrāvaśyaṃ rūpādinivṛttirna caivaṃ dravatvasyeti /
analyzed: naimittikam ca pṛthivī tejasoḥ agni saṃyoga jam katham iti avyutpanna praśnaḥ tatra āha sarpiḥ ādīnām kāraṇeṣu iti ādi padena sūtra uktānām saṃgrahaḥ tathā hi sapiḥ jatu madhūcchiṣṭānām pārthivānām agni saṃyogāt drava tvam adbhiḥ sāmānyam trapu sīsa loha rajata suvarṇānām taijasānām agni saṃyogāt drava tvam adbhiḥ sāmānyam iti vai  / atas sapiḥ ādi kāraṇeṣu ca paramāṇuṣu agni saṃyoga apekṣāt vega apekṣāt karma utpattau sati
translated: And the occasional fluidity of earth and fire is produced by the contact of fire. The question How? is one where the meaning is not understood. There, he says in the causes of ghee, etc. The word etc. includes those mentioned in the sutra. It is as follows: The fluidity of ghee, lac, and wax, which are earthy, is common with water due to the contact of fire. The fluidity of tin, lead, iron, silver, and gold, which are fiery, is common with water. Thus, in the atoms which are the causes of ghee, etc., when action arises in dependence on the contact of fire, and in dependence on velocity, then finally disjunctions are produced. From those disjunctions, there is the destruction of the conjunctions that produce the composite substance. Then there is the cessation of the effect substance. And when that is true, the fluidity is produced in the independent atoms in dependence on the contact of fire and heat. The atoms are the inherent cause. The contact of fire is the non-inherent cause. The hot touch is the instrumental cause. Then immediately after the substance is produced,

original: snehavaidharmyam🔽sneho 'pāṃ viśeṣaguṇaḥ / saṃgrahamṛjādihetuḥ / asyāpi gurutvavannityānityatvaniṣpattayaḥ /PDhS
analyzed: sneha vaidharmyam  viśeṣa guṇaḥ saṃgraha mṛjā ādi hetuḥ asya api guru tva vat nitya anitya tva niṣpattayaḥ
translated: Dissimilarity of fluidity🔽Fluidity is a special quality of water, the cause of cohesion, smoothness, etc. Its eternality and non-eternality are like those of weight.

original: snehasya lakṣaṇaparīkṣārthaṃ sneho 'pāṃ viśeṣaguṇaḥ saṅgrahamṛjādihetuḥ iti / apāṃ viśeṣaguṇo rūpādirapīti saṅgrahamṛjādiheturiti padam / saṅgrahaḥ piṇḍīkaraṇam / mṛjā tu viśadatvam / taddhetutvāditarasmād bhidyate /
analyzed: snehasya lakṣaṇa parīkṣā artham snehaḥ pām viśeṣa guṇaḥ saṅgraha mṛjā ādi hetuḥ iti apām viśeṣa guṇaḥ rūpa ādiḥ api iti saṅgraha mṛjā ādi hetuḥ iti padam saṅgrahaḥ piṇḍīkaraṇam mṛjā tu viśada tvam tad hetu tvāt itarasmāt bhidyate
translated: In order to examine the definition of fluidity, it is said: Fluidity is a special quality of water, the cause of cohesion, smoothness, etc. The word cause of cohesion, smoothness, etc. means that color and other qualities of water are also causes of cohesion, smoothness, etc. Cohesion is the act of making into a lump. Smoothness is clarity. It is distinguished from other [qualities] because it is the cause of that [smoothness].

original: nanu snehasyābhinavapallavādāvupalambhād udakaviśeṣaguṇatvamasiddham / na / saṃyuktasamavāyenopalambhāt / saṃyuktaṃ hi pallavādinā udakaṃ tatsamavetasneho gṛhyate / tadapāye tasyānupalabdheḥ / tathā snānottarakālaṃ keśādau snigdhapratyayadarśanāt / yathā ca saṃyogyāśrayavaiguṇyābhāve sarvasminnudake snigdhajñānaṃ naivaṃ sarvasyāṃ pṛthivyāmiti / asyāpi gurutvavannityānityatvaniṣpattaya iti / nityeṣu nityo 'nityeṣu kāraṇaguṇapūrvaḥ / āśrayavināśād vinaśyatīti /
analyzed: nanu snehasya abhinava pallava ādau upalambhāt udaka viśeṣa guṇa tvam asiddham na saṃyukta samavāyena upalambhāt saṃyuktam hi pallava ādinā udakam tad samaveta snehaḥ gṛhyate tad apāye tasya anupalabdheḥ tathā snāna uttara kālam keśa ādau snigdha pratyaya darśanāt yathā ca saṃyogi āśraya vaiguṇya abhāve sarvasmin udake snigdha jñānam na evam sarvasyām pṛthivyām iti asya api guru tva vat nitya anitya tva niṣpattayaḥ iti nityeṣu nityaḥ nityeṣu kāraṇa gu
translated: But since affection is perceived in fresh sprouts and so on, it is not established that it is a special quality of water. No, because it is perceived through the inherence in the conjoined. For water conjoined with the sprout and so on is grasped as having the affection inherent in it.
