Because it is not perceived when that [conjoined water] is absent. Similarly, because the perception of wetness is seen in hair and so on after bathing. And just as the knowledge of wetness in all water is due to the absence of defects in the conjoined substratum, so it is not in all earth. And this [affection] is established as eternal or non-eternal like weight. It is eternal in eternals, and preceded by the quality of the cause in non-eternals. It is destroyed by the destruction of the substratum.

original: saṃskāravaidharmyam
analyzed: saṃskāra vaidharmyam
translated: Dissimilarity from modification

original: saṃskārastrividho vego bhāvanā sthitisthāpakaśca / tatra vego mūrtimattu pañcasu dravye nimittaviśeṣāpekṣāt karmaṇo jāyate / niyatadikkriyāprabandhahetuḥ sparśavaddravyasaṃyogaviśeṣavirodhī kvacit kāraṇaguṇapūrvakrameṇotpadyate /PDhS
analyzed: saṃskāraḥ trividhaḥ vegaḥ bhāvanā sthiti sthāpakaḥ ca tatra vegaḥ mūrtimat tu pañcasu dravye nimitta viśeṣa apekṣāt karmaṇaḥ jāyate niyata diś kriyā prabandha hetuḥ sparśavat dravya saṃyoga viśeṣa virodhī kvacid kāraṇa guṇa pūrva krameṇa utpadyate
translated: Impression is of three kinds: velocity, impression, and stability-producing. Among them, velocity arises from action in five substances that have form, depending on a particular cause. It is the cause of a continuous action in a fixed direction, opposed to a particular conjunction of a tangible substance, and arises in some cases in the order of the qualities of the cause.

original: saṃskāranirūpaṇārthamāha saṃskārastrividhaḥ / kena rūpeṇa / vego bhāvanā sthitisthāpakatveneti / vibhāga evāsādhāraṇatvāllakṣaṇamiti / tallakṣaṇavaicitryajñāpanārthametat / tatra vegasya samānajātīyāt bhedamāśrayañca nirūpayannāha mūrtimatsu ityādi / mūrtimatsu dravyeṣu / na jñāyate kiyatsu / tadarthaṃ pañcasu / tathāpi na jñāyate keṣu / tadarthaṃ mūrtimatsu ityāśrayanirūpaṇam / yad vā saṃskāratve sati pañcasu mūrtimatsveva vartamānatvād vega iti lakṣaṇam /
analyzed: saṃskāra nirūpaṇa artham āha saṃskāraḥ trividhaḥ kena rūpeṇa vegaḥ bhāvanā sthiti sthāpaka tvena iti vibhāgaḥ eva asādhāraṇa tvāt lakṣaṇam iti tad lakṣaṇa vaicitrya jñāpana artham etat tatra vegasya samāna jātīyāt bhedam āśrayan ca nirūpayan āha mūrtimatsu ityādi mūrtimatsu dravyeṣu na jñāyate kiyatsu tad artham pañcasu tathā api na jñāyate keṣu tad artham mūrtimatsu iti āśraya nirūpaṇam yat vā saṃskāra tve sati pañcasu mūrtimatsu eva
translated: To define impression, it is said that impression is of three kinds. By what form? Velocity, impression, and stability-producing. Division itself is the definition due to its being uncommon. This is to show the variety of its characteristics. Among them, defining the substratum and distinguishing velocity from similar kinds, it is said in substances that have form, etc. In substances that have form. It is not known in how many. For that purpose, in five. Still, it is not known in which. For that purpose, the definition of the substratum is in those that have form. Or the definition of velocity is: being an impression that exists only in the five substances that have form.

original: kāraṇamāha nimittaviśeṣāpekṣāt karmaṇo jāyate iti / saṃyogavibhāgayoḥ karmajatvamiti nimittaviśeṣāpekṣāditi viśeṣaṇam / nimittaviśeṣo nodanābhighātasaṃyuktasaṃyogāḥ / tadapekṣāditi / karma asamavāyikāraṇam / svakāraṇaviṣeṣo nodanādirnimittakāraṇam / vegādhārastu samavāyikāraṇamityasādhāraṇatvāllakṣaṇaṃ cedam / kāryamāha niyatāyāṃ diśi kriyāprabandhasya kriyāsantānasya heturiti /
analyzed: kāraṇam āha nimitta viśeṣa apekṣāt karmaṇaḥ jāyate iti saṃyoga vibhāgayoḥ karma ja tvam iti nimitta viśeṣa apekṣāt iti viśeṣaṇam nimitta viśeṣaḥ nodana abhighāta saṃyukta saṃyogāḥ tad apekṣāt iti karma asamavāyi kāraṇam sva kāraṇa viṣeṣaḥ nodana ādiḥ nimitta kāraṇam vega ādhāraḥ tu samavāyi kāraṇam iti asādhāraṇa tvāt lakṣaṇam ca idam kāryam āha niyatāyām diśi kriyā prabandhasya kriyā santānasya hetuḥ iti
translated: He states the reason: It arises from action that depends on a specific cause. The fact that conjunction and disjunction are produced by action is specified by the phrase that depends on a specific cause. The specific cause is the conjunction of impulsion and contact. The phrase that depends on that means that action is the non-inherent cause. The specific cause of its own effect, such as impulsion, is the instrumental cause. But the substratum of momentum is the inherent cause. Thus, this definition is uncommon. He states the effect: It is the cause of the continuity of action in a restricted direction, meaning the cause of the series of actions.

original: nanu cāyuktametat / aniyatadigdeśasya bhramaṇākhyasyāpi karmaṇaḥ kāraṇaII /tvāt / satyametat / tathāpyadoṣaḥ / niyatadikkriyāprabandhasyaiva heturityavadhāraṇānabhyupagamāt / so 'pi niyatāyāmeva diśi kriyāprabandha iti cānye / aniyatadikkriyāprabandhaheturityavadhāraṇasyātra pūrvarūpatāṃ manyamānā vyākhyāntaraṃ kurvate / tasya vināśakāraṇamāha sparśavaddravyasaṃyogaviśeṣavirodhī iti / sparśavaddravyasaṃyogamātravirodhitve vāyusaṃyogena virodhādiṣorgamanaṃ na syāt / taddhetorvegasya vināśāditi viśeṣagrahaṇam / kaṭhināvayavasaṃyogenādāvapi tadvināśopalabdheḥ /
analyzed: nanu ca ayuktam etat aniyata diś deśasya bhramaṇa ākhyasya api karmaṇaḥ satyam etat tathā api adoṣaḥ niyata diś kriyā prabandhasya eva hetuḥ iti avadhāraṇa anabhyupagamāt saḥ pi niyatāyām eva diśi kriyā prabandhaḥ iti ca anye aniyata diś kriyā prabandha hetuḥ iti avadhāraṇasya atra pūrvarūpa tām manyamānāḥ vyākhyā antaram kurvate tasya vināśa kāraṇam āha sparśavat dravya saṃyoga viśeṣa virodhī iti sparśavat dravya saṃyoga mātra virodhi tve vāy
translated: But this is improper, because motion, which is not restricted to a particular direction, is also a cause. This is true, but still there is no fault, because we do not accept the restriction that it is only the cause of a continuous action in a particular direction. Others say that motion is also a continuous action in a particular direction. Those who consider the restriction that it is the cause of a continuous action in an unspecified direction to be the original form here, give a different explanation. He states the cause of its destruction: It is opposed to the particular conjunction of a tangible substance. If it were merely opposed to the conjunction of a tangible substance, motion would not occur in air due to opposition, because the cause of that, momentum, would be destroyed. The particular is mentioned to avoid this. Since the destruction of that is observed even by the conjunction of hard parts,

original: nanvevamapyākāśe prakṣiptasyeṣornibiḍāvayavasaṃyogasya vegavināśakasyābhāvādapātaḥ syāt / na / anekakāryakaraṇe sparśavaddravyasaṃyogamātreṇāpi vināśasyānvayavyatirekābhyāmupalambhāt / tathā ca kṣiptasyeṣorvegavināśopalabdheravaśyaṃ kāraṇamabhidheyam / nirhetukavināśapratiṣedhāt / ato vāyusaṃyogenāpyanekakāryakaraṇe sati virudhyate / adṛṣṭaprakṣayād veti / kvacit kāraṇaguṇapūrvaprakrameṇotpadyate yathā parvatasrotasāmadhaḥpatatāṃ saṃyoge satyekasminnudake samutpanne rūpādivat kāraṇavegād vego 'pīti /
analyzed: nanu evam api ākāśe prakṣiptasya iṣoḥ nibiḍa avayava saṃyogasya vega vināśakasya abhāvāt apātaḥ syāt na aneka kārya karaṇe sparśavat dravya saṃyoga mātreṇa api vināśasya anvaya vyatirekābhyām upalambhāt tathā ca kṣiptasya iṣoḥ vega vināśa upalabdheḥ avaśyam kāraṇam abhidheyam nirhetuka vināśa pratiṣedhāt atas vāyu saṃyogena api aneka kārya karaṇe sati virudhyate adṛṣṭa prakṣayāt vā iti  /
translated: But even so, in the case of an arrow thrown into the sky, the dense conjunction of its parts, which destroys its momentum, would not be present, so it would not fall. No, because the destruction is observed by positive and negative concomitance even by the mere conjunction of a tangible substance in the production of multiple effects. And thus, the destruction of the momentum of a thrown arrow must be stated as a necessary cause, because the denial of causeless destruction is established. Therefore, when multiple effects are produced even by conjunction with air, it is contradicted. It is said that the destruction of unseen [forces] is the cause. Sometimes it arises in the order of the qualities of the cause, just as when a conjunction occurs in the falling of a mountain stream, a single water is produced, and momentum arises from the momentum of the cause, like color and so on.

original: bhāvanāsañjñakastvātmaguṇo dṛṣṭaśrutānubhūteṣvartheṣu smṛtipratyabhijñānaheturbhavati / jñānamadaduḥkhādivirodhī / paṭvabhyāsādarapratyayajaḥ paṭupratyayāpekṣādātmamanasoḥ saṃyogād āścarye 'rthe paṭuḥ saṃskārātiśayo jāyate / yathā dākṣiṇātyasyoṣṭradarśanāditi / vidyāśilpavyāyāmādiṣvabhyasyamāneṣu tasminnevārthe pūrvapūrvasaṃskāramapekṣamāṇāduttarottarasmāt pratyayādātmamanasoḥ saṃyogāt saṃskārātiśayo jāyate / prayatnena manaścakṣuṣi sthāpayitvā apūrvamarthaṃ didṛkṣamāṇasya vidyutsampātadarśanavadādarapratyayaḥ / tamapekṣamāṇādātmamanasoḥ saṃyogāt saṃskārātiśayo jāyate / yathā devahrade sauvarṇarājatapadmadarśanāditi /PDhS
analyzed: bhāvanā sañjñakaḥ tu ātma guṇaḥ dṛṣṭa śruta anubhūteṣu artheṣu smṛti pratyabhijñāna hetuḥ bhavati jñāna mada duḥkha ādi virodhī paṭu abhyāsa ādara pratyaya jaḥ paṭu pratyaya apekṣāt ātma manasoḥ saṃyogāt āścarye rthe paṭuḥ saṃskāra atiśayaḥ jāyate yathā dākṣiṇātyasya uṣṭra darśanāt iti vidyā śilpa vyāyāma ādiṣu abhyasyamāneṣu tasmin eva arthe pūrva pūrva saṃskāram apekṣamāṇāt uttarottarasmāt pratyayāt ātma
translated: The quality of the self called impression becomes the cause of memory and recognition of things seen, heard, or experienced. Knowledge is the opposite of ignorance, pain, etc. It arises from sharp practice, respect, and conditions. From the contact of the self and mind depending on sharp conditions, a sharp impression is produced in a wonderful object, like from a southerner seeing a camel. In the case of learning, arts, exercises, etc. being practiced, from the contact of the self and mind depending on the subsequent condition, which requires the previous impression in that very object, an impression is produced. When one, desiring to see a new object, fixes the mind and eye with effort, there is a respectful condition, like seeing a flash of lightning. Depending on that, from the contact of the self and mind, an impression is produced, like from seeing golden and silver lotuses in the heavenly lake.

original: bhāvanāsaṃjñakastvātmaguṇatvāditarasmād bhidyate / na ca buddhyādibhirvyabhicāraḥ / saṃskārasya sato 'vāntaraviśeṣanirūpaṇāt / smṛtipratyabhijñānahetuḥ iti kāryanirūpaṇam / sadbhāve pramāṇañceti / smṛtirvāsanākhyāt bhavati / II / tathoktamātmādhikāre / keṣu smṛtipratyabhijñānaheturityāha dṛṣṭaśrutānubhūteṣu iti / nirṇītārtheṣviti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: bhāvanā saṃjñakaḥ tu ātma guṇa tvāt itarasmāt bhidyate na ca buddhi ādibhiḥ vyabhicāraḥ saṃskārasya sataḥ vā antara viśeṣa nirūpaṇāt smṛti pratyabhijñāna hetuḥ iti kārya nirūpaṇam sadbhāve pramāṇam ca iti smṛtiḥ vāsanā ākhyāt bhavati tathā uktam ātma adhikāre keṣu smṛti pratyabhijñāna hetuḥ iti āha dṛṣṭa śruta anubhūteṣu iti nirṇīta artheṣu iti bhāvaḥ
translated: But that which is called bhāvanā is different from the other because it is a quality of the self. And there is no fallacy due to intellect etc., because the existence of impressions is determined by a specific difference. The determination of the effect is that it is the cause of memory and recognition. And the proof of its existence is that memory arises from what is called vāsanā. This has been stated in the chapter on the self. In what does it reside? It is said to be in what is seen, heard, or experienced. The meaning is that it is in what is ascertained.

original: nāśakāraṇamāha jñānamadaduḥkhādivirodhī iti / jñānaṃ pratipakṣajñānaṃ vivakṣitam / tena virudhyate / yathā ātmādijñānajanitaḥ saṃskāro nairātmyādyabhyāseneti / tasmin sati tatrāsmaraṇāt / svamadena virodhaḥ / bālāvasthānubhavajanitasaṃskārasya punaryuvāvasthāyāṃ viṣayābhibhūtasya tatrāsmaraṇāt / duḥkhena / yathā śāstrānubhavajanitasaṃskārasya tīvreṇa dārādiduḥkheneti / tena satā tatrāsmaraṇāt / ādipadena tu krodhāderapi saṃskāranivartakatvamuktam /
analyzed: nāśa kāraṇam āha jñāna mada duḥkha ādi virodhī iti jñānam pratipakṣa jñānam vivakṣitam tena virudhyate yathā ātma ādi jñāna janitaḥ saṃskāraḥ nairātmya ādi abhyāsena iti tasmin sati tatra asmaraṇāt sva madena virodhaḥ bāla avasthā anubhava janita saṃskārasya punar yuva avasthāyām viṣaya abhibhūtasya tatra asmaraṇāt duḥkhena yathā śāstra anubhava janita saṃskārasya tīvreṇa dāra ādi duḥkhena iti tena satā tatra asmaraṇāt ādi padena tu k
translated: The cause of destruction is stated as: Knowledge that is opposed to pride, suffering, etc. Knowledge is intended as the counteractive knowledge, which is opposed to it, just as the impression generated by the knowledge of self etc. is by the practice of selflessness etc. Because there is no recollection of it when that exists. The opposition to one's own pride is due to the impression generated by the experience in the state of childhood being overwhelmed by the object in the state of youth, because there is no recollection of it. By suffering, just as the impression generated by the experience of scripture is by intense suffering from a wife etc. Because there is no recollection of it when that exists. But by the word etc., the reversal of the impression by anger etc. is also stated.

original: tasyotpattikāraṇamāha paṭvabhyāsādarapratyayebhyo jātastatpratyayaja iti / paṭupratyayāpekṣādātmamanasoḥ saṃyogādasamavāyikāraṇādātmanyāścarye 'rthe paṭuḥ saṃskāro jāyate / yathā dākṣiṇātyasyoṣṭradarśanāt / sa cātiśayena smṛtiheturbhavatīti / abhyāsād vidyāśilpavyāyāmādiṣvabhyasyamānaṣu tasminnevārthe pūrvapūrvasaṃskāramapekṣamāṇāduttarottarasmāt pratyayādātmamanasoḥ saṃyogāt saṃskārātiśayo jāyate / pūrvapūrvasaṃskārāpekṣo hi uttarottarapratyayo 'bhyāsaḥ / tamapekṣamāṇādātmamanasoḥ saṃyogādasamavāyikāraṇādātmani saṃskārātiśayo jāyate / tatra vidyāyām upādhyāyoccaritapadaśravaṇe sati saṃskāraḥ / punarvivakṣādikrameṇa svayamuccāraṇe sati tu jñānaṃ pūrvasaṃskārāpekṣaṃ saṃskārāntaramārabhate / punastaduccāraṇe sati tajjñānaṃ pūrvasaṃskāpekṣaṃ saṃskārāntaramārabhata ityevaṃ tricaturādiparivartane satyantyapadānubhavāt saṃskārāpekṣāt saṃskārātiśayo jāyate / etaccāvaśyamabhyupeyam / anyathābhyāsavaiyarthyaṃ syāt / na cātiprasaṅgaḥ / adṛṣṭasya vyavasthāhetutvāt / na ca tasyāsti sarvatra sadbhāvaḥ / kāryasya smaraṇasya sarvatrānupalabdheḥ / yatra hi smaraṇamasti tatraiva pūrvasaṃskārāpekṣaṃ jñānaṃ saṃskāramārabhata iti / āntare cābhyāse pūrvapūrvasaṃskārāpekṣaṃ niyatārthasmaraṇameva saṃskāramārabhata iti cintyam / evaṃ śilpe 'pyupādhyāyalikhitacitradarśanāt saṃskāraḥ / punaḥ svayaṃ sampādyopalabhate / tadanubhavaḥ pūrvasaṃskārāpekṣaḥ saṃskārāntaramārabhate / punaḥ svayaṃ likhitvopalabhate / tadanubhavaḥ pūrvasaṃskārāpekṣaḥ saṃskārāntaramārabhate / ityevaṃ II / dvitryādiparivartanena saṃskārātiśayaḥ / vyāyāme 'pi upādhyāyena dhanurvedaparipaṭhitanyāyena prayukteṣūpalambhādupajāte saṃskāre punastadanusāritayā svayaṃ prayukte tadanubhavena pūrvasaṃskārāpekṣeṇa saṃskārāntaramārabhyate / punastathaiva prayoge sati tadanubhavena pūrvasaṃskārāpekṣeṇānyaḥ saṃskāra ityevamantyānubhavāt saṃskārātiśaya iti /
analyzed: tasya utpatti kāraṇam āha paṭu abhyāsa ādara pratyayebhyaḥ jātaḥ tad pratyaya jaḥ iti paṭu pratyaya apekṣāt ātma manasoḥ saṃyogāt asamavāyi kāraṇāt ātmani āścarye rthe paṭuḥ saṃskāraḥ jāyate yathā dākṣiṇātyasya uṣṭra darśanāt sa ca atiśayena smṛti hetuḥ bhavati iti abhyāsāt vidyā śilpa vyāyāma ādiṣu abhyasyamānaṣu tasmin eva arthe pūrva pūrva saṃskāram apekṣamāṇāt uttarottarasmāt pratyayāt ātma manasoḥ saṃyogāt sa
translated: The cause of its origin is stated: born from keen practice, respect, and conditions, it is called produced from those conditions. From the contact of the self and mind, which depends on keen conditions, and from the non-inherent cause, the self, a keen impression arises regarding the object, just as a southerner's impression from seeing a camel. And that becomes the cause of memory with great intensity. From practice, in the case of learning, crafts, exercise, and so on, which are practiced, from the subsequent contact of the self and mind, which depends on the previous impressions regarding that very object, a superior impression arises. For the subsequent contact, which depends on the previous impressions, is practice. Depending on that, from the contact of the self and mind, which is the non-inherent cause, a superior impression arises in the self. There, in the case of learning, when the words spoken by the teacher are heard, there is an impression. But when one speaks oneself in the sequence beginning with the desire to speak, the knowledge, which depends on the previous impression, produces another impression.

original: ādarapratyayajasaṃskāramāha prayatnena manaḥ cakṣuṣi sthāpayitvā apūrvamarthaṃ didṛkṣamāṇasya iti / draṣṭumicchato vidyutsampātadarśanena tulyaṃ vartate / iti taddarśanavadādarapratyayaḥ / tamapekṣamāṇādātmamanasoḥ saṃyogādasamavāyikāraṇādātmani saṃskārātiśayo jāyate / yathā devahrade sauvarṇarājatapadmadarśanāditi / tatra hi sauvarṇarājatapadmayorutthānamāgamāllokapravādato vā samupalabhya punarviśiṣṭayātrāsamaye prayatnena saṃskārātiśayo bhavatīti /
analyzed: ādara pratyaya ja saṃskāram āha prayatnena manaḥ cakṣuṣi sthāpayitvā apūrvam artham didṛkṣamāṇasya iti draṣṭum icchataḥ vidyut sampāta darśanena tulyam vartate iti tad darśana vat ādara pratyayaḥ tam apekṣamāṇāt ātma manasoḥ saṃyogāt asamavāyi kāraṇāt ātmani saṃskāra atiśayaḥ jāyate yathā devahrade sauvarṇa rājata padma darśanāt iti tatra hi sauvarṇa rājata padmayoḥ utthānam āgamāt loka pravādataḥ vā samupalabhya punar viśiṣṭa
translated: The author of the Nyāyabhāṣya says that the impression produced by the cognition of the object is due to the effort of the mind being fixed on the eye, by one desirous of seeing a new object. It is like the impression produced by seeing lightning, for one who wishes to see it. The impression is produced by the contact of the self and mind, which is the non-inherent cause, in the self, like the impression produced by seeing golden and silver lotuses in a divine lake. For there, the rising of the golden and silver lotuses is known from scriptures or popular sayings. Again, at the time of a special pilgrimage, there is an excess of impression due to effort.

original: sthitisthāpakastu sparśavaddravyeṣu vartamāno ghanāvayavasanniveśaviśiṣṭeṣu kālāntarāvasthāyiṣu svāśrayamanyathākṛtaṃ yathāvat sthāpayati / sthāvarajaṅgamavikāreṣu dhanuḥśākhādantaśṛṅgāsthisūtravastrādiṣu bhugnasaṃvartiteṣu sthitisthāpakasya kāryaṃ saṃlakṣyate / nityānityatvaniṣpattayo 'syāpi gurutvavat draṣṭavyāḥ /PDhS
analyzed: sthiti sthāpakaḥ tu sparśavat dravyeṣu vartamānaḥ ghana avayava sanniveśa viśiṣṭeṣu kāla antara avasthāyiṣu sva āśrayam anyathākṛtam yathāvat sthāpayati sthāvara jaṅgama vikāreṣu dhanuḥ śākhā danta śṛṅga asthi sūtra vastra ādiṣu bhugna saṃvartiteṣu sthiti sthāpakasya kāryam saṃlakṣyate nitya anitya tva niṣpattayaḥ guru tva vat draṣṭavyāḥ pdhs
translated: But the one that maintains stability operates in solid substances that possess touch, which have a special arrangement of dense parts and endure for a period of time, and it maintains its substratum as it was, when it has been altered. The function of the one that maintains stability is observed in the modifications of the stationary and the moving, such as in a bent or twisted bow, branch, tooth, horn, bone, thread, cloth, etc. Its eternality and non-eternality should be understood like that of weight.

original: sthitisthāpakastu saṃskāratve sati sparśavatsveva dravyeṣu vartamānatvāditarasmād bhidyate / kiṃ bhūteṣu / ghanāvayavasanniveśaviśiṣṭeṣu iti / ghanāśca te avayavāśca / teṣāṃ sanniveśo racanāviśeṣaḥ / ghana iti sanniveśasya vā viśeṣaṇam / tadviśiṣṭeṣu / kālāntarāvasthāyiṣu svāśrayamanyathākṛtaṃ yathāvat sthāpayati ityataḥ sthitisthāpakaḥ /
analyzed: sthiti sthāpakaḥ tu saṃskāra tve sati sparśavatsu eva dravyeṣu vartamāna tvāt itarasmāt bhidyate kim bhūteṣu ghana avayava sanniveśa viśiṣṭeṣu iti ghanāḥ ca te avayavāḥ ca teṣām sanniveśaḥ racanā viśeṣaḥ ghanaḥ iti sanniveśasya vā viśeṣaṇam tad viśiṣṭeṣu kāla antara avasthāyiṣu sva āśrayam anyathā kṛtam yathāvat sthāpayati iti atas sthiti sthāpakaḥ
translated: But the one that maintains stability, being a modification and operating only in substances that possess touch, is distinguished from the others. In what kind of substances? In those that have a special arrangement of dense parts. And those are dense and also parts. Their arrangement is a special configuration. Or dense is a qualifier of arrangement. In those that have that, which endure for a period of time. It maintains its substratum as it was, when it has been altered. Therefore, it is the one that maintains stability.

original: sadbhāve pramāṇamāha sthāvarāśca jaṅgamāśceti tathoktāsteṣāṃ vikāreṣu dhanuḥśākhādantaśṛṅgāsthiṣu / sūtravastrādiṣu ca bhugneṣu saṃvartiteṣu piṇḍīkṛteṣu tasya kāryaṃ saṃlakṣyate / tathāhi dhanuṣi śākhādī ca ākarṣaṇakarmaṇyupajāte nodanādibhyastannivṛttāvapi karmopalambhādavaśyamasamavāyikāraṇaṃ vācyam / vastunastadantareṇānutpatteḥ / na ca nodanāderanyatamaḥ sambhāvyata ityanyenāsamavāyikāraṇena bhavitavyam / kriyāvibhāgayośca kriyotpattāvakāraṇatvopalambhāt / II / tathā tannivṛttāvapi pratibandhakābhāve sati śākhādau pūrvāvasthāvasthāpakakarmopalambhānnimittāntarameva nyāyyam / adṛṣṭaviśeṣasya tu sādhāraṇatvāt kāraṇatvaṃ na pratiṣiddhyata iti /
analyzed: sadbhāve pramāṇam āha sthāvarāḥ ca jaṅgamāḥ ca iti tathā uktāḥ teṣām vikāreṣu dhanuḥ śākhā danta śṛṅga asthiṣu sūtra vastra ādiṣu ca bhugneṣu saṃvartiteṣu piṇḍīkṛteṣu tasya kāryam saṃlakṣyate tathā hi dhanuṣi śākhā ādī ca ākarṣaṇa karmaṇi upajāte nodana ādibhyaḥ tad nivṛttau api karma upalambhāt avaśyam asamavāyi kāraṇam vācyam vastunaḥ tat antareṇa anutpatteḥ na ca nodana ādeḥ anyatamaḥ sambhāvyate iti anye
translated: He states the means of valid knowledge regarding existence: The moving and unmoving are so called. In their modifications, such as bows, branches, teeth, horns, and bones, and in bent, twisted, and lumped threads, cloths, etc., its effect is observed. Thus, when the action of drawing is produced in a bow, branch, etc., and ceases due to the strokes, etc., the action is still perceived. Therefore, a non-inherent cause must necessarily be stated, because the object does not arise without it. And since none of the strokes, etc. is possible, it must be by some other non-inherent cause. And because the action and division are observed to be non-causes in the production of the action, likewise, even in their cessation, when the absence of obstruction is present, the action that establishes the previous state is observed in the branch, etc. Therefore, another cause is proper. But the unseen special cause is not denied to be the cause, because it is common to all.

original: nityānityatvaniṣpattayo 'pyasya gurutvavad draṣṭavyā iti / yathā hi gurutvaṃ nityeṣu nityamutpattivināśakāraṇābhāvādanityeṣu kāraṇapūrvakamāśrayavināśād vinaśyati evaṃ sthitisthāpakasaṃskāro 'pīti / kārye tu sthitisthāpakasaṃskāraprasiddhestadārambhakaparamāṇuṣvapi tatkalpanā kriyate /
analyzed: nitya anitya tva niṣpattayaḥ api asya guru tva vat draṣṭavyāḥ iti yathā hi guru tvam nityeṣu nityam utpatti vināśa kāraṇa abhāvāt anityeṣu kāraṇa pūrvakam āśraya vināśāt vinaśyati evam sthiti sthāpaka saṃskāraḥ api iti kārye tu sthiti sthāpaka saṃskāra prasiddheḥ tad ārambhaka paramāṇuṣu api tad kalpanā kriyate
translated: The eternality and non-eternality of its existence should be seen as like gravity. Just as gravity is eternal in eternal [substances], because there is no cause for origination and destruction, and in non-eternal [substances] it is destroyed by the destruction of the substratum due to having a cause, so also is the impression that maintains existence. But since the impression that maintains existence is well-known in effects, it is imagined to exist in the atoms that produce it.

original: dharmavaidharmyam
analyzed: dharma vaidharmyam
translated: Similarity and dissimilarity of properties

original: dharmaḥ puruṣaguṇaḥ / kartuḥ priyahitamokṣahetuḥ / atīndriyo 'ntyasukhasaṃvijñānavirodhī / puruṣāntaḥkaraṇasaṃyogaviśuddhābhisandhijaḥ / varṇāśramiṇāṃ pratiniyatasādhananimittaḥ / tasya tu sādhanāni śrutismṛtivihitāni varṇāśramiṇāṃ sāmānyaviśeṣabhāvenāvasthitāni dravyaguṇakarmāṇi /PDhS
analyzed: dharmaḥ puruṣa guṇaḥ kartuḥ priya hita mokṣa hetuḥ atīndriyaḥ ntya sukha saṃvijñāna virodhī puruṣa antaḥkaraṇa saṃyoga viśuddha abhisandhi jaḥ varṇa āśramiṇām pratiniyata sādhana nimittaḥ tasya tu sādhanāni śruti smṛti vihitāni varṇa āśramiṇām sāmānya viśeṣa bhāvena avasthitāni dravya guṇa karmāṇi pdhs
translated: Dharma is a quality of the soul. It is the cause of the pleasure, benefit, and liberation of the agent. It is beyond the senses, opposed to the consciousness of ultimate pleasure. It arises from the purity of the mind's connection with the soul, from the intention to act. It is caused by the specific means prescribed for the varnas and ashramas. The means of attaining it are the substances, qualities, and actions that exist in general and specific forms for the varnas and ashramas, as prescribed by the Vedas and Smritis.

original: dharmasya lakṣaṇaparīkṣārthamāha dharmaḥ puruṣaguṇaḥ ityādi / puruṣaguṇatvaṃ buddhyādāvapītyataḥ priyahitamokṣahetuḥ iti / priyaṃ sukham / hitaṃ tatsādhanam / navānāmātmaviśeṣaguṇānāmatyantocchittirmokṣa iti / atheśvarajñānamapyeṣāṃ heturataḥ karturiti / yena hi kṛto dharmastatraiva priyahitamokṣahetuḥ / na caivamīśvarajñānasya / akāryatayā karturabhāvāditi / atha tattvajñānaṃ karturyathoktaphalahetustadarthamatīndriya iti / saṃskāro 'pi smṛtidvāreṇaiva bhavatītyato 'ntyasukhasaṃvijñānavirodhīti / antyamāvasānikaṃ sukhaṃ tatsaṃvedanena virudhyate /
analyzed: dharmasya lakṣaṇa parīkṣā artham āha dharmaḥ puruṣa guṇaḥ ityādi puruṣa guṇa tvam buddhi ādau api iti atas priya hita mokṣa hetuḥ iti priyam sukham hitam tat sādhanam navānām ātma viśeṣa guṇānām atyanta ucchittiḥ mokṣaḥ iti atha īśvara jñānam api eṣām hetuḥ atas kartuḥ iti yena hi kṛtaḥ dharmaḥ tatra eva priya hita mokṣa hetuḥ na ca evam īśvara jñānasya akārya tayā kartuḥ abhāvāt iti atha tattva jñānam kartuḥ yathā ukta phala h
translated: To examine the definition of dharma, he says Dharma is a quality of the soul and so on. Since the quality of the soul is also present in intellect etc., he says the cause of pleasure, benefit, and liberation. Pleasure is happiness. Benefit is the means to that. Liberation is the complete destruction of the nine specific qualities of the soul. Now, the knowledge of God is also the cause of these, so He is the agent. For the dharma that is performed by someone is the cause of pleasure, benefit, and liberation only there, not so for the knowledge of God. Because it is not an effect, there is no agent. Now, if the knowledge of reality is the cause of the aforementioned fruits for the agent, then it is supersensible for that purpose. Impression also occurs only through memory, therefore it is contradictory to the last blissful consciousness. The last, final, bliss is contradicted by the experience of that.

original: nanvevamapi atīndriyatve satyantyasukhasaṃvijñānavirodhitvāt / dharmaḥ itarasmād bhidyata ityukte vyabhicārābhāvād vyarthaṃ śeṣābhidhānam / na / anyatvāt kartuḥ / priyahitamokṣaheturiti viśiṣṭārthakriyānirūpaṇam / puruṣaguṇa ityanyathābhāvapratiṣedhārtham /
analyzed: nanu evam api atīndriya tve sati antya sukha saṃvijñāna virodhi tvāt dharmaḥ itarasmāt bhidyate iti ukte vyabhicāra abhāvāt vyartham śeṣa abhidhānam na anyatvāt kartuḥ priya hita mokṣa hetuḥ iti viśiṣṭa artha kriyā nirūpaṇam puruṣa guṇaḥ iti anyathābhāva pratiṣedha artham
translated: Even so, if it is beyond the senses, it is different from the other because it is opposed to the last pleasure-consciousness. When it is said Dharma is different from the other because it is opposed to the last pleasure-consciousness, there is no fallacy, so the mention of the rest is useless. No, because the agent is different. The definition of a specific object is the cause of what is dear, beneficial, and liberation. The phrase a quality of the soul is for the purpose of negating any other state.

original: atha puruṣaguṇatve kiṃ pramāṇam / anumānamāgamaśca / tathāhi tanubhuvanādikāryam / puruṣaguṇapūrvakam / vicitrakāryatvād / rathādivaditi / yathāhi II / rathādikartā bhokturabhiprāyaṃ vicitramapekṣamāṇastathaiva tadracanāṃ karoti evaṃ śarīrādikartāpīti / na ca śarīrotpatteḥ pūrvamasmadādyātmani buddhyādayaḥ santi / saṃskārastu smaraṇotpattāvevāvagatasāmarthya iti guṇāntaraṃ tadgatamapekṣamāṇastadupabhoganiṣpattaye vicitraṃ śarīrādikamārabhata iti / āgamastu yāvadātmani dharmādharmau tāvadāyuḥ śarīramindriyāṇi viṣayāśceti / tathā kṣīyante cāsya karmāṇīti /
analyzed: atha puruṣa guṇa tve kim pramāṇam anumānam āgamaḥ ca tathā hi tanu bhuvana ādi kāryam puruṣa guṇa pūrvakam vicitra kāryatvāt ratha ādi vat iti yathā hi ratha ādi kartā bhoktuḥ abhiprāyam vicitram apekṣamāṇaḥ tathā eva tad racanām karoti evam śarīra ādi kartā api iti na ca śarīra utpatteḥ pūrvam asmat ādi ātmani buddhi ādayaḥ santi saṃskāraḥ tu smaraṇa utpattau eva avagata sāmarthyaḥ iti guṇa antaram tad gatam apekṣamāṇaḥ tad upabhoga ni
translated: Now, what is the evidence for the qualities belonging to the soul? Inference and scripture. Thus, the effects like the body and universe are preceded by the qualities of the soul, because they are diverse effects, like a chariot etc. Just as the maker of a chariot etc., while expecting the diverse intentions of the enjoyer, creates that construction accordingly, so also the maker of the body etc. And before the origin of the body, the intellect etc. do not exist in the soul like us. But the impression, whose efficacy is known only in the production of memory, while expecting another quality in it, creates the diverse body etc. for the accomplishment of its enjoyment. As for scripture, it says as long as virtue and vice exist in the soul, so long does life, body, senses and objects exist. Thus, his actions are exhausted.

original: yeṣāntu buddhiguṇo dharmasteṣāṃ kathaṃ nākarmanimittaḥ svargaḥ / tathāhi pralayāvasthāyāṃ buddheḥ pradhāne pralīnatayā dharmādharmayoranabhivyaktau pradhānasya buddhyādibhāvena pariṇāmo na syāt / abhivyaktasya karmaṇaḥ kāraṇatvābhyupagamāt / na cādāvanabhivyaktameva kāraṇam / buddhisthañcābhivyaktamiti vācyam / viśeṣahetvabhāvāt / buddhyādisampāditaṃ karma karturbhogasampādakamityabhyupagame ca aviśeṣeṇa sakalapuruṣopabhogasampādakaṃ syāt / niyamahetvabhāvāt / tathā muktātmano 'pi śarīrādisampādanāya pravarteta / aviśeṣāditi saṃsāritvaprasaṅgaḥ / guṇapuruṣāntaravivekādarśanañca pradhānapravṛtterna kāraṇam / pūrvameva pratiṣedhāt /
analyzed: yeṣām tu buddhi guṇaḥ dharmaḥ teṣām katham na a karma nimittaḥ svargaḥ tathā hi pralaya avasthāyām buddheḥ pradhāne pralīna tayā dharma adharmayoḥ anabhivyaktau pradhānasya buddhi ādi bhāvena pariṇāmaḥ na syāt abhivyaktasya karmaṇaḥ kāraṇa tva abhyupagamāt na ca ādau anabhivyaktam eva kāraṇam buddhi stham ca abhivyaktam iti vācyam viśeṣa hetu abhāvāt buddhi ādi sampāditam karma kartuḥ bhoga sampādakam iti abhyupagame ca aviśeṣeṇa sakala puruṣ
translated: But if the quality of intellect is dharma, then how can heaven not be caused by action? For when the intellect is merged in prakriti at the time of dissolution, dharma and adharma are not manifest, and the transformation of prakriti into intellect etc. would not occur, because manifest action is accepted as the cause. And manifest action cannot be the cause from the beginning, because it is said to be manifest only when located in the intellect. And it cannot be said that the transformation of prakriti into intellect etc. is due to the manifestation of dharma and adharma, because there is no specific cause for that. And if it is accepted that action performed by the intellect etc. produces enjoyment for the agent, then it would produce enjoyment for all liberated souls without distinction, because there is no cause for restriction. And it would operate to produce body etc. even for a liberated soul, because there is no distinction, and thus there would be the undesirable consequence of his being a transmigrating being. And the non-apprehension of the distinction between the qualities and the purusha cannot be the cause of the operation of prakriti, because it has already been refuted.

original: ye 'pi paramāṇurūpo dharma iti manyante / teṣāmapi tasya nityatāyāṃ sakalakriyāvilopaprasaṅgaḥ / maraṇādyabhāvaśca / anityatā tu paramāṇurūpatāyāṃ na sambhavatyeva / tasya paramāṇutvenotpattivināśakāraṇābhāvāt / tathā paramāṇūnāṃ dharmaśabdenābhidhāne saṃjñābhedamātrameva syāt / atha paramāṇuguṇau dharmādhau / evamapi sarvapuruṣāṇām ekākāro bhogaḥ syāt / puṇyāpuṇyādhikaraṇaiḥ paramāṇubhirārambhāviśeṣāt /
analyzed: ye pi paramāṇu rūpaḥ dharmaḥ iti manyante teṣām api tasya nitya tāyām sakala kriyā vilopa prasaṅgaḥ maraṇa ādi abhāvaḥ ca anitya tā tu paramāṇu rūpa tāyām na sambhavati eva tasya paramāṇu tvena utpatti vināśa kāraṇa abhāvāt tathā paramāṇūnām dharma śabdena abhidhāne saṃjñā bheda mātram eva syāt atha paramāṇu guṇau dharma ādhau evam api sarva puruṣāṇām eka ākāraḥ bhogaḥ syāt puṇya apuṇya adhikaraṇaiḥ paramāṇubhiḥ ārambha
translated: Even for those who think that a dharma is atomic form, if that is eternal, the consequence is the cessation of all action, and the absence of death and so on. But impermanence is not possible in the case of atomic form, because it has no cause for origination or destruction by being an atom. Similarly, if atoms are designated by the word dharma, there would be only a difference in name. If dharma and adharma are the qualities of atoms, even so, all persons would have the same kind of experience, because there would be no difference in the composition by atoms with more or less merit and demerit.

original: atha kecit puṇyādhikaraṇāḥ paramāṇavo 'nye cāpuṇyādhikaraṇāḥ / tatrādhikaiḥ puṇyādhikaraṇairārabdhe sukhātiśayo 'dhikaiścāpuṇyādhikaraṇairduḥkhamiti cet / atrāpi tayornityatve maraṇādyabhāvaprasaṅgaḥ / anityatvantu na yuktam / paramāṇuviśeṣaguṇānāmasmadādivyāpāreṇopapatteradarśanāt /
analyzed: atha kecid puṇya adhikaraṇāḥ paramāṇavaḥ nye ca apuṇya adhikaraṇāḥ tatra adhikaiḥ puṇya adhikaraṇaiḥ ārabdhe sukha atiśayaḥ dhikaiḥ ca apuṇya adhikaraṇaiḥ duḥkham iti ced atra api tayoḥ nitya tve maraṇa ādi abhāva prasaṅgaḥ anitya tvam tu na yuktam paramāṇu viśeṣa guṇānām asmat ādi vyāpāreṇa upapatteḥ adarśanāt
translated: If some atoms are with more merit and others with less merit, and if there is a greater degree of pleasure in what is composed by more atoms with merit, and greater pain in what is composed by more atoms with less merit, even then, if they are eternal, the consequence is the absence of death and so on. But impermanence is not proper, because the qualities of atoms are not seen to be due to the operation of ourselves and others.

original: anye tvanāśrito dharma iti manyante / tatrāpi anityapakṣe na kiñcid anāśritaṃ vastubhūtaṃ kāryaṃ sambhavatīti dūṣaṇam / nityapakṣe tu yāgādikriyā vilopaprasaṅgaḥ / atha kriyābhivyaktaḥ kāryakāraṇaḥ / tarhi kṣaṇikatvena kriyāII /vināśe svargādiphalaṃ na syāt / na ca pradīpasyevābhivyañjakatvaṃ tatprakāśakatvaṃ kriyāyāḥ / tadbhāve 'pi tasyānupalambhāt / atha yāgādikriyā dharmasya sāmarthyamupajanayatīti cet / tarhi yat tat sāmarthyaṃ sa eva dharmaḥ / yatrāśritaḥ sa cātmeti saṃjñābhedamātraṃ syāt / tathā amūrtasyātmanā sambandhābhāvāt tatsambandhitvena phalābhāva ityalaṃ prasaṅgena / na ca bodhātmakameva karma / vyatirekānabhyupagame bodharūpatayā sarvatrāviśeṣeṇa jagadvaicitryāprasaṅgāt /
analyzed: anye tu anāśritaḥ dharmaḥ iti manyante tatra api anitya pakṣe na kiñcid anāśritam vastu bhūtam kāryam sambhavati iti dūṣaṇam nitya pakṣe tu yāga ādi kriyā vilopa prasaṅgaḥ atha kriyā abhivyaktaḥ kārya kāraṇaḥ tarhi kṣaṇika tvena svarga ādi phalam na syāt na ca pradīpasya iva abhivyañjaka tvam tad prakāśaka tvam kriyāyāḥ tad bhāve pi tasya anupalambhāt atha yāga ādi kriyā dharmasya sāmarthyam upajanayati iti ced tarhi yat tat sāmarthyam saḥ eva dhar
translated: Others, however, think that Dharma is not dependent. Even there, if it is non-eternal, the objection is that no effect which is not dependent and is a real entity is possible. But if it is eternal, then the performance of sacrifices and other actions would be meaningless. If it is argued that the effect is the manifestation of the action, then in that case, due to momentariness, the action would be destroyed and heaven and other fruits would not result. And the action does not manifest like a lamp, i.e. it does not illuminate itself. Because even when it exists, it is not perceived. If it is argued that the action of sacrifice etc. generates the potency of Dharma, then that potency itself is Dharma. And what is dependent on that is the Self. So it would be mere verbal difference. Similarly, because the formless Self cannot be related to anything, there would be no fruit related to it. Enough of digression. And action is not of the nature of consciousness. Because if difference is not accepted, then due to being of the nature of consciousness, there would be no diversity in the world, as there would be no difference anywhere.

original: tasyotpattikāraṇamāha puruṣāntaḥkaraṇasaṃyogādasamavāyikāraṇādupajāyate / śuddhābhisandhija iti abhisandhernimittakāraṇatvaṃ darśayati / varṇāśramiṇāṃ pratiniyatāni sādhanāni nimittaṃ yasyāsau tannimittaḥ /
analyzed: tasya utpatti kāraṇam āha puruṣa antaḥkaraṇa saṃyogāt asamavāyi kāraṇāt upajāyate śuddha abhisandhi jaḥ iti abhisandheḥ nimitta kāraṇa tvam darśayati varṇa āśramiṇām pratiniyatāni sādhanāni nimittam yasya asau tad nimittaḥ
translated: He states the cause of its origin: It arises from the non-inherent cause of the conjunction of the soul and internal organ. The word pure shows that the intention is the instrumental cause. It has that as its cause, which has the prescribed means for the varnas and ashramas as its cause.

original: tadevāha tasya tu sādhanāni śrutismṛtivihitāni / varṇāśca brāhmaṇādayaḥ / āśramāśca brahmacaryādayasteṣām / sāmānyaviśeṣabhāvenāvasthitāni dravyaguṇakarmāṇīti /
analyzed: tat eva āha tasya tu sādhanāni śruti smṛti vihitāni varṇāḥ ca brāhmaṇa ādayaḥ āśramāḥ ca brahmacarya ādayaḥ teṣām sāmānya viśeṣa bhāvena avasthitāni dravya guṇa karmāṇi iti
translated: He says that: But its means are prescribed by the Vedas and Smritis. And the varnas are the Brahmins and others. And the ashramas are the stages of life beginning with Brahmacharya. They are the substances, qualities and actions that exist in the general and specific forms.

original: tatra sāmānyāni dharme śraddhā / ahiṃsā / bhūtarhitatvam / satyavacanam / asteyam / anupadhā / brahmacaryam / krodhavarjanam / abhiṣecanam / śucidravyasevanam / viśiṣṭadevatābhaktiḥ / upavāso 'pramādaśca /PDhS
analyzed: tatra sāmānyāni dharme śraddhā ahiṃsā bhūta rhita tvam satya vacanam asteyam anupadhā brahmacaryam krodha varjanam abhiṣecanam śuci dravya sevanam viśiṣṭa devatā bhaktiḥ upavāsaḥ pramādaḥ ca
translated: Among them, the general duties are: faith in Dharma, non-violence, benefiting beings, speaking the truth, not stealing, not backbiting, celibacy, avoiding anger, consecration, using pure substances, devotion to the special deities, fasting and heedfulness.

original: tatra sāmānyāni sādhanāni / dharme śraddhā bhaktiviśeṣaḥ kāraṇam / ahiṃsā tu yatyādeḥ sarvadā / anyasya deśaviśeṣe kālaviśeṣe ceti / yathā tīrthe na haniṣyāmi / amāvāsyādau / bhūtahitatvamapi kasyacit sarvadā / kasyacid deśaviśeṣādāviti / satyavacanaṃ dharmasādhanam yanna pareṣāmaniṣṭam / uktañca 'na brūyāt satyamapriyami'ti / asteyamacauryam / kasyāñcidavasthāyāṃ caurye 'pi na dūṣaṇamityuktam / yathā mumūrṣordvijasyāśanamātrāharaṇamiti / anupadhā parādrohaḥ / brahmacaryam apatyasṛjaḥ karaṇasyopasthasya saṃyamaḥ / tacca kasyacit sarvadā / kasyacid deśakālaviśeṣa iti / krodhavarjanamapyevam / abhiṣecanaṃ snānam / śucidravyāṇāṃ sevanamāsanaparidhānāśanaiḥ / viśiṣṭadevatābhaktiriti trayīprasiddhānumānāvagatadevatāviśeṣabhaktiḥ / upavāso 'horātraṃ nairaśanatā / kālaviśeṣādau dharmasādhanam / apramādo vihitānuṣṭhāne nirālasyam /
analyzed: tatra sāmānyāni sādhanāni dharme śraddhā bhakti viśeṣaḥ kāraṇam ahiṃsā tu yati ādeḥ sarvadā anyasya deśa viśeṣe kāla viśeṣe ca iti yathā tīrthe na haniṣyāmi amāvāsyā ādau bhūta hita tvam api kasyacid sarvadā kasyacid deśa viśeṣa ādau iti satya vacanam dharma sādhanam yat na pareṣām aniṣṭam uktam ca na brūyāt satyam apriyam iti asteyam acauryam kasyāñcid avasthāyām caurye na dūṣaṇam iti uktam yathā mumūrṣoḥ dvijasya aśana mātra āhara
translated: Among them, the general means are: Faith in Dharma is a special cause of devotion. Non-violence is always for ascetics and others, and for others in specific countries and times. For example, I will not kill in a holy place, on new moon days, etc. The welfare of beings is also always for some, and in specific countries and times for others. Speaking the truth is a means of Dharma, which is not unpleasant to others. It is said, One should not speak unpleasant truth. Non-stealing means not stealing. It is said that even stealing in some situations is not a fault, like a dying Brahmin just taking enough food. Non-violence is not harming others. Celibacy is the restraint of the genital organ, the instrument of procreation. And that is always for some, and in specific countries and times for others. Avoiding anger is the same. Consecration is bathing. The well-known triad is: using pure substances through sitting, wearing, and eating; devotion to a special deity;

original: brāhmaṇakṣatriyavaiśyānāmijyādhyayanadānāni / brāhmaṇasya viśiṣṭāni pratigrahādhyāpanayājanāni / svavarṇavihitāśca saṃskārāḥ / kṣatriyasya samyakprajāpālanamasādhunigraho yuddheṣvanivartanam / svakīyāśca saṃskārāḥ / vaiśyasya krayavikrayakṛṣipaśupālanāni svakīyāśca saṃskārāḥ / śūdrasya pūrvavarṇapāratantryam / amantrikāśca kriyāḥ /PDhS
analyzed: brāhmaṇa kṣatriya vaiśyānām ijyā adhyayana dānāni brāhmaṇasya viśiṣṭāni pratigraha adhyāpana yājanāni sva varṇa vihitāḥ ca saṃskārāḥ kṣatriyasya samyak prajā pālanam asādhu nigrahaḥ yuddheṣu anivartanam svakīyāḥ ca saṃskārāḥ vaiśyasya kraya vikraya kṛṣi paśu pālanāni svakīyāḥ ca saṃskārāḥ śūdrasya pūrva varṇa pāratantryam amantrikāḥ ca kriyāḥ
translated: For Brahmins, Kshatriyas, and Vaishyas, the duties are officiating at sacrifices, teaching, and giving gifts. For Brahmins, the special duties are receiving gifts, teaching, and officiating at sacrifices. And the sacraments prescribed for their own class. For Kshatriyas, the duties are proper protection of the people, restraining the wicked, and not turning back in battles. And their own sacraments. For Vaishyas, the duties are buying and selling, agriculture, and cattle-rearing. And their own sacraments. For Shudras, the duty is service to the higher classes. And the rites without sacred formulas.

original: brāhmaṇakṣatriyaviśāṃ sāmānyāni dharmasādhanāni / ijyā yajanam / adhyayanaṃ vedapāṭhaḥ / dānaṃ satpātrasya dravyanivedanamiti / brāhmaṇasyāsādhāraṇāni dharmasādhanāni pratigrahādhyāpanayājanāni / pratigrahaḥ śāstreṇāninditadravyādānam / vedapāṭho / yājanaṃ yāge paurohityam / svavarṇaniyatāśca saṃskārāḥ / kṣatriyasyāsādhāraṇāni dharmasādhanāni samyak prajāpālanam / asādhunigraho yuddheṣvanivartanam / svakīyāśca saṃskārāḥ / vaiśyasya krayavikrayakṛṣipaśupālanāni / svakīyāśca saṃskārāḥ / śūdrasya sarvadā brāhmaṇādyājñayā vartanam / amantrakāścoṅkārādivivarjitāḥ kriyā iti /
analyzed: brāhmaṇa kṣatriya viśām sāmānyāni dharma sādhanāni ijyā yajanam adhyayanam veda pāṭhaḥ dānam sat pātrasya dravya nivedanam iti brāhmaṇasya asādhāraṇāni dharma sādhanāni pratigraha adhyāpana yājanāni pratigrahaḥ śāstreṇa anindita dravya ādānam veda pāṭhaḥ yājanam yāge paurohityam sva varṇa niyatāḥ ca saṃskārāḥ kṣatriyasya asādhāraṇāni dharma sādhanāni samyak prajā pālanam asādhu nigrahaḥ yuddheṣu anivartanam svakīyāḥ ca saṃskā
translated: The common means of accomplishing Dharma for Brahmins, Kshatriyas, and Vaishyas are: sacrifice (offering to gods), officiating at sacrifices, studying (reciting the Vedas), and giving (offering wealth to worthy recipients). The uncommon means of accomplishing Dharma for Brahmins are: accepting gifts, teaching, and officiating at sacrifices. Accepting gifts means receiving wealth that is not condemned by scriptures. Reciting the Vedas. Officiating at sacrifices means being the priest in rituals. And the sacraments prescribed for one's own class. The uncommon means of accomplishing Dharma for Kshatriyas are: proper protection of the people, restraining the wicked, and not turning back in battles. And the sacraments for one's own class. For Vaishyas, buying and selling, agriculture, and animal husbandry. And the sacraments for one's own class. For Shudras, always serving Brahmins and others by their order. And rituals devoid of mantras, excluding the syllable Om and so on.

original: āśramiṇāntu / brahmacāriṇaḥ gurukulanivāsinaḥ svaśāstravihitāni guruśuśrūṣāgnīndhanabhaikṣyācaraṇāni madhumāṃsadivāsvapnāñjanābhyañjanādivarjanañca / vidyāvratasnātakasya kṛtadārasya gṛhasthasya śālīnayāyāvaravṛttyupārjitairarthairbhūtamanuṣyadevapitṛbrahmākhyānāṃ pañcānāṃ mahāyajñānāṃ sāyamprātaranuṣṭhānam / ekāgnividhānena pākayajñasaṃsthānāñca nityānāṃ śaktau vidyamānāyām / agnyādheyādīnāñca haviryajñasaṃsthānām agniṣṭomādīnām / somayajñasaṃsthānāñca / ṛtvantareṣu brahmacaryamapatyotpādanañca / brahmacāriṇo gṛhasthasya vā grāmānnirgatasya vanavāsi balkalājinakeśaśmaśrunakharomadhāraṇañca / vanyāmbuhutātithiśeṣabhojanāni vanasthasya / trayāṇāmanyatamasya śraddhāvataḥ sarvabhūtebhyo nityamabhayaṃ f saṃnyasya svāni karmāṇi yamaniyameṣvapramattasya ṣaṭpadārthaprasaṃkhyānād yogaprasādhanaṃ pravarjitasyeti / dṛṣṭañca prayojanamanuddiśyaitāni sādhanāni bhāvaprasādañcāpekṣya ātmamanasoḥ saṃyogāddharmotpattiriti /PDhS
analyzed: āśramiṇām tu brahmacāriṇaḥ guru kula nivāsinaḥ sva śāstra vihitāni guru śuśrūṣā agni indhana bhaikṣya ācaraṇāni madhu māṃsa divāsvapna añjana abhyañjana ādi varjanam ca vidyāvrata snātakasya kṛtadārasya gṛhasthasya śālīna yāyāvara vṛtti upārjitaiḥ arthaiḥ bhūta manuṣya deva pitṛ brahma ākhyānām pañcānām mahāyajñānām sāyam prātar anuṣṭhānam eka agni vidhānena pākayajña saṃsthānām ca nityānām śaktau vidyamānāyām agnyādh
translated: But for the hermits: The celibate student living in the teacher's house should perform the duties prescribed by his scriptures, such as serving the teacher, maintaining the sacred fires, and begging for alms, and avoid honey, meat, daytime sleep, collyrium, anointing, etc. The householder who has completed his studies, taken the concluding bath, and married, should perform the five great sacrifices to beings, humans, gods, ancestors, and Brahmins, in the evening and morning with wealth earned through the conduct of gleaning and gleaning-like means, and if able, the daily rites of the cooked oblations according to the rules of the one-fire ritual. He should also perform the oblation rites of the fire-laying etc. and the soma sacrifices such as the agniṣṭoma. In the other seasons, he should practice celibacy and beget children. The forest-dweller, whether a celibate student or householder, who has left the village, should wear bark garments, antelope skin, keep hair, beard, nails, and body hair, and eat the remains of offerings to guests with wild water and oblations. The forest-dweller should always have faith in the three, and be compassionate towards all beings.

original: āśramiṇāntu dharmasādhanānyucyante / tatra brahmacāriṇaḥ / kiṃviśiṣṭasya / gurukule vasatastacchīlaṃ veti tadvāsino guruśuśrūṣāgnīndhanabhaikṣyācaraṇāni / II / guruśuśrūṣā tadupāsanam / agnīndhanam agnyarthamindhanāharaṇam / bhikṣāṇāṃ samūho bhaikṣaṃ mādhukarī bhikṣā / tadācaraṇam / madhumāṃsadivāsvapnāñjanābhyañjanādivarjanam / etattu prativedaṃ dvādaśavarṣāṇītyaṣṭacatvāriṃśad varṣāṇi vidyāvrataṃ yāvad grahaṇaṃ bhavet /
analyzed: āśramiṇām tu dharma sādhanāni ucyante tatra brahmacāriṇaḥ kiṃviśiṣṭasya guru kule vasataḥ tad śīlam vā iti tad vāsinaḥ guru śuśrūṣā agni indhana bhaikṣya ācaraṇāni guru śuśrūṣā tad upāsanam agni indhanam agni artham indhana āharaṇam bhikṣāṇām samūhaḥ bhaikṣam mādhukarī bhikṣā tad ācaraṇam madhu māṃsa divāsvapna añjana abhyañjana ādi varjanam etat tu prativedam dvādaśa varṣāṇi iti aṣṭacatvāriṃśat varṣāṇi vidyāvra
translated: Now the means of accomplishing Dharma for the stages of life are being stated. There, for the celibate student, of what specific kind? Dwelling in the teacher's house, following his conduct. The duties of one dwelling there are serving the teacher, kindling the sacred fire, and going on alms rounds. Serving the teacher is attending to him. Kindling the sacred fire is bringing fuel for the fire. A collection of alms is alms. Going on alms rounds. Avoiding honey, meat, daytime sleep, collyrium, anointing, etc. But this is for each Veda, so the study vow would last for twelve years, making forty-eight years.

original: tato vidyāvratasnātakasya cīrṇavidyāvratasya kṛtadārasyodvahitapatnīkasya gṛhasthasya dharmasādhanānyucyante / te caturvidhāḥ / vārtāvṛttayaḥ / śālīnavṛttayaḥ / yāyāvarāḥ / ghorasaṃnyāsikāśceti / tatra vārtāvṛttayaḥ kṛṣivāṇijyādikamaninditaṃ śāstreṇaiva yuñjantaḥ śatasaṃvatsarābhiḥ kriyābhiryajanto yājayanta ātmānaṃ prārthayante / śālīnavṛttayastu yajanto yājayanto dadataḥ pratigṛhṇantaḥ śatasaṃvatsarābhiḥ kriyābhirātmānaṃ prārthayante / yāyāvarāstu adhīyanto na adhyāpayantaḥ / yajanto na / yājayantaḥ / dadato na pratigṛhṇantaḥ / ityātmānaṃ prārthayante / tatra ghorasaṃnyāsikā nāma uddhṛtaparapūtābhiradbhiḥ kāryaṃ kurvāṇāḥ pratidinamāhṛtoñchavṛttimupajīvantaḥ śatasaṃvatsarābhiḥ kriyābhiryajanta ātmānaṃ prārthayante / udāharaṇārthañca gṛhasthadvayam / uktaśīlāna /śālīnayāyāvaravṛttyupārjitadravyairbhūtamanuṣyadevapitṛbrahmākhyānāṃ pañcānāṃ mahāyajñānāṃ sāyaṃ prātaranuṣṭhānam / sāyamaparāhnam / prātaḥ pratyuṣasi / tatra bāhyabalinā bhūtayajñaḥ / hantakāreṇa atithideyataṇḍulena manuṣyayajñaḥ / puṣpapatrādyutsargeṇāgnisantarpaṇena devayajñaḥ / atidānena pitṛyajñaḥ / vedādhyanena brahmayajña ityeṣāṃ sāyaṃ prātaranuṣṭhānam / ekāgnividhānena eko 'gnirvivāhakāle parigṛhīta iti / naimittikānāntu parasparaṃ vyāvṛttamanuṣṭhānabhedaṃ darśayati pākayajñasaṃsthānām ityādinā / pākayajñasaṃsthāstu
analyzed: tatas vidyāvrata snātakasya cīrṇa vidyāvratasya kṛtadārasya udvahita patnīkasya gṛhasthasya dharma sādhanāni ucyante te caturvidhāḥ vārtāvṛttayaḥ śālīna vṛttayaḥ yāyāvarāḥ ghorasaṃnyāsikāḥ ca iti tatra vārtāvṛttayaḥ kṛṣi vāṇijya ādikam aninditam śāstreṇa eva yuñjantaḥ śata saṃvatsarābhiḥ kriyābhiḥ yajantaḥ yājayantaḥ ātmānam prārthayante śālīna vṛttayaḥ tu yajantaḥ yājayantaḥ dadataḥ pratigṛhṇantaḥ śata sa
translated: Then, for the householder who has completed his Vedic studies, who has taken the final bath at the conclusion of his studies, who has married, and whose wife has conceived, the means of accomplishing Dharma are stated. They are of four types: Vartāvṛttis, Śālīnavṛttis, Yāyāvaras, and Ghorasaṃnyāsikas. Among them, the Vartāvṛttis, engaging in agriculture, trade, and so on, which are not censured by the scriptures, worship with rites lasting for a hundred years, perform sacrifices, and seek their own self. The Śālīnavṛttis, while worshipping and performing sacrifices, giving and receiving, seek their own self with rites lasting for a hundred years. The Yāyāvaras, while studying but not teaching, worshipping but not performing sacrifices, giving but not receiving, seek their own self. Among them, the Ghorasaṃnyāsikas, performing their duties with water drawn from a pure source, subsisting on the daily collected alms, worship with rites lasting for a hundred years, and seek their own self.

original: aṣṭakāḥ pārvaṇaṃ śrāddhaṃ śrāvaṇyāgrahāyaṇī tathā /
analyzed: aṣṭakāḥ pārvaṇam śrāddham śrāvaṇī āgrahāyaṇī tathā
translated: The Ashtakas, the Parvana Sraddha, the Sravanya and Agrahayani,

original: caitrī cāśvayujī caiva sapta / pākasaṃsthā imāḥ smṛtāḥ //
analyzed: caitrī ca āśvayujī ca eva sapta pāka saṃsthāḥ imāḥ smṛtāḥ
translated: and the Chaitra and Ashvayuj - these seven are considered the Paka-sthana.

original: eṣāñca nityānāṃ śaktau vidyamānāyāmanuṣṭhānam / asamarthasya tvakaraṇe 'pi na doṣa iti / tadevāha jarayā ha vā eṣa etasmāt satrād vipramucyate mṛtyunā veti / agnyādheyānāñca haviryajñasaṃsthānām / agnyādheyo 'gnihotraṃ darśapūrṇamāsau ca cāturmāsyāgrahāyaṇeṣṭinirūḍhapaśubandhasautrāmaṇī ceti sapta II / haviryajñasaṃsthāḥ / agniṣṭomo 'tyagniṣṭoma ukthyaḥ ṣoḍaśī vājapeyo 'tirātrāptoryāma iti sapta homayajñasaṃsthāḥ / tadāha somayajñasaṃsthānāmagniṣṭomādīnāmiti / evamanye 'pi yajñaviśeṣāstacchāstraprasiddhā eva grāhyā iti / ṛtvantareṣu brahmacaryamapatyotpādanañca /
analyzed: eṣām ca nityānām śaktau vidyamānāyām anuṣṭhānam asamarthasya tu akaraṇe na doṣaḥ iti tat eva āha jarayā ha vai eṣaḥ etasmāt satrāt vipramucyate mṛtyunā vā iti agnyādheyānām ca haviḥ yajña saṃsthānām agnyādheyaḥ gnihotram darśa pūrṇamāsau ca cāturmāsya ā grahāyaṇa iṣṭi nirūḍha paśubandha sautrāmaṇī ca iti sapta haviḥ yajña saṃsthāḥ agniṣṭomaḥ utyagniṣṭomaḥ ukthyaḥ ṣoḍaśī vājapeyaḥ utirātra aptoryāmaḥ iti s
translated: And the performance of these obligatory rites is when one has the ability. But for one who is unable, there is no fault even in not performing them. That is stated as: He is released from this Satra by old age or by death. And of the Haviryagnasthams that are to be installed with fire. The Haviryagnasthams are seven: the installation of fire, the Agnihotra, the Darsha-Purnamasa, the Chaturmasya, the Agrahayani sacrifice, the animal sacrifice of the Nirudha, and the Sautranimanta. The Homyayagnasthams are seven: the Agnistoma, the Atyagnistoma, the Ukthya, the Shodashin, the Vajapeya, the Atiratra, and the Aptoryama. That is stated as: Of the Soma-sacrifice-sthams such as the Agnistoma. Similarly, other specific sacrifices that are well-known in that scripture should be accepted. Celibacy during other seasons and begetting offspring.

original: vanasthasya dharmasādhanamāha brahmacāriṇo gṛhasthasya vā vanavāsaḥ iti / uktañca yadi vā brahmacaryādeva pravrajet iti / ato brahmacāriṇo gṛhasthasya vā adhikāraḥ / te 'pi caturvidhāḥ / vaikhānasāḥ / audumbarāḥ / bālakhilyāḥ / phenapāśceti / tatra vaikhānasā nāma akṛṣṭapacyābhirauṣadhībhirgrāmabahiṣkṛtābhiragniparicaraṇaṃ kṛtvā pañcamahāyajñakriyāṃ nirvartayanta ātmānaṃ prārthayante / tatraudumbarā nāma prātarutthāya yāṃ diśaṃ prekṣante tadāhṛtairbadaranīvāraśyāmākairagniparicaraṇaṃ kṛtvā pañcamahāyajñakriyāṃ nirvartayanta ātmānaṃ prārthayante / tatra bālakhilyā nāma jaṭādharā cīravalkalasaṃvṛtāṅgāḥ paurṇamāsyāṃ vā kārtikyāṃ puṣyādibhakṣamutsṛjanta aṣṭau māsān vṛttyupārjanaṃ kṛtvā pañcamahāyajñakriyāṃ nivartayanta ātmānaṃ prārthayante / tatra phenapā nāma uddaṇḍakānunmattāḥ śīrṇapatrābhibhojino yatra tatra vā vasanta ātmānaṃ prārthayante / tadevāha valkalājinakeśaśmaśrunakharomadhāraṇaṃ vanyāmbuhutātithiśeṣabhojanāni vanasthasya iti / yatyāśramamupadarśayannāha trayāṇāmanyatamasya iti / trayāṇāṃ brahmacārigṛhasthavānaprasthānāmanyatamasya / kiṃ viśiṣṭasya / śraddhāvataḥ / sarvabhūtebhyo nityaṃ sarvadā abhayaṃ dattvā / uktañca na hiṃsyāt sarvabhūtānīti / saṃnyasya svāni karmāṇi agnihotrādīni / yamaniyameṣvapramattasya iti / ahiṃsādayo yamāḥ / śuśrūṣādayā niyamāḥ / teṣvapramattasya / ṣaṭpadārthaprasaṃkhyānāt parijñānād yogasādhanapravarjitasya iti / yoga eva tasya dharmasādhanam /
analyzed: vanasthasya dharma sādhanam āha brahmacāriṇaḥ gṛhasthasya vā vana vāsaḥ iti uktam ca yadi vā brahmacaryāt eva pravrajet iti atas brahmacāriṇaḥ gṛhasthasya vā adhikāraḥ te caturvidhāḥ vaikhānasāḥ audumbarāḥ bālakhilyāḥ phenapāḥ ca iti tatra vaikhānasāḥ nāma a kṛṣṭa pacyābhiḥ auṣadhībhiḥ grāma bahiṣkṛtābhiḥ agni paricaraṇam kṛtvā pañcamahāyajña kriyām nirvartayantaḥ ātmānam prārthayante tatra audumbarāḥ nāma prātar utth
translated: The means of accomplishing Dharma for one living in the forest is stated as either living in the forest as a celibate or a householder. And it is said, Or if one should renounce right from celibacy. Therefore, either a celibate or a householder is eligible. And they are also of four types: Vaikhānasas, Audumbaras, Bālakhilyas, and Phenapas. Among them, those called Vaikhānasas, having performed the worship of the sacred fire with wild herbs that grow without cultivation and are outside the village, accomplish the five great sacrifices and pray for the self. Among them, those called Audumbaras, having risen in the morning and having performed the worship of the sacred fire with jujube, wild rice, and śyāmaka grains obtained in the direction they look, accomplish the five great sacrifices and pray for the self. Among them, those called Bālakhilyas, having matted hair, their bodies covered with bark garments, having offered on the full moon day of Kārtika or the full moon of Phālguna food for sustenance, having earned a living for eight months, perform the five great sacrifices with the food obtained in the morning and evening, and pray for the self.

original: uktanyāyena te 'pi caturvidhāḥ / kuṭīcakāḥ / bahūdakāḥ / haṃsāḥ / paramahaṃsāśceti / kuṭīcakāstridaṇḍakamaṇḍalukanthādidhāriṇo jñātigṛheṣu bhojinaḥ / bahūdakā nāma brāhmaṇagṛheṣu bhikṣāśinaḥ śūnyāgāradevagṛhavāsinaḥ / haṃsā nā śikhākamaṇḍaludaṇḍahastā grāmaikarātravāsinastīrthādiṣu tripañcarātram / evaṃ pakṣopavāsādibhirātmānaṃ prārthayante / paramahaṃsāstvekadaṇḍadharāḥ / muṇḍāḥ / II / kaupīnavāsasaḥ / śikhāyajñopavītakamaṇḍalubhikṣākapālādīnāñca tyāginaḥ / na teṣāṃ dharmo nādharmaḥ / na satyam / na cānṛtam / sarvaṃsahāḥ / sarvasamāḥ / samaloṣṭāśmakāñcanāḥ / eṣāṃ caturṇāmapi dṛṣṭaṃ prayojanamanuddiśyaitāni sādhanāni bhāvaprasādaṃ śuddhābhisandhiñcāpekṣya ātmamanaḥsaṃyogādasamavāyikāraṇāddharmotpattiriti /
analyzed: ukta nyāyena te pi caturvidhāḥ kuṭīcakāḥ bahūdakāḥ haṃsāḥ paramahaṃsāḥ ca iti kuṭīcakāḥ tridaṇḍa kamaṇḍalu kantha ādi dhāriṇaḥ jñāti gṛheṣu bhojinaḥ bahūdakāḥ nāma brāhmaṇa gṛheṣu bhikṣā āśinaḥ śūnya āgāra devagṛha vāsinaḥ haṃsāḥ śikhā kamaṇḍalu daṇḍa hastāḥ grāma eka rātra vāsinaḥ tīrtha ādiṣu tri pañca rātram evam pakṣa upavāsa ādibhiḥ ātmānam prārthayante paramahaṃsāḥ tu eka daṇ
translated: By the stated method, they are also of four kinds: Kuṭīcakas, Bahūdakas, Haṃsas, and Paramahaṃsas. Kuṭīcakas carry a triple staff, water pot, patched garment, etc., and eat in the houses of their relatives. Bahūdakas are named after eating alms in the houses of Brahmins, living in empty houses and temples. Haṃsas have a tuft, water pot, and staff in hand, live in villages for one night, and for three to five nights in holy places, etc. Thus they strive for themselves through fasting for half a month and so on. Paramahaṃsas carry a single staff, are shaven, wear a loincloth, and renounce the tuft, sacred thread, water pot, begging bowl, etc. For them there is no dharma, no adharma, no truth, and no falsehood. They endure all, are equal to all, and consider a clod, a stone, and gold as equal. For these four, disregarding the visible purpose, these means depend on the purity of the mind and the pure intention, and on the non-inherent cause of the union of the self and the mind.

original: adharmavaidharmyam
translated: The nature of non-dharma

original: adharmo 'pyātmaguṇaḥ / karturahitapratyavāyaheturatīndriyo 'ntyaduḥkhasaṃvijñānavirodhī / tasya tu sādhanāni / śāstre pratiṣiddhāni dharmasādhanaviparītāni hiṃsānṛtasteyādīni / vihitākaraṇam / pramādaśca / etāni duṣṭābhisandhiñcāpekṣyātmamanasoḥ saṃyogādadharmasyotpattiḥ /tpādakāni /PDhS
analyzed: adharmaḥ pi ātma guṇaḥ kartuḥ ahita pratyavāya hetuḥ atīndriyaḥ ntya duḥkha saṃvijñāna virodhī tasya tu sādhanāni śāstre pratiṣiddhāni dharma sādhana viparītāni hiṃsā anṛta steya ādīni vihita akaraṇam pramādaḥ ca etāni duṣṭa abhisandhim ca apekṣya ātma manasoḥ saṃyogāt adharmasya utpattiḥ ātpādakāni
translated: Non-dharma is also a quality of the self. It is a cause of undesirable consequences for the agent, is beyond the senses, and opposes the consciousness of final suffering. But its means of accomplishment are the prohibited actions in the scriptures, which are contrary to the means of attaining dharma, such as violence, falsehood, theft, and so on. And the non-performance of what is enjoined, and negligence. These are the means of producing non-dharma from the conjunction of the self and mind, depending on a corrupt intention.

original: na paraṃ dharmo 'dharmopyātmaguṇaḥ / karturahitapratyavāyaheturatīndriyo 'ntyaduḥkhasaṃvijñānavirodhī iti / atīndriyatve satyantyaduḥkhasaṃvijñānavirodhitvāt / adharmaḥ / itarasmād bhidyate / śeṣaṃ pūrvavat / tasya sādhanāni śāstre vipratiṣiddhāni dharmasādhanaviparītāni hiṃsānṛtasteyādīni / hiṃsā prāṇivadho 'nṛtamasatyaṃ steyaṃ cauryam / ādipadenānyeṣāmapi dharmasādhanaviparītānāmavarodhaḥ / avaṣyakartavyasya saṃdhyāvandanāderakaraṇaṃ vihitakālātikrameṇāpyananuṣṭhānam / pramādaścālasyam / etāni nimittāni duṣṭābhisandhiṃ duṣṭābhiprāyaṃ cāpekṣyātmamanaḥsaṃyogādasamavāyikāraṇādātmanyadharmotpattiriti /tpādakānīti /
analyzed: na param dharmaḥ dharmaḥ api ātma guṇaḥ kartuḥ ahita pratyavāya hetuḥ atīndriyaḥ ntya duḥkha saṃvijñāna virodhī iti atīndriya tve sati antya duḥkha saṃvijñāna virodhi tvāt adharmaḥ itarasmāt bhidyate śeṣam pūrvavat tasya sādhanāni śāstre vipratiṣiddhāni dharma sādhana viparītāni hiṃsā anṛta steya ādīni hiṃsā prāṇi vadhaḥ steyam cauryam ādi padena anyeṣām api dharma sādhana viparītānām avarodhaḥ saṃdhyā vandana ādeḥ akaraṇam v
translated: Adharma is also a quality of the self, being the cause of undesirable consequences for the doer, imperceptible, and opposed to the consciousness of final suffering. Being imperceptible and opposed to the consciousness of final suffering, it is different from the other. The rest is as before. Its means are prohibited in the scriptures, being contrary to the means of dharma, such as violence, falsehood, theft, etc. Violence is the killing of living beings, falsehood is untruth, theft is stealing. The word etc. includes others also that are contrary to the means of dharma. Non-performance is the non-performance even by exceeding the prescribed time of what is to be necessarily done, such as the worship of the evening, etc. And negligence is laziness. These are the causes, depending on a bad intention and a bad purpose, for the arising of adharma in the self from the non-inherent cause of the conjunction of the self with the mind.

original: aviduṣo rāgadveṣavataḥ pravartakād dharmāt prakṛṣṭāt svalpādharmasahitād brahmendraprajāpatipitṛmanuṣyalokeṣvāśayānurūpairiṣṭaśarīrendriyaviṣayasukhādibhiryogo bhavati / tathā prakṛṣṭādadharmāt svalpadharmasahitāt pretatiryagyonisthāneṣu aniṣṭaśarīrendriyaviṣayaduḥkhādibhiryogo bhavati / ityevaṃ lakṣaṇād dharmādadharmasahitād devamanuṣyatiryaṅnārakeṣu punaḥ punaḥ saṃsāraprabandho bhavati /PDhS
analyzed: aviduṣaḥ rāga dveṣavataḥ pravartakāt dharmāt prakṛṣṭāt su alpa adharma sahitāt brahma indra prajāpati pitṛ manuṣya lokeṣu āśaya anurūpaiḥ iṣṭa śarīra indriya viṣaya sukha ādibhiḥ yogaḥ bhavati tathā prakṛṣṭāt adharmāt su alpa dharma sahitāt preta tiryagyoni sthāneṣu aniṣṭa śarīra indriya viṣaya duḥkha ādibhiḥ yogaḥ bhavati iti evam lakṣaṇāt dharmāt adharma sahitāt deva manuṣya tiryak nārakeṣu punar punar saṃsāra prabandh
translated: For the ignorant, who have attachment and aversion, there is union with the desired bodies, sense faculties, objects, happiness, etc., in accordance with their aspirations, in the worlds of Brahma, Indra, Prajapati, ancestors, and humans, from the predominant dharma accompanied by little adharma. Similarly, from the predominant adharma accompanied by little dharma, there is union with the undesired bodies, sense faculties, objects, suffering, etc., in the abodes of ghosts, animals, and wombs. Thus, from dharma and adharma of such characteristics, accompanied by each other, there is the continuity of rebirth again and again in the realms of gods, humans, animals, and hell beings.

original: jñānapūrvakāttu kṛtādasaṅkalpitaphalād viśuddhe kule jātasya duḥkhavigamopāyajijñāsorācāryamupasaṅgamyotpannaṣaṭpadārthatattvajñānasyājñānanivṛttau viraktasya rāgadveṣādyabhāvāt tajjayordharmādharmayoranutpattau pūrvaII /sañcitayoścopabhogānnirodhe santoṣasukhaṃ śarīraparicche /khedañcotpādya rāgādinivṛttau nivṛttilakṣaṇaḥ kevalo dharmaḥ paramārthadarśanajaṃ sukhaṃ kṛtvā nivartate / tadā nirodhāt nirbījasyātmanaḥ śārīrādinivṛttiḥ / punaḥ śarīrādyanutpattau dagdhendhanānalavadupaśamo mokṣa iti /PDhS
analyzed: jñāna pūrvakāt tu kṛtāt asaṅkalpita phalāt viśuddhe kule jātasya duḥkha vigama upāya jijñāsoḥ ācāryam upasaṅgamya utpanna ṣaṣ padārtha tattva jñānasya ajñāna nivṛttau viraktasya rāga dveṣa ādi abhāvāt tad jayoḥ dharma adharmayoḥ anutpattau santoṣa sukham śarīra paricchekhedam ca utpādya rāga ādi nivṛttau nivṛtti lakṣaṇaḥ kevalaḥ dharmaḥ paramārtha darśana jam sukham kṛtvā nivartate tadā nirodhāt nirbījasya ātmanaḥ śārīra ādi ni
translated: But from an action done with knowledge, whose fruit is not intended, for one born in a pure family, who desires to know the means of removing suffering, having approached a teacher and produced the knowledge of the truth of the six categories, when ignorance ceases, being detached due to the absence of attachment, aversion, etc., when virtue and vice born from them do not arise, and when the previously accumulated [deeds] cease due to experience, producing the happiness of contentment and the weariness of the limitation of the body, when attachment, etc. cease, the unmanifest virtue alone, characterized by cessation, having produced the happiness born from the realization of the highest truth, ceases. Then, from that cessation, the soul without seed ceases from the body, etc. When the body, etc. do not arise again, there is peace like a fire without fuel - this is liberation.

original: idānīṃ kasyopajātaṃ karma saṃsārasampādakaṃ kathañca nivartakamityupadarśayati aviduṣo mithyājñānavato dharmādharmāvutpannau saṃsāraṃ sampādayatastadāha pravartakāt saṃsārasampādakād dharmāt prakṛṣṭāt svalpādharmasahitāt / iṣṭāni ca tāni śarīrendriyaviṣayasukhādīni taiḥ / kiṃviśiṣṭaiḥ / āśayānurūpaiḥ karmānurūpairyogaḥ sambandho bhavatīti / keṣu sthāneṣu / brahmendraprajāpatipitṛṝṣi /manuṣyalokeṣviti / tathā prakṛṣṭādadharmāt svalpadharmasahitāt / aniṣṭaśarīrendriyaviṣayaduḥkhādibhiryogaḥ keṣu / pretatiryagyonisthāneṣu iti / upasaṃhāramāha ityevaṃ pravṛttilakṣaṇāt tatsvarūpād / dharmādadharmasahitād devamanuṣyatiryaṅnārakeṣu punaḥ punaḥ saṃsārasya prabandhaḥ santāno bhavatīti /
analyzed: idānīm kasya upajātam karma saṃsāra sampādakam kathañca nivartakam iti upadarśayati aviduṣaḥ mithyājñānavataḥ dharma adharmau utpannau saṃsāram sampādayataḥ tat āha pravartakāt saṃsāra sampādakāt dharmāt prakṛṣṭāt su alpa adharma sahitāt iṣṭāni ca tāni śarīra indriya viṣaya sukha ādīni taiḥ kiṃviśiṣṭaiḥ āśaya anurūpaiḥ karma anurūpaiḥ yogaḥ sambandhaḥ bhavati iti keṣu sthāneṣu brahma indra prajāpati pitṛ ṛṣi manuṣya lo
translated: Now he shows whose action has arisen, which produces worldly existence, and how it ceases. For the ignorant one, who has false knowledge, Dharma and Adharma have arisen, which produce worldly existence. He says that from the predominant Dharma, which produces worldly existence, along with a little Adharma, there is a connection with the desired bodies, senses, objects, happiness, etc. What is their distinguishing feature? They are in accordance with the intention, in accordance with the action. In which places? In the worlds of Brahma, Indra, Prajapati, Pitris, Rishis, and human beings. Similarly, from the predominant Adharma, along with a little Dharma, there is a connection with the undesired bodies, senses, objects, suffering, etc. In which places? In the abodes of ghosts and animals. He concludes: Thus, from that characteristic of engagement, from Dharma along with Adharma, there is the continuity, the series, of worldly existence again and again in the gods, humans, animals, and hells.

original: pravartakāddharmāt saṃsārotpattimupadiśya nivartakāt tannivṛttimāha jñānapūrvakāttu kṛtāt iti / jñānaṃ pūrvaṃ yasya sa tathoktastasmāt / kiṃ rūpāt / asaṅkalpitaphalāt iti / itthaṃ me śarīrendriyaviṣayāḥ sampadyantām / netthamityevaṃ na saṅkalpitaṃ phalaṃ yasya sa tathoktastasmād / viśuddhe kule janma bhavati / tasya jātasya duḥkhavigamopāyajijñāsā sampadyate kutaḥ sādhanādatyantaṃ duḥkhasantaterviyogaḥ sampadyata iti / evaṃ jijñāsorācāryopasaṅgamaḥ sampadyate / tañcopasaṅgamya duḥkhasantānavyāvṛtterupāyaṃ vijānāti tattvajñānācchreyaḥ sampadyata iti / tataḥ śāstrābhyāsāt ṣaṭpadārthatattvajñānamutpadyate / tasya cotpannaṣaṭpadārthajñānasya ajñānanivṛttirbhavati / tannivṛttau virāgaḥ / kāraṇābhāvena kāryasyānutpatteḥ / viraktasya rāgadveṣābhāvāt tābhyāṃ jāyate yau dharmādharmau tau tajjau / tayoranutpattiriti / rāgadveṣayordharmādharmajanakatvenopalabdheḥ / tadabhāve tadabhāvo bhavatyeva / sañcitayośca nirodhastattvajñānādupabhogād vā / tato rāgādinivṛttau satyāṃ nivṛttilakṣaṇaḥ kevalo dharmaḥ santoṣasukhaṃ śarīraparicche /khedaṃ cotpādayati / taccotpādya paramārthaḥ sarvapadārthānāmātmā II / taddarśanājjātaṃ paramārthadarśanajaṃ sukhaṃ karoti / tata kṛtvā nivartate / tadā nirgataṃ dharmādharmasamākhyātaṃ bījaṃ yasyāsau tathoktastasyātmanaḥ śarīrādinivṛttiḥ / bījābhāvādeva punaḥ śarīrādyanutpattau satyāṃ dagdhendhanānalavadupaśamo mokṣaḥ iti / yathā dagdhendhanasyānalasyopaśamo jvālādirahitasyāvasthānam tadvadatyantaṃ viśeṣaguṇavimuktasyātmano 'vasthānaṃ mokṣa iti nirṇītamādivākye /
analyzed: pravartakāt dharmāt saṃsāra utpattim upadiśya nivartakāt tad nivṛttim āha jñāna pūrvakāt tu kṛtāt iti jñānam pūrvam yasya sa tathā uktaḥ tasmāt kim rūpāt a saṅkalpita phalāt iti ittham me śarīra indriya viṣayāḥ sampadyantām na ittham iti evam na saṅkalpitam phalam yasya sa tathā uktaḥ tasmāt viśuddhe kule janma bhavati tasya jātasya duḥkha vigama upāya jijñāsā sampadyate kutas sādhanāt atyantam duḥkha santateḥ viyogaḥ sampadyate iti evam jijñāso
translated: Having taught the origin of the world from the Dharma that is the cause of continuation, he now speaks of its cessation from the Dharma that is the cause of cessation, saying But from that which is done with knowledge as the basis. That which has knowledge as the basis is said to be so. What kind of [Dharma]? From that which has an unseen result. It is said to be so because it has a result that is not imagined in this way: May my body, senses, and objects be accomplished in this way, not in this way. From that, birth occurs in a pure family. For one who is born thus, the desire to know the means of removing suffering arises. How can one attain complete separation from the continuum of suffering? Thus, the desire to know leads to approaching a teacher. Having approached him, one learns the means of turning away from the continuum of suffering. From the knowledge of reality, one attains the highest good. Then, from the practice of the scriptures, the knowledge of the truth of the six categories arises. For one who has attained the knowledge of the six categories, the cessation of ignorance occurs. With its cessation, detachment arises. The cause of that is the knowledge of the truth of the six categories.

original: śabdo 'mbaraguṇaḥ / śrotragrāhyaḥ / kṣaṇikaḥ / kāryakāraṇobhayavirodhī / saṃyogavibhāgaśabdajaḥ / pradeśavṛttiḥ / samānāsamānajātīyakāraṇaḥ / dvividho varṇalakṣaṇo dhvanilakṣaṇaśca / tatra akārādirvarṇalakṣaṇaḥ / śaṅkhādinimitto dhvanilakṣaṇaśca / tatra varṇalakṣaṇasyotpattiḥ / ātmamanasoḥ saṃyogāt smṛtyapekṣād varṇoccāraṇecchā / tadanantaraṃ prayatnaḥ / tamapekṣamāṇādātmavāyusaṃyogād vāyau karma jāyate / sa cordhvaṃ gacchan kaṇṭhādīnabhihanti / tataḥ sthānavāyusaṃyogāpekṣāt sthānākāśasaṃyogād varṇotpattiḥ / avarṇalakṣaṇo 'pi bherīdaṇḍasaṃyogāpekṣād bheryākāśasaṃyogādutpadyate / veṇaparvavibhāgād veṇvākāśavibhāgācca śabdācca saṃyogavibhāganiṣpannād vecīsantānavacchabda santāna ityevaṃ santānena śrotrapradeśamāgatasya grahaṇam nāsti / / pariśeṣāt santānasiddhiriti /PDhS
analyzed: śabdaḥ mbara guṇaḥ śrotra grāhyaḥ kṣaṇikaḥ kārya kāraṇa ubhaya virodhī saṃyoga vibhāga śabda jaḥ pradeśa vṛttiḥ samāna asamāna jātīya kāraṇaḥ dvividhaḥ varṇa lakṣaṇaḥ dhvani lakṣaṇaḥ ca tatra akāra ādiḥ varṇa lakṣaṇaḥ śaṅkha ādi nimittaḥ dhvani lakṣaṇaḥ ca tatra varṇa lakṣaṇasya utpattiḥ ātma manasoḥ saṃyogāt smṛti apekṣāt varṇa uccāraṇa icchā tad anantaram prayatnaḥ tam apekṣamāṇāt ātma vāy
translated: Sound is a quality of space. It is perceptible by the ear. It is momentary. It is opposed to both cause and effect. It arises from the sound of conjunction and disjunction. It occurs in a limited space. It has causes of the same and different kinds. It is of two kinds: characterized by letters and characterized by sound. Among them, the letter a etc. is characterized by letters. The sound from a conch etc. is characterized by sound. Among them, the production of the letter-characterized sound is as follows: From the conjunction of the self and the mind, depending on memory, there is a desire to utter the letter. After that, there is effort. Depending on that, from the conjunction of the self and air, action arises in the air. And that, going upwards, strikes the throat etc. Then, depending on the conjunction of the place and air, from the conjunction of the place and space, the letter arises. The sound characterized by letters also arises from the conjunction of the drum and stick, depending on the conjunction of the drum and space. From the separation of the joints of the bamboo and the separation of the space in the bamboo, and from the sound produced by the conjunction and disjunction, there is a continuum of sound like a stream of water. Thus, the continuum

original: śabdasya lakṣaṇaparīkṣārthamāha śabdo 'mbaraguṇaḥ ityādi / ambaraguṇatvācchabda ityukte saṃkhyādibhirvyabhicārastadarthaṃ śrotragrāhya iti / śabdaḥ / itarasmād bhidyate / ambaraguṇatve sati śrotragrāhyatvāditi / kṣaṇika iti parīkṣārtham / pūrvapadāpekṣaṃ vā lakṣaṇam /
analyzed: śabdasya lakṣaṇa parīkṣā artham āha śabdaḥ mbara guṇaḥ ityādi ambara guṇa tvāt śabdaḥ iti ukte saṃkhyā ādibhiḥ vyabhicāraḥ tad artham śrotra grāhyaḥ iti śabdaḥ itarasmāt bhidyate ambara guṇa tve sati śrotra grāhya tvāt iti kṣaṇikaḥ iti parīkṣā artham pūrva pada apekṣam vā lakṣaṇam
translated: To examine the definition of sound, he says sound is a quality of space and so on. When it is said that sound is so because it is a quality of space, there is a fallacy due to number etc. For that purpose, it is said to be perceptible by the ear. Sound is distinguished from other things because it is a quality of space and is perceptible by the ear. To examine whether it is momentary, the definition depends on the previous word.

original: nanu cāsiddhaṃ śabde kṣaṇikatvam / pratyabhijñānāderupalambhāt / yamahamaśrauṣaṃ śabdam / tametarhi śṛṇomi iti śroturvijñānamutpadyamānamupalabdham / na cedamapramāṇam / anyatāgrāhakapramāṇānupalabdheḥ / tathā arthāpattyā ca śabdasya nityatvaṃ vijñāyate / anityatve hi saṅketakālānubhūtaśabdavilayottarakālaṃ śabdāntaropalambhādasaṅketitā tadarthapratipattirna syāt / sā copalabhyata iti tadanyathānupapattyā śabdasya nityatvaṃ jñāyate /
analyzed: nanu ca asiddham śabde kṣaṇika tvam pratyabhijñāna ādeḥ upalambhāt  yam aham aśrauṣam śabdam tam etarhi śṛṇomi iti śrotuḥ vijñānam utpadyamānam upalabdham na ca idam apramāṇam anyatā grāhaka pramāṇa anupalabdheḥ tathā arthāpattyā ca śabdasya nitya tvam vijñāyate anitya tve hi saṅketa kāla anubhūta śabda vilaya uttara kālam śabda antara upalambhāt asaṅketi tā tad artha pratipattiḥ na syāt sā ca upalabhyate iti tad anyathā anupapattyā śabdasya nitya
translated: But momentariness is not established for sound, because of recognition and so on. The cognition of the hearer arises as I heard that sound and now I hear it again, and is perceived. And this is not unestablished, because there is no perception of a valid cognition apprehending difference. Similarly, the eternality of sound is known through presumption. For if it were non-eternal, the understanding of its meaning through convention would not occur due to the perception of a different sound after the cessation of the sound experienced at the time of convention. But that is perceived. Therefore, the eternality of sound is known through the non-apprehension of its difference.

original: tadetadasat / gṛhītagrāhitvena pratyabhijñānasyāpramāṇatvāt / anadhigatārthagantṛ pramāṇam iti sāmānyalakṣaṇābhidhānāt / athānadhigatārthe pratyabhijñānam / tanna / adṛṣṭārthatāyā mithyātvaprasaṅgāt / atha svarūpeṇādhigatārthamapīdānīntanaṃ deśakālādyapekṣayānadhigatārthañceti /
analyzed: tat etat asat gṛhīta grāhi tvena pratyabhijñānasya apramāṇa tvāt anadhigata artha gantṛ pramāṇam iti sāmānya lakṣaṇa abhidhānāt  atha anadhigata arthe pratyabhijñānam tat na adṛṣṭa artha tāyāḥ mithyātva prasaṅgāt atha svarūpeṇa adhigata artham api idānīntanam deśa kāla ādi apekṣayā anadhigata artham ca iti
translated: This is not correct. Because recognition is not a valid means of knowledge, as it apprehends what has already been apprehended. A valid means of knowledge is defined as that which leads to the knowledge of an unknown object. If recognition is said to be a valid means of knowledge with regard to an unknown object, that is not so. Because if an unseen object were to be known, it would lead to falsity. If it is argued that an object is known in its own form but is unknown in relation to the present time, place, etc.,

original: nanvevamapyubhayadoṣopanipātaprasaṅgaḥ / prameyasāmagryāñca deśakālāderantarbhāvābhyupagame 'nadhigatārthatvam / etāvatā prameyasya pūrvamapratipatteḥ / na ca śrotravyāpāreṇa deśakālādergrahaṇaṃ dṛṣṭam / atha pramāṇasāmagryāmantarbhāvaḥ / tarhi pramāṇasyānyatve 'pi prameyasya tādavasthyādadhigatārthaviṣayatvameva / tadapekṣayā cedaṃ viśeṣaṇam / anyathā hi vyavacchedyābhāvādanupapannameva syāt / pramāṇasāmagryā niyatavijñānajanakatvāt / sarvatra prameyabhedādeva vijñānabheda ityabhyupagame pratijñānamanyatāyāṃ kṣaṇikatāprasaṅgaḥ / tasmādanadhigatārthagantṛ pramāṇamityevaṃvādino pramāṇameva pratyabhijñānam / tathā chinnodbhūtakeśanakhādiṣvanyatve 'pi sādṛśyavaśāt pratyabhijñānam / sāmānyādau cārthatathābhāvāditi dvaividhyopalabdherviśeṣānupalabdhau śabde pratyabhijñānam / na ca vyañjakānāṃ sandigdhatvādapramāṇatvam / svataḥ prāmāṇyasya pūrvameva pratiṣedhāt / anyataḥ pramāṇād abhedapratipattyabhyupagame ca tadevāstvalaṃ pratyabhijñānena / tathā vyañjakānāṃ kṣaṇikatayā śabdajñānānantarameva tirobhāve śabdasya / nirviṣayameva syāt pratyabhijñānam / na ca vyañjakānāṃ nityatvam / sarvadā śabdavyaktiprasaṅgāt /
analyzed: nanu evam api ubhaya doṣa upanipāta prasaṅgaḥ prameya sāmagryāḥ ca deśa kāla ādeḥ antarbhāva abhyupagame na adhigata artha tvam etāvatā prameyasya pūrvam apratipatteḥ na ca śrotra vyāpāreṇa deśa kāla ādeḥ grahaṇam dṛṣṭam atha pramāṇa sāmagryām antarbhāvaḥ tarhi pramāṇasya anya tve pi prameyasya tādavasthyāt adhigata artha viṣaya tvam eva tad apekṣayā ca idam viśeṣaṇam anyathā hi vyavacchedya abhāvāt anupapannam eva syāt pramāṇa sāmagry
translated: Even so, there is the contingence of the fault of both [possibilities]. And if space, time, etc. are accepted as included in the totality of the object of knowledge, [the definition] would refer to [a cognition] of a not-yet-known object, because up to this point the object of knowledge has not been apprehended before [by that cognition]. And the apprehension of space, time, etc. is not seen to be by the operation of the ear. If [the definition] is included in the totality of the means of knowledge, then even if the means of knowledge is different, the object of knowledge remains the same, so [the cognition] would have only a known object as its content. And this qualification is in relation to that [known object]. Otherwise, it would be impossible, since there would be nothing to be excluded.
