Because the totality of the means of knowledge produces a cognition that is determined [by the object]. If it is accepted that the difference in cognition is due only to the difference in the object of knowledge everywhere, then in the case of the difference in the definition, momentariness would follow. Therefore, for those who say that a means of knowledge is that which leads to a not-yet-known object, recognition itself is a means of knowledge. original: karṇaśaṣkulyabhyupagame 'pi kvacicchabdasyābhivyaktau tasya vyāpakatayā sarvadeśāvasthitapuruṣāṇāmupalambhaḥ syāt / nirāvaraṇasya vyāpakatvāviśeṣāt / tathaikadeśāstasyābhivyajyante teṣāmabhede śabdasyaivābhivyaktiriti tadeva dūṣaṇam / bhede tu tadabhivyaktau kathaṃ śabdo 'rthamabhidadhyāt / yadi ca śabdaviśeṣaṇaśca śabdābhāvaḥ paricchidyate / viśeṣaṇaviśeṣyabhāvalakṣaṇenaiva sambandhenetyuktaṃ pūrvam /
analyzed: karṇaśaṣkulī abhyupagame pi kvacid śabdasya abhivyaktau tasya vyāpaka tayā sarva deśa avasthita puruṣāṇām upalambhaḥ syāt nirāvaraṇasya vyāpaka tva aviśeṣāt tathā eka deśāḥ tasya abhivyajyante teṣām abhede śabdasya eva abhivyaktiḥ iti tat eva dūṣaṇam bhede tu tad abhivyaktau katham śabdaḥ rtham abhidadhyāt yadi ca śabda viśeṣaṇaḥ ca śabda abhāvaḥ paricchidyate viśeṣaṇa viśeṣya bhāva lakṣaṇena eva sambandhena iti uktam pūrvam
translated: Even if the auditory organ is accepted, when sound is manifested in some places, it would be perceived by all persons situated in all places, because there is no difference in the pervasiveness of what is unobstructed. Similarly, if some parts of it are manifested, then it is the manifestation of sound itself, not of the parts, which are not different from it. This is the same fault. But if the manifestation is of the parts, then how could sound denote the meaning? And if the absence of sound is determined as a qualifier of sound, it has already been said that the relation is only by the relation of qualifier and qualified.

original: atha śabdasyopalambhānantaramu /manupalabdhirvyañjakābhāvād nāsattvāditi cet / na / sadbhāve pramāṇābhāvād āvaraṇāderanupalambhācca / nahi aindriyakasyātīndriyamāvaraṇaṃ pramāṇena kvacidupalabdham / abhyupagame 'pi kvacicchabdasyābhivyaktau tasya vyāpakatayā sarvadeśāvasthitapuruṣāṇāmupalambhaḥ syāt / nirāvaraṇasya vyāpakatvāviśeṣāt / yadi ca śabdātmakāniyatārthapratipādakāścaikadeśāḥ / saṃjñābhedamātrameva /
analyzed: atha śabdasya upalambha anantaram um anupalabdhiḥ vyañjaka abhāvāt na asattvāt iti ced na sadbhāve pramāṇa abhāvāt āvaraṇa ādeḥ anupalambhāt ca  nahi aindriyakasya atīndriyam āvaraṇam pramāṇena kvacid upalabdham abhyupagame pi kvacid śabdasya abhivyaktau tasya vyāpaka tayā sarva deśa avasthita puruṣāṇām upalambhaḥ syāt nirāvaraṇasya vyāpaka tva aviśeṣāt yadi ca śabda ātmaka aniyata artha pratipādakāḥ ca eka deśāḥ saṃjñā bheda mātram eva anyatra
translated: If it is argued that the non-apprehension of sound is due to the absence of manifestors, not to non-existence, that is not so. Because there is no evidence of existence, and because of the non-apprehension of obstruction etc. Nowhere has an imperceptible obstruction of a perceptible object been apprehended by any means of knowledge. Even if it is accepted, when there is manifestation of sound somewhere, it would be apprehended by all persons situated in all places, because of the absence of any distinction in the pervasiveness of the unobstructed. And if certain parts of sound are not determined to convey specific meanings, then there would be only a difference in names.

original: atha bherīdaṇḍasaṃyogād vegāpekṣādutpannakriyo vāyurvegavāṃśchrotradeśenāgatyābhisambadhyate / tadgatāni tu stimitavāyvantarāṇi protsārayati / tataḥ pratibandhakābhāve sati śrotraṃ śabdasya grāhakamiti / nanvevamapi aśeṣaśabdopalambhaprasaṅgaḥ / saṃskṛte hi śrotre sarveṣāṃ sānnidhyam / na ca gośabdābhivyaktyarthaṃ prerito vāyurnāśvaśabdaṃ vyanaktīti vācyam / vyañjakeṣu niyamānupalabdheḥ / yathā ghaṭābhivyaktyarthamutpāditaḥ pradīpaḥ samānendriyagrāhyasamānadeśāvasthitapadārthābhivyañjaka iti / tathāhi na śrotraṃ pratiniyatasaṃskārakasaṃskāryam / samānendriyagrāhyasamānadeśāvasthitavastuprakāśakatvāt / cakṣurvat / pradīpāvaṣṭabdhadeśavyatirekatājñānaṃ pradīpasaṃskṛtaṃ na cakṣuṣā grahaṇamiti samānadeśāvasthitapadam / evaṃvidhāśca rūparasādayo na gṛhyanta iti samānendriyagrāhyagrahaṇam / śabdā vā vivādaviṣayāḥ pratiniyatavyañjakavyaṅgyā na bhavanti / samānendriyagrāhyasamānadeśāvasthitatvāt / ghaṭādivat / atra ca ye pratiniyatasaṃskārakasaṃskāryā na bhavanti cakṣurghaṭādayaste sapakṣāstatra hetoḥ sadbhāvaḥ / tadviparītāstu vipakṣāstasmādatyantaṃ vyāvṛttiriti / pradīpena ca saṃskṛtaṃ cakṣuryugapad ghaṭādiprakāśakamiti dṛṣṭam / evaṃ śrotramapyaśeṣaśabdopalambhakaṃ syāt / atra cāpekṣābuddhivadanekapadārthālambanamevaikaṃ jñānamāśubhāvena vā yugapacchabdaprayoga iti / nanvekasyāmapi pṛthivyāṃ śuklādibhedānāṃ saṃskṛtenāpi cakṣuṣā na yugapat prakāśanam / evaṃ ghrāṇādinā gandhāderiti / evamapi na hetorvyabhicāraḥ / sapakṣaikadeśavṛtterapi gamakatvāt /
analyzed: atha bherī daṇḍa saṃyogāt vega apekṣāt utpanna kriyaḥ vāyuḥ vegavān śrotra deśena āgatya abhisambadhyate tad gatāni tu stimita vāyu antarāṇi protsārayati tatas pratibandhaka abhāve sati śrotram śabdasya grāhakam iti  nanu evam api aśeṣa śabda upalambha prasaṅgaḥ saṃskṛte hi śrotre sarveṣām sānnidhyam na ca go śabda abhivyakti artham preritaḥ vāyuḥ na aśva śabdam vyanakti iti vācyam vyañjakeṣu niyama anupalabdheḥ  /
translated: Now, the air, whose action has arisen from the conjunction of the drum and stick, being swift, comes to the place of the ear and comes into contact with it. But it displaces the still air particles within it. Then, in the absence of obstruction, the ear is the apprehender of sound. But even so, there is the contingence of the apprehension of all sounds, for when the ear is modified, all [sounds] are present. And it cannot be said that the air impelled for the manifestation of the word 'cow' does not manifest the word 'horse', because no restriction is found in the manifesters. Just as a lamp produced for the manifestation of a pot manifests objects of the same sense-organ and the same location. Thus, the ear is not modified by a modification restricted to itself, because it manifests objects of the same sense-organ and the same location, like the eye. The knowledge of the difference from the place occupied by the lamp is produced by the lamp-modified eye, but not by the eye alone.

original: atha yathā cakṣuḥ samānendriyagrāhyasamānadeśāvasthitānāmapi śuklādibhedānāṃ na yugapat prakāśakamevaṃ śrotramapi syāt / iṣṭañca pṛthivyāmanekarūpādhikaraṇatvamapi citrarūpasamarthanāvasare / satyametat / tathāpi rūpabhedānāmagrahaṇaṃ sahakāryabhāvāt / tathā ca nānārūpāvayavopalambhasahakārīndriyamavayavinyanekarūpagrāhakamityuktam / tatsadbhāve vicitrapratibhāsanāt / na caivaṃ śrotrasya vāyunā saṃskṛtasya sarvaśabdānāṃ tatra sānnidhyādagrahaṇe kāraṇamastīti / sāmānyāni tu pratiniyatavyañjakavyaṅgyāni / na tu samānadeśāni svaviṣayasarvagatatvādeveti vyabhicārābhāvaḥ / tathā ātapasamparkāttaiile gandhābhivyaktiḥ / II / grīṣmāvasāne tu dagdhasthalīṣu prathamajaladharadhārāsamparkāt / na ca samānadeśatvam / yad vā jaladharadhārāsamparkād bhūgatānilodbhave satyavayavakriyākrameṇa pūrvadravyanivṛttāvutpannapākairdvyaṇukādiprakrameṇa dravyāntarotpāde sati gandho 'bhivyajyata iti / yaccābhivyajyate sāmānyarūpādi / tad āśrayasthameveti dṛṣṭam / evaṃ śabde 'pi syāt / tattu nāstīti vyaktidharmakatvābhāvaḥ /
analyzed: atha yathā cakṣuḥ samāna indriya grāhya samāna deśa avasthitānām api śukla ādi bhedānām na yugapad prakāśakam evam śrotram api syāt iṣṭam ca pṛthivyām aneka rūpa adhikaraṇa tvam api citra rūpa samarthana avasare satyam etat tathā api rūpa bhedānām agrahaṇam sahakāri abhāvāt tathā ca nānā rūpa avayava upalambha sahakāri indriyam avayavini aneka rūpa grāhakam iti uktam tad sadbhāve vicitra pratibhāsanāt na ca evam śrotrasya vāyunā saṃskṛtasya sarva śab
translated: Now, just as the eye does not simultaneously illuminate the different colors like white, etc., which are grasped by the same sense faculty and located in the same place, in the same way the ear would also be. And it is accepted that even in the case of establishing variegated colors, there can be multiple substrata in the earth. This is true. Nevertheless, the non-apprehension of color differences is due to the absence of cooperating factors. And it has been said that the sense faculty, which is the cooperating factor in the perception of the various colored parts, is the apprehender of the variegated color in the whole, when it exists, because of the variegated appearance. And in this way, for the ear, which is modified by air, there is no cause for non-apprehension of all sounds due to their presence there. But universals are manifested by specific manifesters, and they are not located in the same place, because they are omnipresent in their own objects, so there is no counterexample. Similarly, the manifestation of smell in heated iron is due to contact with heat. But at the end of summer, it is due to contact with the first stream of rain on burnt ground. And it is not the case that the smell is destroyed by heat, because it is not perceived even when the heat subsides.

original: tathā vīṇāśabdābhivyañjakena rāsabhaśabdasyāpyabhivyaktatvād grahaṇe vīṇāśabdasya sarvadānupalambha eva syāt / na caitadasti / kvacideva rāsabhaśabdena vīṇāśabdādiśabdānāmabhibhavopalabdheḥ / na cāyaṃ nityapakṣe abhibhāvyābhibhāvakabhāvo ghaṭate / tīvratarādibhedāsambhavāt / tīvrasya ca dhvanergrahaṇānmandasyāgrahaṇamabhibhavaḥ / na ca tīvreṇa vyañjakenaikasya grahaṇādanyasyāgrahaṇamupapadyate / vyañjakeṣu niyamānupalabdherityuktam / śabdapratyayasamānādhikaraṇaścāyaṃ tīvraḥ śabdo mandaḥ śabda iti pratyayaḥ / na vyañjakapratyayeneti kathaṃ tīvratarādirvyañjakadharmaḥ / tadevaṃ tīvrādibhedabhinnatvāt sukhādivadanityatvaṃ śabdānām / vyañjakānupalabdhau cābhūtvā bhavanasyopalabdheḥ kāryatvādanityatvaṃ ghaṭādivat / tathā paramātmaguṇānyatve sati vyāpakaviśeṣaguṇatvāt sukhādivat / taccoktamākāśādhikāre / anityaviśeṣaguṇamākāśam / salilādiparamāṇuvyatireke sati bhūtatvāt kṣityādivat / pārimāṇḍalyādhāraparatvānumeyaparamātmānyatve sati samavāyikāraṇatvāt kṣityādivadeva /
analyzed: tathā vīṇā śabda abhivyañjakena rāsabha śabdasya api abhivyakta tvāt grahaṇe vīṇā śabdasya sarvadā anupalambhaḥ eva syāt  / na ca etat asti kvacid eva rāsabha śabdena vīṇā śabda ādi śabdānām abhibhava upalabdheḥ  na ca ayam nitya pakṣe abhibhāvya abhibhāvaka bhāvaḥ ghaṭate tīvratara ādi bheda asambhavāt tīvrasya ca dhvaneḥ grahaṇāt mandasya agrahaṇam abhibhavaḥ na ca tīvreṇa vyañjakena ekasya grahaṇāt anyasya agrahaṇam upapadyate vyañjakeṣ
translated: Similarly, since the sound of the donkey would also be manifested by what manifests the sound of the lute, the sound of the lute would never be perceived when the sound of the donkey is heard. And this is not so. Because the sound of the lute, etc. is sometimes perceived to be overwhelmed by the sound of the donkey. And this relation of the overwhelmed and the overwhelm is not possible in the case of eternal entities, because the difference of being more intense, etc. is not possible. And the non-perception of the faint sound is the overwhelming of the sound, when the more intense sound is perceived. And the non-perception of one sound due to the perception of another by a more intense manifestor is not possible. Because no restriction is perceived in the manifestors, as has been said. And this notion of the sound being intense or faint is based on the same cognition as the notion of the sound itself. It is not based on the notion of the manifestor. So how can the property of the manifestor, such as being more intense, etc., be inferred from the perception of one sound and the non-perception of another? Thus, because of the difference of being more intense, etc., like pleasure, etc., sound is non-eternal. And because of the perception of coming into existence after non-existence when the manifestor is not perceived, sound is a product, because of the relation of invariable concomitance with that.

original: atha guṇatve śabdasyānumānam / na dravyakarmajātīyaḥ śabdaḥ / śrotragrahaṇayogyatvāt / śabdatvādivat / guṇaḥ / śabdaḥ / dravyakarmānyatve sati sattāsambandhitvāt / rūpādivat / yaccedam arthapratipattyanyathānupapattyā śabdānāṃ nityatvaṃ vijñāyata ityuktam / tadasat / anityatve 'pi sādṛśyopādāne satyarthapratipatterbhāvāt / yatra yatra gakāraukāravisarjanīyānāmitthambhūtānupūrvīmupalabhase / tatra tatra gotvaviśiṣṭo 'rthaḥ pratipattavyaḥ / pratipādayitavyaśceti saṅketagrahe sati tathāvidhaṃ śabdamupalabhamānastamarthaṃ pratipadyate pratipādayati ceti /
analyzed: atha guṇa tve śabdasya anumānam na dravya karma jātīyaḥ śabdaḥ śrotra grahaṇa yogya tvāt śabda tva ādi vat  guṇaḥ śabdaḥ dravya karma anya tve sati sattā sambandhi tvāt rūpa ādi vat yat ca idam artha pratipatti anyathā anupapattyā śabdānām nitya tvam vijñāyate iti uktam tat asat anitya tve pi sādṛśya upādāne sati artha pratipatteḥ bhāvāt yatra yatra gakāra aukāra visarjanīyānām itthambhūta ānupūrvīm upalabhase tatra tatra go tva viśiṣṭaḥ rthaḥ
translated: Now, if sound is a quality, there is an inference: Sound is not of the same kind as substance or action, because it is fit to be grasped by the ear, like soundness and so on. Sound is a quality, because it is related to existence, while being different from substance and action, like color and so on. And what has been said that the eternality of sounds is known by the impossibility of the cognition of meaning in any other way, that is wrong. Because even if they are non-eternal, when similarity is adopted, the cognition of meaning occurs. Wherever you perceive such a sequence of the letters ga, ō, and sa, there the meaning qualified by the word go should be understood and communicated. When the convention is grasped in this way, perceiving such a sound, one understands that meaning and communicates it.

original: tadevamanityatve vyavasthite vināśakāraṇamāha kāryakāraṇobhayavirodhīti / ādyaḥ śabdaḥ kāryeṇa virudhyate / antyastu kāraṇaṃ viruṇaddhi / madhyagatāstu kāryeṇa virudhyante / kāraṇañca virudhantīti /
analyzed: tat evam anitya tve vyavasthite vināśa kāraṇam āha kārya kāraṇa ubhaya virodhi iti ādyaḥ śabdaḥ kāryeṇa virudhyate antyaḥ tu kāraṇam viruṇaddhi madhya gatāḥ tu kāryeṇa virudhyante kāraṇam ca virudhanti iti
translated: Thus, when impermanence is established in this way, he states the cause of destruction: that which is opposed to both effect and cause. The first word is opposed to the effect. But the last contradicts the cause. And those in the middle are opposed to the effect and also contradict the cause.

original: saṃyogavibhāgaśabdaja ityutpattikāraṇam / saṃyogād vibhāgācchabdācca śabdaniṣpattiḥ iti vai / sū / /
analyzed: saṃyoga vibhāga śabda jaḥ iti utpatti kāraṇam saṃyogāt vibhāgāt śabdāt ca śabda niṣpattiḥ iti vai
translated: Sound born from conjunction, disjunction, and sound is the cause of origination. Sound is produced from conjunction, disjunction, and sound, according to the Vaiśeṣika.

original: sa dvividhaḥ / kena rūpeṇa / varṇalakṣaṇo 'varṇalakṣaṇaśceti / akārādihakāraparyanto varṇalakṣaṇaḥ / śaṅkhādinimittaṃ yasyāsau tannimitto 'varṇalakṣaṇa iti / ādipadenānyeṣāmapi nimittakāraṇānāmavarodhaḥ /
analyzed: sa dvividhaḥ kena rūpeṇa varṇa lakṣaṇaḥ varṇa lakṣaṇaḥ ca iti akāra ādi hakāra paryantaḥ varṇa lakṣaṇaḥ śaṅkha ādi nimittam yasya asau tad nimittaḥ varṇa lakṣaṇaḥ iti ādi padena anyeṣām api nimitta kāraṇānām avarodhaḥ
translated: It is of two kinds. In what form? As characterized by letters and as not characterized by letters. That which has the letter a up to the letter ha is characterized by letters. That which has the conch, etc., as its cause is characterized by the cause of that, not by letters. The word etc. includes other instrumental causes.

original: tatra varṇalakṣaṇasyotpattirabhidhīyate / ātmamanasoḥ saṃyogādasamavāyikāraṇāt smṛtyapekṣādvarṇoccāraṇecchā bhavati / tadanantaraṃ prayatnaḥ / tamapekṣamāṇād ātmavāyusaṃyogādasamavāyikāraṇād vāyau samavāyikāraṇe karma / sa cotpannakarmā vāyurūrdhvaṃ gacchan kaṇṭhādīnabhihantīti / ādipadena tālvoṣṭhādergrahaṇam / tataḥ sthānavāyusaṃyogāpekṣāt sthānākāśasaṃyogādvarṇotpattiriti / ākāśaṃ samavāyikāraṇaṃ sthānākāśasaṃyogo 'samavāyikāraṇaṃ sthānavāyusaṃyogaścāpekṣākāraṇamiti /
analyzed: tatra varṇa lakṣaṇasya utpattiḥ abhidhīyate ātma manasoḥ saṃyogāt asamavāyi kāraṇāt smṛti apekṣāt varṇa uccāraṇa icchā bhavati tad anantaram prayatnaḥ tam apekṣamāṇāt ātma vāyu saṃyogāt asamavāyi kāraṇāt vāyau samavāyi kāraṇe karma sa ca utpanna karmā vāyuḥ ūrdhvam gacchan kaṇṭha ādīn abhihanti iti ādi padena tālu oṣṭha ādeḥ grahaṇam tatas sthāna vāyu saṃyoga apekṣāt sthāna ākāśa saṃyogāt varṇa utpattiḥ iti ākā
translated: There, the production of the characteristics of letters is being described. From the conjunction of the self and mind, which is the non-inherent cause, there arises the desire to utter a letter, dependent on memory. After that, there is effort. Dependent on that, from the conjunction of the self and air, which is the non-inherent cause, there is action in the air, which is the inherent cause. And that air, which has action produced in it, going upwards, strikes the throat and so on. The word and so on includes the palate, lips, and so on. Then, from the conjunction of the place and air, dependent on the conjunction of the place and space, the letter arises. Space is the inherent cause, the conjunction of the place and space is the non-inherent cause, and the conjunction of the place and air is the dependent cause.

original: avarṇalakṣaṇo 'pi bheryākāśasaṃyogādutpadyate / bherīdaṇḍasaṃyogāyapekṣād ityādipadena dikkālādergrahaṇam / atrāpyākāśaṃ samavāyikāraṇam / bheryākāśasaṃyogo 'samavāyikāraṇaṃ bherīdaṇḍasaṃyogādirnimittakāraṇamiti / tathā veṇuparvavibhāgāpekṣāt parvākāśavibhāgādasamavāyikāraṇādākāṣe śabdo niṣpadyata iti /
analyzed: avarṇa lakṣaṇaḥ pi bherī ākāśa saṃyogāt utpadyate iti ādi padena diś kāla ādeḥ grahaṇam atra api ākāśam samavāyi kāraṇam bherī ākāśa saṃyogaḥ samavāyi kāraṇam bherī daṇḍa saṃyoga ādiḥ nimitta kāraṇam iti tathā veṇu parva vibhāga apekṣāt parva ākāśa vibhāgāt asamavāyi kāraṇāt ākāṣe śabdaḥ niṣpadyate iti
translated: The characteristic of sound is also produced from the conjunction of the drum and space, depending on the conjunction of the drum and stick. The word etc. includes direction, time, etc. Here also, space is the inherent cause. The conjunction of the drum and space is the non-inherent cause. The conjunction of the drum and stick, etc. is the instrumental cause. Similarly, sound is produced in space from the non-inherent cause of the separation of the space in the joint, depending on the separation of the bamboo joint.

original: śabdajaṃ śabdamupadarśayati / evaṃ saṃyogād vibhāgācca pariniṣpannaḥ śabdaḥ samantāt śabdāntarāṇyārabhate / tasmādapyasamavāyikāraṇāt svakāraṇapratyāsattyapekṣādākāśe 'nyaḥ śabda iti vīcīsantānavacchabdasantānaḥ / yathā hi mahataḥ pāṣāṇādyabhighātādupajātā vīcī vīcyantaramārabhate / sāpi punarvīcyantaramiti santānāstadvacchabdasantāna ityevaṃ santānanyāyena śrotradeśamāgatasya grahaṇam /
analyzed: śabda jam śabdam upadarśayati evam saṃyogāt vibhāgāt ca pariniṣpannaḥ śabdaḥ samantāt śabda antarāṇi ārabhate  tasmāt api asamavāyi kāraṇāt sva kāraṇa pratyāsatti apekṣāt ākāśe nyaḥ śabdaḥ iti vīcī santāna vat śabda santānaḥ yathā hi mahataḥ pāṣāṇa ādi abhighātāt upajātā vīcī vīci antaram ārabhate sā api punar vīci antaram iti santānāḥ tadvat śabda santānaḥ iti evam santāna nyāyena śrotra deśam āgatasya grahaṇam
translated: He illustrates sound produced from sound. Thus, sound that is fully produced from conjunction and disjunction produces other sounds all around. From that non-inherent cause, depending on the proximity of its own cause, another sound is produced in space. Thus, the continuum of sound is like a series of waves. Just as a wave produced by striking a large stone, etc. produces another wave, and that wave also produces another wave, so is the continuum of sound. Thus, sound is perceived when it reaches the ear through this continuum principle.

original: etacca kalpyate / anyathā karṇaśaṣkulyākāśasaṃyogopalakṣitanabhaḥpradeśavyatirekeṇa pradeśāntarasamavāyātteṣāmavyāpyavṛttitvena viśiṣṭapratyāsatterabhāvādagrahaṇameva syāt / tadāha śrotraśabdayorgamanāsambhavāt santānānabhyupagame na parasparaṃ prāptiḥ / prāptasya copalambha iti santānaḥ kalpyate /
analyzed: etat ca kalpyate anyathā karṇa śaṣkulī ākāśa saṃyoga upalakṣita nabhaḥ pradeśa vyatirekeṇa pradeśa antara samavāyāt teṣām avyāpya vṛtti tvena viśiṣṭa pratyāsatteḥ abhāvāt agrahaṇam eva syāt tat āha śrotra śabdayoḥ gamana asambhavāt santāna anabhyupagame na parasparam prāptiḥ prāptasya ca upalambhaḥ iti santānaḥ kalpyate
translated: And this is imagined. Otherwise, except for the space delimited by the conjunction of the space in the cavity of the ear, due to inherence in another region, their non-pervasiveness and non-existence of a specific proximity, there would be no apprehension at all. He says this: Due to the impossibility of movement of the ear and sound, in the absence of the acceptance of a continuum, there is no mutual contact. And the apprehension of what has been contacted, thus a continuum is imagined.

original: nanvetasmin pakṣe śabdāḥ svāvaruddhanabhodeśa eva yadi śabdāntaramārabheran / na kasyāpyupalambhaḥ syāt / sarveṣāmekatraivopakṣayāt / atha pradeśāntare / tarhi brahmabhāṣitasyāpyupalambho 'smadādiśrotradeśe śabdāntarārambhāt /
analyzed: nanu etasmin pakṣe śabdāḥ sva avaruddha nabhaḥ deśe eva yadi śabda antaram ārabheran na kasya api upalambhaḥ syāt sarveṣām ekatra eva upakṣayāt atha pradeśa antare tarhi brahma bhāṣitasya api upalambhaḥ smat ādi śrotra deśe śabda antara ārambhāt
translated: In this view, if sounds were to produce another sound only in the space of the sky occupied by themselves, there would be no apprehension of any, because all would be destroyed in one place. But if in another region, then there would be apprehension of what is spoken by Brahmā in the region of our ears, due to the production of another sound there.

original: athāṇuvivaramātre svadeśānantaramārabhate / tarhi teṣāṃ kṣaṇaśatādivyavadhānena grahaṇaṃ syāt / tattu na dṛṣṭaṃ kṣaṇadvayādivyavadhānena śravaṇāt / yā ādyaḥ śabdaḥ śabdāntaraṃ nārabhate / śabdatvādantyaśabdavat / antyaśabdo vā śabdāntaramārabhate śabdatvādādyaśabdavat / ataḥ santānapratiṣedhe śabdopalambhānyathānupapattyā vāyorvyañjakasyāgamanaṃ kalpyata iti manyante /
analyzed: atha aṇu vivara mātre sva deśa anantaram ārabhate tarhi teṣām kṣaṇa śata ādi vyavadhānena grahaṇam syāt tat tu na dṛṣṭam kṣaṇa dvaya ādi vyavadhānena śravaṇāt ādyaḥ śabdaḥ śabda antaram na ārabhate śabda tvāt antya śabda vat  antya śabdaḥ vā śabda antaram ārabhate śabda tvāt ādya śabda vat  / atas santāna pratiṣedhe śabda upalambha anyathā anupapattyā vāyoḥ vyañjakasya āgamanam kalpyate iti manyante
translated: If it begins in its own place immediately after the smallest space, then their perception would be through a hundred moments etc. of interval, but that is not seen, because hearing is through two moments etc. of interval. The first sound does not produce another sound, because it is sound, like the last sound. Or the last sound produces another sound, because it is sound, like the first sound. Therefore, in the negation of the continuum, they think that the arrival of the manifesting air is imagined due to the impossibility of the perception of sound.

original: na caitadyuktam / vyaktipakṣasya pūrvameva pratiṣedhādvāyorāgamane pramāṇābhāvācca / na ca śabdopalabdhireva pramāṇam / santānanyāyenāpi tadupapatteḥ / yaccātra dūṣaṇamupanyastaṃ tadvīcīnidarśanopanyāsānnirastam / yathā hi mahataḥ pāṣāṇābhighātādupajātā vīcī svadeśānantaradeśa eva vīcyantaramārabhate / na taṭādāvevaṃ śabdo 'pi svakāraṇapratyāsattimapekṣyānantaradeśa eva śabdāntaramārabhata iti / na ca kṣaṇaśatādivyavadhānena grahaṇaprasaṅgaḥ / ṣaṇṇāmeva śabdānāṃ tīvrādibhedānāmutpatteḥ / tathāhi bherīdaṇḍābhighātādupajāte śabde sannihitasya tīvratamaḥ śabda iti jñānam / tadanantaraṃ vyavahitasya ca tīvataraḥ śabda iti jñānam / tatastīvro mando mandataro mandatamaśceti ṣaḍbhedāḥ krameṇānubhūyanta iti na ānantyapakṣokto doṣaḥ / tathāhi bherīdaṇḍābhighātādeka eva śabdaḥ kalpitaṃ bhūyāṃsaṃ pradeśaṃ vyāpyopajāyata ityanekairapyupalabhyata eveti na sarvatra santānaḥ / yaccedamuktam nādyaḥ śabdaḥ śabdāntaramārabhate śabdatvādantyaśabdavad iti / tanna svatantrasādhanam / svayamādyantaśabdāprasiddheḥ / na ca dṛṣṭāntadārṣṭāntikadharmiṇoraprasiddhau hetoḥ pakṣadharmatvaṃ bahirvyāptirvā sambhavatīti / atha paravyāptyā parasyāniṣṭāpādanametat / tanna / yadi pramāṇapūrvikā paravyāptistayaiva bādhyamānatvād viparītānumānasyānutthānam / athāpramāṇapūrvikā / tarhi prameyāprasiddherāśrayāsiddhaṃ sādhanam / dharmyasiddhaśca dṛṣṭānta iti / śabdasya śabdāntarārambhapratiṣedhe svayamādyantaviśeṣaṇāprasiddheḥ / tasmād vyaktipakṣapratiṣedhe śabdopalambhānyathānupapattyā santānakalpanā II / kriyata iti / na cāntyaśabdasyārambhakatvaparikalpanāyāṃ pramāṇamasti / sarvadopalambhaprasaṅagāt / ato 'ntyaśabdasya sparśavaddravyasaṃyogaikārthasamavāyena pralayaḥ svajñānādupabhogaprāpakādṛṣṭāpakṣayād veti vināśasya pramāṇenopalabdheḥ / tasya ca nirhetukatvapratiṣedhāduktakāraṇādeva vināśaḥ kalpyata ityalam /
analyzed: na ca etat yuktam vyakti pakṣasya pūrvam eva pratiṣedhāt vāyoḥ āgamane pramāṇa abhāvāt ca  / na ca śabda upalabdhiḥ eva pramāṇam santāna nyāyena api tad upapatteḥ yat ca atra dūṣaṇam upanyastam tat vīcī nidarśana upanyāsāt nirastam  yathā hi mahataḥ pāṣāṇa abhighātāt upajātā vīcī sva deśa anantara deśe eva vīci antaram ārabhate na taṭa ādau evam śabdaḥ api sva kāraṇa pratyāsattim apekṣya anantara deśe eva śabda antaram ārabhate iti  /
translated: And this is not proper. Because the theory of individual sounds has already been refuted earlier, and because there is no evidence for the arrival of air. And the perception of sound itself is not evidence, because it can be explained by the principle of continuity. And the refutation presented here is refuted by the example of waves. Just as a wave produced by the impact of a large rock produces another wave in the immediately adjacent region, not on the shore or elsewhere, so sound also, depending on the proximity of its cause, produces another sound in the immediately adjacent region. And there is no possibility of perception after a hundred moments etc., because only six sounds of different intensities are produced. Thus, when a sound is produced by the striking of a hammer on an anvil, there is first the knowledge of the sound as extremely loud, then the knowledge of the sound as louder in the immediately adjacent region, then the knowledge of the sound as louder still in the next adjacent region, and so on. In this way, the six distinctions of loud, medium, soft, softer, softest, and very soft are experienced in sequence.

original: iti śrīvyomaśivācāryaviracitāyāṃ padārthadharmasaṅgrahaṭīkāyāṃ vyomavatyāṃ guṇapadārthaḥ
analyzed: iti śrī vyomaśivācārya viracitāyām padārtha dharmasaṅgraha ṭīkāyām vyomavatyām guṇa padārthaḥ
translated: Thus ends the chapter on the quality substance in the commentary called Vyomavati on the Padarthadharmasangraha composed by the illustrious teacher Vyomaśiva.

original: karmasādharmyanirūpaṇam
translated: The determination of the similarity of action

original: utkṣepaṇādīnāṃ pañcānāmapi karmatvasambandhaḥ / ekadravyavattvaṃ kṣaṇikatvaṃ mūrtadravyavṛtitvam aguṇavattvaṃ gurutvadravatvaprayatnasaṃyogajatvaṃ svakāryasaṃyogavirodhitvaṃ saṃyogavibhāganirapekṣakāraṇatvam asamavāyikāraṇatvam svaparāśrayasamavetakāryārambhakatvaṃ samānajātīyānārambhakatvaṃ dravyānārambhakatvañca pratiniyatajātiyogitvam / digviśiṣṭakāryārambhakatvañca viśeṣaḥ /PDhS
analyzed: utkṣepaṇa ādīnām pañcānām api karmatva sambandhaḥ eka dravyavat tvam kṣaṇika tvam mūrta dravya vṛti tvam aguṇavat tvam guru tva drava tva prayatna saṃyoga ja tvam sva kārya saṃyoga virodhi tvam saṃyoga vibhāga nirapekṣa kāraṇa tvam asamavāyi kāraṇa tvam sva para āśraya samaveta kārya ārambhaka tvam samāna jātīya anārambhaka tvam dravya anārambhaka tvam ca pratiniyata jāti yogi tvam diś viśiṣṭa kārya ārambhaka tvam ca viśeṣaḥ pdhs
translated: All five, including upward motion, are related to action. Having one substance, being momentary, inhering in a corporeal substance, being devoid of qualities, being produced from gravity, fluidity, and effort, being opposed to the conjunction of its own effect, being the cause independent of conjunction and disjunction, being the non-inherent cause, producing an effect inhering in its own and other substrates, not producing similar kinds, and not producing substances - these are the specific properties.

original: idānīmitarapadārthavaidharmyeṇa svabhedavyāpakamutkṣepaṇādīnāṃ sādharmyaṃ tathā parasparavyāvṛttaṃ vaidharmyaṃ kāraṇañca nirūpayannāha utkṣepaṇādīnām iti / na paraṃ dvayostrayāṇāñca / kiṃ tarhi / pañcānāmapi karmatvasambandhaḥ / karmatvopalakṣitaḥ samavāyaḥ / tathā cotkṣepaṇādīni / itarasmād bhiyante / karmāṇīti vā vyavahartavyāni / karmatvābhisambandhāditi / ekadravyavattvamiti / ekañca tad dravyañcetyekadravyam / tadasyāstīti ekadravyavat / tasya bhāva ekadravyavattvam / ekaṃ karmaikasminneva dravye vartate / tathaikamevaikasminniti / kuta etata / ekasmiṃścalite sarveṣāṃ calanānupalabdheḥ / yatrāpi bahūnāmekakālaṃ calanaṃ tatrāpyanekatvameva / kāraṇasyābhighātādeḥ pratyāśrayaṃ bhedāt / anyatra ca samavetamabhighātādi anyatra samavāyikāraṇamityabhyupagame cāśeṣadravyāśritasyotpattiḥ / aviśeṣāt / tathaikasmin dravye saṃyogād vinaṣṭe karmaṇi āśrayāntare 'pi tasyaikatāyāṃ vināśaḥ syāt / ekasmiṃścānekakarmābhyupagame viruddhadigabhimukhatāyāṃ parasparaṃ pratibandhāt agamanameva syāt / ekadigabhimukhatāyāñca ekenaiva karmaṇā saṃyogaII /vibhāgayorjanitatvāt na dvitīyasya sadbhāve pramāṇamasti / taduttarasaṃyogācca prāktanakarmavināśaḥ karmāntarotpattiśca kvacidiṣyata eva / tasmādyatra karmadvayapratibhāsastatra āśubhāvitvenaiveti draṣṭavyam / athaikadravyavattvaṃ rūpāderapīti kṣaṇikagrahaṇam / tathāpi buddhyādibhirvyabhicāraparihārārthaṃ mūrtadravyavṛttitvapadam /
analyzed: idānīm itara padārtha vaidharmyeṇa sva bheda vyāpakam utkṣepaṇa ādīnām sādharmyam tathā paraspara vyāvṛttam vaidharmyam kāraṇam ca nirūpayan āha utkṣepaṇa ādīnām iti na param dvayoḥ trayāṇām ca kim tarhi pañcānām api karma tva sambandhaḥ karma tva upalakṣitaḥ samavāyaḥ tathā ca utkṣepaṇa ādīni itarasmāt bhiyante karmāṇi iti vā vyavahartavyāni karma tva abhisambandhāt iti eka dravyavat tvam iti ekam ca tat dravyam ca iti eka dravyam tat asya asti
translated: Now, by the dissimilarity of the other objects, the similarity of upacaya etc. which is pervasive of its own divisions, and the dissimilarity which is mutually exclusive, and the cause, are being determined, saying of upacaya etc. Not only of two or three, but of all five, there is the relation of being an action. The inherence characterized by being an action. And thus upacaya etc. are to be spoken of as actions, because of the relation of being an action. Being possessed of one substance. One and a substance is one substance. It has that, so it is possessed of one substance. The state of that is being possessed of one substance. One action occurs in only one substance. Similarly, only one occurs in only one. How is this known? Because when one moves, the movement of all is not perceived. Even where many move at the same time, there too it is only multiplicity, because the cause, such as impact, is different for each. Others say that the action of moving is one, because the action of moving is not perceived in the parts of the moving substance.

original: atha kṣaṇikatve sati mūrtadravyeṣveva vartamānatvāt karmetyukte vyabhicārābhāvaḥ / satyam / tathāpi padāntaraṃ sādharmyamātrapratipādanārtham / parīkṣārthañceti / gurutvadravatvaprayatnasaṃyogebhyo jāyata iti gurutvadravatvaprayatnasaṃyogajam tasya bhāvastattvamiti / udāharaṇañcaitat / anyasmādapi kāraṇāt tadutpatteḥ / vyastañca gurutvādikaṃ kāryantarasampādakamapi na samuditaṃ karmavyatirekeṇānyasya ityasādhāraṇameva / na caivaṃ sakalakarmabhedavyāpakamiti vaidharmyamātrameva / yad vā gurutvādyanyatamakāraṇajanyatvaṃ vivakṣitam / tathā svakāryasaṃyogavirodhitvamiti / saṃyogamātreṇa vināśādarśanāditi svakāryagrahaṇam / karmakāryatvañca vibhāgavegayorapīti tatra vyabhicāravāraṇāya saṃyogagrahaṇam / ataḥ svakāryasaṃyogavirodhitvamasādhāraṇamapi kvacidāśrayavināśenāpi vināśānna pakṣavyāpakamiti vaidharmyamātrameva / tathā vibhāge saṃyoge 'pi ca kartavye nirapekṣakāraṇatvaṃ karmaṇaḥ svarūpam /
analyzed: atha kṣaṇika tve sati mūrta dravyeṣu eva vartamāna tvāt karma iti ukte vyabhicāra abhāvaḥ satyam tathā api pada antaram sādharmya mātra pratipādana artham parīkṣā artham ca iti guru tva drava tva prayatna saṃyogebhyaḥ jāyate iti guru tva drava tva prayatna saṃyoga jam tasya bhāvaḥ tattvam iti udāharaṇam ca etat anyasmāt api kāraṇāt tad utpatteḥ vyastam ca guru tva ādikam kāri antara sampādakam api na samuditam karma vyatirekeṇa anyasya iti asādhāraṇam eva n
translated: Now, if it is said that it is called action because it exists only in corporeal substances when they are momentary, there is no fallacy. True, but the other word is used to indicate mere similarity and for the sake of examination. And it is produced from weight, fluidity, effort and conjunction. That is its nature. And this is an example, because it arises from other causes as well. And weight etc. are separate, even though they produce other effects, not other than action when combined. So it is unique. And it is not merely dissimilar, pervading all actions. Or it is intended that it is produced by any one of the causes such as weight etc. And it is opposed to conjunction with its own effect. The word 'own' is used because destruction is not seen merely by conjunction. And action is also the effect of disjunction and velocity. To prevent fallacy there, conjunction is grasped.

original: nanu vibhāge 'napekṣakāraṇatvamiṣṭam / saṃyoge tu paścādbhāvinaṃ prāktanasaṃyogavināśamapekṣata ityanapekṣatvamasiddham / vastubhūtakāraṇāpekṣayā tadupapatteḥ / abhāvavyatirekeṇa ca vastubhūtaṃ kāraṇaṃ nāpekṣata ityanapekṣamityuktam / na cānyasyaitat sambhavatītyasādhāraṇam /
analyzed: nanu vibhāge napekṣa kāraṇa tvam iṣṭam saṃyoge tu paścāt bhāvinam prāktana saṃyoga vināśam apekṣate iti anapekṣa tvam asiddham vastu bhūta kāraṇa apekṣayā tad upapatteḥ abhāva vyatirekeṇa ca vastu bhūtam kāraṇam na apekṣate iti anapekṣam iti uktam na ca anyasya etat sambhavati iti asādhāraṇam
translated: But it may be argued that in the case of Disjunction, the cause is not dependent on anything else, while in the case of Conjunction, it is dependent upon the previous destruction of the previous Conjunction. What is meant by the term ‘not dependent’ is that it does not need a cause in the shape of the negation of something else; and this is not possible in any other case; hence the reason is exclusive.

original: asamavāyikāraṇatvamiti asādhāraṇamitarasmād vyāvṛttam / guṇānāṃ hi dvaividhyam asamavāyitvaṃ nimittatvañca / utkṣepaṇādīnāṃ cāsamavāyikāraṇatvameva na dvaividhyamastīti vipakṣādatyantaṃ vyāvṛttireva / dvaividhyapratiṣedhasya vivakṣitatvāt / tathā svaparāśrayasamavetakāryārambhakatvam / yasminnāśraye samavetaṃ karma / tatra āśrayāntare ca samavetaṃ vibhāgaṃ saṃyogaṃ II / cārabhata iti / samānajātīyānārambhakatvam / tathā cotpannaṃ karma vibhāgaṃ saṃyogaṃ cārabhamāṇamupalabdhaṃ na karmāntaramiti / ekasmin dharmiṇyanekasya karmaṇaḥ pūrvameva pratiṣedhāt / dravyānārambhakatvam / na karma dravyamārabhate / tasyottarasaṃyogena vinaśyadavasthasya kāraṇatvāsambhavāditi svabhedavyāpakaṃ sādharmyam / pratiniyatajātiyogitvamiti / pratiniyatajātirutkṣepaṇatvādikā / tadyogitvaṃ pañcānāmapi / digviśiṣṭakāryārambhakatvañca viśeṣaḥ parasparamiti / /
analyzed: asamavāyi kāraṇa tvam iti asādhāraṇam itarasmāt vyāvṛttam guṇānām hi dvaividhyam asamavāyi tvam nimitta tvam ca utkṣepaṇa ādīnām ca asamavāyi kāraṇa tvam eva na dvaividhyam asti iti vipakṣāt atyantam vyāvṛttiḥ eva dvaividhya pratiṣedhasya vivakṣita tvāt tathā sva para āśraya samaveta kārya ārambhaka tvam yasmin āśraye samavetam karma tatra āśraya antare ca samavetam vibhāgam saṃyogam ca ārabhate iti samāna jātīya anārambhaka tvam tathā ca utpannam
translated: The property of being the non-inherent cause - this is the uncommon, excluded from others. For qualities there are two kinds: non-inherence and instrumentality. And for motion etc. there is only the property of being the non-inherent cause, not a second kind. Thus there is complete exclusion from the contrary. Because the negation of a second kind is intended. Similarly, the property of producing an effect inhering in itself and in another. The action which inheres in a substratum produces disjunction and conjunction inhering in that substratum and in another substratum. It does not produce an effect of the same kind. And such an action is seen to produce disjunction and conjunction when produced, not another action. Because the negation of many actions in one substratum is already established. The property of not producing a substance - action does not produce a substance. Because it is impossible for an action which is in the process of destruction by a subsequent conjunction to be a cause. This is the similarity which pervades its own difference.

original: tatrokṣepaṇaṃ śarīrāvayaveṣu tatsambaddheṣu ca yadūrdhvabhāgbhiḥ pradeśaiḥ saṃyogakāraṇamadhobhāgbhiśca pradeśaiḥ vibhāgakāraṇaṃ karmotpadyate gurutvaprayatnasaṃyogebhyastadutkṣepaṇam /
analyzed: tatra īkṣepaṇam śarīra avayaveṣu tad sambaddheṣu ca yat ūrdhva bhāgbhiḥ pradeśaiḥ saṃyoga kāraṇam adhas bhāgbhiḥ ca pradeśaiḥ vibhāga kāraṇam karma utpadyate guru tva prayatna saṃyogebhyaḥ tat utkṣepaṇam
translated: Among them, throwing upward is the action that arises from heaviness, effort, and conjunction, which causes conjunction with the upper parts and disjunction with the lower parts of the limbs and what is connected to the body. That is throwing upward.

original: tadviparītasaṃyogavibhāgakāraṇaṃ karmāpakṣepaṇam /PDhS
analyzed: tad viparīta saṃyoga vibhāga kāraṇam karma apakṣepaṇam
translated: The action that causes the opposite conjunctions and disjunctions is throwing downward.

original: ṛjuno dravyasyāgrāvayavānāṃ taddeśairvibhāgaḥ saṃyogaśca mūlapradeśaiḥ / yena karmaṇāvayavīkuṭilaḥ saṃjāyate / tadākuñcanam /PDhS
analyzed: ṛjunaḥ dravyasya agra avayavānām tad deśaiḥ vibhāgaḥ saṃyogaḥ ca mūla pradeśaiḥ yena karmaṇā avayavī kuṭilaḥ saṃjāyate tat ākuñcanam
translated: The bending of a straight substance is the disjunction of its end parts from their places and the conjunction of the root parts with those places, by which the substance becomes curved.

original: tadviparyayeṇa saṃyogavibhāgotpattau yena karmaṇāvayavī ṛjuḥ sampadyate / tatprasāraṇam /
analyzed: tad viparyayeṇa saṃyoga vibhāga utpattau yena karmaṇā avayavī ṛjuḥ sampadyate tat prasāraṇam
translated: The stretching is the action by which the straight substance becomes straight again when the conjunctions and disjunctions occur in the opposite way.

original: yadaniyatadigpradeśasaṃyogavibhāgakāraṇaṃ tad gamanamiti //PDhS
analyzed: yat aniyata diś pradeśa saṃyoga vibhāga kāraṇam tat gamanam iti
translated: The motion is the action that causes the conjunctions and disjunctions with unspecified directions and places.

original: tadevāha tatrotkṣepaṇam / yadūrdhvaṃ bhajanta ityūrdhvabhājastaiḥ saṃyoga kāraṇam / adhobhāgbhiśca vibhāgakāraṇaṃ karmotpadyate / kebhyaḥ keṣu ceti / gurutvadravatvaprayatnasaṃyogebhyaḥ samastavyastebhyaḥ / tadutkṣepaṇamityudāharaṇārtham / vegāderapi tat kāraṇatvāt / śarīrāvayaveṣu hastapādādiṣu tatsambaddheṣu musalādiṣvityāśrayanirūpaṇam /
analyzed: tat eva āha tatra utkṣepaṇam yat ūrdhvam bhajante iti ūrdhva bhājaḥ taiḥ saṃyoga kāraṇam adhobhāgbhiḥ ca vibhāga kāraṇam karma utpadyate kebhyaḥ keṣu ca iti guru tva drava tva prayatna saṃyogebhyaḥ samasta vyastebhyaḥ tat utkṣepaṇam iti udāharaṇa artham vega ādeḥ api tat kāraṇa tvāt śarīra avayaveṣu hasta pāda ādiṣu tad sambaddheṣu musala ādiṣu iti āśraya nirūpaṇam
translated: That is stated: Among them, upward motion is the cause of conjunction with those that partake of the upward direction, and the action that is the cause of disjunction with those that partake of the downward direction arises from some to some. original: tadviparītasaṃyogavibhāgakāraṇaṃ karmāpakṣepaṇamiti / ūrdhvabhāgbhirvibhāgakāraṇamadhobhāgbhiśca saṃyogakāraṇamiti /

translated: The action that is the cause of conjunction and disjunction opposite to that is downward motion. Disjunction with those that partake of the upward direction and conjunction with those that partake of the downward direction.

original: ākuñcanam ṛjuno dravyasya ye 'grāvayavāsteṣāṃ taddeśaistadupalakṣitākāśādipradeśairvibhāgaḥ / saṃyogaśca mūlapradeśairiti tadupalakṣitākāśādipradeśaireva /

translated: Contraction is the disjunction of the end parts of a straight substance with the regions of space indicated by those, and the conjunction with the root parts, with the regions of space indicated by them alone.

original: yena karmaṇā samutpannenāvayavī kuṭilaḥ sannṛjuḥ sampadyate / tat prasāraṇamiti /

translated: The action by which a composite substance, having become crooked when produced, becomes straight, that is extension.

translated: That which is the cause of conjunction and disjunction with a place and direction that is not fixed is motion. Those places and directions that are other than the ones mentioned are the causes of conjunction and disjunction with them.

translated: The author now sums up: Thus, all these five kinds of action are with proper cause and without proper cause. Cause means reason. translated: Even so, the determination that there are only five is not logically possible, because in going out, coming in, etc., the occurrence and non-occurrence of cognitions are seen to be in groups. If it is argued that in those cases, the occurrence and non-occurrence of cognitions are due to the difference in effects, then it is not so, because in throwing up, etc. also, the occurrence and non-occurrence of cognitions would follow from the difference in effects alone. If it is argued that even when the occurrence and non-occurrence of cognitions in groups are present in the same way, there is a difference in species only in throwing up, etc., not in going out, etc., because there is a special reason for this, then it is not so, because of the consequence of a mixture of species. translated: Even so, the restriction to only five is not justified, as there are actions like coming out, going in, etc., which are different from throwing upwards, etc., and the corresponding cognitions are seen to occur and cease in groups. translated: Just as going out is due to the production of conjunction with the external region and the production of disjunction with the internal region, and entering is the opposite of that. If there is the presence of the continuation and absence of the notion of the same class in upward motion etc. and going out etc., then there is only the difference of species in upward motion etc., not in going out etc. There is no special reason for this.

translated: This is not so, because of the contingency of a mixture of classes. He says this: When there is the occurrence and non-occurrence of conditions due to the difference in classes of birth, etc., there is the undesirable consequence of a mixture of classes, the inclusion of contradictory classes. And that is undesirable because it is not observed elsewhere. Even though there is a difference in the higher and lower distinctions of existence, substantiality, etc., in a single manifest entity, still cowhood and horsehood, etc., are not observed. And here there is the contingency of the classes of going out and entering in in a single manifest entity. How is this? He says: The conditions of going out and entering in are seen simultaneously in a single action-manifest entity by two observers. Whose is that action? He says: Of a person going from one room to another. For thus, in two rooms there is only one door. When two persons are stationed there, and one person goes to the other, due to the perception of a specific conjunction and disjunction, the conditions of going out and entering in are seen simultaneously.

translated: If it is asked how there can be different cognitions simultaneously, if it is thought that just as there is no confusion of species, so too there is no confusion of multiple actions in a single object, how can there be the cognitions of spinning, falling, and entering simultaneously for the observers in a single action, we say: No. Because of the difference in the conjunctions and disjunctions qualified by direction of the parts and the whole. For the observer who sees the conjunctions and disjunctions with the directional parts of the parts in succession from the side, he has the cognition of spinning. For one who sees the disjunction of the upper part and the conjunction below of the whole, he has the cognition of falling. But for one who sees the conjunction in the inner part of the tube and the disjunction in the outer part, he has the cognition of entering. Thus, the difference in cognitions of going out, etc. is established from the difference in effects.

translated: He anticipates the opponent's view: If it is asked how there can be different perceptions simultaneously, and explains it thus: If it is thought that just as there is no confusion of classes, so there is no confusion of many actions in one thing, it has already been said. translated: Others, however, say that since actions are innumerable due to the differences of whirling, ejecting, moving upwards, burning, etc., and since there is no contradiction in establishing the difference of conditions due to the difference of species of exiting, etc., this is not their own opinion. translated: Let the difference in notions be due to the difference in species of throwing upwards, etc., but the difference in effects be due to the difference in actions of going out, etc. Now, is going a synonym of action, or is it a separate universal? Why do you doubt? Because the notion of going is not distinguished from the notion of action in all cases of throwing upwards, etc., it is understood to be a synonym of action. But because it is mentioned by a specific term like throwing upwards, etc., therefore it should be a separate universal. No, because it is a synonym of action, like the terms self and person. Going is just a synonym of action. Now, why is going mentioned by a specific term? No, because it serves to exclude whirling, etc. The mention of going is made to exclude whirling, falling, flowing, etc., which are not included by the terms throwing upwards, etc. Otherwise, those very four mentioned by specific terms would be the objects of general and specific terms.

original: bhavatūtkṣepaṇādīnāṃ jātibhedād bhedo na niṣkramaṇādīnām / atha gamanatvaṃ kiṃ karmatvaparyāyaḥ ghaṭaḥ kalaśaḥ iti paryāyavat / āhosvidaparaṃ sāmānyam / II / utkṣepaṇatvādivaditi cintyam / kutaḥ kāraṇāt te saṃśaya ityācāryasya praśnaḥ / sa cānupapannaḥ / tathā hi sandigdhena praśne kṛte sati tatpratisamādhānaṃ nyāyyam / na tu saṃśayakaraṇena vacanam / tasya sāmānyadharmādibhyaḥ pūrvamevotpattinirūpaṇāt / naiṣa doṣaḥ / saṃśayakāraṇajñāne sati taducchittāvupāyānuṣṭhānam upalabdhavyādhikāraṇasya vaidyasyeva aprayāsenaiva ghaṭata iti manyamānaḥ kāraṇaṃ praśnayatīti / tadāha samasteṣūtkṣepaṇādiṣu bhramaṇādiṣu ca karmapratyayavad gamanapratyayāviśeṣāt karmatvaparyāya iti gamyate / yathā hyutkṣepaṇakarmāpakṣepaṇakarmetyādivyavahāropalambhādaśeṣabhedavyāpakaṃ karmatvam / evamūrdhvaṃ gacchatyadho gacchatītyādivyavahāropalambhād gamanamapyaśeṣabhedavyāpakamityataḥ karmatvaparyāya iti jñāyate /
analyzed: bhavatu utkṣepaṇa ādīnām jāti bhedāt bhedaḥ na niṣkramaṇa ādīnām atha gamana tvam kim karma tva paryāyaḥ ghaṭaḥ kalaśaḥ iti paryāya vat āhosvit aparam sāmānyam utkṣepaṇa tva ādi vat iti cintyam kutas kāraṇāt te saṃśayaḥ iti ācāryasya praśnaḥ sa ca anupapannaḥ tathā hi sandigdhena praśne kṛte sati tad pratisamādhānam nyāyyam na tu saṃśaya karaṇena vacanam tasya sāmānya dharma ādibhyaḥ pūrvam eva utpatti nirūpaṇāt  na eṣa doṣaḥ
translated: Let there be difference among throwing upwards etc. due to difference in their nature, but not among going out etc. Now, is going-ness a synonym of action, like pot and jar are synonyms? Or is it a separate universal, like throwing upwards-ness etc.? This should be considered. Why is there doubt? This is the teacher's question. And that is unreasonable. For when a question is asked with doubt, it is proper to resolve it, but not to speak by causing doubt. Because it is determined before by general characteristics etc. This is not a fault. Thinking that when the cause of doubt is known, its cessation can be accomplished without effort, like a physician who has understood the cause of a disease, he asks the cause, thinking that the practice of the means can be accomplished without effort. He says: It is understood that going-ness is a synonym of action, like throwing upwards etc., because the notion of going is the same in all actions like throwing upwards etc. For just as throwing upwards etc.

original: na cātra niścaya evetyāha yatastūtkṣepaṇādivad viśeṣasaṃjñayābhihitam / tasmādaparaṃ sāmānyaṃ syāditi / na hi viśeṣadarśanena gaṇanāyāṃ tadavasare sāmānyasaṃjñānirdeśo dṛṣṭaḥ / yathā pṛthivyādisaṃjñāvasare dravyasaṃjñāyāḥ / tasmādubhayarūpadharmopalambhād viśeṣānupalambhādibhyaśca kiṃ karmavad gamanatvaṃ paraṃ sāmānyam / āhosvidutkṣepaṇatvādivadaparamiti saṃśayaḥ kāryaḥ / na saṃśayaḥ kāryaḥ / karmatvaparyāyatvādātmatvapuruṣatvavat paryāya eva gamanatvamiti / sarvatra karmapratyayavad gamanapratyayopalambhāditi nyāyāt / atha viśeṣasaṃjñayā kimarthaṃ gamanagrahaṇaṃ kṛtamiti / viśeṣasaṃjñāvasare sāmānyasaṃjñopadarśanasyādarśanāt / na / bhramaṇādyavarodhārthatvāt / utkṣepaṇādiśabdairanavaruddhānāmasaṅgṛhītānāṃ bhramaṇapatanasyandanādīnāmavarodhārtham / karmatvajñāpanārthamiti / anyathā hi gamanagrahaṇamantareṇa yānyeva catvāri viśeṣasaṃjñoktānyutkṣepaṇādīni tānyeva sāmānyaviśeṣasaṃjñāviṣayāṇi prasajyeranniti / sāmānyasaṃjñā karmasaṃjñā / viśeṣasaṃjñā cotkṣepaṇādisaṃjñā / tadviṣayāṇi catvāryeva prasajyeran / na bhramaṇādīni / kuta etat / viśeṣasaṃjñāviṣayāṇāmeva sāmānyasaṃjñāviṣayatvāt / tasmādutkṣepaṇādivad bhramaṇādīnāmapi karmatvajñāpanārthaṃ gamanagrahaṇaṃ kṛtamiti / na caitasmin pakṣe bhramaṇādīnāmaparajātisambandhe 'pi dūṣaṇam / tadapekṣayā ānantyasyābhyupagamāt / yacca gamanagrahaṇād bhramaṇādayaḥ saṅgṛhītā iti vākyam / tadanyathā vyākhyātam /
analyzed: na ca atra niścayaḥ eva iti āha yatas tu utkṣepaṇa ādi vat viśeṣa saṃjñayā abhihitam tasmāt aparam sāmānyam syāt iti na hi viśeṣa darśanena gaṇanāyām tad avasare sāmānya saṃjñā nirdeśaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ yathā pṛthivī ādi saṃjñā avasare dravya saṃjñāyāḥ tasmāt ubhaya rūpa dharma upalambhāt viśeṣa anupalambha ādibhyaḥ ca kim karma vat gamana tvam param sāmānyam āhosvit utkṣepaṇa tva ādi vat aparam iti saṃśayaḥ kāryaḥ na saṃśayaḥ
translated: And here there is no certainty. Therefore he says: Because it is mentioned by a specific term like 'throwing up' etc., therefore it would be a higher universal. For when a specific thing is seen, the indication of a general term at that time of counting is not seen, just as the indication of a substance is not seen at the time of indicating earth etc. Therefore, due to the perception of a property with both forms, and due to the non-perception of a specific thing etc., the doubt should be raised: Is 'going' a higher universal like 'action', or is it a lower universal like 'throwing up' etc.? Doubt should not be raised. 'Going' is a synonym like 'self' and 'person', because it is a synonym of 'action'. Because the notion of 'going' is perceived everywhere like the notion of 'action', according to the principle. Then, why is 'going' mentioned by a specific term? Because the indication of a general term is not seen at the time of indicating a specific thing. No, because it serves to exclude 'circling' etc.

original: athavā astvaparaṃ sāmānyaṃ gamanatvamaniyatadigdeśasaṃyogavibhāgakāraṇeṣu bhramaṇādiṣveva vartate / notkṣepaṇādiṣu / kathaṃ tarhi teṣu gamanavyavahāra ityāha gamanaśabdastūtkṣepaṇādiṣu bhākto draṣṭavyaḥ / kasmāt / upacārabījāt svāśrayasaṃyogavibhāgakartṛtvasāmānyāditi / yathā utpannamutkṣepaṇādi svāśrayasya padārthāntaraiḥ saṃyogavibhāgān karoti / tathā gamanamapīti / na caitasmādeva nimittādutkṣepaṇādiṣu gamanavyavahāravad gamane 'pi utkṣepaṇādivyavahāraprasaṅgaḥ / kāryasadbhāvena kāraṇakalpanāyāḥ pravartanāt / na cotkṣepaṇādiṣu gamanavyavahāravad gamane 'pi utkṣepaṇādivyavahāro dṛṣṭaḥ / tasmādacodyametat / atha pakṣadvayopanyāsāt kimatrācāryasyābhipretam / pañcānāṃ pratiniyatajātiyogitvābhidhānād gamanatvamaparaṃ samānyamityetat /
analyzed: athavā astu aparam sāmānyam gamana tvam aniyata diś deśa saṃyoga vibhāga kāraṇeṣu bhramaṇa ādiṣu eva vartate na utkṣepaṇa ādiṣu katham tarhi teṣu gamana vyavahāraḥ iti āha gamana śabdaḥ tu utkṣepaṇa ādiṣu bhāktaḥ draṣṭavyaḥ kasmāt upacāra bījāt sva āśraya saṃyoga vibhāga kartṛ tva sāmānyāt iti yathā utpannam utkṣepaṇa ādi sva āśrayasya padārtha antaraiḥ saṃyoga vibhāgān karoti tathā gamanam api iti na ca etasmāt eva nimittāt
translated: Or rather, let there be another general action, called going, which exists only in revolving and other actions that cause conjunctions and disjunctions with directions that are not determined. It does not exist in throwing upwards and other actions. How then is there the usage of going in those? He says: The word going should be seen as figurative in throwing upwards and other actions. Why? From the seed of figurative usage, from the commonality of being the cause of conjunctions and disjunctions with its substratum. Just as throwing upwards and other actions that have arisen cause conjunctions and disjunctions of their substratum with other things, so does going. And from this very reason, there is no consequence of the usage of going in throwing upwards and other actions, nor the usage of throwing upwards and other actions in going, because the postulation of a cause is based on the existence of an effect. And the usage of throwing upwards and other actions in going is not seen as the usage of going in throwing upwards and other actions. Therefore, this is not a matter of dispute. Now, from the presentation of two positions, what is intended here by the teacher? The five actions have the nature of being the cause of conjunctions and disjunctions with their substratum. They are not the cause of conjunctions and disjunctions with other things. Translation: अथवा अस्तु गमनमनियतदिग्देशसंयोगविभागकारणेष्वेव भ्रमणादिष्वपरं सामान्यं गमनत्वं नोत्क्षेपणादिषु । कथं तर्हि तेषु गमनव्यवहार इत्याह गमनशब्दस्तूत्क्षेपणादिषु भाक्तो द्रष्टव्यः । कस्मात् । उपचारबीजात् स्वाश्रयसंयोगविभागकर्तृत्वसामान्यादिति । यथा उत्पन्नमुत्क्षेपणादि स्वाश्रयस्य पदार्थान्तरैः संयोगविभागान् करोति । तथा गमनमपीति । न चैतस्मादेव निमित्तादुत्क्षेपणादिषु गमनव्यवहारवद् गमने ऽपि उत्क्षेपणादिव्यवहारप्रसङ्गः । कार्यसद्भावेन कारणकल्पनायाः प्रवर्तनात् ।

original: anye tu vāstavadūṣaṇasya parasāmānyapakṣe 'nabhidhānāt tadevābhipretamiti manyante /
analyzed: anye tu vāstava dūṣaṇasya para sāmānya pakṣe tat eva abhipretam iti manyante
translated: But others think that the real fault is intended, because it is not stated in the general case of others.

original: satpratyayakarmavidhiḥ / katham / cikīrṣiteṣu yajñādhyayanadānakṛṣyādiṣu yadā hastamutkṣeptumicchati apakṣeptuṃ vā / tadā hastavatyātmapradeśe prayatnaḥ sañjāyate / taṃ prayatnaṃ gurutvaṃ cāpekṣamāṇādātmahastasaṃyogāddhaste karma bhavati / hastavat sarvaśarīrāvayaveṣu pādādiṣu śarīre ceti /PDhS
analyzed: sat pratyaya karma vidhiḥ katham cikīrṣiteṣu yajña adhyayana dāna kṛṣi ādiṣu yadā hastam utkṣeptum icchati apakṣeptum vā tadā hastavati ātma pradeśe prayatnaḥ sañjāyate tam prayatnam guru tvam ca apekṣamāṇāt ātma hasta saṃyogāt haste karma bhavati hasta vat sarva śarīra avayaveṣu pāda ādiṣu śarīre ca iti
translated: The injunction of action with a real cause. How? When one desires to perform sacrifices, study, giving, agriculture, etc., and desires to raise one's hand or lower it, at that time an effort arises in the part of the body with the hand. That effort and gravity, in dependence on the contact of the self with the hand, produce action in the hand. And in all parts of the body such as the feet, etc., and in the body itself.

original: pūrvaṃ satpratyayamasatpratyayañca karmoktam / tatra satpratyayakarmavidhiḥ kathamityāha cikīrṣiteṣu kartumabhīṣṭeṣu / yajñādhyayanadānakṛṣyādiṣvityādipadena bhojanādergrahaṇam / yajñādiṣu ca tilādigrahaṇārthaṃ yadā hastamutkṣeptumicchati apakṣeptuṃ vā / tadā hastavatyātmapradeśe prayatnaḥ sañjāyate / tadutpattāvātmā samavāyikāraṇam / ātmamanaḥsaṃyogo 'samavāyikāraṇam / icchā nimittakāraṇam / tatprayatnaṃ gurutvañcāpekṣamāṇād ātmahastasaṃyogādasamavāyikāraṇād haste samavāyikāraṇe karmotpadyate / hastavat sarvaśarīrāvayaveṣu padādiṣu śarīre ceti / yathā ātmahastasaṃyogo 'samavāyikāraṇaṃ prayatnastu nimittakāraṇaṃ hastakarmotpattau / tathā sarvaśarīrāvayaveṣu śarīre ca samavetakarmotpattau ātmasaṃyogo 'samavāyikāraṇaṃ prayatno nimittakāraṇamityatideśārthaḥ /
analyzed: pūrvam sat pratyayam asat pratyayam ca karma uktam tatra sat pratyaya karma vidhiḥ katham iti āha cikīrṣiteṣu kartum abhīṣṭeṣu yajña adhyayana dāna kṛṣi ādiṣu iti ādi padena bhojana ādeḥ grahaṇam yajña ādiṣu ca tila ādi grahaṇa artham yadā hastam utkṣeptum icchati apakṣeptum vā tadā hastavati ātma pradeśe prayatnaḥ sañjāyate tad utpattau ātmā samavāyi kāraṇam ātma manaḥ saṃyogaḥ samavāyi kāraṇam icchā nimitta kāraṇam tad prayatnam guru
translated: Previously, action with good and bad conditions has been mentioned. There, how is the injunction of action with good conditions? He says: in what is desired to be done, what is wished to be done, in sacrifices, study, giving, agriculture, etc. By the word 'etc.' the inclusion of eating, etc. is meant. And in sacrifices, etc., when one desires to raise one's hand for the purpose of taking sesamum seeds, or to lower it, then an effort arises in the part of the body that has a hand. At its origin, the self is the inherent cause. The conjunction of the self and mind is the non-inherent cause. Desire is the instrumental cause. From that effort and gravity, action arises in the hand, which has the non-inherent cause of the conjunction of the self and hand, and the inherent cause in the hand, in all parts of the body such as the foot, etc., and in the body. Just as the conjunction of the self and hand is the non-inherent cause and effort is the instrumental cause in the origin of the action of the hand, in the same way, in the origin of the action inherent in all parts of the body and in the body, the self is the inherent cause and effort is the instrumental cause.

translated: How is it in the case of things connected with it? When one, with the hand, takes up a pestle and makes a wish, I will raise the pestle with my hand, immediately after that comes effort. Dependent on that effort, from the conjunction of the self and the hand, at the very moment the action of raising arises in the hand, at that very moment, dependent on that same effort, from the conjunction of the hand and the pestle, action also arises in the pestle. Then, when the pestle is raised far away, the desire for that purpose ceases. Again, the desire to lower [it] arises. Immediately after that comes effort. Dependent on that, from the conjunction as described, the actions of lowering arise simultaneously in the hand and the pestle. Then, by the final action of the pestle, a conjunction called striking is produced between the mortar and the pestle. That conjunction, dependent on the momentum in the pestle, produces the action of falling in the pestle without an immediately antecedent condition. That action produces a modification in the pestle dependent on the striking. Dependent on that,

original: athavā prāktana eva paṭuḥ saṃskāro 'bhighātādavinaśyannavasthita iti / ataḥ saṃskāravati punaḥ saṃskārārambho nāsti / ato yasmin kāle saṃskārāpekṣādabhighātādapratyayaṃ musale utpatanakarma tasminneva kāle tameva saṃskāramapekṣamāṇāt musalahastasaṃyogādapratyayaṃ haste 'pyutpatanakarmeti /PDhS
analyzed: athavā prāktanaḥ eva paṭuḥ saṃskāraḥ bhighātāt avinaśyān avasthitaḥ iti atas saṃskāravati punar saṃskāra ārambhaḥ na asti atas yasmin kāle saṃskāra apekṣāt abhighātāt apratyayam musale utpatana karma tasmin eva kāle tam eva saṃskāram apekṣamāṇāt musala hasta saṃyogāt apratyayam haste pi utpatana karma iti
translated: Or, the previous strong impression remains without being destroyed by the blow. Therefore, when there is an impression, there is no beginning of a new impression. Thus, at the time when the action of rebounding in the pestle arises from the blow in dependence on the impression, at that very time, the action of rebounding arises in the hand also from the contact of the hand and the pestle in dependence on that same impression, without a separate cause.
