translated: If it is argued that even a single action, having produced multiple conjunctions, would be destroyed while still potent, then since the impression would persist without any effect having been produced, it would follow that another action is required, which is unacceptable. And the impression does not generate conjunctions, by which it would be destroyed while still potent in producing multiple effects. Because those [conjunctions] are the effects of action. Therefore, it is proper that the actions themselves be destroyed upon the production of those [conjunctions]. And it cannot be said that action is not different from the impression, because the difference of the cognition is the characteristic of difference. And thus, the cognition is seen to be affected by velocity, as in he moves with velocity, and affected by motion. Therefore, velocity is a different thing from action, like conjunction. But if there were no difference, then even in slow motion, there would be the cognition he moves with velocity. And this is not the case.

original: atha saṃyogavibhāgopalambhādanumīyate karmeti cet / na / saṃyogavadindriyavyāpāreṇaiva karmaṇyapi aparokṣajñānasadbhāvasyāviśeṣāt / yathā hi vastunaḥ pradeśāntaraiḥ saṃyogavibhāgāḥ pratyakṣeṇa pratīyante / tadvat karmāpīti /
analyzed: atha saṃyoga vibhāga upalambhāt anumīyate karma iti ced na saṃyoga vat indriya vyāpāreṇa eva karmaṇi api aparokṣa jñāna sadbhāvasya aviśeṣāt yathā hi vastunaḥ pradeśa antaraiḥ saṃyoga vibhāgāḥ pratyakṣeṇa pratīyante tadvat karma api iti
translated: If it is argued that action is inferred from the perception of conjunction and disjunction, that is not so. Because there is no difference in the presence of non-apparent knowledge regarding action as well, just as the conjunctions and disjunctions of an object with other places are perceived by direct perception. In the same way, action is also [perceived].

original: yacca pradeśāntaraiḥ saṃyogavibhāgopalambhe sati calatīti jñānam ānumānikamitīṣṭam / tanna yuktam / nadīsrotasyūrdhvāvasthitasya sthāṇostatsadbhāve 'pi calanapratyayādarśanāt / ākāśe prakṣiptasyeṣostadabhāve 'pi tatsadbhāvadarśanāt /
analyzed: yat ca pradeśa antaraiḥ saṃyoga vibhāga upalambhe sati calati iti jñānam ānumānikam iti iṣṭam tat na yuktam nadī srotasi ūrdhva avasthitasya sthāṇoḥ tad sadbhāve pi calana pratyaya adarśanāt ākāśe prakṣiptasya iṣoḥ tad abhāve pi tad sadbhāva darśanāt
translated: And the knowledge that something is moving when there is perception of conjunction and disjunction with other places is accepted as inferential. That is not correct. Because even when there is the existence of that [motion] in a post standing above the current of a river, the notion of motion is not seen. And because even when there is no existence of that [motion] in an arrow thrown into the sky, its existence is seen.

original: yaccedam ekasmin sthāne pratikṣaṇamutpādāt tiṣṭhatīti vyavahāraḥ / deśāntare ca tadbhāvād gamanavyavahāra ityuktam / tanna yuktam / kṣaṇabhaṅgapratiṣedhāt /
analyzed: yat ca idam ekasmin sthāne pratikṣaṇam utpādāt tiṣṭhati iti vyavahāraḥ deśa antare ca tad bhāvāt gamana vyavahāraḥ iti uktam tat na yuktam kṣaṇa bhaṅga pratiṣedhāt
translated: And what has been said - that there is the convention of remaining at one place due to arising every moment, and the convention of going due to its existence in another place - that is not correct, because the momentariness of things has been refuted.

original: atha saṃyogabahutvād bahūni karmāṇīti satyam / na caivaṃ saṃskārasyāpi saṃyogabahutvād bahutvam / tasya saṃyogamātreṇāvināśāt / vināśe vā karmāntarāṇāmutpattirna syāt / asamavāyikāraṇābhāvāt / na cātmeṣusaṃyoga eva adṛṣṭāpekṣo 'samavāyikāraṇam / pratyakṣānumānābhyāṃ kāraṇāntarānupalambhe sati tat kalpanāyāḥ samāśrayaṇāt / upalabhyate ca akṣavyāpāreṇaiva vegaḥ / tasya pratyākhyānamaśakyam /
analyzed: atha saṃyoga bahu tvāt bahūni karmāṇi iti satyam na ca evam saṃskārasya api saṃyoga bahu tvāt bahu tvam tasya saṃyoga mātreṇa avināśāt vināśe vā karma antarāṇām utpattiḥ na syāt asamavāyi kāraṇa abhāvāt na ca ātma iṣu saṃyogaḥ eva adṛṣṭa apekṣaḥ samavāyi kāraṇam pratyakṣa anumānābhyām kāraṇa antara anupalambhe sati tat kalpanāyāḥ samāśrayaṇāt upalabhyate ca akṣa vyāpāreṇa eva vegaḥ tasya pratyākhyānam aśakyam
translated: If it is argued that many actions arise due to the multiplicity of conjunctions, that is true. But in the same way, the impression also does not become multiple due to the multiplicity of conjunctions, because it is not destroyed by mere conjunction. If it were destroyed, then other actions would not arise, because there would be no non-inherent cause. And the conjunction of the self and the sense organs is not the non-inherent cause, depending on unseen forces, because when another cause is not perceived by perception or inference, it is impossible to assume it. And momentum is perceived by the functioning of the senses. It is impossible to deny it.

original: atha saṃskārādupajātakarmaṇi uttarasaṃyogād vegasya karmaṇaśca vinaśyattā / anyayośca vegakarmaṇorutpadyamānatā / atastayorutpādaḥ prāktanayośca vināśa iti kalpanāyāṃ kiṃ dūṣaṇam / vinaśyadavasthasyāsamavāyikāraṇatvasyābhāva ityetat / tathā hi na prāktanaṃ karma saṃskārāntaramārabhate / nāpi prāktano vegaḥ karmāntaram / ubhayorvinaśyadavasthatvenāsamavāyikāraṇatvābhāvāt / na cānyadasamavāyikāraṇam antarāle karmaṇaḥ sambhavatītyuktam / yacca saṃskārādutpannaṃ karma tanna saṃskārāntaramārabhate / apekṣākāraṇābhāvāt / nāpi prāktanaḥ saṃskāro 'pekṣākāraṇam / saṃskāravati saṃskārārambhapratiṣedhād avaśyaṃ karmāntarotpattisamakālamuttarasaṃyogāt pūrvakarmanivṛttivat pūrvasaṃskārasyāpi nivṛttirvācyā / na ca saṃyogamātramapekṣākāraṇaṃ karmaṇaḥ saṃskārārambhe / II / mandagatāvadarśanāt / tathā hi mandagatau saṃyogasadbhāve 'pi na karma saṃskāramārabhata ityupalabdham / tasmādeka eva saṃskāro 'ntarāle karmaṇo 'pekṣākāraṇābhāvāditi /
analyzed: atha saṃskārāt upajāta karmaṇi uttara saṃyogāt vegasya karmaṇaḥ ca vinaśyat tā anyayoḥ ca vega karmaṇoḥ utpadyamāna tā atas tayoḥ utpādaḥ prāktanayoḥ ca vināśaḥ iti kalpanāyām kim dūṣaṇam vinaśyat avasthasya asamavāyi kāraṇa tvasya abhāvaḥ iti etat tathā hi na prāktanam karma saṃskāra antaram ārabhate na api prāktanaḥ vegaḥ karma antaram ubhayoḥ vinaśyat avastha tvena asamavāyi kāraṇa tva abhāvāt na ca anyat asamavāyi kāraṇam antar
translated: Now, if the subsequent conjunction gives rise to an action in the object that has arisen from the impression, and the momentum and action of the previous ones are destroyed, and two new momentum and action are produced, then what fault is there in assuming that the production of those two and the destruction of the previous two occur simultaneously? The fault is that a thing in the process of destruction cannot be an inherent cause. For the previous action does not give rise to another impression, nor does the previous momentum give rise to another action, because both are in the process of destruction and cannot be inherent causes. And it has been said that no other inherent cause of action is possible in between. And the action that arises from the impression does not give rise to another impression, because there is no causal relation of mutual dependence. Nor can the previous impression be the causal relation of mutual dependence, because it has been refuted that an impression gives rise to another impression when it already exists. Therefore, just as the previous action must necessarily cease simultaneously with the arising of the subsequent action due to the subsequent conjunction, so too the previous impression must be said to cease.

original: nanvevaṃ tarhi saṃskārasyaikarūpatvāt kathaṃ tīvratarādibhedabhinnānāṃ karmaṇāmutpattiḥ / sahakāribhedāt / sa ca kāryabhedenaiva jñeyaḥ / tatra dṛṣṭasyānupalabdheradṛṣṭākhyaḥ kalpata iti / kṣiptasyeṣoḥ pātopalambhena ca vegavināśaprasiddheḥ / tasya sahetutvādanyasya ca vināśahetorabhāvādanekakāryakaraṇe sati śaktiprakṣayādvināśaḥ kalpyata iti / sā ca śaktiradṛṣṭaviśeṣa eva anekakarmasampādakaḥ / etaccānekasaṃskāravādināpyabhyupagantavyam / anyathā hi punaḥ saṃskārotpatteriṣorapāta eva syāt / tasmāduktanyāyenaika eva saṃskāra iti /
analyzed: nanu evam tarhi saṃskārasya eka rūpa tvāt katham tīvratara ādi bheda bhinnānām karmaṇām utpattiḥ sahakāri bhedāt sa ca kārya bhedena eva jñeyaḥ tatra dṛṣṭasya anupalabdheḥ adṛṣṭa ākhyaḥ kalpate iti kṣiptasya iṣoḥ pāta upalambhena ca vega vināśa prasiddheḥ tasya sa hetu tvāt anyasya ca vināśa hetoḥ abhāvāt aneka kārya karaṇe sati śakti prakṣayāt vināśaḥ kalpyate iti sā ca śaktiḥ adṛṣṭa viśeṣaḥ eva aneka karma sampādakaḥ etat
translated: If so, then how do actions with distinctions of being very intense, etc. arise, since the impression is of one form? Due to the distinction of cooperating factors. And that should be known only through the distinction of effects. There, the unseen is imagined due to the non-perception of the seen. And because the destruction of momentum is well-known through the perception of the fall of a thrown arrow, since that [momentum] has a cause and there is no other cause of destruction, destruction is imagined due to the exhaustion of potency when producing multiple effects. And that potency is itself a special unseen [force] that accomplishes multiple actions. And this must be accepted even by one who asserts multiple impressions. Otherwise, the arrow would not fall again due to the arising of the impression. Therefore, by the stated reasoning, there is only one impression.

original: evamātmādhiṣṭhiteṣu satpratyayamasatpratyayañca karmoktam /PDhS
analyzed: evam ātma dhiṣṭhiteṣu sat pratyayam asat pratyayam ca karma uktam
translated: Thus, action with good and bad conditions has been stated in relation to the self and the superintended.

original: upasaṃhāramāha evamātmādhiṣṭhiteṣu prayatnadvāreṇa anadhiṣṭhiteṣu satpratyayamasatpratyayañca karmoktam /
analyzed: upasaṃhāram āha evam ātma dhiṣṭhiteṣu prayatna dvāreṇa anadhiṣṭhiteṣu sat pratyayam asat pratyayam ca karma uktam
translated: He states the conclusion: Thus, in the self-controlled, action with and without thought is stated through the door of effort. In the uncontrolled, action with and without thought is stated.

original: anadhiṣṭhiteṣu bāhyeṣu caturṣu mahābhūteṣvapratyayaṃ karma gamanameva nodanādibhyo bhavati / tatra nodanaṃ gurutvadravatvavegaprayatnāt samastavyastānapekṣamāṇo yaḥ saṃyogaviśeṣaḥ / nodanaṃ parasparamavibhāgakṛtaḥ karmaṇaḥ kāraṇam / tasmāccaturṣvapi mahābhūteṣu karma bhavati / yathā paṅkākhyāyāṃ pṛthivyām /PDhS
analyzed: anadhiṣṭhiteṣu bāhyeṣu caturṣu mahābhūteṣu apratyayam karma gamanam eva nodana ādibhyaḥ bhavati tatra nodanam guru tva drava tva vega prayatnāt samasta vyastān apekṣamāṇaḥ yaḥ saṃyoga viśeṣaḥ nodanam parasparam avibhāga kṛtaḥ karmaṇaḥ kāraṇam tasmāt caturṣu api mahābhūteṣu karma bhavati yathā paṅka ākhyāyām pṛthivyām pdhs ap ro ap sa api ap ro ap sa api ap ro ap sa api ap ro ap sa api ap ro ap sa api ap ro ap sa api ap ro ap sa api ap ro ap sa
translated: In the uncontrolled external four great elements, action without thought, such as mere movement, arises from impulsion and so on. There, impulsion is a particular conjunction that does not depend on the totality or absence of heaviness, fluidity, velocity, and effort. Impulsion is the cause of action, which is not produced by mutual non-separation. And from that, action occurs in all four great elements, just as in the earth called mud.

original: idānīmanadhiṣṭhiteṣu bāhyeṣu śarīrāsambaddheṣu / ākāśādinivṛttyarthaṃ caturṣu / mahābhūteṣviti paramāṇunivṛttyartham / apratyayamaprayatnapūrvakaṃ karma gamanameva nodanādibhyo bhavati / ādipadenābhighātasaṃyuktasaṃyogagurutvādergrahaṇam / tatra nodanaṃ vyākhyāyate / gurutvadravatvaprayatnavegān samastavyastānapekṣamāṇo yaḥ saṃyogaviśeṣaḥ / nodanaṃ parasparamavibhāgakṛtaḥ karmaṇaḥ kāraṇamiti / yaḥ saṃyogastannodanamityukte 'tiprasaṅgaḥ / tadarthaṃ karmaṇaḥ kāraṇamiti / abhighāto 'pyevaṃ bhavatīti avibhāgakṛta iti padam / tathāpyutpannasya karmaṇo 'vaśyaṃ II / vibhāgajanakatvam / ataḥ parasparamiti padam / tathāpi parasparaṃ saṃyogino vibhāgajanakasya karmaṇaḥ kāraṇaṃ saṃyuktasaṃyogo 'pītyato gurutvadravatvaprayatnavegān samastavyastānapekṣamāṇa iti / tatra yadā culukenodakaṃ gṛhītvā vegena pratikṣipati / tadā sarve gurutvādayaḥ sambhavantīti tadapekṣaṃ culukodakasaṃyogo nodanam / vyastapakṣe tu gurutvamapekṣamāṇaḥ saṃyogo nodanam / yathā sūkṣmaśāśākhopari vyavasthāpitamatiśayena gurudravyamadhogatiheturbhavati śākhāyāḥ / dravatvamapekṣamāṇastṛṇodakasaṃyogastṛṇe gamanamārabhate / vegamapekṣamāṇo vāyuvanaspatisaṃyogo vṛkṣādiṣu calanakāraṇam / prayatnāpekṣastu hastamusalasaṃyogo musalakarmotpattau / yadā ca prayatnena paṅke pādamupakṣipati / tadā prayatnagurutve cāpekṣya pādapaṅkasaṃyogaḥ paṅkamadho nayatīti / yadā ca pāṣāṇādervegena pāte sati paṅkena saṃyogastadā pāṣāṇādigataṃ gurutvaṃ vegañca apekṣamāṇaṃ pāṣāṇapaṅkasaṃyogo nodanamiti / yadā kaścid vegena kūpādau patati / tadā gurutvaprayatnavegān apekṣya devadattodakasaṃyogo 'dhogatiheturbhavati / yadā ca jaladharadhārāsambandhāt tṛṇāderadhogamanam / tadā gurutvadravatvavegānapekṣata ityādi draṣṭavyam / tasmād yathoktānnodanāccaturṣvapi mahābhūteṣu karma bhavatītyudāharaṇamāha yathā paṅkākhyāyāṃ pṛthivyāṃ pādādisaṃyogād yathoktaviśeṣaṇāditi /
analyzed: idānīm anadhiṣṭhiteṣu bāhyeṣu śarīra asambaddheṣu ākāśa ādi nivṛtti artham caturṣu mahābhūteṣu iti paramāṇu nivṛtti artham apratyayam aprayatna pūrvakam karma gamanam eva nodana ādibhyaḥ bhavati ādi padena abhighāta saṃyukta saṃyoga guru tva ādeḥ grahaṇam tatra nodanam vyākhyāyate guru tva drava tva prayatna vegān samasta vyastān apekṣamāṇaḥ yaḥ saṃyoga viśeṣaḥ nodanam parasparam avibhāga kṛtaḥ karmaṇaḥ kāraṇam iti yaḥ saṃyo
translated: Now, in external things not controlled, not connected with the body, and in the four great elements, in order to exclude space etc., and in atoms, in order to exclude the four great elements. Effortless action, i.e., action not preceded by effort, is movement only, not from impulsion etc. The word 'etc.' includes impact, conjunction with something joined, heaviness etc. Among them, impulsion is explained. Impulsion is the particular conjunction that does not depend on heaviness, fluidity, effort and speed, either collectively or individually. It is the cause of action not produced by mutual non-separation. If it is said that conjunction is impulsion, there is over-extension. Therefore, it is said 'the cause of action'. Impact also occurs in this way. Therefore, the word 'not produced by mutual non-separation' is used. Even so, action that has arisen necessarily produces separation. Therefore, the word 'mutually' is used. Even so, the conjunction of joined things is also the cause of action that produces mutual separation. Therefore,

original: vegāpekṣo yaḥ saṃyogaviśeṣo vibhāgahetorekasya karmaṇaḥ kāraṇam / so 'bhighātaḥ / tasmādapi caturṣu mahābhūteṣu karma bhavati / yathā pāṣāṇādiṣu niṣṭhure vastunyabhipatiteṣu / tathā pādādibhirnudyamānāyām abhihanyamānāyāṃ vā paṅkākhyāyāṃ pṛthivyāṃ yaḥ saṃyogo nodanābhighātayoranyatarāpekṣaḥ / ubhayāpekṣo vā / sa saṃyuktasaṃyogaḥ / tasmādapi pṛthivyādiṣu karma bhavati / ye ca pradeśā na nudyante nāpyabhihanyante teṣvapi karma jāyate /PDhS
analyzed: vega apekṣaḥ yaḥ saṃyoga viśeṣaḥ vibhāga hetoḥ ekasya karmaṇaḥ kāraṇam saḥ abhighātaḥ tasmāt api caturṣu mahābhūteṣu karma bhavati yathā pāṣāṇa ādiṣu niṣṭhure vastuni abhipatiteṣu tathā pāda ādibhiḥ nudyamānāyām abhihanyamānāyām vā paṅka ākhyāyām pṛthivyām yaḥ saṃyogaḥ nodana abhighātayoḥ anyatara apekṣaḥ ubhaya apekṣaḥ vā sa saṃyukta saṃyogaḥ tasmāt api pṛthivī ādiṣu karma bhavati ye ca pradeśāḥ na nu
translated: Abhighana is the specific conjunction that is the cause of the separation of one action, which depends on the velocity. From that also, action arises in the four great elements, just as when they fall on a hard object like a stone. Similarly, in mud-like earth that is being pushed or struck by feet and other limbs, the conjunction that depends on either pushing or striking, or on both, is the conjunction of the conjoined. From that also, action arises in earth and so on. And in those parts that are not being pushed or struck, action also arises.

original: abhighātasyetarasmād bhedārthamāha vegāpekṣo yaḥ saṃyogāviśeṣaḥ parasparaṃ vibhāgahetorekasya karmaṇaḥ kāraṇam / so 'bhighāta iti / vibhāgahetukarmakāraṇaṃ nodanādirapīti parasparaṃ vibhāgahetoriti padam / tathāpi ātmamanaḥsaṃyogena II / vyabhicāraparihārārthaṃ vegāpekṣa itipadam / na cātmamanaḥsaṃyogaḥ parasparavibhāgahetusampādako vegāpekṣa iti /
analyzed: abhighātasya itarasmāt bheda artham āha vega apekṣaḥ yaḥ saṃyoga aviśeṣaḥ parasparam vibhāga hetoḥ ekasya karmaṇaḥ kāraṇam saḥ bhighātaḥ iti vibhāga hetu karma kāraṇam nodana ādiḥ api iti parasparam vibhāga hetoḥ iti padam tathā api ātma manaḥ saṃyogena vyabhicāra parihāra artham vega apekṣaḥ iti padam na ca ātma manaḥ saṃyogaḥ paraspara vibhāga hetu sampādakaḥ vega apekṣaḥ iti
translated: To distinguish impact from other causes, he says: The specific conjunction dependent on momentum, which is the cause of the action that is the cause of mutual separation, is impact. The word mutual is used because impulsion and so on are also causes of the action that is the cause of separation. Nevertheless, to avoid the fallacy of over-extension, the word dependent on momentum is used. And the conjunction of self and mind is not a producer of the cause of mutual separation, dependent on momentum.

original: nanvekasyeti padaṃ vyartham / abhighātādubhayatrāpi karmopalabdheḥ / satyam / tathāpyekasyeti ādyakarmajñāpanārtham uttarottarāṇi vegādeva bhavantīti / nodanādiścottarakarmaṇāṃ bahūnāmapi kāraṇamiti / anye tu ekasya kāraṇameva / na tvekasyaivetyavadhāraṇaṃ manyante / nodane 'pyekasyeti viśeṣaṇamevaṃ vyākhyeyam / udāharaṇantu yathā pāṣāṇādiṣu pāṣāṇādyabhighātāditi / saṃyuktasaṃyoganirūpaṇārthamāha tathā pādādibhirnudyamānāyāmityādi /
analyzed: nanu ekasya iti padam vyartham abhighātāt ubhayatra api karma upalabdheḥ satyam tathā api ekasya iti ādya karma jñāpana artham uttarottarāṇi vegāt eva bhavanti iti nodana ādiḥ ca uttara karmaṇām bahūnām api kāraṇam iti anye tu ekasya kāraṇam eva na tu ekasya eva iti avadhāraṇam manyante nodane pi ekasya iti viśeṣaṇam evam vyākhyeyam udāharaṇam tu yathā pāṣāṇa ādiṣu pāṣāṇa ādi abhighātāt iti saṃyukta saṃyoga nirūpaṇa artham āha tathā pāda ā
translated: But the word of one is useless, because action is observed in both cases due to impact. True, but the word of one is to indicate the initial action, and the subsequent ones occur only due to momentum, and impulsion etc. are the cause of many subsequent actions. But others think that of one is the cause, but not of only one, and the qualification of one in impulsion should be explained thus. But the example is like the impact of stone etc. on stone etc. To define the conjunction of the conjoined, he says and so on for that being impelled by feet etc..

original: parasparamavibhāgakṛtaḥ karmaṇaḥ kāraṇaṃ nodanamapītyato nodanābhighātayoranyatarāpekṣa ubhayāpekṣo vā yaḥ saṃyogaḥ / sa saṃyuktasaṃyogaḥ / kvacinnodanāpekṣaḥ / kvacidabhighātāpekṣaḥ / kvacidubhayāpekṣa iti / udāharaṇantu yathā paṅkākhyāyāṃ pṛthivyām / kiṃ viśiṣṭāyām / pādādibhirnudyamānāyām abhihanyamānāyāṃ pṛthivyāṃ vā ye pradeśā na nudyante / na sākṣātpādena sambadhyante nāpyabhihanyante na sākṣāt pāṣāṇādinā sambadhyante / teṣvapi karma sañjāyate / pradeśāḥ samavāyikāraṇam / pādādibhiśca sambaddhapradeśaiḥ saha saṃyogo asamavāyikāraṇam / pādādisaṃyogāśca nimittakāraṇam /

translated: The cause of action is the impulse and the striking, which are not separate from each other. An example is in the earth called mud, which is being raised by feet, etc., or in the earth that is being struck. In which regions of the earth that is being raised and struck, the action does not arise directly connected with the feet, nor is it struck directly connected with the stone, etc., in those regions also the action arises. The parts are the inherent cause. The conjunction with the parts connected with the feet, etc. is the non-inherent cause. And the conjunctions with the feet, etc. are the instrumental cause.

original: pṛthivyudakayorgurutvavidhārakasaṃyogaprayatnavegābhāve sati gurutvād yadadhogamanam / tatpatanam / yathā musalaśarīrādiṣūktam / tatrādyaṃ gurutvāt / dvitīyādīni tu gurutvasaṃskārābhyām /PDhS

translated: To define falling, it says: That downward movement due to gravity is falling. The phrase when there is absence of contact that holds gravity, effort, and velocity shows the instrumental cause. The example is such as in a hammer, body, etc. Falling occurs in a hammer due to the absence of contact between hand and hammer, in a body due to the absence of effort, and in a spinning object due to the absence of velocity. Therefore, the second and subsequent fallings arise from gravity and modification, which are the non-inherent causes.

translated: To define syandana (flowing), it is said: The flowing down of water from high places to low places is syandana due to its fluidity. translated: He shows the difference by the difference in effects. In the wind called prāṇa, how does action arise? But for one who is asleep, action arises in the wind called prāṇa from the conjunction of the self and wind, which is the non-inherent cause, in dependence on effort preceded by life. What is the evidence here? The inference is that action in the wind is from effort preceded by life in one who is asleep. This is because the action of the wind in one who is asleep is the effect of effort, because it is the action of the wind that is accepted, like the action of that wind in the waking state. And where no other cause is perceived by perception or inference, there the cause is only unseen. And here, the establishment of being the effect of effort by inference is not contradicted by desire.

original: evaṃ caturṣu mahābhūteṣu nodanādibhyaḥ karmavyākhyāyām ākāśādau kriyāśūnyatve kāraṇamāha ākāśakāladigātmanaḥ / satyapi dravyabhāve niṣkriyāḥ / sāmānyādivad amūrtatvāt / yathā hi sāmānyāderamūrtatvānniṣkriyatvaṃ tadvadākāśāderapīti / mūrtatvena hi kriyāvattvaṃ vyāptam / tacca vyāvartamānam ākāśādibhyaḥ svavyāptaṃ kriyāvattvaṃ gṛhītvā vyāvartata iti / tadevāha mūrtirasarvagatadravyaparimāṇam / tadanuvidhāyinī ca kriyā / yatra yatra kriyā / tatra tatra II / mūrtiriti / sā ca mūrtirākāśādiṣu nāsti / tasmānna teṣāṃ kriyāsambandho 'stīti /
analyzed: evam caturṣu mahābhūteṣu nodana ādibhyaḥ karma vyākhyāyām ākāśa ādau kriyā śūnyatve kāraṇam āha ākāśa kāla diś ātmanaḥ sati api dravya bhāve niṣkriyāḥ sāmānya ādi vat amūrta tvāt yathā hi sāmānya ādeḥ amūrta tvāt niṣkriya tvam tadvat ākāśa ādeḥ api iti  mūrta tvena hi kriyāvat tvam vyāptam tat ca vyāvartamānam ākāśa ādibhyaḥ sva vyāptam kriyāvat tvam gṛhītvā vyāvartate iti tat eva āha mūrtiḥ asarva gata dravya parimāṇam tad
translated: Thus, in the four great elements, after explaining action through impulsion etc., he states the reason for the absence of action in space etc.: Space, time, direction and self, although existing as substances, are inactive, like universals etc., because they are not material. Just as universals etc. are inactive because they are not material, so are space etc. also. For action is pervaded by materiality. And that, being excluded, excludes its own pervasion, action, from space etc. He says that materiality is the dimension of a substance that is not all-pervading, and action conforms to that. Where there is action, there is materiality. And that materiality does not exist in space etc. Therefore, they do not have a relation with action.

original: savigrahe manasīndriyāntarasambandhārtham jāgrataḥ karma ātmamanaḥsaṃyogād icchādveṣapūrvakaprayatnāpekṣāt / anvabhiprāyam indriyāntareṇa viṣayāntaropalabdhidarśanāt / suptasya prabodhakāle jīvanapūrvakaprayatnāpekṣāt / apasarpaṇakarmopasarpaṇakarma cātmanaḥ saṃyogādadṛṣṭāpekṣāt / katham / yadā jīvanasahakāriṇordharmādharmayorupabhogāt prakṣayaḥ / anyonyābhibhavo vā / tadā jīvanasahāyayorvaikalyāt tatpūrvakaprayatnavaikalyāt prāṇanirodhe satyanyābhyāṃ vṛttilabdhadharmādharmābhyāmātmamanaḥsaṃyogasahāyābhyāṃ mṛtaśarīrād vibhāgakāraṇamasarpaṇakarmotpadyate / tataḥ śarīrād bahirapagataṃ tābhyāmeva dharmādharmābhyāṃ samutpannena ātivāhikaśarīreṇa sambadhyate / tatsaṅkrāntañca svargaṃ narakaṃ vā gatvā āśayānurūpeṇa śarīreṇa sambadhyate / tatsaṃyogārthaṃ karmopasarpaṇamiti / yogināñca bahirudrecitasya manaso 'bhipretadeśagamanaṃ pratyāgamanañca / tathā sargakāle pratyagreṇa śarīreṇa sambandhārthaṃ karma adṛṣṭakāritam / evamanyadapi mahābhūteṣu yatpratyakṣānumānābhyāmanupalabhyamānakāraṇamupakārāpakārasamarthañca bhavati tadapyadṛṣṭakāritam / yathā sargādāvaṇukarma / agnivāyvorūrdhvatiryaggamane mahābhūtānāṃ prakṣobhaṇam / abhiṣiktānāṃ maṇīnāṃ taskaraṃ pratigamanam / ayaso 'yaskāntābhisarpaṇañceti /PDhS
analyzed: sa vigrahe manasi indriya antara sambandha artham jāgrataḥ karma ātma manaḥ saṃyogāt icchā dveṣa pūrvaka prayatna apekṣāt anvabhiprāyam indriya antareṇa viṣaya antara upalabdhi darśanāt suptasya prabodha kāle jīvana pūrvaka prayatna apekṣāt apasarpaṇa karma upasarpaṇa karma ca ātmanaḥ saṃyogāt adṛṣṭa apekṣāt katham yadā jīvana sahakāriṇoḥ dharma adharmayoḥ upabhogāt prakṣayaḥ anyonya abhibhavaḥ vā tadā jīvana sahāyayoḥ vaikalyāt tad pū
translated: For the embodied soul, while awake, the action is for the purpose of connecting with another sense organ in the mind, arising from the contact of the self and mind, dependent on effort preceded by desire and aversion, because the perception of another object by another sense organ is in accordance with intention. For one who is asleep, at the time of waking, it arises from effort preceded by life, from the contact of the self and the mind, dependent on unseen [forces]. How? When the life-assisting dharma and adharma are exhausted by experience, or when there is mutual suppression, then due to the deficiency of the life-assisting [forces], due to the deficiency of the effort preceded by them, when the life-force is obstructed, the action of moving away arises as the cause of separation from the dead body, assisted by the two [forces] that have obtained subsistence through the two [forces] of dharma and adharma. Then, having gone out of the body, it becomes connected with a subtle body produced by those very dharma and adharma. And that [subtle body], having transmigrated, goes to heaven or hell.

original: atha yadi mūrtyanuvidhāyinī kriyā manasaḥ tarhi mūrtatvāt kriyāsambandho vācya ityāha savigrahe śarīrāvaruddhe manasi indriyāntarasambandhārthaṃ yajjāgrataḥ karmotpadyate tat kuta ityāha ātmamanasoḥ saṃyogādasamavāyikāraṇād icchādveṣapūrvakaprayatnāpekṣāt / kuta etaditthaṃbhūtāt prayatnājjāgrato manaḥ kriyeta / tadāha anvabhiprāyam indriyāntareṇa viṣayāntaropalabdhidarśanāt / abhiprāyamanu iti abhiprāyānatikrameṇa / yenaivendriyeṇa viṣayagrahaṇābhiprāyo bhavati tenaiva viṣayopalabdhidarśanād vijñāyate antaḥkaraṇasyecchānuvidhāyikriyāśrayatvam / tenānadhiṣṭhitasyendriyasya viṣayagrāhakatvāsambhavād iti manaḥ sambandho II / niścīyate / sa cecchānuvidhānāt tatpūrvakaprayatnajanitakriyākārya iti / suptasya tu yanmanaso nirindriyātmapradeśe pralīnasya indriyāntarasambandhārthaṃ prabodhakāle karma tadātmamanasoḥ saṃyogādasamavāyikāraṇājjīvanapūrvakaprayatnāpekṣādupajāyate / tathā hi suptasya manaḥkriyā / prayatnakāryā / parigṛhītāntaḥkaraṇakriyātvāt / jāgradavasthāyāṃ tatkriyāvat / apasarpaṇakarmopasarpaṇakarma cātmamanasoḥ saṃyogādasamavāyikāraṇādadṛṣṭāpekṣādutpadyata iti / mṛtaśarīrād vibhāgārthaṃ karma apasarpaṇam / garbhaśarīreṇa saṃyogārtham upasarpaṇamiti / kadā punastadapasarpaṇam / kathaṃ bhavatītyāha yadā jīvanasahakāriṇorityādi / jīvanaṃ vyākhyātam / tatsahakāriṇordharmādharmayorupabhogāt sukhaduḥkhasaṃvedanāt prakṣayastadā tena śarīreṇa bhoktavyasya karmaṇo 'bhāvāccharīrāntaropabhogasampādakakarmasadbhāve 'pi śarīrasya pāta eva / anyonyābhibhavo veti sambhāvinaḥ pakṣāntarasyopanyāsaḥ / tathā hi śarīrāntaropabhogadāyakena balīyasā paripakvena karmaṇā ārabdhaśarīrasyopabhogadāyakatvena abhipravṛttasya karmaṇo 'bhibhavo bhogadānasāmarthāpagamastīvraśabdopalambhena mandasyāgrahaṇamiveti / tato jīvanasahāyasya karmaṇo vaikalye sati tatpūrvakasya prayatnasya vaikalyācca prāṇanirodhaḥ / tannirodhe sati anyābhyāṃ vṛttilabdhadharmādharmābhyāmiti / vṛttiḥ sahakārikāraṇam / tayā labdhau tatsahakṛtau yau dharmādhamau tābhyāmātmamanaḥsaṃyogasahakāribhyāṃ mṛtaśarīrād vibhāgakāraṇam apasarpaṇakarmotpadyate / tatastasmāccharīrād bahirapagataṃ tābhyāmeva dharmādharmābhyāṃ sampāditaṃ yad ātivāhikaṃ sūkṣmaśarīram / tenābhisambadhyate / tatsaṅkrāntaśca svargaṃ narakaṃ vā gacchati / gatvā cāśayānurūpeṇa śarīreṇa saṃyujyate / tatsaṃyogārthaṃ karma upasarpaṇākhyamiti / ātivāhikaśarāraṃ cāgamabalādabhyupagatam / antaḥkaraṇasya parigṛhītatvāditi / tathā na kevalametad adṛṣṭād bhavati / yogināñca bahirudrecitasyeti / bahirdeśairudrecitasya manaso 'bhipretadeśagamanaṃ punaḥ punaḥ pratyāgamanañca / tathā sargakāle pratyagreṇa śarīreṇa sambandhārthaṃ karma adṛṣṭakāritamiti / na kevalametad anyadapi ca mahābhūteṣu yat karma / kiṃ viśiṣṭam / pratyakṣānumānābhyāmanupalabhyamānakāraṇam upakārāpakārasamarthamityarthaḥ / tadapi adṛṣṭakāritam / tadevāha / II / yathā sargādau sṛṣṭyādāvaṇuṣu karma śarīrādisampādanārtham / agnivāyvorūrdhvatiryaggamane iti / agnerūrdhvajvalanaṃ vāyostiryaggamanaṃ prāṇināmupakārāpakārasamarthamiti / mahābhūtānāṃ bhūgolakadevakulādīnāṃ prakṣobhaṇaṃ tatkampanaṃ maṇīnāṃ taskaraṃ cauraṃ prati gamanam / ayaso lohasyāyaskāntābhimukhatayā abhisarpaṇañceti /
analyzed: atha yadi mūrti anuvidhāyinī kriyā manasaḥ tarhi mūrta tvāt kriyā sambandhaḥ vācyaḥ iti āha sa vigrahe śarīra avaruddhe manasi indriya antara sambandha artham yat jāgrataḥ karma utpadyate tat kutas iti āha ātma manasoḥ saṃyogāt asamavāyi kāraṇāt icchā dveṣa pūrvaka prayatna apekṣāt kutas etat itthaṃbhūtāt prayatnāt jāgrataḥ manaḥ kriyeta tat āha anu abhiprāyam indriya antareṇa viṣaya antara upalabdhi darśanāt abhiprāyam anu iti abhiprāya anatikrame
translated: Now, if the action of the mind conforms to the body, then, being embodied, the connection with action must be stated. He says: In the embodied mind, enclosed in the body, the action that arises while awake, for the purpose of connecting with another sense organ, from what does that arise? He says: From the conjunction of the self and the mind, which is the non-inherent cause, dependent on the effort preceded by desire and aversion. From what of such a nature does the action of the mind arise while awake? He says: In accordance with the intention, because the perception of another object by another sense organ is seen. Anubhiprāyam means in accordance with the intention, without transgressing the intention. It is understood that the action of the internal organ conforms to the desire, because the perception of an object by that very sense organ by which there is the intention to grasp the object is seen. Therefore, the connection of the mind is ascertained. And that, being in accordance with desire, is the effect of the action produced by the effort preceded by that.

original: iti śrīvyomaśivācāryaviracitāyāṃ padārthasaṅgrahaṭīkāyāṃ karmapadārthaḥ samāptaḥ
analyzed: iti śrī vyomaśiva ācārya viracitāyām padārthasaṅgraha ṭīkāyām karma padārthaḥ samāptaḥ
translated: Thus ends the section on the meaning of action in the commentary on Padārthasangraha composed by the illustrious teacher Vyomasiva.

original: sāmānyapadārthanirūpaṇam
translated: Definition of the meaning of universal

original: sāmānyaṃ dvividham / paramaparañca / svaviṣayasarvagatamabhedātmakamanekavṛtti ekadvibahuṣvātmasvarūpānugamapratyayakāri svarūpābhedenādhāreṣu prabandhena vartamānamanuvṛttipratyayakāraṇam / katham / pratipiṇḍaṃ sāmānyāpekṣaṃ prabandhena jñānotpattāvabhyāsapratyayajanitācca saṃskārādatītajñānaprabandhapratyavekṣaṇād yadanugatamasti tat sāmānyamiti /PDhS
analyzed: sāmānyam dvividham param aparam ca sva viṣaya sarva gatam abheda ātmakam aneka vṛtti eka dvi bahuṣu ātma sva rūpa anugama pratyaya kāri sva rūpa abhedena ādhāreṣu prabandhena vartamānam anuvṛtti pratyaya kāraṇam katham pratipiṇḍam sāmānya apekṣam prabandhena jñāna utpattau abhyāsa pratyaya janitāt ca saṃskārāt atīta jñāna prabandha pratyavekṣaṇāt yat anugatam asti tat sāmānyam iti pdhs
translated: Universal is of two kinds: supreme and inferior. It is all-pervading in its own objects, of the nature of non-difference, occurring in many, causing the cognition of the form of the self in one, two, or many, existing continuously in the substrata as if it were non-different from its own form, and is the cause of the cognition of inherence. How? Because the cognition of inherence arises in each individual in relation to the universal, and from the impression produced by the cognition of repetition, and from the examination of the past series of cognitions, that which is inherent is the universal.

original: atha sāmānyasya lakṣaṇaparīkṣārthaṃ paramaparañca dvividhaṃ sāmānyamityādiprakaraṇam / atra ca pūrvaṃ vibhāgasyābhidhānādaniyamajñāpanena kāryakāraṇabhāvāśaṅkāvyudāsaḥ sāmānyalakṣaṇavibhāgayoḥ / yathā dravyaṃ pṛthivyapteja ityādi prayojanamityupadarśayati / svaviṣayasarvagatamiti vipratipattivyudāsaḥ /
analyzed: atha sāmānyasya lakṣaṇa parīkṣā artham param aparam ca dvividham sāmānyam ityādi prakaraṇam atra ca pūrvam vibhāgasya abhidhānāt aniyama jñāpanena kārya kāraṇa bhāva āśaṅkā vyudāsaḥ sāmānya lakṣaṇa vibhāgayoḥ yathā dravyam pṛthivī ap tejaḥ ityādi prayojanam iti upadarśayati sva viṣaya sarva gatam iti vipratipatti vyudāsaḥ
translated: Now, for the purpose of examining the definition of universals, the section beginning with Universals are of two kinds, higher and lower is presented. And here, since the division is stated first, the doubt regarding the relation of cause and effect is excluded by the knowledge of non-restriction, in the definition and division of universals. The purpose is shown as Substance is earth, water, fire, etc. The exclusion of disagreement is stated as present in all its own substrata.

original: tathā hi pare manyante sarvaṃ sāmānyaṃ sarvagatam / gotvamaśvapiṇḍeṣvapyasti / aśvatvañca gopiṇḍādiṣvapīti / anupalambhastu vyañjakābhāvāt / yatra ca vyañjakasadbhāvastatrābhivyaktiḥ / yathā gopiṇḍeṣu gotvasyāśvapiṇḍe 'śvatvasyeti /
analyzed: tathā hi pare manyante sarvam sāmānyam sarva gatam go tvam aśva piṇḍeṣu api asti aśva tvam ca go piṇḍa ādiṣu api iti anupalambhaḥ tu vyañjaka abhāvāt yatra ca vyañjaka sadbhāvaḥ tatra abhivyaktiḥ yathā go piṇḍeṣu go tvasya aśva piṇḍe śva tvasya iti
translated: For others think that all universals are all-pervading. Gotva exists even in horse individuals. Aśvatva also exists in cow individuals and so on. But non-apprehension is due to the absence of manifesters. And where there is the existence of a manifester, there is manifestation. As gotva in cow individuals, aśvatva in horse individuals, etc.

original: taccāsat / gotvasyāśvādipiṇḍeṣu sadbhāve pramāṇābhāvād / vyavasthite hi sadbhāve 'bhivyañjakābhāvād anupalabdhiḥ kalpyate / atha sāmānyaṃ sarvaiḥ sambadhyate / vyāpakatvādākāśavadityasti /tra kiṃpramāṇam / tatra sarvaiḥ samavāye sādhye sādhyavikalamudāharaṇam / ākāśasya sarvatra samavāyābhāvāt / saṃyogitve tu sādhye sāmānyasya dravyarūpatāprasaṅgaḥ / na caitadyuktam / guṇakarmasu II / samavetasyopalambhād / dravyasya ca dravya eva saṃyogo nānyatreti / tathā yutasiddhyabhāvācca / yutasiddhānāñca saṃyoga iti / atha sāmānyena sambandhamātraṃ sādhyate / tatrāpi siddhasādhanam / svādhāreṇa saṃyuktasaṃyogasya sarvatra sadbhāvāt / tathā hi gotvādhāreṇa saṃyuktamākāśādi tena ca saṃyuktaṃ sarvamūrtamiti / evaṃ vyāpakatvamapi yadi sarvaiḥ saṃyogitvam / tadasiddham / pakṣe tadeva hi sarvagatatvamiti sādhyenāviśeṣa eva / tathā ākāśādervyāpakatve 'pi na sarvaiḥ sambandha ityanekāntaḥ / atha sarvaiḥ sambandhaḥ sādhyate sarvatra sannihitatvāditi hetunā / tadapyasat / ākāśādestadbhāve guṇakarmādinā sambandhābhāvāt / na ca viśiṣṭasambandhānabhyupagame bhāvasya anyasānnidhyaṃ paśyāmaḥ / ataḥ svaviṣayasarvagatameva sāmānyam / gotvaṃ gopiṇḍeṣvevāśvatvamaśvapiṇḍeṣveva / tatraivopalambhāt /
analyzed: tat ca asat go tvasya aśva ādi piṇḍeṣu sadbhāve pramāṇa abhāvāt vyavasthite hi sadbhāve bhivyañjaka abhāvāt anupalabdhiḥ kalpyate  / atha sāmānyam sarvaiḥ sambadhyate vyāpaka tvāt ākāśa vat iti asti tra kiṃpramāṇam tatra sarvaiḥ samavāye sādhye sādhya vikalam udāharaṇam ākāśasya sarvatra samavāya abhāvāt saṃyogi tve tu sādhye sāmānyasya dravya rūpa tā prasaṅgaḥ na ca etat yuktam guṇa karmasu samavetasya upalambhāt dravyasya ca dravye eva saṃyo
translated: And that is wrong. Because there is no evidence for the existence of cowness in the individual of a horse and so on. For when existence is well-established, non-apprehension is imagined due to the absence of an manifester. Now, if the universal is related to all, because of being all-pervading like space, it exists. What is the evidence for that? There, if the relation to all is to be proved, the example is defective in the probandum, because space does not have relation to all. But if the quality of being a conjoin is to be proved, it follows that the universal has the nature of substance. And that is not proper. Because what is related to qualities and actions is perceived. And the conjunction of substance is only with substance, not elsewhere. And so, because of the absence of co-existence. And conjunction is of co-existent things. Now, if mere relation with the universal is to be proved, then also it is the proving of what is already established, because the conjunction of what is conjoined with its own substratum exists everywhere. For instance, space is conjoined with what has cowness as its substratum, and that is conjoined with all corporeal substances.

original: abhedātmakamanekavṛttīti lakṣaṇaṃ darśayati abhedātmakamekasvabhāvam / anekatra vṛttiryasya tadanekavṛttīti / ekatve satyanekatra vartamānatvāt sāmānyam / tathāpi avayavisaṃkhyādibhirvyabhicāraparihārārthaṃ nityatve satīti viśeṣaṇamarthād vyākhyeyam / tathāpi salilādiparamāṇurūpādayo nityāścānekatra vartante / tadarthamekatve satīti viśeṣaṇam / te tu anekatve satyanekatra vartante iti / tathāpi ekatve nityatve ca satyanekatra vartate samavāyaḥ / tadarthaṃ svavyatiriktayā vṛttyā vartamānatve satīti ca viśeṣaṇamadhyāhāryam /
analyzed: abheda ātmakam aneka vṛtti iti lakṣaṇam darśayati abheda ātmakam eka svabhāvam anekatra vṛttiḥ yasya tat aneka vṛtti iti ekatve sati anekatra vartamāna tvāt sāmānyam tathā api avayavi saṃkhyā ādibhiḥ vyabhicāra parihāra artham nitya tve sati iti viśeṣaṇam arthāt vyākhyeyam tathā api salila ādi paramāṇu rūpa ādayaḥ nityāḥ ca anekatra vartante tad artham ekatve sati iti viśeṣaṇam te tu aneka tve sati anekatra vartante iti tathāpi ekatve nitya tve ca sati
translated: The definition shows that the universal has the nature of non-difference and many occurrences. It has the nature of non-difference, i.e., it has one nature. That which has occurrence in many is said to have many occurrences. Because it exists in many while being one, it is a universal. Even so, in order to avoid the fallacy of over-extension with respect to number etc. of the whole, the qualification being eternal should be understood by implication. Even so, the forms etc. of the atoms of water and so on are eternal and occur in many. For that purpose, the qualification being one is added. But they occur in many while being many. Even so, inherence occurs in many while being one and eternal. For that purpose, the qualification occurring by a mode distinct from itself should also be understood by implication.

original: sarvamatraiva vākye labhyate adhyāhāro na kārya iti cānye / tathā hi na vidyate bhedo nānātvaṃ vināśaśca yasyeti tathoktam / tadevātmā svarūpamasyeti abhedātmakamekamavināśi ceti labhyate / anekatra vṛttiryasya iti bahuvrīhiṇā vṛttervṛttimato bhedā'pyupadarśita eva / tasmādekatve nityatve ca sati samavāyena anekatra vartamānatvāt sāmānyamitarasmād bhidyate /
analyzed: sarvam atra eva vākye labhyate adhyāhāraḥ na kāryaḥ iti ca anye tathā hi na vidyate bhedaḥ nānātvam vināśaḥ ca yasya iti tathā uktam tat eva ātmā svarūpam asya iti abheda ātmakam ekam avināśi ca iti labhyate anekatra vṛttiḥ yasya iti bahuvrīhiṇā vṛtteḥ vṛttimataḥ eva tasmāt eka tve nitya tve ca sati samavāyena anekatra vartamāna tvāt sāmānyam itarasmāt bhidyate
translated: Others say that everything is obtained in this very sentence, and nothing should be supplied. For thus it is said that which has no difference, no plurality, and no destruction. That itself is its nature, thus it is obtained as non-different, single, and imperishable. And by the bahuvrihi compound that which exists in many, the difference between the existence and the existent is also shown. Therefore, when there is oneness and permanence, it is a universal, different from the other, because it exists in many by inherence.

original: nanvāśrayāsiddhametallakṣaṇam / sāmānyasadbhāve pramāṇābhāvāt / yaccānugatajñānaṃ na tat sāmānyasattāṃ darśayati / kalpanājñānatvāt / tathā cānādivāsanāvaśādanugatajñānamutpadyate / na punarvāstavaṃ sāmānyamasti / taduktam
analyzed: nanu āśraya asiddham etat lakṣaṇam sāmānya sadbhāve pramāṇa abhāvāt  yat ca anugata jñānam na tat sāmānya sattām darśayati kalpanā jñāna tvāt tathā ca anādi vāsanā vaśāt anugata jñānam utpadyate na punar vāstavam sāmānyam asti tat uktam
translated: But this definition is based on an unestablished substratum, because there is no evidence for the existence of universals. And the cognition that is pervasive does not show the existence of universals, because it is a conceptual cognition. And thus, the pervasive cognition arises from beginningless impressions, and there is no real universal. This is stated:

original: pararūpaṃ svarūpeṇa yayā saṃvriyate dhiyā /
analyzed: para rūpam sva rūpeṇa yayā saṃvriyate dhiyā
translated: By that cognition which conceals the external form under its own form,

original: ekārthapratibhāsinyā bhāvānnāśritya bhedinaḥ // pra / vā / /
analyzed: eka artha pratibhāsinyā bhāvān na āśritya bhedinaḥ pra vā
translated: Uniting the diverse things in the appearance of one object.

original: asyārthaḥ / bhedinaḥ parasparaṃ vyāvṛttātmāno bhāvāsteṣāṃ rūpaṃ bhinnam / svarūpeṇābhinnena saṃvriyate pracchādyate yayā dhiyā / kiṃ viśiṣṭayā / ekārthapratibhāsinyeti / ekaścārthaḥ pratibhāsate 'syāṃ svagatākāra eva bāhyaḥ / tasyā nirviṣayatvāditi /
analyzed: asya arthaḥ bhedinaḥ parasparam vyāvṛtta ātmānaḥ bhāvāḥ teṣām rūpam bhinnam sva rūpeṇa abhinnena saṃvriyate pracchādyate yayā dhiyā kim viśiṣṭayā ekārtha pratibhāsinyā iti ekaḥ ca arthaḥ pratibhāsate syām svagata ākāraḥ eva bāhyaḥ tasyāḥ nirviṣaya tvāt iti
translated: The meaning of this is: The forms of things that are different, having mutually distinct selves, are covered, concealed, by that cognition which is distinguished by what? By that which appears as one object. And the external object itself appears as one in it, because it has no object.

original: tayā saṃvṛtanānātvāḥ saṃvṛtyā bhedinaḥ svayam /
analyzed: tayā saṃvṛta nānātvāḥ saṃvṛtyā bhedinaḥ svayam
translated: By that, having their manifoldness covered, the different things themselves,

original: abhedina ivābhānti bhāvā rūpeṇa kenacit // pra / vā / /
analyzed: abhedinaḥ iva ābhānti bhāvāḥ rūpeṇa kenacid pra vā
translated: appear as if undifferentiated by some form.

original: asyārthaḥ / svayaṃ bhedino 'pi bhāvāstayā saṃvṛtyā saṃvṛtanānātvāḥ santaḥ abhedina ivābhānti / na paramārthataḥ / kathaṃ tarhi sāmānyamucyate / tadāha
analyzed: asya arthaḥ svayam bhedinaḥ pi bhāvāḥ tayā saṃvṛtyā saṃvṛta nānātvāḥ santaḥ abhedinaḥ iva ābhānti na paramārthataḥ katham tarhi sāmānyam ucyate tat āha
translated: The meaning of this is: Although the things themselves are different, being existent with that manifoldness covered by that convention, they appear as if undifferentiated. Not really, however. Then how is the universal said to be? He says:

original: tadabhiprāyavaśāt sāmānyaṃ satprakīrtitam /
analyzed: tad abhiprāya vaśāt sāmānyam sat prakīrtitam
translated: By the power of that intention, the existent is declared to be the universal.

original: tadasat paramārthena yathā saṅkalpitaṃ tayā // pra / vā / /
analyzed: tat asat paramārthena yathā saṅkalpitam tayā pra vā
translated: That is non-existent in reality, as imagined by that.

original: paramārthato 'sadapi sāmānyaṃ sat prakīrtitam / pra / vā / / /
analyzed: paramārthataḥ sat api sāmānyam sat prakīrtitam
translated: The universal, although non-existent in reality, is declared to be existent.

original: tadabhiprāyavaśādekākārapratibhāsavaśāditi / na ca sāmānyam / vyaktīnāṃ vyāvṛttarūpatvādanyasya cāpratibhāsanādityāha
analyzed: tad abhiprāya vaśāt eka ākāra pratibhāsa vaśāt iti na ca sāmānyam vyaktīnām vyāvṛtta rūpa tvāt anyasya ca apratibhāsanāt iti āha
translated: It is on account of the intention of that [consciousness], and on account of the appearance of a single form. And it is not a universal, because the individuals have a distinct form, and because nothing else appears. Thus he says:

original: vyaktayo nānuyantyanyadanuyāyi na bhāsate /
analyzed: vyaktayaḥ na anuyanti anyat anuyāyi na bhāsate
translated: The individuals do not follow, and nothing else that follows appears.

original: jñānādavyatiriktañcet kathamarthāntaraṃ vrajet // pra / vā / /
analyzed: jñānāt a vyatiriktam ced katham artha antaram vrajet pra vā
translated: If it were not different from cognition, how could it become a different object?

original: tasmād buddhireva tadanyavyatirekiṇaḥ padārthān āśrityotpadyamānā vikalpitā svavāsanāprakṛtimanuvidadhātīti bhinnameṣāṃ rūpaṃ tirodhāya abhinnamātmīyaṃ rūpamadhyavasyati saṃsṛjantī saṃdarśayati / sā ca ekasādhanasādhyatayā buddhivartināmeva bhāvānāṃ bahiriva parisphurantī sāmānyamityucyate / sā ca svavyatirikteṣu bhāveṣu bhavatīti viśeṣaviṣayetyucyate / na paramārthataḥ / tasmādanugatavyāvṛttasvarūpatvāt sāmānyaṃ viśeṣaśca / na tu bāhyā vivekinaḥ padārthāḥ / na ca teṣu vikalpavṛttiḥ kathaṃ teṣu bhavatīti / parīkṣakāḥ khalvevaṃ vivecayanti jātyā / na tu vyavahartāraḥ / te tu svālambanāmeva buddhimanugatākārāṃ bahīrūpatayā manyamānā dṛśyavikalpāvarthāvekīkṛtya pravartante pratipādayanti ceti / na tu nityamekamanugataṃ viśeṣavyatiriktaṃ sāmānyaṃ pratibhāsata iti /
analyzed: tasmāt buddhiḥ eva tad anya vyatirekiṇaḥ padārthān āśritya utpadyamānā vikalpitā sva vāsanā prakṛtim anuvidadhāti iti bhinnam eṣām rūpam tirodhāya abhinnam ātmīyam rūpam adhyavasyati saṃsṛjantī saṃdarśayati sā ca eka sādhana sādhya tayā buddhi vartinām eva bhāvānām bahis iva parisphurantī sāmānyam iti ucyate  / sā ca sva vyatirikteṣu bhāveṣu bhavati iti viśeṣa viṣayā iti ucyate na paramārthataḥ tasmāt anugata vyāvṛtta svarūpa tvāt sāmānya
translated: Therefore, the intellect itself, arising in dependence on objects that are different from it, assumes the nature of its own latent impressions when imagined. Thus, it conceals the different forms of those [objects] and grasps its own non-different form, combining and displaying them. And that is called the universal, appearing externally as if it were the means and object of cognition of only the things existing in the intellect. And that is said to be the object of particulars, because it exists in things other than itself, but not ultimately. Therefore, the universal and the particular are [so called] because of their inclusive and exclusive forms, but external differentiated things are not. And how does conceptual cognition occur in them? Indeed, investigators analyze in this way through universals, but not the people engaged in worldly transactions. They, considering the cognition having its own object as having a form that is inclusive, as if it were an external form, identify the seen and the imagined objects and engage in activity and communicate.

original: punarapyuktam🔽śabdo 'rthāṃśakamāheti tatrānyāpoha ucyate /
analyzed: punar api uktam  śabdaḥ rtha aṃśakam āha iti tatra anya apohaḥ ucyate
translated: Again it is said:🔽The word expresses a part of the meaning, and there the exclusion of others is stated.

original: ākāraḥ sa ca nārthe 'sti taṃ vadannarthabhākkatham // pra / vā / /
analyzed: ākāraḥ sa ca na arthe sti tam vadan artha bhāj katham pra vā
translated: And that form does not exist in the object. How can one who speaks of it be said to have the object?

original: iti /
analyzed: iti
translated: Thus.

original: vṛttyanupapatteśca na vāstavaṃ sāmānyamastīti / tathā caikatra vartamānaṃ sāmānyaṃ naikadeśena vartate / tadabhāvāt / na sarvātmanā / anyatra vṛttyabhāvaprasaṅgāt / tathā yenaiva rūpeṇaikatra vartate tenaiva anyatrāpītyabhyupagame sarvapiṇḍānāmekatāprasaṅgaḥ / atha svarūpāntareṇa / tarhi svarūpabhedāt tasya nānātvaṃ prasajyate / svabhāvāntaranivṛttau cānekatra vṛttitvaṃ virudhyata ityuktam / deśakālāvasthāviśeṣaviniyataikasaṃsargāvyavacchinnasvabhāvāntaravirahādanekatra vṛtterekasya na deśādiviśeṣavatā anyena yoga iti /
analyzed: vṛtti anupapatteḥ ca na vāstavam sāmānyam asti iti  tathā ca ekatra vartamānam sāmānyam na eka deśena vartate tad abhāvāt na sarva ātmanā anyatra vṛtti abhāva prasaṅgāt tathā yena eva rūpeṇa ekatra vartate tena eva anyatra api iti abhyupagame sarva piṇḍānām ekatā prasaṅgaḥ atha svarūpa antareṇa tarhi sva rūpa bhedāt tasya nānātvam prasajyate svabhāva antara nivṛttau ca anekatra vṛtti tvam virudhyate iti uktam deśa kāla avasthā viśeṣa viniyata eka saṃ
translated: And because the operation is not possible, there is no real universal. And in that case, a universal that exists in one thing does not exist in part, because it does not exist. Not in its entirety, because it would follow that it exists in another thing. If it is accepted that it exists in the same form in another thing, then all the individual things would be one. If it is by a different form, then its multiplicity would follow from the difference in forms. And it is said that the existence in many things is contradictory when there is the cessation of a different nature. Because there is no absence of a different nature that is not distinguished by the connection with only one thing restricted by the particularities of place, time, and condition, the existence in many things of one thing is not a connection with another that has particularities of place, etc.

original: tatra deśaviśeṣo nagarādiḥ / kālaviśeṣo vasantādiḥ / avasthāviśeṣo bālyādiḥ / teṣu viniyataḥ sarvātmanā pratiṣṭhito yathoktasvabhāvaścāsau ekaśca / tena saṃsargaḥ sambandhaḥ / tatsaṃsargeṇa avyavacchinnamakroḍīkṛtam uktasvabhāvāt svabhāvāntaram / tena viraho viyogaḥ / tadrahitatvāditi hetvarthaḥ / anekavṛtterekasyeti dharminirdeśaḥ / na deśādiviśeṣavatā anyena yoga iti sādhyadharmanirdeśaḥ / rūpādivaditi dṛṣṭāntaḥ / prayogaḥ punarevaṃ bhavati yasya yathoktasvabhāvāntaravirahaḥ / na tasya deśādiviśeṣavatā anyena yogaḥ / yathā rūpādiḥ / asti ca sāmānyāderasāviti viruddhopalabdhiḥ / yadi caikaṃ tena ca svarūpeṇa sarvaiḥ sambadhyeta sāmānyam sarvapiṇḍānāmekadeśakālāvasthāyogitāprasaṅgaḥ / taddeśādiviśeṣitapiṇḍavṛttisvarūpatvāt sāmānyasya / yadā caikasmin piṇḍe deśādiviśeṣite samupalabhyate / tadaivāśeṣasyāśrayaviśeṣitasyopalambhaḥ syāt / tasyaikarūpatvāditi / anekavṛttitvānabhyupagame ca rūpādivadekāśrayatvāt sāmānyarūpatā na syāditi /
analyzed: tatra deśa viśeṣaḥ nagara ādiḥ kāla viśeṣaḥ vasanta ādiḥ avasthā viśeṣaḥ bālya ādiḥ teṣu viniyataḥ sarva ātmanā pratiṣṭhitaḥ yathā ukta svabhāvaḥ ca asau ekaḥ ca tena saṃsargaḥ sambandhaḥ tad saṃsargeṇa avyavacchinnam akroḍīkṛtam ukta svabhāvāt svabhāva antaram tena virahaḥ viyogaḥ tad rahita tvāt iti hetu arthaḥ aneka vṛtteḥ ekasya iti dharmi nirdeśaḥ na deśa ādi viśeṣavatā anyena yogaḥ iti sādhya dharma nirdeśaḥ rū
translated: There, the specific place is the city, etc. The specific time is spring, etc. The specific state is childhood, etc. He is restricted to those, established in every way, and has the nature as stated. He is one. The connection with that is the relation. By that connection, the nature that is not distinguished, not excluded, from the stated nature, is different. The absence of that is separation. The meaning of the reason is because of being devoid of that. The statement of the subject is of one that has many occurrences. The statement of the probandum is not having a relation with another that has specific place, etc. The example is like form, etc. The application, however, is as follows: That which is devoid of a different nature as stated does not have a relation with another that has specific place, etc., like form, etc. But that is present in the universal, etc. This is the perception of the contradictory. And if that were one and related by that nature to all, there would be the consequence that the universal would be connected to all individual things in terms of place, time, and state. That place, time, and state

original: na ca sāmānyasya svabhāvāntaramasti yenānekavṛttitvaṃ syādityuktam / na ca sāmānyasya niyatāśrayeṇa sambandhe niyamaheturastīti / II / tathā gotvaṃ sambadhyamānaṃ na gavā sambadhyate / gotvasambandhāt pūrvaṃ piṇḍasya tadrūpatvāsambhavāt / atha agavā sambadhyate / tarhi tasyāśvenāpi sambandhaḥ syāt / gotvābhisambandhāt pūrvam agorūpatāyāḥ sarvatra sādhāraṇatvāt / yatra ca gopiṇḍādirvartate na tatra gotvādisāmānyaṃ samavaitīti tadāśrayiṇā tu sambadhyata iti citram /
analyzed: na ca sāmānyasya svabhāva antaram asti yena aneka vṛtti tvam syāt iti uktam na ca sāmānyasya niyata āśrayeṇa sambandhe niyama hetuḥ asti iti  / tathā go tvam sambadhyamānam na gavā sambadhyate go tva sambandhāt pūrvam piṇḍasya tad rūpa tva asambhavāt atha a gavā sambadhyate tarhi tasya aśvena api sambandhaḥ syāt go tva abhisambandhāt pūrvam a go rūpa tāyāḥ sarvatra sādhāraṇa tvāt yatra ca go piṇḍa ādiḥ vartate na tatra go tva ādi sāmānyam samavaiti iti ta
translated: And it has been said that there is no other nature of the universal by which there could be occurrence in many. And there is no cause for the restriction of the relation of the universal with a restricted substratum. Thus, when the universal cowness is related, it is not related to the cow, because it is not possible for the individual to have that form before the relation with cowness. If it is related to what is not a cow, then it would be related to a horse also, because the non-cow form prior to the relation with cowness is common to all. And where the individual cow etc. exists, the universal cowness etc. does not inhere. But it is related to what has that as its substratum - this is strange.

original: yatrāsau vartate bhāvastena sambadhayate na tu /
analyzed: yatra asau vartate bhāvaḥ tena sambadhayate na tu
translated: Where that exists, it is related to that, but not to that.

original: taddeśinantu vyāpnoti kimapyetanmahādbhutam // pra / vā / /
analyzed: vyāpnoti kim api etat mahā adbhutam pra vā
translated: But it pervades what is in that place - this is indeed a great wonder.

original: tathā piṇḍe vrajati na sāmānyasya gamanamasti / niṣkriyatvāt / nāpyavasthānam / piṇḍasya tacchūnyatāprasaṅgāt / na bhāgena gamanamavasthānañca / niraṃśatvāt / nāpi paścādāgatya abhisambadhyate / pūrvaṃ tacchūnyasyānupalabdheḥ / taduktam🔽na yāti na ca tatrāsīdasti paścānna cāṃśavat /
analyzed: tathā piṇḍe vrajati na sāmānyasya gamanam asti niṣkriya tvāt na api avasthānam piṇḍasya tad śūnyatā prasaṅgāt na bhāgena gamanam avasthānam ca niraṃśa tvāt nā api paścāt āgatya abhisambadhyate pūrvam tad śūnyasya anupalabdheḥ tat uktam  na yāti na ca tatra āsīt asti paścāt na ca aṃśavat
translated: Similarly, when the aggregate moves, the universal does not move, because it is inactive. Nor does it remain, because the aggregate would be empty of it. Nor does it move or remain partially, because it is partless. Nor does it come from behind and unite with it, because it was not perceived as empty before. As it is said:🔽It does not go, nor does it abide there, nor does it exist later like a part.

original: jahāti pūrvaṃ nādhāramaho vyasanasantatiḥ // pra / vā / /
analyzed: jahāti pūrvam na ādhāra mahaḥ vyasana santatiḥ pra vā
translated: It does not abandon the prior support - oh, the continuity of misfortune!

original: tadetadasat / jātipradveṣāndhatayā pramāṇamārgaparibhraṣṭairabhihitamiti samādhīyate / tathā hi cakṣurādivyāpāreṇa anugatajñānasyābādhyamānasyopalabdheravaśyamanugataṃ nimittaṃ vācyam / na ca vāsanaiva nimittam / tasyāḥ pūrvameva pratiṣedhāt / yadi ca vāsanā viśiṣṭapratyayaheturbāhyā ceti / saṃjñābhedamātrameva syāt / bodhāntarbhāve tu bodharūpatayā tasyāḥ sarvatrāviśeṣād vikalpavaicitryaṃ na syāt / gopiṇḍadarśanād gavākāro vikalpo 'śvapiṇḍadarśanāccāśvādhyavasāyī ityādi / na ca deśādibhedenāpi abādhyamāno 'dhyavasāyo nirviṣayaḥ sambhavatīti pararūpaṃ svarūpeṇa yayā saṃvriyata pra / vā / / ityapāstameva /
analyzed: tat etat asat jāti pradveṣa andha tayā pramāṇa mārga paribhraṣṭaiḥ abhihitam iti samādhīyate tathā hi cakṣuḥ ādi vyāpāreṇa anugata jñānasya a bādhyamānasya upalabdheḥ avaśyam anugatam nimittam vācyam na ca vāsanā eva nimittam tasyāḥ pūrvam eva pratiṣedhāt yadi ca vāsanā viśiṣṭa pratyaya hetuḥ bāhyā ca iti saṃjñā bheda mātram eva syāt bodha antarbhāve tu bodha rūpa tayā tasyāḥ sarvatra aviśeṣāt vikalpa vaicitryam na syāt go piṇḍa dar
translated: This is not correct. It is concluded that this is stated by those blinded by hatred towards universals, who have fallen from the path of valid cognition. Indeed, due to the operation of the eye etc., the cognition of the universal, which is not contradicted, must be explained to have an invariable cause. And the impression alone cannot be the cause, because it has already been refuted earlier. And if the impression is the cause of a particular cognition and is external, then there would be only a difference in name. But if it is included in cognition, then due to the non-difference of that in the form of cognition everywhere, there would be no variety of conceptualization, such as the conceptualization in the form of a cow from seeing a cow, and the conceptualization of a horse from seeing a horse, and so on. And even when the conceptualization is not contradicted by the difference of place etc., it cannot be without an object. Thus, the one by which the external form is concealed by one's own form, is the impression. This is refuted.

original: yaccedam vyaktayo nānuyantyanyadanuyāyi na bhāsata iti / asadetat / anugatajñānena tasya pratibhāsanāt / yathā hi svalakṣaṇaṃ vyāvṛttarūpatayā pratibhāsanād asti evam anugatasvarūpatayā pratibhāsanāt sāmānyamapyastīti / yadi ca vyāvṛttijñāne sāmānyasyāpratibhāsanād asattvam syāt / II / anugatajñāne 'pi svalakṣaṇasyāpratibhāsanād asattvam eva syāt / tasmād yathā abādhyamānajñāne nīlādeḥ pratibhāsanāt sattvam / evamanugatajñāne pratibhāsanāt sāmānyasyāpi sattvamabhyupagantavyam / vṛttivikalpāderbādhakasyāpramāṇatvāditi / tathā hi vṛttyanupapatterasattvamiti nedaṃ svatantrasādhanam / anekāntāt / svatantre hi rūpādīnāṃ sattvamanupapadyamānavṛttitvañceti / evaṃ parapakṣe 'nupapadyamānavṛttitve 'pi ākāśādīnāṃ sattvamiti / svarūpāsiddhaśca / vṛtteḥ samavāyasya sattvāt / ekadeśena sarvātmanā ca na vartata iti ayukto viśeṣapratiṣedhaḥ / prakārāntarasyāsambhavāt / abhinnasvarūpatvācca sāmānyasya na tatra ekadeśasarvaśabdayoḥ pravṛttiḥ / tayorbhinneṣveva pravṛttidarśanāt / samavāyena ca vartate sāmānyam / naikadeśena svarūpeṇa vā / tasya ekadeśasya svarūpasya cāvṛttirūpatvāditi / yadeva caikasmin piṇḍe svarūpaṃ sāmānyasya tadeva piṇḍāntare 'pi / anugatajñānajanakatvasya sarvatra sambhavāt / tadāha ekadvibahuṣu piṇḍeṣvātmasvarūpānuvṛttidarśanāt svapratyayakāraṇamiti / sāmānyasyātmasvarūpamanuvṛttamabhinnam / ato 'nuvṛttipratyayasyānugatajñānasya kāraṇamiti /
analyzed: yat ca idam vyaktayaḥ na anuyanti anyat anuyāyi na bhāsate iti asat etat anugata jñānena tasya pratibhāsanāt yathā hi sva lakṣaṇam vyāvṛtta rūpatayā pratibhāsanāt asti evam anugata sva rūpa tayā pratibhāsanāt sāmānyam api asti iti yadi ca vyāvṛtti jñāne sāmānyasya apratibhāsanāt asattvam syāt  / anugata jñāne pi sva lakṣaṇasya apratibhāsanāt asattvam eva syāt tasmāt yathā abādhyamāna jñāne nīla ādeḥ pratibhāsanāt sattvam evam anugata jñāne pratibh
translated: And this [argument] that the particulars do not continue, and that something else which continues is not manifested, is false, because it is manifested by the cognition of the universal. Just as the particular is indeed existent because it is manifested as having an excluded form, so the universal also exists because it is manifested as having an inclusive nature. And if the universal were non-existent because it is not manifested in the cognition of the excluded [particular], then the particular itself would be non-existent because it is not manifested in the cognition of the inclusive [universal]. Therefore, just as the blue and so on are existent because they are manifested in the cognition that is not contradicted, so the existence of the universal also should be accepted because it is manifested in the inclusive cognition. Because the objections based on the impossibility of inherence, the alternatives regarding inherence, and so on are not valid. For thus, this independent proof that [the universal] does not exist because inherence is impossible is inconclusive, because [inherence] is possible in the case of form and so on. For if [inherence] were impossible in the case of the opponent's position, then [the universal] would be non-existent because it is not manifested in the cognition of the inclusive [universal].

original: na ca sāmānyasyābhede padārthānāṃ tathābhāvaḥ / tato 'nyatvāt / ata eva naikasmin deśādiviśeṣite piṇḍe sāmānyasyopalambhād aśeṣaviśeṣitasyāpyupalambhaprasaṅgaḥ / teṣāmaniyatadigdeśasambandhitvenopalambhābhāvāt / yathaiva ca krameṇa viśeṣā upalabhyante tathaiva tadviśeṣitaṃ sāmānyamapīti / yadā hi paṇya /ñca purāvasthitagopiṇḍānāṃ vasantasamaye bālādyavasthāviśeṣitānāmupalambhastadā tadviśeṣitaṃ sāmānyamupalabhyate anyadā tvanyairviśeṣitamiti piṇḍeṣvanugatajñānajanakatvaṃ sāmānyasya sarvatrāvyabhicārisvarūpam / tasmādabhedātmakamanekavṛtti ca sāmānyaṃ pratyakṣeṇopalambhād abhyupagantavyam / yathā hi rūpamekameva ekatra vartamānaṃ pratyakṣeṇopalabdhaṃ tadvadekaṃ sāmānyamanekatreti /
analyzed: na ca sāmānyasya abhede padārthānām tathābhāvaḥ tatas nya tvāt  atas eva na ekasmin deśa ādi viśeṣite piṇḍe sāmānyasya upalambhāt aśeṣa viśeṣitasya api upalambha prasaṅgaḥ teṣām aniyata diś deśa sambandhi tvena upalambha abhāvāt yathā eva ca krameṇa viśeṣāḥ upalabhyante tathā eva tad viśeṣitam sāmānyam api iti  yadā hi paṇyañca purā avasthita go piṇḍānām vasanta samaye bāla ādi avasthā viśeṣitānām upalambhaḥ tadā tad viśeṣitam s
translated: And when there is no difference in the universal, the entities do not exist in that way, because they are different from it. For this very reason, when the universal is perceived in one individual qualified by place etc., there is no possibility of the perception of even that qualified by all the particulars, because they are not perceived as connected with an indefinite direction and place. And just as the particulars are perceived in sequence, the universal qualified by them is also perceived in the same way. For when the individual cows present in the market are perceived in the spring season, qualified by the particular states of youth etc., then the universal qualified by them is perceived. At other times, it is qualified by others. Thus, the universal's ability to generate cognition following the individuals everywhere is its invariable nature. Therefore, the universal, which is of the nature of non-difference and exists in many, should be accepted as perceived by perception, just as form, which is one only, is perceived by perception as existing in one place, so also the universal is one, though existing in many.

original: yaccedaṃ deśādiviśeṣitasvabhāvād anekavṛtterekasya na deśādiviśeṣavatā anyena yoga ityuktam / tatra vyarthaviśeṣaṇatā hetordharmiṇaśca / tathā hi ekasaṃsargāvyavacchinnasvabhāvāntaravirahānna sāmānyasya viśeṣāntareṇa II / yoga iti pratiṣedhe sādhye vyabhicārābhāvāt sādhyasādhanayordeśādiviśeṣaṇamanarthakam / vyavacchedyasadbhāve hi viśeṣaṇasyārthavattopapatteḥ /
analyzed: yat ca idam deśa ādi viśeṣita svabhāvāt aneka vṛtteḥ ekasya na deśa ādi viśeṣavatā anyena yogaḥ iti uktam tatra vyartha viśeṣaṇa tā hetoḥ dharmiṇaḥ ca tathā hi eka saṃsarga avyavacchinna svabhāva antara virahāt na sāmānyasya viśeṣa antareṇa yogaḥ iti pratiṣedhe sādhye vyabhicāra abhāvāt sādhya sādhanayoḥ deśa ādi viśeṣaṇam anarthakam vyavacchedya sadbhāve hi viśeṣaṇasya arthavat tā upapatteḥ
translated: If what is meant to be proved is the fact of the Universal being incapable of being connected with another Particular, then, as the fact of its being so connected is not admitted, the Reason becomes superfluous. If what is meant to be proved is the fact of its being incapable of being connected with another Universal, then the Reason becomes ‘Inconclusive’, as there can be no connection between Universals at all; and the Corroborative Instance also becomes ‘devoid of the Probandum’.

original: atha yathoktasvabhāvāntaravirahe kathamanyayogaḥ sāmānyādeḥ / anyayoge vā kathaṃ yathoktasvabhāvāntaravirahaḥ / tayoranyatra rūpādau pratibandhasiddhiriti cet / na / vyabhicārāt / tathā hi rūpāśrayasya rūpasaṃsargāvyavacchinnasvabhāvāntaravirahe 'pi rasādibhiryogo dṛṣṭaḥ / tadvat sāmānyasyāpyāśrayāntareṇa yogaḥ kena vāryate / rūpāśrayavat sāmānye 'pi yathoktasvabhāvāntarāsattvasyāviśeṣāditi / asti ca rūpasyāśrayo dravyamityuktam /
analyzed: atha yathā ukta svabhāva antara virahe katham anya yogaḥ sāmānya ādeḥ anya yoge vā katham yathā ukta svabhāva antara virahaḥ tayoḥ anyatra rūpa ādau pratibandha siddhiḥ iti ced na vyabhicārāt tathā hi rūpa āśrayasya rūpa saṃsarga avyavacchinna svabhāva antara virahe pi rasa ādibhiḥ yogaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ tadvat sāmānyasya api āśraya antareṇa yogaḥ kena vāryate rūpa āśraya vat sāmānye pi yathā ukta svabhāva antara asattvasya aviśeṣāt iti  /
translated: If, on the other hand, there is no other nature apart from what has been said, then how can there be any connection with something else in the case of the Universal, etc.? Or, if there is connection with something else, then how can there be absence of any other nature apart from what has been said? If it be argued that “the connection of these with something else is admitted in the case of Colour, etc.”, then, that cannot be; because there is ‘fallibility’ in this; for instance, even though the substratum of Colour is devoid of any other nature apart from what is inseparable from the contact of Colour, yet it is found to be connected with Taste, etc.; in the same manner, why cannot the Universal be regarded as connected with another substratum? Because, as regards the Universal, there is no difference from Colour, etc., in the matter of the absence of any other nature apart from what has been said. It has been asserted that there is a substratum of Colour in the shape of Substance.

original: athaikatvāt sāmānyasya anekatra samavāyaḥ pratiṣidhyate / tarhi yadanekatra samavetam tadanekamevetyabhyupagame hetorvyatirekāvyabhicāreṇaiva gamakatvād ekatra samavetānāṃ rūpādīnāmekatā prasajyeta / na caitadasti / atha ekatvādekatraiva samavāyaḥ sādhyate / tadapyanaikāntikam / ākāśāderekatve 'pyekatraiva samavāyābhāvāt / yadyanekatra samavāyādanekatvaprasaṅgo 'bhidhīyeta / tathāpi yadekaṃ tadekatra samavetamiti vyatirekābhāvaḥ / satyapi ākāśādāvekatve tadabhāvāt / ekatra samavāyādekatvam ityetadapi rūpaśabdādibhiranaikāntikam / ekatvasya sāmānyaviśeṣarūpatvāt tasmin sādhye hetoranvayavyatirekābhāvādagamakatvam / evaṃ nirviśeṣaṇasya hetorantaraḥ sādhyasādhanabhāvaprakāro nirastaḥ / tathā saviśeṣaṇasyāpi hetorākāśādinānaikāntikatvam / tasya hi deśādiviśeṣavatā anyena yoge 'pi tathoktasvabhāvāntaravirahopalabdheḥ /
analyzed: atha eka tvāt sāmānyasya anekatra samavāyaḥ pratiṣidhyate tarhi yat anekatra samavetam tat anekam eva iti abhyupagame hetoḥ vyatireka avyabhicāreṇa eva gamaka tvāt ekatra samavetānām rūpa ādīnām ekatā prasajyeta na ca etat asti atha eka tvāt ekatra eva samavāyaḥ sādhyate tat api anaikāntikam ākāśa ādeḥ eka tve pi ekatra eva samavāya abhāvāt yadi anekatra samavāyāt aneka tva prasaṅgaḥ bhidhīyeta tathā api yat ekam tat ekatra samavetam iti vyatireka abhāvaḥ sati
translated: If, on the other hand, the inherence of the universal in many is denied on the ground of its being one, then it follows that what inheres in many is itself many. Thus, the reason being invariably concomitant with the contrary of the probandum, it becomes a proof of the contrary of the probandum. And in that case, it would follow that colour and other qualities, which inhere in one substratum, are themselves one. But this is not so. If, on the other hand, the inherence of the universal in one is proved on the ground of its being one, that too is inconclusive. Because, even though ākāśa etc. are one, they do not inhere in one substratum. If the consequence that it is many because it inheres in many is stated, then also, the absence of the reason in the contrary of the probandum is not there. Because, even though ākāśa etc. are one, that is absent. The conclusion that it is one because it inheres in one is inconclusive in the case of colour, sound etc. Because, one-ness is of the nature of a universal as well as a particular. Thus, in the case of that probandum, the reason is neither invariably concomitant with the presence of the probandum nor with its absence. Hence, it is not a proof. Thus, the internal relation between the probans and the probandum in the case of the reason without any qualification has been refuted.

original: yaccedaṃ pradīpaprabhāyā deśādiviśeṣaṇaviśiṣṭāyā na deśādiviśeṣavatā anyena yoga ityudāharaṇam / tatrāpi utpatterūrdhvamavayavakriyākrameṇa vināśābhyupagamād anekakālavyavadhāne deśādiviśeṣavatā anyenāpi yogaḥ sambhavatyeva / na ca pradīpaprabhāyāṃ sādhyasādhanasadbhāve 'pi hetorvyabhicāropadarśanād gamakatvam / tathā sāmānyasya svabhāvāntaraviraho 'siddhaḥ / tadādhārāntarasya tadviśeṣakatvena tatsvabhāvāntaratvāt / pratīyate cādhārādheyayorviśeṣaṇaviśeṣyabhāvaḥ / yathā saddravyam / dravyasya satteti / tasmāt svabhāvāntaraviraho 'pi sādhya eveti / tathānekavṛtterekasya na deśādiviśeṣavatā II / anyena yoga iti prasaṅganirdeśe svavacanavirodhaḥ / tathā hi anyayogapratiṣedhe na anekavṛttitvaṃ bhavatīti / atha sāmānyādiparyāyo 'yamanekatra vṛttiriti / tathāpyanekavṛttitvapratiṣedho 'nupapannaḥ / sāmānyasva nityatvaikatve satyanekavṛttitvalakṣaṇatvāt / pratyakṣeṇa ca sāmānyasya anekavṛttitvaprasiddheḥ / tena bādhyatvādanumānamapramāṇam / tathā hi ekadvibahuṣu piṇḍeṣvakṣavyāpārādanugatajñānamutpadyamānaṃ dṛṣṭam / na cedaṃ bhrāntam / pratyakṣāgamasaṃvādena visaṃvādanivṛttau tadvyāptasya bhrāntatvasya nivṛtteriti /
analyzed: yat ca idam pradīpa prabhāyāḥ deśa ādi viśeṣaṇa viśiṣṭāyāḥ na deśa ādi viśeṣavatā anyena yogaḥ iti udāharaṇam tatra api utpatteḥ ūrdhvam avayava kriyā krameṇa vināśa abhyupagamāt aneka kāla vyavadhāne deśa ādi viśeṣavatā anyena api yogaḥ sambhavati eva na ca pradīpa prabhāyām sādhya sādhana sadbhāve pi hetoḥ vyabhicāra upadarśanāt gamaka tvam tathā sāmānyasya svabhāva antara virahaḥ siddhaḥ tad ādhāra antarasya tad viśeṣaka tvena ta
translated: And this example of the lamp-light, which has a particular place, etc., not being connected with anything else having a particular place, etc., even there, because the destruction is accepted to be without the sequence of the operation of the parts after origination, the connection with something else having a particular place, etc., separated by many times is indeed possible. And the lamp-light is not a probans by showing the non-conformity of the probans even when the probandum is present. Similarly, the absence of another nature in the universal is not established, because that which is the basis of another is the qualifier of that, being of the nature of that. And the relation of qualifier and qualified between the support and the supported is perceived, just as a real substance, the reality of the substance. Therefore, the absence of another nature is also to be proved. Similarly, in the statement of the reductio ad absurdum that one which occurs in many is not connected with anything else having a particular place, etc., there is a contradiction with one's own words. For thus, in the negation of connection with another, the occurrence in many is not

original: na ca apohādevānugatajñānam / tasya vyāvṛttirūpatāyāmavastutvenājanakatvāt / janakatve vā tasya arthakriyākāritvāt vastutvaprasaṅgaḥ / atha vyāvṛttādanyā vyāvṛttirneṣyate / tarhi teṣāṃ parasparavyāvṛttasvarūpatayā anugatajñānajanakatvaṃ na syāt /
analyzed: na ca apohāt eva anugata jñānam tasya vyāvṛtti rūpa tāyām avastu tvena ajanaka tvāt janaka tve vā tasya arthakriyā kāri tvāt vastu tva prasaṅgaḥ atha vyāvṛttāt anyā vyāvṛttiḥ na iṣyate tarhi teṣām paraspara vyāvṛtta svarūpa tayā anugata jñāna janaka tvam na syāt
translated: And the cognition of the universal is not due to the apoha itself, because if it has the form of exclusion, it cannot be the cause of cognition as it is not a real entity. If it is the cause, then it must be a real entity as it performs a function. If the exclusion of the excluded is not accepted as different from the exclusion, then they cannot be the cause of the cognition of the universal as they have mutually exclusive forms.

original: yaccedam agovyāvṛttirgotvam ityuktam / tatra gavāṃ svarūpapratipattimantareṇa tato 'nyeṣāmagorūpatāyāmaprasiddhiḥ / tadaprasiddhau ca na gavāṃ svarūpapratipattirityanyonyāśrayatvaṃ syāt / yadi caikasmād gopiṇḍādanyeṣāmagorūpatā tarhi gopiṇḍānāmapyanyeṣāmagorūpatāprasaṅgaḥ / teṣāmapyekasmād gopiṇḍādanyatvāt /
analyzed: yat ca idam a go vyāvṛttiḥ go tvam iti uktam tatra gavām sva rūpa pratipattim antareṇa tatas nyeṣām ago rūpa tāyām aprasiddhiḥ tad aprasiddhau ca na gavām sva rūpa pratipattiḥ iti anyonya āśraya tvam syāt yadi ca ekasmāt go piṇḍāt anyeṣām ago rūpa tā tarhi go piṇḍānām api anyeṣām ago rūpa tā prasaṅgaḥ teṣām api ekasmāt go piṇḍāt anya tvāt
translated: And this statement that the exclusion of non-cow is cowhood - in that case, without the ascertainment of the nature of cows, the form of non-cow in others is not well-known. And in the absence of that, there is no ascertainment of the nature of cows. Thus there would be mutual dependence. And if the form of non-cow in others is due to one cow-individual, then there would be the contingence of the form of non-cow in other cow-individuals also, as they are different from that one cow-individual.

original: atha sarvasmād gopiṇḍādanyeṣāmagotvam / tadasat / vargīkaraṇanimittāsambhave sarveṣāṃ gopiṇḍanāmapratipattau tato 'nyeṣāṃ pratipattumaśakyatvāt / yeṣāñca anugatamabhinnaṃ nimittamasti teṣāṃ gosvarūpaprasiddhau tato 'nyavyāvṛttiḥ pratīyata eva / atha arthakriyāsāmānyādanuvṛttipratyaya iti cet / na / arthakriyāṇāmapi parasparaṃ vyāvṛttatayā anugatajñānājanakatvāt / atha arthakriyāṇāmanugatamabhinnaṃ nimittamupagrāhakamiṣyeta / tadeva tarhi sāmānyam /
analyzed: atha sarvasmāt go piṇḍāt anyeṣām agotvam tat asat vargīkaraṇa nimitta asambhave sarveṣām go piṇḍa nāma pratipattau tatas nyeṣām pratipattum aśakya tvāt yeṣām ca anugatam abhinnam nimittam asti teṣām go sva rūpa prasiddhau tatas nya vyāvṛttiḥ pratīyate eva atha arthakriyā sāmānyāt anuvṛtti pratyayaḥ iti ced na arthakriyāṇām api parasparam vyāvṛtta tayā anugata jñāna ajanaka tvāt atha arthakriyāṇām anugatam abhinnam nimittam upagrāhakam iṣyeta t
translated: If, on the other hand, the non-cow-ness of all other things is different from the cow-ness of the cow, that is not correct. Because, in the absence of a basis for classification, when the name 'cow' is applied to all individual cows, it is impossible to apply it to anything else. And for those things which have a common, non-different basis, when the nature of the cow is well-known, the exclusion from other things is understood itself. If it is argued that the comprehensive cognition arises from the commonality of effective action, that is not so. Because even effective actions, being mutually exclusive, do not generate a comprehensive cognition. If, on the other hand, it is accepted that the basis for effective actions is a common, non-different factor that supports them, then that itself is the universal.

original: kā ceyamarthakriyā yatsāmyādanugatajñānamiti vācyam / yadi vāhādirūpā / sā ca manuṣyādāvapi sambhavatīti tatrāpi gaurgaurityanugatajñānaprasaṅgaḥ / na ca pakṣe sarvatraitadastītyanugatajñānābhāvaprasaṅgaḥ /
analyzed: kā ca iyam arthakriyā yad sāmyāt anugata jñānam iti vācyam yadi vāha ādi rūpā sā ca manuṣya ādau api sambhavati iti tatra api gauḥ gauḥ iti anugata jñāna prasaṅgaḥ na ca pakṣe sarvatra etat asti iti anugata jñāna abhāva prasaṅgaḥ
translated: And what is this effective action, due to the similarity of which there is a comprehensive cognition? If it is said to be the form of carrying etc., and that is possible even in humans, then there would be the undesirable consequence of a comprehensive cognition even in humans, thinking 'cow is cow'. And it is not that this exists everywhere in the subject, leading to the undesirable consequence of the absence of a comprehensive cognition.

original: atha jñānamevānugatavyāvṛttākāraṃ sāmānyamiti cet / so 'yam aśvārūḍhasya vismṛto 'śvaḥ iti nyāyaḥ / na hyanugatanimittaṃ vinā anugatajñānaṃ sambhavati / vāsanādernimittasya pratiṣedhāt /

translated: As for the argument that the Universal moves to the substratum, and in motion there is activity, and in rest there is non-substratum-ness, that is wrong. And that, being excluded from Universals etc., excludes its own pervasion, activity, and thus Universals etc. are inactive. For activity is observed in objects only when there is corporeality, by positive and negative concomitance. That itself is the fitness. And due to its absence, there is no activity in space etc., not due to the obstruction of omnipresence. For if that were absent, there would be activity even in qualities, actions etc. And if the motion of the substratum of some Universal results in the motion of the Universal itself, then its rest would result in rest. Thus it would fall into the irremediable calamity of neither moving nor resting. Therefore, due to the inherence of the same object in conjunction and disjunction, the motion belonging to the substratum is figuratively spoken of as belonging to the inhered in.

translated: He explains the statement of the summary: The cause of the cognition of continuity is that which exists in the substrates such as the cow-calf, with a single form due to the non-difference of its own nature, without interruption, without abandoning the previous substrate, and existing by inherence. Even where a single cognition has many individuals as its object, there too, the cognition of continuity is indeed not perceived. When this supposition is made, the reply is given beginning with 'depending on the universal in each individual'.
